
       
<EOS>
The
Personal
History
,
Adventures
,
Experience
and
Observation
of
David
Copperfield
the
Younger
of
Blunderstone
Rookery
David
Copperfield
 
<EOS>
Charles
Dickens
  
1849
<EOS>
-
-1850
  
<EOS>
Information
about
the
source
     
Chapter
1
.
<EOS>
I
Am
Born
 
Whether
I
shall
turn
out
to
be
the
hero
of
my
own
life
,
or
whether
that
station
will
be
held
by
anybody
else
,
these
pages
must
show
.
<EOS>
To
begin
my
life
with
the
beginning
of
my
life
,
I
record
that
I
was
born
(
as
I
have
been
informed
and
believe
)
on
a
Friday
,
at
twelve
o'clock
at
night
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
remarked
that
the
clock
began
to
strike
,
and
I
began
to
cry
,
simultaneously
.
   
<EOS>
In
consideration
of
the
day
and
hour
of
my
birth
,
it
was
declared
by
the
nurse
,
and
by
some
sage
women
in
the
neighbourhood
who
had
taken
a
lively
interest
in
me
several
months
before
there
was
any
possibility
of
our
becoming
personally
acquainted
,
first
,
that
I
was
destined
to
be
unlucky
in
life
;
and
secondly
,
that
I
was
privileged
to
see
ghosts
and
spirits
;
both
these
gifts
inevitably
attaching
,
as
they
believed
,
to
all
unlucky
infants
of
either
gender
,
born
towards
the
small
hours
on
a
Friday
night
.
   
<EOS>
I
need
say
nothing
here
,
on
the
first
head
,
because
nothing
can
show
better
than
my
history
whether
that
prediction
was
verified
or
falsified
by
the
result
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
second
branch
of
the
question
,
I
will
only
remark
,
that
unless
I
ran
through
that
part
of
my
inheritance
while
I
was
still
a
baby
,
I
have
not
come
into
it
yet
.
<EOS>
But
I
do
not
at
all
complain
of
having
been
kept
out
of
this
property
;
and
if
anybody
else
should
be
in
the
present
enjoyment
of
it
,
he
is
heartily
welcome
to
keep
it
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
born
with
a
caul
,
which
was
advertised
for
sale
,
in
the
newspapers
,
at
the
low
price
of
fifteen
guineas
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
sea
-
going
people
were
short
of
money
about
that
time
,
or
were
short
of
faith
and
preferred
cork
jackets
,
I
do
n't
know
;
all
I
know
is
,
that
there
was
but
one
solitary
bidding
,
and
that
was
from
an
attorney
connected
with
the
bill
-
broking
business
,
who
offered
two
pounds
in
cash
,
and
the
balance
in
sherry
,
but
declined
to
be
guaranteed
from
drowning
on
any
higher
bargain
.
 
<EOS>
Consequently
the
advertisement
was
withdrawn
at
a
dead
loss
---
for
as
to
sherry
,
my
poor
dear
mother
's
own
sherry
was
in
the
market
then
---
and
ten
years
afterwards
,
the
caul
was
put
up
in
a
raffle
down
in
our
part
of
the
country
,
to
fifty
members
at
half
-
a
-
crown
a
head
,
the
winner
to
spend
five
shillings
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
present
myself
,
and
I
remember
to
have
felt
quite
uncomfortable
and
confused
,
at
a
part
of
myself
being
disposed
of
in
that
way
.
 
<EOS>
The
caul
was
won
,
I
recollect
,
by
an
old
lady
with
a
hand
-
basket
,
who
,
very
reluctantly
,
produced
from
it
the
stipulated
five
shillings
,
all
in
halfpence
,
and
twopence
halfpenny
short
---
as
it
took
an
immense
time
and
a
great
waste
of
arithmetic
,
to
endeavour
without
any
effect
to
prove
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
fact
which
will
be
long
remembered
as
remarkable
down
there
,
that
she
was
never
drowned
,
but
died
triumphantly
in
bed
,
at
ninety
-
two
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
understood
that
it
was
,
to
the
last
,
her
proudest
boast
,
that
she
never
had
been
on
the
water
in
her
life
,
except
upon
a
bridge
;
and
that
over
her
tea
(
to
which
she
was
extremely
partial
)
<EOS>
she
,
to
the
last
,
expressed
her
indignation
at
the
impiety
of
mariners
and
others
,
who
had
the
presumption
to
go
<EOS>
"
meandering
"
about
the
world
.
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
to
represent
to
her
that
some
conveniences
,
tea
perhaps
included
,
resulted
from
this
objectionable
practice
.
 
<EOS>
She
always
returned
,
with
greater
emphasis
and
with
an
instinctive
knowledge
of
the
strength
of
her
objection
,
"
Let
us
have
no
meandering
.
"
   
<EOS>
Not
to
meander
myself
,
at
present
,
I
will
go
back
to
my
birth
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
born
at
Blunderstone
,
in
Suffolk
,
or
"
thereby
"
,
as
they
say
in
Scotland
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
a
posthumous
child
.
 
<EOS>
My
father
's
eyes
had
closed
upon
the
light
of
this
world
six
months
,
when
mine
opened
on
it
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
something
strange
to
me
,
even
now
,
in
the
reflection
that
he
never
saw
me
;
and
something
stranger
yet
in
the
shadowy
remembrance
that
I
have
of
my
first
childish
associations
with
his
white
grave
-
stone
in
the
churchyard
,
and
of
the
indefinable
compassion
I
used
to
feel
for
it
lying
out
alone
there
in
the
dark
night
,
when
our
little
parlour
was
warm
and
bright
with
fire
and
candle
,
and
the
doors
of
our
house
were
---
almost
cruelly
,
it
seemed
to
me
sometimes
---
bolted
and
locked
against
it
.
   
<EOS>
An
aunt
of
my
father
's
,
and
consequently
a
great
-
aunt
of
mine
,
of
whom
I
shall
have
more
to
relate
by
and
by
,
was
the
principal
magnate
of
our
family
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Trotwood
,
or
Miss
Betsey
,
as
my
poor
mother
always
called
her
,
when
she
sufficiently
overcame
her
dread
of
this
formidable
personage
to
mention
her
at
all
(
which
was
seldom
)
,
had
been
married
to
a
husband
younger
than
herself
,
who
was
very
handsome
,
except
in
the
sense
of
the
homely
adage
,
"
handsome
is
,
that
handsome
does
"
---
for
he
was
strongly
suspected
of
having
beaten
Miss
Betsey
,
and
even
of
having
once
,
on
a
disputed
question
of
supplies
,
made
some
hasty
but
determined
arrangements
to
throw
her
out
of
a
two
pair
of
stairs
'
window
.
<EOS>
These
evidences
of
an
incompatibility
of
temper
induced
Miss
Betsey
to
pay
him
off
,
and
effect
a
separation
by
mutual
consent
.
 
<EOS>
He
went
to
India
with
his
capital
,
and
there
,
according
to
a
wild
legend
in
our
family
,
he
was
once
seen
riding
on
an
elephant
,
in
company
with
a
Baboon
;
but
I
think
it
must
have
been
a
Baboo
---
or
a
Begum
.
<EOS>
Anyhow
,
from
India
tidings
of
his
death
reached
home
,
within
ten
years
.
 
<EOS>
How
they
affected
my
aunt
,
nobody
knew
;
for
immediately
upon
the
separation
,
she
took
her
maiden
name
again
,
bought
a
cottage
in
a
hamlet
on
the
sea
-
coast
a
long
way
off
,
established
herself
there
as
a
single
woman
with
one
servant
,
and
was
understood
to
live
secluded
,
ever
afterwards
,
in
an
inflexible
retirement
.
   
<EOS>
My
father
had
once
been
a
favourite
of
hers
,
I
believe
;
but
she
was
mortally
affronted
by
his
marriage
,
on
the
ground
that
my
mother
was
"
a
wax
doll
"
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
never
seen
my
mother
,
but
she
knew
her
to
be
not
yet
twenty
.
 
<EOS>
My
father
and
Miss
Betsey
never
met
again
.
<EOS>
He
was
double
my
mother
's
age
when
he
married
,
and
of
but
a
delicate
constitution
.
 
<EOS>
He
died
a
year
afterwards
,
and
,
as
I
have
said
,
six
months
before
I
came
into
the
world
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
the
state
of
matters
,
on
the
afternoon
of
,
what
I
may
be
excused
for
calling
,
that
eventful
and
important
Friday
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
make
no
claim
therefore
to
have
known
,
at
that
time
,
how
matters
stood
;
or
to
have
any
remembrance
,
founded
on
the
evidence
of
my
own
senses
,
of
what
follows
.
   
<EOS>
My
mother
was
sitting
by
the
fire
,
but
poorly
in
health
,
and
very
low
in
spirits
,
looking
at
it
through
her
tears
,
and
desponding
heavily
about
herself
and
the
fatherless
little
stranger
,
who
was
already
welcomed
by
some
grosses
of
prophetic
pins
,
in
a
drawer
upstairs
,
to
a
world
not
at
all
excited
on
the
subject
of
his
arrival
;
my
mother
,
I
say
,
was
sitting
by
the
fire
,
that
bright
,
windy
March
afternoon
,
very
timid
and
sad
,
and
very
doubtful
of
ever
coming
alive
out
of
the
trial
that
was
before
her
,
when
,
lifting
her
eyes
as
she
dried
them
,
to
the
window
opposite
,
she
saw
a
strange
lady
coming
up
the
garden
.
   
<EOS>
MY
mother
had
a
sure
foreboding
at
the
second
glance
,
that
it
was
Miss
Betsey
.
 
<EOS>
The
setting
sun
was
glowing
on
the
strange
lady
,
over
the
garden
-
fence
,
and
she
came
walking
up
to
the
door
with
a
fell
rigidity
of
figure
and
composure
of
countenance
that
could
have
belonged
to
nobody
else
.
   
<EOS>
When
she
reached
the
house
,
she
gave
another
proof
of
her
identity
.
<EOS>
My
father
had
often
hinted
that
she
seldom
conducted
herself
like
any
ordinary
Christian
;
and
now
,
instead
of
ringing
the
bell
,
she
came
and
looked
in
at
that
identical
window
,
pressing
the
end
of
her
nose
against
the
glass
to
that
extent
,
that
my
poor
dear
mother
used
to
say
it
became
perfectly
flat
and
white
in
a
moment
.
   
<EOS>
She
gave
my
mother
such
a
turn
,
that
I
have
always
been
convinced
I
am
indebted
to
Miss
Betsey
for
having
been
born
on
a
Friday
.
   
<EOS>
My
mother
had
left
her
chair
in
her
agitation
,
and
gone
behind
it
in
the
corner
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Betsey
,
looking
round
the
room
,
slowly
and
inquiringly
,
began
on
the
other
side
,
and
carried
her
eyes
on
,
like
a
Saracen
's
Head
in
a
Dutch
clock
,
until
they
reached
my
mother
.
<EOS>
Then
she
made
a
frown
and
a
gesture
to
my
mother
,
like
one
who
was
accustomed
to
be
obeyed
,
to
come
and
open
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
My
mother
went
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mrs
David
Copperfield
,
I
think
,
"
said
Miss
Betsey
;
the
emphasis
referring
,
perhaps
,
to
my
mother
's
mourning
weeds
,
and
her
condition
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
my
mother
,
faintly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Trotwood
,
"
said
the
visitor
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
heard
of
her
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
?
"
   
<EOS>
My
mother
answered
she
had
had
that
pleasure
.
 
<EOS>
And
she
had
a
disagreeable
consciousness
of
not
appearing
to
imply
that
it
had
been
an
overpowering
pleasure
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
you
see
her
,
"
said
Miss
Betsey
.
 
<EOS>
My
mother
bent
her
head
,
and
begged
her
to
walk
in
.
   
<EOS>
They
went
into
the
parlour
my
mother
had
come
from
,
the
fire
in
the
best
room
on
the
other
side
of
the
passage
not
being
lighted
---
not
having
been
lighted
,
indeed
,
since
my
father
's
funeral
;
and
when
they
were
both
seated
,
and
Miss
Betsey
said
nothing
,
my
mother
,
after
vainly
trying
to
restrain
herself
,
began
to
cry
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
tut
,
tut
,
tut
!
"
said
Miss
Betsey
,
in
a
hurry
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
do
that
!
<EOS>
Come
,
come
!
"
   
<EOS>
My
mother
could
n't
help
it
notwithstanding
,
so
she
cried
until
she
had
had
her
cry
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
off
your
cap
,
child
,
"
said
Miss
Betsey
,
"
and
let
me
see
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
MY
mother
was
too
much
afraid
of
her
to
refuse
compliance
with
this
odd
request
,
if
she
had
any
disposition
to
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
she
did
as
she
was
told
,
and
did
it
with
such
nervous
hands
that
her
hair
(
which
was
luxuriant
and
beautiful
)
fell
all
about
her
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
bless
my
heart
!
"
exclaimed
Miss
Betsey
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
very
Baby
!
"
   
<EOS>
My
mother
was
,
no
doubt
,
unusually
youthful
in
appearance
even
for
her
years
;
she
hung
her
head
,
as
if
it
were
her
fault
,
poor
thing
,
and
said
,
sobbing
,
that
indeed
she
was
afraid
she
was
but
a
childish
widow
,
and
would
be
but
<EOS>
a
childish
mother
if
she
lived
.
<EOS>
In
a
short
pause
which
ensued
,
she
had
a
fancy
that
she
felt
Miss
Betsey
touch
her
hair
,
and
that
with
no
ungentle
hand
;
but
,
looking
at
her
,
in
her
timid
hope
,
she
found
that
lady
sitting
with
the
skirt
of
her
dress
tucked
up
,
her
hands
folded
on
one
knee
,
and
her
feet
upon
the
fender
,
frowning
at
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
name
of
Heaven
,
"
said
Miss
Betsey
,
suddenly
,
"
why
Rookery
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
the
house
,
ma'am
?
"
asked
my
mother
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
Rookery
?
"
said
Miss
Betsey
.
 
<EOS>
"
Cookery
would
have
been
more
to
the
purpose
,
if
you
had
had
any
practical
ideas
of
life
,
either
of
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
name
was
Mr
Copperfield
's
choice
,
"
returned
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
he
bought
the
house
,
he
liked
to
think
that
there
were
rooks
about
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
evening
wind
made
such
a
disturbance
just
now
,
among
some
tall
old
elm
-
trees
at
the
bottom
of
the
garden
,
that
neither
my
mother
nor
Miss
Betsey
could
forbear
glancing
that
way
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
elms
bent
to
one
another
,
like
giants
who
were
whispering
secrets
,
and
after
a
few
seconds
of
such
repose
,
fell
into
a
violent
flurry
,
tossing
their
wild
arms
about
,
as
if
their
late
confidences
were
really
too
wicked
for
their
peace
of
mind
,
<EOS>
some
weatherbeaten
ragged
old
rooks'-nests
,
burdening
their
higher
branches
,
swung
like
wrecks
upon
a
stormy
sea
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
are
the
birds
?
"
asked
Miss
Betsey
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
---
?
<EOS>
"
My
mother
had
been
thinking
of
something
else
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
rooks
---
what
has
become
of
them
?
"
asked
Miss
Betsey
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
have
not
been
any
since
we
have
lived
here
,
"
said
my
mother
.
<EOS>
"
We
thought
---
Mr
Copperfield
thought
---
it
was
quite
a
large
rookery
;
but
the
nests
were
very
old
ones
,
and
the
birds
have
deserted
them
a
long
while
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
David
Copperfield
all
over
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Miss
Betsey
.
 
<EOS>
"
David
Copperfield
from
head
to
foot
!
 
<EOS>
Calls
a
house
a
rookery
when
there
's
not
a
rook
near
it
,
and
takes
the
birds
on
trust
,
because
he
sees
the
nests
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
returned
my
mother
,
"
is
dead
,
and
if
you
dare
to
speak
unkindly
of
him
to
me
---
"
   
<EOS>
My
poor
dear
mother
,
I
suppose
,
had
some
momentary
intention
of
committing
an
assault
and
battery
upon
my
aunt
,
who
could
easily
have
settled
her
with
one
hand
,
even
if
my
mother
had
been
in
far
better
training
for
such
an
encounter
than
she
was
that
evening
.
<EOS>
But
it
passed
with
the
action
of
rising
from
her
chair
;
and
she
sat
down
again
very
meekly
,
and
fainted
.
   
<EOS>
When
she
came
to
herself
,
or
when
Miss
Betsey
had
restored
her
,
whichever
it
was
,
she
found
the
latter
standing
at
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
The
twilight
was
by
this
time
shading
down
into
darkness
;
and
dimly
as
they
saw
each
other
,
they
could
not
have
done
that
without
the
aid
of
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
?
"
said
Miss
Betsey
,
coming
back
to
her
chair
,
as
if
she
had
only
been
taking
a
casual
look
at
the
prospect
;
"
and
when
do
you
expect
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
all
in
a
tremble
,
"
faltered
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
's
the
matter
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
die
,
I
am
sure
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
no
,
"
said
Miss
Betsey
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
some
tea
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
me
,
dear
me
,
do
you
think
it
will
do
me
any
good
?
"
<EOS>
cried
my
mother
in
a
helpless
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
it
will
,
"
said
Miss
Betsey
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
nothing
but
fancy
.
<EOS>
What
do
you
call
your
girl
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
it
will
be
a
girl
,
yet
,
ma'am
,
"
said
my
mother
innocently
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
the
Baby
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Miss
Betsey
,
unconsciously
quoting
the
second
sentiment
of
the
pincushion
in
the
drawer
upstairs
,
but
applying
it
to
my
mother
instead
of
me
,
"
I
do
n't
mean
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
mean
your
servant
-
girl
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Peggotty
,
"
said
my
mother
.
   
<EOS>
"
Peggotty
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
Miss
Betsey
,
with
some
indignation
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
to
say
,
child
,
that
any
human
being
has
gone
into
a
Christian
church
,
and
got
herself
named
Peggotty
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
her
surname
,
"
said
my
mother
,
faintly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Copperfield
called
her
by
it
,
because
her
Christian
name
was
the
same
as
mine
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
!
 
<EOS>
Peggotty
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Miss
Betsey
,
opening
the
parlour
door
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Tea
.
 
<EOS>
Your
mistress
is
a
little
unwell
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
dawdle
.
"
   
<EOS>
Having
issued
this
mandate
with
as
much
potentiality
as
if
she
had
been
a
recognized
authority
in
the
house
ever
since
it
had
been
a
house
,
and
having
looked
out
to
confront
the
amazed
Peggotty
coming
along
the
passage
with
a
candle
at
the
sound
of
a
strange
voice
,
Miss
Betsey
shut
the
door
again
,
and
sat
down
as
before
:
with
her
feet
on
the
fender
,
the
skirt
of
her
dress
tucked
up
,
and
her
hands
folded
on
one
knee
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
were
speaking
about
its
being
a
girl
,
"
said
Miss
Betsey
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
it
will
be
a
girl
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
presentiment
that
it
must
be
a
girl
.
 
<EOS>
Now
child
,
from
the
moment
of
the
birth
of
this
girl
---
"
   
"
Perhaps
boy
,
"
my
mother
took
the
liberty
of
putting
in
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
I
have
a
presentiment
that
it
must
be
a
girl
,
"
returned
Miss
Betsey
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
contradict
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
moment
of
this
girl
's
birth
,
child
,
I
intend
to
be
her
friend
.
 
<EOS>
I
intend
to
be
her
godmother
,
and
I
beg
you
'll
call
her
Betsey
Trotwood
Copperfield
.
<EOS>
There
must
be
no
mistakes
in
life
with
THIS
Betsey
Trotwood
.
 
<EOS>
There
must
be
no
trifling
with
HER
affections
,
poor
dear
.
 
<EOS>
She
must
be
well
brought
up
,
and
well
guarded
from
reposing
any
foolish
confidences
where
they
are
not
deserved
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
make
that
MY
care
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
twitch
of
Miss
Betsey
's
head
,
after
each
of
these
sentences
,
as
if
her
own
old
wrongs
were
working
within
her
,
and
she
repressed
any
plainer
reference
to
them
by
strong
constraint
.
<EOS>
So
my
mother
suspected
,
at
least
,
as
she
observed
her
by
the
low
glimmer
of
the
fire
:
too
much
scared
by
Miss
Betsey
,
too
uneasy
in
herself
,
and
too
subdued
and
bewildered
altogether
,
to
observe
anything
very
clearly
,
or
to
know
what
to
say
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
was
David
good
to
you
,
child
?
"
asked
Miss
Betsey
,
when
she
had
been
silent
for
a
little
while
,
and
these
motions
of
her
head
had
gradually
ceased
.
 
<EOS>
"
Were
you
comfortable
together
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
were
very
happy
,
"
said
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Copperfield
was
only
too
good
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
,
he
spoilt
you
,
I
suppose
?
"
returned
Miss
Betsey
.
   
<EOS>
"
For
being
quite
alone
and
dependent
on
myself
in
this
rough
world
again
,
yes
,
I
fear
he
did
indeed
,
"
sobbed
my
mother
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
Do
n't
cry
!
"
said
Miss
Betsey
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
were
not
equally
matched
,
child
---
if
any
two
people
can
be
equally
matched
---
and
so
I
asked
the
question
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
an
orphan
,
were

you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
a
governess
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
nursery
-
governess
in
a
family
where
Mr
Copperfield
came
to
visit
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
was
very
kind
to
me
,
and
took
a
great
deal
of
notice
of
me
,
and
paid
me
a
good
deal
of
attention
,
and
at
last
proposed
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
accepted
him
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
we
were
married
,
"
said
my
mother
simply
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
 
<EOS>
Poor
Baby
!
"
<EOS>
mused
Miss
Betsey
,
with
her
frown
still
bent
upon
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
anything
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
ma'am
,
"
faltered
my
mother
.
   
<EOS>
"
About
keeping
house
,
for
instance
,
"
said
Miss
Betsey
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
much
,
I
fear
,
"
returned
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
so
much
as
I
could
wish
.
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
Copperfield
was
teaching
me
---
"
   
(
"
Much
he
knew
about
it
himself
!
"
)
said
Miss
Betsey
in
a
parenthesis
.
   
<EOS>
---
"
And
I
hope
I
should
have
improved
,
being
very
anxious
to
learn
,
and
he
very
patient
to
teach
me
,
if
the
great
misfortune
of
his
death
"
---
my
mother
broke
down
again
here
,
and
could
get
no
farther
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
"
said
Miss
Betsey
.
   
<EOS>
---
"
I
kept
my
housekeeping
-
book
regularly
,
and
balanced
it
with
Mr
Copperfield
every
night
,
"
cried
my
mother
in
another
burst
of
distress
,
and
breaking
down
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
"
said
Miss
Betsey
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
cry
any
more
.
"
   
---
"
<EOS>
And
I
am
sure
we
never
had
a
word
of
difference
respecting
it
,
except
when
Mr
Copperfield
objected
to
my
threes
and
fives
being
too
much
like
each
other
,
or
to
my
putting
curly
tails
to
my
sevens
and
nines
,
"
resumed
my
mother
in
another
burst
,
and
breaking
down
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
make
yourself
ill
,
"
said
Miss
Betsey
,
"
and
you
know
that
will
not
be
good
either
for
you
or
for
my
god
-
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
Come
!
 
<EOS>
You
must
n't
do
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
argument
had
some
share
in
quieting
my
mother
,
though
her
increasing
indisposition
had
a
larger
one
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
interval
of
silence
,
only
broken
by
Miss
Betsey
's
occasionally
ejaculating
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
"
as
she
sat
with
her
feet
upon
the
fender
.
   
<EOS>
"
David
had
bought
an
annuity
for
himself
with
his
money
,
I
know
,
"
said
she
,
by
and
by
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
did
he
do
for
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
my
mother
,
answering
with
some
difficulty
,
"
was
so
considerate
and
good
<EOS>
as
to
secure
the
reversion
of
a
part
of
it
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
much
?
"
asked
Miss
Betsey
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
hundred
and
five
pounds
a
year
,
"
said
my
mother
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
might
have
done
worse
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
The
word
was
appropriate
to
the
moment
.
 
<EOS>
My
mother
was
so
much
worse
that
Peggotty
,
coming
in
with
the
teaboard
and
candles
,
and
seeing
at
a
glance
how
ill
she
was
,
---
as
Miss
Betsey
might
have
done
sooner
if
there
had
been
light
enough
,
---
conveyed
her
upstairs
to
her
own
room
with
all
speed
;
and
immediately
dispatched
Ham
Peggotty
,
her
nephew
,
who
had
been
for
some
days
past
secreted
in
the
house
,
unknown
to
my
mother
,
as
a
special
messenger
in
case
of
emergency
,
to
fetch
the
nurse
and
doctor
.
   
<EOS>
Those
allied
powers
were
considerably
astonished
,
when
they
arrived
within
a
few
minutes
of
each
other
,
to
find
an
unknown
lady
of
portentous
appearance
,
sitting
before
the
fire
,
with
her
bonnet
tied
over
her
left
arm
,
stopping
her
ears
with
jewellers
'
cotton
.
<EOS>
Peggotty
knowing
nothing
about
her
,
and
my
mother
saying
nothing
about
her
,
she
was
quite
a
mystery
in
the
parlour
;
and
the
fact
of
her
having
a
magazine
of
jewellers
'
cotton
in
her
pocket
,
and
sticking
the
article
in
her
ears
in
that
way
,
did
not
detract
from
the
solemnity
of
her
presence
.
   
<EOS>
The
doctor
having
been
upstairs
and
come
down
again
,
and
having
satisfied
himself
,
I
suppose
,
that
there
was
a
probability
of
this
unknown
lady
and
himself
having
to
sit
there
,
face
to
face
,
for
some
hours
,
laid
himself
out
to
be
polite
and
social
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
the
meekest
of
his
sex
,
the
mildest
of
little
men
.
 
<EOS>
He
sidled
in
and
out
of
a
room
,
to
take
up
the
less
space
.
 
<EOS>
He
walked
as
softly
as
the
Ghost
in
Hamlet
,
and
more
slowly
.
 
<EOS>
He
carried
his
head
on
one
side
,
partly
in
modest
depreciation
of
himself
,
partly
in
modest
propitiation
of
everybody
else
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
nothing
to
say
that
he
had
n't
a
word
to
throw
at
a
dog
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
n't
have
thrown
a
word
at
a
mad
dog
.
 
<EOS>
He
might
have
offered
him
one
gently
,
or
half
a
one
,
or
a
fragment
of
one
;
for
he
spoke
as
slowly
as
he
walked
;
but
he
would
n't
have
been
rude
to
him
,
and
he
could
n't
have
been
quick
with
him
,
for
any
earthly
consideration
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chillip
,
looking
mildly
at
my
aunt
with
his
head
on
one
side
,
and
making
her
a
little
bow
,
said
,
in
allusion
to
the
jewellers
'
cotton
,
as
he
softly
touched
his
left
ear
:
   
<EOS>
"
Some
local
irritation
,
ma'am
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
replied
my
aunt
,
pulling
the
cotton
out
of
one
ear
like
a
cork
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chillip
was
so
alarmed
by
her
abruptness
---
as
he
told
my
mother
afterwards
---
that
it
was
a
mercy
he
did
n't
lose
his
presence
of
mind
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
repeated
sweetly
:
   
<EOS>
"
Some
local
irritation
,
ma'am
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
!
"
<EOS>
replied
my
aunt
,
and
corked
herself
again
,
at
one
blow
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chillip
could
do
nothing
after
this
,
but
sit
and
look
at
her
feebly
,
as
she
sat
and
looked
at
the
fire
,
until
he
was
called
upstairs
again
.
 
<EOS>
After
some
quarter
of
an
hour
's
absence
,
he
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
?
"
said
my
aunt
,
taking
the
cotton
out
of
the
ear
nearest
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
ma'am
,
"
returned
Mr
Chillip
,
"
<EOS>
we
are
---
we
are
progressing
slowly
,
ma'am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ba
-
a
-
ah
!
"
said
my
aunt
,
with
a
perfect
shake
on
the
contemptuous
interjection
.
 
<EOS>
And
corked
herself
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
Really
---
really
---
as
Mr
Chillip
told
my
mother
,
he
was
almost
shocked
;
speaking
in
a
professional
point
of
view
alone
,
he
was
almost
shocked
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
sat
and
looked
at
her
,
notwithstanding
,
for
nearly
two
hours
,
as
she
sat
looking
at
the
fire
,
until
he
was
again
called
out
.
 
<EOS>
After
another
absence
,
he
again
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
?
"
said
my
aunt
,
taking
out
the
cotton
on
that
side
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
ma'am
,
"
returned
Mr
Chillip
,
"
<EOS>
we
are
---
we
are
progressing
slowly
,
ma'am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ya
-
<EOS>
a
-
ah
!
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
With
such
a
snarl
at
him
,
that
Mr
Chillip
absolutely
could
not
bear
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
really
calculated
to
break
his
spirit
,
he
said
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
He
preferred
to
go
and
sit
upon
the
stairs
,
in
the
dark
and
a
strong
draught
,
until
he
was
again
sent
for
.
   
<EOS>
Ham
Peggotty
,
who
went
to
the
national
school
,
and
was
a
very
dragon
at
his
catechism
,
and
who
may
therefore
be
regarded
as
a
credible
witness
,
reported
next
day
,
that
happening
to
peep
in
at
the
parlour
-
door
an
hour
after
this
,
he
was
instantly
descried
by
Miss
Betsey
,
then
walking
to
and
fro
in
a
state
of
agitation
,
and
pounced
upon
before
he
could
make
his
escape
.
 
<EOS>
That
there
were
now
occasional
sounds
of
feet
and
voices
overhead
<EOS>
which
he
inferred
the
cotton
did
not
exclude
,
from
the
circumstance
of
his
evidently
being
clutched
by
the
lady
as
a
victim
on
whom
to
expend
her
superabundant
agitation
when
the
sounds
were
loudest
.
 
<EOS>
That
,
marching
him
constantly
up
and
down
by
the
collar
(
as
if
he
had
been
taking
too
much
laudanum
)
,
she
,
at
those
times
,
shook
him
,
rumpled
his
hair
,
made
light
of
his
linen
,
stopped
his
ears
as
if
she
confounded
them
with
her
own
,
and
otherwise
tousled
and
maltreated

.
 
<EOS>
This
was
in
part
confirmed
by
his
aunt
,
who
saw
him
at
half
past
twelve
o'clock
,
soon
after
his
release
,
and
affirmed
that
he
was
then
as
red
as
I
was
.
   
<EOS>
The
mild
Mr
Chillip
could
not
possibly
bear
malice
at
such
a
time
,
if
at
any
time
.
 
<EOS>
He
sidled
into
the
parlour
as
soon
as
he
was
at
liberty
,
and
said
to
my
aunt
in
his
meekest
manner
:
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
ma'am
,
I
am
happy
to
congratulate
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
upon
?
"
said
my
aunt
,
sharply
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chillip
was
fluttered
again
,
by
the
extreme
severity
of
my
aunt
's
manner
;
so
he
made
her
a
little
bow
and
gave
her
a
little
smile
,
to
mollify
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mercy
on
the
man
,
what
's
he
doing
!
"
<EOS>
cried
my
aunt
,
impatiently
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ca
n't
he
speak
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Be
calm
,
my
dear
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Chillip
,
in
his
softest
accents
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
longer
any
occasion
for
uneasiness
,
ma'am
.
 
<EOS>
Be
calm
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
has
since
been
considered
almost
a
miracle
that
my
aunt
did
n't
shake
him
,
and
shake
what
he
had
to
say
,
out
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
She
only
shook
her
own
head
at
him
,
but
in
a
way
that
made
him
quail
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
ma'am
,
"
resumed
Mr
Chillip
,
as
soon
as
he
had

,
"
I
am
happy
to
congratulate
you
.
 
<EOS>
All
is
now
over
,
ma'am
,
and
well
over
.
"
   
<EOS>
During
the
five

or
so
that
Mr
Chillip
devoted
to
the
delivery
of
this
oration
,
my
aunt
eyed

narrowly
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
is
she
?
"
said
my
aunt
,
folding
her

with
her
bonnet
still

on
one

them
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
ma'am
,
she
will
soon
be
quite
comfortable
,
I
hope
,
"
returned
Mr
Chillip
.
 
<EOS>
"
Quite
as
comfortable
as
we
can
expect
a
young
mother
to
be
,
under
these

.
 
<EOS>
There
can
not
be
any
objection
to
your
seeing
her
presently
,
ma'am
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
do
her
good
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
SHE
.
 
<EOS>
How
is
SHE
?
"
said
my
aunt
,
sharply
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chillip
laid
his
head
a
little
more
on
one
side
,
and
looked
at
my
aunt
like
an
amiable
bird
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
baby
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
is
she
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ma'am
,
"
returned
Mr
Chillip
,
"
<EOS>
I
apprehended
you
had
known
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
boy
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
said
never
a
word
,
but
took
her
bonnet
by
the
strings
,
in
the
manner
of
a
sling
,
aimed
a
blow
at
Mr
Chillip
's
head
with
it
,
put
it
on
bent
,
walked
out
,
and
never
came
back
.
 
<EOS>
She
vanished
like
a
discontented
fairy
;
or
like
one
of
those
supernatural
beings
,
whom
it
was
popularly
supposed
I
was
entitled
to
see
;
and
never
came
back
any
more
.
   
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
I
lay
in
my
basket
,
and
my
mother
lay
in
her
bed
;
but
Betsey
Trotwood
Copperfield
was
for
ever
in
the
land
of
dreams
and
shadows
,
<EOS>
the
tremendous
region
whence
I
had
so
lately
travelled
;
and
the
light
upon
the
window
of
our
room
shone
out
upon
the
earthly
bourne
of
all
such
travellers
,
and
the
mound
above
the
ashes
and
the
dust
that
once
was
he
,
without
whom
I
had
never
been
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
2
.
<EOS>
I
Observe
 
<EOS>
The
first
objects
that
assume
a
distinct
presence
before
me
,
as
I
look
far
back
,
into
the
blank
of
my
infancy
,
are
my
mother
with
her
pretty
hair
and
youthful
shape
,
and
Peggotty
with
no
shape
at
all
,
and
eyes
<EOS>
so
dark
that
they
seemed
to
darken
their
whole
neighbourhood
in
her
face
,
and
cheeks
and
arms
so
hard
and
red
that
I
wondered
the
birds
did
n't
peck
her
in
preference
to
apples
.
   
<EOS>
I
believe
I
can
remember
these
two
at
a
little
distance
apart
,
dwarfed
to
my
sight
by
stooping
down
or
kneeling
on
the
floor
,
and
I
going
unsteadily
from
the
one
to
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
an
impression
on
my
mind
which
I
can
not
distinguish
from
actual
remembrance
,
of
the
touch
of
Peggotty
's
forefinger
as
she
used
to
hold
it
out
to
me
,
and
of
its
being
roughened
by
needlework
,
like
a
pocket
nutmeg
-
grater
.
   
<EOS>
This
may
be
fancy
,
though
I
think
the
memory
of
most
of
us
can
go
farther
back
into
such
times
than
many
of
us
suppose
;
just
as
I
believe
the
power
of
observation
in
numbers
of
very
young
children
to
be
quite
wonderful
for
its
closeness
and
accuracy
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
I
think
that
most
grown
men
who
are
remarkable
in
this
respect
,
may
with
greater
propriety
be
said
not
to
have
lost
the
faculty
,
than
to
have
acquired
it
;
the
rather
,
as
I
generally
observe
such
men
to
retain
a
certain
freshness
,
and
gentleness
,
and
capacity
of
being
pleased
,
which
are
also
an
inheritance
they
have
preserved
from
their
childhood
.
   
<EOS>
I
might
have
a
misgiving
that
I
am
"
meandering
"
in
stopping
to
say
this
,
but
that
it
brings
me
to
remark
that
I
build
these
conclusions
,
in
part
upon
my
own
experience
of
myself
;
and
if
it
should
appear
from
anything
I
may
set
down
in
this
narrative
that
I
was
a
child
of
close
observation
,
or
that
as
a
man
I
have
a
strong
memory
of
my
childhood
,
I
undoubtedly
lay
claim
to
both
of
these
characteristics
.
   
<EOS>
Looking
back
,
as
I
was
saying
,
into
the
blank
of
my
infancy
,
the
first
objects
I
can
remember
as
standing
out
by
themselves
from
a
confusion
of
things
,
are
my
mother
and
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
What
else
do
I
remember
?
 
<EOS>
Let
me
see
.
   
<EOS>
There
comes
out
of
the
cloud
,
our
house
---
not
new
to
me
,
but
quite
familiar
,
in
its
earliest
remembrance
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
ground
-
floor
is
Peggotty
's
kitchen
,
opening
into
a
back
yard
;
with
a
pigeon
-
house
on
a
pole
,
in
the
centre
,
without
any
pigeons
in
it
;
a
great
dog
-
kennel
in
a
corner
,
without
any
dog
;
and
a
quantity
of
fowls
that
look
terribly
tall
to
me
,
walking
about
,
in
a
menacing
and
ferocious
manner
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
one
cock
who
gets
upon
a
post
to
crow
,
and
seems
to
take
particular
notice
of
me
as
I
look
at
him
through
the
kitchen
window
,
who
makes
me
shiver
,
he
is
so
fierce
.
 
<EOS>
Of
the
geese
outside
the
side
-
gate
who
come
waddling
after
me
with
their
long
necks
<EOS>
stretched
out
when
I
go
that
way
<EOS>
,
I
dream
at
night
:
<EOS>
as
a
man
environed
by
wild
beasts
might
dream
of
lions
.
   
<EOS>
Here
is
a
long
passage
---
what
an
enormous
perspective
I
make
of
it
!
<EOS>
---
leading
from
Peggotty
's
kitchen
to
the
front
door
.
 
<EOS>
A
dark
store
-
room
opens
out
of
it
,
and
that
is
a
place
to
be
run
past
at
night
;
for
I
do
n't
know
what
may
be
among
those
tubs
and
jars
and
old
tea
-
chests
,
when
there
is
nobody
in
there
with
a
dimly
-
burning
light
,
letting
a
mouldy
air
come
out
of
the
door
,
in
which
there
is
the
smell
of
soap
,
pickles
,
pepper
,
candles
,
and
coffee
,
all
at
one
whiff
.
 
<EOS>
Then
there
are
the
two
parlours
:
the
parlour
in
which
we
sit
of
an
evening
,
my
mother
and
I
and
Peggotty
---
for
Peggotty
is
quite
our
companion
,
when
her
work
is
done
and
we
are
alone
---
and
the
best
parlour
where
we
sit
on
a
Sunday
;
grandly
,
but
not
so
comfortably
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
something
of
a
doleful
air
about
that
room
to
me
,
for
Peggotty
has
told
me
---
I
do
n't
know
when
,
<EOS>
but
apparently
ages
ago
---
about
my
father
's
funeral
,
and
the
company
having
their
black
cloaks
put
on
.
 
<EOS>
One
Sunday
night
my
mother
reads
to
Peggotty
and
me
in
there
,
how
Lazarus
was
raised
up
from
the
dead
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
am
so
frightened
that
they
are
afterwards
obliged
to
take
me
out
of
bed
,
and
show
me
the
quiet
churchyard
out
of
the
bedroom
window
,
with
the
dead
all
lying
in
their
graves
at
rest
,
below
the
solemn
moon
.
   
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
half
so
green
that
I
know
anywhere
,
as
the
grass
of
that
churchyard
;
nothing
half
so
shady
as
its
trees
;
nothing
half
so
quiet
as
its
tombstones
.
 
<EOS>
The
sheep
are
feeding
there
,
when
I
kneel
up
,
early
in
the
morning
,
in
my
little
bed
in
a
closet
within
my
mother
's
room
,
to
look
out
at
it
;
and
I
see
the
red
light
shining
on
the
sun
-
dial
,
and
think
within
myself
,
"
Is
the
sun
-
dial
glad
,
I
wonder
,
that
it
can
tell
the
time
again
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Here
is
our
pew
in
the
church
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
high
-
backed
pew
!
 
<EOS>
With
a
window
near
it
,
out
of
which
our
house
can
be
seen
,
and
IS
seen
many
times
during
the
morning
's
service
,
by
Peggotty
,
who
likes
to
make
herself
as
sure
as
she
can
that
it
's
not
being
robbed
,
or
is
not
in
flames
.
 
<EOS>
But
though
Peggotty
's
eye
wanders
,
she
is
much
offended
if
mine
does
,
and
frowns
to
me
,
as
I
stand
upon
the
seat
,
that
I
am
to
look
at
the
clergyman
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
ca
n't
always
look
at
him
---
I
know
him
without
that
white
thing
on
,
and
I
am
afraid
of
his
wondering
why
I
stare
so
,
and
perhaps
stopping
the
service
to
inquire
---
and
what
am
I
to
do
?
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
dreadful
thing
to
gape
,
but
I
must
do
something
.
 
<EOS>
I
look
at
my
mother
,
but
she
pretends
not
to
see
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
look
at
a
boy
in
the
aisle
,
and
he
makes
faces
at
me
.
<EOS>
I
look
at
the
sunlight
coming
in
at
the
open
door
through
the
porch
,
and
there
I
see
a
stray
sheep
<EOS>
---
I
do
n't
mean
a
sinner
,
but
mutton
---
half
making
up
his
mind
to
come
into
the
church
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
that
if
I
looked
at
him
any
longer
,
I
might
be
tempted
to
say
something
out
loud
;
and
what
would
become
of
me
then
!
 
<EOS>
I
look
up
at
the
monumental
tablets
on
the
wall
,
and
try
to
think
of
Mr
Bodgers
late
of
this
parish
,
and
what
the
feelings
of
Mrs
Bodgers
must
have
been
,
when
affliction
sore
,
long
time
Mr
Bodgers
bore
,
and
physicians
were
in
vain
.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
whether
they
called
in
Mr
Chillip
,
and
he
was
in
vain
;
and
if
so
,
how
he
likes
to
be
reminded
of
it
once
a
week
.
 
<EOS>
I
look
from
Mr
Chillip
,
in
his
Sunday
neckcloth
,
to
the
pulpit
;
and
think
what
a
good
place
it
would
be
to
play
in
,
and
what
a
castle
it
would
make
,
with
another
boy
coming
up
the
stairs
to
attack
it
,
and
having
the
velvet
cushion
with
the
tassels
thrown
down
on
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
In
time
my
eyes
gradually
shut
up
;
and
,
from
seeming
to
hear
the
clergyman
singing
a
drowsy
song
in
the
heat
,
I
hear
nothing
,
until
I
fall
off
the
seat
with
a
crash
,
and
am
taken
out
,
more
dead
than
alive
,
by
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
I
see
the
outside
of
our
house
,
with
the
latticed
bedroom
-
windows
standing
open
to
let
in
the
sweet
-
smelling
air
,
and
<EOS>
the
ragged
old
rooks'-nests
still
dangling
in
the
elm
-
trees
at
the
bottom
of
the
front
garden
.
 
<EOS>
Now
I
am
in
the
garden
at
the
back
,
beyond
the
yard
where
the
empty
pigeon
-
house
and
dog
-
kennel
are
---
a
very
preserve
of
butterflies
,
as
I
remember
it
,
with
a
high
fence
,
and
a
gate
and
padlock
;
where
the
fruit
clusters
on
the
trees
,
riper
and
richer
than
fruit
has
ever
been
since
,
in
any
other
garden
,
and
where
my
mother
gathers
some
in
a
basket
,
while
I
stand
by
,
bolting
furtive
gooseberries
,
and
trying
to
look
unmoved
.
 
<EOS>
A
great
wind
rises
,
and
the
summer
is
gone
in
a
moment
.
<EOS>
We
are
playing
in
the
winter
twilight
,
dancing
about
the
parlour
.
<EOS>
When
my
mother
is
out
of
breath
and
rests
herself
in
an
elbow
-
chair
,
I
watch
her
winding
her
bright
curls
round
her
fingers
,
and
straitening
her
waist
,
and
nobody
knows
better
than
I
do
that
she
likes
to
look
so
well
,
and
is
proud
of
being
so
pretty
.
   
<EOS>
That
is
among
my
very
earliest
impressions
.
 
<EOS>
That
,
and
a
sense
that
we
were
both
a
little
afraid
of
Peggotty
,
and
submitted
ourselves
in
most
things
to
her
direction
,
were
among
the
first
opinions
---
if
they
may
be
so
called
---
that
I
ever
derived
from
what
I
saw
.
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
and
I
were
sitting
one
night
by
the
parlour
fire
,
alone
.
<EOS>
I
had
been
reading
to
Peggotty
about
crocodiles
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
have
read
very
perspicuously
,
or
the
poor
soul
must
have
been
deeply
interested
,
for
I
remember
she
had
a
cloudy
impression
,
after
I
had
done
,
that
they
were
a
sort
of
vegetable
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
tired
of
reading
,
and
dead
sleepy
;
but
having
leave
,
as
a
high
treat
,
to
sit
up
until
my
mother
came
home
from
spending
the
evening
at
a
neighbour
's
,
I
would
rather
have
died
upon
my
post
(
of
course
)
than
have
gone
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
reached
that
stage
of
sleepiness
when
Peggotty
seemed
to
swell
and
grow
immensely
large
.
 
<EOS>
I
propped
my
eyelids
open
with
my
two
forefingers
,
and
looked
perseveringly
at
her
as
she
sat
at
work
;
at
the
little
bit
of
wax
-
candle
she
kept
for
her
thread
---
how
old
it
looked
,
being
so
wrinkled
in
all
directions
!
<EOS>
---
at
the
little
house
with
a
thatched
roof
,
where
the
yard
-
measure
lived
;
at
her
work
-
box
with
a
sliding
lid
,
with
a
view
of
St
Paul
's
Cathedral
(
with
a
pink
dome
)
painted
on
the
top
;
at
the
brass
thimble
on
her
finger
;
at
herself
,
whom
I
thought
lovely
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
so
sleepy
,
that
I
knew
if
I
lost
sight
of
anything
for
a
moment
,
I
was
gone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Peggotty
,
"
says
I
,
suddenly
,
"
were
you
ever
married
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
,
Master
Davy
,
"
replied
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
put
marriage
in
your
head
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
answered
with
such
a
start
,
that
it
quite
awoke
me
.
 
<EOS>
And
then
she
stopped
in
her
work
,
and
looked
at
me
,
with
her
needle
drawn
out
to
its
thread
's
length
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
WERE
you
ever
married
,
Peggotty
?
"
says
I.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
very
handsome
woman
,
an't
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
thought
her
in
a
different
style
from
my
mother
,
certainly
;
but
of
another
school
of
beauty
,
I
considered
her
a
perfect
example
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
red
velvet
footstool
in
the
best
parlour
,
on
which
my
mother
had
painted
a
nosegay
.
 
<EOS>
The
ground
-
work
of
that
stool
,
and
Peggotty
's
complexion
appeared
to
me
to
be
one
and
the
same
thing
.
<EOS>
The
stool
was
smooth
,
and
Peggotty
was
rough
,
but
that
made
no
difference
.
   
<EOS>
"
Me
handsome
,
Davy
!
"
said
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
Lawk
,
no
,
my
dear
!
 
<EOS>
But
what
put
marriage
in
your
head
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
!
<EOS>
---
You
must
n't
marry
more
than
one
person
at
a
time
,
may
you
,
Peggotty
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
not
,
"
says
Peggotty
,
with
the
promptest
decision
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
if
you
marry
a
person
,
and
the
person
dies
,
why
then
you
may
marry
another
person
,
may
n't
you
,
Peggotty
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
YOU
MAY
,
"
says
Peggotty
,
"
if
you
choose
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
a
matter
of
opinion
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
what
is
your
opinion
,
Peggotty
?
"
said
I.
   
I
asked
her
,
and
looked
curiously
at
her
,
because
she
looked
so
curiously
at
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
opinion
is
,
"
said
Peggotty
,
taking
her
eyes
from
me
,
after
a
little
indecision
and
going
on
with
her
work
,
"
that
I
never
was
married
myself
,
Master
Davy
,
and
that
I
do
n't
expect
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
all
I
know
about
the
subject
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
an't
cross
,
I
suppose
,
Peggotty
,
are
you
?
"
<EOS>
said
I
,
after
sitting
quiet
for
a
minute
.
   
<EOS>
I
really
thought
she
was
,
she
had
been
so
short
with
me
;
but
I
was
quite
mistaken
:
for
she
laid
aside
her
work
(
which
was
a
stocking
of
her
own
)
,
and
opening
her
arms
wide
,
took
my
curly
head
within
them
,
and
gave
it
a
good
squeeze
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
it
was
a
good
squeeze
,
because
,
being
very
plump
,
whenever
she
made
any
little
exertion
after
she
was
dressed
,
some
of
the
buttons
on
the
back
of
her
gown
flew
off
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
recollect
two
bursting
to
the
opposite
side
of
the
parlour
,
while
she
was
hugging
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
let
me
hear
some
more
about
the
Crorkindills
,
"
said
Peggotty
,
who
was
not
quite
right
in
the
name
yet
,
"
<EOS>
for
I
an't
heard
half
enough
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
n't
quite
understand
why
Peggotty
looked
so
queer
,
or
why
she
was
so
ready
to
go
back
to
the
crocodiles
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
we
returned
to
those
monsters
,
with
fresh
wakefulness
on
my
part
,
and
we
left
their
eggs
in
the
sand
for
the
sun
to
hatch
;
and
we
ran
away
from
them
,
and
baffled
them
by
constantly
turning
,
which
they
were
unable
to
do
quickly
,
on
account
of
their
unwieldy
make
;
and
we
went
into
the
water
after
them
,
as
natives
,
and
put
sharp
pieces
of
timber
down
their
throats
;
and
in
short
we
ran
the
whole
crocodile
gauntlet
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
,
at
least
;
but
I
had
my
doubts
of
Peggotty
,
who
was
thoughtfully
sticking
her
needle
into
various
parts
of
her
face
and
arms
,
all
the
time
.
   
<EOS>
We
had
exhausted
the
crocodiles
,
and
begun
with
the
alligators
,
when
the
garden
-
bell
rang
.
 
<EOS>
We
went
out
to
the
door
;
and
there
was
my
mother
,
looking
unusually
pretty
,
I
thought
,
and
with
her
a
gentleman
with
beautiful
black
hair
and
whiskers
,
who
had
walked
home
with
us
from
church
last
Sunday
.
   
<EOS>
As
my
mother
stooped
down
on
the
threshold
to
take
me
in
her
arms
and
kiss
me
,
the
gentleman
said
I
was
a
more
highly
privileged
little
fellow
than
a
monarch
---
or
something
like
that
;
for
my
later
understanding
comes
,
I
am
sensible
,
to
my
aid
here
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
does
that
mean
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
him
,
over
her
shoulder
.
   
<EOS>
He
patted
me
on
the
head
;
but
somehow
,
I
did
n't
like
him
or
his
deep
voice
,
and
I
was
jealous
that
his
hand
should
touch
my
mother
's
in
touching
me
---
which
it
did
.
 
<EOS>
I
put
it
away
,
as
well
as
I
could
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Davy
!
<EOS>
"
remonstrated
my
mother
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
boy
!
"
said
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
wonder
at
his
devotion
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
never
saw
such
a
beautiful
colour
on
my
mother
's
face
before
.
<EOS>
She
gently
chid
me
for
being
rude
;
and
,
keeping
me
close
to
her
shawl
,
turned
to
thank
the
gentleman
for
taking
so
much
trouble
as
to
bring
her
home
.
 
<EOS>
She
put
out
her
hand
to
him
as
she
spoke
,
and
,
as
he
met
it
with
his
own
,
she
glanced
,
I
thought
,
at
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
us
say
"
good
night
"
,
my
fine
boy
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
when
he
had
bent
his
head
---
I
saw
him
!
<EOS>
---
over
my
mother
's
little
glove
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
!
"
said
<EOS>
I.
   
"
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Let
us
be
the
best
friends
in
the
world
!
"
said
the
gentleman
,
laughing
.
 
<EOS>
"
Shake
hands
!
"
   
<EOS>
My
right
hand
was
in
my
mother
's
left
,
so
I
gave
him
the
other
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
that
's
the
Wrong
hand
,
Davy
!
"
laughed
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
MY
mother
drew
my
right
hand
forward
,
but
I
was
resolved
,
for
my
former
reason
,
not
to
give
it
him
,
and
I
did
not
.
 
<EOS>
I
gave
him
the
other
,
and
he
shook
it
heartily
,
and
said
I
was
a
brave
fellow
,
and
went
away
.
   
<EOS>
At
this
minute
I
see
him
turn
round
in
the
garden
,
and
give
us
a
last
look
with
his
ill
-
omened
black
eyes
,
before
the
door
was
shut
.
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
,
who
had
not
said
a
word
or
moved
a
finger
,
secured
the
fastenings
instantly
,
and
we
all
went
into
the
parlour
.
 
<EOS>
My
mother
,
contrary
to
her
usual
habit
,
instead
of
coming
to
the
elbow
-
chair
by
the
fire
,
remained
at
the
other
end
of
the
room
,
and
sat
singing
to
herself
.
   
<EOS>
---
"
Hope
you
have
had
a
pleasant
evening
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Peggotty
,
standing
as
stiff
as
a
barrel
in
the
centre
of
the
room
,
with
a
candlestick
in
her
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Much
obliged
to
you
,
Peggotty
,
"
returned
my
mother
,
in
a
cheerful
voice
,
"
I
have
had
a
VERY
pleasant
evening
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
A
stranger
or
so
makes
an
agreeable
change
,
"
suggested
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
very
agreeable
change
,
indeed
,
"
returned
my
mother
.
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
continuing
to
stand
motionless
in
the
middle
of
the
room
,
and
my
mother
resuming
her
singing
<EOS>
,
I
fell
asleep
,
though
I
was
not
so
sound
asleep
<EOS>
but
that
I
could
hear
voices
,
without
hearing
what
they
said
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
half
awoke
from
this
uncomfortable
doze
,
I
found
Peggotty
and
my
mother
both
in
tears
,
and
both
talking
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
such
a
one
as
this
,
Mr
Copperfield
would
n't
have
liked
,
"
said
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
I
say
,
and
that
I
swear
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
Heavens
!
"
cried
my
mother
,
"
you
'll
drive
me
mad
!
 
<EOS>
Was
ever
any
poor
girl
so
ill
-
used
by
her
servants
as
I
am
!
 
<EOS>
Why
do
I
do
myself
the
injustice
of
calling
myself
a
girl
?
 
<EOS>
Have
I
never
been
married
,
Peggotty
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
God
knows
you
have
,
ma'am
,
"
returned
Peggotty
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
,
how
can
you
dare
,
"
said
my
mother
---
"
<EOS>
you
know
I
do
n't
mean
how
can
you
dare
,
Peggotty
,
but
how
can
you
have
the
heart
---
to
make
me
so
uncomfortable
and
say
such
bitter
things
to
me
,
when
you
are
well
aware
that
I
have
n't
,
out
of
this
place
,
a
single
friend
to
turn
to
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
more
's
the
reason
,
"
returned
Peggotty
,
"
for
saying
that
it
wo
n't
do
.
 
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
That
it
wo
n't
do
.
 
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
No
price
could
make
it
do
.
<EOS>
No
!
"
---
I
thought
Peggotty
would
have
thrown
the
candlestick
away
,
she
was
so
emphatic
with
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
can
you
be
so
aggravating
,
"
said
my
mother
,
shedding
more
tears
than
before
,
"
as
to
talk
in
such
an
unjust
manner
!
 
<EOS>
How
can
you
go
on
as
if
it
was
all
settled
and
arranged
,
<EOS>
Peggotty
,
when
I
tell
you
over
and
over
again
,
you
cruel
thing
,
that
beyond
the
commonest
civilities
nothing
has
passed
!
 
<EOS>
You
talk
of
admiration
.
<EOS>
What
am
I
to
do
?
 
<EOS>
If
people
are
so
silly
as
to
indulge
the
sentiment
,
is
it
my
fault
?
 
<EOS>
What
am
I
to
do
,
I
ask
you
?
 
<EOS>
Would
you
wish
me
to
shave
my
head
and
black
my
face
,
or
disfigure
myself
with
a
burn
,
or
a
scald
,
or
something
of
that
sort
?
 
<EOS>
I
dare
say
you
would
,
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
I
dare
say
you
'd
quite
enjoy
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
seemed
to
take
this
aspersion
very
much
to
heart
,
I
thought
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
my
dear
boy
,
"
cried
my
mother
,
coming
to
the
elbow
-
chair
in
which
I
was
,
and
caressing
me
,
"
my
own
little
Davy
!
 
<EOS>
Is
it
to
be
hinted
to
me
that
I
am
wanting
in
affection
for
my
precious
treasure
,
the
dearest
little
fellow
that
ever
was
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nobody
never
went
and
hinted
no
such
a
thing
,
"
said
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
did
,
Peggotty
!
"
returned
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
you
did
.
 
<EOS>
What
else
was
it
possible
to
infer
from
what
you
said
,
you
unkind
creature
,
when
you
know
as
well
as
I
do
,
that
on
his
account
only
last
quarter
I
would
n't
buy
myself
a
new
parasol
,
though
that
old
green
one
is
frayed
the
whole
way
up
,
and
the
fringe
is
perfectly
mangy
?
 
<EOS>
You
know
it
is
,
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
deny
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Then
,
turning
affectionately
to
me
,
with
her
cheek
against
mine
,
"
Am
I
a
naughty
mama
to
you
,
Davy
?
 
<EOS>
Am
I
a
nasty
,
cruel
,
selfish
,
bad
mama
?
<EOS>
Say
I
am
,
my
child
;
say
"
yes
"
,
dear
boy
,
and
Peggotty
will
love
you
;
and
Peggotty
's
love
is
a
great
deal
better
than
mine
,
Davy
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
love
you
at
all
,
do
I
?
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
,
we
all
fell
a
-
crying
together
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
was
the
loudest
of
the
party
,
but
I
am
sure
we
were
all
sincere
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
quite
heart
-
broken
myself
,
and
am
afraid
that
in
the
first
transports
of
wounded
tenderness
I
called
Peggotty
a
"
Beast
"
.
 
<EOS>
That
honest
creature
was
in
deep
affliction
,
I
remember
,
and
must
have
become
quite
buttonless
on
the
occasion
;
for
a
little
volley
of
those
explosives
went
off
,
when
,
after
having
made
it
up
with
my
mother
,
she
kneeled
down
by
the
elbow
-
chair
,
and
made
it
up
with
me
.
   
<EOS>
We
went
to
bed
greatly
dejected
.
 
<EOS>
My
sobs
kept
waking
me
,
for
a
long
time
;
and
when
one
very
strong
sob
quite
hoisted
me
up
in
bed
,
I
found
my
mother
sitting
on
the
coverlet
,
and
leaning
over
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
fell
asleep
in
her
arms
,
after
that
,
and
slept
soundly
.
   
<EOS>
Whether
it
was
the
following
Sunday
when
I
saw
the
gentleman
again
,
or
whether
there
was
any
greater
lapse
of
time
before
he
reappeared
,
I
can
not
recall
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
profess
to
be
clear
about
dates
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
he
was
,
in
church
,
and
he
walked
home
with
us
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
He
came
in
,
too
,
to
look
at
a
famous
geranium
we
had
,
in
the
parlour
-
window
.
 
<EOS>
It
did
not
appear
to
me
that
he
took
much
notice
of
it
,
but
before
he
went
he
asked
my
mother
to
give
him
a
bit
of
the
blossom
.
 
<EOS>
She
begged
him
to
choose
it
for
himself
,
but
he
refused
to
do
that
<EOS>
---
I
could
not
understand
why
---
so
she
plucked
it
for
him
,
and
gave
it
into
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
he
would
never
,
never
part
with
it
any
more
;
and
I
thought
he
must
be
quite
a
fool
not
to
know
that
it
would
fall
to
pieces
in
a
day
or
two
.
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
began
to
be
less
with
us
,
of
an
evening
,
than
she
had
always
been
.
 
<EOS>
My
mother
deferred
to
her
very
much
---
more
than
usual
,
it
occurred
to
me
---
and
we
were
all
three
excellent
friends
;
still
we
were
different
from
what
we
used
to
be
,
and
were
not
so
comfortable
among
ourselves
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
I
fancied
that
Peggotty
perhaps
objected
to
my
mother
's
wearing
all
the
pretty
dresses
she
had
in
her
drawers
,
or
to
her
going
so
often
to
visit
at
that
neighbour
's
;
but
I
could
n't
,
to
my
satisfaction
,
make
out
how
it
was
.
   
<EOS>
Gradually
,
I
became
used
to
seeing
the
gentleman
with
the
black
whiskers
.
 
<EOS>
I
liked
him
no
better
than
at
first
,
and
had
the
same
uneasy
jealousy
of
him
;
but
if
I
had
any
reason
for
it
beyond
a
child
's
instinctive
dislike
,
and
a
general
idea
that
Peggotty
and
I
could
make
much
of
my
mother
without
any
help
,
it
certainly
was
not
THE
reason
that
I
might
have
found
if
I
had
been
older
.
 
<EOS>
No
such
thing
came
into
my
mind
,
or
near
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
observe
,
in
little
pieces
,
as
it
were
;
but
as
to
making
a
net
of
a
number
of
these
pieces
,
and
catching
anybody
in
it
,
that
was
,
as
yet
,
beyond
me
.
   
<EOS>
One
autumn
morning
I
was
with
my
mother
in
the
front
garden
,
when
Mr
Murdstone
---
I
knew
him
by
that
name
now
---
came
by
,
on
horseback
.
 
<EOS>
He
reined
up
his
horse
to
salute
my
mother
,
and
said
he
was
going
to
Lowestoft
to
see
some
friends
who
were
there
with
a
yacht
,
and
merrily
proposed
to
take
me
on
the
saddle
before
him
if
I
would
like
the
ride
.
   
<EOS>
The
air
was
so
clear
and
pleasant
,
and
the
horse
seemed
to
like
the
idea
of
the
ride
so
much
himself
,
as
he
stood
snorting
and
pawing
at
the
garden
-
gate
,
that
I
had
a
great
desire
to
go
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
was
sent
upstairs
to
Peggotty
to
be
made
spruce
;
and
in
the
meantime
Mr
Murdstone
dismounted
,
and
,
with
his
horse
's
bridle
drawn
over
his
arm
,
walked
slowly
up
and
down
on
the
outer
side
of
the
sweetbriar
fence
,
while
my
mother
walked
slowly
up
and
down
on
the
inner
to
keep
him
company
.
 
<EOS>
I
recollect
Peggotty
<EOS>
and
I
peeping
out
at
them
from
my
little
window
;
I
recollect
how
closely
they
seemed
to
be
examining
the
sweetbriar
between
them
,
as
they
strolled
along
;
and
how
,
from
being
in
a
perfectly
angelic
temper
,
Peggotty
turned
cross
in
a
moment
,
and
brushed
my
hair
the
wrong
way
,
excessively
hard
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Murdstone
and
I
were
soon
off
,
and
trotting
along
on
the
green
turf
by
the
side
of
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
He
held
me
quite
easily
with
one
arm
,
and
I
do
n't
think
I
was
restless
usually
;
but
I
could
not
make
up
my
mind
to
sit
in
front
of
him
without
turning
my
head
sometimes
,
and
looking
up
in
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
that
kind
of
shallow
black
eye
<EOS>
---
I
want
a
better
word
to
express
an
eye
that
has
no
depth
in
it
to
be
looked
into
---
which
,
when
it
is
abstracted
,
seems
from
some
peculiarity
of
light
to
be
disfigured
,
for
a
moment
at
a
time
,
by
a
cast
.
 
<EOS>
Several
times
when
I
glanced
at
him
,
I
observed
that
appearance
with
a
sort
of
awe
,
and
wondered
what
he
was
thinking
about
so
closely
.
 
<EOS>
His
hair
and
whiskers
were
blacker
and
thicker
,
looked
at
so
near
,
than
even
I
had
given
them
credit
for
being
.
 
<EOS>
A
squareness
about
the
lower
part
of
his
face
,
and
the
dotted
indication
of
the
strong
black
beard
he
shaved
close
every
day
,
reminded
me
of
the
wax
-
work
that
had
travelled
into
our
neighbourhood
some
half
-
a
-
year
before
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
his
regular
eyebrows
,
and
the
rich
white
,
and
black
,
and
brown
,
of
his
complexion
---
confound
his
complexion
,
and
his
memory
!
---
made
me
think
him
,
in
spite
of
my
misgivings
,
a
very
handsome
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
that
my
poor
dear
mother
thought
him
so
too
.
   
<EOS>
We
went
to
an
hotel
by
the
sea
,
where
two
gentlemen
were
smoking
cigars
in
a
room
by
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
Each
of
them
was
lying
on
at
least
four
chairs
,
and
had
a
large
rough
jacket
on
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
corner
was
a
heap
of
coats
and
boat
-
cloaks
,
and
a
flag
,
all
bundled
up
together
.
   
<EOS>
They
both
rolled
on
to
their
feet
in
an
untidy
sort
of
manner
,
when
we
came
in
,
and
said
,
"
Halloa
,
Murdstone
!
 
<EOS>
We
thought
you
were
dead
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
yet
,
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
who
's
this
shaver
?
<EOS>
"
said
one
of
the
gentlemen
,
taking
hold
of
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
Davy
,
"
returned
Mr
Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Davy
who
?
"
said
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Jones
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
Bewitching
<EOS>
Mrs
Copperfield
's
encumbrance
?
"
cried
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
pretty
little
widow
?
"
   
"
Quinion
,
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
,
"
take
care
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
Somebody
's
sharp
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
is
?
"
asked
the
gentleman
,
laughing
.
<EOS>
I
looked
up
,
quickly
;
being
curious
to
know
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Only
Brooks
of
Sheffield
,
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
quite
relieved
to
find
that
it
was
only
Brooks
of
Sheffield
;
for
,
at
first
,
I
really
thought
it
was
<EOS>
I.
   
There
seemed
to
be
something
very
comical
in
the
reputation
of
Mr
Brooks
of
Sheffield
,
for
both
the
gentlemen
laughed
heartily
when
he
was
mentioned
,
and
Mr
Murdstone
was
a
good
deal
amused
also
.
<EOS>
After
some
laughing
,
the
gentleman
whom
he
had
called
Quinion
,
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
And
what
is
the
opinion
of
Brooks
of
Sheffield
,
in
reference
to
the
projected
business
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
do
n't
know
that
Brooks
understands
much
about
it
at
present
,
"
replied
Mr
Murdstone
;
"
but
he
is
not
generally
favourable
,
I
believe
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
more
laughter
at
this
,
and
Mr
Quinion
said
he
would
ring
the
bell
for
some
sherry
in
which
to
drink
to
Brooks
.
 
<EOS>
This
he
did
;
and
when
the
wine
came
,
he
made
me
have
a
little
,
with
a
biscuit
,
and
,
before
I
drank
it
,
stand
up
and
say
,
"
Confusion
to
Brooks
of
Sheffield
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
toast
was
received
with
great
applause
,
and
such
hearty
laughter
that
it
made
me
laugh
too
;
at
which
they
laughed
the
more
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
we
quite
enjoyed
ourselves
.
   
<EOS>
We
walked
about
on
the
cliff
after
that
,
and
sat
on
the
grass
,
and
looked
at
things
through
a
telescope
---
I
could
make
out
nothing
myself
when
it
was
put
to
my
eye
,
but
I
pretended
I
could
---
<EOS>
and
then
we
came
back
to
the
hotel
to
an
early
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
time
we
were
out
,
the
two
gentlemen
smoked
incessantly
---
which
,
I
thought
,
if
I
might
judge
from
the
smell
of
their
rough
coats
,
they
must
have
been
doing
,
ever
since
the
coats
had
first
come
home
from
the
tailor
's
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
not
forget
that
we
went
on
board
the
yacht
,
where
they
all
three
descended
into
the
cabin
,
and
were
busy
with
some
papers
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
them
quite
hard
at
work
,
when
I
looked
down
through
the
open
skylight
.
 
<EOS>
They
left
me
,
during
this
time
,
with
a
very
nice
man
with
a
very
large
head
of
red
hair
and
a
very
small
shiny
hat
upon
it
,
who
had
got
a
cross
-
barred
shirt
or
waistcoat
on
,
with
"
Skylark
"
in
capital
letters
across
the
chest
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
it
was
his
name
;
and
that
as
he
lived
on
board
ship
and
had
n't
a
street
door
to
put
his
name
on
,
he
put
it
there
instead
;
but
when
I
called
him
Mr
Skylark
,
he
said
it
meant
the
vessel
.
   
<EOS>
I
observed
all
day
that
Mr
Murdstone
was
graver
and
steadier
than
the
two
gentlemen
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
very
gay
and
careless
.
 
<EOS>
They
joked
freely
with
one
another
,
but
seldom
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
me
that
he
was
more
clever
and
cold
than
they
were
,
and
that
they
regarded
him
with
something
of
my
own
feeling
.
 
<EOS>
I
remarked
that
,
once
or
twice
when
Mr
Quinion
was
talking
,
he
looked
at
Mr
Murdstone
sideways
,
as
if
to
make
sure
of
his
not
being
displeased
;
and
that
once
when
Mr
Passnidge
(
the
other
gentleman
)
was
in
high
spirits
,
he
trod
upon
his
foot
,
and
gave
him
a
secret
caution
with
his
eyes
,
to
observe
Mr
Murdstone
,
who
was
sitting
stern
and
silent
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
do
I
recollect
that
Mr
Murdstone
laughed
at
all
that
day
,
except
at
the
Sheffield
joke
---
and
that
,
by
the
by
,
was
his
own
.
   
<EOS>
We
went
home
early
in
the
evening
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
very
fine
evening
,
and
my
mother
<EOS>
and
he
had
another
stroll
by
the
sweetbriar
,
while
I
was
sent
in
to
get
my
tea
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
was
gone
,
my
mother
asked
me
all
about
the
day
I
had
had
,
and
what
they
had
said
and
done
.
 
<EOS>
I
mentioned
what
they
had
said
about
her
,
and
she
laughed
,
and
told
me
they
were
impudent
fellows
who
talked
nonsense
---
<EOS>
but
I
knew
it
pleased
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
it
quite
as
well
as
I
know
it
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
took
the
opportunity
of
asking
if
she
was
at
all
acquainted
with
Mr
Brooks
of
Sheffield
,
but
she
answered
No
,
only
she
supposed
he
must
be
a
manufacturer
in
the
knife
and
fork
way
.
   
<EOS>
Can
I
say
of
her
face
---
altered
as
I
have
reason
to
remember
it
,
perished
as
I
know
it
is
---
that
it
is
gone
,
when
here
it
comes
before
me
at
this
instant
,
as
distinct
as
any
face
that
I
may
choose
to
look
on
in
a
crowded
street
?
 
<EOS>
Can
I
say
of
her
innocent
and
girlish
beauty
,
that
it
faded
,
and
was
no
more
,
when
its
breath
falls
on
my
cheek
now
,
as
it
fell
that
night
?
 
<EOS>
Can
I
say
she
ever
changed
,
when
my
remembrance
brings
her
back
to
life
,
thus
only
;
and
,
truer
to
its
loving
youth
than
I
have
been
,
or
man
ever
is
,
still
holds
fast
what
it
cherished
then
?
   
<EOS>
I
write
of
her
just
as
she
was
when
I
had
gone
to
bed
after
this
talk
,
and
she
came
to
bid
me
good
night
.
 
<EOS>
She
kneeled
down
playfully
by
the
side
of
the
bed
,
and
laying
her
chin
upon
her
hands
,
and
laughing
,
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
What
was
it
<EOS>
they
said
,
Davy
?
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
believe
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Bewitching
---
<EOS>
"
"
I
began
.
   
<EOS>
My
mother
put
her
hands
upon
my
lips
to
stop
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
never
bewitching
,
"
she
said
,
laughing
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
never
could
have
been
bewitching
,
Davy
.
 
<EOS>
Now
I
know
it
was
n't
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bewitching
Mrs
Copperfield
"
,
"
I
repeated
stoutly
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
"
pretty
.
"
<EOS>
"
   
"
No
,
no
,
it
was
never
pretty
.
 
<EOS>
Not
pretty
,
"
interposed
my
mother
,
laying
her
fingers
on
my
lips
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pretty
little
widow
.
"
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
foolish
,
impudent
creatures
!
<EOS>
"
cried
my
mother
,
laughing
and
covering
her
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
ridiculous
men
!
 
<EOS>
An't
they
?
 
<EOS>
Davy
dear
---
"
   
"
Well
,
Ma
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do
n't
tell
Peggotty
;
she
might
be
angry
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
dreadfully
angry
with
them
myself
;
but
I
would
rather
Peggotty
did
n't
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
promised
,
of
course
;
and
we
kissed
one
another
over
and
over
again
,
and
I
soon
fell
fast
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
It
seems
to
me
,
at
this
distance
of
time
,
as
if
it
were
the
next
day
when
Peggotty
broached
the
striking
and
adventurous
proposition
<EOS>
I
am
about
to
mention
;
but
it
was
probably
about
two
months
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
We
were
sitting
as
before
,
one
evening
(
when
my
mother
was
out
as
before
)
,
in
company
with
the
stocking
and
the
yard
-
measure
,
and
the
bit
of
wax
,
and
the
box
with
St
Paul
's
on
the
lid
,
and
the
crocodile
book
,
when
Peggotty
,
after
looking
at
me
several
times
,
and
opening
her
mouth
as
if
she
were
going
to
speak
,
without
doing
it
---
which
I
thought
was
merely
gaping
,
or
I
should
have
been
rather
