---
said
coaxingly
:
   
"
<EOS>
Master
Davy
,
how
should
you
like
to
go
along
with
me
and
spend
a
fortnight
at
my
brother
's
at
Yarmouth
?
 
<EOS>
Would
n't
that
be
a
treat
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
your
brother
an
agreeable
man
,
Peggotty
?
"
<EOS>
I
inquired
,
provisionally
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
what
an
agreeable
man
he
is
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Peggotty
,
holding
up
her
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
there
's
the
sea
;
and
the
boats
and
ships
;
and
the
fishermen
;
and
the
beach
;
and
<EOS>
Am%
to
play
with
---
"
   
Peggotty
meant
her
nephew
Ham
,
mentioned
in
my
first
chapter
;
but
she
spoke
of
him
as
a
morsel
of
English
Grammar
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
flushed
by
her
summary
of
delights
,
and
replied
that
it
would
indeed
be
a
treat
,
but
what
would
my
mother
say
?
   
<EOS>
"
Why
then
I
'll
as
good
as
bet
a
guinea
,
"
said
Peggotty
,
intent
upon
my
face
,
"
that
she
'll
let
us
go
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
ask
her
,
if
you
like
,
as
soon
as
ever
she
comes
home
.
 
<EOS>
There
now
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
what
's
she
to
do
while
we
're
away
?
<EOS>
"
said
I
,
putting
my
small
elbows
on
the
table
to
argue
the
point
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
ca
n't
live
by
herself
.
"
   
<EOS>
If
Peggotty
were
looking
for
a
hole
,
all
of
a
sudden
,
in
the
heel
of
that
stocking
,
it
must
have
been
a
very
little
one
indeed
,
and
not
worth
darning
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
!
 
<EOS>
Peggotty
!
 
<EOS>
She
ca
n't
live
by
herself
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
bless
you
!
"
<EOS>
said
Peggotty
,
looking
at
me
again
at
last
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
know
?
 
<EOS>
She
's
going
to
stay
for
a
fortnight
with
Mrs
Grayper
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Grayper
's
going
to
have
a
lot
of
company
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
If
that
was
it
,
I
was
quite
ready
to
go
.
 
<EOS>
I
waited
,
in
the
utmost
impatience
,
until
my
mother
came
home
from
Mrs
Grayper
's
<EOS>
(
for
it
was
that
identical
neighbour
)
,
to
ascertain
if
we
could
get
leave
to
carry
out
this
great
idea
.
 
<EOS>
Without
being
nearly
so
much
surprised
as
I
had
expected
,
my
mother
entered
into
it
readily
;
and
it
was
all
arranged
that
night
,
and
my
board
and
lodging
during
the
visit
were
to
be
paid
for
.
   
<EOS>
The
day
soon
came
for
our
going
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
such
an
early
day
that
it
came
soon
,
even
to
me
,
who
was
in
a
fever
of
expectation
,
and
half
afraid
that
an
earthquake
or
a
fiery
mountain
,
or
some
other
great
convulsion
of
nature
,
might
interpose
to
stop
the
expedition
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
to
go
in
a
carrier
's
cart
,
which
departed
in
the
morning
after
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
have
given
any
money
to
have
been
allowed
to
wrap
myself
up
over
-
night
,
and
sleep
in
my
hat
and
boots
.
   
<EOS>
It
touches
me
nearly
now
,
although
I
tell
it
lightly
,
to
recollect
how
eager
I
was
to
leave
my
happy
home
;
to
think
how
little
I
suspected
what
I
did
leave
for
ever
.
   
<EOS>
I
am
glad
to
recollect
that
when
the
carrier
's
cart
was
at
the
gate
,
and
my
mother
stood
there
kissing
me
,
a
grateful
fondness
for
her
and
for
the
old
place
<EOS>
I
had
never
turned
my
back
upon
before
,
made
me
cry
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
to
know
that
my
mother
cried
too
,
and
that
I
felt
her
heart
beat
against
mine
.
   
<EOS>
I
am
glad
to
recollect
that
when
the
carrier
began
to
move
,
my
mother
ran
out
at
the
gate
,
and
called
to
him
to
stop
,
that
she
might
kiss
me
once
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
to
dwell
upon
the
earnestness
and
love
with
which
she
lifted
up
her
face
to
mine
,
and
did
so
.
   
<EOS>
As
we
left
her
standing
in
the
road
,
Mr
Murdstone
came
up
to
where
she
was
,
and
seemed
to
expostulate
with
her
for
being
so
moved
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
looking
back
round
the
awning
of
the
cart
,
and
wondered
what
business
it
was
of
his
.
 
<EOS>
Peggotty
,
who
was
also
looking
back
on
the
other
side
,
seemed
anything
but
satisfied
;
as
the
face
she
brought
back
in
the
cart
denoted
.
   
<EOS>
I
sat
looking
at
Peggotty
for
some
time
,
in
a
reverie
on
this
supposititious
case
:
whether
,
if
she
were
employed
to
lose
me
like
the
boy
in
the
fairy
tale
,
I
should
be
able
to
track
my
way
home
again
by
the
buttons
she
would
shed
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
3
.
<EOS>
I
Have
a
Change
 
<EOS>
The
carrier
's
horse
was
the
laziest
horse
in
the
world
,
I
should
hope
,
and
shuffled
along
,
with
his
head
down
,
as
if
he
liked
to
keep
people
waiting
to
whom
the
packages
were
directed
.
 
<EOS>
I
fancied
,
indeed
,
that
he
sometimes
chuckled
audibly
over
this
reflection
,
but
the
carrier
said
he
was
only
troubled
with
a
cough
.
<EOS>
The
carrier
had
a
way
of
keeping
his
head
down
,
like
his
horse
,
and
of
drooping
sleepily
forward
as
he
drove
,
with
one
of
his
arms
on
each
of
his
knees
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
"
drove
"
,
but
it
struck
me
that
the
cart
would
have
gone
to
Yarmouth
quite
as
well
without
him
,
for
the
horse
<EOS>
did
all
that
;
and
as
to
conversation
,
he
had
no
idea
of
it
but
whistling
.
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
had
a
basket
of
refreshments
on
her
knee
,
which
would
have
lasted
us
out
handsomely
,
if
we
had
been
going
to
London
by
the
same
conveyance
.
 
<EOS>
We
ate
a
good
deal
,
and
slept
a
good
deal
.
<EOS>
Peggotty
always
went
to
sleep
with
her
chin
upon
the
handle
of
the
basket
,
her
hold
of
which
never
relaxed
;
and
I
could
not
have
believed
unless
I
had
heard
her
do
it
,
that
one
defenceless
woman
could
have
snored
so
much
.
   
<EOS>
We
made
so
many
deviations
up
and
down
lanes
,
and
were
such
a
long
time
delivering
a
bedstead
at
a
public
-
house
,
and
calling
at
other
places
,
that
I
was
quite
tired
,
and
very
glad
,
when
we
saw
Yarmouth
.
 
<EOS>
It
looked
rather
spongy
and
soppy
,
I
thought
,
as
I
carried
my
eye
over
the
great
dull
waste
that
lay
across
the
river
;
and
I
could
not
help
wondering
,
if
the
world
were
really
as
round
as
my
geography
book
said
,
how
any
part
of
it
came
to
be
so
flat
.
<EOS>
But
I
reflected
that
Yarmouth
might
be
situated
at
one
of
the
poles
;
which
would
account
for
it
.
   
<EOS>
As
we
drew
a
little
nearer
,
and
saw
the
whole
adjacent
prospect
lying
a
straight
low
line
under
the
sky
,
I
hinted
to
Peggotty
that
a
mound
or
so
might
have
improved
it
;
and
also
that
if
the
land
had
been
a
little
more
separated
from
the
sea
,
and
the
town
and
the
tide
had
not
been
quite
so
much
mixed
up
,
like
toast
and
water
,
it
would
have
been
nicer
.
 
<EOS>
But
Peggotty
said
,
with
greater
emphasis
than
usual
,
that
we
must
take
things
as
we
found
them
,
and
that
,
for
her
part
,
she
was
proud
to
call
herself
a
Yarmouth
Bloater
.
   
<EOS>
When
we
got
into
the
street
(
which
was
strange
enough
to
me
)
and
smelt
the
fish
,
and
pitch
,
and
oakum
,
and
tar
,
and
saw
the
sailors
walking
about
,
and
the
carts
jingling
up
and
down
over
the
stones
<EOS>
,
I
felt
that
I
had
done
so
busy
a
place
an
injustice
;
and
said
as
much
to
Peggotty
,
who
heard
my
expressions
of
delight
with
great
complacency
,
and
told
me
it
was
well
known
(
I
suppose
to
those
who
had
the
good
fortune
to
be
born
Bloaters
)
that
Yarmouth
was
,
upon
the
whole
,
the
finest
place
in
the
universe
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's
my
Am%
!
"
<EOS>
screamed
Peggotty
,
"
growed
out
of
knowledge
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
waiting
for
us
,
in
fact
,
at
the
public
-
house
;
and
asked
me
how
I
found
myself
,
like
an
old
acquaintance
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
not
feel
,
at
first
,
that
I
knew
him
as
well
as
he
knew
me
,
because
he
had
never
come
to
our
house
since
the
night
I
was
born
,
and
naturally
he
had
the
advantage
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
our
intimacy
was
much
advanced
by
his
taking
me
on
his
back
to
carry
me
home
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
,
now
,
a
huge
,
strong
fellow
of
six
feet
high
,
broad
in
proportion
,
and
round
-
shouldered
;
but
with
a
simpering
boy
's
face
and
curly
light
hair
that
gave
him
quite
a
sheepish
look
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
dressed
in
a
canvas
jacket
,
and
a
pair
of
such
very
stiff
trousers
that
they
would
have
stood
quite
as
well
alone
,
without
any
legs
in
them
.
<EOS>
And
you
could
n't
so
properly
have
said
he
wore
a
hat
,
as
that
he
was
covered
in
a
-
top
,
like
an
old
building
,
with
something
pitchy
.
   
<EOS>
Ham
carrying
me
on
his
back
and
a
small
box
of
ours
under
his
arm
,
and
Peggotty
carrying
another
small
box
of
ours
,
we
turned
down
lanes
bestrewn
with
bits
of
chips
and
little
hillocks
of
sand
,
and
went
past
gas
-
works
,
rope
-
walks
,
boat
-
builders
'
yards
,
shipwrights
'
yards
,
ship
-
breakers
'
yards
,
caulkers
'
yards
,
riggers
'
lofts
,
smiths
'
forges
,
and
a
great
litter
of
such
places
,
until
we
came
out
upon
the
dull
waste
I
had
already
seen
at
a
distance
;
when
Ham
said
,
   
"
Yon
's
our
house
,
Mas'r
Davy
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
looked
in
all
directions
,
as
far
as
I
could
stare
over
the
wilderness
,
and
away
at
the
sea
,
and
away
at
the
river
,
but
no
house
<EOS>
could
I
make
out
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
black
barge
,
or
some
other
kind
of
superannuated
boat
,
not
far
off
,
high
and
dry
on
the
ground
,
with
an
iron
funnel
sticking
out
of
it
for
a
chimney
and
smoking
very
cosily
;
but
nothing
else
in
the
way
of
a
habitation
that
was
visible
to
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
not
it
?
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
That
ship
-
looking
thing
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
it
,
Mas'r
Davy
,
"
returned
Ham
.
   
<EOS>
If
it
had
been
Aladdin
's
palace
,
roc
's
egg
and
all
,
I
suppose
I
could
not
have
been
more
charmed
with
the
romantic
idea
of
living
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
delightful
door
cut
in
the
side
,
and
it
was
roofed
in
,
and
there
were
little
windows
in
it
;
but
the
wonderful
charm
of
it
was
,
that
it
was
a
real
boat
which
had
no
doubt
been
upon
the
water
hundreds
of
times
,
and
which
had
never
been
intended
to
be
lived
in
,
on
dry
land
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
the
captivation
of
it
to
me
.
<EOS>
If
it
had
ever
been
meant
to
be
lived
in
,
I
might
have
thought
it
small
,
or
inconvenient
,
or
lonely
;
but
never
having
been
designed
for
any
such
use
,
it
became
a
perfect
abode
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
beautifully
clean
inside
,
and
as
tidy
as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
table
,
and
a
Dutch
clock
,
and
a
chest
of
drawers
,
and
on
the
chest
of
drawers
there
was
a
tea
-
tray
with
a
painting
on
it
of
a
lady
with
a
parasol
,
taking
a
walk
with
a
military
-
looking
child
who
was
trundling
a
hoop
.
 
<EOS>
The
tray
was
kept
from
tumbling
down
,
by
a
bible
;
and
the
tray
,
if
it
had
tumbled
down
,
would
have
smashed
a
quantity
of
cups
and
saucers
and
a
teapot
that
were
grouped
around
the
book
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
walls
there
were
some
common
coloured
pictures
,
framed
and
glazed
,
of
scripture
subjects
;
such
as
I
have
never
seen
since
in
the
hands
of
pedlars
,
without
seeing
the
whole
interior
of
Peggotty
's
brother
's
house
again
,
at
one
view
.
 
<EOS>
Abraham
in
red
going
to
sacrifice
Isaac
in
blue
,
and
Daniel
in
yellow
cast
into
a
den
of
green
lions
,
were
the
most
prominent
of
these
.
 
<EOS>
Over
the
little
mantelshelf
,
was
a
picture
of
the
"
Sarah
Jane
"
lugger
,
built
at
Sunderland
,
with
a
real
little
wooden
stern
stuck
on
to
it
;
a
work
of
art
,
combining
composition
with
carpentry
,
which
I
considered
to
be
one
of
the
most
enviable
possessions
that
the
world
could
afford
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
some
hooks
in
the
beams
of
the
ceiling
,
the
use
of
which
I
did
not
divine
then
;
and
some
lockers
and
boxes
and
conveniences
of
that
sort
,
which
served
for
seats
and
eked
out
the
chairs
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
I
saw
in
the
first
glance
after
I
crossed
the
threshold
---
<EOS>
child
-
like
,
according
to
my
theory
---
and
then
Peggotty
opened
a
little
door
and
showed
me
my
bedroom
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
<EOS>
the
completest
and
most
desirable
bedroom
ever
seen
<EOS>
---
in
the
stern
of
the
vessel
;
with
a
little
window
,
where
the
rudder
used
to
go
through
;
a
little
looking
-
glass
,
just
the
right
height
for
me
,
nailed
against
the
wall
,
and
framed
with
oyster
-
shells
;
a
little
bed
,
which
there
was
just
room
enough
to
get
into
;
and
a
nosegay
of
seaweed
in
a
blue
mug
on
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
The
walls
were
whitewashed
as
white
as
milk
,
and
the
patchwork
counterpane
made
my
eyes
quite
ache
with
its
brightness
.
 
<EOS>
One
thing
I
particularly
noticed
in
this
delightful
house
,
was
the
smell
of
fish
;
which
was
so
searching
,
that
when
I
took
out
my
pocket
-
handkerchief
to
wipe
my
nose
,
I
found
it
smelt
exactly
as
if
it
had
wrapped
up
a
lobster
.
 
<EOS>
On
my
imparting
this
discovery
in
confidence
to
Peggotty
,
she
informed
me
that
her
brother
dealt
in
lobsters
,
crabs
,
and
crawfish
;
and
I
afterwards
found
that
a
heap
of
these
creatures
,
in
a
state
of
wonderful
conglomeration
with
one
another
,
and
never
leaving
off
pinching
whatever
they
laid
hold
of
,
were
usually
to
be
found
in
a
little
wooden
outhouse
where
the
pots
and
kettles
were
kept
.
   
<EOS>
We
were
welcomed
by
a
very
civil
woman
in
a
white
apron
,
whom
I
had
seen
curtseying
at
the
door
when
I
was
on
Ham
's
back
,
about
a
quarter
of
a
mile
off
.
 
<EOS>
Likewise
by
a
most
beautiful
little
girl
<EOS>
(
or
I
thought
her
so
)
with
a
necklace
of
blue
beads
on
,
who
would
n't
let
me
kiss
her
when
I
offered
to
,
but
ran
away
and
hid
herself
.
 
<EOS>
By
and
by
,
when
we
had
dined
in
a
sumptuous
manner
off
boiled
dabs
,
melted
butter
,
and
potatoes
,
with
a
chop
for
me
,
a
hairy
man
with
a
very
good
-
natured
face
came
home
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
called
Peggotty
"
Lass
"
,
and
gave
her
a
hearty
smack
on
the
cheek
,
I
had
no
doubt
,
from
the
general
propriety
of
her
conduct
,
that
he
was
her
brother
;
and
so
he
turned
out
---
<EOS>
being
presently
introduced
to
me
as
Mr
Peggotty
,
the
master
of
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
"
Glad
to
see
you
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll
find
us
rough
,
sir
,
but
you
'll
find
us
ready
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
thanked
him
,
and
replied
that
I
was
sure
I
should
be
happy
in
such
a
delightful
place
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
's
your
Ma
,
sir
?
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
Did
you
leave
her
pretty
jolly
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
gave
Mr
Peggotty
to
understand
that
she
was
as
jolly
as
I
could
wish
,
and
that
she
desired
her
compliments
---
which
was
a
polite
fiction
on
my
part
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
much
obleeged
to
her
,
I
'm
sure
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
if
you
can
make
out
here
,
fur
a
fortnut
,
'
long
wi
'
her
,
"
nodding
at
his
sister
,
"
and
Ham
,
and
<EOS>
little
Em'ly
,
we
shall
be
proud
of
your
company
.
"
   
<EOS>
Having
done
the
honours
of
his
house
in
this
hospitable
manner
,
Mr
Peggotty
went
out
to
wash
himself
in
a
kettleful
of
hot
water
,
remarking
that
"
cold
would
never
get
his
muck
off
"
.
 
<EOS>
He
soon
returned
,
greatly
improved
in
appearance
;
but
so
rubicund
,
that
I
could
n't
help
thinking
his
face
had
this
in
common
with
the
lobsters
,
crabs
,
and
crawfish
,
---
that
it
went
into
the
hot
water
very
black
,
and
came
out
very
red
.
   
<EOS>
After
tea
,
when
the
door
was
shut
and
all
was
made
snug
(
the
nights
being
cold
and
misty
now
)
,
it
seemed
to
me
the
most
delicious
retreat
that
the
imagination
of
man
could
conceive
.
 
<EOS>
To
hear
the
wind
getting
up
out
at
sea
,
to
know
that
the
fog
was
creeping
over
the
desolate
flat
outside
,
and
to
look
at
the
fire
,
and
think
that
there
was
no
house
near
but
this
one
,
and
this
one
a
boat
,
was
like
enchantment
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Em'ly
had
overcome
her
shyness
,
and
was
sitting
by
my
side
upon
the
lowest
and
least
of
the
lockers
,
which
was
just
large
enough
for
us
two
,
and
just
fitted
into
the
chimney
corner
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Peggotty
with
the
white
apron
,
was
knitting
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Peggotty
at
her
needlework
was
as
much
at
home
with
St
Paul
's
and
the
bit
of
wax
-
candle
,
as
if
they
had
never
known
any
other
roof
.
 
<EOS>
Ham
,
who
had
been
giving
me
my
first
lesson
in
all
-
fours
,
was
trying
to
recollect
a
scheme
of
telling
fortunes
with
the
dirty
cards
,
and
was
printing
off
fishy
impressions
of
his
thumb
on
all
the
cards
he
turned
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
was
smoking
his
pipe
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
it
was
a
time
for
conversation
and
confidence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Peggotty
!
<EOS>
"
says
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
says
he
.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
give
your
son
the
name
of
Ham
,
because
you
lived
in
a
sort
of
ark
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
seemed
to
think
it
a
deep
idea
,
but
answered
:
   
"
<EOS>
No
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
giv
him
no
name
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
gave
him
that
name
,
then
?
<EOS>
"
said
I
,
putting
question
number
two
of
the
catechism
to
Mr
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
sir
,
his
father
giv
it
him
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
were
his
father
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
brother
Joe
was
his
father
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dead
,
Mr
Peggotty
?
<EOS>
"
I
hinted
,
after
a
respectful
pause
.
   
<EOS>
"
Drowndead
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
very
much
surprised
that
Mr
Peggotty
was
not
Ham
's
father
,
and
began
to
wonder
whether
I
was
mistaken
about
his
relationship
to
anybody
else
there
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
curious
to
know
,
that
I
made
up
my
mind
to
have
it
out
with
Mr
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
Little
Em'ly
,
"
I
said
,
glancing
at
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
is
your
daughter
,
is
n't
she
,
Mr
Peggotty
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
My
brother
-
in
-
law
,
Tom
,
was
her
father
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
n't
help
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
---
Dead
,
Mr
Peggotty
?
<EOS>
"
I
hinted
,
after
another
respectful
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Drowndead
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
I
felt
the
difficulty
of
resuming
the
subject
,
but
had
not
got
to
the
bottom
of
it
yet
,
and
must
get
to
the
bottom
somehow
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Have
n't
you
ANY
children
,
Mr
Peggotty
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
master
,
"
he
answered
with
a
short
laugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
a
bacheldore
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
bachelor
!
<EOS>
"
I
said
,
astonished
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
who
's
that
,
Mr
Peggotty
?
"
<EOS>
pointing
to
the
person
in
the
apron
who
was
knitting
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
Missis
Gummidge
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gummidge
,
Mr
Peggotty
?
"
   
<EOS>
But
at
this
point
Peggotty
---
I
mean
my
own
peculiar
Peggotty
---
made
such
impressive
motions
to
me
not
to
ask
any
more
questions
,
that
I
could
only
sit
and
look
at
all
the
silent
company
,
until
it
was
time
to
go
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
in
the
privacy
of
my
own
little
cabin
,
she
informed
me
that
Ham
and
Em'ly
were
an
orphan
nephew
and
niece
,
whom
my
host
had
at
different
times
adopted
in
their
childhood
,
when
they
were
left
destitute
:
and
that
Mrs
Gummidge
was
the
widow
of
his
partner
in
a
boat
,
who
had
died
very
poor
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
but
<EOS>
a
poor
man
himself
,
said
Peggotty
,
but
as
good
as
gold
and
as
true
as
steel
---
those
were
her
similes
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
subject
,
she
informed
me
,
on
which
he
ever
showed
a
violent
temper
or
swore
an
oath
,
was
this
generosity
of
his
;
and
if
it
were
ever
referred
to
,
by
any
one
of
them
,
he
struck
the
table
a
heavy
blow
with
his
right
hand
(
had
split
it
on
one
such
occasion
)
,
and
swore
a
dreadful
oath
that
he
would
be
"
Gormed
"
if
he
did
n't
cut
and
run
for
good
,
if
it
was
ever
mentioned
again
.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
,
in
answer
to
my
inquiries
,
that
nobody
had
the
least
idea
of
the
etymology
of
this
terrible
verb
passive
to
be
gormed
;
but
that
they
all
regarded
it
as
constituting
a
most
solemn
imprecation
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
very
sensible
of
my
entertainer
's
goodness
,
and
listened
to
the
women
's
going
to
bed
in
another
little
crib
like
mine
at
the
opposite
end
of
the
boat
,
and
to
him
and
Ham
hanging
up
two
hammocks
for
themselves
on
the
hooks
I
had
noticed
in
the
roof
,
in
a
very
luxurious
state
of
mind
,
enhanced
by
my
being
sleepy
.
 
<EOS>
As
slumber
gradually
stole
upon
me
,
I
heard
the
wind
howling
out
at
sea
and
coming
on
across
the
flat
so
fiercely
,
that
I
had
a
lazy
apprehension
of
the
great
deep
rising
in
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
bethought
myself
that
I
was
in
a
boat
,
after
all
;
and
that
a
man
like
Mr
Peggotty
was
not
a
bad
person
to
have
on
board
if
anything
did
happen
.
   
<EOS>
Nothing
happened
,
however
,
worse
than
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Almost
as
soon
as
it
shone
upon
the
oyster
-
shell
frame
of
my
mirror
I
was
out
of
bed
,
and
out
with
little
Em'ly
,
picking
up
stones
upon
the
beach
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
quite
a
sailor
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
I
said
to
Em'ly
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
that
I
supposed
anything
of
the
kind
,
but
I
felt
it
an
act
of
gallantry
to
say
something
;
and
a
shining
sail
close
to
us
made
such
a
pretty
little
image
of
itself
,
at
the
moment
,
in
her
bright
eye
,
that
it
came
into
my
head
to
say
this
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Em'ly
,
shaking
her
head
,
"
I
'm
afraid
of
the
sea
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Afraid
!
<EOS>
"
I
said
,
with
a
becoming
air
of
boldness
,
and
looking
very
big
at
the
mighty
ocean
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
an't
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
but
it
's
cruel
,
"
said
Em'ly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
it
very
cruel
to
some
of
our
men
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
seen
it
tear
a
boat
as
big
as
our
house
,
all
to
pieces
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
it
was
n't
the
boat
<EOS>
that
---
"
   
"
That
father
was
drownded
in
?
"
said
Em'ly
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
 
<EOS>
Not
that
one
,
I
never
see
that
boat
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nor
him
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
her
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Em'ly
shook
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
to
remember
!
"
   
<EOS>
Here
was
a
coincidence
!
 
<EOS>
I
immediately
went
into
an
explanation
how
I
had
never
seen
my
own
father
;
and
how
my
mother
and
I
had
always
lived
by
ourselves
in
the
happiest
state
imaginable
,
and
lived
so
then
,
and
always
meant
to
live
so
;
and
how
my
father
's
grave
was
in
the
churchyard
near
our
house
,
and
shaded
by
a
tree
,
beneath
the
boughs
of
which
I
had
walked
and
heard
the
birds
sing
many
a
pleasant
morning
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
were
some
differences
between
Em'ly
's
orphanhood
and
mine
,
it
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
lost
her
mother
before
her
father
;
and
where
her
father
's
grave
was
no
one
knew
,
except
that
it
was
somewhere
in
the
depths
of
the
sea
.
   
<EOS>
"
Besides
,
"
said
Em'ly
,
as
she
looked
about
for
shells
and
pebbles
,
"
your
father
was
a
gentleman
and
your
mother
is
a
lady
;
and
my
father
was
a
fisherman
and
my
mother
was
a
fisherman
's
daughter
,
and
my
uncle
Dan
is
a
fisherman
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dan
is
Mr
Peggotty
,
is

?
"
said
I.
   
"
Uncle
Dan
---
yonder
,
"
answered
Em'ly
,
nodding
at
the
boat

house
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
I
mean
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
must
be
very
good
,
I
should
think
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
?
"
said
Em'ly
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
was
ever
to
be
a
lady
,
I
'd
give
him
a
sky
-
blue
coat
with
diamond

,
nankeen

,
a
red

,
a
cocked
hat
,
a
large

watch
,
a
silver

,
and
a
box
of
money
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
I
had
no
doubt
that
Mr
Peggotty
well
deserved
these
treasures
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
acknowledge
that
I
felt
it
difficult
to
picture
him
quite
at
his
ease
in
the
raiment
proposed
for
him
by
his
grateful
little
niece
,
and
that
I
was
particularly
doubtful
of
the
policy
of
the
cocked
hat
;
but
I
kept
these
sentiments
to
myself
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Em'ly
had
stopped
and
looked
up
at
the
sky
in
her
enumeration
of
these
articles
,
as
if
they
were
a
glorious

.
<EOS>
We
went
on
again
,
picking
up
shells
and
pebbles
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
would
like
to
be
a
lady
?
<EOS>
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
Emily
looked
at
me
,
and
laughed
and
nodded
"
yes
"
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
it
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
We
would
all
be
gentlefolks
together
,
then
.
 
<EOS>
Me
,
and
uncle
,
and
Ham
,
and
Mrs
Gummidge
.
 
<EOS>
We
would
n't
mind
then
,
when
there
comes
stormy
weather
.
 
<EOS>
---
Not
for
our
own
sakes
,
I
mean
.
 
<EOS>
We
would
for
the
poor
fishermen
's
,
to
be
sure
,
and
we
'd
help
'em
with
money
when
they
come
to
any
hurt
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
seemed
to
me
to
be
a
very
satisfactory
and
therefore
not
at
all
improbable
picture
.
<EOS>
I
expressed
my
pleasure
in
the
contemplation
of
it
,
and
little
Em'ly
was
emboldened
to
say
,
shyly
,
   
"
Do
n't
you
think
you
are
afraid
of
the
sea
,
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
quiet
enough
to
reassure
me
,
but
I
have
no
doubt
if
I
had
seen
a
moderately
large
wave
come
tumbling
in
<EOS>
,
I
should
have
taken
to
my
heels
,
with
an
awful
recollection
of
her
drowned
relations
.
<EOS>
However
,
I
said
"
No
,
"
and
I

,
"
You
do
n't
seem
to
be
either
,
though
you
say
you
are
,
"
---
for
she
was

much
too
near
the
brink
of
a
sort

old
jetty
or
wooden

we
had
strolled
upon
,
and
<EOS>
I
was
afraid
of
her

over
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
not
afraid
in
this
way
,
"
said
little
Em'ly
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
wake
when
it
blows
,
and
tremble
to
think
of
Uncle
Dan
and
Ham
and
believe
I
hear
'em
crying
out
for

.
 
<EOS>
That
's
why
I
should
like
so
much
to
be
a
lady
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
'm
not
afraid
in
this
way
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
bit
.
 
<EOS>
Look
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
started
from
my
side
,
and
ran
along
a
jagged

which
protruded
from
the
place
we
stood
upon
,
and
overhung
the
deep
water
at
some

,
without

.
 
<EOS>
The
incident
is
so
impressed
on
my

,
that
if
I
were
a
draughtsman
I
could
draw
its

here
,
I
dare
say
,
accurately

it
was
that

,
and
little
Em'ly
springing
forward
to
her

(
as
it
appeared
to

)
,
with
a
look
that
I
have
never

,
directed
far
out
to

.
   
<EOS>
The
light
,
bold
,
fluttering
little
figure
turned
and
came
back
safe
to
me
,
and
I
soon
laughed
at
my
fears
,
and
at
the
cry
I
had
uttered
;
fruitlessly
in
any
case
,
for
there
was
no

near
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
have
been
times
since
,
in
my
manhood
,
many
times
there
have
been
,
when
I
have
thought
<EOS>
,
Is
it
possible
,
among
the

of
hidden
things
,
that
in
the

of
the
child
and
her
wild

so
far

,
there

any

of

,
any

towards
him
permitted
on
the
part

her

,
that
her

might
have

?
<EOS>
There

a

when
I
have

whether
,
if
the
life
before
her
could
have

,

so

as
that
a
child
could
fully

,
and

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
There

since
---
I
do
not

it
lasted

,
but
it
has
been
---
when

;
and

have

Yes
,
it

been
.
   
<EOS>
This
may
be
premature
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
set
it
down
too
soon
,
perhaps
.
 
<EOS>
But
let
it
stand
.
   
<EOS>
We
strolled
a
long
way
,
and
loaded
ourselves
with
things
that
we
thought
curious
,
and
put
some
stranded
starfish
carefully
back
into
the
water
---
I
hardly
know
enough
of
the
race
at
this
moment
to
be
quite
certain
whether
they
had
reason
to
feel
obliged
to
us
for
doing
so
,
or
the

---
and
then
made
our
way
home
to
Mr
Peggotty
's
dwelling
.
 
<EOS>
We
stopped
under
the
lee
of
the
lobster
-
outhouse
to
exchange
an
innocent
kiss
,
and
went
in
to
breakfast
glowing
with
health
and
pleasure
.
   
<EOS>
"
Like
two
young
mavishes
,
"
Mr
Peggotty
said
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
this
meant
,
in
our
local
dialect
,
like
two
young
thrushes
,
and
received
it
as
a
compliment
.
   
<EOS>
Of
course
I
was
in
love
with
little
Em'ly
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
I
loved
that
baby
quite
as
truly
,
quite
as
tenderly
,
with
greater
purity
and
more
disinterestedness
,
than
can
enter
into
the
best
love
of
a
later
time
of
life
,
high
and
ennobling
as
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
my
fancy
raised
up
something
round
that
blue
-
eyed
mite
of
a
child
,
which
etherealized
,
and
made
a
very
angel
of
her
.
 
<EOS>
If
,
any
sunny
forenoon
,
she
had
spread
a
little
pair
of

and
flown
away
before
my

,
I
do
n't
think
I
should
have
regarded
it
as
much
more
than
I
had
had
reason
to
expect
.
   
<EOS>
We
used
to
walk
about
that
dim
old
flat
at
Yarmouth
in
a
loving
manner
,
hours
and
hours
.
 
<EOS>
The
days
sported
by
us
,
as
if
Time
had
not
grown
up
himself
yet
,
but
were
a
child
too
,
and
always
at
play
.
<EOS>
I
told
Em'ly
I
adored
her
,
and
that
unless
she
confessed
she
adored
me
<EOS>
I
should
be
reduced
to
the
necessity
of
killing
myself
with
a

.
 
<EOS>
She
said
she
did
,
and
I
have
no
doubt
she
did
.
   
<EOS>
As
to
any
sense
of
inequality
,
or
youthfulness
,
or
other

in
our
way
,
little
Em'ly
<EOS>
and
I
had
no
such
trouble
,
because
we
had
no
future
.
 
<EOS>
We
made
no
more
provision
for
growing

,
than
we
did
for
growing
younger
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
the
admiration
of
Mrs
Gummidge
and
Peggotty
,
who
used
to
whisper
of
an
evening
when
we
sat
,
lovingly
,
on
our
little
locker
side
by
side
,
"
Lor
!
<EOS>
was
n't
it
beautiful
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
smiled
at
us
from
behind
his
pipe
,
and
Ham
grinned
all
the
evening
and
did
nothing
else
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
something
of
the
sort
of
pleasure
in
us
,
I
suppose
,
that
they
might
have
had
in
a
pretty
toy
,
or
a
pocket
model
of
the
Colosseum
.
   
<EOS>
I
soon
found
out
that
Mrs
Gummidge
did
not
always

herself
so
agreeable
as
she
might
have
been
expected

do
,
under
the

of
her

with
Mr
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Gummidge
's
was
rather
a
fretful
disposition
,
and
she
whimpered
more
sometimes
than
was
comfortable
for
other
parties
in
so
small

establishment
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
very
sorry
for
her
;
but
there
were
moments
when
it
would
have
been
more
agreeable
,
I
thought
,
if
Mrs
Gummidge
had
had
a
convenient
apartment
of
her
own
to
retire
to
,
and
had
stopped
there
until
her
spirits
revived
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
went
occasionally
to
a
public
-
house
called
The
Willing
Mind
.
 
<EOS>
I
discovered
this
,
by
his
being
out
on
the
second
or
third
evening
of
our

,
and
by
Mrs
Gummidge
's
looking
up
at
the
Dutch
clock
,
between
eight
and
nine
,
and
saying
he
was
there
,
and
that
,
what
was
more
,
she
had
known
in
the
morning
he
would
go
there
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gummidge
had
been
in
a
low
state
all
day
,
and
had
burst
into
tears
in
the
forenoon
,
when
the
fire
smoked
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
lone
lorn
creetur
'
,
"
were
Mrs
Gummidge
's
words
,
when
that
unpleasant
occurrence
took
place
,
"
and
everythink
goes
contrary
with
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
'll
soon
leave
off
,
"
said
Peggotty
<EOS>
---
I
again
mean
our
Peggotty
---
"
and
besides
,
you
know
,
it
's
not
more
disagreeable
to
you
than
to
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
feel
it
more
,
"
said
Mrs
Gummidge
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
very
cold
day
,
with
cutting
blasts
of
wind
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Gummidge
's
peculiar
corner
of
the
fireside
seemed
to
me
to
be
the
warmest
and
snuggest
in
the
place
,
as
her
chair
was
certainly
the
easiest
,
but
it
did
n't
suit
her
that
day
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
constantly
complaining
of
the
cold
,
and
of
its
occasioning
a
visitation
in
her
back
<EOS>
which
she
called
"
the
creeps
"
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
she
shed
tears
on
that
subject
,
and
said
again
that
she
was
"
a
lone
lorn
creetur
'
and
everythink
went
contrary
with
her
"
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
certainly
very
cold
,
"
said
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
Everybody
must
feel
it
so
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
feel
it
more
than
other
people
,
"
said
Mrs
Gummidge
.
   
<EOS>
So
at
dinner
;
when
Mrs
Gummidge
was
always
helped
immediately
after
me
,
to
whom
the
preference
was
given
as
a
visitor
of

.
 
<EOS>
The
fish
were
small
and
bony
,
and
the
potatoes
were
a

.
 
<EOS>
We
all
acknowledged
that
we
felt
this
something
of
a
disappointment
;
but
Mrs
Gummidge
said
she
felt
it
more
than
we
did
,
and
shed
tears
again
,
and
made
that
former

with
great

.
   
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
when
Mr
Peggotty
came
home
about

,
this
unfortunate
<EOS>
Mrs
Gummidge
was
knitting
in
her

,
in
a
very

and

.
 
<EOS>
Peggotty
had
been
working
cheerfully
.
 
<EOS>
Ham
had
been
patching
up
a
great

of

;
and
I
,
with
little
Em'ly
by

,
had
been
reading
to

.
<EOS>
Mrs
Gummidge
had
never
made
any
other
remark
than
a

,
and
had
never
raised
her

since

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Mates
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,

,
"
and
how

?
"
   
<EOS>
We

,
or

,
to

,
except
Mrs
Gummidge
,
who
only

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
amiss
?
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,
with

.
<EOS>
"
Cheer

,
old
Mawther
!
"
 
<EOS>
(
Mr
Peggotty
meant
old
girl
.
)
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gummidge
did
not
appear
to

.
 
<EOS>
She
took
out
an
old

;
but
instead

,
and
wiped

again
,
and
still

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
amiss
,

?
"

Mr

.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
've

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why

,
I
've

at
The

,
"
said

Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Drive
!
 
<EOS>
I
do

,
"

Peggotty
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
only

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,
"
said
Mrs
Gummidge
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

along

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

Along

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Yes

<EOS>

<EOS>
It
's

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
I
an't

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
My

has

contrary
.
<EOS>
I
feel
my

,
and
they
make

.
 
<EOS>
I
wish

did

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
've
made
your
sister
so
all

,

Master
Davy
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Here

"
<EOS>
No
,

,
Mrs

,
"
in

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
It

.
 
<EOS>
I

go

.
 
<EOS>
I

a

lorn
creetur
'
,
and

.
 
<EOS>
If

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Dan'l
,
I
'd
better
go
into
the
house
,
and
die
and
be
a
riddance
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gummidge
retired
with

,
and
betook

to

.
<EOS>
When
she
was

,
Mr
Peggotty
,
who
had
not

any

,
looked

,

that

still

,

:
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
been
thinking
of
the
old
'
un
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
did
not
quite
understand
what
old
one
<EOS>
Mrs
Gummidge
was
supposed
to
have
fixed
her

upon
,
until
Peggotty
,
on

me

,

was
the
late
Mr
Gummidge
;
and
that
her
brother
always
took
that
for
a
received
truth
on

,
and
that

always
had
a

upon

.
 
<EOS>
Some

was
in

that

,
I

myself
repeat
to
Ham
,
"
Poor
thing
!
 
<EOS>
She
's
been
thinking
of
the
old
'
un
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
whenever
Mrs
Gummidge
was
overcome
in

similar

during

remainder
of
our
stay
(
which
happened
some

)
,
he
always

in

of

,
and
always

.
   
<EOS>
So
the
fortnight
slipped
away
,
varied
by
nothing
but
the
variation
of
the
tide
,
which
altered
Mr
Peggotty
's
times
of

out

,
and

's

also
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
latter
was
unemployed
,
he
sometimes
walked
with
us
to
show
us
the
boats
and
ships
,
and
once
or
twice

took
us
for

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
why
one
slight
set
of
impressions
should
be
more
particularly
associated
with
a
place
than
another
,
though
I
believe

obtains

,
in
reference

.
 
<EOS>
I
never
hear

,
or
read

,
of
Yarmouth
,
but
I
am
reminded
of
a

on
the

,
the

for

,
little
Em'ly
leaning

,
<EOS>
Ham
lazily

,
and
the

,
away
at

,
just
breaking
through

,
and
showing
us
the
ships
,
like

.
   
<EOS>
At
last
the
day
came
for
going
home
.
 
<EOS>
I
bore
up
against
the

from
Mr
Peggotty
and
Mrs
Gummidge
,
but
my

of
mind
at

little
Em'ly
was

.
 
<EOS>
We
went
arm
-
in
-
arm
to
the
public
-
house
where
the
carrier
put
up
,
and
I
promised
,
on

,

.
 
<EOS>
(
I
redeemed
that

,
in

than

usually

.
)
<EOS>
We

;
and

,

,
I

had

void

,

.
   
<EOS>
Now
,

on

,

to
my
home
again
,

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

to
point

with

;

I

,
all

for

,
that
it
was
my
nest
,
and
that
my
mother
was

.
   
<EOS>
This
gained
upon

as
we
went
along
;
so
that

,
the
more
familiar

objects
became
that

,
<EOS>
the
more

was
to

,

.
 
<EOS>
But
Peggotty
,

sharing
in

,
tried

check

(
though
very

)
,

.
   
<EOS>
Blunderstone
Rookery
would
come
,

,

her
,

---
and

.
 
<EOS>
How
well
I
recollect
it
,
on

,

,
threatening

!
   
<EOS>
The

opened
,
and
I
looked
,
half

half

in

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not

,
but

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Peggotty
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I

,

,
"
is

she

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
She
's

.
 
<EOS>
Wait

,

,

<EOS>
---
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
Between

,

,

was
making

,

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

;

,

;

<EOS>
"
Peggotty
!
<EOS>
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
's
the
matter
,
bless

,
Master
Davy
dear
!
"
<EOS>
she

,
assuming

.
   
<EOS>
"
Something
's

matter
,
I
'm

.
 
<EOS>
Where
's

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
's

,
Master
Davy
?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Why
has

she
come

,
and

?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
Peggotty
!
"
 
<EOS>
My

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless

boy
!
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

?
 
<EOS>
Speak
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,

!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

's

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
cried

<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
with

of

;
and

,

and

I
had

.
   
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"

,
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

have

,

,
but
I
could
n't
azackly
"
---
that

,
in
Peggotty
's

words
<EOS>
---
"
bring

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Go

,

,
"
said

,

<EOS>
"
Master

,
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

?
 
<EOS>
You
have
got

Pa
!
"
   
<EOS>
I

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
Something
---
I

,

---
connected

,

<EOS>
"
A

,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
A
new
one
?
<EOS>
"
I
repeated
.
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
gave
a
gasp
,
as
if
she
were
swallowing
something
that
was
very
hard
,
and
,
putting

,

:
   
"
<EOS>
Come
and
see

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do

want

see
him
.
"
   
---
"
<EOS>
And
your
mama
,
"
said
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
I
ceased
to
draw

,
and
we
went
straight
to
the
best
parlour
,
where
she
left

.
 
<EOS>
On
one

the
fire
,
sat
my
mother
;
on

,
Mr
Murdstone
.
 
<EOS>
My
mother

,
and
arose

,
but

I
thought
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Clara
my
dear
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Recollect
!
control
yourself
,
always
control

!
 
<EOS>
Davy
boy
,
how
do
you
do
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
gave
him

hand
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
moment

suspense
,
I
went
and
kissed
my
mother
:
she
kissed
me
,
patted
me
gently
on
the
shoulder
,
and
sat
down
again
to
her
work
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
look
at
her
<EOS>
,
I
could
not

at
him
,
I
knew

well
that
he

looking

;
and
I

,
at
some

that
were

in

.
   
<EOS>
As

I
could

away
,
I
crept
upstairs
.
 
<EOS>
My
old
dear
bedroom
was
changed
,
and
I
was
to
lie
a
long

off
.
 
<EOS>
I
rambled
downstairs
to
find
anything
that
was
like
itself
,
so
altered
it
all
seemed
;
and
roamed
into
the
yard
.
 
<EOS>
I
very
soon
started
back
from
there
,
for
the
empty
dog
-
kennel
was
filled
up
with
a
great
dog
---
deep

and
black
-

Him
---
and
he
was
very
angry
at
the
sight

me
,
and
sprang

to
get

.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
4
.
<EOS>
I
Fall
into
Disgrace
 
<EOS>
If
the
room
to
which
my
bed
was
removed
were
a
sentient
thing
that
could
give
evidence
,
I
might
appeal
to
it
at
this
day
---
who
sleeps
there
now
,
I
wonder
!
<EOS>
---
to
bear
witness
for
me
what
a
heavy
heart
I
carried
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
up
there
,
hearing
the
dog
in
the
yard
bark

me
all
the
way
while
I
climbed

stairs
;
and
,
looking
as
blank
and
strange
upon
the
room
as
the
room
looked
upon
me
,
sat
down
with
my
small
hands
crossed
,
and
thought
.
   
<EOS>
I
thought
of
the
oddest
things
.
 
<EOS>
Of
the
shape
of
the
room
,
of
the
cracks

,

,

window
-
glass

on
the
prospect
,
of
the
washing
-
stand
being
rickety
on
its
three

,
and
having
a
discontented
something
about

,
which
reminded
me
of
Mrs
Gummidge
under

of
the
old
one
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
crying
all
the
time
,
but
,
except
that
I
was
conscious
of
being
cold
and

,
I
am
sure
I
never

why
I

.
 
<EOS>
At
last

I
began
to
consider
that
I
was
dreadfully
in
love
with
little
Em'ly
,
and
had
been

from
her
to
come
here
where
no

seemed
to
want
me
,
or
to

,
half

she
did
.
 
<EOS>
This
made
such
a
very
miserable
piece

business
of

,
that
I
rolled
myself
up
in
a
corner

,
and

to

.
   
<EOS>
I
was

"
Here
he
is
!
"
and

.
 
<EOS>
My
mother
and
Peggotty
had
come
to

,
and
it
was
one

.
   
<EOS>
"
Davy
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's

?
"
   
<EOS>
I
thought

,

,
"
Nothing
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
turned
over
on

,
I
recollect
,
to

,
which
answered

.
<EOS>
"
Davy
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Davy
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
I
dare

no

she
could

uttered

so

,

,
as
her

me
her

.
 
<EOS>
I

and

<EOS>
"
This

,
Peggotty

"

<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
How

?
 
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Poor

It

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Davy

,

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

hard

"

"

---

"
   
<EOS>
He
drew

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
knew

,

,

<EOS>
I

Go

.
 
<EOS>
"
David

.
 
<EOS>
My

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>
Will

?
"
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
,

,

;
seeing
,
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
When

two

,

,
and

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
my
own
attracted
,
no
less

,
to
his
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
recall

being
opposed
thus
,
face

,
I
seem
again
to
hear
my
heart
beat
fast
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
David
,
"
he
said
,
making

lips
thin
,
by

,
"
if
I
have
an

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beat

.
"
   
<EOS>
I
had

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
make

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

"
I
'll

fellow
"
;

.
 
<EOS>
What
is
that
upon

?
"
   
"
Dirt
,
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
He
knew

was
the
mark
of
tears
as
well
as
I.
 
<EOS>
But
if
he
had
asked

twenty

,
each

with
twenty

,
I
believe
my
baby

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have

,
"
he

,

,
"
and
you
understood
me
very
well
<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
Wash

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
He

,

I

Mrs

,

.
<EOS>
I

,
and
I

,
that

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Clara
,

,
"
he

,
when

,
and

"
you

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
"
   
<EOS>
God

,
I
might
have
been

for
my

,
I
might
have
been
made
another
creature
perhaps
,
for
life
,
by
a

.
 
<EOS>
A
word
of

and

,
of

for
my

,
of
welcome
home
,
of

to

that

was
home
,
might
have

dutiful
to
him
in

,

in

outside
,
and
might

.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
my
mother
was
sorry
to

me

in
the
room
<EOS>
so
scared
and

,
and
that
,

,

I
stole

,
she
followed

with

more

---
missing
,

,

my
childish

---
but
the
word
was
not

,
and
the
time
for
it
was
gone
.
   
<EOS>
We
dined
alone
,
<EOS>
we
three

.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
be
very
fond
of
my
mother
<EOS>
---
I
am
afraid
I

none

---
and
she
was
very

of

.
 
<EOS>
I
gathered
from
what

,
that
an
elder

of
his
was
coming
to
stay
with
them
,
and
that
she
was
expected
that

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
certain
whether
I
found
out
then
,
or

,
that
,
without
being
actively
concerned
in
any

,
he

,

,
a

-

,

had

's

,

;
but
I
may
mention

,
whether
or
no
.
   
<EOS>
After

,
when
we

,
and

to

without

,
lest

house
,
a

and

to
receive

.
<EOS>
My
mother
followed
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
timidly

her
,
when
she
turned
round
at
the

,
in

,
and
taking

in

as
she
had
been
used
to
do
<EOS>
,

to
love

new

and
be

.
 
<EOS>
She
did
this

and

,
as
if

were
wrong
,
but

;
and
,

,
held
mine
in
it
,
until
we
came
near
to
where
he
was
standing
in
the
garden
,
where
she
let
mine
go
,
and
drew
hers
through
his
arm
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
Miss
Murdstone
who
was
arrived
,
and
a
gloomy
-
looking
lady
she
was
;
dark
,
like
her
brother
,
whom
she
greatly
resembled
in
face
and

;
and
with
very

,
nearly
meeting
over
her
large
nose
,
as
if
,
being
disabled
by
the
wrongs
of
her
sex
from
wearing
whiskers
,
she
had
carried
them
to
that
account
.
 
<EOS>
She
brought
with
her
two
uncompromising
hard
black
boxes
,
with
her
initials
on
the
lids
in
hard
brass
nails
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
paid
the
coachman
she
took
her
money
out
of
a
hard
steel
purse
,
and
she
kept
the
purse
in
a
very
jail
of
a
bag
which
hung
upon
her
arm
by
a
heavy
chain
,
and
shut
up
like
a
bite
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
never
,
at
that
time
,
seen
such
a
metallic
lady
altogether
as
Miss
Murdstone
was
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
brought
into
the
parlour
with
many
tokens
of
welcome
,
and
there
formally
recognized
my
mother
as
a
new
and
near
relation
.
<EOS>
Then
she
looked
at
me
,
and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Is
that
your
boy
,
sister
-
in
-
law
?
"
   
<EOS>
My
mother
acknowledged
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Generally
speaking
,
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
,
"
I
do
n't
like
boys
.
 
<EOS>
How
d'ye
do
,
boy
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Under
these
encouraging
circumstances
,
I
replied
that
I
was
very
well
,
and
that
I
hoped
she
was
the
same
;
with
such
an
indifferent
grace
,
that
Miss
Murdstone
disposed
of
me
in
two
words
:
   
"
<EOS>
Wants
manner
!
"
   
<EOS>
Having
uttered
which
,
with
great
distinctness
,
she
begged
the
favour
of
being
shown
to
her
room
,
which
became
to
me
from
that
time
forth
a
place
of
awe
and
dread
,
wherein
the
two
black
boxes
were
never
seen
open
or
known
to
be
left
unlocked
,
and
where
(
for
I
peeped
in
once
or
twice
when
she
was
out
)
numerous
little
steel
fetters
and
rivets
,
with
which
Miss
Murdstone
embellished
herself
when
she
was
dressed
,
generally
hung
upon
the
looking
-
glass
in
formidable
array
.
   
<EOS>
As
well
as
I
could
make
out
,
she
had
come
for
good
,
and
had
no
intention
of
ever
going
again
.
 
<EOS>
She
began
to
"
help
"
my
mother
next
morning
,
and
was
in
and
out
of
the
store
-
closet
all
day
,
putting
things
to
rights
,
and
making
havoc
in
the
old
arrangements
.
 
<EOS>
Almost
the
first
remarkable
thing
I
observed
in
Miss
Murdstone
was
,
her
being
constantly
haunted
by
a
suspicion
that
the
servants
had
a
man
secreted
somewhere
on
the
premises
.
 
<EOS>
Under
the
influence
of
this
delusion
,
she
dived
into
the
coal
-
cellar
at
the
most
untimely
hours
,
and
scarcely
ever
opened
the
door
of
a
dark
cupboard
without
clapping
it
to
again
,
in
the
belief
that
she
had
got
him
.
   
<EOS>
Though
there
was
nothing
very
airy
about
Miss
Murdstone
,
she
was
a
perfect
Lark
in
point
of
getting
up
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
up
(
and
,
as
I
believe
to
this
hour
,
looking
for
that
man
)
before
anybody
in
the
house
was
stirring
.
 
<EOS>
Peggotty
gave
it
as
her
opinion
that
she
even
slept
with
one
eye
open
;
but
I
could
not
concur
in
this
idea
;
for
I
tried
it
myself
after
hearing
the
suggestion
thrown
out
,
and
found
it
could
n't
be
done
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
very
first
morning
after
her
arrival
she
was
up
and
ringing
her
bell
at
cock
-
crow
.
 
<EOS>
When
my
mother
came
down
to
breakfast
and
was
going
to
make
the
tea
,
Miss
Murdstone
gave
her
a
kind
of
peck
on
the
cheek
,
which
was
her
nearest
approach
to
a
kiss
,
and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Now
,
Clara
,
my
dear
,
I
am
come
here
,
you
know
,
to
relieve
you
of
all
the
trouble
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
much
too
pretty
and
thoughtless
"
---
my
mother
blushed
but
laughed
,
and
seemed
not
to
dislike
this
character
---
"
to
have
any
duties
imposed
upon
you
that
can
be
undertaken
by
me
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
'll
be
so
good
as
give
me
your
keys
,
my
dear
,
I
'll
attend
to
all
this
sort
of
thing
in
future
.
"
   
<EOS>
From
that
time
,
Miss
Murdstone
kept
the
keys
in
her
own
little
jail
all
day
,
and
under
her
pillow
all
night
,
and
my
mother
had
no
more
to
do
with
them
than
I
had
.
   
<EOS>
My
mother
did
not
suffer
her
authority
to
pass
from
her
without
a
shadow
of
protest
.
 
<EOS>
One
night
when
Miss
Murdstone
had
been
developing
certain
household
plans
to
her
brother
,
of
which
he
signified
his
approbation
,
my
mother
suddenly
began
to
cry
,
and
said
she
thought
she
might
have
been
consulted
.
   
<EOS>
"
Clara
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
sternly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Clara
!
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
at
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
's
very
well
to
say
you
wonder
,
Edward
!
"
<EOS>
cried
my
mother
,
"
and
it
's
very
well
for
you
to
talk
about
firmness
,
but
you
would
n't
like
it
yourself
.
"
   
<EOS>
Firmness
,
I
may
observe
,
was
the
grand
quality
on
which
both
Mr
and
Miss
Murdstone
took
their
stand
.
 
<EOS>
However
I
might
have
expressed
my
comprehension
of
it
at
that
time
,
if
I
had
been
called
upon
,
I
nevertheless
did
clearly
comprehend
in
my
own
way
,
that
it
was
another
name
for
tyranny
;
and
for
a
certain
gloomy
,
arrogant
,
devil
's
humour
,
that
was
in
them
both
.
 
<EOS>
The
creed
,
as
I
should
state
it
now
,
was
this
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Murdstone
was
firm
;
nobody
in
his
world
was
to
be
so
firm
as
Mr
Murdstone
;
nobody
else
in
his
world
was
to
be
firm
at
all
,
for
everybody
was
to
be
bent
to
his
firmness
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
was
an
exception
.
 
<EOS>
She
might
be
firm
,
but
only
by
relationship
,
and
in
an
inferior
and
tributary
degree
.
 
<EOS>
My
mother
was
another
exception
.
 
<EOS>
She
might
be
firm
,
and
must
be
;
but
only
in
bearing
their
firmness
,
and
firmly
believing
there
was
no
other
firmness
upon
earth
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
hard
,
"
said
my
mother
,
"
that
in
my
own
house
---
"
   
"
My
own
house
?
"
<EOS>
repeated
Mr
Murdstone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Clara
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
OUR
own
house
,
I
mean
,
"
faltered
my
mother
,
evidently
frightened
---
"
<EOS>
I
hope
you
must
know
what
I
mean
,
Edward
<EOS>
---
it
's
very
hard
that
in
YOUR
own
house
I
may
not
have
a
word
to
say
about

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
I
managed
very
well
before
we
were
married
.
<EOS>
There
's
evidence
,
"
said
my
mother
,

;
"
ask
Peggotty
if
I
did

do
very

I
was

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Edward
,
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
,
"
let

an

.
 
<EOS>
I
go
tomorrow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Jane
Murdstone
,
"
said
her
brother
,
"
be

!
 
<EOS>
How
dare
you
to
insinuate
that
you
do
n't
know
my
character
better
than
your

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am

,
"
my

,

,
and

,
"
I
do

.
 
<EOS>
I
should

very

if
anybody
was

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
ask
much
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
unreasonable
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
want
to
be
consulted
sometimes
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
much

to
anybody

me
,

only

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
you
were
pleased
,

,

girlish
,
Edward
<EOS>
---
I
am

---
but

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Edward
,
"

Murdstone
,

,
"
let

end

.
<EOS>
I
go
tomorrow
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Jane
Murdstone
,
"
thundered
Mr
Murdstone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
be
silent
?
<EOS>
How
dare
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
made
a
jail
-

of
her
pocket

,
and
held
it
before

.
   
<EOS>
"
Clara
,
"
he

,

,
"

!
 
<EOS>
You
astound

!
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
had
a
satisfaction
in
the
thought
of
marrying
an
inexperienced
and
artless
person
,
and
forming
her

,
and
infusing

.
 
<EOS>
But

Jane
Murdstone
is

,
and
to

,

,

's
,

---
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,

,
Edward
,
"

,
"
do

.
 
<EOS>
I
am

am
not

.
 
<EOS>
No

was
before
.
 
<EOS>
I

many

,
but
not

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
do

,
my

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
When
Jane
Murdstone

,
I

,
"

,

,
"
with

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do

,

,

!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
do

,
Edward
!
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't

.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
I
am
,
I
am

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Ask
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure

'll
tell
you
<EOS>
I
'm

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There

,
"

"
that
can

.
 
<EOS>
You
lose

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pray

,
"
said
my
mother
,
"
I
could
n't
live
under
coldness

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
so

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
great

,
I

,

,
Edward
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Jane
,
I
do

anything
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
be

broken

if
you

---
<EOS>
"
My
mother
was
too

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Jane
Murdstone
,
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
to

,
"
any

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

my

.
 
<EOS>
I

by

.
 
<EOS>
Nor

your
fault
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
betrayed

it
by
another
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
both

to
forget

.
 
<EOS>
And
as
this
,
"
he

,

,
"

not

boy
---
David
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
hardly
find
the
door
,
through
the
tears
that
stood
in
my

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
sorry
for
my
mother
's

;
but
I
groped

,
and

,
without

the

,

.
 
<EOS>
When
her
coming

to
look

me
,
an
hour

,
awoke

,
she
said
that
my
mother
had
gone
to
bed
poorly
,
and
that
Mr
and
Miss
Murdstone
were
sitting

.
   
<EOS>
Going
down
next
morning
rather
earlier
than
usual
,
I
paused
outside
the
parlour
door
,
on
hearing
my
mother
's
voice
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
very
earnestly
and
humbly
entreating
Miss
Murdstone
's
pardon
,
which
that
lady
granted
,
and
a
perfect

took
place
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
knew
my
mother
afterwards
to
give

on
any

,
without
first
appealing
to
Miss
Murdstone
,
or
without
having
first
ascertained
by
some
sure

,
what
Miss
Murdstone
's
opinion
was
;
and
I
never
saw
Miss
Murdstone
<EOS>
,
when
out
of
temper
(
she
was
infirm
that
way
)
,
move
her

towards

as

and
offer
to
resign
them
to
my
mother
,
without
seeing
that
my
mother
was
in
a
terrible

.
   
<EOS>
The
gloomy
taint
that
was
in
the
Murdstone
blood
,
darkened
the
Murdstone
religion
,
which
was
austere
and
wrathful
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
thought
,
since
,
that
its
assuming
that
character
was
a
necessary
consequence
of
Mr
Murdstone
's
firmness
,
which
would
n't
allow
him
to
let
anybody
off
from
the
utmost
weight
of
the
severest
penalties
he
could
find
any
excuse
for
.
 
<EOS>
Be
this
as
it
may
<EOS>
,
I
well
remember
the
tremendous
visages
with
which
we
used
to
go
to
church
,
and
the
changed
air
of
the
place
.
 
<EOS>
Again
,
the
dreaded
Sunday
comes
round
,
and
I
file
into
the
old
pew
first
,
like
a
guarded

brought
to
a

.
 
<EOS>
Again
,
Miss
Murdstone
,
in
a
black

gown
,
that
looks
as
if
it
had
been
made
out
of
a

,
follows
close
upon
me
;
then
my
mother
;
then
her
husband
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
Peggotty
now
,
as
in
the
old
time
.
 
<EOS>
Again
,
I
listen
to
Miss
Murdstone
mumbling
the
responses
,
and
emphasizing
all
the
dread
words
with
a
cruel
relish
.
 
<EOS>
Again
,
I
see
her
dark
eyes
roll
round
the
church
when
she
says
"
miserable
sinners
"
,
as
if
she
were
calling
all
the
congregation
names
.
 
<EOS>
Again
,
I
catch
rare
glimpses
of
my
mother
,
moving
her
lips
timidly
between
the
two
,
with
one
of
them
muttering
at
each
ear
like
low
thunder
.
 
<EOS>
Again
,
I
wonder
with
a
sudden
fear
whether
it
is
likely
that
our
good
old
clergyman
can
be
wrong
,
and
Mr
and
Miss
Murdstone
right
,
and
that
all
the
angels
in
Heaven
can
be
destroying
angels
.
 
<EOS>
Again
,
if
I
move
a
finger
or
relax
a
muscle
of
my
face
,
Miss
Murdstone
pokes
me
with
her
prayer
-
book
,
and
makes
my
side
ache
.
   
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
again
,
as
we
walk
home
,
I
note
some
neighbours
looking
at
my
mother
and
at
me
,
and
whispering
.
 
<EOS>
Again
,
as
the
three
go
on
arm
-
in
-
arm
,
and
I
linger
behind
alone
<EOS>
,
I
follow
some
of
those
looks
,
and
wonder
if
my
mother
's
step
be
really
not
so
light
as
I
have
seen
it
,
and
if
the
gaiety
of
her
beauty
be
really
almost
worried
away
.
 
<EOS>
Again
,
I
wonder
whether
any
of
the
neighbours
call
to
mind
,
as
I
do
,
how
we
used
to
walk
home
together
,
she
and
I
;
and
I
wonder
stupidly
about
that
,
all
the
dreary
dismal
day
.
   
<EOS>
There
had
been
some
talk
on
occasions
of
my
going
to
boarding
-
school
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
and
Miss
Murdstone
had
originated
it
,
and
my
mother
had
of
course
agreed
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
,
however
,
was
concluded
on
the
subject
yet
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
,
I
learnt
lessons
at
home
.
<EOS>
Shall
I
ever
forget
those
lessons
!
 
<EOS>
They
were
presided
over
nominally
by
my
mother
,
but
really
by
Mr
Murdstone
and
his
sister
,
who
were
always
present
,
and
found
them
a
favourable
occasion
for
giving
my
mother
lessons
in
that
miscalled
firmness
,
which
was
the
bane
of
both
our
lives
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
was
kept
at
home
for
that
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
been
apt
enough
to
learn
,
and
willing
enough
,
when
my
mother
and
I
had
lived
alone
together
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
faintly
remember
learning
the
alphabet
at
her
knee
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
day
,
when
I
look
upon
the
fat
black
letters
in
the
primer
,
the
puzzling
novelty
of
their
shapes
,
and
the
easy
good
-
nature
of
O^
and
Q^
and
S^
,
seem
to
present
themselves
again
before
me
as
they
used
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
recall
no
feeling
of
disgust
or
reluctance
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
I
seem
to
have
walked
along
a
path
of
flowers
as
far
as
the
crocodile
-
book
,
and
to
have
been
cheered
by
the
gentleness
of
my
mother
's
voice
and
manner
all
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
But
these
solemn
lessons
which
succeeded
those
<EOS>
,
I
remember
as
the
death
-
blow
of
my
peace
,
and
a
grievous
daily
drudgery
and
misery
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
very
long
,
very
numerous
,
very
hard
---
perfectly
unintelligible
,
some
of
them
,
to
me
---
and
I
was
generally
as
much
bewildered
by
them
as
I
believe
my
poor
mother
was
herself
.
   
<EOS>
Let
me
remember
how
it
used
to
be
,
and
bring
one
morning
back
again
.
   
<EOS>
I
come
into
the
second
-
best
parlour
after
breakfast
,
with
my
books
,
and
an
exercise
-
book
,
and
a
slate
.
 
<EOS>
My
mother
is
ready
for
me
at
her
writing
-
desk
,
but
not
half
so
ready
as
Mr
Murdstone
in
his
easy
-
chair
by
the
window
(
though
he
pretends
to
be
reading
a
book
)
,
or
as
Miss
Murdstone
,
sitting
near
my
mother
stringing
steel
beads
.
<EOS>
The
very
sight
of
these
two
has
such
an
influence
over
me
,
that
I
begin
to
feel
the
words
I
have
been
at
infinite
pains
to
get
into
my
head
,
all
sliding
away
,
and
going
I
do
n't
know
where
.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
where
they
do
go
,
by
the
by
?
   
<EOS>
I
hand
the
first
book
to
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
is
a
grammar
,
perhaps
a
history
,
or
geography
.
 
<EOS>
I
take
<EOS>
a
last
drowning
look
at
the
page
as
I
give
it
into
her
hand
,
and
start
off
aloud
at
a
racing
pace
while
I
have
got
it
fresh
.
 
<EOS>
I
trip
over
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Murdstone
looks
up
.
 
<EOS>
I
trip
over
another
word
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
looks
up
.
 
<EOS>
I
redden
,
tumble
over
half
-
a
-
dozen
words
,
and
stop
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
my
mother
would
show
me
the
book
if
she
dared
,
but
she
does
not
dare
,
and
<EOS>
she
says
softly
:
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Davy
,
Davy
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Clara
,
"
says
Mr
Murdstone
,
"
be
firm
with
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
say
,
"
Oh
,
Davy
,
Davy
!
"
 
<EOS>
That
's
childish
.
 
<EOS>
He
knows
his
lesson
,
or
he
does
not
know
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
does
NOT
know
it
,
"
Miss
Murdstone
interposes
awfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
really
afraid
he
does
not
,
"
says
my
mother
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
you
see
,
Clara
,
"
returns
Miss
Murdstone
,
"
you
should
just
give
him
the
book
back
,
and
make
him
know
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
certainly
,
"
says
my
mother
;
"
that
is
what
I
intend
to
do
,
my
dear
Jane
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
Davy
,
try
once
more
,
and
do
n't
be
stupid
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
obey
the
first
clause
of
the
injunction
by
trying
once
more
,
but
am
not
so
successful
with
the
second
,
for
I
am
very
stupid
.
 
<EOS>
I
tumble
down
before
I
get
to
the
old
place
,
at
a
point
where
I
was
all
right
before
,
and
stop
to
think
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
ca
n't
think
about
the
lesson
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
of
the
number
of
yards
of
net
in
Miss
Murdstone
's
cap
,
or
of
the
price
of
Mr
Murdstone
's
dressing
-
gown
,
or
any
such
ridiculous
problem
that
I
have
no
business
with
,
and
do
n't
want
to
have
anything
at
all
to
do
with
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Murdstone
makes
a
movement
of
impatience
which
I
have
been
expecting
for
a
long
time
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
does
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
My
mother
glances
submissively
at
them
,
shuts
the
book
,
and
lays
it
by
as
an
arrear
to
be
worked
out
when
my
other
tasks
are
done
.
   
<EOS>
There
is
a
pile
of
these
arrears
very
soon
,
and
it
swells
like
a
rolling
snowball
.
 
<EOS>
The
bigger
it
gets
,
the
more
stupid
I
get
.
 
<EOS>
The
case
is
so
hopeless
,
and
I
feel
that
I
am
wallowing
in
such
a
bog
of
nonsense
,
that
I
give
up
all
idea
of
getting
out
,
and
abandon
myself
to
my
fate
.
 
<EOS>
The
despairing
way
in
which
my
mother
and
I
look
at
each
other
,
as
I
blunder
on
,
is
truly
melancholy
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
greatest
effect
in
these
miserable
lessons
is
when
my
mother
(
thinking
nobody
is
observing
her
)
tries
to
give
me
the
cue
by
the
motion
of
her
lips
.
 
<EOS>
At
that
instant
,
Miss
Murdstone
,
who
has
been
lying
in
wait
for
nothing
else
all
along
,
says
in
a
deep
warning
voice
:
   
"
Clara
!
"
   
<EOS>
My
mother
starts
,
colours
,
and
smiles
faintly
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Murdstone
comes
out
of
his
chair
,
takes
the
book
,
throws
it
at
me
or
boxes
my
ears
with
it
,
and
turns
me
out
of
the
room
by
the
shoulders
.
   
<EOS>
Even
when
the
lessons
are
done
,
the
worst
is
yet
to
happen
,
in
the
shape
of
an
appalling
sum
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
invented
for
me
,
and
delivered
to
me
orally
by
Mr
Murdstone
,
and
begins
,
"
If
I
go
into
a
cheesemonger
's
shop
,
and
buy
five
thousand
double
-
Gloucester
cheeses
at
fourpence
-
halfpenny
each
,
present
payment
"
---
at
which
I
see
Miss
Murdstone
secretly
overjoyed
.
 
<EOS>
I
pore
over
these
cheeses
without
any
result
or
enlightenment
until
dinner
-
time
,
when
,
having
made
a
Mulatto
of
myself
by
getting
the
dirt
of
the
slate
into
the
pores
of
my
skin
,
I
have
a
slice
of
bread
to
help
me
out
with
the
cheeses
,
and
am
considered
in
disgrace
for
the
rest
of
the
evening
.
   
<EOS>
It
seems
to
me
,
at
this
distance
of
time
,
as
if
my
unfortunate
studies
generally
took
this
course
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
have
done
very
well
if
I
had
been
without
the
Murdstones
;
but
the
influence
of
the
Murdstones
upon
me
was
like
the
fascination
of
two
snakes
on
a
wretched
young
bird
.
 
<EOS>
Even
when
I
did
get
through
the
morning
with
tolerable
credit
,
there
was
not
much
gained
but
dinner
;
for
Miss
Murdstone
never
could
endure
to
see
me
untasked
,
and
if
I
rashly
made
any
show
of
being
unemployed
,
called
her
brother
's
attention
to
me
by
saying
,
"
Clara
,
my
dear
,
there
's
nothing
like
work
---
give
your
boy
an
exercise
"
;
which
caused
me
to
be
clapped
down
to
some
new
labour
,
there
and
then
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
any
recreation
with
other
children
of
my
age
,
I
had
very
little
of
that
;
for
the
gloomy
theology
of
the
Murdstones
made
all
children
out
to
be
a
swarm
of
little
vipers
(
though
there
WAS
a
child
once
set
in
the
midst
of
the
Disciples
)
,
and
held
that
they
contaminated
one
another
.
   
<EOS>
The
natural
result
of
this
treatment
,
continued
,
I
suppose
,
for
some
six
months
or
more
,
was
to
make
me
sullen
,
dull
,
and
dogged
.
<EOS>
I
was
not
made
the
less
so
by
my
sense
of
being
daily
more
and
more
shut
out
and
alienated
from
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
should
have
been
almost
stupefied
but
for
one
circumstance
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
this
.
 
<EOS>
My
father
had
left
a
small
collection
of
books
in
a
little
room
upstairs
,
to
which
I
had
access
(
for
it
adjoined
my
own
)
and
which
nobody
else
in
our
house
ever
troubled
.
 
<EOS>
From
that
blessed
little
room
,
Roderick
Random
,
Peregrine
Pickle
,
Humphrey
Clinker
,
Tom
Jones
,
the
Vicar
of
Wakefield
,
Don
Quixote
,
Gil
Blas
,
and
Robinson
Crusoe
,
came
out
,
a
glorious
host
,
to
keep
me
company
.
<EOS>
They
kept
alive
my
fancy
,
and
my
hope
of
something
beyond
that
place
and
time
,
---
they
,
and
the
Arabian
Nights
,
and
the
Tales
of
the
Genii
,
---
and
did
me
no
harm
;
for
whatever
harm
was
in
some
of
them
was
not
there
for
me
;
I
knew
nothing
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
astonishing
to
me
now
,
how
I
found
time
,
in
the
midst
of
my
porings
and
blunderings
over
heavier
themes
,
to
read
those
books
as
I
did
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
curious
to
me
how
I
could
ever
have
consoled
myself
under
my
small
troubles
(
which
were
great
troubles
to
me
)
,
by
impersonating
my
favourite
characters
in
them
---
as
I
did
---
and
by
putting
Mr
and
Miss
Murdstone
into
all
the
bad
ones
---
which
I
did
too
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
Tom
Jones
(
a
child
's
Tom
Jones
,
a
harmless
creature
)
for
a
week
together
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
sustained
my
own
idea
of
Roderick
Random
for
a
month
at
a
stretch
,
I
verily
believe
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
greedy
relish
for
a
few
volumes
of
Voyages
and
Travels
<EOS>
---
I
forget
<EOS>
what
,
now
---
that
were
on
those
shelves
;
and
for
days
and
days
I
can
remember
to
have
gone
about
my
region
of
our
house
,
armed
with
the
centre
-
piece
out
of
an
old
set
of
boot
-
trees
---
the
perfect
realization
of
Captain
Somebody
,
of
the
Royal
British
Navy
,
in
danger
of
being
beset
by
savages
,
and
resolved
to
sell
his
life
at
a
great
price
.
 
<EOS>
The
Captain
never
lost
dignity
,
from
having
his
ears
boxed
with
the
Latin
Grammar
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
;
but
the
Captain
was
a
Captain
and
a
hero
,
in
despite
of
all
the
grammars
of
all
the
languages
in
the
world
,
dead
or
alive
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
my
only
and
my
constant
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
think
of
it
,
the
picture
always
rises
in
my
mind
,
of
a
summer
evening
,
the
boys
at
play
in
the
churchyard
,
and
I
sitting
on
my
bed
,
reading
as
if
for
life
.
 
<EOS>
Every
barn
in
the
neighbourhood
,
every
stone
in
the
church
,
and
every
foot
of
the
churchyard
,
had
some
association
of
its
own
,
in
my
mind
,
connected
with
these
books
,
and
stood
for
some
locality
made
famous
in
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
seen
Tom
Pipes
go
climbing
up
the
church
-
steeple
;
I
have
watched
Strap
,
with
the
knapsack
on
his
back
,
stopping
to
rest
himself
upon
the
wicket
-
gate
;
and
I
know
that
Commodore
Trunnion
held
that
club
with
Mr
Pickle
,
in
the
parlour
of
our
little
village
alehouse
.
   
<EOS>
The
reader
now
understands
,
as
well
as
I
do
,
what
I
was
when
I
came
to
that
point
of
my
youthful
history
to
which
I
am
now
coming
again
.
   
<EOS>
One
morning
when
I
went
into
the
parlour
with
my
books
,
I
found
my
mother
looking
anxious
,
Miss
Murdstone
looking
firm
,
and
Mr
Murdstone
binding
something
round
the
bottom
of
a
cane
---
a
lithe
and
limber
cane
,
which
he
left
off
binding
when
I
came
in
,
and
poised
and
switched
in
the
air
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
,
Clara
,
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
,
"
I
have
been
often
flogged
myself
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
To
be
sure
;
of
course
,
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
my
dear
Jane
,
"
faltered
my
mother
,
meekly
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
---
but
do
you
think
it
did
Edward
good
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
it
did
Edward
harm
,
Clara
?
"
asked
Mr
Murdstone
,
gravely
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
point
,
"
said
his
sister
.
   
<EOS>
To
this
my
mother
returned
,
"
Certainly
,
my
dear
Jane
,
"
and
said
no
more
.
   
<EOS>
I
felt
apprehensive
that
I
was
personally
interested
in
this
dialogue
,
and
sought
Mr
Murdstone
's
eye
as
it
lighted
on
mine
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
David
,
"
he
said
---
<EOS>
and
I
saw
that
cast
again
as
he
said
it
<EOS>
---
"
you
must
be
far
more
careful
today
than
usual
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
gave
the
cane
another
poise
,
and
another
switch
;
and
having
finished
his
preparation
of
it
,
laid
it
down
beside
him
,
with
an
impressive
look
,
and
took
up
his
book
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
a
good
freshener
to
my
presence
of
mind
,
as
a
beginning
.
<EOS>
I
felt
the
words
of
my
lessons
slipping
off
,
not
one
by
one
,
or
line
by
line
,
but
by
the
entire
page
;
I
tried
to
lay
hold
of
them
;
but
they
seemed
,
if
I
may
so
express
it
,
to
have
put
skates
on
,
and
to
skim
away
from
me
with
a
smoothness
there
was
no
checking
.
   
<EOS>
We
began
badly
,
and
went
on
worse
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
come
in
with
an
idea
of
distinguishing
myself
rather
,
conceiving
that
I
was
very
well
prepared
;
but
it
turned
out
to
be
quite
a
mistake
.
 
<EOS>
Book
after
book
was
added
to
the
heap
of
failures
,
Miss
Murdstone
being
firmly
watchful
of
us
all
the
time
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
we
came
at
last
to
the
five
thousand
cheeses
(
canes
he
made
it
that
day
,
I
remember
)
,
my
mother
burst
out
crying
.
   
<EOS>
"
Clara
!
<EOS>
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
,
in
her
warning
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
quite
well
,
my
dear
Jane
,
I
think
,
"
said
my
mother
.
   
<EOS>
I
saw
him
wink
,
solemnly
,
at
his
sister
,
as
he
rose
and
said
,
taking
up
the
cane
:
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Jane
,
we
can
hardly
expect
Clara
to
bear
,
with
perfect
firmness
,
the
worry
and
torment
that
David
has
occasioned
her
today
.
 
<EOS>
That
would
be
stoical
.
 
<EOS>
Clara
is
greatly
strengthened
and
improved
,
but
we
can
hardly
expect
so
much
from
her
.
 
<EOS>
David
,
you
and
I
will
go
upstairs
,
boy
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
took
me
out
at
the
door
,
my
mother
ran
towards
us
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
said
,
"
Clara
!
<EOS>
are
you
a
perfect
fool
?
"
and
interfered
.
<EOS>
I
saw
my
mother
stop
her
ears
then
,
and
I
heard
her
crying
.
   
<EOS>
He
walked
me
up
to
my
room
slowly
and
gravely
<EOS>
---
I
am
certain
he
had
a
delight
in
that
formal
parade
of
executing
justice
---
and
when
we
got
there
,
suddenly
twisted
my
head
under
his
arm
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Murdstone
!
 
<EOS>
Sir
!
<EOS>
"
I
cried
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
!
 
<EOS>
Pray
do
n't
beat
me
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
tried
to
learn
,
sir
,
but
I
ca
n't
learn
while
you
and
Miss
Murdstone
are
by
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
indeed
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
you
,
indeed
,
David
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
'll
try
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
my
head
as
in
a
vice
,
but
I
twined
round
him
somehow
,
and
stopped
him
for
a
moment
,
entreating
him
not
to
beat
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
only
a
moment
that
I
stopped
him
,
for
he
cut
me
heavily
an
instant
afterwards
,
and
in
the
same
instant
I
caught
the
hand
with
which
he
held
me
in
my
mouth
,
between
my
teeth
,
and
bit
it
through
.
 
<EOS>
It
sets
my
teeth
on
edge
to
think
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
He
beat
me
then
,
as
if
he
would
have
beaten
me
to
death
.
 
<EOS>
Above
all
the
noise
we
made
,
I
heard
them
running
up
the
stairs
,
and
crying
out
<EOS>
---
I
heard
my
mother
crying
out
---
and
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
was
gone
;
and
the
door
was
locked
outside
;
and
I
was
lying
,
fevered
and
hot
,
and
torn
,
and
sore
,
and
raging
in
my
puny
way
,
upon
the
floor
.
   
<EOS>
How
well
I
recollect
,
when
I
became
quiet
,
what
an
unnatural
stillness
seemed
to
reign
through
the
whole
house
!
 
<EOS>
How
well
I
remember
,
when
my
smart
and
passion
began
to
cool
,
how
wicked
I
began
to
feel
!
   
<EOS>
I
sat
listening
for
a
long
while
,
but
there
was
not
a
sound
.
 
<EOS>
I
crawled
up
from
the
floor
,
and
saw
my
face
in
the
glass
,
so
swollen
,
red
,
and
ugly
that
it
almost
frightened
me
.
 
<EOS>
My
stripes
were
sore
and
stiff
,
and
made
me
cry
afresh
,
when
I
moved
;
but
they
were
nothing
to
the
guilt
I
felt
.
 
<EOS>
It
lay
heavier
on
my
breast
<EOS>
than
if
I
had
been
a
most
atrocious
criminal
,
I
dare
say
.
   
<EOS>
It
had
begun
to
grow
dark
,
and
I
had
shut
the
window
(
I
had
been
lying
,
for
the
most
part
,
with
my
head
upon
the
sill
,
by
turns
crying
,
dozing
,
and
looking
listlessly
out
)
,
when
the
key
was
turned
,
and
Miss
Murdstone
came
in
with
some
bread
and
meat
,
and
milk
.
 
<EOS>
These
she
put
down
upon
the
table
without
a
word
,
glaring
at
me
the
while
with
exemplary
firmness
,
and
then
retired
,
locking
the
door
after
her
.
   
<EOS>
Long
after
it
was
dark
<EOS>
I
sat
there
,
wondering
whether
anybody
else
would
come
.
 
<EOS>
When
this
appeared
improbable
for
that
night
,
I
undressed
,
and
went
to
bed
;
and
,
there
,
I
began
to
wonder
fearfully
what
would
be
done
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
it
was
a
criminal
act
that
I
had
committed
?
 
<EOS>
Whether
I
should
be
taken
into
custody
,
and
sent
to
prison
?
 
<EOS>
Whether
I
was
at
all
in
danger
of
being
hanged
?
   
<EOS>
I
never
shall
forget
the
waking
,
next
morning
;
the
being
cheerful
and
fresh
for
the
first
moment
,
and
then
the
being
weighed
down
by
the
stale
and
dismal
oppression
of
remembrance
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
reappeared
before
I
was
out
of
bed
;
told
me
,
in
so
many
words
,
that
I
was
free
to
walk
in
the
garden
for
half
an
hour
and
no
longer
;
and
retired
,
leaving
the
door
open
,
that
I
might
avail
myself
of
that
permission
.
   
<EOS>
I
did
so
,
and
did
so
every
morning
of
my
imprisonment
,
which
lasted
five
days
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
could
have
seen
my
mother
alone
,
I
should
have
gone
down
on
my
knees
to
her
and
besought
her
forgiveness
;
but
I
saw
no
one
,
Miss
Murdstone
excepted
,
during
the
whole
time
---
except
at
evening
prayers
in
the
parlour
;
to
which
I
was
escorted
by
Miss
Murdstone
after
everybody
else
was
placed
;
where
I
was
stationed
,
a
young
outlaw
,
all
alone
by
myself
near
the
door
;
and
whence
<EOS>
I
was
solemnly
conducted
by
my
jailer
,
before
any
one
arose
from
the
devotional
posture
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
observed
that
my
mother
was
as
far
off
from
me
as
she
could
be
,
and
kept
her
face
another
way
so
that
I
never
saw
it
;
and
that
Mr
Murdstone
's
hand
was
bound
up
in
a
large
linen
wrapper
.
   
<EOS>
The
length
of
those
five
days
I
can
convey
no
idea
of
to
any
one
.
<EOS>
They
occupy
the
place
of
years
in
my
remembrance
.
 
<EOS>
The
way
in
which
I
listened
to
all
the
incidents
of
the
house
that
made
themselves
audible
to
me
;
the
ringing
of
bells
,
the
opening
and
shutting
of
doors
,
the
murmuring
of
voices
,
the
footsteps
on
the
stairs
;
to
any
laughing
,
whistling
,
or
singing
,
outside
,
which
seemed
more
dismal
than
anything
else
to
me
in
my
solitude
and
disgrace
---
the
uncertain
pace
of
the
hours
,
especially
at
night
,
when
I
would
wake
thinking
it
was
morning
,
and
find
that
the
family
were
not
yet
gone
to
bed
,
and
that
all
the
length
of
night
had
yet
to
come
---
the
depressed
dreams
and
nightmares
I
had
---
the
return
of
day
,
noon
,
afternoon
,
evening
,
when
the
boys
played
in
the
churchyard
,
and
I
watched
them
from
a
distance
within
the
room
,
being
ashamed
to
show
myself
at
the
window
lest
they
should
know
I
was
a
prisoner
---
the
strange
sensation
of
never
hearing
myself
speak
---
the
fleeting
intervals
of
something
like
cheerfulness
,
which
came
with
eating
and
drinking
,
and
went
away
with
it
---
the
setting
in
of
rain
one
evening
,
with
a
fresh
smell
,
and
its
coming
down
faster
and
faster
between
me
and
the
church
,
until
it
and
gathering
night
seemed
to
quench
me
in
gloom
,
and
fear
,
and
remorse
---
all
this
appears
to
have
gone
round
and
round
for
years
instead
of
days
<EOS>
,
it
is
so
vividly
and
strongly
stamped
on
my
remembrance
.
<EOS>
On
the
last
night
of
my
restraint
,
I
was
awakened
by
hearing
my
own
name
spoken
in
a
whisper
.
 
<EOS>
I
started
up
in
bed
,
and
putting
out
my
arms
in
the
dark
,
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Is
that
you
,
Peggotty
?
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
no
immediate
answer
,
but
presently
I
heard
my
name
again
,
in
a
tone
so
very
mysterious
and
awful
,
that
I
think
I
should
have
gone
into
a
fit
,
if
it
had
not
occurred
to
me
that
it
must
have
come
through
the
keyhole
.
   
<EOS>
I
groped
my
way
to
the
door
,
and
putting
my
own
lips
to
the
keyhole
,
whispered
:
"
<EOS>
Is
that
you
,
Peggotty
dear
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
own
precious
Davy
,
"
she
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
as
soft
as
a
mouse
,
or
the
Cat'll
hear
us
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
understood
this
to
mean
Miss
Murdstone
,
and
was
sensible
of
the
urgency
of
the
case
;
her
room
being
close
by
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
's
mama
,
dear
Peggotty
?
 
<EOS>
Is
she
very
angry
with
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
hear
Peggotty
crying
softly
on
her
side
of
the
keyhole
,
as
I
was
doing
on
mine
,
before
she
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
 
Not
very
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
going
to
be
done
with
me
<EOS>
,
Peggotty
dear
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
School
.
 
<EOS>
Near
London
,
"
was
Peggotty
's
answer
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
obliged
to
get
her
to
repeat
it
,
for
she
spoke
it
the
first
time
quite
down
my
throat
,
in
consequence
of
my
having
forgotten
to
take
my
mouth
away
from
the
keyhole
and
put
my
ear
there
;
and
though
her
words
tickled
me
a
good
deal
,
I
did
n't
hear
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
,
Peggotty
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tomorrow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
the
reason
why
Miss
Murdstone
took
the
clothes
out
of
my
drawers
?
"
<EOS>
which
she
had
done
,
though
I
have
forgotten
to
mention
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
Box
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sha
n't
I
see
mama
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
Morning
.
"
   
<EOS>
Then
Peggotty
fitted
her
mouth
close
to
the
keyhole
,
and
delivered
these
words
through
it
with
as
much
feeling
and
earnestness
as
a
keyhole
has
ever
been
the
medium
of
communicating
,
I
will
venture
to
assert
:
shooting
in
each
broken
little
sentence
in
a
convulsive
little
burst
of
its
own
.
   
<EOS>
"
Davy
,
dear
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
ai
n't
been
azackly
as
intimate
with
you
.
<EOS>
Lately
,
as
I
used
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
It
ai
n't
because
I
do
n't
love
you
.
 
<EOS>
just
as
well
and
more
,
my
pretty
poppet
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
because
I
thought
it
better
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
And
for
someone
else
besides
.
 
<EOS>
Davy
,
my
darling
,
are
you
listening
?
 
<EOS>
Can
you
hear
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ye
-
ye
-
ye
-
<EOS>
yes
,
Peggotty
!
<EOS>
"
I
sobbed
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
own
!
<EOS>
"
said
Peggotty
,
with
infinite
compassion
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
I
want
to
say
,
is
.
 
<EOS>
That
you
must
never
forget
me
.
 
<EOS>
For
I
'll
never
forget
you
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
'll
take
as
much
care
of
your
mama
,
Davy
.
 
<EOS>
As
ever
I
took
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
wo
n't
leave
her
.
 
<EOS>
The
day
may
come
when
she
'll
be
glad
to
lay
her
poor
head
.
 
<EOS>
On
her
stupid
,
cross
old
Peggotty
's
arm
again
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
'll
write
to
you
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
Though
I
ai
n't
no
scholar
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
'll
---
<EOS>
I
'll
---
"
Peggotty
fell
to
kissing
the
keyhole
,
as
she
could
n't
kiss
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
dear
Peggotty
!
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
thank
you
!
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
!
<EOS>
Will
you
promise
me
one
thing
,
Peggotty
?
 
<EOS>
Will
you
write
and
tell
Mr
Peggotty
and
little
Em'ly
,
and
Mrs
Gummidge
and
Ham
,
that
I
am
not
so
bad
as
they
might
suppose
,
and
that
I
sent
'em
all
my
love
---
especially
to
little
Em'ly
?
 
<EOS>
Will
you
,
if
you
please
,
Peggotty
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
kind
soul
promised
,
and
we
both
of
us
kissed
the
keyhole
with
the
greatest
affection
<EOS>
---
I
patted
it
with
my
hand
,
I
recollect
,
as
if
it
had
been
her
honest
face
---
and
parted
.
 
<EOS>
From
that
night
there
grew
up
in
my
breast
a
feeling
for
Peggotty
which
I
can
not
very
well
define
.
 
<EOS>
She
did
not
replace
my
mother
;
no
one
could
do
that
;
but
she
came
into
a
vacancy
in
my
heart
,
which
closed
upon
her
,
and
I
felt
towards
her
something
I
have
never
felt
for
any
other
human
being
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
sort
of
comical
affection
,
too
;
and
yet
if
she
had
died
,
I
can
not
think
what
I
should
have
done
,
or
how
I
should
have
acted
out
the
tragedy
it
would
have
been
to
me
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
morning
Miss
Murdstone
appeared
as
usual
,
and
told
me
I
was
going
to
school
;
which
was
not
altogether
such
news
to
me
as
she
supposed
.
 
<EOS>
She
also
informed
me
that
when
I
was
dressed
,
I
was
to
come
downstairs
into
the
parlour
,
and
have
my
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
There
,
I
found
my
mother
,
very
pale
and
with
red
eyes
:
into
whose
arms
I
ran
,
and
begged
her
pardon
from
my
suffering
soul
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Davy
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
you
could
hurt
anyone
I
love
!
 
<EOS>
Try
to
be
better
,
pray
to
be
better
!
 
<EOS>
I
forgive
you
;
but
I
am
so
grieved
,
Davy
,
that
you
should
have
such
bad
passions
in
your
heart
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
had
persuaded
her
that
I
was
a
wicked
fellow
,
and
she
was
more
sorry
for
that
than
for
my
going
away
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
it
sorely
.
 
<EOS>
I
tried
to
eat
my
parting
breakfast
,
but
my
tears
dropped
upon
my
bread
-
and
-
butter
,
and
trickled
into
my
tea
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
my
mother
look
at
me
sometimes
,
and
then
glance
at
the
watchful
Miss
Murdstone
,
and
than
look
down
,
or
look
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
Master
Copperfield
's
box
there
!
<EOS>
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
,
when
wheels
were
heard
at
the
gate
.
   
<EOS>
I
looked
for
Peggotty
,
but
it
was
not
she
;
neither
she
nor
Mr
Murdstone
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
My
former
acquaintance
,
the
carrier
,
was
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
the
box
was
taken
out
to
his
cart
,
and
lifted
in
.
   
<EOS>
"
Clara
!
<EOS>
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
,
in
her
warning
note
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ready
,
my
dear
Jane
,
"
returned
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
,
Davy
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
going
for
your
own
good
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
,
my
child
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
come
home
in
the
holidays
,
and
be
a
better
boy
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Clara
!
"
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
repeated
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
my
dear
Jane
,
"
replied
my
mother
,
who
was
holding
me
.
<EOS>
"
I
forgive
you
,
my
dear
boy
.
 
<EOS>
God
bless
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Clara
!
"
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
repeated
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
was
good
enough
to
take
me
out
to
the
cart
,
and
to
say
on
the
way
that
she
hoped
I
would
repent
,
before
I
came
to
a
bad
end
;
and
then
I
got
into
the
cart
,
and
the
lazy
horse
walked
off
with
it
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
5
.
<EOS>
I
am
sent
away
from
home
 
<EOS>
We
might
have
gone
about
half
a
mile
,
and
my
pocket
-
handkerchief
was
quite
wet
through
,
when
the
carrier
stopped
short
.
 
<EOS>
Looking
out
to
ascertain
for
what
,
I
saw
,
to
MY
amazement
,
Peggotty
burst
from
a
hedge
and
climb
into
the
cart
.
 
<EOS>
She
took
me
in
both
her
arms
,
and
squeezed
me
to
her
stays
until
the
pressure
on
my
nose
was
extremely
painful
,
though
I
never
thought
of
that
till
afterwards
when
I
found
it
very
tender
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
single
word
did
Peggotty
speak
.
<EOS>
Releasing
one
of
her
arms
,
she
put
it
down
in
her
pocket
to
the
elbow
,
and
brought
out
some
paper
bags
of
cakes
which
she
crammed
into
my
pockets
,
and
a
purse
which
she
put
into
my
hand
,
but
not
one
word
<EOS>
did
she
say
.
 
<EOS>
After
another
and
a
final
squeeze
with
both
arms
,
she
got
down
from
the
cart
and
ran
away
;
and
,
my
belief
is
,
and
has
always
been
,
without
a
solitary
button
on
her
gown
.
 
<EOS>
I
picked
up
one
,
of
several
that
were
rolling
about
,
and
treasured
it
as
a
keepsake
for
a
long
time
.
   
<EOS>
The
carrier
looked
at
me
,
as
if
to
inquire
if
she
were
coming
back
.
<EOS>
I
shook
my
head
,
and
said
I
thought
not
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
come
up
,
"
said
the
carrier
to
the
lazy
horse
;
who
came
up
accordingly
.
   
<EOS>
Having
by
this
time
cried
as
much
as
I
possibly
could
,
I
began
to
think
it
was
of
no
use
crying
any
more
,
especially
as
neither
Roderick
Random
,
nor
that
Captain
in
the
Royal
British
Navy
,
had
ever
cried
,
that
I
could
remember
,
in
trying
situations
.
 
<EOS>
The
carrier
,
seeing
me
in
this
resolution
,
proposed
that
my
pocket
-
handkerchief
should
be
spread
upon
the
horse
's
back
to
dry
.
 
<EOS>
I
thanked
him
,
and
assented
;
and
particularly
small
it
looked
,
under
those
circumstances
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
now
leisure
to
examine
the
purse
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
stiff
leather
purse
,
with
a
snap
,
and
had
three
bright
shillings
in
it
,
which
Peggotty
had
evidently
polished
up
with
whitening
,
for
my
greater
delight
.
 
<EOS>
But
its
most
precious
contents
were
two
half
-
crowns
folded
together
in
a
bit
of
paper
,
on
which
was
written
,
in
my
mother
's
hand
,
"
For
Davy
.
 
<EOS>
With
my
love
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
overcome
by
this
,
that
I
asked
the
carrier
to
be
so
good
as
to
reach
me
<EOS>
my
pocket
-
handkerchief
again
;
but
he
said
he
thought
I
had
better
do
without
it
,
and
I
thought
I
really
had
,
so
I
wiped
my
eyes
on
my
sleeve
and
stopped
myself
.
   
<EOS>
For
good
,
too
;
though
,
in
consequence
of
my
previous
emotions
,
I
was
still
occasionally
seized
with
a
