.
 
<EOS>
After
we
had
jogged
on
for
some
little
time
,
I
asked
the
carrier
if
he
was
going
all
the
way
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
the
way
where
?
"
inquired
the
carrier
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
,
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
's
there
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
carrier
.
   
<EOS>
"
Near
London
,
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
that
horse
,
"
said
the
carrier
,
jerking
the
rein
to
point
him
out
,
"
would
be
deader
than
pork
afore
<EOS>
he
got
over
half
the
ground
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
only
going
to
Yarmouth
then
?
<EOS>
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
about
it
,
"
said
the
carrier
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
there
I
shall
take
you
to
the
stage
-
cutch
,
and
the
stage
-
cutch
that
'll
take
you
to
---
wherever
it
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
this
was
a
great
deal
for
the
carrier
(
whose
name
was
Mr
Barkis
)
to
say
---
he
being
,
as
I
observed
in
a
former
chapter
,
of
a
phlegmatic
temperament
,
and
not
at
all
conversational
---
I
offered
him
a
cake
as
a
mark
of
attention
,
which
he
ate
at
one
gulp
,
exactly
like
an
elephant
,
and
which
made
no
more
impression
on
his
big
face
than
it
would
have
done
on
an
elephant
's
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Did
SHE
make
'em
,
now
?
"
said
Mr
Barkis
,
always
leaning
forward
,
in
his
slouching
way
,
on
the
footboard
of
the
cart
with
an
arm
on

.
   
<EOS>
"
Peggotty
,
do
you
mean
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Mr
Barkis
.
 
<EOS>
"
Her
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
She
makes
all
our
pastry
,
and
does
all
our
cooking
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
she
though
?
"
said
Mr
Barkis
.
<EOS>
He
made
up
his
mouth
as
if
to
whistle
,
but
he
did
n't
whistle
.
 
<EOS>
He
sat
looking
at
the
horse
's
ears
,
as
if
he
saw
something
new
there
;
and
sat
so
,
for
a
considerable
time
.
 
<EOS>
By
and
by
<EOS>
,
he
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
No
sweethearts
,
I
b'lieve
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sweetmeats
did
you
say
,
Mr
Barkis
?
"
 
<EOS>
For
I
thought
he
wanted
something
else
to
eat
,
and
had
pointedly
alluded
to
that
description
of
refreshment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hearts
,
"
said
Mr
Barkis
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sweet
hearts
;
no
person
walks
with
her
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
Peggotty
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Her
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
She
never
had
a
sweetheart
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
n't
she
,
though
!
"
said
Mr
Barkis
.
   
<EOS>
Again
he
made
up
his
mouth
to
whistle
,
and
again

did
n't
whistle
,
but
sat
looking
at

horse
's

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
she
makes
,
"
said
Mr
Barkis
,
after

,
"
all
the
apple
parsties
,
and
doos
all
the
cooking
,
do
she
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
replied
that
such
was
the
fact
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
you
what
,
"
said
Mr
Barkis
.
 
<EOS>
"
P'raps
you
might
be
writin
'
to
her
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
certainly
write
to
her
,
"
I
rejoined
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
slowly
turning
his
eyes
towards
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
!
 
<EOS>
If
you
was
writin
'
to
her
,
p'raps
you
'd
recollect
to
say
that
Barkis
was
willin
'
;
would
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
Barkis
is
willing
,
"
I
repeated
,
innocently
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
that
all
the
message
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ye
-
es
,
"
he
said
,
considering
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ye
-
es
.
 
<EOS>
Barkis
is
willin
'
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
you
will
be
at
Blunderstone
again
tomorrow
,
Mr
Barkis
,
"
I
said
,
faltering
a
little
at
the
idea
of
my
being
far
away
from
it
then
,
"
and
could
give
your
own
message
so
much
better
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
repudiated
this
suggestion
,
however
,
with
a
jerk
of
his
head
,
and
once
more
confirmed
his
previous
request
by
saying
,
with
profound
gravity
,
"
Barkis
is
willin
'
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
message
,
"
I
readily
undertook
its
transmission
.
 
<EOS>
While
I
was
waiting
for
the
coach
in
the
hotel
at
Yarmouth
that
very
afternoon
,
I
procured
a
sheet
of
paper
and
an
inkstand
,
and
wrote
a
note
to
Peggotty
,
which
ran
thus
:
"
My
dear
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
come
here
safe
.
 
<EOS>
Barkis
is
willing
.
 
<EOS>
My
love
to
mama
.
 
<EOS>
Yours
affectionately
.
 
<EOS>
PS
.
 
<EOS>
He
says
he
particularly
wants
you
to
know
<EOS>
---
BARKIS
IS
WILLING
.
"
   
<EOS>
When
I
had
taken
this
commission
on
myself
prospectively
,
Mr
Barkis
relapsed
into
perfect
silence
;
and
I
,
feeling
quite
worn
out
by
all
that
had
happened
lately
,
lay
down
on
a
sack
in
the
cart
and
fell
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
I
slept
soundly
until
we
got
to
Yarmouth
;
which
was
so
entirely
new
and
strange
to
me
in
the
inn
-
yard
to
which
we
drove
,
that
I
at
once
abandoned
a
latent
hope
I
had
had
of
meeting
with
some
of
Mr
Peggotty
's
family
there
,
perhaps
even
with
little
Em'ly
herself
.
   
<EOS>
The
coach
was
in
the
yard
,
shining
very
much
all
over
,
but
without
any
horses
to
it
as
yet
;
and
it
looked
in
that
state
as
if
nothing
was
more
unlikely
than
its
ever
going
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
thinking
this
,
and
wondering
what
would
ultimately
become
of
my
box
,
which
Mr
Barkis
had
put
down
on
the
yard
-
pavement
by
the
pole
(
he
having
driven
up
the
yard
to
turn
his
cart
)
,
and
also
what
would
ultimately
become
of
me
,
when
a
lady
looked
out
of
a
bow
-
window
where
some
fowls
and
joints
of
meat
were
hanging
up
,
and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Is
that
the
little
gentleman
from
Blunderstone
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
ma'am
,
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
name
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
Copperfield
,
ma'am
,
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
wo
n't
do
,
"
returned
the
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nobody
's
dinner
is
paid
for
here
,
in
that
name
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
Murdstone
,
ma'am
?
<EOS>
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
're
Master
Murdstone
,
"
said
the
lady
,
"
why
do
you
go
and
give
another
name
,
first
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
explained
to
the
lady
how
it
was
,
who
than
rang
a
bell
,
and
called
out
,
"
William
!
<EOS>
show
the
coffee
-
room
!
"
<EOS>
upon
which
a
waiter
came
running
out
of
a
kitchen
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
yard
to
show
it
,
and
seemed
a
good
deal
surprised
when
he
was
only
to
show
it
to
me
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
large
long
room
with
some
large
maps
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
doubt
if
I
could
have
felt
much
stranger
if
the
maps
had
been
real
foreign
countries
,
and
I
cast
away
in
the
middle
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
it
was
taking
a
liberty
to
sit
down
,
with
my
cap
in
my
hand
,
on
the
corner
of
the
chair
nearest
the
door
;
and
when
the
waiter
laid
a
cloth
on
purpose
for
me
,
and
put
a
set
of
castors
on
it
,
I
think
I
must
have
turned
red
all
over
with
modesty
.
   
<EOS>
He
brought
me
some
chops
,
and
vegetables
,
and
took
the
covers
off
in
such
a
bouncing
manner
that
I
was
afraid
I
must
have
given
him
some
offence
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
greatly
relieved
my
mind
by
putting
a
chair
for
me
at
the
table
,
and
saying
,
very
affably
,
"
Now
,
six
-
foot
!
<EOS>
come
on
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
thanked
him
,
and
took
my
seat
at
the
board
;
but
found
it
extremely
difficult
to
handle
my
knife
and
fork
with
anything
like
dexterity
,
or
to
avoid
splashing
myself
with
the
gravy
,
while
he
was
standing
opposite
,
staring
so
hard
,
and
making
me
blush
in
the
most
dreadful
manner
every
time
I
caught
his
eye
.
 
<EOS>
After
watching
me
into
the
second
chop
,
he
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
half
a
pint
of
ale
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
have
it
now
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
thanked
him
and
said
,
"
Yes
.
"
 
<EOS>
Upon
which
he
poured
it
out
of
a
jug
into
a
large
tumbler
,
and
held
it
up
against
the
light
,
and
made
it
look
beautiful
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
eye
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
seems
a
good
deal
,
do
n't
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
does
seem
a
good
deal
,
"
I
answered
with
a
smile
.
 
<EOS>
For
it
was
quite
delightful
to
me
,
to
find
him
so
pleasant
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
twinkling
-
eyed
,
pimple
-
faced
man
,
with
his
hair
standing
upright
all
over
his
head
;
and
as
he
stood
with
one
arm
a
-
kimbo
,
holding
up
the
glass
to
the
light
with
the
other
hand
,
he
looked
quite
friendly
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
was
a
gentleman
here
,
yesterday
,
"
he
said
---
"
a
stout
gentleman
,
by
the
name
of
Topsawyer
---
perhaps
you
know
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
<EOS>
,
"
I
said
,
"
I
do
n't
think
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
In
breeches
and
gaiters
,
broad
-
brimmed
hat
,
grey
coat
,
speckled
choker
,
"
said
the
waiter
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
I
said
bashfully
,
"
I
have
n't
the
pleasure
---
"
   
"
He
came
in
here
,
"
said
the
waiter
,
looking
at
the
light
through
the
tumbler
,
"
ordered
a
glass
of
this
ale
---
<EOS>
WOULD
order
it
---
I
told
him
not
---
drank
it
,
and
fell
dead
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
too
old
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
ought
n't
to
be
drawn
;
that
's
the
fact
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
very
much
shocked
to
hear
of
this
melancholy
accident
,
and
said
I
thought
I
had
better
have
some
water
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
you
see
,
"
said
the
waiter
,
still
looking
at
the
light
through
the
tumbler
,
with
one
of
his
eyes
shut
up
,
"
our
people
do
n't
like
things
being
ordered
and
left
.
 
<EOS>
It
offends
'em
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
'll
drink
it
,
if
you
like
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
used
to
it
,
and
use
is
everything
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
it
'll
hurt
me
,
if
I
throw
my
head
back
,
and
take
it
off
quick
.
<EOS>
Shall
I
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
replied
that
he
would
much
oblige
me
by
drinking
it
,
if
he
thought
he
could
do
it
safely
,
but
by
no
means
otherwise
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
did
throw
his
head
back
,
and
take
it
off
quick
,
I
had
a
horrible
fear
,
I
confess
,
of
seeing
him
meet
the
fate
of
the
lamented
Mr
Topsawyer
,
and
fall
lifeless
on
the
carpet
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
did
n't
hurt
him
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
I
thought
he
seemed
the
fresher
for
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
have
we
got
here
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
putting
a
fork
into
my
dish
.
"
<EOS>
Not
chops
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Chops
,
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
bless
my
soul
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
,
"
I
did
n't
know
they
were
chops
.
<EOS>
Why
,
a
chop
's
the
very
thing
to
take
off
the
bad
effects
of
that
beer
!
 
<EOS>
Ai
n't
it
lucky
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
So
he
took
a
chop
by
the
bone
in
one
hand
,
and
a
potato
in
the
other
,
and
ate
away
with
a
very
good
appetite
,
to
my
extreme
satisfaction
.
 
<EOS>
He
afterwards
took
another
chop
,
and
another
potato
;
and
after
that
,
another
chop
and
another
potato
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
had
done
,
he
brought
me
a
pudding
,
and
having
set
it
before
me
,
seemed
to
ruminate
,
and
to
become
absent
in
his
mind
for
some
moments
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
's
the
pie
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
rousing
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
pudding
,
"
I
made
answer
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pudding
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
bless
me
,
so
it
is
!
 
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
"
looking
at
it
nearer
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
mean
to
say
it
's
a
batter
-
pudding
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
is
indeed
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
a
batter
-
pudding
,
"
he
said
,
taking
up
a
table
-
spoon
,
"
is
my
favourite
pudding
!
 
<EOS>
Ai
n't
that
lucky
?
 
<EOS>
Come
on
,
little
'
un
,
and
let
's
see
who
'll
get
most
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
waiter
certainly
got
most
.
 
<EOS>
He
entreated
me
more
than
once
to
come
in
and
win
,
but
what
with
his
table
-
spoon
to
my

,
his
dispatch
to
my
dispatch
,
and
his

to
my

,
I
was
left
far
behind
at
the
first

,
and
had
no
chance
with
him
.
<EOS>
I
never
saw
anyone
enjoy
a
pudding
so
much
,
I
think
;
and
he
laughed
,
when
it
was
all
gone
,
as
if
his
enjoyment
of
it
lasted
still
.
   
<EOS>
Finding
him
so
very
friendly
and
companionable
,
it
was
then
that
I
asked
for
the
pen
and
ink
and
paper
,
to
write
to
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
He
not
only
brought
it
immediately
,
but
was
good
enough
to
look
over
me
while
I
wrote
the
letter
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
had
finished
it
,
he
asked
me
where
I
was
going
to
school
.
   
<EOS>
I
said
,
"
Near
London
,
"
which
was
all
I
knew
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
my
eye
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
looking
very
low
-
spirited
,
"
I
am
sorry
for
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Lord
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
shaking
his
head
,
"
that
's
the
school
where
they
broke
the
boy
's
ribs
---
two
ribs
---
a
little
boy
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
say
he
was
---
let
me
see
<EOS>
---
how
old
are
you
,
about
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
told
him
between
eight
and
nine
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
just
his
age
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
was
eight
years
and
six
months
old
when
they
broke
his
first
rib
;
eight
years
and
eight
months
old
when
they
broke
his
second
,
and
did
for
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
not
disguise
from
myself
,
or
from
the
waiter
,
that
this
was
an
uncomfortable
coincidence
,
and
inquired
how
it
was
done
.
 
<EOS>
His
answer
was
not
cheering
to
my
spirits
,
for
it
consisted
of
two
dismal
words
,
"
With
whopping
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
blowing
of
the
coach
-
horn
in
the
yard
was
a
seasonable
diversion
,
which
made
me
get
up
and
hesitatingly
inquire
,
in
the
mingled
pride
and
diffidence
of
having
a
purse
(
which
I
took
out
of
my
pocket
)
,
if
there
were
anything
to
pay
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
sheet
of
letter
-
paper
,
"
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
Did
you
ever
buy
a
sheet
of
letter
-
paper
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
not
remember
that
I
ever
had
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
dear
,
"
he
said
,
"
on
account
of
the
duty
.
 
<EOS>
Threepence
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
way
we
're
taxed
in
this
country
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
nothing
else
,
except
the
waiter
.
 
<EOS>
Never
mind
the
ink
.
 
<EOS>
I
lose
by
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
should
you
---
what
should
I
---
how
much
ought
I
to
---
what
would
it
be
right
to
pay
the
waiter
,
if
you
please
?
<EOS>
"
I
stammered
,
blushing
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
n't
a
family
,
and
that
family
had
n't
the
cowpock
,
"
said
the
waiter
,
"
I
would
n't
take
a
sixpence
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
did
n't
support
a
aged
pairint
,
and
a
lovely
sister
,
"
---
here
the
waiter
was
greatly
agitated
---
"
I
would
n't
take
a
farthing
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
a
good
place
,
and
was
treated
well
here
,
I
should
beg
acceptance
of
a
trifle
,
instead
of
taking
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
live
on
broken
wittles
---
<EOS>
and
I
sleep
on
the
coals
"
---
<EOS>
here
the
waiter
burst
into
tears
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
very
much
concerned
for
his
misfortunes
,
and
felt
that
any
recognition
short
of
ninepence
would
be
mere
brutality
and
hardness
of
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
I
gave
him
one
of
my
three
bright
shillings
,
which
he
received
with
much
humility
and
veneration
,
and
spun
up
with
his
thumb
,
directly
afterwards
,
to
try
the
goodness
of
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
little
disconcerting
to
me
,
to
find
,
when
I
was
being
helped
up
behind
the
coach
,
that
I
was
supposed
to
have
eaten
all
the
dinner
without
any
assistance
.
 
<EOS>
I
discovered
this
,
from
overhearing
the
lady
in
the
bow
-
window
<EOS>
say
to
the
guard
,
"
Take
care
of
that
child
,
George
,
or
he
'll
burst
!
"
<EOS>
and
from
observing
that
the
women
-
servants
who
were
about
the
place
came
out
to
look
and
giggle
at
me
as
a
young
phenomenon
.
 
<EOS>
My
unfortunate
friend
the
waiter
,
who
had
quite
recovered
his
spirits
,
did
not
appear
to
be
disturbed
by
this
,
but
joined
in
the
general
admiration
without
being
at
all
confused
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
any
doubt
of
him
,
I
suppose
this
half
awakened
it
;
but
I
am
inclined
to
believe
that
with
the
simple
confidence
of
a
child
,
and
the
natural
reliance
of
a
child
upon
superior
years
(
qualities
I
am
very
sorry
any
children
should
prematurely
change
for
worldly
wisdom
)
,
I
had
no
serious
mistrust
of
him
on
the
whole
,
even
then
.
   
<EOS>
I
felt
it
rather
hard
,
I
must
own
,
to
be
made
,
without
deserving
it
,
the
subject
of
jokes
between
the
coachman
and
guard
as
to
the
coach
drawing
heavy
behind
,
on
account
of
my
sitting
there
,
and
as
to
the
greater
expediency
of
my
travelling
by
waggon
.
 
<EOS>
The
story
of
my
supposed
appetite
getting
wind
among
the
outside
passengers
<EOS>
,
they
were
merry
upon
it
likewise
;
and
asked
me
whether
I
was
going
to
be
paid
for
,
at
school
,
as
two
brothers
or
three
,
and
whether
I
was
contracted
for
,
or
went
upon
the
regular
terms
;
with
other
pleasant
questions
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
worst
of
it
was
,
that
I
knew
I
should
be
ashamed
to
eat
anything
,
when
an
opportunity
offered
,
and
that
,
after
a
rather
light
dinner
,
I
should
remain
hungry
all
night
---
for
I
had
left
my
cakes
behind
,
at
the
hotel
,
in
my
hurry
.
 
<EOS>
My
apprehensions
were
realized
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
stopped
for
supper
I
could
n't
muster
courage
to
take
any
,
though
I
should
have
liked
it
very
much
,
but
sat
by
the
fire
and
said
I
did
n't
want
anything
.
 
<EOS>
This
did
not
save
me
from
more
jokes
,
either
;
for
a
husky
-
voiced
gentleman
with
a
rough
face
,
who
had
been
eating
out
of
a
sandwich
-
box
nearly
all
the
way
,
except
when
he
had
been
drinking
out
of
a
bottle
,
said
I
was
like
a
boa
-
constrictor
who
took
enough
at
one
meal
to
last
him
a
long
time
;
after
which
,
he
actually
brought
a
rash
out
upon
himself
with
boiled
beef
.
   
<EOS>
We
had
started
from
Yarmouth
at
three
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
,
and
we
were
due
in
London
about
eight
next
morning
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
Mid
-
summer
weather
,
and
the
evening
was
very
pleasant
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
passed
through
a
village
,
I
pictured
to
myself
what
the
insides
of
the
houses
were
like
,
and
what
the
inhabitants
were
about
;
and
when
boys
came
running
after
us
,
and
got
up
behind
and
swung
there
for
a
little
way
,
I
wondered
whether
their
fathers
were
alive
,
and
whether
they
Were
happy
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
plenty
to
think
of
,
therefore
,
besides
my
mind
running
continually
on
the
kind
of
place
I
was
going
to
---
which
was
an
awful
speculation
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
I
remember
,
I
resigned
myself
to
thoughts
of
home
and
Peggotty
;
and
to
endeavouring
,
in
a
confused
blind
way
,
to
recall
how
I
had
felt
,
and
what
sort
of
boy
I
used
to
be
,
<EOS>
before
I
bit
Mr
Murdstone
:
which
I
could
n't
satisfy
myself
about
by
any
means
,
I
seemed
to
have
bitten
him
in
such
a
remote
antiquity
.
   
<EOS>
The
night
was
not
so
pleasant
as
the
evening
,
for
it
got
chilly
;
and
being
put
between
two
gentlemen
(
the
rough
-
faced
one
and
another
)
to
prevent
my
tumbling
off
the
coach
,
I
was
nearly
smothered
by
their
falling
asleep
,
and
completely
blocking
me
up
.
<EOS>
They
squeezed
me
so
hard
sometimes
,
that
I
could
not
help
crying
out
,
"
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
If
you
please
!
"
---
which
they
did
n't
like
at
all
,
because
it
woke
them
.
 
<EOS>
Opposite
<EOS>
me
was
an
elderly
lady
in
a
great
fur
cloak
,
who
looked
in
the
dark
more
like
a
haystack
than
a
lady
<EOS>
,
she
was
wrapped
up
to
such
a
degree
.
 
<EOS>
This
lady
had
a
basket
with
her
,
and
she
had
n't
known
what
to
do
with
it
,
for
a
long
time
,
until
she
found
that
on
account
of
my
legs
being
short
,
it
could
go
underneath
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
cramped
and
hurt
me
so
,
that
it
made
me
perfectly
miserable
;
but
if
I
moved
in
the
least
,
and
made
a
glass
that
was
in
the
basket
rattle
against
something
else
(
as
it
was
sure
to
do
)
,
she
gave
me
the
cruellest
poke
with
her
foot
,
and
said
,
"
Come
,
do
n't
YOU
fidget
.
 
<EOS>
YOUR
bones
are
young
enough
,
I
'm
sure
!
"
   
<EOS>
At
last
the
sun
rose
,
and
then
my
companions
seemed
to
sleep
easier
.
 
<EOS>
The
difficulties
under
which
they
had
laboured
all
night
,
and
which
had
found
utterance
in
the
most
terrific
gasps
and
snorts
,
are
not
to
be
conceived
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
sun
got
higher
,
their
sleep
became
lighter
,
and
so
they
gradually
one
by
one
awoke
.
 
<EOS>
I
recollect
being
very
much
surprised
by
the
feint
everybody
made
,
then
,
of
not
having
been
to
sleep
at
all
,
and
by
the
uncommon

with
which
everyone
repelled

.
 
<EOS>
I
labour
under
the
same
kind
of
astonishment
to
this
day
,
having
invariably
observed
that
of
all
human
weaknesses
,
<EOS>
the
one
to
which
our
common
nature
is
the
least
disposed
to
confess
<EOS>
(
I
can
not
imagine
why
)
is
the
weakness
of
having
gone
to
sleep
in
a
coach
.
   
<EOS>
What
an
amazing
place
London
was
to
me
when
I
saw
it
in
the

,
and
how
I
believed
all
the
adventures
of
all

to
be
constantly
enacting
and
re

there
,
and
how
I
vaguely

out
in
my
own

to
be

of

and

than
all
the
cities
of
the
earth
,
I
need
not

here
to

.
 
<EOS>
We
approached
it
by
degrees
,
and
got
,
in
due

,
to
the
inn
in
the
Whitechapel
district
,
for
which
we
were
bound
.
 
<EOS>
I
forget
whether
it
was
the
Blue
Bull
,
or
the
Blue
Boar
;
but
I
know
it
was
the
Blue
Something
,
and
that
its
likeness
was
painted
up
on
the
back
of
the

.
   
<EOS>
The
guard
's
eye
lighted
on
me
as
he
was
getting
down
,
and
he
said
at
the
booking
-
office

:
   
<EOS>
"
Is
there

here
for
a
yoongster

in
the
name

Murdstone
,
from
Bloonderstone
,
Sooffolk
,
to
be
left
till
called
for
?
"
   
<EOS>
Nobody

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Try
Copperfield
,
if
you
please
,
sir
,
"
said
I
,
looking
helplessly
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
there
anybody
here
for
a
yoongster
,
booked
in
the
name
of
Murdstone
,
from
Bloonderstone
,
Sooffolk
,
but
owning
to
the
name
of
Copperfield
,
to
be
left
till
called
for
?
"
said
the
guard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
!
<EOS>
IS
there
anybody
?
"
   
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
nobody
.
 
<EOS>
I
looked
anxiously
around
;
but
the
inquiry
made
no
impression
on
any
of
the
bystanders
,
if
I
except
a
man
in

,
with
one
eye
,
who
suggested
that
they
had
better
put
a
brass

round

,
and
tie
me
up
in
the
stable
.
   
<EOS>
A
ladder
was
brought
,
and
I
got
down
after
the
lady
,
who
was
like
a
haystack
:
not
daring
to
stir
,
until
her
basket
was
removed
.
 
<EOS>
The
coach
was
clear
of
passengers
by
that
time
,
the
luggage
was
very
soon
cleared
out
,
the
horses
had
been
taken
out
before
the
luggage
,
and
now
the
coach
itself
was
wheeled
and
backed
off
by
some

,
out
of

way
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
nobody
appeared
,
to
claim
the
dusty
youngster
from
Blunderstone
,
Suffolk
.
   
<EOS>
More
solitary
than
Robinson
Crusoe
,
who
had
nobody
to
look
at
him
and
see
that
he
was
solitary
<EOS>
,
I
went
into
the
booking
-
office
,
and
,
by
invitation
of
the
clerk
on
duty
,
passed
behind
the
counter
,
and
sat
down
on
the
scale
at
which
they
weighed
the
luggage
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
as
I
sat
looking
at
the
parcels
,
packages
,
and
books
,
and
inhaling
the
smell
of
stables
(
ever
since
associated
with
that
morning
)
,
a
procession
of
most

began
to
march
through

.
 
<EOS>
Supposing
nobody
should
ever
fetch
me
,
how
long
would
they
consent
to
keep
me
there
?
 
<EOS>
Would
they
keep
me
long
enough
to
spend
seven
shillings
?
 
<EOS>
Should
I
sleep
at

in
one
of
those

bins
,
with
the
other

,
and
wash

at
the

in
the
yard
in
the
morning
;
or
should
I
be
turned
out
every
night
,
and
expected
to
come
again
to
be
left
till
called
for
,
when
the
office
opened
next
day
?
 
<EOS>
Supposing
there
was
no
mistake
in
the
case
,
and
Mr
Murdstone
had
devised
this
plan
to
get
rid

,
what

I
do
?
 
<EOS>
If
they
allowed
me
to
remain
there
until
my
seven
shillings
were
spent
,
I
could
n't
hope
to
remain
there
when
I
began

.
<EOS>
That
would
obviously
be
inconvenient
and

to
the

,
besides
entailing
on
the
Blue
Whatever
-
it
-

,
the
risk

.
 
<EOS>
If
I
started
off
at
once
,
and
tried
to
walk
back

,
how
could
I
ever
find
my

,
how
could
I
ever
hope
to
walk
so
far
<EOS>
,
how
could
I
make

of
anyone

Peggotty
,

?
 
<EOS>
If
I
found

the
nearest

,

for
a

,

,
I
was
such

little
fellow
that
it
was
most
likely

would

me

.
<EOS>
These

,
and
a
hundred

,
turned

,
and
made

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
in
the

my

when
a

and
whispered
to
the
clerk
,
who
presently
slanted

off

,
and
pushed

over
to
him
,
as
if
I
were
weighed
,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
As

,

,

stole

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a

,
with

,

Murdstone
's
;
but

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

in

black

which

,
and
rather

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're

new

?
"
<EOS>
he

.
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

so

to

a

my
box
,
to
a

and

master

Salem
House
,
that

yard

.
 
<EOS>
We

,
on

;
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
If

,

,
"
I

,
when

"

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
far
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
I
diffidently

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
good
step
,
"
he

.
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall

by
the
stage
-

.
<EOS>
It
's
about
six

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

,
that

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
appeared

at
this
<EOS>
---
I
see

and
look

now
---
and
after

,
said
he
wanted
to

old
person
who
lived
not

,
and
that
the

be
for

,
or
whatever
I
liked
best
<EOS>
that
was
wholesome
,
and
make

at
her
house
,
where
we
could

some

.
   
<EOS>
Accordingly

looked
in
at
a

's

,
and
after

had

that
was

,

one

<EOS>
,
we
decided
in

a
nice

,

.
 
<EOS>
Then
,

a

's

,

;

,

,
and

London

.
 
<EOS>
These

laid

,

on
through
a
great

that
confused

weary

beyond

,
and
over
a

which
,
no

,
was
London
Bridge
(
indeed
I
think
he

so
,
<EOS>
but
I
was
half
asleep
)
,
until

came
to
the
poor

's

,
which
was
a

,
as
I
knew

,
and

gate
which
said

were
established
for
twenty
-
five

.
   
<EOS>
The
Master
at
Salem
House
lifted
the
latch
of
one
of
a
number
of
little
black
doors
that
were
all

,
and

,
and

window

;
and

went
into
the
little
house
of
one
of
these
poor

women
,
who
was
blowing
a
fire
to
make
a
little
saucepan
boil
.
 
<EOS>
On
seeing
the
master
enter
,
the
old
woman
stopped
with
the
bellows
on
her
knee
,
and
said
something
that
I
thought
sounded
like
"
My
Charley
!
"
<EOS>
but
on
seeing
me
come
in
too
,
she
got
up
,
and
rubbing
her
hands
made
a
confused
sort
of
half
curtsey
.
   
<EOS>
"
Can
you
cook
this
young
gentleman
's
breakfast
for
him
,
if
you
please
?
"
said
the
Master
at
Salem
House
.
   
<EOS>
"
Can
I
?
"
said
the
old
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
can
I
,
sure
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
's
Mrs
Fibbitson
today
?
"
said
the
Master
,
looking
at
another
old
woman
in
a
large
chair
by
the
fire
,
who
was
such
a
bundle
of
clothes
that
I
feel
grateful
to
this
hour
for
not
having
sat
upon
her
by
mistake
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
she
's
poorly
,
"
said
the
first
old
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
one
of
her
bad
days
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
fire
was
to
go
out
,
through
any
accident
,
I
verily
believe
she
'd
go
out
too
,
and
never
come
to
life
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
they
looked
at
her
,
I
looked
at
her
also
.
 
<EOS>
Although
it
was
a
warm
day
,
she
seemed
to
think
of
nothing
but
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
I
fancied
she
was
jealous
even
of
the
saucepan
on
it
;
and
I
have
reason
to
know
that
she
took
its
impressment
into
the
service
of
boiling
my
egg
and
broiling
my
bacon
,
in
dudgeon
;
for
I
saw
her
,
with
my
own

,
shake
her
fist
at
me
once
,
when
those
culinary
operations
were
going
on
,
and
no
one
else
was
looking
.
 
<EOS>
The
sun
streamed
in
at
the
little
window
,
but
she
sat
with
her
own
back
<EOS>
and
the
back
of
the
large
chair
towards
it
,
screening
the
fire
as
if
she
were
sedulously
keeping
IT
warm
,
instead
of
<EOS>
it
keeping
her
warm
,
and
watching
it
in
a
most
distrustful
manner
.
 
<EOS>
The
completion
of
the
preparations
for
my
breakfast
,
by
relieving
the
fire
,
gave
her
such
extreme
joy
that
she
laughed
aloud
---
and
a
very
unmelodious
laugh
she
had
,
I
must
say
.
   
<EOS>
I
sat
down
to
my
brown
loaf
,
my
egg
,
and
my
rasher
of
bacon
,
with
a
basin
of
milk
besides
,
and
made
a
most
delicious
meal
.
 
<EOS>
While
I
was
yet
in
the
full
enjoyment
of
it
,
the
old
woman
of
the
house
said
to
the
Master
:
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
got
your
flute
with
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
he
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
a
blow
at
it
,
"
said
the
old
woman
,
coaxingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
Master
,
upon
this
,
put
his
hand
underneath
the
skirts
of
his
coat
,
and
brought
out
his
flute
in
three
pieces
,
which
he
screwed
together
,
and
began
immediately
to
play
.
 
<EOS>
My
impression
is
,
after
many
years
of
consideration
,
that
there
never
can
have
been
anybody
in
the
world
who
played
worse
.
 
<EOS>
He
made
the
most
dismal
sounds
I
have
ever
heard
produced
by
any
means
,
natural
or
artificial
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
the
tunes
were
---
if
there
were
such
things
in
the
performance
at
all
,
which
I
doubt
---
<EOS>
but
the
influence
of
the
strain
upon
me
was
,
first
,
to
make
me
think
of
all
my
sorrows
until
I
could
hardly
keep
my
tears
back
;
then
to
take
away
my
appetite
;
and
lastly
,
to
make
me
so
sleepy
that
I
could
n't
keep
my
eyes
open
.
<EOS>
They
begin
to
close
again
,
and
I
begin
to
nod
,
as
the
recollection
rises
fresh
upon
me
.
 
<EOS>
Once
more
the
little
room
,
with
its
open
corner
cupboard
,
and
its
square
-
backed
chairs
,
and
its
angular
little
staircase
leading
to
the
room
above
,
and
<EOS>
its
three
peacock
's
feathers
displayed
over
the
mantelpiece
---
I
remember
wondering
when
I
first
went
in
,
what
that
peacock
would
have
thought
if
he
had
known
what
his
finery
was
doomed
to
come
to
---
<EOS>
fades
from
before
me
,
and
I
nod
,
and
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
The
flute
becomes
inaudible
,
the
wheels
of
the
coach
are
heard
instead
,
and
I
am
on
my
journey
.
 
<EOS>
The
coach
jolts
,
I
wake
with
a
start
,
and
the
flute
has
come
back
again
,
and
the
Master
at
Salem
House
is
sitting
with
his
legs

,
playing
it
dolefully
,
while
the
old
woman
of
the
house

on

.
<EOS>
She
fades
in
her
turn
,
and
he
fades
,
and
all

,
and
there
is
no
flute
,
no
Master
,
no
Salem
House
,
no
David
Copperfield
,
no
anything

heavy

.
   
<EOS>
I
dreamed
,
I
thought
,
that
once
while
he
was
blowing
into
this
dismal
flute
,
the
old
woman
of
the
house
,
who
had
gone
nearer
and
nearer
to
him
in
her

,
leaned
over
the
back

his
chair
and
gave
him
an
affectionate

round
the
neck
,
which
stopped
his
playing
for
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
in
the
middle
state
between
sleeping
and
waking
,
either
then
or
immediately
afterwards
;
for
,
as
he
resumed
---
it
was
a
real

that
he
had
stopped
playing
---
I
saw
and
heard
the
same
old
woman
ask
Mrs
Fibbitson
if
it
was

delicious
(
meaning
the
flute
)
,
to

Mrs
Fibbitson
replied
,
"
Ay
,
ay
!
yes
!
"
and
nodded
at
the
fire
:
to
which
,
I
am
persuaded
,
she
gave
the
credit
of
the
whole
performance
.
   
<EOS>
When
I
seemed
to
have
been
dozing
a
long
while
,
the
Master
at
Salem
House
unscrewed
his
flute
into
the
three
pieces
,
put
them
up
as
before
,
and
took
me
away
.
 
<EOS>
We
found
the
coach
very
near
at
hand
,
and
got
upon
the
roof
;
but
I
was
so
dead
sleepy
,
that
when
we
stopped
on
the
road
to
take
up
somebody
else
,
they
put
me
inside
where
there
were
no
passengers
,
and
where
I
slept
profoundly
,
until
I
found
the
coach
going
at
a
footpace
up
a
steep
hill
among
green

.
 
<EOS>
Presently
,
it
stopped
,
and
had
come
to
its
destination
.
   
<EOS>
A
short
walk
brought
us
---
<EOS>
I
mean
the
Master
and
me
---
to
Salem
House
,
which
was
enclosed
with
a
high
brick
wall
,
and
looked
very

.
 
<EOS>
Over
a
door
in
this
wall
was
a
board
with
SALEM
HousE
upon
it
;
and
through
a
grating
in
this
door
we
were
surveyed
when
we
rang
the
bell
by
a
surly
face
,
which
I
found
,
on
the
door

,
belonged

a
stout
man
with
a
bull

,
a

,
overhanging

,
and
his
hair
cut
close
all
round

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
new
boy
,
"
said
the
Master
.
   
<EOS>
The
man
with
the
wooden
leg
eyed
me
all
over
---
it
did
n't
take
long
,
for
there
was
not
much
of
me
---
and
locked
the
gate
behind
us
,
and
took
out

key
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
going
up
to
the
house
,
among
some
dark
heavy
trees
,
when
he
called
after
my
conductor
.
<EOS>
"
Hallo
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
looked
back
,
and
he
was
standing
at
the
door
of
a
little
lodge
,
where
he
lived
,
with
a
pair
of
boots
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
!
 
<EOS>
The
cobbler
's
been
,
"
he

,
"
since
you
've
been
out
,
Mr
Mell
,
and
he
says
he
ca
n't
mend
'em
any
more
.
 
<EOS>
He
says
there
ai
n't
a
bit
of
the
original
boot
left
,
and
he
wonders
you
expect
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
he
threw
the
boots
towards
Mr
Mell
,
who
went
back
a
few
paces
to
pick
them
up
,
and
looked
at
them
(
very
disconsolately
<EOS>
,
I
was
afraid
)
,
as
we
went
on
together
.
 
<EOS>
I
observed
then
,
for
the
first
time
,
that
the
boots
he
had
on
were
a
good
deal
the
worse
for
wear
,
and
that
his
stocking
was
just
breaking
out
in
one
place
,
like
a
bud
.
   
<EOS>
Salem
House
was
a
square
brick
building
with
wings
;
of
a
bare
and
unfurnished
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
All
about
it
was
so
very
quiet
,
that
I
said
to
Mr
Mell
<EOS>
I
supposed
the
boys
were
out
;
but
he
seemed
surprised
at
my
not
knowing
that
it
was
holiday
-
time
.
 
<EOS>
That
all
the
boys
were
at
their
several
homes
.
 
<EOS>
That
Mr
Creakle
,
the
proprietor
,
was
down
by
the
sea
-
side
with
Mrs
and
Miss
Creakle
;
and
that
I
was
sent
in
holiday
-
time
as
a
punishment
for
my
misdoing
,
all
of
which
he
explained
to
me
as
we
went
along
.
   
<EOS>
I
gazed
upon
the
schoolroom
into
which
he
took
me
,
as
the
most
forlorn
and
desolate
place
I
had
ever
seen
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
it
now
.
 
<EOS>
A
long
room
with
three
long
rows
of
desks
,
and
six
of
forms
,
and
bristling
all
round
with
pegs
for
hats
and
slates
.
 
<EOS>
Scraps
of
old
copy
-
books
and
exercises
litter
the
dirty
floor
.
 
<EOS>
Some
silkworms
'
houses
,
made
of
the
same
materials
,
are
scattered
over
the
desks
.
 
<EOS>
Two
miserable
little
white
mice
,
left
behind
by
their
owner
,
are
running
up
and
down
in
a
fusty
castle
made
of
pasteboard
and
wire
,
looking
in
all
the
corners
with
their
red
eyes
for
anything
to
eat
.
 
<EOS>
A
bird
,
in
a
cage
very
little
bigger
than
himself
,
makes
a
mournful
rattle
now
and
then
in
hopping
on
his
perch
,
two
inches
high
,
or
dropping
from
it
;
but
neither
sings
nor
chirps
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
strange
unwholesome
smell
upon
the
room
,
like
mildewed
corduroys
,
sweet
apples
wanting
air
,
and
rotten
books
.
 
<EOS>
There
could
not
well
be
more
ink
splashed
about
it
,
if
it
had
been
roofless
from
its
first
construction
,
and
the
skies
had
rained
,
snowed
,
hailed
,
and
blown
ink
through
the
varying
seasons
of
the
year
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Mell
having
left
me
while
he
took
his
irreparable
boots
upstairs
,
I
went
softly
to
the
upper
end
of
the
room
,
observing
all
this
as
I
crept
along
.
 
<EOS>
Suddenly
I
came
upon
a
pasteboard
placard
,
beautifully
written
,
which
was
lying
on
the
desk
,
and
bore
these
words
:
"
TAKE
CARE
OF
HIM
.
 
<EOS>
HE
BITES
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
got
upon
the
desk
immediately
,
apprehensive
of
at
least
a
great
dog
underneath
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
though
I
looked
all
round
with
anxious
eyes
,
I
could
see
nothing
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
still
engaged
in
peering
about
,
when
Mr
Mell
came
back
,
and
asked
me
what
I
did
up
there
?
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
,
"
says
I
,
"
if
you
please
,
I
'm
looking
for
the
dog
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dog
?
"
<EOS>
he
says
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
dog
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
n't
it
a
dog
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
n't
what
a
dog
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
to
be
taken
care
of
,
sir
;
that
bites
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Copperfield
,
"
says
he
,
gravely
,
"
that
's
not
a
dog
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
a
boy
.
 
<EOS>
My
instructions
are
,
Copperfield
,
to
put
this
placard
on
your
back
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
to
make
such
a
beginning
with
you
,
but
I
must
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
that
he
took
me
down
,
and
tied
the
placard
,
which
was
neatly
constructed
for
the
purpose
,
on
my
shoulders
like
a
knapsack
;
and
wherever
I
went
,
afterwards
,
I
had
the
consolation
of
carrying
it
.
   
<EOS>
What
I
suffered
from
that
placard
,
nobody
can
imagine
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
it
was
possible
for
people
to
see
me
or
not
,
I
always
fancied
that
somebody
was
reading
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
no
relief
to
turn
round
and
find
nobody
;
for
wherever
my
back
was
,
there
I
imagined
somebody
always
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
That
cruel
man
with
the
wooden
leg
aggravated
my
sufferings
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
in
authority
;
and
if
he
ever
saw
me
leaning
against
a
tree
,
or
a
wall
,
or
the
house
,
he
roared
out
from
his
lodge
door
in
a
stupendous
voice
,
"
Hallo
,
you
sir
!
 
<EOS>
You
Copperfield
!
 
<EOS>
Show
that
badge
conspicuous
,
or
I
'll
report
you
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
playground
was
a
bare
gravelled
yard
,
open
to
all
the
back
of
the
house
and
the
offices
;
and
I
knew
that
the
servants
read
it
,
and
the
butcher
read
it
,
and
the
baker
read
it
;
that
everybody
,
in
a
word
,
who
came
backwards
and
forwards
to
the
house
,
of
a
morning
when
I
was
ordered
to
walk
there
,
read
that
I
was
to
be
taken
care
of
,
<EOS>
for
I
bit
,
I
recollect
that
I
positively
began
to
have
a
dread
of
myself
,
as
a
kind
of
wild
boy
who
did
bite
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
an
old
door
in
this
playground
,
on
which
the
boys
had
a
custom
of
carving
their
names
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
completely
covered
with
such
inscriptions
.
 
<EOS>
In
my
dread
of
the
end
of
the
vacation
and
their
coming
back
,
I
could
not
read
a
boy
's
name
,
without
inquiring
in
what
tone
and
with
what
emphasis
HE
would
read
,
"
Take
care
of
him
.
<EOS>
He
bites
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
There
was
one
boy
---
a
certain
J
Steerforth
---
who
cut
his
name
very
deep
and
very
often
,
who
,
I
conceived
,
would
read
it
in
a
rather
strong
voice
,
and
afterwards
pull
my
hair
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
another
boy
,
one
Tommy
Traddles
,
who
I
dreaded
would
make
game
of
it
,
and
pretend
to
be
dreadfully
frightened
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
third
,
George
Demple
,
who
I
fancied
would
sing
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
looked
,
a
little
shrinking
creature
,
at
that
door
,
until
the
owners
of
all
the
names
---
there
were
five
-
and
-
forty
of
them
in
the
school
then
,
Mr
Mell
said
---
seemed
to
send
me
to
Coventry
by
general
acclamation
,
and
to
cry
out
,
each
in
his
own
way
,
"
Take
care
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
bites
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
the
same
with
the
places
at
the
desks
and
forms
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
same
with
the
groves
of
deserted
bedsteads
I
peeped
at
,
on
my
way
to
,
and
when
I
was
in
,
my
own
bed
.
 
<EOS>
I
remember
dreaming
night
after
night
,
of
being
with
my
mother
as
she
used
to
be
,
or
of
going
to
a
party
at
Mr
Peggotty
's
,
or
of
travelling
outside
the
stage
-
coach
,
or
of
dining
again
with
my
unfortunate
friend
the
waiter
,
and
in
all
these
circumstances
making
people
scream
and
stare
,
by
the
unhappy
disclosure
that
I
had
nothing
on
<EOS>
but
my
little
night
-
shirt
,
and
that
placard
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
monotony
of
my
life
,
and
in
my
constant
apprehension
of
the
re
-
opening
of
the
school
,
it
was
such
an
insupportable
affliction
!
<EOS>
I
had
long
tasks
every
day
to
do
with
Mr
Mell
;
but
I
did
them
,
there
being
no
Mr
and
Miss
Murdstone
here
,
and
got
through
them
without
disgrace
.
 
<EOS>
Before
,
and
after
them
,
I
walked
about
---
supervised
,
as
I
have
mentioned
,
by
the
man
with
the
wooden
leg
.
<EOS>
How
vividly
I
call
to
mind
the
damp
about
the
house
,
the
green
cracked
flagstones
in
the
court
,
an
old
leaky
water
-
butt
,
and
the
discoloured
trunks
of
some
of
the
grim
trees
,
which
seemed
to
have
dripped
more
in
the
rain
than
other
trees
,
and
to
have
blown
less
in
the
sun
!
 
<EOS>
At
one
we
dined
,
Mr
Mell
and
I
,
at
the
upper
end
of
a
long
bare
dining
-
room
,
full
of
deal
tables
,
and
smelling
of
fat
.
<EOS>
Then
,
we
had
more
tasks
until
tea
,
which
Mr
Mell
drank
out
of
a
blue
teacup
,
and
I
out
of
a
tin
pot
.
 
<EOS>
All
day
long
,
and
until
seven
or
eight
in
the
evening
,
Mr
Mell
,
at
his
own
detached
desk
in
the
schoolroom
,
worked
hard
with
pen
,
ink
,
ruler
,
books
,
and
writing
-
paper
,
making
out
the
bills
(
as
I
found
)
for
last
half
-
year
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
put
up
his
things
for
the
night
he
took
out
his
flute
,
and
blew
at
it
,
until
I
almost
thought
he
would
gradually
blow
his
whole
being
into
the
large
hole
at
the
top
,
and
ooze
away
at
the
keys
.
   
<EOS>
I
picture
my
small
self
in
the
dimly
-
lighted
rooms
,
sitting
with
my
head
upon
my
hand
,
listening
to
the
doleful
performance
of
Mr
Mell
,
and
conning
tomorrow
's
lessons
.
 
<EOS>
I
picture
myself
with
my
books
shut
up
,
still
listening
to
the
doleful
performance
of
Mr
Mell
,
and
listening
through
it
to
what
used
to
be
at
home
,
and
to
the
blowing
of
the
wind
on
Yarmouth
flats
,
and
feeling
very
sad
and
solitary
.
 
<EOS>
I
picture
myself
going
up
to
bed
,
among
the
unused
rooms
,
and
sitting
on
my
bed
-
side
crying
for
a
comfortable
word
from
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
I
picture
myself
coming
downstairs
in
the
morning
,
and
looking
through
a
long
ghastly
gash
of
a
staircase
window
at
the
school
-
bell
hanging
on
the
top
of
an
out
-
house
with
a
weathercock
above
it
;
and
dreading
the
time
when
it
shall
ring
J
Steerforth
and
the
rest
to
work
:
which
is
only
second
,
in
my
foreboding
apprehensions
,
to
the
time
when
the
man
with
the
wooden
leg
shall
unlock
the
rusty
gate
to
give
admission
to
the
awful
Mr
Creakle
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
think
I
was
a
very
dangerous
character
in
any
of
these
aspects
,
but
in
all
of
them
I
carried
the
same
warning
on
my
back
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Mell
never
said
much
to
me
,
but
he
was
never
harsh
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
we
were
company
to
each
other
,
without
talking
.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot
to
mention
that
he
would
talk
to
himself
sometimes
,
and
grin
,
and
clench
his
fist
,
and
grind
his
teeth
,
and
pull
his
hair
in
an
unaccountable
manner
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
had
these
peculiarities
:
<EOS>
and
at
first
they
frightened
me
,
though
I
soon
got
used
to
them
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
6
.
<EOS>
I
enlarge
my
circle
of
acquaintance
 
<EOS>
I
HAD
led
this
life
about
a
month
,
when
the
man
with
the
wooden
leg
began
to
stump
about
with
a
mop
and
a
bucket
of
water
,
from
which
I
inferred
that
preparations
were
making
to
receive
Mr
Creakle
and
the
boys
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
mistaken
;
for
the
mop
came
into
the
schoolroom
before
long
,
and
turned
out
Mr
Mell
and
me
,
who
lived
where
we
could
,
and
got
on
how
we
could
,
for
some
days
,
during
which
we
were
always
in
the
way
of
two
or
three
young
women
,
who
had
rarely
shown
themselves
before
,
and
were
so
continually
in
the
midst
of
dust
that
I
sneezed
almost
as
much
as
if
Salem
House
had
been
a
great
snuff
-
box
.
   
<EOS>
One
day
I
was
informed
by
Mr
Mell
that
Mr
Creakle
would
be
home
that
evening
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
evening
,
after
tea
,
I
heard
that
he
was
come
.
<EOS>
Before
bedtime
,
I
was
fetched
by
the
man
with
the
wooden
leg
to
appear
before
him
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Creakle
's
part
of
the
house
was
a
good
deal
more
comfortable
than
ours
,
and
he
had
a
snug
bit
of
garden
that
looked
pleasant
after
the
dusty
playground
,
which
was
such
a
desert
in
miniature
,
that
I
thought
no
one
but
a
camel
,
or
a
dromedary
,
could
have
felt
at
home
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
me
a
bold
thing
even
to
take
notice
that
the
passage
looked
comfortable
,
as
I
went
on
my
way
,
trembling
,
to
Mr
Creakle
's
presence
:
which
so
abashed
me
,
when
I
was
ushered
into
it
,
that
I
hardly
saw
Mrs
Creakle
or
Miss
Creakle
(
who
were
both
there
,
in
the
parlour
)
,
or
anything
but
Mr
Creakle
,
a
stout
gentleman
with
a

of
watch
-
chain
and
seals
,
in
an
arm
-
chair
,
with
a
tumbler
and

beside

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
!
"
said
Mr
Creakle
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
young
gentleman
whose
teeth
are
to
be
filed
!
 
<EOS>
Turn
him
round
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
wooden
-
legged
man
turned
me
about
so
as
to
exhibit
the
placard
;
and
having
afforded
time
for
a
full
survey
of
it
,
turned
me
about
again
,
with
my
face
to
Mr
Creakle
,
and
posted
himself
at
Mr
Creakle
's
side
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Creakle
's
face
was
fiery
,
and
his
eyes
were
small
,
and
deep
in
his
head
;
he
had
thick
veins
in
his
forehead
,
a
little
nose
,
and
a
large
chin
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
bald
on
the
top
of
his
head
;
and
had
some
thin
wet
-
looking
hair
that
was
just
turning
grey
,
brushed
across
each
temple
,
so
that
the
two
sides
interlaced
on
his
forehead
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
circumstance
about
him
which
impressed
me
most
,
was
,
that
he
had
no
voice
,
but
spoke
in
a
whisper
.
 
<EOS>
The
exertion
this
cost
him
,
or
the
consciousness
of
talking
in
that
feeble
way
,
made
his
angry
face
so
much
more
angry
,
and
his
thick
veins
so
much
thicker
,
when
he
spoke
,
that
I
am
not
surprised
,
on
looking
back
,
at
this
peculiarity
striking
me
as
his
chief
one
.
"
<EOS>
Now
,
"
said
Mr
Creakle
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
report
of
this
boy
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
nothing
against
him
yet
,
"
returned
the
man
with
the
wooden
leg
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
has
been
no
opportunity
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
thought
Mr
Creakle
was
disappointed
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
Mrs
and
Miss
Creakle
(
at
whom
I
now
glanced
for
the
first
time
,
and
who
were
,
both
,
thin

)
were
not

.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
here
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
said
Mr
Creakle
,
beckoning
to
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
here
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
man
with
the
wooden
leg
,
repeating
the
gesture
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
the
happiness
of
knowing
your
father
-
in
-
law
,
"
whispered
Mr
Creakle
,
taking
me

;
"
and
a
worthy
man
he
is
,
and
a
man
of
a
strong
character
.
 
<EOS>
He
knows
me
,
and
I
know
him
.
 
<EOS>
Do
YOU
know
me
?
 
<EOS>
Hey
?
"
said
Mr
Creakle
,
pinching
my
ear
with
ferocious
playfulness
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
yet
,
sir
,
"
I
said
,
flinching
with

pain
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
yet
?
 
<EOS>
Hey
?
"
repeated
Mr
Creakle
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
you
will
soon
.
 
<EOS>
Hey
?
"
   
"
You
will
soon
.
 
<EOS>
Hey
?
"
repeated
the
man
with
the
wooden
leg
.
 
<EOS>
I
afterwards
found
that
he
generally
acted
,
with
his
strong
voice
,
as
Mr
Creakle
's
interpreter
to
the
boys
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
very
much

,
and
said
,
I
hoped
so
,
if
he
pleased
.
<EOS>
I
felt
,
all
this
while
,
as
if
my
ear
were
blazing
;
he
pinched
it
so
hard
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
what
I
am
,
"
whispered
Mr
Creakle
,
letting
it
go
at
last
,
with

at
parting
that
brought
the
water
into

eyes
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
a
Tartar
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
Tartar
,
"
said
the
man
with
the
wooden
leg
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
say
I
'll
do

thing
,
I
do

,
"
said
Mr
Creakle
;
"
<EOS>
and
when
I
say
I
will
have
a
thing
done
,
I
will
have
it
done
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
---
Will
have
a
thing
done
,
I
will
have
it
done
,
"
repeated
the
man
with
the

leg
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
determined
character
,
"
said
Mr
Creakle
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
what
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
my
duty
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
what
I
do
.
 
<EOS>
My
flesh
and
blood
"
---
he

Mrs

as

---
"
when

rises

,
is
not
my

.
 
<EOS>
I
discard

.
 
<EOS>
Has
that
fellow
"
---
to

---
"
been
here

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
was

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
knows
better
.
 
<EOS>
He
knows
me
.
 
<EOS>
Let
him
keep
away
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
let
him

away
,
"
said
Mr
Creakle
,

,
and

Mrs
Creakle
,
"
for
he

.
 
<EOS>
Now
you
have
begun

,
my
young

,
and
you
may

.
 
<EOS>
Take
him
away
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
very
glad
to
be
ordered
away
,
for
Mrs
and
Miss
Creakle
<EOS>
were
both
wiping
their
eyes
,
and
I
felt
as
uncomfortable
for
them
as
I
did
for
myself
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
had
a
petition
on
my
mind
which
concerned
me
so
nearly
,
that
I
could
n't
help
saying
,
though
I
wondered
at
my
own
courage
:
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
sir
---
"
   
Mr
Creakle
whispered
,
"
Hah
!
 
<EOS>
What
's
this
?
"
and
bent
his
eyes
upon
me
,
as
if
he
would
have
burnt
me
up
with
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
sir
,
"
I
faltered
,
"
if
I
might
be
allowed
(
I
am
very
sorry
indeed
,
sir
,
for
what
I
did
)
to
take
this
writing
off
,
before
the
boys
come
back
---
"
   
Whether
Mr
Creakle
was
in
earnest
,
or
whether
he
only
did
it
to
frighten
me
,
I
do
n't
know
,
but
he
made
a
burst
out
of
his
chair
,
before
which
I
precipitately
retreated
,
without
waiting
for
the
escort
Of
the
man
with
the
wooden
leg
,
and
never
once
stopped
until
I
reached
my
own
bedroom
,
where
,
finding
I
was
not
pursued
,
I
went
to
bed
,
as
it
was
time
,
and
lay
quaking
,
for
a
couple
of
hours
.
   
<EOS>
Next
morning
Mr
Sharp
came
back
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sharp
was
the
first
master
,
and
superior
to
Mr
Mell
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Mell
took
his
meals
with
the
boys
,
but
Mr
Sharp
dined
and
supped
at
Mr
Creakle
's
table
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
limp
,
delicate
-
looking
gentleman
,
I
thought
,
with
a
good
deal
of
nose
,
and
a
way
of
carrying
his
head
on
one
side
,
as
if
it
were
a
little
too
heavy
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
His
hair
was
very
smooth
and
wavy
;
but
I
was
informed
by
the
very
first
boy
who
came
back
that
it
was
a
wig
(
a
second
-
hand
one
HE
said
)
,
and
that
Mr
Sharp
went
out
every
Saturday
afternoon
to
get
it
curled
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
no
other
than
Tommy
Traddles
who
gave
me
this
piece
of
intelligence
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
the
first
boy
who
returned
.
 
<EOS>
He
introduced
himself
by
informing
me
that
I
should
find
his
name
on
the
right
-
hand
corner
of
the
gate
,
over
the
top
-
bolt
;
upon
that
I
said
,
"
Traddles
?
"
<EOS>
to
which
he
replied
,
"
The
same
,
"
and
then
he
asked
me
for
a
full
account
of
myself
and
family
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
happy
circumstance
for
me
that
Traddles
came
back
first
.
<EOS>
He
enjoyed
my
placard
so
much
,
that
he
saved
me
from
the
embarrassment
of
either
disclosure
or
concealment
,
by
presenting
me
to
every
other
boy
who
came
back
,
great
or
small
,
immediately
on
his
arrival
,
in
this
form
of
introduction
,
"
Look
here
!
 
<EOS>
Here
's
a
game
!
"
 
<EOS>
Happily
,
too
,
the
greater
part
of
the
boys
came
back
low
-
spirited
,
and
were
not
so
boisterous
at
my
expense
as
I
had
expected
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
them
certainly
did
dance
about
me
like
wild
Indians
,
and
the
greater
part
could
not
resist
the
temptation
of
pretending
that
I
was
a
dog
,
and
patting
and
soothing
me
,
lest
I
should
bite
,
and
saying
,
"
Lie
down
,
sir
!
"
and
calling
me
Towzer
.
<EOS>
This
was
naturally
confusing
,
among
so
many
strangers
,
and
cost
me
some
tears
,
but
on
the
whole
it
was
much
better
than
I
had
anticipated
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
not
considered
as
being
formally
received
into
the
school
,
however
,
until
J
Steerforth
arrived
.
 
<EOS>
Before
this
boy
,
who
was
reputed
to
be
a
great
scholar
,
and
was
very
good
-
looking
,
and
at
least
half
-
a
-
dozen
years
my
senior
,
I
was
carried
as
before
a
magistrate
.
 
<EOS>
He
inquired
,
under
a
shed
in
the
playground
,
into
the
particulars
of
my
punishment
,
and
was
pleased
to
express
his
opinion
that
it
was
"
a
jolly
shame
"
;
for
which
I
became
bound
to
him
ever
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
money
have
you
got
,
Copperfield
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
walking
aside
with
me
when
he
had
disposed
of
my
affair
in
these
terms
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
him
seven
shillings
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
give
it
to
me
to
take
care
of
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
least
,
you
can
if
you
like
.
 
<EOS>
You
need
n't
if
you
do
n't
like
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
hastened
to
comply
with
his
friendly
suggestion
,
and
opening
Peggotty
's
purse
,
turned
it
upside
down
into
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
want
to
spend
anything
now
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
thank
you
,
"
I
replied
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
can
,
if
you
like
,
you
know
,
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
Say
the
word
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
thank
you
,
sir
,
"
I
repeated
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
'd
like
to
spend
a
couple
of
shillings
or
so
,
in
a
bottle
of
currant
wine
by
and
by
,
up
in
the
bedroom
?
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
belong
to
my
bedroom
,
I
find
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
certainly
had
not
occurred
to
me
before
,
but
I
said
,
Yes
,
I
should
like
that
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll
be
glad
to
spend
another
shilling
or
so
,
in
almond
cakes
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
,
Yes
,
I
should
like
that
,
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
another
shilling
or
so
in
biscuits
,
and
another
in
fruit
,
eh
?
<EOS>
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
young
Copperfield
,
you
're
going
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
smiled
because
he
smiled
,
but
I
was
a
little
troubled
in
my
mind
,
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
must
make
it
stretch
as
far
as
we
can
;
that
's
all
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
do
the
best
in
my
power
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
go
out
when
I
like
,
and
I
'll
smuggle
the
prog
in
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
these
words
he
put
the
money
in
his
pocket
,
and
kindly
told
me
not
to
make
myself
uneasy
;
he
would
take
care
<EOS>
it
should
be
all
right
.
<EOS>
He
was
as
good
as
his
word
,
if
that
were
all
right
which
I
had
a
secret
misgiving
was
nearly
all
wrong
---
for
I
feared
it
was
a
waste
of
my
mother
's
two
half
-
crowns
---
though
I
had
preserved
the
piece
of
paper
they
were
wrapped
in
:
which
was
a
precious
saving
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
went
upstairs
to
bed
,
he
produced
the
whole
seven
shillings'worth
,
and
laid
it
out
on
my
bed
in
the
moonlight
,
saying
:
   
"
There
you
are
,
young
Copperfield
,
and
a
royal
spread
you
've
got
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
n't
think
of
doing
the
honours
of
the
feast
,
at
my
time
of
life
,
while
he
was
by
;
my
hand
shook
at
the
very
thought
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
begged
him
to
do
me
the
favour
of
presiding
;
and
my
request
being
seconded
by
the
other
boys
who
were
in
that
room
,
he
acceded
to
it
,
and
sat
upon
my
pillow
,
handing
round
the
viands
---
with
perfect
fairness
,
I
must
say
---
and
dispensing
the
currant
wine
in
a
little
glass
without
a
foot
,
which
was
his
own
property
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
me
,
I
sat
on
his
left
hand
,
and
the
rest
were
grouped
about
us
,
on
the
nearest
beds
and
on
the
floor
.
   
<EOS>
How
well
I
recollect
our
sitting
there
,
talking
in
whispers
;
or
their
talking
,
and
my
respectfully
listening
<EOS>
,
I
ought
rather
to
say
;
the
moonlight
falling
a
little
way
into
the
room
,
through
the
window
,
painting
a
pale
window
on
the
floor
,
and
the
greater
part
of
us
in
shadow
,
except
when
Steerforth
dipped
a
match
into
a
phosphorus
-
box
,
when
he
wanted
to
look
for
anything
on
the
board
,
and
shed
a
blue
glare
over
us
that
was
gone
directly
!
 
<EOS>
A
certain
mysterious
feeling
,
consequent
on
the
darkness
,
the
secrecy
of
the
revel
,
and
the
whisper
in
which
everything
was
said
,
steals
over
me
again
,
and
I
listen
to
all
they
tell
me
with
a
vague
feeling
of
solemnity
and
awe
,
which
makes
me
glad
that
they
are
all
so
near
,
and
frightens
me
(
though
I
feign
to
laugh
)
<EOS>
when
Traddles
pretends
to
see
a
ghost
in
the
corner
.
   
<EOS>
I
heard
all
kinds
of
things
about
the
school
and
all
belonging
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
that
Mr
Creakle
had
not
preferred
his
claim
to
being
a
Tartar
without
reason
;
that
he
was
the
sternest
and
most
severe
of
masters
;
that
he
laid
about
him
,
right
and
left
,
every
day
of
his
life
,
charging
in
among
the
boys
like
a
trooper
,
and
slashing
away
,
unmercifully
.
 
<EOS>
That
he
knew
nothing
himself
,
but
the
art
of
slashing
,
being
more
ignorant
(
J
Steerforth
said
)
than
the
lowest
boy
in
the
school
;
that
he
had
been
,
a
good
many
years
ago
,
a
small
hop
-
dealer
in
the
Borough
,
and
had
taken
to
the
schooling
business
after
being
bankrupt
in
hops
,
and
making
away
with
Mrs
Creakle
's
money
.
 
<EOS>
With
a
good
deal
more
of
that
sort
,
which
I
wondered
how
they
knew
.
   
<EOS>
I
heard
that
the
man
with
the
wooden
leg
,
whose
name
was
Tungay
,
was
an
obstinate
barbarian
who
had
formerly
assisted
in
the
hop
business
,
but
had
come
into
the
scholastic
line
with
Mr
Creakle
,
in
consequence
,
as
was
supposed
among
the
boys
,
of
his
having
broken
his
leg
in
Mr
Creakle
's
service
,
and
having
done
a
deal
of
dishonest
work
for
him
,
and
knowing
his
secrets
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
that
with
the
single
exception
of
Mr
Creakle
,
Tungay
considered
the
whole
establishment
,
masters
and
boys
,
as
his
natural
enemies
,
and
that
the
only
delight
of
his
life
was
to
be
sour
and
malicious
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
that
Mr
Creakle
had
a
son
,
who
had
not
been
Tungay
's
friend
,
and
who
,
assisting
in
the
school
,
had
once
held
some
remonstrance
with
his
father
on
an
occasion
when
its
discipline
was
very
cruelly
exercised
,
and
was
supposed
,
besides
,
to
have
protested
against
his
father
's
usage
of
his
mother
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
that
Mr
Creakle
had
turned
him
out
of
doors
,
in
consequence
;
and
that
Mrs
and
Miss
Creakle
had
been
in
a
sad
way
,
ever
since
.
   
<EOS>
But
the
greatest
wonder
that
I
heard
of
Mr
Creakle
was
,
there
being
one
boy
in
the
school
on
whom
he
never
ventured
to
lay
a
hand
,
and
that
boy
being
J
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
Steerforth
himself
confirmed
this
when
it
was
stated
,
and
said
that
he
should
like
to
begin
to
see
him
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
On
being
asked
by
a
mild
boy
(
not
me
)
how
he
would
proceed
if
he
did
begin
to
see
him
do
it
,
he
dipped
a
match
into
his
phosphorus
-
box
on
purpose
to
shed
a
glare
over
his
reply
,
and
said
he
would
commence
by
knocking
him
down
with
a
blow
on
the
forehead
from
the
seven
-
and
-
sixpenny
ink
-
bottle
that
was
always
on
the
mantelpiece
.
 
<EOS>
We
sat
in
the
dark
for
some
time
,
breathless
.
   
<EOS>
I
heard
that
Mr
Sharp
and
Mr
Mell
were
both
supposed
to
be
wretchedly
paid
;
and
that
when
there
was
hot
and
cold
meat
for
dinner
at
Mr
Creakle
's
table
,
Mr
Sharp
was
always
expected
to
say
he
preferred
cold
;
which
was
again
corroborated
by
J
Steerforth
,
the
only
parlour
-
boarder
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
that
Mr
Sharp
's
wig
did
n't
fit
him
;
and
that
he
need
n't
be
so
"
bounceable
"
---
somebody
else
said
"
bumptious
"
---
about
it
,
because
his
own
red
hair
was
very
plainly
to
be
seen
behind
.
   
<EOS>
I
heard
that
one
boy
,
who
was
a
coal
-
merchant
's
son
,
came
as
a
set
-
off
against
the
coal
-
bill
,
and
was
called
,
on
that
account
,
"
Exchange
or
Barter
"
---
a
name
selected
from
the
arithmetic
book
as
expressing
this
arrangement
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
that
the
table
beer
was
a
robbery
of
parents
,
and
the
pudding
an
imposition
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
that
Miss
Creakle
was
regarded
by
the
school
in
general
as
being
in
love
with
Steerforth
;
and
I
am
sure
,
as
I
sat
in
the
dark
,
thinking
of
his
nice
voice
,
and
his
fine
face
,
and
his
easy
manner
,
and
his
curling
hair
,
I
thought
it
very
likely
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
that
Mr
Mell
was
not
a
bad
sort
of
fellow
,
but
had
n't
a
sixpence
to
bless
himself
with
;
and
that
there
was
no
doubt
that
old
Mrs
Mell
,
his
mother
,
was
as
poor
as
job
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
of
my
breakfast
then
,
and
what
had
sounded
like
"
My
Charley
!
"
<EOS>
but
I
was
,
I
am
glad
to
remember
,
as
mute
as
a
mouse
about
it
.
   
<EOS>
The
hearing
of
all
this
,
and
a
good
deal
more
,
outlasted
the
banquet
some
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
greater
part
of
the
guests
had
gone
to
bed
as
soon
as
the
eating
and
drinking
were
over
;
and
we
,
who
had
remained
whispering
and
listening
half
-
undressed
,
at
last
betook
ourselves
to
bed
,
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
young
Copperfield
,
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
care
of
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
very
kind
,
"
I
gratefully
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
much
obliged
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
n't
got
a
sister
,
have
you
?
"
said
Steerforth
,
yawning
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
I
answered
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
pity
,
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
had
one
,
I
should
think
she
would
have
been
a
pretty
,
timid
,
little
,
bright
-
eyed
sort
of
girl
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
liked
to
know
her
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
,
young
Copperfield
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
sir
,
"
I
replied
.
   
<EOS>
I
thought
of
him
very
much
after
I
went
to
bed
,
and
raised
myself
,
I
recollect
,
to
look
at
him
where
he
lay
in
the
moonlight
,
with
his
handsome
face
turned
up
,
and
his
head
reclining
easily
on
his
arm
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
person
of
great
power
in
my
eyes
;
that
was
,
of
course
,
the
reason
of
my
mind
running
on
him
.
 
<EOS>
No
veiled
future
dimly
glanced
upon
him
in
the
moonbeams
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
shadowy
picture
of
his
footsteps
,
in
the
garden
that
I
dreamed
of
walking
in
all
night
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
7
.
<EOS>
My
"
First
Half
"
at
Salem
House
 
School
began
in
earnest
next
day
.
 
<EOS>
A
profound
impression
was
made
upon
me
,
I
remember
,
by
the
roar
of
voices
in
the
schoolroom
suddenly
becoming
hushed
as
death
when
Mr
Creakle
entered
after
breakfast
,
and
stood
in
the
doorway
looking
round
upon
us
like
a
giant
in
a
story
-
book
surveying
his
captives
.
   
<EOS>
Tungay
stood
at
Mr
Creakle
's
elbow
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
occasion
,
I
thought
,
to
cry
out
"
Silence
!
"
<EOS>
so
ferociously
,
for
the
boys
were
all
struck
speechless
and
motionless
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Creakle
was
seen
to
speak
,
and
Tungay
was
heard
,
to
this
effect
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
boys
,
this
is
a
new
half
.
 
<EOS>
Take
care
what
you
're
about
,
in
this
new
half
.
 
<EOS>
Come
fresh
up
to
the
lessons
,
I
advise
you
,
for
I
come
fresh
up
to
the
punishment
.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
flinch
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
be
of
no
use
your
rubbing
yourselves
;
you
wo
n't
rub
the
marks
out
that
I
shall
give
you
.
 
<EOS>
Now
get
to
work
,
every
boy
!
"
   
<EOS>
When
this
dreadful
exordium
was
over
,
and
Tungay
had
stumped
out
again
,
Mr
Creakle
came
to
where
I
sat
,
and
told
me
that
if
I
were
famous
for
biting
,
he
was
famous
for
biting
,
too
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
showed
me
the
cane
,
and
asked
me
what
I
thought
of
THAT
,
for
a
tooth
?
 
<EOS>
Was
it
a
sharp
tooth
,
<EOS>
hey
?
 
<EOS>
Was
it
a
double
tooth
,
<EOS>
hey
?
 
<EOS>
Had
it
a
deep
prong
,
<EOS>
hey
?
 
<EOS>
Did
it
bite
,
hey
?
 
<EOS>
Did
it
bite
?
 
<EOS>
At
every
question
he
gave
me
a
fleshy
cut
with
it
that
made
me
writhe
;
so
I
was
very
soon
made
free
of
Salem
House
(
as
Steerforth
said
)
,
and
was
very
soon
in
tears
also
.
   
<EOS>
Not
that
I
mean
to
say
these
were
special
marks
of
distinction
,
which
only
I
received
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
a
large
majority
of
the
boys
(
especially
the
smaller
ones
)
were
visited
with
similar
instances
of
notice
,
as
Mr
Creakle
made
the
round
of
the
schoolroom
.
 
<EOS>
Half
the
establishment
was
writhing
and
crying
,
before
the
day
's
work
began
;
and
how
much
of
it
had
writhed
and
cried
before
the
day
's
work
was
over
,
I
am
really
afraid
to
recollect
,
lest
I
should
seem
to
exaggerate
.
   
<EOS>
I
should
think
there
never
can
have
been
a
man
who
enjoyed
his
profession
more
than
Mr
Creakle
did
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
delight
in
cutting
at
the
boys
,
which
was
like
the
satisfaction
of
a
craving
appetite
.
<EOS>
I
am
confident
that
he
could
n't
resist
a
chubby
boy
,
especially
;
that
there
was
a
fascination
in
such
a
subject
,
which
made
him
restless
in
his
mind
,
until
he
had
scored
and
marked
him
for
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
chubby
myself
,
and
ought
to
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
<EOS>
when
I
think
of
the
fellow
now
,
my
blood
rises
against
him
with
the
disinterested
indignation
I
should
feel
if
I
could
have
known
all
about
him
without
having
ever
been
in
his
power
;
but
it
rises
hotly
,
because
I
know
him
to
have
been
an
incapable
brute
,
who
had
no
more
right
to
be
possessed
of
the
great
trust
he
held
,
than
to
be
Lord
High
Admiral
,
or
Commander
-
in
-
Chief
---
in
either
of
which
capacities
it
is
probable
that
he
would
have
done
infinitely
less
mischief
.
   
<EOS>
Miserable
little
propitiators
of
a
remorseless
Idol
<EOS>
,
how
abject
we
were
to
him
!
 
<EOS>
What
a
launch
in
life
<EOS>
I
think
it
now
,
on
looking
back
,
to
be
so
mean
and
servile
to
a
man
of
such
parts
and
pretensions
!
   
<EOS>
Here
I
sit
at
the
desk
again
,
watching
his
eye
---
humbly
watching
his
eye
,
as
he
rules
a
ciphering
-
book
for
another
victim
whose
hands
have
just
been
flattened
by
that
identical
ruler
,
and
who
is
trying
to
wipe
the
sting
out
with
a
pocket
-
handkerchief
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
plenty
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
watch
his
eye
in
idleness
,
but
because
I
am
morbidly
attracted
to
it
,
in
a
dread
desire
to
know
what
he
will
do
next
,
and
whether
it
will
be
my
turn
to
suffer
,
or
somebody
else
's
.
<EOS>
A
lane
of
small
boys
beyond
me
,
with
the
same
interest
in
his
eye
,
watch
it
too
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
he
knows
it
,
though
he
pretends
he
do
n't
.
<EOS>
He
makes
dreadful
mouths
as
he
rules
the
ciphering
-
book
;
and
now
he
throws
his
eye
sideways
down
our
lane
,
and
we
all
droop
over
our
books
and
tremble
.
 
<EOS>
A
moment
afterwards
we
are
again
eyeing
him
.
<EOS>
An
unhappy
culprit
,
found
guilty
of
imperfect
exercise
,
approaches
at
his
command
.
 
<EOS>
The
culprit
falters
excuses
,
and
professes
a
determination
to
do
better
tomorrow
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Creakle
cuts
a
joke
before
he
beats
him
,
and
we
laugh
at
it
,
---
<EOS>
miserable
little
dogs
,
we
laugh
,
with
our
visages
as
white
as
ashes
,
and
our
hearts
sinking
into
our
boots
.
   
<EOS>
Here
I
sit
at
the
desk
again
,
on
a
drowsy
summer
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
A
buzz
and
hum
go
up
around
me
,
as
if
the
boys
were
so
many
bluebottles
.
<EOS>
A
cloggy
sensation
of
the
lukewarm
fat
of
meat
is
upon
me
(
we
dined
an
hour
or
two
ago
)
,
and
my
head
is
as
heavy
as
so
much
lead
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
give
the
world
to
go
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
I
sit
with
my
eye
on
Mr
Creakle
,
blinking
at
him
like
a
young
owl
<EOS>
;
when
sleep
overpowers
me
for
a
minute
,
he
still
looms
through
my
slumber
,
ruling
those
ciphering
-
books
,
until
he
softly
comes
behind
me
and
wakes
me
to
plainer
perception
of
him
,
with
a
red
ridge
across
my
back
.
   
<EOS>
Here
I
am
in
the
playground
,
with
my
eye
still
fascinated
by
him
,
though
I
ca
n't
see
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
window
at
a
little
distance
from
which
I
know
he
is
having
his
dinner
,
stands
for
him
,
and
I
eye
that
instead
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
shows
his
face
near
it
,
mine
assumes
an
imploring
and
submissive
expression
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
looks
out
through
the
glass
,
the
boldest
boy
(
Steerforth
excepted
)
stops
in
the
middle
of
a
shout
or
yell
,
and
becomes
contemplative
.
 
<EOS>
One
day
,
Traddles
(
the
most
unfortunate
boy
in
the
world
)
breaks
that
window
accidentally
,
with
a
ball
.
 
<EOS>
I
shudder
at
this
moment
with
the
tremendous
sensation
of
seeing
it
done
,
and
feeling
that
the
ball
has
bounded
on
to
Mr
Creakle
's
sacred
head
.
   
<EOS>
Poor
Traddles
!
 
<EOS>
In
a
tight
sky
-
blue
suit
that
made
his
arms
and
legs
like
German
sausages
,
or
roly
-
poly
puddings
,
he
was
the
merriest
and
most
miserable
of
all
the
boys
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
always
being
caned
<EOS>
---
I
think
he
was
caned
every
day
that
half
-
year
,
except
one
holiday
Monday
when
he
was
only
ruler'd
on
both
hands
---
and
was
always
going
to
write
to
his
uncle
about
it
,
and
never
did
.
 
<EOS>
After
laying
his
head
on
the
desk
for
a
little
while
,
he
would
cheer
up
,
somehow
,
begin
to
laugh
again
,
and
draw
skeletons
all
over
his
slate
,
before
his
eyes
were
dry
.
 
<EOS>
I
used
at
first
to
wonder
what
comfort
Traddles
found
in
drawing
skeletons
;
and
for
some
time
looked
upon
him
as
a
sort
of
hermit
,
who
reminded
himself
by
those
symbols
of
mortality
that
caning
could
n't
last
for
ever
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
believe
he
only
did
it
because
they
were
easy
,
and
did
n't
want
any
features
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
very
honourable
,
Traddles
was
,
and
held
it
as
a
solemn
duty
in
the
boys
to
stand
by
one
another
.
 
<EOS>
He
suffered
for
this
on
several
occasions
;
and
particularly
once
,
when
Steerforth
laughed
in
church
,
and
the
Beadle
thought
it
was
Traddles
,
and
took
him
out
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
him
now
,
going
away
in
custody
,
despised
by
the
congregation
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
said
who
was
the
real
offender
,
though
he
smarted
for
it
next
day
,
and
was
imprisoned
so
many
hours
that
he
came
forth
with
a
whole
churchyard
-
full
of
skeletons
swarming
all
over
his
Latin
Dictionary
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
had
his
reward
.
 
<EOS>
Steerforth
said
there
was
nothing
of
the
sneak
in
Traddles
,
and
we
all
felt
that
to
be
the
highest
praise
.
 
<EOS>
For
my
part
,
I
could
have
gone
through
a
good
deal
(
though
I
was
much
less
brave
than
Traddles
,
and
nothing
like
so
old
)
to
have
won
such
a
recompense
.
   
<EOS>
To
see
Steerforth
walk
to
church
before
us
,
arm
-
in
-
arm
with
Miss
Creakle
,
was
one
of
the
great
sights
of
my
life
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
n't
think
Miss
Creakle
equal
to
little
Em'ly
in
point
of
beauty
,
and
I
did
n't
love
her
<EOS>
(
I
did
n't
dare
)
;
but
I
thought
her
a
young
lady
of
extraordinary
attractions
,
and
in
point
of
gentility
not
to
be
surpassed
.
 
<EOS>
When
Steerforth
,
in
white
trousers
,
carried
her
parasol
for
her
,
I
felt
proud
to
know
him
;
and
believed
that
she
could
not
choose
but
adore
him
with
all
her
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sharp
and
Mr
Mell
were
both
notable
personages
in
my
eyes
;
but
Steerforth
was
to
them
what
the
sun
was
to
two
stars
.
   
<EOS>
Steerforth
continued
his
protection
of
me
,
and
proved
a
very
useful
friend
;
since
nobody
dared
to
annoy
one
whom
he
honoured
with
his
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
n't
---
or
at
all
events
he
did
n't
---
defend
me
from
Mr
Creakle
,
who
was
very
severe
with
me
;
but
whenever
I
had
been
treated
worse
than
usual
,
he
always
told
me
that
I
wanted
a
little
of
his
pluck
,
and
that
he
would
n't
have
stood
it
himself
;
which
I
felt
he
intended
for
encouragement
,
and
considered
to
be
very
kind
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
one
advantage
,
and
only
one
that
I
know
of
,
in
Mr
Creakle
's
severity
.
 
<EOS>
He
found
my
placard
in
his
way
when
he
came
up
or
down
behind
the
form
on
which
I
sat
,
and
wanted
to
make
a
cut
at
me
in
passing
;
for
this
reason
it
was
soon
taken
off
,
and
I
saw
it
no
more
.
   
<EOS>
An
accidental
circumstance
cemented
the
intimacy
between
Steerforth
and
me
,
in
a
manner
that
inspired
me
with
great
pride
and
satisfaction
,
though
it
sometimes
led
to
inconvenience
.
 
<EOS>
It
happened
on
one
occasion
,
when
he
was
doing
me
the
honour
of
talking
to
me
in
the
playground
,
that
I
hazarded
the
observation
that
something
or
somebody
---
I
forget
what
now
---
was
like
something
or
somebody
in
Peregrine
Pickle
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
at
the
time
;
but
when
I
was
going
to
bed
at
night
,
asked
me
if
I
had
got
that
book
?
   
<EOS>
I
told
him
no
,
and
explained
how
it
was
that
I
had
read
it
,
and
all
those
other
books
of
which
I
have
made
mention
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
do
you
recollect
them
?
"
<EOS>
Steerforth
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
,
"
I
replied
;
I
had
a
good
memory
,
and
I
believed
I
recollected
them
very
well
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
I
tell
you
what
,
young
Copperfield
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
"
you
shall
tell
'em
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
get
to
sleep
very
early
at
night
,
and
I
generally
wake
rather
early
in
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
We
'll
go
over
'em
one
after
another
.
 
<EOS>
We
'll
make
some
regular
Arabian
Nights
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
extremely
flattered
by
this
arrangement
,
and
we
commenced
carrying
it
into
execution
that
very
evening
.
 
<EOS>
What
ravages
I
committed
on
my
favourite
authors
in
the
course
of
my
interpretation
of
them
,
I
am
not
in
a
condition
to
say
,
and
should
be
very
unwilling
to
know
;
but
I
had
a
profound
faith
in
them
,
and
I
had
,
to
the
best
of
my
belief
,
a
simple
,
earnest
manner
of
narrating
what
I
did
narrate
;
and
these
qualities
went
a
long
way
.
   
<EOS>
The
drawback
was
,
that
I
was
often
sleepy
at
night
,
or
out
of
spirits
and
indisposed
to
resume
the
story
;
and
then
it
was
rather
hard
work
,
and
it
must
be
done
;
for
to
disappoint
or
to
displease
Steerforth
was
of
course
out
of
the
question
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
morning
,
too
,
when
I
felt
weary
,
and
should
have
enjoyed
another
hour
's
repose
very
much
,
it
was
a
tiresome
thing
to
be
roused
,
like
the
Sultana
Scheherazade
,
and
forced
into
a
long
story
before
the
getting
-
up
bell
rang
;
but
Steerforth
was
resolute
;
and
as
he
explained
to
me
,
in
return
,
my
sums
and
exercises
,
and
anything
in
my
tasks
that
was
too
hard
for
me
,
I
was
no
loser
by
the
transaction
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
do
myself
justice
,
however
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
moved
by
no
interested
or
selfish
motive
,
nor
was
I
moved
by
fear
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
admired
and
loved
him
,
and
his
approval
was
return
enough
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
so
precious
to
me
that
I
look
back
on
these
trifles
,
now
,
with
an
aching
heart
.
   
<EOS>
Steerforth
was
considerate
,
too
;
and
showed
his
consideration
,
in
one
particular
instance
,
in
an
unflinching
manner
that
was
a
little
tantalizing
,
I
suspect
,
to
poor
Traddles
and
the
rest
.
 
<EOS>
Peggotty
's
promised
letter
---
what
a
comfortable
letter
it
was
!
<EOS>
---
arrived
before
"
the
half
"
was
many
weeks
old
;
and
with
it
a
cake
in
a
perfect
nest
of
oranges
,
and
two
bottles
of
cowslip
wine
.
 
<EOS>
This
treasure
,
as
in
duty
bound
,
I
laid
at
the
feet
of
Steerforth
,
and
begged
him
to
dispense
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I
'll
tell
you
what
,
young
Copperfield
,
"
said
he
:
"
the
wine
shall
be
kept
to
wet
your
whistle
when
you
are
story
-
telling
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
blushed
at
the
idea
,
and
begged
him
,
in
my
modesty
,
not
to
think
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
said
he
had
observed
I
was
sometimes
hoarse
---
a
little
roopy
was
his
exact
expression
---
and
it
should
be
,
every
drop
,
devoted
to
the
purpose
he
had
mentioned
.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
it
was
locked
up
in
his
box
,
and
drawn
off
by
himself
in
a
phial
,
and
administered
to
me
through
a
piece
of
quill
in
the
cork
,
when
I
was
supposed
to
be
in
want
of
a
restorative
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
to
make
it
a
more
sovereign
specific
,
he
was
so
kind
as
to
squeeze
orange
juice
into
it
,
or
to
stir
it
up
with
ginger
,
or
dissolve
a
peppermint
drop
in
it
;
and
although
I
can
not
assert
that
the
flavour
was
improved
by
these
experiments
,
or
that
it
was
exactly
the
compound
one
would
have
chosen
for
a
stomachic
,
the
last
thing
at
night
and
the
first
thing
in
the
morning
,
I
drank
it
gratefully
and
was
very
sensible
of
his
attention
.
   
<EOS>
We
seem
,
to
me
,
to
have
been
months
over
Peregrine
,
and
months
more
over
the
other
stories
.
 
<EOS>
The
institution
never
flagged
for
want
of
a
story
,
I
am
certain
;
and
the
wine
lasted
out
almost
as
well
as
the
matter
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
Traddles
---
I
never
think
of
that
boy
but
with
a
strange
disposition
to
laugh
,
and
with
tears
in
my
eyes
---
was
a
sort
of
chorus
,
in
general
;
and
affected
to
be
convulsed
with
mirth
at
the
comic
parts
,
and
to
be
overcome
with
fear
when
there
was
any
passage
of
an
alarming
character
in
the
narrative
.
 
<EOS>
This
rather
put
me
out
,
very
often
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
great
jest
of
his
,
I
recollect
,
to
pretend
that
he
could
n't
keep
his
teeth
from
chattering
,
whenever
mention
was
made
of
an
Alguazill
in
connexion
with
the
adventures
of
Gil
Blas
;
and
I
remember
that
when
Gil
Blas
met
the
captain
of
the
robbers
in
Madrid
,
this
unlucky
joker
counterfeited
such
an
ague
of
terror
,
that
he
was
overheard
by
Mr
Creakle
,
who
was
prowling
about
the
passage
,
and
handsomely
flogged
for
disorderly
conduct
in
the
bedroom
.
<EOS>
Whatever
I
had
within
me
that
was
romantic
and
dreamy
,
was
encouraged
by
so
much
story
-
telling
in
the
dark
;
and
in
that
respect
the
pursuit
may
not
have
been
very
profitable
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
being
cherished
as
a
kind
of
plaything
in
my
room
,
and
the
consciousness
that
this
accomplishment
of
mine
was
bruited
about
among
the
boys
,
and
attracted
a
good
deal
of
notice
to
me
though
I
was
the
youngest
there
,
stimulated
me
to
exertion
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
school
carried
on
by
sheer
cruelty
,
whether
it
is
presided
over
by
a
dunce
or
not
,
there
is
not
likely
to
be
much
learnt
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
our
boys
were
,
generally
,
as
ignorant
a
set
as
any
schoolboys
in
existence
;
they
were
too
much
troubled
and
knocked
about
to
learn
;
they
could
no
more
do
that
to
advantage
,
than
any
one
can
do
anything
to
advantage
in
a
life
of
constant
misfortune
,
torment
,
and
worry
.
<EOS>
But
my
little
vanity
,
and
Steerforth
's
help
,
urged
me
on
somehow
;
and
without
saving
me
from
much
,
if
anything
,
in
the
way
of
punishment
,
made
me
,
for
the
time
I
was
there
,
an
exception
to
the
general
body
,
insomuch
that
I
did
steadily
pick
up
some
crumbs
of
knowledge
.
   
<EOS>
In
this
I
was
much
assisted
by
Mr
Mell
,
who
had
a
liking
for
me
that
I
am
grateful
to
remember
.
 
<EOS>
It
always
gave
me
pain
to
observe
that
Steerforth
treated
him
with
systematic
disparagement
,
and
seldom
lost
an
occasion
of
wounding
his
feelings
,
or
inducing
others
to
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
This
troubled
me
the
more
for
a
long
time
,
because
I
had
soon
told
Steerforth
,
from
whom
I
could
no
more
keep
such
a
secret
,
than
I
could
keep
a
cake
or
any
other
tangible
possession
,
about
the
two
old
women
Mr
Mell
<EOS>
had
taken
me
to
see
;
and
I
was
always
afraid
that
Steerforth
would
let
it
out
,
and
twit
him
with
it
.
   
<EOS>
We
little
thought
<EOS>
,
any
one
of
us
,
I
dare
say
,
when
I
ate
my
breakfast
that
first
morning
,
and
went
to
sleep
under
the
shadow
of
the
peacock
's
feathers
to
the
sound
of
the
flute
,
what
consequences
would
come
of
the
introduction
into
those
alms
-
houses
of
my
insignificant
person
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
visit
had
its
unforeseen
consequences
;
and
of
a
serious
sort
,
too
,
in
their
way
.
   
<EOS>
One
day
when
Mr
Creakle
kept
the
house
from
indisposition
,
which
naturally
diffused
a
lively
joy
through
the
school
,
there
was
a
good
deal
of
noise
in
the
course
of
the
morning
's
work
.
 
<EOS>
The
great
relief
and
satisfaction
experienced
by
the
boys
made
them
difficult
to
manage
;
and
though
the
dreaded
Tungay
brought
his
wooden
leg
in
twice
or
thrice
,
and
took
notes
of
the
principal
offenders
'
names
,
no
great
impression
was
made
by
it
,
as
they
were
pretty
sure
of
getting
into
trouble
tomorrow
,
do
what
they
would
,
and
thought
it
wise
,
no
doubt
,
to
enjoy
themselves
today
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
,
properly
,
a
half
-
holiday
;
being
Saturday
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
the
noise
in
the
playground
would
have
disturbed
Mr
Creakle
,
and
the
weather
was
not
favourable
for
going
out
walking
,
we
were
ordered
into
school
in
the
afternoon
,
and
set
some
lighter
tasks
than
usual
,
which
were
made
for
the
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
day
of
the
week
on
which
Mr
Sharp
went
out
to
get
his
wig
curled
;
so
Mr
Mell
,
who
always
did
the
drudgery
,
whatever
it
was
,
kept
school
by
himself
.
<EOS>
If
I
could
associate
the
idea
of
a
bull
or
a
bear
with
anyone
so
mild
as
Mr
Mell
,
I
should
think
of
him
,
in
connexion
with
that
afternoon
when
the
uproar
was
at
its
height
,
as
of
one
of
those
animals
,
baited
by
a
thousand
dogs
.
 
<EOS>
I
recall
him
bending
his
aching
head
,
supported
on
his
bony
hand
,
over
the
book
on
his
desk
,
and
wretchedly
endeavouring
to
get
on
with
his
tiresome
work
,
amidst
an
uproar
that
might
have
made
the
Speaker
of
the
House
of
Commons
giddy
.
 
<EOS>
Boys
started
in
and
out
of
their
places
,
playing
at
puss
in
the
corner
with
other
boys
;
there
were
laughing
boys
,
singing
boys
,
talking
boys
,
dancing
boys
,
howling
boys
;
boys
shuffled
with
their
feet
,
boys
whirled
about
him
,
grinning
,
making
faces
,
mimicking
him
behind
his
back
and
before
his
eyes
;
mimicking
his
poverty
,
his
boots
,
his
coat
,
his
mother
,
everything
belonging
to
him
that
they
should
have
had
consideration
for
.
   
<EOS>
"
Silence
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Mell
,
suddenly
rising
up
,
and
striking
his
desk
with
the
book
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
does
this
mean
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
impossible
to
bear
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
maddening
.
 
<EOS>
How
can
you
do
it
to
me
,
boys
?
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
my
book
that
he
struck
his
desk
with
;
and
as
I
stood
beside
him
,
following
his
eye
as
it
glanced
round
the
room
,
I
saw
the
boys
all
stop
,
some
suddenly
surprised
,
some
half
afraid
,
and
some
sorry
perhaps
.
   
<EOS>
Steerforth
's
place
was
at
the
bottom
of
the
school
,
at
the
opposite
end
of
the
long
room
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
lounging
with
his
back
against
the
wall
,
and
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
and
looked
at
Mr
Mell
with
his
mouth
shut
up
as
if
he
were
whistling
,
when
Mr
Mell
looked
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Silence
,
Mr
Steerforth
!
"
said
Mr
Mell
.
   
<EOS>
"
Silence
yourself
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
turning
red
.
 
<EOS>
"
Whom
are
you
talking
to
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
,
"
said
Mr
Mell
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
yourself
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
"
and
mind
your
business
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
titter
,
and
some
applause
;
but
Mr
Mell
was
so
white
,
that
silence
immediately
succeeded
;
and
one
boy
,
who
had
darted
out
behind
him
to
imitate
his
mother
again
,
changed
his
mind
,
and
pretended
to
want
a
pen
mended
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
think
,
Steerforth
,
"
said
Mr
Mell
,
"
that
I
am
not
acquainted
with
the
power
you
can
establish
over
any
mind
here
"
<EOS>
---
he
laid
his
hand
,
without
considering
what
he
did
(
as
I
supposed
)
,
upon
my
head
---
"
or
that
I
have
not
observed
you
,
within
a
few
minutes
,
urging

juniors
on
to
every
sort
of
outrage
against
me
,
you
are
mistaken
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
give
myself
the
trouble
of
thinking

you
,
"
said
Steerforth
,

;
"
so
I
'm

,
as

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

your

here
,

,
"
pursued

Mell
,
with

,
"
to
insult

---
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
<EOS>
what
?
<EOS>
---
where
is

?
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
Here

cried

,
"
Shame
,
J
Steerforth
!
 
<EOS>
Too
bad
!
"
 
<EOS>
It
was
Traddles
;
whom
Mr
Mell
instantly
discomfited
by
bidding
him
hold
his

.
   
<EOS>
---
"
To
insult
one
who
is
not
fortunate
in
life
,
sir
,
and
who
never

,
and

whom
you

,
"
said

Mell
,
with

"
you
commit

base

.
 
<EOS>
You
can

,

.
<EOS>
Copperfield
,
go

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Young
Copperfield
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
coming

room
,
"
stop
a
bit
.
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
what
,
<EOS>
Mr
Mell
,
once
for
all
.
 
<EOS>
When
you
take
the
liberty
of
calling
me
mean
or
base
,
or
anything

that
sort
,
you
are

.
 
<EOS>
You
are
always
a
beggar
,
you
know
;
but
when
you
do
that
,
you
are
an
impudent
beggar
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
am
not
clear
whether
he
was
going
