strike
Mr
Mell
,
or
Mr
Mell
was
going
to
strike
him
,
or
there
was

.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
a
rigidity
come
upon
the
whole
school
as
if
they
had
been
turned
into
stone
,
and
found
Mr
Creakle
in

,

,
and
Mrs

Creakle
looking

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Mell
,
with
his

and
his

,
sat
,
for

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Mell
,
"
said
Mr
Creakle
,
shaking

;
and
his

so

,
that
Tungay
felt
it
unnecessary
to
repeat

words
<EOS>
;
"
you
have
not

,
I

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
no
,
"
returned
the
Master
,
showing

,
and
shaking

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
I
have
remembered
myself
,
<EOS>
I
---
<EOS>
no
,
Mr
Creakle
,
I
have
not
forgotten
myself
,
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
---
I
have
remembered
myself
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
---
I
---
could
wish
you
had
remembered
me
a
little
sooner
,
Mr
Creakle
.
 
<EOS>
It
---
it
---
would
have
been
more
kind
,
sir
,
more
just
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
have
saved
me
something
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Creakle
,
looking
hard
at
Mr
Mell
,
put
his
hand
on
Tungay
's
shoulder
,
and
got
his
feet
upon
the
form
close
by
,
and
sat
upon
the
desk
.
 
<EOS>
After
still
looking
hard
at
Mr
Mell
from
his
throne
,
as
he
shook
his
head
,
and
rubbed
his
hands
,
and
remained
in
the
same
state
of
agitation
,
Mr
Creakle
turned
to
Steerforth
,
and
said
:
   
"
Now
,
sir
,
as
he
do
n't
condescend
to
tell
me
,
what
is
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
Steerforth
evaded
the
question
for
a
little
while
;
looking
in
scorn
and
anger
on
his
opponent
,
and
remaining
silent
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
help
thinking
even
in
that
interval
<EOS>
,
I
remember
,
what
a
noble
fellow
he
was
in
appearance
,
and
<EOS>
how
homely
and
plain
Mr
Mell
looked
opposed
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
did
he
mean
by
talking
about
favourites
,
then
?
"
said
Steerforth
at
length
.
   
<EOS>
"
Favourites
?
"
<EOS>
repeated
Mr
Creakle
,
with
the
veins
in
his
forehead
swelling
quickly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
talked
about
favourites
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
did
,
"
said
Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
pray
,
what
did
you
mean
by
that
,
sir
?
"
demanded
Mr
Creakle
,
turning
angrily
on
his
assistant
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
meant
,
Mr
Creakle
,
"
he
returned
in
a
low
voice
,
"
as
I
said
;
that
no
pupil
had
a
right
to
avail
himself
of
his
position
of
favouritism
to
degrade
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
degrade
YOU
?
"
said
Mr
Creakle
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
stars
!
 
<EOS>
But
give
me
leave
to
ask
you
,
Mr
What's
-
your
-
name
"
;
and
here
Mr
Creakle
folded
his
arms
,
cane
and
all
,
upon
his
chest
,
and
made
such
a
knot
of
his
brows
that
his
little
eyes
were
hardly
visible
below
them
;
"
whether
,
when
you
talk
about
favourites
,
you
showed
proper
respect
to
me
?
 
<EOS>
To
me
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Creakle
,
darting
his
head
at
him
suddenly
,
and
drawing
it
back
again
,
"
the
principal
of
this
establishment
,
and
your
employer
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
not
judicious
,
sir
,
I
am
willing
to
admit
,
"
said
Mr
Mell
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
not
have
done
so
,
if
I
had
been
cool
.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
Steerforth
struck
in
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
he
said
I
was
mean
,
and
then
he
said
I
was
base
,
and
then
I
called
him
a
beggar
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
been
cool
,
perhaps
I
should
n't
have
called
him
a
beggar
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
did
,
and
I
am
ready
to
take
the
consequences
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Without
considering
,
perhaps
,
whether
there
were
any
consequences
to
be
taken
,
I
felt
quite
in
a
glow
at
this
gallant
speech
.
 
<EOS>
It
made
an
impression
on
the
boys
too
,
for
there
was
a
low
stir
among
them
,
though
no
one
spoke
a
word
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
surprised
,
Steerforth
---
although
your
candour
does
you
honour
,
"
said
Mr
Creakle
,
"
does
you
honour
,
certainly
---
<EOS>
I
am
surprised
,
Steerforth
,
I
must
say
,
that
you
should
attach
such
an
epithet
to
any
person
employed
and
paid
in
Salem
House
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Steerforth
gave
a
short
laugh
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
not
an
answer
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Creakle
,
"
to
my
remark
.
 
<EOS>
I
expect
more
than
that
from
you
,
Steerforth
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
If
Mr
Mell
looked
homely
,
in
my
eyes
,
before
the
handsome
boy
,
it
would
be
quite
impossible
to
say
how
homely
Mr
Creakle
looked
.
<EOS>
"
Let
him
deny
it
,
"
said
Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Deny
that
he
is
a
beggar
,
Steerforth
?
"
cried
Mr
Creakle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
where
does
he
go
a
-
begging
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
he
is
not
a
beggar
himself
,
his
near
relation
's
one
,
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
the
same
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
glanced
at
me
,
and
Mr
Mell
's
hand
gently
patted
me
upon
the
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
I
looked
up
with
a
flush
upon
my
face
and
remorse
in
my
heart
,
but
Mr
Mell
's
eyes
were
fixed
on
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
He
continued
to
pat
me
kindly
on
the
shoulder
,
but
he
looked
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Since
you
expect
me
,
Mr
Creakle
,
to
justify
myself
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
"
and
to
say
what
I
mean
,
---
what
I
have
to
say
is
,
that
his
mother
lives
on
charity
in
an
alms
-
house
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Mell
still
looked
at
him
,
and
still
patted
me
kindly
on
the
shoulder
,
and
said
to
himself
,
in
a
whisper
,
if
I
heard
right
:
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
thought
so
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Creakle
turned
to
his
assistant
,
with
a
severe
frown
and
laboured
politeness
:
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
you
hear
what
this
gentleman
says
,
Mr
Mell
.
 
<EOS>
Have
the
goodness
,
if
you
please
,
to
set
him
right
before
the
assembled
school
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
right
,
sir
,
without
correction
,
"
returned
Mr
Mell
,
in
the
midst
of
a
dead
silence
;
"
what
he
has
said
is
true
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Be
so
good
then
as
declare
publicly
,
will
you
,
"
said
Mr
Creakle
,
putting
his
head
on
one
side
,
and
rolling
his
eyes
round
the
school
,
"
whether
it
ever
came
to
my
knowledge
until
this
moment
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
believe
not
directly
,
"
he
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
,
you
know
not
,
"
said
Mr
Creakle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
,
man
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
apprehend
you
never
supposed
my
worldly
circumstances
to
be
very
good
,
"
replied
the
assistant
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
what
my
position
is
,
and
always
has
been
,
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
apprehend
,
if
you
come
to
that
,
"
said
Mr
Creakle
,
with
his
veins
swelling
again
bigger
than
ever
,
"
that
you
've
been
in
a
wrong
position
altogether
,
and
mistook
this
for
a
charity
school
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Mell
,
we
'll
part
,
if
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
The
sooner
the
better
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
time
,
"
answered
Mr
Mell
,
rising
,
"
like
the
present
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
to
you
!
"
said
Mr
Creakle
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
take
my
leave
of
you
,
Mr
Creakle
,
and
all
of
you
,
"
said
Mr
Mell
,
glancing
round
the
room
,
and
again
patting
me
gently
on
the
shoulders
.
 
<EOS>
"
James
Steerforth
,
the
best
wish
I
can
leave
you
is
that
you
may
come
to
be
ashamed
of
what
you
have
done
today
.
 
<EOS>
At
present
I
would
prefer
to
see
you
anything
rather
than
a
friend
,
to
me
,
or
to
anyone
in
whom
I
feel
an
interest
.
"
   
<EOS>
Once
more
he
laid
his
hand
upon
my
shoulder
;
and
then
taking
his
flute
and
a
few
books
from
his
desk
,
and
leaving
the
key
in
it
for
his
successor
,
he
went
out
of
the
school
,
with
his
property
under
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Creakle
then
made
a
speech
,
through
Tungay
,
in
which
he
thanked
Steerforth
for
asserting
(
though
perhaps
too
warmly
)
the
independence
and
respectability
of
Salem
House
;
and
which
he
wound
up
by
shaking
hands
with
Steerforth
,
while
we
gave
three
cheers
---
I
did
not
quite
know
what
for
,
but
I
supposed
for
Steerforth
,
and
so
joined
in
them
ardently
,
though
I
felt
miserable
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Creakle
then
caned
Tommy
Traddles
for
being
discovered
in
tears
,
instead
of
cheers
,
on
account
of
Mr
Mell
's
departure
;
and
went
back
to
his
sofa
,
or
his
bed
,
or
wherever
he
had
come
from
.
   
<EOS>
We
were
left
to
ourselves
now
,
and
looked
very
blank
,
I
recollect
,
on
one
another
.
 
<EOS>
For
myself
,
I
felt
so
much
self
-
reproach
and
contrition
for
my
part
in
what
had
happened
,
that
nothing
would
have
enabled
me
to
keep
back
my
tears
but
the
fear
that
Steerforth
,
who
often
looked
at
me
,
I
saw
,
might
think
it
unfriendly
---
or
<EOS>
,
I
should
rather
say
,
considering
our
relative
ages
,
and
the
feeling
with
which
I
regarded
him
,
<EOS>
undutiful
---
if
I
showed
the
emotion
which
distressed
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
very
angry
with
Traddles
,
and
said
he
was
glad
he
had
caught
it
.
   
<EOS>
Poor
Traddles
,
who
had
passed
the
stage
of
lying
with
his
head
upon
the
desk
,
and
was
relieving
himself
as
usual
with
a
burst
of
skeletons
,
said
he
did
n't
care
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Mell
was
ill
-
used
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
has
ill
-
used
him
,
you
girl
?
"
said
Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
have
,
"
returned
Traddles
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
have
I
done
?
"
said
Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
done
?
"
<EOS>
retorted
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hurt
his
feelings
,
and
lost
him
his
situation
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
His
feelings
?
"
repeated
Steerforth
disdainfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
His
feelings
will
soon
get
the
better
of
it
,
I
'll
be
bound
.
 
<EOS>
His
feelings
are
not
like
yours
,
Miss
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
his
situation
---
which
was
a
precious
one
,
was
n't
it
?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
do
you
suppose
I
am
not
going
to
write
home
,
and
take
care
that
he
gets
some
money
?
 
<EOS>
Polly
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
We
thought
this
intention
very
noble
in
Steerforth
,
whose
mother
was
a
widow
,
and
rich
,
and
would
do
almost
anything
,
it
was
said
,
that
he
asked
her
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
all
extremely
glad
to
see
Traddles
so
put
down
,
and
exalted
Steerforth
to
the
skies
:
especially
when
he
told
us
,
as
he
condescended
to
do
,
that
what
he
had
done
had
been
done
expressly
for
us
,
and
for
our
cause
;
and
that
he
had
conferred
a
great
boon
upon
us
by
unselfishly
doing
it
.
<EOS>
But
I
must
say
that
when
I
was
going
on
with
a
story
in
the
dark
that
night
,
Mr
Mell
's
old
flute
seemed
more
than
once
to
sound
mournfully
in
my
ears
;
and
that
when
at
last
Steerforth
was
tired
,
and
I
lay
down
in
my
bed
,
I
fancied
it
playing
so
sorrowfully
somewhere
,
that
I
was
quite
wretched
.
   
<EOS>
I
soon
forgot
him
in
the
contemplation
of
Steerforth
,
who
,
in
an
easy
amateur
way
,
and
without
any
book
(
he
seemed
to
me
to
know
everything
by
heart
)
,
took
some
of
his
classes
until
a
new
master
was
found
.
 
<EOS>
The
new
master
came
from
a
grammar
school
;
and
before
he
entered
on
his
duties
,
dined
in
the
parlour
one
day
,
to
be
introduced
to
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
Steerforth
approved
of
him
highly
,
and
told
us
he
was
a
Brick
.
 
<EOS>
Without
exactly
understanding
what
learned
distinction
was
meant
by
this
,
I
respected
him
greatly
for
it
,
and
had
no
doubt
whatever
of
his
superior
knowledge
:
though
he
never
took
the
pains
with
me
---
not
that
I
was
anybody
---
that
Mr
Mell
had
taken
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
only
one
other
event
in
this
half
-
year
,
out
of
the
daily
school
-
life
,
that
made
an
impression
upon
me
which
still
survives
.
<EOS>
It
survives
for
many
reasons
.
   
<EOS>
One
afternoon
,
when
we
were
all
harassed
into
a
state
of
dire
confusion
,
and
Mr
Creakle
was
laying
about
him
dreadfully
,
Tungay
came
in
,
and
called
out
in
his
usual
strong
way
:
"
Visitors
for
Copperfield
!
"
   
<EOS>
A
few
words
were
interchanged
between
him
and
Mr
Creakle
,
as
,
who
the
visitors
were
,
and
what
room
they
were
to
be
shown
into
;
and
then
I
,
who
had
,
according
to
custom
,
stood
up
on
the
announcement
being
made
,
and
felt
quite
faint
with
astonishment
,
was
told
to
go
by
the
back
stairs
and
get
a
clean
frill
on
,
before
I
repaired
to
the
dining
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
These
orders
I
obeyed
,
in
such
a
flutter
and
hurry
of
my
young
spirits
as
I
had
never
known
before
;
and
when
I
got
to
the
parlour
door
,
and
the
thought
came
into
my
head
that
it
might
be
my
mother
<EOS>
---
I
had
only
thought
of
Mr
or
Miss
Murdstone
until
then
---
I
drew
back
my
hand
from
the
lock
,
and
stopped
to
have
a
sob
before
I
went
in
.
   
<EOS>
At
first
I
saw
nobody
;
but
feeling
a
pressure
against
the
door
,
I
looked
round
it
,
and
there
,
to
my
amazement
,
were
Mr
Peggotty
and
Ham
,
ducking
at
me
with
their
hats
,
and
squeezing
one
another
against
the
wall
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
help
laughing
;
but
it
was
much
more
in
the
pleasure
of
seeing
them
,
than
at
the
appearance
they
made
.
<EOS>
We
shook
hands
in
a
very
cordial
way
;
and
I
laughed
and
laughed
,
until
I
pulled
out
my
pocket
-
handkerchief
and
wiped
my
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
(
who
never
shut
his
mouth
once
,
I
remember
,
during
the
visit
)
showed
great
concern
when
he
saw
me
do
this
,
and
nudged
Ham
to
say
something
.
   
<EOS>
"
Cheer
up
,
Mas'r
Davy
bor
'
!
"
said
Ham
,
in
his
simpering
way
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
how
you
have
growed
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Am
I
grown
?
<EOS>
"
I
said
,
drying
my
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
crying
at
anything
in
particular
that
I
know
of
;
but
somehow
it
made
me
cry
,
to
see
old
friends
.
   
<EOS>
"
Growed
,
Mas'r
Davy
bor
'
?
 
<EOS>
Ai
n't
he
growed
!
"
said
Ham
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ai
n't
he
growed
!
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
They
made
me
laugh
again
by
laughing
at
each
other
,
and
then
we
all
three
laughed
until
I
was
in
danger
of
crying
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
how
mama
is
,
Mr
Peggotty
?
<EOS>
"
I
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
how
my
dear
,
dear
,
old
Peggotty
is
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oncommon
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
little
Em'ly
,
and
Mrs
Gummidge
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
On
---
common
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
silence
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
,
to
relieve
it
,
took
two
prodigious
lobsters
,
and
an
enormous
crab
,
and
a
large
canvas

of
shrimps
,
out
of
his
pockets
,
and
piled

up
in
Ham
's

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,
"
knowing
as
you
was
partial
to
a
little
relish
with
your
wittles
when
you
was
along
with
us
,
we
took
the
liberty
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
Mawther
biled
'em
,
she
did
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Gummidge
biled
'em
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,
slowly
,
who
I
thought
appeared
to
stick
to
the

on

of
having
no
other
subject
ready
,
"
Mrs
Gummidge
<EOS>
,
I
do
assure
you
,
she
biled
'
em
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
expressed
my
thanks
;
and
Mr
Peggotty
,
after
looking
at
Ham
,
who
stood
smiling
sheepishly
over
the
shellfish
,
without
making
any

to
help

,
said
:
   
"
We
come
,
you
see
,
the
wind
and
tide
making
in
our
favour
,
in
one
of
our
Yarmouth
lugs
to
Gravesen
'
.
 
<EOS>
My
sister
she
wrote
to
me
the
name
of
this
here
place
,
and
wrote
to
me
as
if
ever
I
chanced
to
come
to
Gravesen
'
,
I
was
to
come
over
and
inquire
for
Mas'r
Davy
and
give
her
dooty
,
humbly
wishing
him
well
and
reporting
of
the
fam'ly
as
they
was
oncommon
toe
-
be
-
sure
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Em'ly
,
you
see
,
she
'll
write
to
my
sister
when
I
go
back
,
as
I
see
you
and
as
you
was
similarly
oncommon
,
and
so
we
make
it
quite
a
merry
-
go
-
rounder
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
obliged
to
consider
a
little
before
I
understood
what
Mr
Peggotty
meant
by
this
figure
,
expressive
of
a
complete
circle
of
intelligence
.
 
<EOS>
I
then
thanked
him
heartily
;
and
said
,
with
a
consciousness
of
reddening
,
that
I
supposed
little
Em'ly
was
altered
too
,
since
we
used
to
pick
up
shells
and
pebbles
on
the
beach
?
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
getting
to
be
a
woman
<EOS>
,
that
's
wot
<EOS>
she
's
getting
to
be
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ask
HIM
.
"
<EOS>
He
meant
Ham
,
who
beamed
with
delight
and
assent
over
the
bag
of
shrimps
.
   
<EOS>
"
Her
pretty
face
!
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,
with
his
own
shining
like
a
light
.
   
<EOS>
"
Her
learning
!
<EOS>
"
said
Ham
.
   
<EOS>
"
Her
writing
!
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
it
's
as
black
as
jet
!
 
<EOS>
And
so
large
it
is
,
you
might
see
it
anywheres
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
perfectly
delightful
to
behold
with
what
enthusiasm
Mr
Peggotty
became
inspired
when
he
thought
of
his
little
favourite
.
<EOS>
He
stands
before
me
again
,
his
bluff
hairy
face
irradiating
with
a
joyful
love
and
pride
,
for
which
I
can
find
no
description
.
 
<EOS>
His
honest
eyes
fire
up
,
and
sparkle
,
as
if
their
depths
were
stirred
by
something
bright
.
 
<EOS>
His
broad
chest
heaves
with
pleasure
.
 
<EOS>
His
strong
loose
hands
clench
themselves
,
in
his
earnestness
;
and
he
emphasizes
what
he
says
with
a
right
arm
that
shows
,
in
my
pigmy
view
,
like
a
sledge
-
hammer
.
   
<EOS>
Ham
was
quite
as
earnest
as
he
.
 
<EOS>
I
dare
say
they
would
have
said
much
more
about
her
,
if
they
had
not
been
abashed
by
the
unexpected
coming
in
of
Steerforth
,
who
,
seeing
me
in
a
corner
speaking
with
two
strangers
,
stopped
in
a
song
he
was
singing
,
and
said
:
"
I
did
n't
know
you
were
here
,
young
Copperfield
!
"
<EOS>
(
for
it
was
not
the
usual
visiting
room
)
and
crossed
by
us
on
his
way
out
.
   
<EOS>
I
am
not
sure
whether
it
was
in
the
pride
of
having
such
a
friend
as
Steerforth
,
or
in
the
desire
to
explain
to
him
how
I
came
to
have
such
a
friend
as
Mr
Peggotty
<EOS>
,
that
I
called
to
him
as
he
was
going
away
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
said
,
modestly
---
<EOS>
Good
Heaven
,
how
it
all
comes
back
to
me
this
long
time
afterwards
!
<EOS>
---
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
go
,
Steerforth
,
if
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
These
are
two
Yarmouth
boatmen
---
very
kind
,
good
people
---
who
are
relations
of
my
nurse
,
and
have
come
from
Gravesend
to
see
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
aye
?
<EOS>
"
said
Steerforth
,
returning
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
see
them
.
<EOS>
How
are
you
both
?
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
an
ease
in
his
manner
---
a
gay
and
light
manner
it
was
,
but
not
swaggering
---
which
I
still
believe
to
have
borne
a
kind
of
enchantment
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
still
believe
him
,
in
virtue
of
this
carriage
,
his
animal
spirits
,
his
delightful
voice
,
his
handsome
face
and
figure
,
and
,
for
aught
I
know
,
of
some
inborn
power
of
attraction
besides
(
which
I
think
a
few
people
possess
)
,
to
have
carried
a
spell
with
him
to
which
it
was
a
natural
weakness
to
yield
,
and
which
not
many
persons
could
withstand
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
but
see
how
pleased
they
were
with
him
,
and
how
they
seemed
to
open
their
hearts
to
him
in
a
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
let
them
know
at
home
,
<EOS>
if
you
please
,
Mr
Peggotty
,
"
<EOS>
I
said
,
"
when
that
letter
is
sent
,
that
Mr
Steerforth
is
very
kind
to
me
,
and
that
I
do
n't
know
what
I
should
ever
do
here
without

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
!
<EOS>
"
said
Steerforth
,
laughing
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
n't
tell

anything
of
the
sort
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
if
Mr
Steerforth
ever
comes
into
Norfolk

,
Mr
Peggotty
,
"
<EOS>
I
said
,
"
while
I
am
there
,
you
may
depend
upon
it
I
shall
bring
him
to
Yarmouth
,
if
he

let

,
to
see

.
<EOS>
You
never
saw
such
a
good
house
,
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
It
's

of
a
boat
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Made
out
of
a
boat
,
is

?
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
right

of
a

for
such

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
'
tis
,
sir
,
so
'
tis
,
sir
,
"
said
Ham
,
grinning
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
right
,
young

!
 
<EOS>
Mas'r
Davy
bor
'
,
gen'l'm'n
's
right
.
 
<EOS>
A

-
built
boatman
!
 
<EOS>
Hor
,
hor
!
 
<EOS>
That
's
what
he
is
,
too
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
was
no
less
pleased
than
his
nephew
,
though
his
modesty
forbade
him
to
claim
a
personal

so

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
he
said
,
bowing
and

,
and
tucking
in

ends

at

:
<EOS>
"
I
thankee
,
sir
,
I
thankee
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
my
endeavours
in
my
line
of
life
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
best
of
men
can
do
no
more
,
Mr
Peggotty
,
"
said
Steerforth
.
<EOS>
He
had
got
his
name
already
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
pound
it
,
it
's
wot
<EOS>
you
do
yourself
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,
shaking

head
,
"
and
wot
<EOS>
you
do
well
---
right
well
!
 
<EOS>
I
thankee
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
obleeged
to
you
,
sir
,
for
your
welcoming
manner
of
me
.
<EOS>
I
'm
rough
,
sir
,
but
I
'm
ready
---
<EOS>
least
ways
,
I
hope
I
'm
ready
,
you
unnerstand
.
 
<EOS>
My
house
ai
n't
much
for
to
see
,
sir
,
but
it
's
hearty
at
your
service
if
ever
you
should
come
along
with
Mas'r
Davy
to
see

.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
a
reg'lar
Dodman
<EOS>
,
I
am
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,
by
which
he
meant
snail
,
and
this
was
in
allusion
to
his
being
slow
to
go
,
for
he
had
attempted
to
go
after
every
sentence
,
and
had
somehow
or
other
come
back
again
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
wish
you
both
well
,
and
I
wish
you
happy
!
"
   
<EOS>
Ham
echoed
this
sentiment
,
and
we
parted
with
them
in
the
heartiest
manner
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
almost
tempted
that
evening
to
tell
Steerforth
about
pretty
little
Em'ly
,
but
I
was
too
timid
of
mentioning
her
name
,
and
too
much
afraid
of
his
laughing
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
remember
that
I
thought
a
good
deal
,
and
in
an
uneasy
sort
of
way
,
about
Mr
Peggotty
having
said
that
she
was
getting
on
to
be
a
woman
;
but
I
decided
that
was
nonsense
.
   
<EOS>
We
transported
the
shellfish
,
or
the
"
relish
"
as
Mr
Peggotty
had
modestly
called
it
,
up
into
our
room
unobserved
,
and
made
a
great
supper
that
evening
.
 
<EOS>
But
Traddles
could
n't
get
happily
out
of
it
.
<EOS>
He
was
too
unfortunate
even
to
come
through
a
supper
like
anybody
else
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
taken
ill
in
the
night
---
quite
prostrate
he
was
---
in
consequence
of
Crab
;
and
after
being
drugged
with
black
draughts
and
blue
pills
,
to
an
extent
which
Demple
(
whose
father
was
a
doctor
)
said
was
enough
to
undermine
a
horse
's
constitution
,
received
a
caning
and
six
chapters
of
Greek
Testament
for
refusing
to
confess
.
   
<EOS>
The
rest
of
the
half
-
year
is
a
jumble
in
my
recollection
of
the
daily
strife
and
struggle
of
our
lives
;
of
the
waning
summer
and
the
changing
season
;
of
the
frosty
mornings
when
we
were
rung
out
of
bed
,
and
the
cold
,
cold
smell
of
the
dark
nights
when
we
were
rung
into
bed
again
;
of
the
evening
schoolroom
dimly
lighted
and
indifferently
warmed
,
and
the
morning
schoolroom
which
was
nothing
but
a
great
shivering
-
machine
;
of
the
alternation
of
boiled
beef
with
roast
beef
,
and
boiled
mutton
with
roast
mutton
;
of
clods
of
bread
-
and
-
butter
,
dog's
-
eared
lesson
-
books
,
cracked
slates
,
tear
-
blotted
copy
-
books
,
canings
,
rulerings
,
hair
-
cuttings
,
rainy
Sundays
,
suet
-
puddings
,
and
a
dirty
atmosphere
of
ink
,
surrounding
all
.
   
<EOS>
I
well
remember
though
,
how
the
distant
idea
of
the
holidays
,
after
seeming
for
an
immense
time
to
be
a
stationary
speck
,
began
to
come
towards
us
,
and
to
grow
and
grow
.
 
<EOS>
How
from
counting
months
,
we
came
to
weeks
,
and
then
to
days
;
and
how
I
then
began
to
be
afraid
that
I
should
not
be
sent
for
and
when
I
learnt
from
Steerforth
that
I
had
been
sent
for
,
and
was
certainly
to
go
home
,
had
dim
forebodings
that
I
might
break
my
leg
first
.
 
<EOS>
How
the
breaking
-
up
day
changed
its
place
fast
,
at
last
,
from
the
week
after
next
to
next
week
,
this
week
,
the
day
after
tomorrow
,
tomorrow
,
today
,
tonight
---
when
I
was
inside
the
Yarmouth
mail
,
and
going
home
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
many
a
broken
sleep
inside
the
Yarmouth
mail
,
and
many
an
incoherent
dream
of
all
these
things
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
I
awoke
at
intervals
,
the
ground
outside
the
window
was
not
the
playground
of
Salem
House
,
and
the
sound
in
my
ears
was
not
the
sound
of
Mr
Creakle
giving
it
to
Traddles
,
but
the
sound
of
the
coachman
touching
up
the
horses
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
8
.
<EOS>
My
holidays
.
 
<EOS>
Especially
one
happy
afternoon
 
<EOS>
When
we
arrived
before
day
at
the
inn
where
the
mail
stopped
,
which
was
not
the
inn
where
my
friend
the
waiter
lived
,
I
was
shown
up
to
a
nice
little
bedroom
,
with
DOLPHIN
painted
on
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Very
cold
I
was
,
I
know
,
notwithstanding
the
hot
tea
they
had
given
me
before
a
large
fire
downstairs
;
and
very
glad
I
was
to
turn
into
the
Dolphin
's
bed
,
pull
the
Dolphin
's
blankets
<EOS>
round
my
head
,
and
go
to
sleep
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Barkis
the
carrier
was
to
call
for
me
in
the
morning
at
nine
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
I
got
up
at
eight
,
a
little
giddy
from
the
shortness
of
my
night
's
rest
,
and
was
ready
for
him
before
the
appointed
time
.
<EOS>
He
received
me
exactly
as
if
not
five
minutes
had
elapsed
since
we
were
last
together
,
and
I
had
only
been
into
the
hotel
to
get
change
for
sixpence
,
or
something
of
that
sort
.
   
<EOS>
As
soon
as
I
and
my
box
were
in
the
cart
,
and
the
carrier
seated
,
the
lazy
horse
walked
away
with
us
all
at
his
accustomed
pace
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
look
very
well
,
Mr
Barkis
,
"
I
said
,
thinking
he
would
like
to
know
it
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Barkis
rubbed
his
cheek
with
his
cuff
,
and
then
looked
at
his
cuff
as
if
he
expected
to
find
some
of
the
bloom
upon
it
;
but
made
no
other
acknowledgement
of
the
compliment
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
gave
your
message
,
Mr
Barkis
,
"
I
said
:
"
I
wrote
to
Peggotty
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Mr
Barkis
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Barkis
seemed
gruff
,
and
answered
drily
.
   
<EOS>
"
Was
n't
it
right
,
Mr
Barkis
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
,
after
a
little
hesitation
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
no
,
"
said
Mr
Barkis
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
the
message
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
message
was
right
enough
,
perhaps
,
"
said
Mr
Barkis
;
"
but
it
come
to
an
end
there
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Not
understanding
what
he
meant
,
I
repeated
inquisitively
:
"
Came
to
an
end
,
Mr
Barkis
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
come
of
it
,
"
he
explained
,
looking
at
me
sideways
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
answer
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
was
an
answer
expected
,
was
there
,
Mr
Barkis
?
<EOS>
"
said
I
,
opening
my
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
For
this
was
a
new
light
to
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
a
man
says
he
's
willin
'
,
"
said
Mr
Barkis
,
turning
his

on
me
again
,
"
it
's
as
much
as
to
say
,
that
man
's
a
-
waitin
'
for
a
answer
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Mr
Barkis
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
Mr
Barkis
,
carrying
his
eyes
back
to
his
horse
's
ears
;
"
that
man
's
been
a
-
waitin
'
for
a
answer
ever
since
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
told
her
so
,
Mr
Barkis
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
<EOS>
---
no
,
"
growled
Mr
Barkis
,
reflecting
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ai
n't
got
no
call
to
go
and
tell
her
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
said
six
words
to
her
myself
,
<EOS>
I
ai
n't
a
-
goin
'
to
tell
her
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Would
you
like
me
to

,
Mr
Barkis
?
"
said

,
doubtfully
.
<EOS>
"
You
might
tell
her
,
if
you
would
,
"
said
Mr
Barkis
,
with
another
slow

me
,
"
that
Barkis
was
a
-
waitin
'
for
a

.
 
<EOS>
Says
you
---
what
name
is
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Her

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Mr
Barkis
,
with
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
Peggotty
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Chrisen
name
?
 
<EOS>
Or
nat'ral
name
?
"
said
Mr
Barkis
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
it
's
not
her
Christian

.
 
<EOS>
Her
Christian
name
is
Clara
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
though
?
"
said
Mr
Barkis
.
   
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
find
an
immense
fund
of
reflection
in
this
circumstance
,
and
sat
pondering
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
<EOS>
he
resumed
at
length
.
 
<EOS>
"
Says
you
,
"
Peggotty
!
 
<EOS>
Barkis
is
waitin
'
for
a
answer
.
"
 
<EOS>
Says
she
,
perhaps
,
"
Answer
to
what
?
"
 
<EOS>
Says
you
,
"
<EOS>
To
what
I
told
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
that
?
"
says
she
.
 
<EOS>
"
Barkis
is
willin
'
,
"
says
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
extremely
artful
suggestion
<EOS>
Mr
Barkis
accompanied
with
a
nudge
of
his
elbow
that
gave
me
quite
a
stitch
in
my
side
.
 
<EOS>
After
that
,
he
slouched
over
his
horse
in
his
usual
manner
;
and
made
no
other
reference
to
the
subject
except
,
half
an
hour
afterwards
,
taking
a
piece
of
chalk
from
his
pocket
,
and
writing
up
,
inside
the
tilt
of

cart
,
"
Clara
Peggotty
"
---
apparently
as
a
private
memorandum
.
   
<EOS>
Ah
,
what
a
strange
feeling
it
was
to
be
going
home
when
it
was
not
home
,
and
to
find
that
every
object
I
looked
at
,
reminded
me
of
the
happy
old
home
,
which
was
like
a
dream
I
could
never
dream
again
!
<EOS>
The
days
when
my
mother
and
I
and
Peggotty
were
all
in
all
to
one
another
,
and
there
was
no
one
to
come
between
us
,
rose
up
before
me
so
sorrowfully
on
the
road
,
that
I
am
not
sure
I
was
glad
to
be
there
---
not
sure
but
that
I
would
rather
have
remained
away
,
and
forgotten
it
in
Steerforth
's
company
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
I
was
;
and
soon
I
was
at
our
house
,
where
the
bare
old
elm
-
trees
wrung
their
many
hands
in
the
bleak
wintry
air
,
and
shreds
of
the
old
rooks'-nests
drifted
away
upon
the
wind
.
   
<EOS>
The
carrier
put
my
box
down
at
the
garden
-
gate
,
and
left
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
walked
along
the
path
towards
the
house
,
glancing
at
the
windows
,
and
fearing
at
every
step
to
see
Mr
Murdstone
or
Miss
Murdstone
lowering
out
of
one
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
No
face
appeared
,
however
;
and
being
come
to
the
house
,
and
knowing
how
to
open
the
door
,
before
dark
,
without
knocking
<EOS>
,
I
went
in
with
a
quiet
,
timid
step
.
   
<EOS>
God
knows
how
infantine
the
memory
may
have
been
,
that
was
awakened
within
me
by
the
sound
of
my
mother
's
voice
in
the
old
parlour
,
when
I
set
foot
in
the
hall
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
singing
in
a
low
tone
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
must
have
lain
in
her
arms
,
and
heard
her
singing
so
to
me
when
I
was
but
a
baby
.
 
<EOS>
The
strain
was
new
to
me
,
and
yet
it
was
so
old
that
it
filled
my
heart
brim
-
full
<EOS>
;
like
a
friend
come
back
from
a
long
absence
.
   
<EOS>
I
believed
,
from
the
solitary
and
thoughtful
way
in
which
my
mother
murmured
her
song
,
that
she
was
alone
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
went
softly
into
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
sitting
by
the
fire
,
suckling
an
infant
,
whose
tiny
hand
she
held
against
her
neck
.
 
<EOS>
Her
eyes
were
looking
down
upon
its
face
,
and
she
sat
singing
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
far
right
,
that
she
had
no
other
companion
.
   
<EOS>
I
spoke
to
her
,
and
she
started
,
and
cried
out
.
 
<EOS>
But
seeing
me
,
she
called
me
her
dear
Davy
,
her
own
boy
!
<EOS>
and
coming
half
across
the
room
to
meet
me
,
kneeled
down
upon
the
ground
and
kissed
me
,
and
laid
my
head
down
on
her
bosom
near
the
little
creature
that
was
nestling
there
,
and
put
its
hand
to
my
lips
.
   
<EOS>
I
wish
I
had
died
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
I
had
died
then
,
with
that
feeling
in
my
heart
!
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
been
more
fit
for
Heaven
than
I
ever
have
been
since
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
your
brother
,
"
said
my
mother
,
fondling
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
Davy
,
my
pretty
boy
!
 
<EOS>
My
poor
child
!
"
 
<EOS>
Then
she
kissed
me
more
and
more
,
and
clasped
me
round
the
neck
.
 
<EOS>
This
she
was
doing
when
Peggotty
came
running
in
,
and
bounced
down
on
the
ground
beside
us
,
and
went
mad
about
us
both
for
a
quarter
of
an
hour
.
   
<EOS>
It
seemed
that
I
had
not
been
expected
so
soon
,
the
carrier
being
much
before
his
usual
time
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
,
too
,
that
Mr
and
Miss
Murdstone
had
gone
out
upon
a
visit
in
the
neighbourhood
,
and
would
not
return
before
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
never
hoped
for
this
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
never
thought
it
possible
that
we
three
could
be
together
undisturbed
,
once
more
;
and
I
felt
,
for
the
time
,
as
if
the
old
days
were
come
back
.
   
<EOS>
We
dined
together
by
the
fireside
.
 
<EOS>
Peggotty
was
in
attendance
to
wait
upon
us
,
but
my
mother
would
n't
let
her
do
it
,
and
made
her
dine
with
us
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
my
own
old
plate
,
with
a
brown
view
of
a
man
-
of
-
war
in
full
sail
upon
it
,
which
Peggotty
had
hoarded
somewhere
all
the
time
I
had
been
away
,
and
would
not
have
had
broken
,
she
said
,
for
a
hundred
pounds
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
my
own
old
mug
with
David
on
it
,
and
my
own
old
little
knife
and
fork
that
would
n't
cut
.
   
<EOS>
While
we
were
at
table
,
I
thought
it
a
favourable
occasion
to
tell
Peggotty
about
Mr
Barkis
,
who
,
before
I
had
finished
what
I
had
to
tell
her
,
began
to
laugh
,
and
throw
her
apron
over
her
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
Peggotty
,
"
said
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
only
laughed
the
more
,
and
held
her
apron
tight
over
her
face
when
my
mother
tried
to
pull
it
away
,
and
sat
as
if
her
head
were
in
a
bag
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
doing
,
you
stupid
creature
?
"
said
my
mother
,
laughing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
drat
the
man
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
wants
to
marry
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
a
very
good
match
for
you
;
would
n't
it
?
"
said
my
mother
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
,
"
said
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
ask
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
have
him
if
he
was
made
of
gold
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
I
would
n't
have
anybody
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
why
do
n't
you
tell
him
so
,
you
ridiculous
thing
?
"
said
my
mother
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tell
him
so
,
"
retorted
Peggotty
,
looking
out
of
her
apron
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
never
said
a
word
to
me
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
knows
better
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
was
to
make
so
bold
as
say
a
word
to
me
,
I
should
slap
his
face
.
"
   
<EOS>
Her
own
was
as
red
as
ever
<EOS>
I
saw
it
,
or
any
other
face
,
I
think
;
but
she
only
covered
it
again
,
for
a
few
moments
at
a
time
,
when
she
was
taken
with
a
violent

of
laughter
;
and
after
two
or
three
of
those
attacks
,
went
on
with
her
dinner
.
   
<EOS>
I
remarked
that
my
mother
,
though
she
smiled
when
Peggotty
looked
at
her
,
became
more
serious
and
thoughtful
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
seen
at
first
that
she
was
changed
.
 
<EOS>
Her
face
was
very
pretty
still
,
but
it
looked
careworn
,
and
too
delicate
;
and
her
hand
was
so
thin
and
white
<EOS>
that
it
seemed
to
me
to
be
almost
transparent
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
change
to
which
I
now
refer
was
superadded
to
this
:
it
was
in
her
manner
,
which
became
anxious
and
fluttered
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
she
said
,
putting
out
her
hand
,
and
laying
it
affectionately
on
the
hand
of
her
old
servant
,
   
<EOS>
"
Peggotty
,
dear
,
you
are
not
going
to
be
married
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Me
,
ma'am
?
"
returned
Peggotty
,
staring
.
 
<EOS>
"
Lord
bless
you
,
no
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
just
yet
?
"
said
my
mother
,
tenderly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
!
"
cried
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
My
mother
took
her
hand
,
and
said
:
   
"
Do
n't
leave
me
,
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
Stay
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
not
be
for
long
,
perhaps
.
 
<EOS>
What
should
I
ever
do
without
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Me
leave
you
,
my
precious
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
for
all
the
world
and
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
what
's
put
that
in
your
silly
little
head
?
"
<EOS>
---
For
Peggotty
had
been
used
of
old
to
talk
to
my
mother
sometimes
like
a
child
.
   
<EOS>
But
my
mother
made
no
answer
,
except
to
thank
her
,
and
Peggotty
went
running
on
in
her
own
fashion
.
   
<EOS>
"
Me
leave
you
?
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
see
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Peggotty
go
away
from
you
?
<EOS>
I
should
like
to
catch
her
at
it
!
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
no
,
"
said
Peggotty
,
shaking
her
head
,
and
folding
her
arms
;
"
not
she
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
n't
that
there
ai
n't
some
Cats
that
would
be
well
enough
pleased
if
she
did
,
but
they
sha'n't
be
pleased
.
 
<EOS>
They
shall
be
aggravated
.
<EOS>
I
'll
stay
with
you
till
I
am
a
cross
cranky
old
woman
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
I
'm
too
deaf
,
and
too
lame
,
and
too
blind
,
and
too
mumbly
for
want
of
teeth
,
to
be
of
any
use
at
all
,
even
to
be
found
fault
with
,
than
I
shall
go
to
my
Davy
,
and
ask
him
to
take
me
in
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
,
Peggotty
,
"
says
I
,
"
I
shall
be
glad
to
see
you
,
and
I
'll
make
you
as
welcome
as
a
queen
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
your
dear
heart
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
you
will
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
she
kissed
me
beforehand
,
in
grateful
acknowledgement
of
my
hospitality
.
 
<EOS>
After
that
,
she
covered
her
head
up
with
her
apron
again
and
had
another
laugh
about
Mr
Barkis
.
 
<EOS>
After
that
,
she
took
the
baby
out
of
its
little
cradle
,
and
nursed
it
.
 
<EOS>
After
that
,
she
cleared
the
dinner
table
;
after
that
,
came
in
with
another
cap
on
,
and
her
work
-
box
,
and
the
yard
-
measure
,
and
the
bit
of
wax
-
candle
,
all
just
the
same
as
ever
.
   
<EOS>
We
sat
round
the
fire
,
and
talked
delightfully
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
them
what
a
hard
master
Mr
Creakle
was
,
and
they
pitied
me
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
them
what
a
fine
fellow
Steerforth
was
,
and
what
a
patron
of
mine
,
and
Peggotty
said
she
would
walk
a
score
of
miles
to
see
him
.
<EOS>
I
took
the
little
baby
in
my
arms
when
it
was
awake
,
and
nursed
it
lovingly
.
 
<EOS>
When
it
was
asleep
again
,
I
crept
close
to
my
mother
's
side
according
to
my
old
custom
,
broken
now
a
long
time
,
and
sat
with
my
arms
embracing
her
waist
,
and
my
little
red
cheek
on
her
shoulder
,
and
once
more
felt
her
beautiful
hair
drooping
over
me
---
like
an
angel
's
wing
as
I
used
to
think
,
I
recollect
---
and
was
very
happy
indeed
.
   
<EOS>
While
I
sat
thus
,
looking
at
the
fire
,
and
seeing
pictures
in
the
red
-
hot
coals
,
I
almost
believed
that
I
had
never
been
away
;
that
Mr
and
Miss
Murdstone
were
such
pictures
,
and
would
vanish
when
the
fire
got
low
;
and
that
there
was
nothing
real
in
all
that
I
remembered
,
save
my
mother
,
Peggotty
,
and
I.
   
Peggotty
<EOS>
darned
away
at
a
stocking
as
long
as
she
could
see
,
and
then
sat
with
it
drawn
on
her
left
hand
like
a
glove
,
and
her
needle
in
her
right
,
ready
to
take
another
stitch
whenever
there
was
a
blaze
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
conceive
whose
stockings
they
can
have
been
that
Peggotty
was
always
darning
,
or
where
such
an
unfailing
supply
of
stockings
in
want
of
darning
can
have
come
from
.
 
<EOS>
From
my
earliest
infancy
she
seems
to
have
been
always
employed
in
that
class
of
needlework
,
and
never
by
any
chance
in
any
other
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
,
"
said
Peggotty
,
who
was
sometimes
seized
with
a
fit
of
wondering
on
some
most
unexpected
topic
,
"
what
's
become
of
Davy
's
great
-
aunt
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Lor
,
Peggotty
!
"
observed
my
mother
,
rousing
herself
from
a
reverie
,
"
what
nonsense
you
talk
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
but
I
really
do
wonder
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
can
have
put
such
a
person
in
your
head
?
"
inquired
my
mother
.
<EOS>
"
Is
there
nobody
else
in
the
world
to
come
there
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
how
it
is
,
"
said
Peggotty
,
"
unless
it
's
on
account
of
being
stupid
,
but
my
head
never
can
pick
and
choose
its
people
.
<EOS>
They
come
and
they
go
,
and
they
do
n't
come
and
they
do
n't
go
,
just
as
they
like
.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
what
's
become
of
her
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
absurd
you
are
,
Peggotty
!
"
returned
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
One
would
suppose
you
wanted
a
second
visit
from
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
forbid
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
then
,
do
n't
talk
about
such
uncomfortable
things
,
there
's
a
good
soul
,
"
said
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
Miss
Betsey
is
shut
up
in
her
cottage
by
the
sea
,
no
doubt
,
and
will
remain
there
.
 
<EOS>
At
all
events
,
she
is
not
likely
ever
to
trouble
us
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
mused
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
that
ai
n't
likely
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
---
I
wonder
,
if
she
was
to
die
,
whether
she
'd
leave
Davy
anything
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
gracious
me
,
Peggotty
,
"
returned
my
mother
,
"
what
a
nonsensical
woman
you
are
!
<EOS>
when
you
know
that
she
took
offence
at
the
poor
dear
boy
's
ever
being
born
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
she
would
n't
be
inclined
to
forgive
him
now
,
"
hinted
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
should
she
be
inclined
to
forgive
him
now
?
"
said
my
mother
,
rather
sharply
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
that
he
's
got
a
brother
,
I
mean
,
"
said
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
MY
mother
immediately
began
to
cry
,
and
wondered
how
Peggotty
dared
to
say
such
a
thing
.
   
<EOS>
"
As
if
this
poor
little
innocent
in
its
cradle
had
ever
done
any
harm
to
you
or
anybody
else
,
you
jealous
thing
!
"
said
she
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
had
much
better
go
and
marry
Mr
Barkis
,
the
carrier
.
 
<EOS>
Why
do
n't
you
?
"
   
"
I
should
make
Miss
Murdstone
happy
,
if
I
was
to
,
"
said
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
bad
disposition
you
have
,
Peggotty
!
"
returned
my
mother
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
as
jealous
of
Miss
Murdstone
as
it
is
possible
for
a
ridiculous
creature
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
You
want
to
keep
the
keys
yourself
,
and
give
out
all
the
things
,
I
suppose
?
 
<EOS>
I
should
n't
be
surprised
if
you
did
.
 
<EOS>
When
you
know
that
she
only
does
it
out
of
kindness
and
the
best
intentions
!
 
<EOS>
You
know
she
does
,
Peggotty
---
you
know
it
well
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
muttered
something
to
the
effect
of
"
Bother
the
best
intentions
!
"
<EOS>
and
something
else
to
the
effect
that
there
was
a
little
too
much
of
the
best
intentions
going
on
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
what
you
mean
,
you
cross
thing
,
"
said
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
understand
you
,
Peggotty
,
perfectly
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
I
do
,
and
I
wonder
you
do
n't
colour
up
like
fire
.
 
<EOS>
But
one
point
at
a
time
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
is
the
point
now
,
<EOS>
Peggotty
,
and
you
sha'n't
escape
from
it
.
 
<EOS>
Have
n't
you
heard
her
say
,
over
and
over
again
,
that
she
thinks
I
am
too
thoughtless
and
too
---
a
---
a
---
"
   
"
Pretty
,
"
suggested
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
returned
my
mother
,
half
