,
"
and
if
she
is
so
silly
as
to
say
so
,
can
I
be
blamed
for
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
one
says
you
can
,
"
said
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
I
should
hope
not
,
indeed
!
"
returned
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
n't
you
heard
her
say
,
over
and
over
again
,
that
on
this
account
she
wished
to
spare
me
a
great
deal
of
trouble
,
which
she
thinks
I
am
not
suited
for
,
and
which
I
really
do
n't
know
myself
that
I
AM
suited
for
;
and
is
n't
she
up
early
and
late
,
and
going
to
and
fro
continually
---
and
does
n't
she
do
all
sorts
of
things
,
and
grope
into
all
sorts
of
places
,
coal
-
holes
and
pantries
<EOS>
and
I
do
n't
know
where
,
that
ca
n't
be
very
agreeable
---
and
do
you
mean
to
insinuate
that
there
is
not
a
sort
of
devotion
in
that
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
insinuate
at
all
,
"
said
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
,
Peggotty
,
"
returned
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
never
do
anything
else
,
except
your
work
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
always
insinuating
.
 
<EOS>
You
revel
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
you
talk
of
Mr
Murdstone
's
good
intentions
---
"
   
"
I
never
talked
of
'
em
,
"
said
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Peggotty
,
"
returned
my
mother
,
"
but
you
insinuated
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
what
I
told
you
just
now
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
worst
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
WILL
insinuate
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
,
at
the
moment
,
that
I
understood
you
,
and
you
see
I
did
.
 
<EOS>
When
you
talk
of
Mr
Murdstone
's
good
intentions
,
and
pretend
to
slight
them
(
for
I
do
n't
believe
you
really
do
,
in
your
heart
,
Peggotty
)
,
you
must
be
as
well
convinced
as
I
am
how
good
they
are
,
and
how
they
actuate
him
in
everything
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
seems
to
have
been
at
all
stern
with
a
certain
person
,
Peggotty
---
you
understand
,
and
so
I
am
sure
does
Davy
,
that
I
am
not
alluding
to
anybody
present
---
it
is
solely
because
he
is
satisfied
that
it
is
for
a
certain
person
's
benefit
.
 
<EOS>
He
naturally
loves
a
certain
person
,
on
my
account
;
and
acts
solely
for
a
certain
person
's
good
.
<EOS>
He
is
better
able
to
judge
of
it
than
I
am
;
for
I
very
well
know
that
I
am
a
weak
,
light
,
girlish
creature
,
and
that
he
is
a
firm
,
grave
,
serious
man
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
takes
,
"
said
my
mother
,
with
the
tears
which
were
engendered
in
her
affectionate
nature
,
stealing
down
her
face
,
"
he
takes
great
pains
with
me
;
and
I
ought
to
be
very
thankful
to
him
,
and
very
submissive
to
him
even
in
my
thoughts
;
and
when
I
am
not
,
Peggotty
,
I
worry
and
condemn
myself
,
and
feel
doubtful
of
my
own
heart
,
and
do
n't
know
what
to
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
sat
with
her
chin
on
the
foot
of
the
stocking
,
looking
silently
at
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
,
Peggotty
,
"
said
my
mother
,
changing
her
tone
,
"
do
n't
let
us
fall
out
with
one
another
,
for
I
could
n't
bear
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
my
true
friend
,
I
know
,
if
I
have
any
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
call
you
a
ridiculous
creature
,
or
a
vexatious
thing
,
or
anything
of
that
sort
,
Peggotty
<EOS>
,
I
only
mean
that
you
are
my
true
friend
,
and
always
have
been
,
ever
since
the
night
when
Mr
Copperfield
first
brought
me
home
here
,
and
you
came
out
to
the
gate
to
meet
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
was
not
slow
to
respond
,
and
ratify
the
treaty
of
friendship
by
giving
me
one
of
her
best
hugs
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
had
some
glimpses
of
the
real
character
of
this
conversation
at
the
time
;
but
I
am
sure
,
now
,
that
the
good
creature
originated
it
,
and
took
her
part
in
it
,
merely
that
my
mother
might
comfort
herself
with
the
little
contradictory
summary
in
which
she
had
indulged
.
 
<EOS>
The
design
was
efficacious
;
for
I
remember
that
my
mother
seemed
more
at
ease
during
the
rest
of
the
evening
,
and
that
Peggotty
observed
her
less
.
   
<EOS>
When
we
had
had
our
tea
,
and
the
ashes
were
thrown
up
,
and
the
candles
snuffed
<EOS>
,
I
read
Peggotty
a
chapter
out
of
the
Crocodile
Book
,
in
remembrance
of
old
times
---
she
took
it
out
of
her
pocket
:
I
do
n't
know
whether
she
had
kept
it
there
ever
since
---
<EOS>
and
then
we
talked
about
Salem
House
,
which
brought
me
round
again
to
Steerforth
,
who
was
my
great
subject
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
very
happy
;
and
that
evening
,
as
the
last
of
its
race
,
and
destined
evermore
to
close
that
volume
of
my
life
,
will
never
pass
out
of
my
memory
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
almost
ten
o'clock
before
we
heard
the
sound
of
wheels
.
 
<EOS>
We
all
got
up
then
;
and
my
mother
said
hurriedly
that
,
as
it
was
so
late
,
and
Mr
and
Miss
Murdstone
approved
of
early
hours
for
young
people
,
perhaps
I
had
better
go
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
I
kissed
her
,
and
went
upstairs
with
my
candle
directly
,
before
they
came
in
.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
my
childish
fancy
,
as
I
ascended
to
the
bedroom
where
I
had
been
imprisoned
,
that
they
brought
a
cold
blast
of
air
into
the
house
which
blew
away
the
old
familiar
feeling
like
a
feather
.
   
<EOS>
I
felt
uncomfortable
about
going
down
to
breakfast
in
the
morning
,
as
I
had
never
set
eyes
on
Mr
Murdstone
since
the
day
when
I
committed
my
memorable
offence
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
as
it
must
be
done
,
I
went
down
,
after
two
or
three
false
starts
half
-
way
,
and
as
many
runs
back
on
tiptoe
to
my
own
room
,
and
presented
myself
in
the
parlour
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
standing
before
the
fire
with
his
back
to
it
,
while
Miss
Murdstone
made
the
tea
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
at
me
steadily
as
I
entered
,
but
made
no
sign
of
recognition
whatever
.
<EOS>
I
went
up
to
him
,
after
a
moment
of
confusion
,
and
said
:
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
sorry
for
what
I
did
,
and
I
hope
you
will
forgive
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
hear
you
are
sorry
,
David
,
"
he
replied
.
   
<EOS>
The
hand
he
gave
me
was
the
hand
I
had
bitten
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
restrain
my
eye
from
resting
for
an
instant
on
a
red
spot
upon
it
;
but
it
was
not
so
red
as
I
turned
,
when
I
met
that
sinister
expression
in
his
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
,
ma'am
?
<EOS>
"
I
said
to
Miss
Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
dear
me
!
"
sighed
Miss
Murdstone
,
giving
me
the
tea
-
caddy
scoop
instead
of
her
fingers
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
long
are
the
holidays
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
month
,
ma'am
.
"
   
"
Counting
from
when
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
From
today
,
ma'am
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
here
's
one
day
off
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
kept
a
calendar
of
the
holidays
in
this
way
,
and
every
morning
checked
a
day
off
in
exactly
the
same
manner
.
 
<EOS>
She
did
it
gloomily
until
she
came
to
ten
,
but
when
she
got
into
two
figures
she
became
more
hopeful
,
and
,
as
the
time
advanced
,
even
jocular
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
on
this
very
first
day
that
I
had
the
misfortune
to
throw
her
,
though
she
was
not
subject
to
such
weakness
in
general
,
into
a
state
of
violent
consternation
.
 
<EOS>
I
came
into
the
room
where
she
and
my
mother
were
sitting
;
and
the
baby
(
who
was
only
a
few
weeks
old
)
being
on
my
mother
's
lap
<EOS>
,
I
took
it
very
carefully
in
my
arms
.
<EOS>
Suddenly
Miss
Murdstone
gave
such
a
scream
that
I
all
but
dropped
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Jane
!
"
cried
my
mother
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
heavens
,
Clara
,
do
you
see
?
"
exclaimed
Miss
Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
"
See
what
,
my
dear
Jane
?
"
said
my
mother
;
"
where
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
got
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Miss
Murdstone
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
boy
has
got
the
baby
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
limp
with
horror
;
but
stiffened
herself
to
make
a
dart
at
me
,
and
take
it
out
of
my
arms
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
she
turned
faint
;
and
was
so
very
ill
that
they
were
obliged
to
give
her
cherry
brandy
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
solemnly
interdicted
by
her
,
on
her
recovery
,
from
touching
my
brother
any
more
on
any
pretence
whatever
;
and
my
poor
mother
,
who
,
I
could
see
,
wished
otherwise
,
meekly
confirmed
the
interdict
,
by
saying
:
"
No
doubt
you
are
right
,
my
dear
Jane
.
"
   
<EOS>
On
another
occasion
,
when
we
three
were
together
,
this
same
dear
baby
---
it
was
truly
dear
to
me
,
for
our
mother
's
sake
---
<EOS>
was
the
innocent
occasion
of
Miss
Murdstone
's
going
into
a
passion
.
 
<EOS>
My
mother
,
who
had
been
looking
at
its
eyes
as
it
lay
upon
her
lap
,
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Davy
!
come
here
!
"
and
looked
at
mine
.
   
<EOS>
I
saw
Miss
Murdstone
lay
her
beads
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
declare
,
"
said
my
mother
,
gently
,
"
they
are
exactly
alike
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
they
are
mine
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
they
are
the
colour
of
mine
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
are
wonderfully
alike
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
talking
about
,
Clara
?
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Jane
,
"
faltered
my
mother
,
a
little
abashed
by
the
harsh
tone
of
this
inquiry
,
"
I
find
that
the
baby
's
eyes
and
Davy
's
are
exactly
alike
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Clara
!
<EOS>
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
,
rising
angrily
,
"
you
are
a
positive
fool
sometimes
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Jane
,
"
remonstrated
my
mother
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
positive
fool
,
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
else
could
compare
my
brother
's
baby
with
your
boy
?
 
<EOS>
They
are
not
at
all
alike
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
exactly
unlike
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
utterly
dissimilar
in
all
respects
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
they
will
ever
remain
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
sit
here
,
and
hear
such
comparisons
made
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
that
she
stalked
out
,
and
made
the
door
bang
after
her
.
   
<EOS>
In
short
,
I
was
not
a
favourite
with
Miss
Murdstone
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
I
was
not
a
favourite
there
with
anybody
,
not
even
with
myself
;
for
those
who
did
like
me
could
not
show
it
,
and
those
who
did
not
,
showed
it
so
plainly
that
I
had
a
sensitive
consciousness
of
always
appearing
constrained
,
boorish
,
and
dull
.
   
<EOS>
I
felt
that
I
made
them
as
uncomfortable
as
they
made
me
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
came
into
the
room
where
they
were
,
and
they
were
talking
together
and
my
mother
seemed
cheerful
,
an
anxious
cloud
would
steal
over
her
face
from
the
moment
of
my
entrance
.
 
<EOS>
If
Mr
Murdstone
were
in
his
best
humour
,
I
checked
him
.
 
<EOS>
If
Miss
Murdstone
were
in
her
worst
,
I
intensified
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
perception
enough
to
know
that
my
mother
was
the
victim
always
;
that
she
was
afraid
to
speak
to
me
or
to
be
kind
to
me
,
lest
she
should
give
them
some
offence
by
her
manner
of
doing
so
,
and
receive
a
lecture
afterwards
;
that
she
was
not
only
ceaselessly
afraid
of
her
own
offending
,
but
of
my
offending
,
and
uneasily
watched
their
looks
if
I
only
moved
.
<EOS>
Therefore
I
resolved
to
keep
myself
as
much
out
of
their
way
as
I
could
;
and
many
a
wintry
hour
<EOS>
did
I
hear
the
church
clock
strike
,
when
I
was
sitting
in
my
cheerless
bedroom
,
wrapped
in
my
little
great
-
coat
,
poring
over
a
book
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
evening
,
sometimes
,
I
went
and
sat
with
Peggotty
in
the
kitchen
.
 
<EOS>
There
I
was
comfortable
,
and
not
afraid
of
being
myself
.
<EOS>
But
neither
of
these
resources
was
approved
of
in
the
parlour
.
 
<EOS>
The
tormenting
humour
which
was
dominant
there
stopped
them
both
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
still
held
to
be
necessary
to
my
poor
mother
's
training
,
and
,
as
one
of
her
trials
,
could
not
be
suffered
to
absent
myself
.
   
<EOS>
"
David
,
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
,
one
day
after
dinner
when
I
was
going
to
leave
the
room
as
usual
;
"
I
am
sorry
to
observe
that
you
are
of
a
sullen
disposition
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
sulky
as
a
bear
!
<EOS>
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
I
stood
still
,
and
hung
my
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
David
,
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
,
"
<EOS>
a
sullen
obdurate
disposition
is
,
of
all
tempers
,
the
worst
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
the
boy
's
is
,
of
all
such
dispositions
that
ever
I
have
seen
,
"
remarked
his
sister
,
"
the
most
confirmed
and
stubborn
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
,
my
dear
Clara
,
even
you
must
observe
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
my
dear
Jane
,
"
said
my
mother
,
"
but
are
you
quite
sure
---
<EOS>
I
am
certain
you
'll
excuse
me
,
<EOS>
my
dear
Jane
---
that
you
understand
Davy
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
somewhat
ashamed
of
myself
,
Clara
,
"
returned
Miss
Murdstone
,
"
if
I
could
not
understand
the
boy
,
or
any
boy
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
profess
to
be
profound
;
but
I
do
lay
claim
to
common
sense
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
,
my
dear
Jane
,
"
returned
my
mother
,
"
your
understanding
is
very
vigorous
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
,
no
!
 
<EOS>
Pray
do
n't
say
that
,
Clara
,
"
interposed
Miss
Murdstone
,
angrily
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
sure
it
is
,
"
resumed
my
mother
;
"
and
everybody
knows
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
profit
so
much
by
it
myself
,
in
many
ways
---
at
least
I
ought
to
---
that
no
one
can
be
more
convinced
of
it
than
myself
;
and
therefore
I
speak
with
great
diffidence
,
my
dear
Jane
,
I
assure
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
'll
say
I
do
n't
understand
the
boy
,
Clara
,
"
returned
Miss
Murdstone
,
arranging
the
little
fetters
on
her
wrists
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
'll
agree
,
if
you
please
,
that
I
do
n't
understand
him
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
much
too
deep
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
perhaps
my
brother
's
penetration
may
enable
him
to
have
some
insight
into
his
character
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
believe
my
brother
was
speaking
on
the
subject
when
we
---
not
very
decently
---
interrupted
him
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
Clara
,
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
,
in
a
low
grave
voice
,
"
that
there
may
be
better
and
more
dispassionate
judges
of
such
a
question
than
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Edward
,
"
replied
my
mother
,
timidly
,
"
you
are
a
far
better
judge
of
all
questions
than
I
pretend
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
Both
you
and
Jane
are
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
said
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
You
only
said
something
weak
and
inconsiderate
,
"
he
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
Try
not
to
do
it
again
,
my
dear
Clara
,
and
keep
a
watch
upon
yourself
.
"
   
<EOS>
MY
mother
's
lips
moved
,
as
if
she
answered
"
Yes
,
my
dear
Edward
,
"
but
she
said
nothing
aloud
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
sorry
,
David
,
I
remarked
,
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
,
turning
his
head
and
his
eyes
stiffly
towards
me
,
"
to
observe
that
you
are
of
a
sullen
disposition
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
not
a
character
that
I
can
suffer
to
develop
itself
beneath
my
eyes
without
an
effort
at
improvement
.
<EOS>
You
must
endeavour
,
sir
,
to
change
it
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
endeavour
to
change
it
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
,
"
I
faltered
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
meant
to
be
sullen
since
I
came
back
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
take
refuge
in
a
lie
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
he
returned
so
fiercely
,
that
I
saw
my
mother
involuntarily
put
out
her
trembling
hand
as
if
to
interpose
between
us
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
withdrawn
yourself
in
your
sullenness
to
your
own
room
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
kept
your
own
room
when
you
ought
to
have
been
here
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
now
,
once
for
all
,
that
I
require
you
to
be
here
,
and
not
there
.
 
<EOS>
Further
,
that
I
require
you
to
bring
obedience
here
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
me
,
David
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
have
it
done
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
gave
a
hoarse
chuckle
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
have
a
respectful
,
prompt
,
and
ready
bearing
towards
myself
,
"
he
continued
,
"
and
towards
Jane
Murdstone
,
and
towards
your
mother
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
have
this
room
shunned
as
if
it
were
infected
,
at
the
pleasure
of
a
child
.
 
<EOS>
Sit
down
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
ordered
me
like
a
dog
,
and
I
obeyed
like
a
dog
.
   
<EOS>
"
One
thing
more
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
observe
that
you
have
an
attachment
to
low
and
common
company
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
not
to
associate
with
servants
.
<EOS>
The
kitchen
will
not
improve
you
,
in
the
many
respects
in
which
you
need
improvement
.
 
<EOS>
Of
the
woman
who
abets
you
,
I
say
nothing
---
since
you
,
Clara
,
"
addressing
my
mother
in
a
lower
voice
,
"
from
old
associations
and
long
-
established
fancies
,
have
a
weakness
respecting
her
which
is
not
yet
overcome
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
most
unaccountable
delusion
it
is
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Miss
Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
only
say
,
"
he
resumed
,
addressing
me
,
"
that
I
disapprove
of
your
preferring
such
company
as
Mistress
Peggotty
,
and
that
it
is
to
be
abandoned
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
David
,
you
understand
me
,
and
you
know
what
will
be
the
consequence
if
you
fail
to
obey
me
to
the
letter
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
knew
well
---
better
perhaps
than
he
thought
,
as
far
as
my
poor
mother
was
concerned
---
<EOS>
and
I
obeyed
him
to
the
letter
.
 
<EOS>
I
retreated
to
my
own
room
no
more
;
I
took
refuge
with
Peggotty
no
more
;
but
sat
wearily
in
the
parlour
day
after
day
,
looking
forward
to
night
,
and
bedtime
.
   
<EOS>
What
irksome
constraint
I
underwent
,
sitting
in
the
same
attitude
hours
upon
hours
,
afraid
to
move
an
arm
or
a
leg
lest
Miss
Murdstone
should
complain
(
as
she
did
on
the
least
pretence
)
of
my
restlessness
,
and
afraid
to
move
an
eye
lest
she
should
light
on
some
look
of
dislike
or
scrutiny
that
would
find
new
cause
for
complaint
in
mine
!
 
<EOS>
What
intolerable
dulness
to
sit
listening
to
the
ticking
of
the
clock
;
and
watching
Miss
Murdstone
's
little
shiny
steel
beads
as
she
strung
them
;
and
wondering
whether
she
would
ever
be
married
,
and
if
so
,
to
what
sort
of
unhappy
man
;
and
counting
the
divisions
in
the
moulding
of
the
chimney
-
piece
;
and
wandering
away
,
with
my
eyes
,
to
the
ceiling
,
among
the
curls
and
corkscrews
in
the
paper
on
the
wall
!
   
<EOS>
What
walks
I
took
alone
,
down
muddy
lanes
,
in
the
bad
winter
weather
,
carrying
that
parlour
,
and
Mr
and
Miss
Murdstone
in
it
,
everywhere
:
a
monstrous
load
that
I
was
obliged
to
bear
,
a
daymare
that
there
was
no
possibility
of
breaking
in
,
a
weight
that
brooded
on
my
wits
,
and
blunted
them
!
   
<EOS>
What
meals
I
had
in
silence
and
embarrassment
,
always
feeling
that
there
were
a
knife
and
fork
too
many
,
and
that
mine
;
an
appetite
too
many
,
and
that
mine
;
a
plate
and
chair
too
many
,
and
those
mine
;
a
somebody
too
many
,
and
that
<EOS>
I
!
   
<EOS>
What
evenings
,
when
the
candles
came
,
and
I
was
expected
to
employ
myself
,
but
,
not
daring
to
read
an
entertaining
book
,
pored
over
some
hard
-
headed
,
harder
-
hearted
treatise
on
arithmetic
;
when
the
tables
of
weights
and
measures
set
themselves
to
tunes
,
as
"
Rule
Britannia
"
,
or
"
Away
with
Melancholy
"
;
when
they
would
n't
stand
still
to
be
learnt
,
but
would
go
threading
my
grandmother
's
needle
through
my
unfortunate
head
,
in
at
one
ear
and
out
at
the
other
!
<EOS>
What
yawns
and
dozes
I
lapsed
into
,
in
spite
of
all
my
care
;
what
starts
I
came
out
of
concealed
sleeps
with
;
what
answers
I
never
got
,
to
little
observations
that
I
rarely
made
;
what
a
blank
space
I
seemed
,
which
everybody
overlooked
,
and
yet
was
in
everybody
's
way
;
what
a
heavy
relief
it
was
to
hear
Miss
Murdstone
hail
the
first
stroke
of
nine
at
night
,
and
order
me
to
bed
!
   
<EOS>
Thus
the
holidays
lagged
away
,
until
the
morning
came
when
Miss
Murdstone
said
:
"
Here
's
the
last
day
off
!
"
and
gave
me
the
closing
cup
of
tea
of
the
vacation
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
not
sorry
to
go
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
lapsed
into
a
stupid
state
;
but
I
was
recovering
a
little
and
looking
forward
to
Steerforth
,
albeit
Mr
Creakle
loomed
behind
him
.
 
<EOS>
Again
Mr
Barkis
appeared
at
the
gate
,
and
again
Miss
Murdstone
in
her
warning
voice
,
said
:
"
Clara
!
"
<EOS>
when
my
mother
bent
over
me
,
to
bid
me
farewell
.
   
<EOS>
I
kissed
her
,
and
my
baby
brother
,
and
was
very
sorry
then
;
but
not
sorry
to
go
away
,
for
the
gulf
between
us
was
there
,
and
the
parting
was
there
,
every
day
.
 
<EOS>
And
it
is
not
so
much
the
embrace
she
gave
me
,
that
lives
in
my
mind
,
though
it
was
as
fervent
as
could
be
,
as
what
followed
the
embrace
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
in
the
carrier
's
cart
when
I
heard
her
calling
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
looked
out
,
and
she
stood
at
the
garden
-
gate
alone
,
holding
her
baby
up
in
her
arms
for
me
to
see
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
cold
still
weather
;
and
not
a
hair
of
her
head
,
nor
a
fold
of
her
dress
,
was
stirred
,
as
she
looked
intently
at
me
,
holding
up
her
child
.
   
<EOS>
So
I
lost
her
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
saw
her
afterwards
,
in
my
sleep
at
school
---
<EOS>
a
silent
presence
near
my
bed
---
looking
at
me
with
the
same
intent
face
---
holding
up
her
baby
in
her
arms
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
9
.
<EOS>
I
have
a
memorable
birthday
 
<EOS>
I
PASS
over
all
that
happened
at
school
,
until
the
anniversary
of
my
birthday
came
round
in
March
.
 
<EOS>
Except
that
Steerforth
was
more
to
be
admired
than
ever
,
I
remember
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
going
away
at
the
end
of
the
half
-
year
,
if
not
sooner
,
and
was
more
spirited
and
independent
than
before
in
my
eyes
,
and
therefore
more
engaging
than
before
;
but
beyond
this
I
remember
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
The
great
remembrance
by
which
that
time
is
marked
in
my
mind
,
seems
to
have
swallowed
up
all
lesser
recollections
,
and
to
exist
alone
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
even
difficult
for
me
to
believe
that
there
was
a
gap
of
full
two
months
between
my
return
to
Salem
House
and
the
arrival
of
that
birthday
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
only
understand
that
the
fact
was
so
,
because
I
know
it
must
have
been
so
;
otherwise
I
should
feel
convinced
that
there
was
no
interval
,
and
that
the
one
occasion
trod
upon
the
other
's
heels
.
   
<EOS>
How
well
I
recollect
the
kind
of
day
it
was
!
 
<EOS>
I
smell
the
fog
that
hung
about
the
place
;
I
see
the
hoar
frost
,
ghostly
,
through
it
;
I
feel
my
rimy
hair
fall
clammy
on
my
cheek
;
I
look
along
the
dim
perspective
of
the
schoolroom
,
with
a
sputtering
candle
here
and
there
to
light
up
the
foggy
morning
,
and
the
breath
of
the
boys
wreathing
and
smoking
in
the
raw
cold
as
they
blow
upon
their
fingers
,
and
tap
their
feet
upon
the
floor
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
after
breakfast
,
and
we
had
been
summoned
in
from
the
playground
,
when
Mr
Sharp
entered
and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
David
Copperfield
is
to
go
into
the
parlour
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
expected
a
hamper
from
Peggotty
,
and
brightened
at
the
order
.
<EOS>
Some
of
the
boys
about
me
put
in
their
claim
not
to
be
forgotten
in
the
distribution
of
the
good
things
,
as
I
got
out
of
my
seat
with
great
alacrity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
hurry
,
David
,
"
said
Mr
Sharp
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
time
enough
,
my
boy
,
do
n't
hurry
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
might
have
been
surprised
by
the
feeling
tone
in
which
he
spoke
,
if
I
had
given
it
a
thought
;
but
I
gave
it
none
until
afterwards
.
<EOS>
I
hurried
away
to
the
parlour
;
and
there
I
found
Mr
Creakle
,
sitting
at
his
breakfast
with
the
cane
and
a
newspaper
before
him
,
and
Mrs
Creakle
with
an
opened
letter
in
her
hand
.
 
<EOS>
But
no
hamper
.
   
<EOS>
"
David
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mrs
Creakle
,
leading
me
to
a
sofa
,
and
sitting
down
beside
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
speak
to
you
very
particularly
.
<EOS>
I
have
something
to
tell
you
,
my
child
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Creakle
,
at
whom
of
course
I
looked
,
shook
his
head
without
looking
at
me
,
and
stopped
up
a
sigh
with
a
very
large
piece
of
buttered
toast
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
too
young
to
know
how
the
world
changes
every
day
,
"
said
Mrs
Creakle
,
"
and
how
the
people
in
it
pass
away
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
all
have
to
learn
it
,
David
;
some
of
us
when
we
are
young
,
some
of
us
when
we
are
old
,
some
of
us
at
all
times
of
our
lives
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
looked
at
her
earnestly
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
you
came
away
from
home
at
the
end
of
the
vacation
,
"
said
Mrs
Creakle
,
after
a
pause
,
"
were
they
all
well
?
"
 
<EOS>
After
another
pause
,
"
Was
your
mama
well
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
trembled
without
distinctly
knowing
why
,
and
still
looked
at
her
earnestly
,
making
no
attempt
to
answer
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Because
,
"
said
she
,
"
I
grieve
to
tell
you
that
I
hear
this
morning
your
mama
is
very
ill
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
mist
rose
between
Mrs
Creakle
and
me
,
and
her
figure
seemed
to
move
in
it
for
an
instant
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
felt
the
burning
tears
run
down
my
face
,
and
it
was
steady
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
very
dangerously
ill
,
"
she
added
.
   
<EOS>
I
knew
all
now
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
dead
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
no
need
to
tell
me
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
already
broken
out
into
a
desolate
cry
,
and
felt
an
orphan
in
the
wide
world
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
very
kind
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
She
kept
me
there
all
day
,
and
left
me
alone
sometimes
;
and
I
cried
,
and
wore
myself
to
sleep
,
and
awoke
and
cried
again
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
could
cry
no
more
,
I
began
to
think
;
and
then
the
oppression
on
my
breast
was
heaviest
,
and
my
grief
a
dull
pain
that
there
was
no
ease
for
.
   
<EOS>
And
yet
my
thoughts
were
idle
;
not
intent
on
the
calamity
that
weighed
upon
my
heart
,
but
idly
loitering
near
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
of
our
house
shut
up
and
hushed
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
of
the
little
baby
,
who
,
Mrs
Creakle
said
,
had
been
pining
away
for
some
time
,
and
who
,
they
believed
,
would
die
too
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
of
my
father
's
grave
in
the
churchyard
,
by
our
house
,
and
of
my
mother
lying
there
beneath
the
tree
I
knew
so
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
stood
upon
a
chair
when
I
was
left
alone
,
and
looked
into
the
glass
to
see
how
red
my
eyes
were
,
and
how
sorrowful
my
face
.
 
<EOS>
I
considered
,
after
some
hours
were
gone
,
<EOS>
if
my
tears
were
really
hard
to
flow
now
,
as
they
seemed
to
be
,
what
,
in
connexion
with
my
loss
,
it
would
affect
me
most
to
think
of
when
I
drew
near
home
---
for
I
was
going
home
to
the
funeral
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sensible
of
having
felt
that
a
dignity
attached
to
me
among
the
rest
of
the
boys
,
and
that
I
was
important
in
my
affliction
.
   
<EOS>
If
ever
child
were
stricken
with
sincere
grief
,
I
was
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
remember
that
this
importance
was
a
kind
of
satisfaction
to
me
,
when
I
walked
in
the
playground
that
afternoon
while
the
boys
were
in
school
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
saw
them
glancing
at
me
out
of
the
windows
,
as
they
went
up
to
their
classes
,
I
felt
distinguished
,
and
looked
more
melancholy
,
and
walked
slower
.
 
<EOS>
When
school
was
over
,
and
they
came
out
and
spoke
to
me
,
I
felt
it
rather
good
in
myself
not
to
be
proud
to
any
of
them
,
and
to
take
exactly
the
same
notice
of
them
all
,
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
to
go
home
next
night
;
not
by
the
mail
,
but
by
the
heavy
night
-
coach
,
which
was
called
the
Farmer
,
and
was
principally
used
by
country
-
people
travelling
short
intermediate
distances
upon
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
no
story
<EOS>
-
telling
that
evening
,
and
Traddles
insisted
on
lending
me
his
pillow
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
<EOS>
what
good
he
thought
it
would
do
me
,
for
I
had
one
of
my
own
:
<EOS>
but
it
was
all
he
had
to
lend
,
poor
fellow
,
except
a
sheet
of
letter
-
paper
full
of
skeletons
;
and
that
he
gave
me
at
parting
,
as
a
soother
of
my
sorrows
and
a
contribution
to
my
peace
of
mind
.
   
<EOS>
I
left
Salem
House
upon
the
morrow
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
I
little
thought
then
that
I
left
it
,
never
to
return
.
 
<EOS>
We
travelled
very
slowly
all
night
,
and
did
not
get
into
Yarmouth
before
nine
or
ten
o'clock
in
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
looked
out
for
Mr
Barkis
,
but
he
was
not
there
;
and
instead
of
him
a
fat
,
short
-
winded
,
merry
-
looking
,
little
old
man
in
black
,
with
rusty
little
bunches
of
ribbons
at
the
knees
of
his
breeches
,
black
stockings
,
and
a
broad
-
brimmed
hat
,
came
puffing
up
to
the
coach
window
,
and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Master
Copperfield
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
come
with
me
,
young
sir
,
if
you
please
,
"
he
said
,
opening
the
door
,
"
and
I
shall
have
the
pleasure
of
taking
you
home
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
put
my
hand
in
his
,
wondering
who
he
was
,
and
we
walked
away
to
a
shop
in
a
narrow
street
,
on
which
was
written
OMER
,
DRAPER
,
TAILOR
,
HABERDASHER
,
FUNERAL
FURNISHER
,
&
c.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
close
and
stifling
little
shop
;
full
of
all
sorts
of
clothing
,
made
and
unmade
,
including
one
window
full
of
beaver
-
hats
and
bonnets
.
 
<EOS>
We
went
into
a
little
back
-
parlour
behind
the
shop
,
where
we
found
three
young
women
at
work
on
a
quantity
of
black
materials
,
which
were
heaped
upon
the
table
,
and
little
bits
and
cuttings
of
which
were
littered
all
over
the
floor
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
good
fire
in
the
room
,
and
a
breathless
smell
of
warm
black
crape
---
<EOS>
I
did
not
know
what
the
smell
was
then
,
but
I
know
now
.
   
<EOS>
The
three
young
women
,
who
appeared
to
be
very
industrious
and
comfortable
,
raised
their
heads
to
look
at
me
,
and
then
went
on
with
their
work
.
 
<EOS>
Stitch
,
stitch
,
stitch
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
there
came
from
a
workshop
across
a
little
yard
outside
the
window
,
a
regular
sound
of
hammering
that
kept
a
kind
of
tune
:
RAT
---
tat
-
tat
,
RAT
---
tat
-
tat
,
RAT
---
tat
-
tat
,
without
any
variation
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
my
conductor
to
one
of
the
three
young
women
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
get
on
,
Minnie
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
shall
be
ready
by
the
trying
-
on
time
,
"
she
replied
gaily
,
without
looking
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
be
afraid
,
father
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Omer
took
off
his
broad
-
brimmed
hat
,
and
sat
down
and
panted
.
<EOS>
He
was
so
fat
that
he
was
obliged
to
pant
some
time
before
he
could
say
:
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Father
!
<EOS>
"
said
Minnie
,
playfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
porpoise
you
do
grow
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
do
n't
know
how
it
is
,
my
dear
,
"
he
replied
,
considering
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
rather
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
such
a
comfortable
man
,
you
see
,
"
said
Minnie
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
take
things
so
easy
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
use
taking
'em
otherwise
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Omer
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
indeed
,
"
returned
his
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
are
all
pretty
gay
here
,
thank
Heaven
!
 
<EOS>
Ai
n't
we
,
father
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
so
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Omer
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
I
have
got
my
breath
now
,
I
think
I
'll
measure
this
young
scholar
.
 
<EOS>
Would
you
walk
into
the
shop
,
Master
Copperfield
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
preceded
Mr
Omer
,
in
compliance
with
his
request
;
and
after
showing
me
a
roll
of
cloth
which
he
said
was
extra
super
,
and
too
good
mourning
for
anything
short
of
parents
,
he
took
my
various
dimensions
,
and
put
them
down
in
a
book
.
 
<EOS>
While
he
was
recording
them
he
called
my
attention
to
his
stock
in
trade
,
and
to
certain
fashions
which
he
said
had
"
just
come
up
"
,
and
to
certain
other
fashions
which
he
said
had
"
just
gone
out
"
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
by
that
sort
of
thing
we
very
often
lose
a
little
mint
of
money
,
"
said
Mr
Omer
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
fashions
are
like
human
beings
.
 
<EOS>
They
come
in
,
nobody
knows
when
,
why
,
or
how
;
and
they
go
out
,
nobody
knows
when
,
why
,
or
how
.
 
<EOS>
Everything
is
like
life
,
in
my
opinion
,
if
you
look
at
it
in
that
point
of
view
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
too
sorrowful
to
discuss
the
question
,
which
would
possibly
have
been
beyond
me
under
any
circumstances
;
and
Mr
Omer
took
me
back
into
the
parlour
,
breathing
with
some
difficulty
on
the
way
.
   
<EOS>
He
then
called
down
a
little
break
-
neck
range
of
steps
behind
a
door
:
"
Bring
up
that
tea
and
bread
-
and
-
butter
!
"
<EOS>
which
,
after
some
time
,
during
which
I
sat
looking
about
me
and
thinking
,
and
listening
to
the
stitching
in
the
room
and
the
tune
that
was
being
hammered
across
the
yard
,
appeared
on
a
tray
,
and
turned
out
to
be
for
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
acquainted
with
you
,
"
said
Mr
Omer
,
after
watching
me
for
some
minutes
,
during
which
I
had
not
made
much
impression
on
the
breakfast
,
for
the
black
things
destroyed
my
appetite
,
"
I
have
been
acquainted
with
you
a
long
time
,
my
young
friend
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Have
you
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
your
life
,
"
said
Mr
Omer
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
may
say
before
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
your
father
before
you
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
five
foot
nine
and
a
half
,
and
he
lays
in
five
-
and
-
twen
-
ty
foot
of
ground
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
RAT
---
tat
-
tat
,
RAT
---
tat
-
tat
,
RAT
---
tat
-
tat
,
"
across
the
yard
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
lays
in
five
and
twen
-
ty
foot
of
ground
,
if
he
lays
in
a
fraction
,
"
said
Mr
Omer
,
pleasantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
either
his
request
or
her
direction
,
I
forget
which
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
how
my
little
brother
is
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
I
inquired
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Omer
shook
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
RAT
---
tat
-
tat
,
RAT
---
tat
-
tat
,
RAT
---
tat
-
tat
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
in
his
mother
's
arms
,
"
said
he
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
poor
little
fellow
!
 
<EOS>
Is
he
dead
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
mind
it
more
than
you
can
help
,
"
said
Mr
Omer
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
The
baby
's
dead
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
wounds
broke
out
afresh
at
this
intelligence
.
 
<EOS>
I
left
the
scarcely
-
tasted
breakfast
,
and
went
and
rested
my
head
on
another
table
,
in
a
corner
of
the
little
room
,
which
Minnie
hastily
cleared
,
lest
I
should
spot
the
mourning
that
was
lying
there
with
my
tears
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
a
pretty
,
good
-
natured
girl
,
and
put
my
hair
away
from
my
eyes
with
a
soft
,
kind
touch
;
but
she
was
very
cheerful
at
having
nearly
finished
her
work
and
being
in
good
time
,
and
was
so
different
from
me
!
   
<EOS>
Presently
the
tune
left
off
,
and
a
good
-
looking
young
fellow
came
across
the
yard
into
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
hammer
in
his
hand
,
and
his
mouth
was
full
of
little
nails
,
which
he
was
obliged
to
take
out
before
he
could
speak
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Joram
!
"
said
Mr
Omer
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
get
on
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
right
,
"
said
Joram
.
 
<EOS>
"
Done
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Minnie
coloured
a
little
,
and
the
other
two
girls
smiled
at
one
another
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
you
were
at
it
by
candle
-
light
last
night
,
when
I
was
at
the
club
,
then
?
 
<EOS>
Were
you
?
"
said
Mr
Omer
,
shutting
up
one
eye
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Joram
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
you
said
we
could
make
a
little
trip
of
it
,
and
go
over
together
,
if
it
was
done
,
Minnie
and
me
---
and
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
I
thought
you
were
going
to
leave
me
out
altogether
,
"
said
Mr
Omer
,
laughing
till
he
coughed
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
---
As
you
was
so
good
as
to
say
that
,
"
resumed
the
young
man
,
"
why
I
turned
to
with
a
will
,
you
see
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
give
me
your
opinion
of
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
"
said
Mr
Omer
,
rising
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
"
;
and
he
stopped
and
turned
to
me
:
"
would
you
like
to
see
your
---
"
   
"
No
,
father
,
"
Minnie
interposed
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
it
might
be
agreeable
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Omer
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
perhaps
you
're
right
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
say
how
I
knew
it
was
my
dear
,
dear
mother
's
coffin
that
they
went
to
look
at
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
never
heard
one
making
;
I
had
never
seen
one
that
I
know
of
:
but
it
came
into
my
mind
what
the
noise
was
,
while
it
was
going
on
;
and
when
the
young
man
entered
,
I
am
sure
I
knew
what
he
had
been
doing
.
   
<EOS>
The
work
being
now
finished
,
the
two
girls
,
whose
names
I
had
not
heard
,
brushed
the
shreds
and
threads
from
their
dresses
,
and
went
into
the
shop
to
put
that
to
rights
,
and
wait
for
customers
.
<EOS>
Minnie
stayed
behind
to
fold
up
what
they
had
made
,
and
pack
it
in
two
baskets
.
 
<EOS>
This
she
did
upon
her
knees
,
humming
a
lively
little
tune
the
while
.
 
<EOS>
Joram
,
who
I
had
no
doubt
was
her
lover
,
came
in
and
stole
a
kiss
from
her
while
she
was
busy
(
he
did
n't
appear
to
mind
me
,
at
all
)
,
and
said
her
father
was
gone
for
the
chaise
,
and
he
must
make
haste
and
get
himself
ready
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
went
out
again
;
and
then
she
put
her
thimble
and
scissors
in
her
pocket
,
and
stuck
a
needle
threaded
with
black
thread
neatly
in
the
bosom
of
her
gown
,
and
put
on
her
outer
clothing
smartly
,
at
a
little
glass
behind
the
door
,
in
which
I
saw
the
reflection
of
her
pleased
face
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
I
observed
,
sitting
at
the
table
in
the
corner
with
my
head
leaning
on
my
hand
,
and
my
thoughts
running
on
very
different
things
.
 
<EOS>
The
chaise
soon
came
round
to
the
front
of
the
shop
,
and
the
baskets
being
put
in
first
,
I
was
put
in
next
,
and
those
three
followed
.
 
<EOS>
I
remember
it
as
a
kind
of
half
chaise
-
cart
,
half
pianoforte
-
van
,
painted
of
a
sombre
colour
,
and
drawn
by
a
black
horse
with
a
long
tail
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
plenty
of
room
for
us
all
.
   
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
I
have
ever
experienced
so
strange
a
feeling
in
my
life
<EOS>
(
I
am
wiser
now
,
perhaps
)
as
that
of
being
with
them
,
remembering
how
they
had
been
employed
,
and
seeing
them
enjoy
the
ride
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
angry
with
them
;
I
was
more
afraid
of
them
,
as
if
I
were
cast
away
among
creatures
with
whom
I
had
no
community
of
nature
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
very
cheerful
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
sat
in
front
to
drive
,
and
the
two
young
people
sat
behind
him
,
and
whenever
he
spoke
to
them
leaned
forward
,
the
one
on
one
side
of
his
chubby
face
and
the
other
on
the
other
,
and
made
a
great
deal
of
him
.
<EOS>
They
would
have
talked
to
me
too
,
but
I
held
back
,
and
moped
in
my
corner
;
scared
by
their
love
-
making
and
hilarity
,
though
it
was
far
from
boisterous
,
and
almost
wondering
that
no
judgement
came
upon
them
for
their
hardness
of
heart
.
   
<EOS>
So
,
when
they
stopped
to
bait
the
horse
,
and
ate
and
drank
and
enjoyed
themselves
,
I
could
touch
nothing
that
they
touched
,
but
kept
my
fast
unbroken
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
when
we
reached
home
,
I
dropped
out
of
the
chaise
behind
,
as
quickly
as
possible
,
that
I
might
not
be
in
their
company
before
those
solemn
windows
,
looking
blindly
on
me
like
closed
eyes
once
bright
.
 
<EOS>
And
oh
,
how
little
need
I
had
had
to
think
what
would
move
me
to
tears
when
I
came
back
---
seeing
the
window
of
my
mother
's
room
,
and
next
it
that
which
,
in
the
better
time
,
was
mine
!
   
<EOS>
I
was
in
Peggotty
's
arms
before
I
got
to
the
door
,
and
she
took
me
into
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
Her
grief
burst
out
when
she
first
saw
me
;
but
she
controlled
it
soon
,
and
spoke
in
whispers
,
and
walked
softly
,
as
if
the
dead
could
be
disturbed
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
not
been
in
bed
,
I
found
,
for
a
long
time
.
 
<EOS>
She
sat
up
at
night
still
,
and
watched
.
 
<EOS>
As
long
as
her
poor
dear
pretty
was
above
the
ground
,
she
said
,
she
would
never
desert
her
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Murdstone
took
no
heed
of
me
when
I
went
into
the
parlour
where
he
was
,
but
sat
by
the
fireside
,
weeping
silently
,
and
pondering
in
his
elbow
-
chair
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
,
who
was
busy
at
her
writing
-
desk
,
which
was
covered
with
letters
and
papers
,
gave
me
her
cold
finger
-
nails
,
and
asked
me
,
in
an
iron
whisper
,
if
I
had
been
measured
for
my
mourning
.
   
<EOS>
I
said
:
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
your
shirts
,
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
;
"
have
you
brought
'em
home
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
ma'am
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
brought
home
all
my
clothes
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
all
the
consolation
that
her
firmness
administered
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
doubt
that
she
had
a
choice
pleasure
in
exhibiting
what
she
called
her
self
-
command
,
and
her
firmness
,
and
her
strength
of
mind
,
and
her
common
sense
,
and
the
whole
diabolical
catalogue
of
her
unamiable
qualities
,
on
such
an
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
particularly
proud
of
her
turn
for
business
;
and
she
showed
it
now
in
reducing
everything
to
pen
and
ink
,
and
being
moved
by
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
rest
of
that
day
,
and
from
morning
to
night
afterwards
<EOS>
,
she
sat
at
that
desk
,
scratching
composedly
with
a
hard
pen
,
speaking
in
the
same
imperturbable
whisper
to
everybody
;
never
relaxing
a
muscle
of
her
face
,
or
softening
a
tone
of
her
voice
,
or
appearing
with
an
atom
of
her
dress
astray
.
   
<EOS>
Her
brother
took
a
book
sometimes
,
but
never
read
it
that
I
saw
.
<EOS>
He
would
open
it
and
look
at
it
as
if
he
were
reading
,
but
would
remain
for
a
whole
hour
without
turning
the
leaf
,
and
then
put
it
down
and
walk
to
and
fro
in
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
I
used
to
sit
with
folded
hands
watching
him
,
and
counting
his
footsteps
,
hour
after
hour
.
<EOS>
He
very
seldom
spoke
to
her
,
and
never
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
be
the
only
restless
thing
,
except
the
clocks
,
in
the
whole
motionless
house
.
   
<EOS>
In
these
days
before
the
funeral
,
I
saw
but
little
of
Peggotty
,
except
that
,
in
passing
up
or
down
stairs
,
I
always
found
her
close
to
the
room
where
my
mother
and
her
baby
lay
,
and
except
that
she
came
to
me
every
night
,
and
sat
by
my
bed
's
head
while
I
went
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
A
day
or
two
before
the
burial
---
I
think
it
was
a
day
or
two
before
,
but
I
am
conscious
of
confusion
in
my
mind
about
that
heavy
time
,
with
nothing
to
mark
its
progress
---
she
took
me
into
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
recollect
that
underneath
some
white
covering
on
the
bed
,
with
a
beautiful
cleanliness
and
freshness
all
around
it
,
there
seemed
to
me
to
lie
embodied
the
solemn
stillness
that
was
in
the
house
;
and
that
when
she
would
have
turned
the
cover
gently
back
,
I
cried
:
"
<EOS>
Oh
no
!
 
<EOS>
oh
no
!
"
and
held
her
hand
.
   
<EOS>
If
the
funeral
had
been
yesterday
,
I
could
not
recollect
it
better
.
<EOS>
The
very
air
of
the
best
parlour
,
when
I
went
in
at
the
door
,
the
bright
condition
of
the
fire
,
the
shining
of
the
wine
in
the
decanters
,
the
patterns
of
the
glasses
and
plates
,
the
faint
sweet
smell
of
cake
,
the
odour
of
Miss
Murdstone
's
dress
,
and
our
black
clothes
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chillip
is
in
the
room
,
and
comes
to
speak
to
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
how
is
Master
David
?
"
<EOS>
he
says
,
kindly
.
   
<EOS>
I
can
not
tell
him
very
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
give
him
my
hand
,
which
he
holds
in
his
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
says
Mr
Chillip
,
meekly
smiling
,
with
something
shining
in
his
eye
.
 
<EOS>
"
Our
little
friends
grow
up
around
us
.
 
<EOS>
They
grow
out
of
our
knowledge
,
ma'am
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
This
is
to
Miss
Murdstone
,
who
makes
no
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
a
great
improvement
here
,
ma'am
?
"
says
Mr
Chillip
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
merely
answers
with
a
frown
and
a
formal
bend
:
<EOS>
Mr
Chillip
,
discomfited
,
goes
into
a
corner
,
keeping
me
with
him
,
and
opens
his
mouth
no
more
.
   
<EOS>
I
remark
this
,
because
I
remark
everything
that
happens
,
not
because
I
care
about
myself
,
or
have
done
since
I
came
home
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
the
bell
begins
to
sound
,
and
Mr
Omer
and
another
come
to
make
us
ready
.
 
<EOS>
As
Peggotty
was
wo
nt
to
tell
me
,
long
ago
,
the
followers
of
my
father
to
the
same
grave
were
made
ready
in
the
same
room
.
   
<EOS>
There
are
Mr
Murdstone
,
our
neighbour
Mr
Grayper
,
Mr
Chillip
,
and
I.
 
<EOS>
When
we
go
out
to
the
door
,
the
Bearers
and
their
load
are
in
the
garden
;
and
they
move
before

down
the
path
,
and
past
the
elms
,
and
through
the
gate
,
and
into
the
churchyard
,
where
I
have
so
often
heard
the
birds
sing
on
a
summer
morning
.
   
<EOS>
We
stand
around
the
grave
.
 
<EOS>
The
day
seems
different
to
me
from
every
other
day
,
and
the
light
not
of
the
same
colour
---
of
a
sadder
colour
.
 
<EOS>
Now
there
is
a
solemn
hush
,
which
we
have
brought
from
home
with
what
is
resting
in
the

;
and
while
we
stand

,
I
hear
the

of
the
clergyman
,

remote
in
the
open

,
and
yet
distinct

,
saying
:
"
I
am
the
Resurrection
and
the
Life
,
saith
the
Lord
!
"
 
<EOS>
Then
I
hear
sobs
;
and
,
standing
apart
among
the
lookers
-
on
,
I
see
that
good
and
faithful
servant
,
whom
of
all
the
people
upon
earth
<EOS>
I
love
the
best
,
and
unto
whom
my
childish
heart
is
certain
that
the
Lord
will
one
day
say
:
"
Well
done
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
are
many
faces
that
I
know
,
among
the
little
crowd
;
faces
that
I
knew
in
church
,
when
mine
was
always
wondering
there
;
faces
that
first
saw
my
mother
,
when
she
came
to
the
village
in
her

bloom
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
mind
them
<EOS>
---
I
mind
nothing
but
my
grief
---
<EOS>
and
yet
I
see
and
know
them
all
;
and
even
in
the
background
,
far
away
,
see
Minnie
looking
on
,
and
her
eye
glancing
on
her
sweetheart
,
who
is
near
me
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
over
,
and
the
earth
is
filled
in
,
and
we
turn
to
come
away
.
<EOS>
Before
us
stands
our
house
,
so
pretty

unchanged
,
so
linked
in
my
mind
with
the
young
idea
of
what
is
gone
,
that
all
my
sorrow
has
been
nothing
to
the
sorrow
it
calls
forth
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
take
me
on
;
and
Mr
Chillip
talks
to
me
;
and
when
we
get
home
,
puts
some
water
to
my
lips
;
and
when
I
ask
his
leave
to
go
up
to
my
room
,
dismisses
me
with
the
gentleness
of
a
woman
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
,
I
say
,
is
yesterday
's
event
.
 
<EOS>
Events
of
later
date
have
floated
from
me
to
the
shore
where
all
forgotten
things
will
reappear
,
but
this
stands
like
a
high
rock
in
the
ocean
.
   
<EOS>
I
knew
that
Peggotty
would
come
to
me
in
my
room
.
 
<EOS>
The
Sabbath
stillness
of
the
time
<EOS>
(
the
day
was
so
like
Sunday
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
forgotten
that
)
was
suited
to
us
both
.
 
<EOS>
She
sat
down
by
my
side
upon
my
little
bed
;
and
holding
my
hand
,
and
sometimes
putting
it
to
her
lips
,
and
sometimes
smoothing
it
with
hers
,
as
she
might
have
comforted
my
little
brother
,
told
me
,
in
her
way
,
all
that
she
had
to
tell
concerning
what
had
happened
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
was
never
well
,
"
said
Peggotty
,
"
for
a
long
time
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
uncertain
in
her
mind
,
and
not
happy
.
 
<EOS>
When
her
baby
was
born
,
I
thought
at
first
she
would
get
better
,
but
she
was
more
delicate
,
and
sunk
a
little
every
day
.
 
<EOS>
She
used
to
like
to
sit
alone
before
her
baby
came
,
and
then
she
cried
;
but
afterwards
she
used
to
sing
to
it
---
<EOS>
so
soft
,
that
I
once
thought
,
when
I
heard
her
,
it
was
like
a
voice
up
in
the
air
,
that
was
rising
away
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
she
got
to
be
more
timid
,
and
more
frightened
-
like
,
of
late
;
and
that
a
hard
word
was
like
a
blow
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
was
always
the
same
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
She
never
changed
to
her
foolish
Peggotty
,
did
n't
my
sweet
girl
.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
Peggotty
stopped
,
and
softly
beat
upon
my
hand
a
little
while
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
last
time
that
I
saw
her
like
her
own
old
self
,
was
the
night
when
you
came
home
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
The
day
you
went
away
,
she
said
to
me
,
"
I
never
shall
see
my
pretty
darling
again
.
 
<EOS>
Something
tells
me
so
,
that
tells
the
truth
,
I
know
.
"
<EOS>
"
  
"
She
tried

hold

;
and
many

time
,
when
they
told

she
was
thoughtless
and
light

,
made
believe
to
be
so
;
but
it
was
all

.
 
<EOS>
She
never
told
her
husband
what
she
had
told
me
---
she
was
afraid
of
saying

to

---
till
one
night
,
a
little

than
a
week
before

,
when

:
"
My

,
I

.
"
<EOS>
"
   
"
"
It
's

my

,
Peggotty
,
"
she

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
will
believe

more

,

,

;
and

it
will

past
.
<EOS>
I
am
very

.
 
<EOS>
If
this
is
sleep
,
sit

me

:
do

.
 
<EOS>
God
bless
both

children
!
 
<EOS>
God
protect
and
keep
my
fatherless
boy
!
"
<EOS>
"
   
"
I
never
left
her
afterwards
,
"
said
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
often
talked
to
them
two
downstairs
---
for
she
loved

;
she
could
n't

anyone
who
was
about

---
but
when

from

,

,

rest
where
Peggotty
was
,
and
never

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
On

,

,

,

"

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
It

;
for
the
poor
lamb
lived
but

beyond

.
)
<EOS>
"
Let

,
"

,
"

his
mother
,

,
blessed

not

,

.
"
<EOS>
"
   
Another

,
and
another

on

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
pretty
far
in
the
night
,
"
said

,
"
when

;
and
when

,
gave

patient

,
the
dear
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
so
beautiful
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Daybreak
had
come
,
and
the
sun
was
rising
,
when
she
said
to
me
,
how
kind
and
considerate
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
had
always
been
to
her
,
and
how
he
had
borne

her
,

told

,

,
that
a

was
better

,
and
that

.
 
<EOS>
"
Peggotty
,
my
dear
,
"
she

,
"
put
me
nearer
to
you
,
"
for
she
was
very

.
 
<EOS>
"
Lay
your
good

,
"
she

,
"
and
turn

to

,
for
your

going
far

,
and
I

to
be

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
put
it
as
she

;
and
oh
Davy
!
<EOS>
the
time
had
come
when
my
first

to
you
were
true
---
when
she
was

on

stupid
cross
old
Peggotty
's

---
and
she
died
like
a
child
that
had
gone

!
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
ended
Peggotty
's
narration
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
moment
of
my
knowing
of
the
death
of
my
mother
,
the
idea
of
her
as
she
had
been
of
late
had
vanished
from
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
remembered
her
,
from
that
instant
,
only
as
the
young
mother
of
my
earliest
impressions
,
who
had
been
used
to
wind
her
bright
curls
round
and
round
her
finger
,
and
to
dance
with
me
at
twilight
in
the
parlour
.
 
<EOS>
What
Peggotty
had
told
me
now
,
was
so
far
from
bringing
me
back
to
the
later
period
,
that
it
rooted
the
earlier
image
in
my
mind
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
curious
,
but
it
is
true
.
 
<EOS>
In
her
death
she
winged
her
way
back
to
her
calm
untroubled
youth
,
and
cancelled
all
the
rest
.
   
<EOS>
The
mother
who
lay
in
the
grave
,
was
the
mother
of
my
infancy
;
the
little
creature
in
her
arms
,
was
myself
,
as
I
had
once
been
,
hushed
for
ever
on
her
bosom
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
10
.
<EOS>
I
become
neglected
,
and
am
provided
for
 
The
first
act
of
business
Miss
Murdstone
performed
when
the
day
of
the
solemnity
was
over
,
and
light
was
freely
admitted
into
the
house
,
was
to
give
Peggotty
a
month
's
warning
.
 
<EOS>
Much
as
Peggotty
would
have
disliked
such
a
service
,
I
believe
she
would
have
retained
it
,
for
my
sake
,
in
preference
to
the
best
upon
earth
.
<EOS>
She
told
me
we
must
part
,
and
told
me
why
;
and
we
condoled
with
one
another
,
in
all
sincerity
.
   
<EOS>
As
to
me
or
my
future
,
not
a
word
was
said
,
or
a
step
taken
.
 
<EOS>
Happy
<EOS>
they
would
have
been
,
I
dare
say
,
if
they
could
have
dismissed
me
at
a
month
's
warning
too
.
 
<EOS>
I
mustered
courage
once
,
to
ask
Miss
Murdstone
when
I
was
going
back
to
school
;
and
she
answered
dryly
,
she
believed
I
was
not
going
back
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
told
nothing
more
.
<EOS>
I
was
very
anxious
to
know
what
was
going
to
be
done
with
me
,
and
so
was
Peggotty
;
but
neither
she
nor
I
could
pick
up
any
information
on
the
subject
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
one
change
in
my
condition
,
which
,
while
it
relieved
me
of
a
great
deal
of
present
uneasiness
,
might
have
made
me
,
if
I
had
been
capable
of
considering
it
closely
,
yet
more
uncomfortable
about
the
future
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
this
.
 
<EOS>
The
constraint
that
had
been
put
upon
me
,
was
quite
abandoned
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
far
from
being
required
to
keep
my
dull
post
in
the
parlour
<EOS>
,
that
on
several
occasions
,
when
I
took
my
seat
there
,
Miss
Murdstone
frowned
to
me
to
go
away
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
far
from
being
warned
off
from
Peggotty
's
society
,
that
,
provided
I
was
not
in
Mr
Murdstone
's
,
I
was
never
sought
out
or
inquired
for
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
I
was
in
daily
dread
of
his
taking
my
education
in
hand
again
,
or
of
Miss
Murdstone
's
devoting
herself
to
it
;
but
I
soon
began
to
think
that
such
fears
were
groundless
,
and
that
all
I
had
to
anticipate
was
neglect
.
   
<EOS>
I
do
not
conceive
that
this
discovery
gave
me
much
pain
then
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
still
giddy
with
the
shock
of
my
mother
's
death
,
and
in
a
kind
of
stunned
state
as
to
all
tributary
things
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
recollect
,
indeed
,
to
have
speculated
,
at
odd
times
,
on
the
possibility
of
my
not
being
taught
any
more
,
or
cared
for
any
more
;
and
growing
up
to
be
a
shabby
,
moody
man
,
lounging
an
idle
life
away
,
about
the
village
;
as
well
as
on
the
feasibility
of
my
getting
rid
of
this
picture
by
going
away
somewhere
,
like
the
hero
in
a
story
,
to
seek
my
fortune
:
but
these
were
transient
visions
,
daydreams
<EOS>
I
sat
looking
at
sometimes
,
as
if
they
were
faintly
painted
or
written
on
the
wall
of
my
room
,
and
which
,
as
they
melted
away
,
left
the
wall
blank
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Peggotty
,
"
I
said
in
a
thoughtful
whisper
,
one
evening
,
when
I
was
warming
my
hands
at
the
kitchen

,
"
<EOS>
Mr
Murdstone
likes
me
less
than
he
used
to
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
liked
me
much
,
Peggotty
;
but
he
would
rather
not
even
see
me
now
,
if
he
can
help
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
it
's
his
sorrow
,
"
said
Peggotty
,
stroking
my
hair
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
,
Peggotty
,
I
am
sorry
too
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
believed
it
was
his
sorrow
,
I
should
not
think
of
it
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
's
not
that
;
<EOS>
oh
,
no
,
it
's
not
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
know
it
's
not
that
?
"
said
Peggotty
,
after
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
his
sorrow
is
another
and
quite

.
 
<EOS>
He
is
sorry
at
this
moment
,
sitting
by
the

with
Miss
Murdstone
;
but
if
I
was
to
go
in
,
Peggotty
,
he
would
be
something
besides
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
would
he
be
?
"
said
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
Angry
,
"
I
answered
,
with
an
involuntary
imitation
of
his
dark
frown
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
he
was
only
sorry
,
he
would
n't
look
at
me
as
he
does
.
<EOS>
I
am
only
sorry
,
and
it
makes
me
feel
kinder
.
"
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
said
nothing
for
a
little
while
;
and
I
warmed
my
hands
,
as
silent
as
she
.
   
<EOS>
"
Davy
,
"
she
said
at
length
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
Peggotty
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
tried
,
my
dear
,
all
ways
I
could

---
all
the
ways
there
are
,
and
all
the
ways
there
ai
n't
,
in

---
to
get
a
suitable
service
here
,
in
Blunderstone
;
but
there
's
no
such

thing
,
my

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
do

do
,
Peggotty
,
"
says
I
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
to
go
and
seek
your
fortune
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
expect
I
shall
be
forced
to
go
to
Yarmouth
,
"
replied
Peggotty
,
"
and
live
there
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
might
have
gone
farther
off
,
"
I
said
,
brightening
a
little
,
"
and
been
as
bad
as
lost
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
see
you
sometimes
,
<EOS>
my
dear
old
Peggotty
,
there
.
 
<EOS>
You
wo
n't
be
quite
at
the
other
end
of
the
world
,
will
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Contrary
ways
,
please
God
!
"
cried
Peggotty
,
with
great
animation
.
<EOS>
"
As
long
as
you
are
here
,
my
pet
,
I
shall
come
over
every
week
of
my
life
to
see
you
.
 
<EOS>
One
day
,
every
week
of
my
life
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
a
great
weight
taken
off
my
mind
by
this
promise
:
but
even
this
was
not
all
,
for
Peggotty
went
on
to
say
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
a
-
going
,
Davy
,
you
see
,
to
my
brother
's
,
first
,
for
another
fortnight
's
visit
---
just
till
I
have
had
time
to
look
about
me
,
and
get
to
be
something
like
myself
again
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
I
have
been
thinking
that
perhaps
,
as
they
do
n't
want
you
here
at
present
,
you
might
be
let
to
go
along
with
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
If
anything
,
short
of
being
in
a
different

to
every

about
me
,
Peggotty
excepted
,
could
have
given
me
a
sense
of
pleasure
at
that
time
,
it
would
have
been
this
project
of
all
others
.
 
<EOS>
The
idea
of
being
again
surrounded
by
those
honest
faces
,
shining
welcome
on
me
;
of
renewing
the
peacefulness
of
the
sweet
Sunday
morning
,
when
the
bells
were
ringing
,
the
stones
dropping
in
the
water
,
and
the
shadowy
ships
breaking
through
the
mist
;
of
roaming
up
and
down
with
little
Em'ly
,
telling
her
my
troubles
,
and
finding
charms
against
them
in
the
shells
and
pebbles
on
the
beach
;
made
a
calm
in
my
heart
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
ruffled
next
moment
,
to
be
sure
,
by
a
doubt
of
Miss
Murdstone
's
giving
her
consent
;
but
even
that
was
set
at
rest
soon
,
for
she
came
out
to
take
an
evening
grope
in
the
store
-
closet
while
we
were
yet
in
conversation
,
and
Peggotty
,
with
a
boldness
that
amazed
me
,
broached
the
topic
on
the
spot
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
boy
will
be
idle
there
,
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
,
looking
into
a
pickle
-
jar
,
"
and
idleness
is
the
root
of
all
evil
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
to
be
sure
,
he
would
be
idle
here
---
or
anywhere
,
in
my
opinion
.
"
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
had
an
angry
answer
ready
,
I
could
see
;
but
she
swallowed
it
for
my
sake
,
and
remained
silent
.
   
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
<EOS>
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
,
still
keeping
her
eye
on
the
pickles
;
"
it
is
of
more

than
anything
else
---
it
is
of
paramount

---
that
my
brother
should
not
be
disturbed
or
made
uncomfortable
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
had
better
say
yes
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
thanked
her
,
without
making
any
demonstration
of
joy
,
lest
it
should
induce
her
to
withdraw

.
 
<EOS>
Nor
could
I
help
thinking
this
a
prudent
course
,
since
she
looked
at
me
out
of
the
pickle
-
jar
,
with
as
great

access
of
sourness
as
if
her
black

had
absorbed
its
contents
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
the
permission
was
given
,
and
was
never
retracted
;
for
when
the
month
was
out
,
Peggotty
and
I
were
ready
to
depart
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Barkis
came
into
the
house
for
Peggotty
's
boxes
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
never
known
him
to
pass
the
garden
-
gate
before
,
but
on
this
occasion
he
came
into
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
gave
me
a
look
as
he
shouldered
the
largest
box
and
went
out
,
which
I
thought
had
meaning
in
it
,
if
meaning
could
ever
be
said
to
find
its
way
into
Mr
Barkis
's

.
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
was
naturally
in
low
spirits
at
leaving
what
had
been
her
home
<EOS>
so
many
years
,
and
where
the
two
strong
attachments
of
her
life
---
for
my
mother
and
myself
---
had
been
formed
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
been
walking
in
the
churchyard
,
too
,
very
early
;
and
she
got
into
the
cart
,
and
sat
in
it
with

at

.
   
<EOS>
So
long

she
remained
in
this
condition
,
Mr
Barkis
gave
no
sign

life
whatever
.
 
<EOS>
He
sat
in
his
usual

and

like
a
great

figure
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
she
began
to
look
about
her
,
and
to
speak
to
me
,
he
nodded
his
head
and
grinned
several
times
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
the
least
notion
at
whom
,
or
what
he
meant
by

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
beautiful
day
,
Mr
Barkis
!
<EOS>
"
I
said
,
as
an
act
of
politeness
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
ai
n't
bad
,
"
said
Mr
Barkis
,
who
generally
qualified
his
speech
,
and
rarely
committed
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
Peggotty
is
quite
comfortable
now
,
Mr
Barkis
,
"
I

,
for
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
she
,
though
?
"
said
Mr
Barkis
.
   
<EOS>
After

about
it
,
with
a

,
Mr
Barkis
eyed
her
,
and
said
:
   
"
ARE
you
pretty
comfortable
?
"
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
laughed
,
and
answered
in
the
affirmative
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
really
and
truly
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
?
"
<EOS>
growled
Mr
Barkis
,
sliding
nearer
to
her
on
the
seat
,
and
nudging

with
his

.
<EOS>
"
Are
you
?
 
<EOS>
Really
and
truly
pretty
comfortable
?
 
<EOS>
Are
you
?
 
<EOS>
Eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
At
each
of
these
inquiries
Mr
Barkis
shuffled
nearer
to
her
,
and
gave
her
another
nudge
;
so
that
at
last
we
were
all
crowded
together
in
the
left
-
hand
corner
of
the
cart
,
and
<EOS>
I
was
so
squeezed
that
I
could
hardly
bear
it
.
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
calling
his
attention
to
my
sufferings
,
Mr
Barkis
gave
me
a
little
more
room
at
once
,
and
got
away
by
degrees
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
could
not
help
observing
that
he
seemed
to
think
he
had
hit
upon
a
wonderful
expedient
for

himself
in
a
neat
,
agreeable
,
and
pointed

,
without
the
inconvenience
of
inventing
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
He
manifestly
chuckled
over
it
for
some
time
.
 
<EOS>
By
and
<EOS>
by
he
turned
to
Peggotty
again
,
and
repeating
,
"
Are
you
pretty
comfortable
though
?
"
<EOS>
bore
down
upon
us
as
before
,
until
the
breath
was
nearly
edged

of
my

.
 
<EOS>
By
and
by
he
made
another
descent
upon
us
with
the
same

,
and
the
same
result
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
I
got
up
whenever
I
saw
him
coming
,
and
standing
on
the
foot
-
board
,
pretended
to
look
at
the
prospect
;
after
which
I
did
very
well
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
so
polite
as
to
stop
at
a
public
-
house
,
expressly
on
our
account
,
and
entertain
us
with
broiled

and

.
 
<EOS>
Even
when
Peggotty
was
in
the
act
of
drinking
,
he
was
seized
with
one
of
those
approaches
,
and
almost
choked
her
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
we
drew
nearer
to
the
end
of
our
journey
,
he
had
more
to
do
and
less
time
for
gallantry
;
and
when
we
got
on
Yarmouth

,
we
were
all
too
much
shaken
and
jolted
,
I
apprehend
,
to
have
any
leisure
for
anything
else
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
and
Ham
waited
for
us
at
the
old
place
.
 
<EOS>
They
received
me
and
Peggotty
in
an
affectionate
manner
,
and
shook
hands
with
Mr
Barkis
,
who
,
with
his
hat
on
the
very
back
of
his
head
,
and
a
shame
-
faced
leer
upon
his
countenance
,
and
pervading
his
very
legs
,
presented
but
a
vacant
appearance
,
I
thought
.
 
<EOS>
They
each
took
one
of
Peggotty
's
trunks
,
and
we
were
going
away
,
when
Mr
Barkis
solemnly
made
a
sign
to
me
with
his
forefinger
to
come
under
an

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
growled
Mr
Barkis
,
"
it
was
all
right
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
looked
up
into
his
face
,
and
answered
,
with
an
attempt
to
be
very
profound
:
"
Oh
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
did
n't
come
to
a
end
there
,
"
said
Mr
Barkis
,
nodding
confidentially
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
all
right
.
"
   
<EOS>
Again
I
answered
,
"
Oh
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
who
was
willin
'
,
"
said
my
friend
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
Barkis
,
and
Barkis
only
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
nodded
assent
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
right
,
"
said
Mr
Barkis
,
shaking
hands
;
"
I
'm
a
friend
of
your'n
.
 
<EOS>
You
made
it
all
right
,
first
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
all
right
.
"
   
<EOS>
In
his
attempts
to
be
particularly
lucid
,
Mr
Barkis
was
so
extremely
mysterious
,
that
I
might
have
stood
looking
in
his
face
for
an
hour
,
and
most
assuredly
should
have
got
as
much
information

of
it
as
out
of
the
face
of
a
clock
that
had
stopped
,
but
for
Peggotty
's
calling
me
away
.
 
<EOS>
As
we
were
going
along
,

;

he
had
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Like

,
"

,
"
<EOS>
but
I
do

mind
that
!
 
<EOS>
Davy

,
what
should

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

What

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
Little

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

younger
and
lower
in
the
school
than
himself
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
running
on
,
very
fast
indeed
,
when
my
eyes
rested
on
little
Em'ly
's
face
,
which
was
bent
forward
over
the
table
,
listening
with
the
deepest
attention
,
her
breath
held
,
her
blue
eyes
sparkling
like
jewels
,
and
the
colour
mantling
in
her
cheeks
.
 
<EOS>
She
looked
so
extraordinarily
earnest
and
pretty
,
that
I
stopped
in
a
sort
of
wonder
;
and
they
all
observed
her
at
the
same
time
,
for
as
I
stopped
,
they
laughed
and
looked
at
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Em'ly
is
like
me
,
"
said
Peggotty
,
"
and
would
like
to
see
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
Em'ly
was
confused
by
our
all
observing
her
,
and
hung
down
her
head
,
and
her
face
was
covered
with
blushes
.
 
<EOS>
Glancing
up
presently
through
her
stray
curls
,
and
seeing
that
we
were
all
looking
at
her
still
<EOS>
(
I
am
sure
I
,
for
one
,
could
have
looked
at
her
for
hours
)
,
she
ran
away
,
and
kept
away
till
it
was
nearly
bedtime
.
   
<EOS>
I
lay
down
in
the
old
little
bed
in
the
stern
of
the
boat
,
and
the
wind
came
moaning
on
across
the
flat
as
it
had
done
before
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
could
not
help
fancying
,
now
,
that
it
moaned
of
those
who
were
gone
;
and
instead
of
thinking
that
the
sea
might
rise
in
the
night
and
float
the
boat
away
,
I
thought
of
the
sea
that
had
risen
,
since
I
last
heard
those
sounds
,
and
drowned
my
happy
home
.
 
<EOS>
I
recollect
,
as
the
wind
and
water
began
to
sound
fainter
in
my
ears
,
putting
a
short
clause
into
my
prayers
,
petitioning
that
I
might
grow
up
to
marry
little
Em'ly
,
and
so

lovingly
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
The
days
passed
pretty
much
as
they
had
passed
before
,
except
---
it
was
a
great
exception
---
<EOS>
that
little
Em'ly
and
I
seldom
wandered
on
the
beach
now
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
tasks
to
learn
,
and
needle
-
work
to
do
;
and
was
absent
during
a
great
part
of
each
day
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
felt
that
we
should
not
have
had
those
old
wanderings
,
even
if
it
had
been
otherwise
.
 
<EOS>
Wild
and
full
of
childish
whims
as
Em'ly
was
<EOS>
,
she
was
more
of
a
little
woman
than
I
had
supposed
.
 
<EOS>
She
seemed
to
have
got
a
great
distance
away
from
me
,
in
little
more
than
a
year
.
 
<EOS>
She
liked
me
,
but
she
laughed
at
me
,
and
tormented
me
;
and
when
I
went
to
meet
her
,
stole
home
another
way
,
and
was
laughing
at
the
door
when
I
came
back
,
disappointed
.
 
<EOS>
The
best
times
were
when
she
sat
quietly
at
work
in
the
doorway
,
and
I
sat
on
the
wooden
step
at
her
feet
,
reading
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
It
seems
to
me
,
at
this
hour
,
that
I
have
never
seen
such
sunlight
as
on
those
bright
April
afternoons
;
that
I
have
never
seen
such
a
sunny
little
figure
as
I
used
to
see
,
sitting
in
the
doorway
of
the
old
boat
;
that
I
have
never
beheld
such
sky
,
such
water
,
such
glorified
ships
sailing
away
into
golden
air
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
very
first
evening
after
our
arrival
,
Mr
Barkis
appeared
in
an
exceedingly
vacant
and
awkward
condition
,
and
with
a
bundle
of
oranges
tied
up
in
a
handkerchief
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
made
no
allusion
of
any
kind
to
this
property
,
he
was
supposed
to
have
left
it
behind
him
by

when

went
away
;
until
Ham
,
running
after
him
to
restore

,
came
back
with
the
information
that
it
was
intended
for
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
After
that
occasion
he
appeared
every
evening
at
exactly
the
same
hour
,
and
always
with
a
little
bundle
,
to
which
he
never
alluded
,
and
which
he
regularly
put
behind
the
door
and
left
there
.
<EOS>
These
offerings
of
affection
were
of
a
most
various
and
eccentric
description
.
 
<EOS>
Among
them
I
remember
a
double
set
of
pigs
'

,
a
huge
pin
-

,
half
a
bushel
or
so
of
apples
,
a
pair
of
jet

,
some
Spanish

,
a
box
of

,
a
canary
bird
and

,
and
a
leg
of
pickled
pork
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Barkis
's
wooing
,
as
I
remember
it
,
was
altogether
of
a
peculiar
kind
.
 
<EOS>
He
very
seldom
said
anything
;
but
would
sit
by
the
fire
in
much
the
same
attitude
as
he
sat
in
his
cart
,
and
stare
heavily
at
Peggotty
,
who
was
opposite
.
 
<EOS>
One
night
,
being
,
as
I
suppose
,
inspired
by
love
,
he
made
a
dart
at
the
bit
of
wax
-
candle
<EOS>
she
kept
for
her
thread
,
and
put
it
in
his
waistcoat
-
pocket
and
carried
it
off
.
 
<EOS>
After
that
,
his
great
delight
was
to
produce
it
when
it
was
wanted
,
sticking
to
the
lining
of
his
pocket
,
in
a
partially
melted
state
,
and
pocket
it
again
when
it
was
done
with
.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
enjoy
himself
very
much
,
and
not
to
feel
at
all
called
upon
to
talk
.
 
<EOS>
Even
when
he
took
Peggotty
out
for
a

on
the

,
he
had
no
uneasiness
on
that
head
,
I
believe
;
contenting
himself
with
now
and
then
asking
her
if
she
was
pretty

;
and
I
remember
that
sometimes
,
after

was
gone
,
Peggotty
would
throw
her

over
her
face
,
and
laugh
for
half
-
an
-

.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
we
were
all
more
or
less

,
except
that
miserable
Mrs
Gummidge
,
whose
courtship
would
appear
to
have
been
of
an
exactly

,
she
was
so
continually
reminded
by
these
transactions
of
the
old
one
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
,
when

that
Peggotty

Mr

were
going

make

day

,
and
that
little

<EOS>
and

.
 
<EOS>
I
had
but
<EOS>
a
broken
sleep
the
night
before
,
in
anticipation
of
the
pleasure
of
a
whole
day
with
Em'ly
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
all
astir
betimes
in
the
morning
;
and
while
we
were
yet
at
breakfast
,
Mr
Barkis
appeared
in
the
distance
,
driving
a
chaise
-
cart
towards
the
object
of
his

.
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
was
dressed
as
usual
,
in
her
neat
and
quiet

;
but
Mr
Barkis
bloomed
in
a
new
blue
coat
,
of
which
the

had
given
him
such
good
measure
,
that
the

would
have
rendered
gloves

in
the

,
while
the
collar
was
so
high
that
it
pushed
his

up
on
end

.
 
<EOS>
His
bright
buttons
,
too
,
were
of
the
largest

.
 
<EOS>
Rendered
complete
by
drab

and
a
buff
waistcoat
<EOS>
,
I
thought
Mr
Barkis
a
phenomenon
of

.
   
<EOS>
When
we
were
all
in
a

outside
the
door
,
I
found
that
Mr
Peggotty
was
prepared
with
an
old

,
which
was

for

,
and
which
he

to
Mrs
Gummidge
for

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
better
be
done
by
somebody
else
,
Dan'l
,
"
said
Mrs
Gummidge
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
a
lone
lorn
creetur
'
myself
,
and
everythink
that
reminds
me
of
creetur
's
that
ai
n't
lone
and
lorn
,
goes
contrary

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
old
gal
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
and
heave

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Dan'l
,
"
returned
Mrs
Gummidge
,
whimpering

.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
felt
less
,
I
could
do

.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
feel
like
me
,
Dan'l
;
thinks
do

go
contrary
with
you
,
nor
you
with
them
;
you
had

do

.
"
   
<EOS>
But

,
who
had

in

,

,

by

<EOS>
(
Em'ly

on

,

)
,

.
 
<EOS>
So

Gummidge
did

;
and
,
I
am

,
cast

,
by

,
and

into

Ham
,

she
knowed

,

House

.
 
<EOS>
Which
I
really
thought
was
a
sensible

,
that
Ham
might
have
acted
on
.
   
<EOS>
Away
we
went
,
however
,
on
our

;
and
the
first

did
was
to
stop

a

,
where
Mr
Barkis
tied
the
horse
to
some
rails
,
and
went

Peggotty
,
leaving

Em'ly

.
 
<EOS>
I
took
that

to
put
my
arm
round
Em'ly
's

,
and
propose
that
as
I
was
going

so

,
we
should
determine
to
be
very

to
one
another
,
and
very

,
all

.
 
<EOS>
Little
Em'ly
consenting
,
and
allowing

to
kiss
her
<EOS>
,
I

;
informing
her
,
I
recollect
,
that
I
never
could
love
another
,
and
that
I
was
prepared
to
shed

blood
of
anybody
who
should

.
   
<EOS>
How
merry

Em'ly
made
herself
about

!
 
<EOS>
With
what
a
demure

of
being
immensely
older
and

than
I
,
the
fairy
little
woman
said
I
was
"
a
silly
boy
"
;
and
then
laughed
so
charmingly
that
I
forgot
the
pain
of
being
called
by
that
disparaging
name
,
in
the
pleasure
of
looking
at
her
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Barkis
and
Peggotty
were
a
good
while
in
the
church
,
but
came
out
at
last
,
and
then
we
drove
away
into
the
country
.
 
<EOS>
As
we
were
going
along
,
Mr
Barkis
turned
to
me
,
and
said
,
with
a
wink
,
---
by
the
by
,
I
should
hardly

thought
,
before
,
that
he
could
wink
:
   
"
What
name
was
it
as
I
wrote
up
in
the
cart
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Clara
Peggotty
,
<EOS>
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
name
would
it
be
as
I
should
write
up
now
,
if
there

a
tilt
here
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Clara
Peggotty
,
again
?
<EOS>
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
Clara
Peggotty
BARKIS
!
"
<EOS>
he

,
and
burst

shook

chaise
.
   
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
they
were
married
,
and
had
gone
into
the
church
for
no
other

.
 
<EOS>
Peggotty
was
resolved
that
it
should
be
quietly
done
;
and
the
clerk
had
given
her
away
,
and
there
had
been
no

.
 
<EOS>
She
was
a
little
confused
when
Mr
Barkis
made
this
abrupt

of
their
union
,
and
could
not
hug
me
enough
in
token
of
her
unimpaired

;
but
she
soon
became
herself
again
,
and
said
she
was
very
glad

was
over
.
   
<EOS>
We
drove
to
a
little
inn
in
a
by
-
road
,
where
we
were
expected
,
and
where
we
had
a
very
comfortable

,
and
passed
the
day
with
great
satisfaction
.
 
<EOS>
If
Peggotty
had
been
married
every
day
for
the
last
ten
years
,
she
could
hardly
have
been
more
at
her
ease
about
it
;
it
made
no
sort

difference
in
her
:
she
was
just
the
same
as
ever
,
and
went
out
for
a
stroll
with
little
Em'ly
and
me
before
tea
,
while
Mr
Barkis
philosophically
smoked
his
pipe
,
and
enjoyed
himself
,
I
suppose
,
with
the
contemplation
of
his
happiness
.
 
<EOS>
If
so
,
it
sharpened
his
appetite
;
for
I
distinctly
call
to
mind
that
,
although
he
had
eaten
a
good
deal
of
pork
and
greens
at
dinner
,
and
had
finished
off
with
a
fowl
or
two
,
he
was
obliged
to
have
cold
boiled
bacon
for
tea
,
and
disposed
of
a
large

without

.
   
<EOS>
I
have
often
thought
,
since
,
what
an
odd
,
innocent
,
out
-
of
-
the
-

kind

it

!
 
<EOS>
We
got

chaise

soon

,
and
drove
cosily

,
looking
up

the
stars
,
and
talking

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
their
chief
exponent
,
and
opened
Mr
Barkis
's

to
an

.
 
<EOS>
I
told

all
I
knew
,
but
he
would

believed
anything
I

;
for
he
had

profound
veneration
for
my

,
and
informed

in

,

,
that
I

"
a

"
---
by

I
think

meant

.
   
<EOS>
When

the
subject
of

,
or

of

,
little

<EOS>
and
I
made

an
old
wrapper
,
and
sat
under
it
for
the
rest
of
the

.
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
how
I
loved
her
!
 
<EOS>
What
happiness
(
I
thought
)
if
we
were
married
,
and
were
going
away
anywhere
to
live
among
the
trees
and
<EOS>
in
the
fields
,
never
growing
