,
never
growing
wiser
,
children
ever
,
rambling
hand
in
hand
through
sunshine
and
among
flowery
meadows
,
laying
down
our
heads
on
moss
at
night
,
in
a
sweet
sleep
of
purity
and
peace
,
and
buried
by
the
birds
when
we
were
dead
!
 
<EOS>
Some
such
picture
,
with
no
real
world
in
it
,
bright
with
the
light
of
our
innocence
,
and
vague
as
the
stars
afar
off
,
was
in
my
mind
all
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
to
think
there
were
two
such
guileless
hearts
at
Peggotty
's
marriage
as
little
Em'ly
's
and
mine
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
to
think
the
Loves
and
Graces
took
such
airy
forms
in
its
homely
procession
.
   
<EOS>
Well
,
we
came
to
the
old
boat
again
in
good
time
at
night
;
and
there
Mr
and
Mrs
Barkis
bade
us
good
-
bye
,
and
drove
away
snugly
to
their
own
home
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
then
,
for
the
first
time
,
that
I
had
lost
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
gone
to
bed
with
a
sore
heart
indeed
under
any
other
roof
but
that
which
sheltered
little
Em'ly
's
head
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
and
Ham
knew
what
was
in
my
thoughts
as
well
as
I
did
,
and
were
ready
with
some
supper
and
their
hospitable
faces
to
drive
it
away
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Em'ly
came
and
sat
beside
me
on
the
locker
for
the
only
time
in
all
that
visit
;
and
it
was
altogether
a
wonderful
close
to
a
wonderful
day
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
night
tide
;
and
soon
after
we
went
to
bed
,
Mr
Peggotty
and
Ham
went
out
to
fish
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
very
brave
at
being
left
alone
in
the
solitary
house
,
the
protector
of
Em'ly
and
Mrs
Gummidge
,
and
only
wished
that
a
lion
or
a
serpent
,
or
any
ill
-
disposed
monster
,
would
make
an
attack
upon
us
,
that
I
might
destroy
him
,
and
cover
myself
with
glory
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
nothing
of
the
sort
happened
to
be
walking
about
on
Yarmouth
flats
that
night
,
I
provided
the
best
substitute
I
could
by
dreaming
of
dragons
until
morning
.
   
<EOS>
With
morning
came
Peggotty
;
who
called
to
me
,
as
usual
,
under
my
window
as
if
Mr
Barkis
the
carrier
had
been
from
first
to
last
a
dream
too
.
 
<EOS>
After
breakfast
she
took
me
to
her
own
home
,
and
a
beautiful
little
home
<EOS>
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
Of
all
the
moveables
in
it
,
I
must
have
been
impressed
by
a
certain
old
bureau
of
some
dark
wood
in
the
parlour
<EOS>
(
the
tile
-
floored
kitchen
was
the
general
sitting
-
room
)
,
with
a
retreating
top
which
opened
,
let
down
,
and
became
a
desk
,
within
which
was
a
large
quarto
edition
of
Foxe
's
Book
of
Martyrs
.
 
<EOS>
This
precious
volume
,
of
which
I
do
not
recollect
one
word
<EOS>
,
I
immediately
discovered
and
immediately
applied
myself
to
;
and
I
never
visited
the
house
afterwards
,
but
I
kneeled
on
a
chair
,
opened
the
casket
where
this
gem
was
enshrined
,
spread
my
arms
over
the
desk
,
and
fell
to
devouring
the
book
afresh
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
chiefly
edified
,
I
am
afraid
,
by
the
pictures
,
which
were
numerous
,
and
represented
all
kinds
of
dismal
horrors
;
but
the
Martyrs
and
Peggotty
's
house
have
been
inseparable
in
my
mind
ever
since
,
and
are
now
.
   
<EOS>
I
took
leave
of
Mr
Peggotty
,
and
Ham
,
and
Mrs
Gummidge
,
and
little
Em'ly
,
that
day
;
and
passed
the
night
at
Peggotty
's
,
in
a
little
room
in
the
roof
(
with
the
Crocodile
Book
on
a
shelf
by
the
bed
's
head
)
which
was
to
be
always
mine
,
Peggotty
said
,
and
should
always
be
kept
for
me
in
exactly
the
same
state
.
   
<EOS>
"
Young
or
old
,
Davy
dear
,
as
long
as
I
am
alive
and
have
this
house
over
my
head
,
"
said
Peggotty
,
"
you
shall
find
it
as
if
I
expected
you
here
directly
minute
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
keep
it
every
day
,
as
I
used
to
keep
your
old
little
room
,
my
darling
;
and
if
you
was
to
go
to
China
,
you
might
think
of
it
as
being
kept
just
the
same
,
all
the
time
you
were
away
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
the
truth
and
constancy
of
my
dear
old
nurse
,
with
all
my
heart
,
and
thanked
her
as
well
as
I
could
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
not
very
well
,
for
she
spoke
to
me
thus
,
with
her
arms
round
my
neck
,
in
the
morning
,
and
I
was
going
home
in
the
morning
,
and
I
went
home
in
the
morning
,
with
herself
and
Mr
Barkis
in
the
cart
.
 
<EOS>
They
left
me
at
the
gate
,
not
easily
or
lightly
;
and
it
was
a
strange
sight
to
me
to
see
the
cart
go
on
,
taking
Peggotty
away
,
and
leaving
me
under
the
old
elm
-
trees
looking
at
the
house
,
in
which
there
was
no
face
to
look
on
mine
with
love
or
liking
any
more
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
I
fell
into
a
state
of
neglect
,
which
I
can
not
look
back
upon
without
compassion
.
 
<EOS>
I
fell
at
once
into
a
solitary
condition
,
---
apart
from
all
friendly
notice
,
apart
from
the
society
of
all
other
boys
of
my
own
age
,
apart
from
all
companionship
but
my
own
spiritless
thoughts
,
---
which
seems
to
cast
its
gloom
upon
this
paper
as
I
write
.
   
<EOS>
What
would
I
have
given
,
to
have
been
sent
to
the
hardest
school
that
ever
was
kept
!
---
<EOS>
to
have
been
taught
something
,
anyhow
,
anywhere
!
 
<EOS>
No
such
hope
dawned
upon
me
.
 
<EOS>
They
disliked
me
;
and
they
sullenly
,
sternly
,
steadily
,
overlooked
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
Mr
Murdstone
's
means
were
straitened
at
about
this
time
;
but
it
is
little
to
the
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
not
bear
me
;
and
in
putting
me
from
him
he
tried
,
as
I
believe
,
to
put
away
the
notion
that
I
had
any
claim
upon
him
---
and
succeeded
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
not
actively
ill
-
used
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
beaten
,
or
starved
;
but
the
wrong
that
was
done
to
me
had
no
intervals
of
relenting
,
and
was
done
in
a
systematic
,
passionless
manner
.
 
<EOS>
Day
after
day
,
week
after
week
,
month
after
month
,
I
was
coldly
neglected
.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
sometimes
,
when
I
think
of
it
,
what
they
would
have
done
if
I
had
been
taken
with
an
illness
;
whether
I
should
have
lain
down
in
my
lonely
room
,
and
languished
through
it
in
my
usual
solitary
way
,
or
whether
anybody
would
have
helped
me
out
.
   
<EOS>
When
Mr
and
Miss
Murdstone
were
at
home
,
I
took
my
meals
with
them
;
in
their
absence
,
I
ate
and
drank
by
myself
.
 
<EOS>
At
all
times
I
lounged
about
the
house
and
neighbourhood
quite
disregarded
,
except
that
they
were
jealous
of
my
making
any
friends
:
thinking
,
perhaps
,
that
if
I
did
,
I
might
complain
to
someone
.
 
<EOS>
For
this
reason
,
though
Mr
Chillip
often
asked
me
to
go
and
see
him
<EOS>
(
he
was
a
widower
,
having
,
<EOS>
some
years
before
that
,
lost
a
little
small
light
-
haired
wife
,
whom
I
can
just
remember
connecting
in
my
own
thoughts
with
a
pale
tortoise
-
shell
cat
)
,
it
was
but
seldom
that
I
enjoyed
the
happiness
of
passing
an
afternoon
in
his
closet
of
a
surgery
;
reading
some
book
that
was
new
to
me
,
with
the
smell
of
the
whole
Pharmacopoeia
coming
up
my
nose
,
or
pounding
something
in
a
mortar
under
his
mild
directions
.
   
<EOS>
For
the
same
reason
,
added
no
doubt
to
the
old
dislike
of
her
,
I
was
seldom
allowed
to
visit
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
Faithful
to
her
promise
,
she
either
came
to
see
me
,
or
met
me
somewhere
near
,
once
every
week
,
and
never
empty
-
handed
;
but
many
and
bitter
were
the
disappointments
I
had
,
in
being
refused
permission
to
pay
a
visit
to
her
at
her
house
.
 
<EOS>
Some
few
times
,
however
,
at
long
intervals
,
I
was
allowed
to
go
there
;
and
then
I
found
out
that
Mr
Barkis
was
something
of
a
miser
,
or
as
Peggotty
dutifully
expressed
it
,
was
"
a
little
near
"
,
and
kept
a
heap
of
money
in
a
box
under
his
bed
,
which
he
pretended
was
only
full
of
coats
and
trousers
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
coffer
,
his
riches
hid
themselves
with
such
a
tenacious
modesty
,
that
the
smallest
instalments
could
only
be
tempted
out
by
artifice
;
so
that
Peggotty
had
to
prepare
a
long
and
elaborate
scheme
,
a
very
Gunpowder
Plot
,
for
every
Saturday
's
expenses
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
time
I
was
so
conscious
of
the
waste
of
any
promise
I
had
given
,
and
of
my
being
utterly
neglected
,
that
I
should
have
been
perfectly
miserable
,
I
have
no
doubt
,
but
for
the
old
books
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
my
only
comfort
;
and
I
was
as
true
to
them
as
they
were
to
me
,
and
read
them
over
and
over
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
many
times
more
.
   
<EOS>
I
now
approach
a
period
of
my
life
,
which
I
can
never
lose
the
remembrance
of
,
while
I
remember
anything
:
and
the
recollection
of
which
has
often
,
without
my
invocation
,
come
before
me
like
a
ghost
,
and
haunted
happier
times
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
been
out
,
one
day
,
loitering
somewhere
,
in
the
listless
,
meditative
manner
that
my
way
of
life
engendered
,
<EOS>
when
,
turning
the
corner
of
a
lane
near
our
house
,
I
came
upon
Mr
Murdstone
walking
with
a
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
confused
,
and
was
going
by
them
,
when
the
gentleman
cried
:
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
Brooks
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
David
Copperfield
,
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
tell
me
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
Brooks
,
"
said
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
Brooks
of
Sheffield
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
your
name
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
these
words
,
I
observed
the
gentleman
more
attentively
.
 
<EOS>
His
laugh
coming
to
my
remembrance
too
,
I
knew
him
to
be
Mr
Quinion
,
whom
I
had
gone
over
to
Lowestoft
with
Mr
Murdstone
to
see
,
before
<EOS>
---
it
is
no
matter
---
I
need
not
recall
when
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
how
do
you
get
on
,
and
where
are
you
being
educated
,
Brooks
?
"
said
Mr
Quinion
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
put
his
hand
upon
my
shoulder
,
and
turned
me
about
,
to
walk
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
not
know
what
to
reply
,
and
glanced
dubiously
at
Mr
Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
at
home
at
present
,
"
said
the
latter
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
not
being
educated
anywhere
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
to
do
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
difficult
subject
.
"
   
<EOS>
That
old
,
double
look
was
on
me
for
a
moment
;
and
then
his
eyes
darkened
with
a
frown
,
as
it
turned
,
in
its
aversion
,
elsewhere
.
   
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Quinion
,
looking
at
us
both
,
I
thought
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fine
weather
!
"
   
<EOS>
Silence
ensued
,
and
I
was
considering
how
I
could
best
disengage
my
shoulder
from
his
hand
,
and
go
away
,
when
he
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
are
a
pretty
sharp
fellow
still
?
 
<EOS>
Eh
,
Brooks
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
 
<EOS>
He
is
sharp
enough
,
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
,
impatiently
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
let
him
go
.
 
<EOS>
He
will
not
thank
you
for
troubling
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
On
this
hint
,
Mr
Quinion
released
me
,
and
I
made
the
best
of
my
way
home
.
 
<EOS>
Looking
back
as
I
turned
into
the
front
garden
,
I
saw
Mr
Murdstone
leaning
against
the
wicket
of
the
churchyard
,
and
Mr
Quinion
talking
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
both
looking
after
me
,
and
I
felt
that
they
were
speaking
of
me
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Quinion
lay
at
our
house
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
After
breakfast
,
the
next
morning
,
I
had
put
my
chair
away
,
and
was
going
out
of
the
room
,
when
Mr
Murdstone
called
me
back
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
gravely
repaired
to
another
table
,
where
his
sister
sat
herself
at
her
desk
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Quinion
,
with
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
stood
looking
out
of
window
;
and
I
stood
looking
at
them
all
.
   
<EOS>
"
David
,
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
,
"
to
the
young
<EOS>
this
is
a
world
for
action
;
not
for
moping
and
droning
in
.
<EOS>
"
   
---
"
As
you
do
,
"
added
his
sister
.
   
<EOS>
"
Jane
Murdstone
,
leave
it
to
me
,
if
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
,
David
,
to
the
young
<EOS>
this
is
a
world
for
action
,
and
not
for
moping
and
droning
in
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
especially
so
for
a
young
boy
of
your
disposition
,
which
requires
a
great
deal
of
correcting
;
and
to
which
no
greater
service
can
be
done
than
to
force
it
to
conform
to
the
ways
of
the
working
world
,
and
to
bend
it
and
break
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
For
stubbornness
wo
n't
do
here
,
"
said
his
sister
"
<EOS>
What
it
wants
is
,
to
be
crushed
.
 
<EOS>
And
crushed
it
must
be
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
be
,
too
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
gave
her
a
look
,
half
in
remonstrance
,
half
in
approval
,
and
went
on
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
know
,
David
,
that
I
am
not
rich
.
 
<EOS>
At
any
rate
,
you
know
it
now
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
received
some
considerable
education
already
.
 
<EOS>
Education
is
costly
;
and
even
if
it
were
not
,
and
I
could
afford
it
,
I
am
of
opinion
that
it
would
not
be
at
all
advantageous
to
you
to
be
kept
at
school
.
 
<EOS>
What
is
before
you
,
is
a
fight
with
the
world
;
and
the
sooner
you
begin
it
,
the
better
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
think
it
occurred
to
me
that
I
had
already
begun
it
,
in
my
poor
way
:
but
it
occurs
to
me
now
,
whether
or
no
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
heard
the
"
counting
-
house
"
mentioned
sometimes
,
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
counting
-
house
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
I
repeated
.
<EOS>
"
Of
Murdstone
and
Grinby
,
in
the
wine
trade
,
"
he
replied
.
   
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
looked
uncertain
,
for
he
went
on
hastily
:
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
heard
the
"
counting
-
house
"
mentioned
,
or
the
business
,
or
the
cellars
,
or
the
wharf
,
or
something
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
have
heard
the
business
mentioned
,
sir
,
"
I
said
,
remembering
what
I
vaguely
knew
of
his
and
his
sister
's
resources
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
n't
know
when
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
does
not
matter
when
,
"
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Quinion
manages
that
business
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
glanced
at
the
latter
deferentially
as
he
stood
looking
out
of
window
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Quinion
suggests
that
it
gives
employment
to
some
other
boys
,
and
that
he
sees
no
reason
why
it
should
n't
,
on
the
same
terms
,
give
employment
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
having
,
"
Mr
Quinion
observed
in
a
low
voice
,
and
half
turning
round
,
"
no
other
prospect
,
Murdstone
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Murdstone
,
with
an
impatient
,
even
an
angry
gesture
,
resumed
,
without
noticing
what
he
had
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
Those
terms
are
,
that
you
will
earn
enough
for
yourself
to
provide
for
your
eating
and
drinking
,
and
pocket
-
money
.
 
<EOS>
Your
lodging
(
which
I
have
arranged
for
)
will
be
paid
by
me
.
 
<EOS>
So
will
your
washing
---
"
   
"
---
Which
will
be
kept
down
to
my
estimate
,
"
said
his
sister
.
   
<EOS>
"
Your
clothes
will
be
looked
after
for
you
,
too
,
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
;
"
as
you
will
not
be
able
,
yet
awhile
,
to
get
them
for
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
So
you
are
now
going
to
London
,
David
,
with
Mr
Quinion
,
to
begin
the
world
on
your
own
account
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
short
,
you
are
provided
for
,
"
observed
his
sister
;
"
and
will
please
to
do
your
duty
.
"
   
<EOS>
Though
I
quite
understood
that
the
purpose
of
this
announcement
was
to
get
rid
of
me
,
I
have
no
distinct
remembrance
whether
it
pleased
or
frightened
me
.
 
<EOS>
My
impression
is
,
that
I
was
in
a
state
of
confusion
about
it
,
and
,
oscillating
between
the
two
points
,
touched
neither
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
had
I
much
time
for
the
clearing
of
my
thoughts
,
as
Mr
Quinion
was
to
go
upon
the
morrow
.
   
<EOS>
Behold
me
,
on
the
morrow
,
in
a
much
-
worn
little
white
hat
,
with
a
black
crape
round
it
for
my
mother
,
a
black
jacket
,
and
a
pair
of
hard
,
stiff
corduroy
trousers
---
which
Miss
Murdstone
considered
the
best
armour
for
the
legs
in
that
fight
with
the
world
which
was
now
to
come
off
.
 
<EOS>
behold
me
so
attired
,
and
with
my
little
worldly
all
before
me
in
a
small
trunk
,
sitting
,
a
lone
lorn
child
(
as
Mrs
Gummidge
might
have
said
)
,
in
the
post
-
chaise
that
was
carrying
Mr
Quinion
to
the
London
coach
at
Yarmouth
!
 
<EOS>
See
,
how
our
house
and
church
are
lessening
in
the
distance
;
how
the
grave
beneath
the
tree
is
blotted
out
by
intervening
objects
;
how
the
spire
points
upwards
from
my
old
playground
no
more
,
and
the
sky
is
empty
!
      
<EOS>
Chapter
11
.
<EOS>
I
begin
life
on
my
own
account
,
and
do
n't
like
it
 
<EOS>
I
know
enough
of
the
world
now
,
to
have
almost
lost
the
capacity
of
being
much
surprised
by
anything
;
but
it
is
matter
of
some
surprise
to
me
,
even
now
,
that
I
can
have
been
so
easily
thrown
away
at
such
an
age
.
 
<EOS>
A
child
of
excellent
abilities
,
and
with
strong
powers
of
observation
,
quick
,
eager
,
delicate
,
and
soon
hurt
bodily
or
mentally
<EOS>
,
it
seems
wonderful
to
me
that
nobody
should
have
made
any
sign
in
my
behalf
.
 
<EOS>
But
none
was
made
;
and
I
became
,
at
ten
years
old
,
a
little
labouring
hind
in
the
service
of
Murdstone
and
Grinby
.
   
<EOS>
Murdstone
and
Grinby
's
warehouse
was
at
the
waterside
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
down
in
Blackfriars
.
 
<EOS>
Modern
improvements
have
altered
the
place
;
but
it
was
the
last
house
at
the
bottom
of
a
narrow
street
,
curving
down
hill
to
the
river
,
with
some
stairs
at
the
end
,
where
people
took
boat
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
crazy
old
house
with
a
wharf
of
its
own
,
abutting
on
the
water
when
the
tide
was
in
,
and
on
the
mud
when
the
tide
was
out
,
and
literally
overrun
with
rats
.
 
<EOS>
Its
panelled
rooms
,
discoloured
with
the
dirt
and
smoke
of
a
hundred
years
,
I
dare
say
;
its
decaying
floors
and
staircase
;
the
squeaking
and
scuffling
of
the
old
grey
rats
down
in
the
cellars
;
and
the
dirt
and
rottenness
of
the
place
;
are
things
,
not
of
many
years
ago
,
in
my
mind
,
but
of
the
present
instant
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
all
before
me
,
just
as
they
were
in
the
evil
hour
when
I
went
among
them
for
the
first
time
,
with
my
trembling
hand
in
Mr
Quinion
's
.
   
<EOS>
Murdstone
and
Grinby
's
trade
was
among
a
good
many
kinds
of
people
,
but
an
important
branch
of
it
was
the
supply
of
wines
and
spirits
to
certain
packet
ships
.
 
<EOS>
I
forget
now
where
they
chiefly
went
,
but
I
think
there
were
some
among
them
that
made
voyages
both
to
the
East
and
West
Indies
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
that
a
great
many
empty
bottles
were
one
of
the
consequences
of
this
traffic
,
and
that
certain
men
and
boys
were
employed
to
examine
them
against
the
light
,
and
reject
those
that
were
flawed
,
and
to
rinse
and
wash
them
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
empty
bottles
ran
short
,
there
were
labels
to
be
pasted
on
full
ones
,
or
corks
to
be
fitted
to
them
,
or
seals
to
be
put
upon
the
corks
,
or
finished
bottles
to
be
packed
in
casks
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
work
was
my
work
,
and
of
the
boys
employed
upon
it
I
was
one
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
three
or
four
of
us
,
counting
me
.
 
<EOS>
My
working
place
was
established
in
a
corner
of
the
warehouse
,
where
Mr
Quinion
could
see
me
,
when
he
chose
to
stand
up
on
the
bottom
rail
of
his
stool
in
the
counting
-
house
,
and
look
at
me
through
a
window
above
the
desk
.
 
<EOS>
Hither
,
on
the
first
morning
of
my
so
auspiciously
beginning
life
on
my
own
account
,
the
oldest
of
the
regular
boys
was
summoned
to
show
me
my
business
.
 
<EOS>
His
name
was
Mick
Walker
,
and
he
wore
a
ragged
apron
and
a
paper
cap
.
 
<EOS>
He
informed
me
that
his
father
was
a
bargeman
,
and
walked
,
in
a
black
velvet
head
-
dress
,
in
the
Lord
Mayor
's
Show
.
 
<EOS>
He
also
informed
me
that
our
principal
associate
would
be
another
boy
whom
he
introduced
by
the
---
to
me
---
extraordinary
name
of
Mealy
Potatoes
.
 
<EOS>
I
discovered
,
however
,
that
this
youth
had
not
been
christened
by
that
name
,
but
that
it
had
been
bestowed
upon
him
in
the
warehouse
,
on
account
of
his
complexion
,
which
was
pale
or
mealy
.
 
<EOS>
Mealy
's
father
was
a
waterman
,
who
had
the
additional
distinction
of
being
a
fireman
,
and
was
engaged
as
such
at
one
of
the
large
theatres
;
where
some
young
relation
of
Mealy
's
---
I
think
his
little
sister
---
did
Imps
in
the
Pantomimes
.
   
<EOS>
No
words
can
express
the
secret
agony
of
my
soul
as
I
sunk
into
this
companionship
;
compared
these
henceforth
everyday
associates
with
those
of
my
happier
childhood
---
not
to
say
with
Steerforth
,
Traddles
,
and
the
rest
of
those
boys
;
and
felt
my
hopes
of
growing
up
to
be
a
learned
and
distinguished
man
,
crushed
in
my
bosom
.
 
<EOS>
The
deep
remembrance
of
the
sense
I
had
,
of
being
utterly
without
hope
now
;
of
the
shame
I
felt
in
my
position
;
of
the
misery
it
was
to
my
young
heart
to
believe
that
day
by
day
what
I
had
learned
,
and
thought
,
and
delighted
in
,
and
raised
my
fancy
and
my
emulation
up
by
,
would
pass
away
from
me
,
little
by
little
,
never
to
be
brought
back
any
more
;
can
not
be
written
.
 
<EOS>
As
often
as
Mick
Walker
went
away
in
the
course
of
that
forenoon
,
I
mingled
my
tears
with
the
water
in
which
I
was
washing
the
bottles
;
and
sobbed
as
if
there
were
a
flaw
in
my
own
breast
,
and
it
were
in
danger
of
bursting
.
   
<EOS>
The
counting
-
house
clock
was
at
half
past
twelve
,
and
there
was
general
preparation
for
going
to
dinner
,
when
Mr
Quinion
tapped
at
the
counting
-
house
window
,
and
beckoned
to
me
to
go
in
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
in
,
and
found
there
a
stoutish
,
middle
-
aged
person
,
in
a
brown
surtout
and
black
tights
and
shoes
,
with
no
more
hair
upon
his
head
(
which
was
a
large
one
,
and
very
shining
)
than
there
is
upon
an
egg
,
and
with
a
very
extensive
face
,
which
he
turned
full
upon
me
.
 
<EOS>
His
clothes
were
shabby
,
but
he
had
an
imposing
shirt
-
collar
on
.
 
<EOS>
He
carried
a
jaunty
sort
of
a
stick
,
with
a
large
pair
of
rusty
tassels
to
it
;
and
a
quizzing
-
glass
hung
outside
his
coat
,
---
for
ornament
,
I
afterwards
found
,
as
he
very
seldom
looked
through
it
,
and
could
n't
see
anything
when
he
did
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
,
"
said
Mr
Quinion
,
in
allusion
to
myself
,
"
is
he
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
with
a
certain
condescending
roll
in
his
voice
,
and
a
certain
indescribable
air
of
doing
something
genteel
,
which
impressed
me
very
much
,
"
is
Master
Copperfield
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
I
see
you
well
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
I
was
very
well
,
and
hoped
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
sufficiently
ill
at
ease
,
Heaven
knows
;
but
it
was
not
in
my
nature
to
complain
much
at
that
time
of
my
life
,
so
<EOS>
I
said
I
was
very
well
,
and
hoped
he
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
"
thank
Heaven
,
quite
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
received
a
letter
from
Mr
Murdstone
,
in
which
he
mentions
that
he
would
desire
me
to
receive
into
an
apartment
in
the
rear
of
my
house
,
which
is
at
present
unoccupied
---
and
is
,
in
short
,
to
be
let
as
a
---
in
short
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
with
a
smile
and
in
a
burst
of
confidence
,
"
as
a
bedroom
---
the
young
beginner
whom
I
have
now
the
pleasure
to
---
"
and
the
stranger
waved
his
hand
,
and
settled
his
chin
in
his
shirt
-
collar
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
Mr
Micawber
,
"
said
Mr
Quinion
to
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ahem
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
stranger
,
"
that
is
my
name
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Micawber
,
"
said
Mr
Quinion
,
"
is
known
to
Mr
Murdstone
.
 
<EOS>
He
takes
orders
for
us
on
commission
,
when
he
can
get
any
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
been
written
to
by
Mr
Murdstone
,
on
the
subject
of
your
lodgings
,
and
he
will
receive
you
as
a
lodger
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
address
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
is
Windsor
Terrace
,
City
Road
.
<EOS>
I
---
in
short
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
with
the
same
genteel
air
,
and
in
another
burst
of
confidence
---
"
I
live
there
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
made
him
a
bow
.
   
<EOS>
"
Under
the
impression
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
that
your
peregrinations
in
this
metropolis
have
not
as
yet
been
extensive
,
and
that
you
might
have
some
difficulty
in
penetrating
the
arcana
of
the
Modern
Babylon
in
the
direction
of
the
City
Road
,
---
in
short
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
in
another
burst
of
confidence
,
"
that
you
might
lose
yourself
<EOS>
---
I
shall
be
happy
to
call
this
evening
,
and
install
you
in
the
knowledge
of
the
nearest
way
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
thanked
him
with
all
my
heart
,
for
it
was
friendly
in
him
to
offer
to
take
that
trouble
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
what
hour
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
shall
I
---
"
   
"
At
about
eight
,
"
said
Mr
Quinion
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
about
eight
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
beg
to
wish
you
good
day
,
Mr
Quinion
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
intrude
no
longer
.
"
   
<EOS>
So
he
put
on
his
hat
,
and
went
out
with
his
cane
under
his
arm
:
very
upright
,
and
humming
a
tune
when
he
was
clear
of
the
counting
-
house
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Quinion
then
formally
engaged
me
to
be
as
useful
as
I
could
in
the
warehouse
of
Murdstone
and
Grinby
,
at
a
salary
,
I
think
,
of
six
shillings
a
week
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
clear
whether
it
was
six
or
seven
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
inclined
to
believe
,
from
my
uncertainty
on
this
head
,
<EOS>
that
it
was
six
at
first
and
seven
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
He
paid
me
a
week
down
(
from
his
own
pocket
,
I
believe
)
,
and
I
gave
Mealy
sixpence
out
of
it
to
get
my
trunk
carried
to
Windsor
Terrace
that
night
:
it
being
too
heavy
for
my
strength
,
small
as
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
paid
sixpence
more
for
my
dinner
,
which
was
a
meat
pie
and
a
turn
at
a
neighbouring
pump
;
and
passed
the
hour
which
was
allowed
for
that
meal
,
in
walking
about
the
streets
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
appointed
time
in
the
evening
,
Mr
Micawber
reappeared
.
 
<EOS>
I
washed
my
hands
and
face
,
to
do
the
greater
honour
to
his
gentility
,
and
we
walked
to
our
house
,
as
I
suppose
I
must
now
call
it
,
together
;
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
impressing
the
name
of
streets
,
and
the
shapes
of
corner
houses
upon
me
,
as
we
went
along
,
that
I
might
find
my
way
back
,
easily
,
in
the
morning
.
   
<EOS>
Arrived
at
this
house
in
Windsor
Terrace
(
which
I
noticed
was
shabby
like
himself
,
but
also
,
like
himself
,
made
all
the
show
it
could
)
<EOS>
,
he
presented
me
to
Mrs
Micawber
,
a
thin
and
faded
lady
,
not
at
all
young
,
who
was
sitting
in
the
parlour
(
the
first
floor
was
altogether
unfurnished
,
and
the
blinds
were
kept
down
to
delude
the
neighbours
)
,
with
a
baby
at
her
breast
.
 
<EOS>
This
baby
was
one
of
twins
;
and
I
may
remark
here
that
I
hardly
ever
,
in
all
my
experience
of
the
family
,
saw
both
the
twins
detached
from
Mrs
Micawber
at
the
same
time
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
them
was
always
taking
refreshment
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
two
other
children
;
Master
Micawber
,
aged
about
four
,
and
Miss
Micawber
,
aged
about
three
.
 
<EOS>
These
,
and
a
dark
-
complexioned
young
woman
,
with
a
habit
of
snorting
,
who
was
servant
to
the
family
,
and
informed
me
,
before
half
an
hour
had
expired
,
that
she
was
"
a
Orfling
"
,
and
came
from
St
Luke
's
workhouse
,
in
the
neighbourhood
,
completed
the
establishment
.
 
<EOS>
My
room
was
at
the
top
of
the
house
,
at
the
back
:
a
close
chamber
;
stencilled
all
over
with
an
ornament
which
my
young
imagination
represented
as
a
blue
muffin
;
and
very
scantily
furnished
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
thought
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
when
she
came
up
,
twin
and
all
,
to
show
me
the
apartment
,
and
sat
down
to
take
breath
,
"
before
I
was
married
,
<EOS>
when
I
lived
with
papa
and
mama
,
that
I
should
ever
find
it
necessary
to
take
a
lodger
.
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
Micawber
being
in
difficulties
,
all
considerations
of
private
feeling
must
give
way
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
:
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
ma'am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Micawber
's
difficulties
are
almost
overwhelming
just
at
present
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
;
"
and
whether
it
is
possible
to
bring
him
through
them
,
I
do
n't
know
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
lived
at
home
with
papa
and
mama
,
I
really
should
have
hardly
understood
what
the
word
meant
,
in
the
sense
in
which
I
now
employ
it
,
but
experientia
does
it
,
---
as
papa
used
to
say
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
can
not
satisfy
myself
whether
she
told
me
that
Mr
Micawber
had
been
an
officer
in
the
Marines
,
or
whether
I
have
imagined
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
know
that
I
believe
to
this
hour
that
he
WAS
in
the
Marines
once
upon
a
time
,
without
knowing
why
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
sort
of
town
traveller
for
a
number
of
miscellaneous
houses
,
now
;
but
made
little
or
nothing
of
it
,
I
am
afraid
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
Mr
Micawber
's
creditors
will
not
give
him
time
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
they
must
take
the
consequences
;
and
the
sooner
they
bring
it
to
an
issue
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
Blood
can
not
be
obtained
from
a
stone
,
neither
can
anything
on
account
be
obtained
at
present
(
not
to
mention
law
expenses
)
from
Mr
Micawber
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
never
can
quite
understand
whether
my
precocious
self
-
dependence
confused
Mrs
Micawber
in
reference
to
my
age
,
or
whether
she
was
so
full
of
the
subject
that
she
would
have
talked
about
it
to
the
very
twins
if
there
had
been
nobody
else
to
communicate
with
,
but
this
was
the
strain
in
which
she
began
,
and
she
went
on
accordingly
all
the
time
I
knew
her
.
   
<EOS>
Poor
Mrs
Micawber
!
 
<EOS>
She
said
she
had
tried
to
exert
herself
,
and
so
,
I
have
no
doubt
,
she
had
.
 
<EOS>
The
centre
of
the
street
door
was
perfectly
covered
with
a
great
brass
-
plate
,
on
which
was
engraved
"
Mrs
Micawber
's
Boarding
Establishment
for
Young
Ladies
"
:
<EOS>
but
I
never
found
that
any
young
lady
had
ever
been
to
school
there
;
or
that
any
young
lady
ever
came
,
or
proposed
to
come
;
or
that
the
least
preparation
was
ever
made
to
receive
any
young
lady
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
visitors
I
ever
saw
,
or
heard
of
,
were
creditors
.
 
<EOS>
THEY
used
to
come
at
all
hours
,
and
some
of
them
were
quite
ferocious
.
 
<EOS>
One
dirty
-
faced
man
<EOS>
,
I
think
he
was
a
boot
-
maker
,
used
to
edge
himself
into
the
passage
as
early
as
seven
o'clock
in
the
morning
,
and
call
up
the
stairs
to
Mr
Micawber
---
"
Come
!
 
<EOS>
You
ai
n't
out
yet
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
Pay
us
,
will
you
?
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
hide
,
you
know
;
that
's
mean
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
be
mean
if
I
was
you
.
 
<EOS>
Pay
us
,
will
you
?
 
<EOS>
You
just
pay
us
,
d'ye
hear
?
 
<EOS>
Come
!
"
 
<EOS>
Receiving
no
answer
to
these
taunts
,
he
would
mount
in
his
wrath
to
the
words
"
swindlers
"
and
"
robbers
"
;
and
these
being
ineffectual
too
,
would
sometimes
go
to
the
extremity
of
crossing
the
street
,
and
roaring
up
at
the
windows
of
the
second
floor
,
where
he
knew
Mr
Micawber
was
.
 
<EOS>
At
these
times
,
Mr
Micawber
would
be
transported
with
grief
and
mortification
,
even
to
the
length
(
as
I
was
once
made
aware
by
a
scream
from
his
wife
)
of
making
motions
at
himself
with
a
razor
;
but
within
half
-
an
-
hour
afterwards
,
he
would
polish
up
his
shoes
with
extraordinary
pains
,
and
go
out
,
humming
a
tune
with
a
greater
air
of
gentility
than
ever
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Micawber
was
quite
as
elastic
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
known
her
to
be
thrown
into
fainting
fits
by
the
king
's
taxes
at
three
o'clock
,
and
to
eat
lamb
chops
,
breaded
,
and
drink
warm
ale
(
paid
for
with
two
tea
-
spoons
that
had
gone
to
the
pawnbroker
's
)
at
four
.
 
<EOS>
On
one
occasion
,
when
an
execution
had
just
been
put
in
,
coming
home
through
some
chance
as
early
as
six
o'clock
,
I
saw
her
lying
(
of
course
with
a
twin
)
under
the
grate
in
a
swoon
,
with
her
hair
all
torn
about
her
face
;
but
I
never
knew
her
more
cheerful
than
she
was
,
that
very
same
night
,
over
a
veal
cutlet
before
the
kitchen
fire
,
telling
me
stories
about
her
papa
and
mama
,
and
the
company
they
used
to
keep
.
   
<EOS>
In
this
house
,
and
with
this
family
,
I
passed
my
leisure
time
.
 
<EOS>
My
own
exclusive
breakfast
of
a
penny
loaf
and
a
pennyworth
of
milk
<EOS>
,
I
provided
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
kept
another
small
loaf
,
and
a
modicum
of
cheese
,
on
a
particular
shelf
of
a
particular
cupboard
,
to
make
my
supper
on
when
I
came
back
at
night
.
 
<EOS>
This
made
a
hole
in
the
six
or
seven
shillings
,
I
know
well
;
and
I
was
out
at
the
warehouse
all
day
,
and
had
to
support
myself
on
that
money
all
the
week
.
 
<EOS>
From
Monday
morning
until
Saturday
night
,
I
had
no
advice
,
no
counsel
,
no
encouragement
,
no
consolation
,
no
assistance
,
no
support
,
of
any
kind
,
from
anyone
,
that
I
can
call
to
mind
,
as
I
hope
to
go
to
heaven
!
   
<EOS>
I
was
so
young
and
childish
,
and
so
little
qualified
<EOS>
---
how
could
I
be
otherwise
?
---
to
undertake
the
whole
charge
of
my
own
existence
,
that
often
,
in
going
to
Murdstone
and
Grinby
's
,
of
a
morning
,
I
could
not
resist
the
stale
pastry
put
out
for
sale
at
half
-
price
at
the
pastrycooks
'
doors
,
and
spent
in
that
the
money
I
should
have
kept
for
my
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
I
went
without
my
dinner
,
or
bought
a
roll
or
a
slice
of
pudding
.
 
<EOS>
I
remember
two
pudding
shops
,
between
which
I
was
divided
,
according
to
my
finances
.
 
<EOS>
One
was
in
a
court
close
to
St
Martin
's
Church
---
at
the
back
of
the
church
,
---
which
is
now
removed
altogether
.
 
<EOS>
The
pudding
at
that
shop
was
made
of
currants
,
and
was
rather
a
special
pudding
,
but
was
dear
,
twopennyworth
not
being
larger
than
a
pennyworth
of
more
ordinary
pudding
.
 
<EOS>
A
good
shop
for
the
latter
was
in
the
Strand
---
somewhere
in
that
part
which
has
been
rebuilt
since
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
stout
pale
pudding
,
heavy
and
flabby
,
and
with
great
flat
raisins
in
it
,
stuck
in
whole
at
wide
distances
apart
.
 
<EOS>
It
came
up
hot
at
about
my
time
every
day
,
and
many
a
day
did
I
dine
off
it
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
dined
regularly
and
handsomely
,
I
had
a
saveloy
and
a
penny
loaf
,
or
a
fourpenny
plate
of
red
beef
from
a
cook
's
shop
;
or
a
plate
of
bread
and
cheese
and
a
glass
of
beer
,
from
a
miserable
old
public
-
house
opposite
our
place
of
business
,
called
the
Lion
,
or
the
Lion
and
something
else
that
I
have
forgotten
.
 
<EOS>
Once
,
I
remember
carrying
my
own
bread
(
which
I
had
brought
from
home
in
the
morning
)
under
my
arm
,
wrapped
in
a
piece
of
paper
,
like
a
book
,
and
going
to
a
famous
alamode
beef
-
house
near
Drury
Lane
,
and
ordering
a
"
small
plate
"
of
that
delicacy
to
eat
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
What
the
waiter
thought
of
such
a
strange
little
apparition
coming
in
all
alone
,
I
do
n't
know
;
but
I
can
see
him
now
,
staring
at
me
as
I
ate
my
dinner
,
and
bringing
up
the
other
waiter
to
look
.
 
<EOS>
I
gave
him
a
halfpenny
for
himself
,
and
I
wish
he
had
n't
taken
it
.
   
<EOS>
We
had
half
-
an
-
hour
,
I
think
,
for
tea
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
had
money
enough
,
I
used
to
get
half
-
a
-
pint
of
ready
-
made
coffee
and
a
slice
of
bread
and
butter
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
had
none
,
I
used
to
look
at
a
venison
shop
in
Fleet
Street
;
or
I
have
strolled
,
at
such
a
time
,
as
far
as
Covent
Garden
Market
,
and
stared
at
the
pineapples
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
fond
of
wandering
about
the
Adelphi
,
because
it
was
a
mysterious
place
,
with
those
dark
arches
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
myself
emerging
one
evening
from
some
of
these
arches
,
on
a
little
public
-
house
close
to
the
river
,
with
an
open
space
before
it
,
where
some
coal
-
heavers
were
dancing
;
to
look
at
whom
I
sat
down
upon
a
bench
.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
what
they
thought
of
me
!
   
<EOS>
I
was
such
a
child
,
and
so
little
,
that
frequently
when
I
went
into
the
bar
of
a
strange
public
-
house
for
a
glass
of
ale
or
porter
,
to
moisten
what
I
had
had
for
dinner
,
they
were
afraid
to
give
it
me
.
<EOS>
I
remember
one
hot
evening
<EOS>
I
went
into
the
bar
of
a
public
-
house
,
and
said
to
the
landlord
:
"
What
is
your
best
---
your
very
best
---
ale
a
glass
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
For
it
was
a
special
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
have
been
my
birthday
.
   
<EOS>
"
Twopence
-
halfpenny
,
"
says
the
landlord
,
"
is
the
price
of
the
Genuine
Stunning
ale
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"
says
I
,
producing
the
money
,
"
just
draw
me
a
glass
of
the
Genuine
Stunning
,
if
you
please
,
with
a
good
head
to
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
landlord
looked
at
me
in
return
over
the
bar
,
from
head
to
foot
,
with
a
strange
smile
on
his
face
;
and
instead
of
drawing
the
beer
,
looked
round
the
screen
and
said
something
to
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
She
came
out
from
behind
it
,
with
her
work
in
her
hand
,
and
joined
him
in
surveying
me
.
 
<EOS>
Here
we
stand
,
all
three
,
before
me
now
.
 
<EOS>
The
landlord
in
his
shirt
-
sleeves
,
leaning
against
the
bar
window
-
frame
;
his
wife
looking
over
the
little
half
-
door
;
and
I
,
in
some
confusion
,
looking
up
at
them
from
outside
the
partition
.
<EOS>
They
asked
me
a
good
many
questions
;
as
,
what
my
name
was
,
<EOS>
how
old
I
was
,
where
I
lived
,
how
I
was
employed
,
and
how
I
came
there
.
 
<EOS>
To
all
of
which
,
that
I
might
commit
nobody
<EOS>
,
I
invented
,
I
am
afraid
,
appropriate
answers
.
 
<EOS>
They
served
me
with
the
ale
,
though
I
suspect
it
was
not
the
Genuine
Stunning
;
and
the
landlord
's
wife
,
opening
the
little
half
-
door
of
the
bar
,
and
bending
down
,
gave
me
my
money
back
,
and
gave
me
a
kiss
that
was
half
admiring
and
half
compassionate
,
but
all
womanly
and
good
,
I
am
sure
.
   
<EOS>
I
know
I
do
not
exaggerate
,
unconsciously
and
unintentionally
,
<EOS>
the
scantiness
of
my
resources
or
the
difficulties
of
my
life
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
that
if
a
shilling
were
given
me
by
Mr
Quinion
at
any
time
,
I
spent
it
in
a
dinner
or
a
tea
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
that
I
worked
,
from
morning
until
night
,
with
common
men
and
boys
,
a
shabby
child
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
that
I
lounged
about
the
streets
,
insufficiently
and
unsatisfactorily
fed
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
that
,
but
for
the
mercy
of
God
,
I
might
easily
have
been
,
for
any
care
that
was
taken
of
me
,
a
little
robber
or
a
little
vagabond
.
   
<EOS>
Yet
I
held
some
station
at
Murdstone
and
Grinby
's
too
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
that
Mr
Quinion
did
what
a
careless
man
so
occupied
,
and
dealing
with
a
thing
so
anomalous
,
could
,
to
treat
me
as
one
upon
a
different
footing
from
the
rest
,
I
never
said
,
to
man
or
boy
,
how
it
was
that
I
came
to
be
there
,
or
gave
the
least
indication
of
being
sorry
that
I
was
there
.
 
<EOS>
That
I
suffered
in
secret
,
and
that
I
suffered
exquisitely
,
no
one
ever
knew
but
I.
 
How
much
I
suffered
,
it
is
,
as
I
have
said
already
,
utterly
beyond
my
power
to
tell
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
kept
my
own
counsel
,
and
I
did
my
work
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
from
the
first
,
that
,
if
I
could
not
do
my
work
as
well
as
any
of
the
rest
,
I
could
not
hold
myself
above
slight
and
contempt
.
 
<EOS>
I
soon
became
at
least
as
expeditious
and
as
skilful
as
either
of
the
other
boys
.
 
<EOS>
Though
perfectly
familiar
with
them
,
my
conduct
and
manner
were
different
enough
from
theirs
to
place
a
space
between
us
.
 
<EOS>
They
and
the
men
generally
spoke
of
me
as
"
the
little
gent
"
,
or
"
the
young
Suffolker
.
"
 
<EOS>
A
certain
man
named
Gregory
,
who
was
foreman
of
the
packers
,
and
another
named
Tipp
,
who
was
the
carman
,
and
wore
a
red
jacket
,
used
to
address
me
sometimes
as
"
David
"
:
<EOS>
but
I
think
it
was
mostly
when
we
were
very
confidential
,
and
when
I
had
made
some
efforts
to
entertain
them
,
over
our
work
,
with
some
results
of
the
old
readings
;
which
were
fast
perishing
out
of
my
remembrance
.
 
<EOS>
Mealy
Potatoes
uprose
once
,
and
rebelled
against
my
being
so
distinguished
;
but
Mick
Walker
settled
him
in
no
time
.
   
<EOS>
My
rescue
from
this
kind
of
existence
<EOS>
I
considered
quite
hopeless
,
and
abandoned
,
as
such
,
altogether
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
solemnly
convinced
that
I
never
for
one
hour
was
reconciled
to
it
,
or
was
otherwise
than
miserably
unhappy
;
but
I
bore
it
;
and
even
to
Peggotty
,
partly
for
the
love
of
her
and
partly
for
shame
,
never
in
any
letter
(
though
many
passed
between
us
)
revealed
the
truth
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
's
difficulties
were
an
addition
to
the
distressed
state
of
my
mind
.
 
<EOS>
In
my
forlorn
state
I
became
quite
attached
to
the
family
,
and
used
to
walk
about
,
busy
with
Mrs
Micawber
's
calculations
of
ways
and
means
,
and
heavy
with
the
weight
of
Mr
Micawber
's
debts
.
 
<EOS>
On
a
Saturday
night
,
which
was
my
grand
treat
,
---
partly
because
it
was
a
great
thing
to
walk
home
with
six
or
seven
shillings
in
my
pocket
,
looking
into
the
shops
and
thinking
what
such
a
sum
would
buy
,
and
partly
because
I
went
home
early
,
---
Mrs
Micawber
would
make
the
most
heart
-
rending
confidences
to
me
;
also
on
a
Sunday
morning
,
when
I
mixed
the
portion
of
tea
or
coffee
I
had
bought
over
-
night
,
in
a
little
shaving
-
pot
,
and
sat
late
at
my
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
nothing
at
all
unusual
for
Mr
Micawber
to
sob
violently
at
the
beginning
of
one
of
these
Saturday
night
conversations
,
and
sing
about
jack
's
delight
being
his
lovely
Nan
,
towards
the
end
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
known
him
come
home
to
supper
with
a
flood
of
tears
,
and
a
declaration
that
nothing
was
now
left
but
a
jail
;
and
go
to
bed
making
a
calculation
of
the
expense
of
putting
bow
-
windows
to
the
house
,
"
in
case
anything
turned
up
"
,
which
was
his
favourite
expression
.
 
<EOS>
And
Mrs
Micawber
was
just
the
same
.
   
<EOS>
A
curious
equality
of
friendship
,
originating
,
I
suppose
,
in
our
respective
circumstances
,
sprung
up
between
me
and
these
people
,
notwithstanding
the
ludicrous
disparity
in
our
years
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
never
allowed
myself
to
be
prevailed
upon
to
accept
any
invitation
to
eat
and
drink
with
them
out
of
their
stock
(
knowing
that
they
got
on
badly
with
the
butcher
and
baker
,
and
had
often
not
too
much
for
themselves
)
,
until
Mrs
Micawber
took
me
into
her
entire
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
This
<EOS>
she
did
one
evening
as
follows
:
   
<EOS>
"
Master
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
I
make
no
stranger
of
you
,
and
therefore
do
not
hesitate
to
say
that
Mr
Micawber
's
difficulties
are
coming
to
a
crisis
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
It
made
me
very
miserable
to
hear
it
,
and
I
looked
at
Mrs
Micawber
's
red
eyes
with
the
utmost
sympathy
.
   
<EOS>
"
With
the
exception
of
the
heel
of
a
Dutch
cheese
---
which
is
not
adapted
to
the
wants
of
a
young
family
"
---
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
there
is
really
not
a
scrap
of
anything
in
the
larder
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
accustomed
to
speak
of
the
larder
when
I
lived
with
papa
and
mama
,
and
I
use
the
word
almost
unconsciously
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
mean
to
express
is
,
that
there
is
nothing
to
eat
in
the
house
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I
said
,
in
great
concern
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
two
or
three
shillings
of
my
week
's
money
in
my
pocket
---
<EOS>
from
which
I
presume
that
it
must
have
been
on
a
Wednesday
night
when
we
held
this
conversation
---
and
I
hastily
produced
them
,
and
with
heartfelt
emotion
begged
Mrs
Micawber
to
accept
of
them
as
a
loan
.
<EOS>
But
that
lady
,
kissing
me
,
and
making
me
put
them
back
in
my
pocket
,
replied
that
she
could
n't
think
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
my
dear
Master
Copperfield
,
"
said
she
,
"
far
be
it
from
my
thoughts
!
 
<EOS>
But
you
have
a
discretion
beyond
your
years
,
and
can
render
me
another
kind
of
service
,
if
you
will
;
and
a
service
I
will
thankfully
accept
of
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
begged
Mrs
Micawber
to
name
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
parted
with
the
plate
myself
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
"
Six
tea
,
two
salt
,
and
a
pair
of
sugars
,
I
have
at
different
times
borrowed
money
on
,
in
secret
,
with
my
own
hands
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
twins
are
a
great
tie
;
and
to
me
,
with
my
recollections
,
of
papa
and
mama
,
these
transactions
are
very
painful
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
still
a
few
trifles
that
we
could
part
with
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
's
feelings
would
never
allow
him
to
dispose
of
them
;
and
Clickett
"
---
this
was
the
girl
from
the
workhouse
---
"
being
of
a
vulgar
mind
,
would
take
painful
liberties
if
so
much
confidence
was
reposed
in
her
.
 
<EOS>
Master
Copperfield
,
if
I
might
ask
you
---
"
   
I
understood
Mrs
Micawber
now
,
and
begged
her
to
make
use
of
me
to
any
extent
.
 
<EOS>
I
began
to
dispose
of
the
more
portable
articles
of
property
that
very
evening
;
and
went
out
on
a
similar
expedition
almost
every
morning
,
before
I
went
to
Murdstone
and
Grinby
's
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
had
a
few
books
on
a
little
chiffonier
,
which
he
called
the
library
;
and
those
went
first
.
 
<EOS>
I
carried
them
,
one
after
another
,
to
a
bookstall
in
the
City
Road
---
<EOS>
one
part
of
which
,
near
our
house
,
was
almost
all
bookstalls
and
bird
shops
then
---
and
sold
them
for
whatever
they
would
bring
.
 
<EOS>
The
keeper
of
this
bookstall
,
who
lived
in
a
little
house
behind
it
,
used
to
get
tipsy
every
night
,
and
to
be
violently
scolded
by
his
wife
every
morning
.
<EOS>
More
than
once
,
when
I
went
there
early
,
I
had
audience
of
him
in
a
turn
-
up
bedstead
,
with
a
cut
in
his
forehead
or
a
black
eye
,
bearing
witness
to
his
excesses
over
-
night
<EOS>
(
I
am
afraid
he
was
quarrelsome
in
his
drink
)
,
and
he
,
with
a
shaking
hand
,
endeavouring
to
find
the
needful
shillings
in
one
or
other
of
the
pockets
of
his
clothes
,
which
lay
upon
the
floor
,
while
his
wife
,
with
a
baby
in
her
arms
and
her
shoes
down
at
heel
,
never
left
off
rating
him
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
he
had
lost
his
money
,
and
then
he
would
ask
me
to
call
again
;
but
his
wife
had
always
got
some
---
had
taken
his
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
,
while
he
was
drunk
---
and
secretly
completed
the
bargain
on
the
stairs
,
as
we
went
down
together
.
<EOS>
At
the
pawnbroker
's
shop
,
too
,
I
began
to
be
very
well
known
.
 
<EOS>
The
principal
gentleman
who
officiated
behind
the
counter
,
took
a
good
deal
of
notice
of
me
;
and
often
got
me
,
I
recollect
,
to
decline
a
Latin
noun
or
adjective
,
or
to
conjugate
a
Latin
verb
,
in
his
ear
,
while
he
transacted
my
business
.
 
<EOS>
After
all
these
occasions
Mrs
Micawber
made
a
little
treat
,
which
was
generally
a
supper
;
and
there
was
a
peculiar
relish
in
these
meals
which
I
well
remember
.
   
<EOS>
At
last
Mr
Micawber
's
difficulties
came
to
a
crisis
,
and
he
was
arrested
early
one
morning
,
and
carried
over
to
the
King
's
Bench
Prison
in
the
Borough
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
me
,
as
he
went
out
of
the
house
,
that
the
God
of
day
had
now
gone
down
upon
him
---
and
I
really
thought
his
heart
was
broken
and
mine
too
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
heard
,
afterwards
,
that
he
was
seen
to
play
a
lively
game
at
skittles
,
before
noon
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
first
Sunday
after
he
was
taken
there
,
I
was
to
go
and
see
him
,
and
have
dinner
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
ask
my
way
to
such
a
place
,
and
just
short
of
that
place
<EOS>
I
should
see
such
another
place
,
and
just
short
of
that
I
should
see
a
yard
,
which
I
was
to
cross
,
and
keep
straight
on
until
I
saw
a
turnkey
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
I
did
;
and
when
at
last
I
did
see
a
turnkey
(
poor
little
fellow
that
I
was
!
)
,
and
thought
how
,
when
Roderick
Random
was
in
a
debtors
'
prison
,
there
was
a
man
there
with
nothing
on
him
but
an
old
rug
,
the
turnkey
swam
before
my
dimmed
eyes
and
my
beating
heart
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
was
waiting
for
me
within
the
gate
,
and
we
went
up
to
his
room
(
top
story
but
one
)
,
and
cried
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
He
solemnly
conjured
me
,
I
remember
,
to
take
warning
by
his
fate
;
and
to
observe
that
if
a
man
had
twenty
pounds
a
-
year
for
his
income
,
and
spent
nineteen
pounds
nineteen
shillings
and
sixpence
,
he
would
be
happy
,
but
that
if
he
spent
twenty
pounds
one
he
would
be
miserable
.
 
<EOS>
After
which
he
borrowed
a
shilling
of
me
for
porter
,
gave
me
a
written
order
on
Mrs
Micawber
for
the
amount
,
and
put
away
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
and
cheered
up
.
   
<EOS>
We
sat
before
a
little
fire
,
with
two
bricks
put
within
the
rusted
grate
,
one
on
each
side
,
to
prevent
its
burning
too
many
coals
;
until
another
debtor
,
who
shared
the
room
with
Mr
Micawber
,
came
in
from
the
bakehouse
with
the
loin
of
mutton
which
was
our
joint
-
stock
repast
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
was
sent
up
to
"
Captain
Hopkins
"
in
the
room
overhead
,
with
Mr
Micawber
's
compliments
,
and
I
was
his
young
friend
,
and
would
Captain
Hopkins
lend
me
a
knife
and
fork
.
   
<EOS>
Captain
Hopkins
lent
me
the
knife
and
fork
,
with
his
compliments
to
Mr
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
very
dirty
lady
in
his
little
room
,
and
two
wan
girls
,
his
daughters
,
with
shock
heads
of
hair
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
it
was
better
to
borrow
Captain
Hopkins
's
knife
and
fork
,
than
Captain
Hopkins
's
comb
.
 
<EOS>
The
Captain
himself
was
in
the
last
extremity
of
shabbiness
,
with
large
whiskers
,
and
an
old
,
old
brown
great
-
coat
with
no
other
coat
below
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
his
bed
rolled
up
in
a
corner
;
and
what
plates
and
dishes
and
pots
he
had
,
on
a
shelf
;
and
I
divined
(
God
knows
how
)
that
though
the
two
girls
with
the
shock
heads
of
hair
were
Captain
Hopkins
's
children
,
the
dirty
lady
was
not
married
to
Captain
Hopkins
.
 
<EOS>
My
timid
station
on
his
threshold
was
not
occupied
more
than
a
couple
of
minutes
at
most
;
but
I
came
down
again
with
all
this
in
my
knowledge
,
as
surely
as
the
knife
and
fork
were
in
my
hand
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
something
gipsy
-
like
and
agreeable
in
the
dinner
,
after
all
.
 
<EOS>
I
took
back
Captain
Hopkins
's
knife
and
fork
early
in
the
afternoon
,
and
went
home
to
comfort
Mrs
Micawber
with
an
account
of
my
visit
.
 
<EOS>
She
fainted
when
she
saw
me
return
,
and
made
a
little
jug
of
egg
-
hot
afterwards
to
console
us
while
we
talked
it
over
.
   
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
the
household
furniture
came
to
be
sold
for
the
family
benefit
,
or
who
sold
it
,
except
that
I
did
not
.
 
<EOS>
Sold
it
was
,
however
,
and
carried
away
in
a
van
;
except
the
bed
,
a
few
chairs
,
and
the
kitchen
table
.
 
<EOS>
With
these
possessions
we
encamped
,
as
it
were
,
in
the
two
parlours
of
the
emptied
house
in
Windsor
Terrace
;
<EOS>
Mrs
Micawber
,
the
children
,
the
Orfling
,
and
myself
;
and
lived
in
those
rooms
night
and
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
idea
for
how
long
,
though
it
seems
to
me
for
a
long
time
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
Mrs
Micawber
resolved
to
move
into
the
prison
,
where
Mr
Micawber
had
now
secured
a
room
to
himself
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
took
the
key
of
the
house
to
the
landlord
,
who
was
very
glad
to
get
it
;
and
the
beds
were
sent
over
to
the
King
's
Bench
,
except
mine
,
for
which
a
little
room
was
hired
outside
the
walls
in
the
neighbourhood
of
that
Institution
,
very
much
to
my
satisfaction
,
since
the
Micawbers
<EOS>
and
I
had
become
too
used
to
one
another
,
in
our
troubles
,
to
part
.
 
<EOS>
The
Orfling
was
likewise
accommodated
with
an
inexpensive
lodging
in
the
same
neighbourhood
.
 
<EOS>
Mine
was
a
quiet
back
-
garret
with
a
sloping
roof
,
commanding
a
pleasant
prospect
of
a
timberyard
;
and
when
I
took
possession
of
it
,
with
the
reflection
that
Mr
Micawber
's
troubles
had
come
to
a
crisis
at
last
,
I
thought
it
quite
a
paradise
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
time
I
was
working
at
Murdstone
and
Grinby
's
in
the
same
common
way
,
and
with
the
same
common
companions
,
and
with
the
same
sense
of
unmerited
degradation
as
at
first
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
never
,
happily
for
me
no
doubt
,
made
a
single
acquaintance
,
or
spoke
to
any
of
the
many
boys
whom
I
saw
daily
in
going
to
the
warehouse
,
in
coming
from
it
,
and
in
prowling
about
the
streets
at
meal
-
times
.
 
<EOS>
I
led
the
same
secretly
unhappy
life
;
but
I
led
it
in
the
same
lonely
,
self
-
reliant
manner
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
changes
I
am
conscious
of
are
,
firstly
,
that
I
had
grown
more
shabby
,
and
secondly
,
that
I
was
now
relieved
of
much
of
the
weight
of
Mr
and
Mrs
Micawber
's
cares
;
for
some
relatives
or
friends
had
engaged
to
help
them
at
their
present
pass
,
and
they
lived
more
comfortably
in
the
prison
than
they
had
lived
for
a
long
while
out
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
used
to
breakfast
with
them
now
,
in
virtue
of
some
arrangement
,
of
which
I
have
forgotten
the
details
.
 
<EOS>
I
forget
,
too
,
at
what
hour
the
gates
were
opened
in
the
morning
,
admitting
of
my
going
in
;
but
I
know
that
I
was
often
up
at
six
o'clock
,
and
that
my
favourite
lounging
-
place
in
the
interval
was
old
London
Bridge
,
where
I
was
wo
nt
to
sit
in
one
of
the
stone
recesses
,
watching
the
people
going
by
,
or
to
look
over
the

at
the
sun
shining
in
the
water
,
and
lighting
up
the
golden
flame
on
the
top
of
the
Monument
.
 
<EOS>
The
Orfling
met
me
here
sometimes
,
to
be
told
some
astonishing
fictions
respecting
the
wharves
and
the
Tower
;
of
which
I
can
say
no
more
than
that
<EOS>
I
hope
I
believed
them
myself
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
evening
I
used
to
go
back
to
the
prison
,
and
walk
up
and
down
the
parade
with
Mr
Micawber
;
or
play
casino
with
Mrs
Micawber
,
and
hear
reminiscences
of
her
papa
and
mama
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
Mr
Murdstone
knew
where
I
was
,
I
am
unable
to
say
.
<EOS>
I
never
told
them
at
Murdstone
and
Grinby
's
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
's
affairs
,
although
past
their
crisis
,
were
very
much
involved
by
reason
of
a
certain
"
Deed
"
,
of
which
I
used
to
hear
a
great
deal
,
and
which
I
suppose
,
now
,
to
have
been
some
former
composition
with
his
creditors
,
though
I
was
so
far
from
being
clear
about
it
then
,
that
I
am
conscious
of
having

with
those
demoniacal

which
are
held
to
have
,
once
upon
a
time
,
obtained
to
a
great

in
Germany
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
this
document
appeared
to
be
got
out
of
the
way
,
somehow
;
at
all
events
it
ceased
to
be
the
rock
-
ahead
it
had

;
and
Mrs
Micawber

that
"
her
family
"
had

that
Mr
Micawber
should

for

under
the
Insolvent

Act
,
which
would
set
him
free
,
she
expected
,
in
about

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
then
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
who
was
present
,
"
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
I
shall
,
please

,
begin
to
be
beforehand
with
the
world
,
and
to
live
in

new

,
if
---
in

,
if
anything
turns

.
"
   
<EOS>
By
way
of
going
in
for
anything
that
might
be
on
the
cards
,
I
call
to
mind
that
Mr
Micawber
,
about
this
time
,
composed
a
petition
to
the
House
of
Commons
,
praying
for
an
alteration
in
the
law
of
imprisonment
for
debt
.
 
<EOS>
I
set
down
this
remembrance
here
,
because
it
is
an
instance
to
myself
of
the
manner
in
which
I
fitted
my
old
books
to
my
altered
life
,
and
made
stories
for
myself
,
out
of
the
streets
,
and
out
of
men
and
women
;
and
how
some
main
points
in
the
character
I
shall
unconsciously
develop
,
I
suppose
,
in
writing
my
life
,
were
gradually
forming
all
this
while
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
club
in
the
prison
,
in
which
Mr
Micawber
,
as
a
gentleman
,
was
a
great
authority
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
had
stated
his
idea
of
this
petition
to
the
club
,
and
the
club
had
strongly
approved
of
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
Wherefore
Mr
Micawber
(
who
was
a
thoroughly
good
-
natured
man
,
and
as
active
a
creature
about
everything
but
his
own
affairs
as
ever
existed
,
and
never
so
happy
as
when
he
was
busy
about
something
that
could
never
be
of
any
profit
to
him
)
set
to
work
at
the
petition
,
invented
it
,
engrossed
it
on
an
immense
sheet
of
paper
,
spread
it
out
on
a
table
,
and
appointed
a
time
for
all

club
,
and
all
within
the
walls
if
they
chose
,
to
come
up
to
his
room
and
sign

.
   
<EOS>
When
I
heard
of
this
approaching
ceremony
,
I
was
so
anxious
to
see
them
all
come
in
,
one
after
another
,
though
I
knew
the
greater
part
of
them
already
,
and
they
me
,
that
I
got
an
hour
's
leave
of
absence
from
Murdstone
and
Grinby
's
,
and
established
myself
in
a
corner
for
that

.
 
<EOS>
As
many
of
the
principal
members
of
the
club
as
could
be
got
into
the
small
room
without
filling
it
,
supported
Mr
Micawber
in
front
of
the
petition
,
while
my
old
friend
Captain
Hopkins
(
who
had
washed
himself
,
to
do
honour
to
so
solemn
an
occasion
)
<EOS>
stationed
himself
close
to
it
,
to
read
it
to
all
who
were
unacquainted
with
its
contents
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
was
then
thrown
open
,
and
the
general
population
began
to
come
in
,
in
a
long
file
:
several
waiting
outside
,
while
one
entered
,
affixed
his
signature
,
and
went
out
.
 
<EOS>
To
everybody
in
succession
,
Captain
Hopkins
said
:
"
Have
you
read
it
?
"
---
"
No
.
"
 
---
"
Would
you
like
to
hear
it
read
?
"
 
<EOS>
If
he
weakly
showed
the
least
disposition
to
hear
it
,
Captain
Hopkins
,
in
a
loud
sonorous
voice
,
gave
him
every
word
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
Captain
would
have
read
it
twenty
thousand
times
,
if
twenty
thousand
people
would
have
heard
him
,
one
by
one
.
 
<EOS>
I
remember
a
certain
luscious
roll
he
gave
to
such

as
"
The
people
's
representatives
in
Parliament
assembled
,
"
"
Your
petitioners
therefore
humbly
approach
your
honourable
house
,
"
"
His
gracious
Majesty
's
unfortunate
subjects
,
"
as
if
the
words
were
something
real
in
his
mouth
,
and
delicious
to
taste
;
Mr
Micawber
,
meanwhile
,
listening
with
a
little
of
an
author
's
vanity
,
and
contemplating
(
not
severely
)
the
spikes
on
the
opposite
wall
.
   
<EOS>
As
I
walked
to
and
fro
daily
between
Southwark
and
Blackfriars
,
and
lounged
about
at
meal
-
times
in
obscure

,
the
stones
of
which
may
,
for
anything
I
know
,
be
worn
at
this
moment
by
my
childish
feet
,
I
wonder
how
many
of
these
people
were
wanting
in
the
crowd
that
used
to
come
filing
before
me
in
review
again
,
to
the
echo
of
Captain
Hopkins
's
voice
!
 
<EOS>
When
my
thoughts
go
back
,
now
,
to
that
slow

of
my
youth
,
I
wonder
how
much
of
the
histories
I
invented
for
such
people
hangs
like
a
mist
of
fancy
over
well
-
remembered

!
 
<EOS>
When
I
tread
the
old
ground
,
I
do
not
wonder
that
I
seem
to
see
and
pity
,
going
on
before
me
,
an
innocent
romantic
boy
,
making
his
imaginative
world
out
of
such
strange
experiences
and
sordid
things
!
      
<EOS>
Chapter
12
.
<EOS>
Liking
life
on
my
own
account
no
better
,
I
form
a
great
resolution
 
<EOS>
In
due
time
,
Mr
Micawber
's
petition
was
ripe
for
hearing
;
and
that
gentleman
was
ordered
to
be
discharged
under
the
Act
,
to
my
great
joy
.
 
<EOS>
His
creditors
were
not
implacable
;
and
Mrs
Micawber
informed
me
that
even
the
revengeful
boot
-
maker
had
declared
in
open
court
that
he
bore
him
no
malice
,
but
that
when
money
was
owing
to
him
he
liked
to
be
paid
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
he
thought
it
was
human
nature
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
returned
to
the
King
's
Bench
when
his
case
was
over
,
as
some
fees
were
to
be
settled
,
and
some

,
before
he
could
be
actually

.
 
<EOS>
The
club
received
him
with
transport
,
and
held
an
harmonic

that
evening
in
his

;
while
Mrs
Micawber
and
I
had
a
lamb
's

in

,
surrounded
by
the
sleeping
family
.
   
<EOS>
"
On
such

occasion
I
will

,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
in

flip
,
"
for
we
had
been
having
some
already
,
"
the
memory

my

and

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
they
dead
,
ma'am
?
<EOS>
"
I

,
after

in

.
   
<EOS>
"
My
mama
departed
this
life
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
before
Mr
Micawber
's
difficulties
commenced
,
or
at
least

.
 
<EOS>
My
papa
lived
to
bail
Mr
Micawber
several
times
,
and
then
expired
,
regretted
by
a
numerous
circle
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Micawber
shook
her
head
,
and
dropped
a
pious
tear
upon
the
twin
who
happened
to
be
in
hand
.
   
<EOS>
As
I
could
hardly
hope
for
a
more
favourable
opportunity
of
putting
a
question
in
which
I
had
a
near
interest
,
I
said
to
Mrs
Micawber
:
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
ask
,
ma'am
,
what
you

Mr
Micawber

do
,
now
that
Mr
Micawber
is
out

,
and

?
 
<EOS>
Have
you
settled
yet
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
family
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
who
always
said

with
an
air
,
though
I
never

discover
who
came
under

,
"
my
family
are
of
opinion
that
Mr
Micawber
should
quit
London
,
and
exert

in
the
country
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
is
a
man
of
great
talent
,
Master
Copperfield
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
I
was
sure
of
that
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
great
talent
,
"
repeated
Mrs
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
family
are
of
opinion
,
that
,
with
a
little
interest
,
something
might
be
done
for
a
man
of
his
ability
in
the
Custom
House
.
 
<EOS>
The
influence
of
my
family
being
local
,
it
is
their
wish
that
Mr
Micawber
should
go
down
to
Plymouth
.
 
<EOS>
They
think
it
indispensable
that
he
should
be
upon
the
spot
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
he
may
be
ready
?
<EOS>
"
I
suggested
.
   
<EOS>
"
Exactly
,
"
returned
Mrs

.
 
<EOS>
"
That
he
may
be
ready
---
in
case

anything
turning
up
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
do

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
The
events
of

,
in

with
the
twins
,
if
not
with
the
flip
,
had
made
Mrs
Micawber
hysterical
,
and
she

as
she

:
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
will
desert
Mr
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
may
have
concealed
his
difficulties
from
me
in
the
first

,
but
his
sanguine
temper
may
have
led

to
expect
that
he
would
overcome
them
.
 
<EOS>
The

from

,
have
been
disposed

for
less

;
and

coral
,
which
was
the
wedding

of

,
has
been
actually

for
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
never
will
desert
Mr
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
No
!
"
cried
Mrs
Micawber
,
more

before
,
"
I
never
will
do
it
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
of
no
use

me
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
quite
uncomfortable
---
as
if
Mrs

I

to

anything

!
---

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr

has
his

.
 
<EOS>
I
do

.
 
<EOS>
I

that
he
has
kept

in

his
liabilities
both
,
"
she

"
but

never

Mr
Micawber
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs

that

,
and
disturbed
Mr

,

of
   
Gee

,

,

Dobbin
,
Gee

,

<EOS>
o
---
o
!
   
with

Mrs

was

,

<EOS>
"
Emma
,

"

,

"
what

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

!
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>

!
<EOS>
He

"

"
and
<EOS>
I

---
<EOS>
ver
<EOS>
---

---

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

(

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Consequently

was
soon

,
that

and

;
until

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
but
he
would
not
hear
of
my

until

.
 
<EOS>
So
I
sat
at
the

window
,
until

.
   
<EOS>
"
How

,

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,
"

;
"
reaction
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
this
has

!
 
<EOS>
We
stand

now
---
everything
is
gone
from

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
pressed
my

,
and
groaned
,
and
afterwards
shed
tears
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
greatly
touched
,
and

,
for
I

expected
that
we
should
be
quite
gay
on
this
happy

-

.
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
and
Mrs
Micawber
were
so
used

,
I

,
that
they

.
 
<EOS>
All

was

,
and
I
never
saw

half
<EOS>
so

as
on

;
insomuch
that
when

,

Mr

,

,
I

quite
afraid

leave
him
by

,
he

.
   
<EOS>
But
through
all

,

,

,
I
plainly
discerned
that
Mr

Micawber
and
their
family
were
going
away
from
London
,
and
that
a

between

near

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

,
that

first

to

---
though
I
do
n't

how

came

---
which
afterwards
shaped

into
a
settled

.
   
<EOS>
I
had
grown
to

so
accustomed
to
the

,
and
had

so
intimate
with
them
in
their

,
and

,
that
the

upon
some

for

,

among

,
was
like

that

,
with
such

of

ready
made
as
experience

given

.
 
<EOS>
All
the
sensitive
feelings
it
wounded
so
cruelly
<EOS>
,
all

shame
and
misery
it
kept
alive
within

,
became
more
poignant
as
I
thought
of
this
;
and
I
determined
that
the
life
was
unendurable
.
   
<EOS>
That
there
was
no
hope
of
escape
from
it
,
<EOS>
unless
the

was
my

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
rarely

from
Miss
Murdstone
,
and
never
from
Mr
Murdstone
:
but

,

,

that
J*M
trusted
D*C
was
applying

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

,

,
that

.
 
<EOS>
They

,

;

<EOS>

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

Tipp

,

,

by

,

;

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
On

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

Wilkins
Micawber
<EOS>
---

.
 
<EOS>
I

Orfling
,

.
   
<EOS>
We

,

<EOS>
"
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Your

.
 
<EOS>
You
have
never

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My

,
"

;
"
Copperfield
,
"
for

,

"

,

,

---

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,
"

;

<EOS>
---
<EOS>

<EOS>
At

"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

"
the

.
 
<EOS>
My

.
 
<EOS>
Procrastination

.
 
<EOS>
Collar

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My

's

,
"
Mrs

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
Take

in
all
,

---

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

,

.
"
 
<EOS>

"
Not

.
 
<EOS>
Quite

,
my

.
"
 
<EOS>
After

.
   
<EOS>
"
My

,
Copperfield
,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
Annual
income
twenty

,
annual

nineteen
nineteen
and
six
,

.
 
<EOS>
Annual
income
twenty

,
annual

twenty
pounds
ought
and
six
,
result
misery
.
 
<EOS>
The
blossom
is
blighted
,
the
leaf

,

down

dreary

,

---

.
<EOS>
As
I
am
!
"
   
<EOS>
To

the
more

,
Mr

with
an

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
I
did
not
fail

that
I

in

,
though

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Next

at

,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Master
Copperfield
,
"
said

,
"
God

!
 
<EOS>
I
never
can
forget
all
that
,
you
know
,
and
I
never
would
if
I
could
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
farewell
!
 
<EOS>
Every
happiness
and
prosperity
!
 
<EOS>
If
,
in
the
progress
of
revolving
years
,
I
could
persuade
myself
that
my
blighted
destiny
had
been
a
warning
to
you
,
I
should
feel
that
I
had
not
occupied
another
man
's
place
in
existence
altogether
in
vain
.
 
<EOS>
In
case
of
anything
turning
up
(
of
which
I
am
rather
confident
)
,
I
shall
be
extremely
happy
if
it
should
be
in
my
power
to
improve
your
prospects
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
think
,
as
Mrs
Micawber
sat
at
the
back

,
with
the
children
,
and
I
stood
in

,
a

,
and
she

.
 
<EOS>
I
think

,
because

beckoned

to

,
with

,

<EOS>
round

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
I
had
barely

before
the

,
and
I
could

see
the
family
for

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
gone
in

minute
.
 
<EOS>
The
Orfling
and

stood

,
and
then

said

-
bye
<EOS>
;
she
going
back
,
I
suppose
,
to
St
Luke
's
workhouse
,
as
I
went
to
begin
my
weary

at
Murdstone
and
Grinby
's
.
   
<EOS>
But
with
no

of
passing
many
more

there
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
I
had
resolved
to
run
away
.
 
<EOS>
---
To
go
,
by
some
means
or
other
,
down
into
the
country
,
to
the
only
relation
I
had
in
the
world
,
and
tell

story
to

aunt
,
Miss
Betsey
.
<EOS>
I
have
already
observed
that
I
do
n't

this

came

.
 
<EOS>
But
,

,

;
and

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
   
<EOS>
Again
,

,

,

,
I

gone

that

story
of
my
poor
mother
<EOS>
's
about

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
My

,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

.
 
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
As

<EOS>
Peggotty

<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
One

,

.
   
<EOS>
Being

,

I

,

.
 
<EOS>

-

,

.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
,

came
,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
My

,

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

To

<EOS>

<EOS>

Done

<EOS>
Now
,

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

,

Wot
!
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
This

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

"
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come

"

<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

,

"
I

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

:
"

the

!
"

<EOS>
I
ran

as

,
but

,

should

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Now

,

,

,

,

<EOS>
At

;

,

:

<EOS>
Chapter
13
.
<EOS>
The
sequel
of
my
resolution
 
For
anything
I
know
,
I
may

Dover
,
when

,

.
 
<EOS>
My

were
soon

as

,
if

had
;
for
I
came
to

in
the

,
at

piece

water
before

,

a

image
in

,

.
<EOS>
Here
I
sat

,

with

I
had
already
made
,
and
with
hardly
breath

to
cry
for

my

-

.
   
<EOS>
It
was
by
this
time
dark
<EOS>
;
I
heard
the
clocks
strike
ten
,
as
I
sat
resting
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
was
a
summer
night
,
fortunately
,
and
fine
weather
.
<EOS>
When
I
had

,
and
had

of
a

in
my

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
In

my

,
I
had
no

of
going
back
.
 
<EOS>
I
doubt

I
should
have
had
any
,
though
there
had

a
Swiss
snow
-
drift
in

Kent
Road
.
   
<EOS>
But
my
standing
possessed
of
only
three
-
halfpence
in
the
world
(
and
I
am
sure
I
wonder
how

!
)
<EOS>
troubled
me
none

.
 
<EOS>
I
began

picture

,
as

intelligence
,
my

in

,

;
and
I

,

,
until

,
where

written
up
that
ladies
'
and

's

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
The
master
of
this

was

in

,

;
and
as

ceiling
,
and
<EOS>
only
two
feeble
candles
burning
inside
to
show
what
they
were
,
I
fancied
that
he
looked
like
a
man
of
a
revengeful
disposition
,
who
had
hung
all
his
enemies
,
and
was
enjoying
himself
.
   
<EOS>
My
late
experiences
with
Mr
and
Mrs
Micawber
suggested
to
me
that
here
might
be
a
means
of
keeping
off
the
wolf
for
a
little
while
.
<EOS>
I
went
up
the
next
by
-
street
,
took
off
my
waistcoat
,
rolled
it
neatly
under
my
arm
,
and
came
back
to
the
shop
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
sir
,
"
I
said
,
"
I
am
to
sell
this
for
a
fair
price
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dolloby
<EOS>
---
Dolloby
was
the
name
over
the
shop
door
,
at
least
---
took
the
waistcoat
,
stood
his
pipe
on
its
head
,
against
the
door
-
post
,
went
into
the
shop
,
followed
by
me
,
snuffed
the
two
candles
with
his
fingers
,
spread
the
waistcoat
on
the
counter
,
and
looked
at
it
there
,
held
it
up
against
the
light
,
and
looked
at
it
there
,
and
ultimately
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
What
do
you
call
a
price
,
now
,
for
this
here
little
weskit
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
you
know
best
,
sir
,
"
I
returned
modestly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
be
buyer
and
seller
too
,
"
said
Mr
Dolloby
.
 
<EOS>
"
Put
a
price
on
this
here
little
weskit
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Would
eighteenpence
be
?
"
<EOS>
---
I
hinted
,
after
some
hesitation
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dolloby
rolled
it
up
again
,
and
gave
it
me
back
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
rob
my
family
,
"
he
said
,
"
if
I
was
to
offer
ninepence
for
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
a
disagreeable
way
of
putting
the
business
;
because
it
imposed
upon
me
,
a
perfect
stranger
,
the
unpleasantness
of
asking
Mr
Dolloby
to
rob
his
family
on
my
account
.
 
<EOS>
My
circumstances
being
so
very
pressing
,
however
,
I
said
I
would
take
ninepence
for
it
,
if
he
pleased
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dolloby
,
not
without
some
grumbling
,
gave
ninepence
.
 
<EOS>
I
wished
him
good
night
,
and
walked
out
of
the
shop
the
richer
by
that
sum
,
and
the
poorer
by
a
waistcoat
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
I
buttoned
my
jacket
,
that
was
not
much
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
I
foresaw
pretty
clearly
that
my
jacket
would
go
next
,
and
that
I
should
have
to
make
the
best
of
my
way
to
Dover
in
a
shirt
and
a
pair
of
trousers
,
and
might
deem
myself
lucky
if
I
got
there
even
in
that
trim
.
 
<EOS>
But
my
mind
did
not
run
so
much
on
this
as
might
be
supposed
.
 
<EOS>
Beyond
a
general
impression
of
the
distance
before
me
,
and
of
the
young
man
with
the
donkey
-
cart
having
used
me
cruelly
,
I
think
I
had
no
very
urgent
sense
of
my
difficulties
when
I
once
again
set
off
with
my
ninepence
in
my
pocket
.
   
<EOS>
A
plan
had
occurred
to
me
for
passing
the
night
,
which
I
was
going
to
carry
into
execution
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
,
to
lie
behind
the
wall
at
the
back
of
my
old
school
,
in
a
corner
where
there
used
to
be
a
haystack
.
 
<EOS>
I
imagined
it
would
be
a
kind
of
company
to
have
the
boys
,
and
the
bedroom
where
I
used
to
tell
the
stories
,
so
near
me
:
although
the
boys
would
know
nothing
of
my
being
there
,
and
the
bedroom
would
yield
me
no
shelter
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
had
a
hard
day
's
work
,
and
was
pretty
well
jaded
when
I
came
climbing
out
,
at
last
,
upon
the
level
of
Blackheath
.
 
<EOS>
It
cost
me
some
trouble
to
find
out
Salem
House
;
but
I
found
it
,
and
I
found
a
haystack
in
the
corner
,
and
I
lay
down
by
it
;
having
first
walked
round
the
wall
,
and
looked
up
at
the
windows
,
and
seen
that
all
was
dark
and
silent
within
.
 
<EOS>
Never
shall
I
forget
the
lonely
sensation
of
first
lying
down
,
without
a
roof
above
my
head
!
   
<EOS>
Sleep
came
upon
me
as
it
came
on
many
other
outcasts
,
against
whom
house
-
doors
were
locked
,
and
house
-
dogs
barked
,
that
night
---
and
I
dreamed
of
lying
on
my
old
school
-
bed
,
talking
to
the
boys
in
my
room
;
and
found
myself
sitting
upright
,
with
Steerforth
's
name
upon
my
lips
,
looking
wildly
at
the
stars
that
were
glistening
and
glimmering
above
me
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
remembered
where
I
was
at
that
untimely
hour
,
a
feeling
stole
upon
me
that
made
me
get
up
,
afraid
of
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
,
and
walk
about
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
fainter
glimmering
of
the
stars
,
and
the
pale
light
in
the
sky
where
the
day
was
coming
,
reassured
me
:
and
<EOS>
my
eyes
being
very
heavy
,
I
lay
down
again
and
slept
---
<EOS>
though
with
a
knowledge
in
my
sleep
that
it
was
cold
---
until
the
warm
beams
of
the
sun
,
and
the
ringing
of
the
getting
-
up
bell
at
Salem
House
,
awoke
me
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
could
have
hoped
that
Steerforth
was
there
,
I
would
have
lurked
about
until
he
came
out
alone
;
but
I
knew
he
must
have
left
long
since
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
still
remained
,
perhaps
,
but
it
was
very
doubtful
;
and
I
had
not
sufficient
confidence
in
his
discretion
or
good
luck
,
however
strong
my
reliance
was
on
his
good
nature
,
to
wish
to
trust
him
with
my
situation
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
crept
away
from
the
wall
as
Mr
Creakle
's
boys
were
getting
up
,
and
struck
into
the
long
dusty
track
which
I
had
first
known
to
be
the
Dover
Road
when
I
was
one
of
them
,
and
when
I
little
expected
that
any
eyes
would
ever
see
me
the
wayfarer
I
was
now
,
upon
it
.
   
<EOS>
What
a
different
Sunday
morning
from
the
old
Sunday
morning
at
Yarmouth
!
 
<EOS>
In
due
time
I
heard
the
church
-
bells
ringing
,
as
I
plodded
on
;
and
I
met
people
who
were
going
to
church
;
and
I
passed
a
church
or
two
where
the
congregation
were
inside
,
and
the
sound
of
singing
came
out
into
the
sunshine
,
while
the
beadle
sat
and
cooled
himself
in
the
shade
of
the
porch
,
or
stood
beneath
the
yew
-
tree
,
with
his
hand
to
his
forehead
,
glowering
at
me
going
by
.
<EOS>
But
the
peace
and
rest
of
the
old
Sunday
morning
were
on
everything
,
except
me
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
the
difference
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
quite
wicked
in
my
dirt
and
dust
,
with
my
tangled
hair
.
 
<EOS>
But
for
the
quiet
picture
I
had
conjured
up
,
of
my
mother
in
her
youth
and
beauty
,
weeping
by
the
fire
,
and
my
aunt
relenting
to
her
<EOS>
,
I
hardly
think
I
should
have
had
the
courage
to
go
on
until
next
day
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
always
went
before
me
,
and
I
followed
.
   
<EOS>
I
got
,
that
Sunday
,
through
three
-
and
-
twenty
miles
on
the
straight
road
,
though
not
very
easily
,
for
I
was
new
to
that
kind

toil
.
<EOS>
I
see
myself
,
as
evening
closes
in
,
coming
over
the
bridge
at
Rochester
,
footsore
and
tired
,
and
eating
bread
that
I
had
bought
for
supper
.
 
<EOS>
One
or
two
little
houses
,
with
the
notice
,
"
Lodgings
for
Travellers
"
,
hanging
out
,
had
tempted
me
;
but
I
was
afraid
of
spending
the
few
pence
I
had
,
and
was
even
more
afraid
of
the
vicious
looks
of
the
trampers
I
had
met
or
overtaken
.
 
<EOS>
I
sought
no
shelter
,
therefore
,
but
the
sky
;
and
toiling
into
Chatham
,
---
which
,
in
that
night
's
aspect
,
is
a
mere
dream
of
chalk
,
and
drawbridges
,
and
mastless
ships
in
a
muddy
river
,
roofed
like
Noah
's

,
---
crept
,
at
last
,
upon
a
sort

grass
-
grown
battery
overhanging
a
lane
,
where
a
sentry
was
walking
to
and
fro
.
 
<EOS>
Here
I
lay
down
,
near
a
cannon
;
and
,
happy
in
the
society
of
the
sentry
's
footsteps
,
though
he
knew
no
more
of
my
being
above
him
than
the
boys
at
Salem
House
<EOS>
had
known
of
my
lying
by
the
wall
,
slept
soundly
until
morning
.
   
<EOS>
Very
stiff
and
sore
of
foot
I
was
in
the
morning
,
and
quite
dazed
by
the
beating
of
drums
and
marching
of
troops
,
which
seemed
to
hem
me
in
on
every
side
when
I
went
down
towards
the
long
narrow
street
.
 
<EOS>
Feeling
that
I
could
go
but
a
very
little
way
that
day
,
if
I
were
to
reserve
any
strength
for
getting
to
my
journey
's
end
,
I
resolved
to
make
the
sale
of
my
jacket
its
principal
business
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
I
took
the
jacket
off
,
that
I
might
learn
to
do
without
it
;
and
carrying
it
under
my
arm
,
began
a
tour
of
inspection
of
the
various
slop
-
shops
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
likely
place
to
sell
a
jacket
in
;
for
the
dealers
in
second
-
hand
clothes
were
numerous
,
and
were
,
generally
speaking
,
on
the
look
-
out
for
customers
at
their
shop
doors
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
most
of
them
had
,
hanging
up
among
their
stock
,
an
officer
's
coat
or
two
,
epaulettes
and
all
,
I
was
rendered
timid
by
the
costly
nature
of
their
dealings
,
and
walked
about
for
a
long
time
without
offering
my
merchandise
to
anyone
.
   
<EOS>
This
modesty
of
mine
directed
my
attention
to
the
marine
-
store
shops
,
and
such
shops
as
Mr
Dolloby
's
,
in
preference
to
the
regular
dealers
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
I
found
one
that
I
thought
looked
promising
,
at
the
corner
of
a
dirty
lane
,
ending
in
an
enclosure
full
of
stinging
-
nettles
,
against
the
palings
of
which
<EOS>
some
second
-
hand
sailors
'
clothes
,
that
seemed
to
have
overflowed
the
shop
,
were
fluttering
among
some
cots
,
and
rusty
guns
,
and
oilskin
hats
,
and
certain
trays
full
of
so
many
old
rusty
keys
of
so
many
sizes
that
they
seemed
various
enough
to
open
all
the
doors
in
the
world
.
   
<EOS>
Into
this
shop
,
which
was
low
and
small
,
and
which
was
darkened
rather
than
lighted
by
a
little
window
,
overhung
with
clothes
,
and
was
descended
into
by
some
steps
,
I
went
with
a
palpitating
heart
;
which
was
not
relieved
when
an
ugly
old
man
,
with
the
lower
part
of
his
face
all
covered
with
a
stubbly
grey
beard
,
rushed
out
of
a
dirty
den
behind
it
,
and
seized
me
by
the
hair
of
my
head
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
dreadful
old
man
to
look
at
,
in
a
filthy
flannel
waistcoat
,
and
smelling
terribly
of
rum
.
 
<EOS>
His
bedstead
,
covered
with
a
tumbled
and
ragged
piece
of
patchwork
,
was
in
the
den
he
had
come
from
,
where
another
little
window
showed
a
prospect
of
more
stinging
-
nettles
,
and
a
lame
donkey
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
what
do
you
want
?
<EOS>
"
grinned
this
old
man
,
in
a
fierce
,
monotonous
whine
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
my
eyes
and
limbs
,
what
do
you
want
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
lungs
and
liver
,
what
do
you
want
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
goroo
,
goroo
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
so
much
dismayed
by
these
words
,
and
particularly
by
the
repetition
of
the
last
unknown
one
,
which
was
a
kind
of
rattle
in
his
throat
,
that
I
could
make
no
answer
;
<EOS>
hereupon
the
old
man
,
still
holding
me
by
the
hair
,
repeated
:
   
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
what
do
you
want
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
eyes
and
limbs
,
what
do
you
want
?
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
lungs
and
liver
,
what
do
you
want
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
goroo
!
"
<EOS>
---
which
he
screwed
out
of
himself
,
with
an
energy
that
made
his
eyes
start
in
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wanted
to
know
,
"
I
said
,
trembling
,
"
if
you
would
buy
a
jacket
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
let
's
see
the
jacket
!
"
cried
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
my
heart
on
fire
,
show
the
jacket
to
us
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
eyes
and
limbs
,
bring
the
jacket
out
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
that
he
took
his
trembling
hands
,
which
were
like
the
claws
of
a
great
bird
,
out
of
my
hair
;
and
put
on
a
pair
of
spectacles
,
not
at
all
ornamental
to
his
inflamed
