.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
how
much
for
the
jacket
?
"
cried
the
old
man
,
after
examining
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
---
goroo
!
<EOS>
---
how
much
for
the
jacket
?
"
   
"
Half
-
a
-
crown
,
"
I
answered
,
recovering
myself
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
my
lungs
and
liver
,
"
cried
the
old
man
,
"
no
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
eyes
,
no
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
limbs
,
no
!
 
<EOS>
Eighteenpence
.
 
<EOS>
Goroo
!
"
   
<EOS>
Every
time
he
uttered
this
ejaculation
,
his
eyes
seemed
to
be
in
danger
of
starting
out
;
and
every
sentence
he
spoke
,
he
delivered
in
a
sort
of
tune
,
always
exactly
the
same
,
and
more
like
a
gust
of
wind
,
which
begins
low
,
mounts
up
high
,
and
falls
again
,
than
any
other
comparison
I
can
find
for
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
I
,
glad
to
have
closed
the
bargain
,
"
I
'll
take
eighteenpence
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
my
liver
!
<EOS>
"
cried
the
old
man
,
throwing
the
jacket
on
a
shelf
.
"
<EOS>
Get
out
of
the
shop
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
lungs
,
get
out
of
the
shop
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
eyes
and
limbs
---
goroo
!
<EOS>
---
do
n't
ask
for
money
;
make
it
an
exchange
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
never
was
so
frightened
in
my
life
,
before
or
since
;
but
I
told
him
humbly
that
I
wanted
money
,
and
that
nothing
else
was
of
any
use
to
me
,
but
that
I
would
wait
for
it
,
as
he
desired
,
outside
,
and
had
no
wish
to
hurry
him
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
went
outside
,
and
sat
down
in
the
shade
in
a
corner
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
sat
there
so
many
hours
,
that
the
shade
became
sunlight
,
and
the
sunlight
became
shade
again
,
and
still
I
sat
there
waiting
for
the
money
.
   
<EOS>
There
never
was
such
another
drunken
madman
in
that
line
of
business
,
I
hope
.
 
<EOS>
That
he
was
well
known
in
the
neighbourhood
,
and
enjoyed
the
reputation
of
having
sold
himself
to
the
devil
<EOS>
,
I
soon
understood
from
the
visits
he
received
from
the
boys
,
who
continually
came
skirmishing
about
the
shop
,
shouting
that
legend
,
and
calling
to
him
to
bring
out
his
gold
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
ai
n't
poor
,
you
know
,
Charley
,
as
you
pretend
.
 
<EOS>
Bring
out
your
gold
.
 
<EOS>
Bring
out
some
of
the
gold
you
sold
yourself
to
the
devil
for
.
 
<EOS>
Come
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
in
the
lining
of
the
mattress
,
Charley
.
 
<EOS>
Rip
it
open
and
let
's
have
some
!
"
 
<EOS>
This
,
and
many
offers
to
lend
him
a
knife
for
the
purpose
,
exasperated
him
to
such
a
degree
,
that
the
whole
day
was
a
succession
of
rushes
on
his
part
,
and
flights
on
the
part
of
the
boys
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
in
his
rage
he
would
take
me
for
one
of
them
,
and
come
at
me
,
mouthing
as
if
he
were
going
to
tear
me
in
pieces
;
then
,
remembering
me
,
just
in
time
,
would
dive
into
the
shop
,
and
lie
upon
his
bed
,
as
I
thought
from
the
sound
of
his
voice
,
yelling
in
a
frantic
way
,
to
his
own
windy
tune
,
the
"
Death
of
Nelson
"
;
with
an
Oh
!
<EOS>
before
every
line
,
and
innumerable
Goroos
interspersed
.
<EOS>
As
if
this
were
not
bad
enough
for
me
,
the
boys
,
connecting
me
with
the
establishment
,
on
account
of
the
patience
and
perseverance
with
which
I
sat
outside
,
half
-
dressed
,
pelted
me
,
and
used
me
very
ill
all
day
.
   
<EOS>
He
made
many
attempts
to
induce
me
to
consent
to
an
exchange
;
at
one
time
coming
out
with
a
fishing
-
rod
,
at
another
with
a
fiddle
,
at
another
with
a
cocked
hat
,
at
another
with
a
flute
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
resisted
all
these
overtures
,
and
sat
there
in
desperation
;
each
time
asking
him
,
with
tears
in
my
eyes
,
for
my
money
or
my
jacket
.
<EOS>
At
last
he
began
to
pay
me
in
halfpence
at
a
time
;
and
was
full
two
hours
getting
by
easy
stages
to
a
shilling
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
eyes
and
limbs
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
then
cried
,
peeping
hideously
out
of
the
shop
,
after
a
long
pause
,
"
will
you
go
for
twopence
more
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
,
"
I
said
;
"
I
shall
be
starved
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
my
lungs
and
liver
,
will
you
go
for
threepence
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
go
for
nothing
,
if
I
could
,
"
I
said
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
want
the
money
badly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
go
-
roo
!
"
<EOS>
(
it
is
really
impossible
to
express
how
he
twisted
this
ejaculation
out
of
himself
,
as
he
peeped
round
<EOS>
the
door
-
post
at
me
,
showing
nothing
but
his
crafty
old
head
)
<EOS>
;
"
will
you
go
for
fourpence
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
so
faint
and
weary
that
I
closed
with
this
offer
;
and
taking
the
money
out
of
his
claw
,
not
without
trembling
,
went
away
more
hungry
and
thirsty
than
I
had
ever
been
,
a
little
before
sunset
.
<EOS>
But
at
an
expense
of
threepence
I
soon
refreshed
myself
completely
;
and
,
being
in
better
spirits
then
,
limped
seven
miles
upon
my
road
.
   
<EOS>
My
bed
at
night
was
under
another
haystack
,
where
I
rested
comfortably
,
after
having
washed
my
blistered
feet
in
a
stream
,
and
dressed
them
as
well
as
I
was
able
,
with
some
cool
leaves
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
took
the
road
again
next
morning
,
I
found
that
it
lay
through
a
succession
of
hop
-
grounds
and
orchards
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
sufficiently
late
in
the
year
for
the
orchards
to
be
ruddy
with
ripe
apples
;
and
in
a
few
places
the
hop
-
pickers
were
already
at
work
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
it
all
extremely
beautiful
,
and
made
up
my
mind
to
sleep
among
the
hops
that
night
:
imagining
some
cheerful
companionship
in
the
long
perspectives
of
poles
,
with
the
graceful
leaves
twining
round
them
.
   
<EOS>
The
trampers
were
worse
than
ever
that
day
,
and
inspired
me
with
a
dread
that
is
yet
quite
fresh
in
my
mind
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
them
were
most
ferocious
-
looking
ruffians
,
who
stared
at
me
as
I
went
by
;
and
stopped
,
perhaps
,
and
called
after
me
to
come
back
and
speak
to
them
,
and
when
I
took
to
my
heels
,
stoned
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
recollect
one
young
fellow
---
a
tinker
,
I
suppose
,
from
his
wallet
and
brazier
---
who
had
a
woman
with
him
,
and
who
faced
about
and
stared
at
me
thus
;
and
then
roared
to
me
in
such
a
tremendous
voice
to
come
back
,
that
I
halted
and
looked
round
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
here
,
when
you
're
called
,
"
said
the
tinker
,
"
or
I
'll
rip
your
young
body
open
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
thought
it
best
to
go
back
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
drew
nearer
to
them
,
trying
to
propitiate
the
tinker
by
my
looks
,
I
observed
that
the
woman
had
a
black
eye
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
are
you
going
?
"
said
the
tinker
,
gripping
the
bosom
of
my
shirt
with
his
blackened
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
to
Dover
,
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
do
you
come
from
?
"
<EOS>
asked
the
tinker
,
giving
his
hand
another
turn
in
my
shirt
,
to
hold
me
more
securely
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
come
from
London
,
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
lay
are
you
upon
?
"
asked
the
tinker
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
a
prig
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
N
-
no
,
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ai
n't
you
,
by
G
#
#
#
#
?
 
<EOS>
If
you
make
a
brag
of
your
honesty
to
me
,
"
said
the
tinker
,
"
I
'll
knock
your
brains
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
his
disengaged
hand
he
made
a
menace
of
striking
me
,
and
then
looked
at
me
from
head
to
foot
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
got
the
price
of
a
pint
of
beer
about
you
?
"
said
the
tinker
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
have
,
out
with
it
,
afore
I
take
it
away
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
should
certainly
have
produced
it
,
but
that
I
met
the
woman
's
look
,
and
saw
her
very
slightly
shake
her
head
,
and
form
"
No
!
"
<EOS>
with
her
lips
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
poor
,
"
I
said
,
attempting
to
smile
,
"
and
have
got
no
money
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
do
you
mean
?
"
said
the
tinker
,
<EOS>
looking
so
sternly
at
me
,
that
I
almost
feared
he
saw
the
money
in
my
pocket
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
!
<EOS>
"
I
stammered
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
,
"
said
the
tinker
,
"
by
wearing
my
brother
's
silk
handkerchief
!
 
<EOS>
Give
it
over
here
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
he
had
mine
off
my
neck
in
a
moment
,
and
tossed
it
to
the
woman
.
   
<EOS>
The
woman
burst
into
a
fit
of
laughter
,
as
if
she
thought
this
a
joke
,
and
tossed
it
back
to
me
,
nodded
once
,
as
slightly
as
before
,
and
made
the
word
"
Go
!
"
<EOS>
with
her
lips
.
 
<EOS>
Before
I
could
obey
,
however
,
the
tinker
seized
the
handkerchief
out
of
my
hand
with
a
roughness
that
threw
me
away
like
a
feather
,
and
putting
it
loosely
round
his
own
neck
,
turned
upon
the
woman
with
an
oath
,
and
knocked
her
down
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
shall
forget
seeing
her
fall
backward
on
the
hard
road
,
and
lie
there
with
her
bonnet
tumbled
off
,
and
her
hair
all
whitened
in
the
dust
;
nor
,
when
I
looked
back
from
a
distance
,
seeing
her
sitting
on
the
pathway
,
which
was
a
bank
by
the
roadside
,
wiping
the
blood
from
her
face
with
a
corner
of
her
shawl
,
while
he
went
on
ahead
.
   
<EOS>
This
adventure
frightened
me
so
,
that
,
afterwards
,
when
I
saw
any
of
these
people
coming
,
I
turned
back
until
I
could
find
a
hiding
-
place
,
where
I
remained
until
they
had
gone
out
of
sight
;
which
happened
so
often
,
that
I
was
very
seriously
delayed
.
 
<EOS>
But
under
this
difficulty
,
as
under
all
the
other
difficulties
of
my
journey
,
I
seemed
to
be
sustained
and
led
on
by
my
fanciful
picture
of
my
mother
in
her
youth
,
before
I
came
into
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
It
always
kept
me
company
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
there
,
among
the
hops
,
when
I
lay
down
to
sleep
;
it
was
with
me
on
my
waking
in
the
morning
;
it
went
before
me
all
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
associated
it
,
ever
since
,
with
the
sunny
street
of
Canterbury
,
dozing
as
it
were
in
the
hot
light
;
and
with
the
sight
of
its
old
houses
and
gateways
,
and
the
stately
,
grey
Cathedral
,
with
the
rooks
sailing
round
the
towers
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
came
,
at
last
,
upon
the
bare
,
wide
downs
near
Dover
,
it
relieved
the
solitary
aspect
of
the
scene
with
hope
;
and
not
until
I
reached
that
first
great
aim
of
my
journey
,
and
actually
set
foot
in
the
town
itself
,
on
the
sixth
day
of
my
flight
,
did
it
desert
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
then
,
strange
to
say
,
when
I
stood
with
my
ragged
shoes
,
and
my
dusty
,
sunburnt
,
half
-
clothed
figure
,
in
the
place
so
long
desired
,
it
seemed
to
vanish
like
a
dream
,
and
to
leave
me
helpless
and
dispirited
.
   
<EOS>
I
inquired
about
my
aunt
among
the
boatmen
first
,
and
received
various
answers
.
 
<EOS>
One
said
she
lived
in
the
South
Foreland
Light
,
and
had
singed
her
whiskers
by
doing
so
;
another
,
that
she
was
made
fast
to
the
great
buoy
outside
the
harbour
,
and
could
only
be
visited
at
half
-
tide
;
a
third
,
that
she
was
locked
up
in
Maidstone
jail
for
child
-
stealing
;
a
fourth
,
that
she
was
seen
to
mount
a
broom
in
the
last
high
wind
,
and
make
direct
for
Calais
.
 
<EOS>
The
fly
-
drivers
,
among
whom
I
inquired
next
,
were
equally
jocose
and
equally
disrespectful
;
and
the
shopkeepers
,
not
liking
my
appearance
,
generally
replied
,
without
hearing
what
I
had
to
say
,
that
they
had
got
nothing
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
more
miserable
and
destitute
than
I
had
done
at
any
period
of
my
running
away
.
 
<EOS>
My
money
was
all
gone
,
I
had
nothing
left
to
dispose
of
;
I
was
hungry
,
thirsty
,
and
worn
out
;
and
seemed
as
distant
from
my
end
as
if
I
had
remained
in
London
.
   
<EOS>
The
morning
had
worn
away
in
these
inquiries
,
and
I
was
sitting
on
the
step
of
an
empty
shop
at
a
street
corner
,
near
the
market
-
place
,
deliberating
upon
wandering
towards
those
other
places
which
had
been
mentioned
,
when
a
fly
-
driver
,
coming
by
with
his
carriage
,
dropped
a
horsecloth
.
 
<EOS>
Something
good
-
natured
in
the
man
's
face
,
as
I
handed
it
up
,
encouraged
me
to
ask
him
if
he
could
tell
me
where
Miss
Trotwood
lived
;
though
I
had
asked
the
question
so
often
,
that
it
almost
died
upon
my
lips
.
   
<EOS>
"
Trotwood
,
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
the
name
,
too
.
 
<EOS>
Old
lady
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
I
said
,
"
rather
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty
stiff
in
the
back
?
<EOS>
"
said
he
,
making
himself
upright
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
I
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
it
very
likely
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Carries
a
bag
?
"
<EOS>
said
he
---
"
bag
with
a
good
deal
of
room
in
it
---
is
gruffish
,
and
comes
down
upon
you
,
sharp
?
"
   
<EOS>
My
heart
sank
within
me
as
I
acknowledged
the
undoubted
accuracy
of
this
description
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
then
,
I
tell
you
what
,
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
go
up
there
,
"
pointing
with
his
whip
towards
the
heights
,
"
and
keep
right
on
till
you
come
to
some
houses
facing
the
sea
,
I
think
you
'll
hear
of
her
.
<EOS>
My
opinion
is
she
wo
n't
stand
anything
,
so
here
's
a
penny
for
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
accepted
the
gift
thankfully
,
and
bought
a
loaf
with
it
.
<EOS>
Dispatching
this
refreshment
by
the
way
,
I
went
in
the
direction
my
friend
had
indicated
,
and
walked
on
a
good
distance
without
coming
to
the
houses
he
had
mentioned
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
I
saw
some
before
me
;
and
approaching
them
,
went
into
a
little
shop
<EOS>
(
it
was
what
we
used
to
call
a
general
shop
,
at
home
)
,
and
inquired
if
they
could
have
the
goodness
to
tell
me
where
Miss
Trotwood
lived
.
 
<EOS>
I
addressed
myself
to
a
man
behind
the
counter
,
who
was
weighing
some
rice
for
a
young
woman
;
but
the
latter
,
taking
the
inquiry
to
herself
,
turned
round
quickly
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
mistress
?
<EOS>
"
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
with
her
,
boy
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
,
"
I
replied
,
"
to
speak
to
her
,
if
you
please
.
"
   
"
To
beg
of
her
,
you
mean
,
"
retorted
the
damsel
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
I
said
,
"
indeed
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
suddenly
remembering
that
in
truth
I
came
for
no
other
purpose
,
I
held
my
peace
in
confusion
,
and
felt
my
face
burn
.
   
<EOS>
MY
aunt
's
handmaid
,
as
I
supposed
she
was
from
what
she
had
said
,
put
her
rice
in
a
little
basket
and
walked
out
of
the
shop
;
telling
me
that
I
could
follow
her
,
if
I
wanted
to
know
where
Miss
Trotwood
lived
.
 
<EOS>
I
needed
no
second
permission
;
though
I
was
by
this
time
in
such
a
state
of
consternation
and
agitation
,
that
my
legs
shook
under
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
followed
the
young
woman
,
and
we
soon
came
to
a
very
neat
little
cottage
with
cheerful
bow
-
windows
:
in
front
of
it
,
a
small
square
gravelled
court
or
garden
full
of
flowers
,
carefully
tended
,
and
smelling
deliciously
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
Miss
Trotwood
's
,
"
said
the
young
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
you
know
;
and
that
's
all
I
have
got
to
say
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
which
words
she
hurried
into
the
house
,
as
if
to
shake
off
the
responsibility
of
my
appearance
;
and
left
me
standing
at
the
garden
-
gate
,
looking
disconsolately
over
the
top
of
it
towards
the
parlour
window
,
where
a
muslin
curtain
partly
undrawn
in
the
middle
,
a
large
round
green
screen
or
fan
fastened
on
to
the
windowsill
,
a
small
table
,
and
a
great
chair
,
suggested
to
me
that
my
aunt
might
be
at
that
moment
seated
in
awful
state
.
   
<EOS>
My
shoes
were
by
this
time
in
a
woeful
condition
.
 
<EOS>
The
soles
had
shed
themselves
bit
by
bit
,
and
the
upper
leathers
had
broken
and
burst
until
the
very
shape
and
form
of
shoes
had
departed
from
them
.
 
<EOS>
My
hat
(
which
had
served
me
for
a
night
-
cap
,
too
)
was
so
crushed
and
bent
,
that
no
old
battered
handleless
saucepan
on
a
dunghill
need
have
been
ashamed
to
vie
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
My
shirt
and
trousers
,
stained
with
heat
,
dew
,
grass
,
and
the
Kentish
soil
on
which
I
had
slept
---
and
torn
besides
---
might
have
frightened
the
birds
from
my
aunt
's
garden
,
as
I
stood
at
the
gate
.
 
<EOS>
My
hair
had
known
no
comb
or
brush
since
I
left
London
.
 
<EOS>
My
face
,
neck
,
and
hands
,
from
unaccustomed
exposure
to
the
air
and
sun
,
were
burnt
to
a
berry
-
brown
.
 
<EOS>
From
head
to
foot
I
was
powdered
almost
as
white
with
chalk
and
dust
,
as
if
I
had
come
out
of
a
lime
-
kiln
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
plight
,
and
with
a
strong
consciousness
of
it
,
I
waited
to
introduce
myself
to
,
and
make
my
first
impression
on
,
my
formidable
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
The
unbroken
stillness
of
the
parlour
window
leading
me
to
infer
,
after
a
while
,
that
she
was
not
there
,
I
lifted
up
my
eyes
to
the
window
above
it
,
where
I
saw
a
florid
,
pleasant
-
looking
gentleman
,
with
a
grey
head
,
who
shut
up
one
eye
in
a
grotesque
manner
,
nodded
his
head
at
me
several
times
,
shook
it
at
me
as
often
,
laughed
,
and
went
away
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
been
discomposed
enough
before
;
but
I
was
so
much
the
more
discomposed
by
this
unexpected
behaviour
,
that
I
was
on
the
point
of
slinking
off
,
to
think
how
I
had
best
proceed
,
when
there
came
out
of
the
house
a
lady
with
her
handkerchief
tied
over
her
cap
,
and
a
pair
of
gardening
gloves
on
her
hands
,
wearing
a
gardening
pocket
like
a
toll
-
man
's

,
and
carrying
a
great
knife
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
her
immediately
to
be
Miss
Betsey
,
for
she
came
stalking
out
of
the
house
exactly
as
my
poor
mother
had
so
often
described
her
stalking
up
our
garden
at
Blunderstone
Rookery
.
   
<EOS>
"
Go
away
!
"
said
Miss
Betsey
,
shaking
her
head
,
and
making
a
distant
chop
in
the
air
with
her
knife
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
along
!
 
<EOS>
No
boys
here
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
watched
her
,
with
my
heart
at
my
lips
,
as
she
marched
to
a
corner
of
her
garden
,
and
stooped
to
dig
up
some
little
root
there
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
without
a
scrap
of
courage
,
but
with
a
great
deal
of
desperation
,
I
went
softly
in
and
stood
beside
her
,
touching
her
with
my
finger
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
ma'am
,
"
I
began
.
   
<EOS>
She
started
and
looked
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
aunt
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
EH
?
"
exclaimed
Miss
Betsey
,
in
a
tone
of
amazement
<EOS>
I
have
never
heard
approached
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
aunt
,
I
am
your
nephew
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Lord
!
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
And
sat
flat
down
in
the
garden
-
path
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
David
Copperfield
,
of
Blunderstone
,
in
Suffolk
---
where
you
came
,
on
the
night
when
I
was
born
,
and
saw
my
dear
mama
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
very
unhappy
since
she
died
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
slighted
,
and
taught
nothing
,
and
thrown
upon
myself
,
and
put
to
work
not
fit
for
me
.
<EOS>
It
made
me
run
away
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
robbed
at
first
setting
out
,
and
have
walked
all
the
way
,
and
have
never
slept
in
a
bed
since
I
began
the
journey
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
my
self
-
support
gave
way
all
at
once
;
and
with
a
movement
of
my
hands
,
intended
to
show
her
my
ragged
state
,
and
call
it
to
witness
that
I
had
suffered
something
,
I
broke
into
a
passion
of
crying
,
which
I
suppose
had
been
pent
up
within
me
all
the
week
.
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
with
every
sort
of
expression
but
wonder
discharged
from
her
countenance
,
sat
on
the
gravel
,
staring
at
me
,
until
I
began
to
cry
;
when
she
got
up
in
a
great
hurry
,
collared
me
,
and
took
me
into
the
parlour
.
 
<EOS>
Her
first
proceeding
<EOS>
there
was
to
unlock
a
tall
press
,
bring
out
several
bottles
,
and
pour
some
of
the
contents
of
each
into
my
mouth
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
they
must
have
been
taken
out
at
random
,
for
I
am
sure
I
tasted
aniseed
water
,
anchovy
sauce
,
and
salad
dressing
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
administered
these
restoratives
,
as
I
was
still
quite
hysterical
,
and
unable
to
control
my
sobs
,
she
put
me
on
the
sofa
,
with
a
shawl
under
my
head
,
and
the
handkerchief
from
her
own
head
under
my
feet
,
lest
I
should
sully
the
cover
;
and
then
,
sitting
herself
down
behind
the
green
fan
or
screen
I
have
already
mentioned
,
so
that
I
could
not
see
her
face
,
ejaculated
at
intervals
,
"
Mercy
on
us
!
"
<EOS>
letting
those
exclamations
off
like
minute
guns
.
   
<EOS>
After
a
time
she
rang
the
bell
.
 
<EOS>
"
Janet
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
when
her
servant
came
in
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
upstairs
,
give
my
compliments
to
Mr
Dick
,
and
say
I
wish
to
speak
to
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
Janet
looked
a
little
surprised
to
see
me
lying
stiffly
on
the
sofa
<EOS>
(
I
was
afraid
to
move
lest
it
should
be
displeasing
to
my
aunt
)
,
but
went
on
her
errand
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
with
her
hands
behind
her
,
walked
up
and
down
the
room
,
until
the
gentleman
who
had
squinted
at
me
from
the
upper
window
came
in
laughing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dick
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
do
n't
be
a
fool
,
because
nobody
can
be
more
discreet
than
you
can
,
when
you
choose
.
 
<EOS>
We
all
know
that
.
 
<EOS>
So
do
n't
be
a
fool
,
whatever
you
are
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
was
serious
immediately
,
and
looked
at
me
,
I
thought
,
as
if
he
would
entreat
me
to
say
nothing
about
the
window
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dick
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
you
have
heard
me
mention
David
Copperfield
?
 
<EOS>
Now
do
n't
pretend
not
to
have
a
memory
,
because
you
and
I
know
better
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
David
Copperfield
?
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
who
did
not
appear
to
me
to
remember
much
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
David
Copperfield
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
yes
,
to
be
sure
.
<EOS>
David
,
certainly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
this
is
his
boy
---
his
son
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
be
as
like
his
father
as
it
's
possible
to
be
,
if
he
was
not
so
like
his
mother
,
too
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
His
son
?
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
"
David
's
son
?
 
<EOS>
Indeed
!
<EOS>
"
   
"
Yes
,
"
pursued
my
aunt
,
"
and
he
has
done
a
pretty
piece
of
business
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
run
away
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
His
sister
,
Betsey
Trotwood
,
never
would
have
run
away
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
shook
her
head
firmly
,
confident
in
the
character
and
behaviour
of
the
girl
who
never
was
born
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
you
think
she
would
n't
have
run
away
?
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
and
save
the
man
,
"
exclaimed
my
aunt
,
sharply
,
"
how
he
talks
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
I
know
she
would
n't
?
 
<EOS>
She
would
have
lived
with
her
god
-
mother
,
and
we
should
have
been
devoted
to
one
another
.
 
<EOS>
Where
,
in
the
name
of
wonder
,
should
his
sister
,
Betsey
Trotwood
,
have
run
from
,
or
to
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nowhere
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
then
,
"
returned
my
aunt
,
softened
by
the
reply
,
"
how
can
you
pretend
to
be
wool
-
gathering
,
Dick
,
when
you
are
as
sharp
as
a
surgeon
's

?
 
<EOS>
Now
,
here
you
see
young
David
Copperfield
,
and
the
question
I
put
to
you
is
,
what
shall
I
do
with
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
shall
you
do
with
him
?
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
feebly
,
scratching
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
do
with
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
with
a
grave
look
,
and
her
forefinger
held
up
.
<EOS>
"
Come
!
 
<EOS>
I
want
some
very
sound
advice
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
if
I
was
you
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
considering
,
and
looking
vacantly
at
me
,
"
I
should
---
<EOS>
"
The
contemplation
of
me
seemed
to
inspire
him
with
a
sudden
idea
,
and
he
added
,
briskly
,
"
I
should
wash
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Janet
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
turning
round
with
a
quiet
triumph
,
which
I
did
not
then
understand
,
"
Mr
Dick
sets
us
all
right
.
 
<EOS>
Heat
the
bath
!
"
   
<EOS>
Although
I
was
deeply
interested
in
this
dialogue
,
I
could
not
help
observing
my
aunt
,
Mr
Dick
,
and
Janet
,
while
it
was
in
progress
,
and
completing
a
survey
I
had
already
been
engaged
in
making
of
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
MY
aunt
was
a
tall
,
hard
-
featured
lady
,
but
by
no
means
ill
-
looking
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
inflexibility
in
her
face
,
in
her
voice
,
in
her
gait
and
carriage
,
amply
sufficient
to
account
for
the
effect
she
had
made
upon
a
gentle
creature
like
my
mother
;
but
her
features
were
rather
handsome
than
otherwise
,
though
unbending
and
austere
.
 
<EOS>
I
particularly
noticed
that
she
had
a
very
quick
,
bright
eye
.
 
<EOS>
Her
hair
,
which
was
grey
,
was
arranged
in
two
plain
divisions
,
under
what
I
believe
would
be
called
a
mob
-
cap
;
I
mean
a
cap
,
much
more
common
then
than
now
,
with
side
-
pieces
fastening
under
the
chin
.
 
<EOS>
Her
dress
was
of
a
lavender
colour
,
and
perfectly
neat
;
but
scantily
made
,
as
if
she
desired
to
be
as
little
encumbered
as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
I
remember
that
I
thought
it
,
in
form
,
more
like
a
riding
-
habit
with
the
superfluous
skirt
cut
off
,
than
anything
else
.
 
<EOS>
She
wore
at
her
side
a
gentleman
's
gold
watch
,
if
I
might
judge
from
its
size
and
make
,
with
an
appropriate
chain
and
seals
;
she
had
some
linen
at
her
throat
not
unlike
a
shirt
-
collar
,
and
things
at
her
wrists
like
little
shirt
-
wristbands
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
,
as
I
have
already
said
,
was
grey
-
headed
,
and
florid
<EOS>
:
I
should
have
said
all
about
him
,
in
saying
so
,
had
not
his
head
been
curiously
bowed
---
not
by
age
;
it
reminded
me
of
one
of
Mr
Creakle
's
boys
'
heads
after
a
beating
---
and
his
grey
eyes
prominent
and
large
,
with
a
strange
kind
of
watery
brightness
in
them
that
made
me
,
in
combination
with
his
vacant
manner
,
his
submission
to
my
aunt
,
and
his
childish
delight
when
she
praised
him
,
suspect
him
of
being
a
little
mad
;
though
,
if
he
were
mad
,
how
he
came
to
be
there
puzzled
me
extremely
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
dressed
like
any
other
ordinary
gentleman
,
in
a
loose
grey
morning
coat
and
waistcoat
,
and
white
trousers
;
and
had
his
watch
in
his
fob
,
and
his
money
in
his
pockets
:
which
he
rattled
as
if
he
were
very
proud
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
Janet
was
a
pretty
blooming
girl
,
of
about
nineteen
or
twenty
,
and
a
perfect
picture
of
neatness
.
 
<EOS>
Though
I
made
no
further
observation
of
her
at
the
moment
,
I
may
mention
here
what
I
did
not
discover
until
afterwards
,
namely
,
that
she
was
one
of
a
series
of
protegees
whom
my
aunt
had
taken
into
her
service
expressly
to
educate
in
a
renouncement
of
mankind
,
and
who
had
generally
completed
their
abjuration
by
marrying
the
baker
.
   
<EOS>
The
room
was
as
neat
as
Janet
or
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
laid
down
my
pen
,
a
moment
since
,
to
think
of
it
,
the
air
from
the
sea
came
blowing
in
again
,
mixed
with
the
perfume
of
the
flowers
;
and
I
saw
the
old
-
fashioned
furniture
brightly
rubbed
and
polished
,
my
aunt
's
inviolable
chair
and
table
by
the
round
green
fan
in
the
bow
-
window
,
the
drugget
-
covered
carpet
,
the
cat
,
the
kettle
-
holder
,
the
two
canaries
,
the
old
china
,
the
punchbowl
full
of
dried
rose
-
leaves
,
the
tall
press
guarding
all
sorts
of
bottles
and
pots
,
and
,
wonderfully
out
of
keeping
with
the
rest
,
my
dusty
self
upon
the
sofa
,
taking
note
of
everything
.
   
<EOS>
Janet
had
gone
away
to
get
the
bath
ready
,
when
my
aunt
,
to
my
great
alarm
,
became
in
one
moment
rigid
with
indignation
,
and
had
hardly
voice
to
cry
out
,
"
Janet
!
 
<EOS>
Donkeys
!
"
   
<EOS>
Upon
which
,
Janet
came
running
up
the
stairs
as
if
the
house
were
in
flames
,
darted
out
on
a
little
piece
of
green
in
front
,
and
warned
off
two
saddle
-
donkeys
,
lady
-
ridden
,
that
had
presumed
to
set
hoof
upon
it
;
while
my
aunt
,
rushing
out
of
the
house
,
seized
the
bridle
of
a
third
animal
laden
with
a
bestriding
child
,
turned
him
,
led
him
forth
from
those
sacred
precincts
,
and
boxed
the
ears
of
the
unlucky
urchin
in
attendance
who
had
dared
to
profane
that
hallowed
ground
.
   
<EOS>
To
this
hour
I
do
n't
know
whether
my
aunt
had
any
lawful
right
of
way
over
that
patch
of
green
;
but
she
had
settled
it
in
her
own
mind
that
she
had
,
and
it
was
all
the
same
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
The
one
great
outrage
of
her
life
,
demanding
to
be
constantly
avenged
,
was
the
passage
of
a
donkey
over
that
immaculate
spot
.
 
<EOS>
In
whatever
occupation
she
was
engaged
,
however
interesting
to
her
the
conversation
in
which
she
was
taking
part
,
a
donkey
turned
the
current
of
her
ideas
in
a
moment
,
and
she
was
upon
him
straight
.
<EOS>
Jugs
of
water
,
and
watering
-
pots
,
were
kept
in
secret
places
ready
to
be
discharged
on
the
offending
boys
;
sticks
were
laid
in
ambush
behind
the
door
;
sallies
were
made
at
all
hours
;
and
incessant
war
prevailed
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
this
was
an
agreeable
excitement
to
the
donkey
-
boys
;
or
perhaps
the
more
sagacious
of
the
donkeys
,
understanding
how
the
case
stood
,
delighted
with
constitutional
obstinacy
in
coming
that
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
know
that
there
were
three
alarms
before
the
bath
was
ready
;
and
that
on
the
occasion
of
the
last
and
most
desperate
of
all
,
I
saw
my
aunt
engage
,
single
-
handed
,
with
a
sandy
-
headed
lad
of
fifteen
,
and
bump
his
sandy
head
against
her
own
gate
,
before
he
seemed
to
comprehend
what
was
the
matter
.
 
<EOS>
These
interruptions
were
of
the
more
ridiculous
to
me
,
because
she
was
giving
me
broth
out
of
a
table
-
spoon
at
the
time
(
having
firmly
persuaded
herself
that
I
was
actually
starving
,
and
must
receive
nourishment
at
first
in
very
small
quantities
)
,
and
,
while
my
mouth
was
yet
open
to
receive
the
spoon
,
she
would
put
it
back
into
the
basin
,
cry
"
Janet
!
 
Donkeys
!
"
and
go
out
to
the
assault
.
   
<EOS>
The
bath
was
a
great
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
For
I
began
to
be
sensible
of
acute
pains
in
my
limbs
from
lying
out
in
the
fields
,
and
was
now
so
tired
and
low
that
I
could
hardly
keep
myself
awake
for
five
minutes
together
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
had
bathed
,
they
(
I
mean
my
aunt
and
Janet
)
enrobed
me
in
a
shirt
and
a
pair
of
trousers
belonging
to
Mr
Dick
,
and
tied
me
up
in
two
or
three
great
shawls
.
 
<EOS>
What
sort
of
bundle
<EOS>
I
looked
like
,
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
,
but
I
felt
a
very
hot
one
.
<EOS>
Feeling
also
very
faint
and
drowsy
,
I
soon
lay
down
on
the
sofa
again
and
fell
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
It
might
have
been
a
dream
,
originating
in
the
fancy
which
had
occupied
my
mind
so
long
,
but
I
awoke
with
the
impression
that
my
aunt
had
come
and
bent
over
me
,
and
had
put
my
hair
away
from
my
face
,
and
laid
my
head
more
comfortably
,
and
had
then
stood
looking
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
words
,
"
Pretty
fellow
,
"
or
"
Poor
fellow
,
"
seemed
to
be
in
my
ears
,
too
;
but
certainly
there
was
nothing
else
,
when
I
awoke
,
to
lead
me
to
believe
that
they
had
been
uttered
by
my
aunt
,
who
sat
in
the
bow
-
window
gazing
at
the
sea
from
behind
the
green
fan
,
which
was
mounted
on
a
kind
of
swivel
,
and
turned
any
way
.
   
<EOS>
We
dined
soon
after
I
awoke
,
off
a
roast
fowl
and
a
pudding
;
I
sitting
at
table
,
not
unlike
a
trussed
bird
myself
,
and
moving
my
arms
with
considerable
difficulty
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
my
aunt
had
swathed
me
up
,
I
made
no
complaint
of
being
inconvenienced
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
time
I
was
deeply
anxious
to
know
what
she
was
going
to
do
with
me
;
but
she
took
her
dinner
in
profound
silence
,
except
when
she
occasionally
fixed
her
eyes
on
me
sitting
opposite
,
and
said
,
"
Mercy
upon
us
!
"
which
did
not
by
any
means
relieve
my
anxiety
.
   
<EOS>
The
cloth
being
drawn
,
and
some
sherry
put
upon
the
table
(
of
which
I
had
a
glass
)
,
my
aunt
sent
up
for
Mr
Dick
again
,
who
joined
us
,
and
looked
as
wise
as
he
could
when
she
requested
him
to
attend
to
my
story
,
which
she
elicited
from
me
,
gradually
,
by
a
course
of
questions
.
 
<EOS>
During
my
recital
,
she
kept
her
eyes
on
Mr
Dick
,
who
I
thought
would
have
gone
to
sleep
but
for
that
,
and
who
,
whensoever
he
lapsed
into
a
smile
,
was
checked
by
a
frown
from
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Whatever
possessed
that
poor
unfortunate
Baby
,
that
she
must
go
and
be
married
again
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
when
I
had
finished
,
"
I
ca
n't
conceive
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
she
fell
in
love
with
her
second
husband
,
"
Mr
Dick
suggested
.
   
<EOS>
"
Fell
in
love
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
 
<EOS>
What
business
had
she
to
do
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
,
"
Mr
Dick
simpered
,
after
thinking
a
little
,
"
she
did
it
for
pleasure
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pleasure
,
indeed
!
"
replied
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
mighty
pleasure
for
the
poor
Baby
to
fix
her
simple
faith
upon
any
dog
of
a
fellow
,
certain
to
ill
-
use
her
in
some
way
or
other
.
 
<EOS>
What
did
she
propose
to
herself
,
I
should
like
to
know
!
 
<EOS>
She
had
had
one
husband
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
seen
David
Copperfield
out
of
the
world
,
who
was
always
running
after
wax
dolls
from
his
cradle
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
got
a
baby
---
<EOS>
oh
,
there
were
a
pair
of
babies
when
she
gave
birth
to
this
child
sitting
here
,
that
Friday
night
!
<EOS>
---
and
what
more
did
she
want
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
secretly
shook
his
head
at
me
,
as
if
he
thought
there
was
no
getting
over
this
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
could
n't
even
have
a
baby
like
anybody
else
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
was
this
child
's
sister
,
Betsey
Trotwood
?
 
<EOS>
Not
forthcoming
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
tell
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
seemed
quite
frightened
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
little
man
of
a
doctor
,
with
his
head
on
one
side
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
Jellips
,
or
whatever
his
name
was
,
<EOS>
what
was
he
about
?
 
<EOS>
All
he
could
do
,
was
to
say
to
me
,
like
a
robin
redbreast
---
as
he
is
---
"
It
's
a
boy
.
"
 
<EOS>
A
boy
!
 
<EOS>
Yah
,
the
imbecility
of
the
whole
set
of
'
em
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
heartiness
of
the
ejaculation
startled
Mr
Dick
exceedingly
;
and
me
,
too
,
if
I
am
to
tell
the
truth
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
then
,
as
if
this
was
not
enough
,
and
she
had
not
stood
sufficiently
in
the
light
of
this
child
's
sister
,
Betsey
Trotwood
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
she
marries
a
second
time
---
goes
and
marries
a
Murderer
---
or
a
man
with
a
name
like
it
---
and
stands
in
THIS
child
's
light
!
 
<EOS>
And
the
natural
consequence
is
,
as
anybody
but
a
baby
might
have
foreseen
,
that
he
prowls
and
wanders
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
as
like
Cain
before
he
was
grown
up
,
as
he
can
be
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
looked
hard
at
me
,
as
if
to
identify
me
in
this
character
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
then
there
's
that
woman
with
the
Pagan
name
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
that
Peggotty
,
she
goes
and
gets
married
next
.
 
<EOS>
Because
she
has
not
seen
enough
of
the
evil
attending
such
things
,
she
goes
and
gets
married
next
,
as
the
child
relates
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
hope
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
shaking
her
head
,
"
that
her
husband
is
one
of
those
Poker
husbands
who
abound
in
the
newspapers
,
and
will
beat
her
well
with
one
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
not
bear
to
hear
my
old
nurse
so
decried
,
and
made
the
subject
of
such
a
wish
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
my
aunt
that
indeed
she
was
mistaken
.
 
<EOS>
That
Peggotty
was
the
best
,
the
truest
,
the
most
faithful
,
most
devoted
,
and
most
self
-
denying
friend
and
servant
in
the
world
;
who
had
ever
loved
me
dearly
,
who
had
ever
loved
my
mother
dearly
;
who
had
held
my
mother
's
dying
head
upon
her
arm
,
on
whose
face
my
mother
had
imprinted
her
last
grateful
kiss
.
 
<EOS>
And
my
remembrance
of
them
both
,
choking
me
,
I
broke
down
as
I
was
trying
to
say
that
her
home
was
my
home
,
and
that
all
she
had
was
mine
,
and
that
I
would
have
gone
to
her
for
shelter
,
but
for
her
humble
station
,
which
made
me
fear
that
I
might
bring
some
trouble
on
her
---
<EOS>
I
broke
down
,
I
say
,
as
I
was
trying
to
say
so
,
and
laid
my
face
in
my
hands
upon
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
the
child
is
right
to
stand
by
those
who
have
stood
by
him
---
Janet
!
 
<EOS>
Donkeys
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
thoroughly
believe
that
but
for
those
unfortunate
donkeys
,
we
should
have
come
to
a
good
understanding
;
for
my
aunt
had
laid
her
hand
on
my
shoulder
,
and
the
impulse
was
upon
me
,
thus
emboldened
,
to
embrace
her
and
beseech
her
protection
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
interruption
,
and
the
disorder
she
was
thrown
into
by
the
struggle
outside
,
put
an
end
to
all
softer
ideas
for
the
present
,
and
kept
my
aunt
indignantly
declaiming
to
Mr
Dick
about
her
determination
to
appeal
for
redress
to
the
laws
of
her
country
,
and
to
bring
actions
for
trespass
against
the
whole
donkey
proprietorship
of
Dover
,
until
tea
-
time
.
   
<EOS>
After
tea
,
we
sat
at
the
window
---
on
the
look
-
out
,
as
I
imagined
,
from
my
aunt
's
sharp
expression
of
face
,
for
more
invaders
---
until
dusk
,
when
Janet
set
candles
,
and
a
backgammon
-
board
,
on
the
table
,
and
pulled
down
the
blinds
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Mr
Dick
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
with
her
grave
look
,
and
her
forefinger
up
as
before
,
"
I
am
going
to
ask
you
another
question
.
<EOS>
Look
at
this
child
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
David
's
son
?
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
with
an
attentive
,
puzzled
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Exactly
so
,
"
returned
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
would
you
do
with
him
,
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
with
David
's
son
?
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
"
replied
my
aunt
,
"
with
David
's
son
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Do
with
---
I
should
put
him
to
bed
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Janet
!
"
cried
my
aunt
,
with
the
same
complacent

that
I
had
remarked
before
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dick
sets
us
all
right
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
bed
is
ready
,
we
'll
take
him
up
to
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Janet
reporting
it
to
be
quite
ready
,
I
was
taken
up
to
it
;
kindly
,
but
in
some
sort
like

;
my
aunt
going
in
front
and
Janet
bringing
up
the
rear
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
circumstance
which
gave
me
any
new
hope
,
was
my
aunt
's
stopping
on
the
stairs
to
inquire
about
a
smell
of
fire
that
was
prevalent
there
;
and
janet
's
replying
that
she
had
been
making
tinder
down
in
the
kitchen
,
of
my
old
shirt
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
were
no
other
clothes
in
my
room
than
the
odd
heap
of
things
I
wore
;
and
when
I
was
left
there
,
with
a
little
taper
which
my
aunt
forewarned
me
would
burn
exactly
five
minutes
<EOS>
,
I
heard
them
lock
my
door
on
the
outside
.
 
<EOS>
Turning
these
things
over
in
my
mind
<EOS>
I
deemed
it
possible
that
my
aunt
,
who
could
know
nothing
of
me
,
might
suspect
I
had
a
habit
of
running
away
,
and
took
precautions
,
on
that

,
to
have
me
in
safe
keeping
.
   
<EOS>
The
room
was
a
pleasant
one
,
at
the
top
of
the
house
,
overlooking
the
sea
,
on
which
the
moon
was
shining
brilliantly
.
 
<EOS>
After
I
had
said
my
prayers
,
and
the
candle
had
burnt
out
,
I
remember
how
I
still
sat
looking
at
the
moonlight
on
the
water
,
as
if
I
could
hope
to
read
my
fortune
in
it
,
as
in
a
bright
book
;
or
to
see
my
mother
with
her
child
,
coming
from
Heaven
,
along
that
shining
path
,
to
look
upon
me
as
she
had
looked
when
I
last
saw
her
sweet
face
.
 
<EOS>
I
remember
how
the
solemn
feeling
with
which
at
length
I
turned
my
eyes
away
,
yielded
to
the
sensation
of
gratitude
and
rest
<EOS>
which
the
sight
of
the
white
-
curtained
bed
---
and
how
much
more
the
lying
softly
down
upon
it
,
nestling
in
the
snow
-
white
sheets
<EOS>
!
<EOS>
---
inspired
.
<EOS>
I
remember
how
I
thought
of
all
the
solitary
places
under
the
night
sky
where
I
had
slept
,
and
how
I
prayed
that
I
never
might
be
houseless
any
more
,
and
never
might
forget
the
houseless
.
 
<EOS>
I
remember
how
I
seemed
to
float
,
then
,
down
the
melancholy
glory
of
that
track
upon
the
sea
,
away
into
the
world
of
dreams
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
14
.
<EOS>
My
aunt
makes
up
her
mind
about
me
 
On
going
down
in
the
morning
,
I
found
my
aunt
musing
so
profoundly
over
the
breakfast
table
,
with
her
elbow
on
the
tray
,
that
the
contents
of
the
urn
had
overflowed
the
teapot
and
were
laying
the
whole
table
-
cloth
under
water
,
when
my
entrance
put
her
meditations
to
flight
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
sure
that
I
had
been
the
subject
of
her
reflections
,
and
was
more
than
ever
anxious
to
know
her
intentions
towards
me
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
I
dared
not
express
my
anxiety
,
lest
it
should
give
her
offence
.
   
<EOS>
My
eyes
,
however
,
not
being
so
much
under
control
as
my
tongue
,
were
attracted
towards
my
aunt
very
often
during
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
could
look
at
her
for
a
few
moments
together
<EOS>
but
I
found
her
looking
at
me
---
in
an
odd
thoughtful
manner
,
as
if
I
were
an
immense
way
off
,
instead
of
being
on
the
other
side
of
the
small
round
table
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
finished
her
breakfast
,
my
aunt
very
deliberately
leaned
back
in
her
chair
,
knitted
her
brows
,
folded
her
arms
,
and
contemplated
me
at
her
leisure
,
with
such
a
fixedness
of
attention
that
I
was
quite
overpowered
by
embarrassment
.
 
<EOS>
Not
having
as
yet
finished
my
own
breakfast
,
I
attempted
to
hide
my
confusion
by
proceeding
with
it
;
but
my
knife
tumbled
over
my
fork
,
my
fork
tripped
up
my
knife
,
I
chipped
bits
of
bacon
a
surprising
height
into
the
air
instead
of
cutting
them
for
my
own
eating
,
and
choked
myself
with
my
tea
,
which
persisted
in
going
the
wrong
way
instead
of
the
right
one
,
until
I
gave
in
altogether
,
and
sat
blushing
under
my
aunt
's
close
scrutiny
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hallo
!
"
said
my
aunt
,
after
a
long
time
.
   
<EOS>
I
looked
up
,
and
met
her
sharp
bright
glance
respectfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
written
to
him
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
---
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
your
father
-
in
-
law
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
sent
him

letter
that
I
'll

to
attend
to
,
or
he
and
I
will

out
,
I

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Does
he
know
where
I
am
,
aunt
?
<EOS>
"
I
inquired
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
told
him
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
---
be
---
given

to

?
<EOS>
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall
see
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
ca
n't

,
"
I

,
"
if

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

,
"
said

aunt
,

.
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
say
,
I
am

.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
see
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
spirits
sank
under
these
words
,
and
I
became
very
downcast
and
heavy

heart
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
without
appearing
to
take
much
heed
of
me
,
put
on
a
coarse
apron
with
a
bib
,
which
she
took
out
of
the
press
;
washed
up
the
teacups
with
her
own
hands
;
and
,
when
everything
was
washed
and
set

,
and

folded
and
put
on

top

,
rang

Janet
to

.
 
<EOS>
She
next
swept
up
the
crumbs
with
a
little
broom
(

pair

gloves

)
,
until
there
did
not
appear

one

;
next

and

room
,
which
was
dusted
and

to
a

already
.
<EOS>
When
all

were
performed
to

,
she

,
folded

,

in
the
particular

of
the

from

,
brought

work

box
to
her
own

in

,
and

,
with
the

light
,
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said

,

,
"

Mr
Dick
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

"
you
think
Mr
Dick
a
short

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"

<EOS>
"
Babley
---
Mr
Richard
Babley
<EOS>
---
that
's

's

.
"
   
<EOS>
I
was

suggest
,
with

of
my

the

I

<EOS>
,

,

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
Mr

his

,

<EOS>
So

,

anything
<EOS>
BUT
Mr
Dick
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

,

;
thinking
,

,
that

long
,

,

,

,

probably

.
 
<EOS>
I

him
still
driving
at
it
with
a
long

,
and
his
head
almost
laid
upon
the

.
 
<EOS>
He

,
that
I
had
ample

to

the
large

in

,
the

,

,

,

(

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
Phoebus
!
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
How

?
 
<EOS>
I
'll

what
,
"

---
"
<EOS>

---
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
Mad

,

!
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
Without

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said

Dick
,
in

"
my

,

<EOS>
I
<EOS>
---
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

have

start
,
"
said

Dick
,
passing
his

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have

to

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
"
I

;
"
for
a

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

,
"
said

Dick
,

,
and

,
"
when
King
Charles

First
had

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I

I

happened
in

sixteen

-

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"

Mr
Dick
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
So
the
books
say
;
but
I
do
n't
see
how

can

.
 
<EOS>
Because
,
if

was
so
long
ago
,
how
could

some

,

,
into

?
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
very
much

by
the

;
but

no

on

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

,
"
said

,

,
and

hair
again
,
"
that
I
never
can

right
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
can

clear
.
 
<EOS>
But

,
no

!
<EOS>
"
he
said

,
and

,
"
there
's

!
 
<EOS>
My
compliments
to
Miss
Trotwood
<EOS>
,
I
am
getting
on
very

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
was

,
when
he
directed

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
of
that
for

?
"
<EOS>
he

.
   
<EOS>
I
answered
that
it
was
a

one
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
think
it
must
have
been
as
much
as
seven
feet
high
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
made
it
.
 
<EOS>
We
'll
go
and
fly
it
,
you
and
I
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
see
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
showed
me
that
it
was
covered
with
manuscript
,
very
closely
and
laboriously
written
;
but
so
plainly
,
that
as
I
looked
along
the
lines
,
I
thought
I
saw
some
allusion
to
King
Charles
<EOS>
the
First
's
head
again
,
in
one
or
two
places
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
plenty
of
string
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
"
and
when
it
flies
high
,
it
takes
the
facts
a
long
way
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
my
manner
of
diffusing
'em
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
where
they
may
come
down
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
according
to
circumstances
,
and
the
wind
,
and
so
forth
;
but
I
take
my
chance
of
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
face
was
so
very
mild
and
pleasant
,
and
had
something
so
reverend
in
it
,
though
it
was
hale
and
hearty
,
that
I
was
not
sure
but
that
he
was
having
a
good
-
humoured
jest
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
laughed
,
and
he
laughed
,
and
we
parted
the
best
friends
possible
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
child
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
when
I
went
downstairs
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
what
of
Mr
Dick
,
this
morning
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
informed
her
that
he
sent
his
compliments
,
and
was
getting
on
very
well
indeed
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
of
him
?
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
some
shadowy
idea
of
endeavouring
to
evade
the
question
,
by
replying
that
I
thought
him
a
very
nice
gentleman
;
but
my
aunt
was
not
to
be
so
put
off
,
for
she
laid
her
work
down
in
her
lap
,
and
said
,
folding
her
hands
upon
it
:
   
"
<EOS>
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Your
sister
Betsey
Trotwood
would
have
told
me
what
she
thought
of
anyone
,
directly
.
 
<EOS>
Be
as
like
your
sister
as
you
can
,
and
speak
out
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
he
---
is
Mr
Dick
<EOS>
---
I
ask
because
I
do
n't
know
,
aunt
---
is
he
at
all
out
of
his
mind
,
then
?
<EOS>
"
I
stammered
;
for
I
felt
I
was
on
dangerous
ground
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
morsel
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
"
I
observed
faintly
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
there
is
anything
in
the
world
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
with
great
decision
and
force
of
manner
,
"
that
Mr
Dick
is
not
,
it
's
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
had
nothing
better
to
offer
,
than
another
timid
,
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
indeed
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
been
CALLED
mad
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
selfish
pleasure
in
saying
he
has
been
called
mad
,
or
I
should
not
have
had
the
benefit
of
his
society
and
advice
for
these
last
ten
years
and
upwards
---
in
fact
,
ever
since
your
sister
,
Betsey
Trotwood
,
disappointed
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
long
as
that
?
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
nice
people
they
were
,
who
had
the
audacity
to
call
him
mad
,
"
pursued
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dick
is
a
sort
of
distant
connexion
of
mine
---
it
does
n't
matter
how
;
I
need
n't
enter
into
that
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
had
n't
been
for
me
,
his
own
brother
would
have
shut
him
up
for
life
.
<EOS>
That
's
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
it
was
hypocritical
in
me
,
but
seeing
that
my
aunt
felt
strongly
on
the
subject
,
I
tried
to
look
as
if
I
felt
strongly
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
proud
fool
!
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Because
his
brother
was
a
little
eccentric
---
though
he
is
not
half
so
eccentric
as
a
good
many
people
---
he
did
n't
like
to
have
him
visible
about
his
house
,
and
sent
him
away
to
some
private
asylum
-
place
:
though
he
had
been
left
to
his
particular
care
by
their
deceased
father
,
who
thought
him
almost
a
natural
.
 
<EOS>
And
a
wise
man
he
must
have
been
to
think
so
!
<EOS>
Mad
himself
,
no
doubt
.
"
   
<EOS>
Again
,
as
my
aunt
looked
quite
convinced
,
I
endeavoured
to
look
quite
convinced
also
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
I
stepped
in
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
and
made
him
an
offer
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
,
"
Your
brother
's
sane
---
a
great
deal
more
sane
than
you
are
,
or
ever
will
be
,
it
is
to
be
hoped
.
 
<EOS>
Let
him
have
his
little
income
,
and
come
and
live
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
afraid
of
him
,
I
am
not
proud
,
I
am
ready
to
take
care
of
him
,
and
shall
not
ill
-
treat
him
as
some
people
(
besides
the
asylum
-
folks
)
have
done
.
"
 
<EOS>
After
a
good
deal
of
squabbling
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
I
got
him
;
and
he
has
been
here
ever
since
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
the
most
friendly
and
amenable
creature
in
existence
;
and
as
for
advice
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
But
nobody
knows
what
that
man
's
mind
is
,
except
myself
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
smoothed
her
dress
and
shook
her
head
,
as
if
she
smoothed
defiance
of
the
whole
world
out
of
the
one
,
and
shook
it
out
of
the
other
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
had
a
favourite
sister
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
a
good
creature
,
and
very
kind
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
did
what
they
all
do
---
took
a
husband
.
<EOS>
And
HE
did
what
they
all
do
---
made
her
wretched
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
such
an
effect
upon
the
mind
of
Mr
Dick
(
that
's
not
madness
,
I
hope
!
)
<EOS>
that
,
combined
with
his
fear
of
his
brother
,
and
his
sense
of
his
unkindness
,
it
threw
him
into
a
fever
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
before
he
came
to
me
,
but
the
recollection
of
it
is
oppressive
to
him
even
now
.
 
<EOS>
Did
he
say
anything
to
you
about
King
Charles
the
First
,
child
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
aunt
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
my
aunt
,
rubbing
her
nose
as
if
she
were
a
little
vexed
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
his
allegorical
way
of
expressing
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
connects
his
illness
with
great
disturbance
and
agitation
,
naturally
,
and
that
's
the
figure
,
or
the
simile
,
or
whatever
it
's
called
,
which
he
chooses
to
use
.
 
<EOS>
And
why
should
n't
he
,
if
he
thinks
proper
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
:
"
Certainly
,
aunt
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
a
business
-
like
way
of
speaking
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
nor
a
worldly
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
aware
of
that
;
and
that
's
the
reason
why
I
insist
upon
it
,
that
there
sha
n't
be
a
word
about
it
in
his
Memorial
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
a
Memorial
about
his
own
history
that
he
is
writing
,
aunt
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
child
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
rubbing
her
nose
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
memorializing
the
Lord
Chancellor
,
or
the
Lord
Somebody
or
other
---
one
of
those
people
,
at
all
events
,
who
are
paid
to
be
memorialized
---
about
his
affairs
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
it
will
go
in
,
one
of
these
days
.
<EOS>
He
has
n't
been
able
to
draw
it
up
yet
,
without
introducing
that
mode
of
expressing
himself
;
but
it
do
n't
signify
;
it
keeps
him
employed
.
"
   
<EOS>
In
fact
,
I
found
out
afterwards
that
Mr
Dick
had
been
for
upwards
of
ten
years
endeavouring
to
keep
King
Charles
the
First
out
of
the
Memorial
;
but
he
had
been
constantly
getting
into
it
,
and
was
there
now
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
again
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
nobody
knows
what
that
man
's
mind
is
except
myself
;
and
he
's
the
most
amenable
and
friendly
creature
in
existence
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
likes
to
fly
a
kite
sometimes
,
what
of
that
!
<EOS>
Franklin
used
to
fly
a
kite
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
Quaker
,
or
something
of
that
sort
,
if
I
am
not
mistaken
.
 
<EOS>
And
a
Quaker
flying
a
kite
is
a
much
more
ridiculous
object
than
anybody
else
.
"
   
<EOS>
If
I
could
have
supposed
that
my
aunt
had
recounted
these
particulars
for
my
especial
behoof
,
and
as
a
piece
of
confidence
in
me
,
I
should
have
felt
very
much
distinguished
,
and
should
have
augured
favourably
from
such
a
mark
of
her
good
opinion
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
could
hardly
help
observing
that
she
had
launched
into
them
,
chiefly
because
the
question
was
raised
in
her
own
mind
,
and
with
very
little
reference
to
me
,
though
she
had
addressed
herself
to
me
in
the
absence
of
anybody
else
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
,
I
must
say
that
the
generosity
of
her
championship
of
poor
harmless
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
,
not
only
inspired
my
young
breast
with
some
selfish
hope
for
myself
,
but
warmed
it
unselfishly
towards
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
that
I
began
to
know
that
there
was
something
about
my
aunt
,
notwithstanding
her
many
eccentricities
and
odd
humours
,
to
be
honoured
and
trusted
in
.
 
<EOS>
Though
she
was
just
as
sharp
that
day
as
on
the
day
before
,
and
was
in
and
out
about
the
donkeys
just
as
often
,
and
was
thrown
into
a
tremendous
state
of
indignation
,
when
a
young
man
,
going
by
,
ogled
Janet
at
a
window
(
which
was
one
of
the
gravest
misdemeanours
that
could
be
committed
against
my
aunt
's
dignity
)
,
she
seemed
to
me
to
command
more
of
my
respect
,
if
not
less
of
my
fear
.
   
<EOS>
The
anxiety
I
underwent
,
in
the
interval
which
necessarily
elapsed
before
a
reply
could
be
received
to
her
letter
to
Mr
Murdstone
,
was
extreme
;
but
I
made
an
endeavour
to
suppress
it
,
and
to
be
as
agreeable
as
I
could
in
a
quiet
way
,
both
to
my
aunt
and
Mr
Dick
.
<EOS>
The
latter
and
I
would
have
gone
out
to
fly
the
great
kite
;
but
that
I
had
still
no
other
clothes
than
the
anything
but
ornamental
garments
with
which
I
had
been
decorated
on
the
first
day
,
and
which
confined
me
to
the
house
,
except
for
an
hour
after
dark
,
when
my
aunt
,
for
my
health
's
sake
,
paraded
me
up
and
down
on
the
cliff
outside
,
before
going
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
the
reply
from
Mr
Murdstone
came
,
and
my
aunt
informed
me
,
to
my
infinite
terror
,
that
he
was
coming
to
speak
to
her
herself
on
the
next
day
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
next
day
,
still
bundled
up
in
my
curious
habiliments
,
I
sat
counting
the
time
,
flushed
and
heated
by
the
conflict
of
sinking
hopes
and
rising
fears
within
me
;
and
waiting
to
be
startled
by
the
sight
of
the
gloomy
face
,
whose
non
-
arrival
startled
me
every
minute
.
   
<EOS>
MY
aunt
was
a
little
more
imperious
and
stern
than
usual
,
but
I
observed
no
other
token
of
her
preparing
herself
to
receive
the
visitor
so
much
dreaded
by
me
.
 
<EOS>
She
sat
at
work
in
the
window
,
and
I
sat
by
,
with
my
thoughts
running
astray
on
all
possible
and
impossible
results
of
Mr
Murdstone
's
visit
,
until
pretty
late
in
the
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
Our
dinner
had
been
indefinitely
postponed
;
but
it
was
growing
so
late
,
that
my
aunt
had
ordered
it
to
be
got
ready
,
when
she
gave
a
sudden
alarm
of
donkeys
,
and
to
my
consternation
and
amazement
,
I
beheld
Miss
Murdstone
,
on
a
side
-
saddle
,
ride
deliberately
over
the
sacred
piece
of
green
,
and
stop
in
front
of
the
house
,
looking
about
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Go
along
with
you
!
"
<EOS>
cried
my
aunt
,
shaking
her
head
and
her
fist
at
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
no
business
there
.
 
<EOS>
How
dare
you
trespass
?
 
<EOS>
Go
along
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
you
bold
-
faced
thing
!
"
   
<EOS>
MY
aunt
was
so
exasperated
by
the
coolness
with
which
Miss
Murdstone
looked
about
her
,
that
I
really
believe
she
was
motionless
,
and
unable
for
the
moment
to
dart
out
according
to
custom
.
 
<EOS>
I
seized
the
opportunity
to
inform
her
who
it
was
;
and
that
the
gentleman
now
coming
near
the
offender
(
for
the
way
up
was
very
steep
,
and
he
had
dropped
behind
)
,
was
Mr
Murdstone
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
care
who
it
is
!
"
cried
my
aunt
,
still
shaking
her
head
and
gesticulating
anything
<EOS>
but
welcome
from
the
bow
-
window
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
be
trespassed
upon
.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
allow
it
.
 
<EOS>
Go
away
!
 
<EOS>
Janet
,
turn
him
round
.
 
<EOS>
Lead
him
off
!
"
<EOS>
and
I
saw
,
from
behind
my
aunt
,
a
sort
of
hurried
battle
-
piece
,
in
which
the
donkey
stood
resisting
everybody
,
with
all
his
four
legs
planted
different
ways
,
while
Janet
tried
to
pull
him
round
by
the
bridle
,
Mr
Murdstone
tried
to
lead
him
on
,
Miss
Murdstone
struck
at
Janet
with
a
parasol
,
and
several
boys
,
who
had
come
to
see
the
engagement
,
shouted
vigorously
.
 
<EOS>
But
my
aunt
,
suddenly
descrying
among
them
the
young
malefactor
who
was
the
donkey
's
guardian
,
and
who
was
one
of
the
most
inveterate
offenders
against
her
,
though
hardly
in
his
teens
,
rushed
out
to
the
scene
of
action
,
pounced
upon
him
,
captured
him
,
dragged
him
,
with
his
jacket
over
his
head
,
and
<EOS>
his
heels
grinding
the
ground
,
into
the
garden
,
and
,
calling
upon
Janet
to
fetch
the
constables
and
justices
,
that
he
might
be
taken
,
tried
,
and
executed
on
the
spot
,
held
him
at
bay
there
.
 
<EOS>
This
part
of
the
business
,
however
,
did
not
last
long
;
for
the
young
rascal
,
being
expert
at
a
variety
of
feints
and
dodges
,
of
which
my
aunt
had
no
conception
,
soon
went
whooping
away
,
leaving
some
deep
impressions
of
his
nailed
boots
in
the
flower
-
beds
,
and
taking
his
donkey
in
triumph
with
him
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
,
during
the
latter
portion
of
the
contest
,
had
dismounted
,
and
was
now
waiting
with
her
brother
at
the
bottom
of
the
steps
,
until
my
aunt
should
be
at
leisure
to
receive
them
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
a
little
ruffled
by
the
combat
,
marched
past
them
into
the
house
,
with
great
dignity
,
and
took
no
notice
of
their
presence
,
until
they
were
announced
by
Janet
.
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
go
away
,
aunt
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
,
trembling
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Certainly
not
!
"
 
<EOS>
With
which
she
pushed
me
into
a
corner
near
her
,
and
fenced
Me
in
with
a
chair
,
as
if
it
were
a
prison
or
a
bar
of
justice
.
 
<EOS>
This
position
I
continued
to
occupy
during
the
whole
interview
,
and
from
it
I
now
saw
Mr
and
Miss
Murdstone
enter
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
I
was
not
aware
at
first
to
whom
I
had
the
pleasure
of
objecting
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
do
n't
allow
anybody
to
ride
over
that
turf
.
 
<EOS>
I
make
no
exceptions
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
allow
anybody
to
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
regulation
is
rather
awkward
to
strangers
,
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
!
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Murdstone
seemed
afraid
of
a
renewal
of
hostilities
,
and
interposing
began
:
   
"
Miss
Trotwood
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
"
observed
my
aunt
with
a
keen
look
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
the
Mr
Murdstone
who
married
the
widow
of
my
late
nephew
,
David
Copperfield
,
of
Blunderstone
Rookery
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Though
why
Rookery
,
I
do
n't
know
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
excuse
my
saying
,
sir
,
"
returned
my
aunt
,
"
that
I
think
it
would
have
been
a
much
better
and
happier
thing
if
you
had
left
that
poor
child
alone
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
so
far
agree
with
what
Miss
Trotwood
has
remarked
,
"
observed
Miss
Murdstone
,
bridling
,
"
that
I
consider
our
lamented
Clara
to
have
been
,
in
all
essential
respects
,
a
mere
child
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
comfort
to
you
and
me
,
ma'am
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
who
are
getting
on
in
life
,
and
are
not
likely
to
be
made
unhappy
by
our
personal
attractions
,
that
nobody
can
say
the
same
of
us
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
!
<EOS>
"
returned
Miss
Murdstone
,
though
,
I
thought
,
not
with
a
very
ready
or
gracious
assent
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
it
certainly
might
have
been
,
as
you
say
,
a
better
and
happier
thing
for
my
brother
if
he
had
never
entered
into
such
a
marriage
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
always
been
of
that
opinion
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
you
have
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Janet
,
"
ringing
the
bell
,
"
my
compliments
to
Mr
Dick
,
and
beg
him
to
come
down
.
"
   
<EOS>
Until
he
came
,
my
aunt
sat
perfectly
upright
and
stiff
,
frowning
at
the
wall
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
came
,
my
aunt
performed
the
ceremony
of
introduction
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
An
old
and
intimate
friend
.
 
<EOS>
On
whose
judgement
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
with
emphasis
,
as
an
admonition
to
Mr
Dick
,
who
was
biting
his
forefinger
and
looking
rather
foolish
,
"
I
rely
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
took
his
finger
out
of
his
mouth
,
on
this
hint
,
and
stood
among
the
group
,
with
a
grave
and
attentive
expression
of
face
.
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
inclined
her
head
to
Mr
Murdstone
,
who
went
on
:
   
"
Miss
Trotwood
:
on
the
receipt
of
your
letter
,
I
considered
it
an
act
of
greater
justice
to
myself
,
and
perhaps
of
more
respect
to
you
---
"
   
"
Thank
you
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
still
eyeing
him
keenly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
need
n't
mind
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
answer
it
in
person
,
however
inconvenient
the
journey
,
"
pursued
Mr
Murdstone
,
"
rather
than
by
letter
.
 
<EOS>
This
unhappy
boy
who
has
run
away
from
his
friends
and
his
occupation
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
And
whose
appearance
,
"
interposed
his
sister
,
directing
general
attention
to
me
in
my
indefinable
costume
,
"
is
perfectly
scandalous
and
disgraceful
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Jane
Murdstone
,
"
said
her
brother
,
"
have
the
goodness
not
to
interrupt
me
.
 
<EOS>
This
unhappy
boy
,
Miss
Trotwood
,
has
been
the
occasion
of
much
domestic
trouble
and
uneasiness
;
both
during
the
lifetime
of
my
late
dear
wife
,
and
since
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
sullen
,
rebellious
spirit
;
a
violent
temper
;
and
an
untoward
,
intractable
disposition
.
 
<EOS>
Both
my
sister
and
myself
have
endeavoured
to
correct
his
vices
,
but
ineffectually
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
have
felt
<EOS>
---
we
both
have
felt
,
I
may
say
;
my
sister
being
fully
in
my
confidence
---
that
it
is
right
you
should
receive
this
grave
and
dispassionate
assurance
from
our
lips
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
can
hardly
be
necessary
for
me
to
confirm
anything
stated
by
my
brother
,
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
beg
to
observe
,
that
,
of
all
the
boys
in
the
world
,
I
believe
this
is
the
worst
boy
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Strong
!
"
said
my
aunt
,
shortly
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
not
at
all
too
strong
for
the
facts
,
"
returned
Miss
Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
my
own
opinions
,
"
resumed
Mr
Murdstone
,
whose
face
darkened
more
and
more
,
<EOS>
the
more
he
and
my
aunt
observed
each
other
,
which
they
did
very
narrowly
,
"
as
to
the
best
mode
of
bringing
him
up
;
they
are
founded
,
in
part
,
on
my
knowledge
of
him
,
and
in
part
on
my
knowledge
of
my
own
means
and

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
responsible
for
them
to
myself
<EOS>
,
I
act
upon
them
,
and
I
say
no
more
about
them
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
enough
that
I
place
this
boy
under
the
eye
of
a
friend
of
my
own
,
in
a
respectable
business
;
that
it
does
not
please
him
;
that
he
runs
away
from
it
;
makes
himself
a
common
vagabond
about
the
country
;
and
comes
here
,
in
rags
,
to
appeal
to
you
,
Miss
Trotwood
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
to
set
before
you
,
honourably
,
the
exact
consequences
---
so
far
as
they
are
within
my
knowledge
---
of
your
abetting
him
in
this
appeal
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
about
the
respectable
business
first
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
he
had
been
your
own
boy
,
you
would
have
put
him
to
it
,
just
the

,
I

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
he
had
been
my
brother
's
own
boy
,
"
returned
Miss
Murdstone
,
striking
in
,
"
his
character
,
I
trust
,
would
have

altogether
different
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Or
if
the
poor

,
his
mother
,
had

,
he
would
still

gone
into
the

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
,
with
an

,
"
that
Clara
would
have
disputed
nothing
which
myself
and
my
sister
Jane
Murdstone
were
agreed
was
for
the
best
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
confirmed
this
with
an
audible

.
   
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Unfortunate
baby
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
,
who
had
been
rattling
his
money
all
this
time
,
was
rattling
it
so
loudly
now
,
that
my
aunt
felt
it
necessary
to
check
him
with
a
look
,
before
saying
:
   
"
The
poor
child
's
annuity
died
with
her
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Died
with
her
,
"
replied
Mr
Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
there
was
no
settlement
of
the
little
property
---
the
house
and
garden
---
the
what's
-
its
-
name
Rookery
without
any
rooks
in

---
upon
her
boy
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
had
been
left
to
her
,
unconditionally
,
by
her
first
husband
,
"
Mr
Murdstone
began
,
when
my
aunt
caught
him
up
with
the
greatest

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
Lord
,
man
,
there
's
no
occasion
to
say
that
.
 
<EOS>
Left
to
her
unconditionally
!
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
see
David
Copperfield
looking
forward
to
any
condition
of
any
sort
or
kind
,
though
it
stared
him
point
-
blank
in
the
face
!
 
<EOS>
Of
course
it
was
left
to
her
unconditionally
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
she
married
again
---
when
she
took
that
most

step
of
marrying
you
,
in
short
,
"
said

,
"
to
be
plain
<EOS>
---
did
no
one
put
in
a

for
the
boy
at
that

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
late
wife
loved
her
second
husband
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Murdstone
,
"
and
trusted
implicitly
in
him
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
late
wife
,
sir
,
was
a
most
unworldly
,
most
unhappy
,
most
unfortunate
baby
,
"
returned
my
aunt
,
shaking

head
at
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
That
's
what
she
was
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
,
what
have
you
got
to
say
next
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Merely
this
,
Miss
Trotwood
,
"
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
here
to
take
David
back
---
to
take
him
back
unconditionally
,
to
dispose
of
him
as
I
think
proper
,
and
to
deal
with
him
as
I
think
right
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
here
to
make
any
promise
,
or
give
any
pledge
to
anybody
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
possibly
have
some
idea
,
Miss
Trotwood
,
of
abetting
him
in
his
running
away
,
and
in
his
complaints
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
Your
manner
,
which
I
must
say
does
not
seem
intended
to
propitiate
,
induces
me
to
think
it
possible
.
 
<EOS>
Now
I
must
caution
you
that
if
you
abet
him
once
,
you
abet
him
for
good
and
all
;
if
you
step
in
between
him
and
me
,
now
,
you
must
step
in
,
Miss
Trotwood
,
for
ever
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
trifle
,
or
be
trifled
with
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
here
,
for
the
first
and
last
time
,
to
take
him
away
.
 
<EOS>
Is
he
ready
to
go
?
 
<EOS>
If
he
is
not
---
and
you
tell
me
he
is
not
;
on
any
pretence
;
it
is
indifferent
to
me
<EOS>
what
---
my
doors
are
shut
against
him
henceforth
,
and
yours
,
I
take
it
for
granted
,
are
open
to
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
To
this
address
,
my
aunt
had
listened
with
the
closest
attention
,
sitting
perfectly
upright
,
with
her
hands
folded
on
one
knee
,
and
looking
grimly
on
the
speaker
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
finished
,
she
turned
her
eyes
so
as
to
command
Miss
Murdstone
,
without
otherwise
disturbing
her
attitude
,
and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Well
,
ma'am
,
have
YOU
got
anything
to
remark
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
Miss
Trotwood
,
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
,
"
<EOS>
all
that
I
could
say
has
been
so
well
said
by
my
brother
,
and
all
that
I
know
to
be
the
fact
has
been
so
plainly
stated
by
him
,
that
I
have
nothing
to
add
except
my
thanks
for
your
politeness
.
 
<EOS>
For
your
very
great
politeness
,
I
am
sure
,
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
;
with
an
irony
which
no
more
affected
my
aunt
,
than
it
discomposed
the
cannon
I
had
slept
by
at
Chatham
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
does
the
boy
say
?
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
ready
to
go
,
David
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
answered
no
,
and
entreated
her
not
to
let
me
go
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
that
neither
Mr
nor
Miss
Murdstone
had
ever
liked
me
,
or
had
ever
been
kind
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
That
they
had
made
my
mama
,
who
always
loved
me
dearly
,
unhappy
about
me
,
and
that
I
knew
it
well
,
and
that
Peggotty
knew
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
that
I
had
been
more
miserable
than
I
thought
anybody
could
believe
,
who
only
knew
how
young
I
was
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
begged
and
prayed
my
aunt
<EOS>
---
I
forget
in
what
terms
now
,
but
I
remember
that
they
affected
me
very
much
then
---
to
befriend
and
protect

,
for
my
father
's

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dick
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
what
shall
I
do

this
child
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
considered
,
hesitated
,
brightened
,
and
rejoined
,
"
Have
him
measured
for
a
suit

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dick
,
"
said
my
aunt
triumphantly
,
"
give
me
your
hand
,
for
your
common
sense
is
invaluable
.
"
 
<EOS>
Having
shaken

with
great

,
she
pulled
me
towards
her
and
said
to
Mr
Murdstone
:
   
<EOS>
"
You
can

;
I

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
do
n't
believe
a

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Trotwood
,
"

,

,

,
"
if

a

<EOS>
---
"
   
"
Bah
!
 
<EOS>
Stuff
and

!
<EOS>
"
said

aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
How

polite
!
"
exclaimed
Miss
Murdstone
,
rising
.
<EOS>
"
Overpowering
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
I
do
n't
know
,
"
said

aunt
,

,
"
what
kind

you
must

led
that
poor
,

?
 
<EOS>
Do

I
do

her
,
I
'll

could

boh
!
<EOS>
to

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
never

"

Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do

think
I
ca
n't

you
as
well

if

,
"

,
"

DO

and

---
which
,
I
tell

,
is

?
 
<EOS>
Oh
yes
,
bless
us
!
<EOS>
who
so
smooth

as
Mr
Murdstone
at

!
 
<EOS>
The
poor
,
benighted
innocent
had
never

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
He

---

!
 
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
Ugh
!
 
<EOS>
Get

,

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

!
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

"

wo

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
"

"

<EOS>
Miss

<EOS>
"
Mr

,
"

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

---
<EOS>
I

;

,

---

her

.
 
<EOS>
There

for

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

,

YOU

---

,

,

,

---

<EOS>
That

"

"

.
 
<EOS>
Aye

!
<EOS>
you

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

's

.
"
   
<EOS>
He

,
all

,

her
with

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
remarked
now
,
that
,
though

was
on

,
his

had
gone
in

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Good

,

,
"

,
"

!
 
<EOS>
Good

,

,

,
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
you
ride
a

over
my
green
again
,
and
as

you
have
a
head
upon

,
I
'll
knock

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
It

,
and

,

's

of

,

Miss
Murdstone
's

as

.
 
<EOS>
But

,
no

,

,
that
Miss
Murdstone
,
without

in

,
discreetly
put
her
arm
through
her

's
,
and

of

;
my
aunt
remaining
in
the
window
looking

;
prepared
,
I
have
no

,
in

's

,
to

into

.
   
<EOS>
No
attempt
at

being
made
,
however
,
her

gradually

,
and
became
so
pleasant
,
that
I

to

;
which
I

with
great

,
and
with
both
my
arms
clasped
round

neck
.
 
<EOS>
I
then
shook
hands
with
Mr
Dick
,
who
shook
hands
with
me
a
great
many
times
,
and
hailed
this
happy
close
of
the
proceedings
with
repeated

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll

,

,
of
this
child
,
Mr
Dick
,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said

Dick
,
"
to

David
's

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,
"

,
"
that
's

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
<EOS>
do

,
Mr
Dick
,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
David
's

's

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Trotwood
Copperfield
,
you

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Trotwood
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
a

.
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
took
so
kindly
to
the
notion
,
that
some
ready

,
which

,

"
Trotwood
Copperfield
"
,
in

,

-
ink
,
before
I

on
;
and
it
was
settled
that
all
the
other

which
were

to
