for
me
(
a
complete
outfit
was
bespoke
that
afternoon
)
<EOS>
should
be
marked
in
the
same
way
.
   
<EOS>
Thus
I
began
my
new
life
,
in
a
new
name
,
and
with
everything
new
about
me
.
 
<EOS>
Now
that
the
state
of
doubt
was
over
<EOS>
,
I
felt
,
for
many
days
,
like
one
in
a
dream
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
thought
that
I
had
a
curious
couple
of
guardians
,
in
my
aunt
and
Mr
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
thought
of
anything
about
myself
,
distinctly
.
 
<EOS>
The
two
things
clearest
in
my
mind
were
,
that
a
remoteness
had
come
upon
the
old
Blunderstone
life
---
which
seemed
to
lie
in
the
haze
of
an
immeasurable
distance
;
and
that
a
curtain
had
for
ever
fallen
on
my
life
at
Murdstone
and
Grinby
's
.
 
<EOS>
No
one
has
ever
raised
that
curtain
since
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
lifted
it
for
a
moment
,
even
in
this
narrative
,
with
a
reluctant
hand
,
and
dropped
it
gladly
.
 
<EOS>
The
remembrance
of
that
life
is
fraught
with
so
much
pain
to
me
,
with
so
much
mental
suffering
and
want
of
hope
,
that
I
have
never
had
the
courage
even
to
examine
how
long
I
was
doomed
to
lead
it
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
it
lasted
for
a
year
,
or
more
,
or
less
,
I
do
not
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
know
that
it
was
,
and
ceased
to
be
;
and
that
I
have
written
,
and
there
I
leave
it
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
15
.
<EOS>
I
make
another
beginning
 
Mr
Dick
<EOS>
and
I
soon
became
the
best
of
friends
,
and
very
often
,
when
his
day
's
work
was
done
,
went
out
together
to
fly
the
great
kite
.
 
<EOS>
Every
day
of
his
life
he
had
a
long
sitting
at
the
Memorial
,
which
never
made
the
least
progress
,
however
hard
he
laboured
,
for
King
Charles
the
First
always
strayed
into
it
,
sooner
or
later
,
and
then
it
was
thrown
aside
,
and
another
one
begun
.
 
<EOS>
The
patience
and
hope
with
which
he
bore
these
perpetual
disappointments
,
the
mild
perception
he
had
that
there
was
something
wrong
about
King
Charles
<EOS>
the
First
,
the
feeble
efforts
he
made
to
keep
him
out
,
and
the
certainty
with
which
he
came
in
,
and
tumbled
the
Memorial
out
of
all
shape
,
made
a
deep
impression
on
me
.
 
<EOS>
What
Mr
Dick
supposed
would
come
of
the
Memorial
<EOS>
,
if
it
were
completed
;
where
he
thought
it
was
to
go
,
or
what
he
thought
it
was
to
do
;
he
knew
no
more
than
anybody
else
,
I
believe
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
was
it
at
all
necessary
that
he
should
trouble
himself
with
such
questions
,
<EOS>
for
if
anything
were
certain
under
the
sun
,
it
was
certain
that
the
Memorial
never
would
be
finished
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
quite
an
affecting
sight
<EOS>
,
I
used
to
think
,
to
see
him
with
the
kite
when
it
was
up
a
great
height
in
the
air
.
<EOS>
What
he
had
told
me
,
in
his
room
,
about
his
belief
in
its
disseminating
the
statements
pasted
on
it
,
which
were
nothing
but
old
leaves
of
abortive
Memorials
,
might
have
been
a
fancy
with
him
sometimes
;
but
not
when
he
was
out
,
looking
up
at
the
kite
in
the
sky
,
and
feeling
it
pull
and
tug
at
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
looked
so
serene
as
he
did
then
.
 
<EOS>
I
used
to
fancy
,
as
I
sat
by
him
of
an
evening
,
on
a
green
slope
,
and
saw
him
watch
the
kite
high
in
the
quiet
air
,
that
it
lifted
his
mind
out
of
its
confusion
,
and
bore
it
<EOS>
(
such
was
my
boyish
thought
)
into
the
skies
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
wound
the
string
in
and
it
came
lower
and
lower
down
out
of
the
beautiful
light
,
until
it
fluttered
to
the
ground
,
and
lay
there
like
a
dead
thing
,
he
seemed
to
wake
gradually
out
of
a
dream
;
and
I
remember
to
have
seen
him
take
it
up
,
and
look
about
him
in
a
lost
way
,
as
if
they
had
both
come
down
together
,
so
that
I
pitied
him
with
all
my
heart
.
   
<EOS>
While
I
advanced
in
friendship
and
intimacy
with
Mr
Dick
,
I
did
not
go
backward
in
the
favour
of
his
staunch
friend
,
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
She
took
so
kindly
to
me
,
that
,
in
the
course
of
a
few
weeks
,
she
shortened
my
adopted
name
of
Trotwood
into
Trot
;
and
even
encouraged
me
to
hope
,
that
if
I
went
on
as
I
had
begun
,
I
might
take
equal
rank
in
her
affections
with
my
sister
Betsey
Trotwood
.
   
<EOS>
"
Trot
,
"
said
my
aunt
one
evening
,
when
the
backgammon
-
board
was
placed
as
usual
for
herself
and
Mr
Dick
,
"
we
must
not
forget
your
education
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
my
only
subject
of
anxiety
,
and
I
felt
quite
delighted
by
her
referring
to
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Should
you
like
to
go
to
school
at
Canterbury
?
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
I
replied
that
I
should
like
it
very
much
,
as
it
was
so
near
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Should
you
like
to
go
tomorrow
?
"
   
<EOS>
Being
already
no
stranger
to
the
general
rapidity
of
my
aunt
's
evolutions
,
I
was
not
surprised
by
the
suddenness
of
the
proposal
,
and
said
:
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
,
"
said
my
aunt
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Janet
,
hire
the
grey
pony
and
chaise
tomorrow
morning
at
ten
o'clock
,
and
pack
up
Master
Trotwood
's
clothes
tonight
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
greatly
elated
by
these
orders
;
but
my
heart
smote
me
for
my
selfishness
,
when
I
witnessed
their
effect
on
Mr
Dick
,
who
was
so
low
-
spirited
at
the
prospect
of
our
separation
,
and
played
so
ill
in
consequence
,
that
my
aunt
,
after
giving
him
several
admonitory
raps
on
the
knuckles
with
her
dice
-
box
,
shut
up
the
board
,
and
declined
to
play
with
him
any
more
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
on
hearing
from
my
aunt
that
I
should
sometimes
come
over
on
a
Saturday
,
and
that
he
could
sometimes
come
and
see
me
on
a
Wednesday
<EOS>
,
he
revived
;
and
vowed
to
make
another
kite
for
those
occasions
,
of
proportions
greatly
surpassing
the
present
one
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
morning
he
was
downhearted
again
,
and
would
have
sustained
himself
by
giving
me
all
the
money
he
had
in
his
possession
,
gold
and
silver
too
,
if
my
aunt
had
not
interposed
,
and
limited
the
gift
to
five
shillings
,
which
,
at
his
earnest
petition
,
were
afterwards
increased
to
ten
.
 
<EOS>
We
parted
at
the
garden
-
gate
in
a
most
affectionate
manner
,
and
Mr
Dick
did
not
go
into
the
house
until
my
aunt
had
driven
me
out
of
sight
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
who
was
perfectly
indifferent
to
public
opinion
,
drove
the
grey
pony
through
Dover
in
a
masterly
manner
;
sitting
high
and
stiff
like
a
state
coachman
,
keeping
a
steady
eye
upon
him
wherever
he
went
,
and
making
a
point
of
not
letting
him
have
his
own
way
in
any
respect
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
came
into
the
country
road
,
she
permitted
him
to
relax
a
little
,
however
;
and
looking
at
me
down
in
a
valley
of
cushion
by
her
side
,
asked
me
whether
I
was
happy
?
   
<EOS>
"
Very
happy
indeed
,
thank
you
,
aunt
,
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
much
gratified
;
and
both
her
hands
being
occupied
,
patted
me
on
the
head
with
her
whip
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
a
large
school
,
aunt
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
do
n't
know
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
are
going
to
Mr
Wickfield
's
first
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Does
he
keep
a
school
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Trot
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
keeps
an
office
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
asked
for
no
more
information
about
Mr
Wickfield
,
as
she
offered
none
,
and
we
conversed
on
other
subjects
until
we
came
to
Canterbury
,
where
,
as
it
was
market
-
day
,
my
aunt
had
a
great
opportunity
of
insinuating
the
grey
pony
among
carts
,
baskets
,
vegetables
,
and
huckster
's
goods
.
 
<EOS>
The
hair
-
breadth
turns
and
twists
we
made
,
drew
down
upon
us
a
variety
of
speeches
from
the
people
standing
about
,
which
were
not
always
complimentary
;
but
my
aunt
drove
on
with
perfect
indifference
,
and
I
dare
say
would
have
taken
her
own
way
with
as
much
coolness
through
an
enemy
's
country
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
we
stopped
before
a
very
old
house
bulging
out
over
the
road
;
a
house
with
long
low
lattice
-
windows
bulging
out
still
farther
,
and
beams
with
carved
heads
on
the
ends
bulging
out
too
,
so
that
I
fancied
the
whole
house
was
leaning
forward
,
trying
to
see
who
was
passing
on
the
narrow
pavement
below
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
quite
spotless
in
its
cleanliness
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
-
fashioned
brass
knocker
on
the
low
arched
door
,
ornamented
with
carved
garlands
of
fruit
and
flowers
,
twinkled
like
a
star
;
the
two
stone
steps
descending
to
the
door
were
as
white
as
if
they
had
been
covered
with
fair
linen
;
and
all
the
angles
and
corners
,
and
carvings
and
mouldings
,
and
quaint
little
panes
of
glass
,
and
quainter
little
windows
,
<EOS>
though
as
old
as
the
hills
,
were
as
pure
as
any
snow
that
ever
fell
upon
the
hills
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
pony
-
chaise
stopped
at
the
door
,
and
my
eyes
were
intent
upon
the
house
,
I
saw
a
cadaverous
face
appear
at
a
small
window
on
the
ground
floor
(
in
a
little
round
tower
that
formed
one
side
of
the
house
)
,
and
quickly
disappear
.
 
<EOS>
The
low
arched
door
then
opened
,
and
the
face
came
out
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
quite
as
cadaverous
as
it
had
looked
in
the
window
,
though
in
the
grain
of
it
there
was
that
tinge
of
red
which
is
sometimes
to
be
observed
in
the
skins
of
red
-
haired
people
.
 
<EOS>
It
belonged
to
a
red
-
haired
person
---
a
youth
of
fifteen
,
as
I
take
it
now
,
but
looking
much
older
---
whose
hair
was
cropped
as
close
as
the
closest
stubble
;
who
had
hardly
any
eyebrows
,
and
no
eyelashes
,
and
eyes
of
a
red
-
brown
,
so
unsheltered
and
unshaded
,
that
I
remember
wondering
how
he
went
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
high
-
shouldered
and
bony
;
dressed
in
decent
black
,
with
a
white
wisp
of
a
neckcloth
;
buttoned
up
to
the
throat
;
and
had
a
long
,
lank
,
skeleton
hand
,
which
particularly
attracted
my
attention
,
as
he
stood
at
the
pony
's
head
,
rubbing
his
chin
with
it
,
and
looking
up
at
us
in
the
chaise
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Mr
Wickfield
at
home
,
Uriah
Heep
?
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Wickfield
's
at
home
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Uriah
Heep
,
"
if
you
'll
please
to
walk
in
there
"
---
pointing
with
his
long
hand
to
the
room
he
meant
.
   
<EOS>
We
got
out
;
and
leaving
him
to
hold
the
pony
,
went
into
a
long
low
parlour
looking
towards
the
street
,
from
the
window
of
which
I
caught
a
glimpse
,
as
I
went
in
,
of
Uriah
Heep
breathing
into
the
pony
's
nostrils
,
and
immediately
covering
them
with
his
hand
,
as
if
he
were
putting
some
spell
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
Opposite
to
the
tall
old
chimney
-
piece
were
two
portraits
:
one
of
a
gentleman
with
grey
hair
(
though
not
by
any
means
an
old
man
)
and
black
eyebrows
,
who
was
looking
over
some
papers
tied
together
with
red
tape
;
the
other
,
of
a
lady
,
with
a
very
placid
and
sweet
expression
of
face
,
who
was
looking
at
me
.
   
<EOS>
I
believe
I
was
turning
about
in
search
of
Uriah
's
picture
,
when
,
a
door
at
the
farther
end
of
the
room
opening
,
a
gentleman
entered
,
at
sight
of
whom
I
turned
to
the
first
-
mentioned
portrait
again
,
to
make
quite
sure
that
it
had
not
come
out
of
its
frame
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
was
stationary
;
and
as
the
gentleman
advanced
into
the
light
,
I
saw
that
he
was
some
years
older
than
when
he
had
had
his
picture
painted
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Betsey
Trotwood
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
"
pray
walk
in
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
engaged
for
a
moment
,
but
you
'll
excuse
my
being
busy
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
my
motive
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
<EOS>
but
one
in
life
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Betsey
thanked
him
,
and
we
went
into
his
room
,
which
was
furnished
as
an
office
,
with
books
,
papers
,
tin
boxes
,
and
so
forth
.
 
<EOS>
It
looked
into
a
garden
,
and
had
an
iron
safe
let
into
the
wall
;
so
immediately
over
the
mantelshelf
,
that
I
wondered
,
as
I
sat
down
,
how
the
sweeps
got
round
it
when
they
swept
the
chimney
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Miss
Trotwood
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
;
for
I
soon
found
that
it
was
he
,
and
that
he
was
a
lawyer
,
and
steward
of
the
estates
of
a
rich
gentleman
of
the
county
;
"
what
wind
blows
you
here
?
 
<EOS>
Not
an
ill
wind
<EOS>
,
I
hope
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
come
for
any
law
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
come
for
anything
else
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
hair
was
quite
white
now
,
though
his
eyebrows
were
still
black
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
very
agreeable
face
,
and
,
I
thought
,
was
handsome
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
certain
richness
in
his
complexion
,
which
I
had
been
long
accustomed
,
under
Peggotty
's
tuition
,
to
connect
with
port
wine
;
and
I
fancied
it
was
in
his
voice
too
,
and
referred
his
growing
corpulency
to
the
same
cause
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
very
cleanly
dressed
,
in
a
blue
coat
,
striped
waistcoat
,
and
nankeen
trousers
;
and
his
fine
frilled
shirt
and
cambric
neckcloth
looked
unusually
soft
and
white
,
reminding
my
strolling
fancy
<EOS>
(
I
call
to
mind
)
of
the
plumage
on
the
breast
of
a
swan
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
my
nephew
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Was
n't
aware
you
had
one
,
Miss
Trotwood
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
grand
-
nephew
,
that
is
to
say
,
"
observed
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Was
n't
aware
you
had
a
grand
-
nephew
,
I
give
you
my
word
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
adopted
him
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
with
a
wave
of
her
hand
,
importing
that
his
knowledge
and
his
ignorance
were
all
one
to
her
,
"
and
I
have
brought
him
here
,
to
put
to
a
school
where
he
may
be
thoroughly
well
taught
,
and
well
treated
.
 
<EOS>
Now
tell
me
where
that
school
is
,
and
what
it
is
,
and
all
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Before
I
can
advise
you
properly
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
---
"
the
old
question
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
What
's
your
motive
in
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Deuce
take
the
man
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Always
fishing
for
motives
,
when
they
're
on
the
surface
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
to
make
the
child
happy
and
useful
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
a
mixed
motive
,
I
think
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
,
shaking
his
head
and
smiling
incredulously
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
mixed
fiddlestick
,
"
returned
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
claim
to
have
one
plain
motive
in
all
you
do
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
suppose
,
I
hope
,
that
you
are
the
only
plain
dealer
in
the
world
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
but
I
have
only
one
motive
in
life
,
Miss
Trotwood
,
"
he
rejoined
,
smiling
.
 
<EOS>
"
Other
people
have
dozens
,
scores
,
hundreds
.
<EOS>
I
have
only
one
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
the
difference
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
that
's
beside
the
question
.
 
<EOS>
The
best
school
?
 
<EOS>
Whatever
the
motive
,
you
want
the
best
?
"
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
nodded
assent
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
the
best
we
have
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
,
<EOS>
considering
,
"
your
nephew
could
n't
board
just
now
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
he
could
board
somewhere
else
,
I
suppose
?
"
suggested
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Wickfield
thought
I
could
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
little
discussion
,
he
proposed
to
take
my
aunt
to
the
school
,
that
she
might
see
it
and
judge
for
herself
;
also
,
to
take
her
,
with
the
same
object
,
to
two
or
three
houses
where
he
thought
I
could
be
boarded
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
embracing
the
proposal
,
we
were
all
three
going
out
together
,
when
he
stopped
and
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
Our
little
friend
here
might
have
some
motive
,
perhaps
,
for
objecting
to
the
arrangements
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
we
had
better
leave
him
behind
?
"
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
seemed
disposed
to
contest
the
point
;
but
to
facilitate
matters
<EOS>
I
said
I
would
gladly
remain
behind
,
if
they
pleased
;
and
returned
into
Mr
Wickfield
's
office
,
where
I
sat
down
again
,
in
the
chair
I
had
first
occupied
,
to
await
their
return
.
   
<EOS>
It
so
happened
that
this
chair
was
opposite
a
narrow
passage
,
which
ended
in
the
little
circular
room
where
I
had
seen
Uriah
Heep
's
pale
face
looking
out
of
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
Uriah
,
having
taken
the
pony
to
a
neighbouring
stable
,
was
at
work
at
a
desk
in
this
room
,
which
had
a
brass
frame
on
the
top
to
hang
paper
upon
,
and
on
which
the
writing
he
was
making
a
copy
of
was
then
hanging
.
 
<EOS>
Though
his
face
was
towards
me
,
I
thought
,
for
some
time
,
the
writing
being
between
us
,
that
he
could
not
see
me
;
but
looking
that
way
more
attentively
,
it
made
me
uncomfortable
to
observe
that
,
every
now
and
then
,
his
sleepless
eyes
would
come
below
the
writing
,
like
two
red
suns
,
and
stealthily
stare
at
me
for
I
dare
say
a
whole
minute
at
a
time
,
during
which
his
pen
went
,
or
pretended
to
go
,
as
cleverly
as
ever
.
 
<EOS>
I
made
several
attempts
to
get
out
of
their
way
---
such
as
standing
on
a
chair
to
look
at
a
map
on
the
other
side
of
the
room
,
and
poring
over
the
columns
of
a
Kentish
newspaper
---
but
they
always
attracted
me
back
again
;
and
whenever
I
looked
towards
those
two
red
suns
,
I
was
sure
to
find
them
,
either
just
rising
or
just
setting
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
,
much
to
my
relief
,
my
aunt
and
Mr
Wickfield
came
back
,
after
a
pretty
long
absence
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
not
so
successful
as
I
could
have
wished
;
for
though
the
advantages
of
the
school
were
undeniable
,
my
aunt
had
not
approved
of
any
of
the
boarding
-
houses
proposed
for
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
unfortunate
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
to
do
,
Trot
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
does
happen
unfortunately
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
'll
tell
you
what
you
can
do
,
Miss
Trotwood
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Leave
your
nephew
here
,
for
the
present
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
a
quiet
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
He
wo
n't
disturb
me
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
capital
house
for
study
.
 
<EOS>
As
quiet
as
a
monastery
,
and
almost
as
roomy
.
 
<EOS>
Leave
him
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
evidently
liked
the
offer
,
though
she
was
delicate
of
accepting
it
.
 
<EOS>
So
did
I.
"
Come
,
Miss
Trotwood
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
way
out
of
the
difficulty
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
only
a
temporary
arrangement
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
do
n't
act
well
,
or
do
n't
quite
accord
with
our
mutual
convenience
,
he
can
easily
go
to
the
right
-
about
.
 
<EOS>
There
will
be
time
to
find
some
better
place
for
him
in
the
meanwhile
.
 
<EOS>
You
had
better
determine
to
leave
him
here
for
the
present
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
much
obliged
to
you
,
"
said
my
aunt
;
"
<EOS>
and
so
is
he
,
I
see
;
<EOS>
but
---
"
   
"
Come
!
<EOS>
I
know
what
you
mean
,
"
cried
Mr
Wickfield
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
not
be
oppressed
by
the
receipt
of
favours
,
Miss
Trotwood
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
pay
for
him
,
if
you
like
.
 
<EOS>
We
wo
n't
be
hard
about
terms
,
but
you
shall
pay
if
you
will
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
On
that
understanding
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
though
it
does
n't
lessen
the
real
obligation
,
I
shall
be
very
glad
to
leave
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
come
and
see
my
little
housekeeper
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
.
   
<EOS>
We
accordingly
went
up
a
wonderful
old
staircase
;
with
a
balustrade
so
broad
that
we
might
have
gone
up
that
,
almost
as
easily
;
and
into
a
shady
old
drawing
-
room
,
lighted
by
some
three
or
four
of
the
quaint
windows
I
had
looked
up
at
from
the
street
:
which
had
old
oak
seats
in
them
,
that
seemed
to
have
come
of
the
same
trees
as
the
shining
oak
floor
,
and
the
great
beams
in
the
ceiling
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
prettily
furnished
room
,
with
a
piano
and
some
lively
furniture
in
red
and
green
,
and
some
flowers
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
be
all
old
nooks
and
corners
;
and
in
every
nook
and
corner
there
was
some
queer
little
table
,
or
cupboard
,
or
bookcase
,
or
seat
,
or
something
or
other
,
that
made
me
think
there
was
not
such
another
good
corner
in
the
room
;
until
I
looked
at
the
next
one
,
and
found
it
equal
to
it
,
if
not
better
.
 
<EOS>
On
everything
there
was
the
same
air
of
retirement
and
cleanliness
that
marked
the
house
outside
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Wickfield
tapped
at
a
door
in
a
corner
of
the
panelled
wall
,
and
a
girl
of
about
my
own
age
came
quickly
out
and
kissed
him
.
 
<EOS>
On
her
face
,
I
saw
immediately
the
placid
and
sweet
expression
of
the
lady
whose
picture
had
looked
at
me
downstairs
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
my
imagination
as
if
the
portrait
had
grown
womanly
,
and
the
original
remained
a
child
.
 
<EOS>
Although
her
face
was
quite
bright
and
happy
,
there
was
a
tranquillity
about
it
,
and
about
her
---
a
quiet
,
good
,
calm
spirit
---
that
I
never
have
forgotten
;
that
I
shall
never
forget
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
his
little
housekeeper
,
his
daughter
Agnes
,
Mr
Wickfield
said
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
heard
how
he
said
it
,
and
saw
how
he
held
her
hand
,
I
guessed
what
the
one
motive
of
his
life
was
.
   
<EOS>
She
had
a
little
basket
-
trifle
hanging
at
her
side
,
with
keys
in
it
;
and
she
looked
as
staid
and
as
discreet
a
housekeeper
as
the
old
house
could
have
.
 
<EOS>
She
listened
to
her
father
as
he
told
her
about
me
,
with
a
pleasant
face
;
and
when
he
had
concluded
,
proposed
to
my
aunt
that
we
should
go
upstairs
and
see
my
room
.
 
<EOS>
We
all
went
together
,
she
before
us
:
and
a
glorious
old
room
it
was
,
with
more
oak
beams
,
and
diamond
panes
;
and
the
broad
balustrade
going
all
the
way
up
to
it
.
   
<EOS>
I
can
not
call
to
mind
where
or
when
,
in
my
childhood
,
I
had
seen
a
stained
glass
window
in
a
church
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
do
I
recollect
its
subject
.
<EOS>
But
I
know
that
when
I
saw
her
turn
round
,
in
the
grave
light
of
the
old
staircase
,
and
wait
for
us
,
above
,
I
thought
of
that
window
;
and
I
associated
something
of
its
tranquil
brightness
with
Agnes
Wickfield
ever
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
was
as
happy
as
I
was
,
in
the
arrangement
made
for
me
;
and
we
went
down
to
the
drawing
-
room
again
,
well
pleased
and
gratified
.
<EOS>
As
she
would
not
hear
of
staying
to
dinner
,
lest
she
should
by
any
chance
fail
to
arrive
at
home
with
the
grey
pony
before
dark
;
and
as
I
apprehend
Mr
Wickfield
knew
her
too
well
to
argue
any
point
with
her
;
some
lunch
was
provided
for
her
there
,
and
Agnes
went
back
to
her
governess
,
and
Mr
Wickfield
to
his
office
.
 
<EOS>
So
we
were
left
to
take
leave
of
one
another
without
any
restraint
.
   
<EOS>
She
told
me
that
everything
would
be
arranged
for
me
by
Mr
Wickfield
,
and
that
I
should
want
for
nothing
,
and
gave
me
the
kindest
words
and
the
best
advice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Trot
,
"
said
my
aunt
in
conclusion
,
"
be
a
credit
to
yourself
,
to
me
,
and
Mr
Dick
,
and
Heaven
be
with
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
greatly
overcome
,
and
could
only
thank
her
,
again
and
again
,
and
send
my
love
to
Mr
Dick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
be
mean
in
anything
;
never
be
false
;
never
be
cruel
.
 
<EOS>
Avoid
those
three
vices
,
Trot
,
and
I
can
always
be
hopeful
of
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
promised
,
as
well
as
<EOS>
I
could
,
that
I
would
not
abuse
her
kindness
or
forget
her
admonition
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
pony
's
at
the
door
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
and
I
am
off
!
<EOS>
Stay
here
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
these
words
she
embraced
me
hastily
,
and
went
out
of
the
room
,
shutting
the
door
after
her
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
I
was
startled
by
so
abrupt
a
departure
,
and
almost
feared
I
had
displeased
her
;
but
when
I
looked
into
the
street
,
and
saw
how
dejectedly
she
got
into
the
chaise
,
and
drove
away
without
looking
up
,
I
understood
her
better
and
did
not
do
her
that
injustice
.
   
<EOS>
By
five
o'clock
,
which
was
Mr
Wickfield
's
dinner
-
hour
,
I
had
mustered
up
my
spirits
again
,
and
was
ready
for
my
knife
and
fork
.
<EOS>
The
cloth
was
only
laid
for
us
two
;
but
Agnes
was
waiting
in
the
drawing
-
room
before
dinner
,
went
down
with
her
father
,
and
sat
opposite
to
him
at
table
.
 
<EOS>
I
doubted
whether
he
could
have
dined
without
her
.
   
<EOS>
We
did
not
stay
there
,
after
dinner
,
but
came
upstairs
into
the
drawing
-
room
again
:
in
one
snug
corner
of
which
,
Agnes
set
glasses
for
her
father
,
and
a
decanter
of
port
wine
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
he
would
have
missed
its
usual
flavour
,
if
it
had
been
put
there
for
him
by
any
other
hands
.
   
<EOS>
There
he
sat
,
taking
his
wine
,
and
taking
a
good
deal
of
it
,
for
two
hours
;
while
Agnes
played
on
the
piano
,
worked
,
and
talked
to
him
and
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
,
for
the
most
part
,
gay
and
cheerful
with
us
;
but
sometimes
his
eyes
rested
on
her
,
and
he
fell
into
a
brooding
state
,
and
was
silent
.
 
<EOS>
She
always
observed
this
quickly
,
I
thought
,
and
always
roused
him
with
a
question
or
caress
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
came
out
of
his
meditation
,
and
drank
more
wine
.
   
<EOS>
Agnes
made
the
tea
,
and
presided
over
it
;
and
the
time
passed
away
after
it
,
as
after
dinner
,
until
she
went
to
bed
;
when
her
father
took
her
in
his
arms
and
kissed
her
,
and
,
she
being
gone
,
ordered
candles
in
his
office
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
went
to
bed
too
.
   
<EOS>
But
in
the
course
of
the
evening
I
had
rambled
down
to
the
door
,
and
a
little
way
along
the
street
,
that
I
might
have
another
peep
at
the
old
houses
,
and
the
grey
Cathedral
;
and
might
think
of
my
coming
through
that
old
city
on
my
journey
,
and
of
my
passing
the
very
house
I
lived
in
,
without
knowing
it
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
came
back
,
I
saw
Uriah
Heep
shutting
up
the
office
;
and
feeling
friendly
towards
everybody
,
went
in
and
spoke
to
him
,
and
at
parting
,
gave
him
my
hand
.
 
<EOS>
But
oh
,
what
a
clammy
hand
<EOS>
his
was
!
<EOS>
as
ghostly
to
the
touch
as
to
the
sight
!
 
<EOS>
I
rubbed
mine
afterwards
,
to
warm
it
,
AND
TO
RUB
HIS
OFF
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
such
an
uncomfortable
hand
,
that
,
when
I
went
to
my
room
,
it
was
still
cold
and
wet
upon
my
memory
.
 
<EOS>
Leaning
out
of
the
window
,
and
seeing
one
of
the
faces
on
the
beam
-
ends
looking
at
me
sideways
,
I
fancied
it
was
Uriah
Heep
got
up
there
somehow
,
and
shut
him
out
in
a
hurry
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
16
.
<EOS>
I
am
a
new
boy
in
more
senses
than
one
 
Next
morning
,
after
breakfast
,
I
entered
on
school
life
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
,
accompanied
by
Mr
Wickfield
,
to
the
scene
of
my
future
studies
---
a
grave
building
in
a
courtyard
,
with
a
learned
air
about
it
that
seemed
very
well
suited
to
the
stray
rooks
and
jackdaws
who
came
down
from
the
Cathedral
towers
to
walk
with
a
clerkly
bearing
on
the
grass
-
plot
---
and
was
introduced
to
my
new
master
,
Doctor
Strong
.
   
<EOS>
Doctor
Strong
looked
almost
as
rusty
,
to
my
thinking
,
as
the
tall
iron
rails
and
gates
outside
the
house
;
and
almost
as
stiff
and
heavy
as
the
great
stone
urns
that
flanked
them
,
and
were
set
up
,
on
the
top
of
the
red
-
brick
wall
,
at
regular
distances
<EOS>
all
round
the
court
,
like
sublimated
skittles
,
for
Time
to
play
at
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
in
his
library
(
I
mean
Doctor
Strong
was
)
,
with
his
clothes
not
particularly
well
brushed
,
and
his
hair
not
particularly
well
combed
;
his
knee
-
smalls
unbraced
;
his
long
black
gaiters
unbuttoned
;
and
his
shoes
yawning
like
two
caverns
on
the
hearth
-
rug
.
 
<EOS>
Turning
upon
me
a
lustreless
eye
,
that
reminded
me
of
a
long
-
forgotten
blind
old
horse
who
once
used
to
crop
the
grass
,
and
tumble
over
the
graves
,
in
Blunderstone
churchyard
,
he
said
he
was
glad
to
see
me
:
<EOS>
and
then
he
gave
me
his
hand
;
which
I
did
n't
know
what
to
do
with
,
as
it
did
nothing
for
itself
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
sitting
at
work
,
not
far
from
Doctor
Strong
,
was
a
very
pretty
young
lady
---
whom
he
called
Annie
,
and
who
was
his
daughter
<EOS>
,
I
supposed
---
<EOS>
who
got
me
out
of
my
difficulty
by
kneeling
down
to
put
Doctor
Strong
's
shoes
on
,
and
button
his
gaiters
,
which
she
did
with
great
cheerfulness
and
quickness
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
finished
,
and
we
were
going
out
to
the
schoolroom
,
I
was
much
surprised
to
hear
Mr
Wickfield
,
in
bidding
her
good
morning
,
address
her
as
"
Mrs
Strong
"
;
and
I
was
wondering
could
she
be
Doctor
Strong
's
son
's
wife
,
or
could
she
be
Mrs
Doctor
Strong
,
when
Doctor
Strong
himself
unconsciously
enlightened
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
By
the
by
,
Wickfield
,
"
he
said
,
stopping
in
a
passage
with
his
hand
on
my
shoulder
;
"
you
have
not
found
any
suitable
provision
for
my
wife
's
cousin
yet
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
 
Not
yet
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
wish
it
done
as
soon
as
it
can
be
done
,
Wickfield
,
"
said
Doctor
Strong
,
"
for
<EOS>
Jack
Maldon
is
needy
,
and
idle
;
and
of
those
two
bad
things
,
worse
things
sometimes
come
.
 
<EOS>
What
does
Doctor
Watts
say
,
"
he
added
,
looking
at
me
,
and
moving
his
head
to
the
time
of
his
quotation
,
"
"
Satan
finds
some
mischief
still
,
for
idle
hands
to
do
.
"
<EOS>
"
   
"
Egad
,
Doctor
,
"
returned
Mr
Wickfield
,
"
if
Doctor
Watts
knew
mankind
,
he
might
have
written
,
with
as
much
truth
,
"
Satan
finds
some
mischief
still
,
for
busy
hands
to
do
.
<EOS>
"
The
busy
people
achieve
their
full
share
of
mischief
in
the
world
,
you
may
rely
upon
it
.
<EOS>
What
have
the
people
been
about
,
who
have
been
the
busiest
in
getting
money
,
and
in
getting
power
,
this
century
or
two
?
 
<EOS>
No
mischief
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Jack
Maldon
will
never
be
very
busy
in
getting
either
,
I
expect
,
"
said
Doctor
Strong
,
rubbing
his
chin
thoughtfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
not
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
;
"
and
you
bring
me
back
to
the
question
,
with
an
apology
for
digressing
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
I
have
not
been
able
to
dispose
of
Mr
Jack
Maldon
yet
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
,
"
he
said
this
with
some
hesitation
,
"
I
penetrate
your
motive
,
and
it
makes
the
thing
more
difficult
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
motive
,
"
returned
Doctor
Strong
,
"
is
to
make
some
suitable
provision
for
a
cousin
,
and
an
old
playfellow
,
of
Annie
's
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
know
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
;
"
at
home
or
abroad
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
"
replied
the
Doctor
,
apparently
wondering
why
he
emphasized
those
words
so
much
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
home
or
abroad
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
own
expression
<EOS>
,
you
know
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
.
 
<EOS>
"
Or
abroad
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Surely
,
"
the
Doctor
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
Surely
.
 
<EOS>
One
or
other
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
One
or
other
?
 
<EOS>
Have
you
no
choice
?
"
asked
Mr
Wickfield
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
returned
the
Doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
?
"
with
astonishment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
the
least
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
motive
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
,
"
for
meaning
abroad
,
and
not
at
home
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
returned
the
Doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
bound
to
believe
you
,
and
of
course
I
do
believe
you
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
might
have
simplified
my
office
very
much
,
if
I
had
known
it
before
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
confess
I
entertained
another
impression
.
"
   
<EOS>
Doctor
Strong
regarded
him
with
a
puzzled
and
doubting
look
,
which
almost
immediately
subsided
into
a
smile
that
gave
me
great
encouragement
;
for
it
was
full
of
amiability
and
sweetness
,
and
there
was
a
simplicity
in
it
,
and
indeed
in
his
whole
manner
,
when
the
studious
,
pondering
frost
upon
it
was
got
through
,
very
attractive
and
hopeful
to
a
young
scholar
like
me
.
 
<EOS>
Repeating
"
no
"
,
and
"
not
the
least
"
,
and
other
short
assurances
to
the
same
purport
,
Doctor
Strong
jogged
on
before
us
,
at
a
queer
,
uneven
pace
;
and
we
followed
:
<EOS>
Mr
Wickfield
,
looking
grave
,
I
observed
,
and
shaking
his
head
to
himself
,
without
knowing
that
I
saw
him
.
   
<EOS>
The
schoolroom
was
a
pretty
large
hall
,
on
the
quietest
side
of
the
house
,
confronted
by
the
stately
stare
of
some
half
-
dozen
of
the
great
urns
,
and
commanding
a
peep
of
an
old
secluded
garden
belonging
to
the
Doctor
,
where
the
peaches
were
ripening
on
the
sunny
south
wall
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
two
great
aloes
,
in
tubs
,
on
the
turf
outside
the
windows
;
the
broad
hard
leaves
of
which
plant
(
looking
as
if
they
were
made
of
painted
tin
)
<EOS>
have
ever
since
,
by
association
,
been
symbolical
to
me
of
silence
and
retirement
.
<EOS>
About
five
-
and
-
twenty
boys
were
studiously
engaged
at
their
books
when
we
went
in
,
but
they
rose
to
give
the
Doctor
good
morning
,
and
remained
standing
when
they
saw
Mr
Wickfield
and
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
new
boy
,
young
gentlemen
,
"
said
the
Doctor
;
"
Trotwood
Copperfield
.
"
   
<EOS>
One
Adams
,
who
was
the
head
-
boy
,
then
stepped
out
of
his
place
and
welcomed
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
like
a
young
clergyman
,
in
his
white
cravat
,
but
he
was
very
affable
and
good
-
humoured
;
and
he
showed
me
my
place
,
and
presented
me
to
the
masters
,
in
a
gentlemanly
way
that
would
have
put
me
at
my
ease
,
if
anything
could
.
   
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
me
so
long
,
however
,
since
I
had
been
among
such
boys
,
or
among
any
companions
of
my
own
age
,
except
Mick
Walker
and
Mealy
Potatoes
,
that
I
felt
as
strange
as
ever
<EOS>
I
have
done
in
my
life
.
<EOS>
I
was
so
conscious
of
having
passed
through
scenes
of
which
they
could
have
no
knowledge
,
and
of
having
acquired
experiences
foreign
to
my
age
,
appearance
,
and
condition
as
one
of
them
,
that
I
half
believed
it
was
an
imposture
to
come
there
as
an
ordinary
little
schoolboy
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
become
,
in
the
Murdstone
and
Grinby
time
,
<EOS>
however
short
or
long
it
may
have
been
,
so
unused
to
the
sports
and
games
of
boys
<EOS>
,
that
I
knew
I
was
awkward
and
inexperienced
in
the
commonest
things
belonging
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
I
had
learnt
,
had
so
slipped
away
from
me
in
the
sordid
cares
of
my
life
from
day
to
night
,
that
now
,
when
I
was
examined
about
what
I
knew
,
I
knew
nothing
,
and
was
put
into
the
lowest
form
of
the
school
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
troubled
as
I
was
,
by
my
want
of
boyish
skill
,
and
of
book
-
learning
too
,
I
was
made
infinitely
more
uncomfortable
by
the
consideration
,
that
,
in
what
I
did
know
,
I
was
much
farther
removed
from
my
companions
than
in
what
I
did
not
.
 
<EOS>
My
mind
ran
upon
what
they
would
think
,
if
they
knew
of
my
familiar
acquaintance
with
the
King
's
Bench
Prison
?
 
<EOS>
Was
there
anything
about
me
which
would
reveal
my
proceedings
in
connexion
with
the
Micawber
family
---
all
those
pawnings
,
and
sellings
,
and
suppers
---
in
spite
of
myself
?
<EOS>
Suppose
some
of
the
boys
had
seen
me
coming
through
Canterbury
,
wayworn
and
ragged
,
and
should
find
me
out
?
 
<EOS>
What
would
they
say
,
who
made
so
light
of
money
,
if
they
could
know
how
I
had
scraped
my
halfpence
together
,
for
the
purchase
of
my
daily
saveloy
and
beer
,
or
<EOS>
my
slices
of
pudding
?
 
<EOS>
How
would
it
affect
them
,
who
were
so
innocent
of
London
life
,
and
London
streets
,
to
discover
how
knowing
I
was
(
and
was
ashamed
to
be
)
in
some
of
the
meanest
phases
of
both
?
 
<EOS>
All
this
ran
in
my
head
so
much
,
on
that
first
day
at
Doctor
Strong
's
,
that
I
felt
distrustful
of
my
slightest
look
and
gesture
;
shrunk
within
myself
whensoever
I
was
approached
by
one
of
my
new
schoolfellows
;
and
hurried
off
the
minute
school
was
over
,
afraid
of
committing
myself
in
my
response
to
any
friendly
notice
or
advance
.
   
<EOS>
But
there
was
such
an
influence
in
Mr
Wickfield
's
old
house
,
that
when
I
knocked
at
it
,
with
my
new
school
-
books
under
my
arm
,
I
began
to
feel
my
uneasiness
softening
away
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
went
up
to
my
airy
old
room
,
the
grave
shadow
of
the
staircase
seemed
to
fall
upon
my
doubts
and
fears
,
and
to
make
the
past
more
indistinct
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
there
,
sturdily
conning
my
books
,
until
dinner
-
time
<EOS>
(
we
were
out
of
school
for
good
at
three
)
;
and
went
down
,
hopeful
of
becoming
a
passable
sort
of
boy
yet
.
   
<EOS>
Agnes
was
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
waiting
for
her
father
,
who
was
detained
by
someone
in
his
office
.
 
<EOS>
She
met
me
with
her
pleasant
smile
,
and
asked
me
how
I
liked
the
school
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
her
I
should
like
it
very
much
,
I
hoped
;
but
I
was
a
little
strange
to
it
at
first
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
never
been
to
school
,
"
I
said
,
"
have
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
!
 
<EOS>
Every
day
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
,
but
you
mean
here
,
at
your
own
home
?
"
   
"
Papa
could
n't
spare
me
to
go
anywhere
else
,
"
she
answered
,
smiling
and
shaking
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
His
housekeeper
must
be
in
his
house
,
you
know
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
very
fond
of
you
,
I
am
sure
,
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
She
nodded
"
Yes
,
"
and
went
to
the
door
to
listen
for
his
coming
up
,
that
she
might
meet
him
on
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
he
was
not
there
,
she
came
back
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mama
has
been
dead
ever
since
I
was
born
,
"
she
said
,
in
her
quiet
way
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
only
know
her
picture
,
downstairs
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
you
looking
at
it
yesterday
.
 
<EOS>
Did
you
think
whose
it
was
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
told
her
yes
,
because
it
was
so
like
herself
.
   
<EOS>
"
Papa
says
so
,
too
,
"
said
Agnes
,
pleased
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hark
!
 
<EOS>
That
's
papa
now
!
"
   
<EOS>
Her
bright
calm
face
lighted
up
with
pleasure
as
she
went
to
meet
him
,
and
as
they
came
in
,
hand
in
hand
.
 
<EOS>
He
greeted
me
cordially
;
and
told
me
I
should
certainly
be
happy
under
Doctor
Strong
,
who
was
one
of
the
gentlest
of
men
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
may
be
some
,
perhaps
---
I
do
n't
know
that
there
are
---
who
abuse
his
kindness
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
be
one
of
those
,
Trotwood
,
in
anything
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
the
least
suspicious
of
mankind
;
and
whether
that
's
a
merit
,
or
whether
it
's
a
blemish
,
it
deserves
consideration
in
all
dealings
with
the
Doctor
,
great
or
small
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
spoke
,
I
thought
,
as
if
he
were
weary
,
or
dissatisfied
with
something
;
but
I
did
not
pursue
the
question
in
my
mind
,
for
dinner
was
just
then
announced
,
and
we
went
down
and
took
the
same
seats
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
We
had
scarcely
done
so
,
when
Uriah
Heep
put
in
his
red
head
and
his
lank
hand
at
the
door
,
and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Here
's
Mr
Maldon
begs
the
favour
of
a
word
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
<EOS>
but
this
moment
quit
of
Mr
Maldon
,
"
said
his
master
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
returned
Uriah
;
"
but
Mr
Maldon
has
come
back
,
and
he
begs
the
favour
of
a
word
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
held
the
door
open
with
his
hand
,
Uriah
looked
at
me
,
and
looked
at
Agnes
,
and
looked
at
the
dishes
,
and
looked
at
the
plates
,
and
looked
at
every
object
in
the
room
,
I
thought
,
---
yet
seemed
to
look
at
nothing
;
he
made
such
an
appearance
all
the
while
of
keeping
his
red
eyes
dutifully
on
his
master
.
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
only
to
say
,
on
reflection
,
"
observed
a
voice
behind
Uriah
,
as
Uriah
's
head
was
pushed
away
,
and
the
speaker
's
substituted
---
"
pray
excuse
me
for
this
intrusion
---
that
as
it
seems
I
have
no
choice
in
the
matter
,
the
sooner
I
go
abroad
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
My
cousin
Annie
did
say
,
when
we
talked
of
it
,
that
she
liked
to
have
her
friends
within
reach
rather
than
to
have
them
banished
,
and
the
old
Doctor
---
"
   
"
Doctor
Strong
,
was
that
?
"
<EOS>
Mr
Wickfield
interposed
,
gravely
.
   
<EOS>
"
Doctor
Strong
,
of
course
,
"
returned
the
other
;
"
I
call
him
the
old
Doctor
;
it
's
all
the
same
,
you
know
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
returned
Mr
Wickfield
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Doctor
Strong
,
"
said
the
other
---
"
Doctor
Strong
was
of
the
same
mind
,
I
believed
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
it
appears
from
the
course
you
take
with
me
he
has
changed
his
mind
,
why
there
's
no
more
to
be
said
,
except
that
the
sooner
I
am
off
,
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
,
I
thought
I
'd
come
back
and
say
,
that
the
sooner
I
am
off
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
When
a
plunge
is
to
be
made
into
the
water
,
it
's
of
no
use
lingering
on
the
bank
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
shall
be
as
little
lingering
as
possible
,
in
your
case
,
Mr
Maldon
,
you
may
depend
upon
it
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
,
"
said
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
Much
obliged
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
to
look
a
gift
-
horse
in
the
mouth
,
which
is
not
a
gracious
thing
to
do
;
otherwise
,
I
dare
say
,
my
cousin
Annie
could
easily
arrange
it
in
her
own
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
Annie
would
only
have
to
say
to
the
old
Doctor
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Meaning
that
Mrs
Strong
would
only
have
to
say
to
her
husband
<EOS>
---
do
I
follow
you
?
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quite
so
,
"
returned
the
other
,
"
---
would
only
have
to
say
,
that
she
wanted
such
and
such
a
thing
to
be
so
and
so
;
and
it
would
be
so
and
so
,
as
a
matter
of
course
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
why
as
a
matter
of
course
,
Mr
Maldon
?
"
asked
Mr
Wickfield
,
sedately
eating
his
dinner
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
,
because
Annie
's
a
charming
young
girl
,
and
the
old
Doctor
---
Doctor
Strong
,
I
mean
---
is
not
quite
a
charming
young
boy
,
"
said
Mr
Jack
Maldon
,
laughing
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
offence
to
anybody
,
Mr
Wickfield
.
<EOS>
I
only
mean
that
I
suppose
some
compensation
is
fair
and
reasonable
in
that
sort
of
marriage
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Compensation
to
the
lady
,
sir
?
"
asked
Mr
Wickfield
gravely
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
the
lady
,
sir
,
"
Mr
Jack
Maldon
answered
,
laughing
.
 
<EOS>
But
appearing
to
remark
that
Mr
Wickfield
went
on
with
his
dinner
in
the
same
sedate
,
immovable
manner
,
and
that
there
was
no
hope
of
making
him
relax
a
muscle
of
his
face
,
he
added
:
"
However
,
I
have
said
what
I
came
to
say
,
and
,
with
another
apology
for
this
intrusion
,
I
may
take
myself
off
.
 
<EOS>
Of
course
I
shall
observe
your
directions
,
in
considering
the
matter
as
one
to
be
arranged
between
you
and
me
solely
,
and
not
to
be
referred
to
,
up
at
the
Doctor
's
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
dined
?
"
asked
Mr
Wickfield
,
with
a
motion
of
his
hand
towards
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
to
dine
,
"
said
Mr
Maldon
,
"
with
my
cousin
Annie
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Wickfield
,
without
rising
,
looked
after
him
thoughtfully
as
he
went
out
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
rather
a
shallow
sort
of
young
gentleman
,
I
thought
,
with
a
handsome
face
,
a
rapid
utterance
,
and
a
confident
,
bold
air
.
 
<EOS>
And
this
was
the
first
I
ever
saw
of
Mr
Jack
Maldon
;
whom
I
had
not
expected
to
see
so
soon
,
when
I
heard
the
Doctor
speak
of
him
that
morning
.
   
<EOS>
When
we
had
dined
,
we
went
upstairs
again
,
where
everything
went
on
exactly
as
on
the
previous
day
.
 
<EOS>
Agnes
set
the
glasses
and
decanters
in
the
same
corner
,
and
Mr
Wickfield
sat
down
to
drink
,
and
drank
a
good
deal
.
 
<EOS>
Agnes
played
the
piano
to
him
,
sat
by
him
,
and
worked
and
talked
,
and
played
some
games
at
dominoes
with
me
.
<EOS>
In
good
time
she
made
tea
;
and
afterwards
,
when
I
brought
down
my
books
,
looked
into
them
,
and
showed
me
what
she
knew
of
them
(
which
was
no
slight
matter
,
though
she
said
it
was
)
,
and
what
was
the
best
way
to
learn
and
understand
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
her
,
with
her
modest
,
orderly
,
placid
manner
,
and
I
hear
her
beautiful
calm
voice
,
as
I
write
these
words
.
 
<EOS>
The
influence
for
all
good
,
which
she
came
to
exercise
over
me
at
a
later
time
,
begins
already
to
descend
upon
my
breast
.
 
<EOS>
I
love
little
Em'ly
,
and
I
do
n't
love
Agnes
---
<EOS>
no
,
not
at
all
in
that
way
<EOS>
---
but
I
feel
that
there
are
goodness
,
peace
,
and
truth
,
wherever
Agnes
is
;
and
that
the
soft
light
of
the
coloured
window
in
the
church
,
seen
long
ago
,
falls
on
her
always
,
and
on
me
when
I
am
near
her
,
and
on
everything
around
.
   
<EOS>
The
time
having
come
for
her
withdrawal
for
the
night
,
and
she
having
left
us
,
I
gave
Mr
Wickfield
my
hand
,
preparatory
to
going
away
myself
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
checked
me
and
said
:
"
Should
you
like
to
stay
with
us
,
Trotwood
,
or
to
go
elsewhere
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
stay
,
"
I
answered
,
quickly
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
sure
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
may
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
it
's
but
<EOS>
a
dull
life
that
we
lead
here
<EOS>
,
boy
,
I
am
afraid
,
"
he
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
more
dull
for
me
than
Agnes
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Not
dull
at
all
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Than
Agnes
,
"
he
repeated
,
walking
slowly
to
the
great
chimney
-
piece
,
and
leaning
against
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Than
Agnes
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
drank
wine
that
evening
<EOS>
(
or
I
fancied
it
)
,
until
his
eyes
were
bloodshot
.
 
<EOS>
Not
that
I
could
see
them
now
,
for
they
were
cast
down
,
and
shaded
by
his
hand
;
but
I
had
noticed
them
a
little
while
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
I
wonder
,
"
he
muttered
,
"
whether
my
Agnes
tires
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
When
should
I
ever
tire
of
her
!
 
<EOS>
But
that
's
different
<EOS>
,
that
's
quite
different
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
musing
,
not
speaking
to
me
;
so
I
remained
quiet
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
dull
old
house
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
a
monotonous
life
;
but
I
must
have
her
near
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
keep
her
near
me
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
thought
that
I
may
die
and
leave
my
darling
,
or
that
my
darling
may
die
and
leave
me
,
comes
like
a
spectre
,
to
distress
my
happiest
hours
,
and
is
only
to
be
drowned
in
---
"
   
<EOS>
He
did
not
supply
the
word
;
but
pacing
slowly
to
the
place
where
he
had
sat
,
and
mechanically
going
through
the
action
of
pouring
wine
from
the
empty
decanter
,
set
it
down
and
paced
back
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
it
is
miserable
to
bear
,
when
she
is
here
,
"
he
said
,
"
what
would
it
be
,
and
she
away
?
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
try
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
leaned
against
the
chimney
-
piece
,
brooding
so
long
that
I
could
not
decide
whether
to
run
the
risk
of
disturbing
him
by
going
,
or
to
remain
quietly
where
I
was
,
until
he
should
come
out
of
his
reverie
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
aroused
himself
,
and
looked
about
the
room
until
his
eyes
encountered
mine
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
with
us
,
Trotwood
,
eh
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
in
his
usual
manner
,
and
as
if
he
were
answering
something
I
had
just
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
of
it
.
<EOS>
You
are
company
to
us
both
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
wholesome
to
have
you
here
.
<EOS>
Wholesome
for
me
,
wholesome
for
Agnes
,
wholesome
perhaps
for
all
of
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
it
is
for
me
,
sir
,
"
I
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
glad
to
be
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
fine
fellow
!
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
long
as
you
are
glad
to
be
here
,
you
shall
stay
here
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
shook
hands
with
me
upon
it
,
and
clapped
me
on
the
back
;
and
told
me
that
when
I
had
anything
to
do
at
night
after
Agnes
had
left
us
,
or
when
I
wished
to
read
for
my
own
pleasure
,
I
was
free
to
come
down
to
his
room
,
if
he
were
there
<EOS>
and
if
I
desired
it
for
company
's
sake
,
and
to
sit
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
thanked
him
for
his
consideration
;
and
,
as
he
went
down
soon
afterwards
,
and
I
was
not
tired
,
went
down
too
,
with
a
book
in
my
hand
,
to
avail
myself
,
for
half
-
an
-
hour
,
of
his
permission
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
seeing
a
light
in
the
little
round
office
,
and
immediately
feeling
myself
attracted
towards
Uriah
Heep
,
who
had
a
sort
of
fascination
for
me
<EOS>
,
I
went
in
there
instead
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
Uriah
reading
a
great
fat
book
,
with
such
demonstrative
attention
,
that
his
lank
forefinger
followed
up
every
line
as
he
read
,
and
made
clammy
tracks
along
the
page
(
or
so
I
fully
believed
)
like
a
snail
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
working
late
tonight
,
Uriah
,
"
says
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
says
Uriah
.
   
<EOS>
As
I
was
getting
on
the
stool
opposite
,
to
talk
to
him
more
conveniently
,
I
observed
that
he
had
not
such
a
thing
as
a
smile
about
him
,
and
that
he
could
only
widen
his
mouth
and
make
two
hard
creases
down
his
cheeks
,
one
on
each
side
,
to
stand
for
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
doing
office
-
work
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
said
Uriah
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
work
,
then
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
improving
my
legal
knowledge
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
said
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
through
Tidd
's
Practice
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
what
a
writer
Mr
Tidd
is
,
Master
Copperfield
!
"
   
<EOS>
My
stool
was
such
a
tower
of
observation
,
that
as
I
watched
him
reading
on
again
,
after
this
rapturous
exclamation
,
and
following
up
the
lines
with
his
forefinger
,
I
observed
that
his
nostrils
,
which
were
thin
and
pointed
,
with
sharp
dints
in
them
,
had
a
singular
and
most
uncomfortable
way
of
expanding
and
contracting
themselves
---
that
they
seemed
to
twinkle
instead
of
his
eyes
,
which
hardly
ever
twinkled
at
all
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
are
quite
a
great
lawyer
?
<EOS>
"
I
said
,
after
looking
at
him
for
some
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
Me
,
Master
Copperfield
?
"
said
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
!
 
<EOS>
I
'm
a
very
umble
person
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
no
fancy
of
mine
about
his
hands
,
I
observed
;
for
he
frequently
ground
the
palms
against
each
other
as
if
to
squeeze
them
dry
and
warm
,
besides
often
wiping
them
,
in
a
stealthy
way
,
on
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
well
aware
that
I
am
the
umblest
person
going
,
"
said
Uriah
Heep
,
modestly
;
"
let
the
other
be
where
he
may
.
 
<EOS>
My
mother
is
likewise
a
very
umble
person
.
 
<EOS>
We
live
in
a
numble
abode
,
Master
Copperfield
,
but
have
much
to
be
thankful
for
.
 
<EOS>
My
father
's
former
calling
was
umble
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
sexton
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
he
now
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
partaker
of
glory
at
present
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
said
Uriah
Heep
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
we
have
much
to
be
thankful
for
.
 
<EOS>
How
much
have
I
to
be
thankful
for
in
living
with
Mr
Wickfield
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
asked
Uriah
if
he
had
been
with
Mr
Wickfield
long
?
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
with
him
,
going
on
four
year
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
said
Uriah
;
shutting
up
his
book
,
after
carefully
marking
the
place
where
he
had
left
off
.
 
<EOS>
"
Since
a
year
after
my
father
's
death
.
 
<EOS>
How
much
have
I
to
be
thankful
for
,
in
that
!
 
<EOS>
How
much
have
I
to
be
thankful
for
,
in
Mr
Wickfield
's
kind
intention
to
give
me
my
articles
,
which
would
otherwise
not
lay
within
the
umble
means
of
mother
and
self
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
when
your
articled
time
is
over
,
you
'll
be
a
regular
lawyer
,
I
suppose
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
With
the
blessing
of
Providence
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
returned
Uriah
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
'll
be
a
partner
in
Mr
Wickfield
's
business
,
one
of
these
days
,
"
I
said
,
to
make
myself
agreeable
;
"
and
it
will
be
Wickfield
and
Heep
,
or
Heep
late
Wickfield
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
no
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
returned
Uriah
,
shaking
his
head
,
"
I
am
much
too
umble
for
that
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
certainly
did
look
uncommonly
like
the
carved
face
on
the
beam
outside
my
window
,
as
he
sat
,
in
his
humility
,
eyeing
me
sideways
,
with
his
mouth
widened
,
and
the
creases
in
his
cheeks
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
 
Wickfield
is
a
most
excellent
man
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
said
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
have
known
him
long
,
you
know
it
,
I
am
sure
,
much
better
than
I
can
inform
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
replied
that
I
was
certain
he
was
;
but
that
I
had
not
known
him
long
myself
,
though
he
was
a
friend
of
my
aunt
's
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
indeed
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
said
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
aunt
is
a
sweet
lady
,
Master
Copperfield
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
a
way
of
writhing
when
he
wanted
to
express
enthusiasm
,
which
was
very
ugly
;
and
which
diverted
my
attention
from
the
compliment
he
had
paid
my
relation
,
to
the
snaky
twistings
of
his
throat
and
body
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
sweet
lady
,
Master
Copperfield
!
"
said
Uriah
Heep
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
a
great
admiration
for
Miss
Agnes
,
Master
Copperfield
,
I
believe
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
,
"
Yes
,
"
boldly
;
not
that
I
knew
anything
about
it
,
Heaven
forgive
me
!
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
have
,
too
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
said
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
sure
you
must
have
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Everybody
must
have
,
"
I
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
thank
you
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
said
Uriah
Heep
,
"
for
that
remark
!
 
<EOS>
It
is
so
true
!
 
<EOS>
Umble
<EOS>
as
I
am
,
I
know
it
is
so
true
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
thank
you
,
Master
Copperfield
!
"
<EOS>
He
writhed
himself
quite
off
his
stool
in
the
excitement
of
his
feelings
,
and
,
being
off
,
began
to
make
arrangements
for
going
home
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
will
be
expecting
me
,
"
he
said
,
referring
to
a
pale
,
inexpressive
-
faced
watch
in
his
pocket
,
"
and
getting
uneasy
;
for
though
we
are
very
umble
,
Master
Copperfield
,
we
are
much
attached
to
one
another
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
would
come
and
see
us
,
any
afternoon
,
and
take
a
cup
of
tea
at
our
lowly
dwelling
,
mother
would
be
as
proud
of
your
company
as
I
should
be
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
I
should
be
glad
to
come
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
returned
Uriah
,
putting
his
book
away
upon
the
shelf
---
"
I
suppose
you
stop
here
,
some
time
,
Master
Copperfield
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
I
was
going
to
be
brought
up
there
<EOS>
,
I
believed
,
as
long
as
I
remained
at
school
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
indeed
!
"
exclaimed
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
YOU
would
come
into
the
business
at
last
,
Master
Copperfield
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
protested
that
I
had
no
views
of
that
sort
,
and
that
no
such
scheme
was
entertained
in
my
behalf
by
anybody
;
but
Uriah
insisted
on
blandly
replying
to
all
my
assurances
,
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes
,
Master
Copperfield
,
I
should
think
you
would
,
indeed
!
"
<EOS>
and
,
"
Oh
,
indeed
,
Master
Copperfield
,
I
should
think
you
would
,
certainly
!
"
<EOS>
over
and
over
again
.
 
<EOS>
Being
,
at
last
,
ready
to
leave
the
office
for
the
night
<EOS>
,
he
asked
me
if
it
would
suit
my
convenience
to
have
the
light
put
out
;
and
on
my
answering
"
Yes
,
"
instantly
extinguished
it
.
 
<EOS>
After
shaking
hands
with
me
---
his
hand
felt
like
a
fish
,
in
the
dark
---
he
opened
the
door
into
the
street
a
very
little
,
and
crept
out
,
and
shut
it
,
leaving
me
to
grope
my
way
back
into
the
house
:
which
cost
me
some
trouble
and
a
fall
over
his
stool
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
the
proximate
cause
,
I
suppose
,
of
my
dreaming
about
him
,
for
what
appeared
to
me
to
be
half
the
night
;
and
dreaming
,
among
other
things
,
that
he
had
launched
Mr
Peggotty
's
house
on
a
piratical
expedition
,
with
a
black
flag
at
the
masthead
,
bearing
the
inscription
"
Tidd
's
Practice
"
,
under
which
diabolical
ensign
he
was
carrying
me
and
little
Em'ly
to
the
Spanish
Main
,
to
be
drowned
.
   
<EOS>
I
got
a
little
the
better
of
my
uneasiness
when
I
went
to
school
next
day
,
and
a
good
deal
the
better
next
day
,
and
so
shook
it
off
by
degrees
,
that
in
less
than
a
fortnight
<EOS>
I
was
quite
at
home
,
and
happy
,
among
my
new
companions
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
awkward
enough
in
their
games
,
and
backward
enough
in
their
studies
;
but
custom
would
improve
me
in
the
first
respect
,
I
hoped
,
and
hard
work
in
the
second
.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
I
went
to
work
very
hard
,
both
in
play
and
in
earnest
,
and
gained
great
commendation
.
 
<EOS>
And
,
in
a
very
little
while
,
the
Murdstone
and
Grinby
life
became
so
strange
to
me
that
I
hardly
believed
in
it
,
while
my
present
life
grew
so
familiar
,
that
I
seemed
to
have
been
leading
it
a
long
time
.
   
<EOS>
Doctor
Strong
's
was
an
excellent
school
;
as
different
from
Mr
Creakle
's
as
good
is
from
evil
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
gravely
and
decorously
ordered
,
and
on
a
sound
system
;
with
an
appeal
,
in
everything
,
to
the
honour
and
good
faith
of
the
boys
,
and
an
avowed
intention
to
rely
on
their
possession
of
those
qualities
unless
they
proved
themselves
unworthy
of
it
,
which
worked
wonders
.
 
<EOS>
We
all
felt
that
we
had
a
part
in
the
management
of
the
place
,
and
in
sustaining
its
character
and
dignity
.
 
<EOS>
Hence
,
we
soon
became
warmly
attached
to
it
<EOS>
---
I
am
sure
I
did
for
one
,
and
I
never
knew
,
in
all
my
time
,
of
any
other
boy
being
otherwise
---
and
learnt
with
a
good
will
,
desiring
to
do
it
credit
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
noble
games
out
of
hours
,
and
plenty
of
liberty
;
but
even
then
,
as
I
remember
,
we
were
well
spoken
of
in
the
town
,
and
rarely
did
any
disgrace
,
by
our
appearance
or
manner
,
to
the
reputation
of
Doctor
Strong
and
Doctor
Strong
's
boys
.
   
<EOS>
Some
of
the
higher
scholars
boarded
in
the
Doctor
's
house
,
and
through
them
I
learned
,
at
second
hand
,
some
particulars
of
the
Doctor
's
history
---
as
,
how
he
had
not
yet
been
married
twelve
months
to
the
beautiful
young
lady
I
had
seen
in
the
study
,
whom
he
had
married
for
love
;
for
she
had
not
a
sixpence
,
and
had
a
world
of
poor
relations
(
so
our
fellows
said
)
ready
to
swarm
the
Doctor
out
of
house
and
home
.
 
<EOS>
Also
,
how
the
Doctor
's
cogitating
manner
was
attributable
to
his
being
always
engaged
in
looking
out
for
Greek
roots
;
which
,
in
my
innocence
and
ignorance
,
I
supposed
to
be
a
botanical
furor
on
the
Doctor
's
part
,
especially
as
he
always
looked
at
the
ground
when
he
walked
about
,
until
I
understood
that
they
were
roots
of
words
,
with
a
view
to
a
new
Dictionary
which
he
had
in
contemplation
.
 
<EOS>
Adams
,
our
head
-
boy
,
who
had
a
turn
for
mathematics
,
had
made
a
calculation
,
I
was
informed
,
of
the
time
this
Dictionary
would
take
in
completing
,
on
the
Doctor
's
plan
,
and
at
the
Doctor
's
rate
of
going
.
 
<EOS>
He
considered
that
it
might
be
done
in
one
thousand
six
hundred
and
forty
-
nine
years
,
counting
from
the
Doctor
's
last
,
or
sixty
-
second
,
birthday
.
   
<EOS>
But
the
Doctor
himself
was
the
idol
of
the
whole
school
:
and
it
must
have
been
a
badly
composed
school
if
he
had
been
anything
else
,
for
he
was
the
kindest
of
men
;
with
a
simple
faith
in
him
that
might
have
touched
the
stone
hearts
of
the
very
urns
upon
the
wall
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
walked
up
and
down
that
part
of
the
courtyard
which
was
at
the
side
of
the
house
,
with
the
stray
rooks
and
jackdaws
looking
after
him
with
their
heads
cocked
slyly
,
as
if
they
knew
how
much
more
knowing
they
were
in
worldly
affairs
than
he
,
if
any
sort
of
vagabond
could
only
get
near
enough
to
his
creaking
shoes
to
attract
his
attention
to
one
sentence
of
a
tale
of
distress
,
that
vagabond
was
made
for
the
next
two
days
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
so
notorious
in
the
house
,
that
the
masters
and
head
-
boys
took
pains
to
cut
these
marauders
off
at
angles
,
and
to
get
out
of
windows
,
and
turn
them
out
of
the
courtyard
,
before
they
could
make
the
Doctor
aware
of
their
presence
;
which
was
sometimes
happily
effected
within
a
few
yards
of
him
,
without
his
knowing
anything
of
the
matter
,
as
he
jogged
to
and
fro
.
 
<EOS>
Outside
his
own
domain
,
and
unprotected
,
he
was
a
very
sheep
for
the
shearers
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
have
taken
his
gaiters
off
his
legs
,
to
give
away
.
 
<EOS>
In
fact
,
there
was
a
story
current
among
us
<EOS>
(
I
have
no
idea
,
and
never
had
,
on
what
authority
,
but
I
have
believed
it
for
so
many
years
that
I
feel
quite
certain
it
is
true
)
,
that
on
a
frosty
day
,
one
winter
-
time
,
he
actually
did
bestow
his
gaiters
on
a
beggar
-
woman
,
who
occasioned
some
scandal
in
the
neighbourhood
by
exhibiting
a
fine
infant
from
door
to
door
,
wrapped
in
those
garments
,
which
were
universally
recognized
,
being
as
well
known
in
the
vicinity
as
the
Cathedral
.
 
<EOS>
The
legend
added
that
the
only
person
who
did
not
identify
them
was
the
Doctor
himself
,
who
,
when
they
were
shortly
afterwards
displayed
at
the
door
of
a
little
second
-
hand
shop
of
no
very
good
repute
,
where
such
things
were
taken
in
exchange
for
gin
,
was
more
than
once
observed
to
handle
them
approvingly
,
as
if
admiring
some
curious
novelty
in
the
pattern
,
and
considering
them
an
improvement
on
his
own
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
very
pleasant
to
see
the
Doctor
with
his
pretty
young
wife
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
fatherly
,
benignant
way
of
showing
his
fondness
for
her
,
which
seemed
in
itself
to
express
a
good
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
often
saw
them
walking
in
the
garden
where
the
peaches
were
,
and
I
sometimes
had
a
nearer
observation
of
them
in
the
study
or
the
parlour
.
 
<EOS>
She
appeared
to
me
to
take
great
care
of
the
Doctor
,
and
to
like
him
very
much
,
though
I
never
thought
her
vitally
interested
in
the
Dictionary
:
some
cumbrous
fragments
of
which
work
the
Doctor
always
carried
in
his
pockets
,
and
in
the
lining
of
his
hat
,
and
generally
seemed
to
be
expounding
to
her
as
they
walked
about
.
   
<EOS>
I
saw
a
good
deal
of
Mrs
Strong
,
both
because
she
had
taken
a
liking
for
me
on
the
morning
of
my
introduction
to
the
Doctor
,
and
was
always
afterwards
kind
to
me
,
and
interested
in
me
;
and
because
she
was
very
fond
of
Agnes
,
and
was
often
backwards
and
forwards
at
our
house
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
curious
constraint
between
her
and
Mr
Wickfield
,
I
thought
(
of
whom
she
seemed
to
be
afraid
)
,
that
never
wore
off
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
came
there
of
an
evening
,
she
always
shrunk
from
accepting
his
escort
home
,
and
ran
away
with
me
instead
.
 
<EOS>
And
sometimes
,
as
we
were
running
gaily
across
the
Cathedral
yard
together
,
expecting
to
meet
nobody
,
we
would
meet
Mr
Jack
Maldon
,
who
was
always
surprised
to
see
us
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Strong
's
mama
was
a
lady
I
took
great
delight
in
.
 
<EOS>
Her
name
was
Mrs
Markleham
;
but
our
boys
used
to
call
her
the
Old
Soldier
,
on
account
of
her
generalship
,
and
the
skill
with
which
she
marshalled
great
forces
of
relations
against
the
Doctor
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
a
little
,
sharp
-
eyed
woman
,
who
used
to
wear
,
when
she
was
dressed
,
one
unchangeable
cap
,
ornamented
with
some
artificial
flowers
,
and
two
artificial
butterflies
supposed
to
be
hovering
above
the
flowers
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
superstition
among
us
that
this
cap
had
come
from
France
,
and
could
only
originate
in
the
workmanship
of
that
ingenious
nation
:
but
all
I
certainly
know
about
it
,
is
,
that
it
always
made
its
appearance
of
an
evening
,
wheresoever
Mrs
Markleham
made
HER
appearance
;
that
it
was
carried
about
to
friendly
meetings
in
a
Hindoo
basket
;
that
the
butterflies
had
the
gift
of
trembling
constantly
;
and
that
they
improved
the
shining
hours
at
Doctor
Strong
's
expense
,
like
busy
bees
.
   
<EOS>
I
observed
the
Old
Soldier
---
not
to
adopt
the
name
disrespectfully
---
to
pretty
good
advantage
,
on
a
night
which
is
made
memorable
to
me
by
something
else
I
shall
relate
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
night
of
a
little
party
at
the
Doctor
's
,
which
was
given
on
the
occasion
of
Mr
Jack
Maldon
's
departure
for
India
,
whither
he
was
going
as
a
cadet
,
or
something
of
that
kind
:
<EOS>
Mr
Wickfield
having
at
length
arranged
the
business
.
 
<EOS>
It
happened
to
be
the
Doctor
's
birthday
,
too
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
had
a
holiday
,
had
made
presents
to
him
in
the
morning
,
had
made
a
speech
to
him
through
the
head
-
boy
,
and
had
cheered
him
until
we
were
hoarse
,
and
until
he
had
shed
tears
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
,
in
the
evening
,
Mr
Wickfield
,
Agnes
,
and
I
,
went
to
have
tea
with
him
in
his
private
capacity
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jack
Maldon
was
there
,
before
us
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Strong
,
dressed
in
white
,
with
cherry
-
coloured
ribbons
,
was
playing
the
piano
,
when
we
went
in
;
and
he
was
leaning
over
her
to
turn
the
leaves
.
 
<EOS>
The
clear
red
and
white
of
her
complexion
was
not
so
blooming
and
flower
-
like
as
usual
<EOS>
,
I
thought
,
when
she
turned
round
;
but
she
looked
very
pretty
,
Wonderfully
pretty
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
forgotten
,
Doctor
,
"
said
Mrs
Strong
's
mama
,
when
we
were
seated
,
"
to
pay
you
the
compliments
of
the
day
---
though
they
are
,
as
you
may
suppose
,
very
far
from
being
mere
compliments
in
my
case
.
 
<EOS>
Allow
me
to
wish
you
many
happy
returns
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
,
ma'am
,
"
replied
the
Doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
Many
,
many
,
many
,
happy
returns
,
"
said
the
Old
Soldier
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
only
for
your
own
sake
,
but
for
Annie
's
,
and
John
Maldon
's
,
and
many
other
people
's
.
 
<EOS>
It
seems
but
yesterday
to
me
,
John
,
when
you
were
a
little
creature
,
a
head
shorter
than
Master
Copperfield
,
making
baby
love
to
Annie
behind
the
gooseberry

in
the
back
-

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
mama
,
"
said
Mrs
Strong
,
"
never
mind
that
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Annie
,
do
n't
be
absurd
,
"
returned
her
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
are
to
blush
to
hear
of
such
things
now
you
are
an
old
married
woman
,
when
are
you
not
to
blush
to
hear
of
them
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Old
?
"
exclaimed
Mr
Jack
Maldon
.
 
<EOS>
"
Annie
?
 
<EOS>
Come
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
John
,
"
returned
the
Soldier
.
 
<EOS>
"
Virtually
,
an
old
married
woman
.
 
<EOS>
Although
not
old
by
years
---
for
when
did
you
ever
hear
me
say
,
or
who
has
ever
heard
me
say
,
that
a
girl
of
twenty
was
old
by
years
!
<EOS>
---
your
cousin
is
the
wife
of
the
Doctor
,
and
,
as
such
,
what
I
have
described
her
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
well
for
you
,
John
,
that
your
cousin
is
the
wife
of
the
Doctor
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
found
in
him
an
influential
and
kind
friend
,
who
will
be
kinder
yet
<EOS>
,
I
venture
to
predict
,
if
you
deserve
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
false
pride
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
hesitate
to
admit
,
frankly
,
that
there
are
some
members
of
our
family
who
want
a
friend
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
one
yourself
,
before
your
cousin
's
influence
raised
up
one
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Doctor
,
in
the
goodness
of
his
heart
,
waved
his
hand
as
if
to
make
light
of
it
,
and
save
Mr
Jack
Maldon
from
any
further
reminder
.
 
<EOS>
But
Mrs
Markleham
changed
her
chair
for
one
next
the
Doctor
's
,
and
putting
her
fan
on
his
coat
-
sleeve
,
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
No
,
really
,
my
dear
Doctor
,
you
must
excuse
me
if
I
appear
to
dwell
on
this
rather
,
because
I
feel
so
very
strongly
.
 
<EOS>
I
call
it
quite
my
monomania
,
it
is
such
a
subject
of
mine
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
a
blessing
to
us
.
 
<EOS>
You
really
are
a
Boon
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
,
nonsense
,
"
said
the
Doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
I
beg
your
pardon
,
"
retorted
the
Old
Soldier
.
 
<EOS>
"
With
nobody
present
,
but
our
dear
and
confidential
friend
Mr
Wickfield
,
I
can
not
consent
to
be
put
down
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
begin
to
assert
the
privileges
of
a
mother
-
in
-
law
,
if
you
go
on
like
that
,
and
scold
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
perfectly
honest
and
outspoken
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
am
saying
,
is
what
I
said
when
you
first
overpowered
me
with
surprise
---
you
remember
how
surprised
I
was
?
---
by
proposing
for
Annie
.
 
<EOS>
Not
that
there
was
anything
so
very
much
out
of
the
way
,
in
the
mere
fact
of
the
proposal
---
it
would
be
ridiculous
to
say

!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
but
because
,
you
having
known
her
poor
father
,
and
having
known
her
from
a
baby
six
months
old
,
I
had

thought

you
in
such

light
at
all
,
or

as
a
marrying
man
in
any

,
---
simply
that
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
aye
,
"
returned
the
Doctor
,
good

.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
DO
mind
,
"
said
the
Old
Soldier
,
laying
her
fan
upon
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
mind
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
I
recall
these
things
that
I
may
be
contradicted
if
I
am
wrong
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
Then
I
spoke
to
Annie
,
and
I
told
her
what
had
happened
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
,
"
My
dear
,
here
's
<EOS>
Doctor
Strong
has
positively
been
and
made
you
the
subject
of
a
handsome
declaration
and
an
offer
.
<EOS>
"
Did
I
press
it
in
the
least
?
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
,
"
Now
,
Annie
,
tell
me
the
truth
this
moment
;
is
your
heart
free
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mama
,
"
she
said
crying
,
"
I
am
extremely
young
"
---
which
was
perfectly
true
---
"
<EOS>
and
I
hardly
know
if
I
have
a
heart
at
all
.
"
<EOS>
"
Then
,
my
dear
,
"
I
said
,
"
you
may
rely
upon
it
,
it
's
free
.
 
<EOS>
At
all

,
my
love
,
"
said
I
,
"
Doctor
Strong
is
in
an
agitated
state
of
mind
,
and
must

answered
.
 
<EOS>
He
can
not
be
kept
in
his
present
state
of
suspense
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mama
,
"
said
Annie
,
still

,
"
would
he
be
unhappy
without
me
?
 
<EOS>
If
he
would
,
I
honour
and
respect
him
so
much
,
that
I
think
I
will
have
him
.
"
<EOS>
So
it
was
settled
.
 
<EOS>
And
then
,
and
not
till
then
<EOS>
,
I
said
to
Annie
,
"
Annie
,
Doctor
Strong
will
not
only
be
your
husband
,
but
he
will
represent
your
late

:
he
will
represent
the
head
of
our

,
he

represent
the
wisdom
and

,
and
I
may
say

means
,
of
our
family
;
and
will

,
in
short
,
a
Boon
to
it
.
<EOS>
"
I
used
the
word
at
the
time
,
and
I
have
used
it
again
,
today
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
have
any
merit
it
is
consistency
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
daughter
had
sat
quite
silent
and
still
during
this
speech
,
with
her
eyes
fixed
on
the
ground
;
her
cousin
standing
near
her
,
and
looking
on
the
ground
too
.
 
<EOS>
She
now
said
very
softly
,
in
a

:
   
<EOS>
"
Mama
,
I
hope
you
have
finished
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
dear
Annie
,
"
returned
the
Old
Soldier
,
"
I
have
not
quite
finished
.
 
<EOS>
Since
you
ask
me
,
my
love
,
I
reply
that
I
have
not
.
 
<EOS>
I
complain
that
you
really
are
a
little
unnatural
towards
your
own
family
;
and
,
as
it
is
of
no
use
complaining
to

.
 
<EOS>
I
mean
to

to
your
husband
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
my
dear
Doctor
,
do
look
at
that
silly
wife
of
yours
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
the
Doctor
turned
his
kind
face
,
with
its

of
simplicity
and
gentleness
,
towards
her
,
she
drooped
her

more
.
 
<EOS>
I
noticed
that
Mr
Wickfield
looked
at
her
steadily
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
happened
to
say
to
that
naughty
thing
,
the
other
day
,
"
pursued
her

,
shaking

and

at

,

,
"
that
there
was
a
family
circumstance
she
might
mention
to

---
indeed
,
I
think
,
was
bound
to

---
she
said
,
that

mention

was
to

;
and
that
,

you
were
too

,
and
as

her
to
ask
was
always
to
have
,
she
would
n't
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Annie
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
Doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
was
wrong
.
 
<EOS>
It
robbed
me
of
a
pleasure
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Almost
the
very
words
I
said
to
her
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
her
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
really
,
another
time
,
when
I
know
what
she
would
tell
you
but
for
this

,
and
wo
n't
,
I
have
a
great
mind
,
my
dear
Doctor
,
to
tell

myself
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
glad

you
will
,
"
returned
the
Doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Certainly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
I
will
!
"
said
the
Old
Soldier
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
bargain
.
"
<EOS>
And
having
,
I
suppose
,
carried
her
point
,
she
tapped
the
Doctor
's
hand
several
times
with
her
fan
(
which
she
kissed
first
)
,
and
returned
triumphantly
to
her
former
station
.
   
<EOS>
Some
more
company
coming
in
,
among
whom
were
the
two
masters
and
Adams
,
the
talk
became
general
;
and
it
naturally
turned
on
Mr
Jack
Maldon
,
and
his
voyage
,
and
the
country
he
was
going
to
,
and
his
various
plans
and
prospects
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
to
leave
that
night
,
after
supper
,
in
a
post
-
chaise
,
for
Gravesend
;
where
the
ship
,
in
which
he
was
to
make
the
voyage
,
lay
;
and
was
to
be
gone
---
unless
he
came
home
on
leave
,
or
for
his
health
<EOS>
---
I
do
n't
know
<EOS>
how
many
years
.
 
<EOS>
I
recollect
it
was
settled
by
general
consent
that
India
was
quite
a
misrepresented
country
,
and
had
nothing
objectionable
in
it
,
but
a
tiger
or
two
,
and
a
little
heat
in
the
warm
part
of
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
For
my
own
part
,
I
looked
on
Mr
Jack
Maldon
as
a
modern
Sindbad
,
and
pictured
him
the
bosom
friend
of
all
the
Rajahs
in
the
East
,
sitting
under
canopies
,
smoking
curly
golden
pipes
---
a
mile
long
,
if
they
could
be
straightened
out
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Strong
was
a
very
pretty
singer
:
as
I
knew
,
who
often
heard
her
singing
by
herself
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
whether
she
was
afraid
of
singing
before
people
,
or
was
out
of
voice
that
evening
,
it
was
certain
that
she
could
n't
sing
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
She
tried
a
duet
,
once
,
with
her
cousin
Maldon
,
but
could
not
so
much
as
begin
;
and
afterwards
,
when
she
tried
to
sing
by
herself
,
although
she
began
sweetly
,
her
voice
died
away
on
a
sudden
,
and
left
her
quite
distressed
,
with
her
head
hanging
down
over
the
keys
.
 
<EOS>
The
good
Doctor
said
she
was
nervous
,
and
,
to
relieve
her
,
proposed
a
round
game
at
cards
;
of
which
he
knew
as
much
as
of
the
art
of
playing
the
trombone
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
remarked
that
the
Old
Soldier
took
him
into
custody
directly
,
for
her
partner
;
and
instructed
him
,
as
the
first
preliminary
of
initiation
,
to
give
her
all
the
silver
he
had
in
his
pocket
.
   
<EOS>
We
had
a
merry
game
,
not
made
the
less
merry
by
the
Doctor
's
mistakes
,
of
which
he
committed
an
innumerable
quantity
,
in
spite
of
the
watchfulness
of
the
butterflies
,
and
to
their
great
aggravation
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Strong
had
declined
to
play
,
on
the
ground
of
not
feeling
very
well
;
and
her
cousin
Maldon
had
excused
himself
because
he
had
some
packing
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
done
it
,
however
,
he
returned
,
and
they
sat
together
,
talking
,
on
the
sofa
.
 
<EOS>
From
time
to
time
she
came
and
looked
over
the
Doctor
's
hand
,
and
told
him
what
to
play
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
very
pale
,
as
she
bent
over
him
,
and
I
thought
her
finger
trembled
as
she
pointed
out
the
cards
;
but
the
Doctor
was
quite
happy
in
her
attention
,
and
took
no
notice
of
this
,
if
it
were
so
.
   
<EOS>
At
supper
,
we
were
hardly
so
gay
.
 
<EOS>
Everyone
appeared
to
feel
that
a
parting
of
that
sort
was
an
awkward
thing
,
and
that
the
nearer
it
approached
,
the
more
awkward
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jack
Maldon
tried
to
be
very
talkative
,
but
was
not
at
his
ease
,
and
made
matters
worse
.
<EOS>
And
they
were
not
improved
,
as
it
appeared
to
me
,
by
the
Old
Soldier
:
who
continually
recalled
passages
of
Mr
Jack
Maldon
's
youth
.
   
<EOS>
The
Doctor
,
however
,
who
felt
,
I
am
sure
,
that
he
was
making
everybody
happy
,
was
well
pleased
,
and
had
no
suspicion
<EOS>
but
that
we
were
all
at
the
utmost
height
of
enjoyment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Annie
,
my
dear
,
"
said
he
,
looking
at
his
watch
,
and
filling
his
glass
,
"
it
is
past
your
cousin
jack
's
time
,
and
we
must
not
detain
him
,
since
time
and
tide
---
both
concerned
in
this
case
---
wait
for
no
man
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jack
Maldon
,
you
have
a
long
voyage
,
and
a
strange
country
,
before
you
;
but
many
men
have
had
both
,
and
many
men
will
have
both
,
to
the
end
of
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
winds
you
are
going
to
tempt
,
have
wafted
thousands
upon
thousands
to
fortune
,
and
brought
thousands
upon
thousands
happily
back
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
an
affecting
thing
,
"
said
Mrs
Markleham
---
"
<EOS>
however
it
's
viewed
,
it
's
affecting
,
to
see
a
fine
young
man
one
has
known
from
an
infant
,
going
away
to
the
other
end
of
the
world
,
leaving
all
he
knows
behind
,
and
not
knowing
what
's
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
A
young
man
really
well
deserves
constant
support
and
patronage
,
"
looking
at
the
Doctor
,
"
who
makes
such
sacrifices
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Time
will
go
fast
with
you
,
Mr
Jack
Maldon
,
"
pursued
the
Doctor
,
"
and
fast
with
all
of
us
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
us
can
hardly
expect
,
perhaps
,
in
the
natural
course
of
things
,
to
greet
you
on
your
return
.
 
<EOS>
The
next
best
thing
is
to
hope
to
do
it
,
and
that
's
my
case
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
not
weary
you
with
good
advice
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
long
had
a
good
model
before
you
,
in
your
cousin
Annie
.
 
<EOS>
Imitate
her
virtues
as
nearly
as
you
can
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Markleham
fanned
herself
,
and
shook
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
Farewell
,
Mr
Jack
,
"
said
the
Doctor
,
standing
up
;
on
which
we
all
stood
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
prosperous
voyage
out
,
a
thriving
career
abroad
,
and
a
happy
return
home
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
all
drank
the
toast
,
and
all
shook
hands
with
Mr
Jack
Maldon
;
after
which
he
hastily
took
leave
of
the
ladies
who
were
there
,
and
hurried
to
the
door
,
where
he
was
received
,
as
he
got
into
the
chaise
,
with
a
tremendous
broadside
of
cheers
discharged
by
our
boys
,
who
had
assembled
on
the
lawn
for
the
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
Running
in
among
them
to
swell
the
ranks
,
I
was
very
near
the
chaise
when
it
rolled
away
;
and
I
had
a
lively
impression
made
upon
me
,
in
the
midst
of
the
noise
and
dust
,
of
having
seen
Mr
Jack
Maldon
rattle
past
with
an
agitated
face
,
and
something
cherry
-
coloured
in
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
After
another
broadside
for
the
Doctor
,
and
another
for
the
Doctor
's
wife
,
the
boys
dispersed
,
and
I
went
back
into
the
house
,
where
I
found
the
guests
all
standing
in
a
group
about
the
Doctor
,
discussing
how
Mr
Jack
Maldon
had
gone
away
,
and
how
he
had
borne
it
,
and
how
he
had
felt
it
,
and
all
the
rest
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
these
remarks
,
Mrs
Markleham
cried
:
"
Where
's
Annie
?
"
   
<EOS>
No
Annie
was
there
;
and
when
they
called
to
her
,
no
Annie
replied
.
<EOS>
But
all
pressing
out
of
the
room
,
in
a
crowd
,
to
see
what
was
the
matter
,
we
found
her
lying
on
the
hall
floor
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
great
alarm
at
first
,
until
it
was
found
that
she
was
in
a
swoon
,
and
that
the
swoon
was
yielding
to
the
usual
means
of
recovery
;
when
the
Doctor
,
who
had
lifted
her
head
upon
his
knee
,
put
her
curls
aside
with
his
hand
,
and
said
,
looking
around
:
   
"
Poor
Annie
!
 
<EOS>
She
's
so
faithful
and
tender
-
hearted
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
the
parting
from
her
old
playfellow
and
friend
---
her
favourite
cousin
<EOS>
---
that
has
done
this
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
pity
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
sorry
!
"
   
<EOS>
When
she
opened
her
eyes
,
and
saw
where
she
was
,
and
that
we
were
all
standing
about
her
,
she
arose
with
assistance
:
turning
her
head
,
as
she
did
so
,
to
lay
it
on
the
Doctor
's
shoulder
---
or
to
hide
it
<EOS>
,
I
do
n't
know
which
.
 
<EOS>
We
went
into
the
drawing
-
room
,
to
leave
her
with
the
Doctor
and
her
mother
;
but
she
said
,
it
seemed
,
that
she
was
better
than
she
had
been
since
morning
,
and
that
she
would
rather
be
brought
among
us
;
<EOS>
so
they
brought
her
in
,
looking
very
white
and
weak
,
I
thought
,
and
sat
her
on
a
sofa
.
   
<EOS>
"
Annie
,
my
dear
,
"
said
her
mother
,
doing
something
to
her
dress
.
<EOS>
"
See
here
!
 
<EOS>
You
have
lost
a
bow
.
 
<EOS>
Will
anybody
be
so
good
as
find
a
ribbon
;
a
cherry
-
coloured
ribbon
?
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
the
one
she
had
worn
at
her
bosom
.
 
<EOS>
We
all
looked
for
it
;
I
myself
looked
everywhere
<EOS>
,
I
am
certain
---
but
nobody
could
find
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
recollect
where
you
had
it
last
,
Annie
?
"
said
her
mother
.
   
<EOS>
I
wondered
how
I
could
have
thought
she
looked
white
,
or
<EOS>
anything
but
burning
red
,
when
she
answered
that
she
had
had
it
safe
,
a
little
while
ago
<EOS>
,
she
thought
,
but
it
was
not
worth
looking
for
.
   
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
it
was
looked
for
again
,
and
still
not
found
.
 
<EOS>
She
entreated
that
there
might
be
no
more
searching
;
but
it
was
still
sought
for
,
in
a
desultory
way
,
until
she
was
quite
well
,
and
the
company
took
their
