.
   
<EOS>
We
walked
very
slowly
home
,
Mr
Wickfield
,
Agnes
,
and
I
---
<EOS>
Agnes
and
<EOS>
I
admiring
the
moonlight
,
and
Mr
Wickfield
scarcely
raising
his
eyes
from
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
,
at
last
,
reached
our
own
door
,
Agnes
discovered
that
she
had
left
her
little
reticule
behind
.
<EOS>
Delighted
to
be
of
any
service
to
her
,
I
ran
back
to
fetch
it
.
   
<EOS>
I
went
into
the
supper
-
room
where
it
had
been
left
,
which
was
deserted
and
dark
.
 
<EOS>
But
a
door
of
communication
between
that
and
the
Doctor
's
study
,
where
there
was
a
light
,
being
open
<EOS>
,
I
passed
on
there
,
to
say
what
I
wanted
,
and
to
get
a
candle
.
   
<EOS>
The
Doctor
was
sitting
in
his
easy
-
chair
by
the
fireside
,
and
his
young
wife
was
on
a
stool
at
his
feet
.
 
<EOS>
The
Doctor
,
with
a
complacent
smile
,
was
reading
aloud
some
manuscript
explanation
or
statement
of
a
theory
out
of
that
interminable
Dictionary
,
and
she
was
looking
up
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
with
such
a
face
as
I
never
saw
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
so
beautiful
in
its
form
,
it
was
so
ashy
pale
,
it
was
so
fixed
in
its
abstraction
<EOS>
,
it
was
so
full
of
a
wild
,
sleep
-
walking
,
dreamy
horror
of
I
do
n't
know
what
.
 
<EOS>
The
eyes
were
wide
open
,
and
her
brown
hair
fell
in
two
rich
clusters
on
her
shoulders
,
and
on
her
white
dress
,
disordered
by
the
want
of
the
lost
ribbon
.
 
<EOS>
Distinctly
as
I
recollect
her
look
,
I
can
not
say
of
what
it
was
expressive
,
I
can
not
even
say
of
what
it
is
expressive
to
me
now
,
rising
again
before
my
older
judgement
.
 
<EOS>
Penitence
,
humiliation
,
shame
,
pride
,
love
,
and
trustfulness
<EOS>
---
I
see
them
all
;
and
in
them
all
,
I
see
that
horror
of
I
do
n't
know
what
.
   
<EOS>
My
entrance
,
and
my
saying
what
I
wanted
,
roused
her
.
 
<EOS>
It
disturbed
the
Doctor
too
,
for
when
I
went
back
to
replace
the
candle
I
had
taken
from
the
table
,
he
was
patting
her
head
,
in
his
fatherly
way
,
and
saying
he
was
a
merciless
drone
to
let
her
tempt
him
into
reading
on
;
and
he
would
have
her
go
to
bed
.
   
<EOS>
But
she
asked
him
,
in
a
rapid
,
urgent
manner
,
to
let
her
stay
---
to
let
her
feel
assured
<EOS>
(
I
heard
her
murmur
some
broken
words
to
this
effect
)
that
she
was
in
his
confidence
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
And
,
as
she
turned
again
towards
him
,
after
glancing
at
me
as
I
left
the
room
and
went
out
at
the
door
,
I
saw
her
cross
her
hands
upon
his
knee
,
and
look
up
at
him
with
the
same
face
,
something
quieted
,
as
he
resumed
his
reading
.
   
<EOS>
It
made
a
great
impression
on
me
,
and
I
remembered
it
a
long
time
afterwards
;
as
I
shall
have
occasion
to
narrate
when
the
time
comes
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
17
.
<EOS>
Somebody
turns
up
 
It
has
not
occurred
to
me
to
mention
Peggotty
since
I
ran
away
;
but
,
of
course
,
I
wrote
her
a
letter
almost
as
soon
as
I
was
housed
at
Dover
,
and
another
,
and
a
longer
letter
,
containing
all
particulars
fully
related
,
when
my
aunt
took
me
formally
under
her
protection
.
 
<EOS>
On
my
being
settled
at
Doctor
Strong
's
I
wrote
to
her
again
,
detailing
my
happy
condition
and
prospects
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
could
have
derived
anything
like
the
pleasure
from
spending
the
money
Mr
Dick
had
given
me
,
that
I
felt
in
sending
a
gold
half
-
guinea
to
Peggotty
,
per
post
,
enclosed
in
this
last
letter
,
to
discharge
the
sum
I
had
borrowed
of
her
:
in
which
epistle
,
not
before
,
I
mentioned
about
the
young
man
with
the
donkey
-
cart
.
   
<EOS>
To
these
communications
<EOS>
Peggotty
replied
as
promptly
,
if
not
as
concisely
,
as
a
merchant
's
clerk
.
 
<EOS>
Her
utmost
powers
of
expression
(
which
were
certainly
not
great
in
ink
)
were
exhausted
in
the
attempt
to
write
what
she
felt
on
the
subject
of
my
journey
.
 
<EOS>
Four
sides
of
incoherent
and
interjectional
beginnings
of
sentences
,
that
had
no
end
,
except
blots
,
were
inadequate
to
afford
her
any
relief
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
blots
were
more
expressive
to
me
than
the
best
composition
;
for
they
showed
me
that
Peggotty
had
been
crying
all
over
the
paper
,
and
what
could
I
have
desired
more
?
   
<EOS>
I
made
out
,
without
much
difficulty
,
that
she
could
not
take
quite
kindly
to
my
aunt
yet
.
 
<EOS>
The
notice
was
too
short
after
so
long
a
prepossession
the
other
way
.
 
<EOS>
We
never
knew
a
person
,
she
wrote
;
but
to
think
that
Miss
Betsey
should
seem
to
be
so
different
from
what
she
had
been
thought
to
be
,
was
a
Moral
!
<EOS>
---
that
was
her
word
.
<EOS>
She
was
evidently
still
afraid
of
Miss
Betsey
,
for
she
sent
her
grateful
duty
to
her
but
timidly
;
and
she
was
evidently
afraid
of
me
,
too
,
and
entertained
the
probability
of
my
running
away
again
soon
:
if
I
might
judge
from
the
repeated
hints
she
threw
out
,
that
the
coach
-
fare
to
Yarmouth
was
always
to
be
had
of
her
for
the
asking
.
   
<EOS>
She
gave
me
one
piece
of
intelligence
which
affected
me
very
much
,
namely
,
that
there
had
been
a
sale
of
the
furniture
at
our
old
home
,
and
that
Mr
and
Miss
Murdstone
were
gone
away
,
and
the
house
was
shut
up
,
to
be
let
or
sold
.
 
<EOS>
God
knows
I
had
no
part
in
it
while
they
remained
there
,
but
it
pained
me
to
think
of
the
dear
old
place
as
altogether
abandoned
;
of
the
weeds
growing
tall
in
the
garden
,
and
the
fallen
leaves
lying
thick
and
wet
upon
the
paths
.
<EOS>
I
imagined
how
the
winds
of
winter
would
howl
round
it
,
how
the
cold
rain
would
beat
upon
the
window
-
glass
,
how
the
moon
would
make
ghosts
on
the
walls
of
the
empty
rooms
,
watching
their
solitude
all
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
afresh
of
the
grave
in
the
churchyard
,
underneath
the
tree
:
and
it
seemed
as
if
the
house
were
dead
too
,
now
,
and
all
connected
with
my
father
and
mother
were
faded
away
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
no
other
news
in
Peggotty
's
letters
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Barkis
was
an
excellent
husband
,
she
said
,
though
still
a
little
near
;
but
we
all
had
our
faults
,
and
she
had
plenty
(
though
I
am
sure
I
do
n't
know
what
they
were
)
;
and
he
sent
his
duty
,
and
my
little
bedroom
was
always
ready
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
was
well
,
and
Ham
was
well
,
and
Mrs.
 
Gummidge
was
but
poorly
,
and
little
Em'ly
would
n't
send
her
love
,
but
said
that
Peggotty
might
send
it
,
if
she
liked
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
intelligence
I
dutifully
imparted
to
my
aunt
,
only
reserving
to
myself
the
mention
of
little
Em'ly
,
to
whom
I
instinctively
felt
that
she
would
not
very
tenderly
incline
.
 
<EOS>
While
I
was
yet
new
at
Doctor
Strong
's
,
she
made
several
excursions
over
to
Canterbury
to
see
me
,
and
always
at
unseasonable
hours
:
with
the
view
,
I
suppose
,
of
taking
me
by
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
finding
me
well
employed
,
and
bearing
a
good
character
,
and
hearing
on
all
hands
that
I
rose
fast
in
the
school
,
she
soon
discontinued
these
visits
.
<EOS>
I
saw
her
on
a
Saturday
,
every
third
or
fourth
week
,
when
I
went
over
to
Dover
for
a
treat
;
and
I
saw
Mr
Dick
every
alternate
Wednesday
,
when
he
arrived
by
stage
-
coach
at
noon
,
to
stay
until
next
morning
.
   
<EOS>
On
these
occasions
Mr
Dick
never
travelled
without
a
leathern
writing
-
desk
,
containing
a
supply
of
stationery
and
the
Memorial
;
in
relation
to
which
document
he
had
a
notion
that
time
was
beginning
to
press
now
,
and
that
it
really
must
be
got
out
of
hand
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
was
very
partial
to
gingerbread
.
 
<EOS>
To
render
his
visits
the
more
agreeable
,
my
aunt
had
instructed
me
to
open
a
credit
for
him
at
a
cake
shop
,
which
was
hampered
with
the
stipulation
that
he
should
not
be
served
with
more
than
one
shilling's
-
worth
in
the
course
of
any
one
day
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
and
the
reference
of
all
his
little
bills
at
the
county
inn
where
he
slept
,
to
my
aunt
,
before
they
were
paid
,
induced
me
to
suspect
that
he
was
only
allowed
to
rattle
his
money
,
and
not
to
spend
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
on
further
investigation
that
this
was
so
,
or
at
least
there
was
an
agreement
between
him
and
my
aunt
that
he
should
account
to
her
for
all
his
disbursements
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
had
no
idea
of
deceiving
her
,
and
always
desired
to
please
her
,
he
was
thus
made
chary
of
launching
into
expense
.
 
<EOS>
On
this
point
,
as
well
as
on
all
other
possible
points
,
Mr
Dick
was
convinced
that
my
aunt
was
the
wisest
and
most
wonderful
of
women
;
as
he
repeatedly
told
me
with
infinite
secrecy
,
and
always
in
a
whisper
.
   
<EOS>
"
Trotwood
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
with
an
air
of
mystery
,
after
imparting
this
confidence
to
me
,
one
Wednesday
;
"
who
's
the
man
that
hides
near
our
house
and
frightens
her
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Frightens
my
aunt
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
nodded
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
nothing
would
have
frightened
her
,
"
he
said
,
"
for
she
's
---
"
<EOS>
here
he
whispered
softly
,
"
do
n't
mention
it
---
<EOS>
the
wisest
and
most
wonderful
of
women
.
"
 
<EOS>
Having
said
which
,
he
drew
back
,
to
observe
the
effect
which
this
description
of
her
made
upon
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
first
time
he
came
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
"
was
---
<EOS>
let
me
see
---
<EOS>
sixteen
hundred
and
forty
-
nine
was
the
date
of
King
Charles
's
execution
.
<EOS>
I
think
you
said
sixteen
hundred
and
forty
-
nine
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
how
it
can
be
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
sorely

and
shaking
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
I
am
as
old
as
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Was
it
in
that
year
that
the
man
appeared
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
really
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
"
I
do
n't
see
how
it
can
have
been
in
that
year
,
Trotwood
.
 
<EOS>
Did
you
get
that
date
out

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
history
never
lies
,
does

?
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
with
a

of
hope
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
dear
,
no
,
sir
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I
replied
,
most
decisively
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
ingenuous
and
young
,
and
I
thought
so
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
make
it
out
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
shaking
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
something
wrong
,
somewhere
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
it
was
very
soon
after
the
mistake
was

of

some

the
trouble
out
of
King
Charles
's

my

,
that

man

.
 
<EOS>
I
was

Miss
Trotwood
after

,
just

,
and
there
he
was
,
close

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Walking

?
<EOS>
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
Walking

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Let

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
N
-
<EOS>
no
,
no
;
he
was
not

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

,
as
the

WAS

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,

,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
"
until

,

.
 
<EOS>
Then
she
turned
round
and
fainted
,
and
I

,
and
he

;
but

(
in

ground

)
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
HAS
he
been
hiding
ever
since
?
<EOS>
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
he
has
,
"
retorted
Mr
Dick
,
nodding
his

gravely
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Never
came
out
,
till
last
night
!
 
<EOS>
We
were
walking
last
night
,
and
he
came
up
behind
her
again
,
and
I
knew
him
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
did
he
frighten
my
aunt
again
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
of
a
shiver
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
counterfeiting
that
affection
and
making
his
teeth
chatter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Held
by
the
palings
.
 
<EOS>
Cried
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
Trotwood
,
come
here
,
"
getting
me
close
to
him
,
that
he
might
whisper
very
softly
;
"
why
did
she
give
him
money
,
boy
,
in
the
moonlight
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
was
a
beggar
,
perhaps
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
shook
his
head
,
as
utterly
renouncing
the

;
and
having

a
great
many
times
,
and
with
great
confidence
,
"
No
beggar
,
no
beggar
,
no
beggar
,
sir
!
"
went
on
to
say
,
that
from
his
window
he
had
afterwards
,
and
late
at
night
,
seen
my
aunt
give
this
person
money
outside
the
garden
rails
in
the
moonlight
,
who
then
slunk
away
---
into
the
ground
again
,
as
he
thought
probable
---
and
was
seen
no
more
:
while
my
aunt
came
hurriedly
and
secretly
back
into
the
house
,
and
had
,
even
that
morning
,
been
quite
different
from
her
usual
self
;
which
preyed
on
Mr
Dick
's

.
   
<EOS>
I
had
not
the
least
belief
,
in
the
outset
of
this
story
,
that
the
unknown
was
anything
but
a

of
Mr
Dick
's
,
and
one
of
the
line
of
that
ill
-
fated
Prince
who
occasioned

so
much

;
but
after

I
began
to

whether
an

,
or
threat
of
an

,
might
have
been
twice
made
to
take
poor
Mr
Dick
himself
from
under
my
aunt
's
protection
,
and
whether
my
aunt
,
the
strength
of
whose
kind
feeling
towards
him
I
knew
from
herself
,
might
have
been
induced
to
pay
a
price
for
his
peace
and
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
was
already
much
attached
to
Mr
Dick
,
and
very
solicitous
for
his
welfare
,
my
fears
favoured
this
supposition
;
and
for
a
long
time
his
Wednesday
hardly
ever
came
round
,
without
my
entertaining
a
misgiving
that
he
would
not
be
on
the
coach
-
box
as
usual
.
 
<EOS>
There
he
always
appeared
,
however
,
grey
-
headed
,
laughing
,
and
happy
;
and
he
never
had
anything
more
to
tell
of
the
man
who
could
frighten
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
These
Wednesdays
were
the
happiest
days
of
Mr
Dick
's
life
;
they
were
far
from
being
the
least
happy
of
mine
.
 
<EOS>
He
soon
became
known
to
every
boy
in
the
school
;
and
though
he
never
took
an
active
part
in
any
game
but
kite
-
flying
,
was
as
deeply
interested
in
all
our
sports
as
anyone
among
us
.
 
<EOS>
How
often
have
I
seen
him
,
intent
upon
a
match
at
marbles
or
pegtop
,
looking
on
with
a
face
of
unutterable
interest
,
and
hardly
breathing
at
the
critical
times
!
 
<EOS>
How
often
,
at
hare
and
hounds
,
have
I
seen
him
mounted
on
a
little
knoll
,
cheering
the
whole
field
on
to
action
,
and
waving
his
hat
above
his
grey
head
,
oblivious
of
King
Charles
the
Martyr
's
head
,
and
all
belonging
to
it
!
 
<EOS>
How
many
a
summer
hour
have
I
known
to
be
but
<EOS>
blissful
minutes
to
him
in
the
cricket
-
field
!
 
<EOS>
How
many
winter
days
have
I
seen
him
,
standing
blue
-
nosed
,
in
the
snow
and
east
wind
,
looking
at
the
boys
going
down
the
long
slide
,
and
clapping
his
worsted
gloves
in
rapture
!
   
<EOS>
He
was
an
universal
favourite
,
and
his
ingenuity
in
little
things
was
transcendent
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
cut
oranges
into
such
devices
as
none
of
us
had
an
idea
of
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
make
a
boat
out
of
anything
,
from
a
skewer
upwards
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
turn
cramp
-
bones
into
chessmen
;
fashion
Roman
chariots
from
old
court
cards
;
make
spoked
wheels
out
of
cotton
reels
,
and
bird
-
cages
of
old
wire
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
greatest
of
all
<EOS>
,
perhaps
,
in
the
articles
of
string
and
straw
;
with
which
we
were
all
persuaded
he
could
do
anything
that
could
be
done
by
hands
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
's
renown
was
not
long
confined
to
us
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
few
Wednesdays
,
Doctor
Strong
himself
made
some
inquiries
of
me
about
him
,
and
I
told
him
all
my
aunt
had
told
me
;
which
interested
the
Doctor
so
much
that
he
requested
,
on
the
occasion
of
his
next
visit
,
to
be
presented
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
This
ceremony
I
performed
;
and
the
Doctor
begging
Mr
Dick
,
whensoever
he
should
not
find
me
at
the
coach
office
,
to
come
on
there
,
and
rest
himself
until
our
morning
's
work
was
over
,
it
soon
passed
into
a
custom
for
Mr
Dick
to
come
on
as
a
matter
of
course
,
and
,
if
we
were
a
little
late
,
as
often
happened
on
a
Wednesday
,
to
walk
about
the
courtyard
,
waiting
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
Here
he
made
the
acquaintance
of
the
Doctor
's
beautiful
young
wife
(
paler
than
formerly
,
all
this
time
;
more
rarely
seen
by
me
or
anyone
,
I
think
;
and
not
so
gay
,
but
not
less

)
,
and
so
became
more
and
more
familiar
by
degrees
,
until
,
at
last
,
he
would
come
into
the
school
and
wait
.
 
<EOS>
He
always
sat
in
a
particular
corner
,
on
a
particular
stool
,
which
was
called
"
Dick
"
,
after
him
;
here
he
would
sit
,
with
his
grey
head
bent
forward
,
attentively
listening
to
whatever
might
be
going
on
,
with
a
profound
veneration
for
the
learning
he
had
never
been
able
to
acquire
.
   
<EOS>
This
veneration
Mr
Dick
extended
to
the
Doctor
,
whom
he
thought
the
most
subtle
and
accomplished
philosopher
of
any
age
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
long
before
Mr
Dick
ever
spoke
to
him
otherwise
than
bareheaded
;
and
even
when
he
and
the
Doctor
had
struck
up
quite
a
friendship
,
and
would
walk
together
by
the
hour
,
on
that
side
of
the
courtyard
which
was
known
among
us
as
The
Doctor
's
Walk
,
Mr
Dick
would
pull
off
his
hat
at
intervals
to
show
his
respect
for
wisdom
and
knowledge
.
 
<EOS>
How
it
ever
came
about
that
the
Doctor
began
to
read
out
scraps
of
the
famous
Dictionary
,
in
these
walks
,
I
never
knew
;
perhaps
he
felt
it
<EOS>
all
the
same
,
at
first
,
as
reading
to
himself
.
<EOS>
However
,
it
passed
into
a
custom
too
;
and
Mr
Dick
,
listening
with
a
face
shining
with
pride
and
pleasure
,
in
his
heart
of
hearts
believed
the
Dictionary
to
be
the
most
delightful
book
in
the
world
.
   
<EOS>
As
I
think
of
them
going
up
and
down
before
those
schoolroom
windows
---
the
Doctor
reading
with
his
complacent
smile
,
an
occasional
flourish
of
the
manuscript
,
or
grave
motion
of
his
head
;
and
Mr
Dick
listening
,
enchained
by
interest
,
with
his
poor
wits
calmly
wandering
<EOS>
God
knows
where
,
upon
the
wings
of
hard
words
---
I
think
of
it
as
one
of
the
pleasantest
things
,
in
a
quiet
way
,
that
I
have
ever
seen
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
as
if
they
might
go
walking
to
and
fro
for
ever
,
and
the
world
might
somehow
be
the
better
for
it
---
as
if
a
thousand
things
it
makes
a
noise
about
,
were
not
one
half
so
good
for
it
,
or
me
.
   
<EOS>
Agnes
was
one
of
Mr
Dick
's
friends
,
very
soon
;
and
in
often
coming
to
the
house
,
he
made
acquaintance
with
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
The
friendship
between
himself
and
me
increased
continually
,
and
it
was
maintained
on
this
odd
footing
:
<EOS>
that
,
while
Mr
Dick
came
professedly
to
look
after
me
as
my
guardian
,
he
always
consulted
me
in
any
little
matter
of
doubt
that
arose
,
and
invariably
guided
himself
by
my
advice
;
not
only
having
a
high
respect
for
my
native
sagacity
,
but
considering
that
I
inherited
a
good
deal
from
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
One
Thursday
morning
,
when
I
was
about
to
walk
with
Mr
Dick
from
the
hotel
to
the
coach
office
before
going
back
to
school
(
for
we
had
an
hour
's
school
before
breakfast
)
,
I
met
Uriah
in
the
street
,
who
reminded
me
of
the
promise
I
had
made
to
take
tea
with
himself
and
his
mother
:
adding
,
with
a
writhe
,
"
<EOS>
But
I
did
n't
expect
you
to
keep
it
,
Master
Copperfield
,
we
're
so
very
umble
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
really
had
not
yet
been
able
to
make
up
my
mind
whether
I
liked
Uriah
or
detested
him
;
and
I
was
very
doubtful
about
it
still
,
as
I
stood
looking
him
in
the
face
in
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
felt
it
quite
an
affront
to
be
supposed
proud
,
and
said
I
only
wanted
to
be
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
if
that
's
all
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
said
Uriah
,
"
and
it
really
is
n't
our
umbleness
that
prevents
you
<EOS>
,
will
you
come
this
evening
?
 
<EOS>
But
if
it
is
our
umbleness
,
I
hope
you
wo
n't
mind
owning
to
it
,
Master
Copperfield
;
for
we
are
well
aware
of
our
condition
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
I
would
mention
it
to
Mr
Wickfield
,
and
if
he
approved
,
as
I
had
no

,
I

come

.
 
<EOS>
So
,

,
which

one

,
I

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
will
be

,

,
"
he

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Or

proud
,
if

was

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yet
you
did
n't

supposing
<EOS>
I
was
proud
this

,
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh

,
no
,
Master

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,

!
 
<EOS>
Such

!
 
<EOS>
I
should
n't

deemed
it
at
all
proud
if

US
too
umble

.
<EOS>
Because

umble
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have

much
law
lately
?
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

,
"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Rather

,

?
"

<EOS>
"
He

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
But

do
n't

what

.
"
   
<EOS>
After

on

,

:
   
"

,

---
Latin

---
in

Tidd
,
that

umble

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Would

?
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
teach

you

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,

,
"

<EOS>
"

"
   
<EOS>
"
What

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,

!
 
<EOS>
I

,
and
I
should
like
it
of
all
things
<EOS>
,
I
assure

;
but
I

umble
.
 
<EOS>
There

to
tread
upon

in

,
without
my
doing
outrage
to

by
possessing

.
 
<EOS>
Learning
ai
n't
for

.
 
<EOS>
A

like

had

not
aspire
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
is
to
get
on
in
life
,
he
must

,
Master
Copperfield
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
never

,

so

,

of

:
shaking

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

do

,

,
"

;
"

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
wo

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
much
too
umble
.
 
<EOS>
Here

my
umble

,
Master
Copperfield
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
entered
a
low
,
old
-
fashioned
room
,
walked
straight
into
from
the
street
,
and
found
there
<EOS>
Mrs
Heep
,
who
was
the
dead
image
of
Uriah
,
only
short
.
 
<EOS>
She
received
me
with
the
utmost

,
and
apologized
to
me
for
giving
her
son
a
kiss
,
observing
that
,
lowly
as
they
were
,
they
had
their
natural
affections
,
which
they
hoped
would
give
no
offence
to
anyone
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
perfectly
decent
room
,
half
parlour
and
half
kitchen
,
but
not
at
all
a
snug
room
.
 
<EOS>
The
tea
-
things
were
set
upon
the
table
,
and
the
kettle
was
boiling
on
the
hob
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
chest
of
drawers
with
an
escritoire
top
,
for
Uriah
to
read
or
write
at
of
an
evening
;
there
was
Uriah
's
blue
bag
lying
down
and
vomiting
papers
;
there
was
a
company
of
Uriah
's
books
commanded
by
Mr
Tidd
;
there
was
a
corner

:
and
there
were
the
usual
articles
of

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
remember
that
any
individual

had
a
bare
,
pinched
,

look
;
but
I
do
remember
that
the
whole
place
had
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
perhaps
a
part
of
Mrs
Heep
's
humility
,
that
she
still
wore
weeds
.
 
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
the
lapse
of
time
that
had
occurred
since
Mr
Heep
's

,
she
still
wore
weeds
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
there
was
some
compromise
in
the
cap
;
but
otherwise
she
was
as
weedy
as
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
day
to
be

,
my
Uriah
,
I

,
"
said
Mrs
Heep
,
making

,
"
when
Master
Copperfield
pays

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
said

'd

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

,
"

that

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

;

,
of

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"

Heep
,
"
has

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
his
fears
that
our
umbleness
stood

,

.
 
<EOS>
Umble

are
,
<EOS>
umble

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
We
know

station
and

.
"
   
<EOS>
I
found
that
Mrs
Heep
gradually
got

,

Uriah

got
opposite
to
me
,
and
that

with

.
 
<EOS>
There

nothing

,

;
but
I
took
the
will
for

deed
,
and
felt
that
they
were
very
attentive
.
 
<EOS>
Presently
they
began
to
talk
about
aunts
,
and
then
I
told
them
about
mine
;
and
about
fathers
and
mothers
,
and
then
I
told
them
about
mine
;
and
then
Mrs
Heep
began
to
talk
about
fathers
-
in
-
law
,
and
then
I
began
to
tell
her
about
mine
---
but
stopped
,
because
my
aunt
had
advised
me
to
observe
a

on

.
 
<EOS>
A
tender
young
cork
,
however
,
would
have
had
no
more

against
a

,
or

,

little

against

,
than
I

against
Uriah
and
Mrs
Heep
.
 
<EOS>
They
did
just
what
they
liked
with
me
;
and
wormed
things

of
me
that
I
had
no

to
tell
,
with
a

I
blush
to
think

.
 
<EOS>
the
more
especially
,
as
in
my
juvenile

,
I
took

myself
for
being
so
confidential
and
felt
that
I
was
quite
the

of
my
two
respectful

.
   
<EOS>
They
were
very
fond
of
one
another
:
that
was
certain
.
 
<EOS>
I
take
it
,
that
had
its

upon

,
as
a
touch
of
nature
;
but
the
skill

the
one
followed

,

art
which

less

.
 
<EOS>
When

nothing
more

got

about

(
for
on

Murdstone

Grinby
life
,

,

dumb
)
,
they
began

Mr
Wickfield

.
 
<EOS>
Uriah
threw
the
ball
to
Mrs
Heep
<EOS>
,
Mrs
Heep
caught
it
and
threw
it
back
to
Uriah
,
Uriah

it
up
a
little

,
then
sent

back
to
Mrs
Heep
,
and
so

went
on

it
about
until
I
had
no

who
had
got

,
and
was
quite

.
 
<EOS>
The
ball
itself
was
always
changing
too
.
 
<EOS>
Now
it
was
Mr
Wickfield
,
now
Agnes
,
now
the
excellence
of
Mr
Wickfield
,
now
my

of
Agnes
;
now
the

Mr
Wickfield
's

,

our

;

,

that
Mr
Wickfield
took
,
the

took

,
and
the

that
it
was

so

;
now
one

,

,
<EOS>
then
everything

once
;
and
all

,
without

,

but
sometimes

a

,
for
fear

should

by
their
humility
and
the
honour
of
my
company
,
I
found

perpetually
letting

other
that
I

no

to
let
out
and
seeing
the
effect
of
it
in
the

of
Uriah
's

.
   
<EOS>
I
had
begun
to
be
a

,
and
to
wish
myself
well
out
of
the
visit
,
when

figure
coming
down

street
passed

door
---
it

air

room
,
which
was
warm
,
the
weather
being
close
for
the

---
came

again
,
looked

,
and

,

,
"
Copperfield
!
 
<EOS>
Is
it
possible
?
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
Mr
Micawber
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
Mr
Micawber
,
with
his
eye
-

,
and
his

-
stick
,
and
his
shirt

,
and
his

,
and
the

in

voice
,
all

!
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
putting
out

hand
,
"
this
is
indeed
a
meeting
which
is
calculated
to
impress
the

with
a
sense
of
the
instability
and
uncertainty
of
all
human
---
in
short
,
it
is
a
most
extraordinary
meeting
.
 
<EOS>
Walking
along
the
street
,
reflecting
upon
the
probability
of
something
turning
up
(
of
which
I
am
at
present
rather
sanguine
)
<EOS>
,
I
find
a
young
but
valued
friend
turn
up
,
who
is
connected
with
the
most
eventful
period
of
my
life
;
I
may

,
with

-

of
my

.
<EOS>
Copperfield
,
my
dear
fellow
,
how
do

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
---
<EOS>
I
really
can
not

---
that
I
was
glad
to
see
Mr
Micawber
there
;
but
I
was

to
see
him
too
,
and
shook

with

,
heartily
,
inquiring
how
Mrs
Micawber
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
waving
his
hand
as
of
old
,
and
settling
his
chin
in
his
shirt
-
collar
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
is
tolerably
convalescent
.
 
<EOS>
The
twins
no
longer
derive
their
sustenance
from
Nature
's
founts
---
in
short
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
in
one

confidence
,
"
they
are
weaned
---
and
Mrs
Micawber
is
,
at
present
,
my
travelling

.
 
<EOS>
She
will
be
rejoiced
,
Copperfield
,
to
renew
her
acquaintance
with
one
who
has
proved
himself
in
all
respects
a
worthy
minister
at
the
sacred
altar
of
friendship
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
I
should
be
delighted
to
see
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
good
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
then
smiled
,
settled
his
chin
again
,
and
looked
about
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
discovered
my
friend
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
genteelly
,
and
without
addressing
himself
particularly
to
anyone
,
"
not
in
solitude
,
but
partaking
of
a
social
meal
in
company
with
a
widow
lady
,
and
one
who
is
apparently
her

---
in
short
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
in
another
of
his
bursts

confidence
,
"
her
son
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
esteem
it
an
honour
to
be
presented
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
do
no
less
,
under

,
than
make
Mr
Micawber
known
to
Uriah
Heep
and
his
mother
;
which
I
accordingly
did
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
abased
themselves
before
him
,
Mr
Micawber
took
a
seat
,
and
waved
his
hand
in
his
most
courtly
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Any
friend
of
my
friend
Copperfield
's
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
has
a
personal
claim
upon
myself
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
too
umble
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Heep
,
"
my
son
and
me
,
to
be
the
friends
of
Master
Copperfield
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
been
so
good
as
take
his
tea
with
us
,
and
we
are
thankful
to
him
for
his
company
,
also
to
you
,
sir
,
for
your
notice
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ma'am
,
"
returned
Mr
Micawber
,
with
a
bow
,
"
you
are
very
obliging
:
and
what
are
you
doing
,
Copperfield
?
 
<EOS>
Still
in
the
wine
trade
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
excessively
anxious
to
get
Mr
Micawber
away
;
and
replied
,
with
my
hat
in
my
hand
,
and
a
very
red
face
,
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
,
that
I
was
a
pupil
at
Doctor
Strong
's
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
pupil
?
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
raising
his
eyebrows
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
extremely
happy
to
hear
it
.
 
<EOS>
Although
a
mind
like
my
friend
Copperfield
's
"
---
to
Uriah
and
Mrs
Heep
---
"
does
not
require
that
cultivation
which
,
without
his
knowledge
of
men
and
things
,
it
would
require
,
still
it
is
a
rich
soil
teeming
with
latent
vegetation
---
in
short
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
smiling
,
in
another
burst
of
confidence
,
"
it
is
an
intellect
capable
of
getting
up
the
classics
to
any
extent
.
"
   
<EOS>
Uriah
,
with
his
long
hands
slowly
twining
over
one
another
,
made
a
ghastly
writhe
from
the
waist
upwards
,
to
express
his
concurrence
in
this
estimation
of
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
we
go
and
see
Mrs
Micawber
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
I
said
,
to
get
Mr
Micawber
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
do
her
that
favour
,
Copperfield
,
"
replied
Mr
Micawber
,
rising
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
scruple
in
saying
,
in
the
presence
of
our
friends
here
,
that
I
am
a
man
who
has
,
for
some
years
,
contended
against
the
pressure
of
pecuniary
difficulties
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
knew
he
was
certain
to
say
something
of
this
kind
;
he
always
would
be
so
boastful
about
his
difficulties
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sometimes
I
have
risen
superior
to
my
difficulties
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
my
difficulties
have
---
in
short
,
have
floored
me
.
 
<EOS>
There
have
been
times
when
I
have
administered
a
succession
of
facers
to
them
;
there
have
been
times
when
they
have
been
too
many
for
me
,
and
I
have
given
in
,
and
said
to
Mrs
Micawber
,
in
the
words
of
Cato
,
"
Plato
,
thou
reasonest
well
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
all
up
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
show
fight
no
more
.
"
<EOS>
But
at
no
time
of
my
life
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
have
I
enjoyed
a
higher
degree
of
satisfaction
than
in
pouring
my
griefs
<EOS>
(
if
I
may
describe
difficulties
,
chiefly
arising
out
of
warrants
of
attorney
and
promissory
notes
at
two
and
four
months
,
by
that
word
)
into
the
bosom
of
my
friend
Copperfield
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
closed
this
handsome
tribute
by
saying
,
"
Mr
Heep
!
<EOS>
Good
evening
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Heep
!
 
<EOS>
Your
servant
,
"
and
then
walking
out
with
me
in
his
most
fashionable
manner
,
making
a
good
deal
of
noise
on
the
pavement
with
his
shoes
,
and
humming
a
tune
as
we
went
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
little
inn
where
Mr
Micawber
put
up
,
and
he
occupied
a
little
room
in
it
,
partitioned
off
from
the
commercial
room
,
and
strongly
flavoured
with
tobacco
-
smoke
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
it
was
over
the
kitchen
,
because
a
warm
greasy
smell
appeared
to
come
up
through
the
chinks
in
the
floor
,
and
there
was
a
flabby
perspiration
on
the
walls
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
it
was
near
the
bar
,
on
account
of
the
smell
of
spirits
and
jingling
of
glasses
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
recumbent
on
a
small
sofa
,
underneath
a
picture
of
a
race
-
horse
,
with
her
head
close
to
the
fire
,
and
her
feet
pushing
the
mustard
off
the
dumb
-
waiter
at
the
other
end
of
the
room
,
was
Mrs
Micawber
,
to
whom
Mr
Micawber
entered
first
,
saying
,
"
My
dear
,
allow
me
to
introduce
to
you
a
pupil
of
Doctor
Strong
's
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
noticed
,
by
the
by
,
that
although
Mr
Micawber
was
just
as
much
confused
as
ever
about
my
age
and
standing
,
he
always
remembered
,
as
a
genteel
thing
,
that
I
was
a
pupil
of
Doctor
Strong
's
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Micawber
was
amazed
,
but
very
glad
to
see
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
very
glad
to
see
her
too
,
and
,
after
an
affectionate
greeting
on
both
sides
,
sat
down
on
the
small
sofa
near
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
if
you
will
mention
to
Copperfield
what
our
present
position
is
,
which
I
have
no
doubt
he
will
like
to
know
,
I
will
go
and
look
at
the
paper
the
while
,
and
see
whether
anything
turns
up
among
the
advertisements
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
were
at
Plymouth
,
ma'am
,
"
I
said
to
Mrs
Micawber
,
as
he
went
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Master
Copperfield
,
"
she
replied
,
"
we
went
to
Plymouth
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
To
be
on
the
spot
,
"
I
hinted
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Just
so
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
be
on
the
spot
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
the
truth
is
,
talent
is
not
wanted
in
the
Custom
House
.
 
<EOS>
The
local
influence
of
my
family
was
quite
unavailing
to
obtain
any
employment
in
that
department
,
for
a
man
of
Mr
Micawber
's
abilities
.
 
<EOS>
They
would
rather
NOT
have
a
man
of
Mr
Micawber
's
abilities
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
only
show
the
deficiency
of
the
others
.
 
<EOS>
Apart
from
which
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
I
will
not
disguise
from
you
,
my
dear
Master
Copperfield
,
that
when
that
branch
of
my
family
which
is
settled
in
Plymouth
,
became
aware
that
Mr
Micawber
was
accompanied
by
myself
,
and
by
little
Wilkins
and
his
sister
,
and
by
the
twins
,
they
did
not
receive
him
with
that
ardour
which
he
might
have
expected
,
being
so
newly
released
from
captivity
.
 
<EOS>
In
fact
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
lowering
her
voice
,
<EOS>
---
"
this
is
between
ourselves
---
our
reception
was
cool
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
<EOS>
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
truly
painful
to
contemplate
mankind
in
such
an
aspect
,
Master
Copperfield
,
but
our
reception
was
,
decidedly
,
cool
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
doubt
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
In
fact
,
that
branch
of
my
family
which
is
settled
in
Plymouth
became
quite
personal
to
Mr
Micawber
,
before
we
had
been
there
a
week
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
,
and
thought
,
that
they
ought
to
be
ashamed
of
themselves
.
   
<EOS>
"
Still
,
so
it
was
,
"
continued
Mrs
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
"
Under
such
circumstances
,
what
could
a
man
of
Mr
Micawber
's
spirit
do
?
 
<EOS>
But
one
obvious
course
was
left
.
 
<EOS>
To
borrow
,
of
that
branch
of
my
family
,
the
money
to
return
to
London
,
and
to
return
at
any
sacrifice
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
all
came
back
again
,
ma'am
?
<EOS>
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
all
came
back
again
,
"
replied
Mrs
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
"
Since
then
,
I
have
consulted
other
branches
of
my
family
on
the
course
which
it
is
most
expedient
for
Mr
Micawber
to
take
---
for
I
maintain
that
he
must
take
some
course
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
argumentatively
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
clear
that
a
family
of
six
,
not
including
a
domestic
,
can
not
live
upon
air
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
ma'am
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
The
opinion
of
those
other
branches
of
my
family
,
"
pursued
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
is
,
that
Mr
Micawber
should
immediately
turn
his
attention
to
coals
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
what
,
ma'am
?
"
   
"
To
coals
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
the
coal
trade
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
was
induced
to
think
,
on
inquiry
,
that
there
might
be
an
opening
for
a
man
of
his
talent
in
the
Medway
Coal
Trade
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
as
Mr
Micawber
very
properly
said
,
the
first
step
to
be
taken
clearly
was
,
to
come
and
see
the
Medway
.
 
<EOS>
Which
we
came
and
saw
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
"
we
"
,
Master
Copperfield
;
for
I
never
will
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
with
emotion
,
"
I
never
will
desert
Mr
Micawber
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
murmured
my
admiration
and
approbation
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
came
,
"
repeated
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
and
saw
the
Medway
.
 
<EOS>
My
opinion
of
the
coal
trade
on
that
river
is
,
that
it
may
require
talent
,
but
that
it
certainly
requires
capital
.
 
<EOS>
Talent
,
Mr
Micawber
has
;
capital
,
Mr
Micawber
has
not
.
 
<EOS>
We
saw
,
I
think
,
the
greater
part
of
the
Medway
;
and
that
is
my
individual
conclusion
.
 
<EOS>
Being
so
near
here
,
Mr
Micawber
was
of
opinion
that
it
would
be
rash
not
to
come
on
,
and
see
the
Cathedral
.
 
<EOS>
Firstly
,
on
account
of
its
being
so
well
worth
seeing
,
and
our
never
having
seen
it
;
and
secondly
,
on
account
of
the
great
probability
of
something
turning
up
in
a
cathedral
town
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
been
here
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
three
days
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
has
,
as
yet
,
turned
up
;
and
it
may
not
surprise
you
,
my
dear
Master
Copperfield
,
so
much
as
it
would
a
stranger
,
to
know
that
we
are
at
present
waiting
for
a
remittance
from
London
,
to
discharge
our
pecuniary
obligations
at
this
hotel
.
 
<EOS>
Until
the
arrival
of
that
remittance
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
with
much
feeling
,
"
I
am
cut
off
from
my
home
<EOS>
(
I
allude
to
lodgings
in
Pentonville
)
,
from
my
boy
and
girl
,
and
from
my
twins
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
the
utmost
sympathy
for
Mr
and
Mrs
Micawber
in
this
anxious
extremity
,
and
said
as
much
to
Mr
Micawber
,
who
now
returned
:
adding
that
I
only
wished
I
had
money
enough
,
to
lend
them
the
amount
they
needed
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
's
answer
expressed
the
disturbance
of
his
mind
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
,
shaking
hands
with
me
,
"
Copperfield
,
you
are
a
true
friend
;
but
when
the
worst
comes
to
the
worst
,
no
man
is
without
a
friend
who
is
possessed
of
shaving
materials
.
"
 
<EOS>
At
this
dreadful
hint
Mrs
Micawber
threw
her
arms
round
Mr
Micawber
's
neck
and
entreated
him
to
be
calm
.
 
<EOS>
He
wept
;
but
so
far
recovered
,
almost
immediately
,
as
to
ring
the
bell
for
the
waiter
,
and
bespeak
a
hot
kidney
pudding
and
a
plate
of
shrimps
for
breakfast
in
the
morning
.
   
<EOS>
When
I
took
my
leave
of
them
,
they
both
pressed
me
so
much
to
come
and
dine
before
they
went
away
,
that
I
could
not
refuse
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
I
knew
I
could
not
come
next
day
,
when
I
should
have
a
good
deal
to
prepare
in
the
evening
,
Mr
Micawber
arranged
that
he
would
call
at
Doctor
Strong
's
in
the
course
of
the
morning
(
having
a
presentiment
that
the
remittance
would
arrive
by
that
post
)
,
and
propose
the
day
after
,
if
it
would
suit
me
better
.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
I
was
called
out
of
school
next
forenoon
,
and
found
Mr
Micawber
in
the
parlour
;
who
had
called
to
say
that
the
dinner
would
take
place
as
proposed
.
<EOS>
When
I
asked
him
if
the
remittance
had
come
,
he
pressed
my
hand
and
departed
.
   
<EOS>
As
I
was
looking
out
of
window
that
same
evening
,
it
surprised
me
,
and
made
me
rather
uneasy
,
to
see
Mr
Micawber
and
Uriah
Heep
walk
past
,
arm
in
arm
:
<EOS>
Uriah
humbly
sensible
of
the
honour
that
was
done
him
,
and
Mr
Micawber
taking
a
bland
delight
in
extending
his
patronage
to
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
was
still
more
surprised
,
when
I
went
to
the
little
hotel
next
day
at
the
appointed
dinner
-
hour
,
which
was
four
o'clock
,
to
find
,
from
what
Mr
Micawber
said
,
that
he
had
gone
home
with
Uriah
,
and
had
drunk
brandy
-
and
-
water
at
Mrs
Heep
's
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
'll
tell
you
<EOS>
what
,
my
dear
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
<EOS>
your
friend
Heep
is
a
young
fellow
who
might
be
attorney
-
general
.
<EOS>
If
I
had
known
that
young
man
,
at
the
period
when
my
difficulties
came
to
a
crisis
,
all
I
can
say
is
,
that
I
believe
my
creditors
would
have
been
a
great
deal
better
managed
than
they
were
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
hardly
understood
how
this
could
have
been
,
seeing
that
Mr
Micawber
had
paid
them
nothing
at
all
as
it
was
;
but
I
did
not
like
to
ask
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
did
I
like
to
say
,
that
I
hoped
he
had
not
been
too
communicative
to
Uriah
;
or
to
inquire
if
they
had
talked
much
about
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
afraid
of
hurting
Mr
Micawber
's
feelings
,
or
,
at
all
events
,
Mrs
Micawber
's
,
she
being
very
sensitive
;
but
I
was
uncomfortable
about
it
,
too
,
and
often
thought
about
it
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
We
had
a
beautiful
little
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
Quite
an
elegant
dish
of
fish
;
the
kidney
-
end
of
a
loin
of
veal
,
roasted
;
fried
sausage
-
meat
;
a
partridge
,
and
a
pudding
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
wine
,
and
there
was
strong
ale
;
and
after
dinner
Mrs
Micawber
made
us
a
bowl
of
hot
punch
with
her
own
hands
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
was
uncommonly
convivial
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
saw
him
such
good
company
.
 
<EOS>
He
made
his
face
shine
with
the
punch
,
so
that
it
looked
as
if
it
had
been
varnished
all
over
.
 
<EOS>
He
got
cheerfully
sentimental
about
the
town
,
and
proposed
success
to
it
;
observing
that
Mrs
Micawber
and
himself
had
been
made
extremely
snug
and
comfortable
there
and
that
he
never
should
forget
the
agreeable
hours
they
had
passed
in
Canterbury
.
 
<EOS>
He
proposed
me
afterwards
;
and
he
,
and
Mrs
Micawber
,
and
I
,
took
a
review
of
our
past
acquaintance
,
in
the
course
of
which
we
sold
the
property
all
over
again
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
proposed
Mrs
Micawber
:
or
,
at
least
,
said
,
modestly
,
"
If
you
'll
allow
me
,
Mrs
Micawber
,
I
shall
now
have
the
pleasure
of
drinking
your
health
,
ma'am
.
"
 
<EOS>
On
which
Mr
Micawber
delivered
an
eulogium
on
Mrs
Micawber
's
character
,
and
said
she
had
ever
been
his
guide
,
philosopher
,
and
friend
,
and
that
he
would
recommend
me
,
when
I
came
to
a
marrying
time
of
life
,
to
marry
such
another
woman
,
if
such
another
woman
could
be
found
.
   
<EOS>
As
the
punch
disappeared
,
Mr
Micawber
became
still
more
friendly
and
convivial
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Micawber
's
spirits
becoming
elevated
,
too
,
we
sang
"
Auld
Lang
Syne
"
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
came
to
<EOS>
"
Here
's
a
hand
,
my
trusty
frere
"
,
we
all
joined
hands
round
the
table
;
and
when
we
declared
we
would
"
take
a
right
gude
Willie
Waught
"
,
and
had
n't
the
least
idea
<EOS>
what
it
meant
,
we
were
really
affected
.
   
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
I
never
saw
anybody
so
thoroughly
jovial
as
Mr
Micawber
was
,
down
to
the
very
last
moment
of
the
evening
,
when
I
took
a
hearty
farewell
of
himself
and
his
amiable
wife
.
 
<EOS>
Consequently
,
I
was
not
prepared
,
at
seven
o'clock
next
morning
,
to
receive
the
following
communication
,
dated
half
past
nine
in
the
evening
;
a
quarter
of
an
hour
after
I
had
left
him
:
---
   
<EOS>
"
My
DEAR
YOUNG
FRIEND
,
"
   
"
The
die
is
cast
---
all
is
over
.
 
<EOS>
Hiding
the
ravages
of
care
with
a
sickly
mask
of
mirth
,
I
have
not
informed
you
,
this
evening
,
that
there
is
no
hope
of
the
remittance
!
 
<EOS>
Under
these
circumstances
,
alike
humiliating
to
endure
,
humiliating
to
contemplate
,
and
humiliating
to
relate
,
I
have
discharged
the
pecuniary
liability
contracted
at
this
establishment
,
by
giving
a
note
of
hand
,
made
payable
fourteen
days
after
date
,
at
my
residence
,
Pentonville
,
London
.
 
<EOS>
When
it
becomes
due
,
it
will
not
be
taken
up
.
 
<EOS>
The
result
is
destruction
.
 
<EOS>
The
bolt
is
impending
,
and
the
tree
must
fall
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let
the
wretched
man
who
now
addresses
you
,
my
dear
Copperfield
,
be
a
beacon
to
you
through
life
.
 
<EOS>
He
writes
with
that
intention
,
and
in
that
hope
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
could
think
himself
of
so
much
use
,
one
gleam
of
day
might
,
by
possibility
,
penetrate
into
the
cheerless
dungeon
of
his
remaining
existence
---
though
his
longevity
is
,
at
present
(
to
say
the
least
of
it
)
,
extremely
problematical
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
last
communication
,
my
dear
Copperfield
,
you
will
ever
receive
"
   
"
From
"
   
"
The
"
   
"
Beggared
Outcast
,
"
   
"
WILKINS
MICAWBER
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
so
shocked
by
the
contents
of
this
heart
-
rending
letter
,
that
I
ran
off
directly
towards
the
little
hotel
with
the
intention
of
taking
it
on
my
way
to
Doctor
Strong
's
,
and
trying
to
soothe
Mr
Micawber
with
a
word
of
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
half
-
way
there
,
I
met
the
London
coach
with
Mr
and
Mrs
Micawber
up
behind
;
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
,
the
very
picture
of
tranquil
enjoyment
,
smiling
at
Mrs
Micawber
's
conversation
,
eating
walnuts
out
of
a
paper
bag
,
with
a
bottle
sticking
out
of
his
breast
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
did
not
see
me
,
I
thought
it
best
,
all
things
considered
,
not
to
see
them
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
with
a
great
weight
taken
off
my
mind
<EOS>
,
I
turned
into
a
by
-
street
that
was
the
nearest
way
to
school
,
and
felt
,
upon
the
whole
,
relieved
that
they
were
gone
;
though
I
still
liked
them
very
much
,
nevertheless
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
18
.
<EOS>
A
retrospect
 
<EOS>
My
school
-
days
!
 
<EOS>
The
silent
gliding
on
of
my
existence
---
the
unseen
,
unfelt
progress
of
my
life
---
from
childhood
up
to
youth
!
<EOS>
Let
me
think
,
as
I
look
back
upon
that
flowing
water
,
now
a
dry
channel
overgrown
with
leaves
,
whether
there
are
any
marks
along
its
course
,
by
which
I
can
remember
how
it
ran
.
   
<EOS>
A
moment
,
and
I
occupy
my
place
in
the
Cathedral
,
where
we
all
went
together
,
every
Sunday
morning
,
assembling
first
at
school
for
that
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
The
earthy
smell
,
the
sunless
air
,
the
sensation
of
the
world
being
shut
out
,
the
resounding
of
the
organ
through
the
black
and
white
arched
galleries
and
aisles
,
are
wings
that
take
me
back
,
and
hold
me
hovering
above
those
days
,
in
a
half
-
sleeping
and
half
-
waking
dream
.
   
<EOS>
I
am
not
the
last
boy
in
the
school
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
risen
in
a
few
months
,
over
several
heads
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
first
boy
seems
to
me
a
mighty
creature
,
dwelling
afar
off
,
whose
giddy
height
is
unattainable
.
<EOS>
Agnes
says
"
No
,
"
but
I
say
"
Yes
,
"
and
tell
her
that
she
little
thinks
what
stores
of
knowledge
have
been
mastered
by
the
wonderful
Being
,
at
whose
place
she
thinks
I
,
even
I
,
weak
aspirant
,
may
arrive
in
time
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
not
my
private
friend
and
public
patron
,
as
Steerforth
was
,
but
I
hold
him
in
a
reverential
respect
.
 
<EOS>
I
chiefly
wonder
what
he
'll
be
,
when
he
leaves
Doctor
Strong
's
,
and
what
mankind
will
do
to
maintain
any
place
against
him
.
   
<EOS>
But
who
is
this
that
breaks
upon
me
?
 
<EOS>
This
is
Miss
Shepherd
,
whom
I
love
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Shepherd
is
a
boarder
at
the
Misses
Nettingalls
'
establishment
.
 
<EOS>
I
adore
Miss
Shepherd
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
a
little
girl
,
in
a
spencer
,
with
a
round
face
and
curly
flaxen
hair
.
 
<EOS>
The
Misses
Nettingalls
'
young
ladies
come
to
the
Cathedral
too
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
look
upon
my
book
,
<EOS>
for
I
must
look
upon
Miss
Shepherd
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
choristers
chaunt
,
I
hear
Miss
Shepherd
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
service
I
mentally
insert
Miss
Shepherd
's
name
---
I
put
her
in
among
the
Royal
Family
.
<EOS>
At
home
,
in
my
own
room
,
I
am
sometimes
moved
to
cry
out
,
"
Oh
,
Miss
Shepherd
!
"
<EOS>
in
a
transport
of
love
.
   
<EOS>
For
some
time
,
I
am
doubtful
of
Miss
Shepherd
's
feelings
,
but
,
at
length
,
Fate
being
propitious
,
we
meet
at
the
dancing
-
school
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
Miss
Shepherd
for
my
partner
.
 
<EOS>
I
touch
Miss
Shepherd
's
glove
,
and
feel
a
thrill
go
up
the
right
arm
of
my
jacket
,
and
come
out
at
my
hair
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
nothing
to
Miss
Shepherd
,
but
we
understand
each
other
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Shepherd
and
myself
live
but
to
be
united
.
   
<EOS>
Why
do
I
secretly
give
Miss
Shepherd
twelve
Brazil
nuts
for
a
present
,
I
wonder
?
 
<EOS>
They
are
not
expressive
of
affection
,
they
are
difficult
to
pack
into
a
parcel
of
any
regular
shape
,
they
are
hard
to
crack
,
even
in
room
doors
,
and
they
are
oily
when
cracked
;
yet
I
feel
that
they
are
appropriate
to
Miss
Shepherd
.
 
<EOS>
Soft
,
seedy
biscuits
,
also
,
I
bestow
upon
Miss
Shepherd
;
and
oranges
innumerable
.
 
<EOS>
Once
,
I
kiss
Miss
Shepherd
in
the
cloak
-
room
.
<EOS>
Ecstasy
!
 
<EOS>
What
are
my
agony
and
indignation
next
day
,
when
I
hear
a
flying
rumour
that
the
Misses
Nettingall
have
stood
Miss
Shepherd
in
the
stocks
for
turning
in
her
toes
!
   
<EOS>
Miss
Shepherd
being
the
one
pervading
theme
and
vision
of
my
life
,
how
do
I
ever
come
to
break
with
her
?
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
conceive
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
a
coolness
grows
between
Miss
Shepherd
and
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Whispers
reach
me
of
Miss
Shepherd
having
said
she
wished
I
would
n't
stare
so
,
and
having
avowed
a
preference
for
Master
Jones
---
for
Jones
!
<EOS>
a
boy
of
no
merit
whatever
!
 
<EOS>
The
gulf
between
me
and
Miss
Shepherd
widens
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
one
day
,
I
meet
the
Misses
Nettingalls
'
establishment
out
walking
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Shepherd
makes
a
face
as
she
goes
by
,
and
laughs
to
her
companion
.
 
<EOS>
All
is
over
.
 
<EOS>
The
devotion
of
a
life
---
it
seems
a
life
<EOS>
,
it
is
all
the
same
---
is
at
an
end
;
Miss
Shepherd
comes
out
of
the
morning
service
,
and
the
Royal
Family
know
her
no
more
.
   
<EOS>
I
am
higher
in
the
school
,
and
no
one
breaks
my
peace
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
at
all
polite
,
now
,
to
the
Misses
Nettingalls
'
young
ladies
,
and
should
n't
dote
on
any
of
them
,
if
they
were
twice
as
many
and
twenty
times
as
beautiful
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
the
dancing
-
school
a
tiresome
affair
,
and
wonder
why
the
girls
ca
n't
dance
by
themselves
and
leave
us
alone
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
growing
great
in
Latin
verses
,
and
neglect
the
laces
of
my
boots
.
 
<EOS>
Doctor
Strong
refers
to
me
in
public
as
a
promising
young
scholar
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
is
wild
with
joy
,
and
my
aunt
remits
me
a
guinea
by
the
next
post
.
   
<EOS>
The
shade
of
a
young
butcher
rises
,
like
the
apparition
of
an
armed
head
in
Macbeth
.
 
<EOS>
Who
is
this
young
butcher
?
 
<EOS>
He
is
the
terror
of
the
youth
of
Canterbury
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
vague
belief
abroad
,
that
the
beef
suet
with
which
he
anoints
his
hair
gives
him
unnatural
strength
,
and
that
he
is
a
match
for
a
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
broad
-
faced
,
bull
-
necked
,
young
butcher
,
with
rough
red
cheeks
,
an
ill
-
conditioned
mind
,
and
an
injurious
tongue
.
 
<EOS>
His
main
use
of
this
tongue
,
is
,
to
disparage
Doctor
Strong
's
young
gentlemen
.
 
<EOS>
He
says
,
publicly
,
that
if
they
want
anything
he
'll
give
it
'em
.
 
<EOS>
He
names
individuals
among
them
(
myself
included
)
,
whom
he
could
undertake
to
settle
with
one
hand
,
and
the
other
tied
behind
him
.
<EOS>
He
waylays
the
smaller
boys
to
punch
their
unprotected
heads
,
and
calls
challenges
after
me
in
the
open
streets
.
 
<EOS>
For
these
sufficient
reasons
I
resolve
to
fight
the
butcher
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
a
summer
evening
,
down
in
a
green
hollow
,
at
the
corner
of
a
wall
.
 
<EOS>
I
meet
the
butcher
by
appointment
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
attended
by
a
select
body
of
our
boys
;
the
butcher
,
by
two
other
butchers
,
a
young
publican
,
and
a
sweep
.
 
<EOS>
The
preliminaries
are
adjusted
,
and
the
butcher
and
myself
stand
face
to
face
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
moment
the
butcher
lights
ten
thousand
candles
out
of
my
left
eyebrow
.
 
<EOS>
In
another
moment
,
I
do
n't
know
where
the
wall
is
,
or
where
I
am
,
or
where
anybody
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
hardly
know
which
is
myself
and
which
the
butcher
,
we
are
always
in
such
a
tangle
and
tussle
,
knocking
about
upon
the
trodden
grass
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
I
see
the
butcher
,
bloody
but
confident
;
sometimes
I
see
nothing
,
and
sit
gasping
on
my
second
's
knee
;
sometimes
I
go
in
at
the
butcher
madly
,
and
cut
my
knuckles
open
against
his
face
,
without
appearing
to
discompose
him
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
I
awake
,
very
queer
about
the
head
,
as
from
a
giddy
sleep
,
and
see
the
butcher
walking
off
,
congratulated
by
the
two
other
butchers
and
the
sweep
and
publican
,
and
putting
on
his
coat
as
he
goes
;
from
which
I
augur
,
justly
,
that
the
victory
is
his
.
   
<EOS>
I
am
taken
home
in
a
sad
plight
,
and
I
have
beef
-
steaks
put
to
my
eyes
,
and
am
rubbed
with
vinegar
and
brandy
,
and
find
a
great
puffy
place
bursting
out
on
my
upper
lip
,
which
swells
immoderately
.
 
<EOS>
For
three
or
four
days
I
remain
at
home
,
a
very
ill
-
looking
subject
,
with
a
green
shade
over
my
eyes
;
and
I
should
be
very
dull
,
but
that
Agnes
is
a
sister
to
me
,
and
condoles
with
me
,
and
reads
to
me
,
and
makes
the
time
light
and
happy
.
 
<EOS>
Agnes
has
my
confidence
completely
,
always
;
I
tell
her
all
about
the
butcher
,
and
the
wrongs
he
has
heaped
upon
me
;
she
thinks
I
could
n't
have
done
otherwise
than
fight
the
butcher
,
while
she
shrinks
and
trembles
at
my
having
fought
him
.
   
<EOS>
Time
has
stolen
on
unobserved
,
for
Adams
is
not
the
head
-
boy
in
the
days
that
are
come
now
,
nor
has
he
been
this
many
and
many
a
day
.
<EOS>
Adams
has
left
the
school
so
long
,
that
when
he
comes
back
,
on
a
visit
to
Doctor
Strong
,
there
are
not
many
there
,
besides
myself
,
who
know
him
.
 
<EOS>
Adams
is
going
to
be
called
to
the
bar
almost
directly
,
and
is
to
be
an
advocate
,
and
to
wear
a
wig
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
surprised
to
find
him
a
meeker
man
than
I
had
thought
,
and
less
imposing
in
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
not
staggered
the
world
yet
,
either
;
for
it
goes
on
(
as
well
as
I
can
make
out
)
pretty
much
the
same
as
if
he
had
never
joined
it
.
   
<EOS>
A
blank
,
through
which
the
warriors
of
poetry
and
history
march
on
in
stately
hosts
that
seem
to
have
no
end
---
and
what
comes
next
!
<EOS>
I
am
the
head
-
boy
,
now
!
 
<EOS>
I
look
down
on
the
line
of
boys
below
me
,
with
a
condescending
interest
in
such
of
them
as
bring
to
my
mind
<EOS>
the
boy
<EOS>
I
was
myself
,
when
I
first
came
there
.
 
<EOS>
That
little
fellow
seems
to
be
no
part
of
me
;
I
remember
him
as
something
left
behind
upon
the
road
of
life
---
as
something
I
have
passed
,
rather
than
have
actually
been
---
and
almost
think
of
him
as
of
someone
else
.
   
<EOS>
And
the
little
girl
I
saw
on
that
first
day
at
Mr
Wickfield
's
,
where
is
she
?
 
<EOS>
Gone
also
.
 
<EOS>
In
her
stead
,
the
perfect
likeness
of
the
picture
,
a
child
likeness
no
more
,
moves
about
the
house
;
and
Agnes
---
my
sweet
sister
,
as
I
call
her
in
my
thoughts
,
my
counsellor
and
friend
,
the
better
angel
of
the
lives
of
all
who
come
within
her
calm
,
good
,
self
-
denying
influence
---
is
quite
a
woman
.
   
<EOS>
What
other
changes
have
come
upon
me
,
besides
the
changes
in
my
growth
and
looks
,
and
in
the
knowledge
I
have
garnered
all
this
while
?
 
<EOS>
I
wear
a
gold
watch
and
chain
,
a
ring
upon
my
little
finger
,
and
a
long
-
tailed
coat
;
and
I
use
a
great
deal
of
bear
's
grease
---
which
,
taken
in
conjunction
with
the
ring
,
looks
bad
.
 
<EOS>
Am
I
in
love
again
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
I
worship
the
eldest
Miss
Larkins
.
   
<EOS>
The
eldest
Miss
Larkins
is
not
a
little
girl
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
a
tall
,
dark
,
black
-
eyed
,
fine
figure
of
a
woman
.
 
<EOS>
The
eldest
Miss
Larkins
is
not
a
chicken
;
for
the
youngest
Miss
Larkins
is
not
that
,
and
the
eldest
must
be
three
or
four
years
older
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
the
eldest
Miss
Larkins
may
be
about
thirty
.
 
<EOS>
My
passion
for
her
is
beyond
all
bounds
.
   
<EOS>
The
eldest
Miss
Larkins
knows
officers
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
an
awful
thing
to
bear
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
them
speaking
to
her
in
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
them
cross
the
way
to
meet
her
,
<EOS>
when
her
bonnet
(
she
has
a
bright
taste
in
bonnets
)
is
seen
coming
down
the
pavement
,
accompanied
by
her
sister
's
bonnet
.
 
<EOS>
She
laughs
and
talks
,
and
seems
to
like
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
spend
a
good
deal
of
my
own
spare
time
in
walking
up
and
down
to
meet
her
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
can
bow
to
her
once
in
the
day
<EOS>
(
I
know
her
to
bow
to
,
knowing
Mr
Larkins
)
,
I
am
happier
.
 
<EOS>
I
deserve
a
bow
now
and
then
.
 
<EOS>
The
raging
agonies
I
suffer
on
the
night
of
the
Race
Ball
,
where
I
know
the
eldest
Miss
Larkins
will
be
dancing
with
the
military
,
ought
to
have
some
compensation
,
if
there
be
even
-
handed
justice
in
the
world
.
   
<EOS>
My
passion
takes
away
my
appetite
,
and
makes
me
wear
my
newest
silk
neckerchief
continually
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
relief
<EOS>
but
in
putting
on
my
best
clothes
,
and
having
my
boots
cleaned
over
and
over
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
seem
,
then
,
to
be
worthier
of
the
eldest
Miss
Larkins
.
 
<EOS>
Everything
that
belongs
to
her
,
or
is
connected
with
her
,
is
precious
to
me
.
<EOS>
Mr
Larkins
(
a
gruff
old
gentleman
with
a
double
chin
,
and
one
of
his
eyes
immovable
in
his
head
)
is
fraught
with
interest
to
me
.
<EOS>
When
I
ca
n't
meet
his
daughter
,
I
go
where
I
am
likely
to
meet
him
.
<EOS>
To
say
"
How
do
you
do
,
Mr
Larkins
?
 
<EOS>
Are
the
young
ladies
and
all
the
family
quite
well
?
<EOS>
"
seems
so
pointed
,
that
I
blush
.
   
<EOS>
I
think
continually
about
my
age
.
 
<EOS>
Say
I
am
seventeen
,
and
say
that
seventeen
is
young
for
the
eldest
Miss
Larkins
,
what
of
that
?
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
shall
be
one
-
and
-
twenty
in
no
time
almost
.
 
<EOS>
I
regularly
take
walks
outside
Mr
Larkins
's
house
in
the
evening
,
though
it
cuts
me
to
the
heart
to
see
the
officers
go
in
,
or
to
hear
them
up
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
where
the
eldest
Miss
Larkins
plays
the
harp
.
<EOS>
I
even
walk
,
on
two
or
three
occasions
,
in
a
sickly
,
spoony
manner
,
round
and
round
the
house
after
the
family
are
gone
to
bed
,
wondering
which
is
the
eldest
Miss
Larkins
's
chamber
(
and
pitching
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
now
,
on
Mr
Larkins
's
instead
)
;
wishing
that
a
fire
would
burst
out
;
that
the
assembled
crowd
would
stand
appalled
;
that
I
,
dashing
through
them
with
a
ladder
,
might
rear
it
against
her
window
,
save
her
in
my
arms
,
go
back
for
something
she
had
left
behind
,
and
perish
in
the
flames
.
 
<EOS>
For
I
am
generally
disinterested
in
my
love
,
and
think
I
could
be
content
to
make
a
figure
before
Miss
Larkins
,
and
expire
.
   
<EOS>
Generally
,
but
not
always
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
brighter
visions
rise
before
me
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
dress
(
the
occupation
of
two
hours
)
,
for
a
great
ball
given
at
the
Larkins
's
(
the
anticipation
of
three
weeks
)
,
I
indulge
my
fancy
with
pleasing
images
.
 
<EOS>
I
picture
myself
taking
courage
to
make
a
declaration
to
Miss
Larkins
.
 
<EOS>
I
picture
Miss
Larkins
sinking
her
head
upon
my
shoulder
,
and
saying
,
"
Oh
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
can
I
believe
my
ears
!
<EOS>
"
I
picture
Mr
Larkins
waiting
on
me
next
morning
,
and
saying
,
"
My
dear
Copperfield
,
my
daughter
has
told
me
all
.
<EOS>
Youth
is
no
objection
.
 
<EOS>
Here
are
twenty
thousand
pounds
.
 
<EOS>
Be
happy
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I
picture
my
aunt
relenting
,
and
blessing
us
;
and
Mr
Dick
and
Doctor
Strong
being
present
at
the
marriage
ceremony
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
a
sensible
fellow
<EOS>
,
I
believe
---
I
believe
,
on
looking
back
,
I
mean
---
<EOS>
and
modest
I
am
sure
;
but
all
this
goes
on
notwithstanding
.
<EOS>
I
repair
to
the
enchanted
house
,
where
there
are
lights
,
chattering
,
music
,
flowers
,
officers
<EOS>
(
I
am
sorry
to
see
)
,
and
the
eldest
Miss
Larkins
,
a
blaze
of
beauty
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
dressed
in
blue
,
with
blue
flowers
in
her
hair
---
<EOS>
forget
-
me
-
nots
---
as
if
SHE
had
any
need
to
wear
forget
-
me
-
nots
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
first
really
grown
-
up
party
that
I
have
ever
been
invited
to
,
and
I
am
a
little
uncomfortable
;
for
I
appear
not
to
belong
to
anybody
,
and
nobody
appears
to
have
anything
to
say
to
me
,
except
Mr
Larkins
,
who
asks
me
how
my
schoolfellows
are
,
which
he
need
n't
do
,
as
I
have
not
come
there
to
be
insulted
.
   
<EOS>
But
after
I
have
stood
in
the
doorway
for
some
time
,
and
feasted
my
eyes
upon
the
goddess
of
my
heart
,
she
approaches
me
---
she
,
the
eldest
Miss
Larkins
!
---
and
asks
me
pleasantly
,
if
I
dance
?
   
<EOS>
I
stammer
,
with
a
bow
,
"
With
you
,
Miss
Larkins
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
no
one
else
?
"
inquires
Miss
Larkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
no
pleasure
in
dancing
with
anyone
else
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Larkins
laughs
and
blushes
(
or
I
think
she
blushes
)
,
and
says
,
"
Next
time
but
one
,
I
shall
be
very
glad
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
time
arrives
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
waltz
,
I
think
,
"
Miss
Larkins
doubtfully
observes
,
when
I
present
myself
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
waltz
?
 
<EOS>
If
not
,
Captain
Bailey
---
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
But
I
do
waltz
(
pretty
well
,
too
,
as
it
happens
)
,
and
I
take
Miss
Larkins
out
.
 
<EOS>
I
take
her
sternly
from
the
side
of
Captain
Bailey
.
<EOS>
He
is
wretched
<EOS>
,
I
have
no
doubt
;
but
he
is
nothing
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
wretched
,
too
.
 
<EOS>
I
waltz
with
the
eldest
Miss
Larkins
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
where
,
among
whom
,
or
how
long
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
know
that
I
swim
about
in
space
,
with
a
blue
angel
,
in
a
state
of

,
until
I
find
myself
alone
with
her
in
a
little
room
,
resting
on
a
sofa
.
<EOS>
She
admires
a
flower
(
pink
camellia
japonica
,
price
half
-
a
-
crown
)
,
in
my
button
-
hole
.
 
<EOS>
I
give
it
her
,
and
say
:
   
"
I
ask
an
inestimable
price
for
it
,
Miss
Larkins
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Indeed
!
 
<EOS>
What
is
that
?
<EOS>
"
returns
Miss
Larkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
flower
of
yours
,
that
I
may
treasure
it
as
a
miser
does
gold
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
bold
boy
,
"
says
Miss
Larkins
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
gives
it
me
,
not
displeased
;
and
I
put
it
to
my
lips
,
and
then
into
my
breast
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Larkins
,
laughing
,
draws
her
hand
through
my
arm
,
and
says
,
"
Now
take
me
back
to
Captain
Bailey
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
am
lost
in
the
recollection
of
this
delicious
interview
,
and
the
waltz
,
when
she
comes

me
again
,
with
a
plain
elderly
gentleman
who
has
been
playing
whist
all
night
,
upon
her

,
and
says
:
   
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
here
is
my
bold
friend
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chestle
wants
to
know
you
,
Mr
Copperfield
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
feel
at
once
that
he
is
a
friend
of
the
family
,
and
am
much

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
admire
your
taste
,
sir
,
"
says
Mr
Chestle
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
does
you
credit
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
do
n't
take
much
interest
in
hops
;
but
I
am
a
pretty
large
grower
myself
;
and
if
you
ever
like
to
come
over
to
our
neighbourhood
---
neighbourhood
of
Ashford
---
and
take
a
run
about
our
place
,
---
we
shall
be
glad
for
you
to
stop
as
long
as
you
like
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
thank
Mr
Chestle
warmly
,
and
shake
hands
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
am
in
a
happy
dream
.
 
<EOS>
I
waltz
with
the
eldest
Miss
Larkins
once
again
.
 
<EOS>
She
says
I
waltz
so
well
!
 
<EOS>
I
go
home
in
a
state
of
unspeakable
bliss
,
and
waltz
in
imagination
,
all
night
long
,
with
my
arm
round
the
blue
waist
of
my
dear
divinity
.
 
<EOS>
For
some
days
afterwards
,
I
am
lost
in
rapturous
reflections
;
but
I
neither
see
her
in
the
street
,
nor
when
I
call
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
imperfectly
consoled
for
this
disappointment
by
the
sacred
pledge
,
the
perished
flower
.
   
<EOS>
"
Trotwood
,
"
says
Agnes
,
one
day
after

.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
do
you
think
is
going
to
be
married
tomorrow
?
 
<EOS>
Someone
you
admire
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
you
,
I
suppose
,
Agnes
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
me
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
raising
her
cheerful
face
from
the
music
she
is
copying
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
hear
him
,
Papa
?
---
The
eldest
Miss
Larkins
.
"
   
"
To
---
to
Captain
Bailey
?
<EOS>
"
I
have
just
enough
power
to
ask
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
;
to
no
Captain
.
 
<EOS>
To
Mr
Chestle
,
a
hop
-
grower
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
am
terribly
dejected
for
about
a
week
or
two
.
 
<EOS>
I
take
off
my
ring
<EOS>
,
I
wear
my
worst
clothes
,
I
use
no
bear
's
grease
,
and
I
frequently
lament
over
the
late
Miss
Larkins
's
faded
flower
.
<EOS>
Being
,
by
that
time
,
rather
tired
of
this
kind
of
life
,
and
having
received
new
provocation
from
the
butcher
,
I
throw
the
flower
away
,
go
out
with
the
butcher
,
and
gloriously
defeat
him
.
   
<EOS>
This
,
and
the
resumption
of
my
ring
,
as
well
as
of
the
bear
's
grease
in
moderation
,
are
the
last
marks
I
can
discern
,
now
,
in
my
progress
to
seventeen
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
19
.
<EOS>
I
look
about
me
,
and
make
a
discovery
 
I
am
doubtful
whether
I
was
at
heart
glad
or
sorry
,
when
my
school
-
days
drew
to
an
end
,
and
the
time
came
for
my
leaving
Doctor
Strong
's
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
been
very
happy
there
,
I
had
a
great
attachment
for
the
Doctor
,
and
I
was
eminent
and
distinguished
in
that
little
world
.
 
<EOS>
For
these
reasons
I
was
sorry
to
go
;
but
for
other
reasons
,
unsubstantial
enough
,
I
was
glad
.
 
<EOS>
Misty
ideas
of
being
a
young
man
at
my
own
disposal
,
of
the
importance
attaching
to
a
young
man
at
his
own
disposal
,
of
the
wonderful
things
to
be
seen
and
done
by
that
magnificent
animal
,
and
the
wonderful
effects
he
could
not
fail
to
make
upon
society
,
lured
me
away
.
 
<EOS>
So
powerful
were
these
visionary
considerations
in
my
boyish
mind
,
that
I
seem
,
according
to
my
present
way
of
thinking
,
to
have
left
school
without
natural
regret
.
 
<EOS>
The
separation
has
not
made
the
impression
on
me
,
that
other
separations
have
.
 
<EOS>
I
try
in
vain
to
recall
how
I
felt
about
it
,
and
what
its
circumstances
were
;
but
it
is
not
momentous
in
my
recollection
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
the
opening
prospect
confused
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
that
my
juvenile
experiences
went
for
little
or
nothing
then
;
and
that
life
was
more
like
a
great
fairy
story
,
which
I
was
just
about
to
begin
to
read
,
than
anything
else
.
   
<EOS>
MY
aunt
<EOS>
and
I
had
held
many
grave
deliberations
on
the
calling
to
which
I
should
be
devoted
.
 
<EOS>
For
a
year
or
more
I
had
endeavoured
to
find
a
satisfactory
answer
to
her
often
-
repeated
question
,
"
What
I
would
like
to
be
?
"
 
<EOS>
But
I
had
no
particular
liking
,
that
I
could
discover
,
for
anything
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
could
have
been
inspired
with
a
knowledge
of
the
science
of
navigation
,
taken
the
command
of
a
fast
-
sailing
expedition
,
and
gone
round
the
world
on
a
triumphant
voyage
of
discovery
,
I
think
I
might
have
considered
myself
completely
suited
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
in
the
absence
of
any
such
miraculous
provision
,
my
desire
was
to
apply
myself
to
some
pursuit
that
would
not
lie
too
heavily
upon
her
purse
;
and
to
do
my
duty
in
it
,
whatever
it
might
be
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
had
regularly
assisted
at
our
councils
,
with
a
meditative
and
sage
demeanour
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
made
a
suggestion
but
once
;
and
on
that
occasion
(
I
do
n't
know
what
put
it
in
his
head
)
<EOS>
,
he
suddenly
proposed
that
I
should
be
"
a
Brazier
"
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
received
this
proposal
so
very
ungraciously
,
that
he
never
ventured
on
a
second
;
but
ever
afterwards
confined
himself
to
looking
watchfully
at
her
for
her
suggestions
,
and
rattling
his
money
.
   
<EOS>
"
Trot
,
I
tell
you
what
,
my
dear
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
one
morning
in
the
Christmas
season
when
I
left
school
:
"
as
this
knotty
point
is
still
unsettled
,
and
as
we
must
not
make
a
mistake
in
our
decision
if
we
can
help
it
,
I
think
we
had
better
take
a
little
breathing
-
time
.
<EOS>
In
the
meanwhile
,
you
must
try
to
look
at
it
from
a
new
point
of
view
,
and
not
as
a
schoolboy
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
aunt
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
has
occurred
to
me
,
"
pursued
my
aunt
,
"
that
a
little
change
,
and
a
glimpse
of
life
out
of
doors
,
may
be
useful
in
helping
you
to
know
your
own
mind
,
and
form
a
cooler
judgement
.
 
<EOS>
Suppose
you
were
to
go
down
into
the
old
part
of
the
country
again
,
for
instance
,
and
see
that
---
that
out
-
of
-
the
-
way
woman
with
the
savagest
of
names
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
rubbing
her
nose
,
for
she
could
never
thoroughly
forgive
Peggotty
for
being
so
called
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
all
things
in
the
world
,
aunt
,
I
should
like
it
best
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
that
's
lucky
,
for
I
should
like
it
too
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
's
natural
and
rational
that
you
should
like
it
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
am
very
well
persuaded
that
whatever
you
do
,
Trot
,
will
always
be
natural
and
rational
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
so
,
aunt
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
sister
,
Betsey
Trotwood
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
would
have
been
as
natural
and
rational
a
girl
as
ever
breathed
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
be
worthy
of
her
,
wo
n't
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
I
shall
be
worthy
of
YOU
,
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
That
will
be
enough
for
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
mercy
that
poor
dear
baby
of
a
mother
of
yours
did
n't
live
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
looking
at
me
approvingly
,
"
or
she
'd
have
been
so
vain
of
her
boy
by
this
time
,
that
her
soft
little
head
would
have
been
completely
turned
,
if
there
was
anything
of
it
left
to
turn
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
My
aunt
always
excused
any
weakness
of
her
own
in
my
behalf
,
by
transferring
it
in
this
way
to
my
poor
mother
.
)
<EOS>
"
Bless
me
,
<EOS>
Trotwood
,
how
you
do
remind
me
of
her
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pleasantly
,
I
hope
,
aunt
?
<EOS>
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
as
like
her
,
Dick
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
emphatically
,
"
he
's
as
like
her
,
as
she
was
that
afternoon
before
she
began
to
fret
<EOS>
---
bless
my
heart
,
he
's
as
like
her
,
as
he
can
look
at
me
out
of
his
two
eyes
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
he
indeed
?
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
he
's
like
David
,
too
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
decisively
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
very
like
David
!
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
what
I
want
you
to
be
,
Trot
,
"
resumed
my
aunt
,
"
---
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mean
physically
,
but
morally
;
you
are
very
well
physically
---
is
,
a
firm
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
A
fine
firm
fellow
,
with
a
will
of
your
own
.
 
<EOS>
With
resolution
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
shaking
her
cap
at
me
,
and
clenching
her
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
With
determination
.
 
<EOS>
With
character
,
Trot
---
with
strength
of
character
that
is
not
to
be
influenced
,
except
on
good
reason
,
by
anybody
,
or
by
anything
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
what
I
want
you
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
what
your
father
and
mother
might
both
have
been
,
Heaven
knows
,
and
been
the
better
for
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
intimated
that
I
hoped
I
should
be
what
she
described
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
you
may
begin
,
in
a
small
way
,
to
have
a
reliance
upon
yourself
,
and
to
act
for
yourself
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
I
shall
send
you
upon
your
trip
,
alone
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
think
,
once
,
of
Mr
Dick
's
going
with
you
;
but
,
on
second
thoughts
,
I
shall
keep
him
to
take
care
of
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
,
for
a
moment
,
looked
a
little
disappointed
;
until
the
honour
and
dignity
of
having
to
take
care
of
the
most
wonderful
woman
in
the
world
,
restored
the
sunshine
to
his
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
Besides
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
there
's
the
Memorial
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
certainly
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
in
a

,
"
I
intend
,
Trotwood
,
to
get
that
done
immediately
---
it
really
must
be
done
immediately
!
<EOS>
And
then
it
will
go
in
,
you
know
---
and
then
---
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
after
checking
himself
,
and
pausing
a
long
time
,
"
there
'll
be
a
pretty
kettle
of
fish
!
"
   
<EOS>
In
pursuance
of
my
aunt
's
kind
scheme
,
I
was
shortly
afterwards
fitted
out
with
a
handsome
purse
of
money
,
and
a
portmanteau
,
and
tenderly
dismissed
upon
my
expedition
.
 
<EOS>
At
parting
,
my
aunt
gave
me
some
good
advice
,
and
a
good
many
kisses
;
and
said
that
as
her
object
was
that
I
should
look
about
me
,
and
should
think
a
little
,
she
would
recommend
me
to
stay
a
few
days
in
London
,
if
I
liked
it
,
either
on
my
way
down
into
Suffolk
,
or
in
coming
back
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
I
was
at
liberty
to
do
what
I
would
,
for
three
weeks
or
a
month
;
and
no
other
conditions
were
imposed
upon
my
freedom
than
the
before
-
mentioned
thinking
and
looking
about
me
,
and
a
pledge
to
write
three
times
a
week
and
faithfully
report
myself
.
   
<EOS>
I
went
to
Canterbury
first
,
that
I
might
take
leave
of
Agnes
and
Mr
Wickfield
<EOS>
(
my
old
room
in
whose
house
I
had
not
yet
relinquished
)
,
and
also
of
the
good
Doctor
.
 
<EOS>
Agnes
was
very
glad
to
see
me
,
and
told
me
that
the
house
had
not
been
like
itself
since
I
had
left
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
I
am
not
like
myself
when
I
am
away
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
I
seem
to
want
my
right
hand
,
when
I
miss
you
.
 
<EOS>
Though
that
's
not
saying
much
;
for
there
's
no
head
in
my
right
hand
,
and
no
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Everyone
who
knows
you
,
consults
with
you
,
and
is
guided
by
you
,
Agnes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Everyone
who
knows
me
,
spoils
me
,
I
believe
,
"
she
answered
,
smiling
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
it
's
because
you
are
like
no
one
else
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
so
good
,
and
so
sweet
-
tempered
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
such
a
gentle
nature
,
and
you
are
always
right
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
talk
,
"
said
Agnes
,
breaking
into
a
pleasant
laugh
,
as
she
sat
at
work
,
"
as
if
I
were
the
late
Miss
Larkins
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
not
fair
to
abuse
my
confidence
,
"
I
answered
,
reddening
at
the
recollection
of
my
blue
enslaver
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
shall
confide
in
you
,
just
the
same
,
Agnes
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
never
grow
out
of
that
.
 
<EOS>
Whenever
I
fall
into
trouble
,
or
fall
in
love
,
I
shall
always
tell
you
,
if
you
'll
let
me
---
even
when
I
come
to
fall
in
love
in
earnest
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
have
always
been
in
earnest
!
"
<EOS>
said
Agnes
,
laughing
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
that
was
as
a
child
,
or
a
schoolboy
,
"
said
I
,
laughing
in
my
turn
,
not
without
being
a
little
shame
-
faced
.
 
<EOS>
"
Times
are
altering
now
,
and
I
suppose
I
shall
be
in
a
terrible
state
of
earnestness
one
day
or
other
.
 
<EOS>
My
wonder
is
,
that
you
are
not
in
earnest
yourself
,
by
this
time
,
Agnes
.
"
   
<EOS>
Agnes
laughed
again
,
and
shook
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
I
know
you
are
not
!
"
<EOS>
said
I
,
"
because
if
you
had
been
you
would
have
told
me
.
 
<EOS>
Or
at
least
"
---
for
I
saw
a
faint
blush
in
her
face
<EOS>
,
"
you
would
have
let
me
find
it
out
for
myself
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
is
no
one
that
I
know
of
,
who
deserves
to
love
you
,
Agnes
.
 
<EOS>
Someone
of
a
nobler
character
,
and
more
worthy
altogether
than
anyone
I
have
ever
seen
here
,
must
rise
up
,
before
I
give
my
consent
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
time
to
come
,
I
shall
have
a
wary
eye
on
all
admirers
;
and
shall
exact
a
great
deal
from
the
successful
one
,
I
assure
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
We
had
gone
on
,
so
far
,
in
a
mixture
of
confidential
jest
and
earnest
,
that
had
long
grown
naturally
out
of
our
familiar
relations
,
begun
as
mere
children
.
 
<EOS>
But
Agnes
,
now
suddenly
lifting
up
her
eyes
to
mine
,
and
speaking
in
a
different
manner
,
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
Trotwood
,
there
is
something
that
I
want
to
ask
you
,
and
that
I
may
not
have
another
opportunity
of
asking
for
a
long
time
,
perhaps
---
something
I
would
ask
,
I
think
,
of
no
one
else
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
observed
any
gradual
alteration
in
Papa
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
had
observed
it
,
and
had
often
wondered
whether
she
had
too
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
have
shown
as
much
,
now
,
in
my
face
;
for
her
eyes
were
in
a
moment
cast
down
,
and
I
saw
tears
in
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
what
it
is
,
"
she
said
,
in
a
low
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
---
shall
I
be
quite
plain
,
Agnes
,
liking
him
so
much
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
she
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
does
himself
no
good
by
the
habit
that
has
increased
upon
him
since
I
first
came
here
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
often
very
nervous
---
or
I
fancy
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
fancy
,
"
said
Agnes
,
shaking
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
hand
trembles
,
his
speech
is
not
plain
,
and
his
eyes
look
wild
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
remarked
that
at
those
times
,
and
when
he
is
least
like
himself
,
he
is
most
certain
to
be
wanted
on
some
business
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
Uriah
,
"
said
Agnes
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
<EOS>
and
the
sense
of
being
unfit
for
it
,
or
of
not
having
understood
it
,
or
of
having
shown
his
condition
in
spite
of
himself
,
seems
to
make
him
so
uneasy
,
that
next
day
he
is
worse
,
and
next
day
worse
,
and
so
he
becomes
jaded
and
haggard
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
be
alarmed
by
what
I
say
,
Agnes
,
but
in
this
state
I
saw
him
,
only
the
other
evening
,
lay
down
his
head
upon
his
desk
,
and
shed
tears
like
a
child
.
"
   
<EOS>
Her
hand
passed
softly
before
my
lips
while
I
was
yet
speaking
,
and
in
a
moment
she
had
met
her
father
at
the
door
of
the
room
,
and
was
hanging
on
his
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
The
expression
of
her
face
,
as
they
both
looked
towards
me
<EOS>
,
I
felt
to
be
very
touching
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
such
deep
fondness
for
him
,
and
gratitude
to
him
for
all
his
love
and
care
,
in
her
beautiful
look
;
and
there
was
such
a
fervent
appeal
to
me
to
deal
tenderly
by
him
,
even
in
my
inmost
thoughts
,
and
to
let
no
harsh
construction
find
any
place
against
him
;
she
was
,
at
once
,
so
proud
of
him
and
devoted

him
,
yet
so
compassionate
and
sorry
,
and
so
reliant
upon
me
to
be
so
,
too
;
that
nothing
she
could
have
said
would
have
expressed
more
to
me
,
or
moved
me
more
.
   
<EOS>
We
were
to
drink
tea
at
the
Doctor
's
.
 
<EOS>
We
went
there
at
the
usual
hour
;
and
round
the
study
fireside
found
the
Doctor
,
and
his
young
wife
,
and
her
mother
.
 
<EOS>
The
Doctor
,
who
made
as
much
of
my
going
away
as
if
I
were
going
to
China
,
received
me
as
an
honoured
guest
;
and
called
for
a
log
of
wood
to
be
thrown
on
the
fire
,
that
he
might
see
the
face
of
his
old
pupil
reddening
in
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
not
see
many
more
new
faces
in
Trotwood
's
stead
,
Wickfield
,
"
said
the
Doctor
,
warming

;
"
I
am
getting
lazy
,
and
want
ease
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
relinquish
all
my
young
people
in
another
six
months
,
and
lead
a
quieter
life
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
said
so
,
any
time
these
ten
years
,
Doctor
,
"
Mr
Wickfield
answered
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
now
I
mean
to
do
it
,
"
returned
the
Doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
first
master
will
succeed
me
---
I
am
in
earnest
at
last
---
so
you
'll
soon
have
to
arrange

contracts
,
and
to
bind

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And

"

,
"

,

?
 
<EOS>
As
you
certainly

,
in
any

make
for

.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
ready
.
 
<EOS>
There

worse
tasks
than
that
,
in
my
calling
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall

nothing

,
"

Doctor
,

,
"
but
my
Dictionary
;
and
this
other
contract
-
bargain
---
Annie
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Wickfield

,

the
tea

by
Agnes
,
she
seemed
to
me
to
avoid
his

with

,
that

,
as

.
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
a
post
come

,

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
By
the
by
!
and
letters
from
Mr
Jack
Maldon
!
"

Doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
dear
Jack
!
"
said
Mrs
Markleham
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
That
trying
climate
!
<EOS>
---
like
living
,
they
tell
me
,
on
a
sand

,
underneath

-

!
 
<EOS>
He
looked

,
but

.
 
<EOS>
My

Doctor
,
it

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Annie
,

,
I

your

never

strong
---
not

ROBUST
,

"

"
---
from

,
and

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Do

ill
?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ill
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
My

,

's
all

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Except

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Except

,

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
He

dreadful

of

,
no

,

agues
,

.
 
<EOS>
As

,
"

"

"
   
<EOS>
"
Does

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

?
 
<EOS>
My

,
"

,

,
"
<EOS>
you
little
know

poor
Jack
Maldon
when

.
 
<EOS>
Say
?
 
<EOS>
Not
he
.
 
<EOS>
You
might
drag

at
the

four

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mama
!
"
said
Mrs
Strong
.
   
<EOS>
"
Annie
,

,
"

,
"

<EOS>
You

!
 
<EOS>
I
WON'T

---
eight
,

,

,

.

"
   
<EOS>
"
Wickfield
's

<EOS>

That

,
our

.

I

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

;

<EOS>
But

ca

ca

.
 
<EOS>
And

ca

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
"
said

Soldier
,

,
in

,
"
and
<EOS>
I
know

,

's

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

"
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
If

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Markleham
was
so

---
which
,
I

,
she

---
that

it

like

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
After

gently
chid
her
daughter
Annie
,
for
not

more
demonstrative
when
such

were
showered
,
for
her

,

;

concerning
other

her

,
whom

was

to
set
on
their

.
   
<EOS>
All
this

,
her
daughter
Annie
never

,

.
 
<EOS>
All

,
Mr
Wickfield
had
his

as

daughter
's

.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
me
that
he
never

;
but

so

,

,
as

.
 
<EOS>
He
now

what
Mr
Jack
Maldon
had
actually
written
in

,
and

?
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,
"

,

's

"
the
dear

Doctor

---

?
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
---
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
That

!
 
<EOS>
His

!
 
<EOS>
But
Annie
's

.
 
<EOS>
Annie
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,

,
"

<EOS>
"
My

,
you
absolutely
are
,

,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
We

<EOS>
Do

,

Strong
?
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
You
ought
to
know
better
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
letter
was

;

,
I

,

<EOS>
"
Now

,
"

,

"

<EOS>
"
The

,

"
---
<EOS>
and

forth
<EOS>
---

.
 
<EOS>
"
The

Proctor
"

?
 
<EOS>
Dear

,

,

Maldon

,

!
 
<EOS>
"
Doctor
,
"
of

.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
amiable

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here

,

,
and

at

Doctor
,
who

in

.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
I
have
found
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
not

to
hear
,
Annie
,
"
---
<EOS>
no
,
to
be
sure
,
knowing

he
never

really
strong
;
what
did
I
say
just
now
?
---
"
that

undergone
so
much
in

,

at
all

;

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
What

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
And
but

that
best

,
"
said

Markleham
,
telegraphing

Doctor
as

,
and
refolding

,
"
it
would
be
insupportable
to
me
to
think

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Wickfield
said
not
one
word
,
though
the
old
lady
looked
to
him
as
if
for
his
commentary
on
this

;
but
sat
severely

,
with

fixed
on

.
 
<EOS>
Long
after
the
subject
was
dismissed
,
and
other
topics
occupied
us
,
he
remained
so
;
seldom
raising

,
unless
to
rest

for
a

,
with
a
