,
upon
the
Doctor
,
or
his
wife
,
or
both
.
   
<EOS>
The
Doctor
was
very
fond
of
music
.
 
<EOS>
Agnes
sang
with
great
sweetness
and
expression
,
and
so
did
Mrs
Strong
.
 
<EOS>
They
sang
together
,
and
played
duets
together
,
and
we
had
quite
a
little
concert
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
remarked
two
things
:
<EOS>
first
,
that
though
Annie
soon
recovered
her
composure
,
and
was
quite
herself
,
there
was
a
blank
between
her
and
Mr
Wickfield
which
separated
them
wholly
from
each
other
;
secondly
,
that
Mr
Wickfield
seemed
to
dislike
the
intimacy
between
her
and
Agnes
,
and
to
watch
it
with
uneasiness
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
,
I
must
confess
,
the
recollection
of
what
I
had
seen
on
that
night
when
Mr
Maldon
went
away
,
first
began
to
return
upon
me
with
a
meaning
it
had
never
had
,
and
to
trouble
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
innocent
beauty
of
her
face
was
not
as
innocent
to
me
as
it
had
been
;
I
mistrusted
the
natural
grace
and
charm
of
her
manner
;
and
when
I
looked
at
Agnes
by
her
side
,
and
thought
how
good
and
true
Agnes
was
,
suspicions
arose
within
me
that
it
was
an
ill
-
assorted
friendship
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
so
happy
in
it
herself
,
however
,
and
the
other
was
so
happy
too
,
that
they
made
the
evening
fly
away
as
if
it
were
but
an
hour
.
<EOS>
It
closed
in
an
incident
which
I
well
remember
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
taking
leave
of
each
other
,
and
Agnes
was
going
to
embrace
her
and
kiss
her
,
when
Mr
Wickfield
stepped
between
them
,
as
if
by
accident
,
and
drew
Agnes
quickly
away
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
saw
,
as
though
all
the
intervening
time
had
been
cancelled
,
and
I
were
still
standing
in
the
doorway
on
the
night
of
the
departure
,
the
expression
of
that
night
in
the
face
of
Mrs
Strong
,
as
it
confronted
his
.
   
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
what
an
impression
this
made
upon
me
,
or
<EOS>
how
impossible
I
found
it
,
when
I
thought
of
her
afterwards
,
to
separate
her
from
this
look
,
and
remember
her
face
in
its
innocent
loveliness
again
.
 
<EOS>
It
haunted
me
when
I
got
home
.
 
<EOS>
I
seemed
to
have
left
the
Doctor
's
roof
with
a
dark
cloud
lowering
on
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
reverence
that
I
had
for
his
grey
head
,
was
mingled
with
commiseration
for
his
faith
in
those
who
were
treacherous
to
him
,
and
with
resentment
against
those
who
injured
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
impending
shadow
of
a
great
affliction
,
and
a
great
disgrace
that
had
no
distinct
form
in
it
yet
,
fell
like
a
stain
upon
the
quiet
place
where
I
had
worked
and
played
as
a
boy
,
and
did
it
a
cruel
wrong
.
<EOS>
I
had
no
pleasure
in
thinking
,
any
more
,
of
the
grave
old
broad
-
leaved
aloe
-
trees
,
which
remained
shut
up
in
themselves
a
hundred
years
together
,
and
of
the
trim
smooth
grass
-
plot
,
and
the
stone
urns
,
and
the
Doctor
's
walk
,
and
the
congenial
sound
of
the
Cathedral
bell
hovering
above
them
all
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
as
if
the
tranquil
sanctuary
of
my
boyhood
had
been
sacked
before
my
face
,
and
its
peace
and
honour
given
to
the
winds
.
   
<EOS>
But
morning
brought
with
it
my
parting
from
the
old
house
,
which
Agnes
had
filled
with
her
influence
;
and
that
occupied
my
mind
sufficiently
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
be
there
again
soon
,
no
doubt
;
I
might
sleep
again
---
perhaps
often
---
in
my
old
room
;
but
the
days
of
my
inhabiting
there
were
gone
,
and
the
old
time
was
past
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
heavier
at
heart
when
I
packed
up
such
of
my
books
and
clothes
as
still
remained
there
to
be
sent
to
Dover
,
than
I
cared
to
show
to
Uriah
Heep
;
who
was
so
officious
to
help
me
,
<EOS>
that
I
uncharitably
thought
him
mighty
glad
that
I
was
going
.
   
<EOS>
I
got
away
from
Agnes
and
her
father
,
somehow
,
with
an
indifferent
show
of
being
very
manly
,
and
took
my
seat
upon
the
box
of
the
London
coach
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
softened
and
forgiving
,
going
through
the
town
,
that
I
had
half
a
mind
to
nod
to
my
old
enemy
the
butcher
,
and
throw
him
five
shillings
to
drink
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
looked
such
a
very
obdurate
butcher
as
he
stood
scraping
the
great
block
in
the
shop
,
and
moreover
,
his
appearance
was
so
little
improved
by
the
loss
of
a
front
tooth
which
I
had
knocked
out
<EOS>
,
that
I
thought
it
best
to
make
no
advances
.
   
<EOS>
The
main
object
on
my
mind
<EOS>
,
I
remember
,
when
we
got
fairly
on
the
road
,
was
to
appear
as
old
as
possible
to
the
coachman
,
and
to
speak
extremely
gruff
.
 
<EOS>
The
latter
point
I
achieved
at
great
personal
inconvenience
;
but
<EOS>
I
stuck
to
it
,
because
I
felt
it
was
a
grown
-
up
sort
of
thing
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
going
through
,
sir
?
"
said
the
coachman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
William
,
"
<EOS>
I
said
,
condescendingly
(
I
knew
him
)
;
"
I
am
going
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
go
down
into
Suffolk
afterwards
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Shooting
,
sir
?
"
said
the
coachman
.
   
<EOS>
He
knew
as
well
as
I
did
that
it
was
just
as
likely
,
at
that
time
of
year
,
I
was
going
down
there
whaling
;
but
I
felt
complimented
,
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
I
said
,
pretending
to
be
undecided
,
"
whether
I
shall
take
a
shot
or
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Birds
is
got
wery
shy
,
I
'm
told
,
"
said
William
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
I
understand
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Suffolk
your
county
,
sir
?
"
asked
William
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
I
said
,
with
some
importance
.
 
<EOS>
"
Suffolk
's
my
county
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
told
the
dumplings
is
uncommon
fine
down
there
,
"
said
William
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
not
aware
of
it
myself
,
but
I
felt
it
necessary
to
uphold
the
institutions
of
my
county
,
and
to
evince
a
familiarity
with
them
;
so
I
shook
my
head
,
as
much
as
to
say
,
"
I
believe
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
the
Punches
,
"
said
William
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
cattle
!
 
<EOS>
A
Suffolk
Punch
,
when
he
's
a
good
un
,
is
worth
his
weight
in
gold
.
 
<EOS>
Did
you
ever
breed
any
Suffolk
Punches
yourself
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
N
-
no
,
"
I
said
,
"
not
exactly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's
a
gen'lm'n
behind
me
,
I
'll
pound
it
,
"
said
William
,
"
as
has
bred
'em
by
wholesale
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
spoken
of
was
a
gentleman
with
a
very
unpromising
squint
,
and
a
prominent
chin
,
who
had
a
tall
white
hat
on
with
a
narrow
flat
brim
,
and
whose
close
-
fitting
drab
trousers
seemed
to
button
all
the
way
up
outside
his
legs
from
his
boots
to
his
hips
.
<EOS>
His
chin
was
cocked
over
the
coachman
's
shoulder
,
so
near
to
me
,
that
his
breath
quite
tickled
the
back
of
my
head
;
and
as
I
looked
at
him
,
he
leered
at
the
leaders
with
the
eye
with
which
he
did
n't
squint
,
in
a
very
knowing
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ai
n't
you
?
"
asked
William
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ai
n't
I
what
?
"
said
the
gentleman
behind
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bred
them
Suffolk
Punches
by
wholesale
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
so
,
"
said
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
ai
n't
no
sort
of
orse
that
I
ai
n't
bred
,
and
no
sort
of
dorg
.
 
<EOS>
Orses
and
dorgs
is
some
men
's
fancy
.
 
<EOS>
They
're
wittles
and
drink
to
me
---
<EOS>
lodging
,
wife
,
and
children
---
reading
,
writing
,
and
Arithmetic
---
snuff
,
tobacker
,
and
sleep
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
ai
n't
a
sort
of
man
to
see
sitting
behind
a
coach
-
box
,
is
it
though
?
"
said
William
in
my
ear
,
as
he
handled
the
reins
.
   
<EOS>
I
construed
this
remark
into
an
indication
of
a
wish
that
he
should
have
my
place
,
so
I
blushingly
offered
to
resign
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
if
you
do
n't
mind
,
sir
,
"
said
William
,
"
I
think
it
would
be
more
correct
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
have
always
considered
this
as
the
first
fall
I
had
in
life
.
<EOS>
When
I
booked
my
place
at
the
coach
office
<EOS>
I
had
had
"
Box
Seat
"
written
against
the
entry
,
and
had
given
the
book
-
keeper
half
-
a
-
crown
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
got
up
in
a
special
great
-
coat
and
shawl
,
expressly
to
do
honour
to
that
distinguished
eminence
;
had
glorified
myself
upon
it
a
good
deal
;
and
had
felt
that
I
was
a
credit
to
the
coach
.
 
<EOS>
And
here
,
in
the
very
first
stage
,
I
was
supplanted
by
a
shabby
man
with
a
squint
,
who
had
no
other
merit
than
smelling
like
a
livery
-
stables
,
and
being
able
to
walk
across
me
,
more
like
a
fly
than
a
human
being
,
while
the
horses
were
at
a
canter
!
   
<EOS>
A
distrust
of
myself
,
which
has
often
beset
me
in
life
on
small
occasions
,
when
it
would
have
been
better
away
,
was
assuredly
not
stopped
in
its
growth
by
this
little
incident
outside
the
Canterbury
coach
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
to
take
refuge
in
gruffness
of
speech
.
 
<EOS>
I
spoke
from
the
pit
of
my
stomach
for
the
rest
of
the
journey
,
but
<EOS>
I
felt
completely
extinguished
,
and
dreadfully
young
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
curious
and
interesting
,
nevertheless
,
to
be
sitting
up
there
behind
four
horses
:
well
educated
,
well
dressed
,
and
with
plenty
of
money
in
my
pocket
;
and
to
look
out
for
the
places
where
I
had
slept
on
my
weary
journey
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
abundant
occupation
for
my
thoughts
,
in
every
conspicuous
landmark
on
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
looked
down
at
the
trampers
whom
we
passed
,
and
saw
that
well
-
remembered
style
of
face
turned
up
,
I
felt
as
if
the
tinker
's
blackened
hand
were
in
the
bosom
of
my
shirt
again
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
clattered
through
the
narrow
street
of
Chatham
,
and
I
caught
a
glimpse
,
in
passing
,
of
the
lane
where
the
old
monster
lived
who
had
bought
my
jacket
<EOS>
,
I
stretched
my
neck
eagerly
to
look
for
the
place
where
I
had
sat
,
in
the
sun
and
in
the
shade
,
waiting
for
my
money
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
came
,
at
last
,
within
a
stage
of
London
,
and
passed
the
veritable
Salem
House
where
Mr
Creakle
had
laid
about
him
with
a
heavy
hand
,
I
would
have
given
all
I
had
,
for
lawful
permission
to
get
down
and
thrash
him
,
and
let
all
the
boys
out
like
so
many
caged
sparrows
.
   
<EOS>
We
went
to
the
Golden
Cross
at
Charing
Cross
,
then
<EOS>
a
mouldy
sort
of
establishment
in
a
close
neighbourhood
.
 
<EOS>
A
waiter
showed
me
into
the
coffee
-
room
;
and
a
chambermaid
introduced
me
to
my
small
bedchamber
,
which
smelt
like
a
hackney
-
coach
,
and
was
shut
up
like
a
family
vault
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
still
painfully
conscious
of
my
youth
,
for
nobody
stood
in
any
awe
of
me
at
all
:
the
chambermaid
being
utterly
indifferent
to
my
opinions
on
any
subject
,
and
the
waiter
being
familiar
with
me
,
and
offering
advice
to
my
inexperience
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
now
,
"
said
the
waiter
,
in
a
tone
of
confidence
,
"
what
would
you
like
for
dinner
?
 
<EOS>
Young
gentlemen
likes
poultry
in
general
:
have
a
fowl
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
told
him
,
as
majestically
as
I
could
,
that
I
was
n't
in
the
humour
for
a
fowl
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ai
n't
you
?
"
said
the
waiter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Young
gentlemen
is
generally
tired
of
beef
and
mutton
:
have
a
weal
cutlet
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
assented
to
this
proposal
,
in
default
of
being
able
to
suggest
anything
else
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
care
for
taters
?
"
said
the
waiter
,
with
an
insinuating
smile
,
and
his
head
on
one
side
.
 
<EOS>
"
Young
gentlemen
generally
has
been
overdosed
with
taters
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
commanded
him
,
in
my
deepest
voice
,
to
order
a
veal
cutlet
and
potatoes
,
and
all
things
fitting
;
and
to
inquire
at
the
bar
if
there
were
any
letters
for
Trotwood
Copperfield
,
Esquire
---
which
I
knew
there
were
not
,
and
could
n't
be
,
but
thought
it
manly
to
appear
to
expect
.
   
<EOS>
He
soon
came
back
to
say
that
there
were
none
(
at
which
I
was
much
surprised
)
and
began
to
lay
the
cloth
for
my
dinner
in
a
box
by
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
While
he
was
so
engaged
,
he
asked
me
what
I
would
take
with
it
;
and
on
my
replying
"
Half
a
pint
of
sherry
,
"
thought
it
a
favourable
opportunity
,
I
am
afraid
,
to
extract
that
measure
of
wine
from
the
stale
leavings
at
the
bottoms
of
several
small
decanters
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
of
this
opinion
,
because
,
while
I
was
reading
the
newspaper
,
I
observed
him
behind
a
low
wooden
partition
,
which
was
his
private
apartment
,
very
busy
pouring
out
of
a
number
of
those
vessels
into
one
,
like
a
chemist
and
druggist
making
up
a
prescription
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
wine
came
,
too
,
I
thought
it
flat
;
and
it
certainly
had
more
English
crumbs
in
it
,
than
were
to
be
expected
in
a
foreign
wine
in
anything
like
a
pure
state
,
but
I
was
bashful
enough
to
drink
it
,
and
say
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
Being
then
in
a
pleasant
frame
of
mind
(
from
which
I
infer
that
poisoning
is
not
always
disagreeable
in
some
stages
of
the
process
)
,
I
resolved
to
go
to
the
play
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
Covent
Garden
Theatre
that
I
chose
;
and
there
,
from
the
back
of
a
centre
box
,
I
saw
Julius
Caesar
and
the
new
Pantomime
.
 
<EOS>
To
have
all
those
noble
Romans
alive
before
me
,
and
walking
in
and
out
for
my
entertainment
,
instead
of
being
the
stern
taskmasters
they
had
been
at
school
,
was
a
most
novel
and
delightful
effect
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
mingled
reality
and
mystery
of
the
whole
show
,
the
influence
upon
me
of
the
poetry
,
the
lights
,
the
music
,
the
company
,
the
smooth
stupendous
changes
of
glittering
and
brilliant
scenery
,
were
so
dazzling
,
and
opened
up
such
illimitable
regions
of
delight
,
that
when
I
came
out
into
the
rainy
street
,
at
twelve
o'clock
at
night
,
I
felt
as
if
I
had
come
from
the
clouds
,
where
I
had
been
leading
a
romantic
life
for
ages
,
to
a
bawling
,
splashing
,
link
-
lighted
,
umbrella
-
struggling
,
hackney
-
coach
-
jostling
,
patten
-
clinking
,
muddy
,
miserable
world
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
emerged
by
another
door
,
and
stood
in
the
street
for
a
little
while
,
as
if
I
really
were
a
stranger
upon
earth
:
but
the
unceremonious
pushing
and
hustling
that
I
received
,
soon
recalled
me
to
myself
,
and
put
me
in
the
road
back
to
the
hotel
;
whither
I
went
,
revolving
the
glorious
vision
all
the
way
;
and
where
,
after
some
porter
and
oysters
,
I
sat
revolving
it
still
,
at
past
one
o'clock
,
with
my
eyes
on
the
coffee
-
room
fire
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
so
filled
with
the
play
,
and
with
the
past
<EOS>
---
for
it
was
,
in
a
manner
,
like
a
shining
transparency
,
through
which
I
saw
my
earlier
life
moving
along
---
that
I
do
n't
know
when
the
figure
of
a
handsome
well
-
formed
young
man
dressed
with
a
tasteful
easy
negligence
which
I
have
reason
to
remember
very
well
,
became
a
real
presence
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
recollect
being
conscious
of
his
company
without
having
noticed
his
coming
in
---
and
my
still
sitting
,
musing
,
over
the
coffee
-
room
fire
.
   
<EOS>
At
last
I
rose
to
go
to
bed
,
much
to
the
relief
of
the
sleepy
waiter
,
who
had
got
the
fidgets
in
his
legs
,
and
was
twisting
them
,
and
hitting
them
,
and
putting
them
through
all
kinds
of
contortions
in
his
small
pantry
.
 
<EOS>
In
going
towards
the
door
,
I
passed
the
person
who
had
come
in
,
and
saw
him
plainly
.
 
<EOS>
I
turned
directly
,
came
back
,
and
looked
again
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
not
know
me
,
but
I
knew
him
in
a
moment
.
   
<EOS>
At
another
time
I
might
have
wanted
the
confidence
or
the
decision
to
speak
to
him
,
and
might
have
put
it
off
until
next
day
,
and
might
have
lost
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
in
the
then
condition
of
my
mind
,
where
the
play
was
still
running
high
,
his
former
protection
of
me
appeared
so
deserving
of
my
gratitude
,
and
my
old
love
for
him
overflowed
my
breast
so
freshly
and
spontaneously
,
that
I
went
up
to
him
at
once
,
with
a
fast
-
beating
heart
,
and
said
:
   
"
Steerforth
!
<EOS>
wo
n't
you
speak
to
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
looked
at
me
---
just
as
he
used
to
look
,
sometimes
---
<EOS>
but
I
saw
no
recognition
in
his
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
remember
me
,
I
am
afraid
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
My
God
!
"
<EOS>
he
suddenly
exclaimed
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
little
Copperfield
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
grasped
him
by
both
hands
,
and
could
not
let
them
go
.
 
<EOS>
But
for
very
shame
,
and
the
fear
that
it
might
displease
him
,
I
could
have
held
him
round
the
neck
and
cried
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
,
never
,
never
was
so
glad
!
 
<EOS>
My
dear
Steerforth
,
I
am
so
overjoyed
to
see
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
I
am
rejoiced
to
see
you
,
too
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
shaking
my
hands
heartily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Copperfield
,
old
boy
,
do
n't
be
overpowered
!
"
<EOS>
And
yet
he
was
glad
,
too
,
I
thought
,
to
see
how
the
delight
I
had
in
meeting
him
affected
me
.
   
<EOS>
I
brushed
away
the
tears
that
my
utmost
resolution
had
not
been
able
to
keep
back
,
and
I
made
a
clumsy
laugh
of
it
,
and
we
sat
down
together
,
side
by
side
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
how
do
you
come
to
be
here
?
<EOS>
"
said
Steerforth
,
clapping
me
on
the
shoulder
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
came
here
by
the
Canterbury
coach
,
today
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
adopted
by
an
aunt
down
in
that
part
of
the
country
,
and
have
just
finished
my
education
there
.
 
<EOS>
How
do
YOU
come
to
be
here
,
Steerforth
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
am
what
they
call
an
Oxford
man
,
"
he
returned
;
"
that
is
to
say
,
I
get
bored
to
death
down
there
,
periodically
---
<EOS>
and
I
am
on
my
way
now
to
my
mother
's
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
a
devilish
amiable
-
looking
fellow
,
Copperfield
.
 
<EOS>
just
what
you
used
to
be
,
now
I
look
at
you
!
 
<EOS>
Not
altered
in
the
least
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
knew
you
immediately
,
"
I
said
;
"
but
you
are
more
easily
remembered
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
laughed
as
he
ran
his
hand
through
the
clustering
curls
of
his
hair
,
and
said
gaily
:
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
am
on
an
expedition
of
duty
.
 
<EOS>
My
mother
lives
a
little
way
out
of
town
;
and
the
roads
being
in
a
beastly
condition
,
and
our
house
tedious
enough
,
I
remained
here
tonight
instead
of
going
on
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
been
in
town
half
-
a
-
dozen
hours
,
and
those
I
have
been
dozing
and
grumbling
away
at
the
play
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
at
the
play
,
too
,
"
said
I.
 
"
At
Covent
Garden
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
delightful
and
magnificent
entertainment
,
Steerforth
!
"
   
<EOS>
Steerforth
laughed
heartily
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
young
Davy
,
"
he
said
,
clapping
me
on
the
shoulder
again
,
"
you
are
a
very
Daisy
.
 
<EOS>
The
daisy
of
the
field
,
at
sunrise
,
is
not
fresher
than
you
are
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
at
Covent
Garden
,
too
,
and
there
never
was
a
more
miserable
business
.
 
<EOS>
Holloa
,
you
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
addressed
to
the
waiter
,
who
had
been
very
attentive
to
our
recognition
,
at
a
distance
,
and
now
came
forward
deferentially
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
have
you
put
my
friend
,
Mr
Copperfield
?
"
said
Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Beg
your
pardon
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
does
he
sleep
?
 
<EOS>
What
's
his
number
?
 
<EOS>
You
know
what
I
mean
,
"
said
Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
said
the
waiter
,
with
an
apologetic
air
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Copperfield
is
at
present
in
forty
-
four
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
the
devil
do
you
mean
,
"
retorted
Steerforth
,
"
by
putting
Mr
Copperfield
into
a
little
loft
over
a
stable
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
see
we
was
n't
aware
,
sir
,
"
returned
the
waiter
,
still
apologetically
,
"
as
Mr
Copperfield
was
anyways
particular
.
 
<EOS>
We
can
give
Mr
Copperfield
seventy
-
two
,
sir
,
if
it
would
be
preferred
.
<EOS>
Next
you
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
it
would
be
preferred
,
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
do
it
at
once
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
waiter
immediately
withdrew
to
make
the
exchange
.
 
<EOS>
Steerforth
,
very
much
amused
at
my
having
been
put
into
forty
-
four
,
laughed
again
,
and
clapped
me
on
the
shoulder
again
,
and
invited
me
to
breakfast
with
him
next
morning
at
ten
o'clock
---
an
invitation
I
was
only
too
proud
and
happy
to
accept
.
 
<EOS>
It
being
now
pretty
late
,
we
took
our
candles
and
went
upstairs
,
where
we
parted
with
friendly
heartiness
at
his
door
,
and
where
I
found
my
new
room
a
great
improvement
on
my
old
one
<EOS>
,
it
not
being
at
all
musty
,
and
having
an
immense
four
-
post
bedstead
in
it
,
which
was
quite
a
little
landed
estate
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
among
pillows
enough
for
six
,
I
soon
fell
asleep
in
a
blissful
condition
,
and
dreamed
of
ancient
Rome
,
Steerforth
,
and
friendship
,
until
the
early
morning
coaches
,
rumbling
out
of
the
archway
underneath
,
made
me
dream
of
thunder
and
the
gods
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
20
.
<EOS>
Steerforth
's
home
 
<EOS>
When
the
chambermaid
tapped
at
my
door
at
eight
o'clock
,
and
informed
me
that
my
shaving
-
water
was
outside
,
I
felt
severely
the
having
no
occasion
for
it
,
and
blushed
in
my
bed
.
 
<EOS>
The
suspicion
that
she
laughed
too
,
when
she
said
it
,
preyed
upon
my
mind
all
the
time
I
was
dressing
;
and
gave
me
,
<EOS>
I
was
conscious
,
a
sneaking
and
guilty
air
when
I
passed
her
on
the
staircase
,
as
I
was
going
down
to
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
sensitively
aware
,
indeed
,
of
being
younger
than
I
could
have
wished
,
that
for
some
time
I
could
not
make
up
my
mind
to
pass
her
at
all
,
under
the
ignoble
circumstances
of
the
case
;
but
,
hearing
her
there
with
a
broom
,
stood
peeping
out
of
window
at
King
Charles
on
horseback
,
surrounded
by
a
maze
of
hackney
-
coaches
,
and
looking
anything
but
regal
in
a
drizzling
rain
and
a
dark
-
brown
fog
,
until
I
was
admonished
by
the
waiter
that
the
gentleman
was
waiting
for
me
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
not
in
the
coffee
-
room
that
I
found
Steerforth
expecting
me
,
but
in
a
snug
private
apartment
,
red
-
curtained
and
Turkey
-
carpeted
,
where
the
fire
burnt
bright
,
and
a
fine
hot
breakfast
was
set
forth
on
a
table
covered
with
a
clean
cloth
;
and
a
cheerful
miniature
of
the
room
,
the
fire
,
the
breakfast
,
Steerforth
,
and
all
,
was
shining
in
the
little
round
mirror
over
the
sideboard
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
rather
bashful
at
first
,
Steerforth
being
so
self
-
possessed
,
and
elegant
,
and
superior
to
me
in
all
respects
<EOS>
(
age
included
)
;
but
his
easy
patronage
soon
put
that
to
rights
,
and
made
me
quite
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
enough
admire
the
change
he
had
wrought
in
the
Golden
Cross
;
or
compare
the
dull
forlorn
state
I
had
held
yesterday
,
with
this
morning
's
comfort
and
this
morning
's
entertainment
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
the
waiter
's
familiarity
,
it
was
quenched
as
if
it
had
never
been
.
 
<EOS>
He
attended
on
us
,
as
I
may
say
,
in
sackcloth
and
ashes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Copperfield
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
when
we
were
alone
,
"
I
should
like
to
hear
what
you
are
doing
,
and
where
you
are
going
,
and
all
about
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
as
if
you
were
my
property
.
"
<EOS>
Glowing
with
pleasure
to
find
that
he
had
still
this
interest
in
me
,
I
told
him
how
my
aunt
had
proposed
the
little
expedition
that
I
had
before
me
,
and
whither
it
tended
.
   
<EOS>
"
As
you
are
in
no
hurry
,
then
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
"
come
home
with
me
to
Highgate
,
and
stay
a
day
or
two
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
be
pleased
with
my
mother
---
she
is
a
little
vain
and
prosy
about
me
,
but
that
you
can
forgive
her
---
and
she
will
be
pleased
with
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
be
as
sure
of
that
,
as
you
are
kind
enough
to
say
you
are
,
"
I
answered
,
smiling
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Steerforth
,
"
everyone
who
likes
me
,
has
a
claim
on
her
that
is
sure
to
be
acknowledged
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
I
think
I
shall
be
a
favourite
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
!
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
and
prove
it
.
 
<EOS>
We
will
go
and
see
the
lions
for
an
hour
or
two
<EOS>
---
it
's
something
to
have
a
fresh
fellow
like
you
to
show
them
to
,
Copperfield
---
and
then
we
'll
journey
out
to
Highgate
by
the
coach
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
hardly
believe
but
that
I
was
in
a
dream
,
and
that
I
should
wake
presently
in
number
forty
-
four
,
to
the
solitary
box
in
the
coffee
-
room
and
the
familiar
waiter
again
.
 
<EOS>
After
I
had
written
to
my
aunt
and
told
her
of
my
fortunate
meeting
with
my
admired
old
schoolfellow
,
and
my
acceptance
of
his
invitation
,
we
went
out
in
a
hackney
-
chariot
,
and
saw
a
Panorama
and
some
other
sights
,
and
took
a
walk
through
the
Museum
,
where
I
could
not
help
observing
how
much
Steerforth
knew
,
on
an
infinite
variety
of
subjects
,
and
of
how
little
account
he
seemed
to
make
his
knowledge
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
take
a
high
degree
at
college
,
Steerforth
,
"
said
I
,
"
if
you
have
not
done
so
already
;
and
they
will
have
good
reason
to
be
proud
of
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
take
a
degree
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
I
!
<EOS>
my
dear
Daisy
---
will
you
mind
my
calling
you
Daisy
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
!
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
good
fellow
!
 
<EOS>
My
dear
Daisy
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
laughing
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
the
least
desire
or
intention
to
distinguish
myself
in
that
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
done
quite
sufficient
for
my
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
I
find
that
I
am
heavy
company
enough
for
myself
as
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
the
fame
---
"
I
was
beginning
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
romantic
Daisy
!
<EOS>
"
said
Steerforth
,
laughing
still
more
heartily
:
"
why
should
I
trouble
myself
,
that
a
parcel
of
heavy
-
headed
fellows
may
gape
and
hold
up
their
hands
?
 
<EOS>
Let
them
do
it
at
some
other
man
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
fame
for
him
,
and
he
's
welcome
to
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
abashed
at
having
made
so
great
a
mistake
,
and
was
glad
to
change
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
Fortunately
it
was
not
difficult
to
do
,
for
Steerforth
could
always
pass
from
one
subject
to
another
with
a
carelessness
and
lightness
that
were
his
own
.
   
<EOS>
Lunch
succeeded
to
our
sight
-
seeing
,
and
the
short
winter
day
wore
away
so
fast
,
that
it
was
dusk
when
the
stage
-
coach
stopped
with
us
at
an
old
brick
house
at
Highgate
on
the
summit
of
the
hill
.
 
<EOS>
An
elderly
lady
,
though
not
very
far
advanced
in
years
,
with
a
proud
carriage
and
a
handsome
face
,
was
in
the
doorway
as
we
alighted
;
and
greeting
Steerforth
as
"
My
dearest
James
,
"
folded
him
in
her
arms
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
lady
he
presented
me
as
his
mother
,
and
she
gave
me
a
stately
welcome
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
genteel
old
-
fashioned
house
,
very
quiet
and
orderly
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
windows
of
my
room
I
saw
all
London
lying
in
the
distance
like
a
great
vapour
,
with
here
<EOS>
and
there
some
lights
twinkling
through
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
only
time
,
in
dressing
,
to
glance
at
the
solid
furniture
,
the
framed
pieces
of
work
(
done
,
I
supposed
,
by
Steerforth
's
mother
when
she
was
a
girl
)
,
and
some
pictures
in
crayons
of
ladies
with
powdered
hair
and
bodices
,
coming
and
going
on
the
walls
,
as
the
newly
-
kindled
fire
crackled
and
sputtered
,
when
I
was
called
to
dinner
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
second
lady
in
the
dining
-
room
,
of
a
slight
short
figure
,
dark
,
and
not
agreeable
to
look
at
,
but
with
some
appearance
of
good
looks
too
,
who
attracted
my
attention
:
perhaps
because
I
had
not
expected
to
see
her
;
perhaps
because
I
found
myself
sitting
opposite
to
her
;
perhaps
because
of
something
really
remarkable
in
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
black
hair
and
eager
black
eyes
,
and
was
thin
,
and
had
a
scar
upon
her
lip
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
an
old
scar
<EOS>
---
I
should
rather
call
it
seam
,
for
it
was
not
discoloured
,
and
had
healed
years
ago
---
which
had
once
cut
through
her
mouth
,
downward
towards
the
chin
,
but
was
now
barely
visible
across
the
table
,
except
above
and
on
her
upper
lip
,
the
shape
of
which
it
had
altered
.
 
<EOS>
I
concluded
in
my
own
mind
that
she
was
about
thirty
years
of
age
,
and
that
she
wished
to
be
married
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
a
little
dilapidated
---
like
a
house
---
with
having
been
so
long
to
let
;
yet
had
,
as
I
have
said
,
an
appearance
of
good
looks
.
 
<EOS>
Her
thinness
seemed
to
be
the
effect
of
some
wasting
fire
within
her
,
which
found
a
vent
in
her
gaunt
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
introduced
as
Miss
Dartle
,
and
both
Steerforth
and
his
mother
called
her
Rosa
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
that
she
lived
there
,
and
had
been
for
a
long
time
Mrs
Steerforth
's
companion
.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
me
that
she
never
said
anything
she
wanted
to
say
,
outright
;
but
hinted
it
,
and
made
a
great
deal
more
of
it
by
this
practice
.
 
<EOS>
For
example
,
when
Mrs
Steerforth
observed
,
more
in
jest
than
earnest
,
that
she
feared
her
son
led
but
a
wild
life
at
college
,
Miss
Dartle
put
in
thus
:
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
really
?
 
<EOS>
You
know
how
ignorant
I
am
,
and
that
I
only
ask
for
information
,
but
is
n't
it
always
so
?
 
<EOS>
I
thought
that
kind
of
life
was
on
all
hands
understood
to
be
---
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
education
for
a
very
grave
profession
,
if
you
mean
that
,
Rosa
,
"
Mrs
Steerforth
answered
with
some
coldness
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Yes
!
 
<EOS>
That
's
very
true
,
"
returned
Miss
Dartle
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
is
n't
it
,
though
?
<EOS>
---
I
want
to
be
put
right
,
if
I
am
wrong
---
is
n't
it
,
really
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Really
what
?
"
said
Mrs
Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
You
mean
it
's
not
!
"
returned
Miss
Dartle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
'm
very
glad
to
hear
it
!
 
<EOS>
Now
,
I
know
what
to
do
!
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
advantage
of
asking
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
never
allow
people
to
talk
before
me
about
wastefulness
and
profligacy
,
and
so
forth
,
in
connexion
with
that
life
,
any
more
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
you
will
be
right
,
"
said
Mrs
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
son
's
tutor
is
a
conscientious
gentleman
;
and
if
I
had
not
implicit
reliance
on
my
son
,
I
should
have
reliance
on
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Should
you
?
"
said
Miss
Dartle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
 
<EOS>
Conscientious
,
is
he
?
<EOS>
Really
conscientious
,
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
am
convinced
of
it
,
"
said
Mrs
Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
very
nice
!
"
exclaimed
Miss
Dartle
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
comfort
!
 
<EOS>
Really
conscientious
?
 
<EOS>
Then
he
's
not
---
<EOS>
but
of
course
he
ca
n't
be
,
if
he
's
really
conscientious
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
shall
be
quite
happy
in
my
opinion
of
him
,
from
this

.
 
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
think
how
it
elevates
him
in
my
opinion
,
to
know
for
certain
that
he
's
really
conscientious
!
"
   
<EOS>
Her
own
views
of
every
question
,
and
her
correction
of
everything
that
was
said
to
which
she
was
opposed
,
Miss
Dartle
insinuated
in
the
same

:
sometimes
,
I
could
not
conceal
from
myself
,
with
great
power
,
though
in
contradiction
even
of
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
An
instance
happened
before
dinner
was
done
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Steerforth
speaking
to
me
about
my
intention
of
going
down
into
Suffolk
<EOS>
,
I
said
at
hazard
how
glad

should

,
if
Steerforth
would
only
go
there
with
me
;
and
explaining

that

see

old

,
and
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
's
family
<EOS>
,
I
reminded
him
of
the
boatman
whom
he
had
seen
at
school
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
That
bluff
fellow
!
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
had
a
son
with
him
,
had

he
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
his
nephew
,
"
I
replied
;
"
whom
he
adopted
,
though
,
as
a
son
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
very
pretty
little
niece
too
,
whom
he
adopted
as
a
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
his
house
---
or
rather
his
boat
,
for
he
lives
in
one
,
on
dry
land
---
is
full
of
people
who
are
objects
of
his
generosity
and
kindness
.
 
<EOS>
You
would
be
delighted
to
see
that
household
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Should
I
?
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
think
I
should
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
see
what
can
be
done
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
worth
a
journey
(
not
to
mention
the
pleasure
of
a
journey
with
you
,
Daisy
)
,
to
see
that
sort
of
people
together
,
and
to
make
one
of
'
em
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
heart
leaped
with
a
new
hope
of
pleasure
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
was
in
reference
to
the
tone
in
which
he
had
spoken
of
"
that
sort
of
people
"
,
that
Miss
Dartle
,
whose
sparkling
eyes
had
been
watchful
of
us
,
now
broke
in
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
but
,
really
?
 
<EOS>
Do
tell
me
.
 
<EOS>
Are
they
,
though
?
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
they
what
?
 
<EOS>
And
are
who
what
?
"
said
Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
sort
of
people
.
 
<EOS>
---
Are
they
really
animals
and
clods
,
and
beings
of
another
order
?
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
know
SO
much
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
there
's
a
pretty
wide
separation
between
them
and
us
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
with
indifference
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
not
to
be
expected
to
be
as
sensitive
as
we
are
.
 
<EOS>
Their
delicacy
is
not
to
be
shocked
,
or
hurt
easily
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
wonderfully
virtuous
,
I
dare
say
---
some
people
contend
for
that
,
at
least
;
and
I
am
sure
I
do
n't
want
to
contradict
them
---
but
they
have
not
very
fine
natures
,
and
they
may
be
thankful
that
,
like
their
coarse
rough
skins
,
they
are
not
easily
wounded
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Really
!
"
said
Miss
Dartle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
do
n't
know
,
now
,
when
I
have
been
better
pleased
than
to
hear
that
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
so
consoling
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
such
a
delight
to
know
that
,
when
they
suffer
,
they
do
n't
feel
!
<EOS>
Sometimes
I
have
been
quite
uneasy
for
that
sort
of
people
;
but
now
I
shall
just
dismiss
the
idea
of
them
,
altogether
.
 
<EOS>
Live
and
learn
.
<EOS>
I
had
my
doubts
,
I
confess
,
but
now
they
're
cleared
up
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
n't
know
,
and
now
I
do
know
,
and
that
shows
the
advantage
of
asking
---
do
n't
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
believed
that
Steerforth
had
said
what
he
had
,
in
jest
,
or
to
draw
Miss
Dartle
out
;
and
I
expected
him
to
say
as
much
when
she
was
gone
,
and
we
two
were
sitting
before
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
merely
asked
me
what
I
thought
of
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
very
clever
,
is
she
not
?
"
I
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
Clever
!
 
<EOS>
She
brings
everything
to
a
grindstone
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
"
and
sharpens
it
,
as
she
has
sharpened
her
own
face
and
figure
these
years
past
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
worn
herself
away
by
constant
sharpening
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
all
edge
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
remarkable
scar
that
is
upon
her
lip
!
"
<EOS>
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
Steerforth
's
face
fell
,
and
he
paused
a
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the
fact
is
,
"
he
returned
,
"
I
did
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
an
unfortunate
accident
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
a
young
boy
,
and
she
exasperated
me
,
and
I
threw
a
hammer
at
her
.
 
<EOS>
A
promising
young
angel
<EOS>
I
must
have
been
!
<EOS>
"
I
was
deeply
sorry
to
have
touched
on
such
a
painful
theme
,
but
that
was
useless
now
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
has
borne
the
mark
ever
since
,
as
you
see
,
"
said
Steerforth
;
"
and
she
'll
bear
it
to
her
grave
,
if
she
ever
rests
in
one
---
though
I
can
hardly
believe
she
will
ever
rest
anywhere
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
the
motherless
child
of
a
sort
of
cousin
of
my
father
's
.
 
<EOS>
He
died
one
day
.
 
<EOS>
My
mother
,
who
was
then
a
widow
,
brought
her
here
to
be
company
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
a
couple
of
thousand
pounds
of
her
own
,
and
saves
the
interest
of
it
every
year
,
to
add
to
the
principal
.
<EOS>
There
's
the
history
of
Miss
Rosa
Dartle
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
have
no
doubt
she
loves
you
like
a
brother
?
"
said
I.
   
"
Humph
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Steerforth
,
looking
at
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
"
Some
brothers
are
not
loved
over
much
;
and
some
love
---
but
help

,
Copperfield
!
 
<EOS>
We
'll
drink
the
daisies
of
the
field
,
in
compliment
to
you
;
and
the
lilies
of
the
valley
that
toil
not
,
neither
do
they
spin
,
in
compliment
to
me
---
the
more
shame
for
me
!
"
<EOS>
A
moody
smile
that
had
overspread
his
features
cleared
off
as
he
said
this
merrily
,
and
he
was
his
own
frank
,
winning
self
again
.
   
<EOS>
I
could
not
help
glancing
at
the
scar
with
a
painful
interest
when
we
went
in
to
tea
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
long
before
I
observed
that
it
was
the
most
susceptible
part
of
her
face
,
and
that
,
when
she
turned
pale
,
that
mark
altered
first
,
and
became
a
dull
,
lead
-
coloured
streak
,
lengthening
out
to
its
full
extent
,
like
a
mark
in
invisible
ink
brought
to
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
little
altercation
between
her
and
Steerforth
about
a
cast
of
the
dice
at
back
gammon
---
when
I
thought
her
,
for
one
moment
,
in
a
storm
of
rage
;
and
then
I
saw
it
start
forth
like
the
old
writing
on
the
wall
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
no
matter
of
wonder
to
me
to
find
Mrs
Steerforth
devoted
to
her
son
.
 
<EOS>
She
seemed
to
be
able
to
speak
or
think
about
nothing
else
.
 
<EOS>
She
showed
me
his
picture
as
an
infant
,
in
a
locket
,
with
some
of
his
baby
-
hair
in
it
;
she
showed
me
his
picture
as
he
had
been
when
I
first
knew
him
;
and
she
wore
at
her
breast
his
picture
as
he
was
now
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
letters
he
had
ever
written
to
her
<EOS>
,
she
kept
in
a
cabinet
near
her
own
chair
by
the
fire
;
and
she
would
have
read
me
some
of
them
,
and
I
should
have
been
very
glad
to
hear
them
too
,
if
he
had
not
interposed
,
and
coaxed
her
out
of
the
design
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
at
Mr
Creakle
's
,
my
son
tells
me
,
that
you
first
became
acquainted
,
"
said
Mrs
Steerforth
,
as
she
and
I
were
talking
at
one

,
while
they
played
backgammon
at
another
.
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
I
recollect
his
speaking
,
at
that
time
,
of
a
pupil
younger
than
himself
who
had
taken
his
fancy
there
;
but
your
name
,
as
you
may
suppose
,
has
not
lived
in
my
memory
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
was
very
generous
and
noble
to
me
in
those
days
,
I
assure
you
,
ma'am
,
"
said
I
,
"
and
I
stood
in
need
of
such
a
friend
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
been
quite
crushed
without
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
always
generous
and
noble
,
"
said
Mrs
Steerforth
,
proudly
.
   
<EOS>
I
subscribed
to
this
with
all
my
heart
,
God
knows
.
 
<EOS>
She
knew
I
did
;
for
the
stateliness
of
her
manner
already
abated
towards
me
,
except
when
she
spoke
in
praise
of
him
,
and
then
her
air
was
always
lofty
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
not
a
fit
school
generally
for
my
son
,
"
said
she
;
"
far
from
it
;
but
there
were
particular
circumstances
to
be
considered
at
the
time
,
of
more
importance
even
than
that
selection
.
 
<EOS>
My
son
's
high
spirit
made
it
desirable
that
he
should
be
placed
with
some
man
who
felt
its
superiority
,
and
would
be
content
to
bow
himself
before
it
;
and
we
found
such
a
man
there
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
knew
that
,
knowing
the
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
I
did
not
despise
him
the
more
for
it
,
but
thought
it
a
redeeming
quality
in
him
if
he
could
be
allowed
any
grace
for
not
resisting
one
so
irresistible
as
Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
son
's
great
capacity
was
tempted
on
,
there
,
by
a
feeling
of
voluntary
emulation
and
conscious
pride
,
"
the
fond
lady
went
on
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
would
have
risen
against
all
constraint
;
but
he
found
himself
the
monarch
of
the
place
,
and
he
haughtily
determined
to
be
worthy
of
his
station
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
like
himself
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
echoed
,
with
all
my
heart
and
soul
,
that
it
was
like
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
my
son
took
,
of
his
own
will
,
and
on
no

,
to
the
course
in
which
he
can
always
,
when
it
is
his
pleasure
,
outstrip
every

,
"
she
pursued
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
son
informs
me
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
that
you
were
quite
devoted
to
him
,
and
that
when
you
met
yesterday
you
made
yourself
known
to
him
with

of
joy
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
be
an
affected
woman
if
I
made
any
pretence
of
being
surprised
by
my
son
's
inspiring
such
emotions
;
but
I
can
not
be
indifferent
to
anyone
who
is
so
sensible
of
his
merit
,
and
I
am
very
glad
to
see
you
here
,
and
can

you
that
he
feels
an
unusual
friendship
for
you
,
and
that
you
may
rely
on
his
protection
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Dartle
played
backgammon
as
eagerly
as
she
did
everything
else
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
seen
her
,
first
,
at
the
board
,
I
should
have
fancied
that
her
figure
had
got
thin
,
and
her
eyes
had
got
large
,
over
that
pursuit
,
and
no
other
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
very
much
mistaken
if
she
missed
a
word
of
this
,
or
lost
a
look
of
mine
as
I
received
it
with
the
utmost
pleasure
,
and
honoured
by
Mrs
Steerforth
's
confidence
,
felt
older
than
I
had
done
since
I
left
Canterbury
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
evening
was
pretty
far
spent
,
and
a
tray
of
glasses
and
decanters
came
in
,
<EOS>
Steerforth
promised
,
over
the
fire
,
that
he
would
seriously
think
of
going
down
into
the
country
with
me
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
hurry
,
he
said
;
a
week
hence
would
do
;
and
his
mother
hospitably
said
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
While
we
were
talking
,
he
more
than
once
called
me
Daisy
;
which
brought
Miss
Dartle
out
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
really
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
she
asked
,
"
is
it
a
nickname
?
 
<EOS>
And
why
does
he
give
it
you
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
---
eh
?
---
because
he
thinks
you
young
and
innocent
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
so
stupid
in
these
things
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
coloured
in
replying
that
I
believed
it
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Miss
Dartle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
I
am
glad
to
know
that
!
 
<EOS>
I
ask
for
information
,
and
I
am
glad
to
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
thinks
you
young
and
innocent
;
and
so
you
are
his
friend
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
that
's
quite
delightful
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
went
to
bed
soon
after
this
,
and
Mrs
Steerforth
retired
too
.
<EOS>
Steerforth
and
I
,
after
lingering
for
half
-
an
-
hour
over
the
fire
,
talking
about
Traddles
and
all
the
rest
of
them
at
old
Salem
House
,
went
upstairs
together
.
 
<EOS>
Steerforth
's
room
was
next
to
mine
,
and
I
went
in
to
look
at
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
picture
of
comfort
,
full
of
easy
-
chairs
,
cushions
and
footstools
,
worked
by
his
mother
's
hand
,
and
with
no
sort
of
thing
omitted
that
could
help
to
render
it
complete
.
 
<EOS>
Finally
,
her
handsome
features
looked
down
on
her
darling
from
a
portrait
on
the
wall
,
as
if
it
were
even
something
to
her
that
her
likeness
should
watch
him
while
he
slept
.
   
<EOS>
I
found
the
fire
burning
clear
enough
in
my
room
by
this
time
,
and
the
curtains
drawn
before
the
windows
and
round
the
bed
,
giving
it
a
very
snug
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
down
in
a
great
chair
upon
the
hearth
to
meditate
on
my
happiness
;
and
had
enjoyed
the
contemplation
of
it
for
some
time
,
when
I
found
a
likeness
of
Miss
Dartle
looking
eagerly
at
me
from
above
the
chimney
-
piece
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
startling
likeness
,
and
necessarily
had
a
startling
look
.
<EOS>
The
painter
had
n't
made
the
scar
,
but
I
made
it
;
and
there
it
was
,
coming
and
going
;
now
confined
to
the
upper
lip
as
I
had
seen
it
at
dinner
,
and
now
showing
the
whole
extent
of
the
wound
inflicted
by
the
hammer
,
as
I
had
seen
it
when
she
was
passionate
.
   
<EOS>
I
wondered
peevishly
why
they
could
n't
put
her
anywhere
else
instead
of
quartering
her
on
me
.
 
<EOS>
To
get
rid
of
her
,
I
undressed
quickly
,
extinguished
my
light
,
and
went
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
I
fell
asleep
,
I
could
not
forget
that
she
was
still
there
looking
,
"
Is
it
really
,
though
?
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
know
"
;
and
when
I
awoke
in
the
night
,
I
found
that
I
was
uneasily
asking
all
sorts
of
people
in
my
dreams
whether
it
really
was
or
not
---
without
knowing
what
I
meant
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
21
.
<EOS>
Little
Em'ly
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
servant
in
that
house
,
a
man
who
,
I
understood
,
was
usually
with
Steerforth
,
and
had
come
into
his
service
at
the
University
,
who
was
in
appearance
a
pattern
of
respectability
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
there
never
existed
in
his
station
a
more
respectable
-
looking
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
taciturn
,
soft
-
footed
,
very
quiet
in
his
manner
,
deferential
,
observant
,
always
at
hand
when
wanted
,
and
never
near
when
not
wanted
;
but
his
great
claim
to
consideration
was
his
respectability
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
not
a
pliant
face
,
he
had
rather
a
stiff
neck
,
rather
a
tight
smooth
head
with
short
hair
clinging
to
it
at
the
sides
,
a
soft
way
of
speaking
,
with
a
peculiar
habit
of
whispering
the
letter
<EOS>
S^
<EOS>
so
distinctly
,
that
he
seemed
to
use
it
oftener
than
any
other
man
;
but
every
peculiarity
that
he
had
he
made
respectable
.
 
<EOS>
If
his
nose
had
been
upside
-
down
,
he
would
have
made
that
respectable
.
 
<EOS>
He
surrounded
himself
with
an
atmosphere
of
respectability
,
and
walked
secure
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
next
to
impossible
to
suspect
him
of
anything
wrong
,
he
was
so
thoroughly
respectable
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
could
have
thought
of
putting
him
in
a
livery
,
he
was
so
highly
respectable
.
 
<EOS>
To
have
imposed
any
derogatory
work
upon
him
,
would
have
been
to
inflict
a
wanton
insult
on
the
feelings
of
a
most
respectable
man
.
 
<EOS>
And
of
this
,
I
noticed
---
<EOS>
the
women
-
servants
in
the
household
were
so
intuitively
conscious
,
that
they
always
did
such
work
themselves
,
and
generally
while
he
read
the
paper
by
the
pantry
fire
.
   
<EOS>
Such
a
self
-
contained
man
I
never
saw
.
 
<EOS>
But
in
that
quality
,
as
in
every
other
he
possessed
,
he
only
seemed
to
be
the
more
respectable
.
 
<EOS>
Even
the
fact
that
no
one
knew
his
Christian
name
,
seemed
to
form
a
part
of
his
respectability
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
could
be
objected
against
his
surname
,
Littimer
,
by
which
he
was
known
.
<EOS>
Peter
might
have
been
hanged
,
or
Tom
transported
;
but
Littimer
was
perfectly
respectable
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
occasioned
,
I
suppose
,
by
the
reverend
nature
of
respectability
in
the
abstract
,
but
I
felt
particularly
young
in
this
man
's
presence
.
 
<EOS>
How
old
he
was
himself
,
I
could
not
guess
---
and
that
again
went
to
his
credit
on
the
same
score
;
for
in
the
calmness
of
respectability
he
might
have
numbered
fifty
years
as
well
as
thirty
.
   
<EOS>
Littimer
was
in
my
room
in
the
morning
before
I
was
up
,
to
bring
me
that
reproachful
shaving
-
water
,
and
to
put
out
my
clothes
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
undrew
the
curtains
and
looked
out
of
bed
,
I
saw
him
,
in
an
equable
temperature
of
respectability
,
unaffected
by
the
east
wind
of
January
,
and
not
even
breathing
frostily
,
standing
my
boots
right
and
left
in
the
first
dancing
position
,
and
blowing
specks
of
dust
off
my
coat
as
he
laid
it
down
like
a
baby
.
   
<EOS>
I
gave
him
good
morning
,
and
asked
him
what
o'clock
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
out
of
his
pocket
the
most
respectable
hunting
-
watch
I
ever
saw
,
and
preventing
the
spring
with
his
thumb
from
opening
far
,
looked
in
at
the
face
as
if
he
were
consulting
an
oracular
oyster
,
shut
it
up
again
,
and
said
,
if
I
pleased
,
it
was
half
past
eight
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Steerforth
will
be
glad
to
hear
how
you
have
rested
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
said
I
,
"
very
well
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
Is
Mr
Steerforth
quite
well
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
sir
,
Mr
Steerforth
is
tolerably
well
.
"
 
<EOS>
Another
of
his
characteristics
---
no
use
of
superlatives
.
 
<EOS>
A
cool
calm
medium
always
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
there
anything
more
I
can
have
the
honour
of
doing
for
you
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
The
warning
-
bell
will
ring
at
nine
;
the
family
take
breakfast
at
half
past
nine
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
I
thank
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thank
YOU
,
sir
,
if
you
please
"
;
and
with
that
,
and
with
a
little
inclination
of
his
head
when
he
passed
the
bed
-
side
,
as
an
apology
for
correcting
me
,
he
went
out
,
shutting
the
door
as
delicately
as
if
I
had
just
fallen
into
a
sweet
sleep
on
which
my
life
depended
.
   
<EOS>
Every
morning
we
held
exactly
this
conversation
:
never
any
more
,
and
never
any
less
:
and
yet
,
invariably
,
however
far
I
might
have
been
lifted
out
of
myself
over
-
night
,
and
advanced
towards
maturer
years
,
by
Steerforth
's
companionship
,
or
Mrs
Steerforth
's
confidence
,
or
Miss
Dartle
's
conversation
,
in
the
presence
of
this
most
respectable
man
I
became
,
as
our
smaller
poets
sing
,
"
a
boy
again
"
.
   
<EOS>
He
got
horses
for
us
;
and
Steerforth
,
who
knew
everything
,
gave
me
lessons
in
riding
.
 
<EOS>
He
provided
foils
for
us
,
and
Steerforth
gave
me
lessons
in
fencing
---
gloves
,
and
I
began
,
of
the
same
master
,
to
improve
in
boxing
.
 
<EOS>
It
gave
me
no
manner
of
concern
that
Steerforth
should
find
me
a
novice
in
these
sciences
,
but
I
never
could
bear
to
show
my
want
of
skill
before
the
respectable
Littimer
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
reason
to
believe
that
Littimer
understood
such
arts
himself
;
he
never
led
me
to
suppose
anything
of
the
kind
,
by
so
much
as
the
vibration
of
one
of
his
respectable
eyelashes
;
yet
whenever
he
was
by
,
while
we
were
practising
<EOS>
,
I
felt
myself
the
greenest
and
most
inexperienced
of
mortals
.
   
<EOS>
I
am
particular
about
this
man
,
because
he
made
a
particular
effect
on
me
at
that
time
,
and
because
of
what
took
place
thereafter
.
   
<EOS>
The
week
passed
away
in
a
most
delightful
manner
.
 
<EOS>
It
passed
rapidly
,
as
may
be
supposed
,
to
one
entranced
as
I
was
;
and
yet
it
gave
me
so
many
occasions
for
knowing
Steerforth
better
,
and
admiring
him
more
in
a
thousand
respects
,
that
at
its
close
I
seemed
to
have
been
with
him
for
a
much
longer
time
.
 
<EOS>
A
dashing
way
he
had
of
treating
me
like
a
plaything
,
was
more
agreeable
to
me
than
any
behaviour
he
could
have
adopted
.
 
<EOS>
It
reminded
me
of
our
old
acquaintance
;
it
seemed
the
natural
sequel
of
it
;
it
showed
me
that
he
was
unchanged
;
it
relieved
me
of
any
uneasiness
I
might
have
felt
,
in
comparing
my
merits
with
his
,
and
measuring
my
claims
upon
his
friendship
by
any
equal
standard
;
above
all
,
it
was
a
familiar
,
unrestrained
,
affectionate
demeanour
that
he
used
towards
no
one
else
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
had
treated
me
at
school
differently
from
all
the
rest
,
I
joyfully
believed
that
he
treated
me
in
life
unlike
any
other
friend
he
had
.
 
<EOS>
I
believed
that
I
was
nearer
to
his
heart
than
any
other
friend
,
and
my
own
heart
warmed
with
attachment
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
made
up
his
mind
to
go
with
me
into
the
country
,
and
the
day
arrived
for
our
departure
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
doubtful
at
first
whether
to
take
Littimer
or
not
,
but
decided
to
leave
him
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
The
respectable
creature
,
satisfied
with
his
lot
whatever
it
was
,
arranged
our
portmanteaux
on
the
little
carriage
that
was
to
take
us
into
London
,
as
if
they
were
intended
to
defy
the
shocks
of
ages
,
and
received
my
modestly
proffered
donation
with
perfect
tranquillity
.
   
<EOS>
We
bade
adieu
to
Mrs
Steerforth
and
Miss
Dartle
,
with
many
thanks
on
my
part
,
and
much
kindness
on
the
devoted
mother
's
.
 
<EOS>
The
last
thing
I
saw
was
Littimer
's
unruffled
eye
;
fraught
,
as
I
fancied
,
with
the
silent
conviction
that
I
was
very
young
indeed
.
   
<EOS>
What
I
felt
,
in
returning
so
auspiciously
to
the
old
familiar
places
,
I
shall
not
endeavour
to
describe
.
 
<EOS>
We
went
down
by
the
Mail
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
concerned
<EOS>
,
I
recollect
,
even
for
the
honour
of
Yarmouth
,
that
when
Steerforth
said
,
as
we
drove
through
its
dark
streets
to
the
inn
,
that
,
as
well
as
he
could
make
out
,
it
was
a
good
,
queer
,
out
-
of
-
the
-
way
kind
of
hole
,
I
was
highly
pleased
.
 
<EOS>
We
went
to
bed
on
our
arrival
<EOS>
(
I
observed
a
pair
of
dirty
shoes
and
gaiters
in
connexion
with
my
old
friend
the
Dolphin
as
we
passed
that
door
)
,
and
breakfasted
late
in
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Steerforth
,
who
was
in
great
spirits
,
had
been
strolling
about
the
beach
before
I
was
up
,
and
had
made
acquaintance
,
he
said
,
with
half
the
boatmen
in
the
place
.
 
<EOS>
Moreover
,
he
had
seen
,
in
the
distance
,
what
he
was
sure
must
be
the
identical
house
of
Mr
Peggotty
,
with
smoke
coming
out
of
the
chimney
;
and
had
had
a
great
mind
,
he
told
me
,
to
walk
in
and
swear
he
was
myself
grown
out
of
knowledge
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
do
you
propose
to
introduce
me
there
,
Daisy
?
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
at
your
disposal
.
 
<EOS>
Make
your
own
arrangements
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
was
thinking
that
this
evening
would
be
a
good
time
,
Steerforth
,
when
they
are
all
sitting
round
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
like
you
to
see
it
<EOS>
when
it
's
snug
,
it
's
such
a
curious
place
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
be
it
!
"
<EOS>
returned
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
evening
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
not
give
them
any
notice
that
we
are
here
,
you
know
,
"
said
I
,
delighted
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
must
take
them
by
surprise
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
of
course
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
no
fun
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
"
unless
we
take
them
by
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
see
the
natives
in
their
aboriginal
condition
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Though
they
ARE
that
sort
of
people
that
you
mentioned
,
"
I
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Aha
!
 
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
you
recollect
my
skirmishes
with
Rosa
,
do
you
?
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
with
a
quick
look
.
 
<EOS>
"
Confound
the
girl
,
I
am
half
afraid
of
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
's
like
a
goblin
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
never
mind
her
.
 
<EOS>
Now
what
are
you
going
to
do
?
 
<EOS>
You
are
going
to
see
your
nurse
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
yes
,
"
I
said
,
"
I
must
see
Peggotty
first
of
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
replied
Steerforth
,
looking
at
his
watch
.
 
<EOS>
"
Suppose
I
deliver
you
up
to
be
cried
over
for
a
couple
of
hours
.
 
<EOS>
Is
that
long
enough
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
answered
,
laughing
,
that
I
thought
we
might
get
through
it
in
that
time
,
but
that
he
must
come
also
;
for
he
would
find
that
his
renown
had
preceded
him
,
and
that
he
was
almost
as
great
a
personage
as
I
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
come
anywhere
you
like
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
"
or
do
anything
you
like
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
where
to
come
to
;
and
in
two
hours
I
'll
produce
myself
in
any
state
you
please
,
sentimental
or
comical
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
gave
him
minute
directions
for
finding
the
residence
of
Mr
Barkis
,
carrier
to
Blunderstone
and
elsewhere
;
and
,
on
this
understanding
,
went
out
alone
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
sharp
bracing
air
;
the
ground
was
dry
;
the
sea
was
crisp
and
clear
;
the
sun
was
diffusing
abundance
of
light
,
if
not
much
warmth
;
and
everything
was
fresh
and
lively
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
fresh
and
lively
myself
,
in
the
pleasure
of
being
there
,
that
I
could
have
stopped
the
people
in
the
streets
and
shaken
hands
with
them
.
   
<EOS>
The
streets
looked
small
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
The
streets
that
we
have
only
seen
as
children
always
do
<EOS>
,
I
believe
,
when
we
go
back
to
them
.
<EOS>
But
I
had
forgotten
nothing
in
them
,
and
found
nothing
changed
,
until
I
came
to
Mr
Omer
's
shop
.
 
<EOS>
OMER
AND
Joram
was
now
written
up
,
where
OMER
used
to
be
;
but
the
inscription
,
DRAPER
,
TAILOR
,
HABERDASHER
,
FUNERAL
FURNISHER
,
&
c
,
remained
as
it
was
.
   
<EOS>
My
footsteps
seemed
to
tend
so
naturally
to
the
shop
door
,
after
I
had
read
these
words
from
over
the
way
<EOS>
,
that
I
went
across
the
road
and
looked
in
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
pretty
woman
at
the
back
of
the
shop
,
dancing
a
little
child
in
her
arms
,
while
another
little
fellow
clung
to
her
apron
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
difficulty
in
recognizing
either
Minnie
or
Minnie
's
children
.
 
<EOS>
The
glass
door
of
the
parlour
was
not
open
;
but
in
the
workshop
across
the
yard
I
could
faintly
hear
the
old
tune
playing
,
as
if
it
had
never
left
off
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Mr
Omer
at
home
?
"
<EOS>
said
I
,
entering
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
see
him
,
for
a
moment
,
if
he
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
,
sir
,
he
is
at
home
,
"
said
Minnie
;
"
the
weather
do
n't
suit
his
asthma
out
of
doors
.
 
<EOS>
Joe
,
call
your
grandfather
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
little
fellow
,
who
was
holding
her
apron
,
gave
such
a
lusty
shout
,
that
the
sound
of
it
made
him
bashful
,
and
he
buried
his
face
in
her
skirts
,
to
her
great
admiration
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
a
heavy
puffing
and
blowing
coming
towards
us
,
and
soon
Mr
Omer
,
shorter
-
winded
than
of
yore
,
but
not
much
older
-
looking
,
stood
before
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Servant
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Omer
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
can
I
do
for
you
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
can
shake
hands
with
me
,
Mr
Omer
,
if
you
please
,
"
said
I
,
putting
out
my
own
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
were
very
good
-
natured
to
me
once
,
when
I
am
afraid
I
did
n't
show
that
I
thought
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Was
I
though
?
"
<EOS>
returned
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
glad
to
hear
it
,
but
I
do
n't
remember
when
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
sure
it
was
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
my
memory
has
got
as
short
as
my

,
"
said
Mr
Omer
,
looking
at

and
shaking

;
"
for
I
do
n't
remember
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

you
remember
your
coming
to

to

,

my

,

,

,

Mrs

,
and
Mr
Joram
too
---
who
was

her

then
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Lord

my

!
"
<EOS>

,

,
"
you
do

!
 
<EOS>
Minnie
,
my

,
you
recollect
?
 
<EOS>
Dear
me
,
yes
;
the
party
was
a
lady
,
I
think
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
mother
,
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
To
---
be
---
sure
,
"
said
Mr
Omer
,
touching
my

with

,
"
and
there
was
a
little
child

!
 
<EOS>
There
was
two
parties
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
party
was
laid
along
with
the
other
party
.
<EOS>
Over
at
Blunderstone
it
was
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
Dear
me
!
 
<EOS>
And
how
have
you

?
"
   
<EOS>
Very
well
,
I
thanked
him
,
as
I

had
been
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
nothing
to
grumble
at
,
you
know
,
"
said
Mr
Omer
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
find
my
breath
gets
short
,
but
it
seldom
gets

as
a
man
gets
older
.
<EOS>
I
take
it
as
it
comes
,
and
make

.
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
best
way
,
ai

it
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Omer
coughed
again
,
in
consequence
of
laughing
,
and
was
assisted

of
his

by
his
daughter
,
who
now
stood
close

,
dancing
her
smallest
child
on
the
counter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
said
Mr
Omer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
to
be
sure
.
 
<EOS>
Two
parties
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
in
that
very
ride
,
if
you
'll

,
the
day
was
named
for
my
Minnie
to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
father
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
And
now
he
's
come
into
the
business
.
 
<EOS>
And
look
here
!
 
<EOS>
The
youngest
!
"
   
<EOS>
Minnie
laughed
,
and
stroked
her
banded
hair
upon
her
temples
,
as
her
father
put
one
of
his
fat
fingers
into
the
hand
of
the
child
<EOS>
she
was
dancing
on
the
counter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Two
parties
,
of
course
!
"
said
Mr
Omer
,
nodding
his
head
retrospectively
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ex
-
actly
so
!
 
<EOS>
And
Joram
's
at
work
,
at
this
minute
,
on
a
grey
one
with
silver
nails
,
not
this
measurement
"
---
the
measurement
of
the
dancing
child
upon
the
counter
---
"
by
a
good
two
inches
.
 
<EOS>
---
Will
you
take
something
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
thanked
him
,
but
declined
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
,
"
said
Mr
Omer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Barkis
's
the
carrier
's
wife
---
<EOS>
Peggotty
's
the
boatman
's
sister
---
she

something

?
 
<EOS>
She
was

there
,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
My

the

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

my

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
---
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

ah

<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
He

that

<EOS>

<EOS>

You

<EOS>
In

,
that
Em'ly

<EOS>
Now

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
My

<EOS>
I

,
a

,

,

,

<EOS>
The

alas

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
---

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>

!
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
What

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

A

<EOS>
Here

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Then

.
   
<EOS>

Old

"

.
   
<EOS>

Oh

"

<EOS>
"
I

,

,

.
   
<EOS>

But

<EOS>
I
expressed

"
<EOS>
She

C*P

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Em'ly
,

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
Steerforth

(

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

"

<EOS>
As

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
When

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
She
sat
,
at
this

,
and
all

,
on

---
<EOS>
Ham
beside

,
where

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
all

.
   
<EOS>
As

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

,
which

men
(
I

men
,

,

)

.
 
<EOS>
We

;
and
as

all

door
to

,
from

Ham
,
and

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
A
most
engaging
little
Beauty
!
<EOS>
"
said
Steerforth
,
taking

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
It

,

quaint

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"
I

,
"

!
 
<EOS>
I
never
