so
happy
.
 
<EOS>
How
delightful
to
see
it
,
and
to
be
made
the
sharers
in
their
honest
joy
,
as
we
have
been
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
rather
a
chuckle
-
headed
fellow
for
the
girl
;
is
n't
he
?
"
said
Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
been
so
hearty
with
him
,
and
with
them
all
,
that
I
felt
a
shock
in
this
unexpected
and
cold
reply
.
 
<EOS>
But
turning
quickly
upon
him
,
and
seeing
a
laugh
in
his
eyes
,
I
answered
,
much
relieved
:
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Steerforth
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
well
for
you
to
joke
about
the
poor
!
 
<EOS>
You
may
skirmish
with
Miss
Dartle
,
or
try
to
hide
your
sympathies
in
jest
from
me
,
but
I
know
better
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
see
how
perfectly
you
understand
them
,
how
exquisitely
you
can
enter
into
happiness
like
this
plain
fisherman
's
,
or
humour
a
love
like
my
old
nurse
's
,
<EOS>
I
know
that
there
is
not
a
joy
or
sorrow
,
not
an
emotion
,
of
such
people
,
that
can
be
indifferent
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
admire
and
love
you
for
it
,
Steerforth
,
twenty
times
the
more
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
stopped
,
and
,
looking
in
my
face
,
said
,
"
Daisy
,
I
believe
you
are
in
earnest
,
and
are
good
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
we
all
were
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Next
moment
he
was
gaily
singing
Mr
Peggotty
's
song
,
as
we
walked
at
a
round
pace
back
to
Yarmouth
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
22
.
<EOS>
Some
old
scenes
,
and
some
new
people
 
Steerforth
and
I
stayed
for
more
than
a
fortnight
in
that
part
of
the
country
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
very
much
together
,
I
need
not
say
;
but
occasionally
we
were
asunder
for
some
hours
at
a
time
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
good
sailor
,
and
I
was
but
an
indifferent
one
;
and
when
he
went
out
boating
with
Mr
Peggotty
,
which
was
a
favourite
amusement
of
his
,
I
generally
remained
ashore
.
 
<EOS>
My
occupation
of
Peggotty
's
spare
-
room
put
a
constraint
upon
me
,
from
which
he
was
free
:
for
,
knowing
how
assiduously
she
attended
on
Mr
Barkis
all
day
,
I
did
not
like
to
remain
out
late
at
night
;
whereas
Steerforth
,
lying
at
the
Inn
,
had
nothing
to
consult
but
his
own
humour
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
it
came
about
,
that
I
heard
of
his
making
little
treats
for
the
fishermen
at
Mr
Peggotty
's
house
of
call
,
"
The
Willing
Mind
"
,
after
I
was
in
bed
,
and
of
his
being
afloat
,
wrapped
in
fishermen
's
clothes
,
whole
moonlight
nights
,
and
coming
back
when
the
morning
tide
was
at
flood
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
however
,
I
knew
that
his
restless
nature
and
bold
spirits
delighted
to
find
a
vent
in
rough
toil
and
hard
weather
,
as
in
any
other
means
of
excitement
that
presented
itself
freshly
to
him
;
so
none
of
his
proceedings
surprised
me
.
   
<EOS>
Another
cause
of
our
being
sometimes
apart
,
was
,
that
I
had
naturally
an
interest
in
going
over
to
Blunderstone
,
and
revisiting
the
old
familiar
scenes
of
my
childhood
;
while
Steerforth
,
after
being
there
once
,
had
naturally
no
great
interest
in
going
there
again
.
 
<EOS>
Hence
,
on
three
or
four
days
that
I
can
at
once
recall
,
we
went
our
several
ways
after
an
early
breakfast
,
and
met
again
at
a
late
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
idea
how
he
employed
his
time
in
the
interval
,
beyond
a
general
knowledge
that
he
was
very
popular
in
the
place
,
and
had
twenty
means
of
actively
diverting
himself
where
another
man
might
not
have
found
one
.
   
<EOS>
For
my
own
part
,
my
occupation
in
my
solitary
pilgrimages
was
to
recall
every
yard
of
the
old
road
as
I
went
along
it
,
and
to
haunt
the
old
spots
,
of
which
I
never
tired
.
 
<EOS>
I
haunted
them
,
as
my
memory
had
often
done
,
and
lingered
among
them
as
my
younger
thoughts
had
lingered
when
I
was
far
away
.
 
<EOS>
The
grave
beneath
the
tree
,
where
both
my
parents
lay
---
on
which
I
had
looked
out
,
when
it
was
my
father
's
only
,
with
such
curious
feelings
of
compassion
,
and
by
which
I
had
stood
,
so
desolate
,
when
it
was
opened
to
receive
my
pretty
mother
and
her
baby
---
the
grave
which
Peggotty
's
own
faithful
care
had
ever
since
kept
neat
,
and
made
a
garden
of
<EOS>
,
I
walked
near
,
by
the
hour
.
 
<EOS>
It
lay
a
little
off
the
churchyard
path
,
in
a
quiet
corner
,
not
so
far
removed
<EOS>
but
I
could
read
the
names
upon
the
stone
as
I
walked
to
and
fro
,
startled
by
the
sound
of
the
church
-
bell
when
it
struck
the
hour
,
for
it
was
like
a
departed
voice
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
My
reflections
at
these
times
were
always
associated
with
the
figure
I
was
to
make
in
life
,
and
the
distinguished
things
I
was
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
My
echoing
footsteps
went
to
no
other
tune
,
but
were
as
constant
to
that
as
if
I
had
come
home
to
build
my
castles
in
the
air
at
a
living
mother
's
side
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
great
changes
in
my
old
home
.
 
<EOS>
The
ragged
nests
,
so
long
deserted
by
the
rooks
,
were
gone
;
and
the
trees
were
lopped
and
topped
out
of
their
remembered
shapes
.
 
<EOS>
The
garden
had
run
wild
,
and
half
the
windows
of
the
house
were
shut
up
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
occupied
,
but
only
by
a
poor
lunatic
gentleman
,
and
the
people
who
took
care
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
always
sitting
at
my
little
window
,
looking
out
into
the
churchyard
;
and
I
wondered
whether
his
rambling
thoughts
ever
went
upon
any
of
the
fancies
that
used
to
occupy
mine
,
on
the
rosy
mornings
when
I
peeped
out
of
that
same
little
window
in
my
night
-
clothes
,
and
saw
the
sheep
quietly
feeding
in
the
light
of
the
rising
sun
.
   
<EOS>
Our
old
neighbours
,
Mr
and
Mrs
Grayper
,
were
gone
to
South
America
,
and
the
rain
had
made
its
way
through
the
roof
of
their
empty
house
,
and
stained
the
outer
walls
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chillip
was
married
again
to
a
tall
,
raw
-
boned
,
high
-
nosed
wife
;
and
they
had
a
weazen
little
baby
,
with
a
heavy
head
that
it
could
n't
hold
up
,
and
two
weak
staring
eyes
,
with
which
it
seemed
to
be
always
wondering
why
it
had
ever
been
born
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
with
a
singular
jumble
of
sadness
and
pleasure
that
I
used
to
linger
about
my
native
place
,
until
the
reddening
winter
sun
admonished
me
that
it
was
time
to
start
on
my
returning
walk
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
when
the
place
was
left
behind
,
and
especially
when
Steerforth
and
I
were
happily
seated
over
our
dinner
by
a
blazing
fire
,
it
was
delicious
to
think
of
having
been
there
.
 
<EOS>
So
it
was
,
though
in
a
softened
degree
,
when
I
went
to
my
neat
room
at
night
;
and
,
turning
over
the
leaves
of
the
crocodile
-
book
(
which
was
always
there
,
upon
a
little
table
)
<EOS>
,
remembered
with
a
grateful
heart
how
blest
I
was
in
having
such
a
friend
as
Steerforth
,
such
a
friend
as
Peggotty
,
and
such
a
substitute
for
what
I
had
lost
as
my
excellent
and
generous
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
MY
nearest
way
to
Yarmouth
,
in
coming
back
from
these
long
walks
,
was
by
a
ferry
.
 
<EOS>
It
landed
me
on
the
flat
between
the
town
and
the
sea
,
which
I
could
make
straight
across
,
and
so
save
myself
a
considerable
circuit
by
the
high
road
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
's
house
being
on
that
waste
-
place
,
and
not
a
hundred
yards
out
of
my
track
,
I
always
looked
in
as
I
went
by
.
 
<EOS>
Steerforth
was
pretty
sure
to
be
there
expecting
me
,
and
we
went
on
together
through
the
frosty
air
and
gathering
fog
towards
the
twinkling
lights
of
the
town
.
   
<EOS>
One
dark
evening
,
when
I
was
later
than
usual
---
for
I
had
,
that
day
,
been
making
my
parting
visit
to
Blunderstone
,
as
we
were
now
about
to
return
home
---
I
found
him
alone
in
Mr
Peggotty
's
house
,
sitting
thoughtfully
before
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
so
intent
upon
his
own
reflections
that
he
was
quite
unconscious
of
my
approach
.
<EOS>
This
,
indeed
,
he
might
easily
have
been
if
he
had
been
less
absorbed
,
for
footsteps
fell
noiselessly
on
the
sandy
ground
outside
;
but
even
my
entrance
failed
to
rouse
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
standing
close
to
him
,
looking
at
him
;
and
still
,
with
a
heavy
brow
,
he
was
lost
in
his
meditations
.
   
<EOS>
He
gave
such
a
start
when
I
put
my
hand
upon
his
shoulder
,
that
he
made
me
start
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
come
upon
me
,
"
he
said
,
almost
angrily
,
"
like
a
reproachful
ghost
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
obliged
to
announce
myself
,
somehow
,
"
I
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
I
called
you
down
from
the
stars
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
he
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
"
<EOS>
Up
from
anywhere
,
then
?
<EOS>
"
said
I
,
taking
my
seat
near
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
looking
at
the
pictures
in
the
fire
,
"
he
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
spoiling
them
for
me
,
"
said
I
,
as
he
stirred
it
quickly
with
a
piece
of
burning
wood
,
striking
out
of
it
a
train
of
red
-
hot
sparks
that
went
careering
up
the
little
chimney
,
and
roaring
out
into
the
air
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
would
not
have
seen
them
,
"
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
detest
this
mongrel
time
,
neither
day
nor
night
.
 
<EOS>
How
late
you
are
!
 
<EOS>
Where
have
you
been
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
taking
leave
of
my
usual
walk
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
have
been
sitting
here
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
glancing
round
the
room
,
"
thinking
that
all
the
people
we
found
so
glad
on
the
night
of
our
coming
down
,
might
---
to
judge
from
the
present
wasted
air
of
the
place
---
be
dispersed
,
or
dead
,
or
come
to
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
harm
.
 
<EOS>
David
,
I
wish
to
God
I
had
had
a
judicious
father
these
last
twenty
years
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Steerforth
,
what
is
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
with
all
my
soul
I
had
been
better
guided
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
.
<EOS>
"
I
wish
with
all
my
soul
I
could
guide
myself
better
!
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
passionate
dejection
in
his
manner
that
quite
amazed
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
more
unlike
himself
than
I
could
have
supposed
possible
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
better
to
be
this
poor
Peggotty
,
or
his
lout
of
a
nephew
,
"
he
said
,
getting
up
and
leaning
moodily
against
the
chimney
-
piece
,
with
his
face
towards
the
fire
,
"
than
to
be
myself
,
twenty
times
richer
and
twenty
times
wiser
,
and
be
the
torment
to
myself
that
I
have
been
,
in
this
Devil
's
bark
of
a
boat
,
within
the
last
half
-
hour
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
so
confounded
by
the
alteration
in
him
,
that
at
first
I
could
only
observe
him
in
silence
,
as
he
stood
leaning
his
head
upon
his
hand
,
and
looking
gloomily
down
at
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
I
begged
him
,
with
all
the
earnestness
I
felt
,
to
tell
me
what
had
occurred
to
cross
him
so
unusually
,
and
to
let
me
sympathize
with
him
,
if
I
could
not
hope
to
advise
him
.
 
<EOS>
Before
I
had
well
concluded
,
he
began
to
laugh
---
fretfully
at
first
,
but
soon
with
returning
gaiety
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tut
,
it
's
nothing
,
Daisy
!
<EOS>
nothing
!
"
<EOS>
he
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
at
the
inn
in
London
,
I
am
heavy
company
for
myself
,
sometimes
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
a
nightmare
to
myself
,
just
now
---
must
have
had
one
,
I
think
.
 
<EOS>
At
odd
dull
times
,
nursery
tales
come
up
into
the
memory
,
unrecognized
for
what
they
are
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
have
been
confounding
myself
with
the
bad
boy
who
"
did
n't
care
"
,
and
became
food
for
lions
---
a
grander
kind
of
going
to
the
dogs
,
I
suppose
.
 
<EOS>
What
old
women
call
the
horrors
,
have
been
creeping
over
me
from
head
to
foot
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
afraid
of
myself
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
afraid
of
nothing
else
,
I
think
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
not
,
and
yet
may
have
enough
to
be
afraid
of
too
,
"
he
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
!
 
<EOS>
So
it
goes
by
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
about
to
be
hipped
again
,
David
;
but
I
tell
you
,
my
good
fellow
,
once
more
,
that
it
would
have
been
well
for
me
(
and
for
more
than
me
)
if
I
had
had
a
steadfast
and
judicious
father
!
"
   
<EOS>
His
face
was
always
full
of
expression
,
but
I
never
saw
it
express
such
a
dark
kind
of
earnestness
as
when
he
said
these
words
,
with
his
glance
bent
on
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
much
for
that
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
making
as
if
he
tossed
something
light
into
the
air
,
with
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
"
Why
,
being
gone
,
I
am
a
man
again
,
"
like
Macbeth
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
for
dinner
!
 
<EOS>
If
I
have
not
(
Macbeth
-
like
)
broken
up
the
feast
with
most
admired
disorder
,
Daisy
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
where
are
they
all
,
I
wonder
!
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
God
knows
,
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
After
strolling
to
the
ferry
looking
for
you
,
I
strolled
in
here
and
found
the
place
deserted
.
<EOS>
That
set
me
thinking
,
and
you
found
me
thinking
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
advent
of
Mrs
Gummidge
with
a
basket
,
explained
how
the
house
had
happened
to
be
empty
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
hurried
out
to
buy
something
that
was
needed
,
against
Mr
Peggotty
's
return
with
the
tide
;
and
had
left
the
door
open
in
the
meanwhile
,
lest
Ham
and
little
Em'ly
,
with
whom
it
was
an
early
night
,
<EOS>
should
come
home
while
she
was
gone
.
 
<EOS>
Steerforth
,
after
very
much
improving
Mrs
Gummidge
's
spirits
by
a
cheerful
salutation
and
a
jocose
embrace
,
took
my
arm
,
and
hurried
me
away
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
improved
his
own
spirits
,
no
less
than
Mrs
Gummidge
's
,
for
they
were
again
at
their
usual
flow
,
and
he
was
full
of
vivacious
conversation
as
we
went
along
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
,
"
he
said
,
gaily
,
"
we
abandon
this
buccaneer
life
tomorrow
,
do
we
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
we
agreed
,
"
I
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
our
places
by
the
coach
are
taken
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
<EOS>
there
's
no
help
for
it
,
I
suppose
,
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
almost
forgotten
that
there
is
anything
to
do
in
the
world
but
to
go
out
tossing
on
the
sea
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
there
was
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
long
as
the
novelty
should
last
,
"
said
I
,
laughing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Like
enough
,
"
he
returned
;
"
though
there
's
a
sarcastic
meaning
in
that
observation
for
an
amiable
piece
of
innocence
like
my
young
friend
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
I
dare
say
I
am
a
capricious
fellow
,
David
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
I
am
;
but
while
the
iron
is
hot
,
I
can
strike
it
vigorously
too
.
<EOS>
I
could
pass
a
reasonably
good
examination
already
,
as
a
pilot
in
these
waters
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
says
you
are
a
wonder
,
"
I
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
nautical
phenomenon
,
eh
?
"
laughed
Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
he
does
,
and
you
know
how
truly
;
I
know
how
ardent
you
are
in
any
pursuit
you
follow
,
and
how
easily
you
can
master
it
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
amazes
me
most
in
you
,
Steerforth
---
that
you
should
be
contented
with
such
fitful
uses
of
your
powers
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Contented
?
"
<EOS>
he
answered
,
merrily
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
never
contented
,
except
with
your
freshness
,
my
gentle
Daisy
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
fitfulness
,
I
have
never
learnt
the
art
of
binding
myself
to
any
of
the
wheels
on
which
the
Ixions
of
these
days
are
turning
round
and
round
.
 
<EOS>
I
missed
it
somehow
in
a
bad
apprenticeship
,
and
now
do
n't
care
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
---
You
know
I
have
bought
a
boat
down
here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
an
extraordinary
fellow
you
are
,
Steerforth
!
"
<EOS>
I
exclaimed
,
stopping
---
for
this
was
the
first
I
had
heard
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
you
may
never
care
to
come
near
the
place
again
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
,
"
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
taken
a
fancy
to
the
place
.
 
<EOS>
At
all
events
,
"
walking
me
briskly
on
,
"
I
have
bought
a
boat
that
was
for
sale
---
a
clipper
,
Mr
Peggotty
says
;
and
so
she
is
---
and
Mr
Peggotty
will
be
master
of
her
in
my
absence
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
I
understand
you
,
Steerforth
!
"
<EOS>
said
I
,
exultingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
pretend
to
have
bought
it
for
yourself
,
but
you
have
really
done
so
to
confer
a
benefit
on
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
might
have
known
as
much
at
first
,
knowing
you
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
kind
Steerforth
,
how
can
I
tell
you
what
I
think
of
your
generosity
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tush
!
"
<EOS>
he
answered
,
turning
red
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
less
said
,
the
better
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
n't
I
know
<EOS>
?
"
cried
I
,
"
did
n't
I
say
that
there
was
not
a
joy
,
or
sorrow
,
or
any
emotion
of
such
honest
hearts
that
was
indifferent
to
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
aye
,
"
he
answered
,
"
you
told
me
all
that
.
 
<EOS>
There
let
it
rest
.
<EOS>
We
have
said
enough
!
"
   
<EOS>
Afraid
of
offending
him
by
pursuing
the
subject
when
he
made
so
light
of
it
<EOS>
,
I
only
pursued
it
in
my
thoughts
as
we
went
on
at
even
a
quicker
pace
than
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
must
be
newly
rigged
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
"
and
<EOS>
I
shall
leave
Littimer
behind
to
see
it
done
,
that
I
may
know
she
is
quite
complete
.
 
<EOS>
Did
I
tell
you
Littimer
had
come
down
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
!
came
down
this
morning
,
with
a
letter
from
my
mother
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As
our
looks
met
,
I
observed
that
he
was
pale
even
to
his
lips
,
though
he
looked
very
steadily
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
feared
that
some
difference
between
him
and
his
mother
might
have
led
to
his
being
in
the
frame
of
mind
in
which
I
had
found
him
at
the
solitary
fireside
.
 
<EOS>
I
hinted
so
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
no
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
shaking
his
head
,
and
giving
a
slight
laugh
.
<EOS>
"
Nothing
of
the
sort
!
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
come
down
,
that
man
of
mine
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
same
as
ever
?
<EOS>
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
same
as
ever
,
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
Distant
and
quiet
as
the
North
Pole
.
 
<EOS>
He
shall
see
to
the
boat
being
fresh
named
.
 
<EOS>
She
's
the
"
Stormy
Petrel
"
now
.
 
<EOS>
What
does
Mr
Peggotty
care
for
Stormy
Petrels
!
 
<EOS>
I
'll
have
her
christened
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
what
name
?
"
I
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
"
Little
Em'ly
"
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
had
continued
to
look
steadily
at
me
,
I
took
it
as
a
reminder
that
he
objected
to
being
extolled
for
his
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
help
showing
in
my
face
how
much
it
pleased
me
,
but
I
said
little
,
and
he
resumed
his
usual
smile
,
and
seemed
relieved
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
see
here
,
"
he
said
,
looking
before
us
,
"
where
the
original
little
Em'ly
comes
!
 
<EOS>
And
that
fellow
with
her
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
soul
,
he
's
a
true
knight
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
leaves
her
!
"
   
<EOS>
Ham
was
a
boat
-
builder
in
these
days
,
having
improved
a
natural
ingenuity
in
that
handicraft
,
until
he
had
become
a
skilled
workman
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
in
his
working
-
dress
,
and
looked
rugged
enough
,
but
manly
withal
,
and
a
very
fit
protector
for
the
blooming
little
creature
at
his
side
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
there
was
a
frankness
in
his
face
,
an
honesty
,
and
an
undisguised
show
of
his
pride
in
her
,
and
his
love
for
her
,
which
were
,
to
me
,
the
best
of
good
looks
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
,
as
they
came
towards
us
,
that
they
were
well
matched
even
in
that
particular
.
   
<EOS>
She
withdrew
her
hand
timidly
from
his
arm
as
we
stopped
to
speak
to
them
,
and
blushed
as
she
gave
it
to
Steerforth
and
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
passed
on
,
after
we
had
exchanged
a
few
words
,
she
did
not
like
to
replace
that
hand
,
but
,
still
appearing
timid
and
constrained
,
walked
by
herself
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
all
this
very
pretty
and
engaging
,
and
Steerforth
seemed
to
think
so
too
,
as
we
looked
after
them
fading
away
in
the
light
of
a
young
moon
.
   
<EOS>
Suddenly
there
passed
us
---
evidently
following
them
---
a
young
woman
whose
approach
we
had
not
observed
,
but
whose
face
I
saw
as
she
went
by
,
and
thought
I
had
a
faint
remembrance
of
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
lightly
dressed
;
looked
bold
,
and
haggard
,
and
flaunting
,
and
poor
;
but
seemed
,
for
the
time
,
to
have
given
all
that
to
the
wind
which
was
blowing
,
and
to
have
nothing
in
her
mind
but
going
after
them
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
dark
distant
level
,
absorbing
their
figures
into
itself
,
left
but
itself
visible
between
us
and
the
sea
and
clouds
,
her
figure
disappeared
in
like
manner
,
still
no
nearer
to
them
than
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
a
black
shadow
to
be
following
the
girl
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
standing
still
;
"
what
does
it
mean
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
spoke
in
a
low
voice
that
sounded
almost
strange
to
Me
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
must
have
it
in
her
mind
to
beg
of
them
,
I
think
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
A
beggar
would
be
no
novelty
,
"
said
Steerforth
;
"
but
it
is
a
strange
thing
that
the
beggar
should
take
that
shape
tonight
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
For
no
better
reason
,
truly
,
than
because
I
was
thinking
,
"
he
said
,
after
a
pause
,
"
of
something
like
it
,
when
it
came
by
.
 
<EOS>
Where
the
Devil
did
it
come
from
,
I
wonder
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
From
the
shadow
of
this
wall
,
I
think
,
"
said
I
,
as
we
emerged
upon
a
road
on
which
a
wall
abutted
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
gone
!
"
<EOS>
he
returned
,
looking
over
his
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
all
ill
go
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
Now
for
our
dinner
!
"
   
<EOS>
But
he
looked
again
over
his
shoulder
towards
the
sea
-
line
glimmering
afar
off
,
and
yet
again
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
wondered
about
it
,
in
some
broken
expressions
,
several
times
,
in
the
short
remainder
of
our
walk
;
and
only
seemed
to
forget
it
when
the
light
of
fire
and
candle
shone
upon
us
,
seated
warm
and
merry
,
at
table
.
   
<EOS>
Littimer
was
there
,
and
had
his
usual
effect
upon
me
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
said
to
him
that
I
hoped
Mrs
Steerforth
and
Miss
Dartle
were
well
,
he
answered
respectfully
(
and
of
course
respectably
)
,
that
they
were
tolerably
well
,
he
thanked
me
,
and
had
sent
their
compliments
.
<EOS>
This
was
all
,
and
yet
he
seemed
to
me
to
say
as
plainly
as
a
man
could
say
:
"
You
are
very
young
,
sir
;
you
are
exceedingly
young
.
"
   
<EOS>
We
had
almost
finished
dinner
,
when
taking
a
step
or
two
towards
the
table
,
from
the
corner
where
he
kept
watch
upon
us
,
or
rather
upon
me
,
as
I
felt
,
he
said
to
his
master
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Mowcher
is
down
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
?
"
cried
Steerforth
,
much
astonished
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Mowcher
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
on
earth
does
she
do
here
?
"
said
Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
appears
to
be
her
native
part
of
the
country
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
She
informs
me
that
she
makes
one
of
her
professional
visits
here
,
every
year
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
met
her
in
the
street
this
afternoon
,
and
she
wished
to
know
if
she
might
have
the
honour
of
waiting
on
you
after
dinner
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
the
Giantess
in
question
,
Daisy
?
"
inquired
Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
obliged
to
confess
<EOS>
---
I
felt
ashamed
,
even
of
being
at
this
disadvantage
before
Littimer
---
that
Miss
Mowcher
and
I
were
wholly
unacquainted
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
shall
know
her
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
"
<EOS>
for
she
is
one
of
the
seven
wonders
of
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
When
Miss
Mowcher
comes
,
show
her
in
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
some
curiosity
and
excitement
about
this
lady
,
especially
as
Steerforth
burst
into
a
fit
of
laughing
when
I
referred
to
her
,
and
positively
refused
to
answer
any
question
of
which
I
made
her
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
I
remained
,
therefore
,
in
a
state
of
considerable
expectation
until
the
cloth
had
been
removed
some
half
an
hour
,
and
we
were
sitting
over
our
decanter
of
wine
before
the
fire
,
when
the
door
opened
,
and
Littimer
,
with
his
habitual
serenity
quite
undisturbed
,
announced
:
   
"
Miss
Mowcher
!
"
   
<EOS>
I

at

.
 
<EOS>
I
was

,

Miss
Mowcher
was
a
long

,
she

.
 
<EOS>
Her

,

what

,

<EOS>
Throat

;

;

,

;

<EOS>

---

<EOS>

!

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
You

!
"

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

!
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
How
I
have
been
rattling
on
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
all
the
fault
of
you
<EOS>
two
wretches
.
 
<EOS>
I
forgive
you
!
 
<EOS>
"
Bob
swore
!
"
<EOS>
---
as
the
Englishman
said
for
"
Good
night
"
,
when
he
first
learnt
French
,
and
thought
it
so
like
English
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bob
swore
,
"
my
ducks
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
the
bag
slung
over
her
arm
,
and
rattling
as
she
waddled
away
,
she
waddled
to
the
door
,
where
she
stopped
to
inquire
if
she
should
leave
us
a
lock
of
her
hair
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ai
n't
I
volatile
?
"
<EOS>
she
added
,
as
a
commentary
on
this
offer
,
and
,
with
her
finger
on
her
nose
,
departed
.
   
<EOS>
Steerforth
laughed
to
that
degree
,
that
it
was
impossible
for
me
to
help
laughing
too
;
though
I
am
not
sure
I
should
have
done
so
,
but
for
this
inducement
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
had
had
our
laugh
quite
out
,
which
was
after
some
time
,
he
told
me
that
Miss
Mowcher
had
quite
an
extensive
connexion
,
and
made
herself
useful
to
a
variety
of
people
in
a
variety
of
ways
.
 
<EOS>
Some
people
trifled
with
her
as
a
mere
oddity
,
he
said
;
but
she
was
as
shrewdly
and
sharply
observant
as
anyone
he
knew
,
and
as
long
-
headed
as
she
was
short
-
armed
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
me
that
what
she
had
said
of
being
here
,
and
there
,
and
everywhere
,
was
true
enough
;
for
she
made
little
darts
into
the
provinces
,
and
seemed
to
pick
up
customers
everywhere
,
and
to
know
everybody
.
 
<EOS>
I
asked
him
what
her
disposition
was
:
whether
it
was
at
all
mischievous
,
and
if
her
sympathies
were
generally
on
the
right
side
of
things
:
but
,
not
succeeding
in
attracting
his
attention
to
these
questions
after
two
or
three
attempts
,
I
forbore
or
forgot
to
repeat
them
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
me
instead
,
with
much
rapidity
,
a
good
deal
about
her
skill
,
and
her
profits
;
and
about
her
being
a
scientific
cupper
,
if
I
should
ever
have
occasion
for
her
service
in
that
capacity
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
the
principal
theme
of
our
conversation
during
the
evening
:
<EOS>
and
when
we
parted
for
the
night
Steerforth
called
after
me
over
the
banisters
,
"
Bob
swore
!
"
<EOS>
as
I
went
downstairs
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
surprised
,
when
I
came
to
Mr
Barkis
's

,
to

Ham
walking
up

down
in
front

,
and
still

to

that
little
Em'ly

.
 
<EOS>
I
naturally

why
he
was
not
there

,
instead

pacing

?
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you

,

"

,
in

"
Em'ly
,
she
's

to
some

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

"
that

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Mas'r
Davy
,
in

,
so
'

be
,
"

"
but
look'ee

Mas'r

,
"

,

speaking

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
young

,

---
a
young
woman
,
that
Em'ly
knowed
once
,
and
doen't

.
"
   
<EOS>
When

,

<EOS>
"
It

,

,
"

,
"
as

.
 
<EOS>
Up

.
 
<EOS>
The

'

<EOS>

"

"

"

<EOS>
"

I

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
<EOS>
---

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

Endell

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
I

!
"
<EOS>
She

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
What

?
 
<EOS>
She
doen't

,

I
ca

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

her
when

,
Mas'r
Davy
,
"

Ham
,

?
 
<EOS>
Such

!
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
With

money
in

,
Em'ly
my

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
shook
him

when

---
for
that
<EOS>

me
than

anything
---

,
for

,

.
 
<EOS>
The
door
opened
then
,
and
Peggotty
appeared
,
beckoning
to
Ham
to
come
in
.
<EOS>
I
would
have
kept
away
,
but
she
came
after
me
,
entreating
me
to
come
in
too
.
 
<EOS>
Even
then
,
I
would
have
avoided
the
room
where
they
all
were
,
but
for
its
being
the
neat
-
tiled
kitchen
I
have
mentioned
more
than
once
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
opening
immediately
into
it
,
I
found
myself
among
them
before
I
considered
whither
I
was
going
.
   
<EOS>
The
girl
---
the
same
I
had
seen
upon
the
sands
---
was
near
the
fire
.
<EOS>
She
was
sitting
on
the
ground
,
with
her
head
and
one
arm
lying
on
a
chair
.
 
<EOS>
I
fancied
,
from
the
disposition
of
her
figure
,
that
Em'ly
had
but
newly
risen
from
the
chair
,
and
that
the
forlorn
head
might
perhaps
have
been
lying
on
her

.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
but
<EOS>
little
of
the
girl
's
face
,
over
which
her
hair
fell
loose
and
scattered
,
as
if
she
had
been
disordering
it
with
her
own
hands
;
but
I
saw
that
she
was
young
,
and
of
a
fair
complexion
.
 
<EOS>
Peggotty
had
been
crying
.
 
<EOS>
So
had
little
Em'ly
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
word
was
spoken
when
we
first
went
in
;
and
the
Dutch
clock
by
the
dresser
seemed
,
in
the
silence
,
to
tick
twice
as
loud
as
usual
.
 
<EOS>
Em'ly
spoke
first
.
   
<EOS>
"
Martha
wants
,
"
she
said
to
Ham
,
"
to
go
to
London
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
to
London
?
<EOS>
"
returned
Ham
.
   
<EOS>
He
stood
between
them
,
looking
on
the
prostrate
girl
with
a
mixture
of
compassion
for
her
,
and
of
jealousy
of
her
holding
any
companionship
with
her
whom
he
loved
so
well
,
which
I
have
always
remembered
distinctly
.
 
<EOS>
They
both
spoke
as
if
she
were
ill
;
in
a
soft
,
suppressed
tone
that
was
plainly
heard
,
although
it
hardly

above
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
Better
there
than
here
,
"
said
a
third
voice
aloud
---
Martha
's
,
though
she
did
not
move
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
one
knows
me
there
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
knows
me
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
will
she
do
there
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Ham
.
   
<EOS>
She
lifted
up
her

,
and
looked
darkly
round
at

for
a

;
then
laid

again
,
and
curved

about

,
as

in
a

,

,
might

.
   
<EOS>
"
She
will
try
to
do
well
,
"
said
little

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
know
what
she
has
said
to
us
.
 
<EOS>
Does
he
---
do
they
---
aunt
?
"
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
shook
her
head
compassionately
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
try
,
"
said
Martha
,
"
if
you
'll
help
me
away
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
can
do
worse
than
I
have
done
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
do
better
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
"
with

,
"
take
me

these

,
where
the
whole

knows
me
from

!
"
   
<EOS>
As
Em'ly
held

to
Ham
,
I
saw
him
put
in
it
a
little
canvas
bag
.
 
<EOS>
She
took
it
,
as
if
she
thought
it
were
her
purse
,
and
made
a

or
two
forward
;
but
finding
her
mistake
,
came
back
to
where
he
had
retired
near
me
,
and
showed
it
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
yourn
,
Em'ly
,
"
I
could
hear

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
nowt
in
all
the
wureld
that
ai
n't
yourn
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
It
ai
n't
of
no
delight
to
me
,
except
for
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
tears
rose
freshly
in
her
eyes
,
but
she
turned
away
and
went
to
Martha
.
 
<EOS>
What
she
gave
her
,
I
do
n't
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
her
stooping
over
her
,
and
putting
money
in
her
bosom
.
 
<EOS>
She
whispered
something
,
as
she
asked
was
that
enough
?
 
<EOS>
"
More
than
enough
,
"
the
other
said
,
and
took
her
hand
and
kissed
it
.
   
<EOS>
Then
Martha
arose
,
and
gathering
her
shawl
about
her
,
covering
her
face
with
it
,
and
weeping
aloud
,
went
slowly
to
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
She
stopped
a
moment
before
going
out
,
as
if
she
would
have
uttered
something
or
turned
back
;
but
no
word
passed
her

.
 
<EOS>
Making
the
same
low
,
dreary
,
wretched
moaning
in
her

,
she
went
away
.
   
<EOS>
As
the
door
closed
,
little
Em'ly
looked
at
us
three
in
a
hurried
manner
and
then
hid
her
face
in
her
hands
,
and
fell
to
sobbing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Doen't
,
Em'ly
!
"
said
Ham
,
tapping
her
gently

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Doen't
,
my
dear
!
 
<EOS>
You
<EOS>
doen't
ought
to
cry
so
,
pretty
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Ham
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
,
still
weeping
pitifully
,
"
I
am
not
so
good

girl
as
I
ought

!
 
<EOS>
I
know
<EOS>
I
have
not
the
thankful
heart
,
sometimes
,
I
ought
to
have
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
<EOS>
yes
,
you
have
<EOS>
,
I
'm
sure
,
"
said
Ham
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
no
!
<EOS>
no
!
"
cried

Em'ly
,
sobbing
,
and

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter

.
<EOS>
I

When

morning
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
The

to

---

what

;
and

.
   
<EOS>
While

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
He

,

,

St

's

---
what

to

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
's

out
-

-

place
,
where
they
administer
what
is
called

law
,
and

with

monsters
of
acts
of

,
which
three
-

world
know

about
,
and
the

supposes
to
have

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
's

place
that
has
an
ancient
monopoly
in
suits
about
people
's

and
people
's

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
,

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

,

"

"

"

,

evidence
,
pro
and

,

who

;
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
They

:

,

;

"

.
 
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
Both

,

.
 
<EOS>
On

kindly
,

.
 
<EOS>
They

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
I

's
light

,
and
,

"

,

scruple
of
telling
me
that
it
had
occurred
to
her
,
on
her
lately
visiting
her
own
proctor
in
Doctors
'
Commons
for
the
purpose
of
settling
her
will
in
my
favour
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
laudable
proceeding
on
the
part
of
our
aunt
,
at
all
events
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
when
I
mentioned
it
;
"
and
one
deserving
of
all
encouragement
.
 
<EOS>
Daisy
,
my
advice
is
that
you
take
kindly
to
Doctors
'
Commons
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
quite
made
up
my
mind
to
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
then
told
Steerforth
that
my
aunt
was
in
town
awaiting
me
(
as
I
found
from
her
letter
)
,
and
that
she
had
taken
lodgings
for
a
week
at
a
kind
of
private
hotel
at
Lincoln
's
Inn
Fields
,
where
there
was
a
stone
staircase
,
and
a
convenient
door
in
the
roof
;
my
aunt
being
firmly
persuaded
that
every
house
in
London
was
going
to
be
burnt
down
every
night
.
   
<EOS>
We
achieved
the
rest
of
our
journey
pleasantly
,
sometimes
recurring
to
Doctors
'
Commons
,
and
anticipating
the
distant
days
when
I
should
be
a
proctor
there
,
which
Steerforth
pictured
in
a
variety
of
humorous
and
whimsical
lights
,
that
made
us
both
merry
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
came
to
our
journey
's
end
,
he
went
home
,
engaging
to
call
upon
me
next
day
but
one
;
and
I
drove
to
Lincoln
's
Inn
Fields
,
where
I
found
my
aunt
up
,
and
waiting
supper
.
   
<EOS>
If
I
had
been
round
the
world
since
we
parted
,
we
could
hardly
have
been
better
pleased
to
meet
again
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
cried
outright
as
she
embraced
me
;
and
said
,
pretending
to
laugh
,
that
if
my
poor
mother
had
been
alive
,
that
silly
little
creature
would
have
shed
tears
,
she
had
no
doubt
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
you
have
left
Mr
Dick
behind
,
aunt
?
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
Janet
,
how
do
you
do
?
"
   
<EOS>
As
Janet
curtsied
,
hoping
I
was
well
,
I
observed
my
aunt
's
visage
lengthen
very
much
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
for
it
,
too
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
rubbing
her
nose
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
had
no
peace
of
mind
,
Trot
,
since
I
have
been
here
.
<EOS>
"
Before
I
could
ask
why
,
she
told
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
convinced
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
laying
her
hand
with
melancholy
firmness
on
the
table
,
"
that
Dick
's
character
is
not
a
character
to
keep
the
donkeys
off
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
confident
he
wants
strength
of
purpose
.
<EOS>
I
ought
to
have
left
Janet
at
home
,
instead
,
and
then
my
mind
might
perhaps
have
been
at
ease
.
 
<EOS>
If
ever
there
was
a
donkey
trespassing
on
my
green
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
with
emphasis
,
"
there
was
one
this
afternoon
at
four
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
A
cold
feeling
came
over
me
from
head
to
foot
,
and
I
know
it
was
a
donkey
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
tried
to
comfort
her
on
this
point
,
but
she
rejected
consolation
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
donkey
,
"
said
my
aunt
;
"
and
it
was
the
one
with
the
stumpy
tail
which
that
Murdering
sister
of
a
woman
rode
,
when
she
came
to
my
house
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
This
had
been
,
ever
since
<EOS>
,
the
only
name
my
aunt
knew
for
Miss
Murdstone
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
there
is
any
Donkey
in
Dover
,
whose
audacity
it
is
harder
to
me
to
bear
than
another
's
,
that
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
striking
the
table
,
"
is
the
animal
!
"
   
<EOS>
Janet
ventured
to
suggest
that
my
aunt
might
be
disturbing
herself
unnecessarily
,
and
that
she
believed
the
donkey
in
question
was
then
engaged
in
the
sand
-
and
-
gravel
line
of
business
,
and
was
not
available
for
purposes
of
trespass
.
 
<EOS>
But
my
aunt
would
n't
hear
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
Supper
was
comfortably
served
and
hot
,
though
my
aunt
's
rooms
were
very
high
up
---
whether
that
she
might
have
more
stone
stairs
for
her
money
,
or
might
be
nearer
to
the
door
in
the
roof
,
I
do
n't
know
---
and
consisted
of
a
roast
fowl
,
a
steak
,
and
some
vegetables
,
to
all
of
which
I
did
ample
justice
,
and
which
were
all
excellent
.
<EOS>
But
my
aunt
had
her
own
ideas
concerning
London
provision
,
and
ate
but
little
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
this
unfortunate
fowl
was
born
and
brought
up
in
a
cellar
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
and
never
took
the
air
except
on
a
hackney
coach
-
stand
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
the
steak
may
be
beef
,
but
I
do
n't
believe
it
.
<EOS>
Nothing
's
genuine
in
the
place
,
in
my
opinion
,
but
the
dirt
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
think
the
fowl
may
have
come
out
of
the
country
,
aunt
?
<EOS>
"
I
hinted
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
not
,
"
returned
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
no
pleasure
to
a
London
tradesman
to
sell
anything
which
was
what
he
pretended
it
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
did
not
venture
to
controvert
this
opinion
,
but
I
made
a
good
supper
,
which
it
greatly
satisfied
her
to
see
me
do
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
table
was
cleared
,
Janet
assisted
her
to
arrange
her
hair
,
to
put
on
her
nightcap
,
which
was
of
a
smarter
construction
than
usual
(
"
in
case
of
fire
"
,
my
aunt
said
)
,
and
to
fold
her
gown
back
over
her
knees
,
these
being
her
usual
preparations
for
warming
herself
before
going
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
I
then
made
her
,
according
to
certain
established
regulations
from
which
no
deviation
,
however
slight
,
could
ever
be
permitted
,
a
glass
of
hot
wine
and
water
,
and
a
slice
of
toast
cut
into
long
thin
strips
.
 
<EOS>
With
these
accompaniments
we
were
left
alone
to
finish
the
evening
,
my
aunt
sitting
opposite
to
me
drinking
her
wine
and
water
;
soaking
her
strips
of
toast
in
it
,
one
by
one
,
before
eating
them
;
and
looking
benignantly
on
me
,
from
among
the
borders
of
her
nightcap
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Trot
,
"
she
began
,
"
what
do
you
think
of
the
proctor
plan
?
<EOS>
Or
have
you
not
begun
to
think
about
it
yet
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
thought
a
good
deal
about
it
,
my
dear
aunt
,
and
I
have
talked
a
good
deal
about
it
with
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
I
like
it
very
much
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
I
like
it
exceedingly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
cheering
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
only
one
difficulty
,
aunt
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Say
what
it
is
,
Trot
,
"
she
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
want
to
ask
,
aunt
,
as
this
seems
,
from
what
I
understand
,
to
be
a
limited
profession
,
whether
my
entrance
into
it
would
not
be
very
expensive
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
will
cost
,
"
returned
my
aunt
,
"
to
article
you
,
just
a
thousand
pounds
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
dear
aunt
,
"
said
I
,
drawing
my
chair
nearer
,
"
I
am
uneasy
in
my
mind
about
that
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
large
sum
of
money
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
expended
a
great
deal
on
my
education
,
and
have
always
been
as
liberal
to
me
in
all
things
as
it
was
possible
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
been
the
soul
of
generosity
.
 
<EOS>
Surely
there
are
some
ways
in
which
I
might
begin
life
with
hardly
any
outlay
,
and
yet
begin
with
a
good
hope
of
getting
on
by
resolution
and
exertion
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
sure
that
it
would
not
be
better
to
try
that
course
?
 
<EOS>
Are
you
certain
that
you
can
afford
to
part
with
so
much
money
,
and
that
it
is
right
that
it
should
be
so
expended
?
 
<EOS>
I
only
ask
you
,
my
second
mother
,
to
consider
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
certain
?
"
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
finished
eating
the
piece
of
toast
on
which
she
was
then
engaged
,
looking
me
full
in
the
face
all
the
while
;
and
then
setting
her
glass
on
the
chimney
-
piece
,
and
folding
her
hands
upon
her
folded
skirts
,
replied
as
follows
:
   
<EOS>
"
Trot
,
my
child
,
if
I
have
any
object
in
life
,
it
is
to
provide
for
your
being
a
good
,
a
sensible
,
and
a
happy
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
bent
upon
it
---
so
is
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
like
some
people
that
I
know
to
hear
Dick
's
conversation
on
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
Its
sagacity
is
wonderful
.
 
<EOS>
But
no
one
knows
the
resources
of
that
man
's
intellect
,
except
myself
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
stopped
for
a
moment
to
take
my
hand
between
hers
,
and
went
on
:
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
in
vain
,
Trot
,
to
recall
the
past
,
unless
it
works
some
influence
upon
the
present
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
might
have
been
better
friends
with
your
poor
father
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
might
have
been
better
friends
with
that
poor
child
your
mother
,
even
after
your
sister
Betsey
Trotwood
disappointed
me
.
 
<EOS>
When
you
came
to
me
,
a
little
runaway
boy
,
all
dusty
and
way
-
worn
,
perhaps
I
thought
so
.
 
<EOS>
From
that
time
until
now
,
Trot
,
you
have
ever
been
a
credit
to
me
and
a
pride
and
a
pleasure
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
other
claim
upon
my
means
;
at
least
"
---
here
to
my
surprise
she
hesitated
,
and
was
confused
---
"
no
,
I
have
no
other
claim
upon
my
means
---
and
you
are
my
adopted
child
.
<EOS>
Only
be
a
loving
child
to
me
in
my
age
,
and
bear
with
my
whims
and
fancies
;
and
you
will
do
more
for
an
old
woman
whose
prime
of
life
was
not
so
happy
or
conciliating
as
it
might
have
been
,
than
ever
that
old
woman
did
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
the
first
time
I
had
heard
my
aunt
refer
to
her
past
history
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
magnanimity
in
her
quiet
way
of
doing
so
,
and
of
dismissing
it
,
which
would
have
exalted
her
in
my
respect
and
affection
,
if
anything
could
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
is
agreed
and
understood
between
us
,
now
,
Trot
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
and
we
need
talk
of
this
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
a
kiss
,
and
we
'll
go
to
the
Commons
after
breakfast
tomorrow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
We
had
a
long
chat
by
the
fire
before
we
went
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
I
slept
in
a
room
on
the
same
floor
with
my
aunt
's
,
and
was
a
little
disturbed
in
the
course
of
the
night
by
her
knocking
at
my
door
as
often
as
she
was
agitated
by
a
distant
sound
of
hackney
-
coaches
or
market
-
carts
,
and
inquiring
,
"
if
I
heard
the
engines
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
But
towards
morning
she
slept
better
,
and
suffered
me
to
do
so
too
.
   
<EOS>
At
about
mid
-
day
,
we
set
out
for
the
office
of
Messrs
Spenlow
and
Jorkins
,
in
Doctors
'
Commons
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
who
had
this
other
general
opinion
in
reference
to
London
,
that
every
man
she
saw
was
a
pickpocket
,
gave
me
her
purse
to
carry
for
her
,
which
had
ten
guineas
in
it
and
some
silver
.
   
<EOS>
We
made
a
pause
at
the
toy
shop
in
Fleet
Street
,
to
see
the
giants
of
Saint
Dunstan
's
strike
upon
the
bells
---
we
had
timed
our
going
,
so
as
to
catch
them
at
it
,
at
twelve
o'clock
---
and
then
went
on
towards
Ludgate
Hill
,
and
St
Paul
's
Churchyard
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
crossing
to
the
former
place
,
when
I
found
that
my
aunt
greatly
accelerated
her
speed
,
and
looked
frightened
.
 
<EOS>
I
observed
,
at
the
same
time
,
that
a
lowering
ill
-
dressed
man
who
had
stopped
and
stared
at
us
in
passing
,
a
little
before
,
was
coming
so
close
after
us
as
to
brush
against
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Trot
!
 
<EOS>
My
dear
Trot
!
"
cried
my
aunt
,
in
a
terrified
whisper
,
and
pressing
my
arm
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
I
am
to
do
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
alarmed
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
nothing
to
be
afraid
of
.
<EOS>
Step
into
a
shop
,
and
I
'll
soon
get
rid
of
this
fellow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
child
!
<EOS>
"
she
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
speak
to
him
for
the
world
.
<EOS>
I
entreat
,
I
order
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
Heaven
,
aunt
!
<EOS>
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
nothing
but
a
sturdy
beggar
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
know
what
he
is
!
"
replied
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
know
who
he
is
!
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
know
what
you
say
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
had
stopped
in
an
empty
door
-
way
,
while
this
was
passing
,
and
he
had
stopped
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
look
at
him
!
"
<EOS>
said
my
aunt
,
as
I
turned
my
head
indignantly
,
"
but
get
me
a
coach
,
my
dear
,
and
wait
for
me
in
St
Paul
's
Churchyard
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wait
for
you
?
"
<EOS>
I
replied
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
rejoined
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
go
alone
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
go
with
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
him
,
aunt
?
 
<EOS>
This
man
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
in
my
senses
,
"
she
replied
,
"
and
I
tell
you
I
must
.
 
<EOS>
Get
mea
coach
!
"
   
<EOS>
However
much
astonished
I
might
be
,
I
was
sensible
that
I
had
no
right
to
refuse
compliance
with
such
a
peremptory
command
.
 
<EOS>
I
hurried
away
a
few
paces
,
and
called
a
hackney
-
chariot
which
was
passing
empty
.
 
<EOS>
Almost
before
I
could
let
down
the
steps
,
my
aunt
sprang
in
<EOS>
,
I
do
n't
know
how
,
and
the
man
followed
.
 
<EOS>
She
waved
her
hand
to
me
to
go
away
,
so
earnestly
,
that
,
all
confounded
as
I
was
,
I
turned
from
them
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
In
doing
so
,
I
heard
her
say
to
the
coachman
,
"
Drive
anywhere
!
 
<EOS>
Drive
straight
on
!
"
<EOS>
and
presently
the
chariot
passed
me
,
going
up
the
hill
.
   
<EOS>
What
Mr
Dick
had
told
me
,
and
what
I
had
supposed
to
be
a
delusion
of
his
,
now
came
into
my
mind
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
doubt
that
this
person
was
the
person
of
whom
he
had
made
such
mysterious
mention
,
though
what
the
nature
of
his
hold
upon
my
aunt
could
possibly
be
,
I
was
quite
unable
to
imagine
.
 
<EOS>
After
half
an
hour
's
cooling
in
the
churchyard
,
I
saw
the
chariot
coming
back
.
 
<EOS>
The
driver
stopped
beside
me
,
and
my
aunt
was
sitting
in
it
alone
.
   
<EOS>
She
had
not
yet
sufficiently
recovered
from
her
agitation
to
be
quite
prepared
for
the
visit
we
had
to
make
.
 
<EOS>
She
desired
me
to
get
into
the
chariot
,
and
to
tell
the
coachman
to
drive
slowly
up
and
down
a
little
while
.
 
<EOS>
She
said
no
more
,
except
,
<EOS>
"
My
dear
child
,
never
ask
me
what
it
was
,
and
do
n't
refer
to
it
,
"
until
she
had
perfectly
regained
her
composure
,
when
she
told
me
she
was
quite
herself
now
,
and
we
might
get
out
.
 
<EOS>
On
her
giving
me
her
purse
to
pay
the
driver
,
I
found
that
all
the
guineas
were
gone
,
and
only
the
loose
silver
remained
.
   
<EOS>
Doctors
'
Commons
was
approached
by
a
little
low
archway
.
 
<EOS>
Before
we
had
taken
many
paces
down
the
street
beyond
it
,
the
noise
of
the
city
seemed
to
melt
,
as
if
by
magic
,
into
a
softened
distance
.
 
<EOS>
A
few
dull
courts
and
narrow
ways
brought
us
to
the
sky
-
lighted
offices
of
Spenlow
and
Jorkins
;
in
the
vestibule
of
which
temple
,
accessible
to
pilgrims
without
the
ceremony
of
knocking
,
three
or
four
clerks
were
at
work
as
copyists
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
these
,
a
little
dry
man
,
sitting
by
himself
,
who
wore
a
stiff
brown
wig
that
looked
as
if
it
were
made
of
gingerbread
,
rose
to
receive
my
aunt
,
and
show
us
into
Mr
Spenlow
's
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Spenlow
's
in
Court
,
ma'am
,
"
said
the
dry
man
;
"
it
's
an
Arches
day
;
but
it
's
close
by
,
and
I
'll
send
for
him
directly
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
we
were
left
to
look
about
us
while
Mr
Spenlow
was
fetched
,
I
availed
myself
of
the
opportunity
.
 
<EOS>
The
furniture
of
the
room
was
old
-
fashioned
and
dusty
;
and
the
green
baize
on
the
top
of
the
writing
-
table
had
lost
all
its
colour
,
and
was
as
withered
and
pale
as
an
old
pauper
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
a
great
many
bundles
of
papers
on
it
,
some
endorsed
as
Allegations
,
and
some
(
to
my
surprise
)
as
Libels
,
and
some
as
being
in
the
Consistory
Court
,
and
some
in
the
Arches
Court
,
and
some
in
the
Prerogative
Court
,
and
some
in
the
Admiralty
Court
,
and
some
in
the
Delegates
'
Court
;
giving
me
occasion
to
wonder
much
,
how
many
Courts
there
might
be
in
the
gross
,
and
how
long
it
would
take
to
understand
them
all
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
these
,
there
were
sundry
immense
manuscript
Books
of
Evidence
taken
on
affidavit
,
strongly
bound
,
and
tied
together
in
massive
sets
,
a
set
to
each
cause
,
as
if
every
cause
were
a
history
in
ten
or
twenty
volumes
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
looked
tolerably
expensive
,
I
thought
,
and
gave
me
an
agreeable
notion
of
a
proctor
's
business
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
casting
my
eyes
with
increasing
complacency
over
these
and
many
similar
objects
,
when
hasty
footsteps
were
heard
in
the
room
outside
,
and
Mr
Spenlow
,
in
a
black
gown
trimmed
with
white
fur
,
came
hurrying
in
,
taking
off
his
hat
as
he
came
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
a
little
light
-
haired
gentleman
,
with
undeniable
boots
,
and
the
stiffest
of
white
cravats
and
shirt
-
collars
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
buttoned
up
,
mighty
trim
and
tight
,
and
must
have
taken
a
great
deal
of
pains
with
his
whiskers
,
which
were
accurately
curled
.
 
<EOS>
His
gold
watch
-
chain
was
so
massive
,
that
a
fancy
came
across
me
,
that
he
ought
to
have
a
sinewy
golden
arm
,
to
draw
it
out
with
,
like
those
which
are
put
up
over
the
goldbeaters
'
shops
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
got
up
with
such
care
,
and
was
so
stiff
,
that
he
could
hardly
bend
himself
;
being
obliged
,
when
he
glanced
at
some
papers
on
his
desk
,
after
sitting
down
in
his
chair
,
to
move
his
whole
body
,
from
the
bottom
of
his
spine
,
like
Punch
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
previously
been
presented
by
my
aunt
,
and
had
been
courteously
received
.
 
<EOS>
He
now
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
And
so
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
you
think
of
entering
into
our
profession
?
 
<EOS>
I
casually
mentioned
to
Miss
Trotwood
,
when
I
had
the
pleasure
of
an
interview
with
her
the
other
day
,
"
---
with
another
inclination
of
his
body
---
Punch
again
---
"
that
there
was
a
vacancy
here
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Trotwood
was
good
enough
to
mention
that
she
had
a
nephew
who
was
her
peculiar
care
,
and
for
whom
she
was
seeking
to
provide
genteelly
in
life
.
 
<EOS>
That
nephew
,
I
believe
,
I
have
now
the
pleasure
of
"
---
Punch
again
.
<EOS>
I
bowed
my
acknowledgements
,
and
said
,
my
aunt
had
mentioned
to
me
that
there
was
that
opening
,
and
that
I
believed
I
should
like
it
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
That
I
was
strongly
inclined
to
like
it
,
and
had
taken
immediately
to
the
proposal
.
 
<EOS>
That
I
could
not
absolutely
pledge
myself
to
like
it
,
until
I
knew
something
more
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
That
although
it
was
little
else
than
a
matter
of
form
,
I
presumed
I
should
have
an
opportunity
of
trying
how
I
liked
it
,
before
I
bound
myself
to
it
irrevocably
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
surely
!
<EOS>
surely
!
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
always
,
in
this
house
,
propose
a
month
---
an
initiatory
month
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
be
happy
,
myself
,
to
propose
two
months
---
three
---
an
indefinite
period
,
in
fact
---
<EOS>
but
I
have
a
partner
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jorkins
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
And
the
premium
,
sir
,
"
I
returned
,
"
is
a
thousand
pounds
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
the
premium
,
Stamp
included
,
is
a
thousand
pounds
,
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
I
have
mentioned
to
Miss
Trotwood
,
I
am
actuated
by
no
mercenary
considerations
;
few
men
are
less
so
,
I
believe
;
but
Mr
Jorkins
has
his
opinions
on
these
subjects
,
and
I
am
bound
to
respect
Mr
Jorkins
's
opinions
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jorkins
thinks
a
thousand
pounds
too
little
,
in
short
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
,
sir
,
"
said
I
,
still
desiring
to
spare
my
aunt
,
"
that
it
is
not
the
custom
here
,
if
an
articled
clerk
were
particularly
useful
,
and
made
himself
a
perfect
master
of
his
profession
"
---
I
could
not
help
blushing
<EOS>
,
this
looked
so
like
praising
myself
---
"
I
suppose
it
is
not
the
custom
,
in
the
later
years
of
his
time
,
to
allow
him
any
---
"
   
Mr
Spenlow
,
by
a
great
effort
,
just
lifted
his
head
far
enough
out
of
his
cravat
to
shake
it
,
and
answered
,
anticipating
the
word
"
salary
"
:
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
say
what
consideration
I
might
give
to
that
point
myself
,
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
,
if
I
were
unfettered
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jorkins
is
immovable
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
quite
dismayed
by
the
idea
of
this
terrible
Jorkins
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
found
out
afterwards
that
he
was
a
mild
man
of
a
heavy
temperament
,
whose
place
in
the
business
was
to
keep
himself
in
the
background
,
and
be
constantly
exhibited
by
name
as
the
most
obdurate
and
ruthless
of
men
.
 
<EOS>
If
a
clerk
wanted
his
salary
raised
,
Mr
Jorkins
would
n't
listen
to
such
a
proposition
.
 
<EOS>
If
a
client
were
slow
to
settle
his
bill
of
costs
,
Mr
Jorkins
was
resolved
to
have
it
paid
;
and
however
painful
these
things
might
be
(
and
always
were
)
to
the
feelings
of
Mr
Spenlow
,
Mr
Jorkins
would
have
his
bond
.
 
<EOS>
The
heart
and
hand
of
the
good
angel
Spenlow
would
have
been
always
open
,
but
for
the
restraining
demon
Jorkins
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
have
grown
older
,
I
think
I
have
had
experience
of
some
other
houses
doing
business
on
the
principle
of
Spenlow
and
Jorkins
!
   
<EOS>
It
was
settled
that
I
should
begin
my
month
's
probation
as
soon
as
I
pleased
,
and
that
my
aunt
need
neither
remain
in
town
nor
return
at
its
expiration
,
as
the
articles
of
agreement
,
of
which
I
was
to
be
the
subject
,
could
easily
be
sent
to
her
at
home
for
her
signature
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
had
got
so
far
,
Mr
Spenlow
offered
to
take
me
into
Court
then
and
there
,
and
show
me
what
sort
of
place
it
was
.
<EOS>
As
I
was
willing
enough
to
know
,
we
went
out
with
this
object
,
leaving
my
aunt
behind
;
who
would
trust
herself
,
she
said
,
in
no
such
place
,
and
who
,
I
think
,
regarded
all
Courts
of
Law
as
a
sort
of
powder
-
mills
that
might
blow
up
at
any
time
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Spenlow
conducted
me
through
a
paved
courtyard
formed
of
grave
brick
houses
,
which
I
inferred
,
from
the
Doctors
'
names
upon
the
doors
,
to
be
the
official
abiding
-
places
of
the
learned
advocates
of
whom
Steerforth
had
told
me
;
and
into
a
large
dull
room
,
not
unlike
a
chapel
to
my
thinking
,
on
the
left
hand
.
 
<EOS>
The
upper
part
of
this
room
was
fenced
off
from
the
rest
;
and
there
,
on
the
two
sides
of
a
raised
platform
of
the
horse
-
shoe
form
,
sitting
on
easy
old
-
fashioned
dining
-
room
chairs
,
were
sundry
gentlemen
in
red
gowns
and
grey
wigs
,
whom
I
found
to
be
the
Doctors
aforesaid
.
<EOS>
Blinking
over
a
little
desk
like
a
pulpit
-
desk
,
in
the
curve
of
the
horse
-
shoe
,
was
an
old
gentleman
,
whom
,
if
I
had
seen
him
in
an
aviary
,
I
should
certainly
have
taken
for
an
owl
,
but
who
,
I
learned
,
was
the
presiding
judge
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
space
within
the
horse
-
shoe
,
lower
than
these
,
that
is
to
say
,
on
about
the
level
of
the
floor
,
were
sundry
other
gentlemen
,
of
Mr
Spenlow
's
rank
,
and
dressed
like
him
in
black
gowns
with
white
fur
upon
them
,
sitting
at
a
long
green
table
.
 
<EOS>
Their
cravats
were
in
general
stiff
,
I
thought
,
and
their
looks
haughty
;
but
in
this
last
respect
I
presently
conceived
I
had
done
them
an
injustice
,
for
when
two
or
three
of
them
had
to
rise
and
answer
a
question
of
the
presiding
dignitary
,
I
never
saw
anything
more
sheepish
.
 
<EOS>
The
public
,
represented
by
a
boy
with
a
comforter
,
and
a
shabby
-
genteel
man
secretly
eating
crumbs
out
of
his
coat
pockets
,
was
warming
itself
at
a
stove
in
the
centre
of
the
Court
.
 
<EOS>
The
languid
stillness
of
the
place
was
only
broken
by
the
chirping
of
this
fire
and
by
the
voice
of
one
of
the
Doctors
,
who
was
wandering
slowly
through
a
perfect
library
of
evidence
,
and
stopping
to
put
up
,
from
time
to
time
,
at
little
roadside
inns
of
argument
on
the
journey
.
<EOS>
Altogether
,
I
have
never
,
on
any
occasion
,
made
one
at
such
a
cosey
,
dosey
,
old
-
fashioned
,
time
-
forgotten
,
sleepy
-
headed
little
family
-
party
in
all
my
life
;
and
I
felt
it
would
be
quite
a
soothing
opiate
to
belong
to
it
in
any
character
---
except
perhaps
as
a
suitor
.
   
<EOS>
Very
well
satisfied
with
the
dreamy
nature
of
this
retreat
,
I
informed
Mr
Spenlow
that
I
had
seen
enough
for
that
time
,
and
we
rejoined
my
aunt
;
in
company
with
whom
I
presently
departed
from
the
Commons
,
feeling
very
young
when
I
went
out
of
Spenlow
and
Jorkins
's
,
on
account
of
the
clerks
poking
one
another
with
their
pens
to
point
me
out
.
   
<EOS>
We
arrived
at
Lincoln
's
Inn
Fields
without
any
new
adventures
,
except
encountering
an
unlucky
donkey
in
a
costermonger
's
cart
,
who
suggested
painful
associations
to
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
another
long
talk
about
my
plans
,
when
we
were
safely
housed
;
and
as
I
knew
she
was
anxious
to
get
home
,
and
,
between
fire
,
food
,
and
pickpockets
,
could
never
be
considered
at
her
ease
for
half
-
an
-
hour
in
London
,
I
urged
her
not
to
be
uncomfortable
on
my
account
,
but
to
leave
me
to
take
care
of
myself
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
been
here
a
week
tomorrow
,
without
considering
that
too
,
my
dear
,
"
she
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
a
furnished
little
set
of
chambers
to
be
let
in
the
Adelphi
,
Trot
,
which
ought
to
suit
you
to
a
marvel
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
brief
introduction
,
she
produced
from
her
pocket
an
advertisement
,
carefully
cut
out
of
a
newspaper
,
setting
forth
that
in
Buckingham
Street
in
the
Adelphi
there
was
to
be
let
furnished
,
with
a
view
of
the
river
,
a
singularly
desirable
,
and
compact
set
of
chambers
,
forming
a
genteel
residence
for
a
young
gentleman
,
a
member
of
one
of
the
Inns
of
Court
,
or
otherwise
,
with
immediate
possession
.
 
<EOS>
Terms
moderate
,
and
could
be
taken
for
a
month
only
,
if
required
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
this
is
the
very
thing
,
aunt
!
"
said
I
,
flushed
with
the
possible
dignity
of
living
in
chambers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
come
,
"
replied
my
aunt
,
immediately
resuming
the
bonnet
she
had
a
minute
before
laid
aside
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
'll
go
and
look
at
'
em
.
"
   
<EOS>
Away
we
went
.
 
<EOS>
The
advertisement
directed
us
to
apply
to
Mrs
Crupp
on
the
premises
,
and
we
rung
the
area
bell
,
which
we
supposed
to
communicate
with
Mrs
Crupp
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
we
had
rung
three
or
four
times
that
we
could
prevail
on
Mrs
Crupp
to
communicate
with
us
,
but
at
last
she
appeared
,
being
a
stout
lady
with
a
flounce
of
flannel
petticoat
below
a
nankeen
gown
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
us
see
these
chambers
of
yours
,
if
you
please
,
ma'am
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
For
this
gentleman
?
"
said
Mrs
Crupp
,
feeling
in
her
pocket
for
her
keys
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
for
my
nephew
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
a
sweet
set
they
is
for
sich
!
"
said
Mrs
Crupp
.
   
<EOS>
So
we
went
upstairs
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
on
the
top
of
the
house
---
a
great
point
with
my
aunt
,
being
near
the
fire
-
escape
---
and
consisted
of
a
little
half
-
blind
entry
where
you
could
see
hardly
anything
,
a
little
stone
-
blind
pantry
where
you
could
see
nothing
at
all
,
a
sitting
-
room
,
and
a
bedroom
.
 
<EOS>
The
furniture
was
rather
faded
,
but
quite
good
enough
for
me
;
and
,
sure
enough
,
the
river
was
outside
the
windows
.
   
<EOS>
As
I
was
delighted
with
the
place
,
my
aunt
and
Mrs
Crupp
withdrew
into
the
pantry
to
discuss
the
terms
,
while
I
remained
on
the
sitting
-
room
sofa
,
hardly
daring
to
think
it
possible
that
I
could
be
destined
to
live
in
such
a
noble
residence
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
single
combat
of
some
duration
they
returned
,
and
I
saw
,
to
my
joy
,
both
in
Mrs
Crupp
's
countenance
and
in
my
aunt
's
,
that
the
deed
was
done
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
the
last
occupant
's
furniture
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
is
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mrs
Crupp
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
become
of
him
?
"
asked
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Crupp
was
taken
with
a
troublesome
cough
,
in
the
midst
of
which
she
articulated
with
much
difficulty
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
was
took
ill
here
,
ma'am
,
and
---
ugh
!
<EOS>
ugh
!
<EOS>
ugh
!
<EOS>
dear
me
!
<EOS>
---
and
he
died
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Hey
!
 
<EOS>
What
did
he
die
of
?
"
asked
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
ma'am
,
he
died
of
drink
,
"
said
Mrs
Crupp
,
in
confidence
.
"
<EOS>
And
smoke
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Smoke
?
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
mean
chimneys
?
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
ma'am
,
"
returned
Mrs
Crupp
.
 
<EOS>
"
Cigars
and
pipes
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
not
catching
,
Trot
,
at
any
rate
,
"
remarked
my
aunt
,
turning
to
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
indeed
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
In
short
,
my
aunt
,
seeing
how
enraptured
I
was
with
the
premises
,
took
them
for
a
month
,
with
leave
to
remain
for
twelve
months
when
that
time
was
out
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Crupp
was
to
find
linen
,
and
to
cook
;
every
other
necessary
was
already
provided
;
and
Mrs
Crupp
expressly
intimated
that
she
should
always
yearn
towards
me
as
a
son
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
take
possession
the
day
after
tomorrow
,
and
Mrs
Crupp
said
,
thank
Heaven
<EOS>
she
had
now
found
summun
she
could
care
for
!
   
<EOS>
On
our
way
back
,
my
aunt
informed
me
how
she
confidently
trusted
that
the
life
I
was
now
to
lead
would
make
me
firm
and
self
-
reliant
,
which
was
all
I
wanted
.
 
<EOS>
She
repeated
this
several
times
next
day
,
in
the
intervals
of
our
arranging
for
the
transmission
of
my
clothes
and
books
from
Mr
Wickfield
's
;
relative
to
which
,
and
to
all
my
late
holiday
,
I
wrote
a
long
letter
to
Agnes
,
of
which
my
aunt
took
charge
,
as
she
was
to
leave
on
the
succeeding
day
.
 
<EOS>
Not
to
lengthen
these
particulars
,
I
need
only
add
,
that
she
made
a
handsome
provision
for
all
my
possible
wants
during
my
month
of
trial
;
that
Steerforth
,
to
my
great
disappointment
and
hers
too
,
did
not
make
his
appearance
before
she
went
away
;
that
I
saw
her
safely
seated
in
the
Dover
coach
,
exulting
in
the
coming
discomfiture
of
the
vagrant
donkeys
,
with
Janet
at
her
side
;
and
that
when
the
coach
was
gone
,
I
turned
my
face
to
the
Adelphi
,
pondering
on
the
old
days
when
I
used
to
roam
about
its
subterranean
arches
,
and
on
the
happy
changes
which
had
brought
me
to
the
surface
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
24
.
<EOS>
My
first
dissipation
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
wonderfully
fine
thing
to
have
that
lofty
castle
to
myself
,
and
to
feel
,
when
I
shut
my
outer
door
,
like
Robinson
Crusoe
,
when
he
had
got
into
his
fortification
,
and
pulled
his
ladder
up
after
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
wonderfully
fine
thing
to
walk
about
town
with
the
key
of
my
house
in
my
pocket
,
and
to
know
that
I
could
ask
any
fellow
to
come
home
,
and
make
quite
sure
of
its
being
inconvenient
to
nobody
,
if
it
were
not
so
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
wonderfully
fine
thing
to
let
myself
in
and
out
,
and
to
come
and
go
without
a
word
to
anyone
,
and
to
ring
Mrs
Crupp
up
,
gasping
,
from
the
depths
of
the
earth
,
<EOS>
when
I
wanted
her
---
and
when
she
was
disposed
to
come
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
,
I
say
,
was
wonderfully
fine
;
but
I
must
say
,
too
,
that
there
were
times
when
it
was
very
dreary
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
fine
in
the
morning
,
particularly
in
the
fine
mornings
.
 
<EOS>
It
looked
a
very
fresh
,
free
life
,
by
daylight
:
still
fresher
,
and
more
free
,
by
sunlight
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
the
day
declined
,
the
life
seemed
to
go
down
too
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
it
was
;
it
seldom
looked
well
by
candle
-
light
.
 
<EOS>
I
wanted
somebody
to
talk
to
,
then
.
 
<EOS>
I
missed
Agnes
.
<EOS>
I
found
a
tremendous
blank
,
in
the
place
of
that
smiling
repository
of
my
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Crupp
appeared
to
be
a
long
way
off
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
about
my
predecessor
,
who
had
died
of
drink
and
smoke
;
and
I
could
have
wished
he
had
been
so
good
as
to
live
,
and
not
bother
me
with
his
decease
.
   
<EOS>
After
two
days
and
nights
,
I
felt
as
if
I
had
lived
there
for
a
year
,
and
yet
I
was
not
an
hour
older
,
but
was
quite
as
much
tormented
by
my
own
youthfulness
as
ever
.
   
<EOS>
Steerforth
not
yet
appearing
,
which
induced
me
to
apprehend
that
he
must
be
ill
,
I
left
the
Commons
early
on
the
third
day
,
and
walked
out
to
Highgate
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Steerforth
was
very
glad
to
see
me
,
and
said
that
he
had
gone
away
with
one
of
his
Oxford
friends
to
see
another
who
lived
near
St
Albans
,
but
that
she
expected
him
to
return
tomorrow
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
fond
of
him
,
that
I
felt
quite
jealous
of
his
Oxford
friends
.
   
<EOS>
As
she
pressed
me
to
stay
to
dinner
,
I
remained
,
and
I
believe
we
talked
about
nothing
but
him
all
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
her
how
much
the
people
liked
him
at
Yarmouth
,
and
what
a
delightful
companion
he
had
been
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Dartle
was
full
of
hints
and
mysterious
questions
,
but
took
a
great
interest
in
all
our
proceedings
there
,
and
said
,
"
Was
it
really
though
?
"
<EOS>
and
so
forth
,
so
often
,
that
she
got
everything
out
of
me
<EOS>
she
wanted
to
know
.
 
<EOS>
Her
appearance
was
exactly
what
I
have
described
it
,
when
I
first
saw
her
;
but
the
society
of
the
two
ladies
was
so
agreeable
,
and
came
so
natural
to
me
,
that
I
felt
myself
falling
a
little
in
love
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
help
thinking
,
several
times
in
the
course
of
the
evening
,
and
particularly
when
I
walked
home
at
night
,
what
delightful
company
she
would
be
in
Buckingham
Street
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
taking
my
coffee
and
roll
in
the
morning
,
before
going
to
the
Commons
---
and
I
may
observe
in
this
place
that
it
is
surprising
how
much
coffee
Mrs
Crupp
used
,
and
how
weak
it
was
,
<EOS>
considering
---
when
Steerforth
himself
walked
in
,
to
my
unbounded
joy
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Steerforth
,
"
cried
I
,
"
<EOS>
I
began
to
think
I
should
never
see
you
again
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
carried
off
,
by
force
of
arms
,
"
said
Steerforth
,
"
the
very
next
morning
after
I
got
home
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
Daisy
,
what
a
rare
old
bachelor
you
are
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
showed
him
over
the
establishment
,
not
omitting
the
pantry
,
with
no
little
pride
,
and
he
commended
it
highly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
what
,
old
boy
,
"
he
added
,
"
I
shall
make
quite
a
town
-
house
of
this
place
,
unless
you
give
me
notice
to
quit
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
a
delightful
hearing
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
him
if
he
waited
for
that
,
he
would
have
to
wait
till
doomsday
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
you
shall
have
some
breakfast
!
"
<EOS>
said
I
,
with
my
hand
on
the
bell
-
rope
,
"
and
Mrs
Crupp
shall
make
you
some
fresh
coffee
,
and
I
'll
toast
you
some
bacon
in
a
bachelor
's
Dutch
-
oven
,
that
I
have
got
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
!
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
ring
!
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
to
breakfast
with
one
of
these
fellows
who
is
at
the
Piazza
Hotel
,
in
Covent
Garden
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
you
'll
come
back
to
dinner
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
,
upon
my
life
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
nothing
I
should
like
better
,
but
I
must
remain
with
these
two
fellows
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
all
three
off
together
tomorrow
morning
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
bring
them
here
to
dinner
,
"
I
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
they
would
come
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
they
would
come
fast
enough
,
"
said
Steerforth
;
"
but
we
should
inconvenience
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
had
better
come
and
dine
with
us
somewhere
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
would
not
by
any
means
consent
to
this
,
for
it
occurred
to
me
that
I
really
ought
to
have
a
little
house
-
warming
,
and
that
there
never
could
be
a
better
opportunity
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
new
pride
in
my
rooms
after
his
approval
of
them
,
and
burned
with
a
desire
to
develop
their
utmost
resources
.
 
<EOS>
I
therefore
made
him
promise
positively
in
the
names
of
his
two
friends
,
and
we
appointed
six
o'clock
as
the
dinner
-
hour
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
was
gone
,
I
rang
for
Mrs
Crupp
,
and
acquainted
her
with
my
desperate
design
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Crupp
said
,
in
the
first
place
,
of
course
it
was
well
known
she
could
n't
be
expected
to
wait
,
but
she
knew
a
handy
young
man
,
who
she
thought
could
be
prevailed
upon
to
do
it
,
and
whose
terms
would
be
five
shillings
,
and
what
I
pleased
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
,
certainly
we
would
have
him
.
 
<EOS>
Next
Mrs
Crupp
said
it
was
clear
she
could
n't
be
in
two
places
at
once
(
which
I
felt
to
be
reasonable
)
,
and
that
"
a
young
gal
"
stationed
in
the
pantry
with
a
bedroom
candle
,
there
never
to
desist
from
washing
plates
,
would
be
indispensable
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
,
what
would
be
the
expense
of
this
young
female
?
<EOS>
and
Mrs
Crupp
said
she
supposed
eighteenpence
<EOS>
would
neither
make
me
nor
break
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
I
supposed
not
;
and
THAT
was
settled
.
 
<EOS>
Then
Mrs
Crupp
said
,
Now
about
the
dinner
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
remarkable
instance
of
want
of
forethought
on
the
part
of
the
ironmonger
who
had
made
Mrs
Crupp
's
kitchen
fireplace
,
that
it
was
capable
of
cooking
nothing
but
chops
and
mashed
potatoes
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
a
fish
-
kittle
,
Mrs
Crupp
said
,
well
!
<EOS>
would
I
only
come
and
look
at
the
range
?
 
<EOS>
She
could
n't
say
fairer
than
that
.
 
<EOS>
Would
I
come
and
look
at
it
?
 
<EOS>
As
I
should
not
have
been
much
the
wiser
if
I
HAD
looked
at
it
,
I
declined
,
and
said
,
"
Never
mind
fish
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
Mrs
Crupp
said
,
Do
n't
say
that
;
oysters
was
in
,
why
not
them
?
 
<EOS>
So
THAT
was
settled
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Crupp
then
said
what
she
would
recommend
would
be
this
.
 
<EOS>
A
pair
of
hot
roast
fowls
---
from
the
pastry
-
cook
's
;
a
dish
of
stewed
beef
,
with
vegetables
---
from
the
pastry
-
cook
's
;
two
little
corner
things
,
as
a
raised
pie
and
a
dish
of
kidneys
---
from
the
pastrycook
's
;
a
tart
,
and
(
if
I
liked
)
a
shape
of
jelly
---
from
the
pastrycook
's
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
Mrs
Crupp
said
,
would
leave
her
at
full
liberty
to
concentrate
her
mind
on
the
potatoes
,
and
to
serve
up
the
cheese
and
celery
as
she
could
wish
to
see
it
done
.
   
<EOS>
I
acted
on
Mrs
Crupp
's
opinion
,
and
gave
the
order
at
the
pastry
-
cook
's
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Walking
along
the
Strand
,
afterwards
,
and
observing
a
hard
mottled
substance
in
the
window
of
a
ham
and
beef
shop
,
which
resembled
marble
,
but
was
labelled
"
Mock
Turtle
"
,
I
went
in
and
bought
a
slab
of
it
,
which
I
have
since
seen
reason
to
believe
would
have
sufficed
for
fifteen
people
.
 
<EOS>
This
preparation
,
Mrs
Crupp
,
after
some
difficulty
,
consented
to
warm
up
;
and
it
shrunk
so
much
in
a
liquid
state
,
that
we
found
it
what
Steerforth
called
"
rather
a
tight
fit
"
for
four
.
   
<EOS>
These
preparations
happily
completed
,
I
bought
a
little
dessert
in
Covent
Garden
Market
,
and
gave
a
rather
extensive
order
at
a
retail
wine
-
merchant
's
in
that
vicinity
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
came
home
in
the
afternoon
,
and
saw
the
bottles
drawn
up
in
a
square
on
the
pantry
floor
,
they
looked
so
numerous
(
though
there
were
two
missing
,
which
made
Mrs
Crupp
very
uncomfortable
)
,
<EOS>
that
I
was
absolutely
frightened
at
them
.
   
<EOS>
One
of
Steerforth
's
friends
was
named
Grainger
,
and
the
other
Markham
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
both
very
gay
and
lively
fellows
;
Grainger
,
something
older
than
Steerforth
;
Markham
,
youthful
-
looking
,
and
I
should
say
not
more
than
twenty
.
 
<EOS>
I
observed
that
the
latter
always
spoke
of
himself
indefinitely
,
as
"
a
man
"
,
and
seldom
or
never
in
the
first
person
singular
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
man
might
get
on
very
well
here
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
Markham
---
meaning
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
a
bad
situation
,
"
said
I
,
"
and
the
rooms
are
really
commodious
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
have
both
brought
appetites
with
you
?
"
said
Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
honour
,
"
returned
Markham
,
"
town
seems
to
sharpen
a
man
's
appetite
.
 
<EOS>
A
man
is
hungry
all
day
long
.
 
<EOS>
A
man
is
perpetually
eating
.
"
   
<EOS>
Being
a
little
embarrassed
at
first
,
and
feeling
much
too
young
to
preside
,
I
made
Steerforth
take
the
head
of
the
table
when
dinner
was
announced
,
and
seated
myself
opposite
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Everything
was
very
good
;
we
did
not
spare
the
wine
;
and
he
exerted
himself
so
brilliantly
to
make
the
thing
pass
off
well
,
that
there
was
no
pause
in
our
festivity
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
quite
such
good
company
during
dinner
as
I
could
have
wished
to
be
<EOS>
,
for
my
chair
was
opposite
the
door
,
and
my
attention
was
distracted
by
observing
that
the
handy
young
man
went
out
of
the
room
very
often
,
and
that
his
shadow
always
presented
itself
,
immediately
afterwards
,
on
the
wall
of
the
entry
,
with
a
bottle
at
its
mouth
.
 
<EOS>
The
"
young
gal
"
likewise
occasioned
me
some
uneasiness
:
not
so
much
by
neglecting
to
wash
the
plates
,
as
by
breaking
them
.
 
<EOS>
For
being
of
an
inquisitive
disposition
,
and
unable
to
confine
herself
(
as
her
positive
instructions
were
)
to
the
pantry
,
she
was
constantly
peering
in
at
us
,
and
constantly
imagining
herself
detected
;
in
which
belief
,
she
several
times
retired
upon
the
plates
(
with
which
she
had
carefully
paved
the
floor
)
,
and
did
a
great
deal
of
destruction
.
   
<EOS>
These
,
however
,
were
small
drawbacks
,
and
easily
forgotten
when
the
cloth
was
cleared
,
and
the
dessert
put
on
the
table
;
at
which
period
of
the
entertainment
the
handy
young
man
was
discovered
to
be
speechless
.
 
<EOS>
Giving
him
private
directions
to
seek
the
society
of
Mrs
Crupp
,
and
to
remove
the
"
young
gal
"
to
the
basement
also
,
I
abandoned
myself
to
enjoyment
.
   
<EOS>
I
began
,
by
being
singularly
cheerful
and
light
-
hearted
;
all
sorts
of
half
-
forgotten
things
to
talk
about
,
came
rushing
into
my
mind
,
and
made
me
hold
forth
in
a
most
unwonted
manner
.
 
<EOS>
I
laughed
heartily
at
my
own
jokes
,
and
everybody
else
's
;
called
Steerforth
to
order
for
not
passing
the
wine
;
made
several
engagements
to
go
to
Oxford
;
announced
that
I
meant
to
have
a
dinner
-
party
exactly
like
that
,
once
a
week
,
until
further
notice
;
and
madly
took
so
much
snuff
out
of
Grainger
's
box
,
that
I
was
obliged
to
go
into
the
pantry
,
and
have
a
private
fit
of
sneezing
ten
minutes
long
.
   
<EOS>
I
went
on
,
by
passing
the
wine
faster
and
faster
yet
,
and
continually
starting
up
with
a
corkscrew
to
open
more
wine
,
long
before
any
was
needed
.
 
<EOS>
I
proposed
Steerforth
's
health
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
he
was
my
dearest
friend
,
the
protector
of
my
boyhood
,
and
the
companion
of
my
prime
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
I
was
delighted
to
propose
his
health
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
I
owed
him
more
obligations
than
I
could
ever
repay
,
and
held
him
in
a
higher
admiration
than
I
could
ever
express
.
 
<EOS>
I
finished
by
saying
,
"
I
'll
give
you
Steerforth
!
 
<EOS>
God
bless
him
!
 
<EOS>
Hurrah
!
<EOS>
"
We
gave
him
three
times
three
,
and
another
,
and
a
good
one
to
finish
with
.
 
<EOS>
I
broke
my
glass
in
going
round
the
table
to
shake
hands
with
him
,
and
I
said
(
in
two
words
)
<EOS>
"
Steerforth
---
you'retheguidingstarofmyexistence
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
went
on
,
by
finding
suddenly
that
somebody
was
in
the
middle
of
a
song
.
 
<EOS>
Markham
was
the
singer
,
and
he
sang
"
When
the
heart
of
a
man
is
depressed
with
care
"
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
,
when
he
had
sung
it
,
he
would
give
us
"
Woman
!
<EOS>
"
I
took
objection
to
that
,
and
I
could
n't
allow
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
it
was
not
a
respectful
way
of
proposing
the
toast
,
and
I
would
never
permit
that
toast
to
be
drunk
in
my
house
otherwise
than
as
"
The
Ladies
!
<EOS>
"
I
was
very
high
with
him
,
mainly
I
think
because
I
saw
Steerforth
and
Grainger
laughing
at
me
---
or
at
him
---
or
at
both
of
us
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
a
man
was
not
to
be
dictated
to
.
<EOS>
I
said
a
man
was
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
a
man
was
not
to
be
insulted
,
then
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
he
was
right
there
---
never
under
my
roof
,
where
the
Lares
were
sacred
,
and
the
laws
of
hospitality
paramount
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
it
was
no
derogation
from
a
man
's
dignity
to
confess
that
I
was
a
devilish
good
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
I
instantly
proposed
his
health
.
   
<EOS>
Somebody
was
smoking
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
all
smoking
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
smoking
,
and
trying
to
suppress
a
rising
tendency
to
shudder
.
 
<EOS>
Steerforth
had
made
a
speech
about
me
,
in
the
course
of
which
I
had
been
affected
almost
to
tears
.
 
<EOS>
I
returned
thanks
,
and
hoped
the
present
company
would
dine
with
me
tomorrow
,
and
the
day
after
---
each
day
at
five
o'clock
,
that
we
might
enjoy
the
pleasures
of
conversation
and
society
through
a
long
evening
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
called
upon
to
propose
an
individual
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
give
them
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Betsey
Trotwood
,
the
best
of
her
sex
!
   
<EOS>
Somebody
was
leaning
out
of
my
bedroom
window
,
refreshing
his
forehead
against
the
cool
stone
of
the
parapet
,
and
feeling
the
air
upon
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
addressing
myself
as
"
Copperfield
"
,
and
saying
,
"
Why
did
you
try
to
smoke
?
 
<EOS>
You
might
have
known
you
could
n't
do
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
Now
,
somebody
was
unsteadily
contemplating
his
features
in
the
looking
-
glass
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
I
too
.
<EOS>
I
was
very
pale
in
the
looking
-
glass
;
my
eyes
had
a
vacant
appearance
;
and
my
hair
---
only
my
hair
,
nothing
else
---
looked
drunk
.
   
<EOS>
Somebody
said
to
me
,
"
Let
us
go
to
the
theatre
,
Copperfield
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
There
was
no
bedroom
before
me
,
but
again
the
jingling
table
covered
with
glasses
;
the
lamp
;
<EOS>
Grainger
on
my
right
hand
,
Markham
on
my
left
,
and
Steerforth
opposite
---
all
sitting
in
a
mist
,
and
a
long
way
off
.
 
<EOS>
The
theatre
?
 
<EOS>
To
be
sure
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
thing
.
 
<EOS>
Come
along
!
 
<EOS>
But
they
must
excuse
me
if
I
saw
everybody
out
first
,
and
turned
the
lamp
off
---
in
case
of
fire
.
   
<EOS>
Owing
to
some
confusion
in
the
dark
,
the
door
was
gone
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
feeling
for
it
in
the
window
-
curtains
,
when
Steerforth
,
laughing
,
took
me
by
the
arm
and
led
me
out
.
 
<EOS>
We
went
downstairs
,
one
behind
another
.
 
<EOS>
Near
the
bottom
,
somebody
fell
,
and
rolled
down
.
<EOS>
Somebody
else
said
it
was
Copperfield
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
angry
at
that
false
report
,
until
,
finding
myself
on
my
back
in
the
passage
<EOS>
,
I
began
to
think
there
might
be
some
foundation
for
it
.
   
<EOS>
A
very
foggy
night
,
with
great
rings
round
the
lamps
in
the
streets
!
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
indistinct
talk
of
its
being
wet
.
 
<EOS>
I
considered
it
frosty
.
 
<EOS>
Steerforth
dusted
me
under
a
lamp
-
post
,
and
put
my
hat
into
shape
,
which
somebody
produced
from
somewhere
in
a
most
extraordinary
manner
,
for
I
had
n't
had
it
on
before
.
<EOS>
Steerforth
then
said
,
"
You
are
all
right
,
Copperfield
,
are
you
not
?
"
<EOS>
and
I
told
him
,
"
Neverberrer
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
man
,
sitting
in
a
pigeon
-
hole
-
place
,
looked
out
of
the
fog
,
and
took
money
from
somebody
,
inquiring
if
I
was
one
of
the
gentlemen
paid
for
,
and
appearing
rather
doubtful
(
as
I
remember
in
the
glimpse
I
had
of
him
)
<EOS>
whether
to
take
the
money
for
me
or
not
.
<EOS>
Shortly
afterwards
,
we
were
very
high
up
in
a
very
hot
theatre
,
looking
down
into
a
large
pit
,
<EOS>
that
seemed
to
me
to
smoke
;
the
people
with
whom
it
was
crammed
were
so
indistinct
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
great
stage
,
too
,
looking
very
clean
and
smooth
after
the
streets
;
and
there
were
people
upon
it
,
talking
about
something
or
other
,
but
not
at
all
intelligibly
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
abundance
of
bright
lights
,
and
there
was
music
,
and
there
were
ladies
down
in
the
boxes
,
and
I
do
n't
know
what
more
.
 
<EOS>
The
whole
building
looked
to
me
as
if
it
were
learning
to
swim
;
it
conducted
itself
in
such
an
unaccountable
manner
,
when
I
tried
to
steady
it
.
   
<EOS>
On
somebody
's
motion
,
we
resolved
to
go
downstairs
to
the
dress
-
boxes
,
where
the
ladies
were
.
 
<EOS>
A
gentleman
lounging
,
<EOS>
full
dressed
,
on
a
sofa
,
with
an
opera
-
glass
in
his
hand
,
passed
before
my
view
,
and
also
my
own
figure
at
full
length
in
a
glass
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
was
being
ushered
into
one
of
these
boxes
,
and
found
myself
saying
something
as
I
sat
down
,
and
people
about
me
crying
"
Silence
!
"
<EOS>
to
somebody
,
and
ladies
casting
indignant
glances
at
me
,
and
---
what
!
<EOS>
yes
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Agnes
,
sitting
on
the
seat
before
me
,
in
the
same
box
,
with
a
lady
and
gentleman
beside
her
,
whom
I
did
n't
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
her
face
now
,
better
than
I
did
then
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
,
with
its
indelible
look
of
regret
and
wonder

upon

.
   
<EOS>
"
Agnes
!
<EOS>
"
I
said
,
thickly
,
"
Lorblessmer
!
 
<EOS>
Agnes
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
 
<EOS>
Pray
!
"
<EOS>
she
answered
,
I
could
not
conceive
why
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
disturb
the
company
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
the
stage
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
tried
,
on
her

,
to
fix

,
and
to

something
of
what
was
going

there
,
but
quite

.
 
<EOS>
I

again
by
and
by
,
and
saw

into
her

,
and
put
her

.
   
<EOS>
"
Agnes
!
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
"
I'mafraidyou'renorwell
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
.
 
<EOS>
Do

,
Trotwood
,
"
she

.
 
<EOS>
"
Listen
!
 
<EOS>
Are

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Amigoarawaysoo
?
<EOS>
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
had
a
stupid

of
replying
that
I
was
going

wait
,
to
hand
her
downstairs
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
expressed

,
somehow

for
after

a

,
she
appeared
to

and

in

<EOS>
"
I
know
you
will
do

,

tell

I

very

.
 
<EOS>
Go
away
now
,
Trotwood
,
for
my

,
and
ask

.
"
   
<EOS>
She
had
so
far
improved
me
,
for
the
time
,
that
though
I
was
angry
with
her
,
I
felt
ashamed
,
and
with

"
Goori
!
"
<EOS>
(
which
I
intended
for
"
Good
night
!
"
)
got

and
went

.
 
<EOS>
They
followed
,
and
I
stepped
at
once
out
of
the
box

door
into
my
bedroom
,
where
only
Steerforth
was
with
me
,
helping
me
to

,
and
where
I
was
by
turns
telling
him
that
Agnes
was
my
sister
,
and
adjuring
him
to
bring
the
corkscrew
,
that
I
might
open
another
bottle
of
wine
.
   
<EOS>
How
somebody
,
lying
in
my
bed
,
lay
saying
and
doing
all
this
over
again
,
at
cross

,
in
a
feverish
dream
all
