---
the
bed
a
rocking
sea
that
was
never
still
!
 
<EOS>
How
,
as
that
somebody
slowly
settled
down
into
myself
,
did
I
begin
to
parch
,
and
feel
as
if
my
outer
covering
of
skin
were
a
hard
board
;
my
tongue
the
bottom
of
an
empty
kettle
,
furred
with
long
service
,
and
burning
up
over
a
slow
fire
;
the
palms
of
my
hands
,
hot
plates
of
metal
which
no
ice
could
cool
!
   
<EOS>
But
the
agony
of
mind
,
the
remorse
,
and
shame
<EOS>
I
felt
when
I
became
conscious
next
day
!
 
<EOS>
My
horror
of
having
committed
a
thousand
offences
I
had
forgotten
,
and
which
nothing
could
ever
expiate
---
my
recollection
of
that
indelible
look
which
Agnes
had
given

---
the
torturing

of
communicating
with
her
,
not

,
Beast
that
I
was
,
how
she
came
to
be
in
London
,
or
where
she
stayed
---
<EOS>
my
disgust
of
the
very
sight
of
the
room
where
the
revel
had
been
held
---
my
racking
head
---
the
smell
of
smoke
,
the
sight
of
glasses
,
the
impossibility
of
going
out
,
or
even
getting
up
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
what
a
day
it
was
!
   
<EOS>
Oh
,
what
an
evening
,
when
I
sat
down
by
my
fire
to
a
basin
of
mutton

,
dimpled
all
over
with
fat
,
and
thought
I
was
going
the
way

my

,
and
should

his

,

half

to

!
 
<EOS>
What
an

,

Mrs

one

"

<EOS>
I

!
"
<EOS>
---

!
      
<EOS>
Chapter
25
.
<EOS>
Good
and
bad
angels
 
<EOS>
I
was
going
out
at
my
door
on
the
morning
after
that
deplorable
day
of
headache
,
sickness
,
and
repentance
,
with
an
odd

in
my

relative
to
the
date
of
my
dinner

party
,
as
if
a
body
of
Titans
had
taken

lever
and
pushed
the
day
before
yesterday
some
months
back
,
when
I
saw
a
ticket
-
porter
coming
upstairs
,
with
a
letter
in

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
taking
his
time
about
his
errand
,
then
;
but
when
he
saw
me
on
the
top

the

,

him
over

,
he
swung
into
a

,
and
came

into

.
   
<EOS>
"
T
Copperfield
,
Esquire
,
"
said
the
ticket

,
touching

.
   
<EOS>
I
could
scarcely
lay
claim
to
the
name
:
<EOS>
I
was
so
disturbed
by
the
conviction
that
the
letter
came
from
Agnes
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
I
told
him
I
was
T
Copperfield
,
Esquire
,
and
he
believed
it
,
and
gave

the
letter
,
which
he
said
required
an

.
 
<EOS>
I
shut
him
out
on
the
landing
to
wait
for
the
answer
,
and
went
into
my
chambers
again
,
in
such

that
I
was
fain
to
lay
the
letter
down
on
my

,
and
familiarize
myself
with
the
outside
of

a
little
,
before
I
could

to
break

.
   
<EOS>
I
found
,

,
that
it
was
a
very
kind
note
,

no

my

at
the

.
 
<EOS>
All

,
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Trotwood
.
 
<EOS>
I
am

papa
's

,
Mr

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Ever

,
AGNES
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
It

that

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>

"
Shakespeare

<EOS>
my

,

---

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

"
<EOS>
Oh
,
do
not

"
---

,

.
 
<EOS>
After

,
"
<EOS>
My

.
 
<EOS>
Your
letter

,

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Affectionately

,
T*C.
<EOS>
"
 
With

missive
(

was

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
If

half
as

to
any

Doctors
'
Commons

,
I
sincerely

made
some

that
rotten

.
 
<EOS>
Although

left

at

,
and
was

about
the
place
of
appointment
within

,
the
appointed

was

by
a

an

,

of
St
Andrew
's
,
Holborn
,

<EOS>
let
into
the
left

door

of
Mr

's

.
   
<EOS>
The
professional
business
of
Mr
Waterbrook
's

was
done
on
the
ground

,
and
the

business
(
of

)
in

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
shown
into
a
pretty
but

close

room
,
and
there

Agnes
,
netting
a
purse
.
   
<EOS>
She
looked
so
quiet
and
good
,
and
reminded
me
so
strongly
of
my
airy
fresh
school
days
at
Canterbury
,
and
the
sodden
,
smoky
,
stupid
wretch
I
had
been
the
other
night
,
that
,
nobody
being
by
<EOS>
,
I
yielded
to
my
self
-
reproach
and
shame
,
and
---
in
short
,
made
a
fool
of
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
deny
that
I
shed
tears
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
hour
I
am
undecided
whether
it
was
upon
the
whole
the
wisest
thing
I
could

,

the

.
   
<EOS>
"
If
it
had
been
anyone
but
you
,
Agnes
,
"
said

,

away

,
"
I
should
not
have
minded
it
half
so
much
.
 
<EOS>
But
that

should
have
been
you
who
saw

!
 
<EOS>
I
almost
wish
I
had
been
dead
,
first
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
put
her
hand
<EOS>
---
its
touch
was
like
no

---
upon
my
arm
for
a
moment
;
and
I
felt
so

,
that
I
could
not

moving
it
to

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
,
"
said
Agnes
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't

unhappy
,
Trotwood
.
<EOS>
If
you
can
not

me
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Agnes
!
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
my
good
Angel
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
smiled
rather

,
I
thought
,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
Agnes
,
my
good
Angel
!
 
<EOS>
Always
my
good
Angel
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
were
,

,
Trotwood
,
"
she
returned
,
"
there
is
one
thing
that
I
should
set
my
heart

very
much
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
looked
at

inquiringly
;
but
already
with
a

of
her

.
   
<EOS>
"
On
warning
you
,
"
said
Agnes
,
with

,
"
against
your
bad
Angel
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Agnes
,
"
I
began
,
"
<EOS>
if
you
mean
Steerforth
---
"
   
"
I
do
,
Trotwood
<EOS>
,
"
she
returned
.
"
<EOS>
Then
,
Agnes
,
you
wrong
him
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
He
<EOS>
my
bad
Angel
,
or
anyone
's
!
 
<EOS>
He
,
anything
but
a
guide
,
a
support
,
and
a
friend
to

!
<EOS>
My
dear
Agnes
!
 
<EOS>
Now
,
is

,
and
unlike
you
,
to
judge
him
from
what
you
saw
of
me
the
other

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
judge
him
from
what
I
saw
of
you
the
other
night
,
"
she
quietly
replied
.
   
<EOS>
"
From
what
,
then
?
"
   
"
From
many
things
---
trifles
in
themselves
,
but
they
do
not
seem
to
me
to
be
so
,
when

.
 
<EOS>
I
judge
him
,
partly
from
your
account
of
him
,
Trotwood
,
and
your
character
,
and
the
influence
he
has
over
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
always
something
in
her
modest
voice
that
seemed
to
touch
a
chord
within
me
,
answering
to
that
sound
alone
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
always
earnest
;
but
when

was
very

,
as
it

now
,
there
was
a

in

that
quite

.
 
<EOS>
I
sat

as

down

;
I
sat
seeming

her
;
and
Steerforth
,
in
spite

all
my
attachment
to
him
,
darkened

that

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
bold
in
me
,
"
said
Agnes
,
looking

,
"
who
have

,
and

little

,
to
give
you

,

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
know

what
it
is
engendered
,
Trotwood
,
---
in
how
true
a
remembrance
of
our
having
grown
up

,
and
in
how
true
an
interest
in
all
relating
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
that
which
makes
me
bold
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
certain
that
what
I
say
is
right
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
quite
sure
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
as
if
it
were
someone
else
speaking
to
you
,
and
not
I
,
when
I
caution
you
that
you
have
made
a
dangerous
friend
.
"
   
<EOS>
Again
I
looked
at
her
,
again
I
listened
to
her
after
she
was
silent
,
and
again
his
image
,
though
it
was
still
fixed
in
my
heart
,
darkened
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
so
unreasonable
as
to
expect
,
"
said
Agnes
,
resuming
her
usual
tone
,
after
a
little
while
,
"
that
you
will
,
or
that
you
can
,
at
once
,
change
any
sentiment
that
has
become
a
conviction
to
you
;
least
of
all
a
sentiment
that
is
rooted
in
your
trusting
disposition
.
 
<EOS>
You
ought
not
hastily
to
do
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
ask
you
,
Trotwood
,
if
you
ever
think
of
me
---
I
mean
,
"
with
a
quiet
smile
,
for
I
was
going
to
interrupt
her
,
and
she
knew
why
,
"
as
often
as
you
think
of
me
---
to
think
of
what
I
have
said
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
forgive
me
for
all
this
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
forgive
you
,
Agnes
,
"
I
replied
,
"
when
you
come
to
do
Steerforth
justice
,
and
to
like
him
as
well
as
I
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
until
then
?
"
said
Agnes
.
   
<EOS>
I
saw
a
passing
shadow
on
her
face
when
I
made
this
mention
of
him
,
but
she
returned
my
smile
,
and
we
were
again
as
unreserved
in
our
mutual
confidence
as
of
old
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
when
,
Agnes
,
"
said
I
,
"
will
you
forgive
me
the
other
night
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
recall
it
,
"
said
Agnes
.
   
<EOS>
She
would
have
dismissed
the
subject
so
,
but
I
was
too
full
of
it
to
allow
that
,
and
insisted
on
telling
her
how
it
happened
that
I
had
disgraced
myself
,
and
what
chain
of
accidental
circumstances
had
had
the
theatre
for
its
final
link
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
great
relief
to
me
to
do
this
,
and
to
enlarge
on
the
obligation
that
I
owed
to
Steerforth
for
his
care
of
me
when
I
was
unable
to
take
care
of
myself
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
not
forget
,
"
said
Agnes
,
calmly
changing
the
conversation
as
soon
as
I
had
concluded
,
"
that
you
are
always
to
tell
me
,
not
only
when
you
fall
into
trouble
,
but
when
you
fall
in
love
.
 
<EOS>
Who
has
succeeded
to
Miss
Larkins
,
Trotwood
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
one
,
Agnes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Someone
,
Trotwood
,
"
said
Agnes
,
laughing
,
and
holding
up
her
finger
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Agnes
,
upon
my
word
!
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
lady
,
certainly
,
at
Mrs
Steerforth
's
house
,
who
is
very
clever
,
and
whom
I
like
to
talk
to
---
Miss
Dartle
---
but
I
do
n't
adore
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
Agnes
laughed
again
at
her
own
penetration
,
and
told
me
that
if
I
were
faithful
to
her
in
my
confidence
she
thought
she
should
keep
a
little
register
of
my
violent
attachments
,
with
the
date
,
duration
,
and
termination
of
each
,
like
the
table
of
the
reigns
of
the
kings
and
queens
,
in
the
History
of
England
.
 
<EOS>
Then
she
asked
me
if
I
had
seen
Uriah
.
   
<EOS>
"
Uriah
Heep
?
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
 
Is
he
in
London
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
comes
to
the
office
downstairs
,
every
day
,
"
returned
Agnes
.
<EOS>
"
He
was
in
London
a
week
before
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
on
disagreeable
business
,
Trotwood
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
On
some
business
that
makes
you
uneasy
,
Agnes
,
I
see
,
"
said
I.
<EOS>
"
What
can
that
be
?
"
   
<EOS>
Agnes
laid
aside
her
work
,
and
replied
,
folding
her
hands
upon
one
another
,
and
looking
pensively
at
me
out
of
those
beautiful
soft
eyes
of
hers
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
believe
he
is
going
to
enter
into
partnership
with
papa
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
?
 
Uriah
?
 
<EOS>
That
mean
,
fawning
fellow
,
worm
himself
into
such
promotion
!
<EOS>
"
I
cried
,
indignantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
made
no
remonstrance
about
it
,
Agnes
?
 
<EOS>
Consider
what
a
connexion
it
is
likely
to
be
.
<EOS>
You
must
speak
out
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
not
allow
your
father
to
take
such
a
mad
step
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
prevent
it
,
Agnes
,
while
there
's
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
Still
looking
at
me
,
Agnes
shook
her
head
while
I
was
speaking
,
with
a
faint
smile
at
my
warmth
:
and
then
replied
:
   
"
<EOS>
You
remember
our
last
conversation
about
papa
?
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
long
after
that
---
not
more
than
two
or
three
days
---
when
he
gave
me
the
first
intimation
of
what
I
tell
you
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
sad
to
see
him
struggling
between
his
desire
to
represent
it
to
me
as
a
matter
of
choice
on
his
part
,
and
his
inability
to
conceal
that
it
was
forced
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
very
sorry
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Forced
upon
him
,
Agnes
!
 
<EOS>
Who
forces
it
upon
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Uriah
,
"
she
replied
,
after
a
moment
's
hesitation
,
"
has
made
himself
indispensable
to
papa
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
subtle
and
watchful
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
mastered
papa
's
weaknesses
,
fostered
them
,
and
taken
advantage
of
them
,
until
---
to
say
all
that
I
mean
in
a
word
,
Trotwood
,
---
until
papa
is
afraid
of
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
more
that
she
might
have
said
;
more
that
she
knew
,
or
that
she
suspected
;
I
clearly
saw
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
give
her
pain
by
asking
what
it
was
,
for
I
knew
that
she
withheld
it
from
me
,
to
spare
her
father
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
long
been
going
on
to
this
,
I
was
sensible
:
<EOS>
yes
,
I
could
not
but
feel
,
on
the
least
reflection
,
that
it
had
been
going
on
to
this
for
a
long
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
remained
silent
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
ascendancy
over
papa
,
"
said
Agnes
,
"
is
very
great
.
 
<EOS>
He
professes
humility
and
gratitude
---
with
truth
,
perhaps
:
I
hope
so
---
but
his
position
is
really
one
of
power
,
and
I
fear
he
makes
a
hard
use
of
his
power
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
he
was
a
hound
,
which
,
at
the
moment
,
was
a
great
satisfaction
to
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
the
time
I
speak
of
,
as
the
time
when
papa
spoke
to
me
,
"
pursued
Agnes
,
"
he
had
told
papa
that
he
was
going
away
;
that
he
was
very
sorry
,
and
unwilling
to
leave
,
but
that
he
had
better

.
 
<EOS>
Papa
was
very
much
depressed
then
,
and
more
bowed
down
by
care
than
ever
you
or
<EOS>
I
have
seen
him
;
but
he
seemed
relieved
by
this
expedient
of
the
partnership
,
though
at
the
same

he
seemed
hurt
by

and

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
how
did
you
receive
it
,
Agnes
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
,
Trotwood
,
"
she
replied
,
"
what
I
hope
was
right
.
 
<EOS>
Feeling
sure
that
it
was
necessary
for
papa
's
peace
that
the
sacrifice
should
be
made
,
I
entreated
him
to
make

.
 
<EOS>
I
said
it
would
lighten
the
load
of
his
life
<EOS>
---
I
hope
it
will
!
<EOS>
---
and
that
it
would
give
me
increased
opportunities
of
being
his
companion
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
Trotwood
!
"
cried
Agnes
,
putting
her
hands
before
her
face
,
as
her
tears
started
on
it
,
"
<EOS>
I
almost
feel
as
if
I
had
been
papa
's
enemy
,
instead
of
his
loving
child
.
 
<EOS>
For
I
know
how
he
has
altered
,
in
his
devotion
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
how
he
has
narrowed
the
circle
of
his
sympathies
and
duties
,
in
the
concentration
of
his
whole
mind
upon
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
what
a
multitude
of
things
he
has
shut
out
for
my
sake
,
and
how
his
anxious
thoughts
of
me
have
shadowed
his
life
,
and
weakened
his
strength
and
energy
,
by
turning
them
always
upon
one
idea
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
could
ever
set
this
right
!
 
<EOS>
If
I
could
ever
work
out
his
restoration
,
as
I
have
so
innocently
been
the
cause
of
his
decline
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
had
never
before
seen
Agnes
cry
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
seen
tears
in
her
eyes
when
I
had
brought
new
honours
home
from
school
,
and
I
had
seen
them
there
when
we
last
spoke
about
her
father
,
and
I
had
seen
her
turn
her
gentle
head
aside
when
we
took
leave
of
one
another
;
but
I
had
never
seen
her
grieve
like
this
.
 
<EOS>
It
made
me
so
sorry
that
I
could
only
say
,
in
a
foolish
,
helpless
manner
,
"
Pray
,
Agnes
,
do
n't
!
<EOS>
Do
n't
,
my
dear
sister
!
"
   
<EOS>
But
Agnes
was
too
superior
to
me
in
character
and
purpose
,
as
I
know
well
now
,
whatever
I
might
know
or
not
know
then
,
to
be
long
in
need
of
my
entreaties
.
 
<EOS>
The
beautiful
,
calm
manner
,
which
makes
her
so
different
in
my
remembrance
from
everybody
else
,
came
back
again
,
as
if
a
cloud
had
passed
from
a
serene
sky
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
not
likely
to
remain
alone
much
longer
,
"
said
Agnes
,
"
and
while
I
have
an
opportunity
,
let
me
earnestly
entreat
you
,
Trotwood
,
to
be
friendly
to
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
repel
him
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
resent
(
as
I
think
you
have
a
general
disposition
to
do
)
<EOS>
what
may
be
uncongenial
to
you
in
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
may
not
deserve
it
,
for
we
know
no
certain
ill
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
In
any
case
,
think
first
of
papa
and
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
Agnes
had
no
time
to
say
more
,
for
the
room
door
opened
,
and
Mrs
Waterbrook
,
who
was
a
large
lady
---
or
who
wore
a
large
dress
:
<EOS>
I
do
n't
exactly
know
which
,
for
I
do
n't
know
which
was
dress
and
which
was
lady
---
came
sailing
in
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
dim
recollection
of
having
seen
her
at
the
theatre
,
as
if
I
had
seen
her
in
a
pale
magic
lantern
;
but
she
appeared
to
remember
me
perfectly
,
and
still
to
suspect
me
of
being
in
a
state
of
intoxication
.
   
<EOS>
Finding
by
degrees
,
however
,
that
I
was
sober
,
and
(
I
hope
)
<EOS>
that
I
was
a
modest
young
gentleman
<EOS>
,
Mrs
Waterbrook
softened
towards
me
considerably
,
and
inquired
,
firstly
,
if
I
went
much
into
the
parks
,
and
secondly
,
if
I
went
much
into
society
.
 
<EOS>
On
my
replying
to
both
these
questions
in
the
negative
,
it
occurred
to
me
that
I
fell
again
in
her
good
opinion
;
but
she
concealed
the
fact
gracefully
,
and
invited
me
to
dinner
next
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
accepted
the
invitation
,
and
took
my
leave
,
making
a
call
on
Uriah
in
the
office
as
I
went
out
,
and
leaving
a
card
for
him
in
his
absence
.
   
<EOS>
When
I
went
to
dinner
next
day
,
and
on
the
street
door
being
opened
,
plunged
into
a
vapour
-
bath
of
haunch
of
mutton
,
I
divined
that
I
was
not
the
only
guest
,
for
I
immediately
identified
the
ticket
-
porter
in
disguise
,
assisting
the
family
servant
,
and
waiting
at
the
foot
of
the
stairs
to
carry
up
my
name
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
,
to
the
best
of
his
ability
,
when
he
asked
me
for
it
confidentially
,
as
if
he
had
never
seen
me
before
;
but
well
did
I
know
him
,
and
well
did
he
know
me
.
 
<EOS>
Conscience
made
cowards
of
us
both
.
   
<EOS>
I
found
Mr
Waterbrook
to
be
a
middle
-
aged
gentleman
,
with
a
short
throat
,
and
a
good
deal
of
shirt
-
collar
,
who
only
wanted
a
black
nose
to
be
the
portrait
of
a
pug
-
dog
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
me
he
was
happy
to
have
the
honour
of
making
my
acquaintance
;
and
when
I
had
paid
my
homage
to
Mrs
Waterbrook
,
presented
me
,
with
much
ceremony
,
to
a
very
awful
lady
in
a
black
velvet
dress
,
and
a
great
black
velvet
hat
,
whom
I
remember
as
looking
like
a
near
relation
of
Hamlet
's
---
say
his
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Henry
Spiker
was
this
lady
's
name
;
and
her
husband
was
there
too
:
<EOS>
so
cold
a
man
,
that
his
head
,
instead
of
being
grey
,
seemed
to
be
sprinkled
with
hoar
-
frost
.
 
<EOS>
Immense
deference
was
shown
to
the
Henry
Spikers
,
male
and
female
;
which
Agnes
told
me
was
on
account
of
Mr
Henry
Spiker
being
solicitor
to
something
Or
to
Somebody
<EOS>
,
I
forget
what
or
which
,
remotely
connected
with
the
Treasury
.
   
<EOS>
I
found
Uriah
Heep
among
the
company
,
in
a
suit
of
black
,
and
in
deep
humility
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
me
,
when
I
shook
hands
with
him
,
that
he
was
proud
to
be
noticed
by
me
,
and
that
he
really
felt
obliged
to
me
for
my
condescension
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
have
wished
he
had
been
less

to
me
,
for
he
hovered
about
me
in
his
gratitude
all
the
rest
of
the

;
and
<EOS>
whenever
I
said
a
word
to
Agnes
,
was
sure
,
with
his
shadowless
eyes
and
cadaverous

,
to
be
looking

down

.
   
<EOS>
There
were
other
guests
---
all
iced
for
the
occasion
,
as
it

me
,
like
the
wine
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
one
who
attracted

before
he

,
on

my

<EOS>
him
announced
as
Mr

!
 
<EOS>
My

flew
back
to
Salem
House
;
and
could
it
be
Tommy
,
I
thought
,
who
used
to
draw

!
   
<EOS>
I
looked

Mr

with

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
sober
,

man
of

,
with
a

of

,
and

rather

;
and

into
an

,
that

.
 
<EOS>
At

a

,
and
either

,
or
it

the
old

.
   
<EOS>
I

Mr
Waterbrook
,
and
said
,
that
I
believed

.
   
<EOS>
"

!
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Aye

!
 
<EOS>
Indeed
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Possibly
.
"
   
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
A

<EOS>

<EOS>
He

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Oh

.
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
I

"
<EOS>
Yes
"
,

.
 
<EOS>
There

.
 
<EOS>
It

a

who
had

,
not

say
with

,

,

,

,

on

.
   
<EOS>
My

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Waterbrook
went

's

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Henry
Spiker

.
 
<EOS>
Agnes
,

,

.
<EOS>
Uriah
,

,

,

,

,
how

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Traddles

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

about

---
and

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs

,
that

,

Blood
.
   
<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

,
that

.
 
<EOS>
A
<EOS>
Mr

,

what

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
These

Blood
,

.
   
<EOS>
We

.
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr

,

<EOS>

(

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

,

;

,

's

's

,

so
on
,

.
 
<EOS>
All
this

we
,
the
outsiders
,
remained
oppressed
by
the

interests
involved
in
the

;
and
our
host
regarded
us
with

,
as
the
victims
of
a
salutary
awe
and

.
<EOS>
I
was
very

to
get

to
Agnes
,
and
to

in

,
and
to

to
her
,
who
was
shy
,
but

,
and
the

still
.
 
<EOS>
As

was

to
leave
early
,
on
account
of
going
away
next
morning
for
a
month
,
I
had
not
nearly
so
much

with
him
as
I
could
have
wished
;
but
we
exchanged

,
and
promised
ourselves
the
pleasure
of
another

when
he
should

to

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
greatly
interested
to
hear
that
I
knew
Steerforth
,
and
spoke
of
him
with
such
warmth
that
I
made
him
tell
Agnes
what
he
thought
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
Agnes
only
looked
at
me
the
while
,
and
very
slightly
shook
her
head
when
only
I
observed
her
.
   
<EOS>
As
she
was
not
among

she
could
be
very
much
at
home
,
I

she
was

within

,
though
I

.
 
<EOS>
This
caused
me
to
remain
until
all

.
 
<EOS>
Conversing
with
her
,
and

sing
,
was
such

to
me
of
my
happy
life
in
the
grave

house
she
had

so

,
that
I
could
have
remained
there
half
the
night
;
but
,
having
no
excuse
for
staying
any
longer
,
when
the
lights
of
Mr
Waterbrook
's
society
were
all
snuffed
out
<EOS>
,
I
took
my
leave
very
much
against
my
inclination
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
then
,
more
than
ever
,
that
she
was
my
better
Angel
;
and
if
I
thought
of
her
sweet
face
and
placid
smile
,
as
though
they
had
shone
on
me
from
some
removed
being
,
like
an
Angel
<EOS>
,
I
hope
I
thought
no
harm
.
   
<EOS>
I
have
said
that
the
company
were
all
gone
;
but
I
ought
to
have
excepted
Uriah
,
whom
I
do
n't
include
in
that
denomination
,
and
who
had
never
ceased
to
hover
near
us
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
close
behind
me
when
I
went
downstairs
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
close
beside
me
,
when
I
walked
away
from
the
house
,
slowly
fitting
his
long
skeleton
fingers
into
the
still
longer
fingers
of
a
great
Guy
Fawkes
pair
of
gloves
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
in
no
disposition
for
Uriah
's
company
,
but
in
remembrance
of
the
entreaty
Agnes
had
made
to
me
,
that
I
asked
him
if
he
would
come
home
to
my
rooms
,
and
have
some
coffee
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
really
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
he
rejoined
---
"
<EOS>
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Mister
Copperfield
,
but
<EOS>
the
other
comes
so
natural
,
I
do
n't
like
that
you
should
put
a
constraint
upon
yourself
to
ask
a
numble
person
like
me
to
your
ouse
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
constraint
in
the
case
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
come
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
,
very
much
,
"
replied
Uriah
,
with
a
writhe
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
come
along
!
"
said
I.
   
I
could
not
help
being
rather
short
with
him
,
but
he
appeared
not
to
mind
it
.
 
<EOS>
We
went
the
nearest
way
,
without
conversing
much
upon
the
road
;
and
he
was
so
humble
in
respect
of
those
scarecrow
gloves
,
that
he
was
still
putting
them
on
,
and
seemed
to
have
made
no
advance
in
that
labour
,
when
we
got
to
my
place
.
   
<EOS>
I
led
him
up
the
dark
stairs
,
to
prevent
his
knocking
his
head
against
anything
,
and
really
his
damp
cold
hand
felt
so
like
a
frog
in
mine
,
that
I
was
tempted
to
drop
it
and
run
away
.
 
<EOS>
Agnes
and
hospitality
prevailed
,
however
,
and
I
conducted
him
to
my
fireside
.
<EOS>
When
I
lighted
my
candles
,
he
fell
into
meek
transports
with
the
room
that
was
revealed
to
him
;
and
when
I
heated
the
coffee
in
an
unassuming
block
-
tin
vessel
in
which
Mrs
Crupp
delighted
to
prepare
it
(
chiefly
,
I
believe
,
because
it
was
not
intended
for
the
purpose
,
being
a
shaving
-
pot
,
and
because
there
was
a
patent
invention
of
great
price
mouldering
away
in
the
pantry
)
,
he
professed
so
much
emotion
,
that
I
could
joyfully
have
scalded
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
really
,
Master
Copperfield
,
---
I
mean
Mister
Copperfield
,
"
said
Uriah
,
"
to
see
you
waiting
upon
me
<EOS>
is
what
I
never
could
have
expected
!
 
<EOS>
But
,
one
way
and
another
,
so
many
things
happen
to
me
which
I
never
could
have
expected
,
I
am
sure
,
in
my
umble
station
,
that
it
seems
to
rain
blessings
on
my
ed
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
heard
something
,
I
des
-
say
,
of
a
change
in
my
expectations
,
Master
Copperfield
,
---
I
should
say
,
Mister
Copperfield
?
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
sat
on
my
sofa
,
with
his
long

drawn
up
under
his
coffee

cup
,
his
hat
and
gloves
upon
the
ground
close
to

,
his
spoon
going
softly
round
and

,
his
shadowless
red
eyes
,
which
looked
as
if
they
had
scorched
their

off
,
turned
towards
me
without
looking
at
me
,
the
disagreeable
dints
I
have
formerly
described
in
his
nostrils
coming
and
going
with
his
breath
,
and
a
snaky
undulation
pervading
his
frame
from
his
chin
to
his
boots
,
I
decided
in
my
own
mind
that
I
disliked
him
intensely
.
 
<EOS>
It
made
me
very
uncomfortable
to
have
him
for
a
guest
,
for
I
was
young
then
,
and
unused
to
disguise
what
I
so
strongly
felt
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
heard
something
,
I
des
-
say
,
of
a
change
in
my
expectations
,
Master
Copperfield
,
---
I
should
say
,
Mister
Copperfield
?
<EOS>
"
observed
Uriah
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
I
,
"
something
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
I
thought
Miss
Agnes
would
know
of
it
!
"
<EOS>
he
quietly
returned
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
glad
to
find
Miss
Agnes
knows
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
thank
you
,
Master
---
Mister
Copperfield
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
have
thrown
my
bootjack
at
him
<EOS>
(
it
lay
ready
on
the
rug
)
,
for
having
entrapped
me
into
the
disclosure
of
anything
concerning
Agnes
,
however

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
only
drank

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
prophet
you
have
shown

,
Mister
Copperfield
!
"
pursued
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
what
a
prophet
you
have
proved
yourself
to
be
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
remember
saying
to
me
once
,
that
perhaps
I
should
be
a
partner
in
Mr
Wickfield
's

,
and
perhaps
it
might
be
Wickfield
and
Heep
?
 
<EOS>
You
may
not
recollect
it
;
but
when
a
person
is
umble
,
Master
Copperfield
,
a
person
treasures
such
things
up
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
recollect
talking
about
it
,
"
said
I
,
"
though
I
certainly
did
not
think

very
likely

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
who
would
have
thought
it
likely
,
Mister
Copperfield
!
"
<EOS>
returned
Uriah
,
enthusiastically
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
I
did
n't
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
recollect
saying
with
my
own
lips
that
I
was
much
too
umble
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
considered
myself
really
and
truly
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
sat
,
with
that
carved
grin
on
his
face
,
looking
at
the
fire
,
as
I
looked
at

.
   
<EOS>
"
But
the
umblest
persons
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
he
presently
resumed
,
"
may
be
the
instruments
of
good
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
to
think
I
have
been
the
instrument
of
good
to
Mr
Wickfield
,
and
that
I
may
be
more
so
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
what
a
worthy
man
he
is
,
Mister
Copperfield
,
but
how
imprudent
he
has
been
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
hear
it
,
"
said
<EOS>
I.
 
I
could
not
help
adding
,
rather
pointedly
,
"
on
all
accounts
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Decidedly
so
,
Mister
Copperfield
,
"
replied
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
"
On
all
accounts
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Agnes
's
above
all
!
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
remember
your
own
eloquent
expressions
,
Master
Copperfield
;
but
I
remember
how
you
said
one
day
that
everybody
must
admire
her
,
and
how
I
thanked
you
for
it
!
 
<EOS>
You
have
forgot
that
,
I
have
no

,
Master
Copperfield
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
I
,
drily
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
how
glad
I
am
you
have
not
!
"
exclaimed
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
think
that
you
should
be
the
first
to
kindle
the
sparks
of
ambition
in
my
umble
breast
,
and
that
you
've
not
forgot
it
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
---
Would
you
excuse
me
asking
for
a
cup
more
coffee
?
"
   
<EOS>
Something
in
the
emphasis
he
laid
upon
the
kindling
of
those

,
and
something
in

glance
he
directed
at

as

said

,
had
made
me
start
as
if
I
had
seen
him
illuminated
by
a

of
light
.
 
<EOS>
Recalled
by
his
request
,
preferred
in
quite
another
tone
of
voice
,
I
did
the
honours
of
the
shaving
-
pot
;
but
I
did
them
with
an
unsteadiness
of
hand
,
a
sudden
sense
of
being
no
match
for
him
,
and
a

suspicious
anxiety
as
to
what
he
might
be

to
say
next
,
which
I
felt
could
not
escape
his
observation
.
   
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
He
stirred
his
coffee
round
and
round
,
he
sipped
it
<EOS>
,
he
felt
his
chin
softly
with
his
grisly
hand
,
he
looked
at
the
fire
,
he
looked
about
the
room
,
he
gasped
rather
than
smiled
at
me
,
he
writhed
and
undulated
about
,
in
his
deferential
servility
,
he
stirred
and
sipped
again
,
but
he
left
the
renewal
of
the
conversation
to
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
,
Mr
Wickfield
,
"
said
I
,
at
last
,
"
who
is
worth
five
hundred
of
you
---
or
me
"
;
for
my
life
,
I
think
,
I
could
not
have
helped
dividing
that
part
of
the
sentence
with
an
awkward

;
"
has
been
imprudent
,
has
he
,
Mr
Heep
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
very
imprudent
indeed
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
returned
Uriah
,
sighing
modestly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
very
much
so
!
 
<EOS>
But
I
wish
you
'd
call
me
Uriah
,
if
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
like
old
times
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
Uriah
,
"
said
I
,
bolting
it

with
some

.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
he
returned
,
with
fervour
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Master
Copperfield
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
like
the
blowing
of
old
breezes
or
the
ringing
of
old
bellses
to
hear
YOU
say
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
I
beg
your
pardon
.
 
<EOS>
Was
I
making
any
observation
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
About
Mr
Wickfield
,
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
truly
,
"
said
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Great
imprudence
,
Master
Copperfield
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
topic
that
I
would
n't
touch
upon
,
to
any
soul
but
you
.
 
<EOS>
Even
to
you
I
can
only
touch
upon
it
,
and
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
If
anyone
else
had
been
in
my

during
the
last

,
by
this

he
would
have
had
Mr
Wickfield
<EOS>
(
oh
,
what
a
worthy
man
he
is
,
Master
Copperfield
,
too
!
)
<EOS>
under

.
 
<EOS>
Un
-
der
---
his
thumb
,
"
said
Uriah
,
very
slowly
,
as
he
stretched

-

above
my
table
,
and
pressed
his
own
thumb
upon
it
,
until
it
shook
,
and
shook
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
If
I
had
been
obliged
to
look
at
him
with
him
splay
foot
on
Mr
Wickfield
's
head
,
I
think
I
could
scarcely
have
hated
him
more
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
dear
,
yes
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
he
proceeded
,
in
a
soft
voice
,
most
remarkably
contrasting
with
the
action
of
his
thumb
,
which
did
not
diminish
its
hard
pressure
in
the
least
degree
,
"
there
's
no
doubt
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
There
would
have
been
loss
,
disgrace
<EOS>
,
I
do
n't
know
what
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Wickfield
knows
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
the
umble
instrument
of
umbly
serving
him
,
and
he
puts
me
on
an
eminence
I
hardly
could
have
hoped
to
reach
.
 
<EOS>
How
thankful
should
I
be
!
"
<EOS>
With
his
face
turned
towards
me
,
as
he
finished
,
but
without
looking
at
me
,
he
took
his
crooked
thumb
off
the
spot
where
he
had
planted
it
,
and
slowly
and
thoughtfully
scraped
his
lank
jaw
with
it
,
as
if
he
were
shaving
himself
.
   
<EOS>
I
recollect
well
how
indignantly
my
heart
beat
,
as
I
saw
his
crafty
face
,
with
the
appropriately
red
light
of
the
fire
upon
it
,
preparing
for
something
else
.
   
<EOS>
"
Master
Copperfield
,
"
he
began
---
"
but
am
I
keeping
you
up
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
keeping
me
up
.
 
<EOS>
I
generally
go
to
bed
late
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Master
Copperfield
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
risen
from
my
umble
station
since
first
you
used
to
address
me
,
it
is
true
;
but
I
am
umble
still
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
I
never
shall
be
otherwise
than
umble
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
not
think
the
worse
of
my
umbleness
,
if
I
make
a
little
confidence
to
you
,
Master
Copperfield
?
 
<EOS>
Will
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
no
,
"
said
I
,
with
an
effort
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
!
"
<EOS>
He
took
out
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
and
began
wiping
the
palms
of
his
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
Miss
Agnes
,
Master
Copperfield
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Uriah
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
how
pleasant
to
be
called
Uriah
,
spontaneously
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
;
and
gave
himself
a
jerk
,
like
a
convulsive
fish
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
thought
her
looking
very
beautiful
tonight
,
Master
Copperfield
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
her
looking
as
she
always
does
:
superior
,
in
all
respects
,
to
everyone
around
her
,
"
I
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
thank
you
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
so
true
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
thank
you
very
much
for
that
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
,
"
I
said
,
loftily
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
reason
why
you
should
thank
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why

,

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Umble

,
"

"

,

<EOS>
It

<EOS>
He

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
His

,

Mrs

,

.
 
<EOS>
As

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
I
never

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

!

<EOS>
Chapter
26
.
<EOS>
I
fall
into
captivity
 
<EOS>
I
saw
no

of
Uriah
Heep
,

.
<EOS>
I

and

;
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
some

to
me

observe
his
spare
,

-

,
high

,

-
coat

,

like

,

,

was

of

,
inside
;
but
what

underwent
in

,
while

looked
on
,
perhaps
deserved

.
 
<EOS>
At

,
as
at
the

,
he
hovered
about

without
a

's

,
like

:
gorging

on
every

I

to

,
or

said

.
   
<EOS>
In
the

trouble
into
which
his

by
my

had
thrown

,
I
had
thought
very
much
of
the
words
Agnes
had
used
in

the

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
what
I
hope
was
right
.
<EOS>
Feeling
sure
that
it
was
necessary
for
papa
's
peace
that
the
sacrifice
should
be
made
,
I
entreated
him
to
make
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
A
miserable
foreboding
that
she
would
yield
to
,
and
sustain
herself
by
,
the
same
feeling
in
reference
to
any

for
his
sake
,
had
oppressed
me
ever
since
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
how
she
loved
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
what
the
devotion
of
her
nature
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
from
her
own
lips
that
she
regarded
herself
as
the
innocent
cause
of
his
errors
,
and
as
owing
him
a
great
debt
she
ardently
desired
to
pay
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
consolation
in
seeing
how
different
she
was
from
this
detestable
Rufus
with
the
mulberry
-
coloured
great
-
coat
,
<EOS>
for
I
felt
that
in
the
very
difference
between
them
,
in
the
self
-
denial
of
her
pure
soul
and
the
sordid
baseness
of
his
,
the
greatest
danger
lay
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
,
doubtless
,
he
knew
thoroughly
,
and
had
,
in
his
cunning
,
considered
well
.
   
<EOS>
Yet
I
was
so
certain
that
the
prospect
of
such
a
sacrifice
afar
off
,
must
destroy
the
happiness
of
Agnes
;
and
I
was
so
sure
,
from
her
manner
,
of
its
being
unseen
by
her
then
,
and
having
cast
no
shadow
on
her
yet
;
that
I
could
as
soon
have
injured
her
,
as
given
her
any
warning
of
what
impended
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
it
was
that
we
parted
without
explanation
<EOS>
:
she
waving
her
hand
and
smiling
farewell
from
the
coach
window
;
her
evil
genius
writhing
on
the
roof
,
as
if
he
had
her
in
his
clutches
and
triumphed
.
   
<EOS>
I
could
not
get
over
this
farewell
glimpse
of
them
for
a
long
time
.
<EOS>
When
Agnes
wrote
to
tell
me
of
her
safe
arrival
,
I
was
as
miserable
as
when
I
saw
her
going
away
.
 
<EOS>
Whenever
I
fell
into
a
thoughtful
state
,
this
subject
was
sure
to
present
itself
,
and
all
my
uneasiness
was
sure
to
be
redoubled
.
 
<EOS>
Hardly
a
night
passed
without
my
dreaming
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
became
a
part
of
my
life
,
and
as
inseparable
from
my
life
as
my
own
head
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
ample
leisure
to
refine
upon
my
uneasiness
:
for
Steerforth
was
at
Oxford
,
as
he
wrote
to
me
,
and
when
I
was
not
at
the
Commons
,
I
was
very
much
alone
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
had
at
this
time
some
lurking
distrust
of
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
I
wrote
to
him
most
affectionately
in
reply
to
his
,
but
I
think
I
was
glad
,
upon
the
whole
,
that
he
could
not
come
to
London
just
then
.
 
<EOS>
I
suspect
the
truth
to
be
,
that
the
influence
of
Agnes
was
upon
me
,
undisturbed
by
the
sight
of
him
;
and
that
it
was
the
more
powerful
with
me
,
because
she
had
so
large
a
share
in
my
thoughts
and
interest
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
,
days
and
weeks
slipped
away
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
articled
to
Spenlow
and
Jorkins
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
ninety
pounds
a
year
<EOS>
(
exclusive
of
my
house
-
rent
and
sundry
collateral
matters
)
from
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
My
rooms
were
engaged
for
twelve
months
certain
:
and
though
I
still
found
them
dreary
of
an
evening
,
and
the
evenings
long
,
I
could
settle
down
into
a
state
of
equable
low
spirits
,
and
resign
myself
to
coffee
;
which
I
seem
,
on
looking
back
,
to
have
taken
by
the
gallon
at
about
this
period
of
my
existence
.
 
<EOS>
At
about
this
time
,
too
,
I
made
three
discoveries
:
first
,
that
Mrs
Crupp
was
a
martyr
to
a
curious
disorder
called
"
the
spazzums
"
,
which
was
generally
accompanied
with
inflammation
of
the
nose
,
and
required
to
be
constantly
treated
with
peppermint
;
secondly
,
that
something
peculiar
in
the
temperature
of
my
pantry
,
made
the
brandy
-
bottles
burst
;
thirdly
,
that
I
was
alone
in
the
world
,
and
much
given
to
record
that
circumstance
in
fragments
of
English
versification
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
day
when
I
was
articled
,
no
festivity
took
place
,
beyond
my
having
sandwiches
and
sherry
into
the
office
for
the
clerks
,
and
going
alone
to
the
theatre
at
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
see
The
Stranger
,
as
a
Doctors
'
Commons
sort
of
play
,
and
was
so
dreadfully
cut
up
,
that
I
hardly
knew
myself
in
my
own
glass
when
I
got
home
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Spenlow
remarked
,
on
this
occasion
,
when
we
concluded
our
business
,
that
he
should
have
been
happy
to
have
seen
me
at
his
house
at
Norwood
to
celebrate
our
becoming
connected
,
but
for
his
domestic
arrangements
being
in
some
disorder
,
on
account
of
the
expected
return
of
his
daughter
from
finishing
her
education
at
Paris
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
he
intimated
that
when
she
came
home
he
should
hope
to
have
the
pleasure
of
entertaining
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
that
he
was
a
widower
with
one
daughter
,
and
expressed
my
acknowledgements
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Spenlow
was
as
good
as
his
word
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
week
or
two
,
he
referred
to
this
engagement
,
and
said
,
that
if
I
would
do
him
the
favour
to
come
down
next
Saturday
,
and
stay
till
Monday
,
he
would
be
extremely
happy
.
 
<EOS>
Of
course
I
said
I
would
do
him
the
favour
;
and
he
was
to
drive
me
down
in
his
phaeton
,
and
to
bring
me
back
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
day
arrived
,
my
very
carpet
-
bag
was
an
object
of
veneration
to
the
stipendiary
clerks
,
to
whom
the
house
at
Norwood
was
a
sacred
mystery
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
them
informed
me
that
he
had
heard
that
Mr
Spenlow
ate
entirely
off
plate
and
china
;
and
another
hinted
at
champagne
being
constantly
on
draught
,
after
the
usual
custom
of
table
-
beer
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
clerk
with
the
wig
,
whose
name
was
Mr
Tiffey
,
had
been
down
on
business
several
times
in
the
course
of
his
career
,
and
had
on
each
occasion
penetrated
to
the
breakfast
-
parlour
.
 
<EOS>
He
described
it
as
an
apartment
of
the
most
sumptuous
nature
,
and
said
that
he
had
drunk
brown
East
India
sherry
there
,
of
a
quality
so
precious
as
to
make
a
man
wink
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
an
adjourned
cause
in
the
Consistory
that
day
---
about
excommunicating
a
baker
who
had
been
objecting
in
a
vestry
to
a
paving
-
rate
---
and
as
the
evidence
was
just
twice
the
length
of
Robinson
Crusoe
,
according
to
a
calculation
I
made
,
it
was
rather
late
in
the
day
before
we
finished
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
we
got
him
excommunicated
for
six
weeks
,
and
sentenced
in
no
end
of
costs
;
and
then
the
baker
's
proctor
,
and
the
judge
,
and
the
advocates
on
both
sides
(
who
were
all
nearly
related
)
,
went
out
of
town
together
,
and
Mr
Spenlow
<EOS>
and
I
drove
away
in
the
phaeton
.
   
<EOS>
The
phaeton
was
a
very
handsome
affair
;
the
horses
arched
their
necks
and
lifted
up
their
legs
as
if
they
knew
they
belonged
to
Doctors
'
Commons
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
good
deal
of
competition
in
the
Commons
on
all
points
of
display
,
and
it
turned
out
some
very
choice
equipages
then
;
though
I
always
have
considered
,
and
always
shall
consider
,
that
in
my
time
the
great
article
of
competition
there
was
starch
:
which
I
think
was
worn
among
the
proctors
to
as
great
an
extent
as
it
is
in
the
nature
of
man
to
bear
.
   
<EOS>
We
were
very
pleasant
,
going
down
,
and
Mr
Spenlow
gave
me
some
hints
in
reference
to
my
profession
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
it
was
the
genteelest
profession
in
the
world
,
and
must
on
no
account
be
confounded
with
the
profession
of
a
solicitor
:
being
quite
another
sort
of
thing
,
infinitely
more
exclusive
,
less
mechanical
,
and
more
profitable
.
<EOS>
We
took
things
much
more
easily
in
the
Commons
than
they
could
be
taken
anywhere
else
,
he
observed
,
and
that
set
us
,
as
a
privileged
class
,
apart
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
it
was
impossible
to
conceal
the
disagreeable
fact
,
that
we
were
chiefly
employed
by
solicitors
;
but
he
gave
me
to
understand
that
they
were
an
inferior
race
of
men
,
universally
looked
down
upon
by
all
proctors
of
any
pretensions
.
   
<EOS>
I
asked
Mr
Spenlow
what
he
considered
the
best
sort
of
professional
business
?
 
<EOS>
He
replied
,
that
a
good
case
of
a
disputed
will
,
where
there
was
a
neat
little
estate
of
thirty
or
forty
thousand
pounds
,
was
,
perhaps
,
the
best
of
all
.
 
<EOS>
In
such
a
case
,
he
said
,
not
only
were
there
very
pretty
pickings
,
in
the
way
of
arguments
at
every
stage
of
the
proceedings
,
and
mountains
upon
mountains
of
evidence
on
interrogatory
and
counter
-
interrogatory
(
to
say
nothing
of
an
appeal
lying
,
first
to
the
Delegates
,
and
then
to
the
Lords
)
,
but
,
the
costs
being
pretty
sure
to
come
out
of
the
estate
at
last
,
both
sides
went
at
it
in
a
lively
and
spirited
manner
,
and
expense
was
no
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
he
launched
into
a
general
eulogium
on
the
Commons
.
 
<EOS>
What
was
to
be
particularly
admired
(
he
said
)
in
the
Commons
,
was
its
compactness
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
most
conveniently
organized
place
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
complete
idea
of
snugness
.
 
<EOS>
It
lay
in
a
nutshell
.
 
<EOS>
For
example
:
You
brought
a
divorce
case
,
or
a
restitution
case
,
into
the
Consistory
.
<EOS>
Very
good
.
 
<EOS>
You
tried
it
in
the
Consistory
.
 
<EOS>
You
made
a
quiet
little
round
game
of
it
,
among
a
family
group
,
and
you
played
it
out
at
leisure
.
 
<EOS>
Suppose
you
were
not
satisfied
with
the
Consistory
,
what
did
you
do
then
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
you
went
into
the
Arches
.
<EOS>
What
was
the
Arches
?
 
<EOS>
The
same
court
,
in
the
same
room
,
with
the
same
bar
,
and
the
same
practitioners
,
but
another
judge
,
for
there
the
Consistory
judge
could
plead
any
court
-
day
as
an
advocate
.
<EOS>
Well
,
you
played
your
round
game
out
again
.
 
<EOS>
Still
you
were
not
satisfied
.
 
<EOS>
Very
good
.
 
<EOS>
What
did
you
do
then
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
you
went
to
the
Delegates
.
 
<EOS>
Who
were
the
Delegates
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
the
Ecclesiastical
Delegates
were
the
advocates
without
any
business
,
who
had
looked
on
at
the
round
game
when
it
was
playing
in
both
courts
,
and
had
seen
the
cards
shuffled
,
and
cut
,
and
played
,
and
had
talked
to
all
the
players
about
it
,
and
now
came
fresh
,
as
judges
,
to
settle
the
matter
to
the
satisfaction
of
everybody
!
 
<EOS>
Discontented
people
might
talk
of
corruption
in
the
Commons
,
closeness
in
the
Commons
,
and
the
necessity
of
reforming
the
Commons
,
said
Mr
Spenlow
solemnly
,
in
conclusion
;
but
when
the
price
of
wheat
per
bushel
had
been
highest
,
the
Commons
had
been
busiest
;
and
a
man
might
lay
his
hand
upon
his
heart
,
and
say
this
to
the
whole
world
,
---
<EOS>
"
Touch
the
Commons
,
and
down
comes
the
country
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
listened
to
all
this
with
attention
;
and
though
,
I
must
say
,
I
had
my
doubts
whether
the
country
was
quite
as
much
obliged
to
the
Commons
as
Mr
Spenlow
made
out
<EOS>
,
I
respectfully
deferred
to
his
opinion
.
 
<EOS>
That
about
the
price
of
wheat
per
bushel
,
I
modestly
felt
was
too
much
for
my
strength
,
and
quite
settled
the
question
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
never
,
to
this
hour
,
got
the
better
of
that
bushel
of
wheat
.
<EOS>
It
has
reappeared
to
annihilate
me
,
all
through
my
life
,
in
connexion
with
all
kinds
of
subjects
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
now
,
exactly
,
what
it
has
to
do
with
me
,
or
what
right
<EOS>
it
has
to
crush
me
,
on
an
infinite
variety
of
occasions
;
but
whenever
I
see
my
old
friend
the
bushel
brought
in
by
the
head
and
shoulders
(
as
he
always
is
,
I
observe
)
,
I
give
up
a
subject
for
lost
.
   
<EOS>
This
is
a
digression
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
the
man
to
touch
the
Commons
,
and
bring
down
the
country
.
 
<EOS>
I
submissively
expressed
,
by
my
silence
,
my
acquiescence
in
all
I
had
heard
from
my
superior
in
years
and
knowledge
;
and
we
talked
about
The
Stranger
and
the
Drama
,
and
the
pairs
of
horses
,
until
we
came
to
Mr
Spenlow
's
gate
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
lovely
garden
to
Mr
Spenlow
's
house
;
and
though
that
was
not
the
best
time
of
the
year
for
seeing
a
garden
,
it
was
so
beautifully
kept
,
that
I
was
quite
enchanted
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
charming
lawn
,
there
were
clusters
of
trees
,
and
there
were
perspective
walks
that
I
could
just
distinguish
in
the
dark
,
arched
over
with
trellis
-
work
,
on
which
shrubs
and
flowers
grew
in
the
growing
season
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
Miss
Spenlow
walks
by
herself
,
"
I
thought
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
went
into
the
house
,
which
was
cheerfully
lighted
up
,
and
into
a
hall
where
there
were
all
sorts
of
hats
,
caps
,
great
-
coats
,
plaids
,
gloves
,
whips
,
and
walking
-
sticks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
Miss
Dora
?
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
to
the
servant
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dora
!
<EOS>
"
I
thought
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
beautiful
name
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
turned
into
a
room
near
at
hand
(
I
think
it
was
the
identical
breakfast
-
room
,
made
memorable
by
the
brown
East
Indian
sherry
)
,
and
I
heard
a
voice
say
,
"
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
,
my
daughter
Dora
,
and
my
daughter
Dora
's
confidential
friend
!
<EOS>
"
It
was
,
no
doubt
,
Mr
Spenlow
's
voice
,
but
I
did
n't
know
it
,
and
I
did
n't
care
whose
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
All
was
over
in
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
fulfilled
my
destiny
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
a
captive
and
a
slave
.
 
<EOS>
I
loved
Dora
Spenlow
to
distraction
!
   
<EOS>
She
was
more
than
human
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
a
Fairy
,
a
Sylph
<EOS>
,
I
do
n't
know
what
she
was
---
<EOS>
anything
that
no
one
ever
saw
,
and
everything
that
everybody
ever
wanted
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
swallowed
up
in
an
abyss
of
love
in
an
instant
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
pausing
on
the
brink
;
no
looking
down
,
or
looking
back
;
I
was
gone
,
headlong
,
before
I
had
sense
to
say
a
word
to
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
,
"
observed
a
well
-
remembered
voice
,
when
I
had
bowed
and
murmured
something
,
"
have
seen
Mr
Copperfield
before
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
speaker
was
not
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
No
;
the
confidential
friend
,
Miss
Murdstone
!
   
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
I
was
much
astonished
.
 
<EOS>
To
the
best
of
my
judgement
,
no
capacity
of
astonishment
was
left
in
me
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
worth
mentioning
in
the
material
world
,
but
Dora
Spenlow
,
to
be
astonished
about
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
,
"
How
do
you
do
,
Miss
Murdstone
?
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
are
well
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
She
answered
,
"
Very
well
.
"
 
<EOS>
I
said
,
"
How
is
Mr
Murdstone
?
"
<EOS>
She
replied
,
"
My
brother
is
robust
,
I
am
obliged
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Spenlow
,
who
,
I
suppose
,
had
been
surprised
to
see
us
recognize
each
other
,
then
put
in
his
word
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
find
,
"
he
said
,
"
Copperfield
,
that
you
and
Miss
Murdstone
are
already
acquainted
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Copperfield
and
myself
,
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
,
with
severe
composure
,
"
are
connexions
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
once
slightly
acquainted
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
his
childish
days
.
 
<EOS>
Circumstances
have
separated
us
since
.
<EOS>
I
should
not
have
known
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
replied
that
I
should
have
known
her
,
anywhere
.
 
<EOS>
Which
was
true
enough
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Murdstone
has
had
the
goodness
,
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
to
me
,
"
to
accept
the
office
---
if
I
may
so
describe
it
---
of
my
daughter
Dora
's
confidential
friend
.
 
<EOS>
My
daughter
Dora
having
,
unhappily
,
no
mother
,
Miss
Murdstone
is
obliging
enough
to
become
her
companion
and
protector
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
passing
thought
occurred
to
me
that
Miss
Murdstone
,
like
the
pocket
instrument
called
a
life
-
preserver
,
was
not
so
much
designed
for
purposes
of
protection
as
of
assault
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
I
had
none
but
passing
thoughts
for
any
subject
<EOS>
save
Dora
,
I
glanced
at
her
,
directly
afterwards
,
and
was
thinking
that
I
saw
,
in
her
prettily
pettish
manner
,
that
she
was
not
very
much
inclined
to
be
particularly
confidential
to
her
companion
and
protector
,
when
a
bell
rang
,
which
Mr
Spenlow
said
was
the
first
dinner
-
bell
,
and
so
carried
me
off
to
dress
.
   
<EOS>
The
idea
of
dressing
one
's
self
,
or
doing
anything
in
the
way
of
action
,
in
that
state
of
love
,
was
a
little
too
ridiculous
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
only
sit
down
before
my
fire
,
biting
the
key
of
my
carpet
-
bag
,
and
think
of
the
captivating
,
girlish
,
bright
-
eyed
lovely
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
form
she
had
,
what
a
face
<EOS>
she
had
,
what
a
graceful
,
variable
,
enchanting
manner
!
   
<EOS>
The
bell
rang
again
so
soon
that
I
made
a
mere
scramble
of
my
dressing
,
<EOS>
instead
of
the
careful
operation
I
could
have
wished
under
the
circumstances
,
and
went
downstairs
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
some
company
.
 
<EOS>
Dora
was
talking
to
an
old
gentleman
with
a
grey
head
.
<EOS>
Grey
as
he
was
---
and
a
great
-
grandfather
into
the
bargain
,
for
he
said
so
---
I
was
madly
jealous
of
him
.
   
<EOS>
What
a
state
of
mind
<EOS>
I
was
in
!
 
<EOS>
I
was
jealous
of
everybody
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
n't
bear
the
idea
of
anybody
knowing
Mr
Spenlow
better
than
I
did
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
torturing
to
me
to
hear
them
talk
of
occurrences
in
which
I
had
had
no
share
.
 
<EOS>
When
a
most
amiable
person
,
with
a
highly
polished
bald
head
,
asked
me
across
the
dinner
table
,
if
that
were
the
first
occasion
of
my
seeing
the
grounds
,
I
could
have
done
anything
to
him
that
was
savage
and
revengeful
.
   
<EOS>
I
do
n't
remember
who
was
there
,
except
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
the
least
idea
what
we
had
for
dinner
,
besides
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
My
impression
is
,
that
I
dined
off
Dora
,
entirely
,
and
sent
away
half
-
a
-
dozen
plates
untouched
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
next
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
talked
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
the
most
delightful
little
voice
,
the
gayest
little
laugh
,
the
pleasantest
and
most
fascinating
little
ways
,
that
ever
led
a
lost
youth
into
hopeless
slavery
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
rather
diminutive
altogether
.
 
<EOS>
So
much
the
more
precious
,
I
thought
.
   
<EOS>
When
she
went
out
of
the
room
with
Miss
Murdstone
(
no
other
ladies
were
of
the
party
)
,
I
fell
into
a
reverie
,
only
disturbed
by
the
cruel
apprehension
that
Miss
Murdstone
would
disparage
me
to
her
.
<EOS>
The
amiable
creature
with
the
polished
head
told
me
a
long
story
,
which
I
think
was
about
gardening
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
heard
him
say
,
"
my
gardener
"
,
several
times
.
 
<EOS>
I
seemed
to
pay
the
deepest
attention
to
him
,
but
I
was
wandering
in
a
garden
of
Eden
all
the
while
,
with
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
My
apprehensions
of
being
disparaged
to
the
object
of
my
engrossing
affection
were
revived
when
we
went
into
the
drawing
-
room
,
by
the
grim
and
distant
aspect
of
Miss
Murdstone
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
was
relieved
of
them
in
an
unexpected
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
David
Copperfield
,
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
,
beckoning
me
aside
into
a
window
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
word
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
confronted
Miss
Murdstone
alone
.
   
<EOS>
"
David
Copperfield
,
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
,
"
I
need
not
enlarge
upon
family
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
not
a
tempting
subject
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Far
from
it
,
ma'am
,
<EOS>
"
I
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
Far
from
it
,
"
assented
Miss
Murdstone
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
wish
to
revive
the
memory
of
past
differences
,
or
of
past
outrages
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
received
outrages
from
a
person
---
a
female
I
am
sorry
to
say
,
for
the
credit
of
my
sex
---
who
is
not
to
be
mentioned
without
scorn
and
disgust
;
and
therefore
I
would
rather
not
mention
her
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
very
fiery
on
my
aunt
's
account
;
but
I
said
it
would
certainly
be
better
,
if
Miss
Murdstone
pleased
,
not
to
mention
her
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
hear
her
disrespectfully
mentioned
,
I
added
,
without
expressing
my
opinion
in
a
decided
tone
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
shut
her
eyes
,
and
disdainfully
inclined
her
head
;
then
,
slowly
opening
her
eyes
,
resumed
:
   
"
<EOS>
David
Copperfield
,
I
shall
not
attempt
to
disguise
the
fact
,
that
I
formed
an
unfavourable
opinion
of
you
in
your
childhood
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
have
been
a
mistaken
one
,
or
you
may
have
ceased
to
justify
it
.
<EOS>
That
is
not
in
question
between
us
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
belong
to
a
family
remarkable
<EOS>
,
I
believe
,
for
some
firmness
;
and
I
am
not
the
creature
of
circumstance
or
change
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
have
my
opinion
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
have
your
opinion
of
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
inclined
my
head
,
in
my
turn
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
it
is
not
necessary
,
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
,
"
that
these
opinions
should
come
into
collision
here
.
 
<EOS>
Under
existing
circumstances
,
it
is
as
well
on
all
accounts
that
they
should
not
.
<EOS>
As
the
chances
of
life
have
brought
us
together
again
,
and
may
bring
us
together
on
other
occasions
,
I
would
say
,
let
us
meet
here
as
distant
acquaintances
.
 
<EOS>
Family
circumstances
are
a
sufficient
reason
for
our
only
meeting
on
that
footing
,
and
it
is
quite
unnecessary
that
either
of
us
should
make
the
other
the
subject
of
remark
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
approve
of
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Murdstone
,
"
<EOS>
I
returned
,
"
I
think
you
and
Mr
Murdstone
used
me
very
cruelly
,
and
treated
my
mother
with
great

.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
always
think
so
,
as
long
as
I
live
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
quite
agree
in
what
you
propose
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
shut
her
eyes
again
,
and
bent
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
just
touching
the
back
of
my
hand
with
the
tips
of
her
cold
,
stiff
fingers
,
she
walked
away
,
arranging
the
little
fetters
on
her

and
round

;
which
seemed
to
be
the
same
set
,
in
exactly
the
same
state
,
as
when
I
had
seen

last
.
 
<EOS>
These
reminded
me
,
in
reference
to
Miss
Murdstone
's
nature
,
of
the
fetters
over
a
jail
door
;
suggesting
on
the
outside
,
to
all
beholders
,
what
was
to
be
expected
within
.
   
<EOS>
All
I
know
of
the
rest
of
the

is
,
that
I
heard
the
empress
of
my
heart
sing
enchanted

in
the
French
language
,
generally
to
the
effect
that
,
whatever
was
the
matter
,
we
ought
always
to
dance
,
<EOS>
Ta
ra
la
,
<EOS>
Ta
ra
la
<EOS>
!
<EOS>
accompanying
herself
on
a
glorified
instrument
,
resembling
a
guitar
.
 
<EOS>
That
I
was
lost
in
blissful
delirium
.
 
<EOS>
That
I
refused
refreshment
.
 
<EOS>
That
my
soul
recoiled
from
punch
particularly
.
 
<EOS>
That
when
Miss
Murdstone
took
her
into
custody
and
led
her
away
,
she
smiled
and
gave
me
her
delicious

.
 
<EOS>
That
I
caught
a
view
of
myself
in
a
mirror
,
looking
perfectly
imbecile
and

.
 
<EOS>
That
I
retired
to
bed
in
a
most
maudlin
state
of
mind
,
and
got
up
in
a
crisis
of
feeble
infatuation
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
fine
morning
,
and
early
,
and
I
thought
I
would
go
and
take
a
stroll
down
one
of
those
wire

,
and
indulge
my

by
dwelling
on

.
 
<EOS>
On
my
way
through
the
hall
,
I
encountered
her
little
dog
,
who
was
called
Jip
---
short
for
Gipsy
.
<EOS>
I
approached
him
tenderly
,
for
I
loved
even
him
;
but
he
showed
his
whole
set
of
teeth
,
got
under
a
chair
expressly
to
snarl
,
and
would
n't
hear
of
the
least
familiarity
.
   
<EOS>
The
garden
was
cool
and
solitary
.
 
<EOS>
I
walked
about
,
wondering
what
my
feelings
of
happiness
would
be
,
if
I
could
ever
become
engaged
to
this
dear
wonder
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
marriage
,
and
fortune
,
and
all
that
,
I
believe
I
was
almost
as
innocently
undesigning
then
,
as
when
I
loved
little
Em'ly
.
 
<EOS>
To
be
allowed
to
call
her
"
Dora
"
,
to
write
to
her
,
to
dote
upon
and
worship
her
,
to
have

think
that
when
she
was
with
other

she
was
yet

of
me
,
seemed
to
me
the
summit
of
human
ambition
---
<EOS>
I
am
sure
it
was
the
summit
of
mine
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
doubt
whatever
that
I
was
a
lackadaisical
young
spooney
;
but
there
was
a
purity
of
heart
in
all
this
,
that
prevents
my
having
quite
a
contemptuous
recollection
of
it
,
let
me
laugh
as
I
may
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
not
been
walking
long
,
when
I
turned
a
corner
,
and
met
her
.
<EOS>
I
tingle
again
from
head
to
foot
as
my
recollection
turns
that
corner
,
and
my
pen
shakes
in
my
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
---
are
---
out
early
,
Miss
Spenlow
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
so
stupid
at
home
,
"
she
replied
,
"
and
Miss
Murdstone
is
so
absurd
!
 
<EOS>
She
talks
such
nonsense
about
its
being
necessary
for
the
day
to
be
aired
,
before
I
come
out
.
 
<EOS>
Aired
!
"
<EOS>
(
She
laughed
,
here
,
in
the
most
melodious
manner
.
)
<EOS>
"
On
a
Sunday
morning
,
when
I
do
n't
practise
,
I
must
do
something
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
told
papa
last
night
I
must
come
out
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
,
it
's
the
brightest
time
of
the
whole
day
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
think
so
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
hazarded
a
bold
flight
,
and
said
(
not
without
stammering
)
that
it
was
very
bright
to
me
then
,
though
it
had
been
very
dark
to
me
a
minute
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
a
compliment
?
"
said
Dora
,
"
or
that
the
weather
has
really
changed
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
stammered
worse
than
before
,
in
replying
that
I
meant
no
compliment
,
but
the
plain
truth
;
though
I
was
not
aware
of
any
change
having
taken
place
in
the
weather
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
the
state
of
my
own
feelings
,
I
added
bashfully
:
to
clench
the
explanation
.
   
<EOS>
I
never
saw
such
curls
---
how
could
I
,
for
there
never
were
such
curls
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
as
those
she
shook
out
to
hide
her
blushes
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
the
straw
hat
and
blue
ribbons
which
was
on
the
top
of
the
curls
,
if
I
could
only
have
hung
it
up
in
my
room
in
Buckingham
Street
,
what
a
priceless
possession
it
would
have
been
!
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
just
come
home
from
Paris
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
she
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
ever
been
there
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
hope
you
'll
go
soon
!
 
<EOS>
You
would
like
it
so
much
!
"
   
<EOS>
Traces
of
deep
-
seated
anguish
appeared
in
my
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
That
she
should
hope
I
would
go
,
that
she
should
think
it
possible
<EOS>
I
could
go
,
was
insupportable
.
 
<EOS>
I
depreciated
Paris
;
I
depreciated
France
.
<EOS>
I
said
I
would
n't
leave
England
,
under
existing
circumstances
,
for
any
earthly
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
should
induce
me
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
she
was
shaking
the
curls
again
,
when
the
little
dog
came
running
along
the
walk
to
our
relief
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
mortally
jealous
of
me
,
and
persisted
in
barking
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
She
took
him
up
in
her
arms
---
<EOS>
oh
my
goodness
!
---
and
caressed
him
,
but
he
persisted
upon
barking
still
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
n't
let
me
touch
him
,
when
I
tried
;
and
then
she
beat
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
increased
my
sufferings
greatly
to
see
the
pats
she
gave
him
for
punishment
on
the
bridge
of
his
blunt
nose
,
while
he
winked
his
eyes
,
and
licked
her
hand
,
and
still
growled
within
himself
like
a
little
double
-
bass
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
was
quiet
---
well
he
might
be
with
her
dimpled
chin
upon
his
head
!
<EOS>
---
and
we
walked
away
to
look
at
a
greenhouse
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
very
intimate
with
Miss
Murdstone
,
are
you
?
"
said
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
---
"
My
pet
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
(
The
two
last
words
were
to
the
dog
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
if
they
had
only
been
to
me
!
)
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
I
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
a
tiresome
creature
,
"
said
Dora
,
pouting
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
think
what
papa
can
have
been
about
,
when
he
chose
such
a
vexatious
thing
to
be
my
companion
.
 
<EOS>
Who
wants
a
protector
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
I
do
n't
want
a
protector
.
 
<EOS>
Jip
can
protect
me
a
great
deal
better
than
Miss
Murdstone
,
---
ca
n't
you
,
Jip
,
dear
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
only
winked
lazily
,
when
she
kissed
his
ball
of
a
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
Papa
calls
her
my
confidential
friend
,
but
I
am
sure
she
is
no
such
thing
---
is
she
,
Jip
?
 
<EOS>
We
are
not
going
to
confide
in
any
such
cross
people
,
Jip
and
I.
 
<EOS>
We
mean
to
bestow
our
confidence
where
we
like
,
and
to
find
out
our
own
friends
,
instead
of
having
them
found
out
for
us
---
do
n't
we
,
Jip
?
"
   
<EOS>
jip
made
a
comfortable
noise
,
in
answer
,
a
little
like
a
tea
-
kettle
when
it
sings
.
 
<EOS>
As
for
me
,
every
word
was
a
new
heap
of
fetters
,
riveted
above
the
last
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
hard
,
because
we
have
not
a
kind
Mama
,
that
we
are
to
have
,
instead
,
a
sulky
,
gloomy
old
thing
like
Miss
Murdstone
,
always
following
us
about
---
is
n't
it
,
Jip
?
 
<EOS>
Never
mind
,
Jip
.
 
<EOS>
We
wo
n't
be
confidential
,
and
we
'll
make
ourselves
as
happy
as
we
can
in
spite
of
her
,
and
we
'll
tease
her
,
and
not
please
her
---
wo
n't
we
,
Jip
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
If
it
had
lasted
any
longer
,
I
think
I
must
have
gone
down
on
my
knees
on
the
gravel
,
with
the
probability
before
me
of
grazing
them
,
and
of
being
presently
ejected
from
the
premises
besides
.
<EOS>
But
,
by
good
fortune
the
greenhouse
was
not
far
off
,
and
these
words
brought
us
to
it
.
   
<EOS>
It
contained
quite
a
show
of
beautiful
geraniums
.
 
<EOS>
We
loitered
along
in
front
of
them
,
and
Dora
often
stopped
to
admire
this
one
or
that
one
,
and
I
stopped
to
admire
the
same
one
,
and
Dora
,
laughing
,
held
the
dog
up
childishly
,
to
smell
the
flowers
;
and
if
we
were
not
all
three
in
Fairyland
,
certainly
I
was
.
 
<EOS>
The
scent
of
a
geranium
leaf
,
at
this
day
,
strikes
me
with
a
half
comical
half
serious
wonder
as
to
what
change
has
come
over
me
in
a
moment
;
and
then
I
see
a
straw
hat
and
blue
ribbons
,
and
a
quantity
of
curls
,
and
a
little
black
dog
being
held
up
,
in
two
slender
arms
,
against
a
bank
of
blossoms
and
bright
leaves
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
had
been
looking
for
us
.
 
<EOS>
She
found
us
here
;
and
presented
her
uncongenial
cheek
,
the
little
wrinkles
in
it
filled
with
hair
powder
,
to
Dora
to
be
kissed
.
 
<EOS>
Then
she
took
Dora
's
arm
in
hers
,
and
marched
us
into
breakfast
as
if
it
were
a
soldier
's
funeral
.
   
<EOS>
How
many
cups
of
tea
I
drank
,
because
Dora
made
it
,
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
But
,
I
perfectly
remember
that
I
sat
swilling
tea
until
my
whole
nervous
system
,
if
I
had
had
any
in
those
days
,
must
have
gone
by
the
board
.
 
<EOS>
By
and
by
we
went
to
church
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
was
between
Dora
and
me
in
the
pew
;
but
I
heard
her
sing
,
and
the
congregation
vanished
.
 
<EOS>
A
sermon
was
delivered
---
about
Dora
,
of
course
---
and
I
am
afraid
that
is
all
I
know
of
the
service
.
   
<EOS>
We
had
a
quiet
day
.
 
<EOS>
No
company
,
a
walk
,
a
family
dinner
of
four
,
and
an
evening
of
looking
over
books
and
pictures
;
Miss
Murdstone
with
a
homily
before
her
,
and
her
eye
upon
us
,
keeping
guard
vigilantly
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
little
<EOS>
did
Mr
Spenlow
imagine
,
when
he
sat
opposite
to
me
after
dinner
that
day
,
with
his
pocket

over
his
head
,
how
fervently
I
was
embracing
him
,
in
my
fancy
,
as
his
son
-
in
-
law
!
 
<EOS>
Little
<EOS>
did
he
think
,
<EOS>
when
I
took
leave
of
him
at
night
,
that
he
had
just
given
his
full
consent
to
my
being
engaged
to
Dora
,
and
that
I
was
invoking
blessings
on
his
head
!
   
<EOS>
We
departed
early
in
the
morning
,
for
we
had
a
Salvage
case
coming
on
in
the
Admiralty
Court
,
requiring
a
rather
accurate
knowledge
of
the
whole
science
of
navigation
,
in
which
(
as
we
could
n't
be
expected
to
know
much
about
those
matters
in
the
Commons
)
<EOS>
the
judge
had
entreated
two
old
Trinity
Masters
,
for
charity
's
sake
,
to
come
and
help

out
.
 
<EOS>
Dora
was
at
the
breakfast
-
table
to
make
the
tea
again
,
however
;
and
I
had
the
melancholy

of
taking
off
my
hat
to
her
in
the
phaeton
,
as
she
stood
on
the
door

with
Jip
in

.
   
<EOS>
What
the
Admiralty
was
to
me
that
day
;
what
nonsense
I
made
of
our
case
in
my
mind
,
as
I
listened
to
it
;
how
I
saw
"
DORA
"
engraved
upon
the
blade
of
the
silver
oar
which
they
lay
upon
the
table
,
as
the
emblem
of
that
high
jurisdiction
;
and
how
I
felt
when
Mr
Spenlow
went
home
without
me
<EOS>
(
I
had
had
an
insane
hope
that
he
might
take
me
back
again
)
,
as
if
I
were
a
mariner
myself
,
and
the
ship
to
which
I
belonged
had
sailed
away
and
left
me
on
a
desert
island
;
I
shall
make
no
fruitless
effort
to
describe
.
 
<EOS>
If
that
sleepy
old
court
could
rouse
itself
,
and
present
in
any
visible
form
the
daydreams
I
have
had
in
it
about
Dora
,
it
would
reveal
my
truth
.
   
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mean
the
dreams
that
I
dreamed
on
that
day
alone
,
but
day
after
day
,
from
week
to
week
,
and
term
to
term
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
there
,
not
to
attend
to
what
was
going
on
,
but
to
think
about
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
If
ever
I
bestowed
a
thought
upon
the
cases
,
as
they
dragged
their
slow
length
before
me
,
it
was
only
to
wonder
,
in
the
matrimonial
cases
(
remembering
Dora
)
,
how
it
was
that
married
people
could
ever
be
otherwise
than
happy
;
and
,
in
the
Prerogative
cases
,
to
consider
,
if
the
money
in
question
had
been
left
to
me
,
what
were
the
foremost
steps
I
should
immediately
have
taken
in
regard
to
Dora
.
<EOS>
Within
the
first
week
of
my
passion
,
I
bought
four
sumptuous
waistcoats
---
not
for
myself
;
I
had
no
pride
in
them
;
for
Dora
---
and
took
to
wearing
straw
-
coloured
kid
gloves
in
the
streets
,
and
laid
the
foundations
of
all
the
corns
I
have
ever
had
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
boots
I
wore
at
that
period
could
only
be
produced
and
compared
with
the
natural
size
of
my
feet
,
they
would
show
what
the
state
of
my
heart
was
,
in
a
most
affecting
manner
.
   
<EOS>
And
yet
,
wretched
cripple
as
I
made
myself
by
this
act
of
homage
to
Dora
<EOS>
,
I
walked
miles
upon
miles
daily
in
the
hope
of
seeing
her
.
<EOS>
Not
only
was
I
soon
as
well
known
on
the
Norwood
Road
as
the
postmen
on
that
beat
,
but
I
pervaded
London
likewise
.
 
<EOS>
I
walked
about
the
streets
where
the
best
shops
for
ladies
were
,
I
haunted
the
Bazaar
like
an
unquiet
spirit
,
I
fagged
through
the
Park
again
and
again
,
long
after
I
was
quite
knocked
up
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
at
long
intervals
and
on
rare
occasions
,
I
saw
her
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
saw
her
glove
waved
in
a
carriage
window
;
perhaps
I
met
her
,
walked
with
her
and
Miss
Murdstone
a
little
way
,
and
spoke
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
latter
case
I
was
always
very
miserable
afterwards
,
to
think
that
I
had
said
nothing
to
the
purpose
;
or
that
she
had
no
idea
of
the
extent
of
my
devotion
,
or
that
she
cared
nothing
about
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
always
looking
out
,
as
may
be
supposed
,
for
another
invitation
to
Mr
Spenlow
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
always
being
disappointed
,
for
I
got
none
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Crupp
must
have
been
a
woman
of
penetration
;
for
when
this
attachment
was
but
a
few
weeks
old
,
and
I
had
not

the

to
write
more
explicitly
even
to
Agnes
,
than
that
I
had
been
to
Mr
Spenlow
's
house
,
"
whose
family
,
"
I
added
,
"
consists
of
one
daughter
"
;
---
I
say
Mrs
Crupp
must
have
been
a
woman
of
penetration
,
for
,
even
in
that
early
stage
,
she
found
it
out
.
 
<EOS>
She
came
up
to
me
one
evening
,
when
I
was
very
low
,
to
ask
(
she
being
then
afflicted
with
the
disorder
I
have
mentioned
)
if
I
could
oblige
her
with
a
little
tincture
of
cardamums
mixed
with
rhubarb
,
and
flavoured
with
seven
drops
of
the
essence
of
cloves
,
which
was
the
best
remedy
for
her

;
---
or
,
if
I
had
not
such
a
thing
by
me
,
with
a
little
brandy
,
which
was
the
next
best
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
<EOS>
,
she
remarked
,
so
palatable
to
her
,
but
it
was
the
next
best
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
had
never
even
heard
of
the
first
remedy
,
and
always
had
the
second
in
the
closet
,
I
gave
Mrs
Crupp
a
glass
of
the
second
,
which
(
that
I
might
have
no
suspicion
of
its
being
devoted
to
any
improper
use
)
<EOS>
she
began
to
take
in
my

.
   
<EOS>
"
Cheer
up
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Crupp
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
abear
to
see
you
<EOS>
so
,
sir
:
I
'm
a
mother
myself
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
did
not
quite
perceive
the
application
of
this

to
myself
,
but
I
smiled
on
Mrs
Crupp
,
as
benignly
as
was
in
my

.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Crupp
.
 
<EOS>
"
Excuse

.
 
<EOS>
I
know
what
it
is
,
sir
.
<EOS>
There
's
a
lady
in
the
case
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Crupp
?
<EOS>
"
I
returned
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
bless
you
!
 
<EOS>
Keep
a
good
heart
,
sir
!
"
said
Mrs
Crupp
,
nodding

.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
say
die
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
If
She
do
n't
smile
upon
you
,
there
's
a
many
as
will
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
a
young
gentleman
to
be
smiled
on
,
Mr
Copperfull
,
and
you
must
learn
your
walue
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Crupp
always
called
me
Mr
Copperfull
:
firstly
,
no
doubt
,
because
it
was
not
my
name
;
and
secondly
,
I
am
inclined
to
think
,
in
some

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
makes
you
suppose
there
is
any
young

case
,
Mrs
Crupp
?
"
said

<EOS>
"
Mr
Copperfull
,
"
said
Mrs
Crupp
,
with
a
great
deal
of
feeling
,
"
I
'm
a
mother
myself
.
"
   
<EOS>
For
some
time
Mrs
Crupp
could
only
lay
her
hand
upon
her
nankeen
bosom
,
and
fortify
herself
against
returning
pain
with
sips
of
her

.
 
<EOS>
At
length
she
spoke
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
the
present
set
were
took
for
you
by
your
dear
aunt
,
Mr
Copperfull
,
"
said
Mrs
Crupp
,
"
my
remark
were
,
I
had
now
found
summun
I
could
care
for
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
Ev'in
!
"
were
the
expression
,
"
I
have
now
found
summun
I
can
care
for
!
"
<EOS>
---
You
do
n't
eat
enough
,
sir
,
nor
yet
drink
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
what
you
found
your
supposition
on
,
Mrs
Crupp
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Crupp
,
in
a
tone
approaching
to
severity
,
"
I
've
laundressed
other
young
gentlemen
besides
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
A
young
gentleman
may
be
over
-
careful
of
himself
,
or
he
may
be
under
-
careful
of
himself
.
 
<EOS>
He
may
brush
his
hair
too
regular
,
or
too
un
-
regular
.
 
<EOS>
He
may
wear
his
boots
much
too
large
for
him
,
or
much
too
small
.
 
<EOS>
That
is
according
as
the
young
gentleman
has
his
original
character
formed
.
 
<EOS>
But
let
him
go
to
which
extreme
<EOS>
he
may
,
sir
,
there
's
a
young
lady
in
both
of
'
em
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Crupp
shook
her
head
in
such
a
determined
manner
,
that
I
had
not
an
inch
of
vantage
-
ground
left
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
but
the
gentleman
which
died
here
before
yourself
,
"
said
Mrs
Crupp
,
"
that
fell
in
love
---
with
a
barmaid
---
and
had
his
waistcoats
took
in
directly
,
though
much
swelled
by
drinking
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Crupp
,
"
said
I
,
"
I
must
beg
you
not
to
connect
the
young
lady
in
my
case
with
a
barmaid
,
or
anything
of
that
sort
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Copperfull
,
"
returned
Mrs
Crupp
,
"
I
'm
a
mother
myself
,
and
not
likely
.
 
<EOS>
I
ask
your
pardon
,
sir
,
if
I
intrude
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
never
wish
to
intrude
where
I
were
not
welcome
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
are
a
young
gentleman
,
Mr
Copperfull
,
and
my
adwice
to
you
<EOS>
is
,
to
cheer
up
,
sir
,
to
keep
a
good
heart
,
and
to
know
your
own
walue
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
was
to
take
to
something
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Crupp
,
"
if
you
was
to
take
to
skittles
,
now
,
which
is
healthy
,
you
might
find
it
divert
your
mind
,
and
do
you
good
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
Mrs
Crupp
,
affecting
to
be
very
careful
of
the
brandy
---
which
was
all
gone
---
thanked
me
with
a
majestic
curtsey
,
and
retired
.
 
<EOS>
As
her
figure
disappeared
into
the
gloom
of
the
entry
,
this
counsel
certainly
presented
itself
to
my
mind
in
the
light
of
a
slight
liberty
on
Mrs
Crupp
's
part
;
but
,
at
the
same
time
,
I
was
content
to
receive
it
,
in
another
point
of
view
,
as
a
word
to
the
wise
,
and
a
warning
in
future
to
keep
my
secret
better
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
27
.
<EOS>
Tommy
Traddles
 
<EOS>
It
may
have
been
in
consequence
of
Mrs
Crupp
's
advice
,
and
,
perhaps
,
for
no
better
reason
than
because
there
was
a
certain
similarity
in
the
sound
of
the
word
skittles
and
Traddles
,
that
it
came
into
my
head
,
next
day
,
to
go
and
look
after
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
The
time
he
had
mentioned
was
more
than
out
,
and
he
lived
in
a
little
street
near
the
Veterinary
College
at
Camden
Town
,
which
was
principally
tenanted
,
as
one
of
our
clerks
who
lived
in
that
direction
informed
me
,
by
gentlemen
students
,
who
bought
live
donkeys
,
and
made
experiments
on
those
quadrupeds
in
their
private
apartments
.
 
<EOS>
Having
obtained
from
this
clerk
a
direction
to
the
academic
grove
in
question
,
I
set
out
,
the
same
afternoon
,
to
visit
my
old
schoolfellow
.
   
<EOS>
I
found
that
the
street
was
not
as
desirable
a
one
as
I
could
have
wished
it
to
be
,
for
the
sake
of
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
The
inhabitants
appeared
to
have
a
propensity
to
throw
any
little
trifles
they
were
not
in
want
of
,
into
the
road
:
which
not
only
made
it
rank
and
sloppy
,
but
untidy
too
,
on
account
of
the
cabbage
-
leaves
.
 
<EOS>
The
refuse
was
not
wholly
vegetable
either
,
for
I
myself
saw
a
shoe
,
a
doubled
-
up
saucepan
,
a
black
bonnet
,
and
an
umbrella
,
in
various
stages
of
decomposition
,
as
I
was
looking
out
for
the
number
I
wanted
.
   
<EOS>
The
general
air
of
the
place
reminded
me
forcibly
of
the
days
when
I
lived
with
Mr
and
Mrs
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
An
indescribable
character
of
faded
gentility
that
attached
to
the
house
I
sought
,
and
made
it
unlike
all
the
other
houses
in
the
street
---
though
they
were
all
built
on
one
monotonous
pattern
,
and
looked
like
the
early
copies
of
a
blundering
boy
who
was
learning
to
make
houses
,
and
had
not
yet
got
out
of
his
cramped
brick
-
and
-
mortar
pothooks
---
reminded
me
still
more
of
Mr
and
Mrs
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
Happening
to
arrive
at
the
door
as
it
was
opened
to
the
afternoon
milkman
,
I
was
reminded
of
Mr
and
Mrs
Micawber
more
forcibly
yet
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
the
milkman
to
a
very
youthful
servant
girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
Has
that
there
little
bill
of
mine
been
heerd
on
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
master
says
he
'll
attend
to
it
immediate
,
"
was
the
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
Because
,
"
said
the
milkman
,
going
on
as
if
he
had
received
no
answer
,
and
speaking
,
as
I
judged
from
his
tone
,
rather
for
the
edification
of
somebody
within
the
house
,
than
of
the
youthful
servant
---
an
impression
which
was
strengthened
by
his
manner
of
glaring
down
the
passage
---
"
because
that
there
little
bill
has
been
running
so
long
,
that
I
begin
to
believe
it
's
run
away
altogether
,
and
never
wo
n't
be
heerd
of
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
I
'm
not
a
going
to
stand
it
,
you
know
!
"
said
the
milkman
,
still
throwing
his
voice
into
the
house
,
and
glaring
down
the
passage
.
   
<EOS>
As
to
his
dealing
in
the
mild
article
of
milk
,
by
the
by
,
there
never
was
a
greater
anomaly
.
 
<EOS>
His
deportment
would
have
been
fierce
in
a
butcher
or
a
brandy
-
merchant
.
   
<EOS>
The
voice
of
the
youthful
servant
became
faint
,
but
she
seemed
to
me
,
from
the
action
of
her
lips
,
again
to
murmur
that
it
would
be
attended
to
immediate
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
what
,
"
said
the
milkman
,
looking
hard
at
her
for
the
first
time
,
and
taking
her
by
the
chin
,
"
are
you
fond
of
milk
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
likes
it
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
,
"
said
the
milkman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
you
wo
n't
have
none
tomorrow
.
<EOS>
D'ye
hear
?
 
<EOS>
Not
a
fragment
of
milk
<EOS>
you
wo
n't
have
tomorrow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
thought
she
seemed
,
upon
the
whole
,
relieved
by
the
prospect
of
having
any
today
.
 
<EOS>
The
milkman
,
after
shaking
his
head
at
her
darkly
,
released
her
chin
,
and
with
anything
rather
than
good
-
will
opened
his
can
,
and
deposited
the
usual
quantity
in
the
family
jug
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
he
went
away
,
muttering
,
and
uttered
the
cry
of
his
trade
next
door
,
in
a
vindictive
shriek
.
   
<EOS>
"
Does
Mr
Traddles
live
here
?
<EOS>
"
I
then
inquired
.
   
<EOS>
A
mysterious
voice
from
the
end
of
the
passage
replied
"
Yes
.
"
 
<EOS>
Upon
which
the
youthful
servant
replied
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
he
at
home
?
"
said
I.
   
Again
the
mysterious
voice
replied
in
the
affirmative
,
and
again
the
servant
echoed
it
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
I
walked
in
,
and
in
pursuance
of
the
servant
's
directions
walked
upstairs
;
conscious
,
as
I
passed
the
back
parlour
-
door
,
that
I
was
surveyed
by
a
mysterious
eye
,
probably
belonging
to
the
mysterious
voice
.
   
<EOS>
When
I
got
to
the
top
of
the
stairs
---
the
house
was
only
a
story
high
above
the
ground
floor
---
Traddles
was
on
the
landing
to
meet
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
delighted
to
see
me
,
and
gave
me
welcome
,
with
great
heartiness
,
to
his
little
room
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
the
front
of
the
house
,
and
extremely
neat
,
though
sparely
furnished
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
his
only
room
<EOS>
,
I
saw
;
for
there
was
a
sofa
-
bedstead
in
it
,
and
his
blacking
-
brushes
and
blacking
were
among
his
books
---
on
the
top
shelf
,
behind
a
dictionary
.
 
<EOS>
His
table
was
covered
with
papers
,
and
he
was
hard
at
work
in
an
old
coat
.
 
<EOS>
I
looked
at
nothing
,
<EOS>
that
I
know
of
,
but
I
saw
everything
,
even
to
the
prospect
of
a
church
upon
his
china
inkstand
,
as
I
sat
down
---
and
this
,
too
,
was
a
faculty
confirmed
in
me
in
the
old
Micawber
times
.
 
<EOS>
Various
ingenious
arrangements
he
had
made
,
for
the
disguise
of
his
chest
of
drawers
,
and
the
accommodation
of
his
boots
,
his
shaving
-
glass
,
and
so
forth
,
particularly
impressed
themselves
upon
me
,
as
evidences
of
the
same
Traddles
who
used
to
make
models
of
elephants
'
dens
in
writing
-
paper
to
put
flies
in
;
and
to
comfort
himself
under
ill
usage
,
with
the
memorable
works
of
art
I
have
so
often
mentioned
.
   
<EOS>
In
a
corner
of
the
room
was
something
neatly
covered
up
with
a
large
white
cloth
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
make
out
what
that
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
Traddles
,
"
said
I
,
shaking
hands
with
him
again
,
after
I
had
sat
down
,
"
I
am
delighted
to
see
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
delighted
to
see
YOU
,
Copperfield
,
"
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
glad
indeed
to
see
you
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
because
I
was
thoroughly
glad
to
see
you
when
we
met
in
Ely
Place
,
and
was
sure
you
were
thoroughly
glad
to
see
me
,
that
I
gave
you
this
address
instead
of
my
address
at
chambers
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
You
have
chambers
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
have
the
fourth
of
a
room
and
a
passage
,
and
the
fourth
of
a
clerk
,
"
returned
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Three
others
and
myself
unite
to
have
a
set
of
chambers
---
to
look
business
-
like
---
and
we
quarter
the
clerk
too
.
 
<EOS>
Half
-
a
-
crown
a
week
he
costs
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
old
simple
character
and
good
temper
,
and
something
of
his
old
unlucky
fortune
also
<EOS>
,
I
thought
,
smiled
at
me
in
the
smile
with
which
he
made
this
explanation
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
because
I
have
the
least
pride
<EOS>
,
Copperfield
,
you
understand
,
"
said
Traddles
,
"
that
I
do
n't
usually
give
my
address
here
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
only
on
account
of
those
who
come
to
me
,
who
might
not
like
to
come
here
.
 
<EOS>
For
myself
,
I
am
fighting
my
way
on
in
the
world
against
difficulties
,
and
it
would
be
ridiculous
if
I
made
a
pretence
of
doing
anything
else
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
reading
for
the
bar
,
Mr
Waterbrook
informed
me
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
yes
,
"
said
Traddles
,
rubbing
his
hands
slowly
over
one
another
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
reading
for
the
bar
.
 
<EOS>
The
fact
is
,
I
have
just
begun
to
keep
my
terms
,
after
rather
a
long

.
 
<EOS>
It
's
some
time
since
I
was
articled
,
but
the
payment
of
that
hundred
pounds
was
a
great
pull
.
 
<EOS>
A
great
pull
!
<EOS>
"
said
Traddles
,
with
a

,
as
if
he
had
had
a
tooth
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
know
what
I
ca
n't
help
thinking
of
,
Traddles
,
as
I
sit
here
looking

?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
he
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
sky
-
blue
suit
you
used
to
wear
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
,
to
be
sure
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Traddles
,
laughing
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tight
in
the
arms
and
legs
,
you
know
?
 
<EOS>
Dear
me
!
 
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
Those
were
happy
times
,
were

they
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
our

might
have
made

happier
,
without
doing
any

to
any
of
us
<EOS>
,
I
acknowledge
,
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
he
might
,
"
said
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
dear
me
,
there
was
a
good
deal
of
fun
going
on
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
remember
the
nights
in
the
bedroom
?
<EOS>
When
we
used
to
have
the
suppers
?
 
<EOS>
And
when

used

tell
the

?
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
And
do
you
remember
when
I
got
caned
for

Mr
Mell
?
 
<EOS>
Old
Creakle
!
 
<EOS>
I
should
like

again
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
was
a

,

,
"
said

,
indignantly
;
for
his

me

as

had
seen

beaten
but
yesterday
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think

?
"
returned
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Really
?
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
was
rather
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
's
all
over
,
a
long

.
 
<EOS>
Old
Creakle
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
were
brought
up
by
an
uncle
,
then
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
was
!
"
said
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
one
I
was
always
going
to
write
to
.
 
<EOS>
And
always
did
n't
,
eh
!
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
had
an

then
.
 
<EOS>
He
died
soon
after
I
left
school
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Indeed
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
retired
---
what
do

call

!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
draper
---
cloth
-

---
and
had

me
his
heir
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
did

like
me
when
I
grew
up
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
really
mean
