?
"
said
<EOS>
I.
 
He
was
so
composed
,
that
I
fancied
he
must
have
some
other
meaning
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
dear
,
yes
,
Copperfield
!
 
<EOS>
I
mean
it
,
"
replied
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
an
unfortunate
thing
,
but
he
did
n't
like
me
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
I
was
n't
at
all
what
he
expected
,
and
so
he
married
his
housekeeper
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
did
you
do
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
do
anything
in
particular
,
"
said
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
lived
with
them
,
waiting
to
be
put
out
in
the
world
,
until
his
gout
unfortunately
flew
to
his
stomach
---
and
so
he
died
,
and
so
she
married
a
young
man
,
and
<EOS>
so
I
was
n't
provided
for
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
get
nothing
,
Traddles
,
after
all
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
,
yes
!
"
said
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
got
fifty
pounds
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
never
been
brought
up
to
any
profession
,
and
at
first
I
was
at
a
loss
what
to
do
for
myself
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
I
began
,
with
the
assistance
of
the
son
of
a
professional
man
,
who
had
been
to
Salem
House
---
Yawler
,
with
his
nose
on
one
side
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
recollect
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
not
been
there
with
me
;
all
the
noses
were
straight
in
my
day
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
do
n't
matter
,
"
said
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
began
,
by
means
of
his
assistance
,
to
copy
law
writings
.
 
<EOS>
That
did
n't
answer
very
well
;
and
then
I
began
to
state
cases
for
them
,
and
make
abstracts
,
and
that
sort
of
work
.
 
<EOS>
For
I
am
a
plodding
kind
of
fellow
,
Copperfield
,
and
had
learnt
the
way
of
doing
such
things
pithily
.
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
That
put
it
in
my
head
to
enter
myself
as
a
law
student
;
and
that
ran
away
with
all
that
was
left
of
the
fifty
pounds
.
 
<EOS>
Yawler
recommended
me
to
one
or
two
other
offices
,
however
---
<EOS>
Mr
Waterbrook
's
for
one
---
and
I
got
a
good
many
jobs
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
fortunate
enough
,
too
,
to
become
acquainted
with
a
person
in
the
publishing
way
,
who
was
getting
up
an
Encyclopaedia
,
and
he
set
me
to
work
;
and
,
indeed
"
(
glancing
at
his
table
)
<EOS>
,
"
I
am
at
work
for
him
at
this
minute
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
a
bad
compiler
,
Copperfield
,
"
said
Traddles
,
preserving
the
same
air
of
cheerful
confidence
in
all
he
said
,
"
but
I
have
no
invention
at
all
;
not
a
particle
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
there
never
was
a
young
man
with
less
originality
than
I
have
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Traddles
seemed
to
expect
that
I
should
assent
to
this
as
a
matter
of
course
,
I
nodded
;
and
he
went
on
,
with
the
same
sprightly
patience
---
I
can
find
no
better
expression
---
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
,
by
little
and
little
,
and
not
living
high
,
I
managed
to
scrape
up
the
hundred
pounds
at
last
,
"
said
Traddles
;
"
and
thank
Heaven
that
's
paid
---
though
it
was
---
though
it
certainly
was
,
"
said
Traddles
,
wincing
again
as
if
he
had
had
another
tooth
out
,
"
a
pull
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
living
by
the
sort
of
work
I
have
mentioned
,
still
,
and
I
hope
,
one
of
these
days
,
to
get
connected
with
some
newspaper
:
which
would
almost
be
the
making
of
my
fortune
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
Copperfield
,
you
are
so
exactly
what
you
used
to
be
,
with
that
agreeable
face
,
and
it
's
so
pleasant
to
see
you
,
that
I
sha'n't
conceal
anything
.
<EOS>
Therefore
you
must
know
that
I
am
engaged
.
<EOS>
"
   
Engaged
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
Dora
!
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
a
curate
's
daughter
,
"
said
Traddles
;
"
one
of
ten
,
down
in
Devonshire
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
!
"
<EOS>
For
he
saw
me
glance
,
involuntarily
,
at
the
prospect
on
the
inkstand
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
church
!
 
<EOS>
You
come
round
here
to
the
left
,
out
of
this
gate
,
"
tracing
his
finger
along
the
inkstand
,
"
and
exactly
where
I
hold
this
pen
<EOS>
,
there
stands
the
house
---
facing
,
you
understand
,
towards
the
church
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
delight
with
which
he
entered
into
these
particulars
,
did
not
fully
present
itself
to
me
until
afterwards
;
for
my
selfish
thoughts
were
making
a
ground
-
plan
of
Mr
Spenlow
's
house
and
garden
at
the
same
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
such
a
dear
girl
!
"
<EOS>
said
Traddles
;
"
a
little
older
than
me
,
but
the
dearest
girl
!
 
<EOS>
I
told
you
I
was
going
out
of
town
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
down
there
.
 
<EOS>
I
walked
there
,
and
I
walked
back
,
and
I
had
the
most
delightful
time
!
 
<EOS>
I
dare
<EOS>
say
ours
is
likely
to
be
a
rather
long
engagement
,
but
our
motto
is
"
Wait
and
hope
!
<EOS>
"
We
always
say
that
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wait
and
hope
<EOS>
,
"
we
always
say
.
 
<EOS>
And
she
would
wait
,
Copperfield
,
till
she
was
sixty
---
any
age
you
can
mention
---
for
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
Traddles
rose
from
his
chair
,
and
,
with
a
triumphant
smile
,
put
his
hand
upon
the
white
cloth
I
had
observed
.
   
<EOS>
"
However
,
"
he
said
,
"
it
's
not
that
we
have
n't
made
a
beginning
towards
housekeeping
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
;
we
have
begun
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
get
on
by
degrees
,
but
we
have
begun
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
"
drawing
the
cloth
off
with
great
pride
and
care
,
"
are
two
pieces
of
furniture
to
commence
with
.
 
<EOS>
This
flower
-
pot
and
stand
<EOS>
,
she
bought
herself
.
 
<EOS>
You
put
that
in
a
parlour
window
,
"
said
Traddles
,
falling
a
little
back
from
it
to
survey
it
with
the
greater
admiration
,
"
with
a
plant
in
it
,
and
<EOS>
---
and
there
you
are
!
 
<EOS>
This
little
round
table
with
the
marble
top
<EOS>
(
it
's
two
feet
ten
in
circumference
)
,
I
bought
.
 
<EOS>
You
want
to
lay
a
book
down
,
you
know
,
or
somebody
comes
to
see
you
or
your
wife
,
and
wants
a
place
to
stand
a
cup
of
tea
upon
,
and
---
and
there
you
are
again
!
"
<EOS>
said
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
an
admirable
piece
of
workmanship
---
firm
as
a
rock
!
<EOS>
"
I
praised
them
both
,
highly
,
and
Traddles
replaced
the
covering
as
carefully
as
he
had
removed
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
a
great
deal
towards
the
furnishing
,
"
said
Traddles
,
"
but
it
's
something
.
 
<EOS>
The
table
-
cloths
,
and
pillow
-
cases
,
and
articles
of
that
kind
,
are
what
discourage
me
most
,
Copperfield
.
 
<EOS>
So
does
the
ironmongery
---
candle
-
boxes
,
and
gridirons
,
and
that
sort
of
necessaries
---
because
those
things
tell
,
and
mount
up
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
"
wait
and
hope
!
"
<EOS>
And
I
assure
you
she
's
the
dearest
girl
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
certain
of
it
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
meantime
,
"
said
Traddles
,
coming
back
to
his
chair
;
"
and
this
is
the
end
of
my
prosing
about
myself
,
I
get
on
as
well
as
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
make
much
,
but
I
do
n't
spend
much
.
 
<EOS>
In
general
,
I
board
with
the
people
downstairs
,
who
are
very
agreeable
people
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
Both
Mr
and
Mrs
Micawber
have
seen
a
good
deal
of
life
,
and
are
excellent
company
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Traddles
!
<EOS>
"
I
quickly
exclaimed
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
talking
about
?
"
   
<EOS>
Traddles
looked
at
me
,
as
if
he
wondered
what
I
was
talking
about
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
and
Mrs
Micawber
!
"
I
repeated
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
am
intimately
acquainted
with
them
!
"
   
<EOS>
An
opportune
double
knock
at
the
door
,
which
I
knew
well
from
old
experience
in
Windsor
Terrace
,
and
which
nobody
but
Mr
Micawber
could
ever
have
knocked
at
that
door
,
resolved
any
doubt
in
my
mind
as
to
their
being
my
old
friends
.
 
<EOS>
I
begged
Traddles
to
ask
his
landlord
to
walk
up
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
accordingly
did
so
,
over
the
banister
;
and
Mr
Micawber
,
not
a
bit
changed
---
his
tights
,
his
stick
,
his
shirt
-
collar
,
and
his
eye
-
glass
,
all
the
same
as
ever
---
came
into
the
room
with
a
genteel
and
youthful
air
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Mr
Traddles
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
with
the
old
roll
in
his
voice
,
as
he
checked
himself
in
humming
a
soft
tune
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
aware
that
there
was
any
individual
,
alien
to
this
tenement
,
in
your
sanctum
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
slightly
bowed
to
me
,
and
pulled
up
his
shirt
-
collar
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
,
Mr
Micawber
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
you
are
exceedingly
obliging
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
in
statu
quo
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
And
Mrs
Micawber
?
<EOS>
"
I
pursued
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
she
is
also
,
thank
God
,
in
statu
quo
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
And
the
children
,
Mr
Micawber
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
I
rejoice
to
reply
that
they
are
,
likewise
,
in
the
enjoyment
of
salubrity
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
Mr
Micawber
had
not
known
me
in
the
least
,
though
he
had
stood
face
to
face
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
now
,
seeing
me
smile
,
he
examined
my
features
with
more
attention
,
fell
back
,
cried
,
"
Is
it
possible
!
 
<EOS>
Have
I
the
pleasure
of
again
beholding
Copperfield
!
"
and
shook
me
by
both
hands
with
the
utmost
fervour
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
Heaven
,
Mr
Traddles
!
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
to
think
that
I
should
find
you
acquainted
with
the
friend
of
my
youth
,
the
companion
of
earlier
days
!
 
<EOS>
My
dear
!
"
<EOS>
calling
over
the
banisters
to
Mrs
Micawber
,
while
Traddles
looked
(
with
reason
)
not
a
little
amazed
at
this
description
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
is
a
gentleman
in
Mr
Traddles
's
apartment
,
whom
he
wishes
to
have
the
pleasure
of
presenting
to
you
,
my
love
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
immediately
reappeared
,
and
shook
hands
with
me
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
how
is
our
good
friend
the
Doctor
,
Copperfield
?
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
and
all
the
circle
at
Canterbury
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
none
but
good
accounts
of
them
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
most
delighted
to
hear
it
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
at
Canterbury
where
we
last
met
.
 
<EOS>
Within
the
shadow
,
I
may
figuratively
say
,
of
that
religious
edifice
immortalized
by
Chaucer
,
which
was
anciently
the
resort
of
Pilgrims
from
the
remotest
corners
of
---
in
short
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
in
the
immediate
neighbourhood
of
the
Cathedral
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
replied
that
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
continued
talking
as
volubly
as
he
could
;
but
not
,
I
thought
,
without
showing
,
by
some
marks
of
concern
in
his
countenance
,
that
he
was
sensible
of
sounds
in
the
next
room
,
as
of
Mrs
Micawber
washing
her
hands
,
and
hurriedly
opening
and
shutting
drawers
that
were
uneasy
in
their
action
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
find
us
,
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
with
one
eye
on
Traddles
,
"
at
present
established
,
on
what
may
be
designated
as
a
small
and
unassuming
scale
;
but
,
you
are
aware
that
I
have
,
in
the
course
of
my
career
,
surmounted
difficulties
,
and
conquered
obstacles
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
no
stranger
to
the
fact
<EOS>
,
that
there
have
been
periods
of
my
life
,
when
it
has
been
requisite
that
I
should
pause
,
until
certain
expected
events
should
turn
up
;
when
it
has
been
necessary
that
I
should
fall
back
,
before
making
what
I
trust
I
shall
not
be
accused
of
presumption
in
terming
---
a
spring
.
 
<EOS>
The
present
is
one
of
those
momentous
stages
in
the
life
of
man
.
 
<EOS>
You
find
me
,
fallen
back
,
FOR
a
spring
;
and
I
have
every
reason
to
believe
that
a
vigorous
leap
will
shortly
be
the
result
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
expressing
my
satisfaction
,
when
Mrs
Micawber
came
in
;
a
little
more
slatternly
than
she
used
to
be
,
or
so
she
seemed
now
,
to
my
unaccustomed
eyes
,
but
still
with
some
preparation
of
herself
for
company
,
and
with
a
pair
of
brown
gloves
on
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
leading
her
towards
me
,
"
here
is
a
gentleman
of
the
name
of
Copperfield
,
who
wishes
to
renew
his
acquaintance
with
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
better
,
as
it
turned
out
,
to
have
led
gently
up
to
this
announcement
,
for
Mrs
Micawber
,
being
in
a
delicate
state
of
health
,
was
overcome
by
it
,
and
was
taken
so
unwell
,
that
Mr
Micawber
was
obliged
,
in
great
trepidation
,
to
run
down
to
the
water
-
butt
in
the
backyard
,
and
draw
a
basinful
to
lave
her
brow
with
.
 
<EOS>
She
presently
revived
,
however
,
and
was
really
pleased
to
see
me
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
half
-
an
-
hour
's
talk
,
all
together
;
and
I
asked
her
about
the
twins
,
who
,
she
said
,
were
"
grown
great
creatures
"
;
and
after
Master
and
Miss
Micawber
,
whom
she
described
as
"
absolute
giants
"
,
but
they
were
not
produced
on
that
occasion
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
was
very
anxious
that
I
should
stay
to
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
not
have
been
averse
to
do
so
,
but
that
I
imagined
I
detected
trouble
,
and
calculation
relative
to
the
extent
of
the
cold
meat
,
in
Mrs
Micawber
's
eye
.
 
<EOS>
I
therefore
pleaded
another
engagement
;
and
observing
that
Mrs
Micawber
's
spirits
were
immediately
lightened
,
I
resisted
all
persuasion
to
forego
it
.
   
<EOS>
But
I
told
Traddles
,
and
Mr
and
Mrs
Micawber
,
that
before
I
could
think
of
leaving
,
they
must
appoint
a
day
when
they
would
come
and
dine
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
occupations
to
which
Traddles
stood
pledged
,
rendered
it
necessary
to
fix
a
somewhat
distant
one
;
but
an
appointment
was
made
for
the
purpose
,
that
suited
us
all
,
and
then
I
took
my
leave
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
,
under
pretence
of
showing
me
a
nearer
way
than
that
by
which
I
had
come
,
accompanied
me
to
the
corner
of
the
street
;
being
anxious
(
he
explained
to
me
)
to
say
a
few
words
to
an
old
friend
,
in
confidence
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
I
need
hardly
tell
you
that
to
have
beneath
our
roof
,
under
existing
circumstances
,
a
mind
like
that
which
gleams
---
<EOS>
if
I
may
be
allowed
the
expression
---
which
gleams
---
in
your
friend
Traddles
,
is
an
unspeakable
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
With
a
washerwoman
,
who
exposes
hard
-
bake
for
sale
in
her
parlour
-
window
,
dwelling
next
door
,
and
a
Bow
-
street
officer
residing
over
the
way
,
you
may
imagine
that
his
society
is
a
source
of
consolation
to
myself
and
to
Mrs
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
at
present
,
<EOS>
my
dear
Copperfield
,
engaged
in
the
sale
of
corn
upon
commission
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
an
avocation
of
a
remunerative
description
---
in
other
words
,
it
does
not
pay
---
and
some
temporary
embarrassments
of
a
pecuniary
nature
have
been
the
consequence
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
,
however
,
delighted
to
add
that
I
have
now
an
immediate
prospect
of
something
turning
up
<EOS>
(
I
am
not
at
liberty
to
say
in
what
direction
)
,
which
I
trust
will
enable
me
to
provide
,
permanently
,
both
for
myself
and
for
your
friend
Traddles
,
in
whom
I
have
an
unaffected
interest
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
,
perhaps
,
be
prepared
to
hear
that
Mrs
Micawber
is
in
a
state
of
health
which
renders
it
not
wholly
improbable
that
an
addition
may
be
ultimately
made
to
those
pledges
of
affection
which
---
in
short
,
to
the
infantine
group
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Micawber
's
family
have
been
so
good
as
to
express
their
dissatisfaction
at
this
state
of
things
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
merely
to
observe
,
that
I
am
not
aware
that
it
is
any
business
of
theirs
,
and
that
I
repel
that
exhibition
of
feeling
with
scorn
,
and
with
defiance
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
then
shook
hands
with
me
again
,
and
left
me
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
28
.
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
's
gauntlet
 
<EOS>
Until
the
day
arrived
on
which
I
was
to
entertain
my
newly
-
found
old
friends
,
I
lived
principally
on
Dora
and
coffee
.
 
<EOS>
In
my
love
-
lorn
condition
,
my
appetite
languished
;
and
I
was
glad
of
it
,
for
I
felt
as
though
it
would
have
been
an
act
of
perfidy
towards
Dora
to
have
a
natural
relish
for
my
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
The
quantity
of
walking
exercise
I
took
,
was
not
in
this
respect
attended
with
its
usual
consequence
,
as
the
disappointment
counteracted
the
fresh
air
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
my
doubts
,
too
,
founded
on
the
acute
experience
acquired
at
this
period
of
my
life
,
whether
a
sound
enjoyment
of
animal
food
can
develop
itself
freely
in
any
human
subject
who
is
always
in
torment
from
tight
boots
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
the
extremities
require
to
be
at
peace
before
the
stomach
will
conduct
itself
with
vigour
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
occasion
of
this
domestic
little
party
,
I
did
not
repeat
my
former
extensive
preparations
.
 
<EOS>
I
merely
provided
a
pair
of
soles
,
a
small
leg
of
mutton
,
and
a
pigeon
-
pie
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Crupp
broke
out
into
rebellion
on
my
first
bashful
hint
in
reference
to
the
cooking
of
the
fish
and
joint
,
and
said
,
with
a
dignified
sense
of
injury
,
"
No
!
 
<EOS>
No
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
You
will
not
ask
me
sich
a
thing
,
for
you
are
better
acquainted
with
me
than
to
suppose
me
capable
of
doing
what
I
can
not
do
with
ampial
satisfaction
to
my
own
feelings
!
"
<EOS>
But
,
in
the
end
,
a
compromise
was
effected
;
and
Mrs
Crupp
consented
to
achieve
this
feat
,
on
condition
that
I
dined
from
home
for
a
fortnight
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
And
here
I
may
remark
,
that
what
I
underwent
from
Mrs
Crupp
,
in
consequence
of
the
tyranny
she
established
over
me
,
was
dreadful
.
<EOS>
I
never
was
so
much
afraid
of
anyone
.
 
<EOS>
We
made
a
compromise
of
everything
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
hesitated
,
she
was
taken
with
that
wonderful
disorder
which
was
always
lying
in
ambush
in
her
system
,
ready
,
at
the
shortest
notice
,
to
prey
upon
her
vitals
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
rang
the
bell
impatiently
,
after
half
-
a
-
dozen
unavailing
modest
pulls
,
and
she
appeared
at
last
---
which
was
not
by
any
means
to
be
relied
upon
---
she
would
appear
with
a
reproachful
aspect
,
sink
breathless
on
a
chair
near
the
door
,
lay
her
hand
upon
her
nankeen
bosom
,
and
become
so
ill
,
that
I
was
glad
,
at
any
sacrifice
of
brandy
or
anything
else
,
to
get
rid
of
her
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
objected
to
having
my
bed
made
at
five
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
---
which
I
do
still
think
an
uncomfortable
arrangement
---
one
motion
of
her
hand
towards
the
same
nankeen
region
of
wounded
sensibility
was
enough
to
make
me
falter
an
apology
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
I
would
have
done
anything
in
an
honourable
way
rather
than
give
Mrs
Crupp
offence
;
and
she
was
the
terror
of
my
life
.
   
<EOS>
I
bought
a
second
-
hand
dumb
-
waiter
for
this
dinner
-
party
,
in
preference
to
re
-
engaging
the
handy
young
man
;
against
whom
I
had
conceived
a
prejudice
,
in
consequence
of
meeting
him
in
the
Strand
,
one
Sunday
morning
,
in
a
waistcoat
remarkably
like
one
of
mine
,
which
had
been
missing
since
the
former
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
The
"
young
gal
"
was
re
-
engaged
;
but
on
the
stipulation
that
she
should
only
bring
in
the
dishes
,
and
then
withdraw
to
the
landing
-
place
,
beyond
the
outer
door
;
where
a
habit
of
sniffing
she
had
contracted
would
be
lost
upon
the
guests
,
and
where
her
retiring
on
the
plates
would
be
a
physical
impossibility
.
   
<EOS>
Having
laid
in
the
materials
for
a
bowl
of
punch
,
to
be
compounded
by
Mr
Micawber
;
having
provided
a
bottle
of
lavender
-
water
,
two
wax
-
candles
,
a
paper
of
mixed
pins
,
and
a
pincushion
,
to
assist
Mrs
Micawber
in
her
toilette
at
my
dressing
-
table
;
having
also
caused
the
fire
in
my
bedroom
to
be
lighted
for
Mrs
Micawber
's
convenience
;
and
having
laid
the
cloth
with
my
own
hands
,
I
awaited
the
result
with
composure
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
appointed
time
,
my
three
visitors
arrived
together
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
with
more
shirt
-
collar
than
usual
,
and
a
new
ribbon
to
his
eye
-
glass
;
Mrs
Micawber
with
her
cap
in
a
whitey
-
brown
paper
parcel
;
Traddles
carrying
the
parcel
,
and
supporting
Mrs
Micawber
on
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
all
delighted
with
my
residence
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
conducted
Mrs
Micawber
to
my
dressing
-
table
,
and
she
saw
the
scale
on
which
it
was
prepared
for
her
,
she
was
in
such
raptures
,
that
she
called
Mr
Micawber
to
come
in
and
look
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
this
is
luxurious
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
a
way
of
life
which
reminds
me
of
the
period
when
I
was
myself
in
a
state
of
celibacy
,
and
Mrs
Micawber
had
not
yet
been
solicited
to
plight
her
faith
at
the
Hymeneal
altar
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
means
,
solicited
by
him
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
archly
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
can
not
answer
for
others
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
returned
Mr
Micawber
with
sudden
seriousness
,
"
I
have
no
desire
to
answer
for
others
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
too
well
aware
that
when
,
in
the
inscrutable
decrees
of
Fate
,
you
were
reserved
for
me
,
it
is
possible
you
may
have
been
reserved
for
one
,
<EOS>
destined
,
after
a
protracted
struggle
,
at
length
to
fall
a
victim
to
pecuniary
involvements
of
a
complicated
nature
.
 
<EOS>
I
understand
your
allusion
,
my
love
.
 
<EOS>
I
regret
it
,
but
I
can
bear
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Micawber
!
"
exclaimed
Mrs
Micawber
,
in
tears
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
I
deserved
this
!
 
<EOS>
I
,
who
never
have
deserted
you
;
who
never
WILL
desert
you
,
Micawber
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
love
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
much
affected
,
"
you
will
forgive
,
and
our
old
and
tried
friend
<EOS>
Copperfield
will
,
I
am
sure
,
forgive
,
the
momentary
laceration
of
a
wounded
spirit
,
made
sensitive
by
a
recent
collision
with
the
Minion
of
Power
---
in
other
words
,
with
a
ribald
Turncock
attached
to
the
water
-
works
---
and
will
pity
,
not
condemn
,
its
excesses
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
then
embraced
Mrs
Micawber
,
and
pressed
my
hand
;
leaving
me
to
infer
from
this
broken
allusion
that
his
domestic
supply
of
water
had
been
cut
off
that
afternoon
,
in
consequence
of
default
in
the
payment
of
the
company
's
rates
.
   
<EOS>
To
divert
his
thoughts
from
this
melancholy
subject
,
I
informed
Mr
Micawber
that
I
relied
upon
him
for
a
bowl
of
punch
,
and
led
him
to
the
lemons
.
 
<EOS>
His
recent
despondency
,
not
to
say
despair
,
was
gone
in
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
saw
a
man
so
thoroughly
enjoy
himself
amid
the
fragrance
of
lemon
-
peel
and
sugar
,
the
odour
of
burning
rum
,
and
the
steam
of
boiling
water
,
as
Mr
Micawber
did
that
afternoon
.
<EOS>
It
was
wonderful
to
see
his
face
shining
at
us
out
of
a
thin
cloud
of
these
delicate
fumes
,
as
he
stirred
,
and
mixed
,
and
tasted
,
and
looked
as
if
he
were
making
,
instead
of
punch
,
a
fortune
for
his
family
down
to
the
latest
posterity
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
Mrs
Micawber
,
I
do
n't
know
whether
it
was
the
effect
of
the
cap
,
or
the
lavender
-
water
,
or
the
pins
,
or
the
fire
,
or
the
wax
-
candles
,
but
she
came
out
of
my
room
,
comparatively
speaking
,
lovely
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
lark
was
never
gayer
than
that
excellent
woman
.
   
<EOS>
I
suppose
---
I
never
ventured
to
inquire
,
but
I
suppose
---
that
Mrs
Crupp
,
after
frying
the
soles
,
was
taken
ill
.
 
<EOS>
Because
we
broke
down
at
that
point
.
 
<EOS>
The
leg
of
mutton
came
up
very
red
within
,
and
very
pale
without
:
besides
having
a
foreign
substance
of
a
gritty
nature
sprinkled
over
it
,
as
if
if
had
had
a
fall
into
the
ashes
of
that
remarkable
kitchen
fireplace
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
were
not
in
condition
to
judge
of
this
fact
from
the
appearance
of
the
gravy
,
forasmuch
as
the
"
young
gal
"
<EOS>
had
dropped
it
all
upon
the
stairs
---
where
it
remained
,
by
the
by
,
in
a
long
train
,
until
it
was
worn
out
.
 
<EOS>
The
pigeon
-
pie
was
not
bad
,
but
it
was
a
delusive
pie
:
the
crust
being
like
a
disappointing
head
,
phrenologically
speaking
:
<EOS>
full
of
lumps
and
bumps
,
with
nothing
particular
underneath
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
the
banquet
was
such
a
failure
that
I
should
have
been
quite
unhappy
---
about
the
failure
,
I
mean
,
for
I
was
always
unhappy
about
Dora
---
if
I
had
not
been
relieved
by
the
great
good
humour
of
my
company
,
and
by
a
bright
suggestion
from
Mr
Micawber
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
friend
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
accidents
will
occur
in
the
best
-
regulated
families
;
and
in
families
not
regulated
by
that
pervading
influence
which
sanctifies
while
it
enhances
the
---
<EOS>
a
---
I
would
say
,
in
short
,
by
the
influence
of
Woman
,
in
the
lofty
character
of
Wife
<EOS>
,
they
may
be
expected
with
confidence
,
and
must
be
borne
with
philosophy
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
will
allow
me
to
take
the
liberty
of
remarking
that
there
are
few
comestibles
better
,
in
their
way
,
than
a
Devil
,
and
that
I
believe
,
with
a
little
division
of
labour
,
we
could
accomplish
a
good
one
if
the
young
person
in
attendance
could
produce
a
gridiron
,
I
would
put
it
to
you
,
that
this
little
misfortune
may
be
easily
repaired
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
gridiron
in
the
pantry
,
on
which
my
morning
rasher
of
bacon
was
cooked
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
it
in
,
in
a
twinkling
,
and
immediately
applied
ourselves
to
carrying
Mr
Micawber
's
idea
into
effect
.
 
<EOS>
The
division
of
labour
to
which
he
had
referred
was
this
:
---
<EOS>
Traddles
cut
the
mutton
into
slices
;
Mr
Micawber
(
who
could
do
anything
of
this
sort
to
perfection
)
covered
them
with
pepper
,
mustard
,
salt
,
and
cayenne
;
I
put
them
on
the
gridiron
,
turned
them
with
a
fork
,
and
took
them
off
,
under
Mr
Micawber
's
direction
;
and
Mrs
Micawber
heated
,
and
continually
stirred
,
some
mushroom
ketchup
in
a
little
saucepan
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
had
slices
enough
done
to
begin
upon
,
we
fell
-
to
,
with
our
sleeves
still
tucked
up
at
the
wrist
,
more
slices
sputtering
and
blazing
on
the
fire
,
and
our
attention
divided
between
the
mutton
on
our
plates
,
and
the
mutton
then
preparing
.
   
<EOS>
What
with
the
novelty
of
this
cookery
,
the
excellence
of
it
,
the
bustle
of
it
,
the
frequent
starting
up
to
look
after
it
,
the
frequent
sitting
down
to
dispose
of
it
as
the
crisp
slices
came
off
the
gridiron
hot
and
hot
,
the
being
so
busy
,
so
flushed
with
the
fire
,
so
amused
,
and
in
the
midst
of
such
a
tempting
noise
and
savour
,
we
reduced
the
leg
of
mutton
to
the
bone
.
 
<EOS>
My
own
appetite
came
back
miraculously
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
ashamed
to
record
it
,
but
I
really
believe
I
forgot
Dora
for
a
little
while
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
satisfied
that
Mr
and
Mrs
Micawber
could
not
have
enjoyed
the
feast
more
,
if
they
had
sold
a
bed
to
provide
it
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
laughed
as
heartily
,
almost
the
whole
time
,
as
he
ate
and
worked
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
we
all
did
,
all
at
once
;
and
I
dare
say
there
was
never
a
greater
success
.
   
<EOS>
We
were
at
the
height
of
our
enjoyment
,
and
were
all
busily
engaged
,
in
our
several
departments
,
endeavouring
to
bring
the
last
batch
of
slices
to
a
state
of
perfection
that
should
crown
the
feast
,
when
I
was
aware
of
a
strange
presence
in
the
room
,
and
my
eyes
encountered
those
of
the
staid
Littimer
,
standing
hat
in
hand
before
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
I
involuntarily
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
,
I
was
directed
to
come
in
.
 
<EOS>
Is
my
master
not
here
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
not
seen
him
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
;
do
n't
you
come
from
him
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
immediately
so
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
he
tell
you
you
would
find
him
here
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
exactly
so
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
should
think
he
might
be
here
tomorrow
,
as
he
has
not
been
here
today
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
he
coming
up
from
Oxford
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
,
sir
,
"
he
returned
respectfully
,
"
that
you
will
be
seated
,
and
allow
me
to
do
this
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
which
he
took
the
fork
from
my
unresisting
hand
,
and
bent
over
the
gridiron
,
as
if
his
whole
attention
were
concentrated
on
it
.
   
<EOS>
We
should
not
have
been
much
discomposed
,
I
dare
say
,
by
the
appearance
of
Steerforth
himself
,
but
we
became
in
a
moment
the
meekest
of
the
meek
before
his
respectable
serving
-
man
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
,
humming
a
tune
,
to
show
that
he
was
quite
at
ease
,
subsided
into
his
chair
,
with
the
handle
of
a
hastily
concealed
fork
sticking
out
of
the
bosom
of
his
coat
,
as
if
he
had
stabbed
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Micawber
put
on
her
brown
gloves
,
and
assumed
a
genteel
languor
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
ran
his
greasy
hands
through
his
hair
,
and
stood
it
bolt
upright
,
and
stared
in
confusion
on
the
table
-
cloth
.
 
<EOS>
As
for
me
,
I
was
a
mere
infant
at
the
head
of
my
own
table
;
and
hardly
ventured
to
glance
at
the
respectable
phenomenon
,
who
had
come
from
Heaven
knows
where
,
to
put
my
establishment
to
rights
.
   
<EOS>
Meanwhile
he
took
the
mutton
off
the
gridiron
,
and
gravely
handed
it
round
.
 
<EOS>
We
all
took
some
,
but
our
appreciation
of
it
was
gone
,
and
we
merely
made
a
show
of
eating
it
.
 
<EOS>
As
we
severally
pushed
away
our
plates
,
he
noiselessly
removed
them
,
and
set
on
the
cheese
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
that
off
,
too
,
when
it
was
done
with
;
cleared
the
table
;
piled
everything
on
the
dumb
-
waiter
;
gave
us
our
wine
-
glasses
;
and
,
of
his
own
accord
,
wheeled
the
dumb
-
waiter
into
the
pantry
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
was
done
in
a
perfect
manner
,
and
he
never
raised
his
eyes
from
what
he
was
about
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
his
very
elbows
,
when
he
had
his
back
towards
me
,
seemed
to
teem
with
the
expression
of
his
fixed
opinion
that
I
was
extremely
young
.
   
<EOS>
"
Can
I
do
anything
more
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
thanked
him
and
said
,
<EOS>
No
;
but
would
he
take
no
dinner
himself
?
   
<EOS>
"
None
,
I
am
obliged
to
you
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Mr
Steerforth
coming
from
Oxford
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Mr
Steerforth
coming
from
Oxford
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
imagine
that
he
might
be
here
tomorrow
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
rather
thought
he
might
have
been
here
today
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
The
mistake
is
mine
,
no
doubt
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
should
see
him
first
---
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
'll
excuse
me
,
sir
,
I
do
n't
think
I
shall
see
him
first
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
case
you
do
,
"
said
I
,
"
pray
say
that
I
am
sorry
he
was
not
here
today
,
as
an
old
schoolfellow
of
his
was
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
and
he
divided
a
bow
between
me
and
Traddles
,
with
a
glance
at
the
latter
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
moving
softly
to
the
door
,
when
,
in
a
forlorn
hope
of
saying
something
naturally
---
which
I
never
could
,
to
this
man
---
I
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
Littimer
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
remain
long
at
Yarmouth
,
that
time
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
particularly
so
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
saw
the
boat
completed
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
remained
behind
on
purpose
to
see
the
boat
completed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
!
"
<EOS>
He
raised
his

to

respectfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Steerforth
has
not
seen
it
yet
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
really
ca
n't
say
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
---
<EOS>
but
I
really
ca
n't
say
,
sir
.
<EOS>
I
wish
you
good
night
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
comprehended
everybody
present
,
in
the
respectful
bow
with
which
he
followed
these
words
,
and
disappeared
.
 
<EOS>
My
visitors
seemed
to
breathe
more
freely
when
he
was
gone
;
but
my
own
relief
was
very
great
,
for
besides
the
constraint
,
arising
from
that
extraordinary
sense
of
being
at
a
disadvantage
which
I
always
had
in
this
man
's
presence
,
my
conscience
had
embarrassed
me
with
whispers
that
I
had
mistrusted
his
master
,
and
I
could
not
repress
a
vague
uneasy
dread
that
he
might
find
it
out
.
 
<EOS>
How
was
it
,
having
so
little
in
reality
to
conceal
<EOS>
,
that
I
always
DID
feel
as
if
this
man
were
finding
me
out
?
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
roused
me
from
this
reflection
,
which
was
blended
with
a
certain
remorseful
apprehension
of
seeing
Steerforth
himself
,
by
bestowing
many
encomiums
on
the
absent
Littimer
as
a
most
respectable
fellow
,
and
a
thoroughly
admirable
servant
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
,
I
may
remark
,
had
taken
his
full
share
of
the
general
bow
,
and
had
received
it
with
infinite
condescension
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
punch
,
my
dear
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
tasting
it
,
"
like
time
and
tide
,
waits
for
no
man
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
it
is
at
the
present
moment
in
high
flavour
.
 
<EOS>
My
love
,
will
you
give
me
your
opinion
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Micawber
pronounced
it
excellent
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
I
will
drink
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
if
my
friend
Copperfield
will
permit
me
to
take
that
social
liberty
,
to
the
days
when
my
friend
Copperfield
and
myself
were
younger
,
and
fought
our
way
in
the
world
side
by
side
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
say
,
of
myself
and
Copperfield
,
in
words
we
have
sung
together
before
now
,
that
   
<EOS>
"
We
twa
'
<EOS>
hae
run
about
the
braes
   
<EOS>
And
pu'd
<EOS>
the
gowans
fine
"
 
---
in
a
figurative
point
of
view
---
on
several

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
exactly
aware
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
with
the
old
roll
in
his
voice
,
and
the
old
indescribable
air
of
saying
something
genteel
,
"
what
gowans
may
be
,
but
I
have
no
doubt
that
Copperfield
and
myself
would
frequently
have
taken
a
pull
at
them
,
if
it
had
been
feasible
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
,
at
the
then
present
moment
,
took
a
pull
at
his
punch
.
<EOS>
So
we
all
did
:
<EOS>
Traddles
evidently
lost
in
wondering
at
what
distant
time
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
<EOS>
and
I
could
have
been
comrades
in
the
battle
of
the
world
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ahem
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
clearing

,
and
warming
with
the
punch
and

.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
another
glass
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Micawber
said
it
must
be
very
little
;
but
we
could
n't
allow
that
,
so
it
was
a
glassful
.
   
<EOS>
"
As
we
are
quite
confidential
here
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
sipping
her
punch
,
"
Mr
Traddles
being
a
part
of
our
domesticity
<EOS>
,
I
should
much
like
to
have
your
opinion
on
Mr
Micawber
's

.
 
<EOS>
For
corn
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
argumentatively
,
"
as
I
have
repeatedly
said
to
Mr
Micawber
,
may
be
gentlemanly
,
but
it
is
not
remunerative
.
 
<EOS>
Commission
to
the
extent
of
two
and
ninepence
in
a
fortnight
can
not
,
however
limited
our
ideas
,
be
considered
remunerative
.
"
   
<EOS>
We
were
all
agreed
upon
that
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
who
prided
herself
on
taking
a
clear

of
things
,
and
keeping
Mr
Micawber
straight
by
her
woman
's
wisdom
,
when
he
might
otherwise
go
a
little
crooked
,
"
then
I
ask
myself
this
question
.
 
<EOS>
If
corn
is
not
to
be
relied
upon
,
what
is
?
<EOS>
Are
coals
to
be
relied
upon
?
 
<EOS>
Not
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
turned
our
attention
to
that
experiment
,
on
the
suggestion
of
my
family
,
and
we
find
it
fallacious
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
,
leaning
back
in
his
chair
with
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
eyed
us
aside
,
and
nodded
his
head
,
as
much
as
to
say
that
the
case
was
very
clearly
put
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
articles
of
corn
and
coals
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
still
more
argumentatively
,
"
being
equally
out
of
the
question
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
I
naturally
look
round
the
world
,
and
say
,
"
What
is
there
in
which
a
person
of
Mr
Micawber
's
talent
is
likely
to
succeed
?
"
<EOS>
And
I
exclude
the
doing
anything
on
commission
,
because
commission
is
not
a
certainty
.
 
<EOS>
What
is
best
suited
to
a
person
of
Mr
Micawber
's
peculiar
temperament
is
,
I
am
convinced
,
a
certainty
.
"
   
<EOS>
Traddles
and
I
both
expressed
,
by
a
feeling
murmur
,
that
this
great
discovery
was
no
doubt
true
of
Mr
Micawber
,
and
that
it
did
him
much
credit
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
conceal
from
you
,
my
dear
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
that
I
have
long
felt
the
Brewing
business
to
be
particularly
adapted
to
Mr
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
Barclay
and
Perkins
!
<EOS>
Look
at
Truman
,
Hanbury
,
and
Buxton
!
 
<EOS>
It
is
on
that
extensive
footing
that
Mr
Micawber
,
I
know
from
my
own
knowledge
of
him
,
is
calculated
to
shine
;
and
the
profits
,
I
am
told
,
are
e
-
NOR
-
MOUS
!
<EOS>
But
if
Mr
Micawber
can
not
get
into
those

---
which
decline

letters
,
when
he

---

?
 
<EOS>
None
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
have
a
conviction
that
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
's
manners
---
"
   
"
Hem
!
 
<EOS>
Really
,
my
dear
,
"
interposed
Mr
Micawber
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
love
,
be

,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
laying

brown

on

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
may
have
a
conviction
,
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
,
that
Mr
Micawber
's
manners
peculiarly

for
the

.
<EOS>
I
may

,
that
if

,
the

of
Mr
Micawber
,
as

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

of

's

,

THAT

?
<EOS>
None
.
 
<EOS>
As

,
I
may
know
that

my

who
,

Micawber

<EOS>
But

NOT

's

---

---

?
<EOS>
Again

that
we
are
no

than

.
"
   
<EOS>
I

,
and
said
,
"
Not
a
bit
.
"
 
<EOS>
Traddles
also
shook
his

,

,
"
Not
a
bit
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
I
deduce
from
this
?
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Micawber
went
on
to
say
,
still

the
same

of
putting
a
case

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
conclusion
,
my
dear
Mr
Copperfield
,
to

I

?
 
<EOS>
Am

wrong
in
saying
<EOS>
,
it
is
clear
that
we
must
live
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
answered
"
Not
at
all
!
"
<EOS>
and
Traddles
answered
"
Not
at
all
!
"
<EOS>
and
I
found
myself
afterwards
sagely
adding
,
alone
,
that
a
person
must
either
live
or

.
   
<EOS>
"
Just
so
,
"

,
"
It

.
 
<EOS>
And

,
my

Mr
Copperfield
,
that
we
can
not

without
something
widely
different

existing

shortly

.
 
<EOS>
Now
I
am

,
myself
,
and
<EOS>
this
I

Mr
Micawber
several

,
that
things

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

I
have

.
"
   
<EOS>
Both
Traddles
and
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
well
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
what
do
I

?
 
<EOS>
Here
is
Mr
Micawber
with
a

of
qualifications
---
with
great

---
"
   
"
Really
,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Here

Mr

,

,

---
I
should
say
,
with

,
but

---
<EOS>
"
   
Traddles

"
No
.
"
   
"
<EOS>
And

Mr
Micawber
without

.
 
<EOS>
Where

?
 
<EOS>
Clearly

.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
would
make

so
disgraceful
known
,
and
boldly

to

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

Copperfield

"

,

,
"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
Let

.
"
<EOS>
"
   
I

Micawber
how

.
   
<EOS>
"
By

,
"

Mrs

---
"
in

.
 
<EOS>
It

,
that

Mr
Micawber
has
to
do
,
in

,
in

,

<EOS>

"

,

,
"

,

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Advertising

,
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Exactly

!
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quite

,

!
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
It

(

---
on

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

,

,

;
but
I

of
Traddles
,

,
who
was

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If

,
"
said

,
"

bill
<EOS>
---
I
believe

-

---
"
   
Mr
Micawber
,

,

"
Discount
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
To

,
"
said
Mrs

,
"
then
my

,
that

should
go

,
should
take

into

Money

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

Money
Market

Mr
Micawber
to

great

,
that
is
between

and

.
 
<EOS>
I

it
,

,

an
investment
.
 
<EOS>
I
recommend
Mr
Micawber
,
my

Mr
Copperfield
,
to
do

;
to
regard

as
an
investment
which
is
sure
of
return
,
and
to
make

to
any

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
,
but
I
am
sure
I
do
n't

,
that
this
was
self
-
denying
and
devoted
in
Mrs
Micawber
,
and
I
uttered

to
that

.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
,
who
took
his
tone
from
me
,
did
likewise
,
still
looking
at
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
finishing
her

,
and
gathering
her

,

:
"
I
will
not

on
the
subject
of
Mr
Micawber
's
pecuniary
affairs
.
 
<EOS>
At
your
fireside
,
my
dear
Mr
Copperfield
,
and
in
the

Mr
Traddles
,
who
,
though
not
so
old

friend
,
is
quite
one

ourselves
,
I
could
not
refrain
from
making
you

with
the
course
I
advise
Mr
Micawber
to
take
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
that
the
time
is
arrived
when
Mr
Micawber
should
exert
himself
<EOS>
and
---
I
will
add
---
assert
himself
,
and
it
appears
to
me
that
these
are
the
means
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
aware
that
I
am
merely
a
female
,
and
that
a
masculine
judgement
is
usually
considered
more
competent
to
the
discussion
of
such
questions
;
still
I
must
not
forget
that
,
when
I
lived
at
home
with
my
papa
and
mama
,
my
papa
was
in
the
habit
of
saying
,
"
Emma
's
form
is
fragile
,
but
her
grasp
of
a
subject
is
inferior
to
none
.
<EOS>
"
That
my
papa
was
too
partial
,
I
well
know
;
but
that
he
was
an
observer
of
character
in
some
degree
,
my
duty
and
my
reason
equally
forbid
me
to
doubt
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
and
resisting
our
entreaties
that
she
would
grace
the
remaining
circulation
of
the
punch
with
her
presence
,
Mrs
Micawber
retired
to
my
bedroom
.
 
<EOS>
And
really
I
felt
that
she
was
a
noble
woman
---
the
sort
of
woman
who
might
have
been
a
Roman
matron
,
and
done
all
manner
of
heroic
things
,
in
times
of
public
trouble
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
fervour
of
this
impression
,
I
congratulated
Mr
Micawber
on
the
treasure
he
possessed
.
 
<EOS>
So
did
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
extended
his
hand
to
each
of
us
in
succession
,
and
then
covered
his
face
with
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
which
I
think
had
more
snuff
upon
it
than
he
was
aware
of
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
returned
to
the
punch
,
in
the
highest
state
of
exhilaration
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
full
of
eloquence
.
 
<EOS>
He
gave
us
to
understand
that
in
our
children
we
lived
again
,
and
that
,
under
the
pressure
of
pecuniary
difficulties
,
any
accession
to
their
number
was
doubly
welcome
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
that
Mrs
Micawber
had
latterly
had
her
doubts
on
this
point
,
but
that
he
had
dispelled
them
,
and
reassured
her
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
her
family
,
they
were
totally
unworthy
of
her
,
and
their
sentiments
were
utterly
indifferent
to
him
,
and
they
might
---
I
quote
his
own
expression
---
go
to
the
Devil
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
then
delivered
a
warm
eulogy
on
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
Traddles
's
was
a
character
,
to
the
steady
virtues
of
which
he
(
Mr
Micawber
)
could
lay
no
claim
,
but
which
,
he
thanked
Heaven
,
he
could
admire
.
 
<EOS>
He
feelingly
alluded
to
the
young
lady
,
unknown
,
whom
Traddles
had
honoured
with
his
affection
,
and
who
had
reciprocated
that
affection
by
honouring
and
blessing
Traddles
with
her
affection
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
pledged
her
.
 
<EOS>
So
did
I.
 
Traddles
thanked
us
both
,
by
saying
,
with
a
simplicity
and
honesty
<EOS>
I
had
sense
enough
to
be
quite
charmed
with
,
"
I
am
very
much
obliged
to
you
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
do
assure
you
,
she
's
the
dearest
girl
!
---
<EOS>
"
   
Mr
Micawber
took
an
early
opportunity
,
after
that
,
of
hinting
,
with
the
utmost
delicacy
and
ceremony
,
at
the
state
of
MY
affections
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
but
the
serious
assurance
of
his
friend
Copperfield
to
the
contrary
,
he
observed
,
could
deprive
him
of
the
impression
that
his
friend
Copperfield
loved
and
was
beloved
.
<EOS>
After
feeling
very
hot
and
uncomfortable
for
some
time
,
and
after
a
good
deal
of
blushing
,
stammering
,
and
denying
,
I
said
,
having
my
glass
in
my
hand
,
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
I
would
give
them
D
!
"
<EOS>
which
so
excited
and
gratified
Mr
Micawber
,
that
he
ran
with
a
glass
of
punch
into
my
bedroom
,
in
order
that
Mrs
Micawber
might
drink
D
,
who
drank
it
with
enthusiasm
,
crying
from
within
,
in
a
shrill
voice
,
"
Hear
,
hear
!
 
<EOS>
My
dear
Mr
Copperfield
,
I
am
delighted
.
 
<EOS>
Hear
!
"
<EOS>
and
tapping
at
the
wall
,
by
way
of
applause
.
   
<EOS>
Our
conversation
,
afterwards
,
took
a
more
worldly
turn
;
Mr
Micawber
telling
us
that
he
found
Camden
Town
inconvenient
,
and
that
the
first
thing
he
contemplated
doing
,
when
the
advertisement
should
have
been
the
cause
of
something
satisfactory
turning
up
,
was
to
move
.
 
<EOS>
He
mentioned
a
terrace
at
the
western
end
of
Oxford
Street
,
fronting
Hyde
Park
,
on
which
he
had
always
had
his
eye
,
but
which
he
did
not
expect
to
attain
immediately
,
as
it
would
require
a
large
establishment
.
 
<EOS>
There
would
probably
be
an
interval
,
he
explained
,
in
which
he
should
content
himself
with
the
upper
part
of
a
house
,
over
some
respectable
place
of
business
---
say
in
Piccadilly
,
---
which
would
be
a
cheerful
situation
for
Mrs
Micawber
;
and
where
,
by
throwing
out
a
bow
-
window
,
or
carrying
up
the
roof
another
story
,
or
making
some
little
alteration
of
that
sort
,
they
might
live
,
comfortably
and
reputably
,
for
a
few
years
.
<EOS>
Whatever
was
reserved
for
him
,
he
expressly
said
,
or
wherever
his
abode
might
be
,
we
might
rely
on
this
---
there
would
always
be
a
room
for
Traddles
,
and
a
knife
and
fork
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
We
acknowledged
his
kindness
;
and
he
begged
us
to
forgive
his
having
launched
into
these
practical
and
business
-
like
details
,
and
to
excuse
it
as
natural
in
one
who
was
making
entirely
new
arrangements
in
life
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Micawber
,
tapping
at
the
wall
again
to
know
if
tea
were
ready
,
broke
up
this
particular
phase
of
our
friendly
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
She
made
tea
for
us
in
a
most
agreeable
manner
;
and
,
whenever
I
went
near
her
,
in
handing
about
the
tea
-
cups
and
bread
-
and
-
butter
,
asked
me
,
in
a
whisper
,
whether
D
was
fair
,
or
dark
,
or
whether
she
was
short
,
or
tall
:
or
something
of
that
kind
;
which
I
think
I
liked
.
<EOS>
After
tea
,
we
discussed
a
variety
of
topics
before
the
fire
;
and
Mrs
Micawber
was
good
enough
to
sing
us
(
in
a
small
,
thin
,
flat
voice
,
which
I
remembered
to
have
considered
,
when
I
first
knew
her
,
the
very
table
-
beer
of
acoustics
)
<EOS>
the
favourite
ballads
of
"
The
Dashing
White
Sergeant
"
,
and
"
Little
Tafflin
"
.
 
<EOS>
For
both
of
these
songs
Mrs
Micawber
had
been
famous
when
she
lived
at
home
with
her
papa
and
mama
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
told
us
,
that
when
he
heard
her
sing
the
first
one
,
on
the
first
occasion
of
his
seeing
her
beneath
the
parental
roof
,
she
had
attracted
his
attention
in
an
extraordinary
degree
;
but
that
when
it
came
to
Little
Tafflin
,
he
had
resolved
to
win
that
woman
or
perish
in
the
attempt
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
between
ten
and
eleven
o'clock
when
Mrs
Micawber
rose
to
replace
her
cap
in
the
whitey
-
brown
paper
parcel
,
and
to
put
on
her
bonnet
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
took
the
opportunity
of
Traddles
putting
on
his
great
-
coat
,
to
slip
a
letter
into
my
hand
,
with
a
whispered
request
that
I
would
read
it
at
my
leisure
.
 
<EOS>
I
also
took
the
opportunity
of
my
holding
a
candle
over
the
banisters
to
light
them
down
,
when
Mr
Micawber
was
going
first
,
leading
Mrs
Micawber
,
and
Traddles
was
following
with
the
cap
,
to
detain
Traddles
for
a
moment
on
the
top
of
the
stairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Traddles
,
"
said
I
,
"
Mr
Micawber
do
n't
mean
any
harm
,
poor
fellow
:
<EOS>
but
,
if
I
were
you
,
I
would
n't
lend
him
anything
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Copperfield
,
"
returned
Traddles
,
smiling
,
"
I
have
n't
got
anything
to
lend
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
got
a
name
,
you
know
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
You
call
THAT
something
to
lend
?
<EOS>
"
returned
Traddles
,
with
a
thoughtful
look
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
to
be
sure
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
much

to
you
,
Copperfield
;
but
---
I
am
afraid
I
have
lent
him
that
already
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
For
the
bill
that
is
to
be
a
certain
investment
?
"
I
inquired
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
for
that
one
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
first
I
have
heard
of
that
one
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
thinking
that
he
will
most
likely
propose
that
one
,
on
the
way
home
.
 
<EOS>
Mine
's
another
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
there
will
be
nothing
wrong
about
it
,
"
said
I.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
"
said
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
not
,
though
,
because
he
told
me
,
only
the
other
day
,
that
it
was
provided
for
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
Mr
Micawber
's
expression
,
"
Provided
for
.
"
<EOS>
"
   
Mr
Micawber
looking
up
at
this
juncture
to
where
we
were
standing
,
I
had
only
time
to
repeat
my
caution
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
thanked
me
,
and
descended
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
was
much
afraid
,
when
I
observed
the
good
-
natured
manner
in
which
he
went
down
with
the
cap
in
his
hand
,
and
gave
Mrs
Micawber
his
arm
,
that
he
would
be
carried
into
the
Money
Market
neck
and
heels
.
   
<EOS>
I
returned
to
my
fireside
,
and
was
musing
,
half
gravely
and
half
laughing
,
on
the
character
of
Mr
Micawber
and
the
old
relations
between
us
,
when
I
heard
a
quick
step
ascending
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
,
I
thought
it
was
Traddles
coming
back
for
something
Mrs
Micawber
had
left
behind
;
but
as
the
step
approached
,
I
knew
it
,
and
felt
my
heart
beat
high
,
and
the
blood
rush
to
my
face
,
for
it
was
Steerforth
's
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
never
unmindful
of
Agnes
,
and
she
never
left
that
sanctuary
in
my
thoughts
---
if
I
may
call
it
so
---
where
I
had
placed
her
from
the
first
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
he
entered
,
and
stood
before
me
with
his
hand
out
,
the
darkness
that
had
fallen
on
him
changed
to
light
,
and
I
felt
confounded
and
ashamed
of
having
doubted
one
I
loved
so
heartily
.
 
<EOS>
I
loved
her
none
the
less
;
I
thought
of
her
as
the
same
benignant
,
gentle
angel
in
my
life
;
I
reproached
myself
,
not
her
,
with
having
done
him
an
injury
;
and
I
would
have
made
him
any
atonement
if
I
had
known
what
to
make
,
and
how
to
make
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Daisy
,
old
boy
,
dumb
-
foundered
!
"
<EOS>
laughed
Steerforth
,
shaking
my
hand
heartily
,
and
throwing
it
gaily
away
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
I
detected
you
in
another
feast
,
you
Sybarite
!
 
<EOS>
These
Doctors
'
Commons
fellows
are
the
gayest
men
in
town
,
I
believe
,
and
beat
us
sober
Oxford
people
all
to
nothing
!
"
<EOS>
His
bright
glance
went
merrily
round
the
room
,
as
he
took
the
seat
on
the
sofa
opposite
to
me
,
which
Mrs
Micawber
had
recently
vacated
,
and
stirred
the
fire
into
a
blaze
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
so
surprised
at
first
,
"
said
I
,
giving
him
welcome
with
all
the
cordiality
I
felt
,
"
that
I
had
hardly
breath
to
greet
you
with
,
Steerforth
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
the
sight
of
me
is
good
for
sore
eyes
,
as
the
Scotch
say
,
"
replied
Steerforth
,
"
and
so
is
the
sight
of
you
,
Daisy
,
in
full
bloom
.
 
<EOS>
How
are
you
,
my
Bacchanal
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
well
,
"
said
I
;
"
and
not
at
all
Bacchanalian
tonight
,
though
I
confess
to
another
party
of
three
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
of
whom
I
met
in
the
street
,
talking
loud
in
your
praise
,
"
returned
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
's
our
friend
in
the
tights
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
gave
him
the
best
idea
I
could
,
in
a

words
,
of
Mr
Micawber
.
<EOS>
He
laughed
heartily
at
my
feeble
portrait
of
that
gentleman
,
and
said
he
was
a
man
to
know
,
and
he
must
know
him
.
"
<EOS>
But
who
do

suppose
our
other
friend
is
?
"
said
I
,
in
my
turn
.
   
<EOS>
"
Heaven
knows
,
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
a
bore
<EOS>
,
I
hope
?
 
<EOS>
I
thought
he
looked
a
little
like
one
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Traddles
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I
replied
,
triumphantly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
's
he
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Steerforth
,
in
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do

you
remember
Traddles
?
 
<EOS>
Traddles
in
our
room
at
Salem
House
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
That
fellow
!
"
<EOS>
said
Steerforth
,
beating
a
lump
of
coal
on
the
top
of
the
fire
,
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
he
as
soft
as
ever
?
 
<EOS>
And
where
the

did
you
pick
him

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

Traddles
in

,
as

as
I

;
for
I
felt
that
Steerforth
rather
slighted

.
 
<EOS>
Steerforth
,
dismissing
the
subject
with
a
light

,
and
a

,
and
the
remark
that
he
would
be
glad
to
see
the
old
fellow
too
,
for
he
had
always
been
an
odd
fish
,
inquired
if
I
could

him
anything
to

?
 
<EOS>
During

this

,
when

in
a

,
he

sat
idly

.
<EOS>
I
observed
that
he
did

while
I

the
remains
of
the
pigeon

,

forth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Daisy
,
here
's

king
!
"
<EOS>
he

,
starting

,

the

.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
do

,
for
I
have

Yarmouth
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

?
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
seafaring
---
better
employed
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Littimer
was
here
today
,

,
"
I

,
"

that

;
<EOS>

,

"
   
<EOS>
"
Littimer

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
As

,
you

,
Daisy
,
if
you

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's

,

,
"

,

to

.
 
<EOS>
"
So
you
have
been
at
Yarmouth
,
Steerforth
!
"
<EOS>
interested
to
know
all
about

.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
been
there
long
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
he

.
 
<EOS>
"
An
escapade
of
a
week
or

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
how
are
they
all
?
 
<EOS>
Of

,
little
Emily
is
not
married

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

.
 
<EOS>
Going
to
be
,
I

---
in
so

weeks
,

,

something

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not

.
 
<EOS>
By
the
by
"
;
he
laid

,
which

using
with
great

,
and
began
feeling
in
his

;
"
I
have
a
letter
for

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
From
whom
?
"
   
"
Why
,
from
your
old
nurse
,
"
he

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
"
J
Steerforth
,
Esquire
,
debtor
,

The

"
;
that
's

.
 
<EOS>
Patience
,
and
we
'll
find
it

.
 
<EOS>
Old
what's
-
his
-
name
's
in
a
bad

,
and
it
's
about
that
,
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Barkis
,
do
you

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
!
"
still
feeling
in
his
pockets
,
and
looking
over

:
"
it
's
all
over
with
poor
Barkis
,
I
am
afraid
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
a
little
apothecary
there
---
surgeon
,
or
whatever
he
is
---
who
brought
your

into
the

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
mighty
learned
about
the
case
,
to
me
;
but
the
upshot
of
his
opinion
was
,
that
the
carrier
was
making
his
last
journey
rather
fast
.
 
<EOS>
---
Put
your
hand
into
the
breast
pocket
of
my
great
-
coat
on
the
chair
yonder
,
and
I
think
you
'll
find
the
letter
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
there
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
it
is
!
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
from
Peggotty
;
something
less
legible
than
usual
,
and
brief
.
<EOS>
It
informed
me
of
her
husband
's
hopeless
state
,
and
hinted
at
his
being
"
a
little
nearer
"
than
heretofore
,
and
consequently
more
difficult
to
manage
for
his
own
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
It
said
nothing
of
her
weariness
and
watching
,
and
praised
him
highly
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
written
with
a
plain
,
unaffected
,
homely
piety
that
I
knew
to
be
genuine
,
and
ended
with
"
my
duty
to
my
ever
darling
"
---
meaning
myself
.
   
<EOS>
While
I
deciphered
it
,
Steerforth
continued
to
eat
and
drink
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
bad
job
,
"
he
said
,
when
I
had
done
;
"
but
<EOS>
the
sun
sets
every
day
,
and
people
die
every
minute
,
and
we
must
n't
be
scared
by
the
common
lot
.
 
<EOS>
If
we
failed
to
hold
our
own
,
because
that
equal
foot
at
all
men
's
doors
was
heard
knocking
somewhere
,
every
object
in
this
world
would
slip
from
us
.
 
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
Ride
on
!
 
<EOS>
Rough
-
shod
<EOS>
if
need
be
,
smooth
-
shod
if
that
will
do
,
but
ride
on
!
 
<EOS>
Ride
on
over
all
obstacles
,
and
win
the
race
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
win
what
race
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
The
race
that
one
has
started
in
,
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ride
on
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
noticed
,
I
remember
,
as
he
paused
,
looking
at
me
with
his
handsome
head
a
little
thrown
back
,
and
his
glass
raised
in
his
hand
,
that
,
though
the
freshness
of
the
sea
-
wind
was
on
his
face
,
and
it
was
ruddy
,
there
were
traces
in
it
,
made
since
I
last
saw
it
,
as

he
had

some

of
the
fervent

which
,

,
was
so

.
 
<EOS>
I
had
it
in
my

to

upon
his

of

any

---
such

,

,

---
when

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

you
what
,
Steerforth
,
"
said

,
"
if
your
high

will
listen

---
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
are
potent

,

will

,
"

<EOS>
"
Then
I
tell

what
,
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
I

go

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

;

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
It

make
<EOS>
,

<EOS>
Would

?
"
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
---
Bah
!
<EOS>

!
<EOS>
---

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

(

<EOS>

<EOS>
It

<EOS>

"
SIR

"
   
"

<EOS>
Chapter

.
<EOS>
I
visit

again
 
I

,

;

<EOS>

<EOS>
We

,

,
were

<EOS>

called
The

<EOS>

.

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mrs

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

that
Littimer
was

,

,

,

,

,
than

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

,

Miss

;

,
and

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
In

she

saw
I

,

<EOS>

any

she

me
of

,

.
   
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

,

,
until

fixed

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

,

,
while
Steerforth

on

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have

a
long

,
"
she

,
"
without

.
 
<EOS>
Is

?
 
<EOS>
I
ask

I
always

,

.
 
<EOS>
Is

,

?
"
   
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I

,

"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

---

---

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

"

!

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
state
any
opinion
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
found
an
opinion
on
what
you
tell
me
.
<EOS>
Then
,
it
's
not
so
?
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
I
am
very
glad
to
know
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
certainly
is
not
the
fact
,
"
said
I
,
perplexed
,
"
that
I
am
accountable
for
Steerforth
's
having
been
away
from
home
longer
than
usual
---
if
he
has
been
:
which
I
really
do
n't
know
at
this
moment
,
unless
I
understand
it
from
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
seen
him
this
long
while
,
until
last
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
Miss
Dartle
,
no
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
she
looked
full
at
me
,
I
saw
her

grow
sharper
and
paler
,
and
the
marks
of
the
old

lengthen

until

cut

the
disfigured
lip
,
and
deep
into
the
nether

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
There

something
positively
awful

in
this
,
and
in
the

her

,
as

<EOS>
"
What
is
he
doing
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
repeated
the
words
,
more
to
myself

her
,
being
so
amazed
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
he
doing
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
with
an
eagerness
that
seemed
enough
to
consume

like
a
fire
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
what
is
that
man
assisting
him
,
who
never
looks
at
me
without
an
inscrutable
falsehood
in
his
eyes
?
<EOS>
If
you
are
honourable
and
faithful
,
I
do
n't
ask
you
to
betray
your
friend
.
 
<EOS>
I
ask
you
only
to
tell
me
,
is
it
anger
,
is
it
hatred
,
is
it
pride
,
is

,
is

some

,
is

love
,
<EOS>
what
is
it
,
that
is
leading
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Dartle
,
"
<EOS>
I
returned
,
"
how
shall
I
tell
you
,
so
that
you
will
believe
me
,
that
I
know

nothing
in
Steerforth
different
from
what
there
was
when
I
first
came
here
?
 
<EOS>
I
can
think
of
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
I
firmly
believe
there
is
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
I
hardly
understand
even
what
you
mean
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
she
still
stood
looking
fixedly
at
me
,
a

,
from
which
I
could
not
dissociate
the
idea
of
pain
,
came
into
that
cruel

;
and
lifted

the

as

with

,
or

a

that
despised

.
 
<EOS>
She
put
her

upon

hurriedly
---
a

so
thin
and
delicate
,
that
when
I
had
seen

hold

to
shade

,
I
had
compared
it
in
my

to
fine

---
and

,
in

,
"
I
swear
you
to
secrecy
about
this
!
"
<EOS>
said
not
a
word
more
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Steerforth
was
particularly
happy
in
her
son
's
society
,
and
Steerforth
was
,
on
this
occasion
,
particularly
attentive
and
respectful
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
interesting
to
me
to

,
not

of
their

,
but

of

between

,
and
the

was
softened
by
age

,
in

,
to

.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
,
more
than

,
that
it
was
well
no
serious
cause
of
division
<EOS>
had
ever
come
between

;
or
two
such
natures
---
I
ought
rather
to

,
two

the
same

---
might

to

than
the

.
 
<EOS>
The

in

,
I

,
but
in
a

of
Rosa

.
   
<EOS>
She

:
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
but
do

,
though
,
somebody
,
because
I
have
been
thinking

all

,
and
I
want

know
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
want
to

,
Rosa
?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
pray
,
Rosa
,

not

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mysterious
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
really
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
consider

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

,
"
said

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Now

,

I

.
 
<EOS>
We
never

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
has

a
second

,
"
said
Mrs
Steerforth
,

;
"
but
I

,
---
<EOS>
and

,

---

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am

,
"
she

;
"
and
so
it

that
bad

grow
upon

!
 
<EOS>
Really
?
 
<EOS>
Less
guarded
and
more

?
<EOS>
How
can
I
,

,
have
changed
,
I

!
 
<EOS>
Well
,
that
's
very
odd
!
 
<EOS>
I
must
study
to

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you

,
"
said
Mrs
Steerforth
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
I
really
will
,
you

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
learn
frankness
from
---
<EOS>
let

---
from
James
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
learn

,
Rosa
,
"
said
Mrs
Steerforth
quickly
---
<EOS>
for
there

Rosa
Dartle

,
though

was

,
as

,

the
most

---
"
in

better

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
I
am
sure

,
"
she

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I

sure

anything
,
of

,
you

,
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Steerforth
appeared
to

to
regret

been
a

;
for
she
presently
said
,
in

:
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
my

Rosa
,
we

you

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
I

to
be
satisfied
about
?
"
<EOS>
she

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
only
whether
people
,
who

like

in
their

---
is

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
:
---
whether

,

each

in

,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should

,
"

Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Should

?
"
she

.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear

!
 
<EOS>
Supposing

,

---
any

will

---
that

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"

,

,
"
suggest

!
 
<EOS>
James
and
<EOS>
I

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Miss
Dartle
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
To

.
 
<EOS>
That

prevent

?
 
<EOS>
Why
,

.
 
<EOS>
Exactly
.
<EOS>
Now
,
I

!
<EOS>
Thank

"
   
<EOS>
One
other
little
circumstance
connected
with
Miss
Dartle
<EOS>
I
must
not
omit
;
for
I
had
reason
to
remember
it
thereafter
,
when
all
the
irremediable
past
was
rendered
plain
.
 
<EOS>
During
the
whole
of
this
day
,
but
especially

this

,
Steerforth

himself
with
his

,
and
that
was
with
his

,
to
charm
this
singular
creature
into
a
pleasant
and
pleased

.
 
<EOS>
That
he
should
succeed
,
was
no
matter
of
surprise
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
That
she
should
struggle
against
the
fascinating
influence
of
his
delightful
art
---
<EOS>
delightful
nature
<EOS>
I
thought
it
then
---
did
not
surprise
me
either
;
for
I
knew
that
she
was
sometimes

and

.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
her
features
and
her
manner
slowly

;
I
saw

with

;
I

,

,

that
he

;
and

,

,
and
her

quite
gentle
,
and
I
ceased
to
be
afraid
of
her
as
I
had
really
been
all
day
,
and
we
all
sat
about
the
fire
,
talking
and
laughing
together
,
with
as
little

as
if
we
had

.
   
<EOS>
Whether
it
was
because
we
had
sat

,
or

Steerforth
was
resolved
not
to
lose
the

he
had

,
I
do
not

;
but
we

.
 
<EOS>
"
She
is
playing
her
harp
,
"
said
Steerforth
,

,
at
the

,
"
and
nobody
but
my
mother
has
heard
her
do
that
,
I
believe
,
these
three
years
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
said
it
with
a
curious

,
which
was
gone

;
and
we
went
into
the
room
and
found
her
alone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
get
up
,
"
said
Steerforth
(
which
she

already
done
)
"
<EOS>
my
dear
Rosa
,

!
 
<EOS>
Be

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

Irish

?
<EOS>
"
she

.
   
<EOS>
"
Much
!
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Much

than

any

.
 
<EOS>
Here

Daisy
,
too
,
loves
music
from

.
 
<EOS>
Sing

Irish

,
Rosa
!
<EOS>
and
let

listen

I

.
"
   
<EOS>
He
did
not

her
,
or

which
she
had

,
but
sat

.
 
<EOS>
She
stood

some

,
in

,
going
through

of
playing
it

,
but

.
 
<EOS>
At
length

sat
down
,
and
drew
it

her
with
one

,
and
played
and

.
   
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
it
was
,
in
her

,
that
made
that

the
most
unearthly
<EOS>
I
have

in
my

,
or
can

.
 
<EOS>
There
was
something
fearful

the

of
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
as
if
it
had
never
been
written
,
or

,
but
sprung
out

within

;
which
found

in
the
low

of

,
and
crouched
again
when
all
was
still
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
dumb
when
she
leaned
beside
the
harp
again
,
playing
it
,
but
not
sounding
it
,
with
her
right
hand
.
   
<EOS>
A
minute
more
,
and
this
had
roused
me
from
my
trance
:
---
Steerforth
had
left
his
seat
,
and
gone
to
her
,
and
had
put
his
arm
laughingly
about
her
,
and
had
said
,
"
Come
,
Rosa
,
for
the
future
we
will
love
each
other
very
much
!
"
<EOS>
And
she
had
struck
him
,
and
had
thrown
him
off
with
the

of
a

,
and
had
burst

the

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
with
Rosa
?
"
said
Mrs
Steerforth
,
coming

.
   
<EOS>
"
She
has

an
angel
,

,
"
returned

,
"

a

;
and
has

,
since
,
by

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
should

,
James
.
 
<EOS>
Her
temper
has
been
soured
,
remember
,
and
ought

to

.
"
   
<EOS>
Rosa

not

;
and
no

,
until
I

Steerforth
into

.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
laughed
about
her
,
and
asked
me
if
I
had
ever
seen
such
a
fierce
little
piece

.
   
<EOS>
I
expressed
as

my

as
was
then
capable

,
and
asked
if
he
could

what
it
was
that
she
had
taken
so
much

,
so

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Heaven
knows
,
"
said
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
"
Anything
you
like
---
or
nothing
!
 
<EOS>
I
told
you
she
took
everything
,
herself
included
,
to
a
grindstone
,
and

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
,
"
I
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
him
well
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
do
,
"
said
Mr
Omer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
Her
cousin
being
,
as
it
appears
,
in
good
work
,
and
well
to
do
,
thanked
me
in
a
very
manly
sort
of
manner
for
this
(
conducting
himself
altogether
,
I
must
say
,
in
a
way
that
gives
me
a
high
opinion
of
him
)
,
and
went
and
took
as
comfortable
a
little
house
as
you
or

wish
to

.
 
<EOS>
That
little
house
is
now
furnished
right
through
,
as
neat
and

as
a
doll
's

;
and
but
for
Barkis
's
illness
having

this

,
poor

,
they

have
been
man

wife
---
I

,
by
this

.
 
<EOS>
As

is
,
there
's
a
postponement
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
Emily
,
Mr
Omer
?
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
"
Has
she
become
more
settled
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
that
,
you
know
,
"
he

,

double

again
,
"
ca
n't

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

,
is
,
as

,
close

.
 
<EOS>
Barkis
's

,

.
 
<EOS>
Anyway
,
it
's

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

<EOS>
"
Consequently
,
"

,
"
Em'ly
's
still

,
and
a

;
perhaps
,
upon

,
she
's

.
 
<EOS>
Every

of
her
uncle
,
and
more

to
part

all

.
 
<EOS>
A

;

's

,
you
'd

.
 
<EOS>
Bless
my
heart
alive
!
"
said
Mr
Omer
,
pondering
,
"
how
she

that
child
!
"
   
<EOS>
Having
so

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
he

,

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
"
No
good
.
 
<EOS>
A
sad
story
,

,
however
you

to

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
---

---
but
I

.
 
<EOS>
None
of

did
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Omer
,
hearing

daughter
's

before
I

,
touched
me
with
his

,
and
shut

one

,
as

.
 
<EOS>
She

her

came

.
   
<EOS>
Their

was
,
that
Mr
Barkis
was
"
as

could

"
;
that

;

Mr

in

,
on

just

,
that
the

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
past

,
Mr
Chillip
said
,
and
the
Hall
could
only
poison

.
   
<EOS>
Hearing

,
and
learning

Mr
Peggotty
was
there
,
I
determined
to

to

.
 
<EOS>
I

Mr

,
and

Mr
and

;
and
directed

,
with

,
which

quite

.
   
<EOS>
My

tap
at

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
I
remarked
this
in
Peggotty
,

,

;
and
I
have

;
and

think
,
in
the

that

surprise
,
all

dwindle

.
   
<EOS>
I

with
Mr

,
and
passed
into
the

,
while

.
 
<EOS>
Little

was

,
with

.
 
<EOS>
Ham
was
standing
near

.
   
<EOS>
We

;
listening
,

,
for

.
 
<EOS>
I

it

!
   
<EOS>
"
This

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

oncommon

,
"

Ham
.
   
<EOS>
"
Em'ly
,

dear
,
"

Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
See

!
 
<EOS>
Here
's
<EOS>
Mas'r
Davy
come
!
 
<EOS>
What
,
cheer
up
,
pretty
!
 
<EOS>
Not
a
wured

Mas'r
Davy
?
"
   
<EOS>
There

upon

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

when
I
touched
it
<EOS>
,

can
feel

.
 
<EOS>
Its

;

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

,

,
"
that
it
ca
n't
abear

.
 
<EOS>
It

nat'ral

,

,
when

're
new

these
here
trials
,
and
timid
,

my

,
<EOS>
---
it
's
nat'ral
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
clung
the
closer
to

,
but

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

,

,
"

,
"
and
<EOS>
here

Ham
<EOS>
come
fur

.
 
<EOS>
Theer
!
 
<EOS>
Go

art
!
 
<EOS>
What
,

?
 
<EOS>
Eh
,
my

?
"
   
<EOS>
The

,

,

"
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You

---
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
---

"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
What
?
 
<EOS>
You

?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Well
!
come

<EOS>
If

<EOS>
But

!
"
   
<EOS>
Afterwards

.
 
<EOS>
But
,

,

.
   
<EOS>
I

,
before
the

,
of
pretty

's
dread
of
death
---
which
,

,
I

<EOS>
her

---
<EOS>
and
I
had

,
before
Peggotty
came

,
even
to
think
more

of
the

:
as

,
and

of

.
 
<EOS>
Peggotty
took

in

,
and
blessed

over

again
for
being
such

her
<EOS>
(
that

)
in

.
 
<EOS>
She
then
entreated
me
to
come
upstairs
,
sobbing
that
Mr
Barkis
had
always
liked
me
and
admired

;
that
he
had
often

of
me
,
before
he

;
and
that
she
believed
,
in
case

,
he
would

at
sight

,
if

.
   
<EOS>
The

of
his
ever
doing
so
,
appeared

me
,
when
I

,
to
be

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
lying
with
his

of

,
in

,
half

on
the
box
which
had
cost

so
much

and

.
 
<EOS>
I
learned
,
that
,
when
he
was
past
creeping
out
of
bed
to
open

,
and
past
assuring
himself
of
its

by

of
the

rod
I
had
seen

use
,
he
had
required
to
have

placed
on
the
chair
at
the
bed

,
where
he
had
ever
since

,
night

.
 
<EOS>
His
arm
lay
on
it
now
.
 
<EOS>
Time
and
the
world
were
slipping
from
beneath
him
,
but
the
box
was
there
;
and
the
last
words
he
had
uttered
were
(
in
an

)
<EOS>
"
Old
clothes
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Barkis
,
my
dear
!
"
said
Peggotty
,
almost

:
bending
over

,
while
her
brother
<EOS>
and

at

bed
's

.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's

boy
---
my

,
Master
Davy
,
who
brought
us
together
,
Barkis
!
 
<EOS>
That
you
sent
messages
by
,
you

!
 
<EOS>
Wo
n't

speak
to
Master
Davy
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
as
mute
and
senseless
as
the
box
,
from
which
his
form
derived
the
only

.
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
going
out
with
the
tide
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
to

,
behind

.
   
<EOS>
My

were
dim
and
so

Mr
Peggotty
's
;
but
I
repeated
in

,
"
With
the

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
People
ca
n't
die
,
along
the
coast
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,
"
except
when
the
tide
's
pretty
nigh

.
 
<EOS>
They
ca
n't
be
born
,
unless
it
's
pretty
nigh
in
---
not
properly

,
till
flood
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
a
going
out
with
the
tide
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
ebb
at
half
-
arter
three
,
slack
water
half
an
hour
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
lives
till
it
turns
,
he
'll
hold
his
own
till
past
the

,
and
go
out

next

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
We
remained
there
,

,
a

---

.
 
<EOS>
What
mysterious
influence
my
presence
had
upon
him
in
that
state
of
his
senses
,
I
shall
not

to
say
;
but
when
he
at
last
began
to
wander
feebly
,
it
is
certain
he
was
muttering
about
driving
me
to
school
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
coming
to
himself
,
"
said
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
touched
me
,
and
whispered
with
much
awe
and
reverence
.
<EOS>
"
They
are
both
a
-
going
out
fast
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Barkis
,
my
dear
!
"
said
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
C
P
Barkis
,
"
he
cried
faintly
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
better
woman
anywhere
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Look
!
 
<EOS>
Here
's
Master
Davy
!
"
said
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
For
he
now
opened
his
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
on
the
point
of
asking
him
if
he
knew
me
,
when
he
tried
to
stretch
out
his
arm
,
and
said
to
me
,
distinctly
,
with
a
pleasant
smile
:
   
<EOS>
"
Barkis
is
willin
'
!
"
   
<EOS>
And
,
it
being
low
water
,
he
went
out
with
the
tide
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
31
.
<EOS>
A
greater
loss
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
difficult
for
me
,
on
Peggotty
's
solicitation
,
to
resolve
to
stay
where
I
was
,
until
after
the
remains
of
the
poor
carrier
should
have
made
their
last
journey
to
Blunderstone
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
long
ago
bought
,
out
of
her
own
savings
,
a
little
piece
of
ground
in
our
old
churchyard
near
the
grave
of
"
her
sweet
girl
"
,
as
she
always
called
my
mother
;
and
there
they
were
to
rest
.
   
<EOS>
In
keeping
Peggotty
company
,
and
doing
all
I
could
for
her
(
little
enough
at
the
utmost
)
,
I
was
as
grateful
<EOS>
,
I
rejoice
to
think
,
as
even
now
I
could
wish
myself
to
have
been
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
afraid
I
had
a
supreme
satisfaction
,
of
a
personal
and
professional
nature
,
in
taking
charge
of
Mr
Barkis
's
will
,
and
expounding
its
contents
.
   
<EOS>
I
may
claim
the
merit
of
having
originated
the
suggestion
that
the
will
should
be
looked
for
in
the
box
.
 
<EOS>
After
some
search
,
it
was
found
in
the
box
,
at
the
bottom
of
a
horse
's
nose
-
bag
;
wherein
(
besides
hay
)
there
was
discovered
an
old
gold
watch
,
with
chain
and
seals
,
which
Mr
Barkis
had
worn
on
his
wedding
-
day
,
and
which
had
never
been
seen
before
or
since
;
a
silver
tobacco
-
stopper
,
in
the
form
of
a
leg
;
an
imitation
lemon
,
full
of
minute
cups
and
saucers
,
which
I
have
some
idea
<EOS>
Mr
Barkis
must
have
purchased
to
present
to
me
when
I
was
a
child
,
and
afterwards
found
himself
unable
to
part
with
;
<EOS>
eighty
-
seven
guineas
and
a
half
,
in
guineas
and
half
-
guineas
;
two
hundred
and
ten
pounds
,
in
perfectly
clean
Bank
notes
;
certain
receipts
for
Bank
of
England
stock
;
an
old
horseshoe
,
a
bad
shilling
,
a
piece
of
camphor
,
and
an
oyster
-
shell
.
<EOS>
From
the
circumstance
of
the
latter
article
having
been
much
polished
,
and
displaying
prismatic
colours
on
the
inside
,
I
conclude
that
Mr
Barkis
had
some
general
ideas
about
pearls
,
which
never
resolved
themselves
into
anything
definite
.
   
<EOS>
For
years
and
years
,
Mr
Barkis
had
carried
this
box
,
on
all
his
journeys
,
every
day
.
 
<EOS>
That
it
might
the
better
escape
notice
,
he
had
invented
a
fiction
that
it
belonged
to
"
Mr
Blackboy
"
,
and
was
"
to
be
left
with
Barkis
till
called
for
"
;
a
fable
he
had
elaborately
written
on
the
lid
,
in
characters
now
scarcely
legible
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
hoarded
,
all
these
years
,
I
found
,
to
good
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
His
property
in
money
amounted
to
nearly
three
thousand
pounds
.
 
<EOS>
Of
this
he
bequeathed
the
interest
of
one
thousand
to
Mr
Peggotty
for
his
life
;
on
his
decease
,
the
principal
to
be
equally
divided
between
Peggotty
,
little
Emily
,
and
me
,
or
the
survivor
or
survivors
of
us
,
share
and
share
alike
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
rest
he
died
possessed
of
<EOS>
,
he
bequeathed
to
Peggotty
;
whom
he
left
residuary
legatee
,
and
sole
executrix
of
that
his
last
will
and
testament
.
   
<EOS>
I
felt
myself
quite
a
proctor
when
I
read
this
document
aloud
with
all
possible
ceremony
,
and
set
forth
its
provisions
,
any
number
of
times
,
to
those
whom
they
concerned
.
 
<EOS>
I
began
to
think
there
was
more
in
the
Commons
than
I
had
supposed
.
 
<EOS>
I
examined
the
will
with
the
deepest
attention
,
pronounced
it
perfectly
formal
in
all
respects
,
made
a
pencil
-
mark
or
so
in
the
margin
,
and
thought
it
rather
extraordinary
that
I
knew
so
much
.
   
<EOS>
In
this
abstruse
pursuit
;
in
making
an
account
for
Peggotty
,
of
all
the
property
into
which
she
had
come
;
in
arranging
all
the

in
an
orderly

;
and
in
being
her

and

on
every
point
,
to
our
joint

;
I
passed
the
week
before
the
funeral
.
<EOS>
I
did
not
see
little
Emily
in
that
interval
,
but
they
told
me
she
was
to
be
quietly
married
in
a
fortnight
.
   
<EOS>
I
did
not
attend
the
funeral
in
character
,
if
I
may
venture
to
say
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
mean
I
was
not
dressed
up
in
a
black
coat
and
a
streamer
,
to
frighten
the
birds
;
but
I
walked
over
to
Blunderstone
early
in
the
morning
,
and
was
in
the
churchyard
when
it
came
,
attended
only
by
Peggotty
and
her
brother
.
 
<EOS>
The
mad
gentleman
looked
on
,
out
of
my
little
window
;
Mr
Chillip
's
baby
wagged
its
heavy
head
,
and
rolled
its
goggle
eyes
,
at
the
clergyman
,
over
its
nurse
's
shoulder
;
Mr
Omer
breathed
short
in
the
background
;
no
one
else
was
there
;
and
it
was
very
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
We
walked
about
the
churchyard
for
an
hour
,
after
all
was
over
;
and
pulled
some
young
leaves
from
the
tree
above
my
mother
's
grave
.
   
<EOS>
A
dread
falls
on
me
here
.
 
<EOS>
A
cloud
is
lowering
on
the
distant
town
,
towards
which
I
retraced
my
solitary
steps
.
 
<EOS>
I
fear
to
approach
it
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
bear
to
think
of
what
did
come
,
upon
that
memorable
night
;
of
what
must
come
again
,
if
I
go
on
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
no
worse
,
because
I
write
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
no
better
,
if
I
stopped
my
most
unwilling
hand
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
done
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
can
undo
it
;
nothing
can
make
it
otherwise
than
as
it
was
.
   
<EOS>
My
old
nurse
was
to
go
to
London
with
me
next
day
,
on
the
business
of
the
will
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Emily
was
passing
that
day
at
Mr
Omer
's
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
all
to
meet
in
the
old
boathouse
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
Ham
would
bring
Emily
at
the
usual
hour
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
walk
back
at
my
leisure
.
 
<EOS>
The
brother
and
sister
would
return
as
they
had
come
,
and
be
expecting
us
,
when
the
day
closed
in
,
at
the
fireside
.
   
<EOS>
I
parted
from
them
at
the
wicket
-
gate
,
where
visionary
Strap
had
rested
with
Roderick
Random
's
knapsack
in
the
days
of
yore
;
and
,
instead
of
going
straight
back
,
walked
a
little
distance
on
the
road
to
Lowestoft
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
turned
,
and
walked
back
towards
Yarmouth
.
 
<EOS>
I
stayed
to
dine
at
a
decent
alehouse
,
some
mile
or
two
from
the
Ferry
I
have
mentioned
before
;
and
thus
the
day
wore
away
,
and
it
was
evening
when
I
reached
it
.
 
<EOS>
Rain
was
falling
heavily
by
that
time
,
and
it
was
a
wild
night
;
but
there
was
a
moon
behind
the
clouds
,
and
it
was
not
dark
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
soon
within
sight
of
Mr
Peggotty
's
house
,
and
of
the
light
within
it
shining
through

window
.
 
<EOS>
A
little
floundering
across
the
sand
,
which
was
heavy
,
brought
me
to
the
door
,
and
I
went
in
.
   
<EOS>
It
looked
very
comfortable
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
had
smoked
his
evening
pipe
and
there
were
preparations
for
some
supper
by
and
by
.
<EOS>
The
fire
was
bright
,
the
ashes
were
thrown
up
,
the
locker
was
ready
for
little
Emily
in
her
old
place
.
 
<EOS>
In
her
own
old
place
sat
Peggotty
,
once
more
,
looking
(
but
for
her

)
as
if

.
 
<EOS>
She
had
fallen
back
,
already
,
on
the
society
of
the
work
-

Paul
's
upon

,
the
yard
-

in
the

,
and
the
bit

wax
-

;
and
there

all
were
,
just

never

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Gummidge
appeared
to
be
fretting
a
little
,
in
her
old
corner
;
and
consequently
looked

natural
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
first
of
the
lot
,
Mas'r
Davy
!
"
said
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
"
Doen't
keep
in
that
coat
,
sir
,
if
it
's
wet
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
quite
dry
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
'
tis
!
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
As

!
<EOS>
Sit

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
ai

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

,

Peggotty
<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
Well
,

!
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
,

!
"

,

,
and

in

,
and

;
"
there
's

woman

,

---

---
that
need

!
 
<EOS>
She
done
her
dooty
by
the
departed
,
and
the
departed
know'd
it
;
and
the
departed
done
what

,

what
was
right

the

;
---

---

<EOS>
---

's

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs

.
   
<EOS>
"
Cheer

,

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
(
But

,

.
)
<EOS>
"
Doen't

!
 
<EOS>
Cheer

,

,
on'y

,

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothink

to

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"

Peggotty
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,

,
Dan'l
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ai
n't
a

to
live
with

as
has
had

.
 
<EOS>
Thinks
go
too
contrary
with

.
<EOS>
I
had

be

riddance
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
how
should
I
ever
spend
it

you
?
"

,
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
a
talking
on
?
<EOS>
Doen't
<EOS>
I
want
you
more
now
,
than
ever
I
did
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know'd
<EOS>
I
was
never
wanted
before
!
"
<EOS>

Mrs
Gummidge
,
with

,
"
and
now
I
'm
told

!
 
<EOS>
How
could
I
expect
to
be
wanted
,
being
so
lone
and

,
and
so
contrary
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
seemed
very
much
shocked
at
himself
for
having
made
a
speech
capable
of
this
unfeeling
construction
,
but
was
prevented
from

,
by
Peggotty
's

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
After

at
Mrs
Gummidge
for
some

,
in
sore

of
mind
,
he
glanced
at
the
Dutch
clock
,
rose
,
snuffed
the
candle
,
and
put
it
in
the
window
.
   
<EOS>
"
Theer
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,
cheerily
.
<EOS>
"
Theer
we
are
,
Missis
Gummidge
!
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Gummidge
slightly
groaned
.
 
<EOS>
"
Lighted
up
,
accordin
'
to
custom
!
 
<EOS>
You
're
a
wonderin
'
<EOS>
what
that
's
fur
,

!
 
<EOS>
Well
,

's
fur
our
little
Em'ly
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
,
the
path
ai
n't
over
light
or

arter
dark
;
and
when
I
'm
here
at
the
hour
as
she
's
a
comin
'
<EOS>
home
,
I
puts
the
light
in
the
winder
.
 
<EOS>
That
,
you
see
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,
bending

with

,
"
meets

.
<EOS>
She

,
says
Em'ly
,
"
Theer
's
home
!
"
<EOS>
she

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

Em'ly
,
"
My
uncle
's
theer
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Fur
if
I
ai
n't
theer
,
I
never
have
no
light
showed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
baby
!
"
<EOS>
said
Peggotty
;
<EOS>
very
fond
of
him
for
it
,
if
she
thought

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
returned
Mr
Peggotty
,

,
and

up
and
down
them
in
his
comfortable

,
as

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
doen't
know
<EOS>
but
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
Not
,
you
see
,
to
look

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
azackly
,
"
observed
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

Peggotty
,
"
not
to
look
at
,
but
to
---
to
consider
on
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
doen't

,

!
 
<EOS>
Now

.
 
<EOS>
When

a
looking

about
that
theer
pritty
house
of

Em'ly
's
,
I
'm
---
<EOS>
I
'm
Gormed
,
"

Peggotty
,
with

---
"
theer
!
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
say
more
---
<EOS>
if
I
doen't
feel
as
if
the
littlest
things
was
her
,

.
 
<EOS>
I
takes

up
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
So
'

<EOS>
I

on

<EOS>
rough

---

.
 
<EOS>
There

fur
<EOS>
you
,

great

Porkypine
!
"

Peggotty
,

.
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
and

both

,
but

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
my
opinion
,
you

,
"

Peggotty
,

,

"
as
this
is
along
of
my

,

was
Turks
,

,

,

forinners
---

,

;
and

<EOS>
doen't

!
<EOS>
---

.
 
<EOS>
I
've

into
the

,

.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
this
here
candle
,

"

,

"
I
know
wery
well
<EOS>
that
arter
<EOS>
she
's
married

gone
<EOS>
,

theer
,

<EOS>
I

'm

o
'

(
and

,

arts
,

)
<EOS>
and

ai

<EOS>

ai

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
THERE
'S

,
"

,

"

<EOS>
Why

"
She
's

!
 
<EOS>
Em'ly

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
THERE
'S

,

Sea

!
<EOS>
Right

,
"

,

;
"
fur
here

!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
only
Ham
.
 
<EOS>
The
night
should

turned
more

since
I
came
in
,
for
he
had
a
large
sou'wester
hat

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Wheer
's
Em'ly
?
"
said
Mr

.
   
<EOS>
Ham

,
as
if

were
outside
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
took
the
light
from

,
trimmed

,
put
it
on
the

,
and
was

,
when
Ham
,
who
had

,
said
:
   
"
Mas'r
Davy
,
will
you
come
out
a

,
and
see
what
Em'ly
and
me
has
got
to
show

?
"
   
<EOS>
We
went
out
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
passed
him
at
the
door
,
I
saw
,
to

and

,
that
he
was

.
 
<EOS>
He
pushed
me
hastily
into
the

,
and
closed

upon

.
 
<EOS>
Only
upon
us
two
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ham
!
<EOS>
what
's
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mas'r
Davy
!
---
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
for
his
broken
heart
,
how
dreadfully
he
wept
!
   
<EOS>
I
was
paralysed
by
the

of
such

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
I
thought
,
or
what
I
dreaded
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
only
look

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ham
!
 
<EOS>
Poor
good
fellow
!
 
<EOS>
For
Heaven
's

,
tell

what
's
the

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
love
,
Mas'r
Davy
---
the
pride
and

of
my
art
---
her
that
I
'd
have
died
for
,
and
would

---
she
's
gone
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Gone
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Em'ly
's
run
away
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
Mas'r
Davy
,
think
HOW
<EOS>
she
's
run
away
,
when
I
pray
my
good
and

God
to
kill
her
(
her
<EOS>
that
is
so
dear
above
all

)
<EOS>
sooner
than

her
come
to

!
"
   
<EOS>
The
face
he
turned
up
to
the

,
the

,

,
remain

,
in

,
to
this

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
always
night
there
,
and
he
is

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
scholar
,
"
he
said
,
hurriedly
,
"
and
know
what
's
right

.
 
<EOS>
What
