to
say
,
indoors
?
 
<EOS>
How
am
I
ever
to
break
it
to
him
,
Mas'r
Davy
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
saw
the
door
move
,
and
instinctively
tried
to
hold
the
latch
on
the
outside
,
to
gain
a
moment
's

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
too
late
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
thrust
forth
his
face
;
and
never
could
I
forget
the
change
that
came
upon

when

,
if

.
   
<EOS>
I
remember
a

,
and
the

,
and

all

in

;
I
with

,

Ham
had

;
Mr
Peggotty
,

,

,

,

(

,

)
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Read

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Slow
,

.
<EOS>
I
doen't

.
"
   
<EOS>
In

,

,

:
   
"
<EOS>
"
When
you
,

,

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
"
   
"
I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
 
<EOS>
Em'ly
fur
away
.
<EOS>
Well
!
"
   
"
"
When
I

my
dear

---
my

---
oh
,
my
dear

!
---
in
the

,
"
"
 
the

"
"
---

,

.
<EOS>
This

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

.
 
<EOS>
If

,
that

,

,

!
<EOS>
I

to

!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

in

I
am
so

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

's

,

uncle

I
never

half

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
do

how

and

<EOS>
you

---
<EOS>
do

---
but
try

if
I
died
when
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Pray
Heaven

I
am

,

!
 
<EOS>
Tell

I
never

half
<EOS>
so
dear
.
 
<EOS>
Be
his
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
Love
some

girl
that
will

what
I
was
once
to
uncle
,
and
be
true

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
God

!
 
<EOS>
I
'll

all
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

back

,

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
My

love
to
uncle
.
<EOS>
My
last
tears
,
and
my
last
thanks
,
for
uncle
!
"
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
That
was
all
.
   
<EOS>
He
stood
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
At

I
ventured
to

,
and
to

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
replied
,
"
I
thankee
,
sir
,
I
thankee
!
"
without
moving
.
   
<EOS>
Ham
spoke
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
was
so
far
sensible
of
HIS
affliction
,
that
he
wrung
his
hand
;
but
,
otherwise
,
he
remained
in
the
same
state
,
and
no
one
dared
to
disturb

.
   
<EOS>
Slowly
,
at
last
,
he
moved

from
my

,
as
if
he
were

from

,
and
cast
them
round
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
said
,
in
a
low
voice
:
   
<EOS>
"
Who
's
the
man
?
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
know
his
name
.
"
   
<EOS>
Ham
glanced
at
me
,
and
suddenly
I
felt
a
shock
that
struck
me
back
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
man
suspected
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
is
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mas'r
Davy
!
"
<EOS>
implored
Ham
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
out
a
bit
,
and
let
me
tell
him
what
I
must
.
 
<EOS>
You
<EOS>
doen't
ought
to
hear
it
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
the
shock
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
sank
down
in
a
chair
,
and
tried
to
utter
some
reply
;
but
my
tongue
was
fettered
,
and
my
sight
was
weak
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
know
his
name
!
<EOS>
"
I
heard
said
once
more
.
   
<EOS>
"
For
some
time
past
,
"
Ham
faltered
,
"
there
's
been
a
servant
about
here
,
at
odd
times
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
been
a
gen'lm'n
too
.
 
<EOS>
Both
of
'em
belonged
to
one
another
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
stood
fixed
as
before
,
but
now
looking
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
servant
,
"
pursued
Ham
,
"
was
seen
along
with
---
our
poor
girl
---
last
night
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
been
in
hiding
about
here
,
this
week
or
over
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
thought
to
have
gone
,
but
he
was
hiding
.
 
<EOS>
Doen't
stay
,
Mas'r
Davy
,
doen't
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
Peggotty
's
arm
round
my
neck
,
but
I
could
not
have
moved
if
the
house
had
been
about
to
fall
upon
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
strange
chay
and
hosses
was
outside
town
,
this
morning
,
on
the
Norwich
road
,
<EOS>
a'most
afore
the
day
broke
,
"
Ham
went
on
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
servant
went
to
it
,
and
come
from
it
,
and
went
to
it
again
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
went
to
it
again
,
Em'ly
was
nigh
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
t'other
was
inside
.
<EOS>
He
's
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
For
the
Lord
's
love
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,
falling
back
,
and
putting
out
his
hand
,
as
if
to
keep
off
what
he
dreaded
.
 
<EOS>
"
Doen't
tell
me
his
name
's
Steerforth
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mas'r
Davy
,
"
exclaimed
Ham
,
in
a
broken
voice
,
"
it
ai
n't
no
fault
of
yourn
---
and
I
am
far
from
laying
of
it
to
you
---
but
his
name
is
Steerforth
,
and
he
's
a
damned
villain
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
uttered
no
cry
,
and
shed
no
tear
,
and
moved
no
more
,
until
he
seemed
to
wake
again
,
all
at
once
,
and
pulled
down
his
rough
coat
from
its
peg
in
a
corner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bear
a
hand
with
this
!
 
<EOS>
I
'm
struck
of
a
heap
,
and
ca
n't
do
it
,
"
he
said
,
impatiently
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bear
a
hand
and
help
me
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
"
<EOS>
when

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Ham

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
Chapter
32
.
<EOS>
The
beginning
of
a
long
journey
 
<EOS>
What
is
natural
in
me
,
is
natural
in
many
other
men
,
I
infer
,
and
so
I
am
not
afraid
to
write
that
I
never
had
loved
Steerforth
better
than
when
the
ties
that
bound
me
to
him
were
broken
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
keen

of
the
discovery
of
his
unworthiness
,
I
thought
more
of
all
that
was
brilliant
in
him
,
I

all

was
good

him
,
I
did
more

to
the

that
might

and

,
than
ever

had
done
in

.
 
<EOS>
Deeply

my
own
unconscious

in
his

an
honest
home
,
I
believed
that
if

been

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

loved
him
so
well

---
though
he
fascinated
me
no

---
I
should

held
in
so

the

,
that
I

<EOS>
That

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,
that
all

.
 
<EOS>
What

of

,
<EOS>

but

,

was

.
   
<EOS>
Yes
,
Steerforth
,

!
<EOS>
My

you
at

Throne
;
but
my
angry

never

,

!
   
<EOS>
The

had

;
insomuch

.
 
<EOS>
Many

hard
upon
her
,

,

second

.
 
<EOS>
Among

a

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

early
,

<EOS>
It

<EOS>
It

,

<EOS>

.

"
<EOS>

;

.

<EOS>
"

.

"

Mr

<EOS>
The

.
   
<EOS>
We

old

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Gummidge
,
no

her

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

Mr
Peggotty
's

,
and
placed
his

for

,
and
spoke
so
comfortably
and

,
that
I
hardly
knew

.
   
<EOS>
"
Dan'l
,
my

,
"
said

,
"
you

,
and

,

'll

.
 
<EOS>
Try
,
that
's

!
 
<EOS>
An
if
I

with

,
"
she

her

,
"

,

,

I
wo
n't
.
"
   
<EOS>
When

.
 
<EOS>

,

:
   
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

Mr
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
Dan'l
<EOS>
,
"
she
returned
,
"
I
sha
n't
be
that
.
 
<EOS>
Doen't
you
mind
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
have
enough
to
do
to
keep
a
Beein
for
you
"
<EOS>
(
Mrs
Gummidge
meant
a
home
)
,
"
again
you
come
back
---
to
keep
a
Beein
here
for
any
that
may
hap
to
come
back
,
Dan'l
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
fine
time
,
I
shall
set
outside
the
door
as
I
used
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
If
any
should
come
nigh
,
they
shall
see
the
old
widder
woman
true
to
'em
,
a
long
way
off
.
"
   
<EOS>
What
a
change
in
Mrs
Gummidge
in
a
little
time
!
 
<EOS>
She
was
another
woman
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
so
devoted
,
she
had
such
a
quick
perception
of
what
it
would
be
well
to
say
,
and
what
it
would
be
well
to
leave
unsaid
;
she
was
so
forgetful
of
herself
,
and
so
regardful
of
the
sorrow
about
her
,
that
I
held
her
in
a
sort
of
veneration
.
 
<EOS>
The
work
she
did
that
day
!
 
<EOS>
There
were
many
things
to
be
brought
up
from
the
beach
and
stored
in
the
outhouse
---
as
oars
,
nets
,
sails
,
cordage
,
spars
,
lobster
-
pots
,
bags
of
ballast
,
and
the
like
;
and
though
there
was
abundance
of
assistance
rendered
,
there
being
not
a
pair
of
working
hands
on
all
that
shore
but
would
have
laboured
hard
for
Mr
Peggotty
,
and
been
well
paid
in
being
asked
to
do
it
,
yet
she
persisted
,
all
day
long
,
in
toiling
under
weights
that
she
was
quite
unequal
to
,
and
fagging
to
and
fro
on
all
sorts
of
unnecessary
errands
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
deploring
her
misfortunes
,
she
appeared
to
have
entirely
lost
the
recollection
of
ever
having
had
any
.
 
<EOS>
She
preserved
an
equable
cheerfulness
in
the
midst
of
her
sympathy
,
which
was
not
the
least
astonishing
part
of
the
change
that
had
come
over
her
.
 
<EOS>
Querulousness
was
out
of
the
question
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
not
even
observe
her
voice
to
falter
,
or
a
tear
to
escape
from
her
eyes
,
the
whole
day
through
,
until
twilight
;
when
she
and
I
and
Mr
Peggotty
being
alone
together
,
and
he
having
fallen
asleep
in
perfect
exhaustion
,
she
broke
into
a
half
-
suppressed
fit
of
sobbing
and
crying
,
and
taking
me
to
the
door
,
said
,
"
Ever
bless
you
,
Mas'r
Davy
<EOS>
,
be
a
friend
to
him
,
poor
dear
!
"
<EOS>
Then
,
she
immediately
ran
out
of
the
house
to
wash
her
face
,
in
order
that
she
might
sit
quietly
beside
him
,
and
be
found
at
work
there
,
when
he
should
awake
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
I
left
her
,
when
I
went
away
at
night
,
the
prop
and
staff
of
Mr
Peggotty
's
affliction
;
and
I
could
not
meditate
enough
upon
the
lesson
that
I
read
in
Mrs
Gummidge
,
and
the
new
experience
she
unfolded
to
me
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
between
nine
and
ten
o'clock
<EOS>
when
,
strolling
in
a
melancholy
manner
through
the
town
,
I
stopped
at
Mr
Omer
's
door
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Omer
had
taken
it
so
much
to
heart
,
his
daughter
told
me
,
that
he
had
been
very
low
and
poorly
all
day
,
and
had
gone
to
bed
without
his
pipe
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
deceitful
,
bad
-
hearted
girl
,
"
said
Mrs
Joram
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
was
no
good
in
her
,
ever
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
say
so
,
"
I
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
think
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
do
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs
Joram
,
angrily
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
<EOS>
I.
   
Mrs
Joram
tossed
her
head
,
endeavouring
to
be
very
stern
and
cross
;
but
she
could
not
command
her
softer
self
,
and
began
to
cry
.
<EOS>
I
was
young
,
to
be
sure
;
but
I
thought
much
the
better
of
her
for
this
sympathy
,
and
fancied
it
became
her
,
as
a
virtuous
wife
and
mother
,
very
well
indeed
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
will
she
ever
do
!
"
<EOS>
sobbed
Minnie
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
will
she
go
!
 
<EOS>
What
will
become
of
her
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
how
could
she
be
so
cruel
,
to
herself
and
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
remembered
the
time
when
Minnie
was
a
young
and
pretty
girl
;
and
I
was
glad
she
remembered
it
too
,
so
feelingly
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
little
Minnie
,
"
said
Mrs
Joram
,
"
has
only
just
now
been
got
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
Even
in
her
sleep
she
is
sobbing
for
Em'ly
.
 
<EOS>
All
day
long
,
little
Minnie
has
cried
for
her
,
and
asked
me
,
over
and
over
again
,
whether
Em'ly
was
wicked
?
 
<EOS>
What
can
I
say
to
her
,
when
Em'ly
tied
a
ribbon
off
her
own
neck
round
little
Minnie
's
the
last
night
she
was
here
,
and
laid
her
head
down
on
the
pillow
beside
her
till
she
was
fast
asleep
!
 
<EOS>
The
ribbon
's
round
my
little
Minnie
's
neck
now
.
<EOS>
It
ought
not
to
be
,
perhaps
,
but
what
can
I
do
?
 
<EOS>
Em'ly
is
very
bad
,
but
they
were
fond
of
one
another
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
child
knows
nothing
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Joram
was
so
unhappy
that
her
husband
came
out
to
take
care
of
her
.
 
<EOS>
Leaving
them
together
,
I
went
home
to
Peggotty
's
;
more
melancholy
myself
,
if
possible
,
than
I
had
been
yet
.
   
<EOS>
That
good
creature
---
<EOS>
I
mean
Peggotty
---
all
<EOS>
untired
by
her
late
anxieties
and
sleepless
nights
,
was
at
her
brother
's
,
where
she
meant
to
stay
till
morning
.
 
<EOS>
An
old
woman
,
who
had
been
employed
about
the
house
for
some
weeks
past
,
while
Peggotty
had
been
unable
to
attend
to
it
,
was
the
house
's
only
other
occupant
besides
myself
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
had
no
occasion
for
her
services
,
I
sent
her
to
bed
,
by
no
means
against
her
will
,
and
sat
down
before
the
kitchen
fire
a
little
while
,
to
think
about
all
this
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
blending
it
with
the
deathbed
of
the
late
Mr
Barkis
,
and
was
driving
out
with
the
tide
towards
the
distance
at
which
Ham
had
looked
so
singularly
in
the
morning
,
when
I
was
recalled
from
my
wanderings
by
a
knock
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
knocker
upon
the
door
,
but
it
was
not
that
which
made
the
sound
.
 
<EOS>
The
tap
was
from
a
hand
,
and
low
down
upon
the
door
,
as
if
it
were
given
by
a
child
.
   
<EOS>
It
made
me
start
as
much
as
if
it
had
been
the
knock
of
a
footman
to
a
person
of
distinction
.
 
<EOS>
I
opened
the
door
;
and
at
first
looked
down
,
to
my
amazement
,
on
nothing
but
a
great
umbrella
that
appeared
to
be
walking
about
of
itself
.
 
<EOS>
But
presently
I
discovered
underneath
it
,
Miss
Mowcher
.
   
<EOS>
I
might
not
have
been
prepared
to
give
the
little
creature
a
very
kind
reception
,
if
,
on
her
removing
the
umbrella
,
which
her
utmost
efforts
were
unable
to
shut
up
,
she
had
shown
me
the
"
volatile
"
expression
of
face
which
had
made
so
great
an
impression
on
me
at
our
first
and
last
meeting
.
 
<EOS>
But
her
face
,
as
she
turned
it
up
to
mine
,
was
so
earnest
;
and
when
I
relieved
her
of
the
umbrella
<EOS>
(
which
would
have
been
an
inconvenient
one
for
the
Irish
Giant
)
,
she
wrung
her
little
hands
in
such
an
afflicted
manner
;
that
I
rather
inclined
towards
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Mowcher
!
<EOS>
"
said
I
,
after
glancing
up
and
down
the
empty
street
,
without
distinctly
knowing
what
I
expected
to
see
besides
;
"
how
do
you
come
here
?
 
<EOS>
What
is
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
She
motioned
to
me
with
her
short
right
arm
,
to
shut
the
umbrella
for
her
;
and
passing
me
hurriedly
,
went
into
the
kitchen
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
had
closed
the
door
,
and
followed
,
with
the
umbrella
in
my
hand
,
I
found
her
sitting
on
the
corner
of
the
fender
<EOS>
---
it
was
a
low
iron
one
,
with
two
flat
bars
at
top
to
stand
plates
upon
---
in
the
shadow
of
the
boiler
,
swaying
herself
backwards
and
forwards
,
and
chafing
her
hands
upon
her
knees
like
a
person
in
pain
.
   
<EOS>
Quite
alarmed
at
being
the
only
recipient
of
this
untimely
visit
,
and
the
only
spectator
of
this
portentous
behaviour
<EOS>
,
I
exclaimed
again
,
"
Pray
tell
me
,
Miss
Mowcher
,
what
is
the
matter
!
<EOS>
are
you
ill
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
young
soul
,
"
returned
Miss
Mowcher
,
squeezing
her
hands
upon
her
heart
one
over
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
ill
here
,
I
am
very
ill
.
<EOS>
To
think
that
it
should
come
to
this
,
when
I
might
have
known
it
and
perhaps
prevented
it
,
if
I
had
n't
been
a
thoughtless
fool
!
"
   
<EOS>
Again
her
large
bonnet
(
very
disproportionate
to
the
figure
)
went
backwards
and
forwards
,
in
her
swaying
of
her
little
body
to
and
fro
;
while
a
most
gigantic
bonnet
rocked
,
in
unison
with
it
,
upon
the
wall
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
surprised
,
"
I
began
,
"
to
see
you
so
distressed
and
serious
"
---
when
she
interrupted
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
it
's
always
so
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
all
surprised
,
these
inconsiderate
young
people
,
fairly
and
full
grown
,
to
see
any
natural
feeling
in
a
little
thing
like
me
!
 
<EOS>
They
make
a
plaything
of
me
,
use
me
for
their
amusement
,
throw
me
away
when
they
are
tired
,
and
wonder
that
I
feel
more
than
a
toy
horse
or
a
wooden
soldier
!
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
that
's
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
way
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
,
with
others
,
"
I
returned
,
"
but
I
do
assure
you
it
is
not
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
ought
not
to
be
at
all
surprised
to
see
you
as
you
are
now
:
<EOS>
I
know
so
little
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
,
without
consideration
,
what
I
thought
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
can
I
do
?
"
returned
the
little
woman
,
standing
up
,
and
holding
out
her
arms
to
show
herself
.
 
<EOS>
"
See
!
 
<EOS>
What
I
am
,
my
father
was
;
and
my
sister
is
;
and
my
brother
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
worked
for
sister
and
brother
these
many
years
---
<EOS>
hard
,
Mr
Copperfield
---
all
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
live
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
no
harm
.
 
<EOS>
If
there
are
people
so
unreflecting
or
so
cruel
,
as
to
make
a
jest
of
me
,
what
is
left
for
me
to
do
but
to
make
a
jest
of
myself
,
them
,
and
everything
?
 
<EOS>
If
I
do
so
,
for
the
time
,
whose
fault
is
that
?
 
<EOS>
Mine
?
"
   
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
Not
Miss
Mowcher
's
,
I
perceived
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
shown
myself
a
sensitive
dwarf
to
your
false
friend
,
"
pursued
the
little
woman
,
shaking
her
head
at
me
,
with
reproachful
earnestness
,
"
<EOS>
how
much
of
his
help
or
good
will
do
you
think
I
should
ever
have
had
?
 
<EOS>
If
little
Mowcher
(
who
had
no
hand
,
young
gentleman
,
in
the
making
of
herself
)
addressed
herself
to
him
,
or
the
like
of
him
,
because
of
her
misfortunes
,
when
do
you
suppose
her
small
voice
would
have
been
heard
?
 
<EOS>
Little
Mowcher
would
have
as
much
need
to
live
,
if
she
was
the
bitterest
and
dullest
of
pigmies
;
but
she
could
n't
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
She
might
whistle
for
her
bread
and
butter
till
she
died
of
Air
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Mowcher
sat
down
on
the
fender
again
,
and
took
out
her
handkerchief
,
and
wiped
her
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Be
thankful
for
me
,
if
you
have
a
kind
heart
,
as
I
think
you
have
,
"
she
said
,
"
that
while
I
know
well
what
I
am
,
I
can
be
cheerful
and
endure
it
all
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
thankful
for
myself
,
at
any
rate
,
that
I
can
find
my
tiny
way
through
the
world
,
without
being
beholden
to
anyone
;
and
that
in
return
for
all
that
is
thrown
at
me
,
in
folly
or
vanity
,
as
I
go
along
,
I
can
throw
bubbles
back
.
<EOS>
If
I
do
n't
brood
over
all
I
want
,
it
is
the
better
for
me
,
and
not
the
worse
for
anyone
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
am
a
plaything
for
you
giants
,
be
gentle
with
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Mowcher
replaced
her
handkerchief
in
her
pocket
,
looking
at
me
with
very
intent
expression
all
the
while
,
and
pursued
:
   
"
<EOS>
I
saw
you
in
the
street
just
now
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
suppose
I
am
not
able
to
walk
as
fast
as
you
,
with
my
short
legs
and
short
breath
,
and
I
could
n't
overtake
you
;
but
I
guessed
where
you
came
,
and
came
after
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
here
before
,
today
,
but
the
good
woman
was
n't
at
home
.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Therefore

<EOS>
When

.
 
<EOS>
We

of

,
over

,

.
 
<EOS>
When

had

,
I

at
an

,
and
took
my
fellow

travellers
home

tea
;
a

,
I
regret
to
state
,
which
did
not
meet
with
Mrs
Crupp
's

,
but
quite

.
 
<EOS>
I
ought
to

,

,
in

of
that

's

,
that
she

much

by
<EOS>
Peggotty
's
tucking

's

before

ten

in
the
place
,
and
setting

.
 
<EOS>
This
Mrs
Crupp
regarded
in
the
light
of
a

,
and
a

,
she
said
,
was
a
thing
she
never
allowed
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
had
made
a
communication
to
me
on

London
for
which
I

not

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
,
that
he
purposed
first
seeing
Mrs
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
felt
bound
to

him
in
this
,
and
also
to
mediate
between

;
with
the
view
of
sparing
the
mother
's
feelings
as
much

,
I
wrote

that

.
 
<EOS>
I
told

as
mildly
as
I
could
what
his
wrong
was
,
and
what
my
own
share
in
his
injury
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
he
was
a
man
in
very
common
life
,
but
of
a
most
gentle
and
upright
character
;
and
that
I
ventured
to
express
a
hope
that
she
would
not
refuse
to
see
him
in
his
heavy
trouble
.
<EOS>
I
mentioned
two
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
as
the
hour
of
our
coming
,
and
I
sent
the
letter
myself
by
the
first
coach
in
the
morning
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
appointed
time
,
we
stood
at
the
door
---
the
door
of
that
house
where
I
had
been
,
a
few
days
since
,
so
happy
:
where
my
youthful
confidence
and
warmth
of
heart
had
been
yielded
up
so
freely
:
which
was
closed
against
me
henceforth
:
which
was
now
a
waste
,
a
ruin
.
   
<EOS>
No
Littimer
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
The
pleasanter
face
which
had
replaced
his
,
on
the
occasion
of
my
last
visit
,
answered
to
our
summons
,
and
went
before
us
to
the
drawing
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Steerforth
was
sitting
there
.
<EOS>
Rosa
Dartle
glided
,
as
we
went
in
,
from
another
part
of
the
room
and
stood
behind
her
chair
.
   
<EOS>
I
saw
,
directly
,
in
his
mother
's
face
,
that
she
knew
from
himself
what
he
had
done
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
pale
;
and
bore
the
traces
of
deeper
emotion
than
my
letter
alone
,
weakened
by
the
doubts
her
fondness
would
have
raised
upon
it
,
would
have
been
likely
to
create
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
her
more
like
him
than
ever
I
had
thought
her
;
and
I
felt
,
rather
than
saw
,
that
the
resemblance
was
not
lost
on
my
companion
.
   
<EOS>
She
sat
upright
in
her
arm
-
chair
,
with
a
stately
,
immovable
,
passionless
air
,
that
it
seemed
as
if
nothing
could
disturb
.
 
<EOS>
She
looked
very
steadfastly
at
Mr
Peggotty
when
he
stood
before
her
;
and
he
looked
quite
as
steadfastly
at
her
.
 
<EOS>
Rosa
Dartle
's
keen
glance
comprehended
all
of
us
.
 
<EOS>
For
some
moments
not
a
word
was
spoken
.
   
<EOS>
She
motioned
to
Mr
Peggotty
to
be
seated
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
,
in
a
low
voice
,
"
I
should
n't
feel
it
nat'ral
,
ma'am
,
to
sit
down
in
this
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
'd
sooner
stand
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
And
this
was
succeeded
by
another
silence
,
which
she
broke
thus
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
,
with
deep
regret
,
what
has
brought
you
here
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
want
of
me
?
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
ask
me
to
do
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
put
his
hat
under
his
arm
,
and
feeling
in
his
breast
for
Emily
's
letter
,
took
it
out
,
unfolded
it
,
and
gave
it
to
her
.
"
<EOS>
Please
to
read
that
,
ma'am
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
my
niece
's
hand
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
read
it
,
in
the
same
stately
and
impassive
way
,
---
untouched
by
its
contents
,
as
far
as
I
could
see
,
---
and
returned
it
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Unless
he
brings
me
back
a
lady
,
"
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,
tracing
out
that
part
with
his
finger
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
come
to
know
,
ma'am
,
whether
he
will
keep
his
wured
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
she
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
impossible
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
disgrace
himself
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
not
fail
to
know
that
she
is
far
below
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Raise
her
up
!
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
uneducated
and
ignorant
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Maybe
she
's
not
;
maybe
she
is
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
not
,
ma'am
;
but
I
'm
no
judge
of
them
things
.
 
<EOS>
Teach
her
better
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Since
you
oblige
me
to
speak
more
plainly
,
which
I
am
very
unwilling
to
do
,
her
humble
connexions
would
render
such
a
thing
impossible
,
if
nothing
else
did
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hark
to
this
,
ma'am
,
"
he
returned
,
slowly
and
quietly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
what
it
is
to
love
your
child
.
 
<EOS>
So
do
I.
 
<EOS>
If
she
was
a
hundred
times
my
child
,
I
could
n't
love
her
more
.
 
<EOS>
You
<EOS>
doen't
know
what
it
is
to
lose
your
child
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
heaps
of
riches
in
the
wureld
would
be
nowt
to
me
(
if
they
was
mine
)
to
buy
her
back
!
<EOS>
But
,
save
her
from
this
disgrace
,
and
she
shall
never
be
disgraced
by
us
.
 
<EOS>
Not
one
of
us
that
she
's
growed
up
among
,
not
one
of
us
that
's
lived
along
with
her
and
had
her
for
their
all
in
all
<EOS>
,
these
many
year
,
will
ever
look
upon
her
pritty
face
again
.
 
<EOS>
We
'll
be
content
to
let
her
be
;
we
'll
be
content
to
think
of
her
,
far
off
,
as
if
she
was
underneath
another
sun
and
sky
;
we
'll
be
content
to
trust
her
to
her
husband
,
---
to
her
little
children
,
p'raps
,
---
and
bide
the
time
when
all
of
us
shall
be
alike
in
quality
afore
our
God
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
rugged
eloquence
with
which
he
spoke
,
was
not
devoid
of
all
effect
.
 
<EOS>
She
still
preserved
her
proud
manner
,
but
there
was
a
touch
of
softness
in
her
voice
,
as
she
answered
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
justify
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
I
make
no
counter
-
accusations
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
sorry
to
repeat
,
it
is
impossible
.
 
<EOS>
Such
a
marriage
would
irretrievably
blight
my
son
's
career
,
and
ruin
his
prospects
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
is
more
certain
than
that
it
never
can
take
place
,
and
never
will
.
 
<EOS>
If
there
is
any
other
compensation
---
"
   
"
I
am
looking
at
the
likeness
of
the
face
,
"
interrupted
Mr
Peggotty
,
with
a
steady
but
a
kindling
eye
,
"
that
has
looked
at
me
,
in
my
home
,
at
my
fireside
,
in
my
boat
---
<EOS>
wheer
not
?
 
<EOS>
---
smiling
and
friendly
,
when
it
was
so
treacherous
<EOS>
,
that
I
go
half
wild
when
I
think
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
likeness
of
that
face
do
n't
turn
to
burning
fire
,
at
the
thought
of
offering
money
to
me
for
my
child
's
blight
and
ruin
,
it
's
as
bad
.
 
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
doen't
know
,
being
a
lady
's
,
but
<EOS>
what
it
's
worse
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
changed
now
,
in
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
An
angry
flush
overspread
her
features
;
and
she
said
,
in
an
intolerant
manner
,
grasping
the
arm
-
chair
tightly
with
her
hands
:
   
<EOS>
"
What
compensation
can
you
make
to
ME
for
opening
such
a
pit
between
me
and
my
son
?
 
<EOS>
What
is
your
love
to
mine
?
 
<EOS>
What
is
your
separation
to
ours
?
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Dartle
softly
touched
her
,
and
bent
down
her
head
to
whisper
,
but
she
would
not
hear
a
word
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Rosa
,
not
a
word
!
 
<EOS>
Let
the
man
listen
to
what
I
say
!
 
<EOS>
My
son
,
who
has
been
the
object
of
my
life
,
to
whom
its
every
thought
has
been
devoted
,
whom
I
have
gratified
from
a
child
in
every
wish
,
from
whom
I
have
had
no
separate
existence
since
his
birth
,
---
to
take
up
in
a
moment
with
a
miserable
girl
,
and
avoid
me
!
 
<EOS>
To
repay
my
confidence
with
systematic
deception
,
for
her
sake
,
and
quit
me
for
her
!
 
<EOS>
To
set
this
wretched
fancy
,
against
his
mother
's
claims
upon
his
duty
,
love
,
respect
,
gratitude
<EOS>
---
claims
that
every
day
and
hour
of
his
life
should
have
strengthened
into
ties
that
nothing
could
be
proof
against
!
 
<EOS>
Is
this
no
injury
?
"
   
<EOS>
Again
Rosa
Dartle
tried
to
soothe
her
;
again
ineffectually
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
Rosa
,
not
a
word
!
 
<EOS>
If
he
can
stake
his
all
upon
the
lightest
object
,
I
can
stake
my
all
upon
a
greater
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
Let
him
go
where
he
will
,
with
the
means
that
my
love
has
secured
to
him
!
 
<EOS>
Does
he
think
to
reduce
me
by
long
absence
?
 
<EOS>
He
knows
his
mother
very
little
if
he
does
.
 
<EOS>
Let
him
put
away
his
whim
now
,
and
he
is
welcome
back
.
 
<EOS>
Let
him
not
put
her
away
now
,
and
he
never
shall
come
near
me
,
living
or
dying
,
while
I
can
raise
my
hand
to
make
a
sign
against
it
,
unless
,
being
rid
of
her
for
ever
,
he
comes
humbly
to
me
and
begs
for
my
forgiveness
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
my
right
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
acknowledgement
I
WILL
HAVE
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
separation
that
there
is
between
us
!
 
<EOS>
And
is
this
,
"
she
added
,
looking
at
her
visitor
with
the
proud
intolerant
air
with
which
she
had
begun
,
"
no
injury
?
"
   
<EOS>
While
I
heard
and
saw
the
mother
as
she
said
these
words
,
I
seemed
to
hear
and
see
the
son
,
defying
them
.
 
<EOS>
All
that
I
had
ever
seen
in
him
of
an
unyielding
,
wilful
spirit
,
I
saw
in
her
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
understanding
that
I
had
now
of
his
misdirected
energy
,
became
an
understanding
of
her
character
too
,
and
a
perception
that
it
was
,
in
its
strongest
springs
,
the
same
.
   
<EOS>
She
now
observed
to
me
,
aloud
,
resuming
her
former
restraint
,
that
it
was
useless
to
hear
more
,
or
to
say
more
,
and
that
she
begged
to
put
an
end
to
the
interview
.
 
<EOS>
She
rose
with
an
air
of
dignity
to
leave
the
room
,
when
Mr
Peggotty
signified
that
it
was

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Doen't
fear
me
being
any
hindrance
to
you
,
I
have
no
more
to
say
,
ma'am
,
"
he
remarked
,
as
he
moved

the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
come
beer
with
no
hope
,
and
I
take
away
no
hope
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
done
what
I
thowt
should
be
done
,
but
I
never
looked
fur
any
good
to
come
of
my
stan'ning
where
I
do
.
 
<EOS>
This
has
been
too
evil
<EOS>
a
house
fur
me
and
mine
<EOS>
,
fur
me
to
be
in
my
right
senses
and
expect
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
,
we
departed
;
leaving
her
standing
by
her
elbow
-
chair
,
a
picture
of
a
noble
presence
and
a
handsome
face
.
   
<EOS>
We
had
,
on
our
way
out
,
to
cross
a
paved
hall
,
with
glass
sides
and
roof
,
over
which
a
vine
was
trained
.
 
<EOS>
Its
leaves
and
shoots
were
green
then
,
and
the
day
being
sunny
,
a
pair
of
glass
doors
leading
to
the
garden
were
thrown
open
.
 
<EOS>
Rosa
Dartle
,
entering
this
way
with
a
noiseless
step
<EOS>
,
when
we
were
close
to
them
,
addressed
herself
to
me
:
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
well
,
"
she
said
,
"
indeed
,
to
bring
this
fellow
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
Such
a
concentration
of
rage
and
scorn
as
darkened
her
face
,
and
flashed
in
her
jet
-
black
eyes
<EOS>
,
I
could
not
have
thought
compressible
even
into
that
face
.
 
<EOS>
The
scar
made
by
the
hammer
was
,
as
usual
in
this
excited
state
of
her
features
,
strongly
marked
.
<EOS>
When
the
throbbing
I
had
seen
before
,
came
into
it
as
I
looked
at
her
,
she
absolutely
lifted
up
her
hand
,
and
struck
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
fellow
,
"
she
said
,
"
to
champion
and
bring
here
,
is
he
not
?
 
<EOS>
You
are
a
true
man
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Dartle
,
"
I
returned
,
"
you
are
surely
not
so
unjust
as
to
condemn
ME
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
bring
division
between
these
two
mad
creatures
?
<EOS>
"
she
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
know
that
they
are
both
mad
with
their
own
self
-
will
and
pride
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
my
doing
?
<EOS>
"
I
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
your
doing
!
"
<EOS>
she
retorted
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
bring
this
man
here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
deeply
-
injured
man
,
Miss
Dartle
,
"
I
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
not
know
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
James
Steerforth
,
"
she
said
,
with
her
hand
on
her
bosom
,
as
if
to
prevent
the
storm
that
was
raging
there
,
from
being
loud
,
"
has
a
false
,
corrupt
heart
,
and
is
a
traitor
.
 
<EOS>
But
what
need
I
know
or
care
about
this
fellow
,
and
his
common
niece
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Dartle
,
"
I
returned
,
"
you
deepen
the
injury
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
sufficient
already
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
only
say
,
at
parting
,
that
you
do
him
a
great
wrong
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
him
no
wrong
,
"
she
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
a
depraved
,
worthless
set
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
have
her
whipped
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
passed
on
,
without
a
word
,
and
went
out
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
shame
,
Miss
Dartle
!
<EOS>
shame
!
<EOS>
"
I
said
indignantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
can

bear

his
undeserved

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
she

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

his

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
If

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
See
it
done
?
 
<EOS>
I
would
do

!
 
<EOS>
I
detest
her
.
 
<EOS>
If
I

.
 
<EOS>
If

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

and
only

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
The
mere

can

,
I

,

,

<EOS>
No

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
When

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>

,
"
I
'm
a

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
We

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"
All

"

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
shaking

<EOS>
"
I

a

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
but

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
We

to

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a

,

,
just
the
time
when
,
in

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
   
<EOS>
Rarely

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
      
Chapter
33
.
<EOS>
Blissful
 
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
I
had
gone
on
loving
Dora
,
harder
than
ever
.
 
<EOS>
Her
idea
was
my
refuge
in
disappointment
and
distress
,
and
made
some
amends
to
me
,
even
for
the
loss
of
my
friend
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
I
pitied
myself
,
or
pitied
others
,
the
more
I
sought
for
consolation
in
the
image
of
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
The
greater
the
accumulation
of
deceit
and
trouble
in
the
world
,
<EOS>
the
brighter
and
the
purer
shone
the
star
of
Dora
high
above
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
I
had
any
definite
idea
where
Dora
came
from
,
or
in
what
degree
she
was
related
to
a
higher
order
of
beings
;
but
I
am
quite
sure
I
should
have
scouted
the
notion
of
her
being
simply
human
,
like
any
other
young
lady
,
with
indignation
and
contempt
.
   
<EOS>
If
I
may
so
express
it
,
I
was
steeped
in
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
merely
over
head
and
ears
in
love
with
her
,
but
I
was
saturated
through
and
through
.
 
<EOS>
Enough
love
might
have
been
wrung
out
of
me
,
metaphorically
speaking
,
to
drown
anybody
in
;
and
yet
there
would
have
remained
enough
within
me
,
and
all
over
me
,
to
pervade
my
entire
existence
.
   
<EOS>
The
first

I
did
,
on
my
own
account
,
when
I
came
back
,
was
to
take
a
night
-
walk
to
Norwood
,
and
,
like
the
subject
of
a
venerable
riddle
of
my
childhood
,
to
go
"
round
and
round
the
house
,
without
ever
touching
the
house
"
,
thinking
about
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
the
theme
of
this
incomprehensible
conundrum
was
the
moon
.
 
<EOS>
No
matter
what
it
was
,
I
,
the
moon
-
struck
slave
of
Dora
,
perambulated
round
and
round
the
house
and
garden
for
two
hours
,
looking
through
crevices
in
the
palings
,
getting
my
chin
by
dint
of
violent

above
the
rusty
nails
on
the
top
,
blowing

at
the
lights
in
the
windows
,
and
romantically

on
the
night
,
at
intervals
,
to
shield
my
Dora
<EOS>
---
I
do
n't
exactly
know
what
from
,
I
suppose
from
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
from
mice
,
to
which
she
had
a
great
objection
.
   
<EOS>
My
love
was
so
much
in
my
mind
<EOS>
and
it
was
so
natural

me
to
confide

Peggotty
,
when

by
my
side

,

,
that

,
in

,
<EOS>
my

.
 
<EOS>
Peggotty
was
strongly

,
but
I

.
 
<EOS>
She

and

.
<EOS>
"
The

,

.
 
<EOS>

Pa
,
"

"

,

"
   
<EOS>
I

,

,
that
Mr
Spenlow
's

took
Peggotty
down

,

man

in

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

,

;

;

Dora

,

,

yet
not

an

!
   
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Frozen
-

in
the
flower
-

of
the
heart
<EOS>
,
I

.
 
<EOS>
The
Bench

nothing

.
 
<EOS>
The
Bar
had
no

,

.
   
<EOS>
Taking

,

the
Legacy

-
office
,

Bank
,
and
soon

.
 
<EOS>
We

,
in

(
melted
,
I

,
these

)
;

,

;

;

.
 
<EOS>
All

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
's

,

what

"

(
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

had

,
old

,

;

our

,

<EOS>
,

.
   
<EOS>
We
were
a
little
like

,
in
the
Commons
,
as

Probate

;
generally

to
look

,

.
 
<EOS>
In
a

,
we
were
always

with
the

.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
I
hinted
to
Peggotty
that
she

Mr
Spenlow
much
recovered
from

Mr
Barkis
's

;
and
indeed

came
in

.
   
<EOS>
But

nor
I
had

,

,
in

,
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
very
little

.
 
<EOS>
His

looked
as

,
and
was
certainly

,
as

;
and
his

as
little

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Copperfield
?
"
said
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
this
gentleman
,
I
believe
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
made
my
gentleman
a
distant

,
and
Peggotty
barely

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
,

,
somewhat

to
meet
us
two
together
;
but
quickly
decided
what

do
,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
"
he

,
"
that
you
are

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

I.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
if

.
"
   
<EOS>
We

,

he

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
you
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
Mr
Murdstone
,
"
replied
Peggotty
,
trembling
from
head
to
foot
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
hope
that
there
is
nobody
to
blame
for
this
one
,
---
nobody
to
answer
for
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
<EOS>
"
said
he
;
"
that
's
a
comfortable
reflection
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
done
your
duty
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
worn
anybody
's
life
away
,
"
said
Peggotty
,
"
I
am
thankful
to
think
!
 
<EOS>
No
,
Mr
Murdstone
,
I
have
not
worrited
and
frightened
any
sweet
creetur
to
an
early
grave
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
eyed
her
gloomily
---
remorsefully
I
thought
---
for
an
instant
;
and
said
,
turning
his
head
towards
me
,
but
looking
at
my
feet
instead
of
my

:
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
not
likely
to
encounter
soon
again
;
---
a
source
of
satisfaction
to
us
both
,
no
doubt
,
for
such

as
this
can
never

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
expect
that
you
,
who
always
rebelled
against
my
just
authority
,
exerted
for
your

and

,
should
owe
me
any

-
will

.
 
<EOS>
There
is
an
antipathy
between
us
---
"
   
"
An
old
one
,
I
believe
?
"
said
I
,
interrupting

.
   
<EOS>
He
smiled
,
and
shot
as
evil
a

at
me
as
could
come
from
his
dark

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
rankled
in
your
baby

,
"
he

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
embittered
the
life
of
your
poor

.
 
<EOS>
You
are
right
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
may
do
better
,
yet
;
I
hope
you
may
correct

.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
he
ended
the

,
which
had

carried
on
in

,
in
a

,
by

Mr

's

,

in

:
   
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
of
Mr
Spenlow
's
profession
are
accustomed

family

,
and
know
how
complicated

they
always
are
!
"
<EOS>
With

paid

;
and
,

,

.
   
<EOS>
I
might

,
if

upon

(
who

only

,
good

!
)
<EOS>
that

,
and
that

.
 
<EOS>
She

so

,
that
I

,
elicited

,
and
to

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Spenlow
did

;
which

,
for

,
even
in
my
own

,
remembering
what

of
the

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Spenlow
seemed

think
,
if

about

,
that
my

in

,

<EOS>
"
Miss

,
"

"

<EOS>
I

,

,

<EOS>

---

,

:
<EOS>
meaning
<EOS>
,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Rather

<EOS>
,

"

.
   
<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Speaking

Mr

.
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

's

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
Is

?
"
   
<EOS>

Just

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
So

,

"
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
So

.
   
<EOS>
Old

soon

,

,

<EOS>
Mr

's

<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
That

.
 
<EOS>
Quite

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
<EOS>
Copperfield
,

out

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Peggotty

to

,
and
Mr
Spenlow
<EOS>
and

went
into
Court
,
where
we
had
a

-
suit
coming
on
,
under
an
ingenious

(
repealed
now
,
I

,
but

)
,

these
.
<EOS>
The

,

Benjamin
,

as
Thomas

;
suppressing

,

.
 
<EOS>
NOT

,

,

by

,

,

.
<EOS>
Which

,

.
   
<EOS>
I

about

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

Spenlow

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
was

.
 
<EOS>
Very

.
 
<EOS>
There

!
   
<EOS>
I

's

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

that

,

?
   
<EOS>

---

,

Prerogative
Office
<EOS>
---
I

rather

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Spenlow
inquired
in
what

?
 
<EOS>
I
replied
,
with
all

(
but

,

,

)
,

,

of
all

within

,

<EOS>
,
should

,
never

,

for
their
Own

,

,

,
choked

it

,
and

,
from

roof
to

,
a

of
the
registrars
,
who
took
great
fees
from

public
,
and
crammed
the
public
's

away
anyhow
and
anywhere
,
having
no
other

than
to

.
 
<EOS>
That
,
perhaps
,
it
was
a
little
unreasonable
that
these
registrars
in
the
receipt
of
profits
amounting
to
eight
or
nine

a

(
to

nothing
of
the

of

,

)
,

to

,
in

for

which
all

were

to

,
whether

or
no
.
 
<EOS>
That
,
perhaps
,
it
was
a
little
unjust
,
that
all

great

in
this
great
office
should
be
magnificent

,
while
the
unfortunate

-
clerks
in

upstairs
were
the
worst

,
and
the
least

men
,

,
in
London
.
 
<EOS>
That
perhaps
it
was
a
little
indecent
that
the
principal
registrar
of
all
,
whose
duty
it
was
to
find
the
public
,
constantly

this

,
all

,

in

(
and
might

,

,
a

,

,

,

what

)
,
---
while
the
public
was
put
to
the

of
which
we
had
a
specimen
every
afternoon
when
the
office
was

,
and
which
we
knew
to
be

.
 
<EOS>
That
,
perhaps
,
in
short
,
this
Prerogative
Office
of
the
diocese
of
Canterbury
was
altogether
such
a
pestilent

,
and
such

,
that
but
for

being

away
in

of
St
Paul
's
Churchyard
,
which
few
people
knew
,
it
must
have
been
turned
completely
inside
out
,
and
upside
down
,
long
ago
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Spenlow
smiled
as
I
became
modestly
warm
on
the
subject
,
and
then
argued
this
question
with
me
as
he
had
argued

other
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
,
what
was
it
after
all
?
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
question
of
feeling
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
public
felt
that
their
wills
were
in
safe
keeping
,
and
took
it
for
granted
that
the
office
was
not
to
be
made
better
,
<EOS>
who
was
the
worse
for
it
?
 
<EOS>
Nobody
.
 
<EOS>
Who
was
the
better
for
it
?
 
<EOS>
All
the
Sinecurists
.
 
<EOS>
Very
well
.
 
<EOS>
Then
the
good
predominated
.
 
<EOS>
It
might
not
be
a
perfect
system
;
nothing
was
perfect
;
but
what
he
objected
to
,
was
,
the
insertion
of
the
wedge
.
 
<EOS>
Under
the
Prerogative
Office
,
the
country
had
been
glorious
.
 
<EOS>
Insert
the
wedge
into
the
Prerogative
Office
,
and
the
country
would
cease
to
be
glorious
.
 
<EOS>
He
considered
it
the
principle
of
a
gentleman
to
take
things
as
he
found
them
;
and
he
had
no
doubt
the
Prerogative
Office
would
last
our
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
deferred
to
his
opinion
,
though
I
had
great
doubts
of
it
myself
.
<EOS>
I
find
he
was
right
,
however
;
for
it
has
not
only
lasted
to
the
present
moment
,
but
has
done
so
in
the
teeth
of
a
great
parliamentary
report
made
(
not
too
willingly
)
eighteen
years
ago
,
when
all
these
objections
of
mine
were
set
forth
in
detail
,
and
when
the
existing
stowage
for
wills
was
described
as
equal
to
the
accumulation
of
only
two

and
a
half
more
.
 
<EOS>
What
they
have
done
with
them
since
;
whether
they
have
lost
many
,
or
whether
they
sell
any
,
now
and
then
,
to
the
butter
shops
;
I
do
n't
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
mine
is
not
there
,
and
I
hope
it
may
not
go
there
,
yet
awhile
.
   
<EOS>
I
have
set
all
this
down
,
in
my
present
blissful
chapter
,
because
here
it
comes
into
its
natural
place
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Spenlow
and
<EOS>
I
falling
into
this
conversation
,
prolonged
it
and
our
saunter
to
and
fro
,
until
we
diverged
into
general
topics
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
it
came
about
<EOS>
,
in
the
end
,
that
Mr
Spenlow
told
me
this
day
week
was
Dora
's
birthday
,
and
he
would
be
glad
if
I
would
come
down
and
join
a
little
picnic
on
the
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
out
of
my
senses
immediately
;
became
a
mere
driveller
next
day
,
on
receipt
of
a
little
lace
-
edged
sheet
of
note
-
paper
,
"
Favoured
by
papa
.
 
<EOS>
To
remind
"
;
and
passed
the
intervening
period
in
a
state
of
dotage
.
   
<EOS>
I
think
I
committed
every
possible
absurdity
in
the
way
of
preparation
for
this
blessed
event
.
 
<EOS>
I
turn
hot
when
I
remember
the
cravat
I
bought
.
 
<EOS>
My
boots
might
be
placed
in
any
collection
of
instruments
of
torture
.
 
<EOS>
I
provided
,
and
sent
down
by
the
Norwood
coach
the
night
before
,
a
delicate
little
hamper
,
amounting
in
itself
,
I
thought
,
almost
to
a
declaration
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
crackers
in
it
with
the
tenderest
mottoes
that
could
be
got
for
money
.
 
<EOS>
At
six
in
the
morning
,
I
was
in
Covent
Garden
Market
,
buying
a
bouquet
for
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
At
ten
I
was
on
horseback
<EOS>
(
I
hired
a
gallant
grey
,
for
the
occasion
)
,
with
the
bouquet
in
my
hat
,
to
keep
it
fresh
,
trotting
down
to
Norwood
.
   
<EOS>
I
suppose
that
when
I
saw
Dora
in
the
garden
and
pretended
not
to
see
her
,
and
rode
past
the
house
pretending
to
be
anxiously
looking
for
it
,
I
committed
two
small
fooleries
which
other
young
gentlemen
in
my
circumstances
might
have
committed
---
because
they
came
so
very
natural
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
<EOS>
oh
!
<EOS>
when
I
DID
find
the
house
,
and
DID
dismount
at
the
garden
-
gate
,
and
drag
those
stony
-
hearted
boots
across
the
lawn
to
Dora
sitting
on
a
garden
-
seat
under
a
lilac
tree
,
what
a
spectacle
she
was
,
upon
that
beautiful
morning
,
among
the
butterflies
,
in
a
white
chip
bonnet
and
a
dress
of
celestial
blue
!
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
young
lady
with
her
---
comparatively
stricken
in
years
---
almost
twenty
,
I
should
say
.
 
<EOS>
Her
name
was
Miss
Mills
.
 
<EOS>
and
Dora
called
her
Julia
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
the
bosom
friend
of
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
Happy
Miss
Mills
!
   
<EOS>
Jip
was
there
,
and
Jip
WOULD
bark
at
me
again
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
presented
my
bouquet
,
he
gnashed
his
teeth
with
jealousy
.
 
<EOS>
Well
he
might
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
had
the
least
idea
how
I
adored
his
mistress
,
well
he
might
!
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
thank
you
,
Mr
Copperfield
!
 
<EOS>
What
dear
flowers
!
"
said
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
had
an
intention
of
saying
(
and
had
been
studying
the
best
form
of
words
for
three
miles
)
<EOS>
that
I
thought
them
beautiful
before
I
saw
them
so
near
HER
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
could
n't
manage
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
too
bewildering
.
 
<EOS>
To
see
her
lay
the
flowers
against
her
little
dimpled
chin
,
was
to
lose
all
presence
of
mind
and
power
of
language
in
a
feeble

.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
I
did
n't
say
,
"
Kill
me
,
if
you
have
a
heart
,
Miss
Mills
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
die
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
Then
Dora
held
my
flowers
to
Jip
to
smell
.
 
<EOS>
Then
Jip
growled
,
and
would
n't
smell
them
.
 
<EOS>
Then
Dora
laughed
,
and
held
them
a
little
closer
to
Jip
,
to
make
him
.
 
<EOS>
Then
Jip
laid
hold
of
a
bit
of
geranium
with
his
teeth
,
and
worried
imaginary
cats
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
Then
Dora
beat
him
,
and
pouted
,
and
said
,
"
My
poor
beautiful
flowers
!
"
<EOS>
as
compassionately
,
I
thought
,
as
if
Jip
had
laid
hold
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
wished
he
had
!
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
be
so

to
hear
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
Dora
,
"
that
that
cross
Miss
Murdstone
is
not
here
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
gone
to
her
brother
's
marriage
,
and
will
be
away
at
least
three
weeks
.
 
<EOS>
Is

that
delightful
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
I
was
sure
it
must
be
delightful
to
her
,
and
all
that
was
delightful
to
her
was
delightful
to

.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Mills
,
with
an
air

,
smiled
upon

.
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
the
most

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
ca
n't
believe
how
ill

and
shocking
<EOS>
she
is
,
Julia
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
can
,
my
dear
!
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
YOU
can
,
perhaps
,
love
,
"
returned
Dora
,
with
her

on
julia
's
.
<EOS>
"
Forgive
my
not
excepting
you
,
my
dear
,
at
first
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
learnt
,
from

,
that
Miss
Mills
had
had
her

in
the
course
of
a

;
and
that
to
these
,
perhaps
,
I
might
refer
that
wise

of

which
I
had
already
noticed
.
 
<EOS>
i
found
,
in
the
course
of
the
day
,
that
this
was
the
case
:
Miss
Mills
having
been
unhappy
in
a
misplaced

,
and
being
understood
to
have
retired
from
the
world
on
her
awful
stock
of
experience
,
but
still
to
take
a
calm
interest
in
the
unblighted

and

of

.
   
<EOS>
But
now
Mr
Spenlow
came
out
of
the
house
,
and
Dora
went
to
him
,
saying
,
"
Look
,
papa
,
what
beautiful
flowers
!
"
<EOS>
And
Miss
Mills
smiled

,
as
who
should
say
,
"
Ye
Mayflies
,
enjoy
your
brief
existence
in
the
bright
morning
of
life
!
"
<EOS>
And
we
all
walked
from
the
lawn
towards
the
carriage
,
which
was
getting
ready
.
   
<EOS>
I
shall
never
have
such
a
ride
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
never
had
such
another
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
only
those
three
,
their
hamper
,
my
hamper
,
and
the
guitar
-
case
,
in
the
phaeton
;
and
,
of
course
,
the
phaeton
was
open
;
and
I
rode
behind
it
,
and
Dora
sat
with
her
back
to

,
looking

me
.
 
<EOS>
She
kept
the
bouquet
close
to
her
on
the

,
and
would
n't
allow
Jip
to
sit
on
that
side
of
her
at
all
,
for
fear
he
should
crush
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
often
carried
it
in
her
hand
,
often
refreshed

with

.
 
<EOS>
Our
eyes
at
those
times
often
met
;
and
my
great

is
that
I
did
n't
go
over
the
head
of
my
gallant
grey
into
the
carriage
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
dust
,
I
believe
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
good
deal
of
dust
,
I
believe
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
faint

that
Mr
Spenlow
remonstrated
with
me
for
riding
in
it
;
but
I
knew
of
none
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
sensible
of
a
mist
of
love
and
beauty
about
Dora
,
but
of
nothing
else
.
 
<EOS>
He
stood
up
sometimes
,
and
asked
me
what
I
thought
of
the
prospect
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
it
was
delightful
,
and
I
dare
say
it
was
;
but
it
was
all
Dora
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
sun
shone
Dora
,
and
the
birds
sang
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
The
south
wind
blew
Dora
,
and
the
wild
flowers
in
the
hedges
were
all
Doras
,
to
a
bud
.
 
<EOS>
My
comfort
is
,
Miss
Mills
understood
me
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Mills
alone
could
enter
into
my
feelings
thoroughly
.
   
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
long
we
were
going
,
and
to
this
hour
I
know
as
little
where
we
went
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
was
near
Guildford
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
some
Arabian
-
night
magician
,
opened
up
the
place
for
the
day
,
and
shut
it
up
for
ever
when
we
came
away
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
green
spot
,
on
a
hill
,
carpeted
with
soft
turf
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
shady
trees
,
and
heather
,
and
,
as
far
as
the
eye
could
see
,
a
rich
landscape
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
trying
thing
to
find
people
here
,
waiting
for
us
;
and
my
jealousy
,
even
of
the
ladies
,
knew
no
bounds
.
 
<EOS>
But
all
of
my
own
sex
---
especially
one
impostor
,
three
or
four
years
my
elder
,
with
a
red
whisker
,
on
which
he
established
an
amount
of
presumption
not
to
be
endured
---
were
my
mortal
foes
.
   
<EOS>
We
all
unpacked
our
baskets
,
and
employed
ourselves
in
getting
dinner
ready
.
 
<EOS>
Red
Whisker
pretended
he
could
make
a
salad
(
which
I
do
n't
believe
)
,
and
obtruded
himself
on
public
notice
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
the
young
ladies
washed
the
lettuces
for
him
,
and
sliced
them
under
his
directions
.
 
<EOS>
Dora
was
among
these
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
that
fate
had
pitted
me
against
this
man
,
and
one
of
us
must
fall
.
   
<EOS>
Red
Whisker
made
his
salad
(
I
wondered
how
they
could
eat
it
.
<EOS>
Nothing
should
have
induced
ME
to
touch
it
!
)
and
voted
himself
into
the
charge
of
the
wine
-

,
which
he
constructed
,
being
an
ingenious

,
in
the
hollow

of
a

.
 
<EOS>
By
and
by
<EOS>
,
I
saw
him
,
with
the
majority
of
a
lobster
on
his
plate
,
eating
his
dinner
at
the
feet
of
Dora
!
   
<EOS>
I
have
but
<EOS>
an
indistinct
idea
of
what
happened
for
some
time
after
this

object
presented
itself
to

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
very
merry
,
I
know
;
but
it
was
hollow
merriment
.
 
<EOS>
I
attached
myself
to
a
young
creature
in
pink
,
with
little
eyes
,
and
flirted
with
her
desperately
.
 
<EOS>
She
received
my
attentions
with
favour
;
but
whether
on
my
account
solely
,
or
because
she
had
any
designs
on
Red
Whisker
,
I
ca
n't
say
.
 
<EOS>
Dora
's
health
was
drunk
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
drank
it
,
I
affected
to
interrupt
my
conversation
for
that
purpose
,
and
to
resume
it
immediately
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
I
caught
Dora
's
eye
as
I
bowed
to
her
,
and
I
thought
it
looked
appealing
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
looked
at
me
over
the
head
of
Red
Whisker
,
and
I
was
adamant
.
   
<EOS>
The
young
creature
in
pink
had
a
mother
in
green
;
and
I
rather
think
the
latter
separated
us
from
motives
of
policy
.
 
<EOS>
Howbeit
,
there
was
a
general
breaking
up
of
the
party
,
while
the
remnants
of
the
dinner
were
being
put
away
;
and
I
strolled
off
by
myself
among
the
trees
,
in
a
raging

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
debating
whether
I
should
pretend
that
I
was
not
well
,
and
fly
<EOS>
---
I
do
n't
know
where
---
upon
my
gallant
grey
,
when
Dora
and
Miss
Mills
met

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
Miss
Mills
,
"
you
are
dull
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
begged
her

.
 
<EOS>
Not
at
all
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
Dora
,
"
said
Miss
Mills
,
"
YOU
are
dull
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Oh
dear
<EOS>
no
!
 
<EOS>
Not
in

least
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
and
Dora
,
"
said
Miss
Mills
,
with
an
almost

.
 
<EOS>
"
Enough
of
this
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
allow
a
trivial
misunderstanding
to
wither
the
blossoms
of
spring
,
which
,
once
put
forth
and
blighted
,
can
not
be
renewed
.
 
<EOS>
I
speak
,
"
said
Miss
Mills
,
"
from
experience
of
the
past
---
the
remote
,
irrevocable
past
.
 
<EOS>
The
gushing
fountains
which
sparkle
in
the
sun
,
must
not
be
stopped
in
mere
caprice
;
the
oasis
in
the
desert
of
Sahara
must
not
be
plucked
up
idly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
hardly
knew
what
I
did
,
I
was
burning
all
over
to
that
extraordinary
extent
;
but
I
took
Dora
's
little
hand
and
kissed
it
---
and
she
let
me
!
 
<EOS>
I
kissed
Miss
Mills
's
hand
;
and
we
all
seemed
,
to
my
thinking
,
to
go
straight
up
to
the
seventh
heaven
.
<EOS>
We
did
not
come
down
again
.
 
<EOS>
We
stayed
up
there
all
the
evening
.
<EOS>
At
first
we
strayed
to
and
fro
among
the
trees
:
<EOS>
I
with
Dora
's
shy
arm
drawn
through
mine
:
and
Heaven
knows
,
folly
as
it
all
was
,
it
would
have
been
a
happy
fate
to
have
been
struck
immortal
with
those
foolish
feelings
,
and
have
stayed
among
the
trees
for
ever
!
   
<EOS>
But
,
much
too
soon
,
we
heard
the
others
laughing
and
talking
,
and
calling
"
where
's
Dora
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
we
went
back
,
and
they
wanted
Dora
to
sing
.
 
<EOS>
Red
Whisker
would
have
got
the
guitar
-
case
out
of
the
carriage
,
but
Dora
told
him
nobody
knew
where
it
was
,
but
I.
 
So
Red
Whisker
was
done
for
in
a
moment
;
and
I
got
it
,
and
I
unlocked
it
,
and
I
took
the
guitar
out
,
and
I
sat
by
her
,
and
I
held
her
handkerchief
and
gloves
,
and
I
drank
in
every
note
of
her
dear
voice
,
and
she
sang
to
ME
who
loved
her
,
and
all
the
others
might
applaud
as
much
as
they
liked
,
but
they
had
nothing
to
do
with
it
!
   
<EOS>
I
was
intoxicated
with
joy
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
afraid
it
was
too
happy
to
be
real
,
and
that
I
should
wake
in
Buckingham
Street
presently
,
and
hear
Mrs
Crupp
clinking
the
teacups
in
getting
breakfast
ready
.
<EOS>
But
Dora
sang
,
and
others
sang
,
and
Miss
Mills
sang
---
about
the
slumbering
echoes
in
the
caverns
of
Memory
;
as
if
she
were
a
hundred
years
old
---
and
the
evening
came
on
;
and
we
had
tea
,
with
the
kettle
boiling
gipsy
-
fashion
;
and
I
was
still
as
happy
as
ever
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
happier
than
ever
when
the
party
broke
up
,
and
the
other
people
,
defeated
Red
Whisker
and
all
,
went
their
several
ways
,
and
we
went
ours
through
the
still
evening
and
the
dying
light
,
with
sweet
scents
rising
up
around
us
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Spenlow
being
a
little
drowsy
after
the
champagne
---
honour
to
the
soil
that
grew
the
grape
,
to
the
grape
that
made
the
wine
,
to
the
sun
that
ripened
it
,
and
to
the
merchant
who
adulterated
it
!
<EOS>
---
and
being
fast
asleep
in
a
corner
of
the
carriage
,
I
rode
by
the
side
and
talked
to
Dora
.
<EOS>
She
admired
my
horse
and
patted
him
---
<EOS>
oh
,
what
a
dear
little
hand
it
looked
upon
a
horse
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
and
her
shawl
would
not
keep
right
,
and
now
<EOS>
and
then
I
drew
it
round
her
with
my
arm
;
and
I
even
fancied
that
Jip
began
to
see
how
it
was
,
and
to
understand
that
he
must
make
up
his
mind
to
be
friends
with
me
.
   
<EOS>
That
sagacious
Miss
Mills
,
too
;
that
amiable
,
though
quite
used
up
,
recluse
;
that
little
patriarch
of
something
less
than
twenty
,
who
had
done
with
the
world
,
and
must
n't
on
any
account
have
the
slumbering
echoes
in
the
caverns
of
Memory
awakened
;
what
a
kind
thing
she
did
!
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
Miss
Mills
,
"
come
to
this
side
of
the
carriage
a
moment
---
if
you
can
spare
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
speak
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Behold
me
,
on
my
gallant
grey
,
bending
at
the
side
of
Miss
Mills
,
with
my
hand
upon
the
carriage
door
!
   
<EOS>
"
Dora
is
coming
to
stay
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
coming
home
with
me
the
day
after
tomorrow
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
would
like
to
call
,
I
am
sure
papa
would
be
happy
to
see
you
.
<EOS>
"
What
could
I
do
but
invoke
a
silent
blessing
on
Miss
Mills
's
head
,
and
store
Miss
Mills
's
address
in
the
securest
corner
of
my
memory
!
<EOS>
What
could
I
do
but
tell
Miss
Mills
,
with
grateful
looks
and
fervent
words
,
how
much
I
appreciated
her
good
offices
,
and
what
an
inestimable
value
I
set
upon
her
friendship
!
   
<EOS>
Then
Miss
Mills
benignantly
dismissed
me
,
saying
,
"
Go
back
to
Dora
!
"
<EOS>
and
I
went
;
and
Dora
leaned
out
of
the
carriage
to
talk
to
me
,
and
we
talked
all
the
rest
of
the
way
;
and
I
rode
my
gallant
grey
so
close
to
the
wheel
that
I
grazed
his
near
fore
leg
against
it
,
and
"
took
the
bark
off
"
,
as
his
owner
told
me
,
"
to
the
tune
of
three
pun
'
sivin
"
---
which
I
paid
,
and
thought
extremely
cheap
for
so
much
joy
.
 
<EOS>
What
time
Miss
Mills
sat
looking
at
the
moon
,
murmuring
verses
---
and
recalling
,
I
suppose
,
the
ancient
days
when
she
and
earth
had
anything
in
common
.
   
<EOS>
Norwood
was
many
miles
too
near
,
and
we
reached
it
many
hours
too
soon
;
but
Mr
Spenlow
came
to
himself
a
little
short
of
it
,
and
said
,
"
You
must
come
in
,
Copperfield
,
and
rest
!
"
<EOS>
and
I
consenting
,
we
had
sandwiches
and
wine
-
and
-
water
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
light
room
,
Dora
blushing
looked
so
lovely
,
that
I
could
not
tear
myself
away
,
but
sat
there
staring
,
in
a
dream
,
until
the
snoring
of
Mr
Spenlow
inspired
me
with
sufficient
consciousness
to
take
my
leave
.
 
<EOS>
So
we
parted
<EOS>
;
I
riding
all
the
way
to
London
with
the
farewell
touch
of
Dora
's
hand
still
light
on
mine
,
recalling
every
incident
and
word
ten
thousand
times
;
lying
down
in
my
own
bed
at
last
,
as
enraptured
a
young
noodle
as
ever
was
carried
out
of
his
five
wits
by
love
.
   
<EOS>
When
I
awoke
next
morning
,
I
was
resolute
to
declare
my
passion
to
Dora
,
and
know
my
fate
.
 
<EOS>
Happiness
or
misery
was
now
the
question
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
other
question
that
I
knew
of
in
the
world
,
and
only
Dora
could
give
the
answer
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
passed
three
days
in
a
luxury
of
wretchedness
,
torturing
myself
by
putting
every
conceivable
variety
of
discouraging
construction
on
all
that
ever
had
taken
place
between
Dora
and
me
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
,
arrayed
for
the
purpose
at
a
vast
expense
,
I
went
to
Miss
Mills
's
,
fraught
with
a
declaration
.
   
<EOS>
How
many
times
I
went
up
and
down
the
street
,
and
round
the
square
---
painfully
aware
of
being
a
much
better
answer
to
the
old
riddle
than
the
original
one
---
before
I
could
persuade
myself
to
go
up
the
steps
and
knock
,
is
no
matter
now
.
 
<EOS>
Even
when
,
at
last
,
I
had
knocked
,
and
was
waiting
at
the
door
,
I
had
some
flurried
thought
of
asking
if
that
were
Mr
Blackboy
's
<EOS>
(
in
imitation
of
poor
Barkis
)
,
begging
pardon
,
and
retreating
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
kept
my
ground
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Mills
was
not
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
not
expect
he
would
be
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
wanted
HIM
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Mills
was
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Mills
would
do
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
shown
into
a
room
upstairs
,
where
Miss
Mills
and
Dora
were
.
<EOS>
Jip
was
there
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Mills
was
copying
music
<EOS>
(
I
recollect
,
it
was
a
new
song
,
called
"
Affection
's
Dirge
"
)
,
and
Dora
was
painting
flowers
.
 
<EOS>
What
were
my
feelings
,
when
I
recognized
my
own
flowers
;
the
identical
Covent
Garden
Market
purchase
!
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
that
they
were
very
like
,
or
that
they
particularly
resembled
any
flowers
that
have
ever
come
under
my
observation
;
but
I
knew
from
the
paper
round
them
which
was
accurately
copied
,
what
the
composition
was
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Mills
was
very
glad
to
see
me
,
and
very
sorry
her
papa
was
not
at
home
:
though
I
thought
we
all
bore
that
with
fortitude
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Mills
was
conversational
for
a
few
minutes
,
and
then
,
laying
down
her
pen
upon
"
Affection
's
Dirge
"
,
got
up
,
and
left
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
I
began
to
think
I
would
put
it
off
till
tomorrow
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
your
poor
horse
was
not
tired
,
when
he
got
home
at
night
,
"
said
Dora
,
lifting
up
her
beautiful
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
long
way
for
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
began
to
think
I
would
do
it
today
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
long
way
for
him
,
"
said
I
,
"
for
he
had
nothing
to
uphold
him
on
the
journey
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Was
n't
he
fed
,
poor
thing
?
"
asked
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
I
began
to
think
I
would
put
it
off
till
tomorrow
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ye
-
yes
,
"
I
said
,
"
he
was
well
taken
care
of
.
 
<EOS>
I
mean
he
had
not
the
unutterable
happiness
that
I
had
in
being
so
near
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Dora
bent
her
head
over
her
drawing
and
said
,
after
a
little
while
---
I
had
sat
,
in
the
interval
,
in
a
burning
fever
,
and
with
my
legs
in
a
very
rigid

---
   
"
You
did
n't
seem
to
be
sensible
of
that
happiness
yourself
,
at
one
time
of
the
day
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
saw
now
that
I
was
in
for
it
,
and
it
must
be
done
on
the
spot
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
did
n't
care
for
that
happiness
in
the
least
,
"
said
Dora
,
slightly
raising
her

,
and
shaking

head
,
"
when
you
were
sitting
by
Miss
Kitt
.
"
   
<EOS>
Kitt
,
I
should
observe
,
was
the
name
of
the
creature
in
pink
,
with
the
little
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Though
certainly
I
do
n't
know
why
you
should
,
"
said
Dora
,
"
or
why
you
should
call
it
a

at
all
.
 
<EOS>
But
of
course
you
do
n't
mean
what
you
say
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
am
sure
no
one
doubts
your
being
at
liberty
to
do
whatever
you
like
.
 
<EOS>
Jip
<EOS>
,
you
naughty
boy
,
come
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
I
did
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
it
in
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
I
intercepted
Jip
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
Dora
in
my
arms
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
full
of
eloquence
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
stopped
for
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
her
how
I
loved
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
her
I
should
die
without
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
her
that
I
idolized
and
worshipped
her
.
 
<EOS>
Jip
barked
madly
all
the
time
.
   
<EOS>
When
Dora
hung
her
head
and
cried
,
and
trembled
,
my
eloquence
increased
so
much
the
more
.
 
<EOS>
If
she
would
like
me
to
die
for
her
,
she
had
but
<EOS>
to
say
the
word
,
and
I
was
ready
.
 
<EOS>
Life
without
Dora
's
love
was
not
a
thing
to
have
on
any
terms
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
n't
bear
it
,
and
I
would
n't
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
loved
her
every
minute
,
day
and
night
,
since
I
first
saw
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
loved
her
at
that
minute
to
distraction
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
always
love
her
,
every
minute
,
to
distraction
.
 
<EOS>
Lovers
had
loved
before
,
and
lovers
would
love
again
;
but
no
lover
had
loved
,
might
,
could
,
would
,
or
should
ever
love
,
as
I
loved
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
I
raved
,
the
more
Jip
barked
.
 
<EOS>
Each
of
us
,
in
his
own
way
,
got
more
mad
every
moment
.
   
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
 
<EOS>
Dora
and
I
were
sitting
on
the
sofa
by
and
by
,
quiet
enough
,
and
Jip
was
lying
in
her
lap
,
winking
peacefully
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
off
my
mind
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
in
a
state
of
perfect
rapture
.
 
<EOS>
Dora
and
I
were
engaged
.
   
<EOS>
I
suppose
we
had
some
notion
that
this
was
to
end
in
marriage
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
have
had
some
,
because
Dora
stipulated
that
we
were
never
to
be
married
without
her
papa
's
consent
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
in
our
youthful
ecstasy
,
I
do
n't
think
that
we
really
looked
before
us
or
behind
us
;
or
had
any
aspiration
beyond
the
ignorant
present
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
to
keep
our
secret
from
Mr
Spenlow
;
but
I
am
sure
the
idea
never
entered
my
head
,
then
,
that
there
was
anything
dishonourable
in
that
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Mills
was
more
than
usually
pensive
when
Dora
,
going
to
find
her
,
brought
her
back
;
---
I
apprehend
,
because
there
was
a
tendency
in
what
had
passed
to
awaken
the
slumbering
echoes
in
the
caverns
of
Memory
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
gave
us
her
blessing
,
and
the
assurance
of
her
lasting
friendship
,
and
spoke
to
us
,
generally
,
as
became
a
Voice
from
the
Cloister
.
   
<EOS>
What
an
idle
time
it
was
!
 
<EOS>
What
an
insubstantial
,
happy
,
foolish
time
it
was
!
   
<EOS>
When
I
measured
Dora
's
finger
for
a
ring
that
was
to
be
made
of
Forget
-
me
-
nots
,
and
when
the
jeweller
,
to
whom
I
took
the
measure
,
found
me
out
,
and
laughed
over
his
order
-
book
,
and
charged
me
anything
he
liked
for
the
pretty
little
toy
,
with
its
blue
stones
---
so
associated
in
my
remembrance
with
Dora
's
hand
,
that
yesterday
,
when
I
saw
such
another
,
by
chance
,
on
the
finger
of
my
own
daughter
,
there
was
a
momentary
stirring
in
my
heart
,
like
pain
!
   
<EOS>
When
I
walked
about
,
exalted
with
my
secret
,
and
full
of
my
own
interest
,
and
felt
the
dignity
of
loving
Dora
,
and
of
being
beloved
,
so
much
,
that
if
I
had
walked
the
air
,
I
could
not
have
been
more
above
the
people
not
so
situated
,
who
were
creeping
on
the
earth
!
   
<EOS>
When
we
had
those
meetings
in
the
garden
of
the
square
,
and
sat
within
the
dingy
summer
-
house
,
so
happy
,
that
I
love
the
London
sparrows
to
this
hour
,
for
nothing
else
,
and
see
the
plumage
of
the
tropics
in
their
smoky
feathers
!
<EOS>
When
we
had
our
first
great
quarrel
(
within
a
week
of
our
betrothal
)
,
and
when
Dora
sent
me
back
the
ring
,
enclosed
in
a
despairing
cocked
-
hat
note
,
wherein
she
used
the
terrible
expression
that
"
our
love
had
begun
in
folly
,
and
ended
in
madness
!
"
<EOS>
which
dreadful
words
occasioned
me
to
tear
my
hair
,
and
cry
that
all
was
over
!
   
<EOS>
When
,
under
cover
of
the
night
,
I
flew
to
Miss
Mills
,
whom
I
saw
by
stealth
in
a
back
kitchen
where
there
was
a
mangle
,
and
implored
Miss
Mills
to
interpose
between
us
and
avert
insanity
.
 
<EOS>
When
Miss
Mills
undertook
the
office
and
returned
with
Dora
,
exhorting
us
,
from
the
pulpit
of
her
own
bitter
youth
,
to
mutual
concession
,
and
the
avoidance
of
the
Desert
of
Sahara
!
   
<EOS>
When
we
cried
,
and
made
it
up
,
and
were
so
blest
again
,
that
the
back

,
mangle

all
,
changed
to
Love
's
own

,
where
we

through
Miss
Mills
,
always
to
comprehend
at
least
one

!
   
<EOS>
What
an
idle
time
!
 
<EOS>
What
an
insubstantial
,
happy
,

!
 
<EOS>
Of

that

that
in
one

I
can

,
and
think

.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
34
.
<EOS>
My
aunt
astonishes
me
 
<EOS>
I
wrote
to
Agnes
as
soon
as
Dora
and
I
were

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

to

comprehend
how
blest

was
,

what
a

Dora
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
entreated

not
to

which
could

any

,

had

.
 
<EOS>
I

that
its

was
quite

,
and
expressed

belief
that
nothing
like

had

.
   
<EOS>
Somehow

upon

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Of

<EOS>

my
eye
since
,
upon
the
broker
's
shop
,
"
said
Traddles
,
with
a
great
enjoyment
of
his
mystery
,
"
which
is
up
at
the
top
of
Tottenham
Court
Road
,
and
,
at
last
,
today
I
find
them
put
out
for
sale
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
only
noticed
them
from
over
the
way
,
because
if
the
broker
saw
me
,
bless
you
,
he
'd

any

for

!
 
<EOS>
What
has

,
having
now
the
money
,
is
,
that
perhaps
you
would
n't
object

ask
that
good
nurse

yours
to
come

the
shop
<EOS>
---
I
can

her
from
round

---
and
make
the
best
bargain
for

,
as

were
for
herself
,
that
she
can
!
"
   
<EOS>
The

with

propounded
this

to

,

the

had
of
its

,

.
   
<EOS>
I
told

that
my
old
nurse

to

him
,
and
that
we
would
all
three

field

,
but

.
 
<EOS>
That

was
,
that
he

to
grant
no
more

of
his

,

,
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Copperfield
,
"

,
"
I
have
already
done

,
because

.
 
<EOS>
My

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
That

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

Micawber

have

<EOS>
One

in
Mr
Micawber

Copperfield
.
 
<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
do

,

WILL

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
I

good

's

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
After

,
we
went
round
to
the
chandler
's
shop
,
to
enlist
Peggotty
;
<EOS>
Traddles
declining

,

,

he

.
   
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,
that

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

<EOS>

?
"
   
<EOS>
I

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
As

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
   
<EOS>
On

,

<EOS>

(

.
   
<EOS>
We

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

!
 
<EOS>
My

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

,
such

to

,

!
   
<EOS>
"
My

!
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Why
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
We

;

Mrs

,

,

.

"

,

<EOS>

?
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
That

<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
Trot
,

,
another

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
,

<EOS>
Mrs

,

<EOS>
"
Dick
!
"

<EOS>
"
You

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

's

!
"
   
<EOS>
I
knew

aunt
sufficiently

,

<EOS>
I

,

my

otherwise
occupied
;
and

,

<EOS>
I

;

.
 
<EOS>
Could

by

,

<EOS>
As

,

,

,

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
But
I

very

;

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Trot
,
"
said

at

,

,

<EOS>
"

,

!
<EOS>
---

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then

,
my

,
"
said

,

,
"

prefer
to
sit
upon
this
property
of
mine
tonight
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Because
,
"
said

aunt
,
"

's

.
 
<EOS>
Because
I
'm
ruined
,
my
dear
!
"
   
<EOS>
If

,
and

,

,
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
Dick
knows

,
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
ruined
,
my

Trot
!
 
<EOS>
All

,

;

Janet

.
 
<EOS>
Barkis
,

.
 
<EOS>
To

,

.
<EOS>
Anything

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

for
her
<EOS>
---
I
am
sure
,
for

---
by

,

.
 
<EOS>
In

<EOS>
"
We
must
meet

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
We
must
learn

act

play
out
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
live
misfortune
down
,
Trot
!
"
      
<EOS>
Chapter
35
.
<EOS>
Depression
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
I
could
recover
my
presence
of
mind
,
which
quite
deserted
me
in
the
first
overpowering
shock
of
my
aunt
's
intelligence
,
I
proposed
to
Mr
Dick
to
come
round
to
the
chandler
's
shop
,
and
take
possession
of
the
bed
which
Mr
Peggotty
had
lately
vacated
.
 
<EOS>
The
chandler
's
shop
being
in
Hungerford
Market
,
and
Hungerford
Market
being
a
very
different
place
in
those
days
<EOS>
,
there
was
a
low
wooden
colonnade
before
the
door
(
not
very
unlike
that
before
the
house
where
the
little
man
and
woman
used
to
live
,
in
the
old
weather
-
glass
)
,
which
pleased
Mr
Dick
mightily
.
<EOS>
The
glory
of
lodging
over
this
structure
would
have
compensated
him
,
I
dare
say
,
for
many
inconveniences
;
but
,
as
there
were
really
few
to
bear
,
beyond
the
compound
of
flavours
I
have
already
mentioned
,
and
perhaps
the
want
of
a
little
more
elbow
-
room
,
he
was
perfectly
charmed
with
his
accommodation
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Crupp
had
indignantly
assured
him
that
there
was
n't
room
to
swing
a
cat
there
;
but
,
as
Mr
Dick
justly
observed
to
me
,
sitting
down
on
the
foot
of
the
bed
,
nursing
his
leg
,
"
You
know
,
Trotwood
,
I
do
n't
want
to
swing
a
cat
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
do
swing
a
cat
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
,
what
does
that
signify
to
ME
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
tried
to
ascertain
whether
Mr
Dick
had
any
understanding
of
the
causes
of
this
sudden
and
great
change
in
my
aunt
's
affairs
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
might
have
expected
,
he
had
none
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
account
he
could
give
of
it
was
,
that
my
aunt
had
said
to
him
,
the
day
before
yesterday
,
"
Now
,
Dick
,
are
you
really
and
truly
the
philosopher
<EOS>
I
take
you
for
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
That
then
he
had
said
,
Yes
,
he
hoped
so
.
 
<EOS>
That
then
my
aunt
had
said
,
"
Dick
,
I
am
ruined
.
"
 
<EOS>
That
then
he
had
said
,
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
indeed
!
"
That
then
my
aunt
had
praised
him
highly
,
which
he
was
glad
of
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
then
they
had
come
to
me
,
and
had
had
bottled
porter
and
sandwiches
on
the
road
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
was
so
very
complacent
,
sitting
on
the
foot
of
the
bed
,
nursing
his
leg
,
and
telling
me
this
,
with
his
eyes
wide
open
and
a
surprised
smile
,
that
I
am
sorry
to
say
I
was
provoked
into
explaining
to
him
that
ruin
meant
distress
,
want
,
and
starvation
;
but
I
was
soon
bitterly
reproved
for
this
harshness
,
by
seeing
his
face
turn
pale
,
and
tears
course
down
his
lengthened
cheeks
,
while
he
fixed
upon
me
a
look
of
such
unutterable
woe
,
that
it
might
have
softened
a
far
harder
heart
than
mine
.
 
<EOS>
I
took
infinitely
greater
pains
to
cheer
him
up
again
than
I
had
taken
to
depress
him
;
and
I
soon
understood
(
as
I
ought
to
have
known
at
first
)
that
he
had
been
so
confident
,
merely
because
of
his
faith
in
the
wisest
and
most
wonderful
of
women
,
and
his
unbounded
reliance
on
my
intellectual
resources
.
 
<EOS>
The
latter
<EOS>
,
I
believe
,
he
considered
a
match
for
any
kind
of
disaster
not
absolutely
mortal
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
can
we
do
,
Trotwood
?
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
the
Memorial
---
"
   
"
To
be
sure
there
is
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
But
all
we
can
do
just
now
,
Mr
Dick
,
is
to
keep
a
cheerful
countenance
,
and
not
let
my
aunt
see
that
we
are
thinking
about
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
assented
to
this
in
the
most
earnest
manner
;
and
implored
me
,
if
I
should
see
him
wandering
an
inch

the
right
course
,
to
recall
him
by
some
of
those
superior
methods
which
were
always
at
my
command
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
regret
to
state
that
the
fright
I
had
given
him
proved
too
much
for
his
best
attempts
at
concealment
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
evening
his
eyes
wandered
to
my
aunt
's
face
,
with
an
expression
of
the
most
dismal
apprehension
,
as
if
he
saw
her
growing
thin
on
the
spot
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
conscious
of
this
,
and
put
a
constraint
upon
his
head
;
but
his
keeping
that
immovable
,
and
sitting
rolling
his
eyes
like
a
piece
of
machinery
,
did
not
mend
the
matter
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
him
look
at
the
loaf
at
supper
(
which
happened
to
be
a
small
one
)
,
as
if
nothing
else
stood
between
us
and
famine
;
and
when
my
aunt
insisted
on
his
making
his
customary
repast
,
I
detected
him
in
the
act
of
pocketing
fragments
of
his
bread
and
cheese
;
I
have
no
doubt
for
the
purpose
of
reviving
us
with
those
savings
,
when
we
should
have
reached
an
advanced
stage
of
attenuation
.
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
on
the
other
hand
,
was
in
a
composed
frame
of
mind
,
which
was
a
lesson
to
all
of
us
---
to
me
,
I
am
sure
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
extremely
gracious
to
Peggotty
,
except
when
I
inadvertently
called
her
by
that
name
;
and
,
strange
as
I
knew
she
felt
in
London
,
appeared
quite
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
to
have
my
bed
,
and
I
was
to
lie
in
the
sitting
-
room
,
to
keep
guard
over
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
made
a
great
point
of
being
so
near
the
river
,
in
case
of
a
conflagration
;
and
I
suppose
really
did
find
some
satisfaction
in
that
circumstance
.
   
<EOS>
"
Trot
,
my
dear
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
when
she
saw

for

her
usual

,
"
No
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
aunt
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
wine
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
Ale
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
there
is
wine
here
,
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
And
you
always

made
of
wine
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Keep
that
,
in

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
We
must
n't
use
it
carelessly
,
Trot
.
 
<EOS>
Ale
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
Half
a
pint
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
thought
Mr
Dick
would
have
fallen
,
insensible
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
being
resolute
,
I
went
out
and
got
the
ale
myself
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
was
growing
late
,
Peggotty
and
Mr
Dick
took
that
opportunity
of
repairing
to
the
chandler
's
shop
together
.
 
<EOS>
I
parted
from
him
,
poor
fellow
,
at
the
corner
of
the
street
,
with
his
great
kite
at
his
back
,
a
very
monument
of
human
misery
.
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
was
walking
up
and
down
the
room
when
I
returned
,
crimping
the
borders
of
her
nightcap
with
her

.
 
<EOS>
I
warmed
the
ale
and
made
the
toast
on
the
usual
infallible
principles
.
 
<EOS>
When
it
was
ready
for
her
,
she
was
ready
for
it
,
with
her
nightcap
on
,
and
the
skirt
of
her
gown
turned
back
on

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
after
taking
a

it
;
"
it
's
a
great
deal
better
than
wine
.
 
<EOS>
Not
half
so
bilious
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
looked

,
for
she

:
   
<EOS>
"
Tut
,
tut
,
child
.
 
<EOS>
If
nothing
worse
than
Ale
happens
to

,
we
are

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
think

myself
,
aunt
,
I

,
"

<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
why
DON'T

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Because
you

are

,
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
Stuff
and
nonsense
,
Trot
!
"
replied
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
MY
aunt
went
on
with
a
quiet

,
in
which
there
was
very
little
affectation
,
if
any
;
drinking

warm

with

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Trot
,
"
said

,
"
I
do

,
but
I
rather
like
that
Barkis
of

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

than
a

!
"

<EOS>
"
It
's
a
most

,
"
observed

aunt
,

;
"
how
that
woman

got

,
is

.
 
<EOS>
It
would

much
more

to
be

Jackson
,

,
one

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps

,

;

,
"

<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

;
"
but

's
very

.
 
<EOS>
However
,
she
's
Barkis

.
 
<EOS>
That
's
some
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
Barkis
is
uncommonly
fond
of
you
,
Trot
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
she
would
leave
undone
to

it
,
"
said

<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
I
believe
,
"
returned
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
,
the
poor
fool
has
been
begging
and
praying
about
handing
over
some
of
her
money
---
because
she
has
got
too
much
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
A
simpleton
!
"
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
's
tears
of
pleasure
were
positively
trickling
down
into
the
warm
ale
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
the
most

that
ever
was

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

,

of

,

most

.
 
<EOS>
But
there
are
good
points
in
Barkis
!
"
   
<EOS>
Affecting
to
laugh
,
she
got
an

of
putting
her
hand
to
her

.
 
<EOS>
Having
availed
herself
of
it
,
she
resumed

and
her

together
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Mercy
upon
us
!
<EOS>
"

aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
all
about
it
,
Trot
!
<EOS>
Barkis
and
myself
had
quite
a
gossip
while
you
were
out

Dick
.
<EOS>
I
know
all
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
where
these
wretched
girls
expect
to
go
to
,
for
my

.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
they
do

knock

against
---
against
mantelpieces
,
"
said
my
aunt
;
an

which
was

of

.
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
Emily
!
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
Oh
,
do
n't
talk

about
poor
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
She
should
have

,

caused

!
 
<EOS>
Give
me
a

,
Trot
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
for
your
early
experience
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As
I
bent
forward
,
she
put
her
tumbler
on
my
knee
to
detain
me
,
and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Trot
,
Trot
!
 
<EOS>
And
so
you
fancy
yourself
in
love
!
 
<EOS>
Do
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Fancy
,
aunt
!
<EOS>
"
I
exclaimed
,
as
red
as
I
could
be
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
adore
her
with
my
whole
soul
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dora
,
indeed
!
"
returned
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
you
mean
to
say
the
little
thing
is
very
fascinating
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
aunt
,
"
I
replied
,
"
no
one
can
form
the
least
idea
what
she
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
And
not
silly
?
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Silly
,
aunt
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
seriously
believe
it
had
never
once
entered
my
head
for
a
single

,
to
consider
whether
she
was
or

.
 
<EOS>
I
resented
the

,
of

;
but
I
was
in
a

it
,
as
a
new

.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
light
-
headed
?
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Light
-
headed
,
aunt
!
<EOS>
"
I
could
only
repeat
this
daring
speculation
with
the
same
kind

feeling
with
which
I
had
repeated
the
preceding

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
only
ask
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
depreciate
her
.
<EOS>
Poor
little
couple
!
 
<EOS>
And
so
you
think
you
were
formed
for
one
another
,
and
are
to
go
through
a
party
-
supper
-
table
kind
of
life
,
like
two

,
do

,
Trot
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
asked
me
this
so
kindly
,
and
with
such
a
gentle

,
half
playful
and
half

,
that
I
was

.
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
young
and
inexperienced
,
aunt
,
I
know
,
"
<EOS>
I
replied
;
"
and
I
dare
say
we
say
and
think
a
good
deal
that
is
rather
foolish
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
love
one
another
truly
,
I
am
sure
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
thought
Dora
could
ever
love
anybody
else
,
or
cease
to
love
me
;
or
that
I
could
ever
love
anybody
else
,
or
cease
to
love
her
;
I
do
n't
know
what
I
should
do
---
go
out
of
my
mind
,
I
think
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Trot
!
"
said
my
aunt
,
shaking
her
head
,
and
smiling
gravely
;
"
blind
,
blind
,
blind
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Someone
that
I
know
,
Trot
,
"
my
aunt
pursued
,
after
