pause
,
"
though
of
a
very
pliant
disposition
,
has
an
earnestness
of
affection
in
him
that
reminds
me
of
poor
Baby
.
 
<EOS>
Earnestness
is
what
that
Somebody
must
look
for
,
to
sustain
him
and
improve
him
,
Trot
.
<EOS>
Deep
,
downright
,
faithful
earnestness
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
only
knew
the
earnestness
of
Dora
,
aunt
!
"
I
cried
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Trot
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
said
again
;
"
blind
,
blind
!
"
<EOS>
and
without
knowing
why
,
I
felt
a
vague
unhappy
loss
or
want
of
something
overshadow
me
like
a
cloud
.
   
<EOS>
"
However
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
I
do
n't
want
to
put
two
young
creatures
out
of
conceit
with
themselves
,
or
to
make
them
unhappy
;
so
,
though
it
is
a
girl
and
boy
attachment
,
and
girl
and
boy
attachments
very
often
---
mind
!
<EOS>
I
do
n't
say
always
!
<EOS>
---
come
to
nothing
,
still
we
'll
be
serious
about
it
,
and
hope
for
a
prosperous
issue
one
of
these
days
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
time
enough
for
it
to
come
to
anything
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
not
upon
the
whole
very
comforting
to
a
rapturous
lover
;
but
I
was
glad
to
have
my
aunt
in
my
confidence
,
and
I
was
mindful
of
her
being
fatigued
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
thanked
her
ardently
for
this
mark
of
her
affection
,
and
for
all
her
other
kindnesses
towards
me
;
and
after
a
tender
good
night
,
she
took
her
nightcap
into
my
bedroom
.
   
<EOS>
How
miserable
I
was
,
when
I
lay
down
!
 
<EOS>
How
I
thought
and
thought
about
my
being
poor
,
in
Mr
Spenlow
's
eyes
;
about
my
not
being
what
I
thought
I
was
,
when
I
proposed
to
Dora
;
about
the
chivalrous
necessity
of
telling
Dora
what
my
worldly
condition
was
,
and
releasing
her
from
her
engagement
if
she
thought
fit
;
about
how
I
should
contrive
to
live
,
during
the
long
term
of
my
articles
,
when
I
was
earning
nothing
;
about
doing
something
to
assist
my
aunt
,
and
seeing
no
way
of
doing
anything
;
about
coming
down
to
have
no
money
in
my
pocket
,
and
to
wear
a
shabby
coat
,
and
to
be
able
to
carry
Dora
no
little
presents
,
and
to
ride
no
gallant
greys
,
and
to
show
myself
in
no
agreeable
light
!
 
<EOS>
Sordid
and
selfish
as
I
knew
it
was
,
and
as
I
tortured
myself
by
knowing
that
it
was
,
to
let
my
mind
run
on
my
own
distress
so
much
,
I
was
so
devoted
to
Dora
that
I
could
not
help
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
that
it
was
base
in
me
not
to
think
more
of
my
aunt
,
and
less
of
myself
;
but
,
so
far
,
selfishness
was
inseparable
from
Dora
,
and
I
could
not
put
Dora
on
one
side
for
any
mortal
creature
.
 
<EOS>
How
exceedingly
miserable
I
was
,
that
night
!
   
<EOS>
As
to
sleep
,
I
had
dreams
of
poverty
in
all
sorts
of
shapes
,
but
I
seemed
to
dream
without
the
previous
ceremony
of
going
to
sleep
.
<EOS>
Now
I
was
ragged
,
wanting
to
sell
Dora
matches
,
six
bundles
for
a
halfpenny
;
now
I
was
at
the
office
in
a
nightgown
and
boots
,
remonstrated
with
by
Mr
Spenlow
on
appearing
before
the
clients
in
that
airy
attire
;
now
I
was
hungrily
picking
up
the
crumbs
that
fell
from
old
Tiffey
's
daily
biscuit
,
regularly
eaten
when
St
Paul
's
struck
one
;
now
I
was
hopelessly
endeavouring
to
get
a
licence
to
marry
Dora
,
having
nothing
but
one
of
Uriah
Heep
's
gloves
to
offer
in
exchange
,
which
the
whole
Commons
rejected
;
and
still
,
more
or
less
conscious
of
my
own
room
,
I
was
always
tossing
about
like
a
distressed
ship
in
a
sea
of
bed
-
clothes
.
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
was
restless
,
too
,
for
I
frequently
heard
her
walking
to
and
fro
.
 
<EOS>
Two
or
,
three
times
in
the
course
of
the
night
,
attired
in
a
long
flannel
wrapper
in
which
she
looked
seven
feet
high
,
she
appeared
,
like
a
disturbed
ghost
,
in
my
room
,
and
came
to
the
side
of
the
sofa
on
which
I
lay
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
first
occasion
I
started
up
in
alarm
,
to
learn
that
she
inferred
from
a
particular
light
in
the
sky
,
that
Westminster
Abbey
was
on
fire
;
and
to
be
consulted
in
reference
to
the
probability
of
its
igniting
Buckingham
Street
,
in
case
the
wind
changed
.
 
<EOS>
Lying
still
,
after
that
,
I
found
that
she
sat
down
near
me
,
whispering
to
herself
"
Poor
boy
!
"
<EOS>
And
then
it
made
me
twenty
times
more
wretched
,
to
know
how
unselfishly
mindful
she
was
of
me
,
and
how
selfishly
mindful
I
was
of
myself
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
difficult
to
believe
that
a
night
so
long
to
me
,
could
be
short
to
anybody
else
.
 
<EOS>
This
consideration
set
me
thinking
and
thinking
of
an
imaginary
party
where
people
were
dancing
the
hours
away
,
until
that
became
a
dream
too
,
and
I
heard
the
music
incessantly
playing
one
tune
,
and
saw
Dora
incessantly
dancing
one
dance
,
without
taking
the
least
notice
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
who
had
been
playing
the
harp
all
night
,
was
trying
in
vain
to
cover
it
with
an
ordinary
-
sized
nightcap
,
when
I
awoke
;
or
I
should
rather
say
,
when
I
left
off
trying
to
go
to
sleep
,
and
saw
the
sun
shining
in
through
the
window
at
last
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
an
old
Roman
bath
in
those
days
at
the
bottom
of
one
of
the
streets
out
of
the
Strand
---
it
may
be
there
still
---
in
which
I
have
had
many
a
cold
plunge
.
 
<EOS>
Dressing
myself
as
quietly
as
I
could
,
and
leaving
Peggotty
to
look
after
my
aunt
,
I
tumbled
head
foremost
into
it
,
and
then
went
for
a
walk
to
Hampstead
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
hope
that
this
brisk
treatment
might
freshen
my
wits
a
little
;
and
I
think
it
did
them
good
,
for
I
soon
came
to
the
conclusion
that
the
first
step
I
ought
to
take
was
,
to
try
if
my
articles
could
be
cancelled
and
the
premium
recovered
.
 
<EOS>
I
got
some
breakfast
on
the
Heath
,
and
walked
back
to
Doctors
'
Commons
,
along
the
watered
roads
   
and
through
a
pleasant
smell
of
summer
flowers
,
growing
in
gardens
and
carried
into
town
on
hucksters
'

,
intent
on
this
first
effort
to
meet
our
altered

.
   
<EOS>
I
arrived
at
the
office
so
soon
,
after
all
,
<EOS>
that
I
had
half
an
hour
's
loitering
about
the
Commons
,
before
old
Tiffey
,
who
was
always
first
,
appeared
with
his
key
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
sat
down
in
my
shady
corner
,
looking
up
at
the
sunlight
on
the
opposite
chimney
-
pots
,
and
thinking
about
Dora
;
until
Mr
Spenlow
came
in
,
crisp
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
,
Copperfield
?
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fine
morning
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Beautiful
morning
,
sir
,
"
said
<EOS>
I.
 
"
Could
I
say
a
word
to
you
before
you
go
into
Court
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
all
means
,
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
into
my
room
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
followed
him
into
his
room
,
and
he
began
putting
on
his
gown
,
and
touching
himself
up
before
a
little
glass
he
had
,
hanging

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
say
,
"
said
I
,
"
that
I
have
some
rather
disheartening
intelligence
from
my
aunt
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
 
<EOS>
Not
paralysis
,
I
hope
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
has
no
reference
to
her
health
,
sir
,
"
I
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
met
with
some
large

.
 
<EOS>
In
fact
,
she
has
very
little
left
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
as
-
tound
me
,
Copperfield
!
"
cried
Mr
Spenlow
.
   
<EOS>
I
shook
my
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
sir
,
"
said
I
,
"
her
affairs
are
so
changed
,
that
I
wished
to
ask
you
whether
it
would
be
possible
---
at
a

on
our
part
of
some
portion
of
the
premium
,
of
course
,
"
I
put
in
this
,
on
the
spur
of
the
moment
,
warned
by
the
blank

of
his
face
---
"
to
cancel
my
articles
?
"
   
<EOS>
What
it
cost
me
to
make
this
proposal
,
nobody
knows
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
like
asking
,
as
a
favour
,
to
be
sentenced
to
transportation
from
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
cancel
your
articles
,
Copperfield
?
 
<EOS>
Cancel
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
explained
with
tolerable
firmness
,
that
I
really
did
not
know
where
my
means
of
subsistence
were
to
come
from
,
unless
I
could
earn
them
for
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
fear
for
the
future
,
I
said
---
<EOS>
and
I
laid
great
emphasis
on
that
,
as
if
to
imply
that
I
should
still
be
decidedly
eligible
for
a
son
-
in
-
law
one
of
these
days
---
but
,
for
the
present
,
I
was
thrown
upon
my
own
resources
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
extremely
sorry
to
hear
this
,
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Extremely
sorry
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
usual
to
cancel
articles
for
any
such
reason
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
a
professional
course
of
proceeding
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
a
convenient
precedent
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
Far
from
it
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
---
"
   
"
You
are
very
good
,
sir
,
"
I
murmured
,
anticipating
a
concession
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
mention
it
,
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
the
same
time
,
I
was
going
to
say
,
if
it
had
been
my
lot
to
have
my
hands
unfettered
---
if
I
had
not
a
partner
---
<EOS>
Mr
Jorkins
---
"
   
My
hopes
were
dashed
in
a
moment
,
but
I
made
another
effort
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
,
sir
,
"
said
I
,
"
if
I
were
to
mention
it
to
Mr
Jorkins
---
"
   
Mr
Spenlow
shook
his
head
discouragingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
forbid
,
Copperfield
<EOS>
,
"
he
replied
,
"
that
I
should
do
any
man
an
injustice
:
still
less
,
Mr
jorkins
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
know
my
partner
,
Copperfield
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
jorkins
is
not
a
man
to
respond
to
a
proposition
of
this
peculiar
nature
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
jorkins
is
very
difficult
to
move
from
the
beaten
track
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
what
he
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
am
sure
I
knew
nothing
about
him
,
except
that
he
had
originally
been
alone
in
the
business
,
and
now
lived
by
himself
in
a
house
near
Montagu
Square
,
which
was
fearfully
in
want
of
painting
;
that
he
came
very
late
of
a
day
,
and
went
away
very
early
;
that
he
never
appeared
to
be
consulted
about
anything
;
and
that
he
had
a
dingy
little
black
-
hole
of
his
own
upstairs
,
where
no
business
was
ever
done
,
and
where
there
was
a
yellow
old
cartridge
-
paper
pad
upon
his
desk
,
unsoiled
by
ink
,
and
reported
to
be
twenty
years
of
age
.
   
<EOS>
"
Would
you
object
to
my
mentioning
it
to
him
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
By
no
means
,
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
some
experience
of
Mr
jorkins
,
Copperfield
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
it
were
otherwise
,
for
I
should
be
happy
to
meet
your
views
in
any
respect
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
have
the
objection
to
your
mentioning
it
to
Mr
jorkins
,
Copperfield
,
if
you
think
it
worth
while
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Availing
myself
of
this
permission
,
which
was
given
with
a
warm
shake
of
the
hand
,
I
sat
thinking
about
Dora
,
and
looking
at
the
sunlight
stealing
from
the
chimney
-
pots
down
the
wall
of
the
opposite
house
,
until
Mr
jorkins
came
.
 
<EOS>
I
then
went
up
to
Mr
jorkins
's
room
,
and
evidently
astonished
Mr
jorkins
very
much
by
making
my
appearance
there
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
jorkins
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
in
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
went
in
,
and
sat
down
;
and
stated
my
case
to
Mr
jorkins
pretty
much
as
I
had
stated
it
to
Mr
Spenlow
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jorkins
was
not
by
any
means
the
awful
creature
one
might
have
expected
,
but
a
large
,
mild
,
smooth
-
faced
man
of
sixty
,
who
took
so
much
snuff
that
there
was
a
tradition
in
the
Commons
that
he
lived
principally
on
that
stimulant
,
having
little
room
in
his
system
for
any
other
article
of
diet
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
mentioned
this
to
Mr
Spenlow
,
I
suppose
?
"
said
Mr
jorkins
;
when
he
had
heard
me
,
very
restlessly
,
to
an
end
.
   
<EOS>
I
answered
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
told
him
that
Mr
Spenlow
had
introduced
his
name
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
said
I
should
object
?
"
asked
Mr
jorkins
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
obliged
to
admit
that
Mr
Spenlow
had
considered
it
probable
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
say
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
I
ca
n't
advance
your
object
,
"
said
Mr
jorkins
,
nervously
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
fact
is
---
<EOS>
but
I
have
an
appointment
at
the
Bank
,
if
you
'll
have
the
goodness
to
excuse
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
that
he
rose
in
a
great
hurry
,
and
was
going
out
of
the
room
,
when
I
made
bold
to
say
that
I
feared
,
then
<EOS>
,
there
was
no
way
of
arranging
the
matter
?
   
<EOS>

No

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
No

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Least
said
,
soonest
mended
!
"
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
concluded
this
philosophical
summary
,
by
fixing
her
eyes
with
a
kind
of
triumph
on
Agnes
,
whose
colour
was
gradually
returning
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
Miss
Trotwood
,
is
that
all
the
history
?
"
said
Agnes
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
it
's
enough
,
child
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
there
had
been
more
money
to
lose
,
it
would
n't
have
been
all
,
I
dare
say
.
 
<EOS>
Betsey
would
have
contrived
to
throw
that
after
the
rest
,
and
make
another
chapter
,
I
have
little
doubt
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
no
more
money
,
and
there
's
no
more
story
.
"
   
<EOS>
Agnes
had
listened
at
first
with
suspended

.
 
<EOS>
Her
colour
still
came
and
went
,
but
she
breathed
more

.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
I
knew
why
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
she
had
had
some
fear
that
her
unhappy
father
might
be
in
some

blame
for
what
had

.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
took
her

in
hers
,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
all
?
"
repeated

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
yes
,
that
's
all
,
except
,
"
<EOS>
And
she
lived
happy

.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
may
add
that
of
Betsey
yet
,
one

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
Agnes
,
you
have
a

.
<EOS>
So

you
,
Trot
,
in
some

,
though
I
ca
n't
compliment

always
"
;
and

her

at
me
,
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
to

done
?
 
<EOS>
Here
's
the
cottage
,
taking
one
time
with
another
,
will
produce
say
seventy
pounds
a
year
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
we
may
safely

it
down
at
that
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
---
That
's
all
we
've

,
"
said
my
aunt
;
with

it

,
as

to
stop

when
she

going

.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"

,

"
there
's

.
 
<EOS>
He

good

a
hundred

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

,
than

,

.
 
<EOS>
How

do
best
,
upon

?
 
<EOS>
What

say
,
Agnes
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
aunt
,
"
I

"
that

do

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Go
for

,

you
mean
?
<EOS>
"

,

;
"
or
go

?
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't

of
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
to

.
 
<EOS>
We

THIS

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

,

Agnes

?
   
<EOS>
"
You

point
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
They

,

,
unless
they
could

underlet
,

do

.
 
<EOS>
The

died
here
.
 
<EOS>
Five

six
would
die
---
of

of
that

.
 
<EOS>
I
have

;

,

,

,
to

here
,
and
get
a
bedroom
hard

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
thought

my
duty
to
hint

the

my
aunt

,
from
living

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
Trotwood
,
"

"
that
if

had

---
"
   
"
I

,
Agnes
.
 
<EOS>
I

,

early

.
 
<EOS>
In

<EOS>
and

,
"

,

<EOS>

,

to

,
"
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

"

I

"
the

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mind

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because

"

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
Do

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear

!
"

<EOS>
"
What

!
 
<EOS>
You

my

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
never

you

.
"
   
<EOS>
Agnes
answered
with
her
pleasant

,
that
one
good
Angel
(
meaning
Dora
)
was
enough
;
and
went
on
to
remind
me
that
the
Doctor
had
been
used
to
occupy
himself
in

,
early

,
and
in

---
and
that
probably
my
leisure
would
suit
his
requirements
very
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
scarcely
more
delighted
with
the
prospect
of
earning
my
own
bread
,
than
with
the
hope
of
earning
it
under

old

;
in

,
acting

the

Agnes
,

to

,
stating

,
and

next

.
 
<EOS>
This
<EOS>
I
addressed
to
Highgate
---
for
in
that

,
so

me
,
he
lived
---
and
went
and
posted
,
myself
,
without

.
   
<EOS>
Wherever

was
,
some
agreeable

of
her
noiseless

<EOS>
seemed

from
the

.
 
<EOS>
When
I
came
back
,
I
found
my
aunt
's
birds
hanging
,
just

had

so

in
the

;
and
my

-
chair

;
and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
who
had
done
all
this
,
by
its

quietly

;
and

in

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
was
quite

on
the

the
Thames
<EOS>
(
it
really

,

)
,

,

,

,
"
peppered

"
.
 
<EOS>
A

,

Peggotty

,
was

,

little

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
"
said

,

,
"
it
's
papa
.
 
<EOS>
He

.
"
   
<EOS>
I

,
and

,
not

Wickfield
,

Uriah
Heep
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
not

Mr
Wickfield
for
some

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
prepared
for
a
great
change
in
him
,
after
what
I
had
heard
from
Agnes
,
but

.
   
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
he
looked
many
years

,
though
still

old

;

;

;

in

,
the

which
I
knew
,
and
had
for
some
years
seen
at

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
he
had
lost
his

looks
,
or
his
old

of
a

---
for
that

---

that

,

that

Uriah
Heep
.
 
<EOS>
The
reversal
of
the
two

,
in
their
relative
positions
,
Uriah
's
of
power
and
Mr
Wickfield
's
of

,
was

to

I
can
express
.
 
<EOS>
If

seen
an
Ape

,
I

hardly

thought

.
   
<EOS>
He
appeared
to
be
only
too

of
it
himself
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
came
in
,
he
stood
still
;
and
with

,
as
if
he
felt

.
<EOS>
This
was

;
for
Agnes
softly

,
"
Papa
!
<EOS>
Here

Miss
Trotwood
---
and
Trotwood
,
whom

have
not

a
long

!
"
<EOS>
and

,

aunt
his

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
In

I
speak
of
<EOS>
,
I

Uriah
's
countenance

itself

a
most

.
 
<EOS>
Agnes
saw
it
too
,
I

,
for

.
   
<EOS>
What
my
aunt
saw
,
or

,
I
defy

science
of
physiognomy
to
have
made

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
there
never
was
anybody

when
she

.
<EOS>
Her

might

the

,
for
any
light

;
until

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Wickfield
!
"
said
my

;
and

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
telling
your
daughter
how
well
I
have

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

.
 
<EOS>
Agnes

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
If

,
"

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"

,
"
and
that
's
about

you
<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
How

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
In

,

,

,

he
was
pretty

,
he

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
you
,
Master
---
I

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

!
 
<EOS>
I

,
Mister
Copperfield
,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I

that
;
for
he

to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Present

is
not
what
your

,
Mister
Copperfield
,
but
it

n't
money
makes
the
man
<EOS>
:
it
's
---
<EOS>
I
am
really
unequal
with
my

powers
to
express

,
"
said

,
with

,
"
but

!
"
   
<EOS>
Here
he

with

:
not

,
but

,

,
that

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

looking
,
Master
Copperfield
,
---
I

,
Mister
?
<EOS>
"
fawned

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
find
Mr
Wickfield
blooming
,

?
 
<EOS>
Years
do

much
in

firm
,
Master
Copperfield
,
except
in
raising
up
the
umble
,
namely
,
mother

---

"
he

"
the

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
He
jerked
himself
about
,
after
this
compliment
,
in
such
an
intolerable
manner
,
that
my
aunt
,
who
had
sat
looking
straight
at
him
,
lost
all
patience
.
   
<EOS>
"
Deuce
take
the
man
!
"
<EOS>
said
my
aunt
,
sternly
,
"
what
's
he
about
?
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
galvanic
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ask
your
pardon
,
Miss
Trotwood
,
"
returned
Uriah
;
"
I
'm
aware
you
're
nervous
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Go
along
with
you
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
said
my
aunt
,
anything
but
appeased
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
presume
to
say
so
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
nothing
of
the
sort
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
're
an
eel
,
sir
,
conduct
yourself
like
one
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
're
a
man
,
control
your
limbs
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
Good
God
!
"
said
my
aunt
,
with
great
indignation
,
"
I
am
not
going
to
be
serpentined
and
corkscrewed
out
of
my
senses
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Heep
was
rather
abashed
,
as
most
people
might
have
been
,
by
this
explosion
;
which
derived
great
additional
force
from
the
indignant
manner
in
which
my
aunt
afterwards
moved
in
her
chair
,
and
shook
her
head
as
if
she
were
making
snaps
or
bounces
at
him
.
<EOS>
But
he
said
to
me
aside
in
a
meek
voice
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
well
aware
,
Master
Copperfield
,
that
Miss
Trotwood
,
though
an
excellent
lady
,
has
a
quick
temper
(
indeed
I
think
I
had
the
pleasure
of
knowing
her
,
when
I
was
a
numble
clerk
,
before
you
did
,
Master
Copperfield
)
,
and
it
's
only
natural
,
I
am
sure
,
that
it
should
be
made
quicker
by
present
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
The
wonder
is
,
that
it
is
n't
much
worse
!
 
<EOS>
I
only
called
to
say
that
if
there
was
anything
we
could
do
,
in
present
circumstances
,
mother
or
self
,
or
Wickfield
and
Heep
,
---
we
should
be
really
glad
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
go
so
far
?
<EOS>
"
said
Uriah
,
with
a
sickly
smile
at
his
partner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Uriah
Heep
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
,
in
a
monotonous
forced
way
,
"
is
active
in
the
business
,
Trotwood
.
 
<EOS>
What
he
says
,
I
quite
concur
in
.
<EOS>
You
know
I
had
an
old
interest
in
you
.
 
<EOS>
Apart
from
that
,
what
Uriah
says
I
quite
concur
in
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
what
a
reward
it
is
,
"
said
Uriah
,
drawing
up
one
leg
,
at
the
risk
of
bringing
down
upon
himself
another
visitation
from
my
aunt
,
"
to
be
so
trusted
in
!
 
<EOS>
But
I
hope
I
am
able
to
do
something
to
relieve
him
from
the
fatigues
of
business
,
Master
Copperfield
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Uriah
Heep
is
a
great
relief
to
me
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
,
in
the
same
dull
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
load
off
my
mind
,
Trotwood
,
to
have
such
a
partner
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
red
fox
made
him
say
all
this
,
I
knew
,
to
exhibit
him
to
me
in
the
light
he
had
indicated
on
the
night
when
he
poisoned
my
rest
.
<EOS>
I
saw
the
same
ill
-
favoured
smile
upon
his
face
again
,
and
saw
how
he
watched
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
going
,
papa
?
"
said
Agnes
,
anxiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
not
walk
back
with
Trotwood
and
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
would
have
looked
to
Uriah
,
I
believe
,
before
replying
,
if
that
worthy
had
not
anticipated
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
bespoke
myself
,
"
said
Uriah
,
"
on
business
;
otherwise
I
should
have
been
appy
to
have
kept
with
my
friends
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
leave
my
partner
to
represent
the
firm
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Agnes
,
ever
yours
!
 
<EOS>
I
wish
you
good
-
day
,
Master
Copperfield
,
and
leave
my
umble
respects
for
Miss
Betsey
Trotwood
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
those
words
,
he
retired
,
kissing
his
great
hand
,
and
leering
at
us
like
a
mask
.
   
<EOS>
We
sat
there
,
talking
about
our
pleasant
old
Canterbury
days
,
an
hour
or
two
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Wickfield
,
left
to
Agnes
,
soon
became
more
like
his
former
self
;
though
there
was
a
settled
depression
upon
him
,
which
he
never
shook
off
.
 
<EOS>
For
all
that
,
he
brightened
;
and
had
an
evident
pleasure
in
hearing
us
recall
the
little
incidents
of
our
old
life
<EOS>
,
many
of
which
he
remembered
very
well
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
it
was
like
those
times
,
to
be
alone
with
Agnes
and
me
again
;
and
he
wished
to
Heaven
they
had
never
changed
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
there
was
an
influence
in
the
placid
face
of
Agnes
,
and
in
the
very
touch
of
her
hand
upon
his
arm
,
that
did
wonders
for
him
.
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
(
who
was
busy
nearly
all
this
while
with
Peggotty
,
in
the
inner
room
)
would
not
accompany
us
to
the
place
where
they
were
staying
,
but
insisted
on
my
going
;
and
I
went
.
 
<EOS>
We
dined
together
.
<EOS>
After
dinner
,
Agnes
sat
beside
him
,
as
of
old
,
and
poured
out
his
wine
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
what
she
gave
him
,
and
no
more
---
like
a
child
---
<EOS>
and
we
all
three
sat
together
at
a
window
as
the
evening
gathered
in
.
<EOS>
When
it
was
almost
dark
,
he
lay
down
on
a
sofa
,
Agnes
pillowing
his
head
and
bending
over
him
a
little
while
;
and
when
she
came
back
to
the
window
,
it
was
not
so
dark
<EOS>
but
I
could
see
tears
glittering
in
her
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
I
pray
Heaven
that
I
never
may
forget
the
dear
girl
in
her
love
and
truth
,
at
that
time
of
my
life
;
for
if
I
should
,
I
must
be
drawing
near
the
end
,
and
then
I
would
desire
to
remember
her
best
!
 
<EOS>
She
filled
my
heart
with
such
good
resolutions
,
strengthened
my
weakness
so
,
by
her
example
,
so
directed
---
I
know
not
how
,
she
was
too
modest
and
gentle
to
advise
me
in
many
words
---
the
wandering
ardour
and
unsettled
purpose
within
me
,
that
all
the
little
good
I
have
done
,
and
all
the
harm
I
have
forborne
,
I
solemnly
believe
I
may
refer
to
her
.
   
<EOS>
And
how
she
spoke
to
me
of
Dora
,
sitting
at
the
window
in
the
dark
;
listened
to
my
praises
of
her
;
praised
again
;
and
round
the
little
fairy
-
figure
shed
some
glimpses
of
her
own
pure
light
,
that
made
it
yet
more
precious
and
more
innocent
to
me
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
Agnes
,
sister
of
my
boyhood
,
<EOS>
if
I
had
known
then
,
what
I
knew
long
afterwards
!
<EOS>
---
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
beggar
in
the
street
,
when
I
went
down
;
and
as
I
turned
my
head
towards
the
window
,
thinking
of
her
calm
seraphic
eyes
,
he
made
me
start
by
muttering
,
as
if
he
were
an
echo
of
the
morning
:
"
Blind
!
 
<EOS>
Blind
!
 
<EOS>
Blind
!
"
      
<EOS>
Chapter
36
.
<EOS>
Enthusiasm
 
<EOS>
I
began
the
next
day
with
another
dive
into
the
Roman
bath
,
and
then
started
for
Highgate
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
dispirited
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
afraid
of
the
shabby
coat
,
and
had
no
yearnings
after
gallant
greys
.
 
<EOS>
My
whole
manner
of
thinking
of
our
late
misfortune
was
changed
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
had
to
do
,
was
,
to
show
my
aunt
that
her
past
goodness
to
me
had
not
been
thrown
away
on
an
insensible
,
ungrateful
object
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
had
to
do
,
was
,
to
turn
the
painful
discipline
of
my
younger
days
to
account
,
by
going
to
work
with
a
resolute
and
steady
heart
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
had
to
do
,
was
,
to
take
my
woodman
's
axe
in
my
hand
,
and
clear
my
own
way
through
the
forest
of
difficulty
,
by
cutting
down
the
trees
until
I
came
to
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
went
on
at
a
mighty
rate
,
as
if
it
could
be
done
by
walking
.
   
<EOS>
When
I
found
myself
on
the
familiar
Highgate
road
,
pursuing
such
a
different
errand
from
that
old
one
of
pleasure
,
with
which
it
was
associated
,
it
seemed
as
if
a
complete
change
had
come
on
my
whole
life
.
 
<EOS>
But
that
did
not
discourage
me
.
 
<EOS>
With
the
new
life
,
came
new
purpose
,
new
intention
.
 
<EOS>
Great
was
the
labour
;
priceless
the
reward
.
 
<EOS>
Dora
was
the
reward
,
and
Dora
must
be
won
.
   
<EOS>
I
got
into
such
a
transport
,
that
I
felt
quite
sorry
<EOS>
my
coat
was
not
a
little
shabby
already
.
 
<EOS>
I
wanted
to
be
cutting
at
those
trees
in
the
forest
of
difficulty
,
under
circumstances
that
should
prove
my
strength
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
a
good
mind
to
ask
an
old
man
,
in
wire
spectacles
,
who
was
breaking
stones
upon
the
road
,
to
lend
me
his
hammer
for
a
little
while
,
and
let
me
begin
to
beat
a
path
to
Dora
out
of
granite
.
 
<EOS>
I
stimulated
myself
into
such
a
heat
,
and
got
so
out
of
breath
,
that
I
felt
as
if
I
had
been
earning
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
much
.
   
<EOS>
In
this
state
,
I
went
into
a
cottage
that
I
saw
was
to
let
,
and
examined
it
narrowly
,
---
for
I
felt
it
necessary
to
be
practical
.
<EOS>
It
would
do
for
me
and
Dora
admirably
:
with
a
little
front
garden
for
Jip
to
run
about
in
,
and
bark
at
the
tradespeople
through
the
railings
,
and
a
capital
room
upstairs
for
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
I
came
out
again
,
hotter
and
faster
than
ever
,
and
dashed
up
to
Highgate
,
at
such
a
rate
that
I
was
there
an
hour
too
early
;
and
,
though
I
had
not
been
,
should
have
been
obliged
to
stroll
about
to
cool
myself
,
before
I
was
at
all
presentable
.
   
<EOS>
My
first
care
,
after
putting
myself
under
this
necessary
course
of
preparation
,
was
to
find
the
Doctor
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
in
that
part
of
Highgate
where
Mrs
Steerforth
lived
,
but
quite
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
little
town
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
had
made
this
discovery
,
I
went
back
,
in
an
attraction
I
could
not
resist
,
to
a
lane
by
Mrs
Steerforth
's
,
and
looked
over
the
corner
of
the
garden
wall
.
 
<EOS>
His
room
was
shut
up
close
.
 
<EOS>
The
conservatory
doors
were
standing
open
,
and
Rosa
Dartle
was
walking
,
bareheaded
,
with
a
quick
,
impetuous
step
,
up
and
down
a
gravel
walk
on
one
side
of
the
lawn
.
 
<EOS>
She
gave
me
the
idea
of
some
fierce
thing
<EOS>
,
that
was
dragging
the
length
of
its
chain
to
and
fro
upon
a
beaten
track
,
and
wearing
its
heart
out
.
   
<EOS>
I
came
softly
away
from
my
place
of
observation
,
and
avoiding
that
part
of
the
neighbourhood
,
and
wishing
I
had
not
gone
near
it
,
strolled
about
until
it
was
ten
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
The
church
with
the
slender
spire
,
that
stands
on
the
top
of
the
hill
now
,
was
not
there
then
to
tell
me
the
time
.
 
<EOS>
An
old
red
-
brick
mansion
,
used
as
a
school
,
was
in
its
place
;
and
a
fine
old
house
it
must
have
been
to
go
to
school
at
,
as
I
recollect
it
.
   
<EOS>
When
I
approached
the
Doctor
's
cottage
---
a
pretty
old
place
,
on
which
he
seemed
to
have
expended
some
money
,
if
I
might
judge
from
the
embellishments
and
repairs
that
had
the
look
of
being
just
completed
---
I
saw
him
walking
in
the
garden
at
the
side
,
gaiters
and
all
,
as
if
he
had
never
left
off
walking
since
the
days
of
my
pupilage
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
his
old
companions
about
him
,
too
;
for
there
were
plenty
of
high
trees
in
the
neighbourhood
,
and
two
or
three
rooks
were
on
the
grass
,
looking
after
him
,
as
if
they
had
been
written
to
about
him
by
the
Canterbury
rooks
,
and
were
observing
him
closely
in
consequence
.
   
<EOS>
Knowing
the
utter
hopelessness
of
attracting
his
attention
from
that
distance
,
I
made
bold
to
open
the
gate
,
and
walk
after
him
,
so
as
to
meet
him
when
he
should
turn
round
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
did
,
and
came
towards
me
,
he
looked
at
me
thoughtfully
for
a
few
moments
,
evidently
without
thinking
about
me
at
all
;
and
then
his
benevolent
face
expressed
extraordinary
pleasure
,
and
he
took
me
by
both
hands
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
dear
Copperfield
,
"
said
the
Doctor
,
"
you
are
a
man
!
 
<EOS>
How
do
you
do
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
delighted
to
see
you
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
Copperfield
,
how
very
much
you
have
improved
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
quite
---
<EOS>
yes
---
dear
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
hoped
he
was
well
,
and
Mrs
Strong
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
dear
,
yes
!
"
said
the
Doctor
;
"
Annie
's
quite
well
,
and
she
'll
be
delighted
to
see
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
always
her
favourite
.
 
<EOS>
She
said
so
,
last
night
,
when
I
showed
her
your
letter
.
 
<EOS>
And
---
yes
,
to
be
sure
---
you
recollect
Mr
Jack
Maldon
,
Copperfield
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perfectly
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
"
said
the
Doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
pretty
well
,
too
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Has
he
come
home
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
I
inquired
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
From
India
?
"
said
the
Doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jack
Maldon
could
n't
bear
the
climate
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Markleham
---
you
have
not
forgotten
Mrs
Markleham
?
"
   
<EOS>
Forgotten
the
Old
Soldier
!
 
<EOS>
And
in
that
short
time
!
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Markleham
,
"
said
the
Doctor
,
"
was
quite
vexed
about
him
,
poor
thing
;
so
we
have
got
him
at
home
again
;
and
we
have
bought
him
a
little
Patent
place
,
which
agrees
with
him
much
better
.
<EOS>
"
I
knew
enough
of
Mr
Jack
Maldon
to
suspect
from
this
account
that
it
was
a
place
where
there
was
not
much
to
do
,
and
which
was
pretty
well
paid
.
 
<EOS>
The
Doctor
,
walking
up
and
down
with
his
hand
on
my
shoulder
,
and
his
kind
face
turned
encouragingly
to
mine
,
went
on
:
   
"
<EOS>
Now
,
my
dear
Copperfield
,
in
reference
to
this
proposal
of
yours
.
<EOS>
It
's
very
gratifying
and
agreeable
to
me
,
I
am
sure
;
but
do
n't
you
think
you
could
do
better
?
 
<EOS>
You
achieved
distinction
,
you
know
,
when
you
were
with
us
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
qualified
for
many
good
things
.
<EOS>
You
have
laid
a
foundation
that
any
edifice
may
be
raised
upon
;
and
is
it
not
a
pity
that
you
should
devote
the
spring
-
time
of
your
life
to
such
a
poor
pursuit
as
I
can
offer
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
became
very
glowing
again
,
and
,
expressing
myself
in
a
rhapsodical
style
<EOS>
,
I
am
afraid
,
urged
my
request
strongly
;
reminding
the
Doctor
that
I
had
already
a
profession
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
"
said
the
Doctor
,
"
that
's
true
.
 
<EOS>
Certainly
,
your
having
a
profession
,
and
being
actually
engaged
in
studying
it
,
makes
a
difference
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
my
good
young
friend
,
what
's
seventy
pounds
a
year
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
doubles
our
income
,
Doctor
Strong
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
replied
the
Doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
think
of
that
!
 
<EOS>
Not
that
I
mean
to
say
it
's
rigidly
limited
to
seventy
pounds
a
-
year
,
because
I
have
always
contemplated
making
any
young
friend
<EOS>
I
might
thus
employ
,
a
present
too
.
 
<EOS>
Undoubtedly
,
"
said
the
Doctor
,
still
walking
me
up
and
down
with
his
hand
on
my
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
always
taken
an
annual
present
into
account
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
tutor
,
"
said
I
(
now
,
really
,
without
any
nonsense
)
,
"
to
whom
I
owe
more
obligations
already
than
I
ever
can
acknowledge
---
"
   
"
No
,
no
,
"
interposed
the
Doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
take
such
time
as
I
have
,
and
that
is
my
mornings
and
evenings
,
and
can
think
it
worth
seventy
pounds
a
year
,
you
will
do
me
such
a
service
as
I
can
not
express
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
said
the
Doctor
,
innocently
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
think
that
so
little
should
go
for
so
much
!
 
<EOS>
Dear
,
dear
!
 
<EOS>
And
when
you
can
do
better
,
you
will
?
 
<EOS>
On
your
word
,
now
?
"
said
the
Doctor
,
---
which
he
had
always
made
a
very
grave
appeal
to
the
honour
of
us
boys
.
   
<EOS>
"
On
my
word
,
sir
!
<EOS>
"
I
returned
,
answering
in
our
old
school
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
be
it
so
,
"
said
the
Doctor
,
clapping
me
on
the
shoulder
,
and
still
keeping
his
hand
there
,
as
we
still
walked
up
and
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
shall
be
twenty
times
happier
,
sir
,
"
said
I
,
with
a
little
---
I
hope
innocent
---
flattery
,
"
if
my
employment
is
to
be
on
the
Dictionary
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Doctor
stopped
,
smilingly
clapped
me
on
the
shoulder
again
,
and
exclaimed
,
with
a
triumph
most
delightful
to
behold
,
as
if
I
had
penetrated
to
the
profoundest
depths
of
mortal
sagacity
,
"
My
dear
young
friend
,
you
have
hit
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
IS
the
Dictionary
!
"
   
<EOS>
How
could
it
be
anything
else
!
 
<EOS>
His
pockets
were
as
full
of
it
as
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
sticking
out
of
him
in
all
directions
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
me
that
since
his
retirement
from
scholastic
life
,
he
had
been
advancing
with
it
wonderfully
;
and
that
nothing
could
suit
him
better
than
the
proposed
arrangements
for
morning
and
evening
work
,
as
it
was
his
custom
to
walk
about
in
the
daytime
with
his
considering
cap
on
.
 
<EOS>
His
papers
were
in
a
little
confusion
,
in
consequence
of
Mr
Jack
Maldon
having
lately
proffered
his
occasional
services
as
an
amanuensis
,
and
not
being
accustomed
to
that
occupation
;
but
we
should
soon
put
right
<EOS>
what
was
amiss
,
and
go
on
swimmingly
.
 
<EOS>
Afterwards
,
when
we
were
fairly
at
our
work
,
I
found
Mr
Jack
Maldon
's
efforts
more
troublesome
to
me
than
I
had
expected
,
as
he
had
not
confined
himself
to
making
numerous
mistakes
,
but
had
sketched
so
many
soldiers
,
and
ladies
'
heads
,
over
the
Doctor
's
manuscript
,
that
I
often
became
involved
in
labyrinths
of
obscurity
.
   
<EOS>
The
Doctor
was
quite
happy
in
the
prospect
of
our
going
to
work
together
on
that
wonderful
performance
,
and
we
settled
to
begin
next
morning
at
seven
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
to
work
two
hours
every
morning
,
and
two
or
three
hours
every
night
,
except
on
Saturdays
,
when
I
was
to
rest
.
 
<EOS>
On
Sundays
,
of
course
,
I
was
to
rest
also
,
and
I
considered
these
very
easy
terms
.
   
<EOS>
Our
plans
being
thus
arranged
to
our
mutual
satisfaction
,
the
Doctor
took
me
into
the
house
to
present
me
to
Mrs
Strong
,
whom
we
found
in
the
Doctor
's
new
study
,
dusting
his
books
,
---
a
freedom
which
he
never
permitted
anybody
else
to
take
with
those
sacred
favourites
.
   
<EOS>
They
had
postponed
their
breakfast
on
my
account
,
and
we
sat
down
to
table
together
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
not
been
seated
long
,
when
I
saw
an
approaching
arrival
in
Mrs
Strong
's
face
,
before
I
heard
any
sound
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
A
gentleman
on
horseback
came
to
the
gate
,
and
leading
his
horse
into
the
little
court
,
with
the
bridle
over
his
arm
,
as
if
he
were
quite
at
home
,
tied
him
to
a
ring
in
the
empty
coach
-
house
wall
,
and
came
into
the
breakfast
parlour
,
whip
in
hand
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
Mr
Jack
Maldon
;
and
Mr
Jack
Maldon
was
not
at
all
improved
by
India
,
I
thought
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
in
a
state
of
ferocious
virtue
,
however
,
as
to
young
men
who
were
not
cutting
down
trees
in
the
forest
of
difficulty
;
and
my
impression
must
be
received
with
due
allowance
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Jack
!
"
said
the
Doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Copperfield
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jack
Maldon
shook
hands
with
me
;
but
not
very
warmly
,
I
believed
;
and
with
an
air
of
languid
patronage
,
at
which
I
secretly
took
great
umbrage
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
languor
altogether
was
quite
a
wonderful
sight
;
except
when
he
addressed
himself
to
his
cousin
Annie
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Have
you
breakfasted
this
morning
,
Mr
Jack
?
"
said
the
Doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hardly
ever
take
breakfast
,
sir
,
"
he
replied
,
with
his
head
thrown
back
in
an
easy
-
chair
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
find
it
bores
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
there
any
news
today
?
"
inquired
the
Doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
at
all
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Maldon
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
an
account
about
the
people
being
hungry
and
discontented
down
in
the
North
,
but
they
are
always
being
hungry
and
discontented
somewhere
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Doctor
looked
grave
,
and
said
,
as
though
he
wished
to
change
the
subject
,
"
Then
there
's
no
news
at
all
;
and
no
news
,
they
say
,
is
good
news
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
long
statement
in
the
papers
,
sir
,
about
a
murder
,
"
observed
Mr
Maldon
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
somebody
is
always
being
murdered
,
and
I
did
n't
read
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
display
of
indifference
to
all
the
actions
and
passions
of
mankind
was
not
supposed
to
be
such
a
distinguished
quality
at
that
time
,
I
think
,
as
I
have
observed
it
to
be
considered
since
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
known
it
very
fashionable
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
seen
it
displayed
with
such
success
,
that
I
have
encountered
some
fine
ladies
and
gentlemen
who
might
as
well
have
been
born
caterpillars
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
impressed
me
the
more
then
,
because
it
was
new
to
me
,
but
it
certainly
did
not
tend
to
exalt
my
opinion
of
,
or
to
strengthen
my
confidence
in
,
Mr
Jack
Maldon
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
came
out
to
inquire
whether
Annie
would
like
to
go
to
the
opera
tonight
,
"
said
Mr
Maldon
,
turning
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
last
good
night
<EOS>
there
will
be
,
this
season
;
and
there
's
a
singer
there
,
whom
she
really
ought
to
hear
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
perfectly
exquisite
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
which
,
she
is
so
charmingly
ugly
,
"
relapsing
into
languor
.
   
<EOS>
The
Doctor
,
ever
pleased
with
what
was
likely
to
please
his
young
wife
,
turned
to
her
and
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
go
,
Annie
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
go
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
not
,
"
she
said
to
the
Doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
prefer
to
remain
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
much
rather
remain
at
home
.
"
   
<EOS>
Without
looking
at
her
cousin
,
she
then
addressed
me
,
and
asked
me
about
Agnes
,
and
whether
she
should
see
her
,
and
whether
she
was
not
likely
to
come
that
day
;
and
was
so
much
disturbed
,
that
I
wondered
how
even
the
Doctor
,
buttering
his
toast
,
could
be
blind
to
what
was
so
obvious
.
   
<EOS>
But
he
saw
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
her
,
good
-
naturedly
,
that
she
was
young
and
ought
to
be
amused
and
entertained
,
and
must
not
allow
herself
to
be
made
dull
by
a
dull
old
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
Moreover
,
he
said
,
he
wanted
to
hear
her
sing
all
the
new
singer
's
songs
to
him
;
and
how
could
she
do
that
well
,
unless
she
went
?
 
<EOS>
So
the
Doctor
persisted
in
making
the
engagement
for
her
,
and
Mr
Jack
Maldon
was
to
come
back
to
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
This
concluded
,
he
went
to
his
Patent
place
,
I
suppose
;
<EOS>
but
at
all
events
went
away
on
his
horse
,
looking
very
idle
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
curious
to
find
out
next
morning
,
whether
she
had
been
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
not
,
but
had
sent
into
London
to
put
her
cousin
off
;
and
had
gone
out
in
the
afternoon
to
see
Agnes
,
and
had
prevailed
upon
the
Doctor
to
go
with
her
;
and
they
had
walked
home
by
the
fields
,
the
Doctor
told
me
,
the
evening
being
delightful
.
 
<EOS>
I
wondered
then
,
whether
she
would
have
gone
if
Agnes
had
not
been
in
town
,
and
whether
Agnes
had
some
good
influence
over
her
too
!
   
<EOS>
She
did
not
look
very
happy
,
I
thought
;
but
it
was
a
good
face
,
or
a
very
false
one
.
 
<EOS>
I
often
glanced
at
it
,
for
she
sat
in
the
window
all
the
time
we
were
at
work
;
and
made
our
breakfast
,
which
we
took
by
snatches
as
we
were
employed
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
left
,
at
nine
o'clock
,
she
was
kneeling
on
the
ground
at
the
Doctor
's
feet
,
putting
on
his
shoes
and
gaiters
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
softened
shade
upon
her
face
,
thrown
from
some
green
leaves
overhanging
the
open
window
of
the
low
room
;
and
I
thought
all
the
way
to
Doctors
'
Commons
,
of
the
night
when
I
had
seen
it
looking
at
him
as
he
read
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
pretty
busy
now
;
up
at
five
in
the
morning
,
and
home
at
nine
or
ten
at
night
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
had
infinite
satisfaction
in
being
so
closely
engaged
,
and
never
walked
slowly
on
any
account
,
and
felt
enthusiastically
that
the
more
I
tired
myself
,
the
more
I
was
doing
to
deserve
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
not
revealed
myself
in
my
altered
character
to
Dora
yet
,
because
she
was
coming
to
see
Miss
Mills
in
a
few
days
,
and
I
deferred
all
I
had
to
tell
her
until
then
;
merely
informing
her
in
my
letters
(
all
our
communications
were
secretly
forwarded
through
Miss
Mills
)
,
that
I
had
much
to
tell
her
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
,
I
put
myself
on
a
short
allowance
of
bear
's
grease
,
wholly
abandoned
scented
soap
and
lavender
water
,
and
sold
off
three
waistcoats
at
a
prodigious
sacrifice
,
as
being
too
luxurious
for
my
stern
career
.
   
<EOS>
Not
satisfied
with
all
these
proceedings
,
but
burning
with
impatience
to
do
something
more
,
I
went
to
see
Traddles
,
now
lodging
up
behind
the
parapet
of
a
house
in
Castle
Street
,
Holborn
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
,
who
had
been
with
me
to
Highgate
twice
already
,
and
had
resumed
his
companionship
with
the
Doctor
,
I
took
with
me
.
   
<EOS>
I
took
Mr
Dick
with
me
,
because
,
acutely
sensitive
to
my
aunt
's
reverses
,
and
sincerely
believing
that
no
galley
-
slave
or
convict
worked
as
I
did
,
he
had
begun
to
fret
and
worry
himself
out
of
spirits
and
appetite
,
as
having
nothing
useful
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
condition
,
he
felt
more
incapable
of
finishing
the
Memorial
than
ever
;
and
the
harder
he
worked
at
it
,
the
oftener
that
unlucky
head
of
King
Charles
<EOS>
the
First
got
into
it
.
 
<EOS>
Seriously
apprehending
that
his
malady
would
increase
,
unless
we
put
some
innocent
deception
upon
him
and
caused
him
to
believe
that
he
was
useful
,
or
unless
we
could
put
him
in
the
way
of
being
really
useful
(
which
would
be
better
)
,
I
made
up
my
mind
to
try
if
Traddles
could
help
us
.
<EOS>
Before
we
went
,
I
wrote
Traddles
a
full
statement
of
all
that
had
happened
,
and
Traddles
wrote
me
back
a
capital
answer
,
expressive
of
his
sympathy
and
friendship
.
   
<EOS>
We
found
him
hard
at
work
with
his
inkstand
and
papers
,
refreshed
by
the
sight
of
the
flower
-
pot
stand
and
the
little
round
table
in
a
corner
of
the
small
apartment
.
 
<EOS>
He
received
us
cordially
,
and
made
friends
with
Mr
Dick
in
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
professed
an
absolute
certainty
of
having
seen
him
before
,
and
we
both
said
,
"
Very
likely
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
first
subject
on
which
I
had
to
consult
Traddles
was
this
<EOS>
,
---
I
had
heard
that
many
men
distinguished
in
various
pursuits
had
begun
life
by
reporting
the
debates
in
Parliament
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
having
mentioned
newspapers
to
me
,
as
one
of
his
hopes
,
I
had
put
the
two
things
together
,
and
told
Traddles
in
my
letter
that
I
wished
to
know
how
I
could
qualify
myself
for
this
pursuit
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
now
informed
me
,
as
the
result
of
his
inquiries
,
that
the
mere
mechanical
acquisition
necessary
,
except
in
rare
cases
,
for
thorough
excellence
in
it
,
that
is
to
say
,
a
perfect
and
entire
command
of
the
mystery
of
short
-
hand
writing
and
reading
,
was
about
equal
in
difficulty
to
the
mastery
of
six
languages
;
and
that
it
might
perhaps
be
attained
,
by
dint
of
perseverance
,
in
the
course
of
a
few
years
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
reasonably
supposed
that
this
would
settle
the
business
;
but
I
,
only
feeling
that
here
indeed
were
a
few
tall
trees
to
be
hewn
down
,
immediately
resolved
to
work
my
way
on
to
Dora
through
this
thicket
,
axe
in
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
much
obliged
to
you
,
my
dear
Traddles
!
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
begin
tomorrow
.
"
   
<EOS>
Traddles
looked
astonished
,
as
he
well
might
;
but
he
had
no
notion
as
yet
of
my
rapturous
condition
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
buy
a
book
,
"
said
I
,
"
with
a
good
scheme
of
this
art
in
it
;
I
'll
work
at
it
at
the
Commons
,
where
I
have
n't
half
enough
to
do
;
I
'll
take
down
the
speeches
in
our
court
for
practice
---
<EOS>
Traddles
,
my
dear
fellow
,
I
'll
master
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
"
said
Traddles
,
opening
his
eyes
,
"
I
had
no
idea
you
were
such
a
determined
character
,
Copperfield
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
he
should
have
had
,
for
it
was
new
enough
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
passed
that
off
,
and
brought
Mr
Dick
on
the
carpet
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
wistfully
,
"
if
I
could
exert
myself
,
<EOS>
Mr
Traddles
---
if
I
could
beat
a
drum
---
or
blow
anything
!
"
   
<EOS>
Poor
fellow
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
little
doubt
he
would
have
preferred
such
an
employment
in
his
heart
to
all
others
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
,
who
would
not
have
smiled
for
the
world
,
replied
composedly
:
   
"
<EOS>
But
you
are
a
very
good
penman
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
You
told
me
so
,
Copperfield
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Excellent
!
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
And
indeed
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
He
wrote
with
extraordinary
neatness
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
think
,
"
said
Traddles
,
"
you
could
copy
writings
,
sir
,
if
I
got
them
for
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
looked
doubtfully
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
Eh
,
Trotwood
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
shook
my
head
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
shook
his
,
and
sighed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tell
him
about
the
Memorial
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
   
<EOS>
I
explained
to
Traddles
that
there
was
a
difficulty
in
keeping
King
Charles
the
First
out
of
Mr
Dick
's
manuscripts
;
Mr
Dick
in
the
meanwhile
looking
very
deferentially
and
seriously
at
Traddles
,
and
sucking
his
thumb
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
these
writings
,
you
know
,
that
I
speak
of
,
are
already
drawn
up
and
finished
,
"
said
Traddles
after
a
little
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dick
has
nothing
to
do
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
Would
n't
that
make
a
difference
,
Copperfield
?
 
<EOS>
At
all
events
,
would
n't
it
be
well
to
try
?
"
   
<EOS>
This
gave
us
new
hope
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
and
<EOS>
I
laying
our
heads
together
apart
,
while
Mr
Dick
anxiously
watched
us
from
his
chair
,
we
concocted
a
scheme
in
virtue
of
which
we
got
him
to
work
next
day
,
with
triumphant
success
.
   
<EOS>
On
a
table
by
the
window
in
Buckingham
Street
,
we
set
out
the
work
Traddles
procured
for
him
---
which
was
to
make
<EOS>
,
I
forget
how
many
copies
of
a
legal
document
about
some
right
of
way
---
and
on
another
table
we
spread
the
last
unfinished
original
of
the
great
Memorial
.
<EOS>
Our
instructions
to
Mr
Dick
were
that
he
should
copy
exactly
what
he
had
before
him
,
without
the
least
departure
from
the
original
;
and
that
when
he
felt
it
necessary
to
make
the
slightest
allusion
to
King
Charles
<EOS>
the
First
,
he
should
fly
to
the
Memorial
.
 
<EOS>
We
exhorted
him
to
be
resolute
in
this
,
and
left
my
aunt
to
observe
him
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
reported
to
us
,
afterwards
,
that
,
at
first
,
he
was
like
a
man
playing
the
kettle
-
drums
,
and
constantly
divided
his
attentions
between
the
two
;
but
that
,
finding
this
confuse
and
fatigue
him
,
and
having
his
copy
there
,
plainly
before
his
eyes
,
he
soon
sat
at
it
in
an
orderly
business
-
like
manner
,
and
postponed
the
Memorial
to
a
more
convenient
time
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
although
we
took
great
care
that
he
should
have
no
more
to
do
than
was
good
for
him
,
and
although
he
did
not
begin
with
the
beginning
of
a
week
,
he
earned
by
the
following
Saturday
night
ten
shillings
and
nine
-
pence
;
and
never
,
<EOS>
while
I
live
,
shall
I
forget
his
going
about
to
all
the
shops
in
the
neighbourhood
to
change
this
treasure
into
sixpences
,
or
his
bringing
them
to
my
aunt
arranged
in
the
form
of
a
heart
upon
a
waiter
,
with
tears
of
joy
and
pride
in
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
like
one
under
the
propitious
influence
of
a
charm
,
from
the
moment
of
his
being
usefully
employed
;
and
if
there
were
a
happy
man
in
the
world
,
that
Saturday
night
,
it
was
the
grateful
creature
who
thought
my
aunt
the
most
wonderful
woman
in
existence
,
and
me
the
most
wonderful
young
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
starving
now
,
Trotwood
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
shaking
hands
with
me
in
a
corner
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
provide
for
her
,
Sir
!
"
<EOS>
and
he
flourished
his
ten
fingers
in
the
air
,
as
if
they
were
ten
banks
.
   
<EOS>
I
hardly
know
which
was
the
better
pleased
,
Traddles
or
I.
 
<EOS>
"
It
really
,
"
said
Traddles
,
suddenly
,
taking
a
letter
out
of
his
pocket
,
and
giving
it
to
me
,
"
put
Mr
Micawber
quite
out
of
my
head
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
letter
<EOS>
(
Mr
Micawber
never
missed
any
possible
opportunity
of
writing
a
letter
)
was
addressed
to
me
,
"
By
the
kindness
of
T
Traddles
,
Esquire
,
of
the
Inner
Temple
.
"
 
<EOS>
It
ran
thus
:
---
  
<EOS>
"
MY
DEAR
COPPERFIELD
,
"
   
"
You
may
possibly
not
be
unprepared
to
receive
the
intimation
that
something
has
turned
up
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
have
mentioned
to
you
on
a
former
occasion
that
I
was
in
expectation
of
such
an
event
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
about
to
establish
myself
in
one
of
the
provincial
towns
of
our
favoured
island
(
where
the
society
may
be
described
as
a
happy
admixture
of
the
agricultural
and
the
clerical
)
,
in
immediate
connexion
with
one
of
the
learned
professions
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Micawber
and
our
offspring
will
accompany
me
.
 
<EOS>
Our
ashes
,
at
a
future
period
,
will
probably
be
found
commingled
in
the
cemetery
attached
to
a
venerable
pile
,
for
which
the
spot
to
which
I
refer
has
acquired
a
reputation
,
shall
I
say
from
China
to
Peru
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
bidding
adieu
to
the
modern
Babylon
,
where
we
have
undergone
many
vicissitudes
,
I
trust
not
ignobly
,
Mrs
Micawber
and
myself
can
not
disguise
from
our
minds
that
we
part
,
it
may
be
for
years
and
it
may
be
for
ever
,
with
an
individual
linked
by
strong
associations
to
the
altar
of
our
domestic
life
.
 
<EOS>
If
,
on
the
eve
of
such
a
departure
,
you
will
accompany
our
mutual
friend
,
Mr
Thomas
Traddles
,
to
our
present
abode
,
and
there
reciprocate
the
wishes
natural
to
the
occasion
,
you
will
confer
a
Boon
"
"
<EOS>
On
"
"
One
"
"
Who
"
"
Is
"
"
Ever
yours
,
"
"
WILKINS
MICAWBER
.
"
    
<EOS>
I
was
glad
to
find
that
Mr
Micawber
had
got
rid
of
his
dust
and
ashes
,
and
that
something
really
had
turned
up
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
Learning
from
Traddles
that
the
invitation
referred
to
the
evening
then
wearing
away
,
I
expressed
my
readiness
to
do
honour
to
it
;
and
we
went
off
together
to
the
lodging
which
Mr
Micawber
occupied
as
Mr
Mortimer
,
and
which
was
situated
near
the
top
of
the
Gray
's
Inn
Road
.
   
<EOS>
The
resources
of
this
lodging
were
so
limited
,
that
we
found
the
twins
,
now
some
eight
or
nine
years
old
,
reposing
in
a
turn
-
up
bedstead
in
the
family
sitting
-
room
,
where
Mr
Micawber
had
prepared
,
in
a
wash
-
hand
-
stand
jug
<EOS>
,
what
he
called
"
a
Brew
"
of
the
agreeable
beverage
for
which
he
was
famous
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
the
pleasure
,
on
this
occasion
,
of
renewing
the
acquaintance
of
Master
Micawber
,
whom
I
found
a
promising
boy
of
about
twelve
or
thirteen
,
very
subject
to
that
restlessness
of
limb
which
is
not
an
unfrequent
phenomenon
in
youths
of
his
age
.
 
<EOS>
I
also
became
once
more
known
to
his
sister
,
Miss
Micawber
,
in
whom
,
as
Mr
Micawber
told
us
,
"
her
mother
renewed
her
youth
,
like
the
Phoenix
"
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
yourself
and
Mr
Traddles
find
us
on
the
brink
of
migration
,
and
will
excuse
any
little
discomforts
incidental
to
that
position
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Glancing
round
as
I
made
a
suitable
reply
<EOS>
,
I
observed
that
the
family
effects
were
already
packed
,
and
that
the
amount
of
luggage
was
by
no

.
 
<EOS>
I
congratulated
Mrs
Micawber
on
the
approaching
change
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
of
your
friendly
interest
in
all
our
affairs
,
I
am
well
assured
.
 
<EOS>
My
family
may
consider
it
banishment
,
if
they
please
;
but
I
am
a
wife
and
mother
,
and
I
never
will
desert
Mr
Micawber
.
"
   
<EOS>
Traddles
,
appealed
to
by
Mrs
Micawber
's
eye
,
feelingly

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
that
,
at

,
is
my
view
,
my
dear
Mr
Copperfield
and
Mr
Traddles
,
of

I

,
"
I
,
Emma
,
take

,
Wilkins
.
<EOS>
"
I
read

service
over
with
a
flat
-

on
the
previous
night
,
and
the

I
derived
from
it
was
,
that
I
never
could

Mr
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
And
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
though
it
is
possible
<EOS>
I
may
be
mistaken
in
my
view
of
the
ceremony
,
I
never
will
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
a

,
"
I
am
not
conscious
that
you
are
expected
to
do
anything
of
the
sort
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
aware
,
my
dear
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
pursued
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
that
I
am
now
about
to
cast
my
lot
among
strangers
;
and
I
am
also
aware
that
the
various
members
of
my
family
,
to

Mr
Micawber
has
written
in
the
most
gentlemanly
terms
,
announcing
that

,
have
not
taken
the
least
notice
of
Mr
Micawber
's
communication
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
I
may
be
superstitious
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
but
it
appears
to
me
that
Mr
Micawber
is
destined
never
to
receive
any
answers
whatever
to
the
great
majority
of
the
communications
he
writes
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
augur
,
from
the
silence
of
my
family
,
that
they
object
to
the
resolution
I
have
taken
;
but
I
should
not
allow
myself
to
be
swerved
from
the
path
of
duty
,
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
,
even
by
my
papa
and
mama
,
were
they
still
living
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
expressed
my
opinion
that
this
was
going
in
the
right
direction
.
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
a
sacrifice
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
to
immure
one's
-
self
in
a
Cathedral
town
;
but
surely
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
if
it
is
a
sacrifice
in
me
,
it
is
much
more
a
sacrifice
in
a
man
of
Mr
Micawber
's
abilities
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
going
to
a
Cathedral
town
?
"
said
I.
   
Mr
Micawber
,
who
had
been
helping
us
all
,
out
of
the
wash
-
hand
-
stand
jug
,
replied
:
   
"
To
Canterbury
.
 
<EOS>
In
fact
,
my
dear
Copperfield
,
I
have
entered
into
arrangements
,
by
virtue
of
which
I
stand
pledged
and
contracted
to
our
friend
Heep
,
to
assist
and
serve
him
in
the
capacity
of
---
and
to
be
---
his
confidential
clerk
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
stared
at
Mr
Micawber
,
who
greatly
enjoyed
my
surprise
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
bound
to
state
to
you
,
"
he
said
,
with
an
official
air
,
"
that
the
business
habits
,
and
the
prudent
suggestions
,
of
Mrs
Micawber
,
have
in
a
great
measure
conduced
to
this
result
.
 
<EOS>
The
gauntlet
,
to
which
Mrs
Micawber
referred
upon
a
former
occasion
,
being
thrown
down
in
the
form
of
an
advertisement
,
was
taken
up
by
my
friend
Heep
,
and
led
to
a
mutual
recognition
.
 
<EOS>
Of
my
friend
Heep
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
who
is
a
man
of
remarkable
shrewdness
,
I
desire
to
speak
with
all
possible
respect
.
 
<EOS>
My
friend
Heep
has
not
fixed
the
positive
remuneration
at
too
high
a
figure
,
but
he
has
made
a
great
deal
,
in
the
way
of
extrication
from
the
pressure
of
pecuniary
difficulties
,
contingent
on
the
value
of
my
services
;
and
on
the
value
of
those
services
I
pin
my
faith
.
 
<EOS>
Such
address
and
intelligence
as
I
chance
to
possess
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
boastfully
disparaging
himself
,
with
the
old
genteel
air
,
"
will
be
devoted
to
my
friend
Heep
's
service
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
already
some
acquaintance
with
the
law
---
as
a
defendant
on
civil
process
---
and
I
shall
immediately
apply
myself
to
the
Commentaries
of
one
of
the
most
eminent
and
remarkable
of
our
English
jurists
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
it
is
unnecessary
to
add
that
I
allude
to
Mr
justice
Blackstone
.
"
   
<EOS>
These
observations
,
and
indeed
the
greater
part
of
the
observations
made
that
evening
,
were
interrupted
by
Mrs
Micawber
's
discovering
that
Master
Micawber
was
sitting
on
his
boots
,
or
holding
his
head
on
with
both
arms
as
if
he
felt
it
loose
,
or
accidentally
kicking
Traddles
under
the
table
,
or
shuffling
his
feet
over
one
another
,
or
producing
them
at
distances
from
himself
apparently
outrageous
to
nature
,
or
lying
sideways
with
his
hair
among
the
wine
-
glasses
,
or
developing
his
restlessness
of
limb
in
some
other
form
incompatible
with
the
general
interests
of
society
;
and
by
Master
Micawber
's
receiving
those
discoveries
in
a
resentful
spirit
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
all
the
while
,
amazed
by
Mr
Micawber
's
disclosure
,
and
wondering
what
it
meant
;
until
Mrs
Micawber
resumed
the
thread
of
the
discourse
,
and
claimed
my
attention
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
I
particularly
request
Mr
Micawber
to
be
careful
of
,
is
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
that
he
does
not
,
my
dear
Mr
Copperfield
,
in
applying
himself
to
this
subordinate
branch
of
the
law
,
place
it
out
of
his
power
to
rise
,
ultimately
,
to
the
top
of
the
tree
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
convinced
that
Mr
Micawber
,
giving
his
mind
to
a
profession
so
adapted
to
his
fertile
resources
,
and
his
flow
of
language
,
must
distinguish
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
for
example
,
Mr
Traddles
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
assuming
a
profound
air
,
"
a
judge
,
or
even
say
a
Chancellor
.
 
<EOS>
Does
an
individual
place
himself
beyond
the
pale
of
those
preferments
by
entering
on
such
an
office
as
Mr
Micawber
has
accepted
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
observed
Mr
Micawber
---
but
glancing
inquisitively
at
Traddles
,
too
;
"
we
have
time
enough
before
us
,
for
the
consideration
of
those
questions
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Micawber
,
"
she
returned
,
"
no
!
 
<EOS>
Your
mistake
in
life
is
,
that
you
do
not
look
forward
far
enough
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
bound
,
in
justice
to
your
family
,
if
not
to
yourself
,
to
take
in
at
a
comprehensive
glance
the
extremest
point
in
the
horizon
to
which
your
abilities
may
lead
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
coughed
,
and
drank
his
punch
with
an
air
of
exceeding
satisfaction
---
still
glancing
at
Traddles
,
as
if
he
desired
to
have
his
opinion
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the
plain
state
of
the
case
,
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
said
Traddles
,
mildly
breaking

to

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
mean
the
real
prosaic
fact
,
you
know
---
"
   
"
Just
so
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
my
dear
Mr
Traddles
,
I
wish
to
be
as
prosaic
and

as
possible
on

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
---
Is
,
"
said

,
"
that
this
branch
of
the
law
,
even
if
Mr
Micawber
were
a
regular

---
"
   
"
Exactly
so
,
"
returned
Mrs
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
(
"
Wilkins
,
you
are
squinting
,
and
will
not

able
to
get
your

back
.
"
)
   
"
<EOS>
---
Has
nothing
,
"
pursued

,
"
to
do

that
.
 
<EOS>
Only
a
barrister
is
eligible
for
such
preferments
;
and
Mr
Micawber
could
not
be
a

,
without
being
entered
at
an
inn
of
court
as
a
student
,
for
five

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
I
follow
you
?
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
with
her
most

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do

,
<EOS>
my

,

,

,
Mr

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
He

ELIGIBLE
,
"
returned

,
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank

,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
quite
sufficient
.
 
<EOS>
If
such
is
the
case
,
and
Mr
Micawber
forfeits
no

by
entering
on
these

,
my

is

.
 
<EOS>
I
speak
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
as
a
female
,
necessarily
;
but
I
have
always
been
of
opinion
that
Mr
Micawber
possesses
what
I

papa
call
,
when
I
lived

,
the
judicial
mind
;
and
<EOS>
I
hope
Mr
Micawber
is
now
entering
on
a
field
where
that
mind
will
develop
itself
,
and
take

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
quite
believe
that
Mr
Micawber
saw
himself
,
in
his
judicial
mind
's
eye
,
on
the
woolsack
.
 
<EOS>
He
passed
his
hand
complacently
over
his
bald

,
and
said
with

:
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
we
will
not
anticipate
the
decrees
of

.
 
<EOS>
If
I
am
reserved
to

a
wig
,
I
am
at

prepared
,
externally
,
"
in
allusion

his

,
"
for
that

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
regret
my
hair
,
and
I
may
have
been
deprived
of
it
for
a
specific
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
my
intention
,
my
dear
Copperfield
,
to
educate
my
son
for
the
Church
;
I
will
not
deny
that
I
should
be
happy
,

his

,
to
attain
to
eminence
.
"
   
"
<EOS>
For
the
Church
?
"
said
I
,
still
pondering
,
between
whiles
,
on
Uriah
Heep
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
a
remarkable
head
-
voice
,
and
will
commence
as
a
chorister
.
 
<EOS>
Our
residence
at
Canterbury
,
and
our
local

,
will
,
no
doubt
,
enable
him
to
take
advantage
of
any
vacancy
that
may
arise
in
the
Cathedral
corps
.
"
   
<EOS>
On
looking
at
Master
Micawber
again
,
I
saw
that
he
had
a
certain
expression
of
face
,
<EOS>
as
if
his
voice
were
behind
his
eyebrows
;
where
it
presently
appeared
to
be
,
on
his
singing
us
(
as
an
alternative
between
that
and
bed
)
<EOS>
"
The
Wood
-
Pecker
tapping
"
.
 
<EOS>
After
many
compliments
on
this
performance
,
we
fell
into
some
general
conversation
;
and
as
I
was
too
full
of
my
desperate
intentions
to
keep
my
altered
circumstances
to
myself
,
I
made
them
known
to
Mr
and
Mrs
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
express
how
extremely
delighted
they
both
were
,
by
the
idea
of
my
aunt
's
being
in
difficulties
;
and
how
comfortable
and
friendly
it
made
them
.
   
<EOS>
When
we
were
nearly
come
to
the
last
round
of
the
punch
,
I
addressed
myself
to
Traddles
,
and
reminded
him
that
we
must
not
separate
,
without
wishing
our
friends
health
,
happiness
,
and
success
in
their
new
career
.
 
<EOS>
I
begged
Mr
Micawber
to
fill
us
bumpers
,
and
proposed
the
toast
in
due
form
:
shaking
hands
with
him
across
the
table
,
and
kissing
Mrs
Micawber
,
to
commemorate
that
eventful
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
imitated
me
in
the
first
particular
,
but
did
not
consider
himself
a
sufficiently
old
friend
to
venture
on
the
second
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
rising
with
one
of
his
thumbs
in
each
of
his
waistcoat
pockets
,
"
the
companion
of
my
youth
:
if
I
may
be
allowed
the
expression
---
and
my
esteemed
friend
Traddles
:
if
I
may
be
permitted
to
call
him
so
---
will
allow
me
,
on
the
part
of
Mrs
Micawber
,
myself
,
and
our
offspring
,
to
thank
them
in
the
warmest
and
most
uncompromising
terms
for
their
good
wishes
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
expected
that
on
the
eve
of
a
migration
which
will
consign
us
to
a
perfectly
new
existence
,
"
Mr
Micawber
spoke
as
if
they
were
going
five
hundred
thousand
miles
,
"
I
should
offer
a
few
valedictory
remarks
to
two
such
friends
as
I
see
before
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
all
that
I
have
to
say
in
this
way
,
I
have
said
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
station
in
society
I
may
attain
,
through
the
medium
of
the
learned
profession
of
which
I
am
about
to
become
an
unworthy
member
,
I
shall
endeavour
not
to
disgrace
,
and
Mrs
Micawber
will
be
safe
to
adorn
.
 
<EOS>
Under
the
temporary
pressure
of
pecuniary
liabilities
,
contracted
with
a
view
to
their
immediate
liquidation
,
but
remaining
unliquidated
through
a
combination
of
circumstances
,
I
have
been
under
the
necessity
of
assuming
a
garb
from
which
my
natural
instincts
recoil
---
<EOS>
I
allude
to
spectacles
---
and
possessing
myself
of
a
cognomen
,
to
which
I
can
establish
no
legitimate
pretensions
.
 
<EOS>
All
I
have
to
say
on
that
score
is
,
that
the
cloud
has
passed
from
the
dreary
scene
,
and
the
God
of
Day
is
once
more
high
upon
the
mountain
tops
.
 
<EOS>
On
Monday
next
,
on
the
arrival
of
the
four
o'clock
afternoon
coach
at
Canterbury
,
my
foot
will
be
on
my
native
heath
---
my
name
,
Micawber
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
resumed
his
seat
on
the
close
of
these
remarks
,
and
drank
two
glasses
of
punch
in
grave
succession
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
said
with
much
solemnity
:
   
<EOS>
"
One
thing
more
I
have
to
do
,
before
this
separation
is
complete
,
and
that
is
to
perform
an
act
of
justice
.
 
<EOS>
My
friend
Mr
Thomas
Traddles
has
,
on
two
several
occasions
,
"
put
his
name
"
,
if
I
may
use
a
common
expression
,
to
bills
of
exchange
for
my
accommodation
.
<EOS>
On
the
first
occasion
Mr
Thomas
Traddles
was
left
---
let
me
say
,
in
short
,
in
the
lurch
.
 
<EOS>
The
fulfilment
of
the
second
has
not
yet
arrived
.
 
<EOS>
The
amount
of
the
first
obligation
,
"
here
Mr
Micawber
carefully
referred
to
papers
,
"
was
,
I
believe
,
twenty
-
three
,
four
,
nine
and
a
half
,
of
the
second
,
according
to
my
entry
of
that
transaction
,
eighteen
,
six
,
two
.
 
<EOS>
These
sums
,
united
,
make
a
total
,
if
my
calculation
is
correct
,
amounting
to
forty
-
one
,
ten
,
eleven
and
a
half
.
 
<EOS>
My
friend
Copperfield
will
perhaps
do
me
the
favour
to
check
that
total
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
did
so
and
found
it
correct
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
leave
this
metropolis
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
and
my
friend
Mr
Thomas
Traddles
,
without
acquitting
myself
of
the
pecuniary
part
of
this
obligation
,
would
weigh
upon
my
mind
to
an
insupportable
extent
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
,
therefore
,
prepared
for
my
friend
Mr
Thomas
Traddles
,
and
I
now
hold
in
my
hand
,
a
document
,
which
accomplishes
the
desired
object
.
 
<EOS>
I
beg
to
hand
to
my
friend
<EOS>
Mr
Thomas
Traddles
<EOS>
my
IOU
 
for
forty
-
one
,
ten
,
eleven
and
a
half
,
<EOS>
and
I
am
happy
to
recover
my
moral
dignity
,
and
to
know
that
I
can
once
more
walk
erect
before
my
fellow
man
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
introduction
(
which
greatly
affected
him
)
,
Mr
Micawber
placed
his
IOU
 
in
the
hands
of
Traddles
,
and
said
he
wished
him
well
in
every
relation
of
life
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
persuaded
,
not
only
that
this
was
quite
the
same
to
Mr
Micawber
as
paying
the
money
,
but
that
Traddles
himself
hardly
knew
the
difference
until
he
had
had
time
to
think
about
it
.
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
walked
so
erect
before
his
fellow
man
,
on
the
strength
of
this
virtuous
action
,
that
his
chest
looked
half
as
broad
again
when
he
lighted
us
downstairs
.
 
<EOS>
We
parted
with
great
heartiness
on
both
sides
;
and
when
I
had
seen
Traddles
to
his
own
door
,
and
was
going
home
alone
,
I
thought
,
among
the
other
odd
and
contradictory
things
I
mused
upon
,
that
,
slippery
as
Mr
Micawber
was
,
I
was
probably
indebted
to
some
compassionate
recollection
he
retained
of
me
as
his
boy
-
lodger
,
for
never
having
been
asked
by
him
for
money
.
<EOS>
I
certainly
should
not
have
had
the
moral
courage
to
refuse
it
;
and
I
have
no
doubt
he
knew
that
(
to
his
credit
be
it
written
)
,
quite
as
well
as
I
did
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
37
.
<EOS>
A
little
cold
water
 
<EOS>
My
new
life
had
lasted
for
more
than
a
week
,
and
I
was
stronger
than
ever
in
those
tremendous
practical
resolutions
that
I
felt
the
crisis
required
.
 
<EOS>
I
continued
to
walk
extremely
fast
,
and
to
have
a
general
idea
that
I
was
getting
on
.
 
<EOS>
I
made
it
a
rule
to
take
as
much
out
of
myself
as
I
possibly
could
,
in
my
way
of
doing
everything
to
which
I
applied
my
energies
.
 
<EOS>
I
made
a
perfect
victim
of
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
even
entertained
some
idea
of
putting
myself
on
a
vegetable
diet
,
vaguely
conceiving
that
,
in
becoming
a
graminivorous
animal
,
I
should
sacrifice
to
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
As
yet
,
little
Dora
was
quite
unconscious
of
my
desperate
firmness
,
otherwise
than
as
my
letters
darkly
shadowed
it
forth
.
 
<EOS>
But
another
Saturday
came
,
and
on
that
Saturday
evening
she
was
to
be
at
Miss
Mills
's
;
and
when
Mr
Mills
had
gone
to
his
whist
-
club
(
telegraphed
to
me
in
the
street
,
by
a
bird
-
cage
in
the
drawing
-
room
middle
window
)
,
I
was
to
go
there
to
tea
.
   
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
we
were
quite
settled
down
in
Buckingham
Street
,
where
Mr
Dick
continued
his
copying
in
a
state
of
absolute
felicity
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
had
obtained
a
signal
victory
over
Mrs
Crupp
,
by
paying
her
off
,
throwing
the
first
pitcher
she
planted
on
the
stairs
out
of
window
,
and
protecting
in
person
,
up
and
down
the
staircase
,
a
supernumerary
whom
she
engaged
from
the
outer
world
.
<EOS>
These
vigorous
measures
struck
such
terror
to
the
breast
of
Mrs
Crupp
,
that
she
subsided
into
her
own
kitchen
,
under
the
impression
that
my
aunt
was
mad
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
being
supremely
indifferent
to
Mrs
Crupp
's
opinion
and
everybody
else
's
,
and
rather
favouring
than
discouraging
the
idea
,
Mrs
Crupp
,
of
late
the
bold
,
became
within
a
few
days
so
faint
-
hearted
,
that
rather
than
encounter
my
aunt
upon
the
staircase
,
she
would
endeavour
to
hide
her
portly
form
behind
doors
---
leaving
visible
,
however
,
a
wide
margin
of
flannel
petticoat
---
or
would
shrink
into
dark
corners
.
 
<EOS>
This
gave
my
aunt
such
unspeakable
satisfaction
,
that
I
believe
she
took
a
delight
in
prowling
up
and
down
,
with
her
bonnet
insanely
perched
on
the
top
of
her
head
,
at
times
when
Mrs
Crupp
was
likely
to
be
in
the
way
.
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
being
uncommonly
neat
and
ingenious
,
made
so
many
little
improvements
in
our
domestic
arrangements
,
that
I
seemed
to
be
richer
instead
of
poorer
.
 
<EOS>
Among
the
rest
,
she
converted
the
pantry
into
a
dressing
-
room
for
me
;
and
purchased
and
embellished
a
bedstead
for
my
occupation
,
which
looked
as
like
a
bookcase
in
the
daytime
as
a
bedstead
could
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
the
object
of
her
constant
solicitude
;
and
my
poor
mother
herself
could
not
have
loved
me
better
,
or
studied
more
how
to
make
me
happy
.
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
had
considered
herself
highly
privileged
in
being
allowed
to
participate
in
these
labours
;
and
,
although
she
still
retained
something
of
her
old
sentiment
of
awe
in
reference
to
my
aunt
,
had
received
so
many
marks
of
encouragement
and
confidence
,
that
they
were
the
best
friends
possible
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
time
had
now
come
<EOS>
(
I
am
speaking
of
the
Saturday
when
I

to

at
Miss
Mills
's
)
when

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
So
good
-
bye
,
Barkis
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
and

!
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
I
never

I
could
be

!
"
   
<EOS>
I
took
Peggotty
to
the
coach
office
and
saw

.
 
<EOS>
She
cried
at

,
and
confided
her
brother
to
my
friendship
as
Ham
had
done
.
<EOS>
We
had
heard
nothing
of
him
since
he
went
away
,
that

.
   
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
my
own
dear

,
"
said

,
"
if
,
while
you

,

;

,

my

,

(

)

,

my
sweet

's
own
old
stupid
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
not

as

in

,
but
that
if

I

,
I

.
<EOS>
Next
to

a
large
sum
on

,
I
believe
this
gave
Peggotty
more
comfort
than
anything

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
,
my
dear
!
"
<EOS>

,
"
tell
the
pretty
little
angel
that
I

so
have
liked
to

,

!
 
<EOS>
And

boy
,

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
I
declared
that
nobody
else
should
touch
it
;
and
this
gave
Peggotty
such
delight
that
she
went
away
in
good

.
   
<EOS>
I
fatigued
myself
as
much
as
I
possibly
could
in
the
Commons
all
day
,
by
a
variety
of
devices
,
and
at
the
appointed
time
in
the

repaired
to
Mr
Mills
's
street
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Mills
,
who
was
a
terrible
fellow
to
fall
asleep
after
dinner
,
had
not
yet
gone
out
,
and
there
was
no
bird
-
cage
in
the
middle

.
   
<EOS>
He
kept
me
waiting
so
long
,
that
I
fervently
hoped
the
Club
would
fine
him
for
being
late
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
he
came
out
;
and
then
I
saw
my
own
Dora
hang
up
the
bird
-
cage
,
and
peep
into
the
balcony
to
look
for
me
,
and
run
in
again
when
she
saw
I
was
there
,
while
Jip
remained
behind
,
to
bark
injuriously
at
an
immense
butcher
's
dog
in
the
street
,
who
could
have
taken
him
like
a

.
   
<EOS>
Dora
came
to
the
drawing
-
room
door
to
meet
me
;
and
Jip
came
scrambling
out
,
tumbling
over
his
own
growls
,
under
the
impression
that
I
was
a
Bandit
;
and
we
all
three
went
in
,
as
happy
and
loving
as
could
be
.
 
<EOS>
I
soon
carried
desolation
into
the
bosom
of
our
joys
---
<EOS>
not
that
I
meant
to
do
it
,
but
that
I
was
so
full
of
the
subject
---
by
asking
Dora
,
without
the
smallest
preparation
,
if
she
could
love
a
beggar
?
   
<EOS>
My
pretty
,
little
,
startled
Dora
!
 
<EOS>
Her
only
association
with
the
word
was
a
yellow
face
and
a
nightcap
,
or
a
pair
of
crutches
,
or
a
wooden
leg
,
or
a
dog
with
a
decanter
-
stand
in
his
mouth
,
or
something
of
that
kind
;
and
she
stared

me
with
the
most
delightful

.
   
<EOS>
"
How
can
you
ask
me
anything
so
foolish
?
"
<EOS>
pouted
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
Love
a
beggar
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dora
,
my
own
dearest
!
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
beggar
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
can
you
be
such
a
silly
thing
,
"
replied
Dora
,
slapping
my
hand
,
"
as
to
sit
there
,
telling
such
stories
?
 
<EOS>
I
'll
make
Jip
bite
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
Her
childish
way
was
the
most
delicious
way
in
the
world
to
me
,
but
it
was
necessary
to
be
explicit
,
and
I
solemnly

:
   
<EOS>
"
Dora
,
my
own
life
,
I
am
your
ruined
David
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
declare
I
'll
make
Jip
bite
you
!
"
<EOS>
said
Dora
,
shaking
her
curls
,
"
if
you
are
so
ridiculous
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
But
I
looked
so
serious
,
that
Dora
left
off
shaking
her
curls
,
and
laid
her
trembling
little
hand
upon
my
shoulder
,
and
first
looked
scared
and
anxious
,
then
began
to
cry
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
dreadful
.
 
<EOS>
I
fell
upon
my
knees
before
the
sofa
,
caressing
her
,
and
imploring
her
not
to
rend
my
heart
;
but
,
for
some
time
,
poor
little
Dora
did
nothing
but
exclaim
<EOS>
Oh
dear
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
dear
!
 
<EOS>
And
oh
,
she
was
so
frightened
!
 
<EOS>
And
where
was
Julia
Mills
!
 
<EOS>
And
oh
,
take
her
to
Julia
Mills
,
and
go
away
,
please
!
<EOS>
until
I
was
almost
beside
myself
.
   
<EOS>
At
last
,
after
an
agony
of
supplication
and

,
I
got
Dora
to
look
at
me
,
with
a
horrified
expression
of
face
,
which
I
gradually
soothed
until
it
was
only
loving
,
and
her
soft
,
pretty
cheek
was
lying
against

.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
told
her
,
with
my
arms
clasped
round
her
,
how
I
loved
her
,
so
dearly
,
and
so
dearly
;
how
I
felt
it
right
to
offer
to
release
her
from
her
engagement
,
because
now
I
was
poor
;
how
I
never
could
bear
it
,
or
recover
it
,
<EOS>
if
I
lost
her
;
how
I
had
no
fears
of
poverty
,
if
she
had
none
,
my
arm
being
nerved
and
my
heart
inspired
by
her
;
how
I
was
already
working
with
a
courage
such
as
none
but
lovers
knew
;
how
I
had
begun
to
be
practical
,
and
look
into
the
future
;
how
a
crust
well
earned
was
sweeter
far
than
a
feast
inherited
;
and
much
more
to
the
same
purpose
,
which
I
delivered
in
a
burst
of
passionate

quite
surprising
to
myself
,
though
I
had
been
thinking
about
it
,
day
and
night
,
ever
since
my
aunt
had
astonished
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
your
heart
mine
still
,
dear
Dora
?
"
said
I
,
rapturously
,
for
I
knew
by
her
clinging
to
me
that
it
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes
!
"
cried
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
it
's
all
yours
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
do
n't
be
dreadful
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
dreadful
!
 
<EOS>
To
Dora
!
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
talk
about
being
poor
,
and
working
hard
!
"
<EOS>
said
Dora
,
nestling

.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
do
n't
,
do
n't
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dearest
love
,
"
said
I
,
"
the
crust

-

---
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

;
but
I
do
n't

crusts
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
And
Jip
must

-

every

,
or
he
'll
die
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
charmed
with
her
childish
,
winning

.
 
<EOS>
I
fondly
explained
to
Dora
that
Jip
should
have
his
mutton
-
chop
with
his
accustomed

.
 
<EOS>
I
drew
a
picture
of
our
frugal
home
,
made
independent
by
my
labour
---
sketching
in
the
little
house
I
had
seen
at
Highgate
,
and
my
aunt
in
her
room
upstairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
dreadful
now
,
Dora
?
"
said
I
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
no
,
no
!
"
cried
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
hope
your
aunt
will
keep
in
her
own
room
a
good
