.
 
<EOS>
And
I
hope
she
's
not
a
scolding
old
thing
!
"
   
<EOS>
If
it
were
possible
for
me
to
love
Dora
more
than
ever
,
I
am
sure
I
did
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
felt
she
was
a
little
impracticable
.
 
<EOS>
It
damped
my
new
-
born
ardour
,
to
find
that
ardour
so
difficult
of
communication
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
made
another
trial
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
was
quite
herself
again
,
and
was
curling
Jip
's
ears
,
as
he
lay
upon
her
lap
,
I
became
grave
,
and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
My
own
!
 
<EOS>
May
I
mention
something
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
please
do
n't
be
practical
!
"
<EOS>
said
Dora
,
coaxingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Because
it
frightens
me
so
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sweetheart
!
"
<EOS>
I
returned
;
"
there
is
nothing
to
alarm
you
in
all
this
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
you
to
think
of
it
quite
differently
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
make
it
nerve
you
,
and
inspire
you
,
Dora
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
but
that
's
so
shocking
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
love
,
no
.
 
Perseverance
and
strength
of
character
will
enable
us
to
bear
much
worse
things
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
n't
got
any
strength
at
all
,
"
said
Dora
,
shaking
her
curls
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
I
,
Jip
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
do
kiss
Jip
,
and
be
agreeable
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
to
resist
kissing
Jip
,
when
she
held
him
up
to
me
for
that
purpose
,
putting
her
own
bright
,
rosy
little
mouth
into
kissing
form
,
as
she
directed
the
operation
,
which
she
insisted
should
be
performed
symmetrically
,
on
the
centre
of
his
nose
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
as
she
bade
me
---
rewarding
myself
afterwards
for
my
obedience
---
<EOS>
and
she
charmed
me
out
of
my
graver
character
for
I
do
n't
know
how
long
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
Dora
,
my
beloved
!
"
<EOS>
said
I
,
at
last
resuming
it
;
"
I
was
going
to
mention
something
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
judge
of
the
Prerogative
Court
might
have
fallen
in
love
with
her
,
to
see
her
fold
her
little
hands
and
hold
them
up
,
begging
and
praying
me
not
to
be
dreadful
any
more
.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
I
am
not
going
to
be
,
my
darling
!
<EOS>
"
I
assured
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
,
Dora
,
my
love
,
if
you
will
sometimes
think
,
---
not
despondingly
,
you
know
;
far
from
that
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
but
if
you
will
sometimes
think
---
just
to
encourage
yourself
---
that
you
are
engaged
to
a
poor
man
---
"
   
"
Do
n't
,
do
n't
!
 
<EOS>
Pray
do
n't
!
"
cried
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
so
very
dreadful
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
soul
,
not
at
all
!
"
said
I
,
cheerfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
sometimes
think
of
that
,
and
look
about
now
and
then
at
your
papa
's
housekeeping
,
and
endeavour
to
acquire
a
little
habit
---
of
accounts
,
for
instance
---
"
   
Poor
little
Dora
received
this
suggestion
with
something
that
was
half
a
sob
and
half
a
scream
.
   
<EOS>
"
---
It
would
be
so
useful
to
us
afterwards
,
"
I
went
on
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
if
you
would
promise
me
to
read
a
little
---
a
little
Cookery
Book
that
I
would
send
you
,
it
would
be
so
excellent
for
both
of
us
.
 
<EOS>
For
our
path
in
life
,
my
Dora
,
"
said
I
,
warming
with
the
subject
,
"
is
stony
and
rugged
now
,
and
it
rests
with
us
to
smooth
it
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
fight
our
way
onward
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
be
brave
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
obstacles
to
be
met
,
and
we
must
meet
,
and
crush
them
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
going
on
at
a
great
rate
,
with
a
clenched
hand
,
and
a
most
enthusiastic
countenance
;
but
it
was
quite
unnecessary
to
proceed
.
<EOS>
I
had
said
enough
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
done
it
again
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
she
was
so
frightened
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
where
was
Julia
Mills
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
take
her
to
Julia
Mills
,
and
go
away
,
please
!
 
<EOS>
So
that
,
in
short
,
I
was
quite
distracted
,
and
raved
about
the
drawing
-
room
.
   
<EOS>
I
thought
I
had
killed
her
,
this
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
sprinkled
water
on
her
face
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
down
on
my
knees
.
 
<EOS>
I
plucked
at
my
hair
.
 
<EOS>
I
denounced
myself
as
a
remorseless
brute
and
a
ruthless
beast
.
 
<EOS>
I
implored
her
forgiveness
.
 
<EOS>
I
besought
her
to
look
up
.
 
<EOS>
I
ravaged
Miss
Mills
's
work
-
box
for
a
smelling
-
bottle
,
and
in
my
agony
of
mind
applied
an
ivory
needle
-
case
instead
,
and
dropped
all
the
needles
over
Dora
.
<EOS>
I
shook
my
fists
at
Jip
,
who
was
as
frantic
as
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
every
wild
extravagance
that
could
be
done
,
and
was
a
long
way
beyond
the
end
of
my
wits
when
Miss
Mills
came
into
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
has
done
this
?
"
exclaimed
Miss
Mills
,
succouring
her
friend
.
   
<EOS>
I
replied
,
"
I
,
Miss
Mills
!
<EOS>
I
have
done
it
!
 
<EOS>
Behold
the
destroyer
!
"
<EOS>
---
or
words
to
that
effect
---
and
hid
my
face
from
the
light
,
in
the
sofa
cushion
.
   
<EOS>
At
first
Miss
Mills
thought
it
was
a
quarrel
,
and
that
we
were
verging
on
the
Desert
of
Sahara
;
but
she
soon
found
out
how
matters
stood
,
for
my
dear
affectionate
little
Dora
,
embracing
her
,
began
exclaiming
that
I
was
"
a
poor
labourer
"
;
and
then
cried
for
me
,
and
embraced
me
,
and
asked
me
would
I
let
her
give
me
all
her
money
to
keep
,
and
then
fell
on
Miss
Mills
's
neck
,
sobbing
as
if
her
tender
heart
were
broken
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Mills
must
have
been
born
to
be
a
blessing
to
us
.
 
<EOS>
She
ascertained
from
me
in
a
few
words
what
it
was
all
about
,
comforted
Dora
,
and
gradually
convinced
her
that
I
was
not
a
labourer
---
from
my
manner
of
stating
the
case
I
believe
Dora
concluded
that
I
was
a
navigator
,
and
went
balancing
myself
up
and
down
a
plank
all
day
with
a
wheelbarrow
---
and
so
brought
us
together
in
peace
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
were
quite
composed
,
and
Dora
had
gone
up
-
stairs
to
put
some
rose
-
water
to
her
eyes
,
Miss
Mills
rang
for
tea
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
ensuing
interval
,
I
told
Miss
Mills
that
she
was
evermore
my
friend
,
and
that
my
heart
must
cease
to
vibrate
ere
<EOS>
I
could
forget
her
sympathy
.
   
<EOS>
I
then
expounded
to
Miss
Mills
what
I
had
endeavoured
,
so
very
unsuccessfully
,
to
expound
to
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Mills
replied
,
on
general
principles
,
that
the
Cottage
of
content
was
better
than
the
Palace
of
cold
splendour
,
and
that
where
love
was
,
all
was
.
   
<EOS>
I
said
to
Miss
Mills
that
this
was
very
true
,
and
who
should
know
it
better
than
I
,
who
loved
Dora
with
a
love
that
never
mortal
had
experienced
yet
?
 
<EOS>
But
on
Miss
Mills
observing
,
with
despondency
,
that
it
were
well
indeed
for
some
hearts
if
this
were
so
,
I
explained
that
I
begged
leave
to
restrict
the
observation
to
mortals
of
the
masculine
gender
.
   
<EOS>
I
then
put
it
to
Miss
Mills
,
to
say
whether
she
considered
that
there
was
or
was
not
any
practical
merit
in
the
suggestion
I
had
been
anxious
to
make
,
concerning
the
accounts
,
the
housekeeping
,
and
the
Cookery
Book
?
   
<EOS>
Miss
Mills
,
after
some
consideration
,
thus
replied
:
   
"
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
,
I
will
be
plain
with
you
.
 
<EOS>
Mental
suffering
and
trial
supply
,
in
some
natures
,
the
place
of
years
,
and
I
will
be
as
plain
with
you
as
if
I
were
a
Lady
Abbess
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
The
suggestion
is
not
appropriate
to
our
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
Our
dearest
<EOS>
Dora
is
a
favourite
child
of
nature
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
a
thing
of
light
,
and
airiness
,
and
joy
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
free
to
confess
that
if
it
could
be
done
,
it
might
be
well
,
<EOS>
but
---
"
And
Miss
Mills
shook
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
encouraged
by
this
closing
admission
on
the
part
of
Miss
Mills
to
ask
her
,
whether
,
for
Dora
's
sake
,
if
she
had
any
opportunity
of
luring
her
attention
to
such
preparations
for
an
earnest
life
,
she
would
avail
herself
of
it
?
 
<EOS>
Miss
Mills
replied
in
the
affirmative
so
readily
,
that
I
further
asked
her
if
she
would
take
charge
of
the
Cookery
Book
;
and
,
if
she
ever
could
insinuate
it
upon
Dora
's
acceptance
,
without
frightening
her
,
undertake
to
do
me
that
crowning
service
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Mills
accepted
this
trust
,
too
;
but
was
not
sanguine
.
   
<EOS>
And
Dora
returned
,
looking
such
a
lovely
little
creature
,
that
I
really
doubted
whether
she
ought
to
be
troubled
with
anything
so
ordinary
.
 
<EOS>
And
she
loved
me
so
much
,
and
was
so
captivating
(
particularly
when
she
made
Jip
stand
on
his
hind
legs
for
toast
,
and
when
she
pretended
to
hold
that
nose
of
his
against
the
hot
teapot
for
punishment
because
he
would
n't
)
,
that
I
felt
like
a
sort
of
Monster
who
had
got
into
a
Fairy
's
bower
,
when
I
thought
of
having
frightened
her
,
and
made
her
cry
.
   
<EOS>
After
tea
we
had
the
guitar
;
and
Dora
sang
those
same
dear
old
French
songs
about
the
impossibility
of
ever
on
any
account
leaving
off
dancing
,
La
ra
la
,
<EOS>
La
ra
la
,
until
I
felt
a
much
greater
Monster
than
before
.
   
<EOS>
We
had
only
one
check
to
our
pleasure
,
and
that
happened
a
little
while
before
I
took
my
leave
,
when
,
Miss
Mills
chancing
to
make
some
allusion
to
tomorrow
morning
,
I
unluckily
let
out
that
,
being
obliged
to
exert
myself
now
<EOS>
,
I
got
up
at
five
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
Dora
had
any
idea
that
I
was
a
Private
Watchman
,
I
am
unable
to
say
;
but
it
made
a
great
impression
on
her
,
and
she
neither
played
nor
sang
any
more
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
still
on
her
mind
when
I
bade
her
adieu
;
and
she
said
to
me
,
in
her
pretty
coaxing
way
---
as
if
I
were
a
doll
,
I
used
to
think
:
   
"
Now
do
n't
get
up
at
five
o'clock
,
<EOS>
you
naughty
boy
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
so
nonsensical
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
love
,
"
said
I
,
"
I
have
work
to
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
do
n't
do
it
!
"
<EOS>
returned
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
should
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
to
say
to
that
sweet
little
surprised
face
,
otherwise
than
lightly
and
playfully
,
that
we
must
work
to
live
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
How
ridiculous
!
"
cried
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
shall
we
live
without
,
Dora
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
How
?
 
<EOS>
Any
how
!
"
said
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
She
seemed
to
think
she
had
quite
settled
the
question
,
and
gave
me
such
a
triumphant
little
kiss
,
direct
from
her
innocent
heart
,
that
I
would
hardly
have
put
her
out
of
conceit
with
her
answer
,
for
a
fortune
.
   
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
I
loved
her
,
and
I
went
on
loving
her
,
most
absorbingly
,
entirely
,
and
completely
.
 
<EOS>
But
going
on
,
too
,
working
pretty
hard
,
and
busily
keeping
red
-
hot
all
the
irons
I
now
had
in
the
fire
,
I
would
sit
sometimes
of
a
night
,
opposite
my
aunt
,
thinking
how
I
had
frightened
Dora
that
time
,
and
how
I
could
best
make
my
way
with
a
guitar
-
case
through
the
forest
of
difficulty
,
until
I
used
to
fancy
that
my
head
was
turning
quite
grey
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
38
.
<EOS>
A
dissolution
of
partnership
 
<EOS>
I
did
not
allow
my
resolution
,
with
respect
to
the
Parliamentary
Debates
,
to
cool
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
one
of
the
irons
I
began
to
heat
immediately
,
and
one
of
the
irons
I
kept
hot
,
and
hammered
at
,
with
a
perseverance
I
may
honestly
admire
.
 
<EOS>
I
bought
an
approved
scheme
of
the
noble
art
and
mystery
of
stenography
(
which
cost
me
ten
and
sixpence
)
;
and
plunged
into
a
sea
of
perplexity
that
brought
me
,
in
a
few
weeks
,
to
the
confines
of
distraction
.
 
<EOS>
The
changes
that
were
rung
upon
dots
,
which
in
such
a
position
meant
such
a
thing
,
and
in
such
another
position
something
else
,
entirely
different
;
the
wonderful
vagaries
that
were
played
by
circles
;
the
unaccountable
consequences
that
resulted
from
marks
like
flies
'
legs
;
the
tremendous
effects
of
a
curve
in
a
wrong
place
;
not
only
troubled
my
waking
hours
,
but
reappeared
before
me
in
my
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
had
groped
my
way
,
blindly
,
through
these
difficulties
,
and
had
mastered
the
alphabet
,
which
was
an
Egyptian
Temple
in
itself
,
there
then
appeared
a
procession
of
new
horrors
,
called
arbitrary
characters
;
the
most
despotic
characters
I
have
ever
known
;
who
insisted
,
for
instance
,
that
a
thing
like
the
beginning
of
a
cobweb
,
meant
expectation
,
and
that
a
pen
-
and
-
ink
sky
-
rocket
,
stood
for
disadvantageous
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
had
fixed
these
wretches
in
my
mind
,
I
found
that
they
had
driven
everything
else
out
of
it
;
then
,
beginning
again
,
I
forgot
them
;
while
I
was
picking
them
up
,
I
dropped
the
other
fragments
of
the
system
;
in
short
,
it
was
almost
heart
-
breaking
.
   
<EOS>
It
might
have
been
quite
heart
-
breaking
,
but
for
Dora
,
who
was
the
stay
and
anchor
of
my
tempest
-
driven
bark
.
 
<EOS>
Every
scratch
in
the
scheme
was
a
gnarled
oak
in
the
forest
of
difficulty
,
and
I
went
on
cutting
them
down
,
one
after
another
,
with
such
vigour
,
that
in
three
or
four
months
I
was
in
a
condition
to
make
an
experiment
on
one
of
our
crack
speakers
in
the
Commons
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
ever
forget
how
the
crack
speaker
walked
off
from
me
before
I
began
,
and
left
my
imbecile
pencil
staggering
about
the
paper
as
if
it
were
in
a
fit
!
   
<EOS>
This
would
not
do
,
it
was
quite
clear
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
flying
too
high
,
and
should
never
get
on
,
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
resorted
to
Traddles
for
advice
;
who
suggested
that
he
should
dictate
speeches
to
me
,
at
a
pace
,
and
with
occasional
stoppages
,
adapted
to
my
weakness
.
 
<EOS>
Very
grateful
for
this
friendly
aid
,
I
accepted
the
proposal
;
and
night
after
night
,
almost
every
night
,
for
a
long
time
,
we
had
a
sort
of
Private
Parliament
in
Buckingham
Street
,
after
I
came
home
from
the
Doctor
's
.
   
<EOS>
I
should
like
to
see
such
a
Parliament
anywhere
else
!
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
and
Mr
Dick
represented
the
Government
or
the
Opposition
(
as
the
case
might
be
)
,
and
Traddles
,
with
the
assistance
of
Enfield
's
Speakers
,
or
a
volume
of
parliamentary
orations
,
thundered
astonishing
invectives
against
them
.
 
<EOS>
Standing
by
the
table
,
with
his
finger
in
the
page
to
keep
the
place
,
and
his
right
arm
flourishing
above
his
head
,
Traddles
,
as
Mr
Pitt
,
Mr
Fox
,
Mr
Sheridan
,
Mr
Burke
,
Lord
Castlereagh
,
Viscount
Sidmouth
,
or
Mr
Canning
,
would
work
himself
into
the
most
violent
heats
,
and
deliver
the
most
withering
denunciations
of
the
profligacy
and
corruption
of
my
aunt
and
Mr
Dick
;
while
I
used
to
sit
,
at
a
little
distance
,
with
my
notebook
on
my
knee
,
fagging
after
him
with
all
my
might
and
main
.
 
<EOS>
The
inconsistency
and
recklessness
of
Traddles
were
not
to
be
exceeded
by
any
real
politician
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
for
any
description
of
policy
,
in
the
compass
of
a
week
;
and
nailed
all
sorts
of
colours
to
every
denomination
of
mast
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
looking
very
like
an
immovable
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
,
would
occasionally
throw
in
an
interruption
or
two
,
as
"
Hear
!
"
or
"
No
!
"
or
"
Oh
!
"
when
the
text
seemed
to
require
it
:
which
was
always
a
signal
to
Mr
Dick
(
a
perfect
country
gentleman
)
to
follow
lustily
with
the
same
cry
.
<EOS>
But
Mr
Dick
got
taxed
with
such
things
in
the
course
of
his
Parliamentary
career
,
and
was
made
responsible
for
such
awful
consequences
,
that
he
became
uncomfortable
in
his
mind
sometimes
.
<EOS>
I
believe
he
actually
began
to
be
afraid
he
really
had
been
doing
something
,
tending
to
the
annihilation
of
the
British
constitution
,
and
the
ruin
of
the
country
.
   
<EOS>
Often
and
often
we
pursued
these
debates
until
the
clock
pointed
to
midnight
,
and
the
candles
were
burning
down
.
 
<EOS>
The
result
of
so
much
good
practice
was
,
that
by
and
by
I
began
to
keep
pace
with
Traddles
pretty
well
,
and
should
have
been
quite
triumphant
if
I
had
had
the
least
idea
what
my
notes
were
about
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
to
reading
them
after
I
had
got
them
,
I
might
as
well
have
copied
the
Chinese
inscriptions
of
an
immense
collection
of
tea
-
chests
,
or
the
golden
characters
on
all
the
great
red
and
green
bottles
in
the
chemists
'
shops
!
   
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
for
it
,
but
to
turn
back
and
begin
all
over
again
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
hard
,
but
I
turned
back
,
though
with
a
heavy
heart
,
and
began
laboriously
and
methodically
to
plod
over
the
same
tedious
ground
at
a
snail
's
pace
;
stopping
to
examine
minutely
every
speck
in
the
way
,
on
all
sides
,
and
making
the
most
desperate
efforts
to
know
these
elusive
characters
by
sight
wherever
I
met
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
always
punctual
at
the
office
;
at
the
Doctor
's
too
:
and
I
really
did
work
,
as
the
common
expression
is
,
like
a
cart
-
horse
.
<EOS>
One
day
,
when
I
went
to
the
Commons
as
usual
,
I
found
Mr
Spenlow
in
the
doorway
looking
extremely
grave
,
and
talking
to
himself
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
was
in
the
habit
of
complaining
of
pains
in
his
head
---
he
had
naturally
a
short
throat
,
and
I
do
seriously
believe
he
over
-
starched
himself
---
<EOS>
I
was
at
first
alarmed
by
the
idea
that
he
was
not
quite
right
in
that
direction
;
but
he
soon
relieved
my
uneasiness
.
   
<EOS>
Instead
of
returning
my
"
Good
morning
"
with
his
usual
affability
,
he
looked
at
me
in
a
distant
,
ceremonious
manner
,
and
coldly
requested
me
to
accompany
him
to
a
certain
coffee
-
house
,
which
,
in
those
days
,
had
a
door
opening
into
the
Commons
,
just
within
the
little
archway
in
St
Paul
's
Churchyard
.
 
<EOS>
I
complied
,
in
a
very
uncomfortable
state
,
and
with
a
warm
shooting
all
over
me
,
as
if
my
apprehensions
were
breaking
out
into
buds
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
allowed
him
to
go
on
a
little
before
,
on
account
of
the
narrowness
of
the
way
,
I
observed
that
he
carried
his
head
with
a
lofty
air
that
was
particularly
unpromising
;
and
my
mind
misgave
me
that
he
had
found
out
about
my
darling
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
If
I
had
not
guessed
this
,
on
the
way
to
the
coffee
-
house
,
I
could
hardly
have
failed
to
know
what
was
the
matter
when
I
followed
him
into
an
upstairs
room
,
and
found
Miss
Murdstone
there
,
supported
by
a
background
of
sideboard
,
on
which
were
several
inverted
tumblers
sustaining
lemons
,
and
two
of
those
extraordinary
boxes
,
all
corners
and
flutings
,
for
sticking
knives
and
forks
in
,
which
,
happily
for
mankind
,
are
now
obsolete
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
gave
me
her
chilly
finger
-
nails
,
and
sat
severely
rigid
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Spenlow
shut
the
door
,
motioned
me
to
a
chair
,
and
stood
on
the
hearth
-
rug
in
front
of
the
fireplace
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
the
goodness
to
show
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
,
"
what
you
have
in
your
reticule
,
Miss
Murdstone
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
believe
it
was
the
old
identical
steel
-
clasped
reticule
of
my
childhood
,
that
shut
up
like
a
bite
.
 
<EOS>
Compressing
her
lips
,
in
sympathy
with
the
snap
,
Miss
Murdstone
opened
it
---
opening
her
mouth
a
little
at
the
same
time
---
and
produced
my
last
letter
to
Dora
,
teeming
with
expressions
of
devoted
affection
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
believe
that
is
your
writing
,
Mr
Copperfield
?
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
very
hot
,
and
the
voice
I
heard
was
very
unlike
mine
,
when
I
said
,
"
It
is
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
am
not
mistaken
,
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
,
as
Miss
Murdstone
brought
a
parcel
of
letters
out
of
her
reticule
,
tied
round
with
the
dearest
bit
of
blue
ribbon
,
"
those
are
also
from
your
pen
,
Mr
Copperfield
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
took
them
from
her
with
a
most
desolate
sensation
;
and
,
glancing
at
such
phrases
at
the
top
,
as
"
My
ever
dearest
and
own
Dora
,
"
"
My
best
beloved
angel
,
"
"
<EOS>
My
blessed
one
for
ever
,
"
and
the
like
,
blushed
deeply
,
and
inclined
my
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
thank
you
!
"
<EOS>
said
Mr
Spenlow
,
coldly
,
as
I
mechanically
offered
them
back
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
deprive
you
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
,
be
so
good
as
to
proceed
!
"
   
<EOS>
That
gentle
creature
,
after
a
moment
's
thoughtful
survey
of
the
carpet
,
delivered
herself
with
much
dry
unction
as
follows
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
confess
to
having
entertained
my
suspicions
of
Miss
Spenlow
,
in
reference
to
David
Copperfield
,
for
some
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
observed
Miss
Spenlow
and
David
Copperfield
,
when
they
first
met
;
and
the
impression
made
upon
me
then
was
not
agreeable
.
 
<EOS>
The
depravity
of
the
human
heart
is
such
---
"
   
"
You
will
oblige
me
,
ma'am
,
"
interrupted
Mr
Spenlow
,
"
by
confining
yourself
to
facts
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
cast
down
her
eyes
,
shook
her
head
as
if
protesting
against
this
unseemly
interruption
,
and
with
frowning
dignity
resumed
:
   
"
Since
I
am
to
confine
myself
to
facts
,
I
will
state
them
as
dryly
as
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
that
will
be
considered
an
acceptable
course
of
proceeding
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
already
said
,
sir
,
that
I
have
had
my
suspicions
of
Miss
Spenlow
,
in
reference
to
David
Copperfield
,
for
some
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
frequently
endeavoured
to
find
decisive
corroboration
of
those
suspicions
,
but
without
effect
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
therefore
forborne
to
mention
them
to
Miss
Spenlow
's
father
"
;
looking
severely
at
him
---
"
<EOS>
knowing
how
little
disposition
there
usually
is
in
such
cases
,
to
acknowledge
the
conscientious
discharge
of
duty
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Spenlow
seemed
quite
cowed
by
the
gentlemanly
sternness
of
Miss
Murdstone
's
manner
,
and
deprecated
her
severity
with
a
conciliatory
little
wave
of
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
On
my
return
to
Norwood
,
after
the
period
of
absence
occasioned
by
my
brother
's
marriage
,
"
pursued
Miss
Murdstone
in
a
disdainful
voice
,
"
and
on
the
return
of
Miss
Spenlow
from
her
visit
to
her
friend
Miss
Mills
,
I
imagined
that
the
manner
of
Miss
Spenlow
gave
me
greater
occasion
for
suspicion
than
before
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
I
watched
Miss
Spenlow
closely
.
"
   
<EOS>
Dear
,
tender
little
Dora
,
so
unconscious
of
this
Dragon
's
eye
!
   
<EOS>
"
Still
,
"
resumed
Miss
Murdstone
,
"
I
found
no
proof
until
last
night
.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
me
that
Miss
Spenlow
received
too
many
letters
from
her
friend
Miss
Mills
;
but
Miss
Mills
being
her
friend
with
her
father
's
full
concurrence
,
"
another
telling
blow
at
Mr
Spenlow
,
"
it
was
not
for
me
to
interfere
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
may
not
be
permitted
to
allude
to
the
natural
depravity
of
the
human
heart
,
at
least
I
may
---
I
must
---
be
permitted
,
so
far
to
refer
to
misplaced
confidence
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Spenlow
apologetically
murmured
his
assent
.
   
<EOS>
"
Last
evening
after
tea
,
"
pursued
Miss
Murdstone
,
"
I
observed
the
little
dog
starting
,
rolling
,
and
growling
about
the
drawing
-
room
,
worrying
something
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
to
Miss
Spenlow
,
"
Dora
,
what
is
that
the
dog
has
in
his
mouth
?
 
<EOS>
It
's
paper
.
"
<EOS>
Miss
Spenlow
immediately
put
her
hand
to
her
frock
,
gave
a
sudden
cry
,
and
ran
to
the
dog
.
<EOS>
I
interposed
,
and
said
,
"
Dora
,
my
love
,
you
must
permit
me
.
"
<EOS>
"
   
Oh
Jip
,
miserable
Spaniel
,
this
wretchedness
,
then
,
was
your
work
!
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Spenlow
endeavoured
,
"
said
Miss
Murdstone
,
"
to
bribe
me
with
kisses
,
work
-
boxes
,
and
small
articles
of
jewellery
---
that
,
of
course
,
I
pass
over
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
dog
retreated
under
the
sofa
on
my
approaching
him
,
and
was
with
great
difficulty
dislodged
by
the
fire
-
irons
.
 
<EOS>
Even
when
dislodged
,
he
still
kept
the
letter
in
his
mouth
;
and
on
my
endeavouring
to
take
it
from
him
,
at
the
imminent
risk
of
being
bitten
<EOS>
,
he
kept
it
between
his
teeth
so
pertinaciously
as
to
suffer
himself
to
be
held
suspended
in
the
air
by
means
of
the
document
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
I
obtained
possession
of
it
.
<EOS>
After
perusing
it
,
I
taxed
Miss
Spenlow
with
having
many
such
letters
in
her
possession
;
and
ultimately
obtained
from
her
the
packet
which
is
now
in
David
Copperfield
's
hand
.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
she
ceased
;
and
snapping
her
reticule
again
,
and
shutting
her
mouth
,
looked
as
if
she
might
be
broken
,
but
could
never
be
bent
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
heard
Miss
Murdstone
,
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
,
turning
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
I
beg
to
ask
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
if
you
have
anything
to
say
in
reply
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
picture
I
had
before
me
,
of
the
beautiful
little
treasure
of
my
heart
,
sobbing
and
crying
all
night
---
of
her
being
alone
,
frightened
,
and
wretched
,
then
---
of
her
having
so
piteously
begged
and
prayed
that
stony
-
hearted
woman
to
forgive
her
---
of
her
having
vainly
<EOS>
offered
her
those
kisses
,
work
-
boxes
,
and
trinkets
---
of
her
being
in
such
grievous
distress
,
and
<EOS>
all
for
me
---
very
much
impaired
the
little
dignity
<EOS>
I
had
been
able
to
muster
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
I
was
in
a
tremulous
state
for
a
minute
or
so
,
though
I
did
my
best
to
disguise
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
I
can
say
,
sir
,
"
I
returned
,
"
except
that
all
the
blame
is
mine
.
 
<EOS>
Dora
---
"
   
"
Miss
Spenlow
,
if
you
please
,
"
said
her
father
,
majestically
.
   
<EOS>
"
---
was
induced
and
persuaded
by
me
,
"
I
went
on
,
swallowing
that
colder
designation
,
"
to
consent
to
this
concealment
,
and
I
bitterly
regret
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
much
to
blame
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
,
walking
to
and
fro
upon
the
hearth
-
rug
,
and
emphasizing
what
he
said
with
his
whole
body
instead
of
his
head
,
on
account
of
the
stiffness
of
his
cravat
and
spine
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
done
a
stealthy
and
unbecoming
action
,
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
take
a
gentleman
to
my
house
,
no
matter
whether
he
is
nineteen
,
twenty
-
nine
,
or
ninety
,
I
take
him
there
in
a
spirit
of
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
abuses
my
confidence
,
he
commits
a
dishonourable
action
,
Mr
Copperfield
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
feel
it
,
sir
,
I
assure
you
,
"
I
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
never
thought
so
,
before
.
 
<EOS>
Sincerely
,
honestly
,
indeed
,
Mr
Spenlow
,
I
never
thought
so
,
before
.
 
<EOS>
I
love
Miss
Spenlow
to
that
extent
---
<EOS>
"
   
"
Pooh
!
nonsense
!
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
,
reddening
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pray
do
n't
tell
me
to
my
face
that
you
love
my
daughter
,
Mr
Copperfield
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Could
I
defend
my
conduct
if
I
did
not
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
I
returned
,
with
all
humility
.
   
<EOS>
"
Can
you
defend
your
conduct
if
you
do
,
sir
?
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
,
stopping
short
upon
the
hearth
-
rug
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
considered
your
years
,
and
my
daughter
's
years
,
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
?
 
<EOS>
Have
you
considered
what
it
is
to
undermine
the
confidence
that
should
subsist
between
my
daughter
and
myself
?
 
<EOS>
Have
you
considered
my
daughter
's
station
in
life
,
the
projects
I
may
contemplate
for
her
advancement
,
the
testamentary
intentions
I
may
have
with
reference
to
her
?
 
<EOS>
Have
you
considered
anything
,
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
little
,
sir
,
I
am
afraid
;
"
I
answered
,
speaking
to
him
as
respectfully
and
sorrowfully
as
I
felt
;
"
but
pray
believe
me
,
I
have
considered
my
own
worldly
position
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
explained
it
to
you
,
we
were
already
engaged
---
"
   
"
I
BEG
,
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
,
more
like
Punch
than
I
had
ever
seen
him
,
as
he
energetically
struck
one
hand
upon
the
other
<EOS>
---
I
could
not
help
noticing
that
even
in
my
despair
;
"
that
YOU
Will
NOT
talk
to
me
of
engagements
,
Mr
Copperfield
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
otherwise
immovable
Miss
Murdstone
laughed
contemptuously
in
one
short
syllable
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
explained
my
altered
position
to
you
,
sir
,
"
I
began
again
,
substituting
a
new
form
of
expression
for
what
was
so
unpalatable
to
him
,
"
this
concealment
,
into
which
I
am
so
unhappy
as
to
have
led
Miss
Spenlow
,
had
begun
.
 
<EOS>
Since
I
have
been
in
that
altered
position
,
I
have
strained
every
nerve
,
I
have
exerted
every
energy
,
to
improve
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
I
shall
improve
it
in
time
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
grant
me
time
---
any
length
of
time
?
 
<EOS>
We
are
both
so
young
,
sir
<EOS>
,
---
"
   
"
You
are
right
,
"
interrupted
Mr
Spenlow
,
nodding
his
head
a
great
many
times
,
and
frowning
very
much
,
"
you
are
both
very
young
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
all
nonsense
.
 
<EOS>
Let
there
be
an
end
of
the
nonsense
.
 
<EOS>
Take
away
those
letters
,
and
throw
them
in
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
Miss
Spenlow
's
letters
to
throw
in
the
fire
;
and
although
our
future
intercourse
must
,
you
are
aware
,
be
restricted
to
the
Commons
here
<EOS>
,
we
will
agree
to
make
no
further
mention
of
the
past
.
 
<EOS>
Come
,
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
,
you
do
n't
want
sense
;
and
this
is
the
sensible
course
.
"
   
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
n't
think
of
agreeing
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
very
sorry
,
but
there
was
a
higher
consideration
than
sense
.
 
<EOS>
Love
was
above
all
earthly
considerations
,
and
I
loved
Dora
to
idolatry
,
and
Dora
loved
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
n't
exactly
say
so
;
I
softened
it
down
as
much
as
I
could
;
but
I
implied
it
,
and
I
was
resolute
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
I
made
myself
very
ridiculous
,
but
<EOS>
I
know
I
was
resolute
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
well
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
,
"
I
must
try
my
influence
with
my
daughter
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
,
by
an
expressive
sound
,
a
long
drawn
respiration
,
which
was
neither
a
sigh
nor
a
moan
,
but
was
like
both
,
gave
it
as
her
opinion
that
he
should
have
done
this
at
first
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
try
,
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
,
confirmed
by
this
support
,
"
my
influence
with
my
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
decline
to
take
those
letters
,
Mr
Copperfield
?
<EOS>
"
For
I
had
laid
them
on
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
him
I
hoped
he
would
not
think
it
wrong
,
but
I
could
n't
possibly
take
them
from
Miss
Murdstone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nor
from
me
?
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
.
   
<EOS>
No
,
I
replied
with
the
profoundest
respect
;
nor
from
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
well
!
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
.
   
<EOS>
A
silence
succeeding
<EOS>
,
I
was
undecided
whether
to
go
or
stay
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
I
was
moving
quietly
towards
the
door
,
with
the
intention
of
saying
that
perhaps
I
should
consult
his
feelings
best
by
withdrawing
:
when
he
said
,
with
his
hands
in
his
coat
pockets
,
into
which
it
was
as
much
as
he
could
do
to
get
them
;
and
with
what
I
should
call
,
upon
the
whole
,
a
decidedly
pious
air
:
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
probably
aware
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
that
I
am
not
altogether
destitute
of
worldly
possessions
,
and
that
my
daughter
is
my
nearest
and
dearest
relative
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
hurriedly
made
him
a
reply
to
the
effect
,
that
I
hoped
the
error
into
which
I
had
been
betrayed
by
the
desperate
nature
of
my
love
,
did
not
induce
him
to
think
me
mercenary
too
?
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
allude
to
the
matter
in
that
light
,
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
.
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
better
for
yourself
,
and
all
of
us
,
if
you
WERE
mercenary
,
Mr
Copperfield
---
I
mean
,
if
you
were
more
discreet
and
less
influenced
by
all
this
youthful
nonsense
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
I
merely
say
,
with
quite
another
view
,
you
are
probably
aware
I
have
some
property
to
bequeath
to
my
child
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
certainly
supposed
so
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
you
can
hardly
think
,
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
,
"
having
experience
of
what
we
see
,
in
the
Commons
here
,
every
day
,
of
the
various
unaccountable
and
negligent
proceedings
of
men
,
in
respect
of
their
testamentary
arrangements
---
of
all
subjects
,
the
one
on
which
perhaps
the
strangest
revelations
of
human
inconsistency
are
to

met
with
---
but
that
mine
are
made
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
inclined
my
head
in
acquiescence
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
not
allow
,
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
,
with
an
evident
increase
of
pious
sentiment
,
and
slowly
shaking
his
head
as
he
poised
himself
upon
his
toes
and

alternately
,
"
my
suitable
provision
for
my
child
to
be
influenced
by
a
piece
of
youthful
folly
like
the
present
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
mere
folly
.
 
<EOS>
Mere
nonsense
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
little
while
,
it
will
weigh
lighter
than
any
feather
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
might
---
<EOS>
I
might
---
if
this
silly
business
were
not
completely
relinquished
altogether
,
be
induced
in
some
anxious
moment
to
guard
her
from
,
and
surround
her
with
protections
against
,
the
consequences
of
any
foolish
step
in
the
way
of
marriage
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
I
hope
that
you
will
not
render
it
necessary
for
me
to
open
,
even
for
a
quarter
of
an
hour
,
that
closed
page
in
the
book
of
life
,
and
unsettle
,
even
for
a
quarter
of
an
hour
,
grave
affairs
long
since
composed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
serenity
,
a
tranquillity
,
a
calm
sunset
air
about
him
,
which
quite
affected
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
so
peaceful
and
resigned
---
clearly
had
his
affairs
in
such
perfect
train
,
and
so
systematically
wound
up
---
that
he
was
a
man
to
feel
touched
in
the
contemplation
of
.
 
<EOS>
I
really
think
I
saw
tears
rise
to
his
eyes
,
from
the
depth
of
his
own
feeling
of
all
this
.
   
<EOS>
But
what
could
I
do
?
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
deny
Dora
and
my
own
heart
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
told
me
I
had
better
take
a
week
to
consider
of
what
he
had
said
,
how
could
I
say
I
would
n't
take
a
week
,
yet
how
could
I
fail
to
know
that
no
amount
of
weeks
could
influence
such
love
as
mine
?
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
meantime
,
confer
with
Miss
Trotwood
,
or
with
any
person
with
any
knowledge
of
life
,
"
said
Mr
Spenlow
,
adjusting
his
cravat
with
both
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
a
week
,
Mr
Copperfield
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
submitted
;
and
,
with
a
countenance
as
expressive
as
I
was
able
to
make
it
of
dejected
and
despairing
constancy
,
came
out
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
Miss
Murdstone
's
heavy
eyebrows
followed
me
to
the
door
---
I
say
her
eyebrows
rather
than
her
eyes
,
because
they
were
much
more
important
in
her
face
---
and
she
looked
so
exactly
as
she
used
to
look
,
at
about
that
hour
of
the
morning
,
in
our
parlour
at
Blunderstone
,
that
I
could
have
fancied
I
had
been
breaking
down
in
my
lessons
again
,
and
that
the
dead
weight
on
my
mind
was
that
horrible
old
spelling
-
book
,
with
oval
woodcuts
,
shaped
,
to
my
youthful
fancy
,
like
the
glasses
out
of
spectacles
.
   
<EOS>
When
I
got
to
the
office
,
and
,
shutting
out
old
Tiffey
and
the
rest
of
them
with
my
hands
,
sat
at
my
desk
,
in
my
own
particular
nook
,
thinking
of
this
earthquake
that
had
taken
place
so
unexpectedly
,
and
in
the
bitterness
of
my
spirit
cursing
Jip
,
I
fell
into
such
a
state
of
torment
about
Dora
,
that
I
wonder
I
did
not
take
up
my
hat
and
rush
insanely
to
Norwood
.
 
<EOS>
The
idea
of
their
frightening
her
,
and
making
her
cry
,
and
of
my
not
being
there
to
comfort
her
,
was
so
excruciating
,
that
it
impelled
me
to
write
a
wild
letter
to
Mr
Spenlow
,
beseeching
him
not
to
visit
upon
her
the
consequences
of
my
awful
destiny
.
 
<EOS>
I
implored
him
to
spare
her
gentle
nature
---
not
to
crush
a
fragile
flower
---
and
addressed
him
generally
,
to
the
best
of
my
remembrance
,
<EOS>
as
if
,
instead
of
being
her
father
,
he
had
been
an
Ogre
,
or
the
Dragon
of
Wantley.3
<EOS>
This
letter
I
sealed
and
laid
upon
his
desk
before
he
returned
;
and
when
he
came
in
,
I
saw
him
,
through
the
half
-
opened
door
of
his
room
,
take
it
up
and
read
it
.
   
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
about
it
all
the
morning
;
but
before
he
went
away
in
the
afternoon
he
called
me
in
,
and
told
me
that
I
need
not
make
myself
at
all
uneasy
about
his
daughter
's
happiness
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
assured
her
,
he
said
,
that
it
was
all
nonsense
;
and
he
had
nothing
more
to
say
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
He
believed
he
was
an
indulgent
father
<EOS>
(
as
indeed
he
was
)
,
and
I
might
spare
myself
any
solicitude
on
her
account
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
make
it
necessary
,
if
you
are
foolish
or
obstinate
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
he
observed
,
"
for
me
to
send
my
daughter
abroad
again
,
for
a
term
;
but
I
have
a
better
opinion
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
will
be
wiser
than
that
,
in
a
few
days
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
Miss
Murdstone
,
"
for
I
had
alluded
to
her
in
the
letter
,
"
I
respect
that
lady
's
vigilance
,
and
feel
obliged
to
her
;
but
she
has
strict
charge
to
avoid
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
All
I
desire
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
is
,
that
it
should
be
forgotten
.
 
<EOS>
All
you
have
got
to
do
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
is
to
forget
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
All
!
 
<EOS>
In
the
note
I
wrote
to
Miss
Mills
,
I
bitterly
quoted
this
sentiment
.
 
<EOS>
All
I
had
to
do
,
I
said
,
with
gloomy
sarcasm
,
was
to
forget
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
all
,
and
what
was
that
!
 
<EOS>
I
entreated
Miss
Mills
to
see
me
,
that
evening
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
could
not
be
done
with
Mr
Mills
's
sanction
and
concurrence
,
I
besought
a
clandestine
interview
in
the
back
kitchen
where
the
Mangle
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
informed
her
that
my
reason
was
tottering
on
its
throne
,
and
only
she
,
Miss
Mills
,
could
prevent
its
being
deposed
.
 
<EOS>
I
signed
myself
,
hers
distractedly
;
and
I
could
n't
help
feeling
,
while
I
read
this
composition
over
,
before
sending
it
by
a
porter
,
that
it
was
something
in
the
style
of
Mr
Micawber
.
   
<EOS>
However
,
I
sent
it
.
 
<EOS>
At
night
I
repaired
to
Miss
Mills
's
street
,
and
walked
up
and
down
,
until
I
was
stealthily
fetched
in
by
Miss
Mills
's
maid
,
and
taken
the
area
way
to
the
back
kitchen
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
since
seen
reason
to
believe
that
there
was
nothing
on
earth
to
prevent
my
going
in
at
the
front
door
,
and
being
shown
up
into
the
drawing
-
room
,
except
Miss
Mills
's
love
of
the
romantic
and
mysterious
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
back
kitchen
,
I
raved
as
became
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
there
,
I
suppose
,
to
make
a
fool
of
myself
,
and
I
am
quite
sure
I
did
it
.
<EOS>
Miss
Mills
had
received
a
hasty
note
from
Dora
,
telling
her
that
all
was
discovered
,
and
saying
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
pray
come
to
me
,
Julia
,
do
,
do
!
"
<EOS>
But
Miss
Mills
,
mistrusting
the
acceptability
of
her
presence
to
the
higher
powers
,
had
not
yet
gone
;
and
we
were
all
benighted
in
the
Desert
of
Sahara
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Mills
had
a
wonderful
flow
of
words
,
and
liked
to
pour
them
out
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
help
feeling
,
though
she
mingled
her
tears
with
mine
,
that
she
had
a
dreadful
luxury
in
our
afflictions
.
 
<EOS>
She
petted
them
,
as
I
may
say
,
and
made
the
most
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
A
deep
gulf
,
she
observed
,
had
opened
between
Dora
and
me
,
and
Love
could
only
span
it
with
its
rainbow
.
 
<EOS>
Love
must
suffer
in
this
stern
world
;
it
ever
had
been
so
,
it
ever
would
be
so
.
 
<EOS>
No
matter
,
Miss
Mills
remarked
.
 
<EOS>
Hearts
confined
by
cobwebs
would
burst
at
last
,
and
then
Love
was
avenged
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
small
consolation
,
but
Miss
Mills
would
n't
encourage
fallacious
hopes
.
 
<EOS>
She
made
me
much
more
wretched
than
I
was
before
,
and
I
felt
(
and
told
her
with
the
deepest
gratitude
)
that
she
was
indeed
a
friend
.
 
<EOS>
We
resolved
that
she
should
go
to
Dora
the
first
thing
in
the
morning
,
and
find
some
means
of
assuring
her
,
either
by
looks
or
words
,
of
my
devotion
and
misery
.
 
<EOS>
We
parted
,
overwhelmed
with
grief
;
and
<EOS>
I
think
Miss
Mills
enjoyed
herself
completely
.
   
<EOS>
I
confided
all
to
my
aunt
when
I
got
home
;
and
in
spite
of
all
she
could
say
to
me
,
went
to
bed
despairing
.
 
<EOS>
I
got
up
despairing
,
and
went
out
despairing
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
Saturday
morning
,
and
I
went
straight
to
the
Commons
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
surprised
,
when
I
came
within
sight
of
our
office
-
door
,
to
see
the
ticket
-
porters
standing
outside
talking
together
,
and
some
half
-
dozen
stragglers
gazing
at
the
windows
which
were
shut
up
.
 
<EOS>
I
quickened
my
pace
,
and
,
passing
among
them
,
wondering
at
their
looks
,
went
hurriedly
in
.
   
<EOS>
The
clerks
were
there
,
but
nobody
was
doing
anything
.
 
<EOS>
Old
Tiffey
,
for
the
first
time
in
his
life
I
should
think
,
was
sitting
on
somebody
else
's
stool
,
and
had
not
hung
up
his
hat
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
dreadful
calamity
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
he
,
as
I
entered
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
?
"
<EOS>
I
exclaimed
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
know
?
"
cried
Tiffey
,
and
all
the
rest
of
them
,
coming
round
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
<EOS>
"
said
I
,
looking
from
face
to
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Spenlow
,
"
said
Tiffey
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
about
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dead
!
<EOS>
"
I
thought
it
was
the
office
reeling
,
and
not
I
,
as
one
of
the
clerks
caught
hold
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
They
sat
me
down
in
a
chair
,
untied
my
neck
-
cloth
,
and
brought
me
some
water
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
idea
whether
this
took
any
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dead
?
"
said
I.
   
"
<EOS>
He
dined
in
town
yesterday
,
and
drove
down
in
the
phaeton
by
himself
,
"
said
Tiffey
,
"
having
sent
his
own
groom
home
by
the
coach
,
as
he
sometimes
did
,
you
know
---
<EOS>
"
   
"
Well
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
phaeton
went
home
without
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
horses
stopped
at
the
stable
-
gate
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
went
out
with
a
lantern
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
in
the
carriage
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Had
they
run
away
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
were
not
hot
,
"
said
Tiffey
,
putting
on
his
glasses
;
"
no
hotter
,
I
understand
,
than
they
would
have
been
,
going
down
at
the
usual
pace
.
 
<EOS>
The
reins
were
broken
,
but
they
had
been
dragging
on
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
The
house
was
roused
up
directly
,
and
three
of
them
went
out
along
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
They
found
him
a
mile
off
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
More
than
a
mile
off
,
Mr
Tiffey
,
"
interposed
a
junior
.
   
<EOS>
"
Was
it
?
 
<EOS>
I
believe
you
are
right
,
"
said
Tiffey
,
---
"
more
than
a
mile
off
---
not
far
from
the
church
---
lying
partly
on
the
roadside
,
and
partly
on
the
path
,
upon
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
he
fell
out
in
a
fit
,
or
got
out
,
feeling
ill
before
the
fit
came
on
---
or
even
whether
he
was
quite
dead
then
,
though
there
is
no
doubt
he
was
quite
insensible
---
no
one
appears
to
know
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
breathed
,
certainly
he
never
spoke
.
 
<EOS>
Medical
assistance
was
got
as
soon
as
possible
,
but
it
was
quite
useless
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
can
not
describe
the
state
of
mind
into
which
I
was
thrown
by
this
intelligence
.
 
<EOS>
The
shock
of
such
an
event
happening
so
suddenly
,
and
happening
to
one
with
whom
I
had
been
in
any
respect
at
variance
---
the
appalling
vacancy
in
the
room
he
had
occupied
so
lately
,
where
his
chair
and
table
seemed
to
wait
for
him
,
and
his
handwriting
of
yesterday
was
like
a
ghost
---
the
indefinable
impossibility
of
separating
him
from
the
place
,
and
feeling
,
when
the
door
opened
,
as
if
he
might
come
in
---
the
lazy
hush
and
rest
<EOS>
there
was
in
the
office
,
and
the
insatiable
relish
with
which
our
people
talked
about
it
,
and
other
people
came
in
and
out
all
day
,
and
gorged
themselves
with
the
subject
---
this
is
easily
intelligible
to
anyone
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
can
not
describe
is
,
how
,
in
the
innermost
recesses
of
my
own
heart
,
I
had
a
lurking
jealousy
even
of
Death
.
 
<EOS>
How
I
felt
as
if
its
might
would
push
me
from
my
ground
in
Dora
's
thoughts
.
 
<EOS>
How
I
was
,
in
a
grudging
way
I
have
no
words
for
,
envious
of
her
grief
.
 
<EOS>
How
it
made
me
restless
to
think
of
her
weeping
to
others
,
or
being
consoled
by
others
.
 
<EOS>
How
I
had
a
grasping
,
avaricious
wish
to
shut
out
everybody
from
her
but
myself
,
and
to
be
all
in
all
to
her
,
at
that
unseasonable
time
of
all
times
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
trouble
of
this
state
of
mind
---
not
exclusively
my
own
,
I
hope
,
but
known
to
others
---
I
went
down
to
Norwood
that
night
;
and
finding
from
one
of
the
servants
,
when
I
made
my
inquiries
at
the
door
,
that
Miss
Mills
was
there
,
got
my
aunt
to
direct
a
letter
to
her
,
which
I
wrote
.
 
<EOS>
I
deplored
the
untimely
death
of
Mr
Spenlow
,
most
sincerely
,
and
shed
tears
in
doing
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
entreated
her
to
tell
Dora
,
if
Dora
were
in
a
state
to
hear
it
,
that
he
had
spoken
to
me
with
the
utmost
kindness
and
consideration
;
and
had
coupled
nothing
but
tenderness
,
not
a
single
or
reproachful
word
,
with
her
name
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
<EOS>
I
did
this
selfishly
,
to
have
my
name
brought
before
her
;
but
I
tried
to
believe
it
was
an
act
of
justice
to
his
memory
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
did
believe
it
.
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
received
a
few
lines
next
day
in
reply
;
addressed
,
outside
,
to
her
;
within
,
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Dora
was
overcome
by
grief
;
and
when
her
friend
had
asked
her
should
she
send
her
love
to
me
,
had
only
cried
,
as
she
was
always
crying
,
"
Oh
,
dear
papa
!
<EOS>
oh
,
poor
papa
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
she
had
not
said
<EOS>
No
,
and
that
I
made
the
most
of
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
jorkins
,
who
had
been
at
Norwood
since
the
occurrence
,
came
to
the
office
a
few
days
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
He
and
Tiffey
were
closeted
together
for
some
few
moments
,
and
then
Tiffey
looked
out
at
the
door
and
beckoned
me
in
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Mr
jorkins
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Tiffey
and
myself
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
are
about
to
examine
the
desks
,
the
drawers
,
and
other
such
repositories
of
the
deceased
,
with
the
view
of
sealing
up
his
private
papers
,
and
searching
for
a
Will
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
trace
of
any
,
elsewhere
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
as
well
for
you
to
assist
us
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
had
been
in
agony
to
obtain
some
knowledge
of
the
circumstances
in
which
my
Dora
would
be
placed
---
as
,
in
whose
guardianship
,
and
so
forth
---
and
this
was
something
towards
it
.
 
<EOS>
We
began
the
search
at
once
;
Mr
jorkins
unlocking
the
drawers
and
desks
,
and
we
all
taking
out
the
papers
.
 
<EOS>
The
office
-
papers
we
placed
on
one
side
,
and
the
private
papers
(
which
were
not
numerous
)
on
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
very
grave
;
and
when
we
came
to
a
stray
seal
,
or
pencil
-
case
,
or
ring
,
or
any
little
article
of
that
kind
which
we
associated
personally
with
him
,
we
spoke
very
low
.
   
<EOS>
We
had
sealed
up
several
packets
;
and
were
still
going
on
dustily
and
quietly
,
when
Mr
jorkins
said
to
us
,
applying
exactly
the
same
words
to
his
late
partner
as
his
late
partner
had
applied
to
him
:
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Spenlow
was
very
difficult
to
move
from
the
beaten
track
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
what
he
was
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
disposed
to
think
he
had
made
no
will
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
I
know
he
had
!
"
said
I.
   
They
both
stopped
and
looked
at
me
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
On
the
very
day
when
I
last
saw
him
,
"
said
I
,
"
he
told
me
that
he
had
,
and
that
his
affairs
were
long
since
settled
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
jorkins
and
old
Tiffey
shook
their
heads
with
one
accord
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
looks
unpromising
,
"
said
Tiffey
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
unpromising
,
"
said
Mr
jorkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
Surely
you
do
n't
doubt
---
"
I
began
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
good
Mr
Copperfield
!
"
said
Tiffey
,
laying
his
hand
upon
my
arm
,
and
shutting
up
both
his
eyes
as
he
shook
his
head
:
"
if
you
had
been
in
the
Commons
as
long
as
I
have
,
you
would
know
that
there
is
no
subject
on
which
men
are
so
inconsistent
,
and
so
little
to
be
trusted
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
bless
my
soul
,
he
made
that
very
remark
!
<EOS>
"
I
replied
persistently
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
call
that
almost
final
,
"
observed
Tiffey
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
opinion
is
---
no
will
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
appeared
a
wonderful
thing
to
me
,
but
it
turned
out
that
there
was
no
will
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
never
so
much
as
thought
of
making
one
,
so
far
as
his
papers
afforded
any
evidence
;
for
there
was
no
kind
of
hint
,
sketch
,
or
memorandum
,
of
any
testamentary
intention
<EOS>
whatever
.
<EOS>
What
was
scarcely
less
astonishing
to
me
,
was
,
that
his
affairs
were
in
a
most
disordered
state
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
extremely
difficult
,
I
heard
,
to
make
out
what
he
owed
,
or
what
he
had
paid
,
or
of
what
he
died
possessed
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
considered
likely
that
for
years
he
could
have
had
no
clear
opinion
on
these
subjects
himself
.
 
<EOS>
By
little
and
little
it
came
out
,
that
,
in
the
competition
on
all
points
of
appearance
and
gentility
then
running
high
in
the
Commons
,
he
had
spent
more
than
his
professional
income
,
which
was
not
a
very
large
one
,
and
had
reduced
his
private
means
,
if
they
ever
had
been
great
(
which
was
exceedingly
doubtful
)
,
to
a
very
low
ebb
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
sale
of
the
furniture
and

,
at

;
and

told
me
,
little

that

,

.
   
<EOS>
This

at
the

.
 
<EOS>
I
had

all

;
and
thought

,

,

,

"

!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

!
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.

"
<EOS>

Broad

)
"
   
Miss

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

!
      
<EOS>
Chapter
39
.
<EOS>
Wickfield
and
Heep
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
beginning
<EOS>
,
I
imagine
,
to
be
made
seriously
uncomfortable
by
my
prolonged
dejection
,
made
a
pretence
of
being

that
I
should
go
to
Dover
,
to
see
that
all
was
working
well
at
the
cottage
,
which
was
let
;
and
to
conclude
an
agreement
,
with
the
same

,
for
a

term
of
occupation
.
 
<EOS>
Janet
was
drafted
into
the
service
of
Mrs
Strong
,
where
I
saw
her
every
day
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
been
undecided
,
on
leaving
Dover
,
whether
or
no
to
give
the
finishing
touch
to
that

of
mankind
in
which
she
had
been
educated
,
by
marrying
a
pilot
;
but
she
decided
against
that
venture
.
 
<EOS>
Not
so
much
for
the
sake
of
principle
,
I
believe
,
as
because
she
happened
not
to
like
him
.
   
<EOS>
Although
it
required
an
effort
to
leave
Miss
Mills
,
I
fell
rather
willingly
into
my
aunt
's
pretence
,
as
a
means
of
enabling
me
to
pass
a
few
tranquil
hours
with
Agnes
.
 
<EOS>
I
consulted
the
good
Doctor
relative
to
an
absence
of
three
days
;
and
the
Doctor
wishing
me
to
take
that
relaxation
,
---
he
wished
me
to
take
more
;
but
my
energy
could
not
bear
that
,
---
I
made
up
my
mind
to
go
.
   
<EOS>
As
to
the
Commons
,
I
had
no
great
occasion
to
be
particular
about
my
duties
in
that
quarter
.
 
<EOS>
To
say
the
truth
,
we
were
getting
in
no
very
good
odour
among
the
tip
-
top
proctors
,
and
were
rapidly
sliding
down
to
but
a
doubtful
position
.
 
<EOS>
The
business
had
been
indifferent
under
Mr
jorkins
,
before
Mr
Spenlow
's
time
;
and
although
it
had
been
quickened
by
the
infusion
of
new
blood
,
and
by
the
display
which
Mr
Spenlow
made
,
still
it
was
not
established
on
a
sufficiently
strong
basis
to
bear
,
without
being
shaken
,
such
a
blow
as
the
sudden
loss
of
its
active
manager
.
 
<EOS>
It
fell
off
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
jorkins
,
notwithstanding
his
reputation
in
the
firm
,
was
an
easy
-
going
,
incapable
sort
of
man
,
whose
reputation
out
of
doors
was
not
calculated
to
back
it
up
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
turned
over
to
him
now
,
and
when
I
saw
him
take
his
snuff
and
let
the
business
go
,
I
regretted
my
aunt
's
thousand
pounds
more
than
ever
.
   
<EOS>
But
this
was
not
the
worst
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
a
number
of
hangers
-
on
and
outsiders
about
the
Commons
,
who
,
without
being
proctors
themselves
,
dabbled
in
common
-
form
business
,
and
got
it
done
by
real
proctors
,
who
lent
their
names
in
consideration
of
a
share
in
the
spoil
;
---
and
there
were
a
good
many
of
these
too
.
 
<EOS>
As
our
house
now
wanted
business
on
any
terms
,
we
joined
this
noble
band
;
and
threw
out
lures
to
the
hangers
-
on
and
outsiders
,
to
bring
their
business
to
us
.
 
<EOS>
Marriage
licences
and
small
probates
were
what
we
all
looked
for
,
and
what
paid
us
best
;
and
the
competition
for
these
ran
very
high
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
Kidnappers
and
inveiglers
were
planted
in
all
the
avenues
of
entrance
to
the
Commons
,
with
instructions
to
do
their
utmost
to
cut
off
all
persons
in
mourning
,
and
all
gentlemen
with
anything
bashful
in
their
appearance
,
and
entice
them
to
the
offices
in
which
their
respective
employers
were
interested
;
which
instructions
were
so
well
observed
,
that
I
myself
,
before
I
was
known
by
sight
,
was
twice
hustled
into
the
premises
of
our
principal
opponent
.
 
<EOS>
The
conflicting
interests
of
these
touting
gentlemen
being
of
a
nature
to
irritate
their
feelings
,
personal
collisions
took
place
;
and
the
Commons
was
even
scandalized
by
our
principal
inveigler
(
who
had
formerly
been
in
the
wine
trade
,
and
afterwards
in
the
sworn
brokery
line
)
walking
about
for
some
days
with
a
black
eye
.
 
<EOS>
Any
one
of
these
scouts
used
to
think
nothing
of
politely
assisting
an
old
lady
in
black
out
of
a
vehicle
,
killing
any
proctor
whom
she
inquired
for
,
representing
his
employer
as
the
lawful
successor
and
representative
of
that
proctor
,
and
bearing
the
old
lady
off
(
sometimes
greatly
affected
)
to
his
employer
's
office
.
 
<EOS>
Many
captives
were
brought
to
me
in
this
way
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
marriage
licences
,
the
competition
rose
to
such
a
pitch
,
that
a
shy
gentleman
in
want
of
one
,
had
nothing
to
do
but
submit
himself
to
the
first
inveigler
,
or
be
fought
for
,
and
become
the
prey
of
the
strongest
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
our
clerks
,
who
was
an
outsider
,
used
,
in
the
height
of
this
contest
,
to
sit
with
his
hat
on
,
that
he
might
be
ready
to
rush
out
and
swear
before
a
surrogate
any
victim
who
was
brought
in
.
 
<EOS>
The
system
of
inveigling
continues
,
I
believe
,
to
this
day
.
 
<EOS>
The
last
time
I
was
in
the
Commons
,
a
civil
able
-
bodied
person
in
a
white
apron
pounced
out
upon
me
from
a

,
and
whispering

word
"
Marriage
-
licence
"
in
my

,
was
with
great

prevented
from
taking

up
in

and
lifting
me
into
a
proctor
's
.
 
<EOS>
From
this
digression
,
let
me
proceed
to
Dover
.
   
<EOS>
I
found
everything
in
a
satisfactory
state
at
the
cottage
;
and
was
enabled
to
gratify
my
aunt
exceedingly
by
reporting
that
the
tenant
inherited
her
feud
,
and
waged
incessant
war
against
donkeys
.
<EOS>
Having
settled
the
little
business
I
had
to
transact
there
,
and
slept
there
one
night
,
I
walked
on
to
Canterbury
early
in
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
now
winter
again
;
and
the
fresh
,
cold
windy
day
,
and
the
sweeping
downland
,
brightened
up
my
hopes
a
little
.
   
<EOS>
Coming
into
Canterbury
,
I
loitered
through
the
old
streets
with
a
sober
pleasure
that
calmed
my
spirits
,
and
eased
my
heart
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
the
old
signs
,
the
old
names
over
the
shops
,
the
old
people
serving
in
them
.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
so
long
,
since
I
had
been
a
schoolboy
there
,
that
I
wondered
the
place
was
so
little
changed
,
until
I
reflected
how
little
I
was
changed
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Strange
to
say
,
that
quiet
influence
which
was
inseparable
in
my
mind
from
Agnes
,
seemed
to
pervade
even
the
city
where
she
dwelt
.
 
<EOS>
The
venerable
cathedral
towers
,
and
the
old
jackdaws
and
rooks
whose
airy
voices
made
them
more
retired
than
perfect
silence
would
have
done
;
the
battered
gateways
,
one
stuck
full
with
statues
,
long
thrown
down
,
and
crumbled
away
,
like
the
reverential
pilgrims
who
had
gazed
upon
them
;
the
still
nooks
,
where
the
ivied
growth
of
centuries
crept
over
gabled
ends
and
ruined
walls
;
the
ancient
houses
,
the
pastoral
landscape
of
field
,
orchard
,
and
garden
;
everywhere
---
on
everything
---
I
felt
the
same
serener
air
,
the
same
calm
,
thoughtful
,
softening
spirit
.
   
<EOS>
Arrived
at
Mr
Wickfield
's
house
,
I
found
,
in
the
little
lower
room
on
the
ground
floor
,
where
Uriah
Heep
had
been
of
old
accustomed
to
sit
,
Mr
Micawber
plying
his
pen
with
great
assiduity
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
dressed
in
a
legal
-
looking
suit
of
black
,
and
loomed
,
burly
and
large
,
in
that
small
office
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
was
extremely
glad
to
see
me
,
but
a
little
confused
too
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
have
conducted
me
immediately
into
the
presence
of
Uriah
,
but
I
declined
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
the
house
of
old
,
you
recollect
,
"
said
I
,
"
and
will
find
my
way
upstairs
.
 
<EOS>
How
do
you
like
the
law
,
Mr
Micawber
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Copperfield
,
"
he
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
a
man
possessed
of
the
higher
imaginative
powers
,
the
objection
to
legal
studies
is
the
amount
of
detail
which
they
involve
.
 
<EOS>
Even
in
our
professional
correspondence
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
glancing
at
some
letters
he
was
writing
,
"
the
mind
is
not
at
liberty
to
soar
to
any
exalted
form
of
expression
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
it
is
a
great
pursuit
.
 
<EOS>
A
great
pursuit
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
then
told
me
that
he
had
become
the
tenant
of
Uriah
Heep
's
old
house
;
and
that
Mrs
Micawber
would
be
delighted
to
receive
me
,
once
more
,
under
her
own
roof
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
humble
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
---
to
quote
a
favourite
expression
of
my
friend
Heep
;
but
it
may
prove
the
stepping
-
stone
to
more
ambitious
domiciliary
accommodation
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
asked
him
whether
he
had
reason
,
so
far
,
to
be
satisfied
with
his
friend
<EOS>
Heep
's
treatment
of
him
?
 
<EOS>
He
got
up
to
ascertain
if
the
door
were
close
shut
,
before
he
replied
,
in
a
lower
voice
:
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Copperfield
,
a
man
who
labours
under
the
pressure
of
pecuniary
embarrassments
,
is
,
with
the
generality
of
people
,
at
a
disadvantage
.
 
<EOS>
That
disadvantage
is
not
diminished
,
when
that
pressure
necessitates
the
drawing
of
stipendiary
emoluments
,
before
those
emoluments
are
strictly
due
and
payable
.
 
<EOS>
All
I
can
say
is
,
that
my
friend
Heep
has
responded
to
appeals
to
which
I
need
not
more
particularly
refer
,
in
a
manner
calculated
to
redound
equally
to
the
honour
of
his
head
,
and
of
his
heart
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
not
have
supposed
him
to
be
very
free
with
his
money
either
,
"
I
observed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
!
"
<EOS>
said
Mr
Micawber
,
with
an
air
of
constraint
,
"
I
speak
of
my
friend
Heep
as
I
have
experience
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
your
experience
is
so
favourable
,
"
I
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
obliging
,
my
dear
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
;
and
hummed
a
tune
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
see
much
of
Mr
Wickfield
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
,
to
change
the
subject
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
much
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
slightingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Wickfield
is
,
I
dare
say
,
a
man
of
very
excellent
intentions
;
but
he
is
---
in
short
,
he
is
obsolete
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
his
partner
seeks
to
make
him
so
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Copperfield
!
"
returned
Mr
Micawber
,
after
some
uneasy
evolutions
on
his
stool
,
"
allow
me
to
offer
a
remark
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
here
,
in
a
capacity
of
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
here
,
in
a
position
of
trust
.
<EOS>
The
discussion
of
some
topics
,
even
with
Mrs
Micawber
herself
(
so
long
the
partner
of
my
various
vicissitudes
,
and
a
woman
of
a
remarkable
lucidity
of
intellect
)
,
is
,
I
am
led
to
consider
,
incompatible
with
the
functions
now
devolving
on
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
therefore
take
the
liberty
of
suggesting
that
in
our
friendly
intercourse
---
which
I
trust
will
never
be
disturbed
!
<EOS>
---
we
draw
a
line
.
 
<EOS>
On
one
side
of
this
line
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
representing
it
on
the
desk
with
the
office
ruler
,
"
is
the
whole
range
of
the
human
intellect
,
with
a
trifling
exception
;
on
the
other
,
IS
that
exception
;
that
is
to
say
,
the
affairs
of
Messrs
Wickfield
and
Heep
,
with
all
belonging
and
appertaining
thereunto
.
 
<EOS>
I
trust
I
give
no
offence
to
the
companion
of
my
youth
,
in
submitting
this
proposition
to
his
cooler
judgement
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Though
I
saw
an
uneasy
change
in
Mr
Micawber
,
which
sat
tightly
on
him
,
as
if
his
new
duties
were
a
misfit
,
I
felt
I
had
no
right
to
be
offended
.
 
<EOS>
My
telling
him
so
,
appeared
to
relieve
him
;
and
he
shook
hands
with
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
charmed
,
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
let
me
assure
you
,
with
Miss
Wickfield
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
a
very
superior
young
lady
,
of
very
remarkable
attractions
,
graces
,
and
virtues
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
honour
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
indefinitely
kissing
his
hand
and
bowing
with
his
genteelest
air
,
"
I
do
Homage
to
Miss
Wickfield
!
 
<EOS>
Hem
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
of
that
,
at
least
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
not
assured
us
,
my
dear
Copperfield
,
on
the
occasion
of
that
agreeable
afternoon
we
had
the
happiness
of
passing
with
you
,
that
D
was
your
favourite
letter
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
I
should
unquestionably
have
supposed
that
A%
had
been
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
We
have
all
some
experience
of
a
feeling
,
that
comes
over
us
occasionally
,
of
what
we
are
saying
and
doing
having
been
said
and
done
before
,
in
a
remote
time
---
of
our
having
been
surrounded
,
dim
ages
ago
,
by
the
same
faces
,
objects
,
and
circumstances
---
of
our
knowing
perfectly
what
will
be
said
next
,
as
if
we
suddenly
remembered
it
!
 
<EOS>
I
never
had
this
mysterious
impression
more
strongly
in
my
life
,
than
before
he
uttered
those
words
.
   
<EOS>
I
took
my
leave
of
Mr
Micawber
,
for
the
time
,
charging
him
with
my
best
remembrances
to
all
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
left
him
,
resuming
his
stool
and
his
pen
,
and
rolling
his
head
in
his
stock
,
to
get
it
into
easier
writing
order
,
I
clearly
perceived
that
there
was
something
interposed
between
him
and
me
,
since
he
had
come
into
his
new
functions
,
which
prevented
our
getting
at
each
other
as
we
used
to
do
,
and
quite
altered
the
character
of
our
intercourse
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
no
one
in
the
quaint
old
drawing
-
room
,
though
it
presented
tokens
of
Mrs
Heep
's
whereabouts
.
 
<EOS>
I
looked
into
the
room
still
belonging
to
Agnes
,
and
saw
her
sitting
by
the
fire
,
at
a
pretty
old
-
fashioned
desk
she
had
,
writing
.
   
<EOS>
My
darkening
the
light
made
her
look
up
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
pleasure
to
be
the
cause
of
that
bright
change
in
her
attentive
face
,
and
the
object
of
that
sweet
regard
and
welcome
!
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Agnes
!
<EOS>
"
said
I
,
when
we
were
sitting
together
,
side
by
side
;
"
I
have
missed
you
so
much
,
lately
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
?
<EOS>
"
she
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
Again
!
 
<EOS>
And
so
soon
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
shook
my
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
how
it
is
,
Agnes
;
I
seem
to
want
some
faculty
of
mind
that
I
ought
to
have
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
so
much
in
the
habit
of
thinking
for
me
,
in
the
happy
old
days
here
,
and
I
came
so
naturally
to
you
for
counsel
and
support
,
that
I
really
think
I
have
missed
acquiring
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
is
it
?
"
said
Agnes
,
cheerfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
to
call
it
,
"
I
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
am
earnest
and
persevering
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
of
it
,
"
said
Agnes
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
patient
,
Agnes
?
<EOS>
"
I
inquired
,
with
a
little
hesitation
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
returned
Agnes
,
laughing
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pretty
well
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
And
yet
,
"
said
I
,
"
I
get
so
miserable
and
worried
,
and
am
so
unsteady
and
irresolute
in
my
power
of
assuring
myself
,
<EOS>
that
I
know
I
must
want
<EOS>
---
shall
I
call
it
---
reliance
,
of
some
kind
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Call
it
so
,
if
you
will
,
"
said
Agnes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
I
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
See
here
!
 
<EOS>
You
come
to
London
,
I
rely
on
you
,
and
I
have
an
object
and
a
course
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
driven
out
of
it
,
I
come
here
,
and
in
a
moment
I
feel
an
altered
person
.
 
<EOS>
The
circumstances
that
distressed
me
are
not
changed
,
since
I
came
into
this
room
;
but
an
influence
comes
over
me
in
that
short
interval
that
alters
me
,
oh
,
how
much
for
the
better
!
 
<EOS>
What
is
it
?
 
<EOS>
What
is
your
secret
,
Agnes
?
"
   
<EOS>
Her
head
was
bent
down
,
looking
at
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
old
story
,
"
said
I.
 
"
Do
n't
laugh
,
when
I
say
it
was
always
the
same
in
little
things
as
it
is
in
greater
ones
.
 
<EOS>
My
old
troubles
were
nonsense
,
and
now
they
are
serious
;
but
whenever
I
have
gone
away
from
my
adopted
sister
---
"
   
Agnes
looked
up
---
with
such
a
Heavenly
face
!
---
and
gave
me
her
hand
,
which
I
kissed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Whenever
I
have
not
had
you
,
Agnes
,
to
advise
and
approve
in
the
beginning
,
I
have
seemed
to
go
wild
,
and
to
get
into
all
sorts
of
difficulty
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
have
come
to
you
,
at
last
(
as
I
have
always
done
)
,
I
have
come
to
peace
and
happiness
.
 
<EOS>
I
come
home
,
now
,
like
a
tired
traveller
,
and
find
such
a
blessed
sense
of
rest
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
so
deeply
what
I
said
,
it
affected
me
so
sincerely
,
that
my
voice
failed
,
and
I
covered
my
face
with
my
hand
,
and
broke
into
tears
.
 
<EOS>
I
write
the
truth
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
contradictions
and
inconsistencies
there
were
within
me
,
as
there
are
within
so
many
of
us
;
whatever
might
have
been
so
different
,
and
so
much
better
;
whatever
I
had
done
,
in
which
I
had
perversely
wandered
away
from
the
voice
of
my
own
heart
;
I
knew
nothing
of
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
knew
that
I
was
fervently
in
earnest
,
when
I
felt
the
rest
and
peace
of
having
Agnes
near
me
.
   
<EOS>
In
her
placid
sisterly
manner
;
with
her
beaming
eyes
;
with
her
tender
voice
;
and
with
that
sweet
composure
,
which
had
long
ago
made
the
house
that
held
her
quite
a
sacred
place
to
me
;
she
soon
won
me
from
this
weakness
,
and
led
me
on
to
tell
all
that
had
happened
since
our
last
meeting
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
there
is
not
another
word
to
tell
,
Agnes
,
"
said
I
,
when
I
had
made
an
end
of
my
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
reliance
is
on
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
it
must
not
be
on
me
,
Trotwood
,
"
returned
Agnes
,
with
a
pleasant
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
on
someone
else
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
On
Dora
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Assuredly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
have
not
mentioned
,
Agnes
,
"
said
I
,
a
little
embarrassed
,
"
that
Dora
is
rather
difficult
to
---
<EOS>
I
would
not
,
for
the
world
,
say
,
to
rely
upon
,
because
she
is
the
soul
of
purity
and
truth
---
but
rather
difficult
to
---
I
hardly
know
how
to
express
it
,
really
,
Agnes
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
a
timid
little
thing
,
and
easily
disturbed
and
frightened
.
 
<EOS>
Some
time
ago
,
before
her
father
's
death
,
when
I
thought
it
right
to
mention
to
her
---
but
I
'll
tell
you
,
if
you
will
bear
with
me
,
how
it
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
I
told
Agnes
about
my
declaration
of
poverty
,
about
the
cookery
-
book
,
the
housekeeping
accounts
,
and
all
the
rest
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Trotwood
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
remonstrated
,
with
a
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
Just
your
old
headlong
way
!
 
<EOS>
You
might
have
been
in
earnest
in
striving
to
get
on
in
the
world
,
without
being
so
very
sudden
with
a
timid
,
loving
,
inexperienced
girl
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
Dora
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
never
heard
such
sweet
forbearing
kindness
expressed
in
a
voice
,
as
she
expressed
in
making
this
reply
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
as
if
I
had
seen
her
admiringly
and
tenderly
embracing
Dora
,
and
tacitly
reproving
me
,
by
her
considerate
protection
,
for
my
hot
haste
in
fluttering
that
little
heart
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
as
if
I
had
seen
Dora
,
in
all
her
fascinating
artlessness
,
caressing
Agnes
,
and
thanking
her
,
and
coaxingly
appealing
against
me
,
and
loving
me
with
all
her
childish
innocence
.
   
<EOS>
I
felt
so
grateful
to
Agnes
,
and
admired
her
so
!
 
<EOS>
I
saw
those
two
together
,
in
a
bright
perspective
,
<EOS>
such
well
-
associated
friends
,
each
adorning
the
other
so
much
!
   
<EOS>
"
What
ought
I
to
do
then
,
Agnes
?
<EOS>
"
I
inquired
,
after
looking
at
the
fire
a
little
while
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
would
it
be
right
to
do
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
"
said
Agnes
,
"
that
the
honourable
course
to
take
,
would
be
to
write
to
those
two
ladies
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
think
that
any
secret
course
is
an
unworthy
one
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
If
YOU
think
so
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
poorly
qualified
to
judge
of
such
matters
,
"
replied
Agnes
,
with
a
modest
hesitation
,
"
but
I
certainly
feel
---
in
short
<EOS>
,
I
feel
that
your
being
secret
and
clandestine
,
is
not
being
like
yourself
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Like
myself
,
in
the
too
high
opinion
you
have
of
me
,
Agnes
,
I
am
afraid
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Like
yourself
,
in
the
candour
of
your
nature
,
"
she
returned
;
"
and
therefore
I
would
write
to
those
two
ladies
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
relate
,
as
plainly
and
as
openly
as
possible
,
all
that
has
taken
place
;
and
I
would
ask
their
permission
to
visit
sometimes
,
at
their
house
.
<EOS>
Considering
that
you
are
young
,
and
striving
for
a
place
in
life
,
I
think
it
would
be
well
to
say
that
you
would
readily
abide
by
any
conditions
they
might
impose
upon
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
entreat
them
not
to
dismiss
your
request
,
without
a
reference
to
Dora
;
and
to
discuss
it
with
her
when
they
should
think
the
time
suitable
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
not
be
too
vehement
,
"
said
Agnes
,
gently
,
"
or
propose
too
much
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
trust
to
my
fidelity
and
perseverance
---
and
to
Dora
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
if
they
were
to
frighten
Dora
again
,
Agnes
,
by
speaking
to
her
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
And
if
Dora
were
to
cry
,
and
say
nothing
about
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
likely
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Agnes
,
with
the
same
sweet
consideration
in
her
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
God
bless
her
,
she
is
as
easily
scared
as
a
bird
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
It
might
be
!
 
<EOS>
Or
if
the
two
Miss
Spenlows
(
elderly
ladies
of
that
sort
are
odd
characters
sometimes
)
should
not
be
likely
persons
to
address
in
that
way
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
,
Trotwood
,
"
returned
Agnes
,
raising
her
soft
eyes
to
mine
,
"
I
would
consider
that
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
would
be
better
only
to
consider
whether
it
is
right
to
do
this
;
and
,
if
it
is
,
to
do
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
had
no
longer
any
doubt
on
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
With
a
lightened
heart
,
though
with
a
profound
sense
of
the
weighty
importance
of
my
task
,
I
devoted
the
whole
afternoon
to
the
composition
of
the
draft
of
this
letter
;
for
which
great
purpose
,
Agnes
relinquished
her
desk
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
first
I
went
downstairs
to
see
Mr
Wickfield
and
Uriah
Heep
.
   
<EOS>
I
found
Uriah
in
possession
of
a
new
,
plaster
-
smelling
office
,
built
out
in
the
garden
;
looking
extraordinarily
mean
,
in
the
midst
of
a
quantity
of
books
and
papers
.
 
<EOS>
He
received
me
in
his
usual
fawning
way
,
and
pretended
not
to
have
heard
of
my
arrival
from
Mr
Micawber
;
a
pretence
I
took
the
liberty
of
disbelieving
.
 
<EOS>
He
accompanied
me
into
Mr
Wickfield
's
room
,
which
was
the
shadow
of
its
former
self
---
having
been
divested
of
a
variety
of
conveniences
,
for
the
accommodation
of
the
new
partner
---
and
stood
before
the
fire
,
warming
his
back
,
and
shaving
his
chin
with
his
bony
hand
,
while
Mr
Wickfield
<EOS>
and
I
exchanged
greetings
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
stay
with
us
,
Trotwood
,
while
you
remain
in
Canterbury
?
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
,
not
without
a
glance
at
Uriah
for
his
approval
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
there
room
for
me
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
,
Master
Copperfield
---
I
should
say
Mister
,
but
the
other
comes
so
natural
,
"
said
Uriah
,
---
<EOS>
"
I
would
turn
out
of
your
old
room
with
pleasure
,
if
it
would
be
agreeable
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
should
you
be
inconvenienced
?
<EOS>
There
's
another
room
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
another
room
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
but
you
know
,
"
returned
Uriah
,
with
a
grin
,
"
I
should
really
be
delighted
!
"
   
<EOS>
To
cut
the
matter
short
,
I
said
I
would
have
the
other
room
or
none
at
all
;
so
it
was
settled
that
I
should
have
the
other
room
;
and
,
taking
my
leave
of
the
firm
until
dinner
<EOS>
,
I
went
upstairs
again
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
hoped
to
have
no
other
companion
than
Agnes
.
 
<EOS>
But
Mrs
Heep
had
asked
permission
to
bring
herself
and
her
knitting
near
the
fire
,
in
that
room
;
on
pretence
of
its
having
an
aspect
more
favourable
for
her
rheumatics
,
as
the
wind
then
was
,
than
the
drawing
-
room
or
dining
-
parlour
.
 
<EOS>
Though
I
could
almost
have
consigned
her
to
the
mercies
of
the
wind
on
the
topmost
pinnacle
of
the
Cathedral
,
without
remorse
,
I
made
a
virtue
of
necessity
,
and
gave
her
a
friendly
salutation
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
umbly
thankful
to
you
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Heep
,
in
acknowledgement
of
my
inquiries
concerning
her
health
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
'm
only
pretty
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
n't
much
to
boast
of
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
could
see
my
Uriah
well
settled
in
life
,
I
could
n't
expect
much
more
I
think
.
<EOS>
How
do
you
think
my
Ury
looking
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
thought
him
looking
as
villainous
as
ever
,
and
I
replied
that
I
saw
no
change
in
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
do
n't
you
think
he
's
changed
?
"
said
Mrs
Heep
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
I
must
umbly
beg
leave
to
differ
from
you
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
see
a
thinness
in
him
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
more
than
usual
,
"
I
replied
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
though
!
"
said
Mrs
Heep
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
you
do
n't
take
notice
of
him
with
a
mother
's
eye
!
"
   
<EOS>
His
mother
's
eye
was
an
evil
eye
to
the
rest
of
the
world
<EOS>
,
I
thought
as
it
met
mine
,
howsoever
affectionate
to
him
;
and
I
believe
she
and
her
son
were
devoted
to
one
another
.
 
<EOS>
It
passed
me
,
and
went
on
to
Agnes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
YOU
see
a
wasting
and
a
wearing
in
him
,
Miss
Wickfield
?
"
inquired
Mrs
Heep
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Agnes
,
quietly
pursuing
the
work
on
which
she
was
engaged
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
too
solicitous
about
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
very
well
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Heep
,
with
a
prodigious
sniff
,
resumed
her
knitting
.
   
<EOS>
She
never
left
off
,
or
left
us
for
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
arrived
early
in
the
day
,
and
we
had
still
three
or
four
hours
before
dinner
;
but
she
sat
there
,
plying
her
knitting
-
needles
as
monotonously
as
an
hour
-
glass
might
have
poured
out
its
sands
.
 
<EOS>
She
sat
on
one
side
of
the
fire
;
I
sat
at
the
desk
in
front
of
it
;
a
little
beyond
me
,
on
the
other
side
,
sat
Agnes
.
 
<EOS>
Whensoever
,
slowly
pondering
over
my
letter
,
I
lifted
up
my
eyes
,
and
meeting
the
thoughtful
face
of
Agnes
,
saw
it
clear
,
and
beam
encouragement
upon
me
,
with
its
own
angelic
expression
,
I
was
conscious
presently
of
the
evil
eye
passing
me
,
and
going
on
to
her
,
and
coming
back
to
me
again
,
and
dropping
furtively
upon
the
knitting
.
 
<EOS>
What
the
knitting
was
,
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
,
not
being
learned
in
that
art
;
but
it
looked
like
a
net
;
and
as
she
worked
away
with
those
Chinese
chopsticks
of
knitting
-
needles
,
she
showed
in
the
firelight
like
an
ill
-
looking
enchantress
,
baulked
as
yet
by
the
radiant
goodness
opposite
,
but
getting
ready
for
a
cast
of
her
net
by
and
by
.
   
<EOS>
At
dinner
she
maintained
her
watch
,
with
the
same
unwinking
eyes
.
<EOS>
After
dinner
,
her
son
took
his
turn
;
and
when
Mr
Wickfield
,
himself
,
and
I
were
left
alone
together
,
leered
at
me
,
and
writhed
until
I
could
hardly
bear
it
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
drawing
-
room
,
there
was
the
mother
knitting
and
watching
again
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
time
that
Agnes
sang
and
played
,
the
mother
sat
at
the
piano
.
 
<EOS>
Once
she
asked
for
a
particular
ballad
,
which
she
said
her
Ury
(
who
was
yawning
in
a
great
chair
)
doted
on
;
and
at
intervals
she
looked
round
at
him
,
and
reported
to
Agnes
that
he
was
in
raptures
with
the
music
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
hardly
ever
spoke
<EOS>
---
I
question
if
she
ever
did
---
without
making
some
mention
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
evident
to
me
that
this
was
the
duty
assigned
to
her
.
   
<EOS>
This
lasted
until
bedtime
.
 
<EOS>
To
have
seen
the
mother
and
son
,
like
two
great
bats
hanging
over
the
whole
house
,
and
darkening
it
with
their
ugly
forms
,
made
me
so
uncomfortable
,
that
I
would
rather
have
remained
downstairs
,
knitting
and
all
,
than
gone
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
I
hardly
got
any
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
Next
day
the
knitting
and
watching
began
again
,
and
lasted
all
day
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
not
an
opportunity
of
speaking
to
Agnes
,
for
ten
minutes
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
barely
show
her
my
letter
.
 
<EOS>
I
proposed
to
her
to
walk
out
with
me
;
but
Mrs
Heep
repeatedly
complaining
that
she
was
worse
,
Agnes
charitably
remained
within
,
to
bear
her
company
.
 
<EOS>
Towards
the
twilight
I
went
out
by
myself
,
musing
on
what
I
ought
to
do
,
and
whether
I
was
justified
in
withholding
from
Agnes
,
any
longer
,
what
Uriah
Heep
had
told
me
in
London
;
for
that
began
to
trouble
me
again
,
very
much
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
not
walked
out
far
enough
to
be
quite
clear
of
the
town
,
upon
the
Ramsgate
road
,
where
there
was
a
good
path
,
when
I
was
hailed
,
through
the
dust
,
by
somebody
behind
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
shambling
figure
,
and
the
scanty
great
-
coat
,
were
not
to
be
mistaken
.
 
<EOS>
I
stopped
,
and
Uriah
Heep
came
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
How
fast
you
walk
!
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
legs
are
pretty
long
,
but
you
've
given
'em
quite
a
job
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
are
you
going
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
with
you
,
Master
Copperfield
,
if
you
'll
allow
me
the
pleasure
of
a
walk
with
an
old
acquaintance
.
"
 
<EOS>
Saying
this
,
with
a
jerk
of
his
body
,
which
might
have
been
either
propitiatory
or
derisive
,
he
fell
into
step
beside
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Uriah
!
<EOS>
"
said
I
,
as
civilly
as
I
could
,
after
a
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Master
Copperfield
!
"
said
Uriah
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
tell
you
the
truth
(
at
which
you
will
not
be
offended
)
,
I
came
Out
to
walk
alone
,
because
I
have
had
so
much
company
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
looked
at
me
sideways
,
and
said
with
his
hardest
grin
,
"
You
mean
mother
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
yes
,
I
do
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
But
you
know
we
're
so
very
umble
,
"
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
having
such
a
knowledge
of
our
own
umbleness
,
we
must
really
take
care
that
we
're
not
pushed
to
the
wall
by
them
as
is
n't
umble
.
 
<EOS>
All
stratagems
are
fair
in
love
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Raising
his
great
hands
until
they
touched
his
chin
,
he
rubbed
them
softly
,
and
softly
chuckled
;
looking
as
like
a
malevolent
baboon
,
I
thought
,
as
anything
human
could
look
.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
"
he

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

,

?
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
Master
Copperfield
!
 
<EOS>
Those

very

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
You

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>
You

"

<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"
<EOS>

"

!
"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

---

<EOS>

"

?
"

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"
---

.
 
<EOS>
I

contents

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Upon

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
Oh

!
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
I

"

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
Peaceful
!
 
<EOS>
Ai

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
!
 
<EOS>
Now

"
There

"

,

<EOS>
"
Did

!
 
<EOS>
But

think

the
rightful

of

,

!
<EOS>
Father
and
me
was
both

a

;

mother
,

.
 
<EOS>
They

all
a

of

---
not
much
else
that
I
know
of
,

.
 
<EOS>
We
was
to
be
umble

this

,
and
umble

;
and
to
pull

our

here
,
and
to

there
;
and
always
to
know

,
and
abase

.
 
<EOS>
And
we
had
such

!
 
<EOS>
Father
got
the
monitor
-

by
being
umble
.
 
<EOS>
So
did
I.
Father
got
made
a
sexton
by
being
umble
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
the
character
,
among
the

,
of
being
such
a
well
-
behaved

,
that
they

.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
umble
,

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
It

what
was

dinned

you
and

;
it
's
what
goes
down

.
 
<EOS>
Be
umble
,
"
says
father
,
"

!
"
<EOS>
And
really
it
ai

!
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

,

<EOS>
I
ate
umble

.
<EOS>

,

Hold

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
And

---

<EOS>
I

;

<EOS>
His

that

<EOS>
Once

,

;

,

<EOS>
Whether

;

.
 
<EOS>
He

;

(
off

,

re

)

;
and

so
,
that
I

,
for

.
   
<EOS>
When

three
males

,
he

.
 
<EOS>
He
had

little

;
and
I
presume

the
mere

that
was
upon

,
flushed

by

my

.
   
<EOS>
I
had
observed

,
that
he
tried

;
and
,

,
had

.
 
<EOS>
I
would

;
but
Uriah
was

.
   
<EOS>
"
We

,

,
"

<EOS>
Mr

,

elth

!
"
   
<EOS>
I

;

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
I

,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
It

,
and
my

.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,

-

!
"

,

,
"
I

,
and
I
umbly

for
bumpers
,
seeing
I
intend
to
make
it
the
divinest
of
her
sex
.
"
   
<EOS>
Her
father
had
his
empty

in

.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
him
set

down
,
<EOS>
look
at
the
picture
she
was
so

,
put

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
an
umble

,
"

,
"
but
<EOS>
I

---
<EOS>
adore

.
"
   
<EOS>
No

that
her
father
's
grey

borne
,
I

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Agnes
,
"

,

,
"
Agnes
Wickfield
is
,
I

,
the

.
 
<EOS>
May

speak

,

?
 
<EOS>
To

her

is
a

,
but
to

her

---
"
   
Spare

from
ever
again

such

,
as
that
with

her
father
rose
up

the

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
's

?
"
said
Uriah
,
turning

.
 
<EOS>
"
You

not

,
after

,
Mr
Wickfield
,
I

?
 
<EOS>
If
I
say

an
ambition
to
make
your
Agnes
my
Agnes
<EOS>
,
I
have
as
good
a

to

as
another
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
better
right
to
it
than
any
other
man
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
had
<EOS>
my
arms
round
Mr
Wickfield
,
imploring
him
by
everything
that
I
could
think
of
,
oftenest
of
all
by
his
love

Agnes
,
to
calm
himself
a

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
mad
for
the
moment
;
tearing
out
his
hair
,
beating
his
head
,
trying
to
force
me
from
him
,
and
to
force
himself
from
me
,
not
answering
a
word
,
not
looking
at
or
seeing
anyone
;
blindly
striving
for
<EOS>
he
knew
not
what
,
his
face
all
staring
and

---
a
frightful
spectacle
.
   
<EOS>
I
conjured
him
,
incoherently
,
but
in
the
most
impassioned
manner
,
not
to
abandon
himself
to
this
wildness
,
but
to
hear
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
besought
him
to
think
of
Agnes
,
to
connect
me
with
Agnes
,
to
recollect
how
Agnes
and
I
had
grown
up
together
<EOS>
,
how
I
honoured
her
and
loved
her
<EOS>
,
how
she
was
his
pride
and
