.
 
<EOS>
I
tried
to
bring
her
idea
before
him
in
any
form
;
I
even
reproached
him
with
not
having
firmness
to
spare
her
the
knowledge
of
such
a
scene
as
this
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
have
effected
something
,
or
his
wildness
may
have
spent
itself
;
but
by
degrees
he
struggled
less
,
and
began
to
look
at
me
---
strangely
at
first
,
then
with
recognition
in
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
said
,
"
I
know
,
Trotwood
!
 
<EOS>
My
darling
child
and
you
<EOS>
---
I
know
!
 
<EOS>
But
look
at
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
pointed
to
Uriah
,
pale
and
glowering
in
a
corner
,
evidently
very
much
out
in
his
calculations
,
and
taken
by
surprise
.
   
<EOS>
"
Look
at
my
torturer
,
"
he
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
Before
him
I
have
step
by
step
abandoned
name
and
reputation
,
peace
and
quiet
,
house
and
home
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
kept
your
name
and
reputation
for
you
,
and
your
peace
and
quiet
,
and
your
house
and
home
too
,
"
said
Uriah
,
with
a
sulky
,
hurried
,
defeated
air
of
compromise
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
foolish
,
Mr
Wickfield
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
have
gone
a
little
beyond
what
you
were
prepared
for
<EOS>
,
I
can
go
back
,
I
suppose
?
 
<EOS>
There
's
no
harm
done
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
looked
for
single
motives
in
everyone
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
,
"
and
<EOS>
I
was
satisfied
I
had
bound
him
to
me
by
motives
of
interest
.
 
<EOS>
But
see
what
he
is
<EOS>
---
oh
,
see
what
he
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
stop
him
,
Copperfield
,
if
you
can
,
"
cried
Uriah
,
with
his
long
forefinger
pointing
towards
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
'll
say
something
presently
---
<EOS>
mind
you
!
<EOS>
---
he
'll
be
sorry
to
have
said
afterwards
,
and
you
'll
be
sorry
to
have
heard
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
say
anything
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Wickfield
,
with
a
desperate
air
.
<EOS>
"
Why
should
I
not
be
in
all
the
world
's
power
if
I
am
in
yours
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mind
!
<EOS>
I
tell
you
!
"
<EOS>
said
Uriah
,
continuing
to
warn
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
n't
stop
his
mouth
,
you
're
not
his
friend
!
 
<EOS>
Why
should
n't
you
be
in
all
the
world
's
power
,
Mr
Wickfield
?
 
<EOS>
Because
you
have
got
a
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
You
and
me
know
what
we
know
,
do
n't
we
?
 
<EOS>
Let
sleeping
dogs
lie
---
who
wants
to
rouse
'em
?
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
Ca
n't
you
see
I
am
as
umble
as
I
can
be
?
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
,
if
I
've
gone
too
far
,
I
'm
sorry
.
<EOS>
What
would
you
have
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Trotwood
,
Trotwood
!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Wickfield
,
wringing
his
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
I
have
come
down
to
be
,
since
I
first
saw
you
in
this
house
!
 
<EOS>
I
was
on
my
downward
way
then
,
but
the
dreary
,
dreary
road
I
have
traversed
since
!
 
<EOS>
Weak
indulgence
has
ruined
me
.
 
<EOS>
Indulgence
in
remembrance
,
and
indulgence
in
forgetfulness
.
 
<EOS>
My
natural
grief
for
my
child
's
mother
turned
to
disease
;
my
natural
love
for
my
child
turned
to
disease
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
infected
everything
I
touched
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
brought
misery
on
what
I
dearly
love
<EOS>
,
I
know
---
you
know
!
 
<EOS>
I
thought
it
possible
that
I
could
truly
love
one
creature
in
the
world
,
and
not
love
the
rest
;
I
thought
it
possible
that
I
could
truly
mourn
for
one
creature
gone
out
of
the
world
,
and
not
have
some
part
in
the
grief
of
all
who
mourned
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
the
lessons
of
my
life
have
been
perverted
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
preyed
on
my
own
morbid
coward
heart
,
and
it
has
preyed
on
me
.
 
<EOS>
Sordid
in
my
grief
,
sordid
in
my
love
,
sordid
in
my
miserable
escape
from
the
darker
side
of
both
,
<EOS>
oh
see
the
ruin
I
am
,
and
hate
me
,
shun
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
dropped
into
a
chair
,
and
weakly
sobbed
.
 
<EOS>
The
excitement
into
which
he
had
been
roused
was
leaving
him
.
 
<EOS>
Uriah
came
out
of
his
corner
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
all
I
have
done
,
in
my
fatuity
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
,
putting
out
his
hands
,
as
if
to
deprecate
my
condemnation
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
knows
best
,
"
meaning
Uriah
Heep
,
"
for
he
has
always
been
at
my
elbow
,
whispering
me
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
the
millstone
that
he
is
about
my
neck
.
 
<EOS>
You
find
him
in
my
house
,
you
find
him
in
my
business
.
 
<EOS>
You
heard
him
,
but
a
little
time
ago
.
 
<EOS>
What
need
have
I
to
say
more
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
n't
need
to
say
so
much
,
nor
half
so
much
,
nor
anything
at
all
,
"
observed
Uriah
,
half

,

half

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
would
n't
have
took
it
up
<EOS>
so
,
if
it
had

been
for
the
wine
.
<EOS>
You
'll
think
better
of
it
tomorrow
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
have
said
too
much
,
or
more
than
I
meant
,
what
of
it
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
n't
stood
by
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
door
opened
,
and
Agnes
,
gliding
in
,
without
a
vestige
of
colour
in
her
face
,
put
her
arm
round
his
neck
,
and
steadily
said
,
"
Papa
,
you
are
not
well
.
 
<EOS>
Come
with
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
laid
his
head
upon
her
shoulder
,
as
if
he
were
oppressed
with
heavy
shame
,
and
went
out
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
Her
eyes
met
mine
for
but
an
instant
,
yet
I
saw
how
much
she
knew
of
what
had
passed
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
expect
he
'd
cut
up
so
rough
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
said
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
it
's
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
be
friends
with
him
tomorrow
.
<EOS>
It
's
for
his
good
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
umbly
anxious
for
his
good
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
gave
him
no
answer
,
and
went
upstairs
into
the
quiet
room
where
Agnes
had
so
often
sat
beside
me
at
my
books
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
came
near
me
until
late
at
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
took
up
a
book
,
and
tried
to
read
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
the
clocks
strike
twelve
,
and
was
still
reading
,
without
knowing
what
I
read
,
when
Agnes
touched
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
be
going
early
in
the
morning
,
Trotwood
!
 
<EOS>
Let
us
say
good
-
bye
,
now
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
had
been
weeping
,
but
her
face
then
was
so
calm
and
beautiful
!
   
<EOS>
"
Heaven
bless
you
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
giving
me
her
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dearest
Agnes
!
<EOS>
"
I
returned
,
"
I
see
you
ask
me
not
to
speak
of
tonight
---
but
is
there
nothing
to
be
done
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
God
to
trust
in
!
"
<EOS>
she

.
   
<EOS>
"
Can
I
do
nothing
---
<EOS>
I
,
who
come
to
you
with
my
poor
sorrows
?
"
   
"
<EOS>
And
make
mine
so
much
lighter
,
"
she
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
Trotwood
,
no
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
Agnes
,
"
I
said
,
"
it
is
presumptuous
for
me
,
who
am
so
poor
in
all

you
are
so
rich
---
<EOS>
goodness
,
resolution
,
all
noble

---
to
doubt

you
;
<EOS>
but
you
know
how
much
I
love
you
,
and
how
much

owe

.
 
<EOS>
You
will
never
sacrifice
yourself
to
a
mistaken
sense
of
duty
,
Agnes
?
"
   
<EOS>
More
agitated
for
a
moment
than
I
had
ever
seen
her
,
she
took
her
hands
from
me
,
and
moved
a
step
back
.
   
<EOS>
"
Say
you
have
no
such
thought
,
dear
Agnes
!
 
<EOS>
Much
more
than
sister
!
<EOS>
Think
of
the
priceless
gift
of
such
a
heart
as
yours
,
of
such
a
love
as
yours
!
"
   
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
long
,
long
afterwards
,
I
saw
that
face
rise
up
before
me
,
with
its
momentary
look
,
not
wondering
,
not

,
not

.
<EOS>
Oh
,
long
,
long
afterwards
,
I
saw
that
look
subside
,
as
it
did
now
,
into
the
lovely

,
with
which
she
told
me
she
had
no
fear
for
herself
---
I
need
have
none
for
her
---
and
parted
from
me
by
the
name
of
Brother
,
and
was
gone
!
   
<EOS>
It
was
dark
in
the
morning
,
when
I
got
upon
the
coach
at
the
inn
door
.
 
<EOS>
The
day
was
just
breaking
when
we
were
about
to
start
,
and
then
,
as
I
sat
thinking
of
her
,
came
struggling
up
the
coach
side
,
through
the
mingled
day
and
night
,
Uriah
's
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
Copperfield
!
"
<EOS>
said
he
,
in
a
croaking
whisper
,
<EOS>
as
he
hung
by
the
iron
on
the
roof
,
"
I
thought
you
'd
be
glad
to
hear
before
you
went
off
,
that
there
are
no
squares
broke
between
us
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
been
into
his
room
already
,
and
we
've
made
it
all
smooth
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
though
I
'm
umble
,
I
'm
useful
to
him
,
you
know
;
and
he
understands
his
interest
when
he
is
n't
in
liquor
!
 
<EOS>
What
an
agreeable
man
he
is
,
after
all
,
Master
Copperfield
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
obliged
myself
to
say
that
I
was
glad
he
had
made
his
apology
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
to
be
sure
!
"
said
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
a
person
's
umble
,
you
know
,
what
's
an
apology
?
 
<EOS>
So
easy
!
 
<EOS>
I
say
!
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
,
"
with
a
jerk
,
"
you
have
sometimes
plucked
a
pear
before
it
was
ripe
,
Master
Copperfield
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
I
have
,
"
I
replied
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
that
last
night
,
"
said
Uriah
;
"
but
it
'll
ripen
yet
!
 
<EOS>
It
only
wants
attending
to
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
wait
!
"
   
<EOS>
Profuse
in
his
farewells
<EOS>
,
he
got
down
again
as
the
coachman
got
up
.
<EOS>
For
anything
I
know
,
he
was
eating
something
to
keep
the
raw
morning
air
out
;
but
he
made
motions
with
his
mouth
as
if
the
pear
were
ripe
already
,
and
he
were
smacking
his
lips
over
it
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
40
.
<EOS>
The
wanderer
 
<EOS>
We
had
a
very
serious
conversation
in
Buckingham
Street
that
night
,
about
the
domestic
occurrences
I
have
detailed
in
the
last
chapter
.
<EOS>
My
aunt
was
deeply
interested
in
them
,
and
walked
up
and
down
the
room
with
her
arms
folded
,
for
more
than
two
hours
afterwards
.
<EOS>
Whenever
she
was
particularly
discomposed
,
she
always
performed
one
of
these
pedestrian
feats
;
and
the
amount
of
her
discomposure
might
always
be
estimated
by
the
duration
of
her
walk
.
 
<EOS>
On
this
occasion
she
was
so
much
disturbed
in
mind
as
to
find
it
necessary
to
open
the
bedroom
door
,
and
make
a
course
for
herself
,
comprising
the
full
extent
of
the
bedrooms
from
wall
to
wall
;
and
while
Mr
Dick
and
I
sat
quietly
by
the
fire
,
she
kept
passing
in
and
out
,
along
this
measured
track
,
at
an
unchanging
pace
,
with
the
regularity
of
a
clock
-
pendulum
.
   
<EOS>
When
my
aunt
and
I
were
left
to
ourselves
by
Mr
Dick
's
going
out
to
bed
,
I
sat
down
to
write
my
letter
to
the
two
old
ladies
.
 
<EOS>
By
that
time
she
was
tired
of
walking
,
and
sat
by
the
fire
with
her
dress
tucked
up
as
usual
.
 
<EOS>
But
instead
of
sitting
in
her
usual
manner
,
holding
her
glass
upon
her
knee
,
she
suffered
it
to
stand
neglected
on
the
chimney
-
piece
;
and
,
resting
her
left
elbow
on
her
right
arm
,
and
her
chin
on
her
left
hand
,
looked
thoughtfully
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
As
often
as
I
raised
my
eyes
from
what
I
was
about
,
I
met
hers
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
in
the
lovingest
of
tempers
,
my
dear
,
"
she
would
assure
me
with
a
nod
,
"
but
I
am
fidgeted
and
sorry
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
had
been
too
busy
to
observe
,
until
after
she
was
gone
to
bed
,
that
she
had
left
her
night
-
mixture
,
as
she
always
called
it
,
untasted
on
the
chimney
-
piece
.
 
<EOS>
She
came
to
her
door
,
with
even
more
than
her
usual
affection
of
manner
,
when
I
knocked
to
acquaint
her
with
this
discovery
;
but
only
said
,
"
I
have
not
the
heart
to
take
it
,
Trot
,
tonight
,
"
and
shook
her
head
,
and
went
in
again
.
   
<EOS>
She
read
my
letter
to
the
two
old
ladies
,
in
the
morning
,
and
approved
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
posted
it
,
and
had
nothing
to
do
then
,
but
wait
,
as
patiently
as
I
could
,
for
the
reply
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
still
in
this
state
of
expectation
,
and
had
been
,
for
nearly
a
week
;
when
I
left
the
Doctor
's
one
snowy
night
,
to
walk
home
.
   
<EOS>
It

,

a

some

.
 
<EOS>
The

gone
down
with

light
,
and
so

come

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
heavy
,

,
I
recollect
,

;

.
 
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
My

---

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
the

,

;

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

I

Chapter

.
<EOS>
Dora
's

<EOS>

<EOS>
They

,

"
with

---

in

,

had
(
and

)
<EOS>
observed
that
conventional

are
a
sort

,

,
and

.
 
<EOS>

,
"

"
,

's

;

.
   
<EOS>
To

Mr

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Having

,
Mr

fell
into
a
condition

strong

;
and
so

until
the
day

.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
great
augmentation
of
my
uneasiness
to
be

,
at
this

,
of
the

of
Miss
Mills
.
<EOS>
But
Mr
Mills
,
who
was
always
doing
something
or
other
to

---
or
<EOS>
I
felt
as
if
he
were
,
which
was
the

---
had

his

to

,
by

that
he

to

.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
he
go
to
India
,
except
to
harass

?
 
<EOS>
To

sure

had
nothing

do
with
any
other
part

the
world
,
and
had

with
that

;
being
entirely
in
the
India

,
<EOS>
whatever

was
(
I

myself

'

)
;
having

at
Calcutta
in
his

;
and

to
go

again
,
in

.
 
<EOS>
But
this
was
nothing
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
However
,

was
so
much
to
him
that
for
India
he

,
and

with

;
and
Julia

into

country
to
take

;
and
the
house
was
put
into
a
perfect
suit

,

was
to
be
let
or
sold
,
and
that
the
furniture
(
Mangle
and
all
)
was
to
be
taken
at
a
valuation
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
here
was
another
earthquake
of
which
I
became
the
sport
,
before
I
had
recovered
from
the
shock
of
its
predecessor
!
   
<EOS>
I
was
in
several
minds
how
to
dress
myself
on
the
important
day
;
being
divided
between
my
desire
to
appear
to
advantage
,
and
my
apprehensions
of
putting
on
anything
that
might
impair
my
severely
practical
character
in
the
eyes
of
the
Misses
Spenlow
.
 
<EOS>
I
endeavoured
to
hit
a
happy
medium
between
these
two
extremes
;
my
aunt
approved
the
result
;
and
Mr
Dick
threw
one
of
his
shoes
after
Traddles
and
me
,
for
luck
,
as
we
went
downstairs
.
   
<EOS>
Excellent
fellow
as
I
knew
Traddles
to
be
,
and
warmly
attached
to
him
as
I
was
<EOS>
,
I
could
not

,

that
delicate

,
that
he
had
never
contracted
the

of
brushing

so

.
 
<EOS>
It
gave

a
surprised

---
not
to
say
a
hearth

broomy
kind
of
expression
---
which
,
my
apprehensions

,
might
be
fatal
to

.
   
<EOS>
I
took
the
liberty
of
mentioning
it
to
Traddles
,
as
we
were

to
Putney
;
and
saying
that
if
he
WOULD
smooth
it
down
a

---
   
"
My
dear

,
"
said

,

,
and

all

,
"
nothing

.
 
<EOS>
But

wo

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
be

down
?
"

I.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
will

.
 
<EOS>
If
I
was

,
all

Putney
,
it

.
 
<EOS>
You

obstinate
hair
mine

,
<EOS>
Copperfield
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
quite

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
a

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

;
and

that
his
hair
must

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
"

<EOS>
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
My

's

.
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
Very

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
SHE

,
"

;
"
but
<EOS>
her

---

's

---
quite

game
of
it
<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
In

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Agreeable
!
"

<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"

"
it

.
 
<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

,

"
it

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly

"
   
"
The

"

<EOS>
"
The

,
"

---
"
<EOS>
Reverend
Horace
Crewler
---
<EOS>

with

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

(

.
 
<EOS>
As

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"
What

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
She

,

.
 
<EOS>
In

.
 
<EOS>
Sophy

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

;

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
There

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

!
"
   
<EOS>
His

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

,

,

;

,

,

<EOS>
Also

's

,

,

<EOS>

,

---

.
 
<EOS>
Also

.
 
<EOS>
Also

that

,

.
<EOS>
Ultimately

.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
When

,

not

---
my

---
<EOS>
I
so
far

,
as

had

;

;

,

---

---

was

.
 
<EOS>
They
were

alike
,
but
this

than
the
other
;
and

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
They

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

not
my

,
had

on

,
and

,

Idol
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr

,
I

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
This

.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
had
to
indicate
that
I
was
Mr
Copperfield
,
and
I

to
lay

to

,
and

that
Traddles
was
Mr

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
To

,

all

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Copperfield
!
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
I

something
---
<EOS>
bowed
,
I

---
and

all

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
My

,
"
said

"
being

this
nature
<EOS>
,
will
state
what
we
consider
most
calculated
to
promote

of
both

.
"
   
<EOS>
I

that
Miss

was
an

the
heart
,
by

anciently

Mr

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
My

,

,

that
Pidger
was

---

never

.
 
<EOS>
Both
Miss
Lavinia
and
Miss
Clarissa
had
a
superstition
,
however
,
that
he
would
have
declared
his

,
if
he

not

cut
short
in
his
youth
(
at

)

,

.
 
<EOS>
They

,
that
he
died

secret

;
though
I
must
say

in

,
which

not

.
   
<EOS>
"
We
will
not
,
"
said

Lavinia
,
"
enter

past

of
this

.
 
<EOS>
Our
poor
brother
<EOS>
Francis
's
death
has
cancelled

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
had
not
,
"
said
Miss
Clarissa
,
"
been
in

frequent

our

;
but

.
 
<EOS>
Francis
took
his
road
;
we
took

.
 
<EOS>
We
considered
it
conducive
to
the
happiness
of
all

that
it
should
be
so
.
 
<EOS>
And
it
was
so
.
"
   
<EOS>
Each

the
sisters
leaned
a
little
forward
to
speak
,
shook
her
head
after
speaking
,
and
became
upright
again
when
silent
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Clarissa
never
moved
her
arms
.
 
<EOS>
She
sometimes
played
tunes
upon
them
with
her
fingers
---
minuets
and
marches
<EOS>
I
should
think
---
but
never
moved
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
Our
niece
's
position
,
or
supposed
position
,
is
much
changed
by
our
brother
Francis
's
death
,
"
said
Miss
Lavinia
;
"
and
therefore
we
consider
our
brother
's
opinions
as
regarded
her
position
as
being
changed
too
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
no
reason
to
doubt
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
that
you
are
a
young
gentleman
possessed
of
good
qualities
and
honourable
character
;
or
that
you
have
an
affection
---
or
are
fully
persuaded
that
you
have
an
affection
---
for
our
niece
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
replied
,
as
I
usually
did
whenever
I
had
a
chance
,
that
nobody
had
ever
loved
anybody
else
as
I
loved
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
came
to
my
assistance
with
a
confirmatory
murmur
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Lavinia
was
going
on
to
make
some
rejoinder
,
when
Miss
Clarissa
,
who
appeared
to
be
incessantly
beset
by
a
desire
to
refer
to
her
brother
Francis
,
struck
in
again
:
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
Dora
's
mama
,
"
she
said
,
"
when
she
married
our
brother
Francis
,
had
at
once
said
that
there
was
not
room
for
the
family
at
the
dinner
-
table
,
it
would
have
been
better
for
the
happiness
of
all
parties
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sister
Clarissa
,
"
said
Miss
Lavinia
.
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
we
need
n't
mind
that
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sister
Lavinia
,
"
said
Miss
Clarissa
,
"
it
belongs
to
the
subject
.
<EOS>
With
your
branch
of
the
subject
,
on
which
alone
you
are
competent
to
speak
,
I
should
not
think
of
interfering
.
 
<EOS>
On
this
branch
of
the
subject
I
have
a
voice
and
an
opinion
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
better
for
the
happiness
of
all
parties
,
if
Dora
's
mama
,
when
she
married
our
brother
Francis
,
had
mentioned
plainly
what
her
intentions
were
.
 
<EOS>
We
should
then
have
known
what
we
had
to
expect
.
 
<EOS>
We
should
have
said
"
Pray
do
not
invite
us
,
at
any
time
"
;
and
all
possibility
of
misunderstanding
would
have
been
avoided
.
"
   
<EOS>
When
Miss
Clarissa
had
shaken
her
head
,
Miss
Lavinia
resumed
:
again
referring
to
my
letter
through
her
eye
-
glass
.
 
<EOS>
They
both
had
little
bright
round
twinkling
eyes
,
by
the
way
,
which
were
like
birds
'
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
not
unlike
birds
,
altogether
;
having
a
sharp
,
brisk
,
sudden
manner
,
and
a
little
short
,
spruce
way
of
adjusting
themselves
,
like
canaries
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Lavinia
,
as
I
have
said
,
resumed
:
   
<EOS>
"
You
ask
permission
of
my
sister
Clarissa
and
myself
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
to
visit
here
,
as
the
accepted
suitor
of
our
niece
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
our
brother
Francis
,
"
said
Miss
Clarissa
,
breaking
out
again
,
if
I
may
call
anything
so
calm
a
breaking
out
,
"
wished
to
surround
himself
with
an
atmosphere
of
Doctors
'
Commons
,
and
of
Doctors
'
Commons
only
<EOS>
,
what
right
or
desire
had
we
to
object
?
 
<EOS>
None
,
I
am
sure
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
ever
been
far
from
wishing
to
obtrude
ourselves
on
anyone
.
 
<EOS>
But
why
not
say
so
?
 
<EOS>
Let
our
brother
Francis
and
his
wife
have
their
society
.
 
<EOS>
Let
my
sister
Lavinia
and
myself
have
our
society
.
 
<EOS>
We
can
find
it
for
ourselves
,
I
hope
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
this
appeared
to
be
addressed
to
Traddles
and
me
,
both
Traddles
and
I
made
some
sort
of
reply
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
was
inaudible
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
observed
,
myself
,
that
it
was
highly
creditable
to
all
concerned
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
in
the
least
know
what
I
meant
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sister
Lavinia
,
"
said
Miss
Clarissa
,
having
now
relieved
her
mind
,
"
you
can
go
on
,
my
dear
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Lavinia
proceeded
:
   
"
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
,
my
sister
Clarissa
<EOS>
and
I
have
been
very
careful
indeed
in
considering
this
letter
;
and
we
have
not
considered
it
without
finally
showing
it
to
our
niece
,
and
discussing
it
with
our
niece
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
no
doubt
that
you
think
you
like
her
very
much
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Think
,
ma'am
,
"
<EOS>
I
rapturously
began
,
"
oh
!
---
"
   
<EOS>
But
Miss
Clarissa
giving
me
a
look
(
just
like
a
sharp
canary
)
,
as
requesting
that
I
would
not
interrupt
the
oracle
,
I
begged
pardon
.
   
<EOS>
"
Affection
,
"
said
Miss
Lavinia
,
glancing
at
her
sister
for
corroboration
,
which
she
gave
in
the
form
of
a
little
nod
to
every
clause
,
"
mature
affection
,
homage
,
devotion
,
does
not
easily
express
itself
.
 
<EOS>
Its
voice
is
low
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
modest
and
retiring
,
it
lies
in
ambush
,
waits
and
waits
.
 
<EOS>
Such
is
the
mature
fruit
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
a
life
glides
away
,
and
finds
it
still
ripening
in
the
shade
.
"
   
<EOS>
Of
course
I
did
not
understand
then
that
this
was
an
allusion
to
her
supposed
experience
of
the
stricken
Pidger
;
but
I
saw
,
from
the
gravity
with
which
Miss
Clarissa
nodded
her
head
,
that
great
weight
was
attached
to
these
words
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
light
---
for
I
call
them
,
in
comparison
with
such
sentiments
,
the
light
---
inclinations
of
very
young
people
,
"
pursued
Miss
Lavinia
,
"
are
dust
,
compared
to
rocks
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
owing
to
the
difficulty
of
knowing
whether
they
are
likely
to
endure
or
have
any
real
foundation
,
that
my
sister
Clarissa
and
myself
have
been
very
undecided
how
to
act
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
and
Mr
---
"
   
"
Traddles
,
"
said
my
friend
,
finding
himself
looked
at
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
pardon
.
 
<EOS>
Of
the
Inner
Temple
,
I
believe
?
"
said
Miss
Clarissa
,
again
glancing
at
my
letter
.
   
<EOS>
Traddles
said
"
Exactly
so
,
"
and
became
pretty
red
in
the
face
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
although
I
had
not
received
any
express
encouragement
as
yet
,
I
fancied
that
I
saw
in
the
two
little
sisters
,
and
particularly
in
Miss
Lavinia
,
an
intensified
enjoyment
of
this
new
and
fruitful
subject
of
domestic
interest
,
a
settling
down
to
make
the
most
of
it
,
a
disposition
to
pet
it
,
in
which
there
was
a
good
bright
ray
of
hope
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
I
perceived
that
Miss
Lavinia
would
have
uncommon
satisfaction
in
superintending
two
young
lovers
,
like
Dora
and
me
;
and
that
Miss
Clarissa
would
have
hardly
less
satisfaction
in
seeing
her
superintend
us
,
and
in
chiming
in
with
her
own
particular
department
of
the
subject
whenever
that
impulse
was
strong
upon
her
.
 
<EOS>
This
gave
me
courage
to
protest
most
vehemently
that
I
loved
Dora
better
than
I
could
tell
,
or
anyone
believe
;
that
all
my
friends
knew
how
I
loved
her
;
that
my
aunt
,
Agnes
,
Traddles
,
everyone
who
knew
me
,
knew
how
I
loved
her
,
and
how
earnest
my
love
had
made
me
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
truth
of
this
,
I
appealed
to
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
And
Traddles
,
firing
up
as
if
he
were
plunging
into
a
Parliamentary
Debate
,
really
did
come
out
nobly
:
confirming
me
in
good
round
terms
,
and
in
a
plain
sensible
practical
manner
,
that
evidently
made
a
favourable
impression
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
speak
,
if
I
may
presume
to
say
so
,
as
one
who
has
some
little
experience
of
such

,
"
said
Traddles
,
"
being
myself
engaged
to
a
young
lady
---
one
of
ten
,
down
in
Devonshire
---
and
seeing
no
probability
,
at
present
,
of
our
engagement
coming
to

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
be
able
to
confirm
what
I

,
Mr
Traddles
,
<EOS>
"
observed
Miss
Lavinia
,
evidently

in
him
,
"
of
the
affection
that
is
modest
and
retiring
;
that
waits
and
waits
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Entirely
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Traddles
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Clarissa
looked
at
Miss
Lavinia
,
and
shook
her
head
gravely
.
<EOS>
Miss
Lavinia
looked
consciously
at
Miss
Clarissa
,
and
heaved
a
little
sigh
.
"
<EOS>
Sister
Lavinia
,
"
said
Miss
Clarissa
,
"
take
my
smelling
-
bottle
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Lavinia
revived
herself
with
a
few
whiffs
of
aromatic
vinegar
---
<EOS>
Traddles
and
I
looking
on
with
great
solicitude
the
while
;
and
then
went
on
to
say
,
rather
faintly
:
   
<EOS>
"
My
sister
and
myself
have
been
in
great
doubt
,
<EOS>
Mr
Traddles
,
what
course
we
ought
to
take
in
reference
to
the
likings
,
or
imaginary
likings
,
of
such
very
young
people
as
your
friend
Mr
Copperfield
and
our
niece
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Our
brother
Francis
's
child
,
"
remarked
Miss
Clarissa
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
our
brother
Francis
's
wife
had
found
it
convenient
in
her
lifetime
(
though
she
had
an
unquestionable
right
to
act
as
she
thought
best
)
to
invite
the
family
to
her
dinner
-
table
,
we
might
have
known
our
brother
Francis
's
child
better
at
the
present
moment
.
 
<EOS>
Sister
Lavinia
,
proceed
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Lavinia
turned
my
letter
,
so
as
to
bring
the
superscription
towards
herself
,
and
referred
through
her
eye
-
glass
to
some
orderly
-
looking
notes
she
had
made
on
that
part
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
seems
to
us
,
"
said
she
,
"
prudent
,
Mr
Traddles
,
to
bring
these
feelings
to
the
test
of
our
own
observation
.
 
<EOS>
At
present
we
know
nothing
of
them
,
and
are
not
in
a
situation
to
judge
how
much
reality
there
may
be
in
them
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
we
are
inclined
so
far
to
accede
to
Mr
Copperfield
's
proposal
,
as
to
admit
his
visits
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
never
,
dear

,
"
I
exclaimed
,
relieved
of
an
immense
load
of

,
"
forget
your
kindness
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
,
"
pursued
Miss
Lavinia
,
---
"
but
,
we
would
prefer
to
regard
those
visits
,
Mr
Traddles
,
as
made
,
at
present
,
to

.
 
<EOS>
We
must
guard

from
recognizing
any
positive
engagement
between
Mr
Copperfield
and
our
niece
,
until
we
have

an

---
"
   
"
Until
YOU
have
had
an
opportunity
,
sister
Lavinia
,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Be

,
"
assented
Miss
Lavinia
,
with

---
"
until
I
have
had
an

of
observing

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Copperfield
,
"
said
Traddles
,
turning
to
me
<EOS>
,
"
you
feel
,
I
am
sure
,
that
nothing
could
be
more
reasonable
or

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
!
"
<EOS>
cried
I.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
deeply
sensible
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
this
position
of
affairs
,
"
said
Miss
Lavinia
,
again
referring
to
her
notes
,
"
and
admitting
his
visits
on
this

only
,
we
must
require
from
Mr
Copperfield
a
distinct

,
on

of
honour
,
that
no
communication
of
any
kind
shall
take
place
between
him
and
our
niece
without
our
knowledge
.
 
<EOS>
That
no
project
whatever
shall
be
entertained
with
regard
to
our
niece
,
without
being
first
submitted
to
us
---
"
   
"
To
you
,
sister
Lavinia
,
"
Miss
Clarissa
interposed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Be
it
so
,
Clarissa
!
"
<EOS>
assented
Miss
Lavinia
resignedly
---
"
to
me
---
and
receiving
our
concurrence
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
make
this
a
most
express
and
serious
stipulation
,
not
to
be
broken
on
any
account
.
 
<EOS>
We
wished
Mr
Copperfield
to
be
accompanied
by
some
confidential
friend
today
,
"
with
an
inclination
of
her
head
towards
Traddles
,
who
bowed
,
"
in
order
that
there
might
be
no
doubt
or
misconception
on
this
subject
.
 
<EOS>
If
Mr
Copperfield
,
or
if
you
,
Mr
Traddles
,
feel
the
least
scruple
,
in
giving
this
promise
,
I
beg
you
to
take
time
to
consider
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
exclaimed
,
in
a
state
of
high
ecstatic
fervour
,
that
not
a
moment
's
consideration
could
be
necessary
.
 
<EOS>
I
bound
myself
by
the
required
promise
,
in
a
most
impassioned
manner
;
called
upon
Traddles
to
witness
it
;
and
denounced
myself
as
the
most
atrocious
of
characters
if
I
ever
swerved
from
it
in
the
least
degree
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
"
said
Miss
Lavinia
,
holding
up
her
hand
;
"
we
resolved
,
before
we
had
the
pleasure
of
receiving
you
two
gentlemen
,
to
leave
you
alone
for
a
quarter
of
an
hour
,
to
consider
this
point
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
allow
us
to
retire
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
for
me
to
say
that
no
consideration
was
necessary
.
<EOS>
They
persisted
in
withdrawing
for
the
specified
time
.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
these
little
birds
hopped
out
with
great
dignity
;
leaving
me
to
receive
the
congratulations
of
Traddles
,
and
to
feel
as
if
I
were
translated
to
regions
of
exquisite
happiness
.
 
<EOS>
Exactly
at
the
expiration
of
the
quarter
of
an
hour
,
they
reappeared
with
no
less
dignity
than
they
had
disappeared
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
gone
rustling
away
as
if
their
little
dresses
were
made
of
autumn
-
leaves
:
and
they
came
rustling
back
,
in
like
manner
.
   
<EOS>
I
then
bound
myself
once
more
to
the
prescribed
conditions
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sister
Clarissa
,
"
said
Miss
Lavinia
,
"
the
rest
is
with
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Clarissa
,
unfolding
her
arms
for
the
first
time
,
took
the
notes
and
glanced
at
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
shall
be
happy
,
"
said
Miss
Clarissa
,
"
to
see
Mr
Copperfield
to
dinner
,
every
Sunday
,
if
it
should
suit
his
convenience
.
 
<EOS>
Our
hour
is
three
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
bowed
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
course
of
the
week
,
"
said
Miss
Clarissa
,
"
we
shall
be
happy
to
see
Mr
Copperfield
to
tea
.
 
<EOS>
Our
hour
is
half
-
past
six
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
bowed
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Twice
in
the
week
,
"
said
Miss
Clarissa
,
"
but
,
as
a
rule
,
not
oftener
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
bowed
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Trotwood
,
"
said
Miss
Clarissa
,
"
mentioned
in
Mr
Copperfield
's
letter
,
will
perhaps
call
upon
us
.
 
<EOS>
When
visiting
is
better
for
the
happiness
of
all
parties
,
we
are
glad
to
receive
visits
,
and
return
them
.
 
<EOS>
When
it
is
better
for
the
happiness
of
all
parties
that
no
visiting
should
take
place
,
(
as
in
the
case
of
our
brother
Francis
,
and
his
establishment
)
that
is
quite
different
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
intimated
that
my
aunt
would
be
proud
and
delighted
to
make
their
acquaintance
;
though
I
must
say
I
was
not
quite
sure
of
their
getting
on
very
satisfactorily
together
.
 
<EOS>
The
conditions
being
now
closed
,
I
expressed
my
acknowledgements
in
the
warmest
manner
;
and
,
taking
the
hand
,
first
of
Miss
Clarissa
,
and
then
of
Miss
Lavinia
,
pressed
it
,
in
each
case
,
to
my
lips
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Lavinia
then
arose
,
and
begging
Mr
Traddles
to
excuse
us
for
a
minute
,
requested
me
to
follow
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
obeyed
,
all
in
a
tremble
,
and
was
conducted
into
another
room
.
 
<EOS>
There
I
found
my
blessed
darling
stopping
her
ears
behind
the
door
,
with
her
dear
little
face
against
the
wall
;
and
Jip
in
the
plate
-
warmer
with
his
head
tied
up
in
a
towel
.
   
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
How
beautiful
she
was
in
her
black
frock
,
and
how
she
sobbed
and
cried
at
first
,
and
would
n't
come
out
from
behind
the
door
!
<EOS>
How
fond
we
were
of
one
another
,
when
she
did
come
out
at
last
;
and
what
a
state
of
bliss
<EOS>
I
was
in
,
when
we
took
Jip
out
of
the
plate
-
warmer
,
and
restored
him
to
the
light
,
sneezing
very
much
,
and
were
all
three
reunited
!
   
<EOS>
"
My
dearest
Dora
!
 
<EOS>
Now
,
indeed
,
my
own
for
ever
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
DON'T
!
"
pleaded
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
Please
!
"
   
"
Are
you
not
my
own
for
ever
,
Dora
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
,
of
course
I
am
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Dora
,
"
but
I
am
so
frightened
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Frightened
,
my
own
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
like
him
,
"
said
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
do
n't
he
go
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
,
my
life
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
friend
,
"
said
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
n't
any
business
of
his
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
stupid
he
must
be
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
love
!
"
<EOS>
(
There
never
was
anything
so
coaxing
as
her
childish
ways
.
)
<EOS>
"
He
is
the
best
creature
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
but
we
do
n't
want
any
best
creatures
!
"
<EOS>
pouted
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
<EOS>
,
"
I
argued
,
"
you
will
soon
know
him
well
,
and
like
him
of
all
things
.
 
<EOS>
And
here
is
my
aunt
coming
soon
;
and
you
'll
like
her
of
all
things
too
,
when
you
know
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
please
do
n't
bring
her
!
"
<EOS>
said
Dora
,
giving
me
a
horrified
little
kiss
,
and
folding
her
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
<EOS>
she
's
a
naughty
,
mischief
-
making
old
thing
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
let
her
come
here
,
Doady
!
"
<EOS>
which
was
a
corruption
of
David
.
   
<EOS>
Remonstrance
was
of
no
use
,
then
;
so
I
laughed
,
and
admired
,
and
was
very
much
in
love
and
very
happy
;
and
she
showed
me
Jip
's
new
trick
of
standing
on
his
hind
legs
in
a
corner
---
which
he
did
for
about
the
space
of
a
flash
of
lightning
,
and
then
fell
down
---
<EOS>
and
I
do
n't
know
how
long
I
should
have
stayed
there
,
oblivious
of
Traddles
,
if
Miss
Lavinia
had
not
come
in
to
take
me
away
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Lavinia
was
very
fond
of
Dora
<EOS>
(
she
told
me
Dora
was
exactly
like
what
she
had
been
herself
at
her
age
---
she
must
have
altered
a
good
deal
)
,
and
she
treated
Dora
just
as
if
she
had
been
a
toy
.
 
<EOS>
I
wanted
to
persuade
Dora
to
come
and
see
Traddles
,
but
on
my
proposing
it
she
ran
off
to
her
own
room
and
locked
herself
in
;
so
I
went
to
Traddles
without
her
,
and
walked
away
with
him
on
air
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
could
be
more
satisfactory
,
"
said
Traddles
;
"
and
they
are
very
agreeable
old
ladies
,
I
am
sure
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
n't
be
at
all
surprised
if
you
were
to
be
married
years
before
me
,
Copperfield
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Does
your
Sophy
play
on
any
instrument
,
Traddles
?
<EOS>
"
I
inquired
,
in
the
pride
of
my
heart
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
knows
enough
of
the
piano
to
teach
it
to
her
little
sisters
,
"
said
Traddles
.
   
<EOS>
"
Does
she
sing
at
all
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
she
sings
ballads
,
sometimes
,
to
freshen
up
the
others
a
little
when
they
're
out
of
spirits
,
"
said
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
scientific
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
does
n't
sing
to
the
guitar
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
no
!
"
said
Traddles
.
   
<EOS>
"
Paint
at
all
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
,
"
said
Traddles
.
   
<EOS>
I
promised
Traddles
that
he
should
hear
Dora
sing
,
and
see
some
of
her
flower
-
painting
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
he
should
like
it
very
much
,
and
we
went
home
arm
in
arm
in
great
good
humour
and
delight
.
 
<EOS>
I
encouraged
him
to
talk
about
Sophy
,
on
the
way
;
which
he
did
with
a
loving
reliance
on
her
that
I
very
much
admired
.
 
<EOS>
I
compared
her
in
my
mind
with
Dora
,
with
considerable
inward
satisfaction
;
but
I
candidly
admitted
to
myself
that
she
seemed
to
be
an
excellent
kind
of
girl
for
Traddles
,
too
.
   
<EOS>
Of
course
my
aunt
was
immediately
made
acquainted
with
the
successful
issue
of
the
conference
,
and
with
all
that
had
been
said
and
done
in
the
course
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
happy
to
see
me
so
happy
,
and
promised
to
call
on
Dora
's
aunts
without
loss
of
time
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
took
such
a
long
walk
up
and
down
our
rooms
that
night
,
while
I
was
writing
to
Agnes
,
that
I
began
to
think
she
meant
to
walk
till
morning
.
   
<EOS>
My
letter
to
Agnes
was
a
fervent
and
grateful
one
,
narrating
all
the
good
effects
that
had
resulted
from
my
following
her
advice
.
<EOS>
She
wrote
,
by
return
of
post
,
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Her
letter
was
hopeful
,
earnest
,
and
cheerful
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
always
cheerful
from
that
time
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
my
hands
more
full
than
ever
,
now
.
 
<EOS>
My
daily
journeys
to
Highgate
considered
,
Putney
was
a
long
way
off
;
and
I
naturally
wanted
to
go
there
as
often
as
I
could
.
 
<EOS>
The
proposed
tea
-
drinkings
being
quite
impracticable
,
I
compounded
with
Miss
Lavinia
for
permission
to
visit
every
Saturday
afternoon
,
without
detriment
to
my
privileged
Sundays
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
the
close
of
every
week
was
a
delicious
time
for
me
;
and
I
got
through
the
rest
of
the
week
by
looking
forward
to
it
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
wonderfully
relieved
to
find
that
my
aunt
and
Dora
's
aunts
rubbed
on
,
<EOS>
all
things
considered
,
much
more
smoothly
than
I
could
have
expected
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
made
her
promised
visit
within
a
few
days
of
the
conference
;
and
within
a
few
more
days
,
Dora
's
aunts
called
upon
her
,
in
due
state
and
form
.
 
<EOS>
Similar
but
more
friendly
exchanges
took
place
afterwards
,
usually
at
intervals
of
three
or
four
weeks
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
that
my
aunt
distressed
Dora
's
aunts
very
much
,
by
utterly
setting
at
naught
the
dignity
of
fly
-
conveyance
,
and
walking
out
to
Putney
at
extraordinary
times
,
as
shortly
after
breakfast
or
just
before
tea
;
likewise
by
wearing
her
bonnet
in
any
manner
that
happened
to
be
comfortable
to
her
head
,
without
at
all
deferring
to
the
prejudices
of
civilization
on
that
subject
.
 
<EOS>
But
Dora
's
aunts
soon
agreed
to
regard
my
aunt
as
an
eccentric
and
somewhat
masculine
lady
,
with
a
strong
understanding
;
and
although
my
aunt
occasionally
ruffled
the
feathers
of
Dora
's
aunts
,
by
expressing
heretical
opinions
on
various
points
of
ceremony
,
she
loved
me
too
well
not
to
sacrifice
some
of
her
little
peculiarities
to
the
general
harmony
.
   
<EOS>
The
only
member
of
our
small
society
who
positively
refused
to
adapt
himself
to
circumstances
,
was
Jip
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
saw
my
aunt
without
immediately
displaying
every
tooth
in
his
head
,
retiring
under
a
chair
,
and
growling
incessantly
:
with
now
<EOS>
and
then
a
doleful
howl
,
as
if
she
really
were
too
much
for
his
feelings
.
 
<EOS>
All
kinds
of
treatment
were
tried
with
him
,
coaxing
,
scolding
,
slapping
,
bringing
him
to
Buckingham
Street
(
where
he
instantly
dashed
at
the
two
cats
,
to
the
terror
of
all
beholders
)
;
but
he
never
could
prevail
upon
himself
to
bear
my
aunt
's
society
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
sometimes
think
he
had
got
the
better
of
his
objection
,
and
be
amiable
for
a
few
minutes
;
and
then
would
put
up
his
snub
nose
,
and
howl
to
that
extent
,
that
there
was
nothing
for
it
but
to
blind
him
and
put
him
in
the
plate
-
warmer
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
Dora
regularly
muffled
him
in
a
towel
and
shut
him
up
there
,
whenever
my
aunt
was
reported
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
One
thing
troubled
me
much
,
after
we
had
fallen
into
this
quiet
train
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
,
that
Dora
seemed
by
one
consent
to
be
regarded
like
a
pretty
toy
or
plaything
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
with
whom
she
gradually
became
familiar
,
always
called
her
Little
Blossom
;
and
the
pleasure
of
Miss
Lavinia
's
life
was
to
wait
upon
her
,
curl
her
hair
,
make
ornaments
for
her
,
and
treat
her
like
a
pet
child
.
 
<EOS>
What
Miss
Lavinia
did
,
her
sister
did
as
a
matter
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
odd
to
me
;
but
they
all
seemed
to
treat
Dora
,
in
her
degree
,
much
as
Dora
treated
Jip
in
his
.
   
<EOS>
I
made
up
my
mind
to
speak
to
Dora
about
this
;
and
one
day
when
we
were
out
walking
<EOS>
(
for
we
were
licensed
by
Miss
Lavinia
,
after
a
while
,
to
go
out
walking
by
ourselves
)
,
I
said
to
her
that
I
wished
she
could
get
them
to
behave
towards
her
differently
.
   
<EOS>
"
Because
you
know
,
my
darling
,
"
I
remonstrated
,
"
you
are
not
a
child
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
said
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
you
're
going
to
be
cross
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cross
,
my
love
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
they
're
very
kind
to
me
,
"
said
Dora
,
"
and
I
am
very
happy
---
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
But
my
dearest
life
!
<EOS>
"
said
I
,
"
you
might
be
very
happy
,
and
yet
be
treated
rationally
.
"
   
<EOS>
Dora
gave
me
a
reproachful
look
---
<EOS>
the
prettiest
look
!
<EOS>
---
and
then
began
to
sob
,
saying
,
if
I
did
n't
like
her
,
why
had
I
ever
wanted
so
much
to
be
engaged
to
her
?
 
<EOS>
And
why
did
n't
I
go
away
,
now
,
if
I
could
n't
bear
her
?
   
<EOS>
What
could
I
do
,
but
kiss
away
her
tears
,
and
tell
her
how
I
doted
on
her
,
after
that
!
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
I
am
very
affectionate
,
"
said
Dora
;
"
you
ought
n't
to
be
cruel
to
me
,
Doady
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cruel
,
my
precious
love
!
 
<EOS>
As
if
I
would
---
or
could
---
be
cruel
to
you
,
for
the
world
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
do
n't
find
fault
with
me
,
"
said
Dora
,
making
a
rosebud
of
her
mouth
;
"
and
I
'll
be
good
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
charmed
by
her
presently
asking
me
,
of
her
own
accord
,
to
give
her
that
cookery
-
book
I
had
once
spoken
of
,
and
to
show
her
how
to
keep
accounts
as
I
had
once
promised
I
would
.
 
<EOS>
I
brought
the
volume
with
me
on
my
next
visit
<EOS>
(
I
got
it
prettily
bound
,
first
,
to
make
it
look
less
dry
and
more
inviting
)
;
and
as
we
strolled
about
the
Common
,
I
showed
her
an
old
housekeeping
-
book
of
my
aunt
's
,
and
gave
her
a
set
of
tablets
,
and
a
pretty
little
pencil
-
case
and
box
of
leads
,
to
practise
housekeeping
with
.
   
<EOS>
But
the
cookery
-
book
made
Dora
's
head
ache
,
and
the
figures
made
her
cry
.
 
<EOS>
They
would
n't
add
up
,
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
So
she
rubbed
them
out
,
and
drew
little
nosegays
and
likenesses
of
me
and
Jip
,
all
over
the
tablets
.
   
<EOS>
Then
I
playfully
tried
verbal
instruction
in
domestic
matters
,
as
we
walked
about
on
a
Saturday
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
for
example
,
when
we
passed
a
butcher
's
shop
,
I
would
say
:
   
"
<EOS>
Now
suppose
,
my
pet
,
that
we
were
married
,
and
you
were
going
to
buy
a
shoulder
of
mutton
for
dinner
,
would
you
know
how
to
buy
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
My
pretty
little
Dora
's
face
would
fall
,
and
she
would
make
her
mouth
into
a
bud
again
,
as
if
she
would
very
much
prefer
to
shut
mine
with
a
kiss
.
   
<EOS>
"
Would
you
know
how
to
buy
it
,
my
darling
?
<EOS>
"
I
would
repeat
,
perhaps
,
if
I
were
very
inflexible
.
   
<EOS>
Dora
would
think
a
little
,
and
then
reply
,
perhaps
,
with
great
triumph
:
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the
butcher
would
know
how
to
sell
it
,
and
what
need
I
know
?
<EOS>
Oh
,
you
silly
boy
!
"
   
<EOS>
So
,
when
I
once
asked
Dora
,
with
an
eye
to
the
cookery
-
book
,
what
she
would
do
,
if
we
were
married
,
and
I
were
to
say
I
should
like
a
nice
Irish
stew
,
she
replied
that
she
would
tell
the
servant
to
make
it
;
and
then
clapped
her
little
hands
together
across
my
arm
,
and
laughed
in
such
a
charming
manner
that
she
was
more
delightful
than
ever
.
   
<EOS>
Consequently
,
the
principal
use
to
which
the
cookery
-
book
was
devoted
,
was
being
put
down
in
the
corner
for
Jip
to
stand
upon
.
<EOS>
But
Dora
was
so
pleased
,
<EOS>
when
she
had
trained
him
to
stand
upon
it
without
offering
to
come
off
,
and
at
the
same
time
to
hold
the
pencil
-
case
in
his
mouth
,
that
I
was
very
glad
I
had
bought
it
.
   
<EOS>
And
we
fell
back
on
the
guitar
-
case
,
and
the
flower
-
painting
,
and
the
songs
about
never
leaving
off
dancing
,
<EOS>
Ta
ra
la
!
and
were
as
happy
as
the
week
was
long
.
 
<EOS>
I
occasionally
wished
I
could
venture
to
hint
to
Miss
Lavinia
,
that
she
treated
the
darling
of
my
heart
a
little
too
much
like
a
plaything
;
and
I
sometimes
awoke
,
as
it
were
,
wondering
to
find
that
I
had
fallen
into
the
general
fault
,
and
treated
her
like
a
plaything
too
---
but
not
often
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
42
.
<EOS>
Mischief
 
<EOS>
I
feel
as
if
it
were
not
for
me
to
record
,
even
though
this
manuscript
is
intended
for
no
eyes
but
mine
,
how
hard
I
worked
at
that
tremendous
short
-
hand
,
and
all
improvement
appertaining
to
it
,
in
my
sense
of
responsibility
to
Dora
and
her
aunts
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
only
add
,
to
what
I
have
already
written
of
my
perseverance
at
this
time
of
my
life
,
and
of
a
patient
and
continuous
energy
which
then
began
to
be
matured
within
me
,
and
which
I
know
to
be
the
strong
part
of
my
character
,
if
it
have
any
strength
at
all
,
that
there
,
on
looking
back
,
I
find
the
source
of
my
success
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
very
fortunate
in
worldly
matters
;
many
men
have
worked
much
harder
,
and
not
succeeded
half
so
well
;
but
I
never
could
have
done
what
I
have
done
,
without
the
habits
of
punctuality
,
order
,
and
diligence
,
without
the
determination
to
concentrate
myself
on
one
object
at
a
time
,
no
matter
how
quickly
its
successor
should
come
upon
its
heels
,
which
I
then
formed
.
 
<EOS>
Heaven
knows
I
write
this
,
in
no
spirit
of
self
-
laudation
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
who
reviews
his
own
life
,
as
I
do
mine
,
in
going
on
here
,
from
page
to
page
,
had
need
to
have
been
a
good
man
indeed
,
if
he
would
be
spared
the
sharp
consciousness
of
many
talents
neglected
,
many
opportunities
wasted
,
many
erratic
and
perverted
feelings
constantly
at
war
within
his
breast
,
and
defeating
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
hold
one
natural
gift
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
,
that
I
have
not
abused
.
 
<EOS>
My
meaning
simply
is
,
that
whatever
I
have
tried
to
do
in
life
,
I
have
tried
with
all
my
heart
to
do
well
;
that
whatever
I
have
devoted
myself
to
,
I
have
devoted
myself
to
completely
;
that
in
great
aims
and
in
small
,
I
have
always
been
thoroughly
in
earnest
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
never
believed
it
possible
that
any
natural
or
improved
ability
can
claim
immunity
from
the
companionship
of
the
steady
,
plain
,
hard
-
working
qualities
,
and
hope
to
gain
its
end
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
such
thing
as
such
fulfilment
on
this
earth
.
 
<EOS>
Some
happy
talent
,
and
some
fortunate
opportunity
,
may
form
the
two
sides
of
the
ladder
on
which
some
men
mount
,
but
the
rounds
of
that
ladder
must
be
made
of
stuff
to
stand
wear
and
tear
;
and
there
is
no
substitute
for
thorough
-
going
,
ardent
,
and
sincere
earnestness
.
 
<EOS>
Never
to
put
one
hand
to
anything
,
on
which
I
could
throw
my
whole
self
;
and
never
to
affect
depreciation
of
my
work
,
whatever
it
was
;
I
find
,
now
,
to
have
been
my
golden
rules
.
   
<EOS>
How
much
of
the
practice
I
have
just
reduced
to
precept
<EOS>
,
I
owe
to
Agnes
,
I
will
not
repeat
here
.
 
<EOS>
My
narrative
proceeds
to
Agnes
,
with
a
thankful
love
.
   
<EOS>
She
came
on
a
visit
of
a
fortnight
to
the
Doctor
's
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Wickfield
was
the
Doctor
's
old
friend
,
and
the
Doctor
wished
to
talk
with
him
,
and
do
him
good
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
been
matter
of
conversation
with
Agnes
when
she
was
last
in
town
,
and
this
visit
was
the
result
.
<EOS>
She
and
her
father
came
together
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
much
surprised
to
hear
from
her
that
she
had
engaged
to
find
a
lodging
in
the
neighbourhood
for
Mrs
Heep
,
whose
rheumatic
complaint
required
change
of
air
,
and
who
would
be
charmed
to
have
it
in
such
company
.
<EOS>
Neither
was
I
surprised
when
,
on
the
very
next
day
,
Uriah
,
like
a
dutiful
son
,
brought
his
worthy
mother
to
take
possession
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
said
he
,
as
he
forced
himself
upon
my
company
for
a
turn
in
the
Doctor
's
garden
,
"
where
a
person
loves
,
a
person
is
a
little
jealous
---
leastways
,
anxious
to
keep
an
eye
on
the
beloved
one
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
whom
are
you
jealous
,
now
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Thanks
to
you
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
he
returned
,
"
of
no
one
in
particular
just
at
present
---
no
male
person
,
at
least
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
that
you
are
jealous
of
a
female
person
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
gave
me
a
sidelong
glance
out
of
his
sinister
red
eyes
,
and
laughed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Really
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
he
said
,
"
---
I
should
say
Mister
,
but
I
know
you
'll
excuse
the
abit
I
've
got
into
---
you
're
so
insinuating
,
that
you
draw
me
like
a
corkscrew
!
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
do
n't
mind
telling
you
,
"
putting
his
fish
-
like
hand
on
mine
,
"
I
'm
not
a
lady
's
man
in
general
,
sir
,
and
I
never
was
,
with
Mrs
Strong
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
eyes
looked
green
now
,
as
they
watched
mine
with
a
rascally
cunning
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
though
I
am
a
lawyer
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
he
replied
,
with
a
dry
grin
,
"
I
mean
,
just
at
present
,
what
I
say
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
do
you
mean
by
your
look
?
<EOS>
"
I
retorted
,
quietly
.
   
<EOS>
"
By
my
look
?
 
<EOS>
Dear
me
,
Copperfield
,
that
's
sharp
practice
!
 
<EOS>
What
do
I
mean
by
my
look
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
By
your
look
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
seemed
very
much
amused
,
and
laughed
as
heartily
as
it
was
in
his
nature
to
laugh
.
 
<EOS>
After
some
scraping
of
his
chin
with
his
hand
,
he
went
on
to
say
,
with
his
eyes
cast
downward
---
still
scraping
,
very
slowly
:
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
was
but
an
umble
clerk
,
she
always
looked
down
upon
me
.
<EOS>
She
was
for
ever
having
my
Agnes
backwards
and
forwards
at
her
ouse
,
and
she
was
for
ever
being
a
friend
to
you
,
Master
Copperfield
;
but
I
was
too
far
beneath
her
,
myself
,
to
be
noticed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"
said
I
;
"
suppose
you
were
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
---
And
beneath
him
too
,
"
pursued
Uriah
,
very
distinctly
,
and
in
a
meditative
tone
of
voice
,
as
he
continued
to
scrape
his
chin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
know
the
Doctor
better
,
"
said
I
,
"
than
to
suppose
him
conscious
of
your
existence
,
when
you
were
not
before
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
directed
his
eyes
at
me
in
that
sidelong
glance
again
,
and
he
made
his
face
very
lantern
-
jawed
,
for
the
greater
convenience
of
scraping
,
as
he
answered
:
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
,
I
am
not
referring
to
the
Doctor
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
no
,
poor
man
!
 
<EOS>
I
mean
Mr
Maldon
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
My
heart
quite
died
within
me
.
 
<EOS>
All
my
old
doubts
and
apprehensions
on
that
subject
,
all
the
Doctor
's
happiness
and
peace
,
all
the
mingled
possibilities
of
innocence
and
compromise
,
that
I
could
not
unravel
,
I
saw
,
in
a
moment
,
at
the
mercy
of
this
fellow
's
twisting
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
never
could
come
into
the
office
,
without
ordering
and
shoving
me
about
,
"
said
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
"
One
of
your
fine
gentlemen
he
was
!
 
<EOS>
I
was
very
meek
and
umble
---
and
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
did
n't
like
that
sort
of
thing
---
<EOS>
and
I
do
n't
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
left
off
scraping
his
chin
,
and
sucked
in
his
cheeks
until
they
seemed
to
meet
inside
;
keeping
his
sidelong
glance
upon
me
all
the
while
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
one
of
your
lovely
women
,
she
is
,
"
he
pursued
,
when
he
had
slowly
restored
his
face
to
its
natural
form
;
"
and
ready
to
be
no
friend
to
such
as
me
,
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
She
's
just
the
person
as
would
put
my
Agnes
up
to
higher
sort
of
game
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
I
ai
n't
one
of
your
lady
's
men
,
Master
Copperfield
;
but
I
've
had
eyes
in
my
ed
,
a
pretty
long
time
back
.
 
<EOS>
We
umble
ones
have
got
eyes
,
mostly
speaking
---
and
we
look
out
of
'
em
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
endeavoured
to
appear
unconscious
and
not
disquieted
,
but
<EOS>
,
I
saw
in
his
face
,
with
poor
success
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I
'm
not
a
-
going
to
let
myself
be
run
down
,
Copperfield
,
"
he
continued
,
raising
that
part
of
his
countenance
,
where
his
red
eyebrows
would
have
been
if
he
had
had
any
,
with
malignant
triumph
,
"
and
I
shall
do
what
I
can
to
put
a
stop
to
this
friendship
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
approve
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mind
acknowledging
to
you
that
I
've
got
rather
a
grudging
disposition
,
and
want
to
keep
off
all
intruders
.
 
<EOS>
I
ai
n't
a
-
going
,
if
I
know
it
,
to
run
the
risk
of
being
plotted
against
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
always
plotting
,
and
delude
yourself
into
the
belief
that
everybody
else
is
doing
the
like
,
I
think
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Perhaps
so
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
he
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
've
got
a
motive
,
as
my
fellow
-
partner
used
to
say
;
and
I
go
at
it
tooth
and
nail
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
n't
be
put
upon
,
as
a
numble
person
,
too
much
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
allow
people
in
my
way
.
 
<EOS>
Really
they
must
come
out
of
the
cart
,
Master
Copperfield
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
understand
you
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
,
though
?
"
he
returned
,
with
one
of
his
jerks
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
astonished
at
that
,
Master
Copperfield
,
you
being
usually
so
quick
!
<EOS>
I
'll
try
to
be
plainer
,
another
time
.
 
<EOS>
---
Is
that
Mr
Maldon
a
-
norseback
,
ringing
at
the
gate
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
looks
like
him
,
"
I
replied
,
as
carelessly
as
I
could
.
   
<EOS>
Uriah
stopped
short
,
put
his
hands
between
his
great
knobs
of
knees
,
and
doubled
himself
up
with
laughter
.
 
<EOS>
With
perfectly
silent
laughter
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
sound
escaped
from
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
repelled
by
his
odious
behaviour
,
particularly
by
this
concluding
instance
,
that
I
turned
away
without
any
ceremony
;
and
left
him
doubled
up
in
the
middle
of
the
garden
,
like
a
scarecrow
in
want
of
support
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
not
on
that
evening
;
but
,
as
I
well
remember
,
on
the
next
evening
but
one
,
which
was
a
Sunday
;
that
I
took
Agnes
to
see
Dora
.
<EOS>
I
had
arranged
the
visit
,
beforehand
,
with
Miss
Lavinia
;
and
Agnes
was
expected
to
tea
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
in
a
flutter
of
pride
and
anxiety
;
pride
in
my
dear
little
betrothed
,
and
anxiety
that
Agnes
should
like
her
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
way
to
Putney
,
Agnes
being
inside
the
stage
-
coach
,
and
I
outside
,
I
pictured
Dora
to
myself
in
every
one
of
the
pretty
looks
I
knew
so
well
;
now
making
up
my
mind
that
I
should
like
her
to
look
exactly
as
she
looked
at
such
a
time
,
and
then
doubting
whether
I
should
not
prefer
her
looking
as
she
looked
at
such
another
time
;
and
almost
worrying
myself
into
a
fever
about
it
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
troubled
by
no
doubt
of
her
being
very
pretty
,
in
any
case
;
but
it
fell
out
that
I
had
never
seen
her
look
so
well
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
not
in
the
drawing
-
room
when
I
presented
Agnes
to
her
little
aunts
,
but
was
shyly
keeping
out
of
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
where
to
look
for
her
,
now
;
and
sure
enough
I
found
her
stopping
her
ears
again
,
behind
the
same
dull
old
door
.
   
<EOS>
At
first
she
would
n't
come
at
all
;
and
then
she
pleaded
for
five
minutes
by
my
watch
.
 
<EOS>
When
at
length
she
put
her
arm
through
mine
,
to
be
taken
to
the
drawing
-
room
,
her
charming
little
face
was
flushed
,
and
had
never
been
so
pretty
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
when
we
went
into
the
room
,
and
it
turned
pale
,
she
was
ten
thousand
times
prettier
yet
.
   
<EOS>
Dora
was
afraid
of
Agnes
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
told
me
that
she
knew
Agnes
was
"
too
clever
"
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
she
saw
her
looking
at
once
so
cheerful
and
so
earnest
,
and
so
thoughtful
,
and
so
good
,
she
gave
a
faint
little
cry
of
pleased
surprise
,
and
just
put
her
affectionate
arms
round
Agnes
's
neck
,
and
laid
her
innocent
cheek
against
her
face
.
   
<EOS>
I
never
was
so
happy
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
was
so
pleased
as
when
I
saw
those
two
sit
down
together
,
side
by
side
.
 
<EOS>
As
when
I
saw
my
little
darling
looking
up
so
naturally
to
those
cordial
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
As
when
I
saw
the
tender
,
beautiful
regard
which
Agnes
cast
upon
her
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Lavinia
and
Miss
Clarissa
partook
,
in
their
way
,
of
my
joy
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
pleasantest
tea
-
table
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Clarissa
presided
.
 
<EOS>
I
cut
and
handed
the
sweet
seed
-
cake
---
the
little
sisters
had
a
bird
-
like
fondness
for
picking
up
seeds
and
pecking
at
sugar
;
Miss
Lavinia
looked
on
with
benignant
patronage
,
as
if
our
happy
love
were
all
her
work
;
and
we
were
perfectly
contented
with
ourselves
and
one
another
.
   
<EOS>
The
gentle
cheerfulness
of
Agnes
went
to
all
their
hearts
.
 
<EOS>
Her
quiet
interest
in
everything
that
interested
Dora
;
her
manner
of
making
acquaintance
with
Jip
(
who
responded
instantly
)
;
her
pleasant
way
,
when
Dora
was
ashamed
to
come
over
to
her
usual
seat
by
me
;
her
modest
grace
and
ease
,
eliciting
a
crowd
of
blushing
little
marks
of
confidence
from
Dora
;
seemed
to
make
our
circle
quite
complete
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
glad
,
"
said
Dora
,
after
tea
,
"
that
you
like
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
n't
think
you
would
;
and
I
want
,
more
than
ever
,
to
be
liked
,
now
Julia
Mills
is
gone
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
have
omitted
to
mention
it
,
by
the
by
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Mills
had
sailed
,
and
Dora
and
I
had
gone
aboard
a
great
East
Indiaman
at
Gravesend
to
see
her
;
and
we
had
had
preserved
ginger
,
and
guava
,
and
other
delicacies
of
that
sort
for
lunch
;
and
we
had
left
Miss
Mills
weeping
on
a
camp
-
stool
on
the
quarter
-
deck
,
with
a
large
new
diary
under
her
arm
,
in
which
the
original
reflections
awakened
by
the
contemplation
of
Ocean
were
to
be
recorded
under
lock
and
key
.
   
<EOS>
Agnes
said
she
was
afraid
I
must
have
given
her
an
unpromising
character
;
but
Dora
corrected
that
directly
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
no
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
shaking
her
curls
at
me
;
"
it
was
all
praise
.
 
<EOS>
He
thinks
so
much
of
your
opinion
,
that
I
was
quite
afraid
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
good
opinion
can
not
strengthen
his
attachment
to
some
people
whom
he
knows
,
"
said
Agnes
,
with
a
smile
;
"
it
is
not
worth
their
having
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
please
let
me
have
it
,
"
said
Dora
,
in
her
coaxing
way
,
"
if
you
can
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
made
merry
about
Dora
's
wanting
to
be
liked
,
and
Dora
said
I
was
a
goose
,
and
she
did
n't
like
me
at
any
rate
,
and
the
short
evening
flew
away
on
gossamer
-
wings
.
 
<EOS>
The
time
was
at
hand
when
the
coach
was
to
call
for
us
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
standing
alone
before
the
fire
,
when
Dora
came
stealing
softly
in
,
to
give
me
that
usual
precious
little
kiss
before
I
went
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
think
,
if
I
had
had
her
for
a
friend
a
long
time
ago
,
Doady
,
"
said
Dora
,
her
bright
eyes
shining
very
brightly
,
and
her
little
right
hand
idly
busying
itself
with
one
of
the
buttons
of
my
coat
,
<EOS>
"
I
might
have
been
more
clever
perhaps
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
love
!
<EOS>
"
said
I
,
"
what
nonsense
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
it
is
nonsense
?
"
returned
Dora
,
without
looking
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
sure
it
is
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
am
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
forgotten
,
"
said
Dora
,
still
turning
the
button
round
and
round
,
"
what
relation
Agnes
is
to
you
,
<EOS>
you
dear
bad
boy
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
blood
-
relation
,
"
I
replied
;
"
but
we
were
brought
up
together
,
like
brother
and
sister
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
why
you
ever
fell
in
love
with
me
?
"
said
Dora
,
beginning
on
another
button
of
my
coat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
because
I
could
n't
see
you
,
and
not
love
you
,
Dora
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Suppose
you
had
never
seen
me
at
all
,
"
said
Dora
,
going
to
another
button
.
   
<EOS>
"
Suppose
we
had
never
been
born
!
"
<EOS>
said
I
,
gaily
.
   
<EOS>
I
wondered
what
she
was
thinking
about
,
as
I
glanced
in
admiring
silence
at
the
little
soft
hand
travelling
up
the
row
of
buttons
on
my
coat
,
and
at
the
clustering
hair
that
lay
against
my
breast
,
and
at
the
lashes
of
her
downcast
eyes
,
slightly
rising
as
they
followed
her
idle
fingers
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
her
eyes
were
lifted
up
to
mine
,
and
she
stood
on
tiptoe
to
give
me
,
more
thoughtfully
than
usual
,
that
precious
little
kiss
---
once
,
twice
,
three
times
---
and
went
out
of
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
They
all
came
back
together
within
five
minutes
afterwards
,
and
Dora
's
unusual
thoughtfulness
was
quite
gone
then
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
laughingly
resolved
to
put
Jip
through
the
whole
of
his
performances
,
before
the
coach
came
.
 
<EOS>
They
took
some
time
(
not
so
much
on
account
of
their
variety
,
as
Jip
's
reluctance
)
,
and
were
still
unfinished
when
it
was
heard
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
hurried
but
affectionate
parting
between
Agnes
and
herself
;
and
Dora
was
to
write
to
Agnes
(
who
was
not
to
mind
her
letters
being
foolish
,
she
said
)
,
and
Agnes
was
to
write
to
Dora
;
and
they
had
a
second
parting
at
the
coach
door
,
and
a
third
when
Dora
,
in
spite
of
the
remonstrances
of
Miss
Lavinia
,
would
come
running
out
once
more
to
remind
Agnes
at
the
coach
window
about
writing
,
and
to
shake
her
curls
at
me
on
the
box
.
   
<EOS>
The
stage
-
coach
was
to
put
us
down
near
Covent
Garden
,
where
we
were
to
take
another
stage
-
coach
for
Highgate
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
impatient
for
the
short
walk
in
the
interval
,
that
Agnes
might
praise
Dora
to
me
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
what
praise
it
was
!
 
<EOS>
How
lovingly
and
fervently
did
it
commend
the
pretty
creature
I
had
won
,
with
all
her
artless
graces
best
displayed
,
to
my
most
gentle
care
!
 
<EOS>
How
thoughtfully
remind
me
,
yet
with
no
pretence
of
doing
so
,
of
the
trust
in
which
I
held
the
orphan
child
!
   
<EOS>
Never
,
never
,
had
I
loved
Dora
so
deeply
and
truly
,
as
I
loved
her
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
had
again
alighted
,
and
were
walking
in
the
starlight
along
the
quiet
road
that
led
to
the
Doctor
's
house
,
I
told
Agnes
it
was
her
doing
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
you
were
sitting
by
her
,
"
said
I
,
"
you
seemed
to
be
no
less
her
guardian
angel
than
mine
;
and
you
seem
so
now
,
Agnes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
poor
angel
,
"
she
returned
,
"
but
faithful
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
clear
tone
of
her
voice
,
going
straight
to
my
heart
,
made
it
natural
to
me
to
say
:
   
"
<EOS>
The
cheerfulness
that
belongs
to
you
,
Agnes
(
<EOS>
and
to
no
one
else
that
ever
I
have
seen
)
,
is
so
restored
,
I
have
observed
today
,
that
I
have
begun
to
hope
you
are
happier
at
home
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
happier
in
myself
,
"
she
said
;
"
I
am
quite
cheerful
and
light
-
hearted
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
glanced
at
the
serene
face
looking
upward
,
and
thought
it
was
the
stars
that
made
it
seem
so
noble
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
has
been
no
change
at
home
,
"
said
Agnes
,
after
a
few
moments
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
fresh
reference
,
"
said
I
,
"
<EOS>
to
---
<EOS>
I
would
n't
distress
you
,
Agnes
,
but
I
can
not
help
asking
---
to
what
we
spoke
of
,
when
we
parted
last
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
none
,
"
she
answered
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
thought
so
much
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
think
less
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
Remember
that
I
confide
in
simple
love
and
truth
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
Have
no
apprehensions
for
me
,
Trotwood
<EOS>
,
"
she
added
,
after
a
moment
;
"
the
step
you
dread
my
taking
,
I
shall
never
take
.
"
   
<EOS>
Although
I
think
I
had
never
really
feared
it
,
in
any
season
of
cool
reflection
,
it
was
an
unspeakable
relief
to
me
to
have
this
assurance
from
her
own
truthful
lips
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
her
so
,
earnestly
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
when
this
visit
is
over
,
"
said
I
,
---
<EOS>
"
for
we
may
not
be
alone
another
time
,
---
<EOS>
how
long
is
it
likely
to
be
,
my
dear
Agnes
,
before
you
come
to
London
again
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Probably
a
long
time
,
"
she
replied
;
"
I
think
it
will
be
best
---
for
papa
's
sake
---
to
remain
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
not
likely
to
meet
often
,
for
some
time
to
come
;
but
I
shall
be
a
good
correspondent
of
Dora
's
,
and
we
shall
frequently
hear
of
one
another
that
way
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
We
were
now
within
the
little
courtyard
of
the
Doctor
's
cottage
.
<EOS>
It
was
growing
late
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
light
in
the
window
of
Mrs
Strong
's
chamber
,
and
Agnes
,
pointing
to
it
,
bade
me
good
night
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
not
be
troubled
,
"
she
said
,
giving
me
her
hand
,
"
by
our
misfortunes
and
anxieties
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
be
happier
in
nothing
than
in
your
happiness
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
can
ever
give
me
help
,
rely
upon
it
I
will
ask
you
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
God
bless
you
always
!
"
<EOS>
In
her
beaming
smile
,
and
in
these
last
tones
of
her
cheerful
voice
,
I
seemed
again
to
see
and
hear
my
little
Dora
in
her
company
.
 
<EOS>
I
stood
awhile
,
looking
through
the
porch
at
the
stars
,
with
a
heart
full
of
love
and
gratitude
,
and
then
walked
slowly
forth
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
engaged
a
bed
at
a
decent
alehouse
close
by
,
and
was
going
out
at
the
gate
,
when
,
happening
to
turn
my
head
,
I
saw
a
light
in
the
Doctor
's
study
.
 
<EOS>
A
half
-
reproachful
fancy
came
into
my
mind
,
that
he
had
been
working
at
the
Dictionary
without
my
help
.
<EOS>
With
the
view
of
seeing
if
this
were
so
,
and
,
in
any
case
,
of
bidding
him
good
night
,
if
he
were
yet
sitting
among
his
books
,
I
turned
back
,
and
going
softly
across
the
hall
,
and
gently
opening
the
door
,
looked
in
.
   
<EOS>
The
first
person
whom
I
saw
,
to
my
surprise
,
by
the
sober
light
of
the
shaded
lamp
,
was
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
standing
close
beside
it
,
with
one
of
his
skeleton
hands
over
his
mouth
,
and
the
other
resting
on
the
Doctor
's
table
.
 
<EOS>
The
Doctor
sat
in
his
study
chair
,
covering
his
face
with
his
hands
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Wickfield
,
sorely
troubled
and
distressed
,
was
leaning
forward
,
irresolutely
touching
the
Doctor
's
arm
.
   
<EOS>
For
an
instant
,
I
supposed
that
the
Doctor
was
ill
.
 
<EOS>
I
hastily
advanced
a
step
under
that
impression
,
when
I
met
Uriah
's
eye
,
and
saw
what
was
the
matter
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
have
withdrawn
,
but
the
Doctor
made
a
gesture
to
detain
me
,
and
I
remained
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
,
"
observed
Uriah
,
with
a
writhe
of
his
ungainly
person
,
"
we
may
keep
the
door
shut
.
 
<EOS>
We
need
n't
make
it
known
to
ALL
the
town
.
"
   
<EOS>
Saying
which
,
he
went
on
his
toes
to
the
door
,
which
I
had
left
open
,
and
carefully
closed
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
came
back
,
and
took
up
his
former
position
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
obtrusive
show
of
compassionate

in

and

,
more
intolerable
---
at
least

---
than
any

could

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
felt

incumbent

me
,
Master
Copperfield
,
"
said

,
"
to
point
out
to
Doctor
Strong
what
you
and

already
talked
about
.
 
<EOS>
You
did
n't
exactly
understand
me
,
though
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
gave
him
a

,
but
no

;
and
,

to
my
good
old
master
,
said

that
I

comfort

.
 
<EOS>
He
put
his

upon
my

,
as

had

his
custom
to
do
when
I
was
quite
a
little

,
but
did

.
   
<EOS>
"
As
you
did

,
Master
Copperfield
,
"

in

,
"
I

of

,

,
that

Doctor
Strong
's

to
the
goings

on
of
Mrs
Strong
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
much
against
the
grain
with
me
<EOS>
,
I

,
Copperfield
,
to

but
really
,

.
 
<EOS>
That

my

,
sir
,
when

did

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

I

,
that
I

,
and

<EOS>
"
I
dare

I
did

,
"
he

"

.
 
<EOS>
Naturally
,
we

.
 
<EOS>
Hows'ever
,

;
and

Doctor
Strong
that
---
did

speak
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
This

to

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

might
have
touched
any

,
I

,
but

's
.
   
"
---

Doctor
Strong
,
"
he

"
that

Mr
Maldon
,

Strong
's

,

.
 
<EOS>
Really

(
we

)

<EOS>

<EOS>
Come

,

!
 
<EOS>
Would

?
 
<EOS>
Yes
<EOS>

,

?
 
<EOS>
Come
,

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There

"

<EOS>
"
What

:
ai

?
 
<EOS>
Him
!
 
<EOS>
Such

!
 
<EOS>
Bless

,

,
Copperfield
<EOS>
,

,

(

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"

"
my

<EOS>
,

one

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
Wickfield
,
"

<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Speak

"

I

<EOS>
"
I
---

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

No

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
To

<EOS>
Nothing

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
But

---

---

"

That

"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
---

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
For

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
How

!
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Always

"

"

;

---
<EOS>
"
   
"
No
!
 
<EOS>
There

,

"

,
"

"

"
---

"

"

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
And

"

,

"
   
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
Mr

held

<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

that
Copperfield
has

.
"
   
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
it
's

,

,
"

,

"

<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
Do

!
 
<EOS>
You

;
but

,
Copperfield
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

of

good

Doctor
turned
upon
me
for

,
and
I

.
<EOS>
It
was
of
no

.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
undo
that
.
 
<EOS>
Say
what
I

,
I
could

.
   
<EOS>
We
were

again
,
and
remained

,
until

Doctor

and

.
 
<EOS>
Presently

returned
to
where
his

;
and
,

<EOS>
"
I
have
been
much

.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
have

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
exposed
one
whom
I
hold
in

,

<EOS>
---
I
call

,
even

have

conceived

's

---
of
which
she
never
,
but

me
,
could
have
been

.
"
   
<EOS>
Uriah
Heep
gave
a
kind

.
 
<EOS>
I
think
to
express
sympathy
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
which
my
Annie
,
"
said
the
Doctor
,
"
never
,
but
for
me
,

.
 
<EOS>
Gentlemen
,

,

;
I
do
not

,
tonight
,
that

.
 
<EOS>
But

---
my

---
upon

of
the
dear

who
has

!
"
   
<EOS>
I
do
not

that
the
best

of

,
the

of
the
handsomest
and

ever

,

,

Doctor

.
   
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
not

,
"
he

,
"
to

---
<EOS>
perhaps
I
may
have
been
,
without

,
in
some

prepared

---
that
I
may
have
unwittingly

that
lady
into
an
unhappy

.
<EOS>
I
am
a
man
quite
unaccustomed
to
observe
;
and
I
can
not
but

that
the

of
several

,

,
all
too
plainly

one

(
and

so
natural
)
,
is
better
than
mine
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
had
often
admired
,
as
I
have
elsewhere
described
,
his
benignant

towards
his
youthful
wife
;
but
the

he
manifested
in
every

on
