in
which
he
put
away
from
him
the
lightest
doubt
of
her
integrity
,
exalted
him
,
in
my
eyes
,
beyond
description
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
married
that
lady
,
"
said
the
Doctor
,
"
when
she
was
extremely
young
.
 
<EOS>
I
took
her
to
myself
when
her
character
was
scarcely
formed
.
 
<EOS>
So
far
as
it
was
developed
,
it
had
been
my
happiness
to
form
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
her
father
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
her
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
taught
her
what
I
could
,
for
the
love
of
all
her
beautiful
and
virtuous
qualities
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
did
her
wrong
;
as
I
fear
I
did
,
in
taking
advantage
(
but
I
never
meant
it
)
of
her
gratitude
and
her
affection
;
I
ask
pardon
of
that
lady
,
in
my
heart
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
walked
across
the
room
,
and
came
back
to
the
same
place
;
holding
the
chair
with
a
grasp
that
trembled
,
like
his
subdued
voice
,
in
its
earnestness
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
regarded
myself
as
a
refuge
,
for
her
,
from
the
dangers
and
vicissitudes
of
life
.
 
<EOS>
I
persuaded
myself
that
,
unequal
though
we
were
in
years
,
she
would
live
tranquilly
and
contentedly
with
me
.
<EOS>
I
did
not
shut
out
of
my
consideration
the
time
when
I
should
leave
her
free
,
and
still
young
and
still
beautiful
,
but
with
her
judgement
more
matured
---
no
,
gentlemen
---
upon
my
truth
!
"
   
<EOS>
His
homely
figure
seemed
to
be
lightened
up
by
his
fidelity
and
generosity
.
 
<EOS>
Every
word
he
uttered
had
a
force
that
no
other
grace
could
have
imparted
to
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
life
with
this
lady
has
been
very
happy
.
 
<EOS>
Until
tonight
,
I
have
had
uninterrupted
occasion
to
bless
the
day
on
which
I
did
her
great
injustice
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
voice
,
more
and
more
faltering
in
the
utterance
of
these
words
,
stopped
for
a
few
moments
;
then
he
went
on
:
   
"
<EOS>
Once
awakened
from
my
dream
---
I
have
been
a
poor
dreamer
,
in
one
way
or
other
,
all
my
life
<EOS>
---
I
see
how
natural
it
is
that
she
should
have
some
regretful
feeling
towards
her
old
companion
and
her
equal
.
 
<EOS>
That
she
does
regard
him
with
some
innocent
regret
,
with
some
blameless
thoughts
of
what
might
have
been
,
but
for
me
,
is
,
I
fear
,
too
true
.
 
<EOS>
Much
that
I
have
seen
,
but
not
noted
,
has
come
back
upon
me
with
new
meaning
,
during
this
last
trying
hour
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
beyond
this
,
gentlemen
,
the
dear
lady
's
name
never
must
be
coupled
with
a
word
,
a
breath
,
of
doubt
.
"
   
<EOS>
For
a
little
while
,
his
eye
kindled
and
his
voice
was
firm
;
for
a
little
while
he
was
again
silent
.
 
<EOS>
Presently
,
he
proceeded
as
before
:
   
<EOS>
"
It
only
remains
for
me
,
to
bear
the
knowledge
of
the
unhappiness
I
have
occasioned
,
as
submissively
as
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
she
who
should
reproach
;
not
I.
 
<EOS>
To
save
her
from
misconstruction
,
cruel
misconstruction
,
that
even
my
friends
have
not
been
able
to
avoid
,
becomes
my
duty
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
retired
we
live
,
the
better
I
shall
discharge
it
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
the
time
comes
---
may
it
come
soon
,
if
it
be
His
merciful
pleasure
!
<EOS>
---
when
my
death
shall
release
her
from
constraint
,
I
shall
close
my
eyes
upon
her
honoured
face
,
with
unbounded
confidence
and
love
;
and
leave
her
,
with
no
sorrow
then
,
to
happier
and
brighter
days
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
not
see
him
for
the
tears
which
his
earnestness
and
goodness
,
so
adorned
by
,
and
so
adorning
,
the
perfect
simplicity
of
his
manner
,
brought
into
my
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
moved
to
the
door
,
when
he
added
:
   
"
<EOS>
Gentlemen
,
I
have
shown
you
my
heart
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
you
will
respect
it
.
 
<EOS>
What
we
have
said
tonight
is
never
to
be
said
more
.
<EOS>
Wickfield
,
give
me
an
old
friend
's
arm
upstairs
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Wickfield
hastened
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Without
interchanging
a
word
they
went
slowly
out
of
the
room
together
,
Uriah
looking
after
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Master
Copperfield
!
<EOS>
"
said
Uriah
,
meekly
turning
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
thing
has
n't
took
quite
the
turn
that
might
have
been
expected
,
for
the
old
Scholar
---
what
an
excellent
man
!
<EOS>
---
is
as
blind
as
a
brickbat
;
but
this
family
's
out
of
the
cart
,
I
think
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
needed
but
the
sound
of
his
voice
to
be
so
madly
enraged
as
I
never
was
before
,
and
never
have
been
since
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
villain
,
"
said
I
,
"
what
do
you
mean
by
entrapping
me
into
your
schemes
?
 
<EOS>
How
dare
you
appeal
to
me
just
now
,
you
false
rascal
,
as
if
we
had
been
in
discussion
together
?
"
   
<EOS>
As
we
stood
,
front
to
front
,
I
saw
so
plainly
,
in
the
stealthy
exultation
of
his
face
,
what
I
already
so
plainly
knew
;
I
mean
that
he
forced
his
confidence
upon
me
,
expressly
to
make
me
miserable
,
and
had
set
a
deliberate
trap
for
me
in
this
very
matter
;
that
I
could
n't
bear
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
whole
of
his
lank
cheek
was
invitingly
before
me
,
and
I
struck
it
with
my
open
hand
with
that
force
that
my
fingers
tingled
as
if
I
had
burnt
them
.
   
<EOS>
He
caught
the
hand
in
his
,
and
we
stood
in
that
connexion
,
looking
at
each
other
.
 
<EOS>
We
stood
so
,
a
long
time
;
long
enough
for
me
to
see
the
white
marks
of
my
fingers
die
out
of
the
deep
red
of
his
cheek
,
and
leave
it
a
deeper
red
.
   
<EOS>
"
Copperfield
,
"
he
said
at
length
,
in
a
breathless
voice
,
"
<EOS>
have
you
taken
leave
of
your
senses
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
taken
leave
of
you
,
"
said
I
,
wresting
my
hand
away
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
dog
,
I
'll
know
no
more
of
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
you
?
"
said
he
,
constrained
by
the
pain
of
his
cheek
to
put
his
hand
there
.
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
wo
n't
be
able
to
help
it
.
 
<EOS>
Is
n't
this
ungrateful
of
you
,
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
shown
you
often
enough
,
"
said
I
,
"
that
I
despise
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
shown
you
now
,
more
plainly
,
that
I
do
.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
I
dread
your
doing
your
worst
to
all
about
you
?
 
<EOS>
What
else
do
you
ever
do
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
perfectly
understood
this
allusion
to
the
considerations
that
had
hitherto
restrained
me
in
my
communications
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
rather
think
that
neither
the
blow
,
nor
the
allusion
,
would
have
escaped
me
,
but
for
the
assurance
I
had
had
from
Agnes
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
no
matter
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
another
long
pause
.
 
<EOS>
His
eyes
,
as
he
looked
at
me
,
seemed
to
take
every
shade
of
colour
that
could
make
eyes
ugly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Copperfield
,
"
he
said
,
removing
his
hand
from
his
cheek
,
"
you
have
always
gone
against
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
you
always
used
to
be
against
me
at
Mr
Wickfield
's
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
think
what
you
like
,
"
said
I
,
still
in
a
towering
rage
.
<EOS>
"
If
it
is
not
true
,
so
much
the
worthier
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
yet
I
always
liked
you
,
Copperfield
!
"
<EOS>
he
rejoined
.
   
<EOS>
I
deigned
to
make
him
no
reply
;
and
,
taking
up
my
hat
,
was
going
out
to
bed
,
when
he
came
between
me
and
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Copperfield
,
"
he
said
,
"
there
must
be
two
parties
to
a
quarrel
.
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
be
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
go
to
the
devil
!
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
say
that
!
"
<EOS>
he
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
you
'll
be
sorry
afterwards
.
<EOS>
How
can
you
make
yourself
so
inferior
to
me
,
as
to
show
such
a
bad
spirit
?
 
<EOS>
But
I
forgive
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
forgive
me
!
"
<EOS>
I
repeated
disdainfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
and
you
ca
n't
help
yourself
,
"
replied
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
think
of
your
going
and
attacking
me
,
that
have
always
been
a
friend
to
you
!
<EOS>
But
there
ca
n't
be
a
quarrel
without
two
parties
,
and
I
wo
n't
be
one
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
be
a
friend
to
you
,
in
spite
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
So
now
you
know
what
you
've
got
to
expect
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
necessity
of
carrying
on
this
dialogue
(
his
part
in
which
was
very
slow
;
mine
very
quick
)
in
a
low
tone
,
that
the
house
might
not
be
disturbed
at
an
unseasonable
hour
,
did
not
improve
my
temper
;
though
my
passion
was
cooling
down
.
 
<EOS>
Merely
telling
him
that
I
should
expect
from
him
what
I
always
had
expected
,
and
had
never
yet
been
disappointed
in
,
I
opened
the
door
upon
him
,
as
if
he
had
been
a
great
walnut
put
there
to
be
cracked
,
and
went
out
of
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
slept
out
of
the
house
too
,
at
his
mother
's
lodging
;
and
before
I
had
gone
many
hundred
yards
,
came
up
with
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
,
Copperfield
,
"
he
said
,
in
my
ear
(
I
did
not
turn
my
head
)
,
"
you
're
in
quite
a
wrong
position
"
;
which
I
felt
to
be
true
,
and
that
made
me
chafe
the
more
;
"
you
ca
n't
make
this
a
brave
thing
,
and
you
ca
n't
help
being
forgiven
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
intend
to
mention
it
to
mother
,
nor
to
any
living
soul
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
determined
to
forgive
you
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
do
wonder
that
you
should
lift
your
hand
against
a
person
that
you
knew
to
be
so
umble
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
only
less
mean
than
he
.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
me
better
than
I
knew
myself
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
had
retorted
or
openly
exasperated
me
,
it
would
have
been
a
relief
and
a
justification
;
but
he
had
put
me
on
a
slow
fire
,
on
which
I
lay
tormented
half
the
night
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
morning
,
when
I
came
out
,
the
early
church
-
bell
was
ringing
,
and
he
was
walking
up
and
down
with
his
mother
.
 
<EOS>
He
addressed
me
as
if
nothing
had
happened
,
and
I
could
do
no
less
than
reply
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
struck
him
hard
enough
to
give
him
the
toothache
,
I
suppose
.
 
<EOS>
At
all
events
his
face
was
tied
up
in
a
black
silk
handkerchief
,
which
,
with
his
hat
perched
on
the
top
of
it
,
was
far
from
improving
his
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
that
he
went
to
a
dentist
's
in
London
on
the
Monday
morning
,
and
had
a
tooth
out
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
it
was
a
double
one
.
   
<EOS>
The
Doctor
gave
out
that
he
was
not
quite
well
;
and
remained
alone
,
for
a
considerable
part
of
every
day
,
during
the
remainder
of
the
visit
.
 
<EOS>
Agnes
and
her
father
had
been
gone
a
week
,
before
we
resumed
our
usual
work
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
day
preceding
its
resumption
,
the
Doctor
gave
me
with
his
own
hands
a
folded
note
not
sealed
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
addressed
to
myself
;
and
laid
an
injunction
on
me
,
in
a
few
affectionate
words
,
never
to
refer
to
the
subject
of
that
evening
.
<EOS>
I
had
confided
it
to
my
aunt
,
but
to
no
one
else
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
subject
I
could
discuss
with
Agnes
,
and
Agnes
certainly
had
not
the
least
suspicion
of
what
had
passed
.
   
<EOS>
Neither
,
I
felt
convinced
,
had
Mrs
Strong
then
.
 
<EOS>
Several
weeks
elapsed
before
I
saw
the
least
change
in
her
.
 
<EOS>
It
came
on
slowly
,
like
a
cloud
when
there
is
no
wind
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
,
she
seemed
to
wonder
at
the
gentle
compassion
with
which
the
Doctor
spoke
to
her
,
and
at
his
wish
that
she
should
have
her
mother
with
her
,
to
relieve
the
dull
monotony
of
her
life
.
 
<EOS>
Often
,
when
we
were
at
work
,
and
she
was
sitting
by
,
I
would
see
her
pausing
and
looking
at
him
with
that
memorable
face
.
 
<EOS>
Afterwards
,
I
sometimes
observed
her
rise
,
with
her
eyes
full
of
tears
,
and
go
out
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Gradually
,
an
unhappy
shadow
fell
upon
her
beauty
,
and
deepened
every
day
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Markleham
was
a
regular
inmate
of
the
cottage
then
;
but
she
talked
and
talked
,
and
saw
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
As
this
change
stole
on
Annie
,
once
like
sunshine
in
the
Doctor
's
house
,
the
Doctor
became
older
in
appearance
,
and
more
grave
;
but
the
sweetness
of
his
temper
,
the
placid
kindness
of
his
manner
,
and
his
benevolent
solicitude
for
her
,
if
they
were
capable
of
any
increase
,
were
increased
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
him
once
,
early
on
the
morning
of
her
birthday
,
when
she
came
to
sit
in
the
window
while
we
were
at
work
(
which
she
had
always
done
,
but
now
began
to
do
with
a
timid
and
uncertain
air
that
I
thought
very
touching
)
,
take
her
forehead
between
his
hands
,
kiss
it
,
and
go
hurriedly
away
,
too
much
moved
to
remain
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
her
stand
where
he
had
left
her
,
like
a
statue
;
and
then
bend
down
her
head
,
and
clasp
her
hands
,
and
weep
,
I
can
not
say
how
sorrowfully
.
   
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
after
that
,
I
fancied
that
she
tried
to
speak
even
to
me
,
in
intervals
when
we
were
left
alone
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
never
uttered
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
The
Doctor
always
had
some
new
project
for
her
participating
in
amusements
away
from
home
,
with
her
mother
;
and
Mrs
Markleham
,
who
was
very
fond
of
amusements
,
and
very
easily
dissatisfied
with
anything
else
,
entered
into
them
with
great
good
-
will
,
and
was
loud
in
her
commendations
.
 
<EOS>
But
Annie
,
in
a
spiritless
unhappy
way
,
only
went
whither
she
was
led
,
and
seemed
to
have
no
care
for
anything
.
   
<EOS>
I
did
not
know
what
to
think
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
did
my
aunt
;
who
must
have
walked
,
at
various
times
,
a
hundred
miles
in
her
uncertainty
.
 
<EOS>
What
was
strangest
of
all
was
,
that
the
only
real
relief
which
seemed
to
make
its
way
into
the
secret
region
of
this
domestic
unhappiness
,
made
its
way
there
in
the
person
of
Mr
Dick
.
   
<EOS>
What
his
thoughts
were
on
the
subject
,
or
what
his
observation
was
,
I
am
as
unable
to
explain
,
as
I
dare
say
he
would
have
been
to
assist
me
in
the
task
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
I
have
recorded
in
the
narrative
of
my
school
days
,
his
veneration
for
the
Doctor
was
unbounded
;
and
there
is
a
subtlety
of
perception
in
real
attachment
,
even
when
it
is
borne
towards
man
by
one
of
the
lower
animals
,
which
leaves
the
highest
intellect
behind
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
mind
of
the
heart
,
if
I
may
call
it
so
,
in
Mr
Dick
,
some
bright
ray
of
the
truth
shot
straight
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
proudly
resumed
his
privilege
,
in
many
of
his
spare
hours
,
of
walking
up
and
down
the
garden
with
the
Doctor
;
as
he
had
been
accustomed
to
pace
up
and
down
The
Doctor
's
Walk
at
Canterbury
.
<EOS>
But
matters
were
no
sooner
in
this
state
,
than
he
devoted
all
his
spare
time
(
and
got
up
earlier
to
make
it
more
)
to
these
perambulations
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
had
never
been
so
happy
as
when
the
Doctor
read
that
marvellous
performance
,
the
Dictionary
,
to
him
;
he
was
now
quite
miserable
unless
the
Doctor
pulled
it
out
of
his
pocket
,
and
began
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
Doctor
and
I
were
engaged
,
he
now
fell
into
the
custom
of
walking
up
and
down
with
Mrs
Strong
,
and
helping
her
to
trim
her
favourite
flowers
,
or
weed
the
beds
.
 
<EOS>
I
dare
say
he
rarely
spoke
a
dozen
words
in
an
hour
:
but
his
quiet
interest
,
and
his
wistful
face
,
found
immediate
response
in
both
their
breasts
<EOS>
;
each
knew
that
the
other
liked
him
,
and
that
he
loved
both
;
and
he
became
what
no
one
else
could
be
---
a
link
between
them
.
   
<EOS>
When
I
think
of
him
,
with
his
impenetrably
wise
face
,
walking
up
and
down
with
the
Doctor
,
delighted
to
be
battered
by
the
hard
words
in
the
Dictionary
;
when
I
think
of
him
carrying
huge
watering
-
pots
after
Annie
;
kneeling
down
,
in
very
paws
of
gloves
,
at
patient
microscopic
work
among
the
little
leaves
;
expressing
as
no
philosopher
could
have
expressed
,
in
everything
he
did
,
a
delicate
desire
to
be
her
friend
;
showering
sympathy
,
trustfulness
,
and
affection
,
out
of
every
hole
in
the
watering
-
pot
;
when
I
think
of
him
never
wandering
in
that
better
mind
of
his
to
which
unhappiness
addressed
itself
,
never
bringing
the
unfortunate
King
Charles
into
the
garden
,
never
wavering
in
his
grateful
service
,
never
diverted
from
his
knowledge
that
there
was
something
wrong
,
or
from
his
wish
to
set
it
right
<EOS>
---
I
really
feel
almost
ashamed
of
having
known
that
he
was
not
quite
in
his
wits
,
taking
account
of
the
utmost
I
have
done
with
mine
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nobody
but
myself
,
Trot
,
knows
what
that
man
is
!
"
<EOS>
my
aunt
would
proudly
remark
,
when
we
conversed
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dick
will
distinguish
himself
yet
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
must
refer
to
one
other
topic
before
I
close
this
chapter
.
 
<EOS>
While
the
visit
at
the
Doctor
's
was
still
in
progress
,
I
observed
that
the
postman
brought
two
or
three
letters
every
morning
for
Uriah
Heep
,
who
remained
at
Highgate
until
the
rest
went
back
,
it
being
a
leisure
time
;
and
that
these
were
always
directed
in
a
business
-
like
manner
by
Mr
Micawber
,
who
now
assumed
a
round
legal
hand
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
glad
to
infer
,
from
these
slight
premises
,
that
Mr
Micawber
was
doing
well
;
and
consequently
was
much
surprised
to
receive
,
about
this
time
,
the
following
letter
from
his
amiable
wife
:
---
    
"
CANTERBURY
,
Monday
Evening
.
<EOS>
"
    
<EOS>
"
You
will
doubtless
be
surprised
,
my
dear
Mr
Copperfield
,
to
receive
this
communication
.
 
<EOS>
Still
more
so
,
by
its
contents
.
 
<EOS>
Still
more
so
,
by
the
stipulation
of
implicit
confidence
which
I
beg
to
impose
.
 
<EOS>
But
my
feelings
as
a
wife
and
mother
require
relief
;
and
<EOS>
as
I
do
not
wish
to
consult
my
family
(
already
obnoxious
to
the
feelings
of
Mr
Micawber
)
,
I
know
no
one
of
whom
I
can
better
ask
advice
than
my
friend
and
former
lodger
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
be
aware
,
my
dear
Mr
Copperfield
,
that
between
myself
and
Mr
Micawber
(
whom
I
will
never
desert
)
,
there
has
always
been
preserved
a
spirit
of
mutual
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
may
have
occasionally
given
a
bill
without
consulting
me
,
or
he
may
have
misled
me
as
to
the
period
when
that
obligation
would
become
due
.
<EOS>
This
has
actually
happened
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
in
general
,
Mr
Micawber
has
had
no
secrets
from
the
bosom
of
affection
<EOS>
---
I
allude
to
his
wife
---
and
has
invariably
,
on
our
retirement
to
rest
,
recalled
the
events
of
the
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
You
will
picture
to
yourself
,
my
dear
Mr
Copperfield
,
what
the
poignancy
of
my
feelings
must
be
,
when
I
inform
you
that
Mr
Micawber
is
entirely
changed
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
reserved
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
secret
.
 
<EOS>
His
life
is
a
mystery
to
the
partner
of
his
joys
and
sorrows
---
I
again
allude
to
his
wife
---
and
if
I
should
assure
you
that
beyond
knowing
that
it
is
passed
from
morning
to
night
at
the
office
,
I
now
know
less
of
it
than
I
do
of
the
man
in
the
south
,
connected
with
whose
mouth
the
thoughtless
children
repeat
an
idle
tale
respecting
cold
plum
porridge
,
I
should
adopt
a
popular
fallacy
to
express
an
actual
fact
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
this
is
not
all
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
is
morose
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
severe
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
estranged
from
our
eldest
son
and
daughter
,
he
has
no
pride
in
his
twins
,
he
looks
with
an
eye
of
coldness
even
on
the
unoffending
stranger
who
last
became
a
member
of
our
circle
.
 
<EOS>
The
pecuniary
means
of
meeting
our
expenses
,
kept
down
to
the
utmost
farthing
,
are
obtained
from
him
with
great
difficulty
,
and
even
under
fearful
threats
that
he
will
Settle
himself
(
the
exact
expression
)
;
and
he
inexorably
refuses
to
give
any
explanation
whatever
of
this
distracting
policy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
hard
to
bear
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
heart
-
breaking
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
will
advise
me
,
knowing
my
feeble
powers
such
as
they
are
,
how
you
think
it
will
be
best
to
exert
them
in
a
dilemma
so
unwonted
,
you
will
add
another
friendly
obligation
to
the
many
you
have
already
rendered
me
.
 
<EOS>
With
loves
from
the
children
,
and
a
smile
from
the
happily
-
unconscious
stranger
,
I
remain
,
<EOS>
dear
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
 
"
Your
afflicted
,
"
"
EMMA
MICAWBER
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
did
not
feel
justified
in
giving
a
wife
of
Mrs
Micawber
's
experience
any
other
recommendation
,
than
that
she
should
try
to
reclaim
Mr
Micawber
by
patience
and
kindness
(
as
I
knew
she
would
in
any
case
)
;
but
the
letter
set
me
thinking
about
him
very
much
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
43
.
<EOS>
Another
retrospect
 
Once
again
,
let
me
pause
upon
a
memorable
period
of
my
life
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
stand
aside
,
to
see
the
phantoms
of
those
days
go
by
me
,
accompanying
the
shadow
of
myself
,
in
dim
procession
.
   
<EOS>
Weeks
,
months
,
seasons
,
pass
along
.
 
<EOS>
They
seem
little
more
than
a
summer
day
and
a
winter
evening
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
the
Common
where
I
walk
with
Dora
is
all
in
bloom
,
a
field
of
bright
gold
;
and
now
the
unseen
heather
lies
in
mounds
and
bunches
underneath
a
covering
of
snow
.
<EOS>
In
a
breath
,
the
river
that
flows
through
our
Sunday
walks
is
sparkling
in
the
summer
sun
,
is
ruffled
by
the
winter
wind
,
or
thickened
with
drifting
heaps
of
ice
.
 
<EOS>
Faster
than
ever
river
ran
towards
the
sea
,
it
flashes
,
darkens
,
and
rolls
away
.
   
<EOS>
Not
a
thread
changes
,
in
the
house
of
the
two
little
bird
-
like
ladies
.
 
<EOS>
The
clock
ticks
over
the
fireplace
,
the
weather
-
glass
hangs
in
the
hall
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
clock
nor
weather
-
glass
is
ever
right
;
but
we
believe
in
both
,
devoutly
.
   
<EOS>
I
have
come
legally
to
man
's
estate
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
attained
the
dignity
of
twenty
-
one
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
is
a
sort
of
dignity
that
may
be
thrust
upon
one
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
think
what
I
have
achieved
.
   
<EOS>
I
have
tamed
that
savage
stenographic
mystery
.
 
<EOS>
I
make
a
respectable
income
by
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
in
high
repute
for
my
accomplishment
in
all
<EOS>
pertaining
to
the
art
,
and
am
joined
with
eleven
others
in
reporting
the
debates
in
Parliament
for
a
Morning
Newspaper
.
 
<EOS>
Night
after
night
,
I
record
predictions
that
never
come
to
pass
,
professions
that
are
never
fulfilled
,
explanations
that
are
only
meant
to
mystify
.
 
<EOS>
I
wallow
in
words
.
 
<EOS>
Britannia
,
that
unfortunate
female
,
is
always
before
me
,
like
a
trussed
fowl
:
skewered
through
and
through
with
office
-
pens
,
and
bound
hand
and
foot
with
red
tape
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sufficiently
behind
the
scenes
to
know
the
worth
of
political
life
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
quite
an
Infidel
about
it
,
and
shall
never
be
converted
.
   
<EOS>
My
dear
old
Traddles
has
tried
his
hand
at
the
same
pursuit
,
but
it
is
not
in
Traddles
's
way
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
perfectly
good
-
humoured
respecting
his
failure
,
and
reminds
me
that
he
always
did
consider
himself
slow
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
occasional
employment
on
the
same
newspaper
,
in
getting
up
the
facts
of
dry
subjects
,
to
be
written
about
and
embellished
by
more
fertile
minds
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
called
to
the
bar
;
and
with
admirable
industry
and
self
-
denial
has
scraped
another
hundred
pounds
together
,
to
fee
a
Conveyancer
whose
chambers
he
attends
.
<EOS>
A
great
deal
of
very
hot
port
wine
was
consumed
at
his
call
;
and
,
considering
the
figure
,
I
should
think
the
Inner
Temple
must
have
made
a
profit
by
it
.
   
<EOS>
I
have
come
out
in
another
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
taken
with
fear
and
trembling
to
authorship
.
 
<EOS>
I
wrote
a
little
something
,
in
secret
,
and
sent
it
to
a
magazine
,
and
it
was
published
in
the
magazine
.
<EOS>
Since
then
,
I
have
taken
heart
to
write
a
good
many
trifling
pieces
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
I
am
regularly
paid
for
them
.
 
<EOS>
Altogether
,
I
am
well
off
,
when
I
tell
my
income
on
the
fingers
of
my
left
hand
,
I
pass
the
third
finger
and
take
in
the
fourth
to
the
middle
joint
.
   
<EOS>
We
have
removed
,
from
Buckingham
Street
,
to
a
pleasant
little
cottage
very
near
the
one
I
looked
at
,
when
my
enthusiasm
first
came
on
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
however
(
who
has
sold
the
house
at
Dover
,
to
good
advantage
)
,
is
not
going
to
remain
here
,
but
intends
removing
herself
to
a
still
more
tiny
cottage
close
at
hand
.
 
<EOS>
What
does
this
portend
?
 
<EOS>
My
marriage
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
!
   
<EOS>
Yes
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
to
be
married
to
Dora
!
 
<EOS>
Miss
Lavinia
and
Miss
Clarissa
have
given
their
consent
;
and
if
ever
canary
birds
were
in
a
flutter
,
they
are
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Lavinia
,
self
-
charged
with
the
superintendence
of
my
darling
's
wardrobe
,
is
constantly
cutting
out
brown
-
paper
cuirasses
,
and
differing
in
opinion
from
a
highly
respectable
young
man
,
with
a
long
bundle
,
and
a
yard
measure
under
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
A
dressmaker
,
always
stabbed
in
the
breast
with
a
needle
and
thread
,
boards
and
lodges
in
the
house
;
and
seems
to
me
,
eating
,
drinking
,
or
sleeping
,
never
to
take
her
thimble
off
.
 
<EOS>
They
make
a
lay
-
figure
of
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
always
sending
for
her
to
come
and
try
something
on
.
 
<EOS>
We
ca
n't
be
happy
together
for
five
minutes
in
the
evening
,
but
some
intrusive
female
knocks
at
the
door
,
and
says
,
"
Oh
,
if
you
please
,
Miss
Dora
,
would
you
step
upstairs
!
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Clarissa
and
my
aunt
roam
all
over
London
,
to
find
out
articles
of
furniture
for
Dora
and
me
to
look
at
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
better
for
them
to
buy
the
goods
at
once
,
without
this
ceremony
of
inspection
;
for
,
when
we
go
to
see
a
kitchen
fender
and
meat
-
screen
,
Dora
sees
a
Chinese
house
for
Jip
,
with
little
bells
on
the
top
,
and
prefers
that
.
 
<EOS>
And
it
takes
a
long
time
to
accustom
Jip
to
his
new
residence
,
after
we
have
bought
it
;
whenever
he
goes
in
or
out
,
he
makes
all
the
little
bells
ring
,
and
is
horribly
frightened
.
   
<EOS>
Peggotty
comes
up
to
make
herself
useful
,
and
falls
to
work
immediately
.
 
<EOS>
Her
department
appears
to
be
,
to
clean
everything
over
and
over
again
.
 
<EOS>
She
rubs
everything
that
can
be
rubbed
,
until
it
shines
,
like
her
own
honest
forehead
,
with
perpetual
friction
.
<EOS>
And
now
it
is
,
that
I
begin
to
see
her
solitary
brother
passing
through
the
dark
streets
at
night
,
and
looking
,
as
he
goes
,
among
the
wandering
faces
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
speak
to
him
at
such
an
hour
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
too
well
,
as
his
grave
figure
passes
onward
,
what
he
seeks
,
and
what
he
dreads
.
   
<EOS>
Why
does
Traddles
look
so
important
when
he
calls
upon
me
this
afternoon
in
the
Commons
---
where
I
still
occasionally
attend
,
for
form
's
sake
,
when
I
have
time
?
 
<EOS>
The
realization
of
my
boyish
day
-
dreams
is
at
hand
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
to
take
out
the
licence
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
a
little
document
to
do
so
much
;
and
Traddles
contemplates
it
,
as
it
lies
upon
my
desk
,
half
in
admiration
,
half
in
awe
.
<EOS>
There
are
the
names
,
in
the
sweet
old
visionary
connexion
,
David
Copperfield
and
Dora
Spenlow
;
and
there
,
in
the
corner
,
is
that
Parental
Institution
,
the
Stamp
Office
,
which
is
so
benignantly
interested
in
the
various
transactions
of
human
life
,
looking
down
upon
our
Union
;
and
there
is
the
Archbishop
of
Canterbury
invoking
a
blessing
on
us
in
print
,
and
doing
it
as
cheap
as
could
possibly
be
expected
.
   
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
I
am
in
a
dream
,
a
flustered
,
happy
,
hurried
dream
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
believe
that
it
is
going
to
be
;
and
yet
I
ca
n't
believe
but
that
everyone
I
pass
in
the
street
,
must
have
some
kind
of
perception
,
that
I
am
to
be
married
the
day
after
tomorrow
.
 
<EOS>
The
Surrogate
knows
me
,
when
I
go
down
to
be
sworn
;
and
disposes
of
me
easily
,
as
if
there
were
a
Masonic
understanding
between
us
.
<EOS>
Traddles
is
not
at
all
wanted
,
but
is
in
attendance
as
my
general
backer
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
the
next
time
you
come
here
,
my
dear
fellow
,
"
I
say
to
Traddles
,
"
it
will
be
on
the
same
errand
for
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
hope
it
will
be
soon
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
for
your
good
wishes
,
my
dear
Copperfield
,
"
he
replies
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
so
too
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
satisfaction
to
know
that
she
'll
wait
for
me
any
length
of
time
,
and
that
she
really
is
the
dearest
girl
---
"
   
"
When
are
you
to
meet
her
at
the
coach
?
"
I
ask
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
seven
,
"
says
Traddles
,
looking
at
his
plain
old
silver
watch
---
<EOS>
the
very
watch
he
once
took
a
wheel
out
of
,
at
school
,
to
make
a
water
-
mill
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
about
Miss
Wickfield
's
time
,
is
it
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
little
earlier
.
 
<EOS>
Her
time
is
half
past
eight
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
assure
you
,
my
dear
boy
,
"
says
Traddles
,
"
I
am
almost
as
pleased
as
if
I
were
going
to
be
married
myself
,
to
think
that
this
event
is
coming
to
such
a
happy
termination
.
 
<EOS>
And
really
the
great
friendship
and
consideration
of
personally
associating
Sophy
with
the
joyful
occasion
,
and
inviting
her
to
be
a
bridesmaid
in
conjunction
with
Miss
Wickfield
,
demands
my
warmest
thanks
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
extremely
sensible
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
hear
him
,
and
shake
hands
with
him
;
and
we
talk
,
and
walk
,
and
dine
,
and
so
on
;
<EOS>
but
I
do
n't
believe
it
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
is
real
.
   
<EOS>
Sophy
arrives
at
the
house
of
Dora
's
aunts
,
in
due
course
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
the
most
agreeable
of
faces
,
---
not
absolutely
beautiful
,
but
extraordinarily
pleasant
,
---
and
is
one
of
the
most
genial
,
unaffected
,
frank
,
engaging
creatures
I
have
ever
seen
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
presents
her
to
us
with
great
pride
;
and
rubs
his
hands
for
ten
minutes
by
the
clock
,
with
every
individual
hair
upon
his
head
standing
on
tiptoe
,
when
I
congratulate
him
in
a
corner
on
his
choice
.
   
<EOS>
I
have
brought
Agnes
from
the
Canterbury
coach
,
and
her
cheerful
and
beautiful
face
is
among
us
for
the
second
time
.
 
<EOS>
Agnes
has
a
great
liking
for
Traddles
,
and
it
is
capital
to
see
them
meet
,
and
to
observe
the
glory
of
Traddles
as
he
commends
the
dearest
girl
in
the
world
to
her
acquaintance
.
   
<EOS>
Still
I
do
n't
believe
it
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
a
delightful
evening
,
and
are
supremely
happy
;
but
I
do
n't
believe
it
yet
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
collect
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
check
off
my
happiness
as
it
takes
place
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
in
a
misty
and
unsettled
kind
of
state
;
as
if
I
had
got
up
very
early
in
the
morning
a
week
or
two
ago
,
and
had
never
been
to
bed
since
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
make
out
when
yesterday
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
seem
to
have
been
carrying
the
licence
about
,
in
my
pocket
,
many
months
.
   
<EOS>
Next
day
,
too
,
when
we
all
go
in
a
flock
to
see
the
house
---
our
house
---
Dora
's
and
mine
---
I
am
quite
unable
to
regard
myself
as
its
master
.
 
<EOS>
I
seem
to
be
there
,
by
permission
of
somebody
else
.
 
<EOS>
I
half
expect
the
real
master
to
come
home
presently
,
and
say
he
is
glad
to
see
me
.
 
<EOS>
Such
a
beautiful
little
house
as
it
is
,
with
everything
so
bright
and
new
;
with
the
flowers
on
the
carpets
looking
as
if
freshly
gathered
,
and
the
green
leaves
on
the
paper
as
if
they
had
just
come
out
;
with
the
spotless
muslin
curtains
,
and
<EOS>
the
blushing
rose
-
coloured
furniture
,
and
Dora
's
garden
hat
with
the
blue
ribbon
<EOS>
---
do
I
remember
,
now
,
how
I
loved
her
in
such
another
hat
when
I
first
knew
her
!
---
already
hanging
on
its
little
peg
;
the
guitar
-
case
quite
at
home
on
its
heels
in
a
corner
;
and
everybody
tumbling
over
Jip
's
pagoda
,
which
is
much
too
big
for
the
establishment
.
 
<EOS>
Another
happy
evening
,
quite
as
unreal
as
all
the
rest
of
it
,
and
I
steal
into
the
usual
room
before
going
away
.
<EOS>
Dora
is
not
there
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
they
have
not
done
trying
on
yet
.
<EOS>
Miss
Lavinia
peeps
in
,
and
tells
me
mysteriously
that
she
will
not
be
long
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
rather
long
,
notwithstanding
;
but
by
and
by
I
hear
a
rustling
at
the
door
,
and
someone
taps
.
   
<EOS>
I
say
,
"
Come
in
!
"
<EOS>
but
someone
taps
again
.
   
<EOS>
I
go
to
the
door
,
wondering
who
it
is
;
there
,
I
meet
a
pair
of
bright
eyes
,
and
a
blushing
face
;
they
are
Dora
's
eyes
and
face
,
and
Miss
Lavinia
has
dressed
her
in
tomorrow
's
dress
,
bonnet
and
all
,
for
me
to
see
.
 
<EOS>
I
take
my
little
wife
to
my
heart
;
and
Miss
Lavinia
gives
a
little
scream
because
I
tumble
the
bonnet
,
and
Dora
laughs
and
cries
at
once
,
because
I
am
so
pleased
;
and
I
believe
it
less
than
ever
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
it
pretty
,
Doady
?
"
says
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
Pretty
!
 
<EOS>
I
should
rather
think
I
did
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
are
you
sure
you
like
me
very
much
?
"
says
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
The
topic
is
fraught
with
such
danger
to
the
bonnet
,
that
Miss
Lavinia
gives
another
little
scream
,
and
begs
me
to
understand
that
Dora
is
only
to
be
looked
at
,
and
on
no
account
to
be
touched
.
 
<EOS>
So
Dora
stands
in
a
delightful
state
of
confusion
for
a
minute
or
two
,
to
be
admired
;
and
then
takes
off
her
bonnet
---
looking
so
natural
without
it
!
<EOS>
---
and
runs
away
with
it
in
her
hand
;
and
comes
dancing
down
again
in
her
own
familiar
dress
,
and
asks
Jip
if
I
have
got
a
beautiful
little
wife
,
and
whether
he
'll
forgive
her
for
being
married
,
and
kneels
down
to
make
him
stand
upon
the
cookery
-
book
,
for
the
last
time
in
her
single
life
.
   
<EOS>
I
go
home
,
more
incredulous
than
ever
,
to
a
lodging
that
I
have
hard
by
;
and
get
up
very
early
in
the
morning
,
to
ride
to
the
Highgate
road
and
fetch
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
I
have
never
seen
my
aunt
in
such
state
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
dressed
in
lavender
-
coloured
silk
,
and
has
a
white
bonnet
on
,
and
is
amazing
.
<EOS>
Janet
has
dressed
her
,
and
is
there
to
look
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
Peggotty
is
ready
to
go
to
church
,
intending
to
behold
the
ceremony
from
the
gallery
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
,
who
is
to
give
my
darling
to
me
at
the
altar
,
has
had
his
hair
curled
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
,
whom
I
have
taken
up
by
appointment
at
the
turnpike
,
presents
a
dazzling
combination
of
cream
colour
and
light
blue
;
and
both
he
and
Mr
Dick
have
a
general
effect
about
them
of
being
all
gloves
.
   
<EOS>
No
doubt
I
see
this
,
because
I
know
it
is
so
;
but
I
am
astray
,
and
seem
to
see
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
do
I
believe
anything
<EOS>
whatever
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
as
we
drive
along
in
an
open
carriage
,
this
fairy
marriage
is
real
enough
to
fill
me
with
a
sort
of
wondering
pity
for
the
unfortunate
people
who
have
no
part
in
it
,
but
are
sweeping
out
the
shops
,
and
going
to
their
daily
occupations
.
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
sits
with
my
hand
in
hers
all
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
stop
a
little
way
short
of
the
church
,
to
put
down
Peggotty
,
whom
we
have
brought
on
the
box
,
she
gives
it
a
squeeze
,
and
me
a
kiss
.
   
<EOS>
"
God
bless
you
,
Trot
!
 
<EOS>
My
own
boy
never
could
be
dearer
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
of
poor
dear
Baby
this
morning
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
do
I.
 
<EOS>
And
of
all
I
owe
to
you
,
dear
aunt
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Tut
,
child
!
"
says
my
aunt
;
and
gives
her
hand
in
overflowing
cordiality
to
Traddles
,
who
then
gives
his
to
Mr
Dick
,
who
then
gives
his
to
me
,
who
then
gives
mine
to
Traddles
,
and
then
we
come
to
the
church
door
.
   
<EOS>
The
church
is
calm
enough
,
I
am
sure
;
but
it
might
be
a
steam
-
power
loom
in
full
action
,
for
any
sedative
effect
it
has
on
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
too
far
gone
for
that
.
   
<EOS>
The
rest
is
all
a
more
or
less
incoherent
dream
.
   
<EOS>
A
dream
of
their
coming
in
with
Dora
;
of
the
pew
-
opener
arranging
us
,
like
a
drill
-
sergeant
,
before
the
altar
rails
;
of
my
wondering
,
even
then
,
why
pew
-
openers
must
always
be
the
most
disagreeable
females
procurable
,
and
whether
there
is
any
religious
dread
of
a
disastrous
infection
of
good
-
humour
which
renders
it
indispensable
to
set
those
vessels
of
vinegar
upon
the
road
to
Heaven
.
   
<EOS>
Of
the
clergyman
and
clerk
appearing
;
of
a
few
boatmen
and
some
other
people
strolling
in
;
of
an
ancient
mariner
behind
me
,
strongly
flavouring
the
church
with
rum
;
of
the
service
beginning
in
a
deep
voice
,
and
our
all
being
very
attentive
.
   
<EOS>
Of
Miss
Lavinia
,
who
acts
as
a
semi
-
auxiliary
<EOS>
bridesmaid
,
being
the
first
to
cry
,
and
of
her
doing
homage
(
<EOS>
as
I
take
it
)
to
the
memory
of
Pidger
,
in
sobs
;
of
Miss
Clarissa
applying
a
smelling
-
bottle
;
of
Agnes
taking
care
of
Dora
;
of
my
aunt
endeavouring
to
represent
herself
as
a
model
of
sternness
,
with
tears
rolling
down
her
face
;
of
little
Dora
trembling
very
much
,
and
making
her
responses
in
faint
whispers
.
   
<EOS>
Of
our
kneeling
down
together
,
side
by
side
;
of
Dora
's
trembling
less
and
less
,
but
always
clasping
Agnes
by
the
hand
;
of
the
service
being
got
through
,
quietly
and
gravely
;
of
our
all
looking
at
each
other
in
an
April
state
of
smiles
and
tears
,
when
it
is
over
;
of
my
young
wife
being
hysterical
in
the
vestry
,
and
crying
for
her
poor
papa
,
her
dear
papa
.
   
<EOS>
Of
her
soon
cheering
up
again
,
and
our
signing
the
register
all
round
.
 
<EOS>
Of
my
going
into
the
gallery
for
Peggotty
to
bring
her
to
sign
it
;
of
Peggotty
's
hugging
me
in
a
corner
,
and
telling
me
she
saw
my
own
dear
mother
married
;
of
its
being
over
,
and
our
going
away
.
   
<EOS>
Of
my
walking
so
proudly
and
lovingly
down
the
aisle
with
my
sweet
wife
upon
my
arm
,
through
a
mist
of
half
-
seen
people
,
pulpits
,
monuments
,
pews
,
fonts
,
organs
,
and
church
windows
,
in
which
there
flutter
faint
airs
of
association
with
my
childish
church
at
home
,
so
long
ago
.
   
<EOS>
Of
their
whispering
,
as
we
pass
,
what
a
youthful
couple
we
are
,
and
what
a
pretty
little
wife
she
is
.
 
<EOS>
Of
our
all
being
so
merry
and
talkative
in
the
carriage
going
back
.
 
<EOS>
Of
Sophy
telling
us
that
when
she
saw
Traddles
(
whom
I
had
entrusted
with
the
licence
)
asked
for
it
,
she
almost
fainted
,
having
been
convinced
that
he
would
contrive
to
lose
it
,
or
to
have
his
pocket
picked
.
 
<EOS>
Of
Agnes
<EOS>
laughing
gaily
;
and
of
Dora
being
so
fond
of
Agnes
that
she
will
not
be
separated
from
her
,
but
still
keeps
her
hand
.
   
<EOS>
Of
there
being
a
breakfast
,
with
abundance
of
things
,
pretty
and
substantial
,
to
eat
and
drink
,
whereof
I
partake
,
as
I
should
do
in
any
other
dream
,
without
the
least
perception
of
their
flavour
;
eating
and
drinking
,
as
I
may
say
,
nothing
but
love
and
marriage
,
and
no
more
believing
in
the
viands
than
in
anything
else
.
   
<EOS>
Of
my
making
a
speech
in
the
same
dreamy
fashion
,
without
having
an
idea
of
what
I
want
to
say
,
beyond
such
as
may
be
comprehended
in
the
full
conviction
that
I
have
n't
said
it
.
 
<EOS>
Of
our
being
very
sociably
and
simply
happy
(
always
in
a
dream
though
)
;
and
of
Jip
's
having
wedding
cake
,
and
its
not
agreeing
with
him
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
Of
the
pair
of
hired
post
-
horses
being
ready
,
and
of
Dora
's
going
away
to
change
her
dress
.
 
<EOS>
Of
my
aunt
and
Miss
Clarissa
remaining
with
us
;
and
our
walking
in
the
garden
;
and
my
aunt
,
who
has
made
quite
a
speech
at
breakfast
touching
Dora
's
aunts
,
being
mightily
amused
with
herself
,
but
a
little
proud
of
it
too
.
   
<EOS>
Of
Dora
's
being
ready
,
and
of
Miss
Lavinia
's
hovering
about
her
,
loth
to
lose
the
pretty
toy
that
has
given
her
so
much
pleasant
occupation
.
 
<EOS>
Of
<EOS>
Dora
's
making
a
long
series
of
surprised
discoveries
that
she
has
forgotten
all
sorts
of
little
things
;
and
of
everybody
's
running
everywhere
to
fetch
them
.
   
<EOS>
Of
their
all
closing
about
Dora
,
when
at
last
she
begins
to
say
good
-
bye
,
looking
,
with
their
bright
colours
and
ribbons
,
like
a
bed
of
flowers
.
 
<EOS>
Of
my
darling
being
almost
smothered
among
the
flowers
,
and
coming
out
,
laughing
and
crying
both
together
,
to
my
jealous
arms
.
   
<EOS>
Of
my
wanting
to
carry
Jip
(
who
is
to
go
along
with
us
)
,
and
Dora
's
saying
no
,
that
she
must
carry
him
,
or
else
he
'll
think
she
do
n't
like
him
any
more
,
now
she
is
married
,
and
will
break
his
heart
.
<EOS>
Of
our
going
,
arm
in
arm
,
and
Dora
stopping
and
looking
back
,
and
saying
,
"
If
I
have
ever
been
cross
or
ungrateful
to
anybody
,
do
n't
remember
it
!
"
and
bursting
into
tears
.
   
<EOS>
Of
her
waving
her
little
hand
,
and
our
going
away
once
more
.
 
<EOS>
Of
her
once
more
stopping
,
and
looking
back
,
and
hurrying
to
Agnes
,
and
giving
Agnes
,
above
all
the
others
,
her
last
kisses
and
farewells
.
   
<EOS>
We
drive
away
together
,
and
I
awake
from
the
dream
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
it
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
my
dear
,
dear
,
little
wife
beside
me
,
whom
I
love
so
well
!
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
happy
now
,
you
foolish
boy
?
"
says
Dora
,
"
and
sure
you
do
n't
repent
?
"
   
I
have
stood
aside
to
see
the
phantoms
of
those
days
go
by
me
.
<EOS>
They
are
gone
,
and
I
resume
the
journey
of
my
story
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
44
.
<EOS>
Our
housekeeping
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
strange
condition
of
things
,
the
honeymoon
being
over
,
and
the
bridesmaids
gone
home
,
when
I
found
myself
sitting
down
in
my
own
small
house
with
Dora
;
quite
thrown
out
of
employment
,
as
I
may
say
,
in
respect
of
the
delicious
old
occupation
of
making
love
.
   
<EOS>
It
seemed
such
an
extraordinary
thing
to
have
Dora
always
there
.
<EOS>
It
was
so
unaccountable
not
to
be
obliged
to
go
out
to
see
her
,
not
to
have
any
occasion
to
be
tormenting
myself
about
her
,
not
to
have
to
write
to
her
,
not
to
be
scheming
and
devising
opportunities
of
being
alone
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
of
an
evening
,
when
I
looked
up
from
my
writing
,
and
saw
her
seated
opposite
,
I
would
lean
back
in
my
chair
,
and
think
how
queer
it
was
that
there
we
were
,
alone
together
as
a
matter
of
course
---
<EOS>
nobody
's
business
any
more
<EOS>
---
all
the
romance
of
our
engagement
put
away
upon
a
shelf
,
to
rust
---
<EOS>
no
one
to
please
but
one
another
---
one
another
to
please
,
for
life
.
   
<EOS>
When
there
was
a
debate
,
and
I
was
kept
out
very
late
,
it
seemed
so
strange
to
me
,
as
I
was
walking
home
,
to
think
that
Dora
was
at
home
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
such
a
wonderful
thing
,
at
first
,
to
have
her
coming
softly
down
to
talk
to
me
as
I
ate
my
supper
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
such
a
stupendous
thing
to
know
for
certain
that
she
put
her
hair
in
papers
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
altogether
such
an
astonishing
event
to
see
her
do
it
!
   
<EOS>
I
doubt
whether
two
young
birds
could
have
known
less
about
keeping
house
,
than
I
and
my
pretty
Dora
did
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
a
servant
,
of
course
.
<EOS>
She
kept
house
for
us
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
still
a
latent
belief
that
she
must
have
been
Mrs
Crupp
's
daughter
in
disguise
,
we
had
such
an
awful
time
of
it
with
Mary
Anne
.
   
<EOS>
Her
name
was
Paragon
.
 
<EOS>
Her
nature
was
represented
to
us
,
when
we
engaged
her
,
as
being
feebly
expressed
in
her
name
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
a
written
character
,
as
large
as
a
proclamation
;
and
,
according
to
this
document
,
could
do
everything
of
a
domestic
nature
that
ever
I
heard
of
,
and
a
great
many
things
that
I
never
did
hear
of
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
a
woman
in
the
prime
of
life
;
of
a
severe
countenance
;
and
subject
(
particularly
in
the
arms
)
to
a
sort
of
perpetual
measles
or
fiery
rash
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
a
cousin
in
the
Life
-
Guards
,
with
such
long
legs
that
he
looked
like
the
afternoon
shadow
of
somebody
else
.
<EOS>
His
shell
-
jacket
was
as
much
too
little
for
him
as
he
was
too
big
for
the
premises
.
 
<EOS>
He
made
the
cottage
smaller
than
it
need
<EOS>
have
been
,
by
being
so
very
much
out
of
proportion
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
which
,
the
walls
were
not
thick
,
and
,
whenever
he
passed
the
evening
at
our
house
,
we
always
knew
of
it
by
hearing
one
continual
growl
in
the
kitchen
.
   
<EOS>
Our
treasure
was
warranted
sober
and
honest
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
therefore
willing
to
believe
that
she
was
in
a
fit
when
we
found
her
under
the
boiler
;
and
that
the
deficient
tea
-
spoons
were
attributable
to
the
dustman
.
   
<EOS>
But
she
preyed
upon
our
minds
dreadfully
.
 
<EOS>
We
felt
our
inexperience
,
and
were
unable
to
help
ourselves
.
 
<EOS>
We
should
have
been
at
her
mercy
,
if
she
had
had
any
;
but
she
was
a
remorseless
woman
,
and
had
none
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
the
cause
of
our
first
little
quarrel
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dearest
life
,
"
I
said
one
day
to
Dora
,
"
do
you
think
Mary
Anne
has
any
idea
of
time
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Doady
?
"
inquired
Dora
,
looking
up
,
innocently
,
from
her
drawing
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
love
,
because
it
's
five
,
and
we
were
to
have
dined
at
four
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Dora
glanced
wistfully
at
the
clock
,
and
hinted
that
she
thought
it
was
too
fast
.
   
<EOS>
"
On
the
contrary
,
my
love
,
"
said
I
,
referring
to
my
watch
,
"
it
's
a
few
minutes
too
slow
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
little
wife
came
and
sat
upon
my
knee
,
to
coax
me
to
be
quiet
,
and
drew
a
line
with
her
pencil
down
the
middle
of
my
nose
;
but
I
could
n't
dine
off
that
,
though
it
was
very
agreeable
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
think
,
my
dear
,
"
said
I
,
"
it
would
be
better
for
you
to
remonstrate
with
Mary
Anne
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
no
,
please
!
 
<EOS>
I
could
n't
,
Doady
!
"
said
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
not
,
my
love
?
<EOS>
"
I
gently
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
because
I
am
such
a
little
goose
,
"
said
Dora
,
"
and
she
knows
I
am
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
thought
this
sentiment
so
incompatible
with
the
establishment
of
any
system
of
check
on
Mary
Anne
,
that
I
frowned
a
little
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
what
ugly
wrinkles
in
my
bad
boy
's
forehead
!
"
said
Dora
,
and
still
being
on
my
knee
,
she
traced
them
with
her
pencil
;
putting
it
to
her
rosy
lips
to
make
it
mark
blacker
,
and
working
at
my
forehead
with
a
quaint
little
mockery
of
being
industrious
,
that
quite
delighted
me
in
spite
of
myself
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
good
child
,
"
said
Dora
,
"
it
makes
its
face
so
much
prettier
to
laugh
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
,
my
love
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
!
please
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Dora
,
with
a
kiss
,
"
do
n't
be
a
naughty
Blue
Beard
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
serious
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
my
precious
wife
,
"
said
I
,
"
we
must
be
serious
sometimes
.
 
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>
Sit
down
on
this
chair
,
close
beside
me
!
 
<EOS>
Give
me
the
pencil
!
<EOS>
There
!
 
<EOS>
Now
let
us
talk
sensibly
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
,
dear
"
;
what
a
little
hand
it
was
to
hold
,
and
what
a
tiny
wedding
-
ring
it
was
to
see
!
<EOS>
"
You
know
,
my
love
,
it
is
not
exactly
comfortable
to
have
to
go
out
without
one
's
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
is
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
N
-
n
-
no
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Dora
,
faintly
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
love
,
how
you
tremble
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because
I
KNOW
you
're
going
to
scold
me
,
"
exclaimed
Dora
,
in
a
piteous
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
sweet
,
I
am
only
going
to
reason
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
but
reasoning
is
worse
than
scolding
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Dora
,
in
despair
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
marry
to
be
reasoned
with
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
meant
to
reason
with
such
a
poor
little
thing
as
I
am
,
you
ought
to
have
told
me
so
,
you
cruel
boy
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
tried
to
pacify
Dora
,
but
she
turned
away
her
face
,
and
shook
her
curls
from
side
to
side
,
and
said
,
"
You
cruel
,
cruel
boy
!
"
<EOS>
so
many
times
,
that
I
really
did
not
exactly
know
what
to
do
:
so
I
took
a
few
turns
up
and
down
the
room
in
my
uncertainty
,
and
came
back
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dora
,
my
darling
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
am
not
your
darling
.
 
<EOS>
Because
you
must
be
sorry
that
you
married
me
,
or
else
you
would
n't
reason
with
me
!
"
returned
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
I
felt
so
injured
by
the
inconsequential
nature
of
this
charge
,
that
it
gave
me
courage
to
be
grave
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
own
Dora
,
"
said
I
,
"
you
are
very
childish
,
and
are
talking
nonsense
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
remember
,
I
am
sure
,
that
I
was
obliged
to
go
out
yesterday
when
dinner
was
half
over
;
and
that
,
the
day
before
,
I
was
made
quite
unwell
by
being
obliged
to
eat
underdone
veal
in
a
hurry
;
today
,
I
do
n't
dine
at
all
---
and
I
am
afraid
to
say
how
long
we
waited
for
breakfast
---
and
then
the
water
did
n't
boil
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mean
to
reproach
you
,
my
dear
,
but
this
is
not
comfortable
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
you
cruel
,
cruel
boy
,
to
say
I
am
a
disagreeable
wife
!
"
cried
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
dear
Dora
,
you
must
know
that
I
never
said
that
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
said
,
I
was
n't
comfortable
!
"
cried
Dora
.
<EOS>
"
I
said
the
housekeeping
was
not
comfortable
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
exactly
the
same
thing
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
And
she
evidently
thought
so
,
for
she
wept
most
grievously
.
   
<EOS>
I
took
another
turn
across
the
room
,
full
of
love
for
my
pretty
wife
,
and
distracted
by
self
-
accusatory
inclinations
to
knock
my
head
against
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
down
again
,
and
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
blaming
you
,
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
both
a
great
deal
to
learn
.
<EOS>
I
am
only
trying
to
show
you
,
my
dear
,
that
you
must
---
<EOS>
you
really
must
"
<EOS>
(
I
was
resolved
not
to
give
this
up
)
<EOS>
---
"
accustom
yourself
to
look
after
Mary
Anne
.
 
<EOS>
Likewise
to
act
a
little
for
yourself
,
and
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
,
I
do
,
at
your
making
such
ungrateful
speeches
,
"
sobbed
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
you
know
that
the
other
day
,
when
you
said
you
would
like
a
little
bit
of
fish
,
I
went
out
myself
,
miles
and
miles
,
and
ordered

,
to

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
it
was
very
kind

you
,
my
own
darling
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
I
felt
it
so
much
that
I
would
n't
on
any
account
have
even
mentioned
that
you
bought
a
Salmon
---
which
was
too
much
for
two
.
 
<EOS>
Or
that
it
cost
one
pound
six
---
<EOS>
which
was
more
than
we
can
afford
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
enjoyed
it
very
much
,
"
sobbed
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
you
said
I
was
a
Mouse
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
'll
say
so
again
,
my
love
,
"
I
returned
,
"
a
thousand
times
!
"
   
<EOS>
But
I
had
wounded
Dora
's
soft
little
heart
,
and
she
was
not
to
be
comforted
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
so
pathetic
in
her
sobbing
and
bewailing
,
that
I
felt
as
if
I
had
said
I
do
n't
know
what
to
hurt

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
obliged
to
hurry
away
;
I
was
kept
out
late
;
and
I
felt
all
night
such
pangs
of
remorse
as
made
me
miserable
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
the
conscience
of
an
assassin
,
and
was
haunted
by
a
vague
sense
of
enormous
wickedness
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
two
or
three
hours
past
midnight
when
I
got
home
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
my
aunt
,
in
our
house
,
sitting
up
for
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
anything
the
matter
,
aunt
?
<EOS>
"
said
I
,
alarmed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
Trot
,
"
she

.
 
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
,
sit
down
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Blossom
has
been
rather
out
of
spirits
,
and
I
have
been
keeping
her
company
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
leaned
my
head
upon
my
hand
;
and
felt
more
sorry

,
as

sat

the
fire
,
than
I
could
have
supposed
possible
so

the

of
my

.
 
<EOS>
As

sat
thinking
,
I
happened
to

my
aunt
's

,
which
were

on

.
 
<EOS>
There

an
anxious
expression
in

,
but
it
cleared

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
assure

,
aunt
,
"
said

,
"
I
have
been
quite
unhappy
myself
all

,
to

Dora
's

so
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
had
no
other

than
to
speak
to
her
tenderly
and

about
our
home

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
MY
aunt
nodded

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
have
patience
,
Trot
,
"
said
she
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
.
 
<EOS>
Heaven

I
do
n't
mean

be
unreasonable
,
aunt
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
my

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
Little
Blossom
is
a
very
tender

blossom
,
and
the
wind
must
be
gentle
with
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
thanked
my
good
aunt
,
in

,
for
her

towards
my
wife
;
and
I
was

that
she
knew

did
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
think
,
aunt
,
"
said
I
,
after

of
the
fire
,
"
that
you

advise

counsel
Dora
<EOS>
a
little
,

our
mutual

,
<EOS>
now

?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Trot
,
"
returned
my
aunt
,
with
some

,
"
no
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
ask
me
such
a
thing
.
"
   
<EOS>
Her
tone
was
so
very
earnest
that
I
raised
my

in
surprise
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
look
back
on
my
life
,
child
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
and
I
think
of
some
who
are
in
their
graves
,
with
whom
I
might
have
been
on

terms
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
judged
harshly
of
other
people
's
mistakes
in
marriage
,
it
may
have
been
because
I
had
bitter
reason
to
judge
harshly
of
my
own
.
 
<EOS>
Let
that
pass
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
a
grumpy
,
frumpy
,
wayward
sort
of
a
woman
,
a
good
many
years
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
still
,
and
I
always

be
.
<EOS>
But
you
and
I
have
done
one
another
some

,
Trot
,
---
at

,
you
have
done
me
good
,
my
dear
;
and
division
must

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Division
between
us
!
"
<EOS>
cried
I.
   
"
Child
,
child
!
"
<EOS>
said
my
aunt
,
smoothing
her
dress
,
"
how
soon
it
might
come
between

,
or
how
unhappy
I
might

our
Little
Blossom
<EOS>
,

,
a

could

.
 
<EOS>
I
want
our
pet
to
like

,
and
be

.
 
<EOS>
Remember
your
own
home
,
in
that
second

;
and
never
do
both
me

her
<EOS>
the

have

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

,
at

,
that
my
aunt
was

;
and
I
comprehended
the
full

her

.
   
<EOS>
"
These
are
early

,
Trot
,
"
she

,
"
and
Rome
was
not

,

.
 
<EOS>
You
have
chosen
freely
for

"
;
a

for

,
I

;
"
and
you
have
chosen
a
very

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

---
<EOS>
of

I

;
I

---
to

(

)

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

,
child
,
"
here

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
No

;

.
 
<EOS>
This

,

;

Heaven

,
in

,

a

"
   
<EOS>
My

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said

,

,

into

by

"
;

.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
Betsey
Trotwood
's

,

;

do
<EOS>
,

,

,

's

"
   
<EOS>
With

.
 
<EOS>
As

,

,
I
thought

had

anxious

;

---

,

---

Dora
and
I
had
indeed

,
and
that
no

could

,
to

of

.
   
<EOS>
Dora
came
stealing
down
in
her
little

,
to
meet
me
,
now
that
I
was
alone
;
and
cried
upon
my
shoulder
,
and
said
I
had
been
hard
-
hearted
<EOS>
and
she
had
been
naughty
;
and
I
said
much
the
same
thing
in
effect
,
I
believe
;
and
we
made
it
up
,
and
agreed
that
our
first
little
difference
was
to
be
our
last
,
and
that
we
were
never
to
have
another
if
we
lived
a
hundred
years
.
   
<EOS>
The
next
domestic
trial
we
went
through
,
was
the
Ordeal
of
Servants
.
 
<EOS>
Mary
Anne
's
cousin
deserted
into
our
coal
-
hole
,
and
was
brought
out
,
to
our
great
amazement
,
by
a
piquet
of
his
companions
in
arms
,
who
took
him
away
handcuffed
in
a
procession
that
covered
our
front

with
ignominy
.
 
<EOS>
This
nerved
me
to
get
rid
of
Mary
Anne
,
who
went
so
mildly
,
on
receipt
of
wages
,
that
I
was
surprised
,
until
I
found
out
about
the
tea
-

,
and
also
about
the
little
sums
she
had
borrowed
in
my
name
of
the
tradespeople
without

.
 
<EOS>
After
an
interval
of
Mrs
Kidgerbury
---
the
oldest
inhabitant
of
Kentish
Town
,
I
believe
,
who
went
out
charing
,
but
was
too
feeble
to
execute
her
conceptions
of
that
art
<EOS>
---
we
found
another
treasure
,
who
was
one
of
the
most
amiable
of
women
,
but
who
generally
made
a
point
of
falling
either
up
or
down
the

with
the
tray
,
and
almost
plunged
into
the
parlour
,
as
into
a
bath
,
with
the
tea
-
things
.
 
<EOS>
The
ravages
committed
by
this
unfortunate
,
rendering
her
dismissal
necessary
<EOS>
,
she
was
succeeded
(
with

of
Mrs
Kidgerbury
)
by
a
long
line
of
Incapables
;
terminating
in
a
young
person
of
genteel

,
who
went
to
Greenwich
Fair
in
Dora
's

.
 
<EOS>
After
whom
I
remember
nothing
but
an
average
equality
of
failure
.
   
<EOS>
Everybody
we
had
anything
to
do
with
seemed
to
cheat
us
.
 
<EOS>
Our
appearance
in
a
shop
was
a
signal
for
the
damaged
goods
to
be
brought
out
immediately
.
 
<EOS>
If
we
bought
a
lobster
,
it
was
full
of
water
.
 
<EOS>
All
our
meat
turned
out
to
be
tough
,
and
there
was
hardly
any
crust
to
our
loaves
.
 
<EOS>
In
search
of
the
principle
on
which
joints
ought
to
be
roasted
,
to
be
roasted
enough
,
and
not
too
much
,
I
myself
referred
to
the
Cookery
Book
,
and
found
it
there
established
as
the
allowance
of
a
quarter
of
an
hour
to
every
pound
,
and
say
a
quarter
over
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
principle
always
failed
us
by
some
curious
fatality
,
and
we
never
could
hit
any
medium
between
redness
and
cinders
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
reason
to
believe
that
in
accomplishing
these
failures
we
incurred
a
far
greater
expense
than
if
we
had
achieved
a
series
of
triumphs
.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
me
,
on
looking
over
the
tradesmen
's
books
,
as
if
we
might
have
kept
the
basement
storey
paved
with
butter
,
such
was
the
extensive
scale
of
our
consumption
of
that
article
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
whether
the
Excise
returns
of
the
period
may
have
exhibited
any
increase
in
the
demand
for
pepper
;
but
if
our
performances
did
not
affect
the
market
,
I
should
say
several
families
must
have
left
off
using
it
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
most
wonderful
fact
of
all
was
,
that
we
never
had
anything
in
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
As
to
the
washerwoman
pawning
the
clothes
,
and
coming
in
a
state
of
penitent
intoxication
to
apologize
,
I
suppose
that
might
have
happened
several
times
to
anybody
.
 
<EOS>
Also
the
chimney
on
fire
,
the
parish
engine
,
and
perjury
on
the
part
of
the
Beadle
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
apprehend
that
we
were
personally
fortunate
in
engaging
a
servant
with
a
taste
for
cordials
,
who
swelled
our
running
account
for
porter
at
the
public
-
house
by
such
inexplicable
items
as
"
quartern
rum
shrub
(
Mrs
C
)
"
;
"
Half
-
quartern
gin
and
cloves
(
Mrs
C
)
"
;
"
Glass
rum
and
peppermint
(
Mrs
C
)
"
---
the
parentheses
always
referring
to
Dora
,
who
was
supposed
,
it
appeared
on
explanation
,
to
have
imbibed
the
whole
of
these
refreshments
.
   
<EOS>
One
of
our
first
feats
in
the
housekeeping
way
was
a
little
dinner
to
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
I
met
him
in
town
,
and
asked
him
to
walk
out
with
me
that
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
He
readily
consenting
<EOS>
,
I
wrote
to
Dora
,
saying
I
would
bring
him
home
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
pleasant
weather
,
and
on
the
road
we
made
my
domestic
happiness
the
theme
of
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
was
very
full
of
it
;
and
said
,
that
,
picturing
himself
with
such
a
home
,
and
Sophy
waiting
and
preparing
for
him
,
he
could
think
of
nothing
wanting
to
complete
his
bliss
.
   
<EOS>
I
could
not
have
wished
for
a
prettier
little
wife
at
the
opposite
end
of
the
table
,
but
I
certainly
could
have
wished
,
when
we
sat
down
,
for
a
little
more
room
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
not
know
how
it
was
,
but
though
there
were
only
two
of
us
,
we
were
at
once
always
cramped
for
room
,
and
yet
had
always
room
enough
to
lose
everything
in
.
 
<EOS>
I
suspect
it
may
have
been
because
nothing
had
a
place
of
its
own
,
except
Jip
's
pagoda
,
which
invariably
blocked
up
the
main
thoroughfare
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
present
occasion
,
Traddles
was
so
hemmed
in
by
the
pagoda
and
the
guitar
-
case
,
and
<EOS>
Dora
's
flower
-
painting
,
and
my
writing
-
table
,
that
I
had
serious
doubts
of
the
possibility
of
his
using
his
knife
and
fork
;
but
he
protested
,
with
his
own
good
-
humour
,
"
Oceans
of
room
,
Copperfield
!
 
<EOS>
I
assure
you
,
Oceans
!
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
another
thing
I
could
have
wished
,
namely
,
that
Jip
had
never
been
encouraged
to
walk
about
the
tablecloth
during
dinner
.
<EOS>
I
began
to
think
there
was
something
disorderly
in
his
being
there
at
all
,
even
if
he
had
not
been
in
the
habit
of
putting
his
foot
in
the
salt
or
the
melted
butter
.
 
<EOS>
On
this
occasion
he
seemed
to
think
he
was
introduced
expressly
to
keep
Traddles
at
bay
;
and
he
barked
at
my
old
friend
,
and
made
short
runs
at
his
plate
,
with
such
undaunted
pertinacity
,
that
he
may
be
said
to
have
engrossed
the
conversation
.
   
<EOS>
However
,
as
I
knew
how
tender
-
hearted
<EOS>
my
dear
Dora
was
,
and
how
sensitive
she
would
be
to
any
slight
upon
her
favourite
<EOS>
,
I
hinted
no
objection
.
 
<EOS>
For
similar
reasons
I
made
no
allusion
to
the
skirmishing
plates
upon
the
floor
;
or
to
the
disreputable
appearance
of
the
castors
,
which
were
all
at
sixes
and
sevens
,
and
looked
drunk
;
or
to
the
further
blockade
of
Traddles
by
wandering
vegetable
dishes
and
jugs
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
help
wondering
in
my
own
mind
,
as
I
contemplated
the
boiled
leg
of
mutton
before
me
,
previous
to
carving
it
<EOS>
,
how
it
came
to
pass
that
our
joints
of
meat
were
of
such
extraordinary
shapes
---
and
whether
our
butcher
contracted
for
all
the
deformed
sheep
that
came
into
the
world
;
but
I
kept
my
reflections
to
myself
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
love
,
"
said
I
to
Dora
,
"
what
have
you
got
in
that
dish
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
not
imagine
why
Dora
had
been
making
tempting
little
faces
at
me
,
as
if
she
wanted
to
kiss
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oysters
,
dear
,
"
said
Dora
,
timidly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Was
that
YOUR
thought
?
<EOS>
"
said
I
,
delighted
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ye
-
yes
,
Doady
,
"
said
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
never
was
a
happier
one
!
"
<EOS>
I
exclaimed
,
laying
down
the
carving
-
knife
and
fork
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
Traddles
likes
so
much
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ye
<EOS>
-
yes
,
Doady
,
"
said
Dora
,
"
<EOS>
and
so
I
bought
a
beautiful
little
barrel
of
them
,
and
the
man
said
they
were
very
good
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
---
I
am
afraid
there
's
something
the
matter
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
They
do
n't
seem
right
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
Dora
shook
her
head
,
and
diamonds
twinkled
in
her
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
are
only
opened
in
both
shells
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
the
top
one
off
,
my
love
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
it
wo
n't
come
off
!
"
<EOS>
said
Dora
,
trying
very
hard
,
and
looking
very
much
distressed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
,
Copperfield
,
"
said
Traddles
,
cheerfully
examining
the
dish
,
"
I
think
it
is
in
consequence
---
they
are
capital
oysters
,
<EOS>
but
I
think
it
is
in
consequence
---
of
their
never
having
been
opened
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
never
had
been
opened
;
and
we
had
no
oyster
-
knives
---
and
could
n't
have
used
them
if
we
had
;
so
we
looked
at
the
oysters
and
ate
the
mutton
.
 
<EOS>
At
least
we
ate
as
much
of
it
as
was
done
,
and
made
up
with
capers
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
permitted
him
,
I
am
satisfied
that
Traddles
would
have
made
a
perfect
savage
of
himself
,
and
eaten
a
plateful
of
raw
meat
,
to
express
enjoyment
of
the
repast
;
but
I
would
hear
of
no
such
immolation
on
the
altar
of
friendship
,
and
we
had
a
course
of
bacon
instead
;
there
happening
,
by
good
fortune
,
to
be
cold
bacon
in
the
larder
.
   
<EOS>
My
poor
little
wife
was
in
such
affliction
when
she
thought
I
should
be
annoyed
,
and
in
such
a
state
of
joy
when
she
found
I
was
not
,
that
the
discomfiture
I
had
subdued
,
very
soon
vanished
,
and
we
passed
a
happy
evening
;
Dora
sitting
with
her
arm
on
my
chair
while
Traddles
and
I
discussed
a
glass
of
wine
,
and
taking
every
opportunity
of
whispering
in
my
ear
that
it
was
so
good
of
me
not
to
be
a
cruel
,
cross
old
boy
.
 
<EOS>
By
and
by
<EOS>
she
made
tea
for
us
;
which
it
was
so
pretty
to
see
her
do
,
as
if
she
was
busying
herself
with
a
set
of
doll
's
tea
-
things
,
that
I
was
not
particular
about
the
quality
of
the
beverage
.
 
<EOS>
Then
Traddles
and
I
played
a
game
or
two
at
cribbage
;
and
Dora
singing
to
the
guitar
the
while
,
it
seemed
to
me
as
if
our
courtship
and
marriage
were
a
tender
dream
of
mine
,
and
the
night
when
I
first
listened
to
her
voice
were
not
yet
over
.
   
<EOS>
When
Traddles
went
away
,
and
I
came
back
into
the
parlour
from
seeing
him
out
,
my
wife
planted
her
chair
close
to
mine
,
and
sat
down
by
my
side
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
sorry
,
"
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
try
to
teach
me
,
Doady
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
teach
myself
first
,
Dora
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
as
bad
as
you
,
love
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
But
you
can
learn
,
"
she
returned
;
"
<EOS>
and
you
are
a
clever
,
clever
man
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
,
mouse
!
<EOS>
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
,
"
resumed
my
wife
,
after
a
long

,
"
that
I
could
have
gone
down
into
the
country
for
a
whole
year
,
and
lived
with
Agnes
!
"
   
<EOS>
Her
hands
were
clasped
upon
my
shoulder
,
and
her
chin
rested
on
them
,
and
her
blue

looked

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
so
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
she
might
have
improved
me
,
and
I
think
I
might
have
learned
from
her
,
"
said
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
in
good
time
,
my
love
.
 
<EOS>
Agnes
has
had
her
father
to
take
care
of
for
these

,
you
should

.
 
<EOS>
Even
when
she
was
quite
a
child
,
she
was
the
Agnes
whom
we
know
,
"

<EOS>
"
Will
you
call
me
a
name
I
want

to
call
me
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Dora
,
without

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
with
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
stupid
name
,
"
she
said
,
shaking
her
curls
for
a
moment
.
"
<EOS>
Child
-
wife
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
laughingly
asked
my
child
-
wife
what
<EOS>
her
fancy
was
in
desiring
to
be
so
called
.
 
<EOS>
She
answered
without
moving
,
otherwise
than
as
the
arm
I
twined
about
her
may
have
brought
her
blue
eyes
nearer
to
me
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mean
,
you
silly
fellow
,
that
you
should
use

name
instead

Dora
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
mean
that
you
should
think
of
me
that
way
.
<EOS>
When
you
are
going
to
be
angry
with
me
,
say
to

,
"
it
's
only
my
child
-
wife
!
"
<EOS>
When
I
am
very

,
say
,
"
I
knew
,
a
long
time
ago
,
that
she
would
make
but
a
child
-
wife
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
When
you
miss
what
I
should
like
to
be
,
and
I
think
can
never
be
,
say
,
"
still
my
foolish
child
-
wife
loves
me
!
"
<EOS>
For
indeed
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
had
not
been
serious
with
her
;
having
no
idea
until
now
,
that
she
was
serious
herself
.
 
<EOS>
But
her
affectionate
nature
was
so
happy
in
what
I
now
said
to
her
with
my
whole
heart
,
that
her
face
became
a
laughing
one
before
her
glittering
eyes
were
dry
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
soon
my
child
-
wife
indeed
;
sitting
down
on
the
floor
outside
the
Chinese
House
,
ringing
all
the
little
bells
one
after
another
,
to
punish
Jip
for
his
recent
bad
behaviour
;
while
Jip
lay
blinking
in
the
doorway
with
his
head
out
,
even
too
lazy
to
be
teased
.
   
<EOS>
This
appeal
of
Dora
's
made
a
strong
impression
on
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
look
back
on
the
time
I
write
of
;
I
invoke
the
innocent
figure
that
I
dearly
loved
,
to
come
out
from
the
mists
and
shadows
of
the
past
,
and
turn
its
gentle
head
towards
me
once
again
;
and
I
can
still
declare
that
this
one
little
speech
was
constantly
in
my
memory
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
not
have
used
it
to
the
best
account
;
I
was
young
and
inexperienced
;
but
I
never
turned
a
deaf
ear
to
its
artless
pleading
.
   
<EOS>
Dora
told
me
,
shortly
afterwards
,
that
she
was
going
to
be
a
wonderful
housekeeper
.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
she
polished
the
tablets
,
pointed
the
pencil
,
bought
an
immense
account
-
book
,
carefully
stitched
up
with
a
needle
and
thread
all
the
leaves
of
the
Cookery
Book
which
Jip
had
torn
,
and
made
quite
a
desperate
little
attempt
"
to
be
good
"
,
as
she
called
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
figures
had
the
old
obstinate
propensity
---
they
WOULD
NOT
add
up
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
entered
two
or
three
laborious
items
in
the
account
-
book
,
Jip
would
walk
over
the
page
,
wagging
his
tail
,
and
smear
them
all
out
.
 
<EOS>
Her
own
little
right
-
hand
middle
finger
got
steeped
to
the
very
bone
in
ink
;
and
I
think
that
was
the
only
decided
result
obtained
.
   
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
of
an
evening
,
when
I
was
at
home
and
at
work
---
for
I
wrote
a
good
deal
now
,
and
was
beginning
in
a
small
way
to
be
known
as
a
writer
---
I
would
lay
down
my
pen
,
and
watch
my
child
-
wife
trying
to
be
good
.
 
<EOS>
First
of
all
,
she
would
bring
out
the
immense
account
-
book
,
and
lay
it
down
upon
the
table
,
with
a
deep
sigh
.
<EOS>
Then
she
would
open
it
at
the
place
where
Jip
had
made
it
illegible
last
night
,
and
call
Jip
up
,
to
look
at
his
misdeeds
.
 
<EOS>
This
would
occasion
a
diversion
in
Jip
's
favour
,
and
some
inking
of
his
nose
,
perhaps
,
as
a
penalty
.
 
<EOS>
Then
she
would
tell
Jip
to
lie
down
on
the
table
instantly
,
"
like
a
lion
"
---
which
was
one
of
his
tricks
,
though
I
can
not
say
the
likeness
was
striking
---
and
,
if
he
were
in
an
obedient
humour
,
he
would
obey
.
 
<EOS>
Then
she
would
take
up
a
pen
,
and
begin
to
write
,
and
find
a
hair
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
Then
she
would
take
up
another
pen
,
and
begin
to
write
,
and
find
that
it
spluttered
.
 
<EOS>
Then
she
would
take
up
another
pen
,
and
begin
to
write
,
and
say
in
a
low
voice
,
"
Oh
,
it
's
a
talking
pen
,
and
will
disturb
Doady
!
"
<EOS>
And
then
she
would
give
it
up
as
a
bad
job
,
and
put
the
account
-
book
away
,
after
pretending
to
crush
the
lion
with
it
.
   
<EOS>
Or
,
if
she
were
in
a
very
sedate
and
serious
state
of
mind
,
she
would
sit
down
with
the
tablets
,
and
a
little
basket
of
bills
and
other
documents
,
which
looked
more
like
curl
-
papers
than
anything
else
,
and
endeavour
to
get
some
result
out
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
After
severely
comparing
one
with
another
,
and
making
entries
on
the
tablets
,
and
blotting
them
out
,
and
counting
all
the
fingers
of
her
left
hand
over
and
over
again
,
backwards
and
forwards
,
she
would
be
so
vexed
and
discouraged
,
and
would
look
so
unhappy
,
that
it
gave
me
pain
to
see
her
bright
face
clouded
---
and
for
me
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
and
I
would
go
softly
to
her
,
and
say
:
   
"
<EOS>
What
's
the
matter
,
Dora
?
"
   
<EOS>
Dora
would
look
up
hopelessly
,
and
reply
,
"
They
wo
n't
come
right
.
<EOS>
They
make
my
head
ache
so
.
 
<EOS>
And
they
wo
n't
do
anything
I
want
!
"
   
<EOS>
Then
I
would
say
,
"
Now
let
us
try
together
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
show
you
,
Dora
.
"
   
<EOS>
Then
I
would
commence
a
practical
demonstration
,
to
which
Dora
would
pay
profound
attention
,
perhaps
for
five
minutes
;
when
she
would
begin
to
be
dreadfully
tired
,
and
would
lighten
the
subject
by
curling
my
hair
,
or
trying
the
effect
of
my
face
with
my
shirt
-
collar
turned
down
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
tacitly
checked
this
playfulness
,
and
persisted
,
she
would
look
so
scared
and
disconsolate
,
as
she
became
more
and
more
bewildered
,
that
the
remembrance
of
her
natural
gaiety
when
I
first
strayed
into
her
path
,
and
of
her
being
my
child
-
wife
,
would
come
reproachfully
upon
me
;
and
I
would
lay
the
pencil
down
,
and
call
for
the
guitar
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
a
great
deal
of
work
to
do
,
and
had
many
anxieties
,
but
the
same
considerations
made
me
keep
them
to
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
far
from
sure
,
now
,
that
it
was
right
to
do
this
,
but
I
did
it
for
my
child
-
wife
's
sake
.
 
<EOS>
I
search
my
breast
,
and
I
commit
its
secrets
,
if
I
know
them
,
without
any
reservation
to
this
paper
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
unhappy
loss
or
want
of
something
had
,
I
am
conscious
,
some
place
in
my
heart
;
but
not
to
the
embitterment
of
my
life
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
walked
alone
in
the
fine
weather
,
and
thought
of
the
summer
days
when
all
the
air
had
been
filled
with
my
boyish
enchantment
,
I
did
miss
something
of
the
realization
of
my
dreams
;
but
I
thought
it
was
a
softened
glory
of
the
Past
,
which
nothing
could
have
thrown
upon
the
present
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
feel
,
sometimes
,
for
a
little
while
,
that
I
could
have
wished
my
wife
had
been
my
counsellor
;
had
had
more
character
and
purpose
,
to
sustain
me
and
improve
me
by
;
had
been
endowed
with
power
to
fill
up
the
void
which
somewhere
seemed
to
be
about
me
;
but
I
felt
as
if
this
were
an
unearthly
consummation
of
my
happiness
,
that
never
had
been
meant
to
be
,
and
never
could
have
been
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
a
boyish
husband
as
to
years
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
known
the
softening
influence
of
no
other
sorrows
or
experiences
than
those
recorded
in
these
leaves
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
did
any
wrong
,
as
I
may
have
done
much
,
I
did
it
in
mistaken
love
,
and
in
my
want
of
wisdom
.
 
<EOS>
I
write
the
exact
truth
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
avail
me
nothing
to
extenuate
it
now
.
   
<EOS>
Thus
it
was
that
I
took
upon
myself
the
toils
and
cares
of
our
life
,
and
had
no
partner
in
them
.
 
<EOS>
We
lived
much
as
before
,
in
reference
to
our
scrambling
household
arrangements
;
but
I
had
got
used
to
those
,
and
Dora
<EOS>
I
was
pleased
to
see
was
seldom
vexed
now
.
<EOS>
She
was
bright
and
cheerful
in
the
old
childish
way
,
loved
me
dearly
,
and
was
happy
with
her
old
trifles
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
debates
were
heavy
---
I
mean
as
to
length
,
not
quality
,
for
in
the
last
respect
they
were
not
often
otherwise
---
and
I
went
home
late
,
Dora
would
never
rest
when
she
heard
my
footsteps
,
but
would
always
come
downstairs
to
meet
me
.
 
<EOS>
When
my
evenings
were
unoccupied
by
the
pursuit
for
which
I
had
qualified
myself
with
so
much
pains
,
and
I
was
engaged
in
writing
at
home
,
she
would
sit
quietly
near
me
,
however
late
the
hour
,
and
be
so
mute
,
<EOS>
that
I
would
often
think
she
had
dropped
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
But
generally
,
when
I
raised
my
head
,
I
saw
her
blue
eyes
looking
at
me
with
the
quiet
attention
of
which
I
have
already
spoken
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
what
a
weary
boy
!
"
said
Dora
one
night
,
when
I
met
her
eyes
as
I
was
shutting
up
my
desk
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
a
weary
girl
!
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
more
to
the
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
go
to
bed
another
time
,
my
love
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
far
too
late
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
do
n't
send
me
to
bed
!
"
<EOS>
pleaded
Dora
,
coming
to
my
side
.
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
do
n't
do
that
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dora
!
"
<EOS>
To
my
amazement
she
was
sobbing
on
my
neck
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
well
,
my
dear
!
<EOS>
not
happy
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
quite
well
,
and
very
happy
!
<EOS>
"
said
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
say
you
'll
let
me
stop
,
and
see
you
write
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
a
sight
for
such
bright
eyes
at
midnight
!
<EOS>
"
I
replied
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
they
bright
,
though
?
"
<EOS>
returned
Dora
,
laughing
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
so
glad
they
're
bright
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Little
Vanity
!
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
But
it
was
not
vanity
;
it
was
only
harmless
delight
in
my
admiration
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
that
very
well
,
before
she
told

so
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
think
them
pretty
,
say
I
may
always
stop
,
and
see
you
write
!
"
said
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
them
pretty
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
pretty
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
let
me
always
stop
and
see
you
write
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
that
wo
n't
improve
their
brightness
,
Dora
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
will
!
 
<EOS>
Because
,
you
clever
boy
,
you
'll
not
forget
me
then
,
while
you
are
full
of
silent

.
 
<EOS>
Will

,
if
I
say
something
very
,

?
 
<EOS>
---
more
than
usual
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Dora
,
peeping
over
my
shoulder
into
my
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
wonderful
thing
is
that
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Please
let
me
hold
the
pens
,
"
said
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
have
something
to
do
with
all
those
many
hours
when
you
are
so
industrious
.
 
<EOS>
May
I
hold
the
pens
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
remembrance
of
her
pretty
joy
when
I
said
yes
,
brings
tears
into
my
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
The
next
time
I
sat
down
to
write
,
and
regularly
afterwards
,
she
sat
in
her
old
place
,
with
a
spare

of
pens
at
her

.
 
<EOS>
Her
triumph
in
this
connexion
with
my
work
,
and
her
delight
when
I
wanted
a
new
pen
---
which
I
very
often
feigned
to
do
---
suggested
to
me
a
new
way
of
pleasing
my
child
-
wife
.
 
<EOS>
I
occasionally
made
a
pretence
of
wanting
a
page
or
two
of
manuscript
copied
.
 
<EOS>
Then
Dora
was
in
her
glory
.
 
<EOS>
The
preparations
she
made
for
this
great
work
,
the
aprons
she
put
on
,
the
bibs
she
borrowed
from
the
kitchen
to
keep
off
the
ink
,
the
time
she
took
,
the
innumerable
stoppages
she
made
to
have
a
laugh
with
Jip
as
if
he
understood
it
all
,
her
conviction
that
her
work
was
incomplete
unless
she
signed
her
name
at
the
end
,
and
the
way
in
which
she
would
bring
it
to
me
,
like
a
school
-
copy
,
and
then
,
when
I
praised
it
,
clasp
me
round
the
neck
,
are
touching
recollections
to
me
,
simple
as
they
might
appear
to
other
men
.
   
<EOS>
She
took
possession
of
the
keys
soon
after
this
,
and
went
jingling
about
the
house
with
the
whole
bunch
in
a
little
basket
,
tied
to
her
slender
waist
.
 
<EOS>
I
seldom
found
that
the
places
to
which
they
belonged
were
locked
,
or
that
they
were
of
any
use
except
as
a
plaything
for
Jip
---
but
Dora
was
pleased
,
and
that
pleased
me
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
quite
satisfied
that
a
good
deal
was
effected
by
this
make
-
belief
of
housekeeping
;
and
was
as
merry
as
if
we
had
been
keeping
a
baby
-
house
,
for
a
joke
.
   
<EOS>
So
we
went
on
.
 
<EOS>
Dora
was
hardly
less
affectionate
to
my
aunt
than
to
me
,
and
often
told
her
of
the
time
when
she
was
afraid
she
was
"
a
cross
old
thing
"
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
saw
my
aunt
unbend
more
systematically
to
anyone
.
 
<EOS>
She
courted
Jip
,
though
Jip
never
responded
;
listened
,
day
after
day
,
to
the
guitar
,
though
I
am
afraid
she
had
no
taste
for
music
;
never
attacked
the
Incapables
,
though
the
temptation
must
have
been
severe
;
went
wonderful
distances
on
foot
to
purchase
,
as
surprises
,
any
trifles
that
she
found
out
Dora
wanted
;
and
never
came
in
by
the
garden
,
and
missed
her
from
the
room
,
but
she
would
call

,
at
the
foot

stairs
,
in
a
voice
that
sounded

all
over

house
:
   
<EOS>
"
Where
's
Little
Blossom
?
"
      
<EOS>
Chapter
45
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
fulfils
my
aunt
's
predictions
 
<EOS>
It
was
some
time
now
,
since
I
had
left
the
Doctor
.
 
<EOS>
Living
in
his
neighbourhood
,
I
saw
him
frequently
;
and
we
all
went
to
his
house
on
two
or
three
occasions
to
dinner
or
tea
.
 
<EOS>
The
Old
Soldier
was
in
permanent
quarters
under
the
Doctor
's
roof
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
exactly
the
same
as
ever
,
and
the
same
immortal
butterflies
hovered
over
her
cap
.
   
<EOS>
Like
some
other
mothers
,
whom
I
have
known
in
the
course
of
my
life
,
Mrs
Markleham
was
far
more
fond
of
pleasure
than
her
daughter
was
.
 
<EOS>
She
required
a
great
deal
of
amusement
,
and
,
like
a
deep
old
soldier
,
pretended
,
in
consulting
her
own
inclinations
,
to
be
devoting
herself
to
her
child
.
 
<EOS>
The
Doctor
's
desire
that
Annie
should
be
entertained
,
was
therefore
particularly
acceptable
to
this
excellent
parent
;
who
expressed
unqualified
approval
of
his
discretion
.
   
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
,
indeed
,
that
she
probed
the
Doctor
's
wound
without
knowing
it
.
 
<EOS>
Meaning
nothing
but
a
certain
matured
frivolity
and
selfishness
,
not
always
inseparable
from
full
-
blown
years
<EOS>
,
I
think
she
confirmed
him
in
his
fear
that
he
was
a
constraint
upon
his
young
wife
,
and
that
there
was
no
congeniality
of
feeling
between
them
,
by
so
strongly
commending
his
design
of
lightening
the
load
of
her
life
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
soul
,
"
she
said
to
him
one
day
when
I
was
present
,
"
you
know
there
is
no
doubt
it
would
be
a
little
pokey
for
Annie
to
be
always
shut
up
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Doctor
nodded
his
benevolent
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
she
comes
to
her
mother
's
age
,
"
said
Mrs
Markleham
,
with
a
flourish
of
her
fan
,
"
then
it
'll
be
another
thing
.
 
<EOS>
You
might
put
ME
into
a
Jail
,
with
genteel
society
and
a
rubber
,
and
I
should
never
care
to
come
out
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
not
Annie
,
you
know
;
and
Annie
is
not
her
mother
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Surely
,
surely
,
"
said
the
Doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
the
best
of
creatures
---
<EOS>
no
,
I
beg
your
pardon
!
"
<EOS>
for
the
Doctor
made
a
gesture
of
deprecation
,
"
I
must
say
before
your
face
,
as
I
always
say

,
you
are
the
best
of
creatures
;
but

course
you
do
n't
---
now

?
 
<EOS>
---
enter

same

as
Annie
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
the
Doctor
,
in
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
of
course
not
,
"
retorted
the
Old
Soldier
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
your
Dictionary
,
for
example
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
useful
work
a
Dictionary
is
!
 
<EOS>
What
a
necessary
work
!
 
<EOS>
The
meanings
of

!
 
<EOS>
Without
Doctor
Johnson
,

,
we
might

at

calling

Italian
-

,

.
 
<EOS>
But
we
ca
n't
expect
a
Dictionary
---
especially

's
making
---
to
interest
Annie
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
The
Doctor
shook
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
that
's
why
I
so
much
approve
,
"
said
Mrs
Markleham
,
tapping

shoulder
with
her
shut

up

,
"
of
your

.
<EOS>
It
shows
that
you
do
n't
expect
,
as
many

do
expect
,
old
heads
on

.
 
<EOS>
You
have
studied
Annie
's
character
,
and
you
understand
it
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
what
I
find
so
charming
!
"
   
<EOS>
Even
the
calm
and
patient
face
of
Doctor
Strong
expressed
some
little
sense
of
pain
,
I
thought
,
under
the

of
these
compliments
.
   
<EOS>
"
Therefore
,
my
dear
Doctor
,
"
said
the
Old
Soldier
,
giving
him
several
