taps
,
"
you
may
command
me
,
at
all
times
and
seasons
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
do
understand
that
I
am
entirely
at
your
service
.
<EOS>
I
am
ready
to
go
with
Annie
to
operas
,
concerts
,
exhibitions
,
all
kinds
of
places
;
and
you
shall
never
find
that
I
am
tired
.
 
<EOS>
Duty
,
my
dear
Doctor
,
before
every
consideration
in
the
universe
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
as
good
as
her
word
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
one
of
those
people
who
can
bear
a
great
deal
of
pleasure
,
and
she
never
flinched
in
her
perseverance
in
the
cause
.
 
<EOS>
She
seldom
got
hold
of
the
newspaper
(
which
she
settled
herself
down
in
the
softest
chair
in
the
house
to
read
through
an
eye
-
glass
,
every
day
,
for
two
hours
)
,
but
she
found
out
something
that
she
was
certain
<EOS>
Annie
would
like
to
see
.
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
for
Annie
to
protest
that
she
was
weary
of
such
things
.
 
<EOS>
Her
mother
's
remonstrance
always
was
,
"
Now
,
my
dear
Annie
,
I
am
sure
you
know
better
;
and
I
must
tell
you
,
my
love
,
that
you
are
not
making
a
proper
return
for
the
kindness
of
Doctor
Strong
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
usually
said
in
the
Doctor
's
presence
,
and
appeared
to
me
to
constitute
Annie
's
principal
inducement
for
withdrawing
her
objections
when
she
made
any
.
 
<EOS>
But
in
general
she
resigned
herself
to
her
mother
,
and
went
where
the
Old
Soldier
would
.
   
<EOS>
It
rarely
happened
now
that
Mr
Maldon
accompanied
them
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
my
aunt
and
Dora
were
invited
to
do
so
,
and
accepted
the
invitation
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
Dora
only
was
asked
.
 
<EOS>
The
time
had
been
,
when
I
should
have
been
uneasy
in
her
going
;
but
reflection
on
what
had
passed
that
former
night
in
the
Doctor
's
study
,
had
made
a
change
in
my
mistrust
.
 
<EOS>
I
believed
that
the
Doctor
was
right
,
and
I
had
no
worse
suspicions
.
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
rubbed
her
nose
sometimes
when
she
happened
to
be
alone
with
me
,
and
said
she
could
n't
make
it
out
;
she
wished
they
were
happier
;
she
did
n't
think
our
military
friend
(
so
she
always
called
the
Old
Soldier
)
<EOS>
mended
the
matter
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
further
expressed
her
opinion
,
"
that
if
our
military
friend
would
cut
off
those
butterflies
,
and
give
'em
to
the
chimney
-
sweepers
for
May
-
day
,
it
would
look
like
the
beginning
of
something
sensible
on
her
part
.
"
   
<EOS>
But
her
abiding
reliance
was
on
Mr
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
That
man
had
evidently
an
idea
in
his
head
,
she
said
;
and
if
he
could
only
once
pen
it
up
into
a
corner
,
which
was
his
great
difficulty
,
he
would
distinguish
himself
in
some
extraordinary
manner
.
   
<EOS>
Unconscious
of
this
prediction
,
Mr
Dick
continued
to
occupy
precisely
the
same
ground
in
reference
to
the
Doctor
and
to
Mrs
Strong
.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
neither
to
advance
nor
to
recede
.
 
<EOS>
He
appeared
to
have
settled
into
his
original
foundation
,
like
a
building
;
and
I
must
confess
that
my
faith
in
his
ever
Moving
,
was
not
much
greater
than
if
he
had
been
a
building
.
   
<EOS>
But
one
night
,
when
I
had
been
married
some
months
,
Mr
Dick
put
his
head
into
the
parlour
,
where
I
was
writing
alone
<EOS>
(
Dora
having
gone
out
with
my
aunt
to
take
tea
with
the
two
little
birds
)
,
and
said
,
with
a
significant
cough
:
   
<EOS>
"
You
could
n't
speak
to
me
without
inconveniencing
yourself
,
Trotwood
,
I
am
afraid
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
Mr
Dick
,
"
said
I
;
"
come
in
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Trotwood
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
laying
his
finger
on
the
side
of
his
nose
,
after
he
had
shaken
hands
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
Before
I
sit
down
,
I
wish
to
make
an
observation
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
your
aunt
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
little
,
"
I
replied
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
is
the
most
wonderful
woman
in
the
world
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
After
the
delivery
of
this
communication
,
which
he
shot
out
of
himself
as
if
he
were
loaded
with
it
,
Mr
Dick
sat
down
with
greater
gravity
than
usual
,
and
looked
at
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
boy
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
"
I
am
going
to
put
a
question
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
many
as
you
please
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
consider
me
,
sir
?
"
asked
Mr
Dick
,
folding
his
arms
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
dear
old
friend
,
"
said
I.
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Trotwood
,
"
returned
Mr
Dick
,
laughing
,
and
reaching
across
in
high
glee
to
shake
hands
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
mean
,
boy
,
"
resuming
his
gravity
<EOS>
,
"
what
do
you
consider
me
in
this
respect
?
"
touching
his
forehead
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
puzzled
how
to
answer
,
but
he
helped
me
with
a
word
.
   
<EOS>
"
Weak
?
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
I
replied
,
dubiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Rather
so
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Exactly
!
"
cried
Mr
Dick
,
who
seemed
quite
enchanted
by
my
reply
.
<EOS>
"
That
is
,
Trotwood
,
when
they
took
some
of
the
trouble
out
of
you
-
know
-
who
's
head
,
and
put
it
you
know
where
,
there
was
a
---
"
Mr
Dick
made
his
two
hands
revolve
very
fast
about
each
other
a
great
number
of
times
,
and
then
brought
them
into
collision
,
and
rolled
them
over
and
over
one
another
,
to
express
confusion
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
was
that
sort
of
thing
done
to
me
somehow
.
 
<EOS>
Eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
nodded
at
him
,
and
he
nodded
back
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
short
,
boy
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
dropping
his
voice
to
a
whisper
,
"
I
am
simple
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
would
have
qualified
that
conclusion
,
but
he
stopped
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
am
!
 
<EOS>
She
pretends
I
am
not
.
 
<EOS>
She
wo
n't
hear
of
it
;
but
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
If
she
had
n't
stood
my
friend
,
sir
,
I
should
have
been
shut
up
,
to
lead
a
dismal
life
these
many
years
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
'll
provide
for
her
!
 
<EOS>
I
never
spend
the
copying
money
.
 
<EOS>
I
put
it
in
a
box
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
made
a
will
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
leave
it
all
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
shall
be
rich
---
noble
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
took
out
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
and
wiped
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
folded
it
up
with
great
care
,
pressed
it
smooth
between
his
two
hands
,
put
it
in
his
pocket
,
and
seemed
to
put
my
aunt
away
with
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
you
are
a
scholar
,
Trotwood
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
fine
scholar
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
what
a
learned
man
,
what
a
great
man
,
the
Doctor
is
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
what
honour
he
has
always
done
me
.
 
<EOS>
Not
proud
in
his
wisdom
.
 
<EOS>
Humble
,
humble
<EOS>
---
condescending
even
to
poor
Dick
,
who
is
simple
and
knows
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
sent
his
name
up
,
on
a
scrap
of
paper
,
to
the
kite
,
along
the
string
,
when
it
has
been
in
the
sky
,
among
the
larks
.
 
<EOS>
The
kite
has
been
glad
to
receive
it
,
sir
,
and
the
sky
has
been
brighter
with
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
delighted
him
by
saying
,
most
heartily
,
that
the
Doctor
was
deserving
of
our
best
respect
and
highest
esteem
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
his
beautiful
wife
is
a
star
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
shining
star
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
seen
her
shine
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
"
bringing
his
chair
nearer
,
and
laying
one
hand
upon
my
knee
---
"
clouds
,
sir
---
clouds
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
answered
the
solicitude
which
his
face
expressed
,
by
conveying
the
same
expression
into
my
own
,
and
shaking
my
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
clouds
?
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
   
<EOS>
He
looked
so
wistfully
into
my
face
,
and
was
so
anxious
to
understand
,
that
I
took
great
pains
to
answer
him
slowly
and
distinctly
,
as
I
might
have
entered
on
an
explanation
to
a
child
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
some
unfortunate
division
between
them
,
"
I
replied
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Some
unhappy
cause
of
separation
.
 
<EOS>
A
secret
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
inseparable
from
the
discrepancy
in
their
years
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
have
grown
up
out
of
almost
nothing
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
,
who
had
told
off
every
sentence
with
a
thoughtful
nod
,
paused
when
I
had
done
,
and
sat
considering
,
with
his
eyes
upon
my
face
,
and
his
hand
upon
my
knee
.
   
<EOS>
"
Doctor
not
angry
with
her
,
Trotwood
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
after
some
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
Devoted
to
her
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
I
have
got
it
,
boy
!
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
   
<EOS>
The
sudden
exultation
with
which
he
slapped
me
on
the
knee
,
and
leaned
back
in
his
chair
,
with
his
eyebrows
lifted
up
as
high
as
he
could
possibly
lift
them
,
made
me
think
him
farther
out
of
his
wits
than
ever
.
 
<EOS>
He
became
as
suddenly
grave
again
,
and
leaning
forward
as
before
,
said
---
first
respectfully
taking
out
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
as
if
it
really
did
represent
my
aunt
:
   
<EOS>
"
Most
wonderful
woman
in
the
world
,
Trotwood
.
 
<EOS>
Why
has
she
done
nothing
to
set
things
right
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Too
delicate
and
difficult
a
subject
for
such
interference
<EOS>
,
"
I
replied
.
   
<EOS>
"
Fine
scholar
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
touching
me
with
his
finger
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
has
HE
done
nothing
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
For
the
same
reason
,
"
I
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
,
I
have
got
it
,
boy
!
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
stood
up
before
me
,
more
exultingly
than
before
,
nodding
his
head
,
and
striking
himself
repeatedly
upon
the
breast
,
until
one
might
have
supposed
that
he
had
nearly
nodded
and
struck
all
the
breath
out
of
his
body
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
poor
fellow
with
a
craze
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
"
a
simpleton
,
a
weak
-
minded
person
---
present
company
,
you
know
!
<EOS>
"
striking
himself
again
,
"
may
do
what
wonderful
people
may
not
do
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
bring
them
together
,
boy
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
try
.
 
<EOS>
They
'll
not
blame
me
.
 
<EOS>
They
'll
not
object
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
They
'll
not
mind
what
I
do
,
if
it
's
wrong
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
only
Mr
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
And
who
minds
Dick
?
 
<EOS>
Dick
's
nobody
!
 
<EOS>
Whoo
!
"
<EOS>
He
blew
a
slight
,
contemptuous
breath
,
as
if
he
blew
himself
away
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
fortunate
he
had
proceeded
so
far
with
his
mystery
,
for
we
heard
the
coach
stop
at
the
little
garden
gate
,
which
brought
my
aunt
and
Dora
home
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
word
,
boy
!
"
he
pursued
in
a
whisper
;
"
leave
all
the
blame
with
Dick
---
simple
Dick
---
mad
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
thinking
,
sir
,
for
some
time
,
that
I
was
getting
it
,
and
now
I
have
got
it
.
 
<EOS>
After
what
you
have
said
to
me
,
I
am
sure
I
have
got
it
.
 
<EOS>
All
right
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not
another
word
did
Mr
Dick
utter
on
the
subject
;
but
he
made
a
very
telegraph
of
himself
for
the
next
half
-
hour
(
to
the
great
disturbance
of
my
aunt
's
mind
)
,
to
enjoin
inviolable
secrecy
on
me
.
   
<EOS>
To
my
surprise
,
I
heard
no
more
about
it
for
some
two
or
three
weeks
,
though
I
was
sufficiently
interested
in
the
result
of
his
endeavours
;
descrying
a
strange
gleam
of
good
sense
---
I
say
nothing
of
good
feeling
,
for
that
he
always
exhibited
---
in
the
conclusion
to
which
he
had
come
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
I
began
to
believe
,
that
,
in
the
flighty
and
unsettled
state
of
his
mind
,
he
had
either
forgotten
his
intention
or
abandoned
it
.
   
<EOS>
One
fair
evening
,
when
Dora
was
not
inclined
to
go
out
,
my
aunt
and
I
strolled
up
to
the
Doctor
's
cottage
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
autumn
,
when
there
were
no
debates
to
vex
the
evening
air
;
and
I
remember
how
the
leaves
smelt
like
our
garden
at
Blunderstone
as
we
trod
them
under
foot
,
and
how
the
old
,
unhappy
feeling
,
seemed
to
go
by
,
on
the
sighing
wind
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
twilight
when
we
reached
the
cottage
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Strong
was
just
coming
out
of
the
garden
,
where
Mr
Dick
yet
lingered
,
busy
with
his
knife
,
helping
the
gardener
to
point
some
stakes
.
 
<EOS>
The
Doctor
was
engaged
with
someone
in
his
study
;
but
the
visitor
would
be
gone
directly
,
Mrs
Strong
said
,
and
begged
us
to
remain
and
see
him
.
 
<EOS>
We
went
into
the
drawing
-
room
with
her
,
and
sat
down
by
the
darkening
window
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
never
any
ceremony
about
the
visits
of
such
old
friends
and
neighbours
as
we
were
.
   
<EOS>
We
had
not
sat
here
many
minutes
,
when
Mrs
Markleham
,
who
usually
contrived
to
be
in
a
fuss
about
something
,
came
bustling
in
,
with
her
newspaper
in
her
hand
,
and
said
,
out
of
breath
,
"
My
goodness
gracious
,
Annie
<EOS>
,
why
did
n't
you
tell
me
there
was
someone
in
the
Study
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
mama
,
"
she
quietly
returned
,
"
how
could
I
know
that
you
desired
the
information
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Desired
the
information
!
"
said
Mrs
Markleham
,
sinking
on
the
sofa
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
had
such
a
turn
in
all
my
life
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
been
to
the
Study
,
then
,
mama
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Annie
.
   
<EOS>
"
BEEN
to
the
Study
,
my
dear
!
"
<EOS>
she
returned
emphatically
.
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
I
have
!
 
<EOS>
I
came
upon
the
amiable
creature
---
if
you
'll
imagine
my
feelings
,
Miss
Trotwood
and
David
---
in
the
act
of
making
his
will
.
"
   
<EOS>
Her
daughter
looked
round
from
the
window
quickly
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
act
,
my
dear
Annie
,
"
repeated
Mrs
Markleham
,
spreading
the
newspaper
on
her
lap
like
a
table
-
cloth
,
and
patting
her
hands
upon
it
,
"
of
making
his
last
Will
and
Testament
.
 
<EOS>
The
foresight
and
affection
of
the
dear
!
 
<EOS>
I
must
tell
you
how
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
really
must
,
in
justice
to
the
darling
---
for
he
is
nothing
less
!
<EOS>
---
tell
you
how
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
know
,
Miss
Trotwood
,
that
there
is
never
a
candle
lighted
in
this
house
,
until
one
's
eyes
are
literally
falling
out
of
one
's
head
with
being
stretched
to
read
the
paper
.
<EOS>
And
that
there
is
not
a
chair
in
this
house
,
in
which
a
paper
can
be
what
I
call
,
read
,
except
one
in
the
Study
.
 
<EOS>
This
took
me
to
the
Study
,
where
I
saw
a
light
.
 
<EOS>
I
opened
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
In
company
with
the
dear
Doctor
were
two
professional
people
,
evidently
connected
with
the
law
,
and
they
were
all
three
standing
at
the
table
:
the
darling
Doctor
pen
in
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
simply
expresses
then
,
"
said
the
Doctor
---
Annie
,
my
love
,
attend
to
the
very
words
---
<EOS>
"
this
simply
expresses
then
,
gentlemen
,
the
confidence
I
have
in
Mrs
Strong
,
and
gives
her
all
unconditionally
?
<EOS>
"
One
of
the
professional
people
replied
,
"
And
gives
her
all
unconditionally
.
"
<EOS>
Upon
that
,
with
the
natural
feelings
of
a
mother
,
I
said
,
"
Good
God
,
I
beg
your
pardon
!
"
<EOS>
fell
over
the
door
-
step
,
and
came
away
through
the
little
back
passage
where
the
pantry
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Strong
opened
the
window
,
and
went
out
into
the
verandah
,
where
she
stood
leaning
against
a
pillar
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
now
is
n't
it
,
Miss
Trotwood
,
is
n't
it
,
David
,
invigorating
,
"
said
Mrs
Markleham
,
mechanically
following
her
with
her
eyes
,
"
to
find
a
man
at
Doctor
Strong
's
time
of
life
,
with
the
strength
of
mind
to
do
this
kind
of
thing
?
 
<EOS>
It
only
shows
how
right
I
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
to
Annie
,
when
Doctor
Strong
paid
a
very
flattering
visit
to
myself
,
and
made
her
the
subject
of
a
declaration
and
an
offer
,
I
said
,
"
My
dear
,
there
is
no
doubt
whatever
,
in
my
opinion
,
with
reference
to
a
suitable
provision
for
you
,
that
Doctor
Strong
will
do
more
than
he
binds
himself
to
do
.
"
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Here
the
bell
rang
,
and
we
heard
the
sound
of
the
visitors
'
feet
as
they
went
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
over
,
no
doubt
,
"
said
the
Old
Soldier
,
after
listening
;
"
the
dear
creature
has
signed
,
sealed
,
and
delivered
,
and
his
mind
's
at
rest
.
 
<EOS>
Well
it
may
be
!
 
<EOS>
What
a
mind
!
 
<EOS>
Annie
,
my
love
,
I
am
going
to
the
Study
with
my
paper
,
for
I
am
a
poor
creature
without
news
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Trotwood
,
David
,
pray
come
and
see
the
Doctor
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
conscious
of
Mr
Dick
's
standing
in
the
shadow
of
the
room
,
shutting
up
his
knife
,
when
we
accompanied
her
to
the
Study
;
and
of
my
aunt
's
rubbing
her
nose
violently
,
by
the
way
,
as
a
mild
vent
for
her
intolerance
of
our
military
friend
;
but
who
got
first
into
the
Study
,
or
how
Mrs
Markleham
settled
herself
in
a
moment
in
her
easy
-
chair
,
or
how
my
aunt
and
I
came
to
be
left
together
near
the
door
(
unless
her
eyes
were
quicker
than
mine
,
and
she
held
me
back
)
<EOS>
,
I
have
forgotten
,
if
I
ever
knew
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
I
know
,
---
that
we
saw
the
Doctor
before
he
saw
us
,
sitting
at
his
table
,
among
the
folio
volumes
in
which
he
delighted
,
resting
his
head
calmly
on
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
That
,
in
the
same
moment
,
we
saw
Mrs
Strong
glide
in
,
pale
and
trembling
.
 
<EOS>
That
Mr
Dick
supported
her
on
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
That
he
laid
his
other
hand
upon
the
Doctor
's
arm
,
causing
him
to
look
up
with
an
abstracted
air
.
 
<EOS>
That
,
as
the
Doctor
moved
his
head
,
his
wife
dropped
down
on
one
knee
at
his
feet
,
and
,
with
her
hands
imploringly
lifted
,
fixed
upon
his
face
the
memorable
look
I
had
never
forgotten
.
 
<EOS>
That
at
this
sight
Mrs
Markleham
dropped
the
newspaper
,
and
stared
more
like
a
figure
-
head
intended
for
a
ship
to
be
called
The
Astonishment
,
than
anything
else
I
can
think
of
.
   
<EOS>
The
gentleness
of
the
Doctor
's
manner
and
surprise
,
the
dignity
that
mingled
with
the
supplicating
attitude
of
his
wife
,
the
amiable
concern
of
Mr
Dick
,
and
the
earnestness
with
which
my
aunt
said
to

,
"
That
man
mad
!
"
<EOS>
(
triumphantly
expressive
of
the
misery
from
which
she
had
saved
him
)
---
I
see
and
hear
,
rather
than
remember
,
as
I
write
about
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Doctor
!
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
that
's
amiss
?
 
<EOS>
Look
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Annie
!
"
cried
the
Doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
at
my
feet
,
my
dear
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
beg
and
pray
that
no
one
will
leave
the
room
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
husband
and
father
,
break
this
long
silence
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
both
know
what
it
is
that
has
come
between
us
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Markleham
,
by
this
time
recovering
the
power
of
speech
,
and
seeming
to
swell
with
family

and

,
here

,
"
Annie
,
get
up

,
and
do

everybody

you
by
humbling
yourself
like
that
,
unless
you
wish
to
see
me
go
out
of
my
mind
on

spot
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mama
!
"
returned
Annie
.
 
<EOS>
"
Waste
no
words
on
me
,
for
my
appeal
is
to
my
husband
,
and
even
you
are
nothing
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
!
"
exclaimed
Mrs
Markleham
.
 
<EOS>
"
Me
,
nothing
!
<EOS>
The
child
has
taken
leave
of
her

.
 
<EOS>
Please
to
get
me
a
glass

water
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
too
attentive
to
the
Doctor
and
his
wife
,
to
give
any

to
this
request
;
and
it
made
no
impression
on
anybody
else
;
so
Mrs
Markleham
panted
,
stared
,
and
fanned

.
   
<EOS>
"
Annie
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
Doctor
,
tenderly
taking
her
in
his
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
!
 
<EOS>
If
any
unavoidable
change
has
come
,
in
the
sequence
of
time
,
upon
our
married
life
,
you
are
not
to
blame
.
 
<EOS>
The
fault
is
mine
,
and
only
mine
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
change
in
my
affection
,
admiration
,
and
respect
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
to
make
you
happy
.
 
<EOS>
I
truly
love
and
honour
you
.
<EOS>
Rise
,
Annie
,
pray
!
"
   
<EOS>
But
she
did
not
rise
.
 
<EOS>
After
looking
at
him
for
a
little
while
,
she
sank
down
closer
to
him
,
laid
her
arm
across
his
knee
,
and
dropping
her
head
upon
it
,
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
If
I
have
any
friend
here
,
who
can
speak
one
word
for
me
,
or
for
my
husband
in
this
matter
;
if
I
have
any
friend
here
,
who
can
give
a
voice
to
any
suspicion
that
my
heart
has
sometimes
whispered
to
me
;
if
I
have
any
friend
here
,
who
honours
my
husband
,
or
has
ever
cared
for
me
,
and
has
anything
within
his
knowledge
,
no
matter
what
it
is
,
that
may
help
to
mediate
between
us
,
I
implore
that
friend
to
speak
!
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
profound
silence
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
few
moments
of
painful
hesitation
,
I
broke
the
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Strong
,
"
I
said
,
"
there
is
something
within
my
knowledge
,
which
I
have
been
earnestly
entreated
by
Doctor
Strong
to
conceal
,
and
have
concealed
until
tonight
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
I
believe
the
time
has
come
when
it
would
be
mistaken
faith
and
delicacy
to
conceal
it
any
longer
,
and
when
your
appeal
absolves
me
from
his
injunction
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
She
turned
her
face
towards
me
for
a
moment
,
and
I
knew
that
I
was
right
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
have
resisted
its
entreaty
,
if
the
assurance
that
it
gave
me
had
been
less
convincing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Our
future
peace
,
"
she
said
,
"
may
be
in
your
hands
.
 
<EOS>
I
trust
it
confidently
to
your
not
suppressing
anything
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
beforehand
that
nothing
you
,
or
anyone
,
can
tell
me
,
will
show
my
husband
's
noble
heart
in
any
other
light
than
one
.
 
<EOS>
Howsoever
<EOS>
it
may
seem
to
you
to
touch
me
,
disregard
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
speak
for
myself
,
before
him
,
and
before
God
afterwards
.
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
earnestly
besought
,
I
made
no
reference
to
the
Doctor
for
his
permission
,
but
,
without
any
other
compromise
of
the
truth
than
a
little
softening
of
the
coarseness
of
Uriah
Heep
,
related
plainly
what
had
passed
in
that
same
room
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
The
staring
of
Mrs
Markleham
during
the
whole
narration
,
and
the
shrill
,
sharp
interjections
with
which
she
occasionally
interrupted
it
,
defy
description
.
   
<EOS>
When
I
had
finished
,
Annie
remained
,
for
some
few
moments
,
silent
,
with
her
head
bent
down
,
as
I
have
described
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
she
took
the
Doctor
's
hand
(
he
was
sitting
in
the
same
attitude
as
when
we
had
entered
the
room
)
,
and
pressed
it
to
her
breast
,
and
kissed
it
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
softly
raised
her
;
and
she
stood
,
when
she
began
to
speak
,
leaning
on
him
,
and
looking
down
upon
her
husband
---
from
whom
she
never
turned
her
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
that
has
ever
been
in
my
mind
,
since
I
was
married
,
"
she
said
in
a
low
,
submissive
,
tender
voice
,
"
I
will
lay
bare
before
you
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
live
and
have
one
reservation
,
knowing
what
I
know
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
Annie
,
"
said
the
Doctor
,
mildly
,
"
I
have
never
doubted
you
,
my
child
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
need
;
indeed
there
is
no
need
,
my
dear
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
great
need
,
"
she
answered
,
in
the
same
way
,
"
that
I
should
open
my
whole
heart
before
the
soul
of
generosity
and
truth
,
whom
,
year
by
year
,
and
day
by
day
,
I
have
loved
and
venerated
more
and
more
,
as
Heaven
knows
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Really
,
"
interrupted
Mrs
Markleham
,
"
if
I
have
any
discretion
at
all
---
"
   
(
"
Which
you
have
n't
,
you
Marplot
,
"
observed
my
aunt
,
in
an
indignant
whisper
.
)
   
<EOS>
---
"
I
must
be
permitted
to
observe
that
it
can
not
be
requisite
to
enter
into
these
details
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
one
but
my
husband
can
judge
of
that
,
mama
,
"
said
Annie
without
removing
her
eyes
from
his
face
,
"
and
he
will
hear
me
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
say
anything
to
give
you
pain
,
mama
,
forgive
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
borne
pain
first
,
often
and
long
,
myself
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
!
"
gasped
Mrs
Markleham
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
was
very
young
,
"
said
Annie
,
"
quite
a
little
child
,
<EOS>
my
first
associations
with
knowledge
of
any
kind
were
inseparable
from
a
patient
friend
and
teacher
---
the
friend
of
my
dead
father
---
who
was
always
dear
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
remember
nothing
that
I
know
,
without
remembering
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
stored
my
mind
with
its
first
treasures
,
and
stamped
his
character
upon
them
all
.
 
<EOS>
They
never
could
have
been
,
I
think
,
as
good
as
they
have
been
to
me
,
if
I
had
taken
them
from
any
other
hands
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Makes
her
mother
nothing
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Mrs
Markleham
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
so
mama
,
"
said
Annie
;
"
but
I
make
him
what
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
do
that
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
grew
up
,
he
occupied
the
same
place
still
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
proud
of
his
interest
:
<EOS>
deeply
,
fondly
,
gratefully
attached
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
looked
up
to
him
<EOS>
,
I
can
hardly
describe
how
---
as
a
father
,
as
a
guide
,
as
one
whose
praise
was
different
from
all
other
praise
,
as
one
in
whom
I
could
have
trusted
and
confided
,
if
I
had
doubted
all
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
,
mama
,
how
young
and
inexperienced
<EOS>
I
was
,
when
you
presented
him
before
me
,
of
a
sudden
,
as
a
lover
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
mentioned
the
fact
,
fifty
times
at
least
,
to
everybody
here
!
"
said
Mrs
Markleham
.
   
<EOS>
(
"
Then
hold
your
tongue
,
for
the
Lord
's
sake
,
and
do
n't
mention
it
any
more
!
"
<EOS>
muttered
my
aunt
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
so
great
a
change
:
so
great
a
loss
,
I
felt
it
,
at
first
,
"
said
Annie
,
still
preserving
the
same
look
and
tone
,
"
that
I
was
agitated
and
distressed
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
but
a
girl
;
and
when
so
great
a
change
came
in
the
character
in
which
I
had
so
long
looked
up
to
him
,
I
think
I
was
sorry
.
 
<EOS>
But
nothing
could
have
made
him
what
he
used
to
be
again
;
and
I
was
proud
that
he
should
think
me
so
worthy
,
and
we
were
married
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
---
At
Saint
Alphage
,
Canterbury
,
"
observed
Mrs
Markleham
.
   
<EOS>
(
"
Confound
the
woman
!
"
<EOS>
said
my
aunt
,
"
she
WON'T
be
quiet
!
"
)
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
thought
,
"
proceeded
Annie
,
with
a
heightened
colour
,
"
of
any
worldly
gain
that
my
husband
would
bring
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
My
young
heart
had
no
room
in
its
homage
for
any
such
poor
reference
.
 
<EOS>
Mama
,
forgive
me
when
I
say
that
it
was
you
who
first
presented
to
my
mind
the
thought
that
anyone
could
wrong
me
,
and
wrong
him
,
by
such
a
cruel
suspicion
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Me
!
"
cried
Mrs
Markleham
.
   
<EOS>
(
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
You
,
to
be
sure
!
<EOS>
"
observed
my
aunt
,
"
and
you
ca
n't
fan
it
away
,
my
military
friend
!
"
<EOS>
)
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
the
first
unhappiness
of
my
new
life
,
"
said
Annie
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
the
first
occasion
of
every
unhappy
moment
I
have
known
.
 
<EOS>
These
moments
have
been
more
,
of
late
,
than
I
can
count
;
but
not
---
my
generous
husband
!
<EOS>
---
not
for
the
reason
you
suppose
;
for
in
my
heart
there
is
not
a
thought
,
a
recollection
,
or
a
hope
,
that
any
power
could
separate
from
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
raised
her
eyes
,
and
clasped
her
hands
,
and
looked
as
beautiful
and
true
,
I
thought
,
as
any
Spirit
.
 
<EOS>
The
Doctor
looked
on
her
,
henceforth
,
as
steadfastly
as
she
on
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mama
is
blameless
,
"
she
went
on
,
"
of
having
ever
urged
you
for
herself
,
and
she
is
blameless
in
intention
every
way
,
I
am
sure
,
---
but
when
I
saw
how
many
importunate
claims
were
pressed
upon
you
in
my
name
;
how
you
were
traded
on
in
my
name
;
how
generous
you
were
,
and
how
Mr
Wickfield
,
who
had
your
welfare
very
much
at
heart
,
resented
it
;
the
first
sense
of
my
exposure
to
the
mean
suspicion
that
my
tenderness
was
bought
---
and
sold
to
you
,
of
all
men
on
earth
---
fell
upon
me
like
unmerited
disgrace
,
in
which
I
forced
you
to
participate
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
tell
you
what
it
was
<EOS>
---
mama
can
not
imagine
what
it
was
---
to
have
this
dread
and
trouble
always
on
my
mind
,
yet
know
in
my
own
soul
that
on
my
marriage
-
day
I
crowned
the
love
and
honour
of
my
life
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
specimen
of
the
thanks
one
gets
,
"
cried
Mrs
Markleham
,
in
tears
,
"
for
taking
care
of
one
's
family
!
 
<EOS>
I
wish
I
was
a
Turk
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
(
"
I
wish
you
were
,
with
all
my
heart
---
and
in
your
native
country
!
"
said
my
aunt
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
at
that
time
that
mama
was
most
solicitous
about
my
Cousin
Maldon
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
liked
him
"
:
she
spoke
softly
,
but
without
any
hesitation
:
"
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
been
little
lovers
once
.
 
<EOS>
If
circumstances
had
not
happened
otherwise
,
I
might
have
come
to
persuade
myself
that
I
really
loved
him
,
and
might
have
married
him
,
and
been
most
wretched
.
 
<EOS>
There
can
be
no
disparity
in
marriage
like
unsuitability
of
mind
and
purpose
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
pondered
on
those
words
,
even
while
I
was
studiously
attending
to
what
followed
,
as
if
they
had
some
particular
interest
,
or
some
strange
application
that
I
could
not
divine
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
can
be
no
disparity
in
marriage
like
unsuitability
of
mind
and
purpose
"
<EOS>
---
"
no
disparity
in
marriage
like
unsuitability
of
mind
and
purpose
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
,
"
said
Annie
,
"
that
we
have
in
common
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
long
found
that
there
is
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
were
thankful
to
my
husband
for
no
more
,
instead
of
for
so
much
,
I
should
be
thankful
to
him
for
having
saved
me
from
the
first
mistaken
impulse
of
my
undisciplined
heart
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
stood
quite
still
,
before
the
Doctor
,
and
spoke
with
an
earnestness
that
thrilled
me
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
her
voice
was
just
as
quiet
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
he
was
waiting
to
be
the
object
of
your
munificence
,
so
freely
bestowed
for
my
sake
,
and
when
I
was
unhappy
in
the
mercenary
shape
I
was
made
to
wear
,
I
thought
it
would
have
become
him
better
to
have
worked
his
own
way
on
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
that
if
I
had
been
he
,
I
would
have
tried
to
do
it
,
at
the
cost
of
almost
any
hardship
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
thought
no
worse
of
him
,
until
the
night
of
his
departure
for
India
.
 
<EOS>
That
night
I
knew
he
had
a
false
and
thankless
heart
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
a
double
meaning
,
then
,
in
Mr
Wickfield
's
scrutiny
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
perceived
,
for
the
first
time
,
the
dark
suspicion
that
shadowed
my
life
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Suspicion
,
Annie
!
"
said
the
Doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
no
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
your
mind
there
was
none
,
I
know
,
my
husband
!
"
<EOS>
she
returned
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
when
I
came
to
you
,
that
night
,
to
lay
down
all
my
load
of
shame
and
grief
,
and
knew
that
I
had
to
tell
that
,
underneath
your
roof
,
one
of
my
own
kindred
,
to
whom
you
had
been
a
benefactor
,
for
the
love
of
me
,
had
spoken
to
me
words
that
should
have
found
no
utterance
,
even
if
I
had
been
the
weak
and
mercenary
wretch
he
thought
me
---
my
mind
revolted
from
the
taint
the
very
tale
conveyed
.
 
<EOS>
It
died
upon
my
lips
,
and
from
that
hour
till
now
has
never
passed
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Markleham
,
with
a
short
groan
,
leaned
back
in
her
easy
-
chair
;
and
retired
behind
her
fan
,
as
if
she
were
never
coming
out
any
more
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
,
but
in
your
presence
,
interchanged
a
word
with
him
from
that
time
;
then
,
only
when
it
has
been
necessary
for
the
avoidance
of
this
explanation
.
 
<EOS>
Years
have
passed
since
he
knew
,
from
me
,
what
his
situation
here
was
.
 
<EOS>
The
kindnesses
you
have
secretly
done
for
his
advancement
,
and
then
disclosed
to
me
,
for
my
surprise
and
pleasure
,
have
been
,
you
will
believe
,
but
aggravations
of
the
unhappiness
and
burden
of
my
secret
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
sunk
down
gently
at
the
Doctor
's
feet
,
though
he
did
his
utmost
to
prevent
her
;
and
said
,
looking
up
,
tearfully
,
into
his
face
:
   
<EOS>
"
Do
not
speak
to
me
yet
!
 
<EOS>
Let
me
say
a
little
more
!
 
<EOS>
Right
or
wrong
,
if
this
were
to
be
done
again
,
I
think
I
should
do
just
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
You
never
can
know
what
it
was
to
be
devoted
to
you
,
with
those
old
associations
;
to
find
that
anyone
could
be
so
hard
as
to
suppose
that
the
truth
of
my
heart
was
bartered
away
,
and
to
be
surrounded
by
appearances
confirming
that
belief
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
very
young
,
and
had
no
adviser
.
 
<EOS>
Between
mama
and
me
,
in
all
relating
to
you
,
there
was
a
wide
division
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
shrunk
into
myself
,
hiding
the
disrespect
I
had
undergone
,
it
was
because
I
honoured
you
so
much
,
and
so
much
wished
that
you
should
honour
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Annie
,
my
pure
heart
!
"
said
the
Doctor
,
"
my
dear
girl
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
little
more
!
<EOS>
a
very
few
words
more
!
 
<EOS>
I
used
to
think
there
were
so
many
whom
you
might
have
married
,
who
would
not
have
brought
such
charge
and
trouble
on
you
,
and
who
would
have
made
your
home
a
worthier
home
.
 
<EOS>
I
used
to
be
afraid
that
I
had
better
have
remained
your
pupil
,
and
almost
your
child
.
 
<EOS>
I
used
to
fear
that
I
was
so
unsuited
to
your
learning
and
wisdom
.
 
<EOS>
If
all
this
made
me
shrink
within
myself
(
as
indeed
it
did
)
,
when
I
had
that
to
tell
,
it
was
still
because
I
honoured
you
so
much
,
and
hoped
that
you
might
one
day
honour
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
day
has
shone
this
long
time
,
Annie
,
"
said
the
Doctor
,
"
and
can
have
but
<EOS>
one
long
night
,
my
dear
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Another
word
!
 
<EOS>
I
afterwards
meant
---
steadfastly
meant
,
and
purposed
to
myself
---
to
bear
the
whole
weight
of
knowing
the
unworthiness
of
one
to
whom
you
had
been
so
good
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
a
last
word
,
dearest
and
best
of
friends
!
 
<EOS>
The
cause
of
the
late
change
in
you
,
which
I
have
seen
with
so
much
pain
and
sorrow
,
and
have
sometimes
referred
to
my
old
apprehension
---
at
other
times
to
lingering
suppositions
nearer
to
the
truth
---
has
been
made
clear
tonight
;
and
by
an
accident
I
have
also
come
to
know
,
tonight
,
the
full
measure
of
your
noble
trust
in
me
,
even
under
that
mistake
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
hope
that
any
love
and
duty
I
may
render
in
return
,
will
ever
make
me
worthy
of
your
priceless
confidence
;
but
with
all
this
knowledge
fresh
upon
me
,
I
can
lift
my
eyes
to
this
dear
face
,
revered
as
a
father
's
,
loved
as
a
husband
's
,
sacred
to
me
in
my
childhood
as
a
friend
's
,
and
solemnly
declare
that
in
my
lightest
thought
I
have
never
wronged
you
;
never
wavered
in
the
love
and
the
fidelity
I
owe
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
had
her
arms
around
the
Doctor
's
neck
,
and
he
leant
his
head
down
over
her
,
mingling
his
grey
hair
with
her
dark
brown
tresses
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
hold
me
to
your
heart
,
my
husband
!
 
<EOS>
Never
cast
me
out
!
 
<EOS>
Do
not
think
or
speak
of
disparity
between
us
,
for
there
is
none
,
except
in
all
my
many
imperfections
.
 
<EOS>
Every
succeeding
year
I
have
known
this
better
,
as
I
have
esteemed
you
more
and
more
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
take
me
to
your
heart
,
my
husband
,
for
my
love
was
founded
on
a
rock
,
and
it
endures
!
"
   
<EOS>
In
the
silence
that
ensued
,
my
aunt
walked
gravely
up
to
Mr
Dick
,
without
at
all
hurrying
herself
,
and
gave
him
a
hug
and
a
sounding
kiss
.
 
<EOS>
And
it
was
very
fortunate
,
with
a
view
to
his
credit
,
that
she
did
so
<EOS>
;
for
I
am
confident
that
I
detected
him
at
that
moment
in
the
act
of
making
preparations
to
stand
on
one
leg
,
as
an
appropriate
expression
of
delight
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
very
remarkable
man
,
Dick
!
"
said
my
aunt
,
with
an
air
of
unqualified
approbation
;
"
and
never
pretend
to
be
anything
else
,
for
I
know
better
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
that
,
my
aunt
pulled
him
by
the
sleeve
,
and
nodded
to
me
;
and
we
three
stole
quietly
out
of
the
room
,
and
came
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
settler
for
our
military
friend
,
at
any
rate
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
on
the
way
home
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
sleep
the
better
for
that
,
if
there
was
nothing
else
to
be
glad
of
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
was
quite
overcome
,
I
am
afraid
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
with
great
commiseration
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
Did
you
ever
see
a
crocodile
overcome
?
"
inquired
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
I
ever
saw
a
crocodile
,
"
returned
Mr
Dick
,
mildly
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
never
would
have
been
anything
the
matter
,
if
it
had
n't
been
for
that
old
Animal
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
with
strong

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
much
to
be
wished
that
some
mothers
would
leave
their
daughters
alone
after

,
and
not

.
 
<EOS>
They
seem

think
the
only

that
can

for

an

young
woman
into

---
God

,
as

,
or
wanted

!
<EOS>
---
is
full
liberty
to

her
out

again
.
 
<EOS>
What
are
you
thinking
of
,
Trot
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
thinking
of
all
that
had
been
said
.
 
<EOS>
My
mind
was
still
running
on
some

the
expressions
used
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
can
be
no
disparity
in
marriage
like
unsuitability
of
mind
and
purpose
.
"
<EOS>
"
The
first
mistaken
impulse
of
an
undisciplined
heart
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
love
was
founded
on
a
rock
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
we
were
at
home
;
and
the
trodden
leaves
were
lying
under
-
foot
,
and
the
autumn
wind
was

.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
46
.
<EOS>
Intelligence
 
<EOS>
I
must
have
been
married
,
if
I
may
trust
to
my
imperfect
memory
for
dates
,
about
a
year
or
so
,
when
one
evening
,
as
I
was
returning
from
a
solitary
walk
,
thinking
of
the
book
I
was
then
writing
---
for
my
success
had
steadily
increased
with
my
steady

,
and
I
was
engaged
at
that
time
upon
my
first
work
of
fiction
---
<EOS>
I
came
past
Mrs
Steerforth
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
often
passed
it
before
,
during
my
residence
in
that
neighbourhood
,
though
never
when
I
could
choose
another
road
.
 
<EOS>
Howbeit
,
it
did
sometimes
happen
that
it
was
not
easy
to
find
another
,
without
making
a
long
circuit
;
and
so
I
had
passed
that
way
,
upon
the
whole
,
pretty
often
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
never
done
more
than
glance
at
the
house
,
as
I
went
by
with
a
quickened
step
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
been
uniformly
gloomy
and
dull
.
 
<EOS>
None
of
the
best
rooms
abutted
on
the
road
;
and
the
narrow
,
heavily
-
framed
old
-
fashioned
windows
,
never
cheerful
under
any
circumstances
,
looked
very
dismal
,
close
shut
,
and
with
their
blinds
always
drawn
down
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
covered
way
across
a
little
paved
court
,
to
an
entrance
that
was
never
used
;
and
there
was
one
round
staircase
window
,
at
odds
with
all
the
rest
,
and
<EOS>
the
only
one
unshaded
by
a
blind
,
which
had
the
same
unoccupied
blank
look
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
remember
that
I
ever
saw
a
light
in
all
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
been
a
casual
passer
-
by
,
I
should
have
probably
supposed
that
some
childless
person
lay
dead
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
happily
possessed
no
knowledge
of
the
place
,
and
had
seen
it
often
in
that
changeless
state
,
I
should
have
pleased
my
fancy
with
many
ingenious
speculations
,
I
dare
say
.
   
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
I
thought
as
little
of
it
as
I
might
.
 
<EOS>
But
my
mind
could
not
go
by
it
and
leave
it
,
as
my
body
did
;
and
it
usually
awakened
a
long
train
of
meditations
.
 
<EOS>
Coming
before
me
,
on
this
particular

that
I
mention
,
mingled

the
childish

and
later

,
the

of
half

,
the
broken

of

dimly
seen

,
the

of
experience

,
incidental

the
occupation
with
which
my

had
been

,
it
was
more
than
commonly

.
<EOS>
I
fell
into
a
brown
study
as
I
walked
on
,
and
a

at
my
side

.
   
<EOS>
It

a
woman
's

,
too
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
long
in

Mrs
Steerforth
's
little
parlour
-
maid
,
who
had
formerly

blue

in

.
 
<EOS>
She

taken

,
to

,

;
and
wore

one

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Has

?
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
tonight
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Miss

a
night

;

I

,

.
 
<EOS>
She
said
her
lady
was
but
poorly
,
and
kept

room
a

.
   
<EOS>
When

house
,
I

to
Miss
Dartle
in

,
and
left

known

her
myself
.
 
<EOS>
She
was

on

one

a
kind

,
overlooking

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a

,
with
a

the

;
and
as

the

in

,
with
here
and

some

,
I

was
no
inapt

to
the
memory
of

.
   
<EOS>
She
saw
me
as
I
advanced
,
and
rose
for

.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
her
,
then
,
still
more
colourless
and
thin
than
when
I
had
seen
her
last
;
the
flashing

still

,
and
the
scar
still
plainer
.
   
<EOS>
Our

was
not

.
 
<EOS>
We
had
parted

on
the

;
and
there

an
air

disdain
about
her
,
which
she
took
no

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
told

,
Miss

,
"

,

,

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Pray

this

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

!
"
   
<EOS>
I
saw
her
thin
lips
working
while
she
looked
at
me
,
as
if
they
were
eager
to
load
her
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
Run

?
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
From

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
If

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

!
"
   
<EOS>
The

met
my
glance
<EOS>
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
To

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
She

,

,

"
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
Do

is

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
<EOS>
I.
   
She

,
and

that

,

!
"
<EOS>
---

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

,
Mr

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
I

,
without

;

"
Come

!
"
<EOS>
again

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

:

,
strange

,

,
was

.

"
Now
,
"

,

,

:
perhaps

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Tell

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
James

,

---
"
   
"
Do

!
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
James

,

---
<EOS>
"
   
"
Nor

,

,
"

Mr
Littimer
,

,

,
that
anything
that

most

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
James

have

woman
,

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

,
Italy
,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
He

,
as

;
and
softly

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
James
took

to
the

woman
;
and

more

,
for

,

I

.
 
<EOS>
The
young

was
very

,
and

;
and

n't

-

.
 
<EOS>
I

she
was
much
admired
wherever

.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Dartle
put
her
hand
upon

side
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
him
steal
a

at
her
,
and
slightly

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
much
admired
,
indeed
,
the

woman
was
.
 
<EOS>
What

her

;
<EOS>

;
<EOS>

;

,

,

;
her

really

.
"
   
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
Her

wandered
restlessly
over
the
distant
prospect
,
and
she
bit
her
nether
lip
to
stop
that
busy

.
   
<EOS>
Taking
his
hands
from
the
seat
,
and
placing
one

within

other
,
as
he
settled

on
one

,
Mr
Littimer
proceeded
,
with
his

cast
down
,
and
his
respectable
head
a

,
and
a
little

:
   
<EOS>
"
The
young
woman
went
on
in
this

some

,
being

,
until
I

to
weary
Mr
James
by
giving
way
to
her
low
spirits
and

of
that
kind
;
and
things
were
not
so

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
James
he
began
to
be
restless
again
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
restless
he
got
,
the
worse
she
got
;
and
I
must

,
for
myself
,
that
I

a

of
it

between

.
 
<EOS>
Still
matters
were
patched
up
here
,
and
made
good
there
,
over
and
over
again
;
and
altogether
lasted
,
<EOS>
I
am
sure
,
for
a
longer

than
anybody
could

expected
.
"
   
<EOS>
Recalling

from

distance
,
she

at

,
with
her
former
air
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Littimer
,
clearing
his

behind

,
changed

,

:
   
"
<EOS>
At
last
,
when
there
had
been
,
upon
the
whole
,
a
good
many
words
and

,
Mr
James
he

off
one

,
from
the

of
Naples
,
where
we
had
a
villa
(
the
young
woman
being
very
partial

the

)
,

,

,

,

all

,
he
was
"
---
here
an

the
short

---
"
gone
.
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
James
,
I
must

,
certainly
did
behave
extremely
honourable
;
for
he
proposed
that
the
young
woman

marry
a
very

,
who

fully

,

:
<EOS>
her

being
very
common
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
changed
legs
again
,
and
wetted
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
convinced
that
the
scoundrel
spoke
of
himself
,
and
I
saw
my
conviction
reflected
in
Miss
Dartle
's

.
   
<EOS>
"
This
I
also
had
it
in
charge
to

.
 
<EOS>
I

to

James

,

to
restore

and
an

,

.
 
<EOS>
Therefore

.
 
<EOS>
The

woman
's

when

,
after
I
broke
the

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

;
or
,

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But

,
"

"

,

kind

<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
A

.
 
<EOS>
Her

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

<EOS>
Mr

"
Indeed
,

?
 
<EOS>
But

"

<EOS>
"

that

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Or

!

I

"
<EOS>

"
<EOS>

"

"

.

"

,
"

"

,
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
I

to

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

,

,
"
You

.
 
<EOS>
Consider

<EOS>

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"

,
"

;

,

<EOS>
Miss
Dartle
<EOS>
and

;
her

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He

,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>
Between

,

<EOS>
Neither

;

.
 
<EOS>
This

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
Her

"
Is

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>

"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
You

"

?
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"
   
<EOS>
"

"
she
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
would
have
been
proud
of
you
.
<EOS>
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
took
the
hand
she
held
out
with
a

,
unbending
air
,
and
it
was
as
calm
in

as

her

been

.
 
<EOS>
Her

could
still
its

,
it
appeared
,
and
draw
the
placid

before

,

.
   
<EOS>
As

,
I
could

how
steadily

on
the
prospect
,
and

.
 
<EOS>
Here
and
there
,
some
early

were

to
twinkle
in
the
distant
city
;
and
in
the
eastern

of
the
sky
the
lurid

still
hovered
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
from
the
greater

of
the
broad

interposed
,
a

rising
like

,
which
,
mingling
with
the

,
made

as

would
encompass

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
reason
to
remember
this
,
and
think

with
awe
;
for
before
I

again
,
a

had
risen
to

.
   
<EOS>
Reflecting
on
what
had
been
thus
told
me
,
I
felt

that
it
should
be
communicated
to
Mr
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
following

I

into
London
in

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
always
wandering

from

,
with
his
one

of
recovering
his
niece
before
him
;
but
was
more
in
London
than
elsewhere
.
 
<EOS>
Often
and
often
,
now
,
had
I

in
the
dead

night

along

,
searching
,
among
the
few
who

doors
at
those

,
for
what

.
   
<EOS>
He

a
lodging
over
the
little
chandler
's
shop
in
Hungerford

,
which
I
have

mention
more

,
and
from

he
first

upon

.
 
<EOS>
Hither

.
 
<EOS>
On

that

not

,

.
   
<EOS>
He

he

.
<EOS>
The

was
very

.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
in

that
it
was
always

,
and
that
he
never
went
out
<EOS>
but
he

possible

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
"
Mas'r

!
<EOS>
Thankee
,

!
<EOS>
thankee

!
<EOS>
Sit

.
 
<EOS>
You

"

"

"

"

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Of

!
"
   
<EOS>
He

on

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
We

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
We

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

.
   
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
Once
,
she
stopped
to
listen
to
a
band
of
music
;
and
then
we
stopped
too
.
   
<EOS>
She
went
on
a
long
way
.
 
<EOS>
Still
we
went
on
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
evident
,
from
the
manner
in
which
she
held
her
course
,
that
she
was
going
to
some
fixed
destination
;
and
this
,
and
her
keeping
in
the
busy
streets
,
and
I
suppose
the
strange
fascination
in
the
secrecy
and
mystery
of
so
following
anyone
,
made
me
adhere
to
my
first
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
she
turned
into
a
dull
,
dark
street
,
where
the
noise
and
crowd
were
lost
;
and
I
said
,
"
We
may
speak
to
her
now
"
;
<EOS>
and
,
mending
our
pace
,
we
went
after
her
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
47
.
<EOS>
Martha
 
<EOS>
We
were
now
down
in
Westminster
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
turned
back
to
follow
her
,
having
encountered
her
coming
towards
us
;
and
Westminster
Abbey
was
the
point
at
which
she
passed
from
the
lights
and
noise
of
the
leading
streets
.
 
<EOS>
She
proceeded
so
quickly
,
when
she
got
free
of
the
two
currents
of
passengers
setting
towards
and
from
the
bridge
,
that
,
between
this
and
the
advance
she
had
of
us
when
she
struck
off
,
we
were
in
the
narrow
water
-
side
street
by
Millbank
before
we
came
up
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
At
that
moment
she
crossed
the
road
,
as
if
to
avoid
the
footsteps
that
she
heard
so
close
behind
;
and
,
without
looking
back
,
passed
on
even
more
rapidly
.
   
<EOS>
A
glimpse
of
the
river
through
a
dull
gateway
,
where
some
waggons
were
housed
for
the
night
,
seemed
to
arrest
my
feet
.
 
<EOS>
I
touched
my
companion
without
speaking
,
and
we
both
forbore
to
cross
after
her
,
and
both
followed
on
that
opposite
side
of
the
way
;
keeping
as
quietly
as
we
could
in
the
shadow
of
the
houses
,
but
keeping
very
near
her
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
,
and
is
when
I
write
,
at
the
end
of
that
low
-
lying
street
,
<EOS>
a
dilapidated
little
wooden
building
,
probably
an
obsolete
old
ferry
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
Its
position
is
just
at
that
point
where
the
street
ceases
,
and
the
road
begins
to
lie
between
a
row
of
houses
and
the
river
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
she
came
here
,
and
saw
the
water
,
she
stopped
as
if
she
had
come
to
her
destination
;
and
presently
went
slowly
along
by
the
brink
of
the
river
,
looking
intently
at
it
.
   
<EOS>
All
the
way
here
,
I
had
supposed
that
she
was
going
to
some
house
;
indeed
,
I
had
vaguely
entertained
the
hope
that
the
house
might
be
in
some
way
associated
with
the
lost
girl
.
 
<EOS>
But
that
one
dark
glimpse
of
the
river
,
through
the
gateway
,
had
instinctively
prepared
me
for
her
going
no
farther
.
   
<EOS>
The
neighbourhood
was
a
dreary
one
at
that
time
;
as
oppressive
,
sad
,
and
solitary
by
night
,
as
any
about
London
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
neither
wharves
nor
houses
on
the
melancholy
waste
of
road
near
the
great
blank
Prison
.
 
<EOS>
A
sluggish
ditch
deposited
its
mud
at
the
prison
walls
.
 
<EOS>
Coarse
grass
and
rank
weeds
straggled
over
all
the
marshy
land
in
the
vicinity
.
 
<EOS>
In
one
part
,
carcases
of
houses
,
inauspiciously
begun
and
never
finished
,
rotted
away
.
 
<EOS>
In
another
,
the
ground
was
cumbered
with
rusty
iron
monsters
of
steam
-
boilers
,
wheels
,
cranks
,
pipes
,
furnaces
,
paddles
,
anchors
,
diving
-
bells
,
windmill
-
sails
,
and
I
know
not
<EOS>
what
strange
objects
,
accumulated
by
some
speculator
,
and
grovelling
in
the
dust
,
underneath
which
---
having
sunk
into
the
soil
of
their
own
weight
in
wet
weather
<EOS>
---
they
had
the
appearance
of
vainly
trying
to
hide
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
The
clash
and
glare
of
sundry
fiery
Works
upon
the
river
-
side
,
arose
by
night
to
disturb
everything
except
the
heavy
and
unbroken
smoke
that
poured
out
of
their
chimneys
.
 
<EOS>
Slimy
gaps
and
causeways
,
winding
among
old
wooden
piles
,
with
a
sickly
substance
clinging
to
the
latter
,
like
green
hair
,
and
the
rags
of
last
year
's
handbills
offering
rewards
for
drowned
men
fluttering
above
high
-
water
mark
,
led
down
through
the
ooze
and
slush
to
the
ebb
-
tide
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
story
that
one
of
the
pits
dug
for
the
dead
in
the
time
of
the
Great
Plague
was
hereabout
;
and
a
blighting
influence
seemed
to
have
proceeded
from
it
over
the
whole
place
.
 
<EOS>
Or
else
it
looked
as
if
it
had
gradually
decomposed
into
that
nightmare
condition
,
out
of
the
overflowings
of
the
polluted
stream
.
   
<EOS>
As
if
she
were
a
part
of
the
refuse
it
had
cast
out
,
and
left
to
corruption
and
decay
,
the
girl
we
had
followed
strayed
down
to
the
river
's
brink
,
and
stood
in
the
midst
of
this
night
-
picture
,
lonely
and
still
,
looking
at
the
water
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
some
boats
and
barges
<EOS>
astrand
in
the
mud
,
and
these
enabled
us
to
come
within
a
few
yards
of
her
without
being
seen
.
<EOS>
I
then
signed
to
Mr
Peggotty
to
remain
where
he
was
,
and
emerged
from
their
shade
to
speak
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
not
approach
her
solitary
figure
without
trembling
;
for
this
gloomy
end
to
her
determined
walk
,
and
the
way
in
which
she
stood
,
almost
within
the
cavernous
shadow
of
the
iron
bridge
,
looking
at
the
lights
crookedly
reflected
in
the
strong
tide
,
inspired
a
dread
within
me
.
   
<EOS>
I
think
she
was
talking
to
herself
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
,
<EOS>
although
absorbed
in
gazing
at
the
water
,
that
her
shawl
was
off
her
shoulders
,
and
that
she
was
muffling
her
hands
in

,
in
an
unsettled
and
bewildered
way
,
more
like
the
action
of
a

than
a

.
 
<EOS>
I
know
,
and
never
can
forget
,
that
there
was
that
in
her
wild
manner
which
gave

no
assurance
but
that
she
would
sink
before
my
eyes
,
until
I
had
her
arm
within
my
grasp
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
same
moment
I
said
"
Martha
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
uttered
a
terrified
scream
,
and
struggled
with
me
with
such
strength
that
I
doubt
if
I
could
have
held
her
alone
.
 
<EOS>
But
a
stronger
hand
than
mine
was
laid
upon
her
;
and
when
she
raised
her
frightened
eyes
and
saw
whose
it
was
,
she
made
but
one
more

and
dropped
down
between

.
 
<EOS>
We
carried
her
away
from
the
water
to
where
there
were
some
dry
stones
,
and
there
laid
her
down
,
crying
and
moaning
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
little
while
she
sat
among
the
stones
,
holding
her
wretched
head
with
both
her
hands
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
the
river
!
<EOS>
"
she
cried
passionately
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
the
river
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
hush
!
"
said
I.
 
"
Calm
yourself
.
"
   
<EOS>
But
she
still
repeated
the
same
words
,
continually
exclaiming
,
"
Oh
,
the
river
!
"
<EOS>
over
and
over
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
's
like
me
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
I
belong
to
it
.
<EOS>
I
know
that
it
's
the
natural
company
of
such
as
I
am
!
<EOS>
It
comes
from
country
places
,
where
there
was
once
no
harm
in
it
---
and
it
creeps
through
the
dismal

,
defiled
and
miserable
---
and
it
goes
away
,
like
my
life
,
to
a
great
sea
<EOS>
,
that
is
always
troubled
---
and
I
feel
that
I
must
go
with
it
!
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
known
what
despair
was
,
except
in
the
tone
of
those
words
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
keep
away
from
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
forget
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
haunts
me
day
and
night
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
the
only
thing
in
all
the
world
that
I
am
fit
for
,
or
that
's
fit
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
the
dreadful
river
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
thought
passed
through
my
mind
that
in
the
face
of
my
companion
,
as
he
looked
upon
her
without
speech
or
motion
,
I
might
have
read
his
niece
's
history
,
if
I
had

nothing

.
 
<EOS>
I
never
saw
,
in
any

,
horror
and

so

.
 
<EOS>
He
shook
as
if
he
would
have
fallen
;
and
his
hand
<EOS>
---
I
touched
it
with
my
own
,
for
his
appearance
<EOS>
alarmed
me
---
was
deadly
cold
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
in
a
state
of
frenzy
,
"
I
whispered
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
will
speak
differently
in
a
little
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
he
would
have
said
in
answer
.
 
<EOS>
He
made
some
motion
with
his
mouth
,
and
seemed
to
think
he
had
spoken
;
but
he
had
only
pointed
to
her
with

.
   
<EOS>
A
new
burst
of
crying
came
upon
her
now
,
in
which
she
once
more
hid
her
face
among
the
stones
,
and
lay
before
us
,
a
prostrate

of
humiliation
and

.
 
<EOS>
Knowing
that
this
state
must
pass
,
before
we
could
speak
to
her
with
any
hope
,
I
ventured
to
restrain
him
when
he
would
have
raised
her
,
and
we
stood
by
in
silence
until
she
became
more

.
   
<EOS>
"
Martha
,
"
said
I
then
,
leaning
down
,
and
helping
her
to
rise
---
she
seemed
to
want
to
rise
as
if
with
the
intention
of
going
away
,
but
she
was
weak
,
and
leaned
against
a
boat
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
who
this
is
,
who
is
with
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
said
faintly
,
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
that
we
have
followed
you
a
long
way
tonight
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
shook
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
She
looked
neither
at
him
nor
at
me
,
but
stood
in
a
humble
attitude
,
holding
her
bonnet

in
one

,
without
appearing

of

,
and
pressing
the

,
clenched
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
composed
enough
,
"
said
I
,
"
to
speak
on
the
subject
which
so
interested
you
<EOS>
---
I
hope
Heaven
may
remember
it
!
---
that
snowy
night
?
"
   
<EOS>
Her
sobs
broke
out
afresh
,
and
she
murmured
some
inarticulate
thanks
to
me
for
not
having
driven
her

from

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
say
nothing
for
myself
,
"
she
said
,
after
a

.
<EOS>
"
I
am
bad
,
I
am
lost
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
hope
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
But
tell
him
,
sir
,
"
she
had

,
"
if
you
do
n't

to
me
to
do

,
that
I
never
was
in
any

the

of
his

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
has
never
been
attributed
to
you
,
"
<EOS>
I
returned
,
earnestly

to
her

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
you
,
if
I
do

,
"
she

,
in

,
"

came

,

she

such

;
was
so

;
did

me
like
all

,
and
gave

such

!
<EOS>
Was
it
you
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
been
in
the
river
long
ago
,
"
she
said
,
glancing
at
it
with
a

,
"
if
any
wrong
to
her
had
been
upon
my
mind
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
could
have
kept
out
of
it
a
single
winter
's
night
,
if
I
had
not
been
free
of
any

in
that
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
cause
of
her
flight
is
too
well

,
"
I
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
innocent
of
any
part
in
it
,
we
thoroughly
believe
,
---
we
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
might
have
been
much
the
better
for
her
,
if
I
had
had
a
better

!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
girl
,
with
most
forlorn
regret
;
"
for
she
was
always
good
to
me
!
<EOS>
She
never
spoke
a
word
to
me
but
what
was
pleasant
and
right
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
likely
I
would
try
to
make
her
what
I
am
myself
,
knowing
what
I
am
myself
,
so
well
?
 
<EOS>
When
I
lost
everything
that
makes
life
dear
,
the
worst
of
all
my
thoughts
was
that
I
was
parted
for

her
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
,
standing
with
one

on
the
gunwale
of
the
boat
,
and
his
eyes
cast
down
,
put
his
disengaged
hand
before
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
when
I
heard
what
had
happened
before
that
snowy
night
,
from
some
belonging
to
our
town
,
"
cried
Martha
,
"
the
bitterest
thought
in
all
my
mind
was
,
that
the
people
would
remember
she
once
kept
company
with
me
,
and
would
say
I
had
corrupted
her
!
<EOS>
When
,
Heaven
knows
,
I
would
have
died
to
have
brought
back
her

name
!
"
   
<EOS>
Long
unused
to
any
self
-
control
,
the

of

and

was
