.
   
<EOS>
"
To
have
died
,
would
not
have
been
much
---
what
can
I
say
?
 
<EOS>
---
I
would
have
lived
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
have
lived
to
be
old
,
in
the
wretched
streets
---
and
to
wander
about
,
avoided
,
in
the
dark
---
and
to
see
the
day
break
on
the
ghastly
line
of
houses
,
and
remember
how
the
same
sun
used
to
shine
into
my
room
,
and
wake
me
once
---
I
would
have
done
even
that
,
to
save
her
!
"
   
<EOS>
Sinking
on
the
stones
,
she
took
some
in
each
hand
,
and
clenched
them
up
,
as
if
she
would
have
ground
them
.
 
<EOS>
She
writhed
into
some
new
posture
constantly
:
stiffening
her
arms
,
twisting
them
before
her
face
,
as
though
to
shut
out
from
her
eyes
the
little
light
there
was
,
and
drooping
her
head
,
as
if
it
were
heavy
with
insupportable
recollections
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
shall
I
ever
do
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
fighting
thus
with
her
despair
.
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
go
on
as
I
am
,
a
solitary
curse
to
myself
,
a
living
disgrace
to
everyone
I
come
near
!
"
<EOS>
Suddenly
she
turned
to
my
companion
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stamp
upon
me
,
kill
me
!
<EOS>
When
she
was
your
pride
,
you
would
have
thought
I
had
done
her
harm
if
I
had
brushed
against
her
in
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
believe
---
why
should
you
?
 
---
a
syllable
that
comes
out
of
my
lips
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
a
burning
shame
upon
you
,
even
now
,
if
she
and
I
exchanged
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
complain
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
say
she
and
<EOS>
I
are
alike
---
<EOS>
I
know
there
is
a
long
,
long
way
between
us
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
say
,
with
all
my
guilt
and
wretchedness
upon
my
head
,
that
I
am
grateful
to
her
from
my
soul
,
and
love
her
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
do
n't
think
that
all
the
power
I
had
of
loving
anything
is
quite
worn
out
!
<EOS>
Throw
me
away
,
as
all
the
world
does
.
 
<EOS>
Kill
me
for
being
what
I
am
,
and
having
ever
known
her
;
but
do
n't
think
that
of
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
looked
upon
her
,
while
she
made
this
supplication
,
in
a
wild
distracted
manner
;
and
,
when
she
was
silent
,
gently
raised
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Martha
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,
"
God
forbid
as
I
should
judge
you
.
<EOS>
Forbid
as
I
,
of
all
men
,
should
do
that
,
my
girl
!
<EOS>
You
<EOS>
doen't
know
half
the
change
that
's
come
,
in
course
of
time
,
upon
me
,
when
you
think
it
likely
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
"
<EOS>
he
paused
a
moment
,
then
went
on
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
doen't
understand
how
'
tis
that
this
here
gentleman
and
me
has
wished
to
speak
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
<EOS>
doen't
understand
what
'
<EOS>
tis
we
has
afore
us
.
 
<EOS>
Listen
now
!
"
   
<EOS>
His
influence
upon
her
was
complete
.
 
<EOS>
She
stood
,
shrinkingly
,
before
him
,
as
if
she
were
afraid
to
meet
his
eyes
;
but
her
passionate
sorrow
was
quite
hushed
and
mute
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
heerd
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,
"
owt
of
what
passed
between
Mas'r
Davy
and
me
,
th
'
night
when
it
snew
so
hard
,
you
know
as
I
have
been
---
wheer
not
---
fur
to
seek
my
dear
niece
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
niece
,
"
he
repeated
steadily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fur
she
's
more
dear
to
me
now
,
Martha
,
than
she
was
dear
afore
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
put
her
hands
before
her
face
;
but
otherwise
remained
quiet
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
heerd
her
tell
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,
"
as
you
was
early
left
fatherless
and
motherless
,
with
no
friend
fur
to
take
,
in
a
rough
seafaring
-
way
,
their
place
.
 
<EOS>
Maybe
you
can
guess
that
if
you
'd
had
such
a
friend
,
you
'd
have
got
into
a
way
of
being
fond
of
him
in
course
of
time
,
and
that
my
niece
was
kiender
daughter
<EOS>
-
like
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
she
was
silently
trembling
,
he
put
her
shawl
carefully
about
her
,
taking
it
up
from
the
ground
for
that
purpose
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Whereby
,
"
said
he
,
"
I
know
,
both
as
she
would
go
to
the
wureld
's
furdest
end
with
me
,
if
she
could
once
see
me
again
;
and
that
she
would
fly
to
the
wureld
's
furdest
end
to
keep
off
seeing
me
.
 
<EOS>
For
though
she
ai
n't
no
call
to
doubt
my
love
,
and
doen't
---
and
doen't
,
"
he
repeated
,
with
a
quiet
assurance
of
the
truth
of
what
he
said
,
"
there
's
shame
steps
in
,
and
keeps
betwixt
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
read
,
in
every
word
of
his
plain
impressive
way
of
delivering
himself
,
new
evidence
of
his
having
thought
of
this
one
topic
,
in
every
feature
it
presented
.
   
<EOS>
"
According
to
our
reckoning
,
"
he
proceeded
,
"
Mas'r
Davy
's
here
,
and
mine
,
she
is
like
,
one
day
,
to
make
her
own
poor
solitary
course
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
We
believe
---
<EOS>
Mas'r
Davy
,
me
,
and
all
of
us
---
that
you
are
as
innocent
of
everything
that
has
befell
her
,
as
the
unborn
child
.
<EOS>
You
've
spoke
of
her
being
pleasant
,
kind
,
and
gentle
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
Bless
her
,
I
knew
she
was
!
<EOS>
I
knew
she
always
was
,
to
all
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
thankful
to
her
,
and
you
love
her
.
 
<EOS>
Help
us
all
you
can
to
find
her
,
and
may
Heaven
reward
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
looked
at
him
hastily
,
and
for
the
first
time
,
as
if
she
were
doubtful
of
what
he
had
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
trust
me
?
"
<EOS>
she
asked
,
in
a
low
voice
of
astonishment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Full
and
free
!
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
speak
to
her
,
if
I
should
ever
find
her
;
shelter
her
,
if
I
have
any
shelter
to
divide
with
her
;
and
then
,
without
her
knowledge
,
come
to
you
,
and
bring
you
to
her
?
"
<EOS>
she
asked
hurriedly
.
   
<EOS>
We
both
replied
together
,
"
Yes
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
lifted
up
her
eyes
,
and
solemnly
declared
that
she
would
devote
herself
to
this
task
,
fervently
and
faithfully
.
 
<EOS>
That
she
would
never
waver
in
it
,
never
be
diverted
from
it
,
never
relinquish
it
,
while
there
was
any
chance
of
hope
.
 
<EOS>
If
she
were
not
true
to
it
,
might
the
object
she
now
had
in
life
,
which
bound
her
to
something
devoid
of
evil
,
in
its
passing
away
from
her
,
leave
her
more
forlorn
and
more
despairing
,
if
that
were
possible
,
than
she
had
been
upon
the
river
's
brink
that
night
;
and
then
might
all
help
,
human
and
Divine
,
renounce
her
evermore
!
   
<EOS>
She
did
not
raise
her
voice
above
her
breath
,
or
address
us
,
but
said
this
to
the
night
sky
;
then
stood
profoundly
quiet
,
looking
at
the
gloomy
water
.
   
<EOS>
We
judged
it
expedient
,
now
,
to
tell
her
all
we
knew
;
which
I
recounted
at
length
.
 
<EOS>
She
listened
with
great
attention
,
and
with
a
face
that
often
changed
,
but
had
the
same
purpose
in
all
its
varying
expressions
.
 
<EOS>
Her
eyes
occasionally
filled
with
tears
,
but
those
she
repressed
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
as
if
her
spirit
were
quite
altered
,
and
she
could
not
be
too
quiet
.
   
<EOS>
She
asked
,
when
all
was
told
,
where
we
were
to
be
communicated
with
,
if
occasion
should
arise
.
 
<EOS>
Under
a
dull
lamp
in
the
road
,
I
wrote
our
two
addresses
on
a
leaf
of
my
pocket
-
book
,
which
I
tore
out
and
gave
to
her
,
and
which
she
put
in
her
poor
bosom
.
 
<EOS>
I
asked
her
where
she
lived
herself
.
 
<EOS>
She
said
,
after
a
pause
,
in
no
place
long
.
 
<EOS>
It
were
better
not
to
know
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
suggesting
to
me
,
in
a
whisper
<EOS>
,
what
had
already
occurred
to
myself
,
I
took
out
my
purse
;
but
I
could
not
prevail
upon
her
to
accept
any
money
,
nor
could
I
exact
any
promise
from
her
that
she
would
do
so
at
another
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
represented
to
her
that
Mr
Peggotty
could
not
be
called
,
for
one
in
his
condition
,
poor
;
and
that
the
idea
of
her
engaging
in
this
search
,
while
depending
on
her
own
resources
,
shocked
us
both
.
 
<EOS>
She
continued
steadfast
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
particular
,
his
influence
upon
her
was
equally
powerless
with
mine
.
 
<EOS>
She
gratefully
thanked
him
but
remained
inexorable
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
may
be
work
to
be
got
,
"
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
try
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
least
take
some
assistance
,
"
I
returned
,
"
until
you
have
tried
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
not
do
what
I
have
promised
,
for
money
,
"
she
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
could
not
take
it
,
if
I
was
starving
.
 
<EOS>
To
give
me
money
would
be
to
take
away
your
trust
,
to
take
away
the
object
that
you
have
given
me
,
to
take
away
the
only
certain
thing
that
saves
me
from
the
river
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
name
of
the
great
judge
,
"
said
I
,
"
before
whom
you
and
all
of
us
must
stand
at
His
dread
time
,
dismiss
that
terrible
idea
!
<EOS>
We
can
all
do
some
good
,
if
we
will
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
trembled
,
and
her
lip
shook
,
and
her
face
was
paler
,
as
she
answered
:
   
"
It
has
been
put
into
your
hearts
,
perhaps
,
to
save
a
wretched
creature
for
repentance
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
to
think
so
;
it
seems
too
bold
.
 
<EOS>
If
any
good
should
come
of
me
,
I
might
begin
to
hope
;
for
nothing
but
harm
has
ever
come
of
my
deeds
yet
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
to
be
trusted
,
for
the
first
time
in
a
long
while
,
with
my
miserable
life
,
on
account
of
what
you
have
given
me
to
try
for
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
no
more
,
and
I
can
say
no
more
.
"
   
<EOS>
Again
she
repressed
the
tears
that
had
begun
to
flow
;
and
,
putting
out
her
trembling
hand
,
and
touching
Mr
Peggotty
,
as
if
there
was
some
healing
virtue
in
him
,
went
away
along
the
desolate
road
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
been
ill
,
probably
for
a
long
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
observed
,
upon
that
closer
opportunity
of
observation
,
that
she
was
worn
and
haggard
,
and
that
her
sunken
eyes
expressed
privation
and
endurance
.
   
<EOS>
We
followed
her
at
a
short
distance
,
our
way
lying
in
the
same
direction
,
until
we
came
back
into
the
lighted
and
populous
streets
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
such
implicit
confidence
in
her
declaration
,
that
I
then
put
it
to
Mr
Peggotty
,
whether
it
would
not
seem
,
in
the
onset
,
like
distrusting
her
,
to
follow
her
any
farther
.
 
<EOS>
He
being
of
the
same
mind
,
and
equally
reliant
on
her
,
we
suffered
her
to
take
her
own
road
,
and
took
ours
,
which
was
towards
Highgate
.
 
<EOS>
He
accompanied
me
a
good
part
of
the
way
;
and
when
we
parted
,
with
a
prayer
for
the
success
of
this
fresh
effort
,
there
was
a
new
and
thoughtful
compassion
in
him
that
I
was
at
no
loss
to
interpret
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
midnight
when
I
arrived
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
reached
my
own
gate
,
and
was
standing
listening
for
the
deep
bell
of
St
Paul
's
,
the
sound
of
which
I
thought
had
been
borne
towards
me
among
the
multitude
of
striking
clocks
,
when
I
was
rather
surprised
to
see
that
the
door
of
my
aunt
's
cottage
was
open
,
and
that
a
faint
light
in
the
entry
was
shining
out
across
the
road
.
   
<EOS>
Thinking
that
my
aunt
might
have
relapsed
into
one
of
her
old
alarms
,
and
might
be
watching
the
progress
of
some
imaginary
conflagration
in
the
distance
,
I
went
to
speak
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
with
very
great
surprise
that
I
saw
a
man
standing
in
her
little
garden
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
a
glass
and
bottle
in
his
hand
,
and
was
in
the
act
of
drinking
.
 
<EOS>
I
stopped
short
,
among
the
thick
foliage
outside
,
for
the
moon
<EOS>
was
up
now
,
though
obscured
;
and
I
recognized
the
man
whom
I
had
once
supposed
to
be
a
delusion
of
Mr
Dick
's
,
and
had
once
encountered
with
my
aunt
in
the
streets
of
the
city
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
eating
as
well
as
drinking
,
and
seemed
to
eat
with
a
hungry
appetite
.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
curious
regarding
the
cottage
,
too
,
as
if
it
were
the
first
time
he
had
seen
it
.
 
<EOS>
After
stooping
to
put
the
bottle
on
the
ground
,
he
looked
up
at
the
windows
,
and
looked
about
;
though
with
a
covert
and
impatient
air
,
as
if
he
was
anxious
to
be
gone
.
   
<EOS>
The
light
in
the
passage
was
obscured
for
a
moment
,
and
my
aunt
came
out
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
agitated
,
and
told
some
money
into
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
it
chink
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
use
of
this
?
"
he
demanded
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
spare
no
more
,
"
returned
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
I
ca
n't
go
,
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
!
<EOS>
You
may
take
it
back
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
bad
man
,
"
returned
my
aunt
,
with
great
emotion
;
"
how
can
you
use
me
so
?
 
<EOS>
But
why
do
I
ask
?
 
<EOS>
It
is
because
you
know
how
weak
I
am
!
<EOS>
What
have
I
to
do
,
to
free
myself
for
ever
of
your
visits
,
but
to
abandon
you
to
your
deserts
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
why
do
n't
you
abandon
me
to
my
deserts
?
"
said
he
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
ask
me
why
!
"
returned
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
heart
you
must
have
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
stood
moodily
rattling
the
money
,
and
shaking
his
head
,
until
at
length
he
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Is
this
all
you
mean
to
give
me
,
then
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
all
I
CAN
give
you
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
I
have
had
losses
,
and
am
poorer
than
I
used
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
told
you
so
.
<EOS>
Having
got
it
,
why
do
you
give
me
the
pain
of
looking
at
you
for
another
moment
,
and
seeing
what
you
have
become
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
become
shabby
enough
,
if
you
mean
that
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
lead
the
life
of
an
owl
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
stripped
me
of
the
greater
part
of
all
I
ever
had
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
closed
my
heart
against
the
whole
world
,
years
and
years
.
 
<EOS>
You
treated
me
falsely
,
ungratefully
,
and
cruelly
.
 
<EOS>
Go
,
and
repent
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
add
new
injuries
to
the
long
,
long
list
of
injuries
you
have
done
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
<EOS>
"
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
very
fine
---
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
I
must
do
the
best
I
can
,
for
the
present
,
I
suppose
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
In
spite
of
himself
,
he
appeared
abashed
by
my
aunt
's
indignant
tears
,
and
came
slouching
out
of
the
garden
.
 
<EOS>
Taking
two
or
three
quick
steps
,
as
if
I
had
just
come
up
,
I
met
him
at
the
gate
,
and
went
in
as
he
came
out
.
 
<EOS>
We
eyed
one
another
narrowly
in
passing
,
and
with
no
favour
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aunt
,
"
said
I
,
hurriedly
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
man
alarming
you
again
!
<EOS>
Let
me
speak
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Who
is
he
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Child
,
"
returned
my
aunt
,
taking
my
arm
,
"
come
in
,
and
do
n't
speak
to
me
for
ten
minutes
.
"
   
<EOS>
We
sat
down
in
her
little
parlour
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
retired
behind
the
round
green
fan
of
former
days
,
which
was
screwed
on
the
back
of
a
chair
,
and
occasionally
wiped
her
eyes
,
for
about
a
quarter
of
an
hour
.
 
<EOS>
Then
she
came
out
,
and
took
a
seat
beside
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Trot
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
calmly
,
"
it
's
my
husband
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
husband
,
aunt
?
 
<EOS>
I
thought
he
had
been
dead
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dead
to
me
,
"
returned
my
aunt
,
"
but
living
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
sat
in
silent
amazement
.
   
<EOS>
"
Betsey
Trotwood
do
n't
look
a
likely
subject
for
the
tender
passion
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
composedly
,
"
but
the
time
was
,
Trot
,
when
she
believed
in
that
man
most
entirely
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
loved
him
,
Trot
,
right
well
.
 
<EOS>
When
there
was
no
proof
of
attachment
and
affection
that
she
would
not
have
given
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
repaid
her
by
breaking
her
fortune
,
and
nearly
breaking
her
heart
.
 
<EOS>
So
she
put
all
that
sort
of
sentiment
,
once
and
for
ever
,
in
a
grave
,
and
filled
it
up
,
and
flattened
it
down
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
good
aunt
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
left
him
,
"
my
aunt
proceeded
,
laying
her
hand
as
usual
on
the
back
of
mine
,
"
generously
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
say
at
this
distance
of
time
,
Trot
,
that
I
left
him
generously
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
so
cruel
to
me
,
that
I
might
have
effected
a
separation
on
easy
terms
for
myself
;
but
I
did
not
.
 
<EOS>
He
soon
made
ducks
and
drakes
of
what
I
gave
him
,
sank
lower
and
lower
,
married
another
woman
,
I
believe
,
became
an
adventurer
,
a
gambler
,
and
a
cheat
.
 
<EOS>
What
he
is
now
,
you
see
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
a
fine
-
looking
man
when
I
married
him
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
with
an
echo
of
her
old
pride
and
admiration
in
her
tone
;
"
and
I
believed
him
---
I
was
a
fool
!
---
to
be
the
soul
of
honour
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
She
gave
my
hand
a
squeeze
,
and
shook
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
nothing
to
me
now
,
Trot
,
less
than
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
sooner
than
have
him
punished
for
his
offences
(
as
he
would
be
if
he
prowled
about
in
this
country
)
,
I
give
him
more
money
than
I
can
afford
,
at
intervals
when
he
reappears
,
to
go
away
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
a
fool
when
I
married
him
;
and
I
am
so
far
an
incurable
fool
on
that
subject
,
that
,
for
the
sake
of
what
I
once
believed
him
to
be
,
I
would
n't
have
even
this
shadow
of
my
idle
fancy
hardly
dealt
with
.
<EOS>
For
I
was
in
earnest
,
Trot
,
if
ever
a
woman
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
MY
aunt
dismissed
the
matter
with
a
heavy
sigh
,
and
smoothed
her
dress
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
,
my
dear
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
you
know
the
beginning
,
middle
,
and
end
,
and
all
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
We
wo
n't
mention
the
subject
to
one
another
any
more
;
neither
,
of
course
,
will
you
mention
it
to
anybody
else
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
my
grumpy
,
frumpy
story
,
and
we
'll
keep
it
to
ourselves
,
Trot
!
"
      
<EOS>
Chapter
48
.
<EOS>
Domestic
 
<EOS>
I
laboured
hard
at
my
book
,
without
allowing
it
to
interfere
with
the
punctual
discharge
of
my
newspaper
duties
;
and
it
came
out
and
was
very
successful
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
stunned
by
the
praise
which
sounded
in
my
ears
,
notwithstanding
that
I
was
keenly
alive
to
it
,
and
thought
better
of
my
own
performance
,
I
have
little
doubt
,
than
anybody
else
did
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
always
been
in
my
observation
of
human
nature
,
that
a
man
who
has
any
good
reason
to
believe
in
himself
never
flourishes
himself
before
the
faces
of
other
people
in
order
that
they
may
believe
in
him
.
 
<EOS>
For
this
reason
,
I
retained
my
modesty
in
very
self
-
respect
;
and
the
more
praise
I
got
,
the
more
I
tried
to
deserve
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
not
my
purpose
,
in
this
record
,
though
in
all
other
essentials
it
is
my
written
memory
,
to
pursue
the
history
of
my
own
fictions
.
 
<EOS>
They
express
themselves
,
and
I
leave
them
to
themselves
.
<EOS>
When
I
refer
to
them
,
incidentally
,
it
is
only
as
a
part
of
my
progress
.
   
<EOS>
Having
some
foundation
for
believing
,
by
this
time
,
that
nature
and
accident
had
made
me
an
author
,
I
pursued
my
vocation
with
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
Without
such
assurance
I
should
certainly
have
left
it
alone
,
and
bestowed
my
energy
on
some
other
endeavour
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
tried
to
find
out
what
nature
and
accident
really
had
made
me
,
and
to
be
that
,
and
nothing
else
.
<EOS>
I
had
been
writing
,
in
the
newspaper
and
elsewhere
,
so
prosperously
,
that
when
my
new
success
was
achieved
,
I
considered
myself
reasonably
entitled
to
escape
from
the
dreary
debates
.
 
<EOS>
One
joyful
night
,
therefore
,
I
noted
down
the
music
of
the
parliamentary
bagpipes
for
the
last
time
,
and
I
have
never
heard
it
since
;
though
I
still
recognize
the
old
drone
in
the
newspapers
,
without
any
substantial
variation
(
except
,
perhaps
,
that
there
is
more
of
it
)
,
all
the
livelong
session
.
   
<EOS>
I
now
write
of
the
time
when
I
had
been
married
,
I
suppose
,
about
a
year
and
a
half
.
 
<EOS>
After
several
varieties
of
experiment
,
we
had
given
up
the
housekeeping
as
a
bad
job
.
 
<EOS>
The
house
kept
itself
,
and
we
kept
a
page
.
 
<EOS>
The
principal
function
of
this
retainer
was
to
quarrel
with
the
cook
;
in
which
respect
he
was
a
perfect
Whittington
,
without
his
cat
,
or
the
remotest
chance
of
being
made
Lord
Mayor
.
   
<EOS>
He
appears
to
me
to
have
lived
in
a
hail
of
saucepan
-
lids
.
 
<EOS>
His
whole
existence
was
a
scuffle
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
shriek
for
help
on
the
most
improper
occasions
,
---
as
when
we
had
a
little
dinner
-
party
,
or
a
few
friends
in
the
evening
,
---
and
would
come
tumbling
out
of
the
kitchen
,
with
iron
missiles
flying
after
him
.
 
<EOS>
We
wanted
to
get
rid
of
him
,
but
he
was
very
much
attached
to
us
,
and
would
n't
go
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
tearful
boy
,
and
broke
into
such
deplorable
lamentations
,
when
a
cessation
of
our
connexion
was
hinted
at
,
that
we
were
obliged
to
keep
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
mother
---
no
anything
in
the
way
of
a
relative
,
that
I
could
discover
,
except
a
sister
,
who
fled
to
America
the
moment
we
had
taken
him
off
her
hands
;
and
he
became
quartered
on
us
like
a
horrible
young
changeling
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
lively
perception
of
his
own
unfortunate
state
,
and
was
always
rubbing
his
eyes
with
the
sleeve
of
his
jacket
,
or
stooping
to
blow
his
nose
on
the
extreme
corner
of
a
little
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
which
he
never
would
take
completely
out
of
his
pocket
,
but
always
economized
and
secreted
.
   
<EOS>
This
unlucky
page
,
engaged
in
an
evil
hour
at
six
pounds
ten
per
annum
,
was
a
source
of
continual
trouble
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
watched
him
as
he
grew
---
and
he
grew
like
scarlet
beans
---
with
painful
apprehensions
of
the
time
when
he
would
begin
to
shave
;
even
of
the
days
when
he
would
be
bald
or
grey
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
no
prospect
of
ever
getting
rid
of
him
;
and
,
projecting
myself
into
the
future
,
used
to
think
what
an
inconvenience
he
would
be
when
he
was
an
old
man
.
   
<EOS>
I
never
expected
anything
less
,
than
this
unfortunate
's
manner
of
getting
me
out
of
my
difficulty
.
 
<EOS>
He
stole
Dora
's
watch
,
which
,
like
everything
else
belonging
to
us
,
had
no
particular
place
of
its
own
;
and
,
converting
it
into
money
,
spent
the
produce
<EOS>
(
he
was
always
a
weak
-
minded
boy
)
in
incessantly
riding
up
and
down
between
London
and
Uxbridge
outside
the
coach
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
taken
to
Bow
Street
,
as
well
as
I
remember
,
on
the
completion
of
his
fifteenth
journey
;
when
four
-
and
-
sixpence
,
and
a
second
-
hand
fife
which
he
could
n't
play
,
were
found
upon
his
person
.
   
<EOS>
The
surprise
and
its
consequences
would
have
been
much
less
disagreeable
to
me
if
he
had
not
been
penitent
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
very
penitent
indeed
,
and
in
a
peculiar
way
---
not
in
the
lump
,
but
by
instalments
.
 
<EOS>
For
example
:
the
day
after
that
on
which
I
was
obliged
to
appear
against
him
,
he
made
certain
revelations
touching
a
hamper
in
the
cellar
,
which
we
believed
to
be
full
of
wine
,
but
which
had
nothing
in
it
except
bottles
and
corks
.
 
<EOS>
We
supposed
he
had
now
eased
his
mind
,
and
told
the
worst
he
knew
of
the
cook
;
but
,
a
day
or
two
afterwards
,
his
conscience
sustained
a
new
twinge
,
and
he
disclosed
how
she
had
a
little
girl
,
who
,
early
every
morning
,
took
away
our
bread
;
and
also
how
he
himself
had
been
suborned
to
maintain
the
milkman
in
coals
.
 
<EOS>
In
two
or
three
days
more
,
I
was
informed
by
the
authorities
of
his
having
led
to
the
discovery
of
sirloins
of
beef
among
the
kitchen
-
stuff
,
and
sheets
in
the
rag
-
bag
.
 
<EOS>
A
little
while
afterwards
,
he
broke
out
in
an
entirely
new
direction
,
and
confessed
to
a
knowledge
of
burglarious
intentions
as
to
our
premises
,
on
the
part
of
the
pot
-
boy
,
who
was
immediately
taken
up
.
 
<EOS>
I
got
to
be
so
ashamed
of
being
such
a
victim
<EOS>
,
that
I
would
have
given
him
any
money
to
hold
his
tongue
,
or
would
have
offered
a
round
bribe
for
his
being
permitted
to
run
away
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
an
aggravating
circumstance
in
the
case
that
he
had
no
idea
of
this
,
but
conceived
that
he
was
making
me
amends
in
every
new
discovery
:
not
to
say
,
heaping
obligations
on
my
head
.
   
<EOS>
At
last
I
ran
away
myself
,
whenever
I
saw
an
emissary
of
the
police
approaching
with
some
new
intelligence
;
and
lived
a
stealthy
life
until
he
was
tried
and
ordered
to
be
transported
.
 
<EOS>
Even
then
he
could
n't
be
quiet
,
but
was
always
writing
us
letters
;
and
wanted
so
much
to
see
Dora
before
he
went
away
,
that
Dora
went
to
visit
him
,
and
fainted
when
she
found
herself
inside
the
iron
bars
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
I
had
no
peace
of
my
life
until
he
was
expatriated
,
and
made
(
as
I
afterwards
heard
)
a
shepherd
of
,
"
up
the
country
"
somewhere
;
I
have
no
geographical
idea
<EOS>
where
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
led
me
into
some
serious
reflections
,
and
presented
our
mistakes
in
a
new
aspect
;
as
I
could
not
help
communicating
to
Dora
one
evening
,
in
spite
of
my
tenderness
for
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
love
,
"
said
I
,
"
it
is
very
painful
to
me
to
think
that
our
want
of
system
and
management
,
involves
not
only
ourselves
(
which
we
have
got
used
to
)
,
but
other
people
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
silent
for
a
long
time
,
and
now
you
are
going
to
be
cross
!
"
said
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
my
dear
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
Let
me
explain
to
you
what
I
mean
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
do
n't
want
to
know
,
"
said
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
want
you
to
know
,
my
love
.
 
<EOS>
Put
Jip
down
.
"
   
<EOS>
Dora
put
his
nose
to
mine
,
and
said
"
Boh
!
"
to
drive
my
seriousness
away
;
but
,
not
succeeding
,
ordered
him
into
his
Pagoda
,
and
sat
looking
at
me
,
with
her
hands
folded
,
and
a
most
resigned
little
expression
of
countenance
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
fact
is
,
my
dear
,
"
I
began
,
"
there
is
contagion
in
us
.
 
<EOS>
We
infect
everyone
about
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
might
have
gone
on
in
this
figurative
manner
,
if
Dora
's
face
had
not
admonished
me
that
she
was
wondering
with
all
her
might
whether
I
was
going
to
propose
any
new
kind
of
vaccination
,
or
other
medical
remedy
,
for
this
unwholesome
state
of
ours
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
I
checked
myself
,
and
made
my
meaning
plainer
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
merely
,
my
pet
,
"
said
I
,
"
that
we
lose
money
and
comfort
,
and
even
temper
sometimes
,
by
not
learning
to
be
more
careful
;
but
that
we
incur
the
serious
responsibility
of
spoiling
everyone
who
comes
into
our
service
,
or
has
any
dealings
with
us
.
<EOS>
I
begin
to
be
afraid
that
the
fault
is
not
entirely
on
one
side
,
but
that
these
people
all
turn
out
ill
because
we
do
n't
turn
out
very
well
ourselves
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
what
an

,
"
exclaimed
Dora
,

;
"
to
say
that
you
ever
saw
me
take
gold
watches
!
<EOS>
Oh
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dearest
<EOS>
,
"
I
remonstrated
,
"
do
n't
talk
preposterous
nonsense
!
<EOS>
Who
has
made
the
least
allusion
to
gold
watches
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
did
,
"
returned
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
you
did
.
 
<EOS>
You
said
I
had
n't
turned
out
well
,
and
compared
me
to
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
whom
?
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
To

page
,
"
sobbed
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
cruel
fellow
,
to
compare
your

wife
to
a
transported
page
!
<EOS>
Why
did

tell

?
 
<EOS>
Why
did

,
you
hard

,

?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

!
<EOS>
Oh

my

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Dora
,
my
love
,
"
I

,

she

,
"
this

not

,

.
 
<EOS>
In

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
And

!
<EOS>
Oh
,

I
do
!
<EOS>
What

do
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"
I
retorted
,
"
I
really

to
be

,

did

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
My

Dora
,

duty

employ
,

.
 
<EOS>
I

present

to

to
do
wrong
<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
Even

we

,
in
all

,
by

---
which
we

---

,

---
<EOS>

do

<EOS>
---

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
I
ca

,
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
It

I
am
unable

,

.
 
<EOS>
There
,

,
that
's

.
<EOS>
Come

.
 
<EOS>
Do

!
"
   
<EOS>
Dora
would
not
allow
me
,
for
a
long

,
to

.
 
<EOS>
She
sat

and

,
that
,
if
I
was

,
why
had
I
ever

?
 
<EOS>
Why
had

I
said
,

the

,
that
I

be
uneasy
,

?
 
<EOS>
If

could

bear

,

did

her
away
to

aunts

Putney
,
or

Julia
Mills

?
 
<EOS>
Julia
would
be
glad
to
see
her
,
and
would
not
call
her
a
transported
page
;
Julia
never
had
called
her
anything
of
the
sort
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
Dora
was
so
afflicted
,
and
so
afflicted
me
by
being
in
that
condition
,
that
I
felt
it
was
of
no
use
repeating
this
kind
of
effort
,
though
never
so

,
and
I
must
take
some
other
course
.
   
<EOS>
What
other
course
was
left
to
take
?
 
<EOS>
To
"
form
her
mind
"
?
 
<EOS>
This
was
a
common
phrase
of
words
which
had
a
fair
and
promising
sound
,
and
I
resolved
to
form
Dora
's
mind
.
   
<EOS>
I
began
immediately
.
 
<EOS>
When
Dora
was
very
childish
,
and
I
would
have
infinitely
preferred
to
humour
her
,
I
tried
to
be
grave
---
and
disconcerted
her
,
and
myself
too
.
 
<EOS>
I
talked
to
her
on
the
subjects
which
occupied
my
thoughts
;
and
I
read
Shakespeare
to
her
---
and
fatigued
her
to
the
last
degree
.
 
<EOS>
I
accustomed
myself
to
giving
her
,
as
it
were
quite
casually
,
little
scraps
of
useful
information
,
or
sound
opinion
---
and
she
started
from
them
when
I
let
them
off
,
as
if
they
had
been
crackers
.
 
<EOS>
No
matter
how
incidentally
or

I
endeavoured
to
form
my
little
wife
's
mind
,
I
could
not
help
seeing
that
she
always
had
an
instinctive
perception
of
what
I
was
about
,
and
became
a
prey
to
the
keenest

.
 
<EOS>
In
particular
,
it
was
clear
to
me
,
that
she
thought
Shakespeare
a
terrible
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
The
formation
went
on
very
slowly
.
   
<EOS>
I
pressed
Traddles
into
the
service
without
his
knowledge
;
and
whenever
he
came
to
see
us
,
exploded
my
mines
upon
him
for
the
edification
of
Dora
at
second
hand
.
 
<EOS>
The
amount
of
practical
wisdom
I
bestowed
upon
Traddles
in
this
manner
was
immense
,
and
of
the
best
quality
;
but
it
had
no
other
effect
upon
Dora
than
to
depress
her
spirits
,
and
make
her
always
nervous
with
the
dread
that
it
would
be
her
turn
next
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
myself
in
the
condition
of
a

,
a
trap
,
a

;
of
always
playing
spider
to
Dora
's

,
and
always
pouncing
out
of
my
hole
to
her
infinite
disturbance
.
   
<EOS>
Still
,
looking

through
this

,

should

between

,
and

I

"
formed

"

,
I
persevered
,
even

.
 
<EOS>
Finding

,

,
that
,

had
been

a

,

,
I
had
effected
nothing
,

began

me
that
perhaps
Dora
's
mind
was
already
formed
.
   
<EOS>
On

this
appeared
so
likely
,
that
I
abandoned
my

,
which
had
had
a
more
promising

in

than
in

;
resolving
henceforth
to
be
satisfied
with
my
child
-
wife
,
and
to
try
to
change
her
into
nothing
else
by

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
heartily

of
being
sagacious
and
prudent
by
myself
,
and
of
seeing
my
darling
under

;
so
I
bought
a
pretty

for
her
,
and
a
collar
for
Jip
,
and
went
home
one
day
to
make
myself

.
   
<EOS>
Dora
was
delighted
with
the
little
presents
,
and
kissed
me
joyfully
;
but
there
was
a
shadow
between
us
,
however
slight
,
and
I
had
made
up
my
mind
that
it
should
not
be
there
.
 
<EOS>
If
there
must
be
such
a
shadow
anywhere
,
I
would
keep
it
for
the
future
in
my
own

.
   
<EOS>
I
sat
down
by
my
wife
on
the
sofa
,
and
put
the
ear
-
rings
in
her

;
and
then
I
told
her
that
I
feared
we
had
not
been
quite
as
good
company
lately
,
as

used
to

,
and
that

fault

.
<EOS>
Which

sincerely

,
and
which

.
   
<EOS>
"
The
truth

,
Dora
,
my
life
,
"
I

;
"
I
have
been
trying
to
be
wise
.
"
   
"
<EOS>
And
to
make
me
wise
too
,
"
said
Dora
,
timidly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
n't
you
,
Doady
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
nodded

to
the
pretty

of
the
raised

,
and
kissed
the
parted

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
of
not
a
bit
of
use
,
"
said
Dora
,

,
until

-

rang

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
what
a
little
thing
I
am
,

what
I

.
 
<EOS>
If

ca

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
Are

do

,

,

<EOS>
---
"
   
"
Done

,
my
dear
?
"
<EOS>
For

made
no

.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
!
"
said
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
?
<EOS>
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
She
put
her
arms
<EOS>
round

,
and
laughed
,
and
called
herself
by
her
favourite
name
of
a

,

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do

I

,

have
tried

form
my

's

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Is

?
 
<EOS>
Yes
,

,
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is

what
you
have

?
"

Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
what
a
shocking
boy
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
I
shall
never
try
any
more
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
For
I
love
her
dearly

she

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Without
a
story
---
really
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Dora
,
creeping

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
should
I
seek
to
change
,
"
said
I
,
"

has

so

!
<EOS>
You
never
can
show
better

,

;
and

'll

no

,

,
and

.
"
   
"
And

happy
!
"

Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
All

!
<EOS>
And
you
wo
n't
mind
things
going
a
tiny

wrong
,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"

I.
 
<EOS>
"
We

do

best

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And

wo
n't

me
,
any

,

,
"

Dora
;
"

?
 
<EOS>
Because

's
so

cross
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"

I.
   
<EOS>
"
it
's

for
me

,

?
"
said
Dora
.
   
<EOS>
"
Better
to
be
naturally
Dora
than
anything

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
the
world
!
<EOS>
Ah
,
Doady
,
it
's
a
large

!
"
   
<EOS>
She
shook
her
head
,
turned
her
delighted
bright
eyes
up
to
mine
,
kissed
me
,
broke
into
a

laugh
,
and
sprang
away
to
put
on
Jip
's
new
collar
.
   
<EOS>
So
ended
my
last
attempt
to
make
any
change
in
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
been
unhappy
in
trying
it
;
I
could
not
endure
my
own
solitary
wisdom
;
I
could
not
reconcile
it
with
her
former
appeal
to
me
as
my
child
-
wife
.
 
<EOS>
I
resolved
to
do
what
I
could
,
in
a
quiet
way
,
to
improve
our
proceedings
myself
,
but
I
foresaw
that
my
utmost
would
be
very
little
,
or
I
must
degenerate
into
the
spider
again
,
and
be
for
ever
lying
in
wait
.
   
<EOS>
And
the
shadow
I
have
mentioned
,
that
was
not
to
be
between
us
any
more
,
but
was
to
rest
wholly
on
my
own
heart
?
 
<EOS>
How
did
that
fall
?
   
<EOS>
The
old
unhappy
feeling
pervaded
my
life
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
deepened
,
if
it
were
changed
at
all
;
but
it
was
as
undefined
as
ever
,
and
addressed
me
like
a
strain
of
sorrowful
music
faintly
heard
in
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
loved
my
wife
dearly
,
and
I
was
happy
;
but
<EOS>
the
happiness
I
had
vaguely
anticipated
,
once
,
was
not
the
happiness
I
enjoyed
,
and
there
was
always
something
wanting
.
   
<EOS>
In
fulfilment
of
the
compact
I
have
made
with
myself
,
to
reflect
my
mind
on
this
paper
,
I
again
examine
it
,
closely
,
and
bring
its
secrets
to
the
light
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
missed
,
I
still
regarded
<EOS>
---
I
always
regarded
---
as
something
that
had
been
a
dream
of
my
youthful
fancy
;
that
was
incapable
of
realization
;
that
I
was
now
discovering
to
be
so
,
with
some
natural
pain
,
as
all
men
did
.
 
<EOS>
But
that
it
would
have
been
better
for
me
if
my
wife
could
have
helped
me
more
,
and
shared
the
many
thoughts
in
which
I
had
no
partner
;
and
that
this
might
have
been
;
I
knew
.
   
<EOS>
Between
these
two
irreconcilable
conclusions
:
the
one
,
that
what
I
felt
was
general
and
unavoidable
;
the
other
,
that
it
was
particular
to
me
,
and
might
have
been
different
<EOS>
:
I
balanced
curiously
,
with
no
distinct
sense
of
their
opposition
to
each
other
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
thought
of
the
airy
dreams
of
youth
that
are
incapable
of
realization
,
I
thought
of
the
better
state
preceding
manhood
that
I
had
outgrown
;
and
then
the
contented
days
with
Agnes
,
in
the
dear
old
house
,
arose
before
me
,
like
spectres
of
the
dead
,
that
might
have
some
renewal
in
another
world
,
but
never
more
could
be
reanimated
here
.
   
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
the
speculation
came
into
my
thoughts
,
What
might
have
happened
,
or
what
would
have
happened
,
if
Dora
and
I
had
never
known
each
other
?
 
<EOS>
But
she
was
so
incorporated
with
my
existence
,
that
it
was
the
idlest
of
all
fancies
,
and
would
soon
rise
out
of
my
reach
and
sight
,
like
gossamer
floating
in
the
air
.
   
<EOS>
I
always
loved
her
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
am
describing
,
slumbered
,
and
half
awoke
,
and
slept
again
,
in
the
innermost
recesses
of
my
mind
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
evidence
of
it
in
me
;
I
know
of
no
influence
it
had
in
anything
I
said
or
did
.
 
<EOS>
I
bore
the
weight
of
all
our
little
cares
,
and
all
my
projects
;
Dora
held
the
pens
;
and
we
both
felt
that
our
shares
were
adjusted
as
the
case
required
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
truly
fond
of
me
,
and
proud
of
me
;
and
when
Agnes
wrote
a
few
earnest
words
in
her
letters
to
Dora
,
of
the
pride
and
interest
with
which
my
old
friends
heard
of
my
growing
reputation
,
and
read
my
book
as
if
they
heard
me
speaking
its
contents
,
Dora
read
them
out
to
me
with
tears
of
joy
in
her
bright
eyes
,
and
said
I
was
a
dear
old
clever
,
famous
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
first
mistaken
impulse
of
an
undisciplined
heart
.
"
 
<EOS>
Those
words
of
Mrs
Strong
's
were
constantly
recurring
to
me
,
at
this
time
;
were
almost
always
present
to
my
mind
.
 
<EOS>
I
awoke
with
them
,
often
,
in
the
night
;
I
remember
to
have
even
read
them
,
in
dreams
,
inscribed
upon
the
walls
of
houses
.
 
<EOS>
For
I
knew
,
now
,
that
my
own
heart
was
undisciplined
when
it
first
loved
Dora
;
and
that
if
it
had
been
disciplined
,
it
never
could
have
felt
,
when
we
were
married
,
what
it
had
felt
in
its
secret
experience
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
can
be
no
disparity
in
marriage
,
like
unsuitability
of
mind
and
purpose
.
"
 
<EOS>
Those
words
I
remembered
too
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
endeavoured
to
adapt
Dora
to
myself
,
and
found
it
impracticable
.
 
<EOS>
It
remained
for
me
to
adapt
myself
to
Dora
;
to
share
with
her
what
I
could
,
and
be
happy
;
to
bear
on
my
own
shoulders
what
I
must
,
and
be
happy
still
.
<EOS>
This
was
the
discipline
to
which
I
tried
to
bring
my
heart
,
when
I
began
to
think
.
 
<EOS>
It
made
my
second
year
much
happier
than
my
first
;
and
,
what
was
better
still
,
made
Dora
's
life
all
sunshine
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
as
that
year
wore
on
,
Dora
was
not
strong
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
hoped
that
lighter
hands
than
mine
would
help
to
mould
her
character
,
and
that
a
baby
-
smile
upon
her
breast
might
change
my
child
-
wife
to
a
woman
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
The
spirit
fluttered
for
a
moment
on
the
threshold
of
its
little
prison
,
and
,
unconscious
of
captivity
,
took
wing
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
can
run
about
again
,
as
I
used
to
do
,
aunt
,
"
said
Dora
,
"
I
shall
make
Jip
race
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
getting
quite
slow
and
lazy
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
suspect
,
my
dear
,
"
said
my
aunt
quietly
working
by
her
side
,
"
he
has
a
worse
disorder
than
that
.
 
<EOS>
Age
,
Dora
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
he
is
old
?
"
said
Dora
,
astonished
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
how
strange
it
seems
that
Jip
should
be
old
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
complaint
we
are
all
liable
to
,
Little
One
,
as
we
get
on
in
life
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
cheerfully
;
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
feel
more
free
from
it
than
I
used
to
be
,
I
assure
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
Jip
,
"
said
Dora
,
looking
at
him
with
compassion
,
"
even
little
Jip
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
poor
fellow
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
he
'll
last
a
long
time
yet
,
Blossom
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
patting
Dora
on
the
cheek
,
as
she
leaned
out
of
her
couch
to
look
at
Jip
,
who
responded
by
standing
on
his
hind
legs
,
and
baulking
himself
in
various
asthmatic
attempts
to
scramble
up
by
the
head
and
shoulders
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
must
have
a
piece
of
flannel
in
his
house
this
winter
,
and
I
should
n't
wonder
if
he
came
out
quite
fresh
again
,
with
the
flowers
in
the
spring
.
 
<EOS>
Bless
the
little
dog
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
my
aunt
,
"
if
he
had
as
many
lives
as
a
cat
,
and
was
on
the
point
of
losing
'em
all
,
he
'd
bark
at
me
with
his
last
breath
,
I
believe
!
"
   
<EOS>
Dora
had
helped
him
up
on
the
sofa
;
where
he
really
was
defying
my
aunt
to
such
a
furious
extent
,
that
he
could
n't
keep
straight
,
but
barked
himself
sideways
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
my
aunt
looked
at
him
,
the
more
he
reproached
her
;
for
she
had
lately
taken
to
spectacles
,
and
for
some
inscrutable
reason
he
considered
the
glasses
personal
.
   
<EOS>
Dora
made
him
lie
down
by
her
,
with
a
good
deal
of
persuasion
;
and
when
he
was
quiet
,
drew
one
of
his
long
ears
through
and
through
her
hand
,
repeating
thoughtfully
,
"
Even
little
Jip
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
poor
fellow
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
His
lungs
are
good
enough
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
gaily
,
"
and
his
dislikes
are
not
at
all
feeble
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
good
many
years
before
him
,
no
doubt
.
 
<EOS>
But
if
you
want
a
dog
to
race
with
,
Little
Blossom
,
he
has
lived
too
well
for
that
,
and
I
'll
give
you
one
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
aunt
,
"
said
Dora
,
faintly
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
do
n't
,
please
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
?
"
said
my
aunt
,
taking
off
her
spectacles
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
have
any
other
dog
but
Jip
,
"
said
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
so
unkind
to
Jip
!
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
could
n't
be
such
friends
with
any
other
dog
but
Jip
;
because
he
would
n't
have
known
me
before
I
was
married
,
and
would
n't
have
barked
at
Doady
when
he
first
came
to
our
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
n't
care
for
any
other
dog
<EOS>
but
Jip
,
I
am
afraid
,
aunt
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
!
<EOS>
"
said
my
aunt
,
patting
her
cheek
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
offended
,
"
said
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
a
sensitive
pet
it
is
!
"
<EOS>
cried
my
aunt
,
bending
over
her
affectionately
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
think
that
I
could
be
offended
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
I
did
n't
really
think
so
,
"
returned
Dora
;
"
but
I
am
a
little
tired
,
and
it
made
me
silly
for
a
moment
---
I
am
always
a
silly
little
thing
,
you
know
,
but
it
made
me
more
silly
---
to
talk
about
Jip
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
known
me
in
all
that
has
happened
to
me
,
have
n't
you
,
Jip
?
 
<EOS>
And
I
could
n't
bear
to
slight
him
,
because
he
was
a
little
altered
---
<EOS>
could
I
,
Jip
?
"
   
<EOS>
Jip
nestled
closer
to
his
mistress
,
and
lazily
licked
her
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
so
old
,
Jip
,
are
you
,
that
you
'll
leave
your
mistress
yet
?
"
said
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
may
keep
one
another
company
a
little
longer
!
"
   
<EOS>
My
pretty
Dora
!
<EOS>
When
she
came
down
to
dinner
on
the
ensuing
Sunday
,
and
was
so
glad
to
see
old
Traddles
(
who
always
dined
with
us
on
Sunday
)
,
we
thought
she
would
be
"
running
about
as
she
used
to
do
"
,
in
a
few
days
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
said
,
wait
a
few
days
more
;
and
then
,
wait
a
few
days
more
;
and
still
she
neither
ran
nor
walked
.
 
<EOS>
She
looked
very
pretty
,
and
was
very
merry
;
but
the
little
feet
that
used
to
be
so
nimble
when
they
danced
round
Jip
,
were
dull
and
motionless
.
   
<EOS>
I
began
to
carry
her
downstairs
every
morning
,
and
upstairs
every
night
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
clasp
me
round
the
neck
and
laugh
,
<EOS>
the
while
,
as
if
I
did
it
for
a
wager
.
 
<EOS>
Jip
would
bark
and
caper
round
us
,
and
go
on
before
,
and
look
back
on
the
landing
,
breathing
short
,
to
see
that
we
were
coming
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
the
best
and
most
cheerful
of
nurses
,
would
trudge
after
us
,
a
moving
mass
of
shawls
and
pillows
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
would
not
have
relinquished
his
post
of
candle
-
bearer
to
anyone
alive
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
would
be
often
at
the
bottom
of
the
staircase
,
looking
on
,
and
taking
charge
of
sportive
messages
from
Dora
to
the
dearest
girl
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
We
made
quite
a
gay
procession
of
it
,
and
my
child
-
wife
was
the
gayest
there
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
sometimes
,
when
I
took
her
up
,
and
felt
that
she
was
lighter
in
my
arms
,
a
dead
blank
feeling
came
upon
me
,
as
if
I
were
approaching
to
some
frozen
region
yet
unseen
,
that
numbed
my
life
.
<EOS>
I
avoided
the
recognition
of
this
feeling
by
any
name
,
or
by
any
communing
with
myself
;
until
one
night
,
when
it
was
very
strong
upon
me
,
and
my
aunt
had
left
her
with
a
parting
cry
of
"
Good
night
,
Little
Blossom
,
"
I
sat
down
at
my
desk
alone
,
and
cried
to
think
,
<EOS>
Oh
what
a
fatal
name
it
was
,
and
how
the
blossom
withered
in
its
bloom
upon
the
tree
!
      
<EOS>
Chapter
49
.
<EOS>
I
am
involved
in
mystery
 
<EOS>
I
received
one
morning
by
the
post
,
the
following
letter
,
dated
Canterbury
,
and
addressed
to
me
at
Doctor
's
Commons
;
which
I
read
with
some
surprise
:
    
"
MY
DEAR
SIR
,
"
  
"
Circumstances
beyond
my
individual
control
have
,
for
a
considerable
lapse
of
time
,
effected
a
severance
of
that
intimacy
which
,
in
the
limited
opportunities
conceded
to
me
in
the
midst
of
my
professional
duties
,
of
contemplating
the
scenes
and
events
of
the
past
,
tinged
by
the
prismatic
hues
of
memory
,
has
ever
afforded
me
,
as
it
ever
must
continue
to
afford
,
gratifying
emotions
of
no
common
description
.
 
<EOS>
This
fact
,
my
dear
sir
,
combined
with
the
distinguished
elevation
to
which
your
talents
have
raised
you
,

is

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
returned
Mr
Micawber
,
whose
face
clouded
at
this
reference
,
"
she
is
but
so
<EOS>
-
so
.
 
<EOS>
And
this
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
nodding
his
head
sorrowfully
,
"
is
the
Bench
!
<EOS>
Where
,
for
the
first
time
in
many
revolving
years
,
the
overwhelming
pressure
of
pecuniary
liabilities
was
not
proclaimed
,
from
day
to
day
,
by
importune
voices
declining
to
vacate
the
passage
;
where
there
was
no
knocker
on
the
door
for
any
creditor
to
appeal
to
;
where
personal
service
of
process
was
not
required
,
and
detainees
were
merely
lodged
at
the
gate
!
<EOS>
Gentlemen
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
when
the
shadow
of
that
iron
-
work
on
the
summit
of
the
brick
structure
has
been
reflected
on
the
gravel
of
the
Parade
<EOS>
,
I
have
seen
my
children
thread
the
mazes
of
the
intricate
pattern
,
avoiding
the
dark
marks
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
familiar
with
every
stone
in
the
place
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
betray
weakness
,
you
will
know
how
to
excuse
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
have
all
got
on
in
life
since
then
,
Mr
Micawber
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
returned
Mr
Micawber
,
bitterly
,
"
when
I
was
an
inmate
of
that
retreat
<EOS>
I
could
look
my
fellow
-
man
in
the
face
,
and
punch
his
head
if
he
offended
me
.
 
<EOS>
My
fellow
-
man
and
myself
are
no
longer
on
those
glorious
terms
!
"
   
<EOS>
Turning
from
the
building
in
a
downcast
manner
,
Mr
Micawber
accepted
my
proffered
arm
on
one
side
,
and
the
proffered
arm
of
Traddles
on
the
other
,
and
walked
away
between
us
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
are
some
landmarks
,
"
observed
Mr
Micawber
,
looking
fondly
back
over
his
shoulder
,
"
on
the
road
to
the
tomb
,
<EOS>
which
,
but
for
the
impiety
of
the
aspiration
,
a
man
would
wish
never
to
have
passed
.
 
<EOS>
Such
is
the
Bench
in
my
chequered
career
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
are
in
low
spirits
,
Mr
Micawber
,
"
said
Traddles
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
sir
,
"
interposed
Mr
Micawber
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
"
said
Traddles
,
"
it
is
not
because
you
have
conceived
a
dislike
to
the
law
---
for
I
am
a
lawyer
myself
,
you
know
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
answered
not
a
word
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
is
our
friend
Heep
,
Mr
Micawber
?
"
said
I
,
after
a
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Copperfield
,
"
returned
Mr
Micawber
,
bursting
into
a
state
of
much
excitement
,
and
turning
pale
,
"
if
you
ask
after
my
employer
as
your
friend
,
I
am
sorry
for
it
;
if
you
ask
after
him
as
MY
friend
,
I
sardonically
smile
at
it
.
 
<EOS>
In
whatever
capacity
you
ask
after
my
employer
,
I
beg
,
without
offence
to
you
,
to
limit
my
reply
to
this
---
that
whatever
his
state
of
health
may
be
,
his
appearance
is
foxy
:
not
to
say
diabolical
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
allow
me
,
as
a
private
individual
,
to
decline
pursuing
a
subject
which
has
lashed
me
to
the
utmost
verge
of
desperation
in
my
professional
capacity
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
expressed
my
regret
for
having
innocently
touched
upon
a
theme
that
roused
him
so
much
.
 
<EOS>
"
May
I
ask
,
"
said
I
,
"
without
any
hazard
of
repeating
the
mistake
,
how
my
old
friends
Mr
and
Miss
Wickfield
are
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Wickfield
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
now
turning
red
,
"
is
,
as
she
always
is
,
a
pattern
,
and
a
bright
example
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
Copperfield
,
she
is
the
only
starry
spot
in
a
miserable
existence
.
 
<EOS>
My
respect
for
that
young
lady
,
my
admiration
of
her
character
,
my
devotion
to
her
for
her
love
and
truth
,
and
goodness
!
<EOS>
---
Take
me
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
down
a
turning
,
for
,
upon
my
soul
,
in
my
present
state
of
mind
<EOS>
I
am
not
equal
to
this
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
wheeled
him
off
into
a
narrow
street
,
where
he
took
out
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
and
stood
with
his
back
to
a
wall
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
looked
as
gravely
at
him
as
Traddles
did
,
he
must
have
found
our
company
by
no
means
inspiriting
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
my
fate
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
unfeignedly
sobbing
,
but
doing
even
that
,
with
a
shadow
of
the
old
expression
of
doing
something
genteel
;
"
it
is
my
fate
,
gentlemen
,
that
the
finer
feelings
of
our
nature
have
become
reproaches
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
My
homage
to
Miss
Wickfield
,
is
a
flight
of
arrows
in
my
bosom
.
 
<EOS>
You
had
better
leave
me
,
if
you
please
,
to
walk
the
earth
as
a
vagabond
.
 
<EOS>
The
worm
will
settle
my
business
in
double
-
quick
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
Without
attending
to
this
invocation
,
we
stood
by
,
until
he
put
up
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
pulled
up
his
shirt
-
collar
,
and
,
to
delude
any
person
in
the
neighbourhood
who
might
have
been
observing
him
,
hummed
a
tune
with
his
hat
very
much
on
one
side
.
 
<EOS>
I
then
mentioned
---
not
knowing
what
might
be
lost
if
we
lost
sight
of
him
yet
---
that
it
would
give
me
great
pleasure
to
introduce
him
to
my
aunt
,
if
he
would
ride
out
to
Highgate
,
where
a
bed
was
at
his
service
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
shall
make
us
a
glass
of
your
own
punch
,
Mr
Micawber
,
"
said
I
,
"
and
forget
whatever
you
have
on
your
mind
,
in
pleasanter
reminiscences
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Or
,
if
confiding
anything
to
friends
will
be
more
likely
to
relieve
you
,
you
shall
impart
it
to
us
,
Mr
Micawber
,
"
said
Traddles
,
prudently
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
"
returned
Mr
Micawber
,
"
do
with
me
as
you
will
!
<EOS>
I
am
a
straw
upon
the
surface
of
the
deep
,
and
am
tossed
in
all
directions
by
the
elephants
---
I
beg
your
pardon
;
I
should
have
said
the
elements
.
"
   
<EOS>
We
walked
on
,
arm
-
in
-
arm
,
again
;
found
the
coach
in
the
act
of
starting
;
and
arrived
at
Highgate
without
encountering
any
difficulties
by
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
very
uneasy
and
very
uncertain
in
my
mind
what
to
say
or
do
for
the
best
---
so
was
Traddles
,
evidently
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
was
for
the
most
part
plunged
into
deep
gloom
.
 
<EOS>
He
occasionally
made
an
attempt
to
smarten
himself
,
and
hum
the
fag
-
end
of
a
tune
;
but
his
relapses
into
profound
melancholy
were
only
made
the
more
impressive
by
the
mockery
of
a
hat
exceedingly
on
one
side
,
and
a
shirt
-
collar
pulled
up
to
his
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
We
went
to
my
aunt
's
house
rather
than
to
mine
,
because
of
Dora
's
not
being
well
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
presented
herself
on
being
sent
for
,
and
welcomed
Mr
Micawber
with
gracious
cordiality
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
kissed
her
hand
,
retired
to
the
window
,
and
pulling
out
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
had
a
mental
wrestle
with
himself
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
was
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
by
nature
so
exceedingly
compassionate
of
anyone
who
seemed
to
be
ill
at
ease
,
and
was
so
quick
to
find
any
such
person
out
,
that
he
shook
hands
with
Mr
Micawber
,
at
least
half
-
a
-
dozen
times
in
five
minutes
.
 
<EOS>
To
Mr
Micawber
,
in
his
trouble
,
this
warmth
,
on
the
part
of
a
stranger
,
was
so
extremely
touching
,
that
he
could
only
say
,
on
the
occasion
of
each
successive
shake
,
"
My
dear
sir
,
you
overpower
me
!
"
<EOS>
Which
gratified
Mr
Dick
so
much
,
that
he
went
at
it
again
with
greater
vigour
than
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
friendliness
of
this
gentleman
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
to
my
aunt
,
"
if
you
will
allow
me
,
ma'am
,
to
cull
a
figure
of
speech
from
the
vocabulary
of
our
coarser
national
sports
---
floors
me
.
 
<EOS>
To
a
man
who
is
struggling
with
a
complicated
burden
of
perplexity
and
disquiet
,
such
a
reception
is
trying
,
I
assure
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
friend
Mr
Dick
,
"
replied
my
aunt
proudly
,
"
is
not
a
common
man
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
I
am
convinced
of
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
sir
!
"
<EOS>
for
Mr
Dick
was
shaking
hands
with
him
again
;
"
I
am
deeply
sensible
of
your
cordiality
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
find
yourself
?
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
with
an
anxious
look
.
   
<EOS>
"
Indifferent
,
my
dear
sir
,
"
returned
Mr
Micawber
,
sighing
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
keep
up
your
spirits
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
"
and
make
yourself
as
comfortable
as
possible
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
was
quite
overcome
by
these
friendly
words
,
and
by
finding
Mr
Dick
's
hand
again
within
his
own
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
has
been
my
lot
,
"
he
observed
,
"
to
meet
,
in
the
diversified
panorama
of
human
existence
,
with
an
occasional
oasis
,
but
never
with
one
so
green
,
so
gushing
,
as
the
present
!
"
   
<EOS>
At
another
time
I
should
have
been
amused
by
this
;
but
I
felt
that
we
were
all
constrained
and
uneasy
,
and
I
watched
Mr
Micawber
so
anxiously
,
in
his
vacillations
between
an
evident
disposition
to
reveal
something
,
and
a
counter
-
disposition
to
reveal
nothing
,
that
I
was
in
a
perfect
fever
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
,
sitting
on
the
edge
of
his
chair
,
with
his
eyes
wide
open
,
and
his
hair
more
emphatically
erect
than
ever
,
stared
by
turns
at
the
ground
and
at
Mr
Micawber
,
without
so
much
as
attempting
to
put
in
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
though
I
saw
that
her
shrewdest
observation
was
concentrated
on
her
new
guest
,
had
more
useful
possession
of
her
wits
than
either
of
us
;
for
she
held
him
in
conversation
,
and
made
it
necessary
for
him
to
talk
,
whether
he
liked
it
or
not
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
very
old
friend
of
my
nephew
's
,
Mr
Micawber
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
had
had
the
pleasure
of
seeing
you
before
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
"
returned
Mr
Micawber
,
"
<EOS>
I
wish
I
had
had
the
honour
of
knowing
you
at
an
earlier
period
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
always
the
wreck
you
at
present
behold
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
Mrs
Micawber
and
your
family
are
well
,
sir
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
inclined
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
as
well
,
ma'am
,
<EOS>
"
he
desperately
observed
after
a
pause
,
"
as
Aliens
and
Outcasts
can
ever
hope
to
be
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
bless
you
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
my
aunt
,
in
her
abrupt
way
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
talking
about
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
subsistence
of
my
family
,
ma'am
,
"
returned
Mr
Micawber
,
"
trembles
in
the
balance
.
 
<EOS>
My
employer
---
"
   
<EOS>
Here
Mr
Micawber
provokingly
left
off
;
and
began
to
peel
the
lemons
that
had
been
under
my
directions
set
before
him
,
together
with
all
the
other
appliances
he
used
in
making
punch
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
employer
,
you
know
,
"
said
Mr
Dick
,
jogging
his
arm
as
a
gentle
reminder
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
good
sir
,
"
returned
Mr
Micawber
,
"
you
recall
me
,
I
am
obliged
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
They
shook
hands
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
employer
,
ma'am
---
Mr
Heep
---
once
did
me
the
favour
to
observe
to
me
,
that
if
I
were
not
in
the
receipt
of
the
stipendiary
emoluments
appertaining
to
my
engagement
with
him
,
I
should
probably
be
a
mountebank
about
the
country
,
swallowing
a
sword
-
blade
,
and
eating
the
devouring
element
.
 
<EOS>
For
anything
that
I
can
perceive
to
the
contrary
,
it
is
still
probable
that
my
children
may
be
reduced
to
seek
a
livelihood
by
personal
contortion
,
while
Mrs
Micawber
abets
their
unnatural
feats
by
playing
the
barrel
-
organ
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
,
with
a
random
but
expressive
flourish
of
his
knife
,
signified
that
these
performances
might
be
expected
to
take
place
after
he
was
no
more
;
then
resumed
his
peeling
with
a
desperate
air
.
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
leaned
her
elbow
on
the
little
round
table
that
she
usually
kept
beside
her
,
and
eyed
him
attentively
.
 
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
the
aversion
with
which
I
regarded
the
idea
of
entrapping
him
into
any
disclosure
he
was
not
prepared
to
make
voluntarily
,
I
should
have
taken
him
up
at
this
point
,
but
for
the
strange
proceedings
in
which
I
saw
him
engaged
;
whereof
his
putting
the
lemon
-
peel
into
the
kettle
,
the
sugar
into
the
snuffer
-
tray
,
the
spirit
into
the
empty
jug
,
and
confidently
attempting
to
pour
boiling
water
out
of
a
candlestick
,
were
among
the
most
remarkable
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
that
a
crisis
was
at
hand
,
and
it
came
.
 
<EOS>
He
clattered
all
his
means
and
implements
together
,
rose
from
his
chair
,
pulled
out

pocket

,
and
burst

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
behind

,
"
this
is
an
occupation
,
of
all
others
,
requiring
an

,
and
self

.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
perform

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
out
of
the
question
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Micawber
,
"
said

,
"
what
is

matter
?
 
<EOS>
Pray

out
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
among
friends
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Among
friends
,
sir
!
"
repeated
Mr
Micawber
;
and
all

had
reserved
came
breaking

.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
heavens
,
it
is
principally
because
I
AM

friends
that
my

mind
is
what

.
 
<EOS>
What
is

matter
,

?
 
<EOS>
What
is
NOT

?
 
<EOS>
Villainy
is
the
matter
;
baseness
is
the
matter
;
deception
,

,
conspiracy
,
are
the
matter
;
and
the

the
whole

is
---
HEEP
!
"
   
<EOS>
MY
aunt
clapped
her
hands
,
and
we
all
started
up
as
if

were

.
   
<EOS>
"
The
struggle
is
over
!
"
said
Mr
Micawber
violently

with
his
pocket

,
and
fairly

from

with

,
as

were

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
lead
this
life
no
longer
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
a
wretched
being
,
cut
off
from
everything
that
makes

tolerable
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
under
a
Taboo
in
that
infernal
scoundrel
's
service
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
back
my
wife
,
give
me

,
substitute
Micawber
for
the
petty

who
walks

in
the

at
present
on

feet
,
and

to
swallow

,
and
I
'll
do

.
 
<EOS>
With
an
appetite
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
never
saw
a

so

in

.
 
<EOS>
I
tried

,
that

;
but
he
got

and

,
and
would
n't

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll

's

,
"
said

,

,
"
<EOS>
until
I
have
---
blown

---
<EOS>
the
---
a
---

---

---
HEEP
!
<EOS>
I

---
<EOS>
a
---

---

---

---
HEEP

<EOS>
Refreshment
---
<EOS>
a
---

---

<EOS>

---

---

HEEP
!
"
   
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

---
<EOS>

---
<EOS>
a
---

---
Miss
Wickfield
---

---

HEEP
!
"
(

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
But

---
  
"
Most

"
<EOS>
"

,
"
   
"

.
 
<EOS>
An

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Chapter
50
.
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
's
dream
comes
true
 
<EOS>
By
this

,
some

.
 
<EOS>
I
had
never

since
,
but
she
had

Mr
Peggotty
on

.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
had
come
of
her

;
nor

,
from

,

been

,
for

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
I

that
I
began
to
despair
of
her

,
and
gradually
to

deeper
and

into
the
belief
that
she
was
dead
.
   
<EOS>
His
conviction
remained
unchanged
.
 
<EOS>
So
far

I
know
---
and
I
believe
his
honest

was
transparent

---
he
never

again
,
in
his
solemn

of
finding
her
.
 
<EOS>
His
patience
never
tired
.
 
<EOS>
And
,
although
I
trembled
for
the
agony
it
might
one
day
be
to
him
to
have
his
strong
assurance
shivered
at
a
blow
<EOS>
,
there
was
something
so
religious
in
it
,
so
affectingly
expressive
of
its
anchor

in
the

of
his
fine
nature
,
that
the
respect
and

in
which
I
held

were

every

.
   
<EOS>
His
was
not
a
lazy
trustfulness
that
hoped
,
and
did
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
a
man
of
sturdy
action
all
his
life
,
and
he
knew
that
in
all

wherein

wanted
help
he
must
do

own

faithfully
,
and
help
himself
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
known

set
out
in

,
on

that
the
light
might
not
be
,
by
some

,
in

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
known

,
on
reading

to

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
made

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
All

;
for

in
a
purpose
of
saving
money
for
Emily
's

,
when

.
 
<EOS>
In

,
I

;
I
never

,

.
   
<EOS>
Dora
had
often
seen
him
since
our
marriage
,
and
was
quite

.
 
<EOS>
I
fancy
his

before

,

her

,

his

,

my

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes

,
about

,

,

,

;
and

,
the

,

in

of

,

,
came

.
   
<EOS>
One

,

this

,

<EOS>
"
Did

?
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
I

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
No

<EOS>
"
I

more
(

"
   
<EOS>
As

long
forborne

with

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
Such
speculations
as
it
engendered
within
me
<EOS>
I
kept
to
myself
,
and
those
were
faint

.
   
<EOS>
I
was
walking

in
the
garden
,
one

,
about
a

.
 
<EOS>
I
remember
that
evening
well
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
second
in
Mr
Micawber
's
week
of
suspense
.
 
<EOS>
There
had
been
rain
all
day
,
and
there
was
a
damp
feeling
in
the
air
.
 
<EOS>
The
leaves
were
thick
upon
the
trees
,
and
heavy
with
wet
;
but
the
rain
had
ceased
,
though
the
sky
was
still
dark
;
and
the
hopeful
birds
were
singing
cheerfully
.
<EOS>
As
I
walked
to
and
fro
in
the
garden
,
and
the
twilight
began
to
close
around
me
,
their
little
voices
were
hushed
;
and
that
peculiar
silence
which
belongs
to
such
an
evening
in
the
country
when
the
lightest
trees
are
quite
still
,
save
for
the
occasional

from
their

,
prevailed
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
little
green
perspective
of
trellis
-
work
and
ivy
at
the
side
of
our
cottage
,
through
which
I
could
see
,
from
the
garden
where
I
was

,
into
the
road
before
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
happened
to
turn

towards
this
place
,
as
I
was
thinking
of
many
things
;
and
I
saw
a
figure
beyond
,
dressed
in
a
plain

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
bending
eagerly
towards
me
,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Martha
!
<EOS>
"
said
I
,
going
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Can
you
come
with
me
?
"
<EOS>
she
inquired
,
in

agitated

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
to
him
,
and
he
is
not
at

.
 
<EOS>
I
wrote
down
where
he
was
to
come
,
and

.
 
<EOS>
They
said

not

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
tidings
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
Can
you
come
directly
?
"
   
<EOS>
My
answer
was
,
to
pass
out
at

gate

.
 
<EOS>
She
made

with
her

,
as

my

and

,
and

London
,
whence
,
as
her
dress

,
she
had
come

.
   
<EOS>
I
asked

if
that
were
not

?
 
<EOS>
On
her
motioning
<EOS>
Yes
,
with
the
same
hasty
gesture
as
before
,
I
stopped
an
empty
coach
that
was
coming
by
,
and
we
got
into
it
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
asked
her
where
the
coachman
was
to
drive
,
she
answered
,
"
Anywhere
near
Golden
Square
!
<EOS>
And
quick
!
"
<EOS>
---
then
shrunk
into
a
corner
,
with
one
trembling
hand
before
her
face
,
and
the
other
making
the
former
gesture
,
as
if
she
could
not
bear
a
voice
.
   
<EOS>
Now
much
disturbed
,
and
dazzled
with
conflicting
gleams
of
hope
and
dread
,
I
looked
at
her
for
some
explanation
.
 
<EOS>
But
seeing
how
strongly
she
desired
to
remain
quiet
,
and
feeling
that
it
was
my
own
natural
inclination
too
,
at
such
a
time
,
I
did
not
attempt
to
break
the
silence
.
 
<EOS>
We
proceeded
without
a
word
being
spoken
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
she
glanced
out
of
the
window
,
as
though
she
thought
we
were
going
slowly
,
though
indeed
we
were
going
fast
;
but
otherwise
remained
exactly
as
at
first
.
   
<EOS>
We
alighted
at
one
of
the
entrances
to
the
Square
she
had
mentioned
,
where
I
directed
the
coach
to
wait
,
not
knowing
but
that
we
might
have
some
occasion
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
laid
her
hand
on
my
arm
,
and
hurried
me
on
to
one
of
the
sombre
streets
,
of
which
there
are
several
in
that
part
,
where
the
houses
were
once
fair
dwellings
in
the
occupation
of
single
families
,
but
have
,
and
had
,
long
degenerated
into
poor
lodgings
let
off
in
rooms
.
 
<EOS>
Entering
at
the
open
door
of
one
of
these
,
and
releasing
my
arm
,
she
beckoned
me
to
follow
her
up
the
common
staircase
,
which
was
like
a
tributary
channel
to
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
The
house
swarmed
with
inmates
.
 
<EOS>
As
we
went
up
,
doors
of
rooms
were
opened
and
people
's
heads
put
out
;
and
we
passed
other
people
on
the
stairs
,
who
were
coming
down
.
 
<EOS>
In
glancing
up
from
the
outside
,
before
we
entered
,
I
had
seen
women
and
children
lolling
at
the
windows
over
flower
-
pots
;
and
we
seemed
to
have
attracted
their
curiosity
,
for
these
were
principally
the
observers
who
looked
out
of
their
doors
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
broad
panelled
staircase
,
with
massive
balustrades
of
some
dark
wood
;
cornices
above
the
doors
,
ornamented
with
carved
fruit
and
flowers
;
and
broad
seats
in
the
windows
.
 
<EOS>
But
all
these
tokens
of
past
grandeur
were
miserably
decayed
and
dirty
;
<EOS>
rot
,
damp
,
and
age
,
had
weakened
the
flooring
,
which
in
many
places
was
unsound
and
even
unsafe
.
 
<EOS>
Some
attempts
had
been
made
,
I
noticed
,
to
infuse
new
blood
into
this
dwindling
frame
,
by
repairing
the
costly
old
wood
-
work
here
and
there
with
common
deal
;
but
it
was
like
the
marriage
of
a
reduced
old
noble
to
a
plebeian
pauper
,
and
each
party
to
the
ill
-
assorted
union
shrunk
away
from
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
Several
of
the
back
windows
on
the
staircase
had
been
darkened
or
wholly
blocked
up
.
 
<EOS>
In
those
that
remained
,
there
was
scarcely
any
glass
;
and
,
through
the
crumbling
frames
by
which
the
bad
air
seemed
always
to
come
in
,
and
never
to
go
out
,
I
saw
,
through
other
glassless
windows
,
into
other
houses
in
a
similar
condition
,
and
looked
giddily
down
into
a
wretched
yard
,
which
was
the
common
dust
-
heap
of
the
mansion
.
   
<EOS>
We
proceeded
to
the
top
-
storey
of
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
Two
or
three
times
,
by
the
way
,
I
thought
I
observed
in
the
indistinct
light
the
skirts
of
a
female
figure
going
up
before

.
 
<EOS>
As
we
turned
to
ascend
the
last
flight
of
stairs
between
us
and
the
roof
,
we
caught
a
full
view
of
this
figure
pausing
for
a
moment
,
at
a
door
.
 
<EOS>
Then
it
turned
the
handle
,
and
went
in
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
this
!
"
<EOS>
said
Martha
,
in
a

.
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
gone
into
my
room
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
her
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
knew
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
recognized
her
with
amazement
,
for
Miss
Dartle
.
   
<EOS>
I
said
something
to
the
effect
that
it
was
a
lady
whom
I
had
seen
before
,
in
a
few
words
,
to
my
conductress
;
and
had
scarcely

so
,
when
we
heard
her
voice
in
the
room
,
though
not
,
from
where
we
stood
,
what
she
was
saying
.
 
<EOS>
Martha
,
with
an
astonished
look
,
repeated
her
former
action
,
and
softly
led
me
up
the
stairs
;
and
then
,
by
a
little
back
-
door
which
seemed
to
have
no
lock
,
and
which
she
pushed
open
with
a
touch
,
into
a
small
empty
garret
with
a
low
sloping
roof
,
little
better
than
a
cupboard
.
 
<EOS>
Between
this
,
and
the
room
she
had
called
hers
,
there
was
a
small
door
of
communication
,
standing
partly
open
.
 
<EOS>
Here
we
stopped
,
breathless
with
our
ascent
,
and
she
placed
her
hand
lightly
on
my
lips
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
only
see
,
of
the
room
beyond
,
that
it
was
pretty
large
;
that
there
was
a
bed
in
it
;
and
that
there
were
some
common
pictures
of
ships
upon

walls
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
see
Miss
Dartle
,
or
the
person
whom
we
had
heard
her
address
.
 
<EOS>
Certainly
,
my
companion
could
not
,
for
my
position
was
the
best
.
<EOS>
A
dead
silence
prevailed
for
some
moments
.
 
<EOS>
Martha
kept
one
hand
on
my
lips
,
and
raised
the
other
in
a
listening
attitude
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
matters
little
to
me
<EOS>
her
not
being
at
home
,
"
said
Rosa
Dartle
haughtily
,
"
I
know
nothing
of
her
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
you
<EOS>
I
come
to
see
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Me
?
"
replied
a
soft
voice
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
sound
of
it
,
a
thrill
went
through
my
frame
.
 
<EOS>
For
it
was
Emily
's
!
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
returned
Miss
Dartle
,
"
I
have
come
to
look
at
you
.
 
<EOS>
What
?
<EOS>
You
are
not
ashamed
of
the
face
that
has
done
so
much
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
resolute
and
unrelenting
hatred
of
her
tone
,
its
cold
stern
sharpness
,
and
its
mastered
rage
,
presented
her
before
me
,
as
if
I
had
seen
her
standing
in
the
light
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
the
flashing
black
eyes
,
and
the
passion
-
wasted
figure
;
and
I
saw
the
scar
,
with
its
white
track
cutting
through
her
lips
,
quivering
and
throbbing
as
she
spoke
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
come
to
see
,
"
she
said
,
"
James
Steerforth
's
fancy
;
the
girl
who
ran
away
with
him
,
and
is
the
town
-
talk
of
the
commonest
people
of
her
native
place
;
the
bold
,
flaunting
,
practised
companion
of
persons
like
James
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
know
what
such
a
thing
is
like
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
rustle
,
as
if
the
unhappy
girl
,
on
whom
she
heaped
these
taunts
,
ran
towards
the
door
,
and
the
speaker
swiftly
interposed
herself
before
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
succeeded
by
a
moment
's
pause
.
   
<EOS>
When
Miss
Dartle
spoke
again
,
it
was
through
her
set
teeth
,
and
with
a
stamp
upon
the
ground
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
there
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
"
or
I
'll
proclaim
you
to
the
house
,
and
the
whole
street
!
<EOS>
If
you
try
to
evade
me
,
I
'll
stop
you
,
if
it
's
by
the
hair
,
and
raise
the
very
stones
against
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
A
frightened
murmur
was
the
only
reply
that
reached
my
ears
.
 
<EOS>
A
silence
succeeded
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
not
know
what
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
Much
as
I
desired
to
put
an
end
to
the

,
I
felt
that
I
had
no
right
to
present
myself
;
that
it

for
Mr
Peggotty
alone
to
see
her
and
recover
her
.
 
<EOS>
Would
he
never
come
?
 
<EOS>
I
thought
impatiently
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
!
"
said
Rosa
Dartle
,
with
a
contemptuous

,
"
I
see
her
at
last
!
<EOS>
Why
,
he
was
a
poor
creature
to
be
taken
by
that
delicate
mock
-
modesty
,
and
that
hanging

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
for
Heaven
's
sake
,
spare
me
!
"
exclaimed
Emily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Whoever
you
are
,
you
know
my
pitiable
story
,
and
for
Heaven
's
sake
spare
me
,
if
you
would
be
spared
yourself
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
would
be
spared
!
"
returned
the
other

;
"
what
is
there
in
common
between
US
,
do
you
think
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
but
our
sex
,
"
said
Emily
,
with
a
burst

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
that
,
"
said
Rosa
Dartle
,
"
is
so
strong
a
claim
,
preferred
by
one
so
infamous
,
that
if
I
had
any
feeling
in
my
breast
but
scorn
and

of
you
,
it
would
freeze
it
up
.
 
<EOS>
Our
sex
!
<EOS>
You
are
an
honour
to
our
sex
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
deserved
this
,
"
said
Emily
,
"
but
<EOS>
it
's
dreadful
!
<EOS>
Dear
,
dear
lady
,
think
what
I
have
suffered
,
and
how
I
am
fallen
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
Martha
,
come
back
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
home
,
home
!
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Dartle
placed
herself
in
a
chair
,
within
view
of
the
door
,
and
looked
downward
,
as
if
Emily
were

.
 
<EOS>
Being
now
between
me
and
the
light
,
I
could
see
her
curled

,
and
her

intently

one

,
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
Listen
to
what
I
say
!
<EOS>
"
she
said
;
"
and
reserve
your
false
arts
for
your
dupes
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
hope
to
move
me
by
your
tears
?
 
<EOS>
No
more
than
you
could
charm
me
by
your
smiles
,
you
purchased
slave
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
have
some
mercy
on
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Emily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Show
me
some
compassion
,
or
I
shall
die
mad
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
no
great
penance
,
"
said
Rosa
Dartle
,
"
for
your
crimes
.
<EOS>
Do
you
know
what
you
have
done
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
ever
think
of
the
home
<EOS>
you
have
laid
waste
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
is
there
ever
night
or
day
,
when
I
do
n't
think
of
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Emily
;
and
now
I
could
just
see
her
,
on

,
with
her

,
her

,

<EOS>
"
Has

I

for

!
<EOS>
Oh
,
home
,

!
<EOS>
Oh

,

,

good
,

so

;
but

,

,

!
<EOS>
I

,
none
,

earth
,
for
all

!
"
<EOS>
She

in

,
with

.
   
<EOS>
Rosa
Dartle
sat
looking
down
upon
her
,
as
inflexible
as
a
figure
of
brass
.
 
<EOS>
Her
lips
were
tightly
compressed
,
as
if
she
knew
that
she
must
keep
a
strong
constraint
upon
herself
---
I
write
what
I
sincerely
believe
---
or
she
would
be
tempted
to
strike
the
beautiful
form

.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
her
,
distinctly
,
and
the
whole
power
of
her
face
and
character
seemed
forced
into
that

.
 
<EOS>
---
Would
he
never
come
?
   
<EOS>
"
The
miserable
vanity
of
these
earth
-
worms
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
when
she
had
so
far

of
her

,
that
she
could

.
 
<EOS>
"
YOUR
home
!
<EOS>
Do
you

I
bestow
a
thought

,
or
suppose

could
do

harm
to
that
low
place
,
which
money

not

for
,
and

?
 
<EOS>
YOUR
home
!
<EOS>
You
were
a
part
of
the
trade
of
your
home
,
and
were
bought
and
sold
like
any

vendible

your

dealt

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
not

!
"
cried

.
 
<EOS>
"
Say

me
;
but

,

,

!
<EOS>
Have
some

,
as

,
if

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
speak
,
"
she

,
not

,

from

's

,
"
I
speak

HIS

---
where
I

.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
"
she

,

!
"
<EOS>

"

,

"
<EOS>
She

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
It

,

?
"

<EOS>
"
It

,

.
<EOS>
Bless

you

<EOS>
And

.
"
   
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

asthma
,
and
the
failure
of
his
limbs
,
were
the
various

of
a
great
invention
for
enhancing

of
a
pipe
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
see
more
of
the
world
,
I
can
assure

,
"
said
Mr
Omer
,
"
in
this

,
than
ever
I
see

.
 
<EOS>
You
'd

that

.
 
<EOS>
You

!
<EOS>
There

twice

in

,
since

've

.
 
<EOS>
As

,
dear

<EOS>
That

<EOS>
If

?
 
<EOS>
If

<EOS>
Being

?
 
<EOS>
Why

.
 
<EOS>
And

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"
Lord

!
"
<EOS>

,

,
"
a

,

.
 
<EOS>
Joram

.
 
<EOS>
Ex

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
What

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
And

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
I

"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
And

<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
Dear

!
"
   
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
After

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Dear

,
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because

"

"

<EOS>
Put

,

<EOS>
I

the

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Young

<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
Why

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
So
,

for

,

?
 
and

.
 
<EOS>
Dear
me
!
"
said

Omer
,
"
when

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

:
<EOS>
Mr
Omer
indescribably

,
and

on

's

.
   
<EOS>
After

town
I
went

Ham
's

.
 
<EOS>
Peggotty
had
now
removed
here
for

;
and
had
let

own
house
to
the

Mr
Barkis
in
the

,
who
had
paid

very

for
the

-

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
the
very
same
slow

that
Mr
Barkis

was

.
   
<EOS>
I

in

,

Mrs
Gummidge
,
who
had

old

.
 
<EOS>
I

she

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
evidently

all
.
 
<EOS>
Both
Peggotty
and
Mrs
Gummidge
had
their
aprons
to

,
and
Ham
had
just

"
to

"
.
 
<EOS>
He
presently
came
home
,
very
glad
to

;
and
I
hope

were
all

.
 
<EOS>
We
spoke
,
with
some
approach
to
cheerfulness
,
of
Mr
Peggotty
's
growing
rich
in
a
new
country
,
and
of
the
wonders
he
would

in

.
 
<EOS>
We
said
nothing
of
Emily
by
name
,
but
distantly
referred
to
her
more
than
once
.
 
<EOS>
Ham
was
the
serenest
of
the
party
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
Peggotty
told
me
,
when
she
lighted
me
to
a
little
chamber
where
the
Crocodile
book
was
lying
ready
for
me
on
the

,
that
he
always
was
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
She
believed
(
she
told
me
,
crying
)
that
he
was
broken
-
hearted
;
though
he
was
as
full
of
courage
as

,
and
worked
harder
and

than
any
boat
-
builder
in
any

in
all

part
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
times
,
she
said
,
of
an

,
when
he
talked
of
their
old
life
in
the
boat
-
house
;
and
then
he
mentioned
Emily
as
a
child
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
he
never
mentioned
her
as
a
woman
.
   
<EOS>
I
thought
I
had
read
in
his
face
that
he
would
like
to
speak
to
me
alone
.
 
<EOS>
I
therefore
resolved
to
put
myself
in
his
way
next
evening
,
as
he
came
home
from
his
work
.
 
<EOS>
Having
settled
this
with
myself
,
I
fell
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
That
night
,
for
the
first
time
in
all
those
many
nights
,
the
candle
was
taken
out
of
the
window
,
Mr
Peggotty
swung
in
his
old
hammock
in
the
old
boat
,
and
the
wind
murmured
with
the
old
sound
round
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
All
next
day
,
he
was
occupied
in
disposing
of
his
fishing
-
boat
and

;
in
packing
up
,
and
sending
to
London
by
waggon
,
such
of
his
little
domestic
possessions
as
he
thought
would
be
useful
to
him
;
and
in
parting
with
the
rest
,
or
bestowing
them
on
Mrs
Gummidge
.
<EOS>
She
was
with
him
all
day
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
had
a
sorrowful
wish
to
see
the
old
place
once
more
,
before
it
was
locked
up
,
I
engaged
to
meet
them
there
in
the
evening
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
so
arranged
it
,
as
that
I
should
meet
Ham
first
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
easy
to
come
in
his
way
,
as
I
knew
where
he
worked
.
 
<EOS>
I
met
him
at
a
retired
part
of
the
sands
,
which
I
knew
he
would
cross
,
and
turned
back
with
him
,
that
he
might
have
leisure
to
speak
to
me
if
he
really
wished
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
not
mistaken
the
expression
of
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
walked
but
a
little
way
together
,
when
he
said
,
without
looking
at
me
:
   
"
Mas'r
Davy
,
have
you
seen
her
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Only
for
a
moment
,
when
she
was
in
a
swoon
,
"
I
softly
answered
.
   
<EOS>
We
walked
a
little
farther
,
and
he
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Mas'r
Davy
,
shall
you
see
her
,
d'ye
think
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

,

,
"

<EOS>
"
I
have
thowt

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
So
'
twould
,

,

twould
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
Ham

"

<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

!
<EOS>
I

theer

<EOS>
"

?
"
   
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
'
Tan't

.
 
<EOS>
'

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

?

<EOS>
"
Theer

.

"
   
<EOS>
We

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

---

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

A'most

<EOS>

<EOS>
Everything

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.

.
 
<EOS>
Next

,

,

and

and

.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
52
.
<EOS>
I
assist
at
an
explosion
 
<EOS>
When
the
time
Mr
Micawber
had
appointed
so
mysteriously
,
was
within
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
of
being
come
,
my
aunt
and
I
consulted
how
we
should
proceed
;
for
my
aunt
was
very
unwilling
to
leave
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
how
easily
I
carried
Dora
up
and
down
stairs
,
now
!
   
<EOS>
We
were
disposed
,
notwithstanding
Mr
Micawber
's
stipulation
for
my
aunt
's
attendance
,
to
arrange
that
she
should
stay
at
home
,
and
be
represented
by
Mr
Dick
and
me
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
we
had
resolved
to
take
this
course
,
when
Dora
again
unsettled
us
by
declaring
that
she
never
would
forgive
herself
,
and
never
would
forgive
her
bad
boy
,
if
my
aunt
remained
behind
,
on
any
pretence
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
speak
to
you
,
"
said
Dora
,
shaking
her
curls
at
my
aunt
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
be
disagreeable
!
<EOS>
I
'll
make
Jip
bark
at
you
all
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
be
sure
that
you
really
are
a
cross
old
thing
,
if
you
do
n't
go
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tut
,
Blossom
!
<EOS>
"
laughed
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
you
ca
n't
do
without
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
can
,
"
said
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
no
use
to
me
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
You
never
run
up
and
down
stairs
for
me
,
all

.
 
<EOS>
You
never
sit

Doady
,
when
his

were

,
and
he
was

---
<EOS>
oh
,
what
a

mite
of

!
<EOS>
You
never
do
anything
at
all
to
please
me
,

,

?
"
<EOS>
Dora
made
haste
to

aunt
,
and

,
"
Yes
,
you
do
!
<EOS>
I
'm

!
"
<EOS>
---
lest
my

should
think

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
aunt
,
"
said

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
You
must
go
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
tease
you
,
'

.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
lead

boy
<EOS>
such

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
shall

---

!
<EOS>
You
'll
wish

gone
,
like

,
