,
if
you
do
n't
go
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
,
"
said
Dora
,
putting
back
her
hair
,
and
looking
wonderingly
at
my
aunt
and
me
,
<EOS>
"
why
should
n't
you
both
go
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
very
ill
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
Am
I
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
a
question
!
<EOS>
"
cried
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
a
fancy
!
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
I
know
I
am
a
silly
little
thing
!
"
said
Dora
,
slowly
looking
from
one
of
us
to
the
other
,
and
then
putting
up
her
pretty
lips
to
kiss
us
as
she
lay
upon
her
couch
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
you
must
both
go
,
or
I
shall
not
believe
you
;
and
then
I
shall
cry
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
saw
,
in
my
aunt
's
face
,
that
she
began
to
give
way
now
,
and
Dora
brightened
again
,
as
she
saw
it
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
come
back
with
so
much
to
tell
me
,
that
it
'll
take
at
least
a
week
to
make
me
understand
!
"
said
Dora
.
 
<EOS>
"
Because
I
know
I
sha
n't
understand
,
for
a
length
of
time
,
if
there
's
any
business
in
it
.
<EOS>
And
there
's
sure
to
be
some
business
in
it
!
<EOS>
If
there
's
anything
to
add
up
,
besides
,
I
do
n't
know
when
I
shall
make
it
out
;
and
my
bad
boy
will
look
so
miserable
all
the
time
.
 
<EOS>
There
!
<EOS>
Now
you
'll
go
,
wo
n't
you
?
 
<EOS>
You
'll
only
be
gone
one
night
,
and
Jip
will
take
care
of
me
while
you
are
gone
.
 
<EOS>
Doady
will
carry
me
upstairs
before
you
go
,
and
I
wo
n't
come
down
again
till
you
come
back
;
and
you
shall
take
Agnes
a
dreadfully
scolding
letter
from
me
,
because
she
has
never
been
to
see
us
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
agreed
,
without
any
more
consultation
,
that
we
would
both
go
,
and
that
Dora
was
a
little
Impostor
,
who
feigned
to
be
rather
unwell
,
because
she
liked
to
be
petted
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
greatly
pleased
,
and
very
merry
;
and
we
four
,
that
is
to
say
,
my
aunt
,
Mr
Dick
,
Traddles
,
and
I
,
went
down
to
Canterbury
by
the
Dover
mail
that
night
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
hotel
where
Mr
Micawber
had
requested
us
to
await
him
,
<EOS>
which
we
got
into
,
with
some
trouble
,
<EOS>
in
the
middle
of
the
night
,
I
found
a
letter
,
importing
that
he
would
appear
in
the
morning
punctually
at
half
past
nine
.
 
<EOS>
After
which
,
we
went
shivering
,
at
that
uncomfortable
hour
,
to
our
respective
beds
,
through
various
close
passages
;
which
smelt
as
if
they
had
been
steeped
,
for
ages
,
in
a
solution
of
soup
and
stables
.
   
<EOS>
Early
in
the
morning
,
I
sauntered
through
the
dear
old
tranquil
streets
,
and
again
mingled
with
the
shadows
of
the
venerable
gateways
and
churches
.
 
<EOS>
The
rooks
were
sailing
about
the
cathedral
towers
;
and
the
towers
themselves
,
overlooking
many
a
long
unaltered
mile
of
the
rich
country
and
its
pleasant
streams
,
were
cutting
the
bright
morning
air
,
as
if
there
were
no
such
thing
as
change
on
earth
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
the
bells
,
when
they
sounded
,
told
me
sorrowfully
of
change
in
everything
;
told
me
of
their
own
age
,
and
my
pretty
Dora
's
youth
;
and
of
the
many
,
never
old
,
who
had
lived
and
loved
and
died
,
while
the
reverberations
of
the
bells
had
hummed
through
the
rusty
armour
of
the
Black
Prince
hanging
up
within
,
and
,
motes
upon
the
deep
of
Time
,
had
lost
themselves
in
air
,
as
circles
do
in
water
.
   
<EOS>
I
looked
at
the
old
house
from
the
corner
of
the
street
,
but
did
not
go
nearer
to
it
,
lest
,
being
observed
,
I
might
unwittingly
do
any
harm
to
the
design
I
had
come
to
aid
.
 
<EOS>
The
early
sun
was
striking
edgewise
on
its
gables
and
lattice
-
windows
,
touching
them
with
gold
;
and
some
beams
of
its
old
peace
seemed
to
touch
my
heart
.
   
<EOS>
I
strolled
into
the
country
for
an
hour
or
so
,
and
then
returned
by
the
main
street
,
which
in
the
interval
had
shaken
off
its
last
night
's
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
Among
those
who
were
stirring
in
the
shops
,
I
saw
my
ancient
enemy
the
butcher
,
now
advanced
to
top
-
boots
and
a
baby
,
and
in
business
for
himself
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
nursing
the
baby
,
and
appeared
to
be
a
benignant
member
of
society
.
   
<EOS>
We
all
became
very
anxious
and
impatient
,
when
we
sat
down
to
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
approached
nearer
and
nearer
to
half
past
nine
o'clock
,
our
restless
expectation
of
Mr
Micawber
increased
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
we
made
no
more
pretence
of
attending
to
the
meal
,
which
,
except
with
Mr
Dick
,
had
been
a
mere
form
from
the
first
;
but
my
aunt
walked
up
and
down
the
room
<EOS>
,
Traddles
sat
upon
the
sofa
affecting
to
read
the
paper
with
his
eyes
on
the
ceiling
;
and
I
looked
out
of
the
window
to
give
early
notice
of
Mr
Micawber
's
coming
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
had
I
long
to
watch
,
for
,
<EOS>
at
the
first
chime
of
the
half
hour
,
he
appeared
in
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
he
is
,
"
said
I
,
"
and
not
in
his
legal
attire
!
"
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
tied
the
strings
of
her
bonnet
(
she
had
come
down
to
breakfast
in
it
)
,
and
put
on
her
shawl
,
as
if
she
were
ready
for
anything
that
was
resolute
and
uncompromising
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
buttoned
his
coat
with
a
determined
air
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
,
disturbed
by
these
formidable
appearances
,
but
feeling
it
necessary
to
imitate
them
,
pulled
his
hat
,
with
both
hands
,
as
firmly
over
his
ears
as
he
possibly
could
;
and
instantly
took
it
off
again
,
to
welcome
Mr
Micawber
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
and
madam
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
good
morning
!
<EOS>
My
dear
sir
,
"
to
Mr
Dick
,
who
shook
hands
with
him
violently
,
"
you
are
extremely
good
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
breakfasted
?
"
said
Mr
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
a
chop
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
for
the
world
,
my
good
sir
!
"
cried
Mr
Micawber
,
stopping
him
on
his
way
to
the
bell
;
"
appetite
and
myself
,
Mr
Dixon
,
have
long
been
strangers
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dixon
was
so
well
pleased
with
his
new
name
,
and
appeared
to
think
it
so
obliging
in
Mr
Micawber
to
confer
it
upon
him
,
that
he
shook
hands
with
him
again
,
and
laughed
rather
childishly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dick
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
attention
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dick
recovered
himself
,
with
a
blush
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
sir
,
"
said
my
aunt
to
Mr
Micawber
,
as
she
put
on
her
gloves
,
"
we
are
ready
for
Mount
Vesuvius
,
or
anything
else
,
as
soon
as
YOU
please
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
"
returned
Mr
Micawber
,
"
<EOS>
I
trust
you
will
shortly
witness
an
eruption
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Traddles
,
I
have
your
permission
,
I
believe
,
to
mention
here
that
we
have
been
in
communication
together
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
undoubtedly
the
fact
,
Copperfield
,
"
said
Traddles
,
to
whom
I
looked
in
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Micawber
has
consulted
me
in
reference
to
what
he
has
in
contemplation
;
and
I
have
advised
him
to
the
best
of
my
judgement
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Unless
I
deceive
myself
,
Mr
Traddles
,
"
pursued
Mr
Micawber
,
"
what
I
contemplate
is
a
disclosure
of
an
important
nature
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Highly
so
,
"
said
Traddles
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
,
under
such
circumstances
,
madam
and
gentlemen
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
you
will
do
me
the
favour
to
submit
yourselves
,
for
the
moment
,
to
the
direction
of
one
who
,
however
unworthy
to
be
regarded
in
any
other
light
but
as
a
Waif
and
Stray
upon
the
shore
of
human
nature
,
is
still
your
fellow
-
man
,
though
crushed
out
of
his
original
form
by
individual
errors
,
and
the
accumulative
force
of
a
combination
of
circumstances
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
have
perfect
confidence
in
you
,
Mr
Micawber
,
"
said
I
,
"
and
will
do
what
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
returned
Mr
Micawber
,
"
your
confidence
is
not
,
at
the
existing
juncture
,
ill
-
bestowed
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
beg
to
be
allowed
a
start
of
five
minutes
by
the
clock
;
and
then
to
receive
the
present
company
,
inquiring
for
Miss
Wickfield
,
at
the
office
of
Wickfield
and
Heep
,
whose
Stipendiary
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
and
I
looked
at
Traddles
,
who
nodded
his
approval
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
more
,
"
observed
Mr
Micawber
,
"
to
say
at
present
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
which
,
to
my
infinite
surprise
,
he
included
us
all
in
a
comprehensive
bow
,
and
disappeared
;
his
manner
being
extremely
distant
,
and
his
face
extremely
pale
.
   
<EOS>
Traddles
only
smiled
,
and
shook
his
head
(
with
his
hair
standing
upright
on
the
top
of
it
)
,
when
I
looked
to
him
for
an
explanation
;
so
I
took
out
my
watch
,
and
,
as
a
last
resource
,
counted
off
the
five
minutes
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
with
her
own
watch
in
her
hand
,
did
the
like
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
time
was
expired
,
Traddles
gave
her
his
arm
;
and
we
all
went
out
together
to
the
old
house
,
without
saying
one
word
on
the
way
.
   
<EOS>
We
found
Mr
Micawber
at
his
desk
,
in
the
turret
office
on
the
ground
floor
,
either
writing
,
or
pretending
to
write
,
hard
.
 
<EOS>
The
large
office
-
ruler
was
stuck
into
his
waistcoat
,
and
was
not
so
well
concealed
but
that
a
foot
or
more
of
that
instrument
protruded
from
his
bosom
,
like
a
new
kind
of
shirt
-
frill
.
   
<EOS>
As
it
appeared
to
me
that
I
was
expected
to
speak
,
I
said
aloud
:
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
,
Mr
Micawber
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
gravely
,
"
<EOS>
I
hope
I
see
you
well
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Miss
Wickfield
at
home
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Wickfield
is
unwell
in
bed
,
sir
,
of
a
rheumatic
fever
,
"
he
returned
;
"
but
Miss
Wickfield
<EOS>
,
I
have
no
doubt
,
will
be
happy
to
see
old
friends
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
walk
in
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
preceded
us
to
the
dining
-
room
---
the
first
room
I
had
entered
in
that
house
---
and
flinging
open
the
door
of
Mr
Wickfield
's
former
office
,
said
,
in
a
sonorous
voice
:
   
"
Miss
Trotwood
,
Mr
David
Copperfield
,
Mr
Thomas
Traddles
,
and
Mr
Dixon
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
had
not
seen
Uriah
Heep
since
the
time
of
the
blow
.
 
<EOS>
Our
visit
astonished
him
,
evidently
;
not
the
less
,
I
dare
say
,
because
it
astonished
ourselves
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
not
gather
his
eyebrows
together
,
for
he
had
none
worth
mentioning
;
but
he
frowned
to
that
degree
that
he
almost
closed
his
small
eyes
,
while
the
hurried
raising
of
his
grisly
hand
to
his
chin
betrayed
some
trepidation
or
surprise
.
<EOS>
This
was
only
when
we
were
in
the
act
of
entering
his
room
,
and
when
I
caught
a
glance
at
him
over
my
aunt
's
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
A
moment
afterwards
,
he
was
as
fawning
and
as
humble
as
ever
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
am
sure
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
indeed
an
unexpected
pleasure
!
<EOS>
To
have
,
as
I
may
say
,
all
friends
round
<EOS>
St
Paul
's
at
once
,
is
a
treat
unlooked
for
!
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
,
I
hope
I
see
you
well
,
and
---
if
I
may
umbly
express
myself
so
---
friendly
towards
them
as
is
ever
your
friends
,
whether
or
not
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Copperfield
,
sir
<EOS>
,
I
hope
she
's
getting
on
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
been
made
quite
uneasy
by
the
poor
accounts
we
have
had
of
her
state
,
lately
,
I
do
assure
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
ashamed
to
let
him
take
my
hand
,
but
I
did
not
know
yet
what
else
to
do
.
   
<EOS>
"
Things
are
changed
in
this
office
,
Miss
Trotwood
,
since
I
was
an
umble
clerk
,
and
held
your
pony
;
ai
n't
they
?
"
said
Uriah
,
with
his
sickliest
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
not
changed
,
Miss
Trotwood
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
returned
my
aunt
,
"
to
tell
you
the
truth
,
I
think
you
are
pretty
constant
to
the
promise
of
your
youth
;
if
that
's
any
satisfaction
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Miss
Trotwood
,
"
said
Uriah
,
writhing
in
his
ungainly
manner
,
"
for
your
good
opinion
!
<EOS>
Micawber
,
tell
'em
to
let
Miss
Agnes
know
---
and
mother
.
 
<EOS>
Mother
will
be
quite
in
a
state
,
when
she
sees
the
present
company
!
"
said
Uriah
,
setting
chairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
busy
,
Mr
Heep
?
"
said
Traddles
,
whose
eye
the
cunning
red
eye
accidentally
caught
,
as
it
at
once
scrutinized
and
evaded
us
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
Mr
Traddles
,
"
replied
Uriah
,
resuming
his
official
seat
,
and
squeezing
his
bony
hands
,
laid
palm
to
palm
between
his
bony
knees
.
<EOS>
"
Not
so
much
so
as
I
could
wish
.
 
<EOS>
But
lawyers
,
sharks
,
and
leeches
,
are
not
easily
satisfied
,
you
know
!
<EOS>
Not
but
what
myself
and
Micawber
have
our
hands
pretty
full
,
in
general
,
on
account
of
Mr
Wickfield
's
being
hardly
fit
for
any
occupation
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
's
a
pleasure
as
well
as
a
duty
<EOS>
,
I
am
sure
,
to
work
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
You
've
not
been
intimate
with
Mr
Wickfield
,
I
think
,
<EOS>
Mr
Traddles
?
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
've
only
had
the
honour
of
seeing
you
once
myself
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
have
not
been
intimate
with
Mr
Wickfield
,
"
returned
Traddles
;
"
or
I
might
perhaps
have
waited
on
you
long
ago
,
Mr
Heep
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
something
in
the
tone
of
this
reply
,
which
made
Uriah
look
at
the
speaker
again
,
with
a
very
sinister
and
suspicious
expression
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
seeing
only
Traddles
,
with
his
good
-
natured
face
,
simple
manner
,
and
hair
on
end
,
he
dismissed
it
as
he
replied
,
with
a
jerk
of
his
whole
body
,
but
especially
his
throat
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
for
that
,
Mr
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
You
would
have
admired
him
as
much
as
we
all
do
.
 
<EOS>
His
little
failings
would
only
have
endeared
him
to
you
the
more
.
 
<EOS>
But
if
you
would
like
to
hear
my
fellow
-
partner
eloquently
spoken
of
,
I
should
refer
you
to
Copperfield
.
 
<EOS>
The
family
is
a
subject
<EOS>
he
's
very
strong
upon
,
if
you
never
heard
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
prevented
from
disclaiming
the
compliment
(
if
I
should
have
done
so
,
in
any
case
)
,
by
the
entrance
of
Agnes
,
now
ushered
in
by
Mr
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
not
quite
so
self
-
possessed
as
usual
,
I
thought
;
and
had
evidently
undergone
anxiety
and
fatigue
.
 
<EOS>
But
her
earnest
cordiality
,
and
her
quiet
beauty
,
shone
with
the
gentler
lustre
for
it
.
   
<EOS>
I
saw
Uriah
watch
her
while
she
greeted
us
;
and
he
reminded
me
of
an
ugly
and
rebellious
genie
watching
a
good
spirit
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
meanwhile
,
some
slight
sign
passed
between
Mr
Micawber
and
Traddles
;
and
Traddles
,
unobserved
except
by
me
,
went
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
wait
,
Micawber
,
"
said
Uriah
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
,
with
his
hand
upon
the
ruler
in
his
breast
,
stood
erect
before
the
door
,
most
unmistakably
contemplating
one
of
his
fellow
-
men
,
and
that
man
his
employer
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
waiting
for
?
"
said
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
"
Micawber
!
<EOS>
did
you
hear
me
tell
you
not
to
wait
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
!
"
replied
the
immovable
Mr
Micawber
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
why
DO
you
wait
?
"
said
Uriah
.
   
<EOS>
"
Because
I
---
in
short
,
choose
,
"
replied
Mr
Micawber
,
with
a
burst
.
   
<EOS>
Uriah
's
cheeks
lost
colour
,
and
an
unwholesome
paleness
,
still
faintly
tinged
by
his
pervading
red
,
overspread
them
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
at
Mr
Micawber
attentively
,
with
his
whole
face
breathing
short
and
quick
in
every
feature
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
dissipated
fellow
,
as
all
the
world
knows
,
"
he
said
,
with
an
effort
at
a
smile
,
"
and
I
am
afraid
you
'll
oblige
me
to
get
rid
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
Go
along
!
<EOS>
I
'll
talk
to
you
presently
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
there
is
a
scoundrel
on
this
earth
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
suddenly
breaking
out
again
with
the
utmost
vehemence
,
"
with
whom
I
have
already
talked
too
much
,
that
scoundrel
's
name
is
---
HEEP
!
"
   
<EOS>
Uriah
fell
back
,
as
if
he
had
been
struck
or
stung
.
 
<EOS>
Looking
slowly
round
upon
us
with
the
darkest
and
wickedest
expression
that
his
face
could
wear
,
he
said
,
in
a
lower
voice
:
   
<EOS>
"
Oho
!
<EOS>
This
is
a
conspiracy
!
<EOS>
You
have
met
here
by
appointment
!
<EOS>
You
are
playing
Booty
with
my
clerk
,
are
you
,
Copperfield
?
 
<EOS>
Now
,
take
care
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
make
nothing
of
this
.
 
<EOS>
We
understand
each
other
,
you
and
me
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
no
love
between
us
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
always
a
puppy
with
a
proud
stomach
,
from
your
first
coming
here
;
and
you
envy
me
my
rise
,
do
you
?
 
<EOS>
None
of
your
plots
against
me
;
I
'll
counterplot
you
!
<EOS>
Micawber
,
you
be
off
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
talk
to
you
presently
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Micawber
,
"
said
I
,
"
there
is
a
sudden
change
in
this
fellow
.
<EOS>
in
more

than
the

one
of
his
speaking
the
truth

one

,
which
assures
me
that
he
is

to
bay
.
 
<EOS>
Deal
with
him
as

deserves
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
precious
set

,
ai

?
"
<EOS>
said
Uriah
,
in
the
same

,
and
breaking

,

,
with

,
"
to
buy

my
clerk
,
who
is
the

,
---
as

,
Copperfield
<EOS>
,

know

,

,
---

?
 
<EOS>
Miss
Trotwood
,

had

;
or

shorter

.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
know
your
story
professionally
,

,

!
<EOS>
Miss
Wickfield
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,

!
<EOS>
I

got
some

you

.
 
<EOS>
Think

,

.
 
<EOS>
Think

,
you
,
Micawber
,

.
<EOS>
I

to

,

,

!
<EOS>
while

.
 
<EOS>
Where
's

?
"

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Fine

's

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Heep
is

,

,
"

,

that
worthy

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who

?
"
<EOS>
retorted

.
 
<EOS>
"
And

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

,

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

,
"
said
Uriah
,

"

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Something
has

"

"

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ury
---
!
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Heep

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
YOU
hold
your

,
mother
,
"
he
returned
;
"
least

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
,
my
Ury
---
"
   
"
Will
you
hold
your
tongue
,
mother
,
and
leave

to
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
Though
I
had
long
known
that
his
servility
was
false
,
and
all
his
pretences
knavish
and
hollow
,
I
had
had
no
adequate
conception
of
the
extent
of
his

,
until
I
now
saw
him
with
his
mask
off
.
<EOS>
The
suddenness
with
which
he
dropped
it
,
when
he
perceived
that
it
was
useless
to
him
;
the

,

,
and

<EOS>
,
he
revealed
;
the
leer
with
which
he
exulted
,
even

this
moment
,
in
the
evil
he
had
done
---
all
this
time
being
desperate
too
,
and
at
his
wits
'
end
for
the
means
of
getting
the
better
of
us
---
though
perfectly
consistent
with
the
experience
I
had
of
him
,
at
first
took
even
me
by
surprise
,
who
had
known
him
so
long
,
and
disliked
him
so
heartily
.
   
<EOS>
I
say
nothing
of
the
look
he
conferred
on
me
,
as
he
stood
eyeing
us
,
one
after
another
;
for
I
had
always
understood
that
he
hated
me
,
and
I
remembered
the
marks
of
my
hand
upon
his
cheek
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
his
eyes
passed
on
to
Agnes
,
and
I
saw
the
rage
with
which
he
felt
his
power
over
her
slipping
away
,
and
the
exhibition
,
in
their
disappointment
,
of
the
odious
passions
that
had
led
him
to
aspire
to
one
whose
virtues
he
could
never
appreciate
or
care
for
,
I
was
shocked
by
the
mere
thought
of
her
having
lived
,
an
hour
,
within
sight
of
such
a
man
.
   
<EOS>
After
some
rubbing
of
the
lower
part
of
his
face
,
and
some
looking
at
us
with
those
bad
eyes
,
over
his
grisly
fingers
,
he
made
one
more
address
to
me
,
half
whining
,
and
half

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
think
it
justifiable
,
do
you
,
<EOS>
Copperfield
,
you
who
pride
yourself
so
much
on
your
honour
and
all
the
rest
of
it
,
to
sneak
about
my
place
,
eaves
-
dropping
with

clerk
?
 
<EOS>
If
it
had
been
ME
,
I
should
n't
have
wondered
;
for
I
do
n't
make
myself
out

(
though
I
never
was
in
the

,
as
you
were
,
according

Micawber
)
,
but
being
you
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
And
you
're
not
afraid
of
doing
this
,

?
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
think

all
of
what
I
shall
do
,
in
return
;
or
of
getting
yourself
into

for

and

?
 
<EOS>
Very
well
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
see
!
<EOS>
Mr
What's
-
your
-
name
,
you
were
going
to
refer
some

Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
There
's

.
 
<EOS>
Why
do
n't
you
make
him
speak
?
 
<EOS>
He
has
learnt
his
lesson
,
I
see
.
"
   
<EOS>
Seeing
that
what
he
said
had
no
effect
on
me
or
any
of
us
,
he
sat
on
the
edge
of
his

with
his

in

,
and
one

his
splay
feet
twisted
round
the
other

,
waiting
doggedly
for
what
might

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
,
whose
impetuosity
I
had
restrained
thus
far
with
the
greatest
difficulty
,
and
who
had
repeatedly
interposed
with
the
first
syllable
Of
SCOUN
-
drel
!
<EOS>
without
getting
to
the
second
,
now
burst
forward
,
drew
the
ruler
from
his
breast
(
apparently
as
a

)
,
and
produced
from
his
pocket
a
foolscap
document
,
folded
in

a
large

.
 
<EOS>
Opening
this
packet
,
with
his
old
flourish
,
and
glancing
at
the
contents
<EOS>
,
as
if
he
cherished
an
artistic
admiration
of
their
style
of
composition
,
he
began
to
read
as
follows
:
   
"
<EOS>
"
Dear
Miss
Trotwood
and
gentlemen
---
"
"
   
"
Bless
and
save
the
man
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
my
aunt
in
a
low
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
'd
write
letters
by
the
ream
,
if
it
was
a
capital
offence
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
,
without
hearing
her
,
went
on
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
In
appearing
before
you
to
denounce
probably
the
most
consummate
Villain
that
has
ever
existed
,
"
"
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
,
without
looking
off

letter
,
pointed
the
ruler
,
like
a
ghostly
truncheon
,
at
Uriah
Heep
,
"
"
I
ask
no
consideration
for
myself
.
 
<EOS>
The
victim
,
from
my
cradle
,
of
pecuniary
liabilities
to
which
I
have
been
unable
to
respond
,
I
have
ever
been
the
sport
and
toy
of
debasing
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
Ignominy
,
Want
,
Despair
,
and
Madness
,
have
,
collectively
or
separately
,
been
the
attendants
of
my
career
.
"
<EOS>
"
   
The
relish
with
which
Mr
Micawber
described
himself
as
a
prey
to
these
dismal
calamities
,
was
only
to
be
equalled
by
the
emphasis
with
which
he
read
his
letter
;
and
the
kind
of
homage
he
rendered
to
it
with
a
roll
of
his
head
,
when
he
thought
he
had
hit
a
sentence
very
hard
indeed
.
   
"
"
In
an
accumulation
of
Ignominy
,
Want
,
Despair
,
and
Madness
,
I
entered
the
office
---
or
,
as
our
lively
neighbour
the
Gaul
would
term
it
,
the
Bureau
---
of
the
Firm
,
nominally
conducted
under
the
appellation
of
Wickfield
and
---
HEEP
,
but
in
reality
,
wielded
by
---
HEEP
alone
.
 
<EOS>
HEEP
,
and
only
HEEP
,
is
the
mainspring
of
that
machine
.
 
<EOS>
HEEP
,
and
only
HEEP
,
is
the
Forger
and
the
Cheat
.
"
<EOS>
"
   
Uriah
,
more
blue
than
white
at
these
words
,
made
a
dart
at
the
letter
,
as
if
to
tear
it
in
pieces
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
,
with
a
perfect
miracle
of
dexterity
or
luck
,
caught
his
advancing
knuckles
with
the
ruler
,
and
disabled
his
right
hand
.
 
<EOS>
It
dropped
at
the
wrist
,
as
if
it
were
broken
.
 
<EOS>
The
blow
sounded
as
if
it
had
fallen
on
wood
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
Devil
take
you
!
"
<EOS>
said
Uriah
,
writhing
in
a
new
way
with
pain
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
be
even
with
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Approach
me
again
,
you
---
you
---
you
HEEP
of
infamy
,
"
gasped
Mr
Micawber
,
"
and
if
your
head
is
human
,
I
'll
break
it
.
 
<EOS>
Come
on
,
come
on
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
think
I
never
saw
anything
more
ridiculous
<EOS>
---
I
was
sensible
of
it
,
even
at
the
time
---
than
Mr
Micawber
making
broad
-

with
the
ruler
,
and
crying
,
"
Come
on
!
"
<EOS>
while
Traddles
and
I
pushed
him
back
into
a
corner
,
from
which
,
as
often

we
got

into

,
he
persisted
in
emerging
again
.
   
<EOS>
His
enemy
,
muttering
to

,
after

for
sometime
,
slowly
drew
off
his
neck

then
held

in

and
sat
upon

his

down
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
,
when
he
was
sufficiently
cool
,
proceeded
with
his
letter
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
The
stipendiary
emoluments
in

I
entered
into

of
---
HEEP
,
"
"
always

that

and
uttering

"
"
were
not

,
beyond

twenty
-
two

.
 
<EOS>
The
rest

on

;
in

<EOS>
Need

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
   
Mr

's

,

<EOS>
He

"
<EOS>
"

---
HEEP
---
<EOS>

<EOS>
Then

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

an

Mr
W.
 
<EOS>
That
Mr
W
was
imposed

,

,

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
This

;
but
,

,

"
<EOS>
"
   
Mr

,

us

<EOS>

<EOS>

Second

<EOS>
HEEP

,

,

<EOS>
To
wit
,
in
manner
following
<EOS>
,
that
is
to
say
:
"
"
   
Again
,
Mr
Micawber
had
a
relish
in
this
formal
piling
up
of
words
,
which
,
however
ludicrously
displayed
in
his
case
,
was
,
I
must
say
,
not
at
all
peculiar
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
observed
it
,
in
the
course
of
my
life
,
in
numbers
of
men
.
 
<EOS>
It
seems
to
me
to
be
a
general
rule
.
<EOS>
In
the
taking
of
legal
oaths
,
for
instance
,
deponents
seem
to
enjoy
themselves
mightily
when
they
come
to
several
good
words
in
succession
,
for
the
expression
of
one
idea
;
as
,
that
they
utterly
detest
,
abominate
,
and
abjure
,
or
so
forth
;
and
the
old
anathemas
were
made
relishing
on
the
same
principle
.
 
<EOS>
We
talk
about
the
tyranny
of
words
,
but
we
like
to
tyrannize
over
them
too
;
we
are
fond
of
having
a
large
superfluous
establishment
of
words
to
wait
upon
us
on
great
occasions
;
we
think
it
looks
important
,
and
sounds
well
.
 
<EOS>
As
we
are
not
particular
about
the
meaning
of
our
liveries
on
state
occasions
,
if
they
be
but
fine
and
numerous
enough
,
so
,
the
meaning
or

of
our
words
is
a
secondary
consideration
,
if
there
be
but
a
great

of

.
 
<EOS>
And
as
individuals
get
into
trouble
by
making
too
great
a
show
of
liveries
,
or
as
slaves
when
they
are
too
numerous
rise
against

masters
,
so
I
think
I
could
mention
a
nation
that
has
got
into
many

,
and
will
get
into
many
greater
,
from
maintaining
too
large

retinue
of
words
.

Mr
Micawber
read
on
,

:
   
"
"
To
wit
,

,

.

Mr
W

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
Uriah

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
And

"

"
in

,
when
this
was
written
,
but
have
since
relinquished
it
to
Mr
Traddles
.
"
"
   
"
It
is
quite
true
,
"
assented
Traddles
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ury
,
Ury
!
"
cried
the
mother
,
"
be
umble
and
make
terms
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
my
son
will
be
umble
,

,
if
you

to
think
.
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
,
I
'm
sure
you
know
that
he
was
always
very
umble
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
singular
to
see
how
the
mother
still
held
to
the
old
trick
,
when
the
son
had
abandoned

as

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
"
he

,
with

,
"
you

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
I

,
Ury
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
And
I
have
no

did
;
or
that
he
loved
her
<EOS>
,
however
strange

may

;
though
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
ca
n't

to

,

of
yourself
more
.
<EOS>
I

at
first
,

upstairs
it

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
see

umble

,

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
there
's
Copperfield
,

"

;

<EOS>
"
there
's
Copperfield
,

've

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't

,
Ury
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca

,

.
 
<EOS>
Better
be
umble
,

was
.
"
   
<EOS>
He

a

,

<EOS>
"
What

?
 
<EOS>
If

,

.
 
<EOS>
What

for
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
promptly
resumed
his
letter
,
glad
to
revert
to
a
performance
with
which
he
was
so

.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Third
.
 
<EOS>
And
last
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
now
in

condition
to
show
,
by
---
HEEP
'S
---
false

,
and
---
HEEP
'S
---
real

,

with
the

(

,

the

,

W

---
HEEP
.
 
<EOS>
That

W

---
HEEP
.
 
<EOS>
That

---
HEEP
---

,

,

Mr

W
(
of

the

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
That

,

,

to

W

---
HEEP
---
on

.
 
<EOS>
That
these
meshes
;
beginning
with
alarming
and
falsified
accounts
of
the
estate
of
which
Mr
W
is
the
receiver
,
at
a
period
when
Mr
W
had
launched
into
imprudent
and
ill

judged
speculations
,
and
may
not
have
had
the

,
for

was
morally

,
in

;
going
on
with

of

at

,

from
---
HEEP
---
and
by
---
HEEP
---
fraudulently

or

from
Mr
W
himself
,
on

of
such

or

;
perpetuated

a

of
unscrupulous

---
gradually
thickened
,
until
the
unhappy
Mr
W
could
see
no

beyond
.
 
<EOS>
Bankrupt
,
as
he
believed
,
alike
in

,
in

,
and

,
his

upon
the

man
,
"
"
<EOS>
---
Mr
Micawber
made
a

this
,
as
a
new

expression
,
---
"
"
who
,

making

necessary

,

.
 
<EOS>
All
this
I
undertake
to
show
.
<EOS>
Probably
much

!
"
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
whispered

to
Agnes
,
who
was

,
half

,
half

,
at
my

;
and
there
was

among

,
as
if
Mr
Micawber
had
finished
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
,
with
exceeding

,
"
Pardon
me
,
"
and
proceeded
,
with
a

the
lowest

,
to
the

of
his
letter
.
    
<EOS>
"
"
I
have
now
concluded
.
 
<EOS>
It
merely
remains
for
me
to
substantiate
these
accusations
;
and
then
,
with
my
ill
-
starred
family
,
to
disappear
from
the
landscape
on
which
we
appear
to
be
an
encumbrance
.
 
<EOS>
That
is
soon
done
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
reasonably
inferred
that
our
baby
will
first
expire
of
inanition
,
as
being
the
frailest
member
of
our
circle
;
and
that
our
twins
will
follow
next
in
order
.
<EOS>
So
be
it
!
<EOS>
For
myself
,
my
Canterbury
Pilgrimage
has
done
much
;
imprisonment
on
civil
process
,
and
want
,
will
soon
do
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
trust
that
the
labour
and
hazard
of
an
investigation
---
of
which
the
smallest
results
have
been
slowly
pieced
together
,
in
the
pressure
of
arduous
avocations
,
under
grinding
penurious
apprehensions
,
at
rise

,

,

,
under
the

of
one
whom
it
were

to
call
Demon
---
combined
with
the

of
parental
Poverty
to
turn
it
,
when

,
to
the
right
account
,
may
be
as

few

.
 
<EOS>
I
ask
no

.
 
<EOS>
Let
it
be
,
in
justice
,
merely
said
of
me
,
as
of
a
gallant
and

Hero
,
with

I

cope
,
that
what
I

,
I

,
in

of

.
"
<EOS>
"
    
"
For
England
,

,

.
"
     
<EOS>
"
"
Remaining
always
,
&
c
 
&
c
,
WILKINS
MICAWBER
.
"
<EOS>
"
     
Much

,
but

,

,

my
aunt
,
as
something
she
might
like
to
keep
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
,
as
I

on
my

visit
long

,
an
iron
safe
in
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
The
key
was
in

.
 
<EOS>
A

Uriah
;
and
,

Mr
Micawber
,
he
went
to

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
empty
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where

?
<EOS>
"
he

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Some

has

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
tapped

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
,
when
I
got
the
key
from
you

---
but

---

.

<EOS>
"
Do

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
They

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
receive

,

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Under
such

,
"

,
"
yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
What

,

,
make

Uriah
Heep
,

seize

!
   
<EOS>
"
You

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
A

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
My
property
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Agnes
,
my
dear
,

I

,
I

---
and
,
my

<EOS>
,

,

Trot
,

---
breathe

.
<EOS>
But
,

's

,
and
I
'll

!
<EOS>
Trot
,
come

it
away

!
"
   
<EOS>
Whether

aunt
supposed
,

,
that
he
kept
her
property
in
his
neck
-
kerchief
,
I
am
sure
I
do
n't

;
but
she
certainly
pulled
at
it
as
if

thought

.
 
<EOS>
I
hastened
to
put
myself
between
them
,
and
to
assure
her
that
we
would
all
take

that
he
should
make
the
utmost

of
everything
he
had
wrongly
got
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
and
a

'

,
pacified
her
;
but
she
was
not
at

by

she
had
done
<EOS>
(
though
I
can
not
say

much
for
her
bonnet
)
and
resumed
her
seat
composedly
.
   
<EOS>
During
the
last

minutes
,
Mrs
Heep
had
been
clamouring
to
her
son
to
be
"
umble
"
;
and
had
been
going
down
on
her

to
all

us
in

,
and
making

.
 
<EOS>
Her
son
sat

down

;
and
,
standing

by

,
holding
her
arm
with

,
but

,
said
to

,
with

:
   
"
What
do
you
want
done
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
tell
you
what
must

done
,
"
said
Traddles
.
   
<EOS>
"
Has
that
Copperfield
no
tongue
?
"
<EOS>
muttered
Uriah
,
"
I
would
do
a

for

if
you

tell

,
without

,
that
somebody
had
cut

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
Uriah
means
to
be
umble
!
"
cried

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't

what

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
First
,

,

,

---

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Suppose
I
have
n't

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
But

have
,
"
said
Traddles
;
"
therefore
,

know
,
we
wo
n't
suppose
so
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
I

justice
to

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
,
"

,
"

,

to

.
 
<EOS>
All

books
and

must

our

;

and

;
all

,

.
 
<EOS>
In

,
everything
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Must
it
?
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
that
,
"
said
Uriah
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
have
time
to
think

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
replied
Traddles
;
"
but
,

,
and
until
everything
is
done
to

,
we
shall
maintain

these

;
and
beg

---
in

,
compel

---
to
keep

,

hold

with
anyone
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
do
it
!
"
<EOS>
said
Uriah
,
with
an
oath
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Maidstone
jail
is
a
safer
place
of
detention
,
"
observed
Traddles
;
"
and
though
the
law
may
be
longer
in
righting
us
,
and
may
not

able
to
right
us
so
completely
as
you
can
,
there
is
no
doubt
of
its
punishing
YOU
.
 
<EOS>
Dear
me
,
you
know
that
quite
as
well
as
I
!
<EOS>
Copperfield
,
will
you
go
round
to
the
Guildhall
,
and
bring
a
couple
of
officers
?
"
   
<EOS>
Here
,
Mrs
Heep
broke
out
again
,
crying
on
her
knees
to
Agnes
to
interfere
in
their
behalf
,
exclaiming
that
he
was
very
humble
,
and
it
was
all
true
,
and
if
he
did
n't
do
what
we
wanted
,
she
would
,
and
much
more
to
the
same
purpose
;
being
half
frantic
with
fears
for
her
darling
.
 
<EOS>
To
inquire
what
he
might
have
done
,
if
he
had
had
any
boldness
,
would
be
like
inquiring
what
a
mongrel
cur
might
do
,
if
it
had
the
spirit
of
a
tiger
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
coward
,
from
head
to
foot
;
and
showed
his
dastardly
nature
through
his
sullenness
and
mortification
,
as
much
as
at
any
time
of
his
mean
life
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
"
<EOS>
he
growled
to
me
;
and
wiped
his
hot
face
with
his
hand
.
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
hold
your
noise
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
Let
'em
have
that
deed
.
 
<EOS>
Go
and
fetch
it
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
help
her
,
Mr
Dick
,
"
said
Traddles
,
"
if
you
please
.
"
   
<EOS>
Proud
of
his
commission
,
and
understanding
it
<EOS>
,
Mr
Dick
accompanied
her
as
a
shepherd
's
dog
might
accompany
a
sheep
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
Mrs
Heep
gave
him
little
trouble
;
for
she
not
only
returned
with
the
deed
,
but
with
the
box
in
which
it
was
,
where
we
found
a
banker
's
book
and
some
other
papers
that
were
afterwards
serviceable
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
!
"
said
Traddles
,
when
this
was
brought
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Mr
Heep
,
you
can
retire
to
think
:
particularly
observing
,
if
you
please
,
that
I
declare
to
you
,
on
the
part
of
all
present
,
that
there
is
only
one
thing
to
be
done
;
that
it
is
what
I
have
explained
;
and
that
it
must
be
done
without
delay
.
"
   
<EOS>
Uriah
,
without
lifting
his
eyes
from
the
ground
,
shuffled
across
the
room
with
his
hand
to
his
chin
,
and
pausing
at
the
door
,
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
Copperfield
,
I
have
always
hated
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
've
always
been
an
upstart
,
and
you
've
always
been
against
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
I
think
I
told
you
once
before
,
"
said
I
,
<EOS>
"
it
is
you
who
have
been
,
in
your
greed
and
cunning
,
against
all
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
profitable
to
you
to
reflect
,
in
future
,
that
there
never
were
greed
and
cunning
in
the
world
yet
,
<EOS>
that
did
not
do
too
much
,
and
overreach
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
as
certain
as
death
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Or
as
certain
as
they
used
to
teach
at
school
(
the
same
school
where
I
picked
up
so
much
umbleness
)
,
from
nine
o'clock
to
eleven
,
that
labour
was
a
curse
;
and
from
eleven
o'clock
to
one
,
that
it
was
a
blessing
and
a
cheerfulness
,
and
a
dignity
,
and
I
do
n't
know
what
all
,
eh
?
<EOS>
"
said
he
with
a
sneer
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
preach
,
about
as
consistent
as
they
did
.
 
<EOS>
Wo
n't
umbleness
go
down
?
 
<EOS>
I
should
n't
have
got
round
<EOS>
my
gentleman
fellow
-
partner
without
it
<EOS>
,
I
think
.
 
<EOS>
---
Micawber
,
you
old
bully
,
I
'll
pay
YOU
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
,
supremely
defiant
of
him
and
his
extended
finger
,
and
making
a
great
deal
of
his
chest
until
he
had
slunk
out
at
the
door
,
then
addressed
himself
to
me
,
and
proffered
me
the
satisfaction
of
"
witnessing
the
re
-
establishment
of
mutual
confidence
between
himself
and
Mrs
Micawber
"
.
 
<EOS>
After
which
,
he
invited
the
company
generally
to
the
contemplation
of
that
affecting
spectacle
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
veil
that
has
long
been
interposed
between
Mrs
Micawber
and
myself
,
is
now
withdrawn
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
;
"
and
my
children
and
the
Author
of
their
Being
can
once
more
come
in
contact
on
equal
terms
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As
we
were
all
very
grateful
to
him
,
and
all
desirous
to
show
that
we
were
,
as
well
as
the
hurry
and
disorder
of
our
spirits
would
permit
,
I
dare
say
we
should
all
have
gone
,
but
that
it
was
necessary
for
Agnes
to
return
to
her
father
,
as
yet
unable
to
bear
more
than
the
dawn
of
hope
;
and
for
someone
else
to
hold
Uriah
in
safe

.
 
<EOS>
So
,
Traddles
remained
for
the
latter
purpose
,
to
be
presently
relieved
by
Mr
Dick
;
and
Mr
Dick
,
my
aunt
,
and
I
,
went
home
with
Mr
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
parted
hurriedly
from
the
dear
girl
to
whom
I
owed
so
much
,
and
thought
from
what
she
had
been
saved
,
perhaps
,
that
morning
---
her
better
resolution
notwithstanding
---
I
felt
devoutly
thankful
for
the
miseries
of
my
younger
days
which
had
brought
me
to
the
knowledge
of
Mr
Micawber
.
   
<EOS>
His
house
was
not
far
off
;
and
as
the
street
door
opened
into
the
sitting
-
room
,
and
he
bolted
in
with
a
precipitation
quite
his
own
,
we
found
ourselves
at
once
in
the
bosom
of
the
family
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
exclaiming
,
"
Emma
!
<EOS>
my
life
!
<EOS>
"
rushed
into
Mrs
Micawber
's
arms
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Micawber
shrieked
,
and
folded
Mr
Micawber
in
her
embrace
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Micawber
,
nursing
the
unconscious
stranger
of
Mrs
Micawber
's
last
letter
to
me
,
was
sensibly
affected
.
 
<EOS>
The
stranger
leaped
.
 
<EOS>
The
twins
testified
their
joy
by
several
inconvenient
but
innocent
demonstrations
.
 
<EOS>
Master
Micawber
,
whose
disposition
appeared
to
have
been
soured
by
early
disappointment
,
and
whose
aspect
had
become
morose
,
yielded
to
his
better
feelings
,
and
blubbered
.
   
<EOS>
"
Emma
!
"
said
Mr
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
cloud
is
past
from
my
mind
.
<EOS>
Mutual
confidence
,
so
long
preserved
between
us
once
,
is
restored
,
to
know
no
further
interruption
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
welcome
poverty
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Mr
Micawber
,
shedding
tears
.
 
<EOS>
"
Welcome
misery
,
welcome
houselessness
,
welcome
hunger
,
rags
,
tempest
,
and
beggary
!
<EOS>
Mutual
confidence
will
sustain
us
to
the
end
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
expressions
,
Mr
Micawber
placed
Mrs
Micawber
in
a
chair
,
and
embraced
the
family
all
round
;
welcoming
a
variety
of
bleak
prospects
,
which
appeared
,
to
the
best
of
my
judgement
,
to
be
anything
but
welcome
to
them
;
and
calling
upon
them
to
come
out
into
Canterbury
and
sing
a
chorus
,
as
nothing
else
was
left
for
their
support
.
   
<EOS>
But
Mrs
Micawber
having
,
in
the
strength
of
her
emotions
,
fainted
away
,
the
first
thing
to
be
done
,
even
before
the
chorus
could
be
considered
complete
,
was
to
recover
her
.
 
<EOS>
This
my
aunt
and
Mr
Micawber
did
;
and
then
my
aunt
was
introduced
,
and
Mrs
Micawber
recognized
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Excuse
me
,
dear
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
the
poor
lady
,
giving
me
her
hand
,
"
but
I
am
not
strong
;
and
the
removal
of
the
late
misunderstanding
between
Mr
Micawber
and
myself
was
at
first
too
much
for
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
this
all
your
family
,
ma'am
?
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
are
no
more
at
present
,
"
returned
Mrs
Micawber
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
gracious
,
I
did
n't
mean
that
,
ma'am
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
mean
,
are
all
these
yours
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
"
replied
Mr
Micawber
,
"
it
is
a
true
bill
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
And
that
eldest
young
gentleman
,
now
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
musing
,
"
what
has
he
been
brought
up
to
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
my
hope
when
I
came
here
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
to
have
got
Wilkins
into
the
Church
:
or
perhaps
I
shall
express
my
meaning
more

,
if
I
say
the
Choir
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
no
vacancy
for
a
tenor
in
the
venerable
Pile
for
which
this
city
is
so
justly
eminent
;
and
he
has
---
in

,
he
has
contracted
a
habit
of
singing
in
public
-
houses
,
rather
than
in

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
he
means
well
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
tenderly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
,
my
love
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Micawber
,
"
that
he
means
particularly
well
;
but
I
have
not
yet
found
that
he
carries
out
his
meaning
,
in
any
given
direction
whatsoever
.
"
   
<EOS>
Master
Micawber
's
moroseness
of
aspect
returned
upon
him
again
,
and
he
demanded
,
with
some
temper
,
what
he
was
to
do
?
 
<EOS>
Whether
he
had
been
born
a
carpenter
,
or
a
coach
-
painter
,
any
more
than
he
had
been
born
a
bird
?
 
<EOS>
Whether
he
could
go
into
the
next
street
,
and
open
a
chemist
's
shop
?
 
<EOS>
Whether
he
could
rush
to
the
next
assizes
,
and
proclaim
himself
a
lawyer
?
 
<EOS>
Whether
he
could
come
out
by
force
at
the
opera
,
and
succeed
by
violence
?
 
<EOS>
Whether
he
could
do
anything
,
without
being
brought
up
to
something
?
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
mused
a
little
while
,
and
then
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
,
I
wonder
you
have
never
turned
your

to
emigration
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
"
returned
Mr
Micawber
,
"
it
was
the
dream
of
my
youth
,
and
the
fallacious
aspiration
of
my
riper
years
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
am
thoroughly
persuaded
,
by
the
by
,
that
he
had
never
thought
of
it
in
his
life
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
?
"
said
my
aunt
,
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what

would
be

and
your

,
Mr

Mrs

,
if

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Capital
,
madam
,
capital
,
"

Micawber
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
That

principal
,
I
may

,

Mr
Copperfield
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Capital
?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
doing
us
a
great
service
---
have
done

a

,
I

,
for
surely
much
will

---
and

do
for
you
,
that

half

as

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
not

as

,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
full
of
fire
and

,
"
but
if

advanced
,
say

five

,
per

,
upon

---
<EOS>
say

notes

hand
,
at
twelve
,

,

four

,

,
to

something
to

---
"
   
"
Could
be
?
 
<EOS>
Can
be
and
shall
be
,
on
your
own
terms
,
"
returned
my
aunt
,
"
if
you
say

.
 
<EOS>
Think
of
this
now
,
both

you
.
 
<EOS>
Here
are
some
people
David
knows
,
going
out
to
Australia
shortly
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
decide
to
go
,
why

?
 
<EOS>
You
may

.
 
<EOS>
Think

this
now
,
Mr
and
Mrs
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
Take
your
time
,
and
weigh

well
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
but
one
question
,
my
dear

,
I
could

,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
climate
,
I
believe
,
is
healthy
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Finest
in
the
world
!
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Just
so
,
"
returned
Mrs
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
my
question
arises
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
are

of
the
country
such
,
that
a

Mr
Micawber
's

would

?
 
<EOS>
I

not

,

,

,

;
but

to

---

---
and

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
better
opening
anywhere
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
"
for
a
man
who
conducts
himself
well
,
and
is

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
For
a
man
who
conducts
himself
well
,
"
repeated
Mrs
Micawber
,
with
her
clearest
business
manner
,
"
and
is
industrious
.
 
<EOS>
Precisely
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
evident
to
me
that
Australia
is
the
legitimate
sphere
of
action
for
Mr
Micawber
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
entertain
the
conviction
,
my
dear
madam
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
"
that
it
is
,
under
existing
circumstances
,
the
land
,
the
only
land
,
for
myself
and
family
;
<EOS>
and
that
something
of
an
extraordinary
nature
will
turn
up
on
that
shore
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
no
distance
---
comparatively
speaking
;
and
though
consideration
is
due
to
the
kindness
of
your
proposal
,
I
assure
you
that
is
a
mere
matter
of
form
.
"
   
<EOS>
Shall
I
ever
forget
how
,
in
a
moment
,
he
was
the
most
sanguine
of
men
,
looking
on
to

;
or
how
Mrs
Micawber
presently
discoursed
about
the
habits
of
the
kangaroo
!
<EOS>
Shall
I
ever
recall
that
street
of
Canterbury
on
a
market
-
day
,
without
recalling
him
,
as
he
walked
back
with
us
;
expressing
,
in
the
hardy
roving
manner
he
assumed
,
the
unsettled
habits
of
a
temporary
sojourner
in
the
land
;
and
looking
at
the
bullocks
,
as
they
came
by
,
with
the
eye
of
an
Australian
farmer
!
      
<EOS>
Chapter
53
.
<EOS>
Another
retrospect
 
<EOS>
I
must
pause
yet
once
again
.
 
<EOS>
O
,
my
child
-
wife
,
there
is
a
figure
in
the
moving
crowd
before
my
memory
,
quiet
and
still
,
saying
in
its
innocent
love
and
childish
beauty
,
Stop
to
think
of
me
---
turn
to
look
upon
the
Little
Blossom
,
as
it
flutters
to
the
ground
!
   
<EOS>
I
do
.
 
<EOS>
All
else
grows
dim
,
and
fades
away
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
again
with
Dora
,
in
our
cottage
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
how
long
she
has
been
ill
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
so
used
to
it
in
feeling
,
that
I
can
not
count
the
time
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
really
long
,
in
weeks
or
months
;
but
,
in
my
usage
and
experience
,
it
is
a
weary
,
weary
while
.
   
<EOS>
They
have
left
off
telling
me
to
"
wait
a
few
days
more
"
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
begun
to
fear
,
remotely
,
that
the
day
may
never
shine
,
when
I
shall
see
my
child
-
wife
running
in
the
sunlight
with
her
old
friend
Jip
.
   
<EOS>
He
is
,
as
it
were
suddenly
,
grown
very
old
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
that
he
misses
in
his
mistress
,
something
that
enlivened
him
and
made
him
younger
;
but
he
mopes
,
and
his
sight
is
weak
,
and
his
limbs
are
feeble
,
and
my
aunt
is
sorry
that
he
objects
to
her
no
more
,
but
creeps
near
her
as
he
lies
on
Dora
's
bed
<EOS>
---
she
sitting
at
the
bedside
---
and
mildly
licks
her
hand
.
   
<EOS>
Dora
lies
smiling
on
us
,
and
is
beautiful
,
and
utters
no
hasty
or
complaining
word
.
 
<EOS>
She
says
that
we
are
very
good
to
her
;
that
her
dear
old
careful
boy
is
tiring
himself
out
,
she
knows
;
that
my
aunt
has
no
sleep
,
yet
is
always
wakeful
,
active
,
and
kind
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
the
little
bird
-
like
ladies
come
to
see
her
;
and
then
we
talk
about
our
wedding
-
day
,
and
all
that
happy
time
.
   
<EOS>
What
a
strange
rest
and
pause
in
my
life
there
seems
to
be
---
and
in
all
life
,
within
doors
and
without
---
when
I
sit
in
the
quiet
,
shaded
,
orderly
room
,
with
the
blue
eyes
of
my
child
-
wife
turned
towards
me
,
and
her
little
fingers
twining
round
my
hand
!
<EOS>
Many
and
many
an
hour
I
sit
thus
;
but
,
of
all
those
times
,
three
times
come
the
freshest
on
my
mind
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
morning
;
and
Dora
,
made
so
trim
by
my
aunt
's
hands
,
shows
me
how
her
pretty
hair
will
curl
upon
the
pillow
yet
,
an
how
long
and
bright
it
is
,
and
how
she
likes
to
have
it
loosely
gathered
in
that
net
she
wears
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
that
I
am
vain
of
it
,
now
,
you
mocking
boy
,
"
she
says
,
when
I
smile
;
"
but
because
you
used
to
say
you
thought
it
so
beautiful
;
and
because
,
when
I
first
began
to
think
about
you
,
I
used
to
peep
in
the
glass
,
and
wonder
whether
you
would
like
very
much
to
have
a
lock
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
what
a
foolish
fellow
you
were
,
Doady
,
when
I
gave
you
one
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
was
on
the
day
when
you
were
painting
the
flowers
I
had
given
you
,
Dora
,
and
when
I
told
you
how
much
in
love
I
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
but
I
did
n't
like
to
tell
you
,
"
says
Dora
,
"
then
,
how
I
had
cried
over
them
,
because
I
believed
you
really
liked
me
!
<EOS>
When
I
can
run
about
again
as
I
used
to
do
,
Doady
,
let
us
go
and
see
those
places
where
we
were
such
a
silly
couple
,
shall
we
?
 
<EOS>
And
take
some
of
the
old
walks
?
 
<EOS>
And
not
forget
poor
papa
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
we
will
,
and
have
some
happy
days
.
 
<EOS>
So
you
must
make
haste
to
get
well
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
shall
soon
do
that
!
<EOS>
I
am
so
much
better
,
you
do
n't
know
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
is
evening
;
and
I
sit
in
the
same
chair
,
by
the
same
bed
,
with
the
same
face
turned
towards
me
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
been
silent
,
and
there
is
a
smile
upon
her
face
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
ceased
to
carry
my
light
burden
up
and
down
stairs
now
.
 
<EOS>
She
lies
here
all
the
day
.
   
<EOS>
"
Doady
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Dora
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
think
what
I
am
going
to
say
,
unreasonable
,
after
what
you
told
me
,
such
a
little
while
ago
,
of
Mr
Wickfield
's
not
being
well
?
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
see
Agnes
.
 
<EOS>
Very
much
I
want
to
see
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
write
to
her
,
my
dear
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Directly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
good
,
kind
boy
!
<EOS>
Doady
,
take
me
on
your
arm
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
my
dear
,
it
's
not
a
whim
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
not
a
foolish
fancy
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
,
very
much
indeed
,
to
see
her
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
certain
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
only
to
tell
her
so
,
and
she
is
sure
to
come
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
lonely
when
you
go
downstairs
,
now
?
"
<EOS>
Dora
whispers
,
with
her
arm
about
my
neck
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
be
otherwise
,
my
own
love
,
when
I
see
your
empty
chair
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
empty
chair
!
"
<EOS>
She
clings
to
me
for
a
little
while
,
in
silence
.
"
<EOS>
And
you
really
miss
me
,
Doady
?
"
looking
up
,
and
brightly
smiling
.
<EOS>
"
Even
poor
,
giddy
,
stupid
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
heart
,
who
is
there
upon
earth
that
I
could
miss
so
much
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
husband
!
<EOS>
I
am
so
glad
,
yet
so
sorry
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
creeping
closer
to
me
,
and
folding
me
in
both
her
arms
.
 
<EOS>
She
laughs
and
sobs
,
and
then
is
quiet
,
and
quite
happy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
!
"
<EOS>
she
says
.
 
<EOS>
"
Only
give
Agnes
my
dear
love
,
and
tell
her
that
I
want
very
,
very
,
much
to
see
her
;
and
I
have
nothing
left
to
wish
for
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Except
to
get
well
again
,
Dora
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Doady
!
<EOS>
Sometimes
I
think
---
<EOS>
you
know
I
always
was
a
silly
little
thing
!
<EOS>
---
that
that
will
never
be
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
say
so
,
Dora
!
<EOS>
Dearest
love
,
do
n't
think
so
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
,
if
I
can
help
it
,
Doady
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
very
happy
;
though
my
dear
boy
is
so
lonely
by
himself
,
before
his
child
-
wife
's
empty
chair
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
is
night
;
and
I
am
with
her
still
.
 
<EOS>
Agnes
has
arrived
;
has
been
among
us
for
a
whole
day
and
an
evening
.
 
<EOS>
She
,
my
aunt
,
and
I
,
have
sat
with
Dora
since
the
morning
,
all
together
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
not
talked
much
,
but
Dora
has
been
perfectly
contented
and
cheerful
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
now
alone
.
   
<EOS>
Do
I
know
,
now
,
that
my
child
-
wife
will
soon
leave
me
?
 
<EOS>
They
have
told
me
so
;
they
have
told
me
nothing
new
to
my
thoughts
---
but
I
am
far
from
sure
that
I
have
taken
that
truth
to
heart
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
master
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
withdrawn
by
myself
,
many
times
today
,
to
weep
.
<EOS>
I
have
remembered
Who
wept
for
a
parting
between
the
living
and
the
dead
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
bethought
me
of
all
that
gracious
and
compassionate
history
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
tried
to
resign
myself
,
and
to
console
myself
;
and
that
,
I
hope
,
I
may
have
done
imperfectly
;
but
what
I
can
not
firmly
settle
in
my
mind
is
,
that
the
end
will
absolutely
come
.
 
<EOS>
I
hold
her
hand
in
mine
<EOS>
,
I
hold
her
heart
in
mine
,
I
see
her
love
for
me
,
alive
in
all
its
strength
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
shut
out
a
pale
lingering
shadow
of
belief
that
she
will
be
spared
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
to
speak
to
you
,
Doady
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
to
say
something
I
have
often
thought
of
saying
,
lately
.
 
<EOS>
You
wo
n't
mind
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
with
a
gentle
look
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mind
,
my
darling
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Because
I
do
n't
know
what
you
will
think
,
or
what
you
may
have
thought
sometimes
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
have
often
thought
the
same
.
<EOS>
Doady
,
dear
,
I
am
afraid
I
was
too
young
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
lay
my
face
upon
the
pillow
by
her
,
and
she
looks
into
my
eyes
,
and
speaks
very
softly
.
 
<EOS>
Gradually
,
as
she
goes
on
,
I
feel
,
with
a
stricken
heart
,
that
she
is
speaking
of
herself
as
past
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
,
dear
,
I
was
too
young
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mean
in
years
only
,
but
in
experience
,
and
thoughts
,
and
everything
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
such
a
silly
little
creature
!
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
it
would
have
been
better
,
if
we
had
only
loved
each
other
as
a
boy
and
girl
,
and
forgotten
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
begun
to
think
I
was
not
fit
to
be
a
wife
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
try
to
stay
my
tears
,
and
to
reply
,
"
Oh
,
Dora
,
love
,
as
fit
as
I
to
be
a
husband
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
with
the
old
shake
of
her
curls
.
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
!
<EOS>
But
if
I
had
been
more
fit
to
be
married
I
might
have
made
you
more
so
,
too
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
,
you
are
very
clever
,
and
I
never
was
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
have
been
very
happy
,
my
sweet
Dora
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
very
happy
,
very
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
years
went
on
,
my
dear
boy
would
have
wearied
of
his
child
-
wife
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
have
been
less
and
less
a
companion
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
have
been
more
and
more
sensible
of
what
was
wanting
in
his
home
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
n't
have
improved
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
better
as
it
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Dora
,
dearest
,
dearest
,
do
not
speak
to
me
so
.
 
<EOS>
Every
word
seems
a
reproach
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
not
a
syllable
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
answers
,
kissing
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
my
dear
,
you
never
deserved
it
,
and
I
loved
you
far
too
well
to
say
a
reproachful
word
to
you
,
in
earnest
---
it
was
all
the
merit
I
had
,
except
being
pretty
---
or
you
thought
me
so
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
lonely
,
down
-
stairs
,
Doady
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
!
Very
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
cry
!
<EOS>
Is
my
chair
there
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
its
old
place
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
how
my
poor
boy
cries
!
<EOS>
Hush
,
hush
!
<EOS>
Now
,
make
me
one
promise
.
<EOS>
I
want
to
speak
to
Agnes
.
 
<EOS>
When
you
go
downstairs
,
tell
Agnes
so
,
and
send
her
up
to
me
;
and
while
I
speak
to
her
,
let
no
one
come
---
not
even
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
speak
to
Agnes
by
herself
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
speak
to
Agnes
,
quite
alone
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
promise
that
she
shall
,
immediately
;
but
I
can
not
leave
her
,
for
my
grief
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
said
that
it
was
better
as
it
is
!
"
<EOS>
she
whispers
,
as
she
holds
me
in
her
arms
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Doady
,
after
more
years
,
you
never
could
have
loved
your
child
-
wife
better
than
you
do
;
and
,
after
more
years
,
she
would
so
have
tried
and
disappointed
you
,
that
you
might
not
have
been
able
to
love
her
half
so
well
!
<EOS>
I
know
I
was
too
young
and
foolish
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
much
better
as
it
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
Agnes
is
downstairs
,
when
I
go
into
the
parlour
;
and
I
give
her
the
message
.
 
<EOS>
She
disappears
,
leaving
me
alone
with
Jip
.
   
<EOS>
His
Chinese
house
is
by
the
fire
;
and
he
lies
within
it
,
on
his
bed
of
flannel
,
querulously
trying
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
The
bright
moon
is
high
and
clear
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
look
out
on
the
night
,
my
tears
fall
fast
,
and
my
undisciplined
heart
is
chastened
heavily
---
heavily
.
   
<EOS>
I
sit
down
by
the
fire
,
thinking
with
a
blind
remorse
of
all
those
secret
feelings
I
have
nourished
since
my
marriage
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
of
every
little
trifle
between
me
and
Dora
,
and
feel
the
truth
,
that

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Undisciplined

,

!
   
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

so

enthralled
him
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
"
and
of
commencing
a
new
career
in
a
country
where
there
is
sufficient
range
for
his
abilities
,
---
which
,
in
my
opinion
,
is
exceedingly
important
;
Mr
Micawber
's
abilities
peculiarly
requiring
space
,
---
it
seems
to
me
that
my
family
should
signalize
the
occasion
by
coming
forward
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
could
wish
to
see
,
would
be
a
meeting
between
Mr
Micawber
and
my
family
at
a
festive
entertainment
,
to
be
given
at
my
family
's
expense
;
where
Mr
Micawber
's
health
and
prosperity
being
proposed
,
by
some
leading
member
of
my
family
,
Mr
Micawber
might
have
an
opportunity
of
developing
his
views
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
with
some
heat
,
"
it
may
be
better
for
me
to
state
distinctly
,
at
once
,
that
if
I
were
to
develop
my
views
to
that
assembled
group
,
they
would
possibly
be
found
of
an
offensive
nature
:
my
impression
being
that
your
family
are
,
in
the
aggregate
,
impertinent
Snobs
;
and
,
in
detail
,
unmitigated

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Micawber
,
"
said
Mrs
Micawber
,
shaking
her
head
,
"
no
!
<EOS>
You
have
never
understood
them
,
and
they
have
never
understood
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
coughed
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
have
never
understood
you
,
Micawber
,
"
said
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
may
be
incapable
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
so
,
that
is
their
misfortune
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
pity
their
misfortune
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
extremely
sorry
,
my
dear
Emma
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
relenting
,
"
to
have
been
betrayed
into
any
expressions
that
might
,
even

,
have
the
appearance
of
being
strong

.
 
<EOS>
All
I
would
say
is
,
that
I
can
go
abroad
without
your
family
coming
forward
to
favour
me
,
---
in
short
,
with
a
parting
Shove
of
their
cold

;
and
that
,
upon
the
whole
,
I
would
rather
leave
England
with
such
impetus
as
I
possess
,
than
derive
any
acceleration
of

from
that
quarter
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
same

,
my
dear
,
if
they

condescend
to
reply

your
communications
---
which
our
joint
experience
renders
most
improbable
<EOS>
---
far
be
it
from
me
to
be
a
barrier
to
your
wishes
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
matter
being
thus

,
Mr

gave
Mrs
Micawber
his

,
and

Traddles
on

,
said
they
would
leave

to

;
which

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Copperfield
,
"
said
Traddles
,
leaning

,

with
an

that
made

red
,
and

all

"
I
do

with

,
because

know

interested

,

.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
boy
,
I

you
are

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
myself
,
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
We
have
more

think
of
my
aunt
than

.
 
<EOS>
You
know
how
much
she
has
done
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Surely
,
surely
,
"
answered

.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
can
forget
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
But

is

,
"
said

"
During
the

,
some
new
trouble
has
vexed

;
and
she
has
been
in

.
 
<EOS>
Several

has
gone

,

.
 
<EOS>
Last

,
Traddles
,
with
this

before
her
,
it
was
almost

she
came

.
 
<EOS>
You
know
what
her

others
is
.
 
<EOS>
She
will
not
tell
me
what
has
happened

distress

.
"
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
very

,
and
with

,

I
had

;
when

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
nothing
,
Trot
;
it
's
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
There
will
be
no
more
of
it
.
<EOS>
You

know

and

.
 
<EOS>
Now
Agnes
,
my
dear
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
do
Mr
Micawber
the

say
,
"
Traddles
began
,
"
that
although

would
appear
not

have
worked

any

for
himself
,
he
is
a
most
untiring

he

for
other

.
<EOS>
I
never
saw
such

fellow
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
always

on
in
the
same
way
,
he
must
be
,
virtually
,
about
two
hundred

,

.
<EOS>
The
heat
into

he
has
been
continually

;

,

;

;
is

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Letters
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
believe

dreams

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
There

Mr
Dick
,

,
"

,
"
has

!
<EOS>
As

,
whom

,

.
 
<EOS>
And
really

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dick
is

,
"

;
"
and

.
 
<EOS>
Trot
,
you

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
Miss

,
"

,
at

,
"
that
in
your

Mr
Wickfield
has
considerably

.
 
<EOS>
Relieved
of
the

that
had

for
so
long

,
and
of
the

under
which
he
had
lived
<EOS>
,
he
is

.
 
<EOS>
At

,

impaired

,
has
recovered

;
and

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

to

results
;
which

;
not

gossip
on
all

hopeful

I
have
observed
,
or
I

never

.
"
<EOS>
His
natural

and

made

that

to

to

mentioned

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
Having

,
and
reduced

a

in

,

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
"

"
the

---
<EOS>
and

,

---

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

---
<EOS>
Copperfield
---
<EOS>
I
---
"
   
"
I

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
No

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"

"

.
 
<EOS>
Dear
Mr
Traddles
and
dear
Trotwood
,
papa
once
free

,
what
could
I
wish
for
!
<EOS>
I
have

,

,

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
To

---

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have

,
Agnes
?
"
   
"
Often
!
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

certain
of
success
.
<EOS>
So

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Do

.
 
<EOS>
Our

.
 
<EOS>
If

rent

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

,

itself
,

<EOS>
Traddles
pretended

.
   
<EOS>
"
Next
,

,
"
said

,
"
that

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
All

,

;

<EOS>
"
It

,

,

,

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Right
!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca

,
"

<EOS>
"
---

,
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"

"

"
   
<EOS>
"
Five

,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
sold

,
myself
.
<EOS>
One
,
I

your

,
Trot
,
my

;

I

.
 
<EOS>
When

rest
,
I
thought

to

that

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
Trot
;
and

---

,

,

!
<EOS>
So

Dick
.
<EOS>
Do

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
Nobody

,

,

;
but

.
   
<EOS>
"
Then

"

,

"

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
How

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

"

<EOS>
"

,
"
said

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Agnes
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,
"

,
"

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

to
Mr
Wickfield
,
by

,
---
and

,

,
by

,
---
that

(
on

,
he

)
to

.
<EOS>
Mr
Wickfield
,
being
so
weak
and

in
his
hands
as
to
pay

,
afterwards
,
several

of
interest
on

which

,
made

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
at
last
took
the
blame
upon
himself
,
"
added
my
aunt
;
"
and
wrote
me
a
mad
letter
,
charging
himself
with
robbery
,
and
wrong
unheard
of
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
which
I
paid
him
a
visit
early
one
morning
,
called
for
a
candle
,
burnt
the
letter
,
and
told
him
if
he
ever
could
right
me
and
himself
,
to
do
it
;
and
if
he
could
n't
,
to
keep
his
own
counsel
for
his
daughter
's
sake
.
 
<EOS>
---
If
anybody
speaks
to
me
,
I
'll
leave
the
house
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
all
remained
quiet
;
Agnes
covering
her
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
dear
friend
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
after
a
pause
,
"
and
you
have
really
extorted
the
money
back
from
him
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the
fact
is
,
"
returned
Traddles
,
"
Mr
Micawber
had
so
completely
hemmed
him
in
,
and
was
always
ready
with
so
many
new
points
if
an
old
one
failed
,
that
he
could
not
escape
from
us
.
 
<EOS>
A
most
remarkable
circumstance
is
,
that
I
really
do
n't
think
he
grasped
this
sum
even
so
much
for
the
gratification
of
his
avarice
,
which
was
inordinate
,
as
in
the
hatred
he
felt
for
Copperfield
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
so
to
me
,
plainly
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
he
would
even
have
spent
as
much
,
to
baulk
or
injure
Copperfield
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
"
said
my
aunt
,
knitting
her
brows
thoughtfully
,
and
glancing
at
Agnes
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
what
's
become
of
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
.
 
<EOS>
He
left
here
,
"
said
Traddles
,
"
with
his
mother
,
who
had
been
clamouring
,
and
beseeching
,
and
disclosing
,
the
whole
time
.
 
<EOS>
They
went
away
by
one
of
the
London
night
coaches
,
and
I
know
no
more
about
him
;
except
that
his
malevolence
to
me
at
parting
was
audacious
.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
consider
himself
hardly
less
indebted
to
me
,
than
to
Mr
Micawber
;
which
I
consider
(
as
I
told
him
)
quite
a
compliment
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
suppose
he
has
any
money
,
Traddles
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
dear
,
yes
,
I
should
think
so
,
"
he
replied
,
shaking
his
head
,
seriously
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
say
he
must
have
pocketed
a
good
deal
,
in
one
way
or
other
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
I
think
you
would
find
,
Copperfield
,
if
you
had
an
opportunity
of
observing
his
course
,
that
money
would
never
keep
that
man
out
of
mischief
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
such
an
incarnate
hypocrite
,
that
whatever
object
he
pursues
,
he
must
pursue
crookedly
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
his
only
compensation
for
the
outward
restraints
he
puts
upon
himself
.
<EOS>
Always
creeping
along
the
ground
to
some
small
end
or
other
,
he
will
always
magnify
every
object
in
the
way
;
and
consequently
will
hate
and
suspect
everybody
that
comes
,
in
the
most
innocent
manner
,
between
him
and
it
.
 
<EOS>
So
the
crooked
courses
will
become
crookeder
,
at
any
moment
,
for
the
least
reason
,
or
for
none
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
only
necessary
to
consider
his
history
here
,
"
said
Traddles
,
"
to
know
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
monster
of
meanness
!
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Really
I
do
n't
know
about
that
,
"
observed
Traddles
thoughtfully
.
<EOS>
"
Many
people
can
be
very
mean
,
when
they
give
their
minds
to
it
.
"
   
"
And
now
,
touching
Mr
Micawber
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
really
,
"
said
Traddles
,
cheerfully
,
"
I
must
,
once
more
,
give
Mr
Micawber
high
praise
.
 
<EOS>
But
for
his
having
been
so
patient
and
persevering
for
so
long
a
time
,
we
never
could
have
hoped
to
do
anything
worth
speaking
of
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
think
we
ought
to
consider
that
Mr
Micawber
did
right
,
for
right
's
sake
,
when
we
reflect
what
terms
he
might
have
made
with
Uriah
Heep
himself
,
for
his
silence
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
so
too
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
what
would
you
give
him
?
"
inquired
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Before
you
come
to
that
,
"
said
Traddles
,
a
little
disconcerted
,
"
I
am
afraid
I
thought
it
discreet
to
omit
(
not
being
able
to
carry
everything
before
me
)
<EOS>
two
points
,
in
making
this
lawless
adjustment
---
for
it
's
perfectly
lawless
from
beginning
to
end
---
of
a
difficult
affair
.
 
<EOS>
Those
IOU
's
,
and
so
forth
,
which
Mr
Micawber
gave
him
for
the
advances
he
had
---
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
They
must
be
paid
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
but
I
do
n't
know
when
they
may
be
proceeded
on
,
or
where
they
are
,
"
rejoined
Traddles
,
opening
his
eyes
;
"
and
I
anticipate
,
that
,
between
this
time
and
his
departure
,
Mr
Micawber
will
be
constantly
arrested
,
or
taken
in
execution
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
he
must
be
constantly
set
free
again
,
and
taken
out
of
execution
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
amount
altogether
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Mr
Micawber
has
entered
the
transactions
---
he
calls
them
transactions
---
with
great
form
,
in
a
book
,
"
rejoined
Traddles
,
smiling
;
"
and
he
makes
the
amount
a
hundred
and
three
pounds
,
five
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
what
shall
we
give
him
,
that
sum
included
?
"
said
my
aunt
.
<EOS>
"
Agnes
,
my
dear
,
you
and
I
can
talk
about
division
of
it
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
What
should
it
be
?
 
<EOS>
Five
hundred
pounds
?
"
   
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
Traddles
and
I
both
struck
in
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
We
both
recommended
a
small
sum
in
money
,
and
the
payment
,
without
stipulation
to
Mr
Micawber
,
of
the
Uriah
claims
as
they
came
in
.
<EOS>
We
proposed
that
the
family
should
have
their
passage
and
their
outfit
,
and
a
hundred
pounds
;
and
that
Mr
Micawber
's
arrangement
for
the
repayment
of
the
advances
should
be
gravely
entered
into
,
as
it
might
be
wholesome
for
him
to
suppose
himself
under
that
responsibility
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
,
I
added
the
suggestion
,
that
I
should
give
some
explanation
of
his
character
and
history
to
Mr
Peggotty
,
who
I
knew
could
be
relied
on
;
and
that
to
Mr
Peggotty
should
be
quietly
entrusted
the
discretion
of
advancing
another
hundred
.
 
<EOS>
I
further
proposed
to
interest
Mr
Micawber
in
Mr
Peggotty
,
by
confiding
so
much
of
Mr
Peggotty
's
story
to
him
as
I
might
feel
justified
in
relating
,
or
might
think
expedient
;
and
to
endeavour
to
bring
each
of
them
to
bear
upon
the
other
,
for
the
common
advantage
.
 
<EOS>
We
all
entered
warmly
into
these
views
;
and
I
may
mention
at
once
,
that
the
principals
themselves
did
so
,
shortly
afterwards
,
with
perfect
good
will
and
harmony
.
   
<EOS>
Seeing
that
Traddles
now
glanced
anxiously
at
my
aunt
again
,
I
reminded
him
of
the
second
and
last
point
to
which
he
had
adverted
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
and
your
aunt
will
excuse
me
,
Copperfield
,
if
I
touch
upon
a
painful
theme
,
as
I
greatly
fear
I
shall
,
"
said
Traddles
,
hesitating
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
think
it
necessary
to
bring
it
to
your
recollection
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
day
of
Mr
Micawber
's
memorable
denunciation
a
threatening
allusion
was
made
by
Uriah
Heep
to
your
aunt
's
---
husband
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
retaining
her
stiff
position
,
and
apparent
composure
,
assented
with
a
nod
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
,
"
observed
Traddles
,
"
it
was
mere
purposeless
impertinence
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
returned
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
was
---
pardon
me
---
really
such
a
person
,
and
at
all
in
his
power
?
"
hinted
Traddles
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
good
friend
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
Traddles
,
with
a
perceptible
lengthening
of
his
face
,
explained
that
he
had
not
been
able
to
approach
this
subject
;
that
it
had
shared
the
fate
of
Mr
Micawber
's
liabilities
,
in
not
being
comprehended
in
the
terms
he
had
made
;
that
we
were
no
longer
of
any
authority
with
Uriah
Heep
;
and
that
if
he
could
do
us
,
or
any
of
us
,
any
injury
or
annoyance
,
no
doubt
he
would
.
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
remained
quiet
;
until
again
some
stray
tears
found
their
way
to
her
cheeks
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite
right
,
"
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
very
thoughtful
to
mention
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Can
I
---
or
Copperfield
---
do
anything
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Traddles
,
gently
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
many
times
.
 
<EOS>
Trot
,
my
dear
,
a
vain
threat
!
<EOS>
Let
us
have
Mr
and
Mrs
Micawber
back
.
 
<EOS>
And
do
n't
any
of
you
speak
to
me
!
"
<EOS>
With
that
she
smoothed
her
dress
,
and
sat
,
with
her
upright
carriage
,
looking
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Mr
and
Mrs
Micawber
!
"
said
my
aunt
,
when
they
entered
.
<EOS>
"
We
have
been
discussing
your
emigration
,
with
many
apologies
to
you
for
keeping
you
out
of
the
room
so
long
;
and
I
'll
tell
you
what
arrangements
we
propose
.
"
   
<EOS>
These
she
explained
to
the
unbounded
satisfaction
of
the
family
,
---
<EOS>
children
and
all
being
then
present
,
---
and
so
much
to
the
awakening
of
Mr
Micawber
's
punctual
habits
in
the
opening
stage
of
all
bill
transactions
,
that
he
could
not
be
dissuaded
from
immediately
rushing
out
,
in
the
highest
spirits
,
to
buy
the
stamps
for
his
notes
of
hand
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
his
joy
received
a
sudden
check
;
for
within
five
minutes
,
he
returned
in
the
custody
of
a
sheriff
's
officer
,
informing
us
,
in
a
flood
of
tears
,
that
all
was
lost
.
 
<EOS>
We
,
being
quite
prepared
for
this
event
,
which
was
of
course
a
proceeding
of
Uriah
Heep
's
,
soon
paid
the
money
;
and
in
five
minutes
more
Mr
Micawber
was
seated
at
the
table
,
filling
up
the
stamps
with
an
expression
of
perfect
joy
,
which
only
that
congenial
employment
,
or
the
making
of
punch
,
could
impart
in
full
completeness
to
his
shining
face
.
 
<EOS>
To
see
him
at
work
on
the
stamps
,
with
the
relish
of
an
artist
,
touching
them
like
pictures
,
looking
at
them
sideways
,
taking
weighty
notes
of
dates
and
amounts
in
his
pocket
-
book
,
and
contemplating
them
when
finished
,
with
a
high
sense
of
their
precious
value
,
was
a
sight
indeed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
the
best
thing
you
can
do
,
sir
,
if
you
'll
allow
me
to
advise
you
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
after
silently
observing
him
,
"
is
to
abjure
that
occupation
for
evermore
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
"
replied
Mr
Micawber
,
"
it
is
my
intention
to
register
such
a
vow
on
the
virgin
page
of
the
future
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Micawber
will
attest
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
trust
,
"
said
Mr
Micawber
,
solemnly
,
"
that
my
son
Wilkins
will
ever
bear
in
mind
,
that
he
had
infinitely
better
put
his
fist
in
the
fire
,
than
use
it
to
handle
the
serpents
that
have
poisoned
the
life
-
blood
of
his
unhappy
parent
!
"
<EOS>
Deeply
affected
,
and
changed
in
a
moment
to
the
image
of
despair
,
Mr
Micawber
regarded
the
serpents
with
a
look
of
gloomy
abhorrence
(
in
which
his
late
admiration
of
them
was
not
quite
subdued
)
,
folded
them
up
and
put
them
in
his
pocket
.
   
<EOS>
This
closed
the
proceedings
of
the
evening
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
weary
with
sorrow
and
fatigue
,
and
my
aunt
<EOS>
and
I
were
to
return
to
London
on
the
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
arranged
that
the
Micawbers
should
follow
us
,
after
effecting
a
sale
of
their
goods
to
a
broker
;
that
Mr
Wickfield
's
affairs
should
be
brought
to
a
settlement
,
with
all
convenient
speed
,
under
the
direction
of
Traddles
;
and
that
Agnes
should
also
come
to
London
,
pending
those
arrangements
.
 
<EOS>
We
passed
the
night
at
the
old
house
,
which
,
freed
from
the
presence
of
the
Heeps
,
seemed
purged
of
a
disease
;
and
I
lay
in
my
old
room
,
like
a
shipwrecked
wanderer
come
home
.
   
<EOS>
We
went
back
next
day
to
my
aunt
's
house
---
not
to
mine
---
and
when
she
and
I
sat
alone
,
as
of
old
,
before
going
to
bed
,
she
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
Trot
,
do
you
really
wish
to
know
what
I
have
had
upon
my
mind
lately
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
I
do
,
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
If
there
ever
was
a
time
when
I
felt
unwilling
that
you
should
have
a
sorrow
or
anxiety
which
I
could
not
share
,
it
is
now
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
had
sorrow
enough
,
child
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
affectionately
,
"
without
the
addition
of
my
little
miseries
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
have
no
other
motive
,
Trot
,
in
keeping
anything
from
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
well
,
"
said
I.
 
"
<EOS>
But
tell
me
now
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Would
you
ride
with
me
a
little
way
tomorrow
morning
?
"
asked
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
.
"
   
"
At
nine
,
"
said
she
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
then
,
my
dear
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
nine
,
accordingly
,
we
went
out
in
a
little
chariot
,
and
drove
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
We
drove
a
long
way
through
the
streets
,
until
we
came
to
one
of
the
large
hospitals
.
 
<EOS>
Standing
hard
by
the
building
was
a
plain
hearse
.
 
<EOS>
The
driver
recognized
my
aunt
,
and
,
in
obedience
to
a
motion
of
her
hand
at
the
window
,
drove
slowly
off
;
we
following
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
understand
it
now
,
Trot
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
gone
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
he
die
in
the
hospital
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
sat
immovable
beside
me
;
but
,
again
I
saw
the
stray
tears
on
her
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
was
there
once
before
,
"
said
my
aunt
presently
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
was
ailing
a
long
time
---
a
shattered
,
broken
man
,
these
many
years
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
knew
his
state
in
this
last
illness
,
he
asked
them
to
send
for
me
.
<EOS>
He
was
sorry
then
.
 
<EOS>
Very
sorry
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
went
,
I
know
,
aunt
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
went
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
with
him
a
good
deal
afterwards
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
died
the
night
before
we
went
to
Canterbury
?
"
said
I.
My
aunt
nodded
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
one
can
harm
him
now
,
"
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
vain
threat
.
"
   
<EOS>
We
drove
away
,
out
of
town
,
to
the
churchyard
at
Hornsey
.
 
<EOS>
"
Better
here
than
in
the
streets
,
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
was
born
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
We
alighted
;
and
followed
the
plain
coffin
to
a
corner
<EOS>
I
remember
well
,
where
the
service
was
read
consigning
it
to
the
dust
.
   
<EOS>
"
Six
-
and
-
thirty
years
ago
,
this
day
,
my
dear
,
"
said
my
aunt
,
as
we
walked
back
to
the
chariot
,
"
I
was
married
.
 
<EOS>
God
forgive
us
all
!
<EOS>
"
We
took
our
seats
in
silence
;
and
so
she
sat
beside
me
for
a
long
time
,
holding
my
hand
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
she
suddenly
burst
into

,
and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
He
was
a
fine
-
looking
man
when
I
married
him
,
Trot
---
and
he
was
sadly
changed
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
did
not
last
long
.
 
<EOS>
After
the
relief
of
tears
,
she
soon
became
composed
,
and
even
cheerful
.
 
<EOS>
Her
nerves
were
a
little
shaken
,
she
said
,
or
she
would
not
have
given
way
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
God
forgive
us
all
!
   
<EOS>
So
we
rode
back
to
her
little
cottage
at
Highgate
,
where
we
found
the
following
short
note
,
which
had
arrived
by
that

Mr

:
    
"
Canterbury
,
"
   
"
Friday
.
<EOS>
"
     
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Madam
,
and
Copperfield
,
"
   
"
The
fair
land
of
promise
lately
looming
on
the
horizon
is
again
enveloped
in
impenetrable
mists
,
and
for

withdrawn
from
the

of
a
drifting
wretch
whose
Doom
is
sealed
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Another
writ
has

(
in
His

's
High

of
King
's

Westminster
)
,
in
another

of
 
<EOS>
\Heep
v

,
and
<EOS>
the

in

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Now
's
the
day
,
and
now
's

,
  
See
the

battle
lower
,
  
<EOS>
See

<EOS>
proud
EDWARD
'S
power
---
   
Chains
and

!
"
<EOS>
"
   
"
Consigned

,
and

(
for

is
not
supportable
beyond
a
certain
point
,
and
that
point
I
feel
I
have
attained
)
,
my
course
is
run
.
 
<EOS>
Bless
you
,
bless

!
<EOS>
Some

,

,
from

,

,
let

,
with

,
the

allotted

in
this

,
may
,
and
I
trust

,
Ponder
,
as
he
traces
on

,
