,
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
obscure
initials
,
"
 
"
W*M.
"
    
"
PS
.
 
<EOS>
I
re
-
open
this
to
say
that
our
common
friend
,
Mr
Thomas
Traddles
(
who
has
not
yet
left
us
,
and
is
looking
extremely
well
)
,
has
paid
the
debt
and
costs
,
in
the
noble
name
of
Miss
Trotwood
;
and
that
myself
and
family
are
at
the
height
of
earthly
bliss
.
"
      
<EOS>
Chapter
55
.
<EOS>
Tempest
 
<EOS>
I
now
approach
an
event
in
my
life
,
so
indelible
,
so
awful
,
so
bound
by
an
infinite
variety
of
ties
to
all
that
has
preceded
it
,
in
these
pages
,
that
,
from
the
beginning
of
my
narrative
,
I
have
seen
it
growing
larger
and
larger
as
I
advanced
,
like
a
great
tower
in
a
plain
,
and
throwing
its
fore
-
cast
shadow
even
on
the
incidents
of
my
childish
days
.
   
<EOS>
For
years
after
it
occurred
,
I
dreamed
of
it
often
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
started
up
so
vividly
impressed
by
it
,
that
its
fury
has
yet
seemed
raging
in
my
quiet
room
,
in
the
still
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
dream
of
it
sometimes
,
though
at
lengthened
and
uncertain
intervals
,
to
this
hour
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
an
association
between
it
and
a
stormy
wind
,
or
the
lightest
mention
of
a
sea
-
shore
,
as
strong
as
any
of
which
my
mind
is
conscious
.
 
<EOS>
As
plainly
as
I
behold
what
happened
,
I
will
try
to
write
it
down
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
recall
it
,
but
see
it
done
;
for
it
happens
again
before
me
.
   
<EOS>
The
time
drawing
on
rapidly
for
the
sailing
of
the
emigrant
-
ship
,
my
good
old
nurse
(
almost
broken
-
hearted
for
me
,
when
we
first
met
)
came
up
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
constantly
with
her
,
and
her
brother
,
and
the
Micawbers
<EOS>
(
they
being
very
much
together
)
;
but
Emily
I
never
saw
.
   
<EOS>
One
evening
when
the
time
was
close
at
hand
,
I
was
alone
with
Peggotty
and
her
brother
.
 
<EOS>
Our
conversation
turned
on
Ham
.
 
<EOS>
She
described
to
us
how
tenderly
he
had
taken
leave
of
her
,
and
how
manfully
and
quietly
he
had
borne
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Most
of
all
,
of
late
,
when
she
believed
he
was
most
tried
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
subject
of
which
the
affectionate
creature
never
tired
;
and
our
interest
in
hearing
the
many
examples
which
she
,
who
was
so
much
with
him
,
had
to
relate
,
was
equal
to
hers
in
relating
them
.
   
<EOS>
MY
aunt
<EOS>
and
I
were
at
that
time
vacating
the
two
cottages
at
Highgate
;
I
intending
to
go
abroad
,
and
she
to
return
to
her
house
at
Dover
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
a
temporary
lodging
in
Covent
Garden
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
walked
home
to
it
,
after
this
evening
's
conversation
,
reflecting
on
what
had
passed
between
Ham
and
myself
when
I
was
last
at
Yarmouth
,
I
wavered
in
the
original
purpose
I
had
formed
,
of
leaving
a
letter
for
Emily
when
I
should
take
leave
of
her
uncle
on
board
the
ship
,
and
thought
it
would
be
better
to
write
to
her
now
.
 
<EOS>
She
might
desire
,
I
thought
,
after
receiving
my
communication
,
to
send
some
parting
word
by
me
to
her
unhappy
lover
.
 
<EOS>
I
ought
to
give
her
the
opportunity
.
   
<EOS>
I
therefore
sat
down
in
my
room
,
before
going
to
bed
,
and
wrote
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
her
that
I
had
seen
him
,
and
that
he
had
requested
me
to
tell
her
what
I
have
already
written
in
its
place
in
these
sheets
.
 
<EOS>
I
faithfully
repeated
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
need
to
enlarge
upon
it
,
if
I
had
had
the
right
.
 
<EOS>
Its
deep
fidelity
and
goodness
were
not
to
be
adorned
by
me
or
any
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
left
it
out
,
to
be
sent
round
in
the
morning
;
with
a
line
to
Mr
Peggotty
,
requesting
him
to
give
it
to
her
;
and
went
to
bed
at
daybreak
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
weaker
than
I
knew
then
;
and
,
not
falling
asleep
until
the
sun
was
up
,
lay
late
,
and
unrefreshed
,
next
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
roused
by
the
silent
presence
of
my
aunt
at
my
bedside
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
it
in
my
sleep
,
as
I
suppose
we
all
do
feel
such
things
.
   
<EOS>
"
Trot
,
my
dear
,
"
she
said
,
when
I
opened
my
eyes
,
"
I
could
n't
make
up
my
mind
to
disturb
you
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
is
here
;
shall
he
come
up
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
replied
<EOS>
yes
,
and
he
soon
appeared
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mas'r
Davy
,
"
he
said
,
when
we
had
shaken
hands
,
"
I
giv
Em'ly
your
letter
,
sir
,
and
she
writ
this
heer
;
and
begged
of
me
fur
to
ask
you
to
read
it
,
and
if
you
see
no
hurt
in't
,
to
be
so
kind
as
take
charge
on't
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
read
it
?
"
said
I.
   
He
nodded
sorrowfully
.
 
<EOS>
I
opened
it
,
and
read
as
follows
:
     
<EOS>
"
I
have
got
your
message
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
what
can
I
write
,
to
thank
you
for
your
good
and
blessed
kindness
to
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
put
the
words
close
to
my
heart
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
keep
them
till
I
die
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
sharp
thorns
,
but
they
are
such
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
prayed
over
them
,
<EOS>
oh
,
I
have
prayed
so
much
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
find
what
you
are
,
and
what
uncle
is
,
I
think
what
God
must
be
,
and
can
cry
to
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
for
ever
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
my
dear
,
my
friend
,
good
-
bye
for
ever
in
this
world
.
 
<EOS>
In
another
world
,
if
I
am
forgiven
,
I
may
wake
a
child
and
come
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
All
thanks
and
blessings
.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
,
evermore
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
,
blotted
with
tears
,
was
the
letter
.
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
tell
her
as
you
doen't
<EOS>
see
no
hurt
in't
,
and
as
you
'll
be
so
kind
as
take
charge
on't
,
Mas'r
Davy
?
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,
when
I
had
read
it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Unquestionably
,
"
said
I
---
"
but
I
am
thinking
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
Mas'r
Davy
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
thinking
,
"
said
I
,
"
that
I
'll
go
down
again
to
Yarmouth
.
<EOS>
There
's
time
,
and
to
spare
,
for
me
to
go
and
come
back
before
the
ship
sails
.
 
<EOS>
My
mind
is
constantly
running
on
him
,
in
his
solitude
;
to
put
this
letter
of
her
writing
in
his
hand
at
this
time
,
and
to
enable
you
to
tell
her
,
in
the
moment
of
parting
,
that
he
has
got
it
,
will
be
a
kindness
to
both
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
solemnly
accepted
his
commission
,
dear
good
fellow
,
and
can
not
discharge
it
too
completely
.
 
<EOS>
The
journey
is
nothing
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
restless
,
and
shall
be
better
in
motion
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
go
down
tonight
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Though
he
anxiously
endeavoured
to
dissuade
me
,
I
saw
that
he
was
of
my
mind
;
and
this
,
if
I
had
required
to
be
confirmed
in
my
intention
,
would
have
had
the
effect
.
 
<EOS>
He
went
round
to
the
coach
office
,
at
my
request
,
and
took
the
box
-
seat
for
me
on
the
mail
.
<EOS>
In
the
evening
I
started
,
by
that
conveyance
,
down
the
road
I
had
traversed
under
so
many
vicissitudes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
think
that
,
"
I
asked
the
coachman
,
in
the
first
stage
out
of
London
,
"
a
very
remarkable
sky
?
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
remember
to
have
seen
one
like
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nor
I
---
not
equal
to
it
,
"
he
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
wind
,
sir
.
<EOS>
There
'll
be
mischief
done
at
sea
,
I
expect
,
before
long
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
murky
confusion
---
here
and
there
blotted
with
a
colour
like
the
colour
of
the
smoke
from
damp
fuel
---
of
flying
clouds
,
<EOS>
tossed
up
into
most
remarkable
heaps
,
suggesting
greater
heights
in
the
clouds
than
there
were
depths
below
them
to
the
bottom
of
the
deepest
hollows
in
the
earth
,
through
which
the
wild
moon
seemed
to
plunge
headlong
,
as
if
,
in
a
dread
disturbance
of
the
laws
of
nature
,
she
had
lost
her
way
and
were
frightened
.
 
<EOS>
There
had
been
a
wind
all
day
;
and
it
was
rising
then
,
with
an
extraordinary
great
sound
.
 
<EOS>
In
another
hour
it
had
much
increased
,
and
the
sky
was
more
overcast
,
and
blew
hard
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
as
the
night
advanced
,
the
clouds
closing
in
and
densely
over
-
spreading
the
whole
sky
,
then
very
dark
,
it
came
on
to
blow
,
harder
and
harder
.
 
<EOS>
It
still
increased
,
until
our
horses
could
scarcely
face
the
wind
.
 
<EOS>
Many
times
,
in
the
dark
part
of
the
night
(
it
was
then
late
in
September
,
when
the
nights
were
not
short
)
,
the
leaders
turned
about
,
or
came
to
a
dead
stop
;
and
we
were
often
in
serious
apprehension
that
the
coach
would
be
blown
over
.
<EOS>
Sweeping
gusts
of
rain
came
up
before
this
storm
,
like
showers
of
steel
;
and
,
at
those
times
,
when
there
was
any
shelter
of
trees
or
lee
walls
to
be
got
,
we
were
fain
to
stop
,
in
a
sheer
impossibility
of
continuing
the
struggle
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
day
broke
,
it
blew
harder
and
harder
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
been
in
Yarmouth
when
the
seamen
said
it
blew
great
guns
,
but
I
had
never
known
the
like
of
this
,
or
anything
approaching
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
We
came
to
Ipswich
---
very
late
,
having
had
to
fight
every
inch
of
ground
since
we
were
ten
miles
out
of
London
;
and
found
a
cluster
of
people
in
the
market
-
place
,
who
had
risen
from
their
beds
in
the
night
,
fearful
of
falling
chimneys
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
these
,
congregating
about
the
inn
-
yard
while
we
changed
horses
,
told
us
of
great
sheets
of
lead
having
been
ripped
off
a
high
church
-
tower
,
and
flung
into
a
by
-
street
,
which
they
then
blocked
up
.
 
<EOS>
Others
had
to
tell
of
country
people
,
coming
in
from
neighbouring
villages
,
who
had
seen
great
trees
lying
torn
out
of
the
earth
,
and
whole
ricks
scattered
about
the
roads
and
fields
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
there
was
no
abatement
in
the
storm
,
but
it
blew
harder
.
   
<EOS>
As
we
struggled
on
,
nearer
and
nearer
to
the
sea
,
from
which
this
mighty
wind
was
blowing
dead
on
shore
,
its
force
became
more
and
more
terrific
.
 
<EOS>
Long
before
we
saw
the
sea
,
its
spray
was
on
our
lips
,
and
showered
salt
rain
upon
us
.
 
<EOS>
The
water
was
out
,
over
miles
and
miles
of
the
flat
country
adjacent
to
Yarmouth
;
and
every
sheet
and
puddle
lashed
its
banks
,
and
had
its
stress
of
little
breakers
setting
heavily
towards
us
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
came
within
sight
of
the
sea
,
the
waves
on
the
horizon
,
caught
at
intervals
above
the
rolling
abyss
,
were
like
glimpses
of
another
shore
with
towers
and
buildings
.
 
<EOS>
When
at
last
we
got
into
the
town
,
the
people
came
out
to
their
doors
,
all
aslant
,
and
with
streaming
hair
,
making
a
wonder
of
the
mail
that
had
come
through
such
a
night
.
   
<EOS>
I
put
up
at
the
old
inn
,
and
went
down
to
look
at
the
sea
;
staggering
along
the
street
,
which
was
strewn
with
sand
and
seaweed
,
and
with
flying
blotches
of
sea
-
foam
;
afraid
of
falling
slates
and
tiles
;
and
holding
by
people
I
met
,
at
angry
corners
.
<EOS>
Coming
near
the
beach
,
I
saw
,
not
only
the
boatmen
,
but
half
the
people
of
the
town
,
lurking
behind
buildings
;
some
,
now
and
then
braving
the
fury
of
the
storm
to
look
away
to
sea
,
and
blown
sheer
out
of
their
course
in
trying
to
get
zigzag
back
.
   
<EOS>
joining
these
groups
,
I
found
bewailing
women
whose
husbands
were
away
in
herring
or
oyster
boats
,
which
there
was
too
much
reason
to
think
might
have
foundered
before
they
could
run
in
anywhere
for
safety
.
 
<EOS>
Grizzled
old
sailors
were
among
the
people
,
shaking
their
heads
,
as
they
looked
from
water
to
sky
,
and
muttering
to
one
another
;
ship
-
owners
,
excited
and
uneasy
;
children
,
huddling
together
,
and
peering
into
older
faces
;
even
stout
mariners
,
disturbed
and
anxious
,
levelling
their
glasses
at
the
sea
from
behind
places
of
shelter
,
as
if
they
were
surveying
an
enemy
.
   
<EOS>
The
tremendous
sea
itself
,
when
I
could
find
sufficient
pause
to
look
at
it
,
in
the
agitation
of
the
blinding
wind
,
the
flying
stones
and
sand
,
and
the
awful
noise
,
confounded
me
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
high
watery
walls
came
rolling
in
,
and
,
at
their
highest
,
tumbled
into
surf
,
they
looked
as
if
the
least
would
engulf
the
town
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
receding
wave
swept
back
with
a
hoarse
roar
,
it
seemed
to
scoop
out
deep
caves
in
the
beach
,
as
if
its
purpose
were
to
undermine
the
earth
.
 
<EOS>
When
some
white
-
headed
billows
thundered
on
,
and
dashed
themselves
to
pieces
before
they
reached
the
land
,
every
fragment
of
the
late
whole
seemed
possessed
by
the
full
might
of
its
wrath
,
rushing
to
be
gathered
to
the
composition
of
another
monster
.
<EOS>
Undulating
hills
were
changed
to
valleys
,
undulating
valleys
(
with
a
solitary
storm
-
bird
sometimes
skimming
through
them
)
were
lifted
up
to
hills
;
masses
of
water
shivered
and
shook
the
beach
with
a
booming
sound
;
every
shape
tumultuously
rolled
on
,
as
soon
as
made
,
to
change
its
shape
and
place
,
and
beat
another
shape
and
place
away
;
the
ideal
shore
on
the
horizon
,
with
its
towers
and
buildings
,
rose
and
fell
<EOS>
;
the
clouds
fell
fast
and
thick
;
I
seemed
to
see
a
rending
and
upheaving
of
all
nature
.
   
<EOS>
Not
finding
Ham
among
the
people
whom
this
memorable
wind
---
for
it
is
still
remembered
down
there
,
as
the
greatest
ever
known
to
blow
upon
that
coast
---
had
brought
together
,
I
made
my
way
to
his
house
.
<EOS>
It
was
shut
;
and
as
no
one
answered
to
my
knocking
,
I
went
,
by
back
ways
and
by
-
lanes
,
to
the
yard
where
he
worked
.
 
<EOS>
I
learned
,
there
,
that
he
had
gone
to
Lowestoft
,
to
meet
some
sudden
exigency
of
ship
-
repairing
in
which
his
skill
was
required
;
but
that
he
would
be
back
tomorrow
morning
,
in
good
time
.
   
<EOS>
I
went
back
to
the
inn
;
and
when
I
had
washed
and
dressed
,
and
tried
to
sleep
,
but
in
vain
,
it
was
five
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
.
<EOS>
I
had
not
sat
five
minutes
by
the
coffee
-
room
fire
,
when
the
waiter
,
coming
to
stir
it
,
as
an
excuse
for
talking
,
told
me
that
two
colliers
had
gone
down
,
with
all
hands
,
a
few
miles
away
;
and
that
some
other
ships
had
been
seen
labouring
hard
in
the
Roads
,
and
trying
,
in
great
distress
,
to
keep
off
shore
.
 
<EOS>
Mercy
on
them
,
and
on
all
poor
sailors
,
said
he
,
if
we
had
another
night
like
the
last
!
   
<EOS>
I
was
very
much
depressed
in
spirits
;
very
solitary
;
and
felt
an
uneasiness
in
Ham
's
not
being
there
,
disproportionate
to
the
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
seriously
affected
,
without
knowing
how
much
,
by
late
events
;
and
my
long
exposure
to
the
fierce
wind
had
confused
me
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
that
jumble
in
my
thoughts
and
recollections
,
that
I
had
lost
the
clear
arrangement
of
time
and
distance
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,
if
I
had
gone
out
into
the
town
,
I
should
not
have
been
surprised
,
I
think
,
to
encounter
someone
who
I
knew
must
be
then
in
London
.
 
<EOS>
So
to
speak
,
there
was
in
these
respects
a
curious
inattention
in
my
mind
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
it
was
busy
,
too
,
with
all
the
remembrances
the
place
naturally
awakened
;
and
they
were
particularly
distinct
and
vivid
.
   
<EOS>
In
this
state
,
the
waiter
's
dismal
intelligence
about
the
ships
immediately
connected
itself
,
without
any
effort
of
my
volition
,
with
my
uneasiness
about
Ham
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
persuaded
that
I
had
an
apprehension
of
his
returning
from
Lowestoft
by
sea
,
and
being
lost
.
 
<EOS>
This
grew
so
strong
with
me
,
that
I
resolved
to
go
back
to
the
yard
before
I
took
my
dinner
,
and
ask
the
boat
-
builder
if
he
thought
his
attempting
to
return
by
sea
at
all
likely
?
 
<EOS>
If
he
gave
me
the
least
reason
to
think
so
,
I
would
go
over
to
Lowestoft
and
prevent
it
by
bringing
him
with
me
.
   
<EOS>
I
hastily
ordered
my
dinner
,
and
went
back
to
the
yard
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
none
too
soon
;
for
the
boat
-
builder
,
with
a
lantern
in
his
hand
,
was
locking
the
yard
-
gate
.
 
<EOS>
He
quite
laughed
when
I
asked
him
the
question
,
and
said
there
was
no
fear
;
no
man
in
his
senses
,
or
out
of
them
,
would
put
off
in
such
a
gale
of
wind
,
least
of
all
Ham
Peggotty
,
who
had
been
born
to
seafaring
.
   
<EOS>
So
sensible
of
this
,
beforehand
,
that
I
had
really
felt
ashamed
of
doing
what
I
was
nevertheless
impelled
to
do
,
I
went
back
to
the
inn
.
 
<EOS>
If
such
a
wind
could
rise
,
I
think
it
was
rising
.
 
<EOS>
The
howl
and
roar
,
the
rattling
of
the
doors
and
windows
,
the
rumbling
in
the
chimneys
,
the
apparent
rocking
of
the
very
house
that
sheltered
me
,
and
the
prodigious
tumult
of
the
sea
,
were
more
fearful
than
in
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
now
a
great
darkness
besides
;
and
that
invested
the
storm
with
new
terrors
,
real
and
fanciful
.
   
<EOS>
I
could
not
eat
<EOS>
,
I
could
not
sit
still
,
I
could
not
continue
steadfast
to
anything
.
 
<EOS>
Something
within
me
,
faintly
answering
to
the
storm
without
,
tossed
up
the
depths
of
my
memory
and
made
a
tumult
in
them
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
,
in
all
the
hurry
of
my
thoughts
,
wild
running
with
the
thundering
sea
,
---
<EOS>
the
storm
,
and
my
uneasiness
regarding
Ham
were
always
in
the
fore
-
ground
.
   
<EOS>
My
dinner
went
away
almost
untasted
,
and
I
tried
to
refresh
myself
with
a
glass
or
two
of
wine
.
 
<EOS>
In
vain
.
 
<EOS>
I
fell
into
a
dull
slumber
before
the
fire
,
without
losing
my
consciousness
,
either
of
the
uproar
out
of
doors
,
or
of
the
place
in
which
I
was
.
 
<EOS>
Both
became
overshadowed
by
a
new
and
indefinable
horror
;
and
when
I
awoke
---
or
rather
when
I
shook
off
the
lethargy
that
bound
me
in
my
chair
---
my
whole
frame
thrilled
with
objectless
and
unintelligible
fear
.
   
<EOS>
I
walked
to
and
fro
,
tried
to
read
an
old
gazetteer
,
listened
to
the
awful
noises
:
<EOS>
looked
at
faces
,
scenes
,
and
figures
in
the
fire
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
the
steady
ticking
of
the
undisturbed
clock
on
the
wall
tormented
me
to
that
degree
that
I
resolved
to
go
to
bed
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
reassuring
,
on
such
a
night
,
to
be
told
that
some
of
the
inn
-
servants
had
agreed
together
to
sit
up
until
morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
to
bed
,
exceedingly
weary
and
heavy
;
but
,
on
my
lying
down
,
all
such
sensations
vanished
,
as
if
by
magic
,
and
I
was
broad
awake
,
with
every
sense
refined
.
   
<EOS>
For
hours
I
lay
there
,
listening
to
the
wind
and
water
;
imagining
,
now
,
that
I
heard
shrieks
out
at
sea
;
now
,
that
I
distinctly
heard
the
firing
of
signal
guns
;
and
now
,
the
fall
of
houses
in
the
town
.
<EOS>
I
got
up
,
several
times
,
and
looked
out
;
but
could
see
nothing
,
except
the
reflection
in
the
window
-
panes
of
the
faint
candle
I
had
left
burning
,
and
of
my
own
haggard
face
looking
in
at
me
from
the
black
void
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
,
my
restlessness
attained
to
such
a
pitch
,
that
I
hurried
on
my
clothes
,
and
went
downstairs
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
large
kitchen
,
where
I
dimly
saw
bacon
and
ropes
of
onions
hanging
from
the
beams
,
the
watchers
were
clustered
together
,
in
various
attitudes
,
about
a
table
,
purposely
moved
away
from
the
great
chimney
,
and
brought
near
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
A
pretty
girl
,
who
had
her
ears
stopped
with
her
apron
,
and
her
eyes
upon
the
door
,
screamed
when
I
appeared
,
supposing
me
to
be
a
spirit
;
but
the
others
had
more
presence
of
mind
,
and
were
glad
of
an
addition
to
their
company
.
 
<EOS>
One
man
,
referring
to
the
topic
they
had
been
discussing
,
asked
me
whether
I
thought
the
souls
of
the
collier
-
crews
who
had
gone
down
,
were
out
in
the
storm
?
   
<EOS>
I
remained
there
,
I
dare
say
,
two
hours
.
 
<EOS>
Once
,
I
opened
the
yard
-
gate
,
and
looked
into
the
empty
street
.
 
<EOS>
The
sand
,
the
sea
-
weed
,
and
the
flakes
of
foam
,
were
driving
by
;
and
I
was
obliged
to
call
for
assistance
before
I
could
shut
the
gate
again
,
and
make
it
fast
against
the
wind
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
dark
gloom
in
my
solitary
chamber
,
when
I
at
length
returned
to
it
;
but
I
was
tired
now
,
and
,
getting
into
bed
again
,
fell
---
off
a
tower
and
down
a
precipice
---
into
the
depths
of
sleep
.
<EOS>
I
have
an
impression
that
for
a
long
time
,
though
I
dreamed
of
being
elsewhere
and
in
a
variety
of
scenes
,
it
was
always
blowing
in
my
dream
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
I
lost
that
feeble
hold
upon
reality
,
and
was
engaged
with
two
dear
friends
,
but
who
they
were
I
do
n't
know
,
at
the
siege
of
some
town
in
a
roar
of
cannonading
.
   
<EOS>
The
thunder
of
the
cannon
was
so
loud
and
incessant
,
that
I
could
not
hear
something
I
much
desired
to
hear
,
until
I
made
a
great
exertion
and
awoke
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
broad
day
---
eight
or
nine
o'clock
;
<EOS>
the
storm
raging
,
in
lieu
of
the
batteries
;
and
someone
knocking
and
calling
at
my
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
I
cried
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
wreck
!
<EOS>
Close
by
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
sprung
out
of
bed
,
and
asked
,
what
wreck
?
   
<EOS>
"
A
schooner
,
from
Spain
or
Portugal
,
laden
with
fruit
and
wine
.
<EOS>
Make
haste
,
sir
,
if
you
want
to
see
her
!
<EOS>
It
's
thought
,
down
on
the
beach
,
she
'll
go
to
pieces
every
moment
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
excited
voice
went
clamouring
along
the
staircase
;
and
I
wrapped
myself
in
my
clothes
as
quickly
as
I
could
,
and
ran
into
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
Numbers
of
people
were
there
before
me
,
all
running
in
one
direction
,
to
the
beach
.
 
<EOS>
I
ran
the
same
way
,
outstripping
a
good
many
,
and
soon
came
facing
the
wild
sea
.
   
<EOS>
The
wind
might
by
this
time
have
lulled
a
little
,
though
not
more
sensibly
than
if
the
cannonading
I
had
dreamed
of
,
had
been
diminished
by
the
silencing
of
half
-
a
-
dozen
guns
out
of
hundreds
.
<EOS>
But
the
sea
,
having
upon
it
the
additional
agitation
of
the
whole
night
,
was
infinitely
more
terrific
than
when
I
had
seen
it
last
.
<EOS>
Every
appearance
it
had
then
presented
,
bore
the
expression
of
being
swelled
;
and
the
height
to
which
the
breakers
rose
,
and
,
looking
over
one
another
,
bore
one
another
down
,
and
rolled
in
,
in
interminable
hosts
,
was
most
appalling
.
<EOS>
In
the
difficulty
of
hearing
anything
but
wind
and
waves
,
and
in
the
crowd
,
and
the
unspeakable
confusion
,
and
my
first
breathless
efforts
to
stand
against
the
weather
,
I
was
so
confused
that
I
looked
out
to
sea
for
the
wreck
,
and
saw
nothing
but
the
foaming
heads
of
the
great
waves
.
 
<EOS>
A
half
-
dressed
boatman
,
standing
next
me
,
pointed
with
his
bare
arm
(
a
tattoo'd
arrow
on
it
,
pointing
in
the
same
direction
)
to
the
left
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
O
great
Heaven
,
I
saw
it
,
close
in
upon
us
!
   
<EOS>
One
mast
was
broken
short
off
,
six
or
eight
feet
from
the
deck
,
and
lay
over
the
side
,
entangled
in
a
maze
of
sail
and
rigging
;
and
all
that
ruin
,
as
the
ship
rolled
and
beat
---
which
she
did
without
a
moment
's
pause
,
and
with
a
violence
quite
inconceivable
---
beat
the
side
as
if
it
would
stave
it
in
.
 
<EOS>
Some
efforts
were
even
then
being
made
,
to
cut
this
portion
of
the
wreck
away
;
for
,
as
the
ship
,
which
was
broadside
on
,
turned
towards
us
in
her
rolling
<EOS>
,
I
plainly
descried
her
people
at
work
with
axes
,
especially
one
active
figure
with
long
curling
hair
,
conspicuous
among
the
rest
.
 
<EOS>
But
a
great
cry
,
which
was
audible
even
above
the
wind
and
water
,
rose
from
the
shore
at
this
moment
;
the
sea
,
sweeping
over
the
rolling
wreck
,
made
a
clean
breach
,
and
carried
men
,
spars
,
casks
,
planks
,
bulwarks
,
heaps
of
such
toys
,
into
the
boiling
surge
.
   
<EOS>
The
second
mast
was
yet
standing
,
with
the
rags
of
a
rent
sail
,
and
a
wild
confusion
of
broken
cordage
flapping
to
and
fro
.
 
<EOS>
The
ship
had
struck
once
,
the
same
boatman
hoarsely
said
in
my
ear
,
and
then
lifted
in
and
struck
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
understood
him
to
add
that
she
was
parting
amidships
,
and
I
could
readily
suppose
so
,
for
the
rolling
and
beating
were
too
tremendous
for
any
human
work
to
suffer
long
.
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
there
was
another
great
cry
of
pity
from
the
beach
;
four
men
arose
with
the
wreck
out
of
the
deep
,
clinging
to
the
rigging
of
the
remaining
mast
;
uppermost
,
the
active
figure
with
the
curling
hair
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
bell
on
board
;
and
as
the
ship
rolled
and
dashed
,
like
a
desperate
creature
driven
mad
,
now
showing
us
the
whole
sweep
of
her
deck
,
as
she
turned
on
her
beam
-
ends
towards
the
shore
,
now
nothing
but
her
keel
,
as
she
sprung
wildly
over
and
turned
towards
the
sea
,
the
bell
rang
;
and
its
sound
,
the
knell
of
those
unhappy
men
,
was
borne
towards
us
on
the
wind
.
 
<EOS>
Again
we
lost
her
,
and
again
she
rose
.
 
<EOS>
Two
men
were
gone
.
 
<EOS>
The
agony
on
the
shore
increased
.
 
<EOS>
Men
groaned
,
and
clasped
their
hands
;
women
shrieked
,
and
turned
away
their
faces
.
 
<EOS>
Some
ran
wildly
up
and
down
along
the
beach
,
crying
for
help
where
no
help
could
be
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
myself
one
of
these
,
frantically
imploring
a
knot
of
sailors
whom
I
knew
,
not
to
let
those
two
lost
creatures
perish
before
our
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
making
out
to
me
,
in
an
agitated
way
---
I
do
n't
know
how
,
for
the
little
I
could
hear
I
was
scarcely
composed
enough
to
understand
---
that
the
lifeboat
had
been
bravely
manned
an
hour
ago
,
and
could
do
nothing
;
and
that
as
no
man
would
be
so
desperate
as
to
attempt
to
wade
off
with
a
rope
,
and
establish
a
communication
with
the
shore
<EOS>
,
there
was
nothing
left
to
try
;
when
I
noticed
that
some
new
sensation
moved
the
people
on
the
beach
,
and
saw
them
part
,
and
Ham
come
breaking
through
them
to
the
front
.
   
<EOS>
I
ran
to
him
---
as
well
as
I
know
,
to
repeat
my
appeal
for
help
.
<EOS>
But
,
distracted
though
I
was
,
by
a
sight
so
new
to
me
and
terrible
,
the
determination
in
his
face
,
and
his

out
to
sea
---
exactly
the
same

as
I
remembered
in
connexion
with
the
morning
after
Emily
's

---
awoke
me
to
a
knowledge
of
his
danger
.
 
<EOS>
I
held
him
back
with
both
arms
;
and
implored
the
men
with
whom
I
had
been
speaking
,
not
to
listen
to
him
,
not
to
do
murder
,
not
to
let
him
stir
from
off
that
sand
!
   
<EOS>
Another
cry
arose
on
shore
;
and
looking
to
the
wreck
,
we
saw
the
cruel
sail
,
with
blow
on
blow
,
beat
off
the
lower
of
the
two
men
,
and
fly
up
in
triumph
round
the
active
figure
left
alone
upon
the
mast
.
   
<EOS>
Against
such
a
sight
,
and
against
such
determination
as
that
of
the
calmly
desperate
man
who
was
already
accustomed
to
lead
half
the
people
present
,
I
might
as
hopefully
have
entreated
the
wind
.
"
<EOS>
Mas'r
Davy
,
"
he
said
,
cheerily
grasping
me
by
both
hands
,
"
if
my
time
is
come
,
'
tis
come
.
 
<EOS>
If
'
tan't
,
I
'll
bide
it
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
above
bless
you
,
and
bless
all
!
<EOS>
Mates
,
make
me
ready
!
<EOS>
I
'm
a
-
going
off
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
swept
away
,
but
not
unkindly
,
to
some
distance
,
where
the
people
around
me
made
me
stay
;
urging
,
as
I
confusedly
perceived
,
that
he
was
bent
on
going
,
with
help
or
without
,
and
that
I
should
endanger
the
precautions
for
his
safety
by
troubling
those
with
whom
they
rested
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
I
answered
,
or
what
they
rejoined
;
but
I
saw
hurry
on
the
beach
,
and
men
running
with
ropes
from
a
capstan
that
was
there
,
and
penetrating
into
a
circle
of
figures
that
hid
him
from
me
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
I
saw
him
standing
alone
,
in
a
seaman
's
frock
and
trousers
:
a
rope
in
his
hand
,
or
slung
to
his
wrist
:
<EOS>
another
round
his
body
:
and
several
of
the
best
men
holding
,
at
a
little
distance
,
to
the
latter
,
which
he
laid
out
himself
,
slack
upon
the
shore
,
at
his
feet
.
   
<EOS>
The
wreck
,
even
to
my
unpractised
eye
,
was
breaking
up
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
that
she
was
parting
in
the
middle
,
and
that
the
life
of
the
solitary
man
upon
the
mast
hung
by
a
thread
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
he
clung
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
singular
red
cap
on
,
---
not
like
a
sailor
's
cap
,
but
of
a
finer
colour
;
and
as
the
few
yielding
planks
between
him
and
destruction
rolled
and
bulged
,
and
his
anticipative
death
-
knell
rung
,
he
was
seen
by
all
of
us
to
wave
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
him
do
it
now
,
and
thought
I
was
going
distracted
,
when
his
action
brought
an
old
remembrance
to
my
mind
of
a
once
dear
friend
.
   
<EOS>
Ham
watched
the
sea
,
standing
alone
,
with
the
silence
of
suspended
breath
behind
him
,
and
the
storm
before
,
until
there
was
a
great
retiring
wave
,
when
,
with
a
backward
glance
at
those
who
held
the
rope
which
was
made
fast
round
his
body
,
he
dashed
in
after
it
,
and
in
a
moment
was
buffeting
with
the
water
;
rising
with
the
hills
,
falling
with
the
valleys
,
lost
beneath
the
foam
;
then
drawn
again
to
land
.
 
<EOS>
They
hauled
in
hastily
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
hurt
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
blood
on
his
face
,
from
where
I
stood
;
but
he
took
no
thought
of
that
.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
hurriedly
to
give
them
some
directions
for
leaving
him
more
free
---
or
<EOS>
so
I
judged
from
the
motion
of
his
arm
---
and
was
gone
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
he
made
for
the
wreck
,
rising
with
the
hills
,
falling
with
the
valleys
,
lost
beneath
the
rugged
foam
,
borne
in
towards
the
shore
,
borne
on
towards
the
ship
,
striving
hard
and
valiantly
.
 
<EOS>
The
distance
was
nothing
,
but
the
power
of
the
sea
and
wind
made
the
strife
deadly
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
neared
the
wreck
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
so
near
,
that
with
one
more
of
his
vigorous
strokes
he
would
be
clinging
to
it
,
---
<EOS>
when
a
high
,
green
,
vast
hill
-
side
of
water
,
moving
on
shoreward
,
from
beyond
the
ship
,
he
seemed
to
leap
up
into
it
with
a
mighty
bound
,
and
the
ship
was
gone
!
   
<EOS>
Some
eddying
fragments
I
saw
in
the
sea
,
as
if
a
mere
cask
had
been
broken
,
in
running
to
the
spot
where
they
were
hauling
in
.
<EOS>
Consternation
was
in
every
face
.
 
<EOS>
They
drew
him
to
my
very
feet
---
insensible
---
dead
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
carried
to
the
nearest
house
;
and
,
no
one
preventing
me
now
,
I
remained
near
him
,
busy
,
while
every
means
of
restoration
were
tried
;
but
he
had
been
beaten
to
death
by
the
great
wave
,
and
his
generous
heart
was
stilled
for
ever
.
   
<EOS>
As
I
sat
beside
the
bed
,
when
hope
was
abandoned
and
all
was
done
,
a
fisherman
,
who
had
known
me
when
Emily
and
I
were
children
,
and
ever
since
,
whispered
my
name
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
he
,
with
tears
starting
to
his
weather
-
beaten
face
,
which
,
with
his
trembling
lips
,
was
ashy
pale
,
"
will
you
come
over
yonder
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
remembrance
that
had
been
recalled
to
me
,
was
in
his
look
.
<EOS>
I
asked
him
,
terror
-
stricken
,
leaning
on
the
arm
he
held
out
to
support
me
:
   
"
<EOS>
Has
a
body
come
ashore
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
said
,
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
I
know
it
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
then
.
   
<EOS>
He
answered
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
But
he
led
me
to
the
shore
.
 
<EOS>
And
on
that
part
of
it
where
she
and
I
had
looked
for
shells
,
two
children
---
on
that
part
of
it
where
some
lighter
fragments
of
the
old
boat
,
blown
down
last
night
,
had
been
scattered
by
the
wind
---
among
the
ruins
of
the
home
he
had
wronged
<EOS>
---
I
saw
him
lying
with
his
head
upon
his
arm
,
as
I
had
often
seen
him
lie
at
school
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
56
.
<EOS>
The
new
wound
,
and
the
old
 
<EOS>
No
need
,
O
Steerforth
,
to
have
said
,
when
we
last
spoke
together
,
in
that
hour
which
I
so
little
deemed
to
be
our
parting
-
hour
---
<EOS>
no
need
to
have
said
,
"
Think
of
me
at
my
best
!
<EOS>
"
I
had
done
that
ever
;
and
could
I
change
now
,
looking
on
this
sight
!
   
<EOS>
They
brought
a
hand
-
bier
,
and
laid
him
on
it
,
and
covered
him
with
a
flag
,
and
took
him
up
and
bore
him
on
towards
the
houses
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
men
who
carried
him
had
known
him
,
and
gone
sailing
with
him
,
and
seen
him
merry
and
bold
.
 
<EOS>
They
carried
him
through
the
wild
roar
,
a
hush
in
the
midst
of
all
the
tumult
;
and
took
him
to
the
cottage
where
Death
was
already
.
   
<EOS>
But
when
they
set
the
bier
down
on
the
threshold
,
they
looked
at
one
another
,
and
at
me
,
and
whispered
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
why
.
 
<EOS>
They
felt
as
if
it
were
not
right
to
lay
him
down
in
the
same
quiet
room
.
   
<EOS>
We
went
into
the
town
,
and
took
our
burden
to
the
inn
.
 
<EOS>
So
soon
as
I
could
at
all
collect
my
thoughts
,
I
sent
for
Joram
,
and
begged
him
to
provide
me
a
conveyance
in
which
it
could
be
got
to
London
in
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
that
the
care
of
it
,
and
the
hard
duty
of
preparing
his
mother
to
receive
it
,
could
only
rest
with
me
;
and
I
was
anxious
to
discharge
that
duty
as
faithfully
as
I
could
.
   
<EOS>
I
chose
the
night
for
the
journey
,
that
there
might
be
less
curiosity
when
I
left
the
town
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
although
it
was
nearly
midnight
when
I
came
out
of
the
yard
in
a
chaise
,
followed
by
what
I
had
in
charge
,
there
were
many
people
waiting
.
 
<EOS>
At
intervals
,
along
the
town
,
and
even
a
little
way
out
upon
the
road
,
I
saw
more
:
but
at
length
only
the
bleak
night
and
the
open
country
were
around
me
,
and
the
ashes
of
my
youthful
friendship
.
   
<EOS>
Upon
a
mellow
autumn
day
,
about
noon
,
when
the
ground
was
perfumed
by
fallen
leaves
,
and
many
more
,
in
beautiful
tints
of
yellow
,
red
,
and
brown
,
yet
hung
upon
the
trees
,
through
which
the
sun
was
shining
,
I
arrived
at
Highgate
.
 
<EOS>
I
walked
the
last
mile
,
thinking
as
I
went
along
of
what
I
had
to
do
;
and
left
the
carriage
that
had
followed
me
all
through
the
night
,
awaiting
orders
to
advance
.
   
<EOS>
The
house
,
when
I
came
up
to
it
,
looked
just
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
blind
was
raised
;
no
sign
of
life
was
in
the
dull
paved
court
,
with
its
covered
way
leading
to
the
disused
door
.
 
<EOS>
The
wind
had
quite
gone
down
,
and
nothing
moved
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
not
,
at
first
,
the
courage
to
ring
at
the
gate
;
and
<EOS>
when
I
did
ring
,
my
errand
seemed
to
me
to
be
expressed
in
the
very
sound
of
the
bell
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
parlour
-
maid
came
out
,
with
the
key
in
her
hand
;
and
looking
earnestly
at
me
as
she
unlocked
the
gate
,
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
ill
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
much
agitated
,
and
am
fatigued
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
anything
the
matter
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
---
Mr
James
?
 
<EOS>
---
"
   
"
Hush
!
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
something
has
happened
,
that
I
have
to
break
to
Mrs
Steerforth
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
at
home
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
girl
anxiously
replied
that
her
mistress
was
very
seldom
out
now
,
even
in
a
carriage
;
that
she
kept
her
room
;
that
she
saw
no
company
,
but
would
see
me
.
 
<EOS>
Her
mistress
was
up
,
she
said
,
and
Miss
Dartle
was
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
What
message
should
she
take
upstairs
?
   
<EOS>
Giving
her
a
strict
charge
to
be
careful
of
her
manner
,
and
only
to
carry
in
my
card
and
say
I
waited
,
I
sat
down
in
the
drawing
-
room
(
which
we
had
now
reached
)
until
she
should
come
back
.
 
<EOS>
Its
former
pleasant
air
of
occupation
was
gone
,
and
the
shutters
were
half
closed
.
 
<EOS>
The
harp
had
not
been
used
for
many
and
many
a
day
.
 
<EOS>
His
picture
,
as
a
boy
,
was
there
.
 
<EOS>
The
cabinet
in
which
his
mother
had
kept
his
letters
was
there
.
 
<EOS>
I
wondered
if
she
ever
read
them
now
;
if
she
would
ever
read
them
more
!
   
<EOS>
The
house
was
so
still
that
I
heard
the
girl
's
light
step
upstairs
.
<EOS>
On
her
return
,
she
brought
a
message
,
to
the
effect
that
Mrs
Steerforth
was
an
invalid
and
could
not
come
down
;
but
that
if
I
would
excuse
her
being
in
her
chamber
,
she
would
be
glad
to
see
me
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
moments
I
stood
before
her
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
in
his
room
;
not
in
her
own
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
,
of
course
,
that
she
had
taken
to
occupy
it
,
in
remembrance
of
him
;
and
that
the
many
tokens
of
his
old
sports
and
accomplishments
,
by
which
she
was
surrounded
,
remained
there
,
just
as
he
had
left
them
,
for
the
same
reason
.
 
<EOS>
She
murmured
<EOS>
,
however
,
even
in
her
reception
of
me
,
that
she
was
out
of
her
own
chamber
because
its
aspect
was
unsuited
to
her
infirmity
;
and
with
her
stately
look
repelled
the
least
suspicion
of
the
truth
.
   
<EOS>
At
her
chair
,
as
usual
,
was
Rosa
Dartle
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
first
moment
of
her
dark
eyes
resting
on
me
,
I
saw
she
knew
I
was
the
bearer
of
evil
tidings
.
 
<EOS>
The
scar
sprung
into
view
that
instant
.
 
<EOS>
She
withdrew
herself
a
step
behind
the
chair
,
to
keep
her
own
face
out
of
Mrs
Steerforth
's
observation
;
and
scrutinized
me
with
a
piercing
gaze
that
never
faltered
,
never
shrunk
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
observe
you
<EOS>
are
in
mourning
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Steerforth
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
unhappily
a
widower
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
young
to
know
so
great
a
loss
,
"
she
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
grieved
to
hear
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
grieved
to
hear
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
Time
will
be
good
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
Time
,
"
said
I
,
looking
at
her
,
"
will
be
good
to
all
of
us
.
<EOS>
Dear
Mrs
Steerforth
,
we
must
all
trust
to
that
,
in
our
heaviest
misfortunes
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
earnestness
of
my
manner
,
and
the
tears
in
my
eyes
,
alarmed
her
.
 
<EOS>
The
whole
course
of
her
thoughts
appeared
to
stop
,
and
change
.
   
<EOS>
I
tried
to
command
my
voice
in
gently
saying
his
name
,
but
it
trembled
.
 
<EOS>
She
repeated
it
to
herself
,
two
or
three
times
,
in
a
low
tone
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
addressing
me
,
she
said
,
with
enforced
calmness
:
   
<EOS>
"
My
son
is
ill
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
ill
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
seen
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
reconciled
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
not
say
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
could
not
say
No
.
 
<EOS>
She
slightly
turned
her
head
towards
the
spot
where
Rosa
Dartle
had
been
standing
at
her
elbow
,
and
in
that
moment
I
said
,
by
the
motion
of
my
lips
,
to
Rosa
,
"
Dead
!
"
   
<EOS>
That
Mrs
Steerforth
might
not
be
induced
to
look
behind
her
,
and
read
,
plainly
written
,
what
she
was
not
yet
prepared
to
know
,
I
met
her
look
quickly
;
but
I
had
seen
Rosa
Dartle
throw
her
hands
up
in
the
air
with
vehemence
of
despair
and
horror
,
and
then
clasp
them
on
her
face
.
   
<EOS>
The
handsome
lady
---
<EOS>
so
like
,
<EOS>
oh
so
like
!
---
regarded
me
with
a
fixed
look
,
and
put
her
hand
to
her
forehead
.
 
<EOS>
I
besought
her
to
be
calm
,
and
prepare
herself
to
bear
what
I
had
to
tell
;
but
I
should
rather
have
entreated
her
to
weep
,
for
she
sat
like
a
stone
figure
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
was
last
here
,
"
I
faltered
,
"
Miss
Dartle
told
me
he
was
sailing
here
and
there
.
 
<EOS>
The
night
before
last
was
a
dreadful
one
at
sea
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
were
at
sea
that
night
,
and
near
a
dangerous
coast
,
as
it
is
said
he
was
;
and
if
the
vessel
that
was
seen
should
really
be
the
ship
which
---
"
   
"
Rosa
!
"
said
Mrs
Steerforth
,
"
come
to
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
came
,
but
with
no
sympathy
or
gentleness
.
 
<EOS>
Her
eyes
gleamed
like
fire
as
she
confronted
his
mother
,
and
broke
into
a
frightful
laugh
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
she
said
,
"
is
your
pride
appeased
,
you
madwoman
?
 
<EOS>
Now
has
he
made
atonement
to
you
---
with
his
life
!
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
?
 
<EOS>
---
His
life
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Steerforth
,
fallen
back
stiffly
in
her
chair
,
and
making
no
sound
but
a
moan
,
cast
her
eyes
upon
her
with
a
wide
stare
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
"
cried
Rosa
,
smiting
herself
passionately
on
the
breast
,
"
look
at
me
!
<EOS>
Moan
,
and
groan
,
and
look
at
me
!
<EOS>
Look
here
!
"
<EOS>
striking
the
scar
,
"
at
your
dead
child
's
handiwork
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
moan
the
mother
uttered
,
from
time
to
time
,
went
to
My
heart
.
<EOS>
Always
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
Always
inarticulate
and
stifled
.
 
<EOS>
Always
accompanied
with
an
incapable
motion
of
the
head
,
but
with
no
change
of
face
.
 
<EOS>
Always
proceeding
from
a
rigid
mouth
and
closed
teeth
,
as
if
the
jaw
were
locked
and
the
face
frozen
up
in
pain
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
remember
when
he
did
this
?
"
she
proceeded
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
remember
when
,
in
his
inheritance
of
your
nature
,
and
in
your
pampering
of
his
pride
and
passion
,
he
did
this
,
and
disfigured
me
for
life
?
 
<EOS>
Look
at
me
,
marked
until
I
die
with
his
high
displeasure
;
and
moan
and
groan
for
what
you
made
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Dartle
,
<EOS>
"
I
entreated
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
Heaven
's
sake
---
"
   
"
I
WILL
speak
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
turning
on
me
with
her
lightning
eyes
.
"
<EOS>
Be
silent
,
you
!
<EOS>
Look
at
me
,
I
say
,
proud
mother
of
a
proud
,
false
son
!
<EOS>
Moan
for
your
nurture
of
him
,
moan
for
your
corruption
of
him
,
moan
for
your
loss
of
him
,
moan
for
mine
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
clenched
her
hand
,
and
trembled
through
her
spare
,
worn
figure
,
as
if
her
passion
were
killing
her
by
inches
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
,
resent
his
self
-
will
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
,
injured
by
his
haughty
temper
!
<EOS>
You
,
who
opposed
to
both
,
when
your
hair
was
grey
,
the
qualities
which
made
both
when
you
gave
him
birth
!
<EOS>
YOU
,
who
from
his
cradle
reared
him
to
be
what
he
was
,
and
stunted
what
he
should
have
been
!
<EOS>
Are
you
rewarded
,
now
,
for
your
years
of
trouble
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Miss
Dartle
,
shame
!
<EOS>
Oh
cruel
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
,
"
she
returned
,
"
I
WILL
speak
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
No
power
on
earth
should
stop
me
,
while
I
was
standing
here
!
<EOS>
Have
I
been
silent
all
these
years
,
and
shall
I
not
speak
now
?
 
<EOS>
I
loved
him
better
than
you
ever
loved
him
!
"
<EOS>
turning
on
her
fiercely
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
could
have
loved
him
,
and
asked
no
return
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
been
his
wife
,
I
could
have
been
the
slave
of
his
caprices
for
a
word
of
love
a
year
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
been
.
 
<EOS>
Who
knows
it
better
than
I
?
 
<EOS>
You
were
exacting
,
proud
,
punctilious
,
selfish
.
 
<EOS>
My
love
would
have
been
devoted
---
would
have
trod
your
paltry
whimpering
under
foot
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
flashing
eyes
,
she
stamped
upon
the
ground
as
if
she
actually
did
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Look
here
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
striking
the
scar
again
,
with
a
relentless
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
he
grew
into
the
better
understanding
of
what
he
had
done
,
he
saw
it
,
and
repented
of
it
!
<EOS>
I
could
sing
to
him
,
and
talk
to
him
,
and
show
the
ardour
that
I
felt
in
all
he
did
,
and
attain
with
labour
to
such
knowledge
as
most
interested
him
;
and
I
attracted
him
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
was
freshest
and
truest
,
he
loved
me
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
he
did
!
<EOS>
Many
a
time
,
when
you
were
put
off
with
a
slight
word
,
he
has
taken
Me
to
his
heart
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
said
it
with
a
taunting
pride
in
the
midst
of
her
frenzy
---
for
it
was
little
less
---
yet
with
an
eager
remembrance
of
it
,
in
which
the
smouldering
embers
of
a
gentler
feeling
kindled
for
the
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
descended
---
as
I
might
have
known
I
should
,
but
that
he
fascinated
me
with
his
boyish
courtship
---
into
a
doll
,
a
trifle
for
the
occupation
of
an
idle
hour
,
to
be
dropped
,
and
taken
up
,
and
trifled
with
,
as
the
inconstant
humour
took
him
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
grew
weary
,
I
grew
weary
.
 
<EOS>
As
his
fancy
died
out
,
I
would
no
more
have
tried
to
strengthen
any
power
I
had
,
than
I
would
have
married
him
on
his
being
forced
to
take
me
for
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
We
fell
away
from
one
another
without
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
saw
it
,
and
were
not
sorry
.
<EOS>
Since
then
,
I
have
been
a
mere
disfigured
piece
of
furniture
between
you
both
;
having
no
eyes
,
no
ears
,
no
feelings
,
no
remembrances
.
 
<EOS>
Moan
?
 
<EOS>
Moan
for
what
you
made
him
;
not
for
your
love
.
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
that
the
time
was
,
when
I
loved
him
better
than
you
ever
did
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
stood
with
her
bright
angry
eyes
confronting
the
wide
stare
,
and
the
set
face
;
and
softened
no
more
,
when
the
moaning
was
repeated
,
than
if
the
face
had
been
a
picture
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Dartle
,
"
said
I
,
"
if
you
can
be
so
obdurate
as
not
to
feel
for
this
afflicted
mother
---
"
   
"
Who
feels
for
me
?
<EOS>
"
she
sharply
retorted
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
sown
this
.
 
<EOS>
Let
her
moan
for
the
harvest
that
she
reaps
today
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
if
his
faults
---
"
I
began
.
   
<EOS>
"
Faults
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
,
bursting
into
passionate

.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
dares
malign
him
?
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
soul
worth
millions
of
the
friends
to
whom
he
stooped
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
one
can
have
loved
him
better
,
no
one
can
hold
him
in
dearer

than
I
,
"
I
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
meant
to
say
,
if
you
have
no

for
his
mother
;
or
if
his
faults
---
you
have
been
bitter
on

---
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
false
,
"
she
cried
,
tearing
her
black

;
"
I
loved
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
---
if
his
faults
can
not
,
"
I
went
on
,
"
be

your

,
in

look

that

,
even
as

have
never
seen

,
and
render
it
some
help
!
"
   
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
the
figure
was
unchanged
,
and
looked
unchangeable
.
<EOS>
Motionless
,
rigid
,
staring
;
moaning
in
the
same

from
time
to

,
with
the

of

;
but
giving
no

life
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Dartle
suddenly
kneeled
down
before
it
,
and
began
to
loosen
the
dress
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
curse
upon
you
!
"
<EOS>
she

,
looking

,
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
in
an
evil
hour
that
you
ever
came
here
!
<EOS>
A
curse
upon
you
!
<EOS>
Go
!
"
   
<EOS>
After

of
the
room
,
I
hurried
back
to
ring
the
bell
,
the
sooner
to

.
 
<EOS>
She
had
then
taken
the
impassive
figure
in
her

,
and
,
still

,
was

,

calling

,

,
and
trying
every

means
to
rouse

dormant

.
 
<EOS>
No
longer
afraid
of
leaving
her
,
I
noiselessly
turned
back
again
;
and
alarmed
the
house
as
I
went
out
.
   
<EOS>
Later
in
the
day
,
I
returned
,
and
we
laid
him
in
his
mother
's
room
.
<EOS>
She
was
just
the
same
,
they
told
me
;
Miss
Dartle
never
left
her
;
doctors
were
in
attendance
,
many
things
had
been
tried
;
but
she
lay
like
a
statue
,
except
for
the
low
sound
now
and
then
.
   
<EOS>
I
went
through
the
dreary
house
,
and
darkened
the
windows
.
 
<EOS>
The
windows
of
the
chamber
where
he
lay
<EOS>
,
I
darkened
last
.
 
<EOS>
I
lifted
up
the
leaden

,
and
held
it
to
my
heart
;
and
all
the
world
seemed
death
and
silence
,
broken
only
by
his

's

.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
57
.
<EOS>
The
emigrants
 
One
thing
more
<EOS>
,
I
had
to
do
,
before

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
,
to
conceal
what
had
occurred
,
from
those
who
were
going
away
;
and
to
dismiss

on
their

in
happy

.
 
<EOS>
In
this
,
no
time
was
to

.
   
<EOS>
I
took
Mr
Micawber
aside
that
same
night
,
and
confided
to
him
the
task
of
standing
between
Mr
Peggotty
and
intelligence
of
the
late

.
 
<EOS>
He
zealously

to
do

,
and
to
intercept
any
newspaper
through
which
it
might
,
without
such

.
   
<EOS>
"
If

,

,
"
said

,

,
"

first

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
,
I
must
observe
,
in
his
adaptation
of
himself
to
a
new
state
of
society
,
had
acquired
a
bold

air
,
not

,
but
defensive
and

.
 
<EOS>
One
might
have
supposed
him
a
child
of
the

,
long

to
live
out
of
the
confines
of
civilization
,
and
about
to
return
to
his
native

.
   
<EOS>
He
had
provided
himself
,
among
other
things
,
with
a
complete
suit
of
oilskin
,
and
a
straw
hat
with
a
very
low
crown
,
pitched
or
caulked
on
the
outside
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
rough
clothing
,
with
a
common
mariner
's

under
his
arm
,
and
a
shrewd
trick
of
casting
up
his
eye
at
the
sky
as
looking
out
for
dirty
weather
,
he
was
far
more
nautical
,
after
his
manner
,
than
Mr
Peggotty
.
 
<EOS>
His
whole
family
,
if
I
may
so
express
it
,
were
cleared
for
action
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
Mrs
Micawber
in
the
closest
and
most
uncompromising
of
bonnets
,
made
fast
under
the
chin
;
and
in
a
shawl
which
tied
her
up
(
as
I
had
been
tied
up
,
when
my
aunt
first
received
me
)
like
a
bundle
,
and
was
secured
behind
at

,
in
a
strong

.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Micawber
<EOS>
I
found
made
snug
for
stormy
weather
,
in
the
same
manner
;
with
nothing
superfluous
about
her
.
 
<EOS>
Master
Micawber
was
hardly
visible
in
a
Guernsey
shirt
,
and
the
shaggiest
suit
of
slops
I
ever
saw
;
and
the
children
were
done
up
,
like

,
in
impervious
cases
.
 
<EOS>
Both
Mr
Micawber
and
his
eldest

wore
their

loosely
turned
back
at

,
as

ready

lend

in

,
and
to
"
tumble
up
"
,
or
sing
out
,
"
Yeo
---
Heave
---
Yeo
!
"
<EOS>
on

.
   
<EOS>
Thus
Traddles
and
<EOS>
I
found

at

,

the

,
at

known

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
had
told

of

,

;
but
there

no

the

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
It

I

Mr
Micawber
aside
,

.
   
<EOS>
The
Micawber
family
were
lodged
in
a
little
,
dirty
,
tumble

down
public
-
house
,
which
in
those
days

close
to

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
The

,
as

,

in
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

one

upstairs
,
with

.
 
<EOS>
My

and

were

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Peggotty

,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
It

;
still

Mr

,

,
that

<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>
If

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

Emma

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr

,

;

<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
Mrs

and

of
the
family
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
In

,

,
Mr

,

;

<EOS>
"
The

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"
Micawber

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

not

repulsed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
he
returned
,
"
so
be
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
not
for
their
sakes
;
for
mine
,
Micawber
,
"
said

wife
.
   
<EOS>
"
Emma
,
"
he
returned
,
"
that
view
of
the
question
is
,
at
such
a
moment
,
irresistible
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
,
even
now
,
distinctly
pledge
myself
to
fall
upon
your
family
's
neck
;
but
the
member
of
your
family
,
who
is
now
in

,
shall
have
no
genial

frozen
by

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
withdrew
,
and
was
absent
some
little
time
;
in
the
course
of
which
Mrs
Micawber
was
not
wholly
free
from
an
apprehension
that
words
might
have
arisen
between
him
and
the
Member
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
the
same
boy
reappeared
,
and
presented
me
with
a
note
written
in
pencil
,
and
headed
,
in

legal

,
"
Heep
v
Micawber
"
.
 
<EOS>
From
this
document
,
I
learned
that
Mr
Micawber
being
again
arrested
,
was
in
a
final
paroxysm
of
despair
;
and
that
he
begged
me
to
send
him
his

and
pint
pot
,
by
bearer
,
as
they
might
prove
serviceable
during
the
brief

of
his

,
in

.
 
<EOS>
He
also
requested
,
as
a
last

of

,
that
I
would
see
his
family
to
the
Parish
Workhouse
,
and
forget
that
such
a
Being
ever
lived
.
   
<EOS>
Of
course
I
answered
this
note
by
going
down
with
the
boy
to
pay
the
money
,
where
I
found
Mr
Micawber
sitting
in
a
corner
,
looking
darkly
at
the
Sheriff
's
Officer
who
had
effected
the
capture
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
release
,
he
embraced
me
with
the
utmost
fervour
;
and
made
an
entry
of
the
transaction
in
his
pocket
-
book
---
being
very
particular
,
I
recollect
,
about
a
halfpenny
I
inadvertently
omitted
from
my
statement
of
the
total
.
   
<EOS>
This
momentous
pocket
-
book
was
a
timely
reminder
to
him
of
another
transaction
.
 
<EOS>
On
our

to
the
room
upstairs
(
where
he
accounted
for
his
absence
by
saying
that
it
had
been
occasioned
by

over
which
he
had
no

)
,
he
took
out
of
it
a
large

of
paper
,
folded
small
,
and
quite
covered
with
long

,
carefully
worked
.
 
<EOS>
From
the

I
had
of
them
,
I
should
say
that
I
never
saw
such

out

.
<EOS>
These
,
it

,

on

he

"
the

forty

,
ten
,

"
,
for

.
 
<EOS>
After

,
and
an

,

had

the

to

that
sum
which
represented
the
amount
with

to
two
years
,
fifteen

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
For

a
note
-
of

,

over
to
Traddles
on
the
spot
,
a

in

(
as

man

)
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have

,
"

Micawber
,

,
"
that

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

"

,

"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
,
I

,
himself

"
   
<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Please

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
The

,

,

;
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

,
"

,

,
"
merely

.
 
<EOS>
The
distance
is
quite

.
"
   
<EOS>
I

,

,
how
odd

was
,
<EOS>
but

like
Mr
Micawber
<EOS>
,
that
,

,

<EOS>
"

,

"

,
"

;

.
 
<EOS>
When

she

,

,
"
<EOS>
Little
Tafflin
"
.
 
<EOS>
Porpoises

,

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
In

,
"

,

Land
<EOS>
-

!
<EOS>

!
"
   
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
Do

,
Micawber
!
<EOS>
I

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
However
vigorous
the

,
"

,

,
"

;

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Micawber
,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

,
"

<EOS>
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Micawber
,
"

<EOS>
"
There
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

that

,
even
in
this
step

,
the

between

and
Albion
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

sat
in

,

;
half

's

,
but
very

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
Mrs

,
"
I
wish
Mr
Micawber
to
feel
his
position
.
 
<EOS>
It
appears
to
me
highly
important
that
Mr
Micawber
should
,
from
the
hour
of
his
embarkation
,
feel
his
position
.
 
<EOS>
Your
old
knowledge
of
me
,
my
dear
Mr
Copperfield
,
will
have
told

that
I
have
not
the

Mr
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
My

is
,
if
I

say

,
eminently

.
<EOS>
I
know
that
this
is
a
long

.
 
<EOS>
I

will
involve
many

and

.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not

to

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
also
know
what
Mr
Micawber
is
.
 
<EOS>
I

latent
power
of
Mr
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
And
therefore
I
consider
it
vitally

that
Mr
Micawber
should
feel
his
position
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
love
,
"
he
observed
,
"
perhaps
you
will
allow

to
remark
that
it
is
barely

that
I
DO

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
not
,
Micawber
,
"
she

.
 
<EOS>
"
Not

.
 
<EOS>
My

Mr
Copperfield
,
Mr
Micawber
's
is

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
is
going
to
a
distant
country
expressly
in

that
he
may

fully

and

.
 
<EOS>
I

's

,

,
"
This
country
I

!
<EOS>
Have

?
 
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
Let

.
 
<EOS>
They
are

!
"
<EOS>
"
   
Mr
Micawber
,

all
,
seemed

think

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

Micawber
,

"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
That
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
From

,

"
Enough

:

:

.
 
<EOS>
That

.
 
<EOS>
This

.
 
<EOS>
Produce

.
<EOS>
Bring

!
"
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
folded

in

,
as

.
   
<EOS>
"
And

,
"

Mrs
Micawber
,
"
---
feeling
his
position
---
am
I
not

Mr
Micawber

,

,

Britain
?
 
<EOS>
An
important
public
character
arising
in
that
hemisphere
,
shall
I
be
told
that
its

will
not

?
 
<EOS>
Can

Mr
Micawber
,

,

?
 
<EOS>
I

;

I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Micawber
's

that
her

were

,
gave

I

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,
"

Micawber
,
"
that
I
the
more

,

,

,
we

.
<EOS>
Mr
Micawber
may

---
I

that

,
Mr
Micawber

---
a

;

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My

,
"
observed

Micawber
,
"
it

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
always

.
 
<EOS>
What
will
be
---
will
be
.
 
<EOS>
Heaven

that
I
should
grudge
my
native
country
any

of
the

that
may

by

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
well
,
"
said
my

,
nodding

Mr
Peggotty
,
"
and
I
drink
my
love
to
you
all
,
and
every

and

attend

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
put
down

two
children
he
had

,
one

,
to
join
Mr

in

all
of
us
in

;
and
when
he
and
the
Micawbers
cordially

as

,
and
his
brown
face
brightened
with
a
smile
,
I
felt
that
he
would
make
his
way
,
establish
a
good
name
,
and
be
beloved
,
go
where
he
would
.
   
<EOS>
Even

children
were
instructed
,
each

Mr
Micawber
's

,

pledge

in

.
 
<EOS>
When

,
my
aunt
and

rose
,
and
parted
from
the
emigrants
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
