farewell
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
all
crying
;
the
children
hung
about
Agnes
to
the
last
;
and
we
left
poor
Mrs
Micawber
in
a
very
distressed
condition
,
sobbing
and
weeping
by
a
dim
candle
,
that
must
have
made
the
room
look
,
from
the
river
,
like
a
miserable
light
-
house
.
   
<EOS>
I
went
down
again
next
morning
to
see
that
they
were
away
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
departed
,
in
a
boat
,
as
early
as
five
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
wonderful
instance
to
me
of
the
gap
such
partings
make
,
<EOS>
that
although
my
association
of
them
with
the
tumble
-
down
public
-
house
and
the
wooden
stairs
dated
only
from
last
night
,
both
seemed
dreary
and
deserted
,
now
that
they
were
gone
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
afternoon
of
the
next
day
,
my
old
nurse
and
I
went
down
to
Gravesend
.
 
<EOS>
We
found
the
ship
in
the
river
,
surrounded
by
a
crowd
of
boats
;
a
favourable
wind
blowing
;
the
signal
for
sailing
at
her
mast
-
head
.
 
<EOS>
I
hired
a
boat
directly
,
and
we
put
off
to
her
;
and
getting
through
the
little
vortex
of
confusion
of
which
she
was
the
centre
,
went
on
board
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Peggotty
was
waiting
for
us
on
deck
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
me
that
Mr
Micawber
had
just
now
been
arrested
again
(
and
for
the
last
time
)
at
the
suit
of
Heep
,
and
that
,
in
compliance
with
a
request
I
had
made
to
him
,
he
had
paid
the
money
,
which
I
repaid
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
took
us
down
between
decks
;
and
there
,
<EOS>
any
lingering
fears
I
had
of
his
having
heard
any
rumours
of
what
had
happened
,
were
dispelled
by
Mr
Micawber
's
coming
out
of
the
gloom
,
taking
his
arm
with
an
air
of
friendship
and
protection
,
and
telling
me
that
they
had
scarcely
been
asunder
for
a
moment
,
since
the
night
before
last
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
such
a
strange
scene
to
me
,
and
so
confined
and
dark
,
that
,
at
first
,
I
could
make
out
hardly
anything
;
but
,
by
degrees
,
it
cleared
,
as
my
eyes
became
more
accustomed
to
the
gloom
,
and
I
seemed
to
stand
in
a
picture
by
OSTADE
.
 
<EOS>
Among
the
great
beams
,
bulks
,
and
ringbolts
of
the
ship
,
and
the
emigrant
-
berths
,
and
chests
,
and
bundles
,
and
barrels
,
and
heaps
of
miscellaneous
baggage
---
lighted
up
,
here
and
there
,
by
dangling
lanterns
;
and
elsewhere
by
the
yellow
daylight
straying
down
a
windsail
or
a
hatchway
---
were
crowded
groups
of
people
,
making
new
friendships
,
taking
leave
of
one
another
,
talking
,
laughing
,
crying
,
eating
and
drinking
;
some
,
already
settled
down
into
the
possession
of
their
few
feet
of
space
,
with
their
little
households
arranged
,
and
tiny
children
established
on
stools
,
or
in
dwarf
elbow
-
chairs
;
others
,
despairing
of
a
resting
-
place
,
and
wandering
disconsolately
.
 
<EOS>
From
babies
who
had
but
a
week
or
two
of
life
behind
them
,
to
crooked
old
men
and
women
who
seemed
to
have
but
<EOS>
a
week
or
two
of
life
before
them
;
and
from
ploughmen
bodily
carrying
out
soil
of
England
on
their
boots
,
to
smiths
taking
away
samples
of
its
soot
and
smoke
upon
their
skins
;
every
age
and
occupation
appeared
to
be
crammed
into
the
narrow
compass
of
the
'
tween
decks
.
   
<EOS>
As
my
eye
glanced
round
this
place
,
I
thought
I
saw
sitting
,
by
an
open
port
,
with
one
of
the
Micawber
children
near
her
,
a
figure
like
Emily
's
;
it
first
attracted
my
attention
,
by
another
figure
parting
from
it
with
a
kiss
;
and
as
it
glided
calmly
away
through
the
disorder
,
reminding
me
of
---
Agnes
!
<EOS>
But
in
the
rapid
motion
and
confusion
,
and
in
the
unsettlement
of
my
own
thoughts
,
I
lost
it
again
;
and
only
knew
that
the
time
was
come
when
all
visitors
were
being
warned
to
leave
the
ship
;
that
my
nurse
was
crying
on
a
chest
beside
me
;
and
that
Mrs
Gummidge
,
assisted
by
some
younger
stooping
woman
in
black
,
was
busily
arranging
Mr
Peggotty
's
goods
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
there
any
last
wured
,
Mas'r
Davy
?
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
there
any
one
forgotten
thing
<EOS>
afore
we
parts
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
One
thing
!
<EOS>
"
said
I.
 
"
Martha
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
touched
the
younger
woman
I
have
mentioned
on
the
shoulder
,
and
Martha
stood
before
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Heaven
bless
you
,
you
good
man
!
"
<EOS>
cried
I.
 
<EOS>
"
You
take
her
with
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
answered
for
him
,
with
a
burst
of
tears
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
speak
no
more
at
that
time
,
but
I
wrung
his
hand
;
and
if
ever
I
have
loved
and
honoured
any
man
,
I
loved
and
honoured
that
man
in
my
soul
.
   
<EOS>
The
ship
was
clearing
fast
of
strangers
.
 
<EOS>
The
greatest
trial
that
I
had
,
remained
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
him
what
the
noble
spirit
that
was
gone
,
had
given
me
in
charge
to
say
at
parting
.
 
<EOS>
It
moved
him
deeply
.
<EOS>
But
when
he
charged
me
,
in
return
,
with
many
messages
of
affection
and
regret
for
those
deaf
ears
,
he
moved
me
more
.
   
<EOS>
The
time
was
come
.
 
<EOS>
I
embraced
him
,
took
my
weeping
nurse
upon
my
arm
,
and
hurried
away
.
 
<EOS>
On
deck
,
I
took
leave
of
poor
Mrs
Micawber
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
looking
distractedly
about
for
her
family
,
even
then
;
and
her
last
words
to
me
were
,
that
she
never
would
desert
Mr
Micawber
.
   
<EOS>
We
went
over
the
side
into
our
boat
,
and
lay
at
a
little
distance
,
to
see
the
ship
wafted
on
her
course
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
then
calm
,
radiant
sunset
.
 
<EOS>
She
lay
between
us
,
and
the
red
light
;
and
every
taper
line
and
spar
was
visible
against
the
glow
.
 
<EOS>
A
sight
at
once
so
beautiful
,
so
mournful
,
and
so
hopeful
,
as
the
glorious
ship
,
lying
,
still
,
on
the
flushed
water
,
with
all
the
life
on
board
her
crowded
at
the
bulwarks
,
and
there
clustering
,
for
a
moment
,
bare
-
headed
and
silent
,
I
never
saw
.
   
<EOS>
Silent
,
only
for
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
sails
rose
to
the
wind
,
and
the
ship
began
to
move
,
there
broke
from
all
the
boats
three
resounding
cheers
,
which
those
on
board
took
up
,
and
echoed
back
,
and
which
were
echoed
and
re
-
echoed
.
 
<EOS>
My
heart
burst
out
when
I
heard
the
sound
,
and
beheld
the
waving
of
the
hats
and
handkerchiefs
---
<EOS>
and
then
I
saw
her
!
   
<EOS>
Then
I
saw
her
,
at
her
uncle
's
side
,
and
trembling
on
his
shoulder
.
<EOS>
He
pointed
to
us
with
an
eager
hand
;
and
she
saw
us
,
and
waved
her
last
good
-
bye
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Aye
,
Emily
,
beautiful
and
drooping
,
cling
to
him
with
the
utmost
trust
of
thy
bruised
heart
;
for
he
has
clung
to
thee
,
with
all
the
might
of
his
great
love
!
   
<EOS>
Surrounded
by
the
rosy
light
,
and
standing
high
upon
the
deck
,
apart
together
,
she
clinging
to
him
,
and
he
holding
her
,
they
solemnly
passed
away
.
 
<EOS>
The
night
had
fallen
on
the
Kentish
hills
when
we
were
rowed
ashore
---
and
fallen
darkly
upon
me
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
58
.
<EOS>
Absence
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
long
and
gloomy
night
that
gathered
on
me
,
haunted
by
the
ghosts
of
many
hopes
,
of
many
dear
remembrances
,
many
errors
,
many
unavailing
sorrows
and
regrets
.
   
<EOS>
I
went
away
from
England
;
not
knowing
,
even
then
,
how
great
the
shock
was
,
that
I
had
to
bear
.
 
<EOS>
I
left
all
who
were
dear
to
me
,
and
went
away
;
and
believed
that
I
had
borne
it
,
and
it
was
past
.
 
<EOS>
As
a
man
upon
a
field
of
battle
will
receive
a
mortal
hurt
,
and
scarcely
know
that
he
is
struck
,
so
I
,
when
I
was
left
alone
with
my
undisciplined
heart
,
had
no
conception
of
the
wound
with
which
it
had
to
strive
.
   
<EOS>
The
knowledge
came
upon
me
,
not
quickly
,
but
little
by
little
,
and
grain
by
grain
.
 
<EOS>
The
desolate
feeling
with
which
I
went
abroad
,
deepened
and
widened
hourly
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
it
was
a
heavy
sense
of
loss
and
sorrow
,
wherein
I
could
distinguish
little
else
.
 
<EOS>
By
imperceptible
degrees
,
it
became
a
hopeless
consciousness
of
all
that
I
had
lost
---
love
,
friendship
,
interest
;
of
all
that
had
been
shattered
---
my
first
trust
,
my
first
affection
,
the
whole
airy
castle
of
my
life
;
of
all
that
remained
---
a
ruined
blank
and
waste
,
lying
wide
around
me
,
unbroken
,
to
the
dark
horizon
.
   
<EOS>
If
my
grief
were
selfish
,
I
did
not
know
it
to
be
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
mourned
for
my
child
-
wife
,
taken
from
her
blooming
world
,
so
young
.
 
<EOS>
I
mourned
for
him
who
might
have
won
the
love
and
admiration
of
thousands
,
as
he
had
won
mine
long
ago
.
 
<EOS>
I
mourned
for
the
broken
heart
that
had
found
rest
in
the
stormy
sea
;
and
for
the
wandering
remnants
of
the
simple
home
,
where
I
had
heard
the
night
-
wind
blowing
,
when
I
was
a
child
.
   
<EOS>
From
the
accumulated
sadness
into
which
I
fell
,
I
had
at
length
no
hope
of
ever
issuing
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
roamed
from
place
to
place
,
carrying
my
burden
with
me
everywhere
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
its
whole
weight
now
;
and
I
drooped
beneath
it
,
and
I
said
in
my
heart
that
it
could
never
be
lightened
.
   
<EOS>
When
this
despondency
was
at
its
worst
,
I
believed
that
I
should
die
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
I
thought
that
I
would
like
to
die
at
home
;
and
actually
turned
back
on
my
road
,
that
I
might
get
there
soon
.
 
<EOS>
At
other
times
,
I
passed
on
farther
away
,
---
from
city
to
city
,
seeking
<EOS>
I
know
not
what
,
and
trying
to
leave
<EOS>
I
know
not
<EOS>
what
behind
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
not
in
my
power
to
retrace
,
one
by
one
,
all
the
weary
phases
of
distress
of
mind
through
which
I
passed
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
some
dreams
that
can
only
be
imperfectly
and
vaguely
described
;
and
when
I
oblige
myself
to
look
back
on
this
time
of
my
life
,
I
seem
to
be
recalling
such
a
dream
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
myself
passing
on
among
the
novelties
of
foreign
towns
,
palaces
,
cathedrals
,
temples
,
pictures
,
castles
,
tombs
,
fantastic
streets
---
the
old
abiding
places
of
History
and
Fancy
---
as
a
dreamer
might
;
bearing
my
painful
load
through
all
,
and
hardly
conscious
of
the
objects
as
they
fade
before
me
.
 
<EOS>
Listlessness
to
everything
,
but
brooding
sorrow
,
was
the
night
that
fell
on
my
undisciplined
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
look
up
from
it
---
as
at
last
<EOS>
I
did
,
thank
Heaven
!
<EOS>
---
and
from
its
long
,
sad
,
wretched
dream
,
to
dawn
.
   
<EOS>
For
many
months
I
travelled
with
this
ever
-
darkening
cloud
upon
my
mind
.
 
<EOS>
Some
blind
reasons
that
I
had
for
not
returning
home
---
reasons
then
struggling
within
me
,
vainly
,
for
more
distinct
expression
---
kept
me
on
my
pilgrimage
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
I
had
proceeded
restlessly
from
place
to
place
,
stopping
nowhere
;
sometimes
,
I
had
lingered
long
in
one
spot
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
had
no
purpose
,
no
sustaining
soul
within
me
,
anywhere
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
in
Switzerland
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
come
out
of
Italy
,
over
one
of
the
great
passes
of
the
Alps
,
and
had
since
wandered
with
a
guide
among
the
by
-
ways
of
the
mountains
.
 
<EOS>
If
those
awful
solitudes
had
spoken
to
my
heart
,
I
did
not
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
found
sublimity
and
wonder
in
the
dread
heights
and
precipices
,
in
the
roaring
torrents
,
and
the
wastes
of
ice
and
snow
;
but
as
yet
,
they
had
taught
me
nothing
else
.
   
<EOS>
I
came
,
one
evening
before
sunset
,
down
into
a
valley
,
where
I
was
to
rest
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
my
descent
to
it
,
by
the
winding
track
along
the
mountain
-
side
,
from
which
I
saw
it
shining
far
below
,
I
think
some
long
-
unwonted
sense
of
beauty
and
tranquillity
,
some
softening
influence
awakened
by
its
peace
,
moved
faintly
in
my
breast
.
 
<EOS>
I
remember
pausing
once
,
with
a
kind
of
sorrow
that
was
not
all
oppressive
,
not
quite
despairing
.
 
<EOS>
I
remember
almost
hoping
that
some
better
change
was
possible
within
me
.
   
<EOS>
I
came
into
the
valley
,
as
the
evening
sun
was
shining
on
the
remote
heights
of
snow
,
that
closed
it
in
,
like
eternal
clouds
.
<EOS>
The
bases
of
the
mountains
forming
the
gorge
in
which
the
little
village
lay
,
were
richly
green
;
and
high
above
this
gentler
vegetation
,
grew
forests
of
dark
fir
,
cleaving
the
wintry
snow
-
drift
,
wedge
-
like
,
and
stemming
the
avalanche
.
 
<EOS>
Above
these
,
were
range
upon
range
of
craggy
steeps
,
grey
rock
,
bright
ice
,
and
smooth
verdure
-
specks
of
pasture
,
all
gradually
blending
with
the
crowning
snow
.
 
<EOS>
Dotted
here
and
there
on
the
mountain's
-
side
,
each
tiny
dot
a
home
,
were
lonely
wooden
cottages
,
<EOS>
so
dwarfed
by
the
towering
heights
that
they
appeared
too
small
for
toys
.
 
<EOS>
So
did
even
the
clustered
village
in
the
valley
,
with
its
wooden
bridge
across
the
stream
,
where
the
stream
tumbled
over
broken
rocks
,
and
roared
away
among
the
trees
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
quiet
air
,
there
was
a
sound
of
distant
singing
---
shepherd
voices
;
but
,
as
one
bright
evening
cloud
floated
midway
along
the
mountain's
-
side
,
I
could
almost
have
believed
it
came
from
there
,
and
was
not
earthly
music
.
 
<EOS>
All
at
once
,
in
this
serenity
,
great
Nature
spoke
to
me
;
and
soothed
me
to
lay
down
my
weary
head
upon
the
grass
,
and
weep
as
I
had
not
wept
yet
,
since
Dora
died
!
   
<EOS>
I
had
found
a
packet
of
letters
awaiting
me
but
a
few
minutes
before
,
and
had
strolled
out
of
the
village
to
read
them
while
my
supper
was
making
ready
.
 
<EOS>
Other
packets
had
missed
me
,
and
I
had
received
none
for
a
long
time
.
 
<EOS>
Beyond
a
line
or
two
,
to
say
that
I
was
well
,
and
had
arrived
at
such
a
place
,
I
had
not
had
fortitude
or
constancy
to
write
a
letter
since
I
left
home
.
   
<EOS>
The
packet
was
in
my
hand
.
 
<EOS>
I
opened
it
,
and
read
the
writing
of
Agnes
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
happy
and
useful
,
was
prospering
as
she
had
hoped
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
all
she
told
me
of
herself
.
 
<EOS>
The
rest
referred
to
me
.
   
<EOS>
She
gave
me
no
advice
;
she
urged
no
duty
on
me
;
she
only
told
me
,
in
her
own
fervent
manner
,
what
her
trust
in
me
was
.
 
<EOS>
She
knew
(
she
said
)
<EOS>
how
such
a
nature
as
mine
would
turn
affliction
to
good
.
 
<EOS>
She
knew
how
trial
and
emotion
would
exalt
and
strengthen
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
sure
that
in
my
every
purpose
I
should
gain
a
firmer
and
a
higher
tendency
,
through
the
grief
I
had
undergone
.
 
<EOS>
She
,
who
so
gloried
in
my
fame
,
and
so
looked
forward
to
its
augmentation
,
well
knew
that
I
would
labour
on
.
 
<EOS>
She
knew
that
in
me
,
sorrow
could
not
be
weakness
,
but
must
be
strength
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
endurance
of
my
childish
days
had
done
its
part
to
make
me
what
I
was
,
so
greater
calamities
would
nerve
me
on
,
to
be
yet
better
than
I
was
;
and
<EOS>
so
,
as
they
had
taught
me
,
would
I
teach
others
.
 
<EOS>
She
commended
me
to
God
,
who
had
taken
my
innocent
darling
to
His
rest
;
and
in
her
sisterly
affection
cherished
me
always
,
and
was
always
at
my
side
go
where
I
would
;
proud
of
what
I
had
done
,
but
infinitely
prouder
yet
of
what
I
was
reserved
to
do
.
   
<EOS>
I
put
the
letter
in
my
breast
,
and
thought
what
had
I
been
an
hour
ago
!
<EOS>
When
I
heard
the
voices
die
away
,
and
saw
the
quiet
evening
cloud
grow
dim
,
and
all
the
colours
in
the
valley
fade
,
and
the
golden
snow
upon
the
mountain
-
tops
become
a
remote
part
of
the
pale
night
sky
,
yet
felt
that
the
night
was
passing
from
my
mind
,
and
all
its
shadows
clearing
,
there
was
no
name
for
the
love
I
bore
her
,
<EOS>
dearer
to
me
,
henceforward
,
than
ever
until
then
.
   
<EOS>
I
read
her
letter
many
times
.
 
<EOS>
I
wrote
to
her
before
I
slept
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
her
that
I
had
been
in
sore
need
of
her
help
;
that
without
her
I
was
not
,
and
I
never
had
been
,
what
she
thought
me
;
but
that
she
inspired
me
to
be
that
,
and
I
would
try
.
   
<EOS>
I
did
try
.
 
<EOS>
In
three
months
more
,
a
year
would
have
passed
since
the
beginning
of
my
sorrow
.
 
<EOS>
I
determined
to
make
no
resolutions
until
the
expiration
of
those
three
months
,
but
to
try
.
 
<EOS>
I
lived
in
that
valley
,
and
its
neighbourhood
,
all
the
time
.
   
<EOS>
The
three
months
gone
,
I
resolved
to
remain
away
from
home
for
some
time
longer
;
to
settle
myself
for
the
present
in
Switzerland
,
which
was
growing
dear
to
me
in
the
remembrance
of
that
evening
;
to
resume
my
pen
;
to
work
.
   
<EOS>
I
resorted
humbly
whither
Agnes
had
commended
me
;
I
sought
out
Nature
,
never
sought
in
vain
;
and
I
admitted
to
my
breast
the
human
interest
I
had
lately
shrunk
from
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
long
,
before
I
had
almost
as
many
friends
in
the
valley
as
in
Yarmouth
:
<EOS>
and
when
I
left
it
,
before
the
winter
set
in
,
for
Geneva
,
and
came
back
in
the
spring
,
their
cordial
greetings
had
a
homely
sound
to
me
,
although
they
were
not
conveyed
in
English
words
.
   
<EOS>
I
worked
early
and
late
,
patiently
and
hard
.
 
<EOS>
I
wrote
a
Story
,
with
a
purpose
growing
,
not
remotely
,
out
of
my
experience
,
and
sent
it
to
Traddles
,
and
he
arranged
for
its
publication
very
advantageously
for
me
;
and
the
tidings
of
my
growing
reputation
began
to
reach
me
from
travellers
whom
I
encountered
by
chance
.
<EOS>
After
some
rest
and
change
,
I
fell
to
work
,
in
my
old
ardent
way
,
on
a
new
fancy
,
which
took
strong
possession
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
advanced
in
the
execution
of
this
task
,
I
felt
it
more
and
more
,
and
roused
my
utmost
energies
to
do
it
well
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
my
third
work
of
fiction
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
half
written
,
when
,
in
an
interval
of
rest
,
I
thought
of
returning
home
.
   
<EOS>
For
a
long
time
,
though
studying
and
working
patiently
,
I
had
accustomed
myself
to
robust
exercise
.
 
<EOS>
My
health
,
severely
impaired
when
I
left
England
,
was
quite
restored
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
seen
much
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
been
in
many
countries
,
and
I
hope
I
had
improved
my
store
of
knowledge
.
   
<EOS>
I
have
now
recalled
all
that
I
think
it
needful
to
recall
here
,
of
this
term
of
absence
---
with
one
reservation
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
made
it
,
thus
far
,
with
no
purpose
of
suppressing
any
of
my
thoughts
;
for
,
as
I
have
elsewhere
said
,
this
narrative
is
my
written
memory
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
desired
to
keep
the
most
secret
current
of
my
mind
apart
,
and
to
the
last
.
 
<EOS>
I
enter
on
it
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
so
completely
penetrate
the
mystery
of
my
own
heart
,
as
to
know
when
I
began
to
think
that
I
might
have
set
its
earliest
and
brightest
hopes
on
Agnes
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
at
what
stage
of
my
grief
it
first
became
associated
with
the
reflection
,
that
,
in
my
wayward
boyhood
,
I
had
thrown
away
the
treasure
of
her
love
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
may
have
heard
some
whisper
of
that
distant
thought
,
in
the
old
unhappy
loss
or
want
of
something
never
to
be
realized
,
of
which
I
had
been
sensible
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
thought
came
into
my
mind
as
a
new
reproach
and
new
regret
,
when
I
was
left
so
sad
and
lonely
in
the
world
.
   
<EOS>
If
,
at
that
time
,
I
had
been
much
with
her
,
I
should
,
in
the
weakness
of
my
desolation
,
have
betrayed
this
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
what
I
remotely
dreaded
when
I
was
first
impelled
to
stay
away
from
England
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
have
borne
to
lose
the
smallest
portion
of
her
sisterly
affection
;
yet
,
in
that
betrayal
,
I
should
have
set
a
constraint
between
us
hitherto
unknown
.
   
<EOS>
I
could
not
forget
that
the
feeling
with
which
she
now
regarded
me
had
grown
up
in
my
own
free
choice
and
course
.
 
<EOS>
That
if
she
had
ever
loved
me
with
another
love
---
and
I
sometimes
thought
the
time
was
when
she
might
have
done
so
---
I
had
cast
it
away
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
nothing
,
now
,
that
I
had
accustomed
myself
to
think
of
her
,
when
we
were
both
mere
children
,
as
one
who
was
far
removed
from
my
wild
fancies
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
bestowed
my
passionate
tenderness
upon
another
object
;
and
what
I
might
have
done
,
I
had
not
done
;
and
what
Agnes
was
to
me
,
I
and
her
own
noble
heart
had
made
her
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
beginning
of
the
change
that
gradually
worked
in
me
,
when
I
tried
to
get
a
better
understanding
of
myself
and
be
a
better
man
,
I
did
glance
,
through
some
indefinite
probation
,
to
a
period
when
I
might
possibly
hope
to
cancel
the
mistaken
past
,
and
to
be
so
blessed
as
to
marry
her
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
time
wore
on
,
this
shadowy
prospect
faded
,
and
departed
from
me
.
 
<EOS>
If
she
had
ever
loved
me
,
then
,
I
should
hold
her
the
more
sacred
;
remembering
the
confidences
I
had
reposed
in
her
,
her
knowledge
of
my
errant
heart
,
the
sacrifice
she
must
have
made
to
be
my
friend
and
sister
,
and
the
victory
she
had
won
.
 
<EOS>
If
she
had
never
loved
me
,
could
I
believe
that
she
would
love
me
now
?
   
<EOS>
I
had
always
felt
my
weakness
,
in
comparison
with
her
constancy
and
fortitude
;
and
now
I
felt
it
more
and
more
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
I
might
have
been
to
her
,
or
she
to
me
,
if
I
had
been
more
worthy
of
her
long
ago
,
I
was
not
now
,
and
she
was
not
.
 
<EOS>
The
time
was
past
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
let
it
go
by
,
and
had
deservedly
lost
her
.
   
<EOS>
That
I
suffered
much
in
these
contentions
,
that
they
filled
me
with
unhappiness
and
remorse
,
and
yet
that
I
had
a
sustaining
sense
that
it
was
required
of
me
,
in
right
and
honour
,
to
keep
away
from
myself
,
with
shame
,
the
thought
of
turning
to
the
dear
girl
in
the
withering
of
my
hopes
,
from
whom
I
had
frivolously
turned
when
they
were
bright
and
fresh
---
which
consideration
was
at
the
root
of
every
thought
I
had
concerning
her
---
is
all
equally
true
.
 
<EOS>
I
made
no
effort
to
conceal
from
myself
,
now
,
that
I
loved
her
,
that
I
was
devoted
to
her
;
but
I
brought
the
assurance
home
to
myself
,
that
it
was
now
too
late
,
and
that
our
long
-
subsisting
relation
must
be
undisturbed
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
thought
,
much
and
often
,
of
my
Dora
's
shadowing
out
to
me
what
might
have
happened
,
in
those
years
that
were
destined
not
to
try
us
;
I
had
considered
how
the
things
that
never
happen
,
are
often
as
much
realities
to
us
,
in
their
effects
,
as
those
that
are
accomplished
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
years
she
spoke
of
,
were
realities
now
,
for
my
correction
;
and
would
have
been
,
one
day
,
a
little
later
perhaps
,
though
we
had
parted
in
our
earliest
folly
.
 
<EOS>
I
endeavoured
to
convert
what
might
have
been
between
myself
and
Agnes
,
into
a
means
of
making
me
more
self
-
denying
,
more
resolved
,
more
conscious
of
myself
,
and
my
defects
and
errors
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,
through
the
reflection
that
it
might
have
been
,
I
arrived
at
the
conviction
that
it
could
never
be
.
   
<EOS>
These
,
with
their
perplexities
and
inconsistencies
,
were
the
shifting
quicksands
of
my
mind
,
from
the
time
of
my
departure
to
the
time
of
my
return
home
,
three
years
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
Three
years
had
elapsed
since
the
sailing
of
the
emigrant
ship
;
when
,
at
that
same
hour
of
sunset
,
and
in
the
same
place
,
I
stood
on
the
deck
of
the
packet
vessel
that
brought
me
home
,
looking
on
the
rosy
water
where
I
had
seen
the
image
of
that
ship
reflected
.
   
<EOS>
Three
years
.
 
<EOS>
Long
in
the
aggregate
,
though
short
as
they
went
by
.
<EOS>
And
home
was
very
dear
to
me
,
and
Agnes
too
---
but
she
was
not
mine
---
she
was
never
to
be
mine
.
 
<EOS>
She
might
have
been
,
but
that
was
past
!
      
<EOS>
Chapter
59
.
<EOS>
Return
 
<EOS>
I
landed
in
London
on
a
wintry
autumn
evening
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
dark
and
raining
,
and
I
saw
more
fog
and
mud
in
a
minute
than
I
had
seen
in
a
year
.
 
<EOS>
I
walked
from
the
Custom
House
to
the
Monument
before
I
found
a
coach
;
and
although
the
very
house
-
fronts
,
looking
on
the
swollen
gutters
,
were
like
old
friends
to
me
,
<EOS>
I
could
not
but
admit
that
they
were
very
dingy
friends
.
   
<EOS>
I
have
often
remarked
---
I
suppose
everybody
has
---
that
one
's
going
away
from
a
familiar
place
,
would
seem
to
be
the
signal
for
change
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
looked
out
of
the
coach
window
,
and
observed
that
an
old
house
on
Fish
-
street
Hill
,
which
had
stood
untouched
by
painter
,
carpenter
,
or
bricklayer
,
for
a
century
,
had
been
pulled
down
in
my
absence
;
and
that
a
neighbouring
street
,
of
time
-
honoured
insalubrity
and
inconvenience
,
was
being
drained
and
widened
;
I
half
expected
to
find
St
Paul
's
Cathedral
looking
older
.
   
<EOS>
For
some
changes
in
the
fortunes
of
my
friends
,
I
was
prepared
.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
had
long
been
re
-
established
at
Dover
,
and
Traddles
had
begun
to
get
into
some
little
practice
at
the
Bar
,
in
the
very
first
term
after
my
departure
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
chambers
in
Gray
's
Inn
,
now
;
and
had
told
me
,
in
his
last
letters
,
that
he
was
not
without
hopes
of
being
soon
united
to
the
dearest
girl
in
the
world
.
   
<EOS>
They
expected
me
home
before
Christmas
;
but
had
no
idea
of
my
returning
so
soon
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
purposely
misled
them
,
that
I
might
have
the
pleasure
of
taking
them
by
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
,
I
was
perverse
enough
to
feel
a
chill
and
disappointment
in
receiving
no
welcome
,
and
rattling
,
alone
and
silent
,
through
the
misty
streets
.
   
<EOS>
The
well
-
known
shops
,
however
,
with
their
cheerful
lights
,
did
something
for
me
;
and
when
I
alighted
at
the
door
of
the
Gray
's
Inn
Coffee
-
house
,
I
had
recovered
my
spirits
.
 
<EOS>
It
recalled
,
at
first
,
that
so
-
different
time
when
I
had
put
up
at
the
Golden
Cross
,
and
reminded
me
of
the
changes
that
had
come
to
pass
since
then
;
but
that
was
natural
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
where
Mr
Traddles
lives
in
the
Inn
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
the
waiter
,
as
I
warmed
myself
by
the
coffee
-
room
fire
.
   
<EOS>
"
Holborn
Court
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Number
two
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Traddles
has
a
rising
reputation
among
the
lawyers
,
I
believe
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
returned
the
waiter
,
"
<EOS>
probably
he
has
,
sir
;
but
I
am
not
aware
of
it
myself
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
waiter
,
who
was
middle
-
aged
and
spare
,
looked
for
help
to
a
waiter
of
more
authority
---
a
stout
,
potential
old
man
,
with
a
double
chin
,
in
black
breeches
and
stockings
,
who
came
out
of
a
place
like
a
churchwarden
's
pew
,
at
the
end
of
the
coffee
-
room
,
where
he
kept
company
with
a
cash
-
box
,
a
Directory
,
a
Law
-
list
,
and
other
books
and
papers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Traddles
,
"
said
the
spare
waiter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Number
two
in
the
Court
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
potential
waiter
waved
him
away
,
and
turned
,
gravely
,
to
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
inquiring
,
"
said
I
,
"
whether
Mr
Traddles
,
at
number
two
in
the
Court
,
has
not
a
rising
reputation
among
the
lawyers
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
heard
his
name
,
"
said
the
waiter
,
in
a
rich
husky
voice
.
   
<EOS>
I
felt
quite
apologetic
for
Traddles
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
young
man
,
sure
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
portentous
waiter
,
fixing
his
eyes
severely
on
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
long
has
he
been
in
the
Inn
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
above
three
years
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
The
waiter
,
who
I
supposed
had
lived
in
his
churchwarden
's
pew
for
forty
years
,
could
not
pursue
such
an
insignificant
subject
.
 
<EOS>
He
asked
me
what
I
would
have
for
dinner
?
   
<EOS>
I
felt
I
was
in
England
again
,
and
really
was
quite
cast
down
on
Traddles
's
account
.
 
<EOS>
There
seemed
to
be
no
hope
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
meekly
ordered
a
bit
of
fish
and
a
steak
,
and
stood
before
the
fire
musing
on
his
obscurity
.
   
<EOS>
As
I
followed
the
chief
waiter
with
my
eyes
,
I
could
not
help
thinking
that
the
garden
in
which
he
had
gradually
blown
to
be
the
flower
he
was
,
was
an
arduous
place
to
rise
in
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
such
a
prescriptive
,
stiff
-
necked
,
long
-
established
,
solemn
,
elderly
air
.
<EOS>
I
glanced
about
the
room
,
which
had
had
its
sanded
floor
sanded
,
no
doubt
,
in
exactly
the
same
manner
when
the
chief
waiter
was
a
boy
---
if
he
ever
was
a
boy
,
which
appeared
improbable
;
and
at
the
shining
tables
,
where
I
saw
myself
reflected
,
in
unruffled
depths
of
old
mahogany
;
and
at
the
lamps
,
without
a
flaw
in
their
trimming
or
cleaning
;
and
at
the
comfortable
green
curtains
,
with
their
pure
brass
rods
,
snugly
enclosing
the
boxes
;
and
at
the
two
large
coal
fires
,
brightly
burning
;
and
at
the
rows
of
decanters
,
burly
as
if
with
the
consciousness
of
pipes
of
expensive
old
port
wine
below
;
and
both
England
,
and
the
law
,
appeared
to
me
to
be
very
difficult
indeed
to
be
taken
by
storm
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
up
to
my
bedroom
to
change
my
wet
clothes
;
and
the
vast
extent
of
that
old
wainscoted
apartment
(
which
was
over
the
archway
leading
to
the
Inn
,
I
remember
)
,
and
the
sedate
immensity
of
the
four
-
post
bedstead
,
and
the
indomitable
gravity
of
the
chests
of
drawers
,
all
seemed
to
unite
in
sternly
frowning
on
the
fortunes
of
Traddles
,
or
on
any
such
daring
youth
.
<EOS>
I
came
down
again
to
my
dinner
;
and
even
the
slow
comfort
of
the
meal
,
and
the
orderly
silence
of
the
place
---
which
was
bare
of
guests
,
the
Long
Vacation
not
yet
being
over
---
were
eloquent
on
the
audacity
of
Traddles
,
and
his
small
hopes
of
a
livelihood
for
twenty
years
to
come
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
seen
nothing
like
this
since
I
went
away
,
and
it
quite
dashed
my
hopes
for
my
friend
.
 
<EOS>
The
chief
waiter
had
had
enough
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
came
near
me
no
more
;
but
devoted
himself
to
an
old
gentleman
in
long
gaiters
,
to
meet
whom
a
pint
of
special
port
seemed
to
come
out
of
the
cellar
of
its
own
accord
,
for
he
gave
no
order
.
 
<EOS>
The
second
waiter
informed
me
,
in
a
whisper
,
that
this
old
gentleman
was
a
retired
conveyancer
living
in
the
Square
,
and
worth
a
mint
of
money
,
which
it
was
expected
he
would
leave
to
his
laundress
's
daughter
;
likewise
that
it
was
rumoured
that
he
had
a
service
of
plate
in
a
bureau
,
all
tarnished
with
lying
by
,
though
more
than
one
spoon
and
a
fork
had
never
yet
been
beheld
in
his
chambers
by
mortal
vision
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
I
quite
gave
Traddles
up
for
lost
;
and
settled
in
my
own
mind
that
there
was
no
hope
for
him
.
   
<EOS>
Being
very
anxious
to
see
the
dear
old
fellow
,
nevertheless
,
I
dispatched
my
dinner
,
in
a
manner
not
at
all
calculated
to
raise
me
in
the
opinion
of
the
chief
waiter
,
and
hurried
out
by
the
back
way
.
 
<EOS>
Number
two
in
the
Court
was
soon
reached
;
and
an
inscription
on
the
door
-
post
informing
me
that
Mr
Traddles
occupied
a
set
of
chambers
on
the
top
storey
<EOS>
,
I
ascended
the
staircase
.
 
<EOS>
A
crazy
old
staircase
<EOS>
I
found
it
to
be
,
feebly
lighted
on
each
landing
by
a
club
-
headed
little
oil
wick
,
dying
away
in
a
little
dungeon
of
dirty
glass
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
my
stumbling
upstairs
,
I
fancied
I
heard
a
pleasant
sound
of
laughter
;
and
not
the
laughter
of
an
attorney
or
barrister
,
or
attorney
's
clerk
or
barrister
's
clerk
,
but
of
two
or
three
merry
girls
.
 
<EOS>
Happening
,
however
,
as
I
stopped
to
listen
,
to
put
my
foot
in
a
hole
where
the
Honourable
Society
of
Gray
's
Inn
had
left
a
plank
deficient
,
I
fell
down
with
some
noise
,
and
when
I
recovered
my
footing
all
was
silent
.
   
<EOS>
Groping
my
way
more
carefully
,
for
the
rest
of
the
journey
,
my
heart
beat
high
when
I
found
the
outer
door
,
which
had
Mr
TRADDLES
painted
on
it
,
open
.
 
<EOS>
I
knocked
.
 
<EOS>
A
considerable
scuffling
within
ensued
,
but
nothing
else
.
 
<EOS>
I
therefore
knocked
again
.
   
<EOS>
A
small
sharp
-
looking
lad
,
half
-
footboy
and
half
-
clerk
,
who
was
very
much
out
of
breath
,
but
who
looked
at
me
as
if
he
defied
me
to
prove
it
legally
,
presented
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Mr
Traddles
within
?
<EOS>
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
sir
,
but
he
's
engaged
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
see
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
After
a
moment
's
survey
of
me
,
the
sharp
-
looking
lad
decided
to
let
me
in
;
and
opening
the
door
wider
for
that
purpose
,
admitted
me
,
first
,
into
a
little
closet
of
a
hall
,
and
next
into
a
little
sitting
-
room
;
where
I
came
into
the
presence
of
my
old
friend
(
also
out
of
breath
)
,
seated
at
a
table
,
and
bending
over
papers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
God
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Traddles
,
looking
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
Copperfield
!
"
and
rushed
into
my
arms
,
where
I
held
him
tight
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
All
well
,
my
dear
Traddles
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
All
well
,
my
dear
,
dear
Copperfield
,
and
nothing
but
good
news
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
We
cried
with
pleasure
,
both
of
us
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
fellow
,
"
said
Traddles
,
rumpling
his
hair
in
his
excitement
,
which
was
a
most
unnecessary
operation
,
"
my
dearest
Copperfield
,
my
long
-
lost
and
most
welcome
friend
,
how
glad
I
am
to
see
you
!
<EOS>
How
brown
you
are
!
<EOS>
How
glad
I
am
!
<EOS>
Upon
my
life
and
honour
,
I
never
was
so
rejoiced
,
my
beloved
Copperfield
,
never
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
equally
at
a
loss
to
express
my
emotions
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
quite
unable
to
speak
,
at
first
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
fellow
!
"
said
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
grown
so
famous
!
<EOS>
My
glorious
Copperfield
!
<EOS>
Good
gracious
me
,
WHEN
did
you
come
,
WHERE
have
you
come
from
,
WHAT
have
you
been
doing
?
"
   
<EOS>
Never
pausing
for
an
answer
to
anything
he
said
,
Traddles
,
who
had
clapped
me
into
an
easy
-
chair
by
the
fire
,
all
this
time
impetuously
stirred
the
fire
with
one
hand
,
and
pulled
at
my
neck
-
kerchief
with
the
other
,
under
some
wild
delusion
that
it
was
a
great
-
coat
.
 
<EOS>
Without
putting
down
the
poker
,
he
now
hugged
me
again
;
and
I
hugged
him
;
and
,
both
laughing
,
and
both
wiping
our
eyes
,
we
both
sat
down
,
and
shook
hands
across
the
hearth
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
think
,
"
said
Traddles
,
"
that
you
should
have
been
so
nearly
coming
home
as
you
must
have
been
,
my
dear
old
boy
,
and
not
at
the
ceremony
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
ceremony
,
my
dear
Traddles
?
"
   
"
Good
gracious
me
!
"
cried
Traddles
,
opening
his
eyes
in
his
old
way
.
 
<EOS>
"
Did
n't
you
get
my
last
letter
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
not
,
if
it
referred
to
any
ceremony
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
dear
Copperfield
,
"
said
Traddles
,
sticking
his
hair
upright
with
both
hands
,
and
then
putting
his
hands
on
my
knees
,
"
I
am
married
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Married
!
<EOS>
"
I
cried
joyfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
bless
me
,
yes
,
!
"
<EOS>
said
Traddles
---
"
by
the
Reverend
Horace
---
to
Sophy
---
down
in
Devonshire
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
my
dear
boy
,
she
's
behind
the
window
curtain
!
<EOS>
Look
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
To
my
amazement
,
the
dearest
girl
in
the
world
came
at
that
same
instant
,
laughing
and
blushing
,
from
her
place
of
concealment
.
 
<EOS>
And
a
more
cheerful
,
amiable
,
honest
,
happy
,
bright
-
looking
bride
<EOS>
,
I
believe
(
as
I
could
not
help
saying
on
the
spot
)
<EOS>
the
world
never
saw
.
 
<EOS>
I
kissed
her
as
an
old
acquaintance
<EOS>
should
,
and
wished
them
joy
with
all
my
might
of
heart
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
"
said
Traddles
,
"
what
a
delightful
re
-
union
this
is
!
<EOS>
You
are
so
extremely
brown
,
<EOS>
my
dear
Copperfield
!
<EOS>
God
bless
my
soul
,
how
happy
I
am
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
am
I
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
am
sure
I
am
!
"
said
the
blushing
and
laughing
Sophy
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
all
as
happy
as
possible
!
"
said
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Even
the
girls
are
happy
.
 
<EOS>
Dear
me
,
I
declare
I
forgot
them
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Forgot
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
The
girls
,
"
said
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sophy
's
sisters
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
staying
with
us
.
 
<EOS>
They
have
come
to
have
a
peep
at
London
.
 
<EOS>
The
fact
is
,
when
---
was
it
you
that
tumbled
upstairs
,
Copperfield
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
,
"
said
I
,
laughing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
then
,
when
you
tumbled
upstairs
,
"
said
Traddles
,
"
I
was
romping
with
the
girls
.
 
<EOS>
In
point
of
fact
,
we
were
playing
at
Puss
in
the
Corner
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
that
would
n't
do
in
Westminster
Hall

<EOS>
Mrs

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
If

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
If

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
But
their
self

.
 
<EOS>
Their

these

,
and
their

all

,
was

own
worth
I

.
 
<EOS>
If

"

"
,

;

,
or
carry
something
there
,
or
take
something
up
,
or
put
something
down
,
or
find
something
,
or
fetch
something
,
he
was
so
addressed
,
by
one
or
other
of
his
sisters
-
in
-
law
,
at
least
twelve
times
in
an
hour
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
could
they
do
anything
without
Sophy
.
 
<EOS>
Somebody
's
hair
fell
down
,
and
nobody
but
Sophy
could
put
it
up
.
 
<EOS>
Somebody
forgot
how
a
particular
tune
went
,
and
nobody
but
Sophy
could
hum
that
tune
right
.
 
<EOS>
Somebody
wanted
to
recall
the
name
of
a
place
in
Devonshire
,
and
only
Sophy
knew
it
.
 
<EOS>
Something
was
wanted
to
be
written
home
,
and
Sophy
alone
could
be
trusted
to
write
before
breakfast
in
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Somebody
broke
down
in
a
piece
of
knitting
,
and
no
one
but
Sophy
was
able
to
put
the
defaulter
in
the
right
direction
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
entire
mistresses
of
the
place
,
and
Sophy
and
Traddles
waited
on
them
.
 
<EOS>
How
many
children
Sophy
could
have
taken
care
of
in
her
time
,
I
ca
n't
imagine
;
but
she
seemed
to
be
famous
for
knowing
every
sort
of
song
that
ever
was
addressed
to
a
child
in
the
English
tongue
;
and
she
sang
dozens
to
order
with
the
clearest
little
voice
in
the
world
,
one
after
another
(
every
sister
issuing
directions
for
a
different
tune
,
and
the
Beauty
generally
striking
in
last
)
,
so
that
I
was
quite
fascinated
.
 
<EOS>
The
best
of
all
was
,
that
,
in
the
midst
of
their
exactions
,
all
the
sisters
had
a
great
tenderness
and
respect
both
for
Sophy
and
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
,
when
I
took
my
leave
,
and
Traddles
was
coming
out
to
walk
with
me
to
the
coffee
-
house
<EOS>
,
I
thought
I
had
never
seen
an
obstinate
head
of
hair
,
or
any
other
head
of
hair
,
rolling
about
in
such
a
shower
of
kisses
.
   
<EOS>
Altogether
,
it
was
a
scene
I
could
not
help
dwelling
on
with
pleasure
,
for
a
long
time
after
I
got
back
and
had
wished
Traddles
good
night
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
beheld
a
thousand
roses
blowing
in
a
top
set
of
chambers
,
in
that
withered
Gray
's
Inn
,
they
could
not
have
brightened
it
half
so
much
.
 
<EOS>
The
idea
of
those
Devonshire
girls
,
among
the
dry
law
-
stationers
and
the
attorneys
'
offices
;
and
of
the
tea
and
toast
,
and
children
's
songs
,
in
that
grim
atmosphere
of
pounce
and
parchment
,
red
-
tape
,
dusty
wafers
,
ink
-
jars
,
brief
and
draft
paper
,
law
reports
,
writs
,
declarations
,
and
bills
of
costs
;
seemed
almost
as
pleasantly
fanciful
as
if
I
had
dreamed
that
the
Sultan
's
famous
family
had
been
admitted
on
the
roll
of
attorneys
,
and
had
brought
the
talking
bird
,
the
singing
tree
,
and
the
golden
water
into
Gray
's
Inn
Hall
.
 
<EOS>
Somehow
,
I
found
that
I
had
taken
leave
of
Traddles
for
the
night
,
and
come
back
to
the
coffee
-
house
,
with
a
great
change
in
my
despondency
about
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
began
to
think
he
would
get
on
,
in
spite
of
all
the
many
orders
of
chief
waiters
in
England
.
   
<EOS>
Drawing
a
chair
before
one
of
the
coffee
-
room
fires
to
think
about
him
at
my
leisure
,
I
gradually
fell
from
the
consideration
of
his
happiness
to
tracing
prospects
in
the
live
-
coals
,
and
to
thinking
,
as
they
broke
and
changed
,
of
the
principal
vicissitudes
and
separations
that
had
marked
my
life
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
not
seen
a
coal
fire
,
since
I
had
left
England
three
years
ago
:
though
many
a
wood
fire
had
I
watched
,
as
it
crumbled
into
hoary
ashes
,
and
mingled
with
the
feathery
heap
upon
the
hearth
,
which
not
inaptly
figured
to
me
,
in
my
despondency
,
my
own
dead
hopes
.
   
<EOS>
I
could
think
of
the
past
now
,
gravely
,
but
not
bitterly
;
and
could
contemplate
the
future
in
a
brave
spirit
.
 
<EOS>
Home
,
in
its
best
sense
,
was
for
me
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
She
in
whom
I
might
have
inspired
a
dearer
love
<EOS>
,
I
had
taught
to
be
my
sister
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
marry
,
and
would
have
new
claimants
on
her
tenderness
;
and
in
doing
it
,
would
never
know
the
love
for
her
that
had
grown
up
in
my
heart
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
right
that
I
should
pay
the
forfeit
of
my
headlong
passion
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
reaped
,
I
had
sown
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
thinking
.
 
<EOS>
And
had
I
truly
disciplined
my
heart
to
this
,
and
could
I
resolutely
bear
it
,
and
calmly
hold
the
place
in
her
home
which
she
had
calmly
held
in
mine
,
---
when
I
found
my
eyes
resting
on
a
countenance
that
might
have
arisen
out
of
the
fire
,
in
its
association
with
my
early
remembrances
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Mr
Chillip
the
Doctor
,
to
whose
good
offices
<EOS>
I
was
indebted
in
the
very
first
chapter
of
this
history
,
sat
reading
a
newspaper
in
the
shadow
of
an
opposite
corner
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
tolerably
stricken
in
years
by
this
time
;
but
,
being
a
mild
,
meek
,
calm
little
man
,
had
worn
so
easily
,
<EOS>
that
I
thought
he
looked
at
that
moment
just
as
he
might
have
looked
when
he
sat
in
our
parlour
,
waiting
for
me
to
be
born
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chillip
had
left
Blunderstone
six
or
seven
years
ago
,
and
I
had
never
seen
him
since
.
 
<EOS>
He
sat
placidly
perusing
the
newspaper
,
with
his
little
head
on
one
side
,
and
a
glass
of
warm
sherry
negus
at
his
elbow
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
so
extremely
conciliatory
in
his
manner
that
he
seemed
to
apologize
to
the
very
newspaper
for
taking
the
liberty
of
reading
it
.
   
<EOS>
I
walked
up
to
where
he
was
sitting
,
and
said
,
"
How
do
you
do
,
Mr
Chillip
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
greatly
fluttered
by
this
unexpected
address
from
a
stranger
,
and
replied
,
in
his
slow
way
,
"
I
thank
you
,
sir
,
you
are
very
good
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
YOU
are
well
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
remember
me
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mr
Chillip
,
smiling
very
meekly
,
and
shaking
his
head
as
he
surveyed
me
,
"
I
have
a
kind
of
an
impression
that
something
in
your
countenance
is
familiar
to
me
,
sir
;
but
I
could
n't
lay
my
hand
upon
your
name
,
really
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
yet
you
knew
it
,
long
before
I
knew
it
myself
,
"
I
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Did
I
indeed
,
sir
?
"
said
Mr
Chillip
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
it
possible
that
I
had
the
honour
,
sir
,
of
officiating
when
---
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
cried
Mr
Chillip
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
no
doubt
you
are
a
good
deal
changed
since
then
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Probably
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
observed
Mr
Chillip
,
"
<EOS>
I
hope
you
'll
excuse
me
,
if
I
am
compelled
to
ask
the
favour
of
your
name
?
"
   
<EOS>
On
my
telling
him
my
name
,
he
was
really
moved
.
 
<EOS>
He
quite
shook
hands
with
me
---
which
was
a
violent
proceeding
for
him
,
his
usual
course
being
to
slide
a
tepid
little
fish
-
slice
,
an
inch
or
two
in
advance
of
his
hip
,
and
evince
the
greatest
discomposure
when
anybody
grappled
with

.
 
<EOS>
Even
now
,
he
put
his
hand
in

coat

pocket
as
soon
as
he
could
disengage
it
,
and
seemed
relieved
when
he
had
got
it
safe

.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
sir
!
"
said
Mr
Chillip
,
surveying
me
with
his
head
on
one
side
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
it
's
Mr
Copperfield
,
is

?
 
<EOS>
Well
,

,
I
think
I
should
have

,

.
 
<EOS>
There
's
a
strong
resemblance
between
you
and
your
poor

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
had
the

seeing

father
,
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,

,
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
And
very
much
to

it

,

!
<EOS>
We

,

,
"

,

,
"
down

,

.
 
<EOS>
There

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

your

the

?
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

established

of
Bury
St
Edmund
's
,

,
"

Chillip
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Chillip
,

,
under
her

's

,
I
bought

,

.
 
<EOS>
My
daughter
is
growing

,

,
"
said
Mr
Chillip
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Her
mother
let
down
two
tucks
in

.
 
<EOS>
Such
is
time
,
you

,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
As

little
man
put
his
now

,
when

,
I
proposed

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"
he

,
in

,
"
it
's
more

I

;
but
I
ca

.
 
<EOS>
It

but

that

in

.
 
<EOS>
You
came
through

charmingly
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
I
acknowledged
this

,
and
ordered

negus
,

was

.
 
<EOS>
"
Quite
an
uncommon
dissipation
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Chillip
,
stirring

,
"
but
I
ca
n't
resist
so
extraordinary

.
 
<EOS>
You
have
no

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

-

.
<EOS>
Very

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Where

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No

"

<EOS>
"
He

,

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Married

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
---

,

?
 
<EOS>
Do

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
Do

?
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Strong

of

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

,

,

"
<EOS>
Ah

!
<EOS>
We

,

<EOS>
"

,

?
"

<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"

,
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

:

.

<EOS>
"

,

"
I

"

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
She

,

!
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

Mrs

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A

,

,
"

;
"
as

,

!
<EOS>
Mrs
Chillip
's
opinion

,
that
her

since
her

,
and

she

all

<EOS>
And

,
"

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

"
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
,

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

Chapter

.
<EOS>
Agnes
 
<EOS>
My

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
They

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
right
to
speak
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
it
should
be
so
,
"
I
repeated
,
"
Agnes
will
tell
me
at
her
own
good
time
.
 
<EOS>
A
sister
to
whom
I
have
confided
so
much
,
aunt
,
will
not
be
reluctant
to
confide
in
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
withdrew
her
eyes
from
mine
,
as
slowly
as
she
had
turned
them
upon
me
;
and
covered
them
thoughtfully
with
her
hand
.
 
<EOS>
By
and
by
<EOS>
she
put
her
other
hand
on
my
shoulder
;
and
so
we
both
sat
,
looking
into
the
past
,
without
saying
another
word
,
until
we
parted
for
the
night
.
   
<EOS>
I
rode
away
,
early
in
the
morning
,
for
the
scene
of
my
old
school
-
days
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
that
I
was
yet
quite
happy
,
in
the
hope
that
I
was
gaining
a
victory
over
myself
;
even
in
the
prospect
of
so
soon
looking
on
her
face
again
.
   
<EOS>
The
well
-
remembered
ground
was
soon
traversed
,
and
I
came
into
the
quiet
streets
,
where
every
stone
was
a
boy
's
book
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
on
foot
to
the
old
house
,
and
went
away
with
a
heart
too
full
to
enter
.
 
<EOS>
I
returned
;
and
looking
,
as
I
passed
,
through
the
low
window
of
the
turret
-
room
where
first
Uriah
Heep
,
and
afterwards
Mr
Micawber
,
had
been
wo
nt
to
sit
,
saw
that
it
was
a
little
parlour
now
,
and
that
there
was
no
office
.
 
<EOS>
Otherwise
the
staid
old
house
was
,
as
to
its
cleanliness
and
order
,
still
just
as
it
had
been
when
I
first
saw
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
requested
the
new
maid
who
admitted
me
,
to
tell
Miss
Wickfield
that
a
gentleman
who
waited
on
her
from
a
friend
abroad
,
was
there
;
and
I
was
shown
up
the
grave
old
staircase
<EOS>
(
cautioned
of
the
steps
I
knew
so
well
)
,
into
the
unchanged
drawing
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
The
books
that
Agnes
and
I
had
read
together
,
were
on
their
shelves
;
and
the
desk
where
I
had
laboured
at
my
lessons
,
many
a
night
,
stood
yet
at
the
same
old
corner
of
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
little
changes
that
had
crept
in
when
the
Heeps
were
there
,
were
changed
again
.
 
<EOS>
Everything
was
as
it
used
to
be
,
in
the
happy
time
.
   
<EOS>
I
stood
in
a
window
,
and
looked
across
the
ancient
street
at
the
opposite
houses
,
recalling
how
I
had
watched
them
on
wet
afternoons
,
when
I
first
came
there
;
and
how
I
had
used
to
speculate
about
the
people
who
appeared
at
any
of
the
windows
,
and
had
followed
them
with
my
eyes
up
and
down
stairs
,
while
women
went
clicking
along
the
pavement
in
pattens
,
and
the
dull
rain
fell
in
slanting
lines
,
and
poured
out
of
the
water
-
spout
yonder
,
and
flowed
into
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
The
feeling
with
which
I
used
to
watch
the
tramps
,
as
they
came
into
the
town
on
those
wet
evenings
,
at
dusk
,
and
limped
past
,
with
their
bundles
drooping
over
their
shoulders
at
the
ends
of
sticks
,
came
freshly
back
to
me
;
fraught
,
as
then
,
with
the
smell
of
damp
earth
,
and
wet
leaves
and
briar
,
and
the
sensation
of
the
very
airs
that
blew
upon
me
in
my
own
toilsome
journey
.
   
<EOS>
The
opening
of
the
little
door
in
the
panelled
wall
made
me
start
and
turn
.
 
<EOS>
Her
beautiful
serene
eyes
met
mine
as
she
came
towards
me
.
 
<EOS>
She
stopped
and
laid
her
hand
upon
her
bosom
,
and
I
caught
her
in
my
arms
.
   
<EOS>
"
Agnes
!
<EOS>
my
dear
girl
!
<EOS>
I
have
come
too
suddenly
upon
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
!
<EOS>
I
am
so
rejoiced
to
see
you
,
Trotwood
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
Agnes
,
the
happiness
<EOS>
it
is
to
me
,
to
see
you
once
again
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
folded
her
to
my
heart
,
and
,
for
a
little
while
,
we
were
both
silent
.
 
<EOS>
Presently
we
sat
down
,
side
by
side
;
and
her
angel
-
face
was
turned
upon
me
with
the
welcome
I
had
dreamed
of
,
waking
and
sleeping
,
for
whole
years
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
so
true
,
she
was
so
beautiful
<EOS>
,
she
was
so
good
,
---
I
owed
her
so
much
gratitude
,
she
was
so
dear
to
me
,
that
I
could
find
no
utterance
for
what
I
felt
.
 
<EOS>
I
tried
to
bless
her
,
tried
to
thank
her
,
tried
to
tell
her
(
as
I
had
often
done
in
letters
)
<EOS>
what
an
influence
she
had
upon
me
;
but
all
my
efforts
were
in
vain
.
 
<EOS>
My
love
and
joy
were
dumb
.
   
<EOS>
With
her
own
sweet
tranquillity
,
she
calmed
my
agitation
;
led
me
back
to
the
time
of
our
parting
;
spoke
to
me
of
Emily
,
whom
she
had
visited
,
in
secret
,
many
times
;
spoke
to
me
tenderly
of
Dora
's
grave
.
 
<EOS>
With
the
unerring
instinct
of
her
noble
heart
,
she
touched
the
chords
of
my
memory
so
softly
and
harmoniously
,
that
not
one
jarred
within
me
;
I
could
listen
to
the
sorrowful
,
distant
music
,
and
desire
to
shrink
from
nothing
it
awoke
.
 
<EOS>
How
could
I
,
when
,
blended
with
it
all
,
was
her
dear
self
,
the
better
angel
of
my
life
?
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
you
,
Agnes
,
"
I
said
,
by
and
by
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
of
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
hardly
ever
told
me
of
your
own
life
,
in
all
this
lapse
of
time
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
should
I
tell
?
"
<EOS>
she
answered
,
with
her
radiant
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
Papa
is
well
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
us
here
,
quiet
in
our
own
home
;
our
anxieties
set
at
rest
,
our
home
restored
to
us
;
and
knowing
that
,
dear
Trotwood
,
you
know
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
,
Agnes
?
"
said
I.
   
She
looked
at
me
,
with
some
fluttering
wonder
in
her
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
there
nothing
else
,
Sister
?
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
Her
colour
,
which
had
just
now
faded
,
returned
,
and
faded
again
.
<EOS>
She
smiled
;
with
a
quiet
sadness
,
I
thought
;
and
shook
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
sought
to
lead
her
to
what
my
aunt
had
hinted
at
;
for
,
sharply
painful
to
me
as
it
must
be
to
receive
that
confidence
,
I
was
to
discipline
my
heart
,
and
do
my
duty
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
,
however
,
that
she
was
uneasy
,
and
I
let
it
pass
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
much
to
do
,
dear
Agnes
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
my
school
?
"
said
she
,
looking
up
again
,
in
all
her
bright
composure
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
laborious
,
is
it
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
labour
is
so
pleasant
,
"
she
returned
,
"
that
it
is
scarcely
grateful
in
me
to
call
it
by
that
name
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
good
is
difficult
to
you
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
Her
colour
came
and
went
once
more
;
and
once
more
,
as
she
bent
her
head
<EOS>
,
I
saw
the
same
sad
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
wait
and
see
papa
,
"
said
Agnes
,
cheerfully
,
"
and
pass
the
day
with
us
?
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
will
sleep
in
your
own
room
?
 
<EOS>
We
always
call
it
yours
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
not
do
that
,
having
promised
to
ride
back
to
my
aunt
's
at
night
;
but
I
would
pass
the
day
there
,
joyfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
be
a
prisoner
for
a
little
while
,
"
said
Agnes
,
"
but
here
are
the
old
books
,
Trotwood
,
and
the
old
music
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Even
the
old
flowers
are
here
,
"
said
I
,
looking
round
;
"
or
the
old
kinds
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
found
a
pleasure
,
"
returned
Agnes
,
smiling
,
"
while
you
have
been
absent
,
in
keeping
everything
as
it
used
to
be
when
we
were
children
.
 
<EOS>
For
we
were
very
happy
then
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Heaven
knows
we
were
!
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
And
every
little
thing
that
has
reminded
me
of
my
brother
,
"
said
Agnes
,
with
her
cordial
eyes
turned
cheerfully
upon
me
,
"
has
been
a
welcome
companion
.
 
<EOS>
Even
this
,
"
showing
me
the
basket
-
trifle
,
full
of
keys
,
still
hanging
at
her
side
,
"
seems
to
jingle
a
kind
of
old
tune
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
smiled
again
,
and
went
out
at
the
door
by
which
she
had
come
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
for
me
to
guard
this
sisterly
affection
with
religious
care
.
<EOS>
It
was
all
that
I
had
left
myself
,
and
it
was
a
treasure
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
once
shook
the
foundations
of
the
sacred
confidence
and
usage
,
in
virtue
of
which
<EOS>
it
was
given
to
me
,
it
was
lost
,
and
could
never
be
recovered
.
 
<EOS>
I
set
this
steadily
before
myself
.
 
<EOS>
The
better
I
loved
her
,
the
more
it
behoved
me
never
to
forget
it
.
   
<EOS>
I
walked
through
the
streets
;
and
,
once
more
seeing
my
old
adversary
<EOS>
the
butcher
---
now
a
constable
,
with
his
staff
hanging
up
in
the
shop
---
went
down
to
look
at
the
place
where
I
had
fought
him
;
and
there
meditated
on
Miss
Shepherd
and
the
eldest
Miss
Larkins
,
and
all
the
idle
loves
and
likings
,
and
dislikings
,
of
that
time
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
seemed
to
have
survived
that
time
but
Agnes
;
and
she
,
ever
a
star
above
me
,
was
brighter
and
higher
.
   
<EOS>
When
I
returned
,
Mr
Wickfield
had
come
home
,
from
a
garden
he
had
,
a
couple
of
miles
or
so
out
of
town
,
where
he
now
employed
himself
almost
every
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
him
as
my
aunt
had
described
him
.
 
<EOS>
We
sat
down
to
dinner
,
with
some
half
-
dozen
little
girls
;
and
he
seemed
but
the
shadow
of
his
handsome
picture
on
the
wall
.
   
<EOS>
The
tranquillity
and
peace
belonging
,
of
old
,
to
that
quiet
ground
in
my
memory
,
pervaded
it
again
.
 
<EOS>
When
dinner
was
done
,
Mr
Wickfield
taking
no
wine
,
and
I
desiring
none
,
we
went
up
-
stairs
;
where
Agnes
and
her
little
charges
sang
and
played
,
and
worked
.
<EOS>
After
tea
the
children
left
us
;
and
we
three
sat
together
,
talking
of
the
bygone
days
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
part
in
them
,
"
said
Mr
Wickfield
,
shaking
his
white
head
,
"
has
much
matter
for
regret
---
for
deep
regret
,
and
deep
contrition
,
Trotwood
,
you
well
know
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
would
not
cancel
it
,
if
it
were
in
my
power
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
readily
believe
that
,
looking
at
the
face
beside
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
cancel
with
it
,
"
he
pursued
,
"
such
patience
and
devotion
,
such
fidelity
,
such
a
child
's
love
,
as
I
must
not
forget
,
no
!
<EOS>
even
to
forget
myself
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
understand
you
,
sir
,
"
I
softly
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hold
it
---
I
have
always
held
it
---
in
veneration
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
no
one
knows
,
not
even
you
,
<EOS>
"
he
returned
,
"
how
much
she
has
done
,
how
much
she
has
undergone
,
how
hard
she
has
striven
.
 
<EOS>
Dear
Agnes
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
She
had
put
her
hand
entreatingly
on
his
arm
,
to
stop
him
;
and
was
very
,
very
pale
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
with
a
sigh
,
dismissing
,
as
I
then
saw
,
some
trial
she
had
borne
,
or
was
yet
to
bear
,
in
connexion
with
what
my
aunt
had
told
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
!
I
have
never
told
you
,
Trotwood
,
of
her
mother
.
 
<EOS>
Has
anyone
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
much
---
though
it
was
much
to
suffer
.
 
<EOS>
She
married
me
in
opposition
to
her
father
's
wish
,
and
he
renounced
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
prayed
him
to
forgive
her
,
before
my
Agnes
came
into
this
world
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
very
hard
man
,
and
her
mother
had
long
been
dead
.
 
<EOS>
He
repulsed
her
.
 
<EOS>
He
broke
her
heart
.
"
   
<EOS>
Agnes
leaned
upon
his
shoulder
,
and
stole
her
arm
about
his
neck
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
had
an
affectionate
and
gentle
heart
,
"
he
said
;
"
and
it
was
broken
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
its
tender
nature
very
well
.
 
<EOS>
No
one
could
,
if
I
did
not
.
 
<EOS>
She
loved
me
dearly
,
but
was
never
happy
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
always
labouring
,
in
secret
,
under
this
distress
;
and
being
delicate
and
downcast
at
the
time
of
his
last
repulse
---
for
it
was
not
the
first
,
by
many
---
<EOS>
pined
away
and
died
.
 
<EOS>
She
left
me
Agnes
,
two
weeks
old
;
and
the
grey
hair
that
you
recollect
me

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
61
.
<EOS>
I
am
shown
two
interesting
penitents
 
<EOS>
For

---
at
all
events
until
my

,
which

---
I
took

;
and
there
,

,

that

,
I

.
   
<EOS>
In
pursuance
of
my
intention
of
referring
to
my
own

only
when
their

incidentally

,
I
do
not
enter
on

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
That
I
truly

myself
to
it
with
my
strongest

,
and
bestowed
upon
it
every
energy
of
my
soul
<EOS>
,
I
have
already
said
.
 
<EOS>
If

books
I
have
written
be

any

,
they
will

rest
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
otherwise
have
written
to
poor

,
and
the
rest
will
be
of
interest
to
no

.
   
<EOS>
Occasionally
,
I
went
to
London
;
to

in

life

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
managed
for
me
,
in
my

,
with
the
soundest

;
and
my
worldly

were

.
 
<EOS>
As

,

I

.
 
<EOS>
There
,

devoted

;
and
there
,

,
I
laboured

,
like
a

State
without

.
   
<EOS>
Among

,

always

,

(

)
,

.
 
<EOS>
But

;
being

,
and

the
Commons
quite
bad

,

my

<EOS>
The

had

,
when
my

's

;

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>

(

)

?
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

"
It

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

Traddles

's

;

---

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
My

,

,

"

,

<EOS>

"

!
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

,
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
I
positively
sometimes
ca
n't

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
our

!
<EOS>
Dear

,

,

!
<EOS>
When

,

,

,

---

---

?
 
<EOS>
When

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

grounds
<EOS>
,
I

;

Sophy

which
of

that
are

and
jewelled
and
engine
-
turned
,
and
possessed
of
the
horizontal
lever
-
escape
-
movement
,
and
all
sorts
of
things
,
she
would
buy
for
me
if
she
could
afford
it
;
and
we
pick
out
the
spoons
and
forks
,
fish
-
slices
,
butter
-
knives
,
and
sugar
-
tongs
,
we
should
both
prefer
if
we
could
both
afford
it
;
and
really
we
go
away
as
if
we
had
got
them
!
<EOS>
Then
,
when
we
stroll
into
the
squares
,
and
great
streets
,
and
see
a
house
to
let
,
sometimes
we
look
up
at
it
,
and
say
,
how
would
THAT
do
,
if
I
was
made
a
judge
?
 
<EOS>
And
we
parcel
it
out
---
<EOS>
such
a
room
for
us
,
such
rooms
for
the
girls
,
and
so
forth
;
until
we
settle
to
our
satisfaction
that
it
would
do
,
or
it
would
n't
do
,
as
the
case
may
be
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
we
go
at
half
-
price
to
the
pit
of
the
theatre
---
<EOS>
the
very
smell
of
which
is
cheap
,
in
my
opinion
,
at
the
money
---
and
there
we
thoroughly
enjoy
the
play
:
which
Sophy
believes
every
word
of
,
and
so
do
I.
 
<EOS>
In
walking
home
,
perhaps
we
buy
a
little
bit
of
something
at
a
cook's
-
shop
,
or
a
little
lobster
at
the
fishmongers
,
and
bring
it
here
,
and
make
a
splendid
supper
,
chatting
about
what
we
have
seen
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
you
know
,
Copperfield
,
if
I
was
Lord
Chancellor
,
we
could
n't
do
this
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
would
do
something
,
whatever
you
were
,
my
dear
Traddles
,
"
thought
I
,
"
that
would
be
pleasant
and
amiable
.
 
<EOS>
And
by
the
way
,
"
I
said
aloud
,
"
I
suppose
you
never
draw
any
skeletons
now
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Really
,
"
replied
Traddles
,
laughing
,
and
reddening
,
"
I
ca
n't
wholly
deny
that
I
do
,
my
dear
Copperfield
.
 
<EOS>
For
being
in
one
of
the
back
rows
of
the
King
's
Bench
the
other
day
,
with
a
pen
in
my
hand
,
the
fancy
came
into
my
head
to
try
how
I
had
preserved
that
accomplishment
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
am
afraid
there
's
a
skeleton
---
in
a
wig
---
on
the
ledge
of
the
desk
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
After
we
had
both
laughed
heartily
,
Traddles
wound
up
by
looking
with
a
smile
at
the
fire
,
and
saying
,
in
his
forgiving
way
,
"
Old
Creakle
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
letter
from
that
old
---
<EOS>
Rascal
here
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
For
I
never
was
less
disposed
to
forgive
him
the
way
he
used
to
batter
Traddles
,
than
when
I
saw
Traddles
so
ready
to
forgive
him
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
From
Creakle
the
schoolmaster
?
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Among
the
persons
who
are
attracted
to
me
in
my
rising
fame
and
fortune
,
"
said
I
,
looking
over
my
letters
,
"
and
who
discover
that
they
were
always
much
attached
to
me
,
is
the
self
-
same
Creakle
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
not
a
schoolmaster
now
,
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
retired
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
Middlesex
Magistrate
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
thought
Traddles
might
be
surprised
to
hear
it
,
but
he
was
not
so
at
all
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
suppose
he
comes
to
be
a
Middlesex
Magistrate
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
me
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Traddles
,
"
it
would
be
very
difficult
to
answer
that
question
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
voted
for
somebody
,
or
lent
money
to
somebody
,
or
bought
something
of
somebody
,
or
otherwise
obliged
somebody
,
or
jobbed
for
somebody
,
who
knew
somebody
who
got
the
lieutenant
of
the
county
to
nominate
him
for
the
commission
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
On
the
commission
he
is
,
at
any
rate
,
"
said
I.
 
"
<EOS>
And
he
writes
to
me
here
,
that
he
will
be
glad
to
show
me
,
in
operation
,
the
only
true
system
of
prison
discipline
;
the
only
unchallengeable
way
of
making
sincere
and
lasting
converts
and
penitents
---
which
,
you
know
,
is
by
solitary
confinement
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
say
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
To
the
system
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Traddles
,
looking
grave
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
To
my
accepting
the
offer
,
and
your
going
with
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
object
,
"
said
Traddles
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
I
'll
write
to
say
so
.
 
<EOS>
You
remember
(
to
say
nothing
of
our
treatment
)
this
same
Creakle
turning
his
son
out
of
doors
,
I
suppose
,
and
the
life
he
used
to
lead
his
wife
and
daughter
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perfectly
,
"
said
Traddles
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yet
,
if
you
'll
read
his
letter
,
you
'll
find
he
is
the
tenderest
of
men
to
prisoners
convicted
of
the
whole
calendar
of
felonies
,
"
said
I
;
"
though
I
ca
n't
find
that
his
tenderness
extends
to
any
other
class
of
created
beings
.
"
   
<EOS>
Traddles
shrugged
his
shoulders
,
and
was
not
at
all
surprised
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
not
expected
him
to
be
,
and
was
not
surprised
myself
;
or
my
observation
of
similar
practical
satires
would
have
been
but
scanty
.
 
<EOS>
We
arranged
the
time
of
our
visit
,
and
I
wrote
accordingly
to
Mr
Creakle
that
evening
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
appointed
day
---
I
think
it
was
the
next
day
,
but
no
matter
---
Traddles
and
I
repaired
to
the
prison
where
Mr
Creakle
was
powerful
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
an
immense
and
solid
building
,
erected
at
a
vast
expense
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
help
thinking
,
as
we
approached
the
gate
,
what
an
uproar
would
have
been
made
in
the
country
,
if
any
deluded
man
had
proposed
to
spend
one
half
the
money
it
had
cost
,
on
the
erection
of
an
industrial
school
for
the
young
,
or
a
house
of
refuge
for
the
deserving
old
.
   
<EOS>
In
an
office
that
might
have
been
on
the
ground
-
floor
of
the
Tower
of
Babel
,
it
was
so
massively
constructed
,
we
were
presented
to
our
old
schoolmaster
;
who
was
one
of
a
group
,
composed
of
two
or
three
of
the
busier
sort
of
magistrates
,
and
some
visitors
they
had
brought
.
 
<EOS>
He
received
me
,
like
a
man
who
had
formed
my
mind
in
bygone
years
,
and
had
always
loved
me
tenderly
.
 
<EOS>
On
my
introducing
Traddles
,
Mr
Creakle
expressed
,
in
like
manner
,
but
in
an
inferior
degree
,
that
he
had
always
been
Traddles
's
guide
,
philosopher
,
and
friend
.
 
<EOS>
Our
venerable
instructor
was
a
great
deal
older
,
and
not
improved
in
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
His
face
was
as
fiery
as
ever
;
his
eyes
were
as
small
,
and
rather
deeper
set
.
 
<EOS>
The
scanty
,
wet
-
looking
grey
hair
,
by
which
I
remembered
him
,
was
almost
gone
;
and
the
thick
veins
in
his
bald
head
were
none
the
more
agreeable
to
look
at
.
   
<EOS>
After
some
conversation
among
these
gentlemen
,
from
which
I
might
have
supposed
that
there
was
nothing
in
the
world
to
be
legitimately
taken
into
account
but
the
supreme
comfort
of
prisoners
,
at
any
expense
,
and
nothing
on
the
wide
earth
to
be
done
outside
prison
-
doors
,
we
began
our
inspection
.
 
<EOS>
It
being
then
just
dinner
-
time
,
we
went
,
first
into
the
great
kitchen
,
where
every
prisoner
's
dinner
was
in
course
of
being
set
out
separately
(
to
be
handed
to
him
in
his
cell
)
,
with
the
regularity
and
precision
of
clock
-
work
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
aside
,
to
Traddles
,
that
I
wondered
whether
it
occurred
to
anybody
,
that
there
was
a
striking
contrast
between
these
plentiful
repasts
of
choice
quality
,
and
the
dinners
,
not
to
say
of
paupers
,
but
of
soldiers
,
sailors
,
labourers
,
the
great
bulk
of
the
honest
,
working
community
;
of
whom
not
one
man
in
five
hundred
<EOS>
ever
dined
half
so
well
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
learned
that
the
"
system
"
required
high
living
;
and
,
in
short
,
to
dispose
of
the
system
,
once
for
all
,
I
found
that
on
that
head
and
on
all
others
,
"
the
system
"
put
an
end
to
all
doubts
,
and
disposed
of
all
anomalies
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
appeared
to
have
the
least
idea
that
there
was
any
other
system
,
but
THE
system
,
to
be
considered
.
   
<EOS>
As
we
were
going
through
some
of
the
magnificent
passages
,
I
inquired
of
Mr
Creakle
and
his
friends
what
were
supposed
to
be
the
main
advantages
of
this
all
-
governing
and
universally
over
-
riding
system
?
 
<EOS>
I
found
them
to
be
the
perfect
isolation
of
prisoners
---
so
that
no
one
man
in
confinement
there
,
knew
anything
about
another
;
and
the
reduction
of
prisoners
to
a
wholesome
state
of
mind
,
leading
to
sincere
contrition
and
repentance
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
it
struck
me
,
when
we
began
to
visit
individuals
in
their
cells
,
and
to
traverse
the
passages
in
which
those
cells
were
,
and
to
have
the
manner
of
the
going
to
chapel
and
so
forth
,
explained
to
us
,
that
there
was
a
strong
probability
of
the
prisoners
knowing
a
good
deal
about
each
other
,
and
of
their
carrying
on
a
pretty
complete
system
of
intercourse
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
at
the
time
I
write
,
has
been
proved
,
I
believe
,
to
be
the
case
;
but
,
as
it
would
have
been
flat
blasphemy
against
the
system
to
have
hinted
such
a
doubt
then
,
I
looked
out
for
the
penitence
as
diligently
as
I
could
.
   
<EOS>
And
here
again
,
I
had
great
misgivings
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
as
prevalent
a
fashion
in
the
form
of
the
penitence
,
as
I
had
left
outside
in
the
forms
of
the
coats
and
waistcoats
in
the
windows
of
the
tailors
'
shops
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
a
vast
amount
of
profession
,
varying
very
little
in
character
:
varying
very
little
(
which
I
thought
exceedingly
suspicious
)
,
even
in
words
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
a
great
many
foxes
,
disparaging
whole
vineyards
of
inaccessible
grapes
;
but
I
found
very
few
foxes
whom
I
would
have
trusted
within
reach
of
a
bunch
.
<EOS>
Above
all
,
I
found
that
the
most
professing
men
were
the
greatest
objects
of
interest
;
and
that
their
conceit
,
their
vanity
,
their
want
of
excitement
,
and
their
love
of
deception
(
which
many
of
them
possessed
to
an
almost
incredible
extent
,
as
their
histories
showed
)
,
all
prompted
to
these
professions
,
and
were
all
gratified
by
them
.
   
<EOS>
However
,
I
heard
so
repeatedly
,
in
the
course
of
our
goings
to
and
fro
,
of
a
certain
Number
Twenty
Seven
,
who
was
the
Favourite
,
and
who
really
appeared
to
be
a
Model
Prisoner
,
that
I
resolved
to
suspend
my
judgement
until
I
should
see
Twenty
Seven
.
 
<EOS>
Twenty
Eight
,
I
understood
,
was
also
a
bright
particular
star
;
but
it
was
his
misfortune
to
have
his
glory
a
little
dimmed
by
the
extraordinary
lustre
of
Twenty
Seven
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
so
much
of
Twenty
Seven
,
of
his
pious
admonitions
to
everybody
around
him
,
and
of
the
beautiful
letters
he
constantly
wrote
to
his
mother
(
whom
he
seemed
to
consider
in
a
very
bad
way
)
,
that
I
became
quite
impatient
to
see
him
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
to
restrain
my
impatience
for
some
time
,
on
account
of
Twenty
Seven
being
reserved
for
a
concluding
effect
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
at
last
,
we
came
to
the
door
of
his
cell
;
and
Mr
Creakle
,
looking
through
a
little
hole
in
it
,
reported
to
us
,
in
a
state
of
the
greatest
admiration
,
that
he
was
reading
a
Hymn
Book
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
such
a
rush
of
heads
immediately
,
to
see
Number
Twenty
Seven
reading
his
Hymn
Book
,
that
the
little
hole
was
blocked
up
,
six
or
seven
heads
deep
.
 
<EOS>
To
remedy
this
inconvenience
,
and
give
us
an
opportunity
of
conversing
with
Twenty
Seven
in
all
his
purity
,
Mr
Creakle
directed
the
door
of
the
cell
to
be
unlocked
,
and
Twenty
Seven
to
be
invited
out
into
the
passage
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
done
;
and
whom
should
Traddles
and
I
then
behold
,
to
our
amazement
,
in
this
converted
Number
Twenty
Seven
,
but
Uriah
Heep
!
   
<EOS>
He
knew
us
directly
;
and
said
,
as
he
came
out
---
with
the
old
writhe
,
---
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
,
<EOS>
Mr
Copperfield
?
 
<EOS>
How
do
you
do
,
Mr
Traddles
?
"
   
<EOS>
This
recognition
caused
a
general
admiration
in
the
party
.
 
<EOS>
I
rather
thought
that
everyone
was
struck
by
his
not
being
proud
,
and
taking
notice
of
us
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Twenty
Seven
,
"
said
Mr
Creakle
,
mournfully
admiring
him
.
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
find
yourself
today
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
umble
,
sir
!
"
replied
Uriah
Heep
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
always
so
,
Twenty
Seven
,
"
said
Mr
Creakle
.
   
<EOS>
Here
,
another
gentleman
asked
,
with
extreme
anxiety
:
"
Are
you
quite
comfortable
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
thank
you
,
sir
!
"
said
Uriah
Heep
,
looking
in
that
direction
.
 
<EOS>
"
Far
more
comfortable
here
,
than
ever
I
was
outside
.
<EOS>
I
see
my
follies
,
now
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
what
makes
me
comfortable
.
"
   
<EOS>
Several
gentlemen
were
much
affected
;
and
a
third
questioner
,
forcing
himself
to
the
front
,
inquired
with
extreme
feeling
:
"
How
do
you
find
the
beef
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
sir
,
"
replied
Uriah
,
glancing
in
the
new
direction
of
this
voice
,
"
it
was
tougher
yesterday
than
I
could
wish
;
but
it
's
my
duty
to
bear
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
committed
follies
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
Uriah
,
looking
round
with
a
meek
smile
,
"
and
<EOS>
I
ought
to
bear
the
consequences
without
repining
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
murmur
,
partly
of
gratification
at
Twenty
Seven
's
celestial
state
of
mind
,
and
partly
of
indignation
against
the
Contractor
who
had
given
him
any
cause
of
complaint
(
a
note
of
which
was
immediately
made
by
Mr
Creakle
)
,
having
subsided
,
Twenty
Seven
stood
in
the
midst
of
us
,
as
if
he
felt
himself
the
principal
object
of
merit
in
a
highly
meritorious
museum
.
 
<EOS>
That
we
,
the
neophytes
,
might
have
an
excess
of
light
shining
upon
us
all
at
once
,
orders
were
given
to
let
out
Twenty
Eight
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
been
so
much
astonished
already
,
that
I
only
felt
a
kind
of
resigned
wonder
when
Mr
Littimer
walked
forth
,
reading
a
good
book
!
   
<EOS>
"
Twenty
Eight
,
"
said
a
gentleman
in
spectacles
,
who
had
not
yet
spoken
,
"
<EOS>
you
complained
last
week
,
my
good
fellow
,
of
the
cocoa
.
<EOS>
How
has
it
been
since
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Littimer
,
"
it
has
been
better
made
.
<EOS>
If
I
might
take
the
liberty
of
saying
so
,
sir
,
I
do
n't
think
the
milk
which
is
boiled
with
it
is
quite

;
but
I
am
aware
,
sir
,
that
there
is
a
great

of
milk
,
in
London
,
and
that
the
article
in
a
pure

is
difficult
to
be
obtained
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
me
that
the
gentleman
in
spectacles
backed
his
Twenty
Eight
against
Mr
Creakle
's
Twenty
Seven
,
for
each
of
them
took
his
own
man
in
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
your
state
of
mind
,
Twenty
Eight
?
"
said
the
questioner
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mr
Littimer
;
"
I
see
my
follies
now
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
a

deal

when
I
think

the

my

,

;
but
I
trust

may

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite
happy
yourself
?
"
said
the
questioner
,
nodding

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
much

to
you
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mr
Littimer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Perfectly
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
there
anything
at
all
on
your
mind
now
?
"
said
the
questioner
.
<EOS>
"
If
so
,
mention
it
,
Twenty
Eight
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Littimer
,
without
looking
up
,
"
if
my
eyes
have
not
deceived
me
,
there
is
a
gentleman
present
who
was
acquainted
with
me
in
my
former

.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
profitable
to
that
gentleman
to
know
,
sir
,
that
I
attribute
my
past
follies
,
entirely
to
having
lived
a
thoughtless
life
in
the
service
of
young
men
;
and
to
having
allowed
myself
to
be
led
by
them
into
weaknesses
,
which
I
had
not
the
strength
to
resist
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
that
gentleman
will
take
warning
,
sir
,
and
will
not
be
offended
at
my
freedom
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
for
his
good
.
<EOS>
I
am
conscious
of
my
own
past
follies
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
he
may
repent
of
all
the
wickedness
and
sin
to
which
he
has
been
a
party
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
observed
that
several
gentlemen
were
shading
their

,
each
with
one
hand
,
as
if
they
had
just
come
into

.
   
<EOS>
"
This
does
you
credit
,
Twenty
Eight
,
"
returned
the
questioner
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
expected
it
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
Is
there
anything
else
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
returned
Mr
Littimer
,
slightly

up

,
but
not

,
"
there
was
a
young
woman
who
fell
into
dissolute

,
that
I

to

,

,

not

.
 
<EOS>
I

that

,

,

from

her

,

---
if

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
Twenty
Eight
,
"

,
"

you

to

---

---

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

Littimer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
I
wish

,
and

will

,
and

!
"
   
<EOS>
With

,
Number
Twenty
Eight
retired
,
after

Uriah
;
as

,
through

;
and
a

,
as
his

shut
upon

,
that
he
was
a
most
respectable
man
,
and
a
beautiful
case
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Twenty
Seven
,
"
said
Mr
Creakle
,

,
"
is

?
 
<EOS>
If
so
,
mention
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
umbly
ask
,
sir
,
"
returned
Uriah
,
with

malevolent

,
"
for

to
write
again
to
mother
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
sir
!
<EOS>
I
am
anxious
about
mother
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
she
ai
n't
safe
.
"
   
<EOS>
Somebody
incautiously
asked
,
what
from
?
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
a
scandalized

of
"
Hush
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Immortally
safe
,
sir
,
"
returned
Uriah
,
writhing
in
the
direction
of
the
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
wish
mother
to
be
got
into
my
state
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
should
have
been
got
into
my
present
state
if
I
had
n't
come
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
mother
had
come
here
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
better
for
everybody
,
if
they
got
took
up
,
and
was
brought
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
sentiment
gave
unbounded
satisfaction
---
greater
satisfaction
,
I
think
,
than
anything
that
had
passed
yet
.
   
<EOS>
"
Before
I
come
here
,
"
said
Uriah
,
stealing
a

at
us
,
as
if
he
would
have
blighted

outer
world
to
which
we
belonged
,
if
he

,
"
I
was
given
to
follies
;
but
now
I
am
sensible
of
my
follies
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
a
deal
of

outside
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
a

of
sin
in

.
 
<EOS>
There
's
nothing
but
sin
everywhere
---
except
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite
changed
?
"
said
Mr
Creakle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
dear
,
yes
,

!
"
cried
this

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
would
n't
relapse
,
if

were

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
de
-
ar
<EOS>
no
,

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Mr
Creakle
,
"
this
is
very
gratifying
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
addressed
Mr
Copperfield
,
Twenty
Seven
.
 
<EOS>
Do

wish

anything

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
knew
me
,
a
long

before
I
came
here
and
was
changed
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
Uriah
,
looking
at

;
and
a
more
villainous

I
never

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
knew
me
when
,
in
spite

my
follies
,
I
was
umble
among
them
that
was
proud
,
and
meek
among
them
<EOS>
that
was
violent
<EOS>
---
you
was
violent
to
me
yourself
,
Mr
Copperfield
.
<EOS>
Once
,
you
struck
me
a
blow
in
the
face
,
you
know
.
"
   
<EOS>
General
commiseration
.
 
<EOS>
Several
indignant
glances
directed
at
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
forgive
you
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
"
said
Uriah
,
making
his
forgiving
nature
the
subject
of
a
most
impious
and
awful
parallel
,
which
I
shall
not
record
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
forgive
everybody
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
ill
become
me
to
bear
malice
.
 
<EOS>
I
freely
forgive
you
,
and
I
hope
you
'll
curb
your
passions
in
future
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
Mr
W
will
repent
,
and
Miss
W
,
and
all
of
that
sinful
lot
.
 
<EOS>
You
've
been
visited
with
affliction
,
and
I
hope
it
may
do
you
good
;
but
you
'd
better
have
come
here
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
W
had
better
have
come
here
,
and
Miss
W
too
.
 
<EOS>
The
best
wish
I
could
give
you
,
Mr
Copperfield
,
and
give
all
of
you
gentlemen
,
is
,
that
you
could
be
took
