and
brought
here
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
think
of
my
past
follies
,
and
my
present
state
,
I
am
sure
it
would
be
best
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
pity
all
who
ai
n't
brought
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
sneaked
back
into
his
cell
,
amidst
a
little
chorus
of
approbation
;
and
both
Traddles
and
I
experienced
a
great
relief
when
he
was
locked
in
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
characteristic
feature
in
this
repentance
,
that
I
was
fain
to
ask
what
these
two
men
had
done
,
to
be
there
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
That
appeared
to
be
the
last
thing
about
which
they
had
anything
to
say
.
<EOS>
I
addressed
myself
to
one
of
the
two
warders
,
who
,
I
suspected
from
certain
latent
indications
in
their
faces
,
knew
pretty
well
what
all
this
stir
was
worth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
,
"
said
I
,
as
we
walked
along
the
passage
,
"
what
felony
was
Number
Twenty
Seven
's
last
"
folly
"
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
answer
was
that
it
was
a
Bank
case
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
fraud
on
the
Bank
of
England
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Fraud
,
forgery
,
and
conspiracy
.
 
<EOS>
He
and
some
others
.
<EOS>
He
set
the
others
on
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
deep
plot
for
a
large
sum
.
<EOS>
Sentence
,
transportation
for
life
.
 
<EOS>
Twenty
Seven
was
the
knowingest
bird
of
the
lot
,
and
had
very
nearly
kept
himself
safe
;
but
not
quite
.
 
<EOS>
The
Bank
was
just
able
to
put
salt
upon
his
tail
---
and
only
just
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
Twenty
Eight
's
offence
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Twenty
Eight
,
"
returned
my
informant
,
speaking
throughout
in
a
low
tone
,
and
looking
over
his
shoulder
as
we
walked
along
the
passage
,
to
guard
himself
from
being
overheard
,
in
such
an
unlawful
reference
to
these
Immaculates
,
by
Creakle
and
the
rest
;
"
Twenty
Eight
(
also
transportation
)
got
a
place
,
and
robbed
a
young
master
of
a
matter
of
two
hundred
and
fifty
pounds
in
money
and
valuables
,
the
night
before
they
were
going
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
I
particularly
recollect
his
case
,
from
his
being
took
by
a
dwarf
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
what
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
little
woman
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
forgot
her
name
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Not
Mowcher
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
it
!
<EOS>
He
had
eluded
pursuit
,
and
was
going
to
America
in
a
flaxen
wig
,
and
whiskers
,
and
such
a
complete
disguise
as
never
you
see
in
all
your
born
days
;
when
the
little
woman
,
being
in
Southampton
,
met
him
walking
along
the
street
---
picked
him
out
with
her
sharp
eye
in
a
moment
---
ran
betwixt
his
legs
to
upset
him
---
and
held
on
to
him
like
grim
Death
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Excellent
Miss
Mowcher
!
"
cried
I.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'd
have
said
so
,
if
you
had
seen
her
,
standing
on
a
chair
in
the
witness
-
box
at
the
trial
,
as
I
did
,
"
said
my
friend
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
cut
her
face
right
open
,
and
pounded
her
in
the
most
brutal
manner
,
when
she
took
him
;
but
she
never
loosed
her
hold
till
he
was
locked
up
.
 
<EOS>
She
held
so
tight
to
him
,
in
fact
,
that
the
officers
were
obliged
to
take
'em
both
together
.
 
<EOS>
She
gave
her
evidence
in
the
gamest
way
,
and
was
highly
complimented
by
the
Bench
,
and
cheered
right
home
to
her
lodgings
.
 
<EOS>
She
said
in
Court
that
she
'd
have
took
him
single
-
handed
(
on
account
of
what
she
knew
concerning
him
)
,
if
he
had
been
Samson
.
 
<EOS>
And
it
's
my
belief
she
would
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
mine
too
,
and
I
highly
respected
Miss
Mowcher
for
it
.
   
<EOS>
We
had
now
seen
all
there
was
to
see
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
in
vain
to
represent
to
such
a
man
as
the
Worshipful
Mr
Creakle
,
that
Twenty
Seven
and
Twenty
Eight
were
perfectly
consistent
and
unchanged
;
that
exactly
what
they
were
then
,
they
had
always
been
;
that
the
hypocritical
knaves
were
just
the
subjects
to
make
that
sort
of
profession
in
such
a
place
;
that
they
knew
its
market
-
value
at
least
as
well
as
we
did
,
in
the
immediate
service
it
would
do
them
when
they
were
expatriated
;
in
a
word
,
that
it
was
a
rotten
,
hollow
,
painfully
suggestive
piece
of
business
altogether
.
 
<EOS>
We
left
them
to
their
system
and
themselves
,
and
went
home
wondering
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
it
's
a
good
thing
,
Traddles
,
"
said
I
,
"
to
have
an
unsound
Hobby
ridden
hard
;
for
it
's
the
sooner
ridden
to
death
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
so
,
"
replied
Traddles
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
62
.
<EOS>
A
light
shines
on
my
way
 
<EOS>
The
year
came
round
to
Christmas
-
time
,
and
I
had
been
at
home
above
two
months
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
seen
Agnes
frequently
.
 
<EOS>
However
loud
the
general
voice
might
be
in
giving
me
encouragement
,
and
however
fervent
the
emotions
and
endeavours
to
which
it
roused
me
<EOS>
,
I
heard
her
lightest
word
of
praise
as
I
heard
nothing
else
.
   
<EOS>
At
least
once
a
week
,
and
sometimes
oftener
,
I
rode
over
there
,
and
passed
the
evening
.
 
<EOS>
I
usually
rode
back
at
night
;
for
the
old
unhappy
sense
was
always
hovering
about
me
now
---
most
sorrowfully
when
I
left
her
---
and
I
was
glad
to
be
up
and
out
,
rather
than
wandering
over
the
past
in
weary
wakefulness
or
miserable
dreams
.
<EOS>
I
wore
away
the
longest
part
of
many
wild
sad
nights
,
in
those
rides
;
reviving
,
as
I
went
,
the
thoughts
that
had
occupied
me
in
my
long
absence
.
   
<EOS>
Or
,
if
I
were
to
say
rather
that
I
listened
to
the
echoes
of
those
thoughts
,
I
should
better
express
the
truth
.
 
<EOS>
They
spoke
to
me
from
afar
off
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
put
them
at
a
distance
,
and
accepted
my
inevitable
place
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
read
to
Agnes
what
I
wrote
;
when
I
saw
her
listening
face
;
moved
her
to
smiles
or
tears
;
and
heard
her
cordial
voice
so
earnest
on
the
shadowy
events
of
that
imaginative
world
in
which
I
lived
<EOS>
;
I
thought
what
a
fate
mine
might
have
been
---
but
only
thought
so
,
as
I
had
thought
after
I
was
married
to
Dora
<EOS>
,
what
I
could
have
wished
my
wife
to
be
.
   
<EOS>
My
duty
to
Agnes
,
who
loved
me
with
a
love
,
which
,
if
I
disquieted
,
I
wronged
most
selfishly
and
poorly
,
and
could
never
restore
;
my
matured
assurance
that
I
,
who
had
worked
out
my
own
destiny
,
and
won
what
I
had
impetuously
set
my
heart
on
,
had
no
right
to
murmur
,
and
must
bear
;
comprised
what
I
felt
and
what
I
had
learned
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
loved
her
:
and
now
it
even
became
some
consolation
to
me
,
vaguely
to
conceive
a
distant
day
when
I
might
blamelessly
avow
it
;
when
all
this
should
be
over
;
when
I
could
say
"
Agnes
,
so
it
was
when
I
came
home
;
and
now
I
am
old
,
and
I
never
have
loved
since
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
did
not
once
show
me
any
change
in
herself
.
 
<EOS>
What
she
always
had
been
to
me
,
she
still
was
;
wholly
unaltered
.
   
<EOS>
Between
my
aunt
and
me
there
had
been
something
,
in
this
connexion
,
since
the
night
of
my
return
,
which
I
can
not
call
a
restraint
,
or
an
avoidance
of
the
subject
,
so
much
as
an
implied
understanding
that
we
thought
of
it
together
,
but
did
not
shape
our
thoughts
into
words
.
 
<EOS>
When
,
according
to
our
old
custom
,
we
sat
before
the
fire
at
night
,
we
often
fell
into
this
train
;
as
naturally
,
and
as
consciously
to
each
other
,
as
if
we
had
unreservedly
said
so
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
preserved
an
unbroken
silence
.
 
<EOS>
I
believed
that
she
had
read
,
or
partly
read
,
my
thoughts
that
night
;
and
that
she
fully
comprehended
why
I
gave
mine
no
more
distinct
expression
.
   
<EOS>
This
Christmas
-
time
being
come
,
and
Agnes
having
reposed
no
new
confidence
in
me
,
a
doubt
that
had
several
times
arisen
in
my
mind
---
whether
she
could
have
that
perception
of
the
true
state
of
my
breast
,
which
restrained
her
with
the
apprehension
of
giving
me
pain
---
began
to
oppress
me
heavily
.
 
<EOS>
If
that
were
so
,
my
sacrifice
was
nothing
;
my
plainest
obligation
to
her
unfulfilled
;
and
every
poor
action
I
had
shrunk
from
,
I
was
hourly
doing
.
 
<EOS>
I
resolved
to
set
this
right
beyond
all
doubt
;
---
if
such
a
barrier
were
between
us
,
to
break
it
down
at
once
with
a
determined
hand
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
---
what
lasting
reason
have
I
to
remember
it
!
---
<EOS>
a
cold
,
harsh
,
winter
day
.
 
<EOS>
There
had
been
snow
,
some
hours
before
;
and
it
lay
,
not
deep
,
but
hard
-
frozen
on
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
Out
at
sea
,
beyond
my
window
,
the
wind
blew
ruggedly
from
the
north
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
been
thinking
of
it
,
sweeping
over
those
mountain
wastes
of
snow
in
Switzerland
,
then
inaccessible
to
any
human
foot
;
and
had
been
speculating
which
was
the
lonelier
,
those
solitary
regions
,
or
a
deserted
ocean
.
   
<EOS>
"
Riding
today
,
Trot
?
"
said
my
aunt
,
putting
her
head
in
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
I
,
"
I
am
going
over
to
Canterbury
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
good
day
for
a
ride
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
your
horse
may
think
so
too
,
"
said
my
aunt
;
"
but
at
present
he
is
holding
down
his
head
and
his
ears
,
standing
before
the
door
there
,
as
if
he
thought
his
stable
preferable
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
I
may
observe
,
allowed
my
horse
on
the
forbidden
ground
,
but
had
not
at
all
relented
towards
the
donkeys
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
will
be
fresh
enough
,
presently
!
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
The
ride
will
do
his
master
good
,
at
all
events
,
"
observed
my
aunt
,
glancing
at
the
papers
on
my
table
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
child
,
you
pass
a
good
many
hours
here
!
<EOS>
I
never
thought
,
when
I
used
to
read
books
,
what
work
it
was
to
write
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
work
enough
to
read
them
,
sometimes
,
"
I
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
to
the
writing
,
it
has
its
own
charms
,
aunt
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
I
see
!
"
said
my
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ambition
,
love
of
approbation
,
sympathy
,
and
much
more
<EOS>
,
I
suppose
?
 
<EOS>
Well
:
go
along
with
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
anything
more
,
"
said
I
,
standing
composedly
before
her
<EOS>
---
she
had
patted
me
on
the
shoulder
,
and
sat
down
in
my
chair
---
"
of
that
attachment
of
Agnes
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
looked
up
in
my
face
a
little
while
,
before
replying
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
do
,
Trot
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
confirmed
in
your
impression
?
<EOS>
"
I
inquired
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
am
,
Trot
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
looked
so
steadfastly
at
me
:
with
a
kind
of
doubt
,
or
pity
,
or
suspense
in
her
affection
:
<EOS>
that
I
summoned
the
stronger
determination
to
show
her
a
perfectly
cheerful
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
is
more
,
Trot
---
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
Agnes
is
going
to
be
married
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
God
bless
her
!
"
<EOS>
said
I
,
cheerfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
God
bless
her
!
"
<EOS>
said
my
aunt
,
"
and
her
husband
too
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
echoed
it
,
parted
from
my
aunt
,
and
went
lightly
downstairs
,
mounted
,
and
rode
away
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
greater
reason
than
before
to
do
what
I
had
resolved
to
do
.
   
<EOS>
How
well
I
recollect
the
wintry
ride
!
<EOS>
The
frozen
particles
of
ice
,
brushed
from
the
blades
of
grass
by
the
wind
,
and
borne
across
my
face
;
the
hard
clatter
of
the
horse
's
hoofs
,
beating
a
tune
upon
the
ground
;
the
stiff
-
tilled
soil
;
the
snowdrift
,
lightly
eddying
in
the
chalk
-
pit
as
the
breeze
ruffled
it
;
the
smoking
team
with
the
waggon
of
old
hay
,
stopping
to
breathe
on
the
hill
-
top
,
and
shaking
their
bells
musically
;
the
whitened
slopes
and
sweeps
of
Down
-
land
lying
against
the
dark
sky
,
as
if
they
were
drawn
on
a
huge
slate
!
   
<EOS>
I
found
Agnes
alone
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
girls
had
gone
to
their
own
homes
now
,
and
she
was
alone
by
the
fire
,
reading
.
 
<EOS>
She
put
down
her
book
on
seeing
me
come
in
;
and
having
welcomed
me
as
usual
,
took
her
work
-
basket
and
sat
in
one
of
the
old
-
fashioned
windows
.
   
<EOS>
I
sat
beside
her
on
the
window
-
seat
,
and
we
talked
of
what
I
was
doing
,
and
when
it
would
be
done
,
and
of
the
progress
I
had
made
since
my
last
visit
.
 
<EOS>
Agnes
was
very
cheerful
;
and
laughingly
predicted
that
I
should
soon
become
too
famous
to
be
talked
to
,
on
such
subjects
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
I
make
the
most
of
the
present
time
,
you
see
,
"
said
Agnes
,
"
and
talk
to
you
while
I
may
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As
I
looked
at
her
beautiful
face
,
observant
of
her
work
,
she
raised
her
mild
clear
eyes
,
and
saw
that
I
was
looking
at
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
thoughtful
today
,
Trotwood
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Agnes
,
shall
I
tell
you
what
about
?
 
<EOS>
I
came
to
tell
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
put
aside
her
work
,
as
she
was
used
to
do
when
we
were
seriously
discussing
anything
;
and
gave
me
her
whole
attention
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Agnes
,
do
you
doubt
my
being
true
to
you
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
<EOS>
she
answered
,
with
a
look
of
astonishment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
doubt
my
being
what
I
always
have
been
to
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
<EOS>
she
answered
,
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
remember
that
I
tried
to
tell
you
,
when
I
came
home
,
what
a
debt
of
gratitude
I
owed
you
,
dearest
Agnes
,
and
how
fervently
I
felt
towards
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
remember
it
,
"
she
said
,
gently
,
"
very
well
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
secret
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
share
it
,
Agnes
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
cast
down
her
eyes
,
and
trembled
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
hardly
fail
to
know
,
even
if
I
had
not
heard
---
but
from
other
lips
than
yours
,
Agnes
,
which
seems
strange
---
that
there
is
someone
upon
whom
you
have
bestowed
the
treasure
of
your
love
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
shut
me
out
of
what
concerns
your
happiness
so
nearly
!
<EOS>
If
you
can
trust
me
,
as
you
say
you
can
,
and
as
I
know
you
may
,
let
me
be
your
friend
,
your
brother
,
in
this
matter
,
of
all
others
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
an
appealing
,
almost
a
reproachful
,
glance
,
she
rose
from
the
window
;
and
hurrying
across
the
room
as
if
without
knowing
where
,
put
her
hands
before
her
face
,
and
burst
into
such
tears
as
smote
me
to
the
heart
.
   
<EOS>
And
yet
they
awakened
something
in
me
,
bringing
promise
to
my
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Without
my
knowing
why
,
these
tears
allied
themselves
with
the
quietly
sad
smile
which
was
so
fixed
in
my
remembrance
,
and
shook
me
more
with
hope
than
fear
or
sorrow
.
   
<EOS>
"
Agnes
!
<EOS>
Sister
!
<EOS>
Dearest
!
<EOS>
What
have
I
done
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
away
,
Trotwood
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
speak
to
you
by
and
by
---
another
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
write
to
you
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
speak
to
me
now
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
!
<EOS>
do
n't
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
sought
to
recollect
what
she
had
said
,
when
I
had
spoken
to
her
on
that
former
night
,
of
her
affection
needing
no
return
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
a
very
world
that
I
must
search
through
in
a
moment
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Agnes
,
I
can
not
bear
to
see
you
so
,
and
think
that
I
have
been
the
cause
.
 
<EOS>
My
dearest
girl
,
dearer
to
me
than
anything
in
life
,
if
you
are
unhappy
,
let
me
share
your
unhappiness
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
are
in
need
of
help
or
counsel
,
let
me
try
to
give
it
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
have
indeed
a
burden
on
your
heart
,
let
me
try
to
lighten
it
.
 
<EOS>
For
whom
do
I
live
now
,
Agnes
,
if
it
is
not
for
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
spare
me
!
<EOS>
I
am
not
myself
!
<EOS>
Another
time
!
<EOS>
"
was
all
I
could
distinguish
.
   
<EOS>
Was
it
a
selfish
error
that
was
leading
me
away
?
 
<EOS>
Or
,
having
once
a
clue
to
hope
,
was
there
something
opening
to
me
that
I
had
not
dared
to
think
of
?
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
say
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
let
you
leave
me
so
!
<EOS>
For
Heaven
's
sake
,
Agnes
,
let
us
not
mistake
each
other
after
all
these
years
,
and
all
that
has
come
and
gone
with
them
!
<EOS>
I
must
speak
plainly
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
have
any
lingering
thought
that
I
could
envy
the
happiness
you
will
confer
;
that
I
could
not
resign
you
to
a
dearer
protector
,
of
your
own
choosing
;
that
I
could
not
,
from
my
removed
place
,
be
a
contented
witness
of
your
joy
;
dismiss
it
,
for
I
do
n't
deserve
it
!
<EOS>
I
have
not
suffered
quite
in
vain
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
not
taught
me
quite
in
vain
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
alloy
of
self
in
what
I
feel
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
quiet
now
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
little
time
,
she
turned
her
pale
face
towards
me
,
and
said
in
a
low

,
broken
here
and
there
,
but
very
clear
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
owe
it
to
your
pure
friendship
for
me
,
Trotwood
---
which
,
indeed
,
I
do
not
doubt
---
to
tell
you
,
you
are
mistaken
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
do
no
more
.
<EOS>
If
I
have
sometimes
,
in
the
course
of
years
,
wanted
help
and
counsel
,
they
have
come
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
have
sometimes
been
unhappy
,
the
feeling
has
passed
away
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
have
ever
had
a
burden
on
my
heart
,
it
has
been
lightened
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
have
any
secret
,
it
is
---
no
new
one
;
and
is
---
not
what
you
suppose
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
reveal
it
,
or
divide
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
long
been
mine
,
and
must
remain
mine
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Agnes
!
<EOS>
Stay
!
<EOS>
A
moment
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
going
away
,
but
I
detained
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
clasped
my
arm
about
her
waist
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
the
course
of
years
!
"
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
a
new
one
!
"
<EOS>
New
thoughts
and
hopes
were
whirling
through
my
mind
,
and
all
the
colours
of
my
life
were
changing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dearest
Agnes
!
<EOS>
Whom
I
so
respect
and
honour
---
whom
I
so
devotedly

!
<EOS>
When
I
came
here
today
,
I
thought
that
nothing
could
have
wrested
this

from

.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
I
could
have
kept
it
in
my
bosom
all
our
lives
,
till
we
were
old
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
Agnes
,
if

hope
that
I
may
ever
call

something
more

Sister
,
widely

Sister
!
---
"
   
Her

;
but

were
not
like
those
she
had
lately

,
and
I
saw
my

brighten
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
Agnes
!
<EOS>
Ever
my
guide
,
and
best
support
!
<EOS>
If
you
had
been
more
mindful
of
yourself
,
and
less
of
me
,
when
we
grew
up
here
together
,
I
think
my
heedless

never
would
have
wandered

.
 
<EOS>
But

were
so
much

than
I
,
so
necessary

in
every

and

,
that
to

you
to

,
and
rely

,

,

one
of

!
"
   
<EOS>
Still

,
but
not

---
joyfully
!
<EOS>
And
clasped
in
my
arms
as
she
had

,

had

!
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
loved
Dora
---
fondly
,
Agnes
,
as
you
know
---
"
   
"
Yes
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am

to
know
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
loved
her
---
even

,
my

,
without
your

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
And
when
I
lost
her
,
Agnes
,
what
should
I
have
been
without
you
,
still
!
"
   
<EOS>
Closer

,

,
<EOS>
her

,

,

!
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

you
.
<EOS>
I

,
loving
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
And

,
I
tried
to
tell

of
the

I

had
,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

I
had

;

and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

(
I

)
that

for
her
husband
<EOS>
,
she
could

,

no

,

,

had

;

.
 
<EOS>
And

,
Agnes
,

,

,
the

,

;

,

,

of

that

!
   
<EOS>
"
I

blest
,
Trotwood
---

---
but
there

one

I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dearest
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
She

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do

,

?
"
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Tell

,
my

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have

!
"
   
<EOS>
O
,
we
were
happy
,
we
were

!
<EOS>
Our

were
not
for

(
hers
so

the

)
through

had
come
to

,
but
for
the

of
being
thus
,
never

!
   
<EOS>
We

,
that
winter

,
in

together
;
and
<EOS>
the

within

seemed
to
be
partaken
by

.
<EOS>
The
early

began
to
shine
while
we
were
lingering
on
,
and

,
we

GOD
for

.
   
<EOS>
We
stood

in
the
same
old
-
fashioned

,
when

was

;
Agnes

;

following

.
 
<EOS>
Long

opened

;
and
,

,

,

,
who
should

call

,

.
   
<EOS>
It
was
nearly
dinner

next
day
when
we
appeared
before
my
aunt
.
<EOS>
She
was
up

,
Peggotty

:
which

her
pride
to

.
 
<EOS>
We
found
her
,
in
her

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Goodness
me
!
"
<EOS>

my
aunt
,

,
"
who
's
this
you
're
bringing
home
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Agnes
,
"
said
I.
   
As
we
had
arranged
to
say
nothing
at

,
my
aunt
was
not

.
 
<EOS>
She
darted

,
when
I
said
"
Agnes
"
;
but
seeing

I
looked
as

,

took

in

,
and
rubbed
her

with

.
   
<EOS>
She

Agnes
heartily
,
nevertheless
;
and
we
were
soon
in
the
lighted

downstairs
,
at

.
 
<EOS>
My
aunt
put
on
her
spectacles
twice
or
thrice
,
to
take
another
look
at
me
,
but
as
often
took
them
off
again
,
disappointed
,
and
rubbed
her
nose
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
Much
to

of
Mr
Dick
,
who
knew

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
By

,

,
"

,

;
"
I
have

speaking

Agnes
about

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
Trot
,
"

,

,
"
you
did

,
and
broke

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
aunt
,

?
 
<EOS>
I

sure
you
wo
n't
be
,
when

Agnes
is
not

in
any

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stuff
and

!
"
said
my
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
As

appeared
to

,

to

.
 
<EOS>
I

in

.
 
<EOS>
My

,

,

,
for

.
   
<EOS>
The

called

.
 
<EOS>
The

aunt
was
restored
<EOS>
,
she
flew
at
Peggotty
,
and

a

,

with

.
 
<EOS>
After

,

Mr
Dick
(
who

,
but

)
;
and
after

,
told

why
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
we
were
all
happy
together
.
   
<EOS>
I

not

my

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
was

,

,
that

was
going
to
be

;
and
that
I

.
   
<EOS>
We
were
married
within
a

.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
and
Sophy
,
and
Doctor
and
Mrs
Strong
,
were

at
our

.
 
<EOS>
We
left
them
full
of
joy
;
and
drove

together
.
 
<EOS>
Clasped

my

,
I
held
the
source
of
every
worthy
aspiration
I
had
ever
had
;
the
centre

,

,
my
own
,
my
wife
;
my

of
whom
was

!
   
<EOS>
"
Dearest
husband
!
"
said
Agnes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
that
I
may
call

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
grows
out
of
the
night
when
Dora

.
 
<EOS>
She
sent
you
for
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
did
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
told

that
she
left

something
.
 
<EOS>
Can

think
what
it
was
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
believed
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
drew
the
wife
who
had
so
long

,
closer

.
   
<EOS>
"
She

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

---
"
   
"
<EOS>
That
only

would
occupy
this
vacant

.
"
   
<EOS>
And
Agnes
laid
her
head
upon
my
breast
,
and

;
and
I
wept
with
her
,
though
we
were
so
happy
.
      
Chapter
63
.
<EOS>
A
visitor
 
<EOS>
What
I
have
purposed
to
record
is
nearly
finished
;
but
there
is
yet
an
incident
conspicuous
in
my
memory
,
on
which
it
often
rests
with
delight
,
and
without
which
one
thread
in
the
web
I
have
spun
would
have
a
ravelled
end
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
advanced
in
fame
and
fortune
,
my
domestic
joy
was
perfect
,
I
had
been
married
ten
happy
years
.
 
<EOS>
Agnes
and
I
were
sitting
by
the
fire
,
in
our
house
in
London
,
one
night
in
spring
,
and
three
of
our
children
were
playing
in
the
room
,
when
I
was
told
that
a
stranger
wished
to
see
me
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
been
asked
if
he
came
on
business
,
and
had
answered
No
<EOS>
;
he
had
come
for
the
pleasure
of
seeing
me
,
and
had
come
a
long
way
.
<EOS>
He
was
an
old
man
,
my
servant
said
,
and
looked
like
a
farmer
.
   
<EOS>
As
this
sounded
mysterious
to
the
children
,
and
moreover
was
like
the
beginning
of
a
favourite
story
Agnes
used
to
tell
them
,
introductory
to
the
arrival
of
a
wicked
old
Fairy
in
a
cloak
who
hated
everybody
,
it
produced
some
commotion
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
our
boys
laid
his
head
in
his
mother
's
lap
to
be
out
of
harm
's
way
,
and
little
Agnes
(
our
eldest
child
)
left
her
doll
in
a
chair
to
represent
her
,
and
thrust
out
her
little
heap
of
golden
curls
from
between
the
window
-
curtains
,
to
see
what
happened
next
.

<EOS>
"
Mr
Micawber
was
in
the
Bush
near
you
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
you
,
yes
,
"
said
Mr
Peggotty
,
"
and
turned
to
with
a
will
.
<EOS>
I
never
wish
to
meet
a
better
gen'l'man
for
turning
to
with
a
will
.
<EOS>
I
've
seen
that
theer
bald
head
of
his
a
perspiring
in
the
sun
,
Mas'r
Davy
,
till
I
a'most
thowt
it
would

.
 
<EOS>
And
now
he
's
a
Magistrate
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
Magistrate
,
eh
?
"
said
I.
   
Mr
Peggotty
pointed
to
a
certain
paragraph
in
the
newspaper
,
where
I
read
aloud
as
follows
,
from
the
Port
Middlebay
Times
:
   
<EOS>
"
The
public
dinner
to
our
distinguished
fellow
-
colonist
and
townsman
,
WILKINS
MICAWBER
,
ESQUIRE
,
Port
Middlebay
District
Magistrate
,
came
off
yesterday
in
the
large
room
of
the
Hotel
,
which
was
crowded
to
suffocation
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
estimated
that
not
fewer
than
forty
-
seven
persons
must
have
been
accommodated
with
dinner
at
one
time
,
exclusive
of
the
company
in
the
passage
and
on
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
The
beauty
,
fashion
,
and
exclusiveness
of
Port
Middlebay
,
flocked
to
do
honour
to
one
so
deservedly
esteemed
,
so
highly
talented
,
and
so
widely
popular
.
 
<EOS>
Doctor
Mell
(
of
Colonial
Salem
-
House
Grammar
School
,
Port
Middlebay
)
presided
,
and
on
his
right
sat
the
distinguished
guest
.
 
<EOS>
After
the
removal
of
the
cloth
,
and
the
singing
of
Non
Nobis
(
beautifully
executed
,
and
in
which
we
were
at
no
loss
to
distinguish
the
bell
-
like
notes
of
that
gifted
amateur
,
WILKINS
MICAWBER
,
ESQUIRE
,
JUNIOR
)
,
the
usual
loyal
and
patriotic
toasts
were
severally
given
and
rapturously
received
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Mell
,
in
a
speech
replete
with
feeling
,
then
proposed
"
Our
distinguished
Guest
,
the
ornament
of
our
town
.
 
<EOS>
May
he
never
leave
us
but
to
better
himself
,
and
may
his
success
among
us
be
such
as
to
render
his
bettering
himself
impossible
!
"
<EOS>
The
cheering
with
which
the
toast
was
received
defies
description
.
 
<EOS>
Again
and
again
it
rose
and
fell
,
like
the
waves
of
ocean
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
all
was
hushed
,
and
WILKINS
MICAWBER
,
ESQUIRE
,
presented
himself
to
return
thanks
.
 
<EOS>
Far
be
it
from
us
,
in
the
present
comparatively
imperfect
state
of
the
resources
of
our
establishment
,
to
endeavour
to
follow
our
distinguished
townsman
through
the
smoothly
-
flowing
periods
of
his
polished
and
highly
-
ornate
address
!
<EOS>
Suffice
it
to
observe
,
that
it
was
a
masterpiece
of
eloquence
;
and
that
those
passages
in
which
he
more
particularly
traced
his
own
successful
career
to
its
source
,
and
warned
the
younger
portion
of
his
auditory
from
the
shoals
of
ever
incurring
pecuniary
liabilities
which
they
were
unable
to
liquidate
,
brought
a
tear
into
the
manliest
eye
present
.
<EOS>
The
remaining
toasts
were
DOCTOR
MELL
;
Mrs
MICAWBER
(
who
gracefully
bowed
her
acknowledgements
from
the
side
-
door
,
where
a
galaxy
of
beauty
was
elevated
on
chairs
,
at
once
to
witness
and

)
,
Mrs
RIDGER
BEGS
(
late
Miss
Micawber
)
;
Mrs
MELL
;
WILKINS
MICAWBER
,
ESQUIRE
,
JUNIOR
(
who

by

he
found

,
but

,

,
in

)
;
<EOS>
Mrs
MICAWBER
'S
FAMILY
(
well
known
<EOS>
,
it
is
needless

,
in
the
mother

)
,
&
c
 
&
c
 
&
c.
 
<EOS>
At
the
conclusion
of
the
proceedings
the
tables
were
cleared
as
if
by
art
-
magic
for
dancing
.
 
<EOS>
Among
the
votaries
of
TERPSICHORE
,
who
disported

until
Sol
gave
warning
for

,
Wilkins
Micawber
,
Esquire
,
Junior
,
and
the
lovely

Miss
Helena
,
fourth

of
Doctor
Mell
,
were

.
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
looking
back
to
the
name
of
Doctor
Mell
,
pleased
to
have
discovered
,
in
these
happier

,
Mr
Mell
,
formerly
poor
pinched
usher
to
my
Middlesex
magistrate
,
when
Mr
Peggotty
pointing
to
another

of
the
paper
,
my

rested
on
my
own

,
and
I
read
thus
:
 
"
TO
DAVID
COPPERFIELD
,
ESQUIRE
,
"
"
THE
EMINENT
AUTHOR
.
"
<EOS>
"
My
Dear
Sir
,
"
   
"
Years
have
elapsed
,
since
I
had
an
opportunity
of
ocularly
perusing
the
lineaments
,
now
familiar
to
the
imaginations
of
a
considerable

of
the
civilized
world
.
"
  
"
But
,
my
dear
Sir
,
though
estranged
(
by
the
force

circumstances
over
which
I
have
had
no
control
)
from
the
personal

of
the
friend
and

of
my
youth
,
I
have
not
been
unmindful
of
his
soaring
flight
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
have
I
been
debarred
,
"
   
<EOS>
Though
seas
between
us
braid
ha
'
<EOS>
roared
,
 
"
(
BURNS
)
from
participating
in
the
intellectual
feasts
he
has
spread
before

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
,
therefore
,
allow

the

from

of
an

whom

,

,
my

,

,

,

,

,

of
Port
Middlebay
,
for

of

you

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Go
on
,
my
dear
Sir
!
<EOS>
You
are
not
unknown
here
,
you
are

.
 
<EOS>
Though
"
remote
"
,
we
are
neither
"
unfriended
"
,
"
melancholy
"
,
nor
(
I

)
"
slow
"
.
 
<EOS>
Go
on
,
my
dear
Sir
,
in
your
Eagle
course
!
<EOS>
The
inhabitants
of
Port
Middlebay
may
at
least
aspire
to
watch

,
with
delight
,
with

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Among

from

,
will
ever

,
while
it
has
light
and

,
"
  
"
The
"
  
"
Eye
"
  
"
Appertaining
to
"
  
"
WILKINS
MICAWBER
,
"
  
"
Magistrate
.
"
    
<EOS>
I
found
,
on
glancing
at
the
remaining
contents
of
the
newspaper
,
that
Mr
Micawber
was
a
diligent
and
esteemed
correspondent
of
that
journal
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
another
letter
from
him
in
the
same
paper
,
touching
a
bridge
;
there
was
an
advertisement
of
a
collection
of
similar
letters
by
him
,
to
be
shortly
republished
,
in
a
neat
volume
,
"
with
considerable
additions
"
;
and
,
unless
I
am
very
much
mistaken
,
the
Leading
Article
was
his
also
.
   
<EOS>
We
talked
much
of
Mr
Micawber
,
on
many
other
evenings
while
Mr
Peggotty
remained
with
us
.
 
<EOS>
He
lived
with
us
during
the
whole
term
of
his
stay
,
---
which
,
I
think
,
was
something
less
than
a
month
,
---
and
his
sister
and
my
aunt
came
to
London
to
see
him
.
 
<EOS>
Agnes
and
I
parted
from
him
aboard
-
ship
,
when
he
sailed
;
and
we
shall
never
part
from
him
more
,
on
earth
.
   
<EOS>
But
before
he
left
,
he
went
with
me
to
Yarmouth
,
to
see
a
little
tablet
I
had
put
up
in
the
churchyard
to
the
memory
of
Ham
.
 
<EOS>
While
I
was
copying
the
plain
inscription
for
him
at
his
request
,
I
saw
him
stoop
,
and
gather
a
tuft
of
grass
from
the
grave
and
a
little
earth
.
   
<EOS>
"
For
Em'ly
,
"
he
said
,
as
he
put
it
in
his
breast
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
promised
,
Mas'r
Davy
.
"
      
Chapter
64
.
<EOS>
A
last
retrospect
 
<EOS>
And
now
my
written
story
ends
.
 
<EOS>
I
look
back
,
once
more
---
for
the
last
time
---
before
I
close
these
leaves
.
   
<EOS>
I
see
myself
,
with
Agnes
at
my
side
,
journeying
along
the
road
of
life
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
our
children
and
our
friends
around
us
;
and
I
hear
the
roar
of
many
voices
,
not
indifferent
to
me
as
I
travel
on
.
   
<EOS>
What
faces
are
the
most
distinct
to
me
in
the
fleeting
crowd
?
 
<EOS>
Lo
,
these
;
all
turning
to
me
as
I
ask
my
thoughts
the
question
!
   
<EOS>
Here
is
my
aunt
,
in
stronger
spectacles
,
an
old
woman
of
four
-
score
years
and
more
,
but
upright
yet
,
and
a
steady
walker
of
six
miles
at
a
stretch
in
winter
weather
.
   
<EOS>
Always
with
her
,
here
comes
Peggotty
,
my
good
old
nurse
,
likewise
in
spectacles
,
accustomed
to
do
needle
-
work
at
night
very
close
to
the
lamp
,
but
never
sitting
down
to
it
without
a
bit
of
wax
candle
,
a
yard
-
measure
in
a
little
house
,
and
a
work
-
box
with
a
picture
of
St
Paul
's
upon
the
lid
.
   
<EOS>
The
cheeks
and
arms
of
Peggotty
,
so
hard
and
red
in
my
childish
days
,
when
I
wondered
why
the
birds
did
n't
peck
her
in
preference
to
apples
,
are
shrivelled
now
;
and
her
eyes
,
that
used
to
darken
their
whole
neighbourhood
in
her
face
,
are
fainter
(
though
they
glitter
still
)
;
but
her
rough
forefinger
,
which
I
once
associated
with
a
pocket
nutmeg
-
grater
,
is
just
the
same
,
and
when
I
see
my
least
child
catching
at
it
as
it
totters
from
my
aunt
to
her
,
I
think
of
our
little
parlour
at
home
,
when
I
could
scarcely
walk
.
<EOS>
My
aunt
's
old
disappointment
is
set
right
,
now
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
godmother
to
a
real
living
Betsey
Trotwood
;
and
Dora
(
the
next
in
order
)
says
she
spoils
her
.
   
<EOS>
There
is
something
bulky
in
Peggotty
's
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
nothing
smaller
than
the
Crocodile
Book
,
which
is
in
rather
a
dilapidated
condition
by
this
time
,
with
divers
of
the
leaves
torn
and
stitched
across
,
but
which
Peggotty
exhibits
to
the
children
as
a
precious
relic
.
 
<EOS>
I
find
it
very
curious
to
see
my
own
infant
face
,
looking
up
at
me
from
the
Crocodile
stories
;
and
to
be
reminded
by
it
of
my
old
acquaintance
Brooks
of
Sheffield
.
   
<EOS>
Among
my
boys
,
this
summer
holiday
time
,
I
see
an
old
man
making
giant
kites
,
and
gazing
at
them
in
the
air
,
with
a
delight
for
which
there
are
no
words
.
 
<EOS>
He
greets
me
rapturously
,
and
whispers
,
with
many
nods
and
winks
,
"
Trotwood
,
you
will
be
glad
to
hear
that
I
shall
finish
the
Memorial
when
I
have
nothing
else
to
do
,
and
that
your
aunt
's
the
most
extraordinary
woman
in
the
world
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
Who
is
this
bent
lady
,
supporting
herself
by
a
stick
,
and
showing
me
a
countenance
in
which
there
are
some
traces
of
old
pride
and
beauty
,
feebly
contending
with
a
querulous
,
imbecile
,
fretful
wandering
of
the
mind
?
 
<EOS>
She
is
in
a
garden
;
and
near
her
stands
a
sharp
,
dark
,
withered
woman
,
with
a
white
scar
on
her
lip
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
hear
what
they
say
.
   
<EOS>
"
Rosa
,
I
have
forgotten
this
gentleman
's
name
.
"
   
<EOS>
Rosa
bends
over
her
,
and
calls
to
her
,
"
Mr
Copperfield
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
see
you
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
to
observe
you
<EOS>
are
in
mourning
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
Time
will
be
good
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Her
impatient
attendant
scolds
her
,
tells
her
I
am
not
in
mourning
,
bids
her
look
again
,
tries
to
rouse
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
seen
my
son
,
sir
,
"
says
the
elder
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
reconciled
?
"
   
<EOS>
Looking
fixedly
at
me
,
she
puts
her
hand
to
her
forehead
,
and
moans
.
 
<EOS>
Suddenly
,
she
cries
,
in
a
terrible
voice
,
"
Rosa
,
come
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
dead
!
"
<EOS>
Rosa
kneeling
at
her
feet
,
by
turns
caresses
her
,
and
quarrels
with
her
;
now
fiercely
telling
her
,
"
I
loved
him
better
than
you
ever
did
!
"
---
now
soothing
her
to
sleep
on
her
breast
,
like
a
sick
child
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
I
leave
them
;
thus
I
always
find
them
;
thus
they
wear
their
time
away
,
from
year
to
year
.
   
<EOS>
What
ship
comes
sailing
home
from
India
,
and
what
English
lady
is
this
,
married
to
a
growling
old
Scotch
Croesus
with
great
flaps
of
ears
?
 
<EOS>
Can
this
be
Julia
Mills
?
   
<EOS>
Indeed
it
is
Julia
Mills
,
peevish
and
fine
,
with
a
black
man
to
carry
cards
and
letters
to
her
on
a
golden
salver
,
and
a
copper
-
coloured
woman
in
linen
,
with
a
bright
handkerchief
round
her
head
,
to
serve
her
Tiffin
in
her
dressing
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
But
Julia
keeps
no
diary
in
these
days
;
never
sings
Affection
's
Dirge
;
eternally
quarrels
with
the
old
Scotch
Croesus
,
who
is
a
sort
of
yellow
bear
with
a
tanned
hide
.
 
<EOS>
Julia
is
steeped
in
money
to
the
throat
,
and
talks
and
thinks
of
nothing
else
.
 
<EOS>
I
liked
her
better
in
the
Desert
of
Sahara
.
   
<EOS>
Or
perhaps
this
IS
the
Desert
of
Sahara
!
<EOS>
For
,
though
Julia
has
a
stately
house
,
and
mighty
company
,
and
sumptuous
dinners
every
day
,
I
see
no
green
growth
near
her
;
nothing
that
can
ever
come
to
fruit
or
flower
.
 
<EOS>
What
Julia
calls
"
society
"
,
I
see
;
among
it
<EOS>
Mr
Jack
Maldon
,
from
his
Patent
Place
,
sneering
at
the
hand
that
gave
it
him
,
and
speaking
to
me
of
the
Doctor
as
"
so
charmingly
antique
"
.
<EOS>
But
when
society
is
the
name
for
such
hollow
gentlemen
and
ladies
,
Julia
,
and
when
its
breeding
is
professed
indifference
to
everything
that
can
advance
or
can
retard
mankind
,
I
think
we
must
have
lost
ourselves
in
that
same
Desert
of
Sahara
,
and
had
better
find
the
way
out
.
   
<EOS>
And
lo
,
the
Doctor
,
always
our
good
friend
,
labouring
at
his
Dictionary
(
somewhere
about
the
letter
D^
)
,
and
happy
in
his
home
and
wife
.
 
<EOS>
Also
the
Old
Soldier
,
on
a
considerably
reduced
footing
,
and
by
no
means
so
influential
as
in
days
of
yore
!
   
<EOS>
Working
at
his
chambers
in
the
Temple
,
with
a
busy
aspect
,
and
his
hair
(
where
he
is
not
bald
)
made
more
rebellious
than
ever
by
the
constant
friction
of
his
lawyer's
-
wig
<EOS>
,
I
come
,
in
a
later
time
,
upon
my
dear
old
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
His
table
is
covered
with
thick
piles
of
papers
;
and
I
say
,
as
I
look
around
me
:
   
<EOS>
"
If
Sophy
were
your
clerk
,
now
,
Traddles
,
she
would
have
enough
to
do
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
say
that
,
my
dear
Copperfield
!
<EOS>
But
those
were
capital
days
,
too
,
in
Holborn
Court
!
<EOS>
Were
they
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
When
she
told
you
you
would
be
a
judge
?
 
<EOS>
But
it
was
not
the
town
talk
then
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
all
events
,
"
says
Traddles
,
"
if
I
ever
am
one
---
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
know
you
will
be
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
dear
Copperfield
,
WHEN
I
am
one
,
I
shall
tell
the
story
,
as
I
said
I
would
.
"
   
<EOS>
We
walk
away
,
arm
in
arm
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
to
have
a
family
dinner
with
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
Sophy
's
birthday
;
and
,
on
our
road
,
Traddles
discourses
to
me
of
the
good
fortune
he
has
enjoyed
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
really
have
been
able
,
my
dear
Copperfield
,
to
do
all
that
I
had
most
at
heart
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
the
Reverend
Horace
promoted
to
that
living
at
four
hundred
and
fifty
pounds
a
year
;
there
are
our
two
boys
receiving
the
very
best
education
,
and
distinguishing
themselves
as
steady
scholars
and
good
fellows
;
there
are
three
of
the
girls
married
very
comfortably
;
there
are
three
more
living
with
us
;
there
are
three
more
keeping
house
for
the
Reverend
Horace
since
Mrs
Crewler
's
decease
;
and
all
of
them
happy
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Except
---
"
I
suggest
.
   
<EOS>
"
Except
the
Beauty
,
"
says
Traddles
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
unfortunate
that
she
should
marry
such
a
vagabond
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
a
certain
dash
and
glare
about
him
that
caught
her
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
now
we
have
got
her
safe
at
our
house
,
and
got
rid
of
him
,
we
must
cheer
her
up
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
Traddles
's
house
is
one
of
the
very
houses
---
or
it
easily
may
have
been
---
which
he
and
Sophy
used
to
parcel
out
,
in
their
evening
walks
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
large
house
;
but
Traddles
keeps
his
papers
in
his
dressing
-
room
and
his
boots
with
his
papers
;
and
he
and
Sophy
squeeze
themselves
into
upper
rooms
,
reserving
the
best
bedrooms
for
the
Beauty
and
the
girls
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
room
to
spare
in
the
house
;
for
more
of
"
the
girls
"
are
here
,
and
always
are
here
,
by
some
accident
or
other
,
than
I
know
how
to
count
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
when
we
go
in
,
is
a
crowd
of
them
,
running
down
to
the
door
,
and
handing
Traddles
about
to
be
kissed
,
until
he
is
out
of
breath
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
established
in
perpetuity
,
is
the
poor
Beauty
,
a
widow
with
a
little
girl
;
here
,
at
dinner
on
Sophy
's
birthday
,
are
the
three
married
girls
with
their
three
husbands
,
and
one
of
the
husband
's
brothers
,
and
another
husband
's
cousin
,
and
another
husband
's
sister
,
who
appears
to
me
to
be
engaged
to
the
cousin
.
 
<EOS>
Traddles
,
exactly
the
same
simple
,
unaffected
fellow
as
he
ever
was
,
sits
at
the
foot
of
the
large
table
like
a
Patriarch
;
and
Sophy
beams
upon
him
,
from
the
head
,
across
a
cheerful
space
that
is
certainly
not
glittering
with
Britannia
metal
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
,
as
I
close
my
task
,
subduing
my
desire
to
linger
yet
,
these
faces
fade
away
.
 
<EOS>
But
one
face
,
shining
on
me
like
a
Heavenly
light
by
which
I
see
all
other
objects
,
is
above
them
and
beyond
them
all
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
remains
.
   
<EOS>
I
turn
my
head
,
and
see
it
,
in
its
beautiful
serenity
,
beside
me
.
   
<EOS>
My
lamp
burns
low
,
and
I
have
written
far
into
the
night
;
but
the
dear
presence
,
without
which
I
were
nothing
,
bears
me
company
.
   
<EOS>
O
Agnes
,
O
my
soul
,
so
may
thy
face
be
by
me
when
I
close
my
life
indeed
;
<EOS>
so
may
I
,
when
realities
are
melting
from
me
,
like
the
shadows
which
I
now
dismiss
,
still
find
thee
near
me
,
pointing
upward
!
    
<EOS>
